headline: Totals
‘Granddaddy’ of Bowls Has Touch of the Blues
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 31 — Even Chad Henne, the Michigan quarterback, called this year’s Rose Bowl “almost like a consolation match.” And Henne is as enthusiastic as anyone about Monday’s game between the Wolverines and Southern California in Pasadena.

headline: What Did Hussein’s Execution Accomplish? (11 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marsh & McLennan to Sell Putnam Funds to Canadian Group
text: Marsh & McLennan Companies, the big New York insurance broker, is planning to sell its troubled mutual fund business, Putnam Investments, to the Power Corporation of Canada for about $3.9 billion.

headline: The Lonely Newspaper Reader
text: In the house where I grew up, everybody ate breakfast at the same time. The younger ones would sit at the table elbowing one another for toast while my dad stood, drinking coffee and reading The Minneapolis Star Tribune.

headline: Muslim’s Swearing-In (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Journal Hits a Closed Market
text: You know what they say about the best-laid plans. The Wall Street Journal is now an expert.

headline: Disney Plans to Introduce a Sleek Makeover of Disney.com Site
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 — When the Walt Disney Company’s chief executive, Robert A. Iger, takes the stage at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas on Jan. 8, he is expected to introduce the new Disney.com Web site that has taken more than a year to redesign.

headline: A New Middle Stance Emerges in Debate over Climate
text: Amid the shouting lately about whether global warming is a human-caused catastrophe or a hoax, some usually staid climate scientists in the usually invisible middle are speaking up.

headline: Tehran Radio Lets Critics Vent Over Iran’s Nuclear Plans
text: TEHRAN, Dec. 31 — A radio program on a government-run station has been conducting an open debate for the past month about whether Iran should change its tough stance on its nuclear program.

headline: A Century Later, Los Angeles Atones for Water Sins
text: INDEPENDENCE, Calif. — It may fall short of a feel-good sequel to “Chinatown,” the movie based on the notorious, somewhat shady water grab by Los Angeles that allowed the city to bloom from a semi-arid desert.

headline: Knicks Have a Hard Time Dealing With Rejection
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 — After running through the gamut of emotions, from the highest highs late last week to another stupefying low Sunday afternoon, the Knicks were left with a bad case of whiplash.

headline: 3,000 Deaths in Iraq, Countless Tears at Home
text: Jordan W. Hess was the unlikeliest of soldiers.

headline: Once Cast as the Accidental Governor, Rell Is Primed to Pursue Her Own Agenda
text: HARTFORD, Dec. 29  As she wrote her first inaugural speech, M. Jodi Rell turned to the remarks of Gerald R. Ford. Like the former president who took over after the resignation of Richard M. Nixon, Governor Rell was looking for a way to soothe nerves, not make waves.

headline: A Healthy New Year
text: The U.S. health care system is a scandal and a disgrace. But maybe, just maybe, 2007 will be the year we start the move toward universal coverage.

headline: Hush, Little Baby, Mama’s Crooning
text: Entering the world of Carly Simon’s new album “Into White” (Columbia) is like tiptoeing into an enchanted garden. The fanciful Cat Stevens song that opens the record and gives it its title establishes a mood of deep, dreamy calm that is sustained over 14 songs.

headline: France Frets as Louvre Looks Overseas
text: PARIS, Dec. 31 — When the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation began offering its expertise, collections and name to new museums around the world some years ago, not a few French curators and art critics sniffed disdainfully at the idea that a major museum should rent its art and sell its brand.

headline: Like It or Not, City’s Lack of Snow Is a Rarity
text: No children screeching on toboggans. No thwack against a friend’s head. No melting on tongues. No snow. November. December, too.

headline: Is It Who We Are, or How We Act? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Remaking of Downtown Has Downside
text: MADISON, Wis.  This college town received what it wanted when, during the 1980s and 90s, it sought to reverse the decline of its downtown and to create a more vibrant civic center that would draw people at night and on weekends.

headline: Satellite Radio May Try a Merger
text: Last year’s debut of Howard Stern’s radio show on Sirius Satellite Radio put the technology on the map, raising the public’s awareness of satellite radio and helping to boost significantly subscriber totals for Sirius and its larger rival, XM Satellite Radio.

headline: Songwriter’s Death Leads to Suits Against Preacher
text: Darlene Bishop, the nationally renowned evangelical preacher, begins her book about how God cured the cancer afflicting one of her brothers with a Biblical verse: “And the prayer of faith shall save the sick, and the Lord shall raise him up.”

headline: Giants Get Fresh Start but Face Whole New Round of Questions
text: Only 24 hours earlier, it seemed that Giants Coach Tom Coughlin could be fired by the time dawn broke on a new year. But on Sunday, as the early results from the day’s N.F.L. schedule were confirming the Giants’ place in the playoffs, Coughlin was on the telephone, cheerfully talking like the leader of a team reborn.

headline: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s Inaugural Address
text: Following is the text of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s inaugural address as prepared for delivery:

headline: The Burden of an Unsolved Case and Its Nameless Victim
text: PHILADELPHIA — For a half-century, he has been the center of a heartbreaking mystery, this boy of 4 or 5 who lies buried beneath a black granite stone in the shade of rhododendrons.

headline: Wave of Development, Cleared for Takeoff
text: City, state and federal agencies granted final approvals last month to a half-dozen wide-ranging projects in a political aligning of the stars that will promote New York City’s most ambitious economic development agenda in decades.

headline: McNabb Watches and Wonders About the Future
text: Philadelphia

headline: Russia-Belarus Gas Deal Averts Feared Disruptions in Europe
text: MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 1  As a New Year’s deadline arrived, Russia’s natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, struck a deal early Monday to supply gas to Belarus for the next five years, averting a price dispute that threatened to disrupt supplies to Europe, the company said in a statement.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Peaceful Protest at ‘Idomeneo’

headline: Edges and Order
text: The heavy winds that blew through the Northeast a couple of weeks ago mostly missed our place. They took only the dead boughs, which now lie scattered along the edges of the pastures like porous old bones. The farmers up here will have a lot of cleaning to do along the fencelines before they bale hay next June or they will be baling kindling. In the woods across from our house, the wind snapped off the top of a sugar maple. The crown lies jagged, uneven, on the ground, not yet weighed down by gravity or moss. It exaggerates the disorder of nature, which seems so apparent in the absence of snow this time of year.

headline: Pain Is Real; Coles’s Role Is as a Decoy
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 31 — Laveranues Coles’s face brightened when somebody mentioned the block he made to help spring running back Leon Washington on his 15-yard scoring run in the fourth quarter of the Jets’ 23-3 victory against the Oakland Raiders.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 — In brand-new offices with a still-empty game room and enough space to triple their staff of nearly 30, a trio of entrepreneurs is leading an Internet start-up with an improbable mission: to out-Google Google.

headline: Supporters of Thai Ex-Premier Blamed for Blasts
text: BANGKOK, Jan. 1 — Supporters of the government that was ousted in a coup three months ago were responsible for explosions across Bangkok during New Year’s Eve celebrations, Gen. Surayud Chulanont, the interim prime minister, said today.

headline: With Renovations Set for Official Residence, U.N. Chief Can’t Unpack Yet
text: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 29 — When Ban Ki-moon takes over as secretary general of the United Nations on Monday, he may quickly have to grapple with the crisis in Darfur, fighting in Somalia and the continuing strife in the Middle East. But he will have to wait to enjoy one of the more glamorous trappings of his new post: the secretary general’s official residence on Sutton Place, the exclusive Manhattan enclave off the East River.

headline: Thousands Honor Ford Under Capitol Dome
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 — Thousands of mourners filed past the coffin of former President Gerald R. Ford on Sunday as he lay in state below the Capitol dome, many saying they came to pay overdue respect to an overshadowed leader.

headline: Interfaith Approach to Forgiving Trespass
text: As a child Amy-Jill Levine insisted on attending catechism class at a Catholic church. She faithfully administered Holy Communion to her Barbie doll. This, despite being, then as now, an observant Jew. A professor of New Testament studies at Vanderbilt Divinity School, Ms. Levine has spent a lifetime exploring the profound connections and equally profound divisions between Christianity and Judaism — and, perhaps more important, between Christians and Jews.

headline: Environmental Harmony
text: The long history of Congressional bipartisan cooperation on environmental issues dating back to Richard Nixon has been seriously challenged only twice. The first time was in 1995, when the Gingrich Republicans swept into Washington determined to roll back environmental laws, a threat averted by President Bill Clinton’s veto pen and the exertions of a group of moderate Republicans. The second challenge occurred during the Congress that has now thankfully drawn to a close.

headline: For Sunnis, Dictator’s Degrading End Signals Ominous Dawn for the New Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 31 — For Sunni Arabs here, the ugly reality of the new Iraq seemed to crystallize in a two-minute segment of Saddam Hussein’s hanging, filmed surreptitiously on a cellphone.

headline: Murdoch vs. Regan: Hollywood Girds for Latest Boldface Battle of Egos
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 — When it comes to spectacle, Hollywood enjoys nothing better than a nasty legal battle between two determined and egotistical adversaries: Bette Davis meets Joan Crawford, in a courtroom.

headline: S.U.V. Kills Boxer, 28, in a Dispute Outside a Bar
text: A professional boxer was killed in the Bronx early yesterday when a barroom argument spilled outside and one of the men involved drove his sport utility vehicle into a group of people on the sidewalk, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Gumbel’s Studio Skills Are Lost in Transition to NFL Network Booth
text: The plan to turn Bryant Gumbel into a play-by-play announcer for the NFL Network was always a risky wager that at age 58, he could adapt his broadcasting skills from the studio to the booth without prior experience.

headline: With Paterno Coaching From Above, Penn St. Takes Outback Bowl
text: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 — Joe Paterno stepped gingerly onto the sideline at Raymond James Stadium this morning, his cane firmly in hand as a Penn State staffer, security and cameras hovered. It was a significant milestone in Paterno’s recovery from a broken left leg and torn ligaments on Nov. 4, when he was run over on the sideline by two players during a game at Wisconsin. Finally, Paterno was back on the field.

headline: Less Shoplifting in Health and Beauty Aisle
text: Cosmetics and health-care products were the items most likely to be shoplifted in 2000, according to a report on supermarket theft recently issued by the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group. Last year, they were the third most shoplifted category, after meat and analgesics.

headline: Department of Household Security
text: Thousands of handicapped immigrants who received asylum to enter the United States are beginning the new year caught up in the immense backlog of background checks that now chokes government administration in the wake of 9/11. The glut of all cases from years past is 2.7 million and growing, according to the F.B.I., as investigators receive a weekly torrent of 67,000 new requests  half of them from the immigration services dealing with the normal flood of mostly healthy newcomers.

headline: Hard Choices Over Video of Execution
text: Confronted with a second, unofficial and more graphic video account of the moments leading up to the execution of Saddam Hussein, and the hanging itself, executives at television news organizations made a series of what one executive, President Steve Capus of NBC News, called “delicate editorial decisions” about what they would put on the air on Saturday night and Sunday to augment the first pictures of the execution.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,984 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last weekend:

headline: Folly’s Antidote
text: MANY signs point to a growing historical consciousness among the American people. I trust that this is so. It is useful to remember that history is to the nation as memory is to the individual. As persons deprived of memory become disoriented and lost, not knowing where they have been and where they are going, so a nation denied a conception of the past will be disabled in dealing with its present and its future. “The longer you look back,” said Winston Churchill, “the farther you can look forward.”

headline: Dennis Linde, 63, Hit Songwriter, Dies
text: Dennis Linde, an influential and publicity-shy country songwriter who composed Elvis Presley’s soulful 1972 hit “Burning Love” and the Dixie Chicks’ mordantly humorous 1999 anthem “Goodbye Earl,” died on Dec. 22 in Nashville. He was 63.

headline: Queens: Driver Killed in Racing Accident
text: A driver killed on Saturday when his car flipped and overturned in a parking lot was racing another driver, the police said yesterday. The driver who died was identified as John Southern, 35, of South Jamaica, Queens. The second driver, Edwin Washington, 22, of Jamaica, was charged with criminally negligent homicide, reckless endangerment and reckless driving, the police said. The two men were racing about 5:30 p.m. on Saturday along North Conduit Avenue near 78th Street in Jamaica when Mr. Southern’s white Mitsubishi Galant overturned, the police said. A passenger in Mr. Southern’s car, Cory Sapp, 18, of Queens, was also arrested and charged, after police officers found a gun in the Galant, the police said.

headline: Spitzer Arrives With Mandate, but Faces Challenges
text: ALBANY — Eliot Laurence Spitzer takes the oath of office as New York’s 54th governor in a capital desperately in need of a new moral authority figure.

headline: Nonrenewal of TV License Stokes Debate in Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 31  President Hugo Chávez’s decision not to renew the broadcast license of RCTV, one of this country’s oldest television stations and a frequent critic of his government, has fueled a fierce debate over whether he is stifling dissent in Venezuela as he strengthens his control of the broadcasting industry.

headline: Newark: One Is Killed in Fire
text: One person was found dead after a fire tore through a third-floor apartment last night, the authorities said. The victim, who was too badly burned to be immediately identified, was found in an apartment building on Manor Drive, south of Ivy Hill Park, said John Brown, a Fire Department spokesman. The one-alarm fire apparently started sometime before 10:30 p.m. in the bedroom, Chief Michael Lalor said. The cause was still being investigated.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Chief Justice Advocates Higher Pay for Judiciary
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. made judicial pay the sole topic of his second annual report, issued on Sunday, declaring that the failure by Congress to raise federal judges’ salaries in recent years has become a “constitutional crisis” that puts the future of the federal courts in jeopardy.

headline: The Sleepy Subject of Canada’s Grain Exports Perks Up
text: OTTAWA, Dec. 31 — The business of grain marketing has not been its usual sleepy self lately in Western Canada.

headline: Queens: Man Charged in Accident
text: A driver from New Rochelle ran another vehicle off the Long Island Expressway yesterday morning, then pulled over, and at the sight of a severely injured passenger in the other vehicle, fled on foot, the police said. Two of the three men in the injured passenger’s vehicle, a GMC Yukon, and a passing off-duty police officer, Michael Leone, caught up with the driver, the police said. The collision occurred shortly before 6 a.m. on the eastbound lanes of the expressway at 69th Street in Maspeth, Queens, the police said. The man’s sport utility vehicle veered into the GMC Yukon, pushing it onto the shoulder, the police said. The badly injured passenger, a woman who was in the back seat, was said to be in critical condition yesterday evening at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. All three men in the Yukon suffered minor injuries. The driver of the first vehicle, Alexie Quiles, 26, was charged with vehicular assault and driving while intoxicated, the police said. He was also charged with illegal possession of a weapon after officers found a gun in his vehicle, the police said.

headline: Woman Killed and Her Son Is Wounded in L.I. Home
text: A mother and her adult son were shot inside their family’s basement apartment in Coram, N.Y., on Saturday, the police said. She was killed and he was badly wounded.

headline: After a Fire, Putting an Immigrant Family’s Dreams Back on Track
text: A year ago, as the Mendez-Rojas family slept on New Year’s Day after a night of celebrating, a fire was spreading in the walls of their studio apartment on Gerard Avenue in the South Bronx.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: PRESIDENTIAL HONORS Markets are closed Monday for the New Year’s holiday, and most will remain closed Tuesday for the national day of mourning for former President Gerald R. Ford. The bond markets will be open only until 2 p.m. Mr. Ford’s funeral will be held Tuesday, and he will be buried Wednesday in his hometown, Grand Rapids, Mich.

headline: From Father to Son, Last Words to Live By
text: He drew pictures of himself with angel wings. He left a set of his dog tags on a nightstand in my Manhattan apartment. He bought a tiny blue sweat suit for our baby to wear home from the hospital.

headline: Craig Hugh Smyth, 91, Dies; Renaissance Art Historian
text: Craig Hugh Smyth, an art historian who drew attention to the importance of conservation and the recovery of purloined art and cultural objects, died on Dec. 22 in Englewood, N.J. He was 91 and lived in Cresskill, N.J.

headline: A Dazzling Defensive Squeeze to Welcome the New Year
text: To begin the year the diagramed deal features one of the rarest plays in bridge, a defensive squeeze. It occurred during the World Bridge Federation’s junior training camp in Slovakia last July. Sitting East and West were Niclas Ege from Denmark and Adam Edgtton from Australia. Since they were not regular partners, that makes this defensive tour de force even more impressive.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Homicides Up in New York; Other Crimes Keep Falling
text: In New York City, rapes, robberies and assaults, among other crimes, continued to decline last year, prompting the Police Department’s top official to herald 2006 as a very good year. Homicides, however, climbed 10 percent in the city, reversing a much-hailed decrease.

headline: Bombs in Bangkok Kill 2 and Wound More Than 30
text: BANGKOK, Monday, Jan. 1  Nine small bombs exploded around Bangkok overnight, killing two people and wounding 34 people in a city that remains under martial law after a coup three months ago. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

headline: Costly Gift From Microsoft Is an Invitation to Blog
text: In Microsoft’s latest attempt to reach out to bloggers, the company recently gave away expensive laptops loaded with its new Windows Vista operating system. But the gifts generated controversy as well as good will, as many in that community accused Microsoft of bribery and their peers of unethical behavior.

headline: The Hope of a Fresh Start
text: New Year’s Day is the simplest holiday in the calendar, a Champagne cork of a day after all the effervescence of the evening before. There is no civic agenda, no liturgical content, only the sense of something ended, something begun. It is a good day to clean the ashes out of the wood stove, to consider the possibilities of next summer’s garden, to wonder how many weeks into the new year you will be before you marvel at how quickly 2007 is going. “This will be the year ...,” you find yourself thinking, but before you can finish the thought you remember what all the previous years have taught you — that there’s just no telling.

headline: Share Grandma’s Birthday, With Music and Animation
text: FOR years, Internet users have treated online photo services like a batch of holiday snapshots — checking them out for a while, then letting them collect dust on the shelf as soon as something new comes along.

headline: With Wild-Card Spot Clinched, Jets Can Finally Talk Playoffs
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 31 — The Jets’ offense was on the field Sunday running out the clock on the regular season when the Jets’ defense ran its own two-minute drill.

headline: One Team Thrives on Chemistry; Another Survives Without It
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Amid Champagne and Cheers, Spitzer Is Sworn In as Governor
text: ALBANY, Monday, Jan. 1 — With his wife, his children and his parents looking on, Eliot Laurence Spitzer was officially sworn in at midnight as the 54th governor of New York State during a private ceremony here at the governor’s mansion.

headline: Another Last Chance to Change Your Life
text: Paris

headline: Studios’ DVDs Face a Crack in Security
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 — An anonymous computer programmer may have skewed the competition over standards for high-definition DVD discs by possibly defeating a scheme that both sides use to protect digital content.

headline: Somalia Orders Islamists to Turn in Weapons
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 1 — After Somalia’s Islamist forces abandoned their final outpost today, the transitional government moved aggressively to assert control by setting a three-day deadline for all weapons to be turned in and calling for international peacekeeping troops to be deployed immediately.

headline: At Sea With a Book to Read, and the Author of It, Too
text: As the Jewel of the Seas, a luxury cruise ship owned by Royal Caribbean, steamed down the coast toward Bermuda in late October, there were plenty of distractions, including two Olympic-size pools, Latin dance lessons and Boozer Bingo. But Birdie Jaworski was having none of it.

headline: The Not Wanted Signs
text: I’ve heard the concern expressed dozens of times by New Orleans residents who are poor and black and still living in enforced exile from their wounded city: Maybe they don’t want us back.

headline: Romania and Bulgaria Join European Union
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 1 — Romania and Bulgaria joined the European Union today, helping to end geographic divisions left over from the cold war and extending the borders of the now 27-member bloc eastward to the Black Sea.

headline: Hamas Reports Progress on Freeing Israeli Soldier
text: JERUSALEM, Dec. 31  Palestinian groups involved in holding an Israeli soldier who was captured in late June said Sunday that significant progress had been made toward a prisoner exchange that would release him.

headline: Cross-Check Brings Orr Five-Game Suspension
text: The National Hockey League suspended Rangers right wing Colton Orr for five games yesterday for cross-checking the Washington Capitals star Alexander Ovechkin in the head late in the Rangers’ 4-1 victory Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Something Wiki Is Coming to the Web Search Market
text: The voluntary collaborative “wiki” model, which was marshaled to create the behemoth online encyclopedia Wikipedia, is being recruited for another challenge: to build a better search engine.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: While Favre Shows Greatness, Grossman Worries Chicago
text: CHICAGO, Dec. 31  While the Green Bay Packers wonder about Brett Favre’s future, the Chicago Bears worry about Rex Grossman as they head into the playoffs.

headline: New CDs
text: DAVID BANNER “Spare Clips: The Mixtape” (B.I.G.F.A.C.E.)

headline: States Take Lead on Ethics Rules for Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 — The Democrats taking over Congress this week are promising sweeping changes to ethics and lobbying laws, pledging to clean up after a spate of corruption scandals under Republican rules.

headline: Broncos Player Is Killed in Drive-By Shooting
text: About a month ago, the Denver Broncos’ starting cornerback Darrent Williams said he looked forward to returning to Fort Worth, Tex., in the off-season to warn young people in his hometown about staying away from violence and drugs. Williams never got home. Hours after the Broncos lost to the San Francisco 49ers to be knocked from the playoff race, Williams was shot to death in what the police said was a drive-by shooting in downtown Denver early on New Year’s Day.

headline: Eagles Clinch the N.F.C. East, Then They Win Again
text: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31  A few minutes into Sunday’s game against Atlanta, a hard season finally got easy for the Philadelphia Eagles. The National Football Conference East was clinched for the fifth time in six seasons, win or lose against the Falcons.

headline: Mozart, Now Singing at a Theater Near You
text: In movie theaters across the United States on Saturday, people did an odd thing during the main attraction: They clapped. They clapped between scenes and when certain characters left the screen.

headline: Toting Up the Sum of Its Influences
text: Gov’t Mule played two Beatles songs as encores at the Beacon Theater on Friday night. Earlier in the show the band covered Cream, Jimi Hendrix, Willie Dixon (by way of Howlin’ Wolf) and Little Milton (via Jerry Garcia). A James Brown jam was offered in tribute. A Stevie Wonder vamp cropped up in a Mahavishnu Orchestra tune. And during John Fogerty’s “Effigy” there were quotations of Johnny Cash songs.

headline: North Bergen, N.J.: 2 People Killed in Collision
text: Two people were killed and another person was seriously injured after a sport utility vehicle slammed into a sedan on Route 1 and 9 yesterday evening, the police said. They did not identify the victims, but said the two people killed had been in the same car, a red Ford Fusion. According to a witness, a woman walked out of the Days Inn at 2750 Tonnelle Avenue about 6 p.m. and got into the driver’s seat of the Ford. She left the motel’s driveway and tried to cut across the northbound lane of Route 1 and 9, but a Dodge Durango plowed into her car, causing serious damage to the driver’s side, said Amir Kadri, 26, a witness. The driver of the Dodge, a man, was taken to Jersey City Medical Center in serious condition, the police said.

headline: 2006 Called the Deadliest Year for Journalists and Media Workers
text: BRUSSELS, Dec. 31 (Dow Jones/AP) — The year 2006 was the deadliest for journalists and news media workers worldwide, with at least 155 killings and unexplained deaths, the International Federation of Journalists said Sunday.

headline: Somali Clan Elders Urge Islamists to Leave Stronghold
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 31  As fighting began to flare Sunday around Kismayo, in southern Somalia, the final redoubt for the country’s diminished Islamic movement, elders within the city demanded that the Islamists go.

headline: Johnny Gibson, 101, Track Coach With a Long Legacy, Is Dead
text: Johnny Gibson, a former world-record holder in the 400-meter hurdles and a highly successful track coach at Seton Hall University for 26 years, died Friday in a nursing home in Newton, N.J. He was 101.

headline: U.S. Questioned Iraq on the Rush to Hang Hussein
text: BAGHDAD, Dec. 31 — With his plain pine coffin strapped into an American military helicopter for a predawn journey across the desert, Saddam Hussein, the executed dictator who built a legend with his defiance of America, completed a turbulent passage into history on Sunday.

headline: In Starting Role, Barrett Sets Positive Tone Early
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 31  Cornerback David Barrett typifies the mind-set Jets Coach Eric Mangini tried to instill during his first year as a head coach. He does not pout about playing time, knowing that his time to contribute will eventually come.

headline: Day of Remembrance
text: Federal offices, courts and post offices will be closed tomorrow for a national day of remembrance in honor of President Gerald R. Ford. Stock markets in New York will also be closed, but city and state government offices, courts and schools will be open.

headline: What Sticks from ’06
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: An Opera at the Met That’s Real and ‘Loud’
text: Even before the Metropolitan Opera’s Saturday matinee of Mozart’s “Magic Flute” began, this family-friendly version of Julie Taymor’s 2004 production looked to be a huge success. Children were everywhere, a rare sight at the venerable institution. They were having pictures taken in front of the house, dashing up and down the stairs of the Grand Promenade and, before long, sitting up in their seats all over the auditorium.

headline: New Year’s Day
text: NEW YORK.

headline: With Slick Offense, U.C.L.A. Proves to Be Worthy No. 1
text: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 — With conference play beginning in earnest across the country this weekend, it has become clear that this college basketball season is playing out in the same frenetic manner as the N.C.A.A. tournament last spring.

headline: Spitzer, Sworn In, Signs Ethics Orders and Seeks Reform
text: ALBANY, Jan. 1 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed five executive orders in his first morning as governor of New York, including orders establishing a number of ethical guidelines for state workers and making the government more open to the public.

headline: Estimates of Iraqi Civilian Deaths
text: Unlike the tally for American service members, no official count is available for the number of civilians killed in Iraq. Estimates based on mortuary tallies, news reports and household surveys vary widely.

headline: Inauguration Day
text: Eliot Spitzer, the new governor of New York, ended 12 years of Republican rule with a blunt critique of the past and a call to “end the politics of cynicism and division in our state.”

headline: A Revival for 'Tea and Sympathy'
text: “Tea and Sympathy,” the Robert Anderson play about a lonely, misunderstood boarding-school boy that opened on Broadway in 1953 and ran for more than 700 performances, will be revived by the Keen Company as the final production of its season.

headline: U.S.C. Tops Michigan in Rose Bowl
text: Although no national title was at stake, no game in college football’s postseason has more historical resonance than the Rose Bowl.

headline: The Eliot Dash
text: The sky was pitch black and a steady rain was falling when Eliot Spitzer, the new governor, arrived at the Spanish Revival lake house in Washington Park at 5:43 a.m. Monday to keep his first campaign promise: taking a morning run through the park on his first day in office.

headline: Getting to Work Already
text: Governor Eliot Spitzer signed five executive orders in his first morning as governor of New York, including orders establishing a number of ethical guidelines for state workers and making the government more open to the public.

headline: Out With the Old, In With the New
text: Governor Eliot Spitzer and his wife, Silda, climbed the 77 steps up to the eastern entrance of the Capitol, where they were greeted by former Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby. As the two couples chatted and posed for pictures, the overcast skies suddenly lightened, giving a hint that the sun was up there somewhere.

headline: Washington Irving, Political Cudgel

Giuliani was campaigning for Republican candidates last fall, his aides were secretly planning a Giuliani presidential campaign despite his statements to the contrary, targeting potential donors and assessing possible liabilities, including his controversial former aide, Bernard B. Kerik, and his ex-wife Donna Hanover, according to a 140-page strategy document apparently prepared by Giuliani advisers.

headline: Helping New York Youths, Fresh Out of Jail, Stay Out

Just as dawn broke in April, a Department of Correction van dropped the 17-year-old and about 30 other convicts at Queensborough Plaza, among the “homeless, a lot of prostitutes, and crackheads” on the street that morning, he said. He shared a few of his $22 with three other teenage convicts, before hopping on the train home to Brownsville, Brooklyn.

headline: Pop Music and the War: The Sound of Resignation

Whatever the line means within the band’s cryptic lyrics, it could also apply to the past year’s popular music. Thoughts of romance, vice and comfort still dominated the charts and the airwaves. But amid the entertainment, songwriters — including some aiming for the Top 10 — were also grappling with a war that wouldn’t go away.

headline: What's on Tuesday Night
text: 10 P.M. (FX) DIRT It’s payback time. Courteney Cox is said to have turned the tables on all those paparazzi who have stalked her for years and asked them for professional advice regarding this, her new series, in which she stars and, with her husband, David Arquette, executive produces. In it, Ms. Cox plays the aptly christened Lucy Spiller, an unscrupulous tabloid editor who will stop at nothing — like convincing the struggling-actor boyfriend of a big star to sell her out, or hiring a fake groupie to sexually ensnare a married basketball player — to dig up the Hollywood gossip her readers can’t get enough of. Ian Hart plays Don Konkey, her favorite, schizophrenic photographer, who doesn’t mind hurting himself in the process.

headline: Heart Health: Vitamin Does Not Prevent Death by Heart Disease
text: Vitamin B12 supplements are not effective in preventing strokes, heart attacks or death in people with a history of vascular disease, a new review of studies concludes. Vitamin B12 reduces the blood levels of homocysteine, a risk factor for cardiovascular disease, but the reduction apparently has no effect on survival.

headline: Playbook Full of Tricks Gives Boise State Dramatic and Defining Victory
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Monday, Jan. 2 — After a hook-and-lateral, a Statue of Liberty play and a halfback toss launched the Boise State football team to an upset that will long resonate in college football lore, the star tailback Ian Johnson might have saved the night’s most memorable surprise for the postgame interview. With the national television cameras focused on him after the chaos of Boise State’s 43-42 overtime victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night, Johnson proposed to his girlfriend, the Boise State cheerleader Christine Barbara Popadics. Popadics was so stunned and thrilled that she could barely speak. Just like everyone else watching. “She had no idea it was coming,” Johnson said. Neither did Oklahoma. Johnson’s proposal capped a dizzying, riveting, back-and-forth game that will be remembered as one of the most exciting in college football history. Boise squandered an 18-point second-half lead, tied the score with seven seconds remaining on a hook-and-lateral play, then used two more trick plays in overtime to cap a perfect 13-0 season. (Ohio State is the only other undefeated team.) “This probably goes down in the history of college football,” Boise quarterback Jared Zabransky said. “It can be argued as the best game ever.” The lasting memory of the game will most likely be the combination of three crazy trick plays — called Statue, Toss Halfback Pass and Circus. But the lasting effect — with a team that plays on blue turf competing against one of college football’s bluebloods — may be the removal of doubt about whether teams from smaller conferences can beat champions of the six major conferences. No one can doubt the daring of Boise’s play-calling. On the final play, Broncos Coach Chris Petersen decided to leave his offense on the field for a 2-point conversion attempt after Boise matched Oklahoma’s touchdown to open overtime. The call was for “Statue,” in which Boise lines up with three wide receivers stacked on the right side. The real guts by Petersen and Bryan Harsin, Boise’s 30-year old offensive coordinator, may have come with sticking with the play after Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops called a timeout. Boise went with the same look, with the stacked right side, showing a formation from which they often throw a wide receiver screen. Instead, Zabransky faked a screen pass to Legedu Naanee on his right, then hid the ball behind his back with his left hand. Johnson never moved, staying frozen until the fake was properly sold. Johnson then broke left against the grain of play, grabbed the ball from behind Zabransky’s back and strolled untouched around the left side into the end zone. The final 2 yards of his 101-yard night will forever be remembered in Boise history. The 2-point conversion made it 43-42 and set off a wild celebration on the Boise sideline and in the stands, where a majority of the 73,719 fans were decked out in Bronco blue and orange. “We needed a play like that to get it over with,” Petersen said after the game with a smile. But the two plays that got them there may have been even more creative. After Oklahoma tailback Adrian Peterson took the first play of overtime 25 yards for a touchdown, Boise needed to convert on a fourth-and-2 from the 5-yard line. Things got crazy, though, when Zabransky left his usual spot under center and broke in motion to the left. Vinny Perretta, a tailback who hadn’t thrown a pass all year, then lined up under center and threw a 5-yard touchdown pass to tight end Derek Schouman. That call was for “Toss Halfback Pass,” and it was the first time Boise had run it in a game this season. “We’ve been practicing it for the past month or so, and it couldn’t have worked out any better,” said Schouman, who also caught a 10-yard pass on third-and-8 to extend the overtime drive. Just to get to overtime, though, Boise pulled off perhaps the grandest of its three trick plays. On fourth-and-18 play from midfield, the Broncos called a hook-and-lateral play, “Circus.” They think so little of it that they hadn’t run it in a game or practice all season. They only did it while goofing off during informal Friday walk-through sessions. And even then it didn’t really work. “Usually we just run it when we’re joking around,” Schouman said. “I never thought that we’d actually run it, never mind for a touchdown.” Boise lined up with three wide receivers to the right and Drisan James alone on the left. James caught the ball about 12 yards from the line of scrimmage, with the defense playing soft to prevent him from getting a first down. The key to the play was James’s ability to fake that he was going to try and run for a first down. He tucked the ball and ran about 4 yards, which drew all the Oklahoma defenders toward him. Then he pitched the ball 4 yards behind him to Jerard Rabb, who had run over from the cluster of receivers on the other side of the field. “I didn’t even want to look after I pitched it,” James said. But the pitch went seamlessly, and Rabb knew almost instantly that James had executed the perfect fake. “When he caught it, he sucked the defensive backs, safeties and corners, they all came straight to him,” Rabb said. “He held it just long enough for me to escape around the side. “As soon as I got the ball and took about two steps, I was gone. Other than the time I was getting chased by a pit bull, it was the fastest I’ve run in my life.” Rabb’s mad dash to force overtime with seven seconds left also chased away some of Boise’s demons. Thanks to Paul Thompson’s four turnovers, which included a pick-six by Boise defensive back Marty Tadman and a fumble deep in Oklahoma territory, Boise was able to build a 28-10 third-quarter lead. But Oklahoma gutted its way back into the game, and scored two touchdowns in the final 90 seconds of regulation to go ahead. The first score came on a 5-yard pass from Thompson to Quentin Chaney to cut the Boise lead to 28-26. The drama came on the 2-point conversion; Oklahoma attempted it three times, thanks to a pass-interference call on Boise and a pre-snap motion penalty on the Sooners. On the third play, Thompson found Jauquin Iglesias in the end zone to tie the score at 28-28. Oklahoma cornerback Marcus Walker then seemingly decided matters when he returned an interception 33 yards for a touchdown with 1:02 remaining. “The game isn’t over until the clock hits zero,” Walker said in a stunned Oklahoma locker room. Many players wept openly. “But you would think the game is over then, right?” By then, it had only just begun. And on a deeper level, the Broncos were able to legitimize the very game that they were permitted to play. For the first time this season, there are five B.C.S. games this season instead of four because the smaller conferences fought hard for access to the B.C.S. and won. In one surreal night, the long battle spearheaded by Tulane’s president, Scott Cowan, seemed worthwhile. “The gap is decreasing fast,” Johnson said. “The smaller schools are going to start getting recognition now. Just because we haven’t been around forever doesn’t mean we don’t play great football.” Johnson and his teammates showed the college football establishment they have a few tricks up their sleeves. And if you don’t believe him, just ask a certain Boise State cheerleader.

headline: To Protect Against Drug Errors, Ask Questions
text: The elderly aunt of a colleague was sharp as a tack, living on her own and busy doing everything a healthy woman in her 80s might want to do. That is, until she went to the pharmacy to pick up a refill of methazolamide, the pills she took to control her glaucoma, and instead was given methotrexate, a potent chemotherapy drug that suppresses immunity. The woman noticed that the color of the new pills was different from her previous pills and questioned the pharmacist, who told her they were fine. She even counted them, noting that she was short six pills. But on the pharmacist’s reassurance, she took them for a month, by which time the drug had seriously suppressed her body’s immune system.

headline: Few Clues in Fatal Shooting of Woman and Son on L.I.
text: CORAM, N.Y., Jan. 1  Police investigators sifted through what they said were few clues on Monday in the fatal shooting of a 52-year-old woman and her 30-year-old son, who were found on Saturday night in a basement apartment where they lived with the son’s wife and two young children.

headline: When Teachers Choose Their Schools (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ethiopia Plans to Pull Troops From Somalia
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 2 — The prime minister of Ethiopia, Meles Zenawi, said today that his country, one of the poorest in the world, could not afford to keep its troops in neighboring Somalia much longer, and that Somalia’s stability depended on the quick injection of foreign peacekeepers.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: New Year’s Eve Brings Wardrobe Malfunction

headline: Chaos Overran Iraq Plan in ’06, Bush Team Says
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 — President Bush began 2006 assuring the country that he had a “strategy for victory in Iraq.” He ended the year closeted with his war cabinet on his ranch trying to devise a new strategy, because the existing one had collapsed.

headline: Iraq Plans Inquiry Into Hussein Execution
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 2 — With angry demonstrations spreading across Iraq’s Sunni Arab heartland, the country’s Shiite-led government said today that it had ordered an investigation into the disorderly scenes at the execution of Saddam Hussein, who was mocked and taunted by Shiite witnesses and guards as he stood on the gallows.

headline: Kissinger’s Appearance Revives Memories of Vietnam Era
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 — Of all the aging Washington power brokers who have re-emerged in the shadow of the death of former President Gerald R. Ford, there is one, Henry A. Kissinger, for whom the return to the spotlight may be as much curse as blessing.

headline: A Road Through History, Paved in Spanish Tile
text: New Yorkers don’t often meet up with tiles, outside subway stations or the shower. Tiles flourish, after all, at latitudes where palm trees grow and window shutters are needed to minimize abundant sunlight.

headline: Jeb Bush Ponders Future, Not Knowing What It Holds
text: MIAMI, Jan. 1 — When the same old irksome question popped up recently at one of his final public events here, Gov. Jeb Bush, addressing Spanish-speaking reporters, gave an atypically dramatic answer: “Yo no tengo futuro,” or “I have no future.”

headline: Second Thoughts on Gays in the Military
text: Steilacoom, Wash.

headline: The Fine Art of Watching a Bug’s Life to Explain a Death
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — For a man with a truly curious profession, Robert D. Hall, 59, has a relaxed way of talking about his work.

headline: Cookie Conundrum in the Doctor-Patient Drama
text: She always came on time to our sessions, even in the thick of a Boston blizzard. She always wore the best clothing her hardscrabble life in “the projects” permitted her. And after each session, she would place a small bag of her homemade cookies on my desk, leaving with a shy smile that flickered with pride.

headline: Raging Against the Dying of the Good Old Ways
text: A nagging question may come to mind throughout the film “A Fish Story,” tonight on the PBS series “Independent Lens”: Would anyone bother telling or watching this tale if it didn’t lend itself to all those picturesque shots of weather-hardened men working the ocean?

headline: Jets and Patriots Echo a Past N.F.L. Reunion
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 1 — The family reunion featured the usual menu of gratitude mixed with grudges. Those who follow football ate it up and asked for seconds and thirds. It got to the point where the players in the postseason game between the rookie head coach and his mentor wished they could be excused from the table.

headline: In the Long Run, Great Arms Come With Big Risks
text: Pete Seeger wrote it and Peter, Paul and Mary sang it and made it hugely popular during the Vietnam War. It could apply to the war in Iraq, but the refrain in “Where Have All the Flowers Gone” applies to baseball as well:

headline: Exposed: Celebrities, Tabloids and Sleaze!
text: There is no role as delicious as a truly nasty, sneaky gossipmonger. Burt Lancaster shone as J. J. Hunsecker, the Walter Winchellesque villain of “Sweet Smell of Success.” George Sanders stole scenes as the poison pen Addison DeWitt in “All About Eve,” and Henry Daniell was weasel incarnate as Sidney Kidd, the editor of Spy magazine in “The Philadelphia Story.”

headline: Romania and Bulgaria Celebrate Entry Into European Union
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 1  Romania and Bulgaria joined the European Union on Monday, helping to end geographic divisions left over from the cold war and extending the borders of the now 27-member bloc eastward to the Black Sea.

headline: A Party, With Pelosi Front and Center
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1  During her first 100 hours as House speaker, Nancy Pelosi has vowed, she will sweep an aggressive legislative agenda through the newly Democratic-controlled House.

headline: Celebrating Movie Musicals That Are Never Out of Date
text: You can’t accuse the New York Philharmonic of not having a sense of occasion. As it often does, the orchestra set aside the formalities of the classical repertory on New Year’s Eve in favor of lighter fare, although this time another kind of formality was evident. With Audra McDonald in the spotlight, her regular conductor, Ted Sperling, on the podium, and a jazz rhythm section deployed within the orchestra, the Philharmonic offered an evening of songs drawn mostly from film musicals of the 1930s through the ’50s.

headline: Kicking an Addiction, With Real People
text: Smokers are lectured enough by nonsmokers, so some advertisers say the best way to persuade people to give up cigarettes is to tell the stories of other smokers.

headline: Henry A. Kissinger’s Eulogy for President Ford
text: Following is the transcript of the eulogy for former President Gerald R. Ford delivered today by Henry A. Kissinger in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: Holding the Line
text: The old year was certainly a boom one for American business, with record profits for companies and record bonuses on Wall Street. But in the background a major accounting scandal has quietly spread, now encompassing more than 120 companies. Fudging the grant date for stock options doesn’t quite have the spotlight-grabbing immediacy of Enron’s collapse, but it is still gaming the system at the expense of shareholders.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: A Past That Makes Us Squirm
text: Crawford, Colo.

headline: Squirrels That Predict the Future
text: It’s like the Beach Boys said: Catch a wave and you’re sitting on top of the world.

headline: From Far Beneath the Israeli Desert, Water Sustains a Fertile Enterprise
text: KIBBUTZ MASHABBE SADE, Israel — The day’s coppery last light reflects off the backs of sea bass swimming in fish ponds lined in neat rows on this desert farm.

headline: Auburn and Bowl Try to Find Their Place
text: DALLAS, Jan. 1  Forget poignant toasts or sappy resolutions for the new year. The Auburn Tigers were still living in the present and believed they needed to define this season once and for all.

headline: Wi-Fi Is Hitting the Road in Cars From Avis, but Technical and Legal Bumps Lie Ahead
text: Try connecting to a high-speed wireless network from a car, and you are pretty much limited to one method: rigging your laptop computer with a special modem and subscribing to a costly, and sometimes temperamental, wireless service.

headline: Top Israeli General Admits Errors in Lebanon War
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 — The Israeli chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, conceded today that the military made serious errors during last summer’s war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, but he said he would not resign his post.

headline: After 15 Years, Someone’s in Charge in Somalia, if Barely
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 1 — After Somalia’s Islamist forces abandoned their final outpost on Monday, the transitional government moved aggressively to assert control, setting a three-day deadline for all weapons to be turned in and calling for international peacekeeping troops to be sent immediately.

headline: Broncos Cornerback Dies in Shooting
text: About a month ago, the Denver Broncos starting cornerback Darrent Williams said he looked forward to returning to Fort Worth during the off-season to warn young people in his hometown about staying away from violence and drugs.

headline: Dollars in the Sand
text: Ocho Rios, Jamaica

headline: When Bad Things Come From ‘Good’ Food
text: People in the United States have gotten used to the repulsive fact that raw chicken, meat and eggs are often contaminated with dangerous bacteria. Scrub the cutting board, we are warned, don’t nibble the cookie dough, don’t eat burgers rare. In other words, handle meat like a biohazard — and then eat it.

headline: Should Boise State Get a Share?
text: The Boise State-Oklahoma game last night had one of the greatest finishes for a big game in football history. Click here, then go to the fourth-quarter video highlights.

headline: Rome: The Sequel
text: Can a made-for-TV empire stand up to the real thing?

headline: A Villa in Valencia
text: Joe and Lucrecia Neira, and their two children, moved from Westchester County, N.Y., to a sun-drenched home outside the Spanish port city of Valencia.

headline: Efforts to Save a London Museum
text: The Theater Museum in London, Britain’s national museum of the performing arts, is scheduled to close to the public on Sunday after almost 20 years at its Russell Street location in Covent Garden.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Yale Repertory Theater will present "In the Continuum," written and performed by Danai Gurira and Nikkole Salter, beginning on Jan. 12 at that New Haven theater. The production, which had a critically acclaimed Off Broadway run in the fall of 2005, is on an international tour.

headline: A Year of Wheeling, Dealing and Reeling
text: To commemorate a banner year for deals, we raised a glass to some of the notable names of 2006 in DealBook’s annual “closing dinner” column. We toasted the likes of Lloyd Blankfein, who ascended to the role of chief executive at investment banking giant Goldman Sachs, and Stephen Schwarzman, whose Blackstone Group raised record sums of money for its buyout fund. We also lobbed zingers at some of the players who failed to wow Wall Street in the past year. To them, we say better luck in 2007.

headline: Not the Case
text: Even among those who opposed the Iraq war from the start, there was always hope that bringing Saddam Hussein to justice would be a saving grace of the entire misbegotten enterprise. Now it seems that even this comfort will be denied. Far from healing old wounds, as some suggested it would, his conviction by the Iraqi special tribunal has exerted little effect on the deepening civil conflict between Shiites and Sunnis. The often circuslike atmosphere of the trial, as well as the murder of three defense lawyers, led groups like Human Rights Watch to condemn the tribunal as flawed and illegitimate. And the charge for which Saddam Hussein received the death penalty did not include his most heinous acts. His execution must still remind the world of the horror of the atrocities he committed while in power. But unfortunately, the disarray of the legal process calls greater attention to the failings of the United States, the Iraqis and the international community in dealing with all that has come after.

headline: Blodget Warns on Hedge-Fund Investing
text: Average investors should be wary of taking the plunge into hedge funds, the former Internet analyst Henry Blodget cautions in a Slate article adapted from his book, “The Wall Street Self-Defense Manual.”

headline: Pinault Keeps Door Open to $92 Billion Suez Bid
text: Is one of France’s biggest corporate raiders looking to break up a government-engineered energy merger? According to The New York Times, François Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the luxury fashion house Gucci, is exploring a bid for the French utility Suez that could be as high as 70 billion euros ($92 billion). In an e-mailed statement Tuesday, Mr. Pinault’s holding company, Artemis, said that “all options remain open” for a possible bid, sending shares of the world’s second-largest water company to a record.

headline: Loaded With Personalities, Now Satellite Radio May Try a Merger
text: Will 2007 be the year that Sirius Satellite Radio and its larger rival XM Satellite Radio do a deal? Following persistent speculation that the two satellite radio companies may merge (egged on by determined cheerleading from pugnacious market pundit Jim Cramer), The New York Times takes a look at why this year may be the year for a deal.

headline: CITIC of China Buys Kazakhstan Oil Assets
text: China, which is aggressively seeking overseas energy assets to run its booming economy, said Sunday that one of its biggest conglomerates had bought the Kazakhstan oil assets of a Canadian company for $1.91 billion. The CITIC Group of China bought the oil assets of the Nations Energy Company of Canada and granted KazMunaiGas, Kazakhstan’s state-owned oil company, an option to a 50 percent interest in Nations Energy, the official Xinhua Agency said.

headline: Whither Nasdaq’s Bid for the L.S.E.?
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market‘s chief executive, Robert Greifeld, will begin a second round of meetings with investors in the London Stock Exchange this week, in a sign that the exchange has no intention of raising its 12.43-pound-a-share ($24.48-a-share) bid for its British rival, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Israeli Property Consortium Buys Marriott Hotels from Royal Bank of Scotland
text: Delek Real Estate, an Israeli property company, and its partners have agreed to buy 47 British hotels operated by Marriott International from Royal Bank of Scotland for about $2.1 billion. Delek will purchase a 17 percent stake in the hotels through its Delek-Belron International unit, while Electra Real Estate will buy a 9.9 percent stake.

headline: Chinese Bank Buys Indonesian Rival
text: The Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, which had a record initial public offering in October, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Bank Halim of Indonesia in its first such overseas purchase. Industrial & Commercial, which did not disclose the deal price, said it would buy 90 percent of Bank Halim and take an option to buy the rest from shareholders in three years.

headline: Banks Get Noticed for Their Artsy Side
text: Since its creation in 2002, ArtReview magazine’s authoritative Power 100, the annual ranking of those who hold sway in the art world, has included artists like Damien Hirst of Britain, collectors like the French billionaire François Pinault or art dealers n the United States like Larry Gagosian. Last year, for the first time, banks were added to the list.

headline: A Nouvelle Vague for Tech I.P.O.s?
text: Will 2007 be the year that the tech I.P.O. makes its comeback? A steadying of interest rates and inflation, a recent rally in the tech-heavy Nasdaq, and exceptional performance of tech offerings since the summer of 2006 have given observers hope of a significant rise in initial public offerings of technology start-ups this year, BusinessWeek writes. Already, 2006 saw a 31 percent rise in I.P.O. filings, with 67 tech companies filing to go public.

headline: L.S.E. Moves to Tighten Rules for Alternative Exchange
text: The London Stock Exchange is planning to tighten regulations in a move that would make it easier to take disciplinary action against brokers that bring unsuccessful companies to the Alternative Investment Market. The change is part of a bid to toughen rules governing the nominated advisers, or nomads, that oversee companies coming to the alternative market, which is administered by the London exchange.

headline: Sinclair Pharma Plans I.P.O.
text: Sinclair Pharma, the oral hygiene and skincare specialist, will list its shares on Euronext in the first half of the year as the company gears up for further acquisitions in Europe. Valued at about 100 milion pounds ($197 million), the company is one of Britain’s larger healthcare firms and is expected by analysts to be planning a string of deals this year.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Race Is On to Trump Google
text: As Google continues to outmaneuver its main search rivals, Yahoo and Microsoft, plenty of newcomers – with names like Powerset, hakia, ChaCha and Snap – are trying to beat the company at its own game. And Wikia, a company started by a founder of Wikipedia, plans to develop a search engine that, like the popular Web-based encyclopedia, would be built by a community of programmers and users.

headline: Leases to Hedge Funds Raise Questions
text: They are known as “hedge fund hotels”: Offices that investment banks lease out to upstart hedge-fund traders, usually in hopes that the traders-in-residence will become big clients. As The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson reports, they often come with luxurious amenities, such as receptionists, espresso machines and consultants to help manage their information systems. But, Ms. Anderson wrties, they are also raising questions. William F. Galvin, the Massachusetts secretary of state, has subpoenaed UBS, the leader in this business, and is examining other banks with hedge fund hotels in Boston to determine how they are charging for their services.

headline: Virgin in Investment Talks With AirAsia, Report Says
text: Virgin Group has re-entered talks with AirAsia about taking a stake in the Malaysia-based low-cost airline, in a move that would give the British company a wider foothold in the Asian market. The Times of London reported that AirAsia has approached Virgin in the hope that its Virgin Atlantic subsidiary would invest in the Malaysian airline.

headline: Using Web Cams but Few Inhibitions, the Young Turn to Risky Social Sites
text: How far will uptsarts go to try and topple popular web starts like YouTube and MySpace? Quite a bit further, it seems. Increasingly, new Web sites like Stickam.com, Dailymotion, and LiveLeak are building their businesses by going where others fear to tread: into the realm of unmonitored downloading, depictions of nudity and violence and unfiltered live broadcasts from Web cameras, writes The New York Times.

headline: Wi-Fi Is Hitting the Road in Cars From Avis
text: Autonet Mobile, a start-up wireless technology company based in San Francisco, is expected to announce this week that it has reached an agreement with Avis Rent A Car System to provide a rolling Wi-Fi hotspot to Avis customers by March.

headline: CVC Capital Partners Gears Up to Go Hostile
text: One of Europe’s largest private equity houses plans to carry out hostile bids on public companies. The fund, CVC Capital Partners, has changed the terms of agreement with its investors so that it can attempt to take over businesses without the support of management, The Telegraph reported. The move will no doubt be unwelcome for directors of many publicly quoted companies who had previously thought they could resist a private equity bid, so long as they declined to play ball.

headline: The Lonely Newspaper Reader
text: Recalling the recent surprise announcement by McClatchy that it had decided to sell The Minneapolis Star Tribune for $530 million to a group of private equity bidders, The New York Times’s David Carr takes a look at what has happened to reading the newspaper at the breakfast table.

headline: Insurers to Pay DaimlerChrysler $221 Million
text: DaimlerChrysler will recover about 168 million euros ($221.5 million) from insurers in settling a dispute over the costs of a 2003 class-action lawsuit in the United States, the Financial Times Deutschland reported.DaimlerChrysler and a group of insurance companies led by the insurer ACE had reached an agreement shortly before the end of the year, the report said. The suit was related to the acquisition of Chrysler by Daimler.

headline: Sony BMG Inks First Podcast Pacts
text: Rock River Communications has struck some of the first deals to license major-label content for podcasts, downloadable audio programs. Rock River, which specializes in making the mix CDs sold at the check-out counters of retailers like Gap and Williams-Sonoma‘s Pottery Barn, is creating a series of promotional podcasts on behalf of corporate clients including DaimlerChrysler and Ford Motor, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: A Long Way to Learn How to Help Those Back in Nepal
text: Kunsang Sherpa volunteers at Elmhust Hospital Center, and got aid to start in a nursing assistant’s program.

headline: Loose Ends in Enron’s Tangled Web
text: You might think that after last year’s trials of Enron’s former top two corporate chiefs, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, that the corporate fraud saga would finally be over. But several loose ends of the scandal that burst open when the company collapsed in December 2001 are still pending, although they are expected to be resolved in 2007.

headline: The Merger Outlook and This Year’s Targets
text: After helping to drive a record year for mergers and buyouts, will deal makers take a breather in 2007? Don’t count on it, several market watchers are saying this week. Among these M&A bulls is talk-show host and former hedge-fund manager James Cramer, who writes in the latest issue of New York magazine that “2007 will be even bigger than 2006″ in terms of deals. He also ticks off a series of well-known companies that he thinks are logical targets.

headline: $575,000 Homes
text: A chalet-style home in Maryland, a Mediterranean in Texas, and a condo in Marina del Rey, Calif.

headline: Essar Lines Up Financial Pledges for Cellphone Company Bid
text: Essar of India has secured financing pledges for a potential bid for the 67 percent that it does not own of Hutchison Essar, the cellphone operator it jointly owns with Hong Kong’s Hutchison Telecommunication International, The Financial Times reported. The paper said that Essar’s move underscores its seriousness and proves its toughness against rival bidders Vodafone and Reliance Communications.

headline: A New Year Marked by Mortal Transitions … and Debate
text: We wish all Lede readers the very best in the New Year.

headline: Story Schmory II
text: A while ago, the Bagger linked to Ray Pride’s interview with Alfonso Cuarón, in which he said that story qua story was waaaaaay overrated. The point was well made, but the Bagger thought again about the value of narrative this weekend when he made his way through several screeners, including “The Painted Veil” and “Water.”

headline: Now, for Even Longer Odds
text: Tired of all this year’s predictions? Why not switch to next year? Yes, that’s right, over at Oscar Igloo, they are working on the favorites for February, 2007.Turns out that making picks for this year is child’s play. It’s next year you should be thinking about. The Bagger will take “The Kite Runner” for now.

headline: Paper Hardware
text: Like millions of Americans yesterday, the Bagger was tired of staring into the faces of his loved ones, making small talk at parties and eating ham. So he opened up the paper to see what movie he should see — that way he could be with his loved ones, but not have to speak with them.

headline: Rethinking Middle School
text: Driven by slumps in learning and by high dropout rates, educators are struggling to rethink middle school.

headline: Downloading the Downbeat
text: David Denby of the New Yorker looks deep into his iPod and sees … a murky future for Hollywood.

headline: Bounty Hunting Online
text: People tend to use online personas to say things in print they otherwise would not. Take the Bagger: in real life, he is a complete nerd, scared of his own shadow. But give him a nom-de-blog and he suddenly blossoms into an avatar of cool, able to towel snap anyone with the greatest of ease.

headline: Republicans Turn Against the War
The Democrats’ Hill: Drawing the Battle Lines
text: With the opening of the 110th Congress set for later this week, Carl Hulse, the Times’s chief congressional correspondent writes today:

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Giuliani Exposed
text: This is probably not how former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani envisioned starting off the year. Well, actually, we can figure out exactly how he meant to start the year because he lost his campaign playbook (yes, an actual 140-page set of documents). It was left in one of the cities where he’s campaigning, and someone “sympathetic to one of Giuliani’s rivals for the White House” passed it off to The New York Daily News. The dossier detailed schedules, ambitious fundraising plans and possible liabilities for Mr. Giuliani:

headline: Lennar and Cerberus Sell LandSource Stake
text: The Home builder Lennar and LNR Property, a holding of Cerberus Capital Management, said on Tuesday they were selling a 62 percent stake in their LandSource joint venture to MW Housing Partners. Lennar also slashed its fourth-quarter profit forecast by as much as 46 percent, citing lower profit margins amid the deteriorating housing market in the United States

headline: Comment Zone: Dear Mr. Spitzer
text: So, Empire Zone readers, what should be at the top of Eliot Spitzer’s agenda as governor of New York? (He is expected to talk about his plans tomorrow in his first State of the State address.)

headline: Will Bill Miller Have a Happier New Year?
text: There has been a lot of talk about Wall Street’s many winners in 2006. It was a record year for worldwide merger activity and for profits at the bulge-bracket investment banks. Goldman Sachs‘s chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein, received the largest annual bonus ever awarded to a Wall Street chief. But there is at least one person on Wall Street who was probably very glad to ring out the old year: Bill Miller, the legendary mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason.

headline: Nucor to Acquire Harris Steel for $1.07 Billion
text: Nucor, the second-largest steel producer in the United States, agreed to acquire the Harris Steel Group of Canada for about $1.07 billion as the steel industry continues to see record consolidation. Nucor agreed to pay 46.25 Canadian dollars ($39.76) for each Harris Steel share, or 6.3 percent above the closing price Dec. 29.

headline: Qatar’s Contributions Curtailed at Wikipedia
text: A bit of controversy was brewing this morning over at Wikipedia, the freewheeling transcription of human knowledge by a hive of transient, often pseudonymous Internet users, when it was reported by CNet, BBC News, Slashdot and others that the site would no longer reflect the singular contributions of Qataris.

headline: Shoney’s Chain Finds New Buyer
text: Private equity firm Lone Star Funds has lined up a new buyer for Shoney’s, after a previous deal to sell the restaurant chain reportedly fell through. A unit of Royal Capital said Tuesday it would acquire the chain, known across the South for its buffets, for an undisclosed price. In July, Lone Star announced that it would sell Shoney’s, which it took private in 2002, to an affiliate of a Chicago real estate developer, Centrum Properties. But the Nashville Post reported in September that the deal collapsed, prompting a lawsuit.

headline: Execution Samizdat Investigated in Iraq
text: Iraqi officials have begun an investigation into the widespread distribution of shaky cellphone video footage (warning: it’s disturbingly graphic)  of the hanging of Saddam Hussein on Saturday. The video revealed that Mr. Hussein exchanged taunts and jeers with jailers in his final moments, and was told to “go to hell” by someone witnessing the event.

headline: Developer Accuses Hard Rock of Rigging Sale
text: Management of Hard Rock International, the chain of music-themed restaurants, hotels and casinos, rigged the $965 million sale of the company to favor the Seminole Tribe of Florida, a would-be bidder alleged in court filings Friday. The suit was filed by Cordish, a real-estate developer that worked with the Seminoles in developing its Hard Rock properties, accusing the franchise and its chief executive, Hamish Dodds, of collaborating with the tribe on the sale to insure that management was kept in place.

headline: The NYSE’s Electronic Man
text: In a long profile of the NYSE Group‘s chief executive, John Thain, New York magazine says Mr. Thain’s modus operandi has “always been to give the coming technocracy a human face.” It can be a tricky strategy to pull off, however. The essential functions of Wall Street, like trading on the New York Stock Exchange, are increasingly being handled by machines, threatening to uproot many of the Street’s long-standing traditions, the article notes.

headline: National Mourning
text: There’s nothing in Washington like the somber pageantry of a presidential funeral, from the camera studies of a frail but stoic widow, to the honor guard carrying the flag-draped coffin down the Capitol steps, the visages of an aging inner circle of a cabinet and the eulogies recalling memorable moments. And of course, the 21-gun salute.

headline: Vacation Home Resolutions
text: When you are obsessed with building a new home, your New Year’s resolutions have much more to do with tracking down the perfect flooring for the guest room than they do with diet and exercise.

headline: For Dodd, Wall Street Looms Large
text: Democrats take control of Congress this week, and many in the financial services industry are wondering what legal or regulatory changes are in store. An important figure to watch is Christopher Dodd, the Connecticut senator who will become chair of the powerful Senate Banking Committee. On Tuesday, the Associated Press suggested that Mr. Dodd’s potential presidential ambitions may temper any zeal to slap additional regulations on Wall Street.

headline: Why Go Cold Turkey? Try Playoff Fantasy
text: According to the semireliable end-all/be-all source of universal knowledge, Wikipedia, addiction is described as “a mental or physical disorder proposed to be precipitated by a combination of genetic, biological/pharmacological and social factors. Addiction is characterized by the repeated use of substances or behaviors despite clear evidence of morbidity secondary to such use.” Using these parameters, fantasy football is clearly an addiction.Mental disorder. Check. Anything that makes you worry incessantly about, say, Fred Taylor’s job security in light of Maurice Jones-Drew’s rising production — and do so during (allegedly) more important moments like client meetings, late night baby-feedings and/or intercourse with your significant other – clearly qualifies.

headline: Floating Away From New York
text: It was a hardly a bad year for the NYSE Group, whose shares have roughly doubled since June. But 2006 did bring one unhappy milestone for the NYSE, which operates the New York Stock Exchange. Thomson Financial notes that for the first time ever, the NYSE’s New York Stock Exchange was bested in the global market for initial public offerings. Both the London Stock Exchange and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange were bigger venues for public floats in 2006, as measured by the volume of proceeds raised, the research firm said.

headline: Blogtalk: Day 2
text: What good government groups hope to hear in Eliot Spitzer’s State of the State address tomorrow. An 8th grader’s perspective on the inaugural speech yesterday: “kind of mean” to George Pataki. [The Politicker]An anonymous speechwriter critiques the inaugural address, saying the closing line was good (“Day One is now”), but that Eliot should have skipped the Lincoln and Kennedyesque phrases. Praise for this line: “No matter how great the challenge – no matter how impossible the odds –- our destiny will never be a path to follow, but always a trail to blaze.” [Capitol Confidential]

headline: Study: Being Abused Is Not An Uplifting Experience
text: This might seem to have been better published in the Journal of Obvious Outcomes, but Reuters reports that a study published in this month’s Archives of General Psychiatry finds that “physically abused children have a 59 percent increased risk of lifetime major depression compared with similar children who were not abused.”

headline: Boise State and the Top 3 List
text: Driving back to the hotel with a few sportswriters after Boise State’s 43-42 victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl, we began kicking around the notion about whether it was the best game we’d ever covered.

headline: Corporate America Gets the (McNulty) Memo
text: Last year “will be remembered for introducing the phrase ‘stock options backdating’ to the general public,” law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen and Katz declared in a recent letter to clients. But it added that the year’s more-important legal catch phrase may be the “McNulty Memo,” which did not get quite as much attention in the media. Wachtell Lipton suggests that the memo was part of a “significant retreat” by the Justice Department, which was reacting to “the beginning of a true push-back against what have come to be perceived as overly aggressive government enforcement policies and practices.”

headline: For a Much-Mocked Resume, One More Dig
text: Michael Cera, who played George Michael, the would-be scion of the Bluth family, on the late, lamented TV show “Arrested Development,” has found new work: He is starring in an online video that parodies the egomaniacal video resume of Alexey Vayner. Mr. Vayner, a Yale student, sent his video, called “Impossible Is Nothing,” to investment banks in hopes of securing a job. But it was leaked to YouTube and beyond last summer, prompting a flood of ridicule and many comments on DealBook.

headline: A Congressman, a Muslim and a Buddhist Walk Into a Bar…
text: With all the uproar over the decision by Representative-elect Keith Ellison, the first Muslim to serve in Congress, to swear-in using the Koran, we’ve neglected the fact that another faith is making its first showing in the Capitol with not one but two freshmen.

headline: The State of the State
text: Governor Eliot Spitzer’s staff just released excerpts from his State of the State speech, which takes place at 1 p.m. tomorrow.

headline: U.F.O. Hits Congestion at O’Hare, Turns Back
text: A column in The Chicago Tribune yesterday has had many skywatchers atwitter over the last 24 hours, in that it details the apparent sighting by several United Airlines workers at Chicago’s O’Hare airport of … something hovering over Concourse C on Nov. 7.

headline: Pork Tenderloin
text: Food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares twice cooked pork tenderloin.

headline: Completely
Too Good to Be Real?
text: Happy New Year, dudes!

headline: Ford’s Lost Legacy
text: With the passing of Gerald Ford, we have lost more than a former president who served the nation honorably in trying times. The Republican Party has also lost its last link to a tradition it once embraced. Gone now is any trace of the solid Midwestern ethics that Ford personified — things like not spending more than you take in, being skeptical about the use of force, and not imposing one’s values on others.

headline: It’s the Year to Keep an Eye on Paychecks
text: What do you think will happen to the economy and to Americans’ paychecks in 2007?

headline: Peterson Considers Jump From Oklahoma to N.F.L.
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 2  Lost in the aftermath of Oklahoma’s wild overtime loss to Boise State in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night was what might have been the final college game of the star tailback Adrian Peterson.

headline: Recipe: Bucatini With Raw Nut Pesto and Tomato Sauce (Bucatini alla Lipari)
text: Time: About 40 minutes

headline: Patent Lawsuit Names Leading Technology Firms
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 — In 1997, Jonathan T. Taplin, a veteran film and television producer, stood up at a cable industry convention and asserted that in the future all movies would be distributed over the Internet. He recalls being laughed out of the room.

headline: Totals
