Bronx: Man Sentenced for Killing Son
text: A Bronx man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 25 years in prison for beating his 5-week-old son to death in a homeless shelter, the Bronx district attorney’s office said. The man, Michael Williams, 25, was convicted last month of second-degree murder in the death of Michael Williams Jr., his son. The boy died in December 2003 after he had 12 broken ribs, bruises all over his body and signs of chronic trauma to the spinal cord, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson said in a statement. Prosecutors said the child had been abused his entire life.

headline: After a Fire, a Beloved California Restaurant Vows to Rebuild
text: TO the people who found inspiration and solace at Manka’s Inverness Lodge, word that a fire took down the small restaurant and lodge two hours northwest of San Francisco last week was akin to news that a brilliant, eccentric and dear old friend had passed away.

headline: Daylight in Boeing’s Shadow
text: When Bob Baker at Harvest Partners, a real estate development company, tells people he is putting up a shopping center across the street from Boeing’s commercial jet factory, he usually gets quizzical looks. Although Renton, Wash., is a town better known for airplanes than Armani, Mr. Baker is convinced his mall will do well.

headline: Political Paper Stolen, Giuliani Camp Says
text: Advisers to former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that someone infiltrated the Giuliani camp last fall and stole a document about his presidential prospects and political liabilities. It was then leaked, they said, as a “dirty trick” to embarrass Mr. Giuliani and highlight such headaches as his controversial former aide, Bernard B. Kerik, and one of his ex-wives, Donna Hanover.

headline: Queens: Vigil by Shooting Victim’s Mother
text: The mother of Sean Bell, the unarmed man fatally shot by the police in November outside a Jamaica nightclub, said yesterday that she would stand vigil outside the police station for the 103rd Precinct, where the shooting occurred. The mother, Valerie Bell, said she would continue the vigil for 50 days, the number of bullets fired in the Nov. 25 shooting, or until indictments were filed in the case. Mr. Bell and a group of friends were in a car after his bachelor party when the shooting occurred. Two of Mr. Bell’s friends were wounded in the shooting. The officers have said that they thought one of the men in the car had a gun. The five police officers involved have been on desk duty since the shooting. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, is investigating.

headline: As Costs of Wildfires Grow, So Does a Question: Who Should Pay?
text: DENVER, Jan. 2 — The steeply rising cost of preventing and suppressing wildfires, which burned more of the American landscape in 2006 than in any other year since at least 1960, is creating a rift between Washington and state and local governments over how the burden ought to be shouldered.

headline: Excerpts From Eulogies
text: Following are excerpts from eulogies yesterday for former President Gerald R. Ford by former President George Bush; former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger; Tom Brokaw, the former NBC News anchor; and President Bush. A full transcript: nytimes.com/washington.

headline: White House Says It Would Have Handled Execution Differently
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — The Bush administration sought today to distance the United States and President Bush from the handling of Saddam Hussein’s execution, asserting that the growing controversy is a matter for the Iraqi government to investigate.

headline: A Princeton Maverick Succumbs to a Cultural Shift
text: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 29 — Logan Fox can’t quite pinpoint the moment when movies and television shows replaced books as the cultural topics people liked to talk about over dinner, at cocktail parties, at work. He does know that at Micawber Books, his 26-year-old independent bookstore here that is to close for good in March, his own employees prefer to come in every morning and gossip about “Survivor” or “that fashion reality show” whose title he can’t quite place.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Oprah Winfrey Opens Her South African School

headline: Sri Lanka: Tigers Say Air Raids Killed 15 Civilians
text: The Tamil Tiger rebels said that 15 people, including 4 children, had been killed in government airstrikes in the northwestern coastal town of Mannar and that dozens more had beeb wounded. The military said it bombed a rebel naval position and denied it had hit any civilians.

headline: Venezuela: 16 Dead in Prison Melee
text: Sixteen inmates were killed as rival gangs clashed at a prison in Uribana, in western Lara State. Violent deaths have plagued the country’s prisons, a system with about 19,000 inmates, as the authorities struggle with crowding and a shortage of trained guards. More than 300 inmates were killed in the first nine months of 2006. Almost 50 prisoners were killed in 2006 in Uribana, a six-year-old prison considered the most violent in Venezuela.

headline: China: Venture to Build Vans
text: DaimlerChrysler said a joint venture with the China Motor Corporation to make vans won state approval, allowing the company to add capacity in China. DaimlerChrysler, China Motor and the Fujian Motor Industry Group received permission from the Ministry of Commerce in China for a 200 million euro ($264 million) venture to build as many as 40,000 Mercedes-Benz vans a year, said Trevor Hale, the Beijing-based spokesman for DaimlerChrysler.

headline: Man Sentenced to 26 Years for Reporter’s Murder
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — One of the two men convicted of murdering a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced today to 26 years in prison.

headline: New U.N. Chief Invites Controversy by Declining to Oppose Hussein Execution
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 2 — On his first day of work as secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, the mild-spoken South Korean diplomat who had suggested he would bring new caution to the post, invited controversy by declining to criticize the death penalty applied to Saddam Hussein.

headline: Ford Will Quit Minivan Market
text: Ford Motor said yesterday that it would abandon the minivan market in the United States by discontinuing its Freestar model and instead seek to bolster output of two new so-called crossover vehicles.

headline: Sprint Nextel Puts Its Big Ad Account in Review
text: Sprint Nextel, one of the country’s biggest marketers, said late today that it had placed the creative part of its advertising account in review. Sprint Nextel spends an estimated $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion each year on advertising.

headline: U.S. and Brazil to Talk About Talks
text: The top trade negotiators for the United States and Brazil will meet in New York to discuss global trade talks that collapsed last year, Brazil’s Foreign Ministry said. The foreign minister, Celso Amorim, and the United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, will talk today about how to reopen the negotiations and overcome obstacles that have prevented a World Trade Organization deal aimed at strengthening the global economy. A round of talks began in 2001 in Doha, Qatar, but they collapsed last year over disagreements on farm subsidies and tariffs.

headline: A Long Way to Learn How to Help Those Back in Nepal
text: Growing up in Nepal, Kunsang Sherpa, 23, knew what it was like to go without. His family farmed for a living, but in the mountainous landscape they grew only enough crops to eat. They mostly went without money and without medical care.

headline: Stained Glass and Strained Egos
text: Washington

headline: Bush Says Plan Would Balance Budget by ’12
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 — President Bush said on Tuesday that he would propose a plan that he insists would, if followed, achieve a balanced budget by 2012, the most optimistic he has been in at least five years, and he said the goal could be achieved without rescinding any of his big tax cuts.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Film entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report of Arts & Leisure about a Robert Altman retrospective gave an incorrect address and phone number for the theater, IFC Center. It is at 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village — not at 209 West Houston Street, South Village. The number is (212) 924-7771.

headline: Ethiopian Premier Says His Troops Won’t Stay in Somalia
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 2 — Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia said Tuesday that his country, one of the poorest in the world, could not afford to keep troops in Somalia much longer and that it was ill equipped to play the role of peacekeeper there.

headline: New Evidence of Liquid Methane on Saturn’s Moon
text: As scientists predicted but have had a hard time proving, the surface of Titan, Saturn’s largest moon, appears to be dotted with an abundance of lakes of liquid methane. The lakes are more intriguing evidence of the active phenomena at play on the only moon in the solar system that has a dense atmosphere.

headline: Bracing for Higher Premiums
text: To the mantra of life’s certainties, add higher home-insurance rates to death and taxes.

headline: For Some Moviegoers, It’s ‘Hooray for Bollywood’
text: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Dec. 27 — Swollen ticket lines, shouting children, tempers rising as the movies sold out: This was any suburban multiplex during the holidays.

headline: Zimbabwe Sanctions (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Service for Ford, a Gathering of Ex-Presidents and Family
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 — In a moment of presidential empathy, former President George Bush recalled a skill he had learned from Gerald R. Ford: how to handle being ridiculed on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Amgen Acquires Option for a Heart Failure Drug
text: Making a further move into the market for cardiovascular drugs, the biotechnology giant Amgen has formed an alliance with Cytokinetics, a smaller company developing an experimental drug to treat heart failure.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music column yesterday about pop songs on war misstated the title of the song, about a lover killed in combat, that starts the Norah Jones album due out this month. It is “Wish I Could” — not “Thinking About You,” which is the title of another song on the album.

headline: MoMA to Gain Exhibition Space by Selling Adjacent Lot for $125 Million
text: Capitalizing on Manhattan’s robust real estate prices, the Museum of Modern Art is selling its last vacant parcel of land in Midtown for $125 million to Hines, an international real estate developer based in Houston, the museum’s director said yesterday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about possible ways to curb sharp increases in executive pay misstated the percentage increase in the value of a pension for Lee R. Raymond, the former chief executive for Exxon Mobil, because of bonuses from 2003 to 2005. It was a 50 percent increase, to $98.4 million from just under $66 million — not 33 percent.

headline: Trying to Find Solutions in Chaotic Middle Schools
text: Sit in with a seventh-grade science class at Seth Low, a cavernous Brooklyn middle school, as paper balls fly and pens are flicked from desk to desk.

headline: Spitzer Speech Will Urge Fiscal Restraint
text: ALBANY, Jan. 2 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer will call for the state government to “rein in spending,” cut property taxes and overhaul the workers’ compensation system in his first address to state lawmakers on Wednesday.

headline: Democrats Plan First 100 Hours, Give or Take a Speech
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  House Democrats intend to kick off their new regime with a 100-hour legislative blitz that would allow them to post a series of quick victories before President Bush even delivers his State of the Union address toward the end of this month.

headline: Louisville Hoping Big Finish Carries Over to Next Season
text: MIAMI, Jan. 2 — The long path to respect and recognition was about to be completed by Louisville. The Cardinals had only recently raised their national profile with the move to the Big East from Conference USA two seasons ago, and the Orange Bowl on Tuesday night at Dolphin Stadium was to be the final step in Louisville’s ascension to the short list of national contenders for next season.

headline: Letters
text: Value in the Organic Label

headline: Ford’s Funeral Draws Array of Politicians and Dignitaries
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 — Scores of politicians and dignitaries from across the political spectrum poured into Washington National Cathedral on a clear and blustery Tuesday to mourn President Gerald R. Ford at his funeral service here.

headline: A Somber Farewell to Gerald Ford (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Monday about the Knicks’ 90-80 loss to the Clippers in Los Angeles misidentified the team that drafted guard Nate Robinson in 2005. It was the Phoenix Suns, who selected him at the Knicks’ request, then traded him and Quentin Richardson to the Knicks for Kurt Thomas the same day; the Knicks did not draft Robinson.

headline: It’s More or Less Natural, and It’s Getting Bigger by the Day
text: EACH year grocery manufacturers roll out tens of thousands of products, ever hopeful that a new box of crackers or a frozen entree will be a hit with consumers.

headline: Home Prices Fall Just a Bit; Brokers See ‘Soft Landing’
text: Sale prices for Manhattan apartments fell in the last quarter of 2006, while the pace of sales was reported to be strong and the backlog of unsold apartments fell, according to several market studies released yesterday by large real estate brokerage firms.

headline: After the Rip van Winkle Years
text: The mood at Eliot Spitzer’s Jan. 1 inauguration was exuberant, and that was hardly surprising. Few politicians are offered the opportunity that greets Mr. Spitzer as he becomes New York’s 54th governor.

headline: McGreevey Finds Way Back to the State House, on Canvas
text: TRENTON, Jan. 2 — The last time James E. McGreevey was inside the governor’s office, his name was painted on the glass door.

headline: From Banker to Baker in TriBeCa
text: You can’t open a bakery in New York without cupcakes these days, so Rachel Thebault, a former investment banker who has opened Tribeca Treats, offers small ones ($2 each) aswirl with chocolate, vanilla, coconut, espresso, peanut butter, caramel or marshmallow frostings. There is even a red velvet one with cream cheese icing. Her sandwich cookies are also modest in size and come in chocolate, vanilla, peanut and graham cracker with various cream fillings, $1.25 each or $18 a dozen. Chocolates and cakes round out the inventory. The shop also sells gift items. It’s at 94 Reade Street (Church Street), (212) 571-0500.

headline: Itche Goldberg, Yiddish Advocate, 102, Dies
text: Itche Goldberg, a champion of Yiddish who wrote and edited and taught his beloved language in the face of all those who said keeping Yiddish alive was a lost cause, died last Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 102.

headline: The Fiesta Bowl: And Now, a Few More Words
text: This is the first college football postseason I can recall without Keith Jackson, whose voice defined bowl games. Although Jackson was frustrated with his performance in his finale, last year’s Rose Bowl, his presence was welcome. His retirement coincided with the conclusion of ABC’s era of dominance over televising the Bowl Championship Series.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an investigation into the possibility that banks are luring hedge funds as tenants in order to solicit their trading business misstated the nature of a request made by the Massachusetts secretary of state, William F. Galvin, to UBS, the Swiss bank. While Mr. Galvin has requested information from UBS, he has not issued a subpoena. UBS is cooperating with the inquiry. (Go to Article)

headline: New York Transit Chief Plans to Resign
text: Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the branch of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the city’s subways and buses, said today that he would resign, clearing the way for new leadership at the agency he has run since 1996.

headline: After the Hanging of Saddam Hussein (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 2 — The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles for the company, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Bag Handlers Held in Theft of Luggage in Houston
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 2  Wondering what happened to your lost airline luggage?

headline: Embattled Chief Executive Resigns at Home Depot
text: Robert L. Nardelli, the chief executive of Home Depot, who came under heavy criticism for his pay package and failure to lift the chain’s stagnant stock price, has abruptly resigned, the company said today.

headline: A Time of Temptation for the Thrifty of Ireland
text: DUBLIN, Jan. 2  A government effort to cool Ireland’s roaring economy by encouraging people to save is threatening to backfire.

headline: 3,000 Americans: Let Us Remember (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Over Gold in the Land of Dracula
text: ROSIA MONTANA, Romania — Eugen David, a small-time farmer with a chipped tooth and muddy boots in this obscure wrinkle of Transylvania, is an unlikely man to attract the attention of movie stars and moguls. But he counts Vanessa Redgrave, George Soros and Teddy Goldsmith among his backers in a land battle with a Canadian gold mining company.

headline: Sawyer Signals Commitment to Morning Show
text: Diane Sawyer, whose continued commitment to “Good Morning America” has been the subject of speculation since Charles Gibson departed the show in June, has in recent weeks left some executives at ABC with the impression that she intends to remain with the program until at least early summer, according to one executive briefed directly on Ms. Sawyer’s status.

headline: When She Speaks, He’s Breaking All of Islam’s Taboos
text: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 2 — Ali Saleem may have devised the perfect, if improbable, cover for breaking taboos in conservative, Muslim Pakistan.

headline: Bridgeport: Campaign Law Partly Halted
text: A federal judge issued a preliminary injunction yesterday blocking part of a state lobbying and campaign finance law that is one of the toughest in the country. The provision, blocked by Judge Stefan R. Underhill of Federal District Court, would have required the executives of companies seeking state contracts to disclose the names of their children on a Web site to ensure that the executives do not make illegal campaign contributions through their dependents. Contractors must still disclose the names of their spouses. Contractors and their family members are still barred from contributing to officials who control state contracts. The law, enacted in response to a state payoff scandal, was set to take effect at the start of the year. The request for an injunction was filed by a securities industry trade group. The American Civil Liberties Union has also sought to overturn elements of the law.

headline: Recipe: Tomato Sushi
text: Time: 3½ hours

headline: Global Rally on First Day of Trading in New Year
text: Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers would support global equities for a fifth year.

headline: Cancer Patients’ Wait Times Cost Billions
text: A new study says that $2.3 billion worth of time is spent in waiting rooms, doctors’ offices, hospitals and transportation in the first year after cancer is diagnosed. Patients with gastric and ovarian cancers lost the most time, valued around $5,300 and $5,600 per person, compared with costs associated with skin and prostate cancers of $300 and $800 each, according to a study in today’s issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute. Researchers looked at records from 764,000 Americans 65 years old or older who had received a diagnosis of 11 common forms of cancer from 1995 to 2001. They estimated the average amount of time spent seeking treatment and multiplied it by $15.23 an hour, the median United States wage rate in 2002. The study did not look at the value of time spent by members of a patient’s family.

headline: Artest Reminds the Knicks What They’re Missing
text: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 2 — There is no shortage of ghosts in the Knicks’ file cabinet of misguided transactions, and perhaps none more haunting than the image of Ron Artest, all muscle and swagger, hitting shots from every panel of the hardwood.

headline: In Rustic Greek Dishes, a Fresh Approach to Ancient Flavors
text: ASK New Yorkers to name a classic Greek dish, and many would say moussaka — gooey layers of eggplant, ground meat and comfort. But a new breed of Greek restaurants here also serves dishes like rabbit phyllo, grilled branzino with artichoke confit and dandelion greens, and Cretan honey-braised lamb shank with yogurt pasta.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Wednesday about Iran’s effort to exert greater influence in Afghanistan omitted a credit. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London.

headline: A Surprising Secret to a Long Life: Stay in School
text: James Smith, a health economist at the RAND Corporation, has heard a variety of hypotheses about what it takes to live a long life — money, lack of stress, a loving family, lots of friends. But he has been a skeptic.

headline: Layoffs Imminent at Philadelphia Inquirer
text: The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to announce today that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper and its sister publication, The Daily News.

headline: A Hanging and a Funeral
text: Last Saturday was a strange day. It started with the hanging of Saddam Hussein. The more I read about the hasty, quasi-legal maneuvers used by Iraq’s Shiite leaders to rush Saddam to the gallows on a Muslim holiday, Id al-Adha, and the more I watched the grainy cellphone video of the event, in which a guard is heard taunting Saddam with chants of “Moktada! Moktada!” — the Shiite cleric whose death squads have killed hundreds of Sunnis — and the more I read of the insults Saddam spat back, the more it resembled a tribal revenge ritual rather than the culmination of a constitutional process in which America should be proud to have participated.

headline: Now It’s Belarus’s Turn
text: A year after Russia put the gas squeeze on Ukraine, it was Belarus’s turn. Unlike Ukraine, Belarus blinked two minutes before the Jan. 1 deadline and Russia had its booty: a 50 percent share of Belarus’s pipeline network and a more than doubling of the price Belarus will now pay for Russian gas.

headline: After Bringing Adu to Utah, Checketts Wants Him to Stay
text: Few people would accuse Dave Checketts of not thinking ahead, whether in the N.B.A., the N.H.L. or M.L.S.

headline: Spitzer Seeks Sweeping Changes in Albany
text: ALBANY, Jan. 3 — In his first annual address to the Legislature, Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed to overhaul almost every corner of the state’s operations and policies, saying he would move swiftly to guarantee health insurance for all children in the state, publicly finance state elections, rein in spending and draft a constitutional amendment to overhaul the state’s courts.

headline: In Croatia, an Empty Life in Full View
text: “I Love You,” a bleak drama from the Croatian writer and director Dalibor Matanic, is an unusually perceptive scrutiny of absence and emptiness. Set in the filmmaker’s hometown, Zagreb, the movie follows a young advertising hotshot named Kreso (Kresimir Mikic), whose life is a thoughtless round of drinking, drugs and sex. When he gets into trouble, his lawyer father bails him out; when he is lonely, his gym buddies are preferable to the live-in girlfriend he barely speaks to. Then he learns he is H.I.V.-positive.

headline: Peruvian Proficiency on a Spit, With Pictures
text: IT was with great indifference that I dropped in on Pardo’s, a month-old spot on Seventh Avenue South in the West Village.

headline: Blair’s Deputy Calls Taunting of Hussein at Execution ‘Deplorable’
text: LONDON, Jan. 2 — Britain’s deputy prime minister said Tuesday that the taunting and baiting that accompanied Saddam Hussein’s execution was unacceptable and that the people responsible should be condemned for taking part.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Monday about American military members who have died in the Iraq war misstated the number of crewmates who survived an explosion that killed a tank driver, Specialist Jordan W. Hess. There were three, not four.

headline: An American University for Iraq but Not in Baghdad
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — It would be an ambitious project even in a Middle Eastern country not embroiled in war: build an American-style university where classes are taught in English, teachers come from around the world and graduates compete for lucrative jobs in fields like business and computer science.

headline: Panel Seeks End to Death Penalty for New Jersey
text: TRENTON, Jan. 2 — A legislative commission recommended on Tuesday that New Jersey become the first state to abolish the death penalty since states began reinstating their capital punishment laws 35 years ago. Its report found “no compelling evidence” that capital punishment serves a legitimate purpose, and increasing evidence that it “is inconsistent with evolving standards of decency.”

headline: Luring Americans to Spain
text: VALENCIA, Spain — Long neglected as one of Spain’s secondary cities, Valencia’s role as host of the America’s Cup this year and its ambitious efforts to showcase new architecture are enticing an increasing number of expatriates to visit the City of Oranges.

headline: Man Is Rescued by Stranger on Subway Tracks
text: It was every subway rider’s nightmare, times two.

headline: A Light Bulb Goes On
text: Bad habits can be hard to break. So it’s great news that Wal-Mart is putting its considerable heft behind one of the easiest ways to reduce energy consumption and the production of global-warming gases: the corkscrew-shaped light bulbs of the future.

headline: Recipe: Timbale of Skate
text: Time: 1 hour, plus 1 hour’s chilling

headline: SoHo Bounces Back as a Fashion Center
text: Before Sept. 11, 2001, SoHo seemed on the way to emerging as one of the most prestigious shopping districts in Manhattan. But after the attack on the World Trade Center, many retailers eventually left their stores after it appeared that shoppers had abandoned the district.

headline: Yankees Crave Young Pitchers, but Have One Eye on Clemens
text: The Yankees hope to have at least one 44-year-old starting pitcher later this year. If they can trade Randy Johnson to the Arizona Diamondbacks, they will have more money available to sign Roger Clemens.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article on Dec. 27 about land that is being rented from farmers in Skagit County, Wash., to create a habitat for birds misidentified the birds shown on flooded land. They were waterfowl, not shorebirds.

headline: Dollar’s Skid Puts a Glow on the Euro
text: The dollar slumped yesterday and the euro climbed to a three-week high against the currency.

headline: Trying to Regain Initiative, Bush Looks Ahead
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — President Bush sought today to regain the initiative on the eve of the Democratic takeover of Congress, pledging to work enthusiastically with the new lineup of lawmakers but holding fast to his own goals.

headline: Be It Ever So Homespun, There’s Nothing Like Spin
text: SOMETHING made me uneasy when I dropped a box of gluten-free EnviroKidz organic Koala Crisp cereal in my shopping cart. But it’s hard to suspect a cartoon koala, so I moved on.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,986 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about former President Gerald R. Ford misstated his relationship to the three brothers with whom he was raised. They were his half-brothers, not his stepbrothers.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Dec. 15 about Queens International 2006, at the Queens Museum of Art, misspelled the given name of the artist whose embroidered panels explore female sexuality. She is Blanka Amezcua, not Blanca.

headline: Iraq Defends Hussein Execution, but Detains Guard
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 3 — The Iraqi prime minister’s office on Wednesday mounted its first public defense of the way the government carried out the execution of Saddam Hussein, and it said that Iraqi authorities had detained a guard whom they believed was involved in recording the moment in a macabre and unauthorized video that has generated revulsion around the world.

headline: Sensing Opportunity in Dormitory Air
text: College stinks. Just ask Emily Watson, a sophomore at Dartmouth, who sprays her dorm room once a week and her clothes two to three times a week with fresheners, usually in citrus or other fruity flavors.

headline: A Familiar Formula, Until You Take a Bite
text: IT would be easy to feel cynical about Mai House.

headline: It’s the Year to Keep an Eye on Paychecks
text: Do you remember all those books from the 1980s and ’90s explaining why the United States couldn’t keep up with Japan? Once they were proved wrong, pundits came forth with a new batch of titles to explain why the American boom might last forever. The masterwork of the genre was “Dow 36,000.”

headline: Ancient Messages, Hidden in a Dusty Bottle From Long Ago
text: BEAUNE, France

headline: Singapore: Growth Spurt in Quarter
text: Singapore’s economic growth unexpectedly accelerated in the fourth quarter to the fastest pace in a year as a record number of tourists and an all-time high stock market spurred service industries and helped offset lower electronics exports. Its economy grew an annualized 7.6 percent in the final three months of 2006, after expanding a revised 5.6 percent in the third quarter, the trade ministry said. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in his New Year’s message that the pace of expansion may ease in 2007 because of an economic slowdown in the United States and weaker global demand for electronics, which account for about half the $118 billion economy’s exports. The economy may expand between 4 percent and 6 percent this year, Mr. Lee said.

headline: Protecting Internet Democracy
text: One of the big winners in the last election may turn out to be the principle, known as net neutrality, that Internet service providers should not be able to favor some content over others. Democrats who are moving into the majority in Congress  led by Ron Wyden in the Senate and Edward Markey in the House  say they plan to fight hard to pass a net neutrality bill, and we hope that they do. It is vital to preserve the Internet’s role in promoting entrepreneurship and free expression.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Setback in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON, Jan. 2 — Massachusetts, the only state where same-sex marriage is legal, took a first step toward possibly banning it Tuesday when legislators voted to advance a constitutional amendment defining marriage as the union between a man and a woman.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about mourning for former President Gerald R. Ford in Palm Desert, Calif., misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976.

headline: Police Call Woman’s Death Murder for Hire
text: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 2 — A man accused of fatally shooting the owner of a beauty salon here had been hired by a companion she was trying to break up with, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Trying to Clear Absinthe’s Reputation
text: READERS of Ernest Hemingway know “Death in the Afternoon” as a book about bullfighting. But to drinkers with a taste for obscure booze, it is also a cocktail that Hemingway contributed to a 1935 collection of celebrity recipes. His directions: “Pour one jigger absinthe into a Champagne glass. Add iced Champagne until it attains the proper opalescent milkiness. Drink three to five of these slowly.”

headline: Israeli Admits Big Errors in Lebanon War, but Won’t Resign
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 — The Israeli chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, conceded Tuesday that the military had made serious errors during last summer’s war against Hezbollah in Lebanon but said he would not resign his post.

headline: Google Answer to Filling Jobs Is an Algorithm
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Have you ever made a profit from a catering business or dog walking? Do you prefer to work alone or in groups? Have you ever set a world record in anything?

headline: Data on Hispanic Immigrants Presents Puzzle on Aging
text: If medical researchers were to pick someone who might defy national life expectancy statistics, few would pick Irma Lara.

headline: Shifts in Stock Indexes
text: Ensco International Inc., a United States oil and natural gas driller, will join the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, replacing BellSouth, S.& P. said yesterday in a statement posted on its Web site.

headline: EGL Gets Buyout Bid From Its Chief
text: EGL, a manager of freight services for customers, said yesterday that its chief executive, James R. Crane, and a private equity firm had offered to buy the company for $1.2 billion.

headline: In Meetings With Allies, Clinton Hones ’08 Strategy
text: The topic was the Democratic sweep in New Hampshire in November, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton couldn’t get enough of it.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Drugs, Dad
text: San Francisco

headline: Annie Leibovitz Gets Her Close-Up (No Need for Touch-Ups)
text: “Annie Leibovitz: Life Through a Lens,” which makes its debut on PBS tonight, reminds us how profoundly American culture values branding, not only from software packagers and congressional candidates but also from artists high and low. Just as a Whopper can be confused with no other hamburger, Ms. Leibovitz’s photographs of the beloved and ignominious are virtually impossible to mistake for someone else’s. Her work raises interesting questions about the primacy of creative signature — to what extent should we consider distinctiveness its own merit? But the failure of “Life Through a Lens” is its refusal to embark on this inquiry at all.

headline: Teddy Kollek Dies at 95; Led Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 — Teddy Kollek, who as mayor of Jerusalem for nearly three decades did more to build and develop the city as Israel’s capital than any other figure while promoting coexistence with a sometimes hostile Arab population, died Tuesday in Jerusalem. He was 95.

headline: Hossa Delivers for Rangers in Shootout With Devils
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 2  In the excitement of a shootout against the Devils on Tuesday night, a game the Rangers felt they desperately needed to win, Marcel Hossa took the ice as the Rangers’ eighth shooter.

headline: Brown, Slice, Brown, Sauce
text: PORK tenderloin, like its relative the beef tenderloin (sometimes called filet mignon), is among the leanest cuts of meat. Its versatility, ease of cooking and eating — there are no bones and essentially no fat — and relatively low price have made it popular.

headline: Giving Minority Students a Push Along the Path to Leadership Roles
text: On a recent cold Saturday, when most children around the city were relaxing after a week at school, 320 boys and girls, ages 10 to 13, filed into Nightingale-Bamford, a private girls’ school in a stately brick building on the Upper East Side.

headline: Ensuring College Access (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recipe: Slow-Cooked Beef With Cracked Wheat
text: Time: 3½ hours

headline: From the Stage to the Movie Screen, Seeing the Dancer in a Different Light
text: In the very best of this year’s Dance on Camera offerings, there is a sense of looking back. Documentaries celebrate artists who have transformed the field; stage adaptations preserve treasured productions for the long haul; and stylistic experiments show the way directors radically changed the approach of filming dance.

headline: A Brooklyn Furrier and Artist Finds Soul Mates Among the Indians of the West
Muslims in the Melting Pot: Portraits of a Post-9/11 World
text: A few weeks ago a conference of accomplished Muslim women gathered at the Westin Hotel near Times Square to debate how women might exert greater influence on the interpretation of Islamic Scriptures. During a panel discussion, an Iranian-born anthropologist from Britain said she seconded the position taken by the Labor politician Jack Straw, that the full facial veils worn by some Muslims have no place in Western society because they erase a woman’s humanity.

headline: Cuomo’s Opening Moves Echo Spitzer’s Reform Ideas
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo began his first full day in office yesterday by meeting with officials who could play a pivotal role in investigating any state corruption cases in Albany. This opening step signals that he intends to join in Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s calls for major reform of the capital’s political culture.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in The Arts on Thursday with an article about Dance Theater Workshop’s program to provide subsidized rehearsal space outside Manhattan carried an erroneous credit. While the picture of the dancer Miguel Gutierrez was indeed by Julieta Cervantes, the picture of his rehearsal space in Woodside, Queens, was by Todd Richmond.

headline: The Two Sides of Jim Tressel
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Jim Tressel’s six years of coaching Ohio State have presented a jarring contrast of Ozzie and Harriet virtue and Ozzy Osbourne excess.

headline: For Boise State, Winning Respect Is the Real Trick
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 2 — After scoring the winning 2-point conversion on a Statue of Liberty play and proposing to his girlfriend on national television, Boise State tailback Ian Johnson could have completed the storybook night by saying he was going to Disneyland.

headline: Controversy Rules Oscar Contenders
text: “I didn’t go there to make a point,” said Laura Poitras, a documentary filmmaker, about traveling in Iraq to make “My Country, My Country,” one of four documentaries about the war contending for Oscar nominations this year.

headline: Serving Memory
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Ford Is Remembered at Funeral in Washington
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 — In a soaring tribute to a modest man, Gerald R. Ford was remembered on Tuesday as bringing the ordinary virtues of decency, integrity and humility to mend a broken government after the pain of war and scandal.

headline: N.F.L. Parity Ensures Anxiety Is Shared Equally
text: It was not Michael Vick and the ingenuity required to coach him that unraveled Jim Mora in Atlanta or Arizona’s genetic losing disorder that vanquished Dennis Green in the desert.

headline: Parolee With Violent Past Is Charged in 2 L.I. Killings
text: A parolee who has served more than 30 years in prison for two separate homicides and other violent crimes in New York City was arrested yesterday by the Suffolk County police and charged in the shooting deaths of a 52-year-old woman and her 30-year-old son over the weekend.

headline: Euro-Wary Slovenians Already Miss Their Tolar
text: Ivanka Rihtar has seen four currencies come and go in Slovenia during her lifetime. Ms. Rihtar, a 70-year-old storekeeper, has little nostalgia for any of them today.

headline: Music and Food? The Pros Step In
text: DREW NIEPORENT still remembers the afternoon in the 1970s when Warner LeRoy ordered him to turn off the Barbra Streisand eight-track.

headline: Hey! Never Underestimate the Average Joe
text: “The King of Queens,” the longest-running live-action comedy currently on television, is the opposite of an acquired taste. Like pizza or the Doors, the show just hits the spot — the simple, happy sitcom spot.

headline: Chrysler Is Only U.S. Carmaker to See Sales Gains
text: DETROIT, Jan. 3 — The Chrysler Group was the only Detroit carmaker to report a sales increase for December, while the Japanese carmakers Toyota and Honda both saw their sales grow last month, figures from the auto companies showed today.

headline: I’ll Have What They Don’t Know About Yet
text: OFF the menu. Have sweeter words ever been spoken, especially by New Yorkers? We all believe we deserve something more special than the people at the next table, and who’s to say we’re wrong?

headline: Indonesian Officials Now Say They Don’t Know Fate of Missing Jet
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 2  Indonesian officials reversed themselves on Tuesday and admitted that they did not know what had happened to a passenger jet that disappeared from radar screens in bad weather on Monday shortly after issuing a distress signal.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about four shows at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens misstated the name of the artist who has a large embroidered silk screen in the “Gold Standard” show. He is Kent Henricksen, not Kurt Hendrickson.

headline: What’s on Wednesday Night
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ANNIE LEIBOVITZ: LIFE THROUGH A LENS Ms. Leibovitz is arguably the most influential woman photographer in the country. But her private life is rarely exposed. In this documentary, which closes the 20th season of “American Masters,” Ms. Leibovitz shares her artistic process with her younger sister, the filmmaker Barbara Leibovitz, as she travels from her Manhattan studio to her idyllic farm in upstate New York, and through countless photo shoots and the creation of her latest retrospective book, while trying to balance career and motherhood.

headline: Agency Lifts Restrictions on Caviar
text: ALL the nations surrounding the Caspian Sea can resume exporting sevruga and osetra caviar, an international environmental agency ruled yesterday. The agency, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or Cites, said the nations’ efforts to monitor the depletion of endangered sturgeon had improved.

headline: Iraq to Review Hussein’s Execution
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 2 — Iraq’s Shiite-led government said Tuesday that it had ordered an investigation into the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, who was subjected to a battery of taunts by official Shiite witnesses and guards as he awaited his hanging.

headline: What You Get for ... $575,000
text: McHenry, Md.

headline: Enron's Last Victim: American Markets
text: Washington

headline: Weis Has His Focus On Game, Not Giants
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2  Notre Dame Coach Charlie Weis tried his best Tuesday to remove his name from consideration for the not-yet-vacant Giants coaching job, saying emphatically that he was not a liar.

headline: Two Governors Brace for a Showdown Over How Deep a River Should Run
text: TRENTON, Jan. 2 — The Delaware River, which separates New Jersey and Pennsylvania, is putting distance between the Democratic governors of the two states, who are at a standoff over the financing and environmental implications of a plan to deepen the river for larger cargo ships and oil tankers.

headline: Male Misery Just Loves Female Company
text: Time magazine shocked America by asking “Is God Dead?” on its cover in 1966. Vanity Fair is now needling the nation with Christopher Hitchens’s essay “Why Women Aren’t Funny.”

headline: Knicks’ Francis Is Forgotten, but Not Officially Gone
text: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 2  Steve Francis is gone, whether for days, weeks or months, and it is possible the Knicks will be better for it. For all of his innate talent, Francis has spent an entirely forgettable 11 months in a city that has not embraced him and with a franchise that perhaps did not want him.

headline: Ethics Overhaul Tops Agenda for Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — On the precipice of regaining power after 12 years, House Democrats Wednesday said they would move immediately to try to sever ties between lawmakers and lobbyists that figured into scandals that helped Democrats win control of Congress.

headline: The Ex-Presidents’ Club Bids a Member Goodbye
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 — In a moment of presidential empathy, former President George Bush recalled a skill he had learned from Gerald R. Ford: how to handle being ridiculed on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Numbers Put Up by the Defense Don’t Add Up to a Giants Title
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 2 — Lost behind the stir of a fired offensive coordinator and the unbending focus on offensive stars — Tiki this, Eli that, Shockey here, Plaxico there — toils the part of the Giants that most threatens their chance to win a championship:

headline: From Sex Trade to Vultures: Asia Outside In
text: Film Forum’s omnibus of work by the writer-director-cinematographer-editor Ellen Bruno covers a spectrum of Asian subjects. The 50-minute featurette “Sacrifice” depicts young Burmese girls conscripted into prostitution in Thailand; the bill also includes shorts about a village of Nepalese lepers and a Tibetan monastery where “body breakers” feed the stripped flesh and ground bones of the dead to giant vultures.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an investigation into the possibility that banks are luring hedge funds as tenants in order to solicit their trading business misstated the nature of a request made by the Massachusetts secretary of state, William F. Galvin, to UBS, the Swiss bank. While Mr. Galvin has requested information from UBS, he has not issued a subpoena. UBS is cooperating with the inquiry.

headline: Sick and Can’t Go to School? Or, Sick Because You Didn’t Go?
Tillie Olsen, Feminist Writer, Dies at 94
text: Tillie Olsen, whose short stories, books and essays lent a heartfelt voice to the struggles of women and working-class people, died on Monday in Oakland, Calif. She was 94.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: A Bowl for the Ages
text: Boise State's victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl will be remembered as one of the most exciting in college football history.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Mantels, screens and glass to add sparkle.

headline: Currents Slide Show
text: Accents for the home, brushed with darkness, turning 60 and reflecting on the past and more.

headline: A Pocketful of Better Skiing
text: Wax your skis and snowboards at home.

headline: Galvin Sees Broader Hedge-Fund Concerns
text: William F. Galvin, Massachusetts’ secretary of state, said yesterday that his investigation of UBS‘s relationship with certain hedge funds, reported in Tuesday’s New York Times, stems from broader concerns about the practices of a lightly regulated corner of the financial services industry, The Boston Globe reported. He said UBS officials have agreed to provide testimony about the firm’s relationship with hedge fund traders who operate out of UBS’s Boston office.

headline: BenQ to Liquidate German Unit As White Knight Fails to Emerge
text: The German mobile phone unit that the Taiwan company BenQ bought from Siemens will shut down, after no investor stepped in to rescue it. Once among the top phone brands, the phone maker first stumbled under Siemens and then collapsed under BenQ because both owners failed to compete on a global scale with rivals like Nokia.

headline: Indian Commodities Exchange Seeks Overseas Investor
text: The Multi Commodity Exchange of India, the biggest commodity exchange in India, said it is receiving at least one approach a month from overseas investors seeking a stake in the exchange.

headline: At Home With Ann Brashares and Jacob Collins
text: A visit to the renovated New York City carriage house of Ann Brashares, author of the "Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants" books.

headline: Global Rally on First Day of Trading in New Year
text: Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers would support global equities for a fifth year. Share indexes in all 16 West European markets gained, while benchmarks in Australia, Hong Kong and Indonesia climbed to records. In Latin America, equity gauges in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico headed toward all-time highs.

headline: Unicredit Buys Stake in Moscow Bank
text: The Eastern European division of Unicredit of Italy agreed Tuesday to buy a 20 percent stake in a Russian lender, the International Moscow Bank.

headline: CheckFree Takes Carreker into the Fold
text: CheckFree, an Atlanta-based provider of electronic bill payment and electronic banking services, said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Carreker for $8.05 a share, or a total of $206 million. CheckFree said the deal for Carreker, a Dallas-based provider of payments technology and consulting services for the financial services industry, will help it expand in software and consulting.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Close Deal for Nortel Unit
text: Alcatel-Lucent, a maker of telecommunications network equipment, said Tuesday it had completed its acquisition of Nortel Networks‘ UMTS radio access business after winning regulatory approval.

headline: Undertaker to Start-Ups Evolves Amid Good Times for Entrepeneurs
text: While times may be good for venture capitalists and the start-ups they fund, things are not looking so hot for firms like Sherwood Partners, long known in the industry as “the undertaker.” Firms like Sherwood are in the business of shutting down failed start-ups, and The San Jose Mercury News reports that Sherwood wound down 180 start-ups in its heyday during the dot-com bust.

headline: A New Sheriff With a Different Agenda?
text: Now that Eliot Spitzer, whom some called the Sheriff of Wall Street, has moved into the New York governor’s mansion, financial-industry observers are turning their eyes to his successor as New York attorney general, the freshly sworn-in Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Venture-Backed I.P.O.’s on Deck Double
text: The number of venture-backed initial public offerings awaiting their stock market debut more than doubled at the start of 2007 with a tech filing from Omneon Video Networks marking a late-entry addition to the roster. Hailing largely from the tech sector, the ranks of venture-backed I.P.O.’s swelled to 36 as of Tuesday, up from 16 in the same period last year, according to a survey by the National Venture Capital Association and Thomson Financial. The numbers, however, are down from the start of the busy fourth quarter of 2006, when 51 were waiting to take a crack at the public markets.

headline: Refco Emerges From Bankruptcy
text: Refco, the commodities broker that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2005, has exited Chapter 11 and is starting to make initial payouts to creditors. The firm formally emerged on Dec. 26 under a liquidation plan, although its estate still faces disputed claims and expected lawsuits from creditors, The Deal reported.

headline: EGL Gets Buyout Bid From Its Chief
text: EGL, a manager of freight services for customers, said yesterday that its chief executive, James R. Crane, and a private equity firm had offered to buy the company for $1.2 billion. Mr. Crane, EGL’s founder and largest shareholder with an 18 percent stake, and the equity firm General Atlantic want to pay $36 a share for the rest of the stock, EGL said yesterday.

headline: Winter Garden's Drive Time Ends
text: The Winter Garden Theater officially returned to Broadway on Monday as simply the Winter Garden Theater, after almost five years of working under another name: the Cadillac Winter Garden.

headline: Layoffs Imminent at Philadelphia Inquirer
text: The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to announce Wednesday that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper and its sister publication, The Daily News. The Philadelphia papers were sold in March by Knight Ridder to the McClatchy newspaper group, which in turn sold them to a group of businessmen, led by Brian P. Tierney, an advertising and public relations executive.

headline: Shanghai May Overtake Hong Kong in I.P.O.’s This Year
text: After beating out the New York Stock Exchange in initial public offerings this year to take the I.P.O. crown, Hong Kong’s stock market might see itself outdone by its mainland competitor. Shanghai’s bourse is expected to attract $26 billion in fundraising this year, overtaking Hong Kong, as more of the nation’s largest companies sell shares domestically, according to a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers. Hong Kong, by contrast, is expected to receive 150 billion Hong Kong dollars ($19.3 billion) in I.P.O.’s in 2007.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Previews don’t begin until next Wednesday, but the run of the Classic Stage Company’s presentation of the American premiere of “A Spanish Play,” written by Yasmina Reza, directed by John Turturro and featuring Zoe Caldwell, has been extended by two weeks, through March 4, at the theater at 136 East 13th Street, East Village.

headline: Amgen Acquires Option for a Heart Failure Drug
text: Making a further move into the market for cardiovascular drugs, the biotechnology giant Amgen has formed an alliance with Cytokinetics, a smaller company developing an experimental drug to treat heart failure. Under the agreement, which is expected to be announced Wednesday, Amgen will pay Cytokinetics $75 million to gain an option on the drug, which is about to enter the second of three stages of clinical trials.

headline: Energy Investments Likely to Burn Even Hotter This Year
text: Venture capitalists are expected to pump even more money into energy ventures in 2007 after doubling their bets last year amid shifting politics and global-warming worries. Venture capital investment in energy start-ups exploded in the first three quarters of 2006, hitting $536 million, compared with $224 million in all of 2005, according to industry tracker Dow Jones VentureOne. Now, V.C.’s are returning to the sector, following a “sea change” of interest in alternatives to conventional energy sources, John Denniston, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, told USA Today.

headline: Industry Ventures Bags $105 Million for New Fund
text: A secondary fund operator, Industry Ventures, raised $105 million in committed capital for its fourth fund aimed at buying up venture capital investments from corporate portfolios, liquidating funds and special situation investors looking for early liquidity.

headline: ICV and Palladium Sell Eyewear Supplier Hilsinger
text: ICV Capital Partners and Palladium Equity Partners said Tuesday they sold a vision-products business, Hilsinger Holdings to PNC Equity Partners in a secondary buyout that The Deal.com said was valued at more than $100 million. The sale allowed ICV and Palladium to pocket 2.5 times their original money and yielded an internal rate of return of more than 30 percent.

headline: Apple, Google and Napster Named in Patent Lawsuit
text: Intertainer, a video-on-demand company, last week filed a broad lawsuit asserting that Apple, Google and Napster are infringing on a 2005 patent that covers the commercial distribution of audio and video over the Internet.

headline: Sharper Image Cuts Chief’s Severance to Offset Options Gain
text: The specialty retailer Sharper Image chopped more than $3 million from the severance pay of its founder and recently departed chief executive, Richard Thalheimer, to offset his past windfalls from favorably priced stock options. The package, disclosed in a regulatory filing late last week, includes retirement benefits of $3.9 million and a severance payment of $1.78 million, below the $5 million minimum guaranteed to Mr. Thalheimer under a contract signed in 2002.

headline: Qualcomm Under Scrutiny by Korean Antitrust Agency
text: The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles for the company, officials said on Tuesday. In Japan, Europe and the United States, Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego, faces accusations by rivals that it has abused its market dominance in wireless technology to demand excessive royalties and block fair competition.

headline: Class Action Suits Hit All-Time Low in 2006
text: Class action lawsuits filed over securities fraud reached an all-time low in 2006, according to a Stanford Law School report. The drop is linked to tougher federal enforcement on securities fraud, a stronger stock market with lower price volatility and the settlements of the slew of securities fraud lawsuits filed in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the report said.

headline: Enron Accountant Heads to Jail
text: Richard A. Causey, Enron‘s former chief accounting officer, was on his way Tuesday to a federal prison in Bastrop, Tex., to begin a 5 1/2-year sentence for his role in the fraud that destroyed the company. Mr. Causey, 46, pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud in December 2005, less than a month before he was to stand trial with former chief executives Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, both of whom were found guilty.

headline: Malone and Dolans Talk about Cable Networks Deal, Report Says
text: As shareholders await Cablevision‘s decision on a $19.2 billion buyout offer from the controlling Dolan clan, Liberty Media’s John Malone has reached out to the family to talk about selling Rainbow Media, the unit that manages cable networks AMC, IFC and WE: Women’s Entertainment, sources told The New York Post.

headline: Home Depot’s Chief Resigns as Proxy Fight Looms
text: Home Depot, the giant home-improvement chain, said Wednesday that Robert L. Nardelli resigned as its chairman and chief executive. Mr. Nardelli’s departure, which the company said was part of a mutual agreement, comes amid mounting criticism of Home Depot’s executive compensation practices and its flagging stock price.

headline: Specter of Saddam Shopping in Baghdad?
text: According to a recent gem in the India Daily, “some people in Baghdad are claiming that they are seeing Saddam Hussein’s ghost in Baghdad public areas.”

headline: Alleged Hussein-Execution Auteur Arrested
text: The Times of London is reporting that the Iraqi government has arrested a prison guard  “for filming and posting to the Internet” the unauthorized video showing the hanging of Saddam Hussein on Saturday.

headline: The Day the Earth Stood Still
text: Those of you who have been drinking a bit too deeply from the Oscar cup may not have heard that Gerald R. Ford, a common man who came to the presidency in an uncommon way, has died. The funeral for the 38th president of the United States took place yesterday at Washington National Cathedral.

headline: The Democrats’ Hill: First 100-plus Hours
text: The schedule for the much-touted “first 100 hours” in the House is shaping up—it starts late, and it takes more than 100 hours, as Carl Hulse explains:

headline: The President Restates His Principles
text: President Bush shows up on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal to explain to the new Democratic Congress how he views his principles and his key legislative accomplishments of the previous six years. He also previews his administration’s forthcoming new strategy in Iraq. Bush writes:

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Lost and Found
text: Rudy Giuliani’s camp is crying dirty trickery, saying that a campaign dossier obtained by the Daily News was stolen last fall. His aides played down the importance of the documents, with spokeswoman Sunny Mindel calling it akin to a grocery list from October, written in pencil. Still, the camp has its theories on how it fell from custody. Maggie Haberman at the New York Post traces the broken chain of custody to “lost” luggage of an aide while Mr. Giuliani was campaigning in Florida for the state’s soon-to-be elected governor, Charles Crist.Senator Barack Obama’s dirty laundry wasn’t aired through some dastardly deed, but rather by every politician’s own worst enemy: himself. Mr. Obama never really suffered from confessions about drug use in his first book, “Dreams from my Father,” during his Senate race, but the narrative could be problematic in a presidential campaign, writes Lois Romano in The Washington Post. Then there’s also more name confusion. Why, it was just on Tuesday that CNN’s Wolf Blitzer had to apologize to Mr. Obama for mistakenly using his name in a headline _ “Where’s Obama” _ on a graphic when they meant “Osama,” as in bin Laden.

headline: Color Combos: Can You Name the School?
text: Many schools use these colors, but they're most identified with famous universities (among the 10 top earners for merchandise licensed by the Collegiate Licensing Company). So name them.

headline: China’s New Cultural Revolution
text: More images from some emerging Chinese contemporary artists.

headline: The ‘Tech Expert’ Is Stumped
text: For a year or so, I contributed monthly answers to the “Ask a Tech Expert” column in Best Life magazine. One reader question, I’m embarrassed to say, stumped me (I wrote about something else that month):

headline: Kravis and Roberts on the Buyout Boom
text: Two of the three names behind private equity behemoth Kohlberg Kravis Roberts weighed in on the state of the buyout industry in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. Henry Kravis and George Roberts told the newspaper that much has changed since the firm’s first leveraged buyout in 1979 (price: $355 million). These days, banks are eager to lend billions of dollars to help take companies private, although Mr. Roberts suggests that debt is used more judiciously than it was in the go-go 1980’s. He said:

headline: Should U.S. C.E.O.’s Prepare for a Tougher 2007?
text: Despite recommendations that federal regulations over corporate governance be lightened, American chief executives expect further challenges this year to their control over the companies they run, according to The Financial Times. Developments like stock-options backdating, anger over executive compensation and increased shareholder activism have contributed to a more hostile environment for chief executives, who have been departing in greater numbers.

headline: Second Life and the People’s House
text: We can just see it now: the scantily clad women, flying chipmunks and robots roaming around the House of Representatives, debating health care policy and energy independence.

headline: Gävle Goat Survives, But Will Interest?
text: This just in to update our story from last month — on the famous Christmas Goat of Gävle, Sweden.

headline: Goldman Sachs: An Embarassment of Riches?
text: Lloyd Blankfein appears to have little in common with Marie Antoinette, but readers of Michael M. Thomas’s fiery opinion column in this week’s New York Observer can be forgiven for thinking otherwise. Mr. Thomas, a former investment banker and observer of Wall Street manners, has produced an incendiary diatribe that focuses on the year-end bonuses recently doled out at Goldman Sachs, where Mr. Blankfein is chief executive. Using revolutionary imagery, Mr. Thomas suggests that Goldman’s bonuses could become a touchstone for a national (and possibly irrational) debate on the wealth gap.

headline: Getting Touchy
text: Is this waiter too close for comfort?(Reuters/Lee Celano)

headline: Paterson Returns to the Senate
text: Lieutenant Governor David A. Paterson returned to his old haunting grounds – the State Senate – where he now presides as one of his few official duties. He asked if all the Senators had been sworn in. “Sworn in, not sworn at,’’ he clarified.

headline: Goldman, Citi Top List of 2006 M&A Deal Makers
text: After giving us a preview late last year, Thomson Financial this week sent DealBook its official tally of last year’s merger and acquisitions activity. Global M&A topped $3.8 trillion in 2006, a bump of nearly 38 percent over the previous year. Nearly 20 percent of the year’s deals involved private-equity buyers. And large swaths of the deal-making were handled by two investment banks, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

headline: A Golden Goodbye for Home Depot Chief
text: When you are carrying $210 million in goodies, it is hard to make a quiet exit. This is especially true when you are Robert Nardelli, whose pay as the chief executive of Home Depot has long been a source of controversy. Hours after his resignation was announced early Wednesday, there were some strong reactions to Mr. Nardelli’s severance package, which the company valued at $210 million.

headline: Should U.S. Airlines Give Foreign Owners a Try?
text: The Federal Aviation Act prohibits foreign investors from owning more than 25 percent of an American airline. This, writes Daniel Gross at Slate, is an example of “sometimes misplaced hostility to foreigners, national-security paranoia, and plain-old protectionism.” The law may be old, but its relevance is new, as many analysts think the United States airline industry is due a round of transformational mergers.

headline: Revolving Door: Weil Gotshal
text: Law firm Weil Gotshal & Manges said Wednesday that it hired Michael J. Aiello as a partner in the mergers and acquisitions group of its corporate department. Mr. Aiello was previously a partner at Dewey Ballantine, where he was part of the legal team that advised Walt Disney as it fought off Comcast‘s unsolicited bid in 2004.

headline: As Ben Tells It
text: Ben Affleck, who made something of a comeback last year with “Hollywoodland,” sits in on a roundtable conversation at the Hollywood Reporter  with Nicole Kidman, Edward Norton and Forest Whitaker. Mr. Affleck employs a little-used tactic in celebrity communications strategy: Telling the truth.

headline: Eliot: Democrat? Republican? Other?
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s first State of the State is over, and large swaths of the speech struck a few of us as language that a Republican governor could’ve easily delivered.

headline: The Stealth Campaign
text: Trying to arrange to screen “Factory Girl” continues to be like tackling a blob of mercury. When the Baguette e-mailed a publicist at the Weinstein Company today she was told no screenings were planned for this week so far. But if not this week, when? The press has had so little chance to see and write about the actual film — as opposed to the hoopla around it — that “Factory Girl” seems basically to have been shut out of any awards consideration. Sure there’s a one week run of the film in Los Angeles going on, but that’s probably not going to be enough to get it in the mix.

headline: An Investment Banking Love Story
text: How does a harried investment banker send love notes? By BlackBerry, of course.

headline: Joy, Finally, From Buffalo
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s announcement that he would name a co-chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, based in Buffalo, to focus on revitalizating the upstate economy brought joy to Byron W. Brown.

headline: War Protest Mom Upstages Democrats
text: Representative Rahm Emanuel was starting to address about 70 media types who had waited patiently for him to emerge from a meeting of the House Democratic Caucus on Capitol Hill. He wished everyone a Happy New Year, apologized for being late — ­45 minutes, if you’re counting at home — and was promptly drowned out by a group of anti-war protestors.

headline: The Producers Speak in Tongues
text: The first of the guilds is in, no thanks to the mail, and “Babel,” which got significant love from the Golden Globes, continues to be on a roll. The multi-lingual triptych, which stars Cate Blanchett and Brad Pitt, was selected as a nominee in the feature film category, along with “The Departed,” “Dreamgirls,” “The Queen” and “Little Miss Sunshine.” The inclusion of the wacky family in the van is good news for the backers of “Little Miss,” who have hoped that it will be the little movie that could. More than a few people have talked about how the movie has managed to hang on in the midst of it much larger competition. “Letters From Iwo Jima” was skunked.

headline: The Mike Crew in Town
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his top aides are used to being the center of attention. But in the world of New York politics, City Hall has been eclipsed by the State Capitol this week.

headline: Turning a Statistic On Its Head
text: In an op-ed article in today’s Times, William A. Niskanen, the president of the Cato Institute, fails to understand a statistic on which he bases his conclusion that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act should be repealed.

headline: F.B.I.: Witness to Guantánamo Abuses
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation on Tuesday released documents relating to “a survey of 493 FBI personnel who were asked whether they observed aggressive mistreatment, interrogations or interview techniques” used on detainees held at the U.S. military base at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba.

headline: It Takes a Village
text: Patrick Healy and Adam Nagourney of The Times  describe  many interesting details from “a series of nearly nonstop political consultations” that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has engaged in since November as she prepares a probable run for the White House.

headline: Thanks for Writing
text: We have been delighted by how many comments we have received. And not just from our relatives, though it is certainly good to hear from our parents and our cousin Keri.

headline: Blogtalk
text: Reactions to Eliot Spitzer’s State of the State Address: Joe Bruno and an assortment of others, including a Pataki spokesman. [Capitol Confidential]Oh, and Larry Schwartz, deputy county executive in Westchester: “…great speech…bold…visionary.” [Politics on the Hudson]

headline: Teatime With Pelosi
text: Pelosi-palooza (we’re totally stealing that from our colleague Anne Kornblut) kicked off today on a somber note, but the next round shifted into a celebration of gals in government.

headline: Ethics Changes Proposed for House Trips, K Street
text: On the House’s first day of really any business, Representative Louise Slaughter, chairwoman of the Rules Committee, released a set of proposed ethics changes that would considerably alter how business is done on the Hill and might crimp the interchange between lobbyists and lawmakers.

headline: For Your Consideration
text: Damn. So, as you surely know by now, one unsigned entry for the big 2006 Online Video Awards appeared just under the wire. December 30, 2006.

headline: Construction Worker One Day, Celebrity Subway Hero the Next
text: Would you jump onto the subway tracks to save a stranger?

headline: Spitzer’s Health Care Pledge Focuses on Easing the Way for Those Entitled
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer vowed yesterday to make health insurance available to all children and enroll all eligible adults in Medicaid. If carried out fully, his pledges would cut the number of uninsured New Yorkers in half.

headline: Yonkers: Doctor Found Fatally Shot
text: A 46-year-old physician was found fatally shot on his bedroom floor yesterday afternoon, the Yonkers police said. The body of the physician, Dr. Leandro Lozada, who had a practice in the Bronx, was discovered by a friend around 3 p.m. at 43 Brendon Hill Road, the police said. They said that Dr. Lozada lived alone and that there was no sign of forced entry or a weapon.

headline: Samsung to Unveil Slimmer Rear-Projection TVs
text: Samsung, the world's largest seller of televisions, will introduce at next week's Consumer Electronics Show a new line of rear-projection D.L.P. televisions that will not be much thicker than flat-panel TVs but will cost about 30 percent less.

headline: Below Haze, Saturn’s Biggest Moon Has Lakes
text: As scientists have predicted but have had a hard time proving, the surface of Titan, Saturn’s largest moon, appears to be dotted with lakes of liquid methane. The lakes are more intriguing evidence of the active phenomena at play on the only moon in the solar system with a dense atmosphere.

headline: Pakistan Wants Afghan Refugees Resettled
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 4 — Pakistan’s prime minister, Shaukat Aziz, said today that three million Afghan refugees living in Pakistan must be resettled in their native country so that their refugee camps can no longer be used as safe havens by insurgents.

headline: Lilly to Pay Up to $500 Million to Settle Claims
text: Eli Lilly agreed today to pay up to $500 million to settle 18,000 lawsuits from people who claimed they developed diabetes or other diseases after taking Zyprexa, Lilly’s drug for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder

headline: Awaiting Bush’s Iraq Plan, Democrats Weigh Replies
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — Some key Senate Democrats say they could consider supporting a short-term increase in American troop levels in Iraq, a stance that reflects division within the party and could provide an opening for President Bush as he prepares to announce his revised plan for Iraq as early as next week.

headline: Harriet Miers Plans to Leave White House
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 — Harriet E. Miers, the White House counsel who endured a brief moment in the spotlight as President Bush’s Supreme Court nominee in 2005, is leaving the administration, Mr. Bush’s chief spokesman said today.

headline: Britain: First Female Beefeater Appointed
text: The Tower of London, one of Britain’s most popular tourist attractions, has appointed a female guard for the first time in its 900-year history. She will join the ranks of the Yeoman Warders who wear a red-and-gold ceremonial uniform and are known as Beefeaters. The Yeoman Warders were officially appointed to guard the tower in 1485 and trace their origins even further back, to William the Conqueror’s reign in the 11th century. The origin of the term Beefeater is unclear. One theory is that the first guards were paid in beef. To join the 35-strong ranks of the Beefeaters, a candidate must have served 22 years in the armed forces.

headline: The Ugly Death of Saddam Hussein
text: Saddam Hussein deserves no one’s pity. But as anyone who has seen the graphic cellphone video of his hanging can testify, his execution bore little resemblance to dispassionate, state-administered justice. The condemned dictator appeared to have been delivered from United States military custody into the hands of a Shiite lynch mob.

headline: A Big Hero in the Big City
text: New Yorkers have long rolled their eyes when politicians, TV commercials and after-dinner speakers endlessly extolled “small-town values.” The truth is that integrity, compassion and heroism are no scarcer on the sidewalks of Chicago or Harlem than they are in Dubuque. If anyone doubts this, they should consider Wesley Autrey’s heroic turn at the 137th Street and Broadway subway station this week.

headline: Town Considers Guards for Library Disrupted by Students
text: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 3  The Maplewood Township Committee is asking the public library’s board of trustees not to follow through with a plan to close its two buildings during after-school hours and is considering providing security guards to help quell disruptive behavior, Mayor Fred R. Profeta Jr. said Wednesday.

headline: And Now, the Eyes of Texas Are Upon Jones and Parcells
text: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 3  Bill Parcells was careful with his words, even as he picked a curious time to hint at his future as Dallas Cowboys coach.

headline: Helping Make the Shift From Combat to Commerce
text: Coming home from their respective tours of duty in Iraq, John Reid and Alina Gutierrez had never met but they had a lot in common. Both were sergeants in the 42nd Infantry Division of the Army and were deployed in Iraq from autumn 2004 to autumn 2005. And both had a strong interest in running their own businesses when they got home.

headline: Manhattan: Injuries From Fire Kill Man
text: A 65-year-old Washington Heights man was killed in his apartment last night by a fire that residents say was started with a hair dryer left on a bed by a neighbor living one floor below him, city officials and witnesses said. Neighbors said that fire alarms in the building did not go off, so they only became aware of the fire when they felt the heat of the flames and smelled the smoke in their building, at 517 West 160th Street. The man, identified by his brother as Miguel Grullon, was pronounced dead at a hospital a short while later.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit brought by Intertainer, a digital media company, against Apple Computer, Google and Napster misstated the nature of the litigation. It involves a patent, not a copyright.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture credit on Dec. 26 with the Books of The Times Review, about “The Girl With the Gallery: Edith Gregor Halpert and the Making of the Modern Art Market,” by Lindsay Pollock, misspelled the surname of the man whose estate holds the copyright to the picture of Mrs. Halpert. He was Louis Faurer, not Fauer.

headline: Costly Calls From Prison (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Despite Misgivings, White House Says Little Against Hanging
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  The White House declined Wednesday to criticize the conduct of the execution of Saddam Hussein, even as State Department officials and military leaders in Baghdad raised questions about the timing of the hanging and the way the condemned dictator was taunted by Shiite guards as he stood on the gallows.

headline: France: Bill to Redress Homelessness
text: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin introduced legislation that would give the homeless an enforceable right to housing. The move was in response to a yearlong campaign on behalf of the homeless that included the distribution of tents for people living on the street. A concentration of the tents in the 10th Arrondissement in Paris brought the issue to a head, and on New Year’s Eve, President Jacques Chirac promised to ask the government to work on legislation. The proposed law, Mr. de Villepin said, would “put the right to housing on the same level as the right to medical care or education.”

headline: A Store to Make Your Feet Say Olé
text: MANY years ago, I lived in Spain for a summer, teaching English at 5:45 a.m. to a group of pharmaceutical executives, most of whom knew only three words in English at the onset of the season: “yes” (enthusiastic bobbing of heads), “no” (sad frowns) and “marketing” (big smiles and thumbs-up gestures).

headline: Giants See the Angles in a Prism Tinted Blue
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 3  At one end of the range of possibilities is a blowout first-round playoff loss to the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday. On the opposite end is a Super Bowl victory next month.

headline: From Hussein, a Florid Farewell to the Iraqi People
