text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 3 — The dictator sat alone in his cell, three years in American custody. His beard had gone gray, his sons were dead and the gallows were being readied.

headline: France: Deadline for Suez Bid Disclosure
text: The French stock market regulator, Autorité des Marchés Financiers, will set a deadline next week for the billionaire François Pinault to say whether he plans to make an offer for the utility Suez. Failure to meet the deadline would prevent Mr. Pinault’s holding company, Artemis, from bidding for the company for six months, unless there were “significant” changes in Suez’s situation or shareholder structure, the regulatory agency said. Suez, which supplies water and electric power, asked the regulator on Tuesday to set a deadline after reports surfaced that Artemis was considering the acquisition.

headline: The Sky Wasn’t Falling, Just a Tiny Chunk of It
text: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 3 — Whatever it was, the object that fell from the sky was not part of an airplane. That was all anyone knew for sure.

headline: Resisting the Big Contract and the Quick Fix
text: This being the fourth day of January, it is not too early to talk about baseball — even in New York, with our two local pro football teams in the playoffs.

headline: New Disc May Sway DVD Wars
text: Consumers wary of buying new high-definition DVD players because of a technology war reminiscent of the days of Betamax versus VHS will soon have a new kind of DVD that might make the decision less daunting.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article yesterday about an Iraqi government investigation of the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, including the unauthorized cellphone camera recording of it, misstated the account of a witness who said he saw two others there holding cellphone cameras aloft to record Mr. Hussein’s final moments. While the witness, Munkith al-Faroun, a prosecutor at Mr. Hussein’s trial, said both of the others were officials, he did not identify one of them as Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser. Mr. Rubaie, who could not be reached for comment in the article, said yesterday that he had handed his cellphone to security officials an hour before the hanging and had not recorded it. (Go to Article)

headline: Another Thousand Lives
text: How long can this go on?

headline: Big East Nearing Perfection in Bowl Games
text: With just a handful of days remaining in the college football season, it is not too early to declare which conference had the best year in 2006.

headline: Kenya Closes Border but Denies Turning Back Refugees
text: BAIDOA, Somalia, Jan. 3 — Kenyan officials announced Wednesday that they were closing their northern border because of the conflict in Somalia, but denied that they had turned back hundreds of refugees.

headline: Giuliani Leak: Attention Turns to Florida
text: Mischief in presidential politics in Florida?

headline: Romney Takes Step Toward an ’08 Run
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  On his last full day as governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney created a presidential exploratory committee Wednesday, the first formal step in a likely run for the 2008 Republican nomination.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Barbara Walters Sails Into Troubled Waters

headline: Taiwan’s Bullet Trains Can’t Outrun Controversy
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 28 — The sleek, bulbous-nosed new bullet trains here look like they are designed to whisk passengers across wide-open spaces. But on this congested island, they represent the start of a 180-mile-per-hour commuter train system.

headline: Markets Finish Mixed as Fed Hints at Nagging Concern With Inflation
text: Stocks surged early yesterday, the first trading day of 2007, but fell sharply after minutes from a Federal Reserve meeting indicated that inflation remained the chief concern of policy makers even as they started to worry about a weakening economy. Markets closed mixed for the day.

headline: Tennessee’s Tax on Illegal Drugs Nets $3.5 Million
text: ATLANTA, Jan. 3  Tennessee has collected nearly $3.5 million since it began enforcing its tax on illegal drugs two years ago, officials from the Department of Revenue said Wednesday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the debate over free will misstated the location of Elizabethtown College, where Michael Silberstein, who commented on free will and popular culture, is a science philosopher. It is in Pennsylvania, not Maryland.

headline: Catch the Next Chapter on Your iPod (It’s Even Cheaper)
text: On a recent afternoon Laura Wilson was speaking through a microphone to Oliver Wyman, who was on the other side of a pane of glass. “Just hit Samaritan a little harder,” she said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the most popular movies of 2006 and others that did not do as well at the box office referred incorrectly to two languages spoken in “Babel,” one of the films with subtitles that did not draw big crowds. They are Spanish and Berber, not “Mexican” and “Moroccan.”

headline: To Sleep, Perchance to Succeed
text: FOR those who have failed in a decade or three’s worth of New Year’s resolutions to become better workers, spouses, parents, athletes or lovers, there is a new frontier in personal growth — or at least a proliferation of products, mostly hawked over the Internet, that promise to help turn the last bit of untrammeled downtime (sleep) into an opportunity for improvement.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The On Education column yesterday, about A Better Chance, a nonprofit group that helps minority children apply to private day and boarding high schools, misstated the surname of the president of the group and omitted her middle initial. She is Sandra E. Timmons, not Simmons.

headline: Comptroller Voices Concern About Brooklyn Golf Deal
text: A $9.6 million city contract to renovate and operate a golf course in Marine Park in Brooklyn was headed for further review yesterday after the city comptroller raised concerns about ties between the contractor and a man accused of being a soldier in the Colombo crime family.

headline: Exxon Accused of Trying to Mislead Public
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 3 — The Union of Concerned Scientists released a report on Wednesday accusing Exxon Mobil of spending millions of dollars to manipulate public opinion on the seriousness of global warming.

headline: Dress Their Way
text: WHEN self-improvement begins at home, alone, in the closet, it most often ends on the couch, alone, watching television. Fortunately, as marathon viewings of “What Not to Wear” on TLC remind us, reforming our errant ways in fashion is best done with professional help, of which there is a sudden outpouring.

headline: A Snit in First Class
text: I have a dream, my friends. I have a dream that we are approaching the day when a ranch-owning millionaire Republican like George Bush will make peace with a vineyard-owning millionaire Democrat like Nancy Pelosi.

headline: Importing Contacts From Eudora
text: Q. Is there a way to transfer a large address book from Eudora to another e-mail program?

headline: Chasing Solar Power in the Northeast
text: HOME solar systems in the Northeast can produce up to 90 percent of the electricity generated by those in California, said Michael Hall, chief marketing officer for Borrego Solar Systems, a company in California. It is not surprising, then, that some California installers are expanding nationally. They include PowerLight and Akeena Solar, which opened offices in New Jersey in the last two years.

headline: Childhood Friends, Partners in Crime
text: Marcus Sakey is a first-time author who successfully jump-starts his first book, “The Blade Itself.” He does this with a nod to Dennis Lehane’s “Mystic River,” which is never a bad gambit for a hard-charging thriller. So Mr. Sakey presents a group of young Irish guys from the Old Neighborhood (in this case on the South Side of Chicago). He describes a crime committed in their shadowy past. And he guarantees that the crime will come back to bite them.

headline: Vietnam: Bird Flu Measures Stepped Up
text: Vietnam, which wiped out avian flu in its poultry in 2005, is facing a resurgence and has ordered millions of vaccine doses from China to quell it, health officials said. Since last month, the disease has been found in more than 25 villages in three provinces. Officials blamed farmers who evaded twice-yearly vaccination drives and the smuggling of chickens and ducks from China as demand surges for next month’s celebration of Tet, the Vietnamese New Year. Vietnam has had more confirmed human cases than any other country — 93, with 42 deaths — but had none last year.

headline: Indications of a Slowdown in Sex Entertainment Trade
text: The sex-related entertainment industry’s leading performers, owners and fans gather in Las Vegas for three conferences starting next week amid indications that pornography’s robust growth since it came out from behind the counter in the 1970s is slowing.

headline: Empty Seat on Giants’ Bus to Philadelphia
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Spitzer Requests Sweeping Array of New Measures
text: ALBANY, Jan. 3 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed overhauling almost every corner of the state’s operations and policies in his first address to the Legislature on Wednesday. He said he would move swiftly to guarantee health insurance for all children in the state, toughen campaign finance laws, cut property taxes by $6 billion and draft constitutional amendments to overhaul the state’s courts.

headline: Jets’ Kendall Not Afraid to Talk One for the Team
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 3  Pete Kendall strolled out of the training room Monday clutching a three-week-old U.S. News & World Report magazine.

headline: In China’s New Revolution, Art Greets Capitalism
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 3 — After the peppered beef carpaccio and before the pan-fried sea bass there were raucous toasts and the clinking of wine glasses in the V.I.P. room of New Heights, a jazzy restaurant in this city’s most luxurious location, overlooking the Bund.

headline: Plugging Into the Sun
text: WILLIAM LEININGER is not your typical environmental zealot. A Navy commander who works as a doctor at the Naval Medical Center San Diego, he is a Republican and lives in one of California’s most conservative counties, in a development of neat lawns and Spanish-style houses. His 2,400-square-foot, single-level house — “the usual Southern California design,” he said recently — is barely distinguishable from its neighbors, apart from one detail: the red-tile roof is crammed with solar panels.

headline: Fans Track Air Traffic for Hints on Coaching Vacancies
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 3 — As rumors about Alabama’s coaching search reached a fever pitch here in recent weeks, many fans seeking clues about who might fill the Crimson Tide’s vacancy looked to the skies.

headline: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
text: Arrogance has never been attractive in a leader. Now, in corporate chief executives anyhow, it may be a career ender.

headline: After Rotation, Yankees Still Seek Help at First
text: The Yankees continued their attempt to trade Randy Johnson yesterday, talking with multiple teams about a deal. The most likely match remains Johnson’s former team, the Arizona Diamondbacks, but Arizona has not been granted a 72-hour window to speak with him. Johnson must approve a trade and it is not clear how the Diamondbacks would afford him.

headline: With Ad Deal, Insurer Wades Into Bridge Traffic
text: Drivers crossing the George Washington Bridge must contend with 18-wheelers, infuriating delays and noxious exhaust. Soon, they will also have advertisements from Geico.

headline: Brooklyn: Four Shot Outside Rink
text: Two women and two men were shot early yesterday in front of a roller skating rink just east of Prospect Park, the police said. Gunfire broke out shortly before 1 a.m. outside the Empire Roller Skating Center at 200 Empire Boulevard, the police said. Two people were hit in the leg, one in the foot and the fourth in the abdomen, the police said. All four victims, whose names were not released, were in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center yesterday, the police said. No arrests have been made.

headline: In Nod to Realpolitik, Offering Carrots to Both Sides
text: ALBANY, Jan. 3  Sure, some of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s calls in his first address to the Legislature on Wednesday  for spending less money, ending gerrymandering and limiting campaign donations  were met with the kind of icy reception he might have received if he had worn a Red Sox cap to Yankee Stadium.

headline: Lack of Rules on Protective Gear Brings Suit Against Labor Dept.
text: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United Food and Commercial Workers sued the Department of Labor yesterday, asserting that it broke the law by failing to issue regulations requiring employers to pay for protective equipment for their workers.

headline: A Guitar That Plugs Into a Computer via U.S.B.? Oh, It Makes Me Wonder
text: With the right equipment, future guitar virtuosos and “Stairway to Heaven” fanatics don’t have to be chained to bulky amplifiers in the basement to practice and record their riffs. Hammacher Schlemmer offers the PC Recording Studio Guitar, a six-string electric instrument that comes with a U.S.B. port to connect it directly to a PC or Mac.

headline: In Meetings With Allies, Clinton Hones ’08 Strategy
text: The topic was the Democratic sweep in New Hampshire in November, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton could not get enough of it.

headline: A Crop of Azure, Scarlet and Gold
text: A FEW years ago, when I first glimpsed the azure wing of a bluebird in the hedgerow that borders my meadow, I could hardly believe my eyes.

headline: Congress Renews Vows of Civility — for a Day
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 — Like baseball and nature, Washington runs in cycles, replete with power shifts, reversals of fortune and, of course, renewed vows of civility and bipartisanship.

headline: Bush Reaches Out, but Keeps One Hand on the Wheel
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — In an article published on a friendly op-ed page, and from the regal confines of the White House, President Bush greeted the incoming Democratic leadership of Congress on Wednesday with a message of bipartisanship.

headline: Defensive Strategies and Fast Food Cravings
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. - The media poured into town this week for the Bowl Championship Series national title game between Florida and Ohio State. The first day of news conferences Tuesday offered a nice snapshot of some of the storylines emerging this week.

headline: Iran’s President Promises More Nuclear Fuel and a Celebration
text: TEHRAN, Jan. 3  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad warned Wednesday that Iran would not back down from its nuclear ambitions and said his country would soon start producing nuclear fuel on an industrial scale.

headline: Bronx: Construction Worker Killed
text: A 47-year-old laborer was killed yesterday after the machine he was operating fell off a building and crashed to the ground two stories below, the police and City Building Department officials said. The accident happened around 8:30 a.m. as workers were demolishing an eight-story commercial building at 587 River Avenue. City officials said the laborer, Carlos Reinoso, of Jackson Heights, Queens, was using a Bobcat excavator to push a concrete beam over the building’s side, and fell after the beam snagged the Bobcat and dragged it over the edge. The contractor, Bedroc Contracting, was issued a citation alleging unsafe practices. Bedroc’s managing partner, Frank Weidner, said in a statement that his company was also looking into the accident. The police said no charges would be filed.

headline: Free the Mind and Fewer Injuries May Follow
text: IN a high school locker room in Worthington, Ohio, Sam Maniar handed a piece of string tied to a washer to each of the field hockey players sitting around him. He told the athletes to use their minds to move the washer from side to side, and he watched as each girl’s washer started to swing.

headline: Addenda
text: Sprint Nextel Reviews Its Creative Account

headline: School Is Shut After Outbreak of Encephalitis Kills a Pupil
text: WARWICK, R.I., Jan. 3 — State and federal health officials are investigating an extremely rare outbreak of encephalitis here that killed a second grader last month and led officials to close his elementary school this week.

headline: Pulling It All Together
text: WILLIAM D. WATKINS has seven terabytes of data storage tucked into a cabinet in the media room of his beach home in Aptos, Calif. That is not a big thing for Mr. Watkins, the chief executive of Seagate, which makes hard disk drives. But it is enough space to hold 600,000 songs, 584,000 photographs and 1,000 hours of TV shows.

headline: Position Wanted
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Correction
text: A front-page article yesterday about an Iraqi government investigation of the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, including the unauthorized cellphone camera recording of it, misstated the account of a witness who said he saw two others there holding cellphone cameras aloft to record Mr. Hussein’s final moments. While the witness, Munkith al-Faroun, a prosecutor at Mr. Hussein’s trial, said both of the others were officials, he did not identify one of them as Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser. Mr. Rubaie, who could not be reached for comment in the article, said yesterday that he had handed his cellphone to security officials an hour before the hanging and had not recorded it.

headline: The Cosmetics Restriction Diet
text: DR. FRAN E. COOK-BOLDEN, a dermatologist in Manhattan, is an advocate of skin-care minimalism. When a patient recently arrived for an appointment toting 20 different products she was using regularly — including an eye cream, a vitamin C cream, a wrinkle serum, a pigmentation cream, a mask, a peel, a scrub and “some sort of special oxygen detoxifying cream” — Dr. Cook-Bolden said she confiscated all but three.

headline: And Now for Something Classically Odd
text: Going to a P. D. Q. Bach concert is like listening to a Beethoven symphony: You know what’s coming but still like it when it gets there. The tradition (or is it habit?) survives after more than 40 years; so do its ritual formats. Both were greeted at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday by a large and unusually smart-mouthed audience. Members of the New York Philharmonic played along mostly with good grace, though some looked to be salvaging what they could of their dignity.

headline: U.S. Requiring Port Workers to Have IDs and Reviews
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — More than 750,000 port workers will be required to have criminal background and immigration checks in an antiterrorism program that the Homeland Security Department announced on Wednesday, and industry leaders say the effort could disrupt port traffic nationally.

headline: Who Is That Wearing That Milk Mustache?
text: BRAND mascots and other types of brand ambassadors — meant to bring a brand to life in tangible form — are everywhere these days, as marketers look for new ways to spread their messages across a variety of media.

headline: My Father’s Red Scare
text: Vancouver, British Columbia

headline: Brain Exercise and the Elderly (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Country Less Dependent on Oil Is Free to Make Other New Year’s Resolutions
text: Well, another New Year’s Day has come and gone. A string of holiday meals and sitting on the couch have, no doubt, started another wave of resolutions to get some exercise and go on a diet. But after seeing gas prices pass $3 a gallon last year, hearing all the talk about global warming and having a bad feeling about all the bluster coming from the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, a great many folks wish the economy would go on a diet, too, and stop using so much energy.

headline: Bud Delp, 74, Who Trained Derby Winner Spectacular Bid, Is Dead
text: Bud Delp, the Hall of Fame thoroughbred trainer who saddled the brilliant colt Spectacular Bid, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in 1979, died last Friday in Ellicott City, Md. He was 74.

headline: L.S.U. Swarms Quinn, and Offense Does the Rest
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 — JaMarcus Russell came into the Sugar Bowl as the other quarterback, a gifted one but not the one wearing the iconic gold helmet or the one trying to put a happy ending on a storybook career at Notre Dame, like Brady Quinn. But Russell left the Superdome on Wednesday night as a Louisiana State legend and may just leave college football altogether as the N.F.L’s next No. 1 pick.

headline: 2 Top Hollywood Agents Move to a Rival Firm
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 — Two leading Hollywood agents with top-ranked writer and director clients in movies and television joined the Endeavor talent agency on Wednesday, after many years at the rival International Creative Management.

headline: Wheeldon Forms a Dance Company
text: Christopher Wheeldon, one of the world’s most sought-after choreographers, who recently announced an end to his residency at New York City Ballet, has formed his own company, a major event in the dance world.

headline: Stepping Back From the Ledge of the Overly Appointed Life
text: Dan Ho is right. Something is wrong when scraping honeycomb candle wax off the bathtub is a justifiable household chore, and (what’s worse) evidence that one is living well, since everyone knows that “me time” is nothing without bathroom atmospherics.

headline: Mexican U.N. Insider Gets Manager’s Post
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 3  Ban Ki-moon, on his second day as secretary general, appointed a high-level United Nations insider, Alicia Bárcena Ibarra, to the top management post, a signal that he does not plan aggressive reforms in the much-criticized bureaucracy.

headline: Soldier Reaches Plea Deal in the Killing of 3 Iraqis
text: A soldier from the 101st Airborne Division is scheduled to plead guilty next Tuesday to a reduced charge for mercy killing in connection with the death of three unarmed Iraqi men shot by American infantrymen last spring, according to lawyers for other defendants in the case.

headline: Seton Hall Starts Big East Play on Right Track, Beating Rutgers
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 3 — For now, Seton Hall looks like the best Big East basketball team from the state of New Jersey. For the Pirates, that may be as good as it gets the rest of this season.

headline: New Congress, Leftover Challenge
text: The nation should welcome the ambitious agenda being offered today by the new Congress’s Democratic majority, from raising the minimum wage to advancing stem cell research to restoring oversight of the executive branch. But the real test for the 110th Congress will be its willingness to clean up its own act by adopting forceful and credible ethics reform. That is what the Democratic leadership promised voters. Any hesitation will be rightly seen as a cynical re-endorsement of the Capitol’s lobbyist-enabling, corruption-steeped business as usual.

headline: Boy, 17, Dies in School Shooting in Tacoma, and Student Is Held
text: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 3 — A student shot and killed another student at a public high school here on Wednesday, and the accused gunman was arrested a few hours later while walking down a nearby street, the police said.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,991 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Owner of Sardi’s Restaurant Dies at 91
text: Vincent Sardi Jr., who owned and managed Sardi’s restaurant, his father’s theater-district landmark, for more than half a century and became, by wide agreement, the unofficial mayor of Broadway, died today. He was 91 and had lived in Warren, Vt., since retiring in 1997.

headline: For the Well-Dressed iPod, a Leather Jacket in the Color of Your Choice
text: Like reggae? Encase your iPod in Rasta colors. Rooting for Manchester United or the Giants? Get an iPod case in your team colors. Vaja offers its i-Volution cases in thousands of color combinations, all in Argentine leather.

headline: Not an iPod, but It’s Child-Friendly and Uses One AAA Battery
text: Playaway is known for its Ready-to-Go line of audio book players, which are about the size of an iPod and play one book each. It is a concept that seems easy to apply to music, and that’s the idea behind the company’s $30 Kidz Bop to Go players, each featuring 20 songs aimed at children.

headline: Scenes From Another Deadly Bombing in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 4 — The foot was balanced on a shopping bag after being scooped up off the dirty street by a man in a track suit. There was no person to go with the limb. Nearby a charred body was still smoldering, smoke coming off the black corpse 45 minutes after the attack. For 50 yards, the dead were scattered about, some in pieces, some whole but badly burned.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Q. We have heard that Australian laurel is a great houseplant: pretty, fragrant and easy to grow. But our local nursery doesn’t have it and it isn’t in our houseplant book. Can you help?

headline: Israeli Raid Overshadows Meeting in Egypt
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met this evening to discuss how to restore momentum to negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians.

headline: Correction
text: A front-page article on Saturday about adult children who take care of their aging parents referred incorrectly to expenses for the care of a spouse that are tax deductible if they exceed 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income. They are medical expenses, not any expenses.

headline: Staten Island Sees a Decline in New Homes
text: The 20-year building boom on Staten Island, long the city’s fastest-growing borough, is decelerating drastically, thanks largely to a reining-in of the island’s freewheeling zoning laws, officials say. According to city figures released yesterday, permits for new buildings plunged by 43 percent last year.

headline: Beware the No. 2 Fighter With a Fierce Mission
text: “Afro Samurai,” a friend said recently, picking up the DVD from my desk. “Cool.”

headline: Drugstores Bank on Snob Appeal (but Can You Pronounce It?)
text: LUMENE. Lierac. Olí. Arnaud. Proraso.

headline: Construction Worker One Day, Subway Hero the Next
text: Wesley Autrey teetered back and forth on the edge of a subway platform yesterday, re-enacting how he dived onto the tracks of a southbound No. 1 train in Manhattan on Tuesday to save another man’s life.

headline: Where Up Is Still Down, but the Rest Is Changing
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — There were comparisons to “Alice in Wonderland,” “Star Trek,” “The Twilight Zone,” and all manner of clichés to convey the strangeness engulfing Washington this week as the Democrats prepared to assume control of Congress after 12 years in the minority wilderness. But nothing distilled the new aura of things like this conceit: Steny Hoyer, Rock Star.

headline: Iraq Defends Hanging, but Holds Hussein Guard
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 3  The Iraqi prime minister’s office on Wednesday mounted its first public defense of the way the government carried out the execution of Saddam Hussein, and said that Iraqi authorities had detained a guard who they believed was involved in recording the moment in a macabre and unauthorized video that has generated revulsion around the world.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday misstated the surname of the artist whose “Urban Air Scrubber” was at the Tribes Gallery on East Third Street in the East Village. He is William Meyer, not Brent. (Adam Brent is the artist who made another work that was on display.)

headline: Calendar
text: Landscapes in America

headline: The Paths to Universal Health Care (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline:
Democrats Taking Reins 
as New Session Opens on Hill
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — On the brink of regaining power after 12 years, House Democrats said Wednesday that they would move immediately to try to sever ties between lawmakers and lobbyists who figured into scandals that helped Democrats win control of Congress.

headline: Intelligence Chief to Shift to  Deputy State Dept. Post
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 — John D. Negroponte, whom President Bush installed less than two years ago as the first director of national intelligence, will soon leave his post to become the State Department’s second-ranking official, administration officials said Wednesday.

headline: Chávez Plans One Big Venezuela Leftist Party, Led by Him
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 3 — President Hugo Chávez has begun forging a single Socialist party among his varied supporters, one of his recent efforts to create momentum for far-reaching changes to Venezuela’s political system that analysts say will effectively concentrate greater political power in his hands.

headline: Studies Find Harm in 2 Parkinson’s Drugs
text: Two drugs used to treat Parkinson’s disease and other disorders can seriously damage heart valves, researchers are reporting.

headline: Adelphia Bankruptcy Plan Is Approved
text: Adelphia Communications’ plan to pay creditors and end one of the biggest bankruptcy cases in United States history was approved yesterday by a judge in New York.

headline: Ford Is Buried After Thousands in Hometown Pay Respects
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 3  Gerald R. Ford was buried on Wednesday on a grassy hill beside the rushing waters of the Grand River as the sun set, a final farewell in a week of remembrances for the nation’s 38th president.

headline: Home Depot Ousts Highly Paid Chief
text: In May, in a nearly empty basement ballroom at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del., Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, stood between huge timers, intended to limit questions from the handful of shareholders present. After dismissing questions about his compensation or the independence of the board, Mr. Nardelli abruptly ended the meeting after only 30 minutes.

headline: Garry Betty, 49, Chief of the Internet Provider EarthLink, Dies
text: Garry Betty, who built the EarthLink Corporation from a struggling start-up into a public company that took on telecommunications giants, died Tuesday in Atlanta. He was 49.

headline: Accessorizing at the Buena Vista Scrabble Club
text: LAST week a winter storm blew into town like a stranger with a bad attitude.

headline: Iona Seeks a Change, or at Least a Victory
text: There have been times when Iona, one of the nation’s better midmajor basketball programs in recent seasons, might have had a legitimate chance to beat an opponent like Maryland. They did not expect last night to be one of them.

headline: China: Sabmiller Expands Venture
text: SABMiller said its China venture would buy a local partner for $320 million to expand in the world’s biggest beer market. China Resources Snow Breweries, 49 percent owned by SABMiller, agreed to buy the shares it does not already own in the Blue Sword Group, which owns 38 percent stakes in 14 breweries in central Sichuan province. The remaining shares are owned by China Resources Snow. In October, SABMiller said that its China Resources Snow venture had become China’s largest brewer by sales volume, beating its domestic rival Tsingtao Brewery.

headline: U.S. Is Looking Into Bruno’s Ties to an Investment Firm
text: ALBANY, Jan. 3  The federal investigation into the business activities of Joseph L. Bruno, who was re-elected majority leader of the State Senate on Wednesday, has widened to include an Albany investment firm that has had close ties to him, public records show.

headline: Elections for 2 Council Seats Will Be on Feb. 20
text: A special election will be held on Feb. 20 to fill two City Council seats left vacant in Brooklyn and on Staten Island, the city’s Board of Elections said yesterday.

headline: The Democrats’ Cautious Tiptoe Around the President’s Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  President Bush is all but daring Democratic leaders to attack his signature tax cuts as they take over Congress. But Democrats, perhaps to his frustration, are having none of it.

headline: Citing ‘Egregious Misconduct,’ Panel Removes a Town Justice
text: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct announced yesterday that it had removed an upstate town justice for a number of improper acts, including efforts to intimidate prosecutors to keep them from complaining to the commission.

headline: Duke Players Once Accused of Rape Can Return to School
text: Duke University invited two former lacrosse players to return to school yesterday while they fight charges of sexual offense and kidnapping arising from a stripper’s complaint after a team party last March.

headline: Totals
A ThinkPad Tablet Tries to Find Its Place in the Sun
text: Tablet PCs have not gained much traction in the marketplace, but Lenovo’s latest may rev up the genre. The X60 ThinkPad Tablet has a 12-inch screen that flips around to fold flat, and it is brighter than usual, with a polarizing filter to cut glare — perhaps for those who would walk in the sun while Web surfing. There is a stylus for writing on the touch screen, and its other end has an electronic eraser for quick deletions.

headline: Deconstructing Meaning by Truly Mincing Words
text: There is more than one way to take the measure of books. You can of course read them. You can count pages, lines or words. Or you can dissect their texts, parsing and weighing words until they lose meaning while gaining literal substance, and then arrange the physical remnants of this concrete poetry into an epic of their own.

headline: Switzerland: Nestlé Sells Composting Unit
text: Nestlé, the food company, agreed to sell a soil-composting unit in the United States to the Garick Corporation for an undisclosed price. Garick, which is based in Cleveland, said it would add the unit, New Milford Farms, to its reusable waste business. New Milford, part of a Nestlé unit in New Milford, Conn., turns processed food byproducts into compost. Terms were not disclosed. Nestlé is based in Vevey, Switzerland.

headline: Nets Save About $5 Million by Trading McInnis to Bobcats
text: The Nets traded the disgruntled point guard Jeff McInnis to the Charlotte Bobcats yesterday for the swingman Bernard Robinson.

headline: In the Albany of 2007, Many Familiar Faces and a Few New Names
text: ALBANY, Jan. 3 — Change is in the air at the State Capitol, but the top faces in the Legislature are staying the same. The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, were both confirmed on Wednesday as the leaders of their respective chambers — positions they have held since 1994.

headline: Fewer Excuses for Not Doing a PC Backup
text: If there’s one New Year’s resolution even more likely to fail than “I vow to lose weight,” it’s “I vow to start backing up my computer.”

headline: New York Times to Sell 9 Local TV Stations
text: The New York Times Company announced today that it had agreed to sell its nine local television stations to Oak Hill Capital Partners, a private equity firm, for $575 million.

headline: Judge Drops KPMG Charge in Tax Case
text: A federal judge has dismissed a criminal charge accusing KPMG, the accounting firm, of conspiring to sell illegal tax shelters, after prosecutors said that the firm had met its obligations under a 2005 deferred- prosecution agreement.

headline: Saban Leaving the Dolphins for Alabama
text: DAVIE, Fla., Jan. 3 — Nick Saban had been saying for more than a month that he would not leave the Miami Dolphins. Nearly two weeks ago, he said, “I’m not going to be the Alabama coach.”

headline: After String of Crises, a Family Finds Some Security
text: When Destiny-Rae was quiet at 18 months old, Delores Pryce knew that something was wrong. “All my children talked early,” she said. “But she wasn’t speaking.”

headline: U.S. Bars Lab From Testing Electronic Voting
text: A laboratory that has tested most of the nation’s electronic voting systems has been temporarily barred from approving new machines after federal officials found that it was not following its quality-control procedures and could not document that it was conducting all the required tests.

headline: Somali Government Compound Hit by Grenade
text: KISMAYO, Somalia, Jan. 4 — A hand grenade was tossed into a government compound today in Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, in yet another sign of a growing insurgency as security seems to be unraveling across the country.

headline: Agitprop Tactics, Spoofs and Semantics in the Bronx
text: A favorite sport in today’s bloated art world is to lament the surfeit of commercial galleries, biennials and art fairs, which have replaced the “genuine” art experience provided by nonprofit organizations. But as Matthew Higgs, director of White Columns, the city’s oldest alternative art space, recently pointed out in Artforum, the nonprofit scene in New York is thriving.

headline: A New Entry in Push-to-Talk
text: Push-to-talk, another name for walkie-talkie cellphone features, has been popular for years, but until recently it was largely available on Nextel phones. Now you can get push-to-talk from Cingular as well, and the LG CU400 cellphone it recently began offering adds high-speed data services to the mix.

headline: Garden City: Judges Sue, Seeking Raise
text: Demanding raises for 1,300 state and local judges, four jurists have taken the rare step of suing the governor, Legislature and court system. The suit, filed Friday in State Supreme Court, contends that inflation has effectively cut salaries 28 percent since the last raise, in 1999, violating a constitutional bar against reducing judges’ compensation. The suit also accuses legislators of linking judicial pay to their own, violating the separation of powers and ignoring the fact that judges work full time with limited outside work, unlike legislators. The lawyer filing the suit, Steven Cohn, said he had been inundated with support from judges. A court spokesman declined to comment but said court officials were pushing hard for raises. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has said he also supports raises for judges. Legislative leaders declined to comment.

headline: In Padilla Wiretaps, Murky View of ‘Jihad’ Case
text: In 1997, as the government listened in on their phone call, Adham Hassoun, a computer programmer in Broward County, Fla., proposed a road trip to Jose Padilla, a low-wage worker there. The excursion to Tampa would be his treat, Mr. Hassoun said, and a chance to meet “some nice, uh, brothers.”

headline: An Ousted Chief’s Going-Away Pay Is Seen by Many as Typically Excessive
text: Robert L. Nardelli’s rich compensation and poor performance at Home Depot have long been cited by shareholder activists as a prime example of what they view as excessive executive pay. Some union members dressed up in giant chicken outfits to protest the board’s reluctance to clip Mr. Nardelli’s wings.

headline: Hussein Poem: Baathists Bloom, Enemy Is Hollow
text: Following is the first half of a poem attributed to Saddam Hussein, as transcribed and translated by The New York Times from a reading by his cousin Muayed Dhamin al-Hazza.

headline: Auto Sales at Big 3 Fall Further
text: DETROIT, Jan. 3 — The Detroit auto show, which opens next week, is all about new concepts, building buzz and making fresh starts. And the Detroit auto companies can use all of that.

headline: Health Scare Closes More Rhode Island Schools
text: More than 21,000 students in public schools in three communities in Rhode Island were told today to stay home for the rest of the week after a child who attended one of the schools was admitted to a hospital with a probable case of meningitis.

headline: Dismantling the Beat to Get to the Heart of It
text: All good musicians have a physical relationship to their instruments, but a few make it really apparent. They tend to be big people with big instruments. Charles Mingus was this way, as are the Brazilian percussionist Carlinhos Brown and the trombonist Wycliffe Gordon. And so is the drummer Tyshawn Sorey, who isn’t yet so well known outside inner-circle jazz audiences, who may have heard him play in bands with Dave Douglas or Vijay Iyer or Steve Coleman.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Bermuda: New Insurer to Focus on Coasts
text: The Bear Stearns Companies, Greenhill & Company and three other firms have invested $1 billion to create Ironshore Insurance, an insurer that will be based in Bermuda and will specialize in disaster-prone commercial properties along the Southeast and Gulf coasts of the United States. Robert Clements, who helped start various Bermuda-based insurers including ACE and XL Capital, arranged the financing with his son John Clements. “We see a marketplace that is starved for quality capacity,” Robert V. Deutsch, Ironshore’s chief executive, above, said in a telephone interview.

headline: G.E. Magic Can Fade, After G.E.
text: When boards of directors go shopping for a new chief executive, their first stop is often General Electric.

headline: Lieberman’s Party Now Has Critic as Its Chief
text: HARTFORD, Jan. 3  Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut was able to beat back a fierce challenge last fall, but now his critics are joining the very party he created to win his way back to Washington for a fourth term.

headline: Mother Wonders if Psychosis Drug Helped Kill Son
text: At first, the psychiatric drug Zyprexa may have saved John Eric Kauffman’s life, rescuing him from his hallucinations and other symptoms of acute psychosis.

headline: Getting the Middle East Back on Our Side
text: Washington

headline: Democrats Take the Gavels in Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 — Jubilant Democrats took the gavels in the Senate and House today for the first time in 12 years, pledging a new era in Congress and a new effort at bipartisan progress.

headline: Defense May Be Ultimate Measure of Colts’ Success
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 3 — Running backs have relished playing against the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Web sites that offer unfiltered video clips misstated the type of aircraft shown attacking Taliban forces in Afghanistan in one such video. It was an A-10 Thunderbolt, not an A-20 Havoc.

headline: Not Quite a Détente in Belichick-Mangini Relations
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 3 — Nick Saban had left the Miami Dolphins only minutes earlier Wednesday morning when Patriots Coach Bill Belichick was asked what he thought of the move. He praised Saban’s intelligence. He revealed that he and Saban had spoken by phone Tuesday night. He called him a good friend.

headline: A 180° View of a Hotbed of Housing Design
text: Venice, Calif.

headline: East Orange, N.J.: Store Owner Is Killed
text: EAST ORANGE: STORE OWNER IS KILLED The owner of a clothing store was fatally shot yesterday afternoon in his shop by a gunman who entered it and opened fire, the authorities said. The shooting took place around 2:30 p.m. inside 353 Clothing on Main Street, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor’s office. No arrests had been made as of last night, and investigators were trying to determine a motive. The victim was identified by the East Orange Police Department as Allan Cuff, 34, of East Orange.

headline: Seymour Martin Lipset, Sociologist, Dies at 84
text: Seymour Martin Lipset, who ignored family pressure to be a dentist and instead became a pre-eminent sociologist, political scientist and incisive theorist on American uniqueness, died on Dec. 31 in Arlington, Va. He was 84.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Out With the Old
text: There was good news and bad news yesterday for shareholders of Home Depot. The good news is that Robert Nardelli, the imperious chief executive who had presided over a difficult, stagnant period for the company, has resigned. The bad news is that he’ll be taking $210 million worth of compensation with him, one of the highest severance packages ever, which is saying a lot in this era of runaway executive pay.

headline: Where You Least Expect It
text: HAS it ever seemed clearer that fashion is not about clothes? Has it ever appeared more inevitable that the cult of the designer is slated for the cultural slag heap, there to join all those other monuments to the outmoded notion of the grand career (retrospective albums, DVD collections, the Great Novel)?

headline: Knicks’ Troubles Extend to Defense and Jeffries
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3  Disillusionment blanketed the small visitors’ locker room at Arco Arena in Sacramento late Tuesday night. In one corner, Eddy Curry sat glumly, hardly looking up as he blamed himself for the Knicks’ latest defeat. A few feet over and a few minutes later, Stephon Marbury later spoke in low tones that conveyed distress. It was hard to find even a resigned grin or a hopeful glance in the crowd.

headline: The Building That Wouldn’t Go Away
text: THE dismantling of the Deutsche Bank building will begin this fall and — after careful, systematic deconstruction — it will be gone next year.”

headline: Jurors in Drunken-Driver Trial May Be Queried on Verdict
text: MINEOLA, N.Y., Jan. 3 — In a rare reprise to a rare trial, the jury that convicted a Long Island man of murder by depraved indifference last October in a drunken-driving crash that killed a limousine driver and a 7-year-old girl may be brought back to court for hearings on whether some members acted improperly during deliberations.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.My kitchen cabinets are scarred and scuffed. Should I repair or replace them?

headline: Florida: Hotel Is Sued Over Carbon Monoxide
text: An Iowa family that fell ill at a Key West hotel nearly a week before a man who stayed in the same room died of carbon monoxide poisoning has sued the hotel, claiming they were injured. David and Jody Smith and their son Nathan, of Ankeny, Iowa, stayed at the hotel, the Doubletree Grand Key Resort, and were treated at a local hospital on Dec. 21, less than a week before Thomas Lueders, 26, died from inhaling carbon monoxide fumes that came from a boiler adjacent to his room. The Smiths’ lawsuit seeks compensation for hospital expenses and emotional anguish. Ira Leesfield, the lawyer for the Smiths, said he expected at least three other families to join the suit.

headline: Pondering Six Diamonds and Contemplating the Other Table
text: The premier event at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Midtown Manhattan, which finished last Saturday, was the Truscott Board-a-Match Teams.

headline: Art Above and Below, With Life in the Middle
text: IT has been more than five years since the first of Ann Brashares’s “Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants” novels, which would become a sensation among teenage girls, hit the best-seller list. The last book in the series, “Forever in Blue: The Fourth Summer of the Sisterhood,” will be published on Tuesday, but during that half decade, the characters have aged only about three years.

headline: Manhattan: Transit Chief to Resign
text: Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the branch of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the subways and buses, announced his resignation yesterday, clearing the way for new leadership at the agency he has run since 1996. Finding a replacement for Mr. Reuter, above, will now become one of the first tasks for the transportation authority’s incoming executive director and chief executive, Elliot G. Sander. Mr. Sander was chosen to head the authority by Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who has frequently called for a management shake-up at the agency. Mr. Reuter said his departure was not influenced by the change in administration. He plans to leave the authority in early February and will take a job in Miami with Parsons Brinckerhoff, a large engineering company.

headline: 26-year Sentence in Reporter’s Death
text: One of two men convicted in the killing of a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced to 26 years in prison. The defendant, Michael C. Hamlin, had faced a term of up to 60 years after pleading guilty late last year to second-degree murder, robbery and conspiracy to commit robbery for his part in the attack on the reporter, David E. Rosenbaum, near Mr. Rosenbaum’s Washington home a year ago. At the trial of his cousin Percey Jordan Jr., Mr. Hamlin, 24, testified that he had stolen Mr. Rosenbaum’s wallet but that it was Mr. Jordan, wielding a pipe, who had delivered a fatal blow to the victim’s head. Mr. Rosenbaum, 63, died two days later. Mr. Jordan is to be sentenced before the same judge, Erik P. Christian of District of Columbia Superior Court, later this month. Convicted of first-degree murder, he faces at least 30 years in prison and a maximum of life without the possibility of parole.

headline: Travails of Adolescence? He’s Been There
text: What makes ninth grade funny? Having your mom beat you in basketball? Figuring out why girls like bad boys? Learning to be a team player only after not making the basketball team? James Lewis, popularly known as Lil’ J J, a 16-year-old stand-up comedian from Little Rock, Ark., is plying those examples of teenage angst as the character Jordan Lewis, on “Just Jordan,” a new Nickelodeon series about Jordan, his friends and family in Los Angeles that begins Sunday.

headline: Curry Finds Form and Knicks Find a Way to Win
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3 — Eddy Curry found daylight on a dull gray evening in the Pacific Northwest. It was perhaps the most pleasant sight the Knicks had seen on their extended tour of the N.B.A.’s better conference.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the handling of the video of Saddam Hussein’s execution by television networks and Web sites referred imprecisely to the site littlegreenfootballs.com. It posted a link to the video, not the video itself.

headline: Words We Understand (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pomp and Promises as Rell Begins Full Term
text: HARTFORD, Jan. 3  Casting her first full term as governor as a chance to guide the state through a “crossroads of needed economic, social, cultural and educational change,” M. Jodi Rell was sworn in as Connecticut’s 87th governor on Wednesday, promising to “lead” and “inspire.”

headline: Spin Around League
text: (Andrew Das, Toni Monkovic, Naila-Jean Meyers, Benjamin Hoffman and John Woods contributed items)

headline: After the Flood, the Debris
text: “Floodwall,” an installation of hundreds of drawers salvaged from Katrina's trash heaps by New Orleans artist Jana Napoli, can now be found in Lower Manhattan.

headline: N.F.L. vs. College Football
text: Boise State-Oklahoma still resonates. In our department, we haven’t hooted and hollered over a game like that in a long time. Moments after Jared Zabransky’s Statue of Liberty handoff to Ian Johnson for the winning 2-point conversion, a colleague did a little hop and said: “That’s why college football is so much better! You’ll never see that in the N.F.L.! You’ll never see it!”

headline: It Is What It Is (Aaaargh)
text: Gene Collier’s column on sports cliches is an annual delight for us editor types. (O.K., so we’re easily amused)

headline: Low-Key Punta del Este
text: Despite its jet-set reputation, Punta has other charms, like surprisingly nice people, blond beaches and flawless architectural vistas.

headline: Shakespeare's Church Is Crumbling
text: The church where Shakespeare is buried is “urgently” seeking nearly $400,000 for repairs to its tower and spire, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Stone's Village
A Fairy Tale for Fractured Times
text: Anyone who dismisses the “Shrek” movies as lowbrow junk should see “Happily N’Ever After,” a cartoon feature that apes those films’ visuals, soundtrack choices and rude jokes, while throwing away their sweetness and conviction.

headline: Online Job Sites: Ripe for Consolidation?
text: The proliferation of niche help-wanted Web sites, as well as networking sites like Craigslist and LinkedIn, could lead to consolidation among more general jobs sites like Monster, HotJobs, and CareerBuilder. Niche sites made up 64 percent of the market in 2005, according to BusinessWeek, up from 39 percent in 2004. And visits to the “big three” jobs sites are falling fast, though sales are rising thanks to the strength of the job market.

headline: Adelphia Bankruptcy Plan Is Approved
text: Adelphia Communications‘s plan to pay creditors and end one of the biggest bankruptcy cases in United States history was approved Wednesday by a judge in New York. Adelphia, once one of the biggest American cable television companies, filed for protection from creditors in June 2002, a month before its founder, John J. Rigas, was arrested and charged with looting the company.

headline: Finance Firm Hercules Raises $11 Million in Stock Sale
text: Hercules Technology Growth Capital, a specialty finance company, said Wednesday it had raised about $11 million when its underwriters exercised their option to buy an additional 840,000 shares of common stock. Hercules, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the net proceeds will be used to reduce borrowings under its credit facilities, to originate new investments and provide funds for existing investments, and for general corporate purposes.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Macrovision Buys Mediabolic
text: Macrovision has acquired a consumer electronics software provider, Mediabolic, for $43.5 million, the company said Tuesday. Macrovision is best known for its DVD copy-protection software and programs that secure entertainment content like movies and games.

headline: R.R. Donnelly to Acquire Von Hoffmann, a Trade Printer
text: R.R. Donnelley & Sons, the largest North American printing company and the printer of titles like Sports Illustrated and TV Guide, agreed to buy Von Hoffmann from Visant for $412.5 million in cash, furthering its strategy of increasing production capacity for educational and business publishers.

headline: Whirlpool Unloads Maytag Properties
text: Whirlpool said Wednesday that it had sold a number of properties belonging to Maytag, including most of Maytag’s headquarters complex in Newton, Iowa. Whirlpool said it also had sold former Maytag manufacturing sites in Galesburg and Herrin, Ill.; Searcy, Ark.; and Ranson, W.Va. The company did not disclose the terms of the deals.

headline: Nestlé Sells Composting Unit
text: Nestlé, the Swiss food company, agreed to sell a soil-composting unit in the United States to Garick for an undisclosed price. Garick, which is based in Cleveland, said it would add the unit, New Milford Farms, to its reusable waste business. New Milford, part of a Nestlé unit in New Milford, Conn., turns processed food byproducts into compost.

headline: Judge Drops KPMG Charge in Tax Case
text: A federal judge has dismissed a criminal charge accusing KPMG, the accounting firm, of conspiring to sell illegal tax shelters, after prosecutors said that the firm had met its obligations under a 2005 deferred-prosecution agreement.

headline: 3 Cellphone Makers Are Sued Over Bluetooth Technology
text: A United States research institute has sued three cellphone makers, accusing them of violating a patent for Bluetooth technology. The Washington Research Foundation, which markets technology from universities and other nonprofit research institutions in Washington State, is seeking damages from Nokia, Samsung Electronics and Panasonic, owned by Matsushita, contending that the three companies were using a radio frequency receiver technology patented by a University of Washington scientist in 1999.

headline: Cisco to Buy Network Security Firm IronPort
text: Cisco Systems said Thursday it would buy a Web messaging and e-mail security company, IronPort Systems, for $830 million to tap growing demand for anti-virus and anti-spam software. The deal for IronPort would be Cisco’s biggest since its $6.9 billion purchase of Scientific-Atlanta, announced in 2005.

headline: Everbright Bank Said to Seek Investor
text: China Everbright Bank, which plans to hold an initial public offering this year, has hired China International Capital and Morgan Stanley to find a foreign investor before the offering, according to Bloomberg News. Everbright Bank, which in 1996 became the first Chinese bank to sell stock to an overseas financial institution, is trying to bolster its capital to comply with government guidelines, Bloomberg said.

headline: Macquarie to Outsource Jobs to India, Report Says
text: Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, plans to shift as many as 100 administrative jobs, including positions from payroll services in Sydney and London, to India, according to Bloomberg News. The bank plans to combine its global human resources functions as part of a “strategic review,” a Macquarie spokesman told Bloomberg. Macquarie joins the Credit Suisse Group and the Australia & New Zealand Banking Group among banks that are hiring in India to take advantage of the nation’s lower labor costs and pool of skilled workers.

headline: Morgan Stanley Faces Age-Bias Suit
text: A former Morgan Stanley regional director in wealth management sued the company on Wednesday, saying he was fired because of his age. The executive, Edward Sullivan, 56, who had been a managing director, accused human resources executives Jeffrey Brodsky and Eric Kayne of conspiring to end his employment, in part to make room for a friend of Mr. Brodsky’s who lacked an assignment.

headline: Bezos Offers Glimpse into Space Venture
text: Amazon.com‘s founder, Jeff Bezos, wants engineers to join his fledgling and secretive private aerospace business, Blue Origin, breaking a long silence about his operation by posting photos and videos on the company’s Web site of a test launch of a reusable spacecraft. The posting, dated Tuesday, shows a cone-shaped vehicle with four metal legs, launching in a cloud of smoke, reaching an altitude of about 285 feet, according to Blue Origin, then landing on its legs.

headline: Bank of America Steps Back from Venture Arm
text: Bank of America is distancing itself from its venture capital arm, BA Venture Partners, to concentrate on its middle-market private equity unit, BA Capital Investors. BA Ventures said Wednesday that it would rename itself Scale Venture Partners as Bank of America repositions itself as a minority investor.

headline: Private Equity Boom Racks Up Bankers’ Fees
text: Bankers enjoying their record bonuses from 2006 have, at least in part, private equity to thank, as the industry is poised to pay $11 billion in fees in an unprecedented year for leveraged buyouts. Taking the crown is Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which will pay out more than $837 million in fees to investment banks in 2006, more than any other private equity firm.

headline: Pinault Faces Deadline for 70 Billion Euro Suez Bid
text: The French financial markets regulator said Wednesday that it would decide Tuesday on a target date by which François Pinault, the billionaire investor who owns the fashion house Gucci, must make a bid for Suez or else abstain from bidding for six months. A bid could derail a government-orchestrated plan for an 80 billion euro ($106.2 billion) merger between Suez, a water and energy group, and the state-controlled Gaz de France.

headline: AGL Makes Pass at Origin to Create Australia’s Largest Energy Retailer
text: AGL Energy, Australia’s biggest power and gas retailer, has made an initial approach to its biggest rival, Origin Energy, about a merger valued at 13 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to create the country’s biggest gas and electricity supplier.

headline: Wall Street’s Not-So-Green Deal
text: As a big battle over global warming is unfolding in Texas, Fortune takes a look at how green Wall Street’s investment banks really are. At the heart of the controversy is a Dallas-based energy company that wants to build 11 coal-fired plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air. In an effort to stop the plants, environmentalists, along with a coalition of institutional investors, have turned their attention to Merrill Lynch, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, the three lead arrangers of TXU‘s financing.

headline: Radio One Picks Up Giant Magazine
text: Radio One, an urban-music radio broadcaster, has purchased the struggling magazine Giant for a song. The broadcaster, which owns 70 radio stations in 22 urban markets, paid $275,000 for the magazine, which was founded by Jamie Hooper, a one-time publisher of Stuff.

headline: Home Depot Moves Put G.E., Martin Lipton in Spotlight
text: As shareholders, industry watchers and lawmakers continued to express outrage over the $210 million golden farewell that Home Depot awarded its ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, The New York Times takes a look at where it all began: General Electric, which has become a kind of high-end boutique where company directors go when they are looking for the cream of the crop in chief executives.

headline: Icahn May Take Sands Stake from Troubled GB Holdings
text: GB Holdings, which is liquidating its assets, will seek approval of a plan anchored by Carl Icahn’s $53 million offer to buy the debtor’s stake in Atlantic City’s Sands Hotel & Casino. Chief Judge Judith Wizmur in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey in Camden set Jan. 30 for a confirmation hearing on GB’s eighth modified disclosure statement, records show. The plan requires Mr. Icahn to pay $53 million for GB’s remaining 28.2 percent interest in Atlantic Coast Entertainment Holdings, one of his affiliates.

headline: After Newspaper Deal, Avista Strikes Again
text: Avista Capital Partners, fresh off last week’s purchase of the Minneapolis Star Tribune, agreed Wednesday to acquire a self-directed investment advisory firm, Phillips Investment Resources, for an amount The Deal.com put between $140 million and $160 million. Phillips, a well-known provider of independent advice, offers 23 different subscription-based services for delivery in digital forms as well as print newsletters.

headline: Polygon Drops Pursuit of Soccer Club
text: A consortium led by the hedge fund Polygon Investment Partners said Thursday that it had dropped plans to make a bid for the British soccer club Newcastle United, which is valued at 91 million pounds ($177 million). Last month, the team confirmed that it was in talks with the consortium, St. James’ Park Group, about a possible bid, and rumors swirled that Polygon had approached the club’s former chairman, Sir John Hall, about buying his 28.8 percent stake. The Times of London said that the Belgravia Group, a British investment company, confirmed that it is still in talks with Newcastle about a possible bid.

headline: Major Tribune Shareholder to Review Stake
text: Tribune shareholder McCormick Tribune Foundation said Thursday in a regulatory filing that it is considering various options for its investment in the publishing and broadcasting company. The disclosure comes as Tribune, which owns the Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Tribune newspapers, is conducting a strategic review that could lead to a sale of all or part of the company.

headline: Backing Up Online
text: David Pogue experiences the ups and downs of YouTube while reviewing backup services.

headline: What’s Mine Is Mine, Even if It’s Yours
text: Bob Yari is a sought-after guy in Hollywood. He has money, is willing to finance adventurous films, and did the Bagger mention he has a lot of loot? Last year, Mr. Yari ended up in an unseemly tussle over credits. He sued every which way — he named both the Producer’s Guild of America and the Academy — for what he felt was rightfully his, but his suit was eventually thrown out. Now Mr. Yari is back in the news, actually at the top of Page Six, almost never a friendly place, because he is said to have dumped a project directed by Don Cheadle and based on a book by Elmore Leonard.

headline: This, Too, Belongs to Me
text: One would think that things were pretty jolly over at the Paramount lot yesterday, after the Producer Guild Awards nominees were announced.

headline: Fiji Update: President Returns; Prime Minister Still Banished
text: A bit of news from post-putsch Fiji: The military’s commander, Frank Bainimarama, who seized power last month in the coup-prone Pacific nation (it was the fourth in the last 20 years), reinstated the president, Ratu Josefa Iloilo, according to The Australian.

headline: Conrad Black: a Media King Dethroned
text: New York, according to Vanity Fair’s Maureen Orth, was Conrad Black’s downfall.

headline: CNN Steps Into Osama/Obama Bramble; Blogs Document It
text: Readers might recall the Baltimore radio host who cheekily asked passers-by last fall whether “Barack Obama” posed a threat to the nation. Said one respondent:

headline: SAGS Drop
text: The five nominess for best ensemble were:

headline: The SAG Nominees for Motion Pictures
text: For this year’s entire SAG Awards nominees list, click here.

headline: Berkeley Bubble
text: With a mandate that says merit trumps all, the University of California, Berkeley, finds itself looking across the Pacific for its identity.

headline: Acting, As If
text: It was another helping of love for “Babel,” which had picked up seven Globes, a producer’s nomination yesterday, and this morning, a best ensemble nod from the Screen Actor’s Guild.

headline: Obama’s Approach on Congressional Ethics
2008 Like It’s Today: Romney In
text: Gov. Mitt Romney is now officially exploring. That means he can start raising money. And his campaign wasted no time in doing that, sending an e-mail to supporters around 7:15 Wednesday evening.

headline: How Secure Is Your Wi-Fi Connection?
text: Long-time readers know that I'm not exactly one of the privacy paranoid.

headline: The Democrats’ Hill: First Official Day, Still Adjusting
text: Today, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California will become the first female speaker of the House, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada will become Senate majority leader, and Democrats will control both chambers as new members are sworn in. The Caucus will be on the Hill, too, reporting on all the pomp and circumstance.

headline: The Pleasing Sound of Hawks
text: Do hawks have a genetic advantage when it comes to political argument? Writing in Foreign Policy, Daniel Kahneman and Jonathan Renshon say yes. Kahneman, a Princeton professor of psychology and public affairs, and Rehnson, the author of “Why Leaders Choose War: The Psychology of Prevention,” write:

headline: Bush’s First Shot at the Dems
text: Jim Rutenberg, The Times’s White House correspondent, parses the messages in President Bush’s Wall Street Journal op-ed.

headline: Just Another Bric-a-Brac on the Wall
text: Audio antiques as wall art, courtesy of mom and pop's record collection.

headline: Banking Looks Brighter in Europe, Analyst Says
text: After forecasting that Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and UBS would all face declining fees from investment-banking work in 2007, Bear Stearns analyst Christopher Wheeler has turned much more upbeat. In a note published Thursday, Mr. Wheeler said each of those banks should be able to match last year’s revenue from investment banking compared with his previous expectation of a 7 percent to 8 percent year-over-year decline.

headline: Good Sense for a New Year
text: Melissa Clark, left, and Robin Aronson, divas of restraint. (Courtesy of The Skinny)

headline: Snickerdoodle Spillage in Puget Sound?
text: The United States Geological Survey has famously found all manner of funky chemicals  in groundwater, floodwater runoff, snowpack and even in animals who hang about the edges of our water systems. (Yes, we’re talking the usual PCB’s and pesticides, but also more interesting stuff like, say,  perfume, or the antidepressant drug Venlafaxine.)

headline: Newark: Death Sentence Changed to Life
text: After nearly 19 years on death row, a man who admitted killing a pizzeria owner was resentenced to life in prison in State Superior Court. The resentencing came after the State Supreme Court overturned a death sentence for the man, Anthony DiFrisco, 46, last summer. Mr. DiFrisco said he was paid $2,500 to kill Edward Potcher, the owner of Jack’s Pizzeria in Maplewood, in 1986, prosecutors said.

headline: On the Senate Side of the 110th Congress
text: The new Senate met in the old Senate chamber today, with most senators, from both parties, in attendance. Slowly, people trickled out. Ben Cardin, Maryland’s newly elected senator, ducked out well before the rest—maybe to go visit his old friends in the House of Representatives, where he just completed his tenth term.

headline: How Secure Is Your Wi-Fi Connection?
text: Long-time readers know that I’m not exactly one of the privacy paranoid.

headline: Cuomo to Feast on Pork
text: The death watch continues for the member item system that proliferated in the Pataki era, as Attorney General Andrew Cuomo said this morning he will review the roughly 6,000 items sponsored by legislators this year “and seek to recover any misspent funds.”

headline: Wells Fargo and Wachovia: Is This the Year?
text: The latest financial pundit to unfurl 2007 predictions is David Weidner of MarketWatch, who offers a list of events he expects to see in the next year. A few of them are pretty safe bets: Executive pay will rise, he says; brokerage profits will fall. But his prediction that Wachovia will merge with Wells Fargo — a banking combination that he is not the first to propose — comes with a considerable amount of detail. He writes:

headline: L.S.U. Routs Notre Dame in Sugar Bowl
text: Overshadowed by Notre Dame quarterback Brady Quinn going into the Sugar Bowl, L.S.U. quarterback JaMarcus Russell emerged as the game’s true star.

headline: The More Things Change…
text: One of the enduring truths of Washington is that for as much as everyone rails against the place — even runs against “same old Washington” — few people ever leave.

headline: Fired SEC Lawyer Answers Wall Street Journal Editorial
text: Gary Aguirre, who criticized his former bosses at the Securities and Exchange Commission at a Senate hearing last month, is now taking the Wall Street Journal editorial page to task.

headline: Law Firms Dewey and Orrick Cancel Merger
text: The wedding between Dewey Ballantine and Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe is off, the two law firms said Thursday afternoon. In a joint statement, the firms attributed the failure of the proposed merger to unspecified complexities in bringing the firms together.

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Adds M&A Partner in London
text: The law firm Sullivan & Cromwell said Thursday that Tim Emmerson will join its London office as a partner, where he will focus on mergers and acquisitions, private equity and equity capital markets law. Mr. Emmerson was previously a partner at Milbank Tweed Hadley and McCloy in London.

headline: Nardelli’s Departure
text: There is a wonderful irony to the departure of Bob Nardelli from Home Depot.

headline: The Obama Watch Continues
text: Senator Barack Obama is back from his Hawaiian holiday vacation, but those waiting to find out whether he’s going to run for president will have to wait at least a little while longer.

headline: A New Racing Web Site
text: If I don’t talk much about discovering other racing Web sites or blogs, it’s not by design. There’s usually just too much other news. But I just learned of a new project that seems worthy of mentioning in this fairly quiet period of F1 news (the calm before the storm). Racer magazine today announced the launch of a new interactive racing Web site that looks interesting: Myracer.com

headline: Building a Better TiVo
text: In three days, 140,000 gadget-minded geeks and 2,700 publicity-hungry companies will cram into Las Vegas to jostle each other on 1.7 million square feet of trade show floor. The cab lines will be long, dinner reservations scarce and sleep nonexistent. I’m looking forward to it.

headline: Macworld Rumors
text: Next week, I’ll be in San Francisco to cover the Macworld Expo. It’s nominally a show about Apple products, but as everyone knows, what Apple does is usually adopted shortly thereafter by the rest of the industry (think CD-ROM, Wi-Fi, music player/online music store). So it’s a big deal, and loads of fun.

headline: The Other Clinton on the Hill
text: The opening day of Congress always brings spouses to Capitol Hill and today was no exception.

headline: Blogtalk
text: Marriage, Spitzer and the legislature. [The Politicker]

headline: My Outfits Have Audiences
text: If someone turned a camera on you RIGHT NOW, and asked you about your clothes, do you know what you’d say?

headline: On the Hill: All Their Children
text: Most of the time, Congress looks as if it’s run by children.

headline: Aon May Sell Combined Unit, Analyst Says
text: Insurance broker Marsh & McLennan has been slimming down its business mix, and at least one analyst thinks that rival Aon will make a similar move. Credit Suisse analyst Charles Gates said Thursday that he expects Aon to sell its Combined Insurance unit as it “transitions completely away from retaining and underwriting risk.” In his research note, Mr. Gates estimates the unit, which sells accident, health and life insurance, could fetch $2.4 billion.

headline: The Product E-Mails Pile Up
text: Spam pales in quantity compared to the number of e-mails you receive when you’re on the CES press list. Not only is the Consumer Electronics Show the biggest convention in the U.S., but it must also generate the largest number of electronic messages for any event. For six weeks prior to the show, anyone who’s registered begins to receive hundreds of e-mails from P.R. agents, practically begging you to check out their latest products. Unfortunately, many of the agencies don’t seem to do their homework because like spam, most of these messages don’t seem to have any particular target audience in mind.

headline: An Odd Couple
text: You would have to forgive Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee if he felt a little lonely today. He was, after all, the only new Republican elected to the Senate in the 110th Congress.

headline: Texas Pacific Thinks Smaller With Latest Fund
text: Here is a twist on the “biggest fund ever” stories that have become routine in the booming private-equity industry. Reuters notes that Texas Pacific Group is raising eyebrows with its new — and relatively puny — buyout fund. At about $1 billion, the latest fund is really midsized, but it is tiny compared with Texas Pacific’s previous investment vehicle, which came in at $15 billion.

headline: What’s the Theme?
text: Last year, when you asked industry analysts and marketing executives what the theme of the Consumer Electronics show was going to be they said, “home networking.” Yes, 2006 was the year we’d connect all our TVs in our homes to all our PCs and move movies and videos around between them.

headline: East Coast-West Coast Beef
text: The Bagger watched with some amusement as the gatekeepers of journalistic Hollywood gently knocked down David Denby’s big heave about movies in the New Yorker.

headline: Heap of the Top
text: What came out on top of the rock pile at Metacritic, the place where criticism is a common endeavor? The best reviewed film of the year is from El Gordo, Guillermo del Toro: “Pan’s Labyrinth.” Other critical beanie babies among the top ten include “L’Enfant,” “United 93,” and yes, “Borat.” “The Departed” just missed, coming in at number 11.

headline: Race to Replace Balboni Begins
text: Now that State Senator Michael A.L. Balboni, a Nassau County Republican, has joined the Spitzer administration, Republicans are wasting no time trying to hold on to his seat.

headline: Where’s the Beef? Snowbound After Two Blizzards
text: While those of us in Eastern climes have been enjoying unseasonably balmy weather, the fallout from heavy snows in several Western states may well leave some residents without power for weeks.

headline: Smut Revenue Growth Slows — But There’s Always the ‘Stifler’s Mom’ Effect
text: This little nugget is worth noting from The Times’ own David Cay Johnston: Seems the trafficking of smut — an inimitable boom industry since the dawn of video tape, cable television and the Internet — may be slowing overall.

headline: From the Kitchen to the Congress
text: There’s so much talk about breaking through the marble ceilings on the Hill today that we wondered whether any ceiling had literally cracked by the time Nancy Pelosi assumed the speakership of the House this afternoon. (Certainly not the cast iron of the Capitol dome.)

headline: Cattle Call at the Capitol
text: In the Capitol, understandably, congressmen and women get special treatment. They get their own elevators, they don’t have to go through security and, of course, a staff to handle the day-to-day chores. But just in case the new members were starting to let their newly acquired power go to their heads, the cattle call that was the ceremonial swearing-in/photo-op with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, served as a reminder of real life.

headline: The Times's John Burns
text: The Times's Baghdad bureau chief, John F. Burns, appeared on The Charlie Rose Show to discuss the situation in Iraq.

headline: Exit and Election Strategies
text: It’s true that politicians are polarized—they’re often either over-eager to talk or they won’t talk at all. Today, Representative Dennis Kucinich enthusiastically told us about his presidential plans (he even drew us a rough map of the Middle East), while Howard Dean, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was fairly restrained, about, well, everything.

headline: A Day on the Hill: Democrats Take It Over
text: We’ve had a small caucus of a caucus from The Times up here on the Hill today, culling color and some substance from the mainly ceremonial moments of the day. Both chambers have promised to make ethics reform their top priority, and the House jumped onto the floor to start debating some of the procedural matters surrounding the newly proposed rules that would ban most gifts and corporate jet travel, among other things.

headline: Movie Minutes: Best of 2006
text: A. O. Scott, The Times's chief movie critic, revisits his ten favorite movies of 2006.

headline: Movie Minutes: Worst of 2006
text: A. O. Scott, The Times's chief movie critic, revisits his five least favorite movies of 2006.

headline: The People Predict
text: David Carr (a k a The Carpetbagger) asks moviegoers in Times Square what films they think should be nominated for Academy Awards.

headline: Survey Finds Embezzlement in Many Catholic Dioceses
text: A survey by researchers at Villanova University has found that 85 percent of Roman Catholic dioceses that responded had discovered embezzlement of church money in the last five years, with 11 percent reporting that more than $500,000 had been stolen.

headline: Pedestrian Video
