text: Signs that Charles Krauthammer was souring on the Iraq war began to appear in the spring, when Krauthammer wrote in his Washington Post column that there is only “one hope for success in Iraq”: “an effective, broad-based national unity government that, during its mandatory four-year term, presides over an American withdrawal.” Now, the manner in which Saddam Hussein was executed has led Krauthammer to conclude that the current Iraq government is not worth defending. “We should not be surging American troops in defense of such a government,” he argues in The Washington Post. Krauthammer writes:

headline: On the Hill: Bang the Gavel Slowly
text: This year, Congress is going to be civil and bipartisan. And we’re going to actually lose those 20 pounds! But seriously, folks, leave it to Carl Hulse to dig under the jubilation to find the real meaning in yesterday’s Democratic takeover:

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Read His Lips
text: Mitt Romney refused to sign a “no new taxes” pledge while he was running for governor of Massachusetts, but now that he is shooting for the presidency, he has done just that.

headline: Will It Blend?
text: I’m not alone when I say that I’ll happily watch your ad if it’s entertaining and worth my while. The number of hilarious ad videos circulating on YouTube—millions of people VOLUNTARILY watching corporate ads—is testimony to that.

headline: Q & A: Brian Bistrong
text: Brian Bistrong (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

headline: The Plumbing Stops Up, and Owners Get the Bill
text: Q Recently, the two apartments below me had a plumbing problem. There are four apartments on the same septic system, including my own. Normally, the co-op is responsible for plumbing problems, but our president felt that since the problem was caused by paper towels blocking the system, and since only my apartment and my next-door neighbor’s were occupied when the problem occurred, the co-op should not pay for the repairs.

headline: Kerkorian’s MGM Offer Comes Up Short
text: The year is starting with another underwhelming showing from Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor and corporate agitator who backed out of his General Motors investment late last year. Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian’s holding vehicle, said Friday its offer to buy up to 15 million shares of MGM Mirage ended with a paltry 445,000 shares tendered, potentially quelling for now speculation that Mr. Kerkorian will mount a takeover of the casino operator.

headline: Where’s Eddie?
text: The nominations for Eddie Murphy in the best supporting category for “Dreamgirls” have been piling up. Yesterday, he received one from the Screen Actors Guild, and he’s already gotten a Golden Globe, so it looks like he may have a shot at dancing with Oscar.

headline: A Father Teaches the Son
text: A.O. Scott suggests that parents who find themselves condemned to mediocre “family movies,” try something new.

headline: CSI Continues to Take Over the Universe
text: Fresh off the announcement of yesterday’s nominations for the Screen Actor’s Guild Awards, Alan Rosenberg, SAG’s president, said he would seek a second two-year term when elections are held later this year, subject to an O.K. from his spouse, Marg Helgenberger.

headline: Nightmare at the Museum
text: Let’s say you’re a museum in pursuit of additional traffic. You’ve tried brochures, gussying up your Web site, and even bus-side advertising. But nothing worked like having a blockbuster movie made about your collection. According to Reuters, “Night at the Museum” boosted attendance at American Museum of Natural history by 50,000 over last year, and the movie has only been around a few weeks.

headline: Her Majesty and Her Agent
text: Breaking news: The Brits love “Casino Royale” and “The Queen.”Variety breaks down the British Academy Film Awards, their Oscars, thusly:

headline: The War at Home: Staff Shake-Ups
text: The White House is denying claims that a statement Mr. Bush issued after signing postal legislation last month asserted new executive authority to allow the opening of mail without a warrant in “exigent circumstances.”

headline: Amorous Brazilian Banker Wins Round With YouTube
text: As if YouTube  did not have enough trouble with its users posting clips that violate copyrights, the video-sharing site, newly acquired by Google, must now find a way to remove a video depicting a Merrill Lynch banker and a supermodel in what the Associated Press calls “intimate scenes.” A Brazilian judge this week ordered YouTube to filter out the video, which was the talk of Brazil when it first surfaced last fall.

headline: Tijuana Streets Are Too Dangerous, So Police Are Disarmed
text: The entire Tijuana police force walked off the job yesterday after being effectively disarmed by 3,000 Mexican troops and federal agents — themselves dispatched two days ago to the crime-ridden border city to try to combat drug-cartel violence and chaos.

headline: Former Merrill Analyst Sentenced in Insider-Trading Case
text: Stanislav Shpigelman, the former Merrill Lynch analyst who pleaded guilty to leaking confidential information to a $6.7 million insider-trading ring, was sentenced to three years and one month in prison in Manhattan federal court Friday. He was the second person and the first banker sentenced in connection with the conspiracy. Mr. Shpigelman, 24, admitted in July that he had given material nonpublic information about upcoming deals to Eugene Plotkin and David Pajcin, both former Goldman Sachs employees.

headline: The Hill: Not Exactly 8 Days a Week
text: Democrats are already grumbling about the five-day work week — at least among themselves.

headline: Viacom’s Deal Strategist Expands Role
text: The former investment banker who has overseen Viacom‘s acquisition strategy for the past year just got a longer title for his business card. Wade Davis, the media group’s senior vice president of mergers and acquisitions since December 2005, has become senior vice president of strategy, mergers and acquisitions, Viacom said Friday.

headline: Cablevision Buyout Offer Is a Drag, Analyst Says
text: A takeover bid is usually seen as something that props up a company’s share price. But a Pali Research analyst, Richard Greenfield, argues that just the reverse is true for Cablevision, the giant cable operator. In a research report on Friday, he suggests that Cablevision’s stock is worth far more than what its controlling family, the Dolans, has said it is willing to pay.

headline: Comment Zone: Advice for Spitzer
text: The other day, we asked Empire Zone readers to give advice to New York’s new governor. There were suggestions to improve the upstate economy, provide affordable housing and health care for all, reform workers compensation and workplace safety, impose term limits on legislators, reduce  pollution, raise the minimum wage, repeal the Rockefeller-era drug laws, pass legislation allowing same-sex marriage or civil unions, and more. Following is an edited selection.“As a student, my main concern is college tuition,” writes  the commenter Amy. “I believe that Governor Spitzer should investigate and take a look at how college funds are truly used. As a student I am extremely disappointed in the education I am paying to receive, and also extremely broke.”

headline: Macworld Bingo
text: As the rumor mill for Apple’s big announcements on Tuesday goes into overdrive, this witty programmer has treated viewers of the presentation to a game of Macworld Bingo. As Apple chief Steve Jobs goes through his speech, check off the typical Apple presentation elements as they occur. Get one row across, down or diagonally, and YOU WIN!

headline: Stop Yer Engines
text: After mulling it for a day, the New York State Board of Elections has ordered Ciber, the Colorado-based information systems company contracted to test new voting machines for the state, to stop their tests. The board wants to figure out why a federal election assistance committee delayed giving Ciber permission last summer to accredit new voting machines. The word went out early this morning, and Ciber agreed to stop testing. Meanwhile, state elections officials are trying to get access to the federal committee’s internal assessment of Ciber’s problems.

headline: Dem Leaders to Bush: Don’t Surge
text: As President Bush inches closer to presenting his Iraq strategy, he is scheduling a series of meetings with members of Congress this afternoon and Monday. The White House is hoping to find support for its plan by reaching out to moderate Democrats and friendly Republicans. A meeting has not been scheduled with Democratic Congressional leaders, so Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California have just sent a letter to Mr. Bush.

headline: Purnick on the Real Rudy
text: In a Political Memo, Joyce Purnick riffs on the recent brouhaha over the the Giuliani campaign papers. To get a more concrete view of his campaign strategy, she suggests, look at the Giuliani 2000 Web site, in which he glosses over his three marriages, the Kerik affair and other potentially troublesome matters.

headline: Hewlett-Packard
text: The most requested ad of the day, from AdForum.

headline: Windfall Awaits Readers Digest Banker
text: February 2 is likely to be a happy day for Michael Lynch. That is when shareholders of Readers Digest Association are set to vote on Ripplewood Holdings‘ offer to take the publishing company private. If the deal closes, Mr. Lynch, who advised Readers Digest alongside his former employer, Goldman Sachs, is individually eligible for a $2.75 million fee. TheStreet.com wrote about the fee Friday, labelling it “quite a coup” for Mr. Lynch and calling the tag-team advisory arrangement “highly unusual.”

headline: A Good Selling Point: A Small, Nearby Airport
text: The smallest things can influence where you end up living. It could be that the location provides an easy commute, or you love the early morning light, or it might be that you are right next door is the world’s best fly-fishing.

headline: Who Needs Web 2.0 Anyway?
text: Some venture-capital types are sounding awfully weary about Web 2.0, a much-hyped term that The New York Times’s David Pogue recently defined as “participatory Web sites, like YouTube, MySpace, Wikipedia, Digg and Flickr, which [rely] on material supplied by the audience itself.”

headline: Carlyle Names Managing Directors
text: Carlyle Group, the giant private equity firm based in Washington, D.C., said this week it promoted 16 professionals to managing director, including three members of its New York office. It also promoted 18 people to principal or director, titles it said are equivalent in rank, principal being used in the United States and director in Europe and Asia.

headline: ‘King of Queens’ Sex Video!
text: It’s official: everyone has a secret.

headline: British Cartoon Protester Found Guilty of “Soliciting Murder”
text: BBC News  reports that Umran Javed, a 27-year-old British Muslim, has been found guilty of soliciting murder during a London rally last year, where he and others were protesting the publication in Denmark of cartoons that satirized the prophet Muhammad.

headline: Blogtalk
text: According to a CNN transcript of the program “Glenn Beck on Headline News,” when it was suggested that a hurricane could cause a 20- to 25-foot storm surge in New York City, Mr. Beck said, “Actually, that would clean the streets out. It might not be bad.” Liberal blogs have cried foul, noting that studies show such a storm would cause “heavy loss of life.” One local blog’s summary: “Glenn Beck wants to kill you.” (It should be noted his show is based here.) [Raw Story, AmericaBlog, My Two Senses and The Daily Gotham]

headline: What’s in a Slogan?
text: President Bush is said to be calling his shift in Iraq war policy “the New Way Forward.”

headline: Anti-Surge Protests Against McCain, Lieberman
text: Don’t expect Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and anti-war activists to be kissing and making up anytime soon. Demonstrators were out in full force, despite the light sprinkle of rain, to protest his appearance at the American Enterprise Institute here in the nation’s capital. The self-styled Democrat-Independent joined Senator John McCain to speak about Iraq at the conservative think tank, and their call for more troops in Iraq was a foregone conclusion.

headline: Vows: Kathryn and Michael
text: Kathryn Berger and Michael Herrington met during a business trip.

headline: And This Is Detroit Once the Aliens Showed Up
text: The remake of War of the Worlds starring Tom Cruise is one of the movies lampooned in Scary Movie 4. In one scene, a newscaster narrates a video of a shattered city—skyscrapers are on fire, gunshots ring out, people are screaming. “This is Detroit,” the newscaster says solemnly, pausing a moment before the punch line, “And this is Detroit once the aliens showed up!” It is, of course, the exact same scene, but with aliens. Last spring, The Onion ran a story entitled, “Detroit Sold for Scrap”. And so on.

headline: A Pregnant Pause
text: Looking forward to next week’s director and writer guild nominations, OscarWatch ovulates, gestates and cogitates. The process eventually produces … some pretty keen guesses.

headline: A Status Quo Secretary General
text: The big powers in the United Nations Security Council chose Ban Ki-moon as secretary general because they wanted a low-key bureaucrat who wouldn’t rock the boat. Judging by Mr. Ban’s early moves, the world has gotten exactly that.

headline: Zalmay Khalilzad, on to a New Trouble Spot
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — In successive tours in Afghanistan and Iraq, Zalmay Khalilzad earned a reputation as a high-flying, independent, smooth operator — an Afghan-born problem solver who worked with two fragile countries recently invaded by the United States to try to cobble together stability.

headline: Bush Facing Deep Divide Over More Troops for Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — The new Democratic leaders of the Senate and the House warned President Bush on Friday against sending additional troops to Iraq, setting the stage for what could become a major confrontation over a new war strategy.

headline: Rival Coaches Share Bond, Except on Game Days
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 5  The longtime friendship between Tony Dungy and Herman Edwards was severely tested in 1996.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Thursday about the side effects of the psychiatric drug Zyprexa misstated the name of a older drug tested against Zyprexa in a federally sponsored clinical trial. It was perphenazine (also called Trilafon), not Stelazine.

headline: Jack Myers, 93, Editor Who Geared Science to Children, Dies
text: Jack E. Myers, a molecular biologist who not only researched algae as a food source that could be grown in space but also made science comprehensible to youngsters as an editor of Highlights for Children magazine, died Dec. 28 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 93.

headline: Patriots' Recipe for Success Is Envy of the League
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 5  The huge Super Bowl banners hang from the upper deck of the stadium. Images of the Lombardi Trophy  three of them  are silhouetted on the front marquee at Gillette Stadium.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A museum entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday, about the New-York Historical Society, included an outdated closing date for an exhibition there. The exhibition, “Elegy in the Dust: September 11th and the Chelsea Jeans Memorial,” has been extended through July 1. It will not close tomorrow.

headline: Leaked Notes on ’08 Show Giuliani Without the Spin
text: The country sure has been enjoying itself reading about the Rudy Caper, feasting on the inside dish gleaned from Rudolph W. Giuliani’s presidential playbook.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) MUNICH (2005). Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this story’s historical impetus — the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli hostages were murdered by members of a Palestinian terrorist group known as Black September — to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath, when Israel purportedly waged a campaign of vengeance with five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects over months and then years. Eric Bana plays the film’s moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the murders. Daniel Craig (the newest James Bond), Ciaran Hinds, Hans Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas.

headline: Eagles Look to the Past to Bring Future Success
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 — When the phone rang Monday morning, Koy Detmer let his answering machine pick up.

headline: Knicks Take Lead Early and Keep Adding to It
text: SEATTLE, Jan. 5 — Eddy Curry found perfection Friday night, Jamal Crawford had a happy homecoming and the Knicks transformed a once-miserable trip into a modest sign of hope for the coming months.

headline: Faces on a Coin (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Friday about notable anniversaries this year misspelled the name of a former Soviet premier. It is Nikita Khrushchev, not Kruschev.

headline: Totals
The Land of Rising Conservation
text: TOKYO, Jan. 5 — In many countries, higher oil prices have hurt pocketbooks and led to worries about economic slowdowns. But here in Japan, Kiminobu Kimura, an architect, says he has not felt the pinch. In fact, his monthly energy bill is lower than a year ago.

headline: For Record-Setting Recruit, Full-Throated Praise and Whispered Doubts
text: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 5  Jimmy Clausen, one of the nation’s top-rated high school football players, watched most of Notre Dame’s dismal 41-14 loss to Louisiana State in the Sugar Bowl on Wednesday night.

headline: San Franciscans Hurl Their Rage at Parking Patrol
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 — It bears the hallmarks of a classic urban scourge: back-channel sales, assaults on enforcement officials and even death.

headline: Marching Their Way Before Title Game’s Cameras
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5  On the sideline of a scruffy practice field late this week, the leader of the Florida Gators gathered his players after a long workout in the heat and the humidity to remind them that they would face more celebrated Ohio State opponents Monday.

headline: Two Teenagers Confess to Committing Deadly Spree of Robberies in Queens Park, Police Say
text: The trail of the crime spree is brutal and damning: a burned-out minivan, a string of victims viciously beaten and robbed, a dead man’s body found floating near a boathouse in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.

headline: Reunion of Meyer and Smith Succeeds at Florida
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., Jan. 5 — When Florida Coach Urban Meyer scored his biggest recruiting victory last summer, it was not achieved by beating out Miami, Florida State or Tennessee.

headline: Monument to the Planet Suffers a Hard Fall to Earth
text: An artist who hoped to stir debate over global warming with his 175-ton quartzite and bronze sculpture “Spaceship Earth” is instead struggling to solve the mystery of its spectacular crash at Kennesaw State University last week.

headline: Pursuing Writers, but Letting Them Lead the Chase
text: Opinions at length grow ugly, and so does talking about yourself: two traps the journalistic interview can fall into. One way out is to arm it with a needle of challenge. The subject, instead of standing to pronounce from a podium, is led to scurry, dodge and perhaps fight back, displaying paces and not just poundage.

headline: A Blending of Euripides, Martial Arts and Noh
text: Something must have happened to Company East’s well-reviewed “Medea” on its way from the Edinburgh Festival Fringe to New York, where it opened on Thursday night for two weeks at La MaMa. Directed, choreographed and designed by Kenji Kawarasaki, this staging of “Medea” looked hastily put together and insubstantial, with a sudden last conceit suggesting some indecision about what it means to be.

headline: Urgent Tasks for the New Congress (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Future With the Wind
text: AES, the big power company, is branching out to wind power generation and other alternative energy. The company, which generates and distributes electricity in 26 countries, is also entering the $28 billion carbon trading market, where credits are exchanged to reduce or offset greenhouse gas emissions. Its chief executive, Paul Hanrahan, sat down in his office at the company’s sleek new headquarters in Arlington, Va., to discuss these developments. Following are excerpts:

headline: Higher Pay Is Set for Transit Chief
text: The new leader of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will be paid $42,000 more than his predecessor, a raise that is justified because he will have a wider role in running the agency and shaping policy, a spokesman for Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday.

headline: A Little Folk, a Little Rock and a Lot of Minimalism
text: White Magic is an entity in flux. It began in 2004 as a trio, led by the singer and keyboardist Mira Billotte. Then it became a duo, with Ms. Billotte and the guitarist Doug Shaw. For now it’s a shambly, spooked quartet, not quite folk and not quite rock, and as such it played with the bassist Brad Truax and the drummer Jim White on Thursday night at the Mercury Lounge.

headline: The Vanishing Man of the Forest
text: ONCE again, I am driving, under the blazing equatorial sun, down an uncomfortable, rutty relic of a road into the interior of central Borneo. With me are two uniformed police men, one armed with a machine gun. The landscape is bleak, no trees, no shade as far as the eye can see. Our mission is to confiscate orangutan orphans whose mothers have been killed as a result of the sweeping forest clearance taking place throughout Borneo.

headline: Knicks Eager to Have Robinson Back in Mix
text: SEATTLE, Jan. 5  The last 24 hours of Nate Robinson’s league-mandated penance were packed with conflicting emotions  adulation and comfort mixed with sorrow and regret.

headline: What's on Monday Night
text: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO His first film role was a one-liner in “Mystic Pizza.” And that was about it, career-wise, for the next few years. But then he and his childhood friend Ben Affleck came up with a project called “Good Will Hunting,” and suddenly he was ascending the A-list, with an Oscar nomination for best actor and a win for best screenplay. Tonight, Mr. Damon, considered one of Hollywood’s most good-natured actors (have you ever seen the man frown?), talks about a career that has included Steven Speilberg’s “Saving Private Ryan,” Anthony Minghella’s “Talented Mr. Ripley” — not to mention Steven Soderbergh’s “Ocean’s Eleven,” “Twelve” and, soon, “Thirteen” — and his latest role, with Angelina Jolie, as the operative Edward Wilson in Robert De Niro’s “Good Shepherd.”

headline: Highly Paid Chief Is Paid $210 Million to Go Away
text: THE new year began with a series of surprises, not all of them pleasant.

headline: At Home Depot, the New Chief Needs to Sell an Old Story to Wall Street
text: Frank Blake, the new chief at Home Depot, has a challenge.

headline: China Media Battle Hints at Shift on Intellectual Property
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 3  One of China’s largest newspapers has filed a lawsuit against one of the country’s leading Internet portals claiming that it violated copyright laws, setting off a media war and highlighting the first signs of a possible shift in policies toward intellectual property rights here.

headline: Justices to Consider Impact of Mental Illness on Death Penalty
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to use the case of a schizophrenic death row inmate in Texas to set the standard for determining when a mental illness is so severe that execution would be constitutionally impermissible.

headline: Tanzanian Woman Is Chosen for U.N.’s 2nd Highest Post
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 5  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday appointed Asha-Rose Mtengeti-Migiro, the foreign minister of Tanzania, to be deputy secretary general and said he intended to give her responsibility for day-to-day management of the world organization.

headline: At Armenian Churches, a Distinct Observance Today
text: Today the Armenian Church, one of the most ancient branches of Christianity, celebrates the birth of Jesus. One wonders, admittedly a bit fancifully, if there is a lesson in the Armenian practice for the many Christians who desperately wish that the religious meaning of Jesus’ birth could be rescued from angry culture wars and commercial frenzy.

headline: Cowher Resigns; Stops Short of Retiring
text: In 15 years as the coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, Bill Cowher compiled a brilliant record: 161-99-1, 10 playoff seasons, 6 American Football Conference championship games, 2 Super Bowl appearances and, a year ago, a Super Bowl championship. His reign as the N.F.L. coach with the longest tenure ended yesterday, when he resigned, not unexpectedly, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family.

headline: Britain: New Restaurant on Radiation Trail
text: The authorities investigating the killing of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer who died in London in November of a high dose of the radioactive isotope polonium 210, said they had detected radiation contamination at a restaurant in the Mayfair district of London. The Health Protection Agency said the restaurant, Pescatori, had been closed, decontaminated and reopened for business. The authorities have found traces of radiation in several other restaurants and hotels visited by Mr. Litvinenko and his associates just before he fell ill. This week, a staff member at the Best Western Shaftesbury Hotel in central London reportedly tested positive for low levels of polonium 210, bringing to 12 the number of people said by the authorities to have been contaminated in Britain. The others are nine staff members at two other London hotels and Mr. Litvinenko’s widow, Marina.

headline: Copyrights and Congress
text: ADVOCATES for looser restrictions on copyrights had high hopes for the new Democratic Congress. Those hopes faded somewhat last month when Representative Howard L. Berman was named chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the Internet and intellectual property.

headline: Dow’s Dogs Still Having Their Day
text: EVERY dog has its day, but the Dogs of the Dow have had their day for seven years. During that span, the Dogs  the 10 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average with the highest dividend yields at the end of each year  have handily outperformed the index itself and other benchmarks of blue-chip stocks.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Religion Journal last Saturday, about the complexities of tithing, misstated the name of a company where Tom Norwood, a Presbyterian minister, advises churches on how to increase giving by their congregants. It is Capstone Advancement Partners, not Capstone Investment Partners.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Movie Dividends

headline: A Renegade’s Tale of His Scorn for Japan’s ‘Club of Old Men’
text: TOKYO

headline: DuPont Drops Plan for Nerve Gas Wastewater
text: TRENTON, Jan. 5 — Bringing an abrupt end to a three-year fight between environmentalists and federal officials, the DuPont Company announced on Friday that it would not participate in an Army plan to dispose of wastewater from neutralized VX nerve gas by dumping it into the Delaware River.

headline: In Upton Sinclair’s Spirit (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Either Victory Song After Title Game Will Please Steinbrenner
text: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ principal owner, has not had a World Series champion since 2000, but he will back a winner in Monday’s title game of the Bowl Championship Series between Ohio State and Florida.

headline: Tipping Over a Defense of Enron
text: Malcolm Gladwell is one smart cookie.

headline: X-Ray Vision Would Be Nice, but Sometimes a Nudge Will Do
text: Most bridge deals would cease to be interesting if everyone knew where all of the cards were located  what is called playing double-dummy. If declarer could peek into his opponents’ hands, he would almost always make his contract. But since he is not blessed with X-ray vision, sometimes the defenders can nudge declarer off the road to Rome and onto a dead end.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Dec. 15 about Queens International 2006, at the Queens Museum of Art, misspelled the given name and surname of the artist whose embroidered panels explore female sexuality, and a correction in this space on Wednesday repeated the misspelling of her surname. She is Blanka Amezkua, not Blanca Amezcua.

headline: China Currency Near Parity With Hong Kong’s Dollar
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 5 — For more than half a century, residents of Hong Kong have taken pride in being more prosperous than their cousins nearby in mainland China, and have enjoyed feeling like big spenders whenever they crossed the border.

headline: 6 Ohio Cities Rush to File Suits Against Makers of Lead Paint
text: CINCINNATI, Jan. 5  Racing against a proposed state law that would limit paint manufacturers’ liability for lead poisoning in aging neighborhoods, Cincinnati has joined five other Ohio cities in filing suits that seek millions of dollars from the companies to clean up lead paint.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: How I Spent My Summer Vacation: Now a Major Motionless Book
text: I COME from a family that has a somewhat odd relationship with technology. My father, for instance, refused to give up his manual typewriter when newfangled electric typewriters came onto the market. But now his computer system has more bells and whistles than mine.

headline: New Diet Drug Is Approved for Pudgy Dogs
text: Too many dogs are lounging around at home all day while their owners work, then stuffing on table scraps in front of the television at night, so much so that veterinarians say there is an epidemic of canine obesity in this country.

headline: Encouraging More Reality in Economics
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 — The annual meeting of the American Economic Association, which opened here on Friday, is usually a pretty esoteric affair.

headline: First-Baby Sweepstakes Fuels Immigration Debate
text: It seemed like a perfect formula for good publicity: A national sweepstakes would award a $25,000 United States savings bond to the first American baby born in 2007, courtesy of the toy chain Toys “R” Us and its Babies “R” Us division.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article and picture caption on Dec. 27 about David A. Paterson, the incoming lieutenant governor of New York, and his father, Basil A. Paterson, the Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor in 1970, referred incorrectly to the senior Mr. Paterson. He was the second black politician nominated for statewide office in New York, not the first. (Edward R. Dudley, nominated for attorney general at the Democratic State Convention in 1962, holds that distinction.)

headline: Who Is Best at R&D?
text: TODAY’S quiz: What do Apple, Caterpillar, Google, Kellogg and Toyota have in common?

headline: Ties to Communist Secret Police Snare Polish Bishop
text: PARIS, Jan. 5 — Warsaw’s new archbishop, Stanislaw W. Wielgus, caught in Eastern Europe’s widening witch hunt for former Communist secret police informers, admitted Friday that he had collaborated with the Sluzba Bezpieczenstwa, or Security Service, known as the S.B.

headline: For This Broadway Musical, the Casting Agents Are TV Viewers
text: In almost every way, “You’re the One That I Want,” the “American Idol”-like reality show in which viewers pick actors to play Sandy Dumbrowski and Danny Zuko in a Broadway production of “Grease,” was inevitable.

headline: Job Growth Is Strong, Surprising Economists
text: Job growth was brisk last month as businesses added to their payrolls with surprising confidence, further evidence that the economy is not likely to slip into a recession.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column last Saturday about criticism of officials at the J. Paul Getty Museum by the former antiquities curator referred imprecisely to the origin of two artifacts that the museum agreed to hand over to Greece last month. Although the Greek government contends they were looted from Greek soil, and the Getty says they should rightfully be returned, there has been no independent finding that the objects were illegally excavated.

headline: Safe as Milk?
text: The Food and Drug Administration’s assessment that food from cloned animals is safe to eat is a victory for biotech companies and a loss for everyone else. Like many decisions on the cutting edge of agricultural technology, it was hurried along in a way that is more sensitive to political and economic pressure than to the long-term welfare of animals, humans and the world they inhabit. Asking whether cloned meat and milk are safe is not even the right question. The right question is, why clone at all?

headline: Best Buy and Circuit City Report Brisk Sales for December
text: Best Buy and Circuit City Stores, the nation’s largest electronics retailers, reported December sales yesterday that exceeded analysts’ estimates.

headline: U.N. Expels 6 in Sex Case
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 5  Six United Nations peacekeeping soldiers have been sent home from duty in Sudan in recent months after they were investigated in connection with sexual crimes, officials here said Friday.

headline: San Francisco to Go Wireless
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 — After eight months of sometimes difficult negotiations, EarthLink and the city of San Francisco said on Friday that they had reached an agreement to create a citywide wireless broadband network.

headline: A New Commander, in Step With the White House on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — The selection of Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus to serve as the senior American commander in Iraq signals an important turn in United States strategy.

headline: With Mild Winter, the City Revisits Fall Fashion and the Record Books
text: The last recorded time the snowfall in Central Park came so late in the season, the date was Jan. 4, 1878.

headline: Grand-Scale Lawn Art Stirs a Debate in Connecticut
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 5  Talk about making waves.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the McCormick Tribune Foundation, a large shareholder in the Tribune Company, to hire the Blackstone Group as an adviser while the Tribune is up for sale, misstated the role of the company’s chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in the sales process. Mr. FitzSimons, who is also chairman of the foundation’s board, has recused himself from issues regarding the sale; he is not a member of the special committee dealing with the Blackstone Group. (Go to Article)

headline: City Ballet Brings Passion to Podium
text: As the house lights dimmed in the New York State Theater last Saturday night before Act II of George Balanchine’s “Nutcracker,” the conductor, Fayçal Karoui, turned around and presented a red rose to a woman in the first row. Mr. Karoui became the New York City Ballet’s music director on Dec. 1, and his tenure seems to have started with a flourish. Earlier he had given each female player in the orchestra a rose for the end of the “Nutcracker” season, and upon finding a spare flower on his podium, he appeared to see no point in letting a chance for a charming gesture go to waste.

headline: Making No Small Plans
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is fond of saying that you can’t change the world by whispering. What New Yorkers saw in his first week in office was a governor in full trumpet about how to overhaul their state government. While some veterans of state politics saw Mr. Spitzer’s State of the State speech on Wednesday as too ambitious, former Gov. Hugh Carey got it just right. “It’s a very big agenda,” he said, “but it’s not too big for New York.”

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the McCormick Tribune Foundation, a large shareholder in the Tribune Company, to hire the Blackstone Group as an adviser while the Tribune is up for sale, misstated the role of the company’s chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in the sales process. Mr. FitzSimons, who is also chairman of the foundation’s board, has recused himself from issues regarding the sale; he is not a member of the special committee dealing with the Blackstone Group.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture in Business Day on Thursday of the home of Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted as chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Chris Rank of Bloomberg News, not by Home Depot.

headline: With Mientkiewicz at First, Giambi Likely to Shift to D.H.
text: When Doug Mientkiewicz was a rookie, struggling to stick with the Minnesota Twins, Jason Giambi pulled him aside for a pep talk. Giambi was a star for the Oakland Athletics at the time, and Mientkiewicz did not know him. But the encouragement helped.

headline: City Backs Union Wages in Tax-Break Buildings
text: The Bloomberg administration said this week that it planned to require many developers who construct apartment buildings under a popular tax break to pay the superintendents and janitors the prevailing wage, essentially a union-level wage of $18 an hour and health benefits.

headline: Return Is Made Away From Crowds and Disease
text: For the most part, it was a typical day at Aqueduct, New York’s no-frills racetrack. It was gray and drizzly, the place was virtually empty and most of the horses on the card have not and never will do anything special. It was hardly the place where you would expect to find a Belmont Stakes winner returning to action.

headline: Abroad at Home
text: HOUSTON — Like many illegal immigrants, Javier Huete did not dare plan a trip home for the holidays for fear he would not be able to re-enter the United States. But he was able to see his mother, in-laws and cousins in Honduras anyway thanks to videoconferencing services provided at an Order Express storefront in Houston.

headline: Health Guidelines Suggested for Models
text: The fashion industry sells modish trapeze dresses and $800 platform ankle boots. But it also sells women an ideal of beauty embodied by the models who walk the runways and appear in fashion magazines.

headline: American Diplomat to Visit Strife-Torn Somali Capital
text: KISMAYO, Somalia, Jan. 5 — The State Department’s top diplomat for Africa plans to visit Mogadishu, the violence-scarred Somali capital, on Sunday, American officials said Friday. It would be the first time in more than a decade that a high-ranking United States official has set foot there.

headline: What Landed in New Jersey? It Came From Outer Space
text: It was not from the neighborhood.

headline: Bernard Meltzer, 92, Labor Expert and Nuremberg Prosecutor, Dies
text: Bernard D. Meltzer, a law professor who helped bring clarity to labor-management issues at a time of great change in the field, who was a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials and who helped draft the United Nations Charter, died Thursday at his home in Chicago. He was 92.

headline: Images of Hanging Make Hussein a Martyr to Many
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5 — In the week since Saddam Hussein was hanged in an execution steeped in sectarian overtones, his public image in the Arab world, formerly that of a convicted dictator, has undergone a resurgence of admiration and awe.

headline: Six Women, All Headed in Different Directions
text: “Fresh Tracks,” an annual series of new choreography, has been presented by Dance Theater Workshop since the organization’s creation in 1965, giving more than 400 artists — Bill T. Jones, David Parsons, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker among them — their first opportunity to try their craft onstage.

headline: Monkey on a Tiger
text: Washington

headline: The Canapé War (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Viacom Selects President for MTV International Unit
text: In a series of appointments expected to solidify the management at Viacom, the company named Robert M. Bakish as president of MTV Networks International.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Saturday about mourning for Gerald R. Ford in California misstated the year he moved there after leaving the White House. It was 1977, not 1976. A correction in this space on Wednesday misspelled the name of the city where the Fords' church was located. It is Palm Desert, not Palm Dessert.

headline: Just Days Into the Year, Killings Toll Hits 8 in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 — A surge in murders since the new year has residents on edge and has raised new fears that officials here remain helpless to contain a lethal combination of guns, drugs and jobless young men.

headline: White House Seeks Lawyer Wise to Ways of Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — President Bush is seeking a new chief lawyer with credentials as a proven combatant as he and his staff prepare for a potential raft of investigations from Democrats in Congress who have promised to challenge the White House’s conduct of policy and its assertions of executive power.

headline: Commuters Stranded After a Boy, 13, Is Killed on L.I.R.R. Tracks
text: A 13-year-old boy was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train in Queens at the height of yesterday evening’s rush, the police said. The accident shut down the railroad’s Main Line for nearly two hours and stranded thousands of commuters at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

headline: Katrina Victims Find a Solution: Modular House
text: PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss. — Of the hundreds of houses swept away by Hurricane Katrina in this small Gulf Coast town, only a fraction have been replaced. The price of building materials has skyrocketed, and the services of even mediocre contractors can be hard to come by.

headline: With Each Fallen Soldier, a Field of Flags Grows
text: MIDDLE GROVE, N.Y., Jan. 4  The flags are cut from rolls of yellow plastic tablecloth, then woven onto thin wire rods. Each is about as long as a man’s size 7 shoe, as wide as an outstretched hand.

headline: Giddy Sea of Fresh Faces in the Capitol, United by a Serious Mission
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  Hours after casting his first votes in Congress, Representative Zack Space still beamed with excitement on Thursday, showing off the identification card that doubles as an electronic balloting device.

headline: Canada: Liberal Lawmaker Defects
text: Prime Minister Stephen Harper lured a Liberal member of Parliament to his Conservative caucus, improving odds that his minority government will survive attempts by opposition parties to force an election. The lawmaker, Wajid Khan of Toronto, a former pilot in the Pakistani Air Force, said he had defected partly because he had to choose between staying a Liberal and continuing as a special adviser to Mr. Harper on South Asia and the Middle East. The Conservatives control 125 seats in the 308-seat House of Commons, and can now win votes with the support of any one of three opposition parties.

headline: A Former Leader Returns, Taking a Different Path
text: Can it be that absence actually does make the heart grow fonder? Or is it just that hearing Lorin Maazel’s micromanipulations of the standard canon so regularly has made almost any guest conductor at the New York Philharmonic sound refreshing?

headline: The Senate’s Task on Warming
text: Here are a few bulletins from planet Earth:

headline: Companies Pay Dearly for Tech Trade Show
text: For a small technology company called Digeo, the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is one of the biggest opportunities of the year. For the next few days, the city will be jampacked with potential customers, partners and press — but the price of participation is daunting.

headline: Editor’s E-Mail May Be Used in Suit Against The Times
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 5 — A lawyer for a former government scientist who is suing The New York Times for defamation over a series of columns about the deadly anthrax mailings of 2001 said Friday in court that he was prepared to introduce an internal e-mail message from a senior Times editor that raised questions about one of the columns.

headline: Hard Epilogue to ‘Freedom Writers’: A Violent Death
text: Hollywood endings aren’t always simple.

headline: Colorado, Still Recovering From 2 Storms, Is Hit With a 3rd
text: DENVER, Jan. 5 — Another winter storm bore down on snow-weary Colorado on Friday, complicating the recovery from back-to-back blizzards in December and raising fears that livestock losses would continue to mount.

headline: Coles’s Status Remains Mystery, but His Toughness Is Clear
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 5  The pass from Chad Pennington hit Laveranues Coles in stride as he was running across the middle of the Jets’ soggy practice field Friday. It looked like child’s play, and in some ways it was; for it was a route-running drill, the football equivalent of playing tic-tac-toe by yourself.

headline: Germany: Sentence Trial for 9/11 Friend
text: A Hamburg court began a hearing on whether to give a stiffer prison sentence to Mounir el-Motassadeq, the Moroccan who was a friend of the three 9/11 pilots. He was convicted in 2005 of belonging to a terrorist organization and sentenced to seven years in prison. But an appeals court ruled in November that he had been wrongly acquitted of direct involvement in the attacks. Now he may face 15 years in prison. A decision is expected next month.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article last Saturday about the Supreme Court Documentary History Project reversed the names of two of the project’s editors. Robert Frankel was standing at left and Stephen Tull in the middle, next to another editor, Natalie Wexler.

headline: Verizon to Announce Plan for TV Shows on Cellphones
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5  Verizon Wireless is expected to announce on Sunday that it will offer full-length programming to its cellular subscribers from several major television networks, according to people apprised of the deal.

headline: Camera Sees Officer Fishing for Restaurant’s Lobster, Authorities Say
text: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 5 — One night in October, a police officer in Madison, a small coastal Connecticut town, called in to dispatchers, telling them that he noticed a door to a restaurant had been left ajar. Not to worry, he said, he would check it out.

headline: Hey, Young Writers, That’s Mr. Rolling Stone to You
text: There must have been a time when Jann Wenner was scrappy and wild — the kind of guy who bet his career on Hunter S. Thompson and begged, borrowed and stole to create a San Francisco rocker magazine called Rolling Stone. That time was 1967, 40 years ago.

headline: China Moves to Tighten the Money Supply
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 5 — China’s central bank said late Friday that it had raised the reserve requirement ratio for banks, the fourth increase in six months, to further tighten the nation’s money supply.

headline: In Its American Debut, a Band Stays Close to Home
text: “We were offered a chugging competition last night, because we’re Scottish.” So said Kieren Webster, more or less. He was onstage at the Mercury Lounge with his band, the View, which made its American debut on Tuesday after generating an unreasonable amount of excitement in Britain. The room was full of guest-listed industry professionals, all trying their best to decipher his Scottish brogue. (Thus, “more or less.”)

headline: Retired Bull Rider Scouts Biggest Stars on Four Hooves
text: After a rough career in bull riding, maybe all a cowboy needs is some rest and relaxation. But after retiring from the circuit in 1996, Cody Lambert decided to devote his free time to making the sport tougher for riders.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Sunday about the Phillip family of Brooklyn, who received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misstated in some copies where the picture was taken. It was at the offices of New Alternatives for Children, a charity that helped the family — not at their apartment.

headline: Chirac Says Time Proves France Was Right to Resist War
text: PARIS, Jan. 5  In a scathing attack of the American-led war in Iraq, President Jacques Chirac said Friday that his predictions that the war would spread chaos and more terrorism had come true.

headline: Harry Falk, 66, Chief of New York Board of Trade, Dies
text: C. Harry Falk, the chief executive and president of the New York Board of Trade, died Wednesday. He was 66 and lived in Rockland County in New York.

headline: Britain: Cartoons Protester Convicted
text: A jury convicted a 27-year-old British Muslim, Umran Javed, of soliciting murder and inciting racial hatred after he spoke at a rally outside the Danish Embassy in London last February against the Danish cartoons about the Prophet Muhammad. Sentencing will be in April. Prosecutors said he appeared to lead protesters in chants of “Bomb, bomb Denmark. Bomb, bomb U.S.A.” Mr. Javed told the court that they were “just slogans, sound bites,” and that he regretted saying them. “I did not want to see Denmark and the U.S.A. being bombed,” he said.

headline: House Tightens Disclosure Rules for Pet Projects
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — The House voted on Friday to pull the shadowy tradition of Congressional earmarking into the daylight, requiring lawmakers to attach their names to the pet items they slip into spending or tax bills and certify that they have no financial interest in the provisions.

headline: A Single Mother Takes Charge, Trading Helplessness for Ambition
text: “Blood” is spray painted over the front door of the apartment building where Patricia Barnes’s family lives. It appears again and again on the walls of the stairwell leading to their second-floor apartment.

headline: Schwarzenegger Opens in a Sequel
text: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 5 — Nursing a broken leg but armed with an electoral mandate, Arnold Schwarzenegger was sworn in Friday to his second term as governor of California.

headline: Google Makes Another Investment in the Internet in China
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 5  Like almost all of the American Internet giants that have ventured this far, Google is losing in China. So too, are eBay, Yahoo and Amazon. But flush with cash, Google  the world’s leading search engine company  is beginning to invest heavily in research and development here. In its latest move, announced Friday, Google struck a deal to invest about $5 million in one of the country’s fastest-growing Internet start-ups, Xunlei.com, according to people close to the deal.

headline: City Takes Aim at Illegal Ads on Sidewalk Sheds
text: Since $2,500 fines against building owners have done little in the past to stop the proliferation of illegal advertising on sidewalk construction sheds in Manhattan, the Bloomberg administration is getting ready this month to battle the signs themselves.

headline: A. Richard Newton, 55, Electronic Design Pioneer, Is Dead
text: A. Richard Newton, a pioneer in electronic design technology who directly influenced the industry as well as being a mentor to countless engineering students, died on Tuesday in San Francisco. He was 55.

headline: A Giant Receives a Second Chance, Twice
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 5 — There was a palpable sense of calm in the Giants’ locker room during the week as the Giants prepared to play the Philadelphia Eagles, a reflection of the second chance that the team received by making the playoffs. And nobody knows the meaning of second chances better than Grey Ruegamer.

headline: Federal Funds May Now Pay Police Salaries in Terror Fight
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — New York City will be able for the first time to use federal grant dollars to pay basic salaries of police officers assigned to counterterrorism tasks, like guarding city bridges and subway tunnels, the secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff, said on Friday.

headline: Conservatism at Its Worst (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Day After Killings, a Hamas Leader Calls for a Truce
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 5 — The Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, called Friday for an end to the internal violence in the Gaza Strip, a day after members of his own Hamas militia surrounded the house of a Fatah commander, killed him and his bodyguards and seriously wounded his wife and brother.

headline: Scowcroft’s Strategy for the Middle East (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Saturday about memorials in Washington, D.C., that are dedicated to the history of other countries misstated the location of a statue to Tomas Masaryk, the first president of Czechoslovakia. It is at the intersection of 22nd Street, Massachusetts Avenue and Q Street — not in front of the World Bank on H Street.

headline: ‘The OC’: A Fast Start, a Faster Finish
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 — The end was in sight for “The OC” by at least last summer, according to Josh Schwartz, the wunderkind creator of the show that, with its glamorous locations, beautiful actors and hip soundtrack, defined new trends for music, fashion, celebrity and, of course, television.

headline: Mr. Ford Gets the Last Laugh
text: IN recent days, I’ve been bombarded by requests to comment on my relationship with President Gerald Ford. Until now, I’ve tried to say nothing — any remarks from me during the Ford family’s private time of grief would have been inappropriate.

headline: Ryan Clark Crocker, a Diplomat Used to Danger
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — When Ryan C. Crocker was trying to improve his Arabic in the late 1970s, he traveled to Jordan, made contact with a desert tribe and settled in for some hands-on training a little different from the standard State Department regimen.

headline: Nets Keep Composure and Pull Off Comeback
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 5  Jason Kidd hit a shot Friday night that had his teammate Hassan Adams running in place and screaming on the sideline like a child in a schoolyard. The shot left many in Continental Arena with ear-to-ear grins, wide-eyed looks and hanging jaws.

headline: Bridge Ad Deal Is Bargain for Geico, Some Experts Say
text: Did Geico, the giant auto insurer, get too good of a deal from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey?

headline: Goal Is to Look Good, Writer of Democratic Memoir Admits
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  Most memoirs  and virtually all memoirs by people in politics  are heavily varnished and blatantly self-serving. Say this for Terry McAuliffe, the former Democratic Party chairman and fund-raiser extraordinaire: at least he admits it right up front in his author’s note.

headline: A Meeting With Gerald Ford
text: In the summer of 1975, I was asked by Robert Goldman, President Ford’s in-house intellectual, to participate in a discussion on ethnicity at the White House, one of a series put on for the edification of the president.

headline: World View Podcast
text: SUMMARY: A transcript of Calvin Sims interviewing Times Latin America correspondent Marc Lacey about rap music in Cuba.

headline: Battlegrounds: An Op-Ed Series
text: The Op-Ed page asked writers from four key states — Minnesota, Ohio, Tennessee and Montana — to contribute occasional dispatches during the 2006 Senate campaign.

headline: The Kings of Clubland
text: Photographer Shannon Fagan focused on bouncers, those sentinels of New York nights.

headline: Herman and Huard Today
text: Playoff time! Join us for live game-tracking and commentary at 4:30 p.m. Eastern for Chiefs-Colts and then at 8 p.m. for Cowboys-Seahawks, and feel free to send along comments on any topic you wish.

headline: Bull Riding in the Big Apple
text: Cowboys from around the world gathered at Madison Square Garden for the Professional Bull Riders Versus Invitational.

headline: And the Nominees Should Be. . .
text: The ideal slate of Oscar candidates, as chosen by the three critics of The New York Times.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu: Jan. 7
text: With the advent of the 110th Congress, and the expected call for a troop surge in Iraq by President Bush mid-week, we resume offering you the lineup for the shows to watch, or to Tivo, as part of your weekend poli-nutrition.

headline: Who Will Bring the Internet to Your TV?
text: Get ready: we’re about to hear a confusing array of new plans to bring the boundless realm of the Internet to the 83-year-old TV. The companies involved are taking one of three markedly different approaches. So before we head into the geeks’ version of Super Bowl week, let’s do a quick and dirty review of the three kinds of contenders.

headline: In da Car at Dakar
text: No, I’m nowhere near the cars of the Dakar rally. But I will be following this as a fan. The race started today, and for the moment, it looks as if Volkswagen is ready to crush all competition after taking the top five spots of the first stage.

headline: Fun Facts
text: Journalists have to have these kind of silly facts about extremes at every county fair, 4-H exposition, Shriner convention, and NASA launch. Here they are for the Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: Tesla Chargers
text: Among the hundreds of pre-show announcements, this one made the hairs on the back of my neck stand up, as only standing too close to a sparking Tesla coil can do.

headline: FINAL: Chiefs 8 at Colts 23
text: Review the play-by-play commentary of the Kansas City-Indianapolis A.F.C. wild-card game, as it was typed in LIVE.

headline: The Macworld-C.E.S. Conflict
text: There is no way to escape it. Macworld is going to steal some of the thunder from C.E.S. this year. Usually, the Apple love fest in San Francisco doesn’t begin until C.E.S. in Las Vegas is winding down, but this year it begins Tuesday, the second official day of C.E.S.

headline: Game Over! Seahawks 21, Cowboys 20
text: Review the play-by-play commentary of the Cowboys-Seahawks N.F.C. wild-card game as it was typed in LIVE.

headline: Send in a Romo Headline
text: Here’s your chance to play editor. Send in headline suggestions for the Dallas-Seattle game (in the comment section below).

headline: Genetic Park
text: Though the moment may lack the inherent gravitas of Harriet Beecher Stowe’s encounter with Abraham Lincoln, or even Elvis Presley’s private audience with Richard Nixon, surely history should reserve a special place for the day in 2005 when Michael Crichton was invited to the White House to meet with George W. Bush. Imagine: the modern era’s leading purveyor of alarmist fiction, seated side by side with Michael Crichton. Oh, to be a concealed recording system in that Oval Office! Did Crichton confess to his host that he’d been inspired to write “Rising Sun” by a certain Poppy in chief with a propensity for puking on Japanese dignitaries? Did our president tell Crichton he found the dinosaurs of “Jurassic Park” every bit as frightening as our ancestors did at the dawn of time, 6,000 years ago?

headline: Common Sense, 34 Years Later
text: IF one of your New Year’s resolutions is to improve your personal finances, here’s a suggestion: Instead of picking up one of the scores of new works now flooding into bookstores, reread an old one: “A Random Walk Down Wall Street” (Norton, $29.95) which has just been updated.

headline: When Buying a Diamond Starts With a Mouse
text: Seattle

headline: Bipartisanship as the First Resort?
text: The House’s new Democratic majority is mounting a legislative blitzkrieg meant to leave the displaced Republicans gasping in the dust. In successive working days, the Democrats plan to enact legislation to bolster homeland security, raise the minimum wage, encourage embryonic stem cell research, require the government to bargain for lower Medicare drug prices, recoup lost royalties on offshore oil and gas leases, and lower interest rates on student loans.

headline: Love Child
text: War makes us weak! Wage peace! War sucks!

headline: 72-Degree Day Breaks Record in New York
text: Hundreds of tourists and locals packed the ice-skating rink at Rockefeller Center yesterday, pretending that it really was a cold, snowy day in early January as they circled the ice beneath the giant Christmas tree. In Brooklyn, eight members of a cold-water-braving organization known as the Coney Island Polar Bear Club walked toward the waves, some wearing nothing but swim trunks.

headline: Big Sur Without the Crowds
text: WHEN he moved there from France in 1940, Henry Miller, who had grown up in Brooklyn, called Big Sur his “first real home in America.” Running from Carmel, 150 miles south of San Francisco, to San Simeon, Big Sur's mass of tight mountains pushes brazenly against the Pacific swell. Kelp forests sway at the feet of rugged sea cliffs. Deep valleys shelter some of the southernmost redwoods. The only way through this fastness is along winding, breathtaking California Route 1.

headline: The Poncho Bearer
text: SAM wears a Mexican poncho to school every Friday.

headline: Christian Empire
text: Of course there are Christian fascists in America. How else to describe, say, the administrator of a faith-based drug treatment program who bound and beat a resident, then subjected her to 32 straight hours of recorded sermons? Or American Veterans in Domestic Defense, the uniform-clad cadres who took former Chief Justice Roy Moore’s Ten Commandments monument on tour after a judge banned it from the Montgomery, Ala., judicial building? (American Jews, the group’s founder explained, are “a driving force behind trying to take everything to do with Christianity out of our system.”) Whatever one’s definition of this most vexed of “f” words, in a time when the chief of staff for United States Senator Tom Coburn tells a reporter soon after the Terri Schiavo crisis, “I don’t want to impeach judges; I want to impale them,” to flinch from examining the authoritarian impulses coursing through American life becomes a moral abdication.

headline: Sports Briefing
text: college football

headline: Sock Away That Retirement Cash, and the Sooner the Better
text: FOR some investors, the new year offers a reminder to rebalance their portfolios. Others use this time to make tactical, short-term bets on certain stocks or commodities. But many investors often overlook the simplest step of all: increasing the amount of money they set aside in their 401(k) retirement plans, individual retirement accounts and other savings vehicles.

headline: From the Glare of Flashbulbs, a Serious Actor Steps Forward
text: WHILE the world was shouting Brangelina and Brad Pitt was dodging paparazzi, he also pulled off this unlikely feat: He was involved in two of the past year’s best films. In one he is a silent partner, a producer of Martin Scorsese’s “Departed.” For the other — his supporting role in Alejandro González Iñárritu’s wrenching political fable “Babel” — he has become the subject of Oscar chatter and a studio campaign. Plenty of Oscar promotions exist only to massage stars’ egos, but here is a campaign that actually makes sense.

headline: Gangsta Raj
text: This immense, demanding novel can be recommended, with scarcely a cavil, to well-educated Indians who have lots of free time, are fluent in (at the very least) English and Hindi, and have a thorough knowledge of South Asian politics; Hindu, Muslim and Sikh religious practices; and the stars and story lines of hundreds of Bollywood films. Longtime Bombay residents will have an extra advantage, since they will know, without consulting a gazeteer or Google, why the city is now called Mumbai. Prospective readers who don’t fit this profile will have some catching up to do.

headline: Common Application Supplements: Too Much Information?
text: TO ease the trauma of filling in the same blanks over and over, the Common Application — a four-page form that asks for basic information and a 250- to 500-word essay — was created. But even Common App colleges want to get their two cents in, so they make students fill out supplements.

headline: Venezuelan Parents Love a Famous Name
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: Offerings to Mother Ganga, Worries About Mother Nature
text: Dorothea Poggi marched past the muddy cricket fields and weathered picnic benches to a little stretch of beach in Ferry Point Park in the Bronx. She padded in sneakers on the damp sand littered with coconut shells, synthetic flowers and wet coils of golden yellow fabric. Plunging a hand between the reeds, she picked up a water-faded picture of a goddess with four arms and raven black hair.

headline: When the Choreographer Is Out of the Picture
text: LIKE so much else in American dance, it all began with Martha Graham. When the mother of modern dance died in 1991 at the age of 96, she bequeathed control of her work to her friend Ronald Protas. But in a bitter and very public legal battle, the Martha Graham Center claimed that it, and not Ms. Graham, owned the rights to her dances and that they were not hers to give away.

headline: Using the Victims Yet Again
text: For nearly five years, the Diocese of Bridgeport has been fighting to keep secret thousands of documents that detail how it handled 23 sex-abuse cases settled in 2001. Several newspapers, among them The Times, have gone to court repeatedly to argue that the documents involved should be public. Last month Judge Jon Alander of the Superior Court dismissed the diocese’s latest attempt to keep the cases sealed. The diocese announced it would appeal Judge Alander’s ruling on 19 different grounds.

headline: Deal Near on Transport of Bridge Sections
text: WORK on replacing the Roslyn Viaduct is expected to continue unabated now that the contractor and the Village of Roslyn Harbor are near agreement on how to transport large concrete beams to the construction site.

headline: Congressional Budget Delay Stymies Scientific Research
text: The failure of Congress to pass new budgets for the current fiscal year has produced a crisis in science financing that threatens to close major facilities, delay new projects and leave thousands of government scientists out of work, federal and private officials say.

headline: A Sizzling Six Months for Technology Shares
text: SOMEONE somewhere must have rung a bell last summer.

headline: The Incredibles
text: QUIZ yourself: One American history course gets at pre-Civil War tensions through primary source readings, including William Lloyd Garrison’s editorial from The Liberator in 1831 and Abraham Lincoln’s “House Divided” speech. A second American history course leans on primary sources, too. Students parse each Supreme Court justice’s opinion in the 1857 Dred Scott decision as well as texts of the first and second Lincoln-Douglas debates. Students must also demonstrate knowledge of historic maps.

headline: A Very Model of a Modern Meta-Musical
text: Los Angeles

headline: Democrats Step Up Criticism of Iraq Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — As the contours emerge of President Bush’s expected plan to increase troop levels in Iraq, Congressional Democrats, who now hold the power to restrain military spending for the war, sharpened their opposition today — and revealed their internal divisions.

headline: Mythic Pizza
text: WHEN Domino’s announced its Brooklyn Style Pizza, New York City had a predictable response. This newspaper ran a story comparing Domino’s mass-produced creation with the legendary coal-oven pies made by Totonno’s in Coney Island. Food blogs were filled with indignant commentary about what makes a real Brooklyn pizza.

headline: 30 Dead in Baghdad Clash; Bodies Found on Lampposts
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 6  A fierce clash left at least 30 people dead in central Baghdad late Saturday night as Iraqi Army forces fought with gunmen in an area where several residents had been killed and their bodies hanged from street lampposts, the Iraqi military said.

headline: Natalie's Triumph
text: FATHERHOOD is filled with moments of self-revelation, some magical (sitting in a sandbox, sharing my daughter’s fascination with a bright green shovel) and others depressing (hearing the sound of my own reprimanding voice). But no event in my life as a father better proved my transformation from a sane, balanced person into a deluded, ambitious parent than when, a year ago, my daughter, Natalie, had her first pre-nursery school interview. As the thousands of parents facing the same soul-churning experience this winter will discover, there’s a fine line between good parenting and aggressive pimping, especially in brownstone Brooklyn, where competition for those tiny seats is soaring.

headline: Bomb’s Lasting Toll: Lost Laughter and Broken Lives
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 6  If the cost of this war is measured in human lives, one block in southeast Baghdad has paid more than its share.

headline: Third Youth Is Arrested in Series of Queens Attacks
text: A third youth has been arrested in connection with a series of vicious crimes in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens that left one man dead and another in a coma, the police said yesterday.

headline: Links to Slavery and N.F.L. Star on a Hill in Texas
text: TOMLINSON HILL, Tex.  One hundred and fifty years ago, a white farmer named James K. Tomlinson rode through central Texas in a covered wagon and settled 15 acres of pasture land.

headline: Living With Fidel
text: Within the revolution, everything; outside the revolution, nothing,” has long been a favorite saying of Fidel Castro’s, the memorable, simple-sounding formula he has cited when he has felt the need to silence a critic, justify an apparently indefensible repressive measure or simply remind Cubans that his all-seeing eye is ever upon them. Jesús Díaz’s ambitious novel “The Initials of the Earth” was published in Cuba in 1987, which makes it by definition a within-the-revolution product. But that distinction was, it seems, hard won — the prize at the end of an arduous journey from nothingness to the sanctifying light of full, Fidel-approved being. In an essay appended to this first English-language edition, Ambrosio Fornet, a friend of the writer’s, tells us that Díaz wrote a version of the book in the late ’70s that was “condemned ... to the limbo of a tacit censure.” When the censure was lifted (presumably also tacitly) in the early ’80s, Díaz had, we are told, “the composure and professional sobriety to sit down and rewrite the novel from scratch.”

headline: Hidden Stories and Unsung Songs, All for $8
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Healthy Feast to Follow Sugar Fest
text: In December, what we lacked in snow we made up for in blizzards of sugar: fudge, sugar cookies, fruit cake and candy canes. The calories took their toll, so in the first days of January, while the children polished off the last of the bonbons, my husband and I dutifully turned to light, nutritious food. Last week, the venerable gourmet outlet Susan Lawrence in Chappaqua, caterer to the svelte and well-manicured for more than 30 years, had just what I wanted.

headline: Investors Start the New Year Indecisively
text: The year got off to an uneven start on Wall Street last week, with the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index both dropping modestly. But the Nasdaq composite index, in which technology stocks dominate, eked out a small gain.

headline: Along Broadway, Jettisoned Cornices Are Being Rebuilt
text: BROADWAY, as it snakes through the Upper West Side, is a laboratory revealing the shift in contemporary attitudes toward historic buildings over the decades. For most of its length it is unfettered by landmark regulation, and owners and architects can do as they wish with the slightly threadbare prewar apartment houses. As a result, many buildings scalped of their cornices in the mid-20th century have been recrowned in the last decade.

headline: Toy Trains and Real Pizza, Discovered by Chance
text: I HAD never paid much attention to Pizzaworks, at the Old Saybrook train station, until the night my daughter called to say that her train was running a few hours late. We were already at the station, so the restaurant there, its roof adorned with the funky “Pie and Suds” sign, emerged as an unexpected ally.

headline: Louisiana Star Scans Field, Looking for a Place to Run
text: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 6  As he signed autographs after Saturday’s United StatesArmy All-American Bowl for fans who handed him footballs, jerseys and yellow towels, running back Joe McKnight made sure that each signature he hastily scribbled bore a 1.

headline: This Steakhouse Has Aged as Well as, Well, Its Steaks
text: ABEL CONKLIN’S was reviewed in this newspaper 20 years ago; it was my first column, on Jan. 4, 1987. Both restaurant and reviewer have seen myriad changes in Long Island dining in the ensuing years; restaurants, like everything else, are subject to trends.

headline: ’08 Candidacy Could Shake Up Giuliani’s Firm
text: In the time since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani left office in 2001, he has told friends and political allies that he would consider running for the presidency in 2008, and that he wanted to use the interim to create a consulting business that would both burnish and broaden his image as a leader and security expert.

headline: An Election With No Losers
text: Franklin, Tenn.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: Amid Oodles of Ambience, a Menu With Vast Appeal
text: Diners looking for a big night out in Westchester now have Backals, an arriviste with good looks and city smarts that takes the place of the old Heathcote Tavern in Scarsdale. With its broadly appealing menu, Backals (pronounced ba-CALLS) is just as suitable for a little night out; it is one of the new hybrids that successfully blur the lines between special occasion and everyday dining. On a recent night, a couple held hands and nursed flutes of Champagne, while nearby a family of five ordered $20 burgers all around.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: FILM

headline: Acceptance Still Lags for Black Quarterbacks
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: Deals With River Views (Yes, There’s a Catch)
text: EXCEPT for the presence of Indian Point, with its two active nuclear reactors, the village of Buchanan might be just another expensive suburb perched above the Hudson River in northwestern Westchester.

headline: Genealogists Find New Roots
text: RELOCATING multiple tenants at once can be tricky enough. Moving them en masse to the same new home, one that suits all their tastes, is about as much fun as “corralling cats,” says Clinton W. Blume Jr., who has been saddled with finding new quarters for 15 small ancestry-themed clubs based in the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society’s building at 122 East 58th Street. The society, in search of better-configured space, is selling the building, between Park and Lexington Avenues, and Mr. Blume is coping as best he can.

headline: Japan’s Retooling Is Distinctly Japanese
text: WHAT’S up with Japan? China’s ascent has diverted attention from East Asia’s other formidable power. With an economy still the world’s second-largest ($4.7 trillion) after the United States, and one of the top three or four militaries, Japan is not to be taken lightly.

headline: Meals Cooked and Eaten
text: A cookbook is generally understood to be a collection of recipes amplified by short illustrative or explanatory narratives. Nora Ephron set the modern standard for the inverse with her 1983 novel “Heartburn,” a retelling of her marriage’s dissolution punctuated by instructions for dishes like butter-drenched bread pudding.

headline: Mr. Rock ’n’ Roll Goes to Congress
text: AT the peak of their popularity, the 1970s band Orleans was touring 10 months a year, performing their big hits “Still the One” and “Dance With Me.” But John Hall, the band’s guitarist, wasn’t content to stick to the bouncy tunes and lyrics about sweet romance. He also used the stage to lecture audiences about the dangers of plutonium production.

headline: In the Middle of Broadway, Sickness, and a Sturdy Legacy
text: IN the summer of 2005, Diana Biederman, a publicist with long black locks and an air of girlish candor, was nearing the end of a seven-month stretch of chemotherapy after surgery for colon cancer. Because of the side effects, she had to stay within sprinting distance of a bathroom at all times, which effectively left her a single place to relax: a bench on the mall of Broadway at 80th Street, across the street from her gym and a block from her apartment.

headline: Faces of War
text: The phrase “inspired by” — beloved of fusion restaurants, cover bands and biopics about suicidal poets and dyslexic linebackers — ought to strike caution, if not fear, in the hearts of readers. This is particularly true when it comes to historical fiction. In her 2000 novel, “The Fig Eater,” Jody Shields reimagined, to moderate acclaim, one of Freud’s famous patients, Dora, as the victim of a grisly murder. Now, with “The Crimson Portrait,” she has traded the gumshoes of turn-of-the-last-century Vienna for the less hospitable milieu of maxillofacial surgeons in World War I Britain.

headline: And a River, Such as It Is, Runs Through It
text: Upper Saddle River

headline: Where the Muffins Are a Must
text: Charisma is as difficult to define in a restaurant as it is in a person. While I sat at a tiny marble-topped table at Connecticut Muffin in New Canaan, nibbling my orange-cranberry muffin and sipping my Earl Grey tea, a steady stream of people stood in line at the counter for their takeout tea or coffee and assorted Danish, muffins and scones. Every table (four tiny ones, one large round one seating up to five) was taken, as were the brightly painted stools facing the counter.

headline: Tips for Protecting the Home Computer
text: Botnet programs and other malicious software largely take aim at PCs running the Microsoft Windows operating system, because Windows’ ubiquity makes it fertile ground for network-based attacks.

headline: The Factory Retooled
text: THE Warhol era’s 15 minutes continue at the 205 Club, a new Lower East Side spot done up in the style of the Factory. Like that hangout, the interior of 205 is silver, a mix of paint and aluminum foil.

headline: Yoga on the Rocks
text: STACEY BENDET, 28, the lively titan behind the five-year-old design label Alice + Olivia, stretched herself across a half-filled table of friends at Kobe Club, a new steakhouse in Midtown. Addressing everyone present, she asked, “Can we get the bowl of punch?”

headline: Caramoor Receives Grant for Latin Music Initiative
text: The Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah has received a $500,000 grant from the New York State Music Fund for a two-year initiative that will make Latin American music widely available through new commissions, family concerts and radio broadcasts of live recorded performances at Caramoor.

headline: Gerard Beekman and Michael Kaminsky
text: Gerard Jacques Beekman and Michael Sean Kaminsky celebrated their partnership yesterday at their apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Friends and family spoke about Mr. Beekman and Mr. Kaminsky and toasted them.

headline: Questions on Education
text: My son is a student at a Miami prep school for children with learning issues. His SAT scores, after much tutoring, averaged 900 on the verbal and math sections.
