He has a great grade point average — 3.6 (no Advanced Placement) — but is simply a terrible test-taker, even with untimed allowances. Do you have suggestions for resources that will help us choose a college that cares more about hard work and perseverance than SATs? He would like a school in a warm climate, and he is an excellent golfer, probably could play on a Division III team.

headline: New Nicknames, All to Replace Nutmegger
text: IT turns out that many Connecticut residents find Nutmegger as troubling as I do.

headline: Looking Down the Road That Leads Across the U.S.A.
text: Sooner or later the pickup will be packed and the dogs loaded. We’ll roll down the driveway and around the corner and onto the highway. With any luck it will still be early in the morning. The horses will be standing over a bale of hay, and the chickens and geese and ducks will be wondering why they weren’t let out of the poultry yard. The dogs, too, will have some questions, especially as the day of driving grows longer and longer and we don’t seem to be getting to the vet or the dog sitter’s house.

headline: The Week in New Jersey
text: Passaic Opens Center for Day Laborers

headline: Retronym
text: Ruminating in his Washington Post column about the potential political “firsts” in the 2008 campaign, Eugene Robinson noted that “we’ve come far enough to seriously consider electing the first U.S. president who can be described without using the adjectives ‘white’ and ‘male.’ Who has the better chance of breaking through, Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama?”

headline: Beauty and Beasts of England, in a World on Its Last Legs
text: POP mythology meets political allegory in “Children of Men,” one of the most vivid and plausible dystopian films ever made and among the most agonizingly beautiful. Agonizing because this is a film about the end of our world, a world that the film’s director, Alfonso Cuarón, insists — despite everything, despite the hate and hopelessness, the brandished guns and spewing smokestacks — is overwhelmingly beautiful. A world that is, as Mr. Cuarón’s visual style argues in image after lapidary image, worth saving.

headline: Linda Abrehu and Gregory Profeta
text: Linda Catherine Abrehu, a daughter of Luz Marina Abrehu and Julio Abrehu of Macungie, Pa., was married on Friday evening to Gregory Fred Profeta, the son of Donna Schirripa of West New York, N.J., and Allan Profeta of Cedarhurst, N.Y. Msgr. David L. Cassato performed the ceremony at St. Athanasius Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

headline: Correction: Megadeal: Inside a New York Real Estate Coup
text: A picture with an article last Sunday about the sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan by Metropolitan Life Insurance was published in error. It showed Frederic W. Ecker, who served as president and chief executive of MetLife beginning in 1953 — not his father, Frederick H. Ecker, who was chairman and chief executive when the developments were built in the 1940s.

headline: The Ultimate Distance Learning
text: Isaac Greenbaum, a continuing education student at New York University, remembers the day last semester when his media studies class was settling into a discussion of its next group project. Shortly after class began, a brawny, bare-chested figure bounded in wielding a crossbow.

headline: Unbalanced Schedule Leaves Many Unhappy
text: After only a year and a half with a new scheduling arrangement, the N.H.L. is considering another change.

headline: T. Rowe Sticks to Basics and Finds Success Again
text: WITH the retirement of George A. Roche, its chairman and president, at the end of 2006, the last of a generation of executives at T. Rowe Price Associates has stepped aside, making way for three new leaders.

headline: If You Misplace Co-op Documents
text: FOR home and condo owners, losing a deed is usually no big deal. But for co-op owners, the loss of a share certificate — and the proprietary lease that goes with it — will almost always cause a problem, and in some cases can get quite expensive when the time comes to sell or refinance the apartment.

headline: Ballot First-Timers Could Keep Repeaters Out of Hall of Fame
text: Conventional wisdom doesn’t have a vote, but it says that Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn will be elected to the Hall of Fame this week. History says that no one else will be.

headline: Classic Gets a Face-Lift, but No Nose Job
text: The Adventures of Pinocchio,” by Carlo Collodi, first appeared in installments in an Italian magazine and was published as a book in 1883. But like many children in 20th-century America, the artist Jim Dine was introduced to the character by Disney when he saw the animated film version in the early 1940s at the age of 6. Even though he’d seen plenty of movies before, “this one really got me,” he recalled, “particularly if you’re a little boy and a liar.”

headline: Polish Bishop Tied to Secret Police Resigns
text: WARSAW, Jan. 7 — The newly appointed archbishop of Warsaw, Stanislaw W. Wielgus, resigned today after admitting two days earlier that he had collaborated with Poland’s Communist-era secret police.

headline: A Tax Over Their Heads
text: Cornwall

headline: Leadership Tries to Restrain Fiefs in New Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — Less than 24 hours after taking over as speaker, Representative Nancy Pelosi summoned the new chairmen of five committees with responsibility for various aspects of Iraq policy to her office to review and coordinate plans for hearings and inquiries.

headline: Even Mangini and Belichick Can Adjust Only So Much
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 5 — On Wednesday morning, according to quarterback Tom Brady, Bill Belichick delivered a detailed synopsis of the Jets to his New England Patriots. It explored the strengths, weaknesses and tendencies of an opponent he knows intimately and yet in some ways is only beginning to acquaint himself with.

headline: Embracing Winter Instead of Fleeing It
text: BALMY waters, sandy beaches and relentless sun might be the most obvious features of a perfect winter getaway, but after a while it gets a little hackneyed to be just another slab of pale flesh nursing a midday daiquiri on the beach in Cancún. Instead, consider the more character-building charms of destinations that embrace the awesome power of winter: these aren't just cold versions of their summer selves — they're spots where the planet reveals some of its most impressive natural phenomena.

headline: Togas? They Are So Last Century
text: Partying can quickly become repetitive on a college campus — same old faces, same old places. But instead of staying home, students get creative. Here are some party themes that have caught on across the country.

headline: Bridging the Worlds of Commerce and the Arts
text: IN her 30 years as a jazz vocalist, Ellen Christi has received numerous grants from arts organizations to finance music and theater projects in the United States and Europe.

headline: Mexico’s New President Sends Thousands of Federal Officers to Fight Drug Cartels
text: TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 6 — President Felipe Calderón ran last summer on a promise to create jobs, but in his first five weeks as chief executive he has made it clear his first priority is to turn his government into the scourge of organized crime.

headline: Can They Block It Like Brodeur?
text: DESPITE the fact that pucks often ricochet off their heads, hockey goaltenders are widely considered the Einsteins of the ice. “Goalies are the most intelligent hockey players out there,” said Sonya Dibiase, a product manager at the Hockey Company, a Montreal-based division of Reebok International.

headline: The Penguins and People Look Great, but Are They Animation?
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Letters
text: What Should a Billionaire Give – and What Should You?

headline: In Days Before Hanging, a Push for Revenge and a Push Back From the U.S.
text: This article was reported by John F. Burns, James Glanz, Sabrina Tavernise and Marc Santora and written by Mr. Burns.

headline: Exile on Sesame Street
text: Depending on whether you’re a fan or not, Neal Pollack is either blessed or cursed with the gene for boundless self-promotion. So it’s no surprise that, having become a father, the writer of “The Neal Pollack Anthology of American Literature” and the rock novel “Never Mind the Pollacks” and the front man of the band the Neal Pollack Invasion has written a memoir about the experience. The surprise is that “Alternadad” isn’t entitled “What to Expect When You Are Expecting Neal Pollack’s Baby.”

headline: Two Urban Congregations to Form One New Suburban Church
text: THE Greek Orthodox churches St. Nicholas in Newark and SS. Constantine and Helen in nearby Orange have deep urban roots that go back decades, but in the coming months they will merge to create a single new church in suburban Roseland.

headline: Jazz Is Alive and Well. In the Classroom, Anyway.
text: IF you happen to stop by the Hilton New York or Sheraton New York during the latter half of this week, you’ll be about as close as possible to the global epicenter of jazz. That’s because both hotels are playing host to the 34th annual conference of the International Association for Jazz Education, which is expected to attract more than 8,000 registered attendees from 45 countries: students and teachers, promoters and producers, and musicians of every tier of accomplishment.

headline: Reaching for Help, a Mother Regains Dignity and a Stable Family Life
text: Most of her last six years, Patricia Ramos says, have been a torturous trip through poverty and degradation. But, she says, she and her two children are now on an upward path.

headline: A Bagel-Shaped Hole on an Unexpected Strip
text: GEOGRAPHICALLY speaking, West 72nd Street isn’t quite the center of the Upper West Side. But any street where a person can buy kosher barbecue, kosher pizza and kosher sushi, not to mention brisket, latkes and matzo ball soup, would seem to have its Jewish culinary bases well covered.

headline: A Father and a Father Figure Teach Meyer the Rewards of Tough Love
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., Jan. 6 — Dean Hood remembered making plans to hang out with Urban Meyer after a baseball game during their senior year of high school. Meyer had three hits and made a diving stop before making the last out in a loss. Hood recalled vividly that Meyer was the best player on the field that day, but not good enough for his father, Bud.

headline: Hide-Out
text: Garboesque sentiments are resurfacing from the past as a new generation adapts the 19th-century train engineer’s striped denim cap as the hat of the season. Pulled down low, they hide the wearer from unwanted eye contact on the street.

headline: Taking the Measure of Snowfalls, or, This Year, the Lack of Them
text: CORNWALL, N.Y.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,993 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: Colleen Saidman and Rodney Yee
text: IT’S as difficult to categorize Colleen Saidman, an owner of Yoga Shanti, a papaya-color studio in Sag Harbor, N.Y., as it is to hold a headstand for the duration of the Beatles song “Let It Be,” a challenge often presented in the classes she teaches.

headline: Getting the Balls Rolling
text: Getting the Balls Rolling

headline: Audi’s Show of Force
text: Introduced on Sunday: Audi Q7 V-12 TDI design study

headline: A Cultural Gulf That You Can Invest In
text: IN one election after another, American voters have shown that they are sharply divided along partisan lines. Now, Americans have a new way to demonstrate whether they lean red or blue: through their choice of a mutual fund.

headline: A Slice of Black History, With Language That Sings
text: AUGUST Wilson started out as a poet, and in some ways, that is all a theatergoer needs to know about his plays. Though they are rich in character and incident and freighted with the history of black America in the 20th century, it is the declamatory force and seductive rhythm of their poetry that slice through the protective armor we all bring with us to the theater. The audience says, “Show me”; Mr. Wilson responds with language that sings and shouts and aches, like that of the bluesmen and preachers whose cadences permeated the poor Pittsburgh neighborhood where Mr. Wilson grew up.

headline: Bomb Attack on Bus in Sri Lanka Kills 11
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 6  A powerful bomb blew up a passenger bus on Saturday, killing 11 people and wounding more than 40 others on the southern coast of Sri Lanka.

headline: A Franchise in Flux, a Quarterback at a Standstill
text: The question that will still not go away was asked for the first time this season on the eve of training camp, under a searing sun in Albany.

headline: Attack of the Zombie Computers Is Growing Threat
text: In their persistent quest to breach the Internet’s defenses, the bad guys are honing their weapons and increasing their firepower.

headline: Looks Like a Business; Should Be Taxed Like One
text: Now I’ve seen everything. Nick Saban walked away from the Miami Dolphins last week to be the coach at the University of Alabama.

headline: Natalie Brown, Michael Shirts
text: Natalie Elisabeth Brown, the daughter of Mary Anderson Brown and Dr. Paul N. Brown of Birmingham, Mich., was married yesterday in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., to Michael Randall Shirts, a son of Kathryn Hanson Shirts and Dr. Randall Brent Shirts of Provo, Utah. Keith Holden, a Mormon counselor, performed the ceremony at the Detroit Michigan Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

headline: Feeling at Home Among the Elite in Uruguay’s Punta del Este
text: PERCHED on a bar stool and sipping a $7 Negroni, I surveyed the casino of the Conrad Hotel in Punta del Este with keen but detached interest. The slot machines blinked and burbled like exotic birds, and at the blackjack and poker tables, neatly dressed men and women glanced at their cards with stony faces. A poster near the V.I.P. rooms advertised an Enrique Iglesias concert.

headline: Correction: Courtenay Seabring, Nathaniel Ebel
text: A report last Sunday about the Seabring-Ebel marriage misspelled the bride’s given name. She is Courtenay Cooper Seabring, not Courtney.

headline: Law’s Side Effect: Putting School Budgets on a Diet, Too
text: Trumbull, Conn.

headline: Plagiarism: Everybody Into the Pool
text: THE club of people accused of plagiarism gets ever larger. High-profile members include Stephen Ambrose, Doris Kearns Goodwin, Kaavya Viswanathan — of chick-lit notoriety — and now even Ian McEwan, whose best-selling novel “Atonement” has recently been discovered to harbor passages from a World War II memoir by Lucilla Andrews. Plagiarism is apparently so rife these days that it would be extremely satisfying to discover that “The Little Book of Plagiarism,” by Richard A. Posner, has itself been plagiarized.

headline: Incandescence, Yes. Fluorescence, We’ll See.
text: WHEN I found out last week that Wal-Mart, America’s biggest company, was putting a push on compact fluorescent light bulbs, hoping to make them a new lighting standard at home because they use 75 percent less energy, last 10 times longer and would save me $30 over the life of each bulb, I thought to myself, what’s not to like?

headline: After Pataki’s 12 Years, Is New York Better Off?; The Island’s Farmland Is Good for Our Health (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Doctor Killed by Ex-Owner of Yonkers Home, Police Say
text: The former owner of a Yonkers house where a doctor was found shot to death last week has been charged in the murder, the Yonkers police said yesterday. They also suggested that he may have had an accomplice.

headline: How to Speak a Book
text: Except for brief moments of duress, I haven’t touched a keyboard for years. No fingers were tortured in producing these words — or the last half a million words of my published fiction. By rough count, I’ve sent 10,000 e-mail messages without typing. My primary digital prosthetic doesn’t even have keys.

headline: The Invasion of the Alpha Male Democrat
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Building a Fashion Empire
text: BRANDUSA NIRO, dedicated follower of fashion and publishing mogul, knows a chicette when she sees one, and lately she sees them all over Westchester.

headline: Knowing Noreen
text: The public seating in Room 25 of the Circuit Criminal Court complex in Dublin is not designed for comfort. The half-dozen rows of benches are wooden and narrow, with barely enough room for your knees. I spent the better part of October trying not to fidget in those pews, sitting, as I was, just a few paces away from the defendant, who was under strict orders from her lawyer not to fidget at all.

headline: The Motor Stadt in Stuttgart, Germany (Psst! This Isn’t Michigan)
text: THE taxi driver, a middle-aged man from India, wasted no time as he barreled away from the Stuttgart airport, his scrappy Citroën whizzing past Audis, BMWs and an unusually high number of Mercedes-Benzes at over 140 kilometers (85 miles) an hour.

headline: Correction: A Former Studio, Still Chockablock With Art
text: The Habitats article last Sunday about the art-filled apartment on the Upper West Side of Violy McCausland and Frederico Sève misspelled the city in Colombia where McCausland was born. It is Barranquilla, not Baranquilla.

headline: Park Vistas, With Produce
text: LIVING near a fabulous farmers’ market that sells fresh produce has always seemed to me an idyllic situation, but not one that I have ever really been able to take advantage of in New York City.

headline: Storm Clouds Over Risky Loans
text: IN recent years, borrowers have flocked to riskier mortgages that gave them the means of keeping up with an overheated housing market. Now some advocacy groups say that as delinquencies and foreclosures mount, so too will lawsuits against lenders.

headline: Ann Leventhal and Jon Newman
text: Ann Z. Leventhal and Judge Jon O. Newman were married on Monday at their home in West Hartford, Conn. Cantor Pamela Siskin officiated.

headline: Capitalizing on a Town’s High Values
text: TWO major corporations have decided to cash out of Greenwich’s high-flying office market and relocate to less expensive settings, abandoning their headquarters in the town this year. Though the moves will open up nearly 300,000 square feet of office space, commercial brokers say the surge in availability will amount to not much, in a community increasingly dominated by companies willing to pay to be in a business district that has become nearly as exclusive as the lanes winding past back-country estates.

headline: Florida Is Sending a Recruiting Message (by BlackBerry)
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., Jan. 6 — Florida Coach Urban Meyer fancies himself an old-school coach, which he shows with his staunch devotion to Woody Hayes, Earle Bruce and Bo Schembechler.

headline: Stepping Aside, a Maverick Opens a Window
text: TRENTON

headline: To Cross the Bridge, Job No. 1 Is to Get on It
text: You can see them everywhere in the blocks near Cadman Plaza: lost tourists, brows furrowed over guidebooks, looking for that most elusive of landmarks, the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Democrats’ Drug Plan Has Pitfalls, Critics Say
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — Democrats want the government to negotiate lower drug prices for Medicare beneficiaries, but insist that the government should not decide which drugs are covered.

headline: Things Looking Up for Knicks and Coach
text: Isiah Thomas and Larry Brown will cross paths in a few days — if not literally, then at least by proxy, via their respective teams. Less than seven months after being fired as the Knicks’ coach, Brown was hired as an executive for the Philadelphia 76ers, who visit Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

headline: ‘A Mania for Hegel’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suspicions Lead to Detention of 3 Men at Port of Miami
text: Three men were detained today while trying to enter the Port of Miami in a semi-trailer truck without all the necessary paperwork, prompting authorities to take them into custody for questioning.

headline: First-and-10, Starting With Brunch
text: Minnesota’s in Long Beach, established in 1994, is the kind of place where everybody knows not only your name, but also which New York football team you pledge allegiance to.

text: New Plan Approved for Kings Park Property

headline: Letters: Neuroscience of Music; Performing Albums Live; Damian Woetzel
text: NEUROSCIENCE OF MUSIC What Can’t Be Measured

headline: Expressing Themselves Here, With Art From There
text: NOT every foreign-born local artist can count on Madonna for a career boost, but that is how it worked for Rashmi Jhaveri of Edison.

headline: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
text: FOR investors who have been missing out on the prolonged run-up in the shares of real estate investment trusts, or maybe jumped in only recently, the end may not be in sight: there are growing opportunities overseas. Some industry experts say that this is an opportune time to make a move into these nascent markets.

headline: Where’s the Party? In Emerging Markets
text: BOND investors seldom find themselves reveling in fancy, stocklike gains. But those who have been buying the debt of Brazil, Russia and other emerging-market countries have been having just such a celebration.

headline: Erica Piccininni, Andrew Brettler
text: Erica Piccininni, an actress, is to be married in Newark today to Andrew Brad Brettler, a lawyer. The Rev. Deborah Steen Ross, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Newark Club, a caterer, with Rabbi Roger Ross, her husband, taking part.

headline: The Scold
text: Dick Pound, chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency and global evangelist for the cause of pure sport, is not, technically, a law-enforcement man, but he thinks like one. He is part romantic, part hard-boiled realist. He hopes for the best from people but is not surprised when he doesn’t get it. He believes deeply in the grandeur of sport, less so in the goodness of athletes.

headline: Correction: A Quarter-Century of Threats and Bluster
text: A chart last week recalling various statements made by Saddam Hussein since 1980 misstated the year of a television address he gave to Iraqis after American air strikes began in the invasion of Iraq. It was March 24, 2003 — not 2005.

headline: Quiz Answers
text: RUSSELL A. STONE

headline: Low-Cost Options for Flights From Washington to Ho Chi Minh City
text: Can you give us information about low-cost flights to Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam? Where would a good jumping-off point be for travel around the region? — Lester Steinfeld, Washington

headline: Spanish Cuisine (From Scratch)
text: On the second Saturday of every month, the importer Olé Olé Foods in Belleville opens its warehouse doors to the public and puts its stock of spices, artisanal olive oils and vinegars, sweets and other goods from Spain on sale. What ensues is a food fiesta.

headline: Correction: The Glam, the Baroque and the Gritty
text: A pop music list on Dec. 24 of the best albums of 2006 omitted a songwriter. The songs on “Yellow House,” from Grizzly Bear, were written by Daniel Rossen as well as the group’s founder, Edward Droste.

headline: Big Investors Still Crave Commercial Real Estate
text: THE long-running rally in real estate funds gained strength in 2006, as the category led most others for the year. The surge caught off-guard even some seasoned money managers, who only a year ago were cautioning giddy investors not to expect a repeat of previous years’ stellar returns.

headline: Hotel Décor: Where Fires Are Cool
text: GUESTS might expect traditional tiki torches in Hawaii or bonfires in mountain resorts like the Park Hyatt Beaver Creek in Colorado, where families gather to hear a storyteller. But the hottest of fires are lighting up in unexpected places, like the rooftops of urban hotels.

headline: The Overlook
text: Chapter 14: Dumpster Diving

headline: Car Boom Puts Europe on Road to a Smoggy Future
text: DUBLIN — Rebecca and Emmet O’Connell swear that they are not car people and that they worry about global warming. Indeed, they looked miserable one recent evening as they drove home to suburban Lucan from central Dublin, a crawling 8.5-mile journey that took an hour.

headline: Pacific Theater
text: A peculiar characteristic of warfare after 1945 was that while navies became steadily more powerful and more expensive, naval battles — that is, combat between fleets of ships at sea — became almost extinct. Thus it is easy to understand the fascination of the Battle of Leyte Gulf, the last great naval confrontation of the 20th century, fought from Oct. 23 to 26, 1944, between the American and Japanese Navies in the waters off the Philippines. The scale of the battle was immense, involving four separate engagements extending over hundreds of miles, between fleets that included 35 large and small aircraft carriers, 21 battleships, 34 cruisers and hundreds of destroyers, along with submarines and motor torpedo boats and more than 1,700 aircraft.

headline: Breakfast Is Late, So Business Is Good
text: SHARON COPLAN HUROWITZ was on her second cappuccino and fifth air kiss by 10:30 a.m. She was standing, as she often does Friday mornings, at the long marble coffee counter at Sant Ambroeus on Madison Avenue near 77th Street, a traditional Milanese restaurant done up with pink shimmery mosaics and crystal chandeliers.

headline: A Red Warmer for Winter
text: Old-timers love to pass a January evening with a good book, an armchair, fresh walnuts and a warming glass or two of Fonseca Bin No. 27 nonvintage port.

headline: New York City:  Hotel 17
text: THE BASICS

headline: MoMA’s Off-the-Wall Cinema
text: DOUG AITKEN does not want you to sit back and enjoy the show. He tends to use multiple screens in his video installations to force you to move around. And he likes to project his films onto unlikely surfaces to snap you out of the usual cinematic reverie. In the past he has trapped characters inside a large wooden crate, flashed pairs of eyes on the facade of the Secession Building in Vienna and flooded the basement of the Serpentine Gallery in London with watery images.

headline: For Pierce, Muted Tone and Sharp Intensity
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 5  Antonio Pierce majored in communications at the University of Arizona. So when he spoke to reporters earlier this week about Sunday’s first-round game in Philadelphia, his words were most certainly chosen with care.

headline: Sleek They Are. But Will They Make the Cut?
text: Even at Atlantic Avenue and Court Street, a bustling corner of Brooklyn that is home to a freshly built luxury apartment building and a gleaming new Y.M.C.A., the structure on the southeast corner of the intersection is the shiniest thing in sight.

headline: As the Flattery Flies: A Buzzology Primer
text: JUST because most of us can’t vote for Academy Awards, that doesn’t mean we’re innocent bystanders. Oscar campaigns wash over ordinary moviegoers like a media deluge: talk-show hosts promote their favorites so relentlessly, you wonder if Al Roker invested money in “Dreamgirls”; magazine covers planned months ago blare “Oscar” for sure-fire losers; and performers abandon their wildly disparate screen roles to face a common acting challenge: trolling for awards while pretending, humbly, not to.

headline: A Poolside Idyll, an Unwelcome Visitor, an Explosion of Fear
text: ON a hot summer afternoon in an affluent Boston suburb, the town swimming pool is swarming with watchful mothers and their noisy young children at play. The pool is where Sarah Pierce (Kate Winslet), the mother of a little girl, Lucy (Sadie Goldstein), and Brad Adamson (Patrick Wilson), a stay-at-home father, whose son, Aaron (Ty Simpkins), is Lucy’s age, have chosen to carry on a discreet flirtation under the guise of neighborly parenting in Todd Field’s “Little Children.”

headline: Deep in the Heart of Tennessee Williams
text: AT a recent rehearsal of Tennessee Williams’s “Summer and Smoke,” Kevin Anderson wore a suit.

headline: A Sun Tzu of Oscar Warfare Resurfaces
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Recipe Redux: 1959: Stuffed Pork Chops
text: Thrift is often the best catalyst for culinary invention. Penny-pinching dishes like panzanella, poule au pot and beef ragù were all responses of wily cooks to hard times. Likewise, the recipe for these pork chops with rye-bread stuffing, which The Times published in 1959, was billed as a dinner on the cheap. Pork chops are an inexpensive cut of meat, and bread stuffing was used, as it has been for hundreds of years, to stretch the portions.

headline: Shipyard Worker Killed by Falling Metal Plate
text: Christopher G. Thomas hardly ever worked on Saturdays. It was his day to shop, do laundry and, most important, languidly pass the hours with his wife.

headline: Lessons for Homesick Evacuees on How to Be Houstonian
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 6 — Hurricane Katrina evacuees take note: You’re not in New Orleans anymore.

headline: Kate Winslet Vanishes Into Her Roles
text: SARAH PIERCE, the central figure in “Little Children,” is a mess. It goes beyond her uncombed hair, baggy overalls and rat’s-nest purse. She’s a smart woman who has somehow ended up in a dumb life that doesn’t feel like it belongs to her. In this she seems very different from the famously grounded Kate Winslet, who plays her in the Todd Field film of Tom Perrotta’s story of suburbia and its discontents.

headline: Violence in Somalia Over Disarmament
text: KISMAYO, Somalia, Jan. 6  Hundreds of Somalis stormed Saturday into the streets of Mogadishu, Somalia’s already unsteady capital, to hurl rocks at Ethiopian troops allied with the government and to protest a disarmament program that Somali leaders ended up scrapping.

headline: Up Front
text: Rick Perlstein, who reviews Chris Hedges’ book “American Fascists: The Christian Right and the War on America,” is not a man of the right, but a dozen years ago he became interested in writing about conservatism. “The 1994 off-year election — the one dominated by Newt Gingrich’s conservative revolutionaries — awakened a burning fascination in me,” Perlstein said in an e-mail message. “How was it that so many of my fellow citizens were taking things for granted that were absolutely the opposite of what I then took for granted? It’s part of the fascination of belonging to such a big, complex country like America: we’re all surrounded by people who are utterly exotic to us, and us to them.”

headline: Behind the Berlin Wall, Listening to Life
text: BERLIN

headline: Stateless
text: Perhaps Rashid Khalidi would have done better calling his book “Cry, the Beloved Country That Never May Be.” That title would have conveyed how glum he is about the likelihood of the Palestinians ever getting their own state. By some calculations, he says, they are worse off than they have been in decades.

headline: Breakfast of Champions
text: Minneapolis

headline: Grand Plans for a Pier, From Fish to Fountain
text: A stiff wind was blowing over Canarsie Pier the other day, and the wide parking lot, wedged between the Belt Parkway and the waterfront of southern Brooklyn, was empty except for a few cars and a cloud of seagulls swooping back and forth. Sitting in one of those cars, a blue station wagon with the window rolled down even in runny-nose weather, was Luis Irizarry, 60, retired from a job as a peace officer at the Aqueduct and Belmont horse racing tracks.

headline: Correction: Brick Houses, Winding Paths and Unexpected Sharp Elbows
text: An article last Sunday about a campaign to designate Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, as a historic district misstated the academic affiliation of Jeffrey Kroessler, an area resident and a founder of the Queensborough Preservation League. He is an associate professor in the library at John Jay College of Criminal Justice — not a professor of urban history.

headline: Chile Copper Windfall Forces Hard Choices on Spending
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  President Michelle Bachelet is learning the hard way that it really is possible to have too much of a good thing. Record prices for copper, Chile’s main export, have given her government a multibillion-dollar windfall but have also produced unexpected economic side effects and set off a sharp political debate about how to use the money.

headline: How to End Long Island’s Sour Vintages
text: THE decision by the Leucadia Corporation to forgo planting vines on the two Long Island vineyards it purchased in 2005 is only the latest news to give pause to supporters of Long Island wine.

headline: Feminist Artworks With an Edge
text: The Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London is not known for displaying feisty contemporary art, which is what makes “femme brut(e), its big fall show of artworks by women, so surprising. Given that this sort of thing is so rarely on display at the museum, it was even more surprising to discover that some of the art comes from the museum’s own collection. This is a terrific show, perhaps one of the best to be staged at the museum in some time.

headline: Running Dry on the M.T.A.
text: The Long Island Rail Road concourse at Pennsylvania Station has at least a dozen places where a commuter can get liquored up for the ride home. Two are saloons, one is a wine shop, and the rest are simple ice-filled plastic bins next to the magazine racks and popcorn machines. The bins overflow with cans, bottles and, for the powerhouse drinker, 24-ounce aluminum hogsheads. A $10 bill will buy you so many supersize Budweisers that the clerk has to double the plastic shopping bag, leaving just enough change for popcorn.

headline: With Geno Auriemma
text: Geno Auriemma, in his 22nd season as coach of the University of Connecticut women’s basketball team, recorded his 600th victory last week. The Huskies, who have won five national championships on his watch, won their first 12 games this season. He has been inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame and the Women’s Basketball Hall of Fame. FRANK LITSKY

headline: New Jersey’s Millstone
text: For New Jersey’s policy makers, the key to success in 2007 hangs on two words: property taxes. If the Democratic-controlled Legislature and Gov. Jon Corzine can reduce and stabilize property taxes for the foreseeable future, they will be hailed for an achievement that has eluded Trenton for years. If they do not, they will create even more dissatisfaction and cynicism from New Jerseyans long fed up with high taxes and official corruption.

text: CONAN O’BRIEN

text: ONCE in a great while, an honest-to-goodness visionary shows up — someone who sees things in an utterly different way and helps to change our perspective as well.

headline: Stage Mother
text: The theater group at my mother’s seniors’ community typically does a lot of editing — removing expletives and cutting scenes so plays don’t run too long. If they didn’t, they could not do the plays at all. But what’s worse, my mother recently changed a line in a play she is directing, Neil Simon’s “California Suite,” to improve it. Isn’t she wrong to do these things? LANE GALLOWAY, SEATTLE

headline: Editors' Choice
text: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

headline: School Spirit: Rah, Rah, Rah (It’s Protected)
text: THERE’S something about school colors — that signature combination of greens, oranges, blues not to be found in nature — that makes an alumnus tingle. Universities earn millions marketing school spirit, and they have become more vigilant, and litigious, about protecting what inspires it. That includes what is known in legal circles as “trade dress,” the distinctive combination of colors, abstract symbols and significant numbers — founding years or even well-known win-loss records — affiliated with a brand.

headline: In Special Election, Another Hurdle for G.O.P.
text: WHEN Republican leaders meeting in Albany on Nov. 30 named Joseph N. Mondello their state chairman on the heels of an election in which Republicans took a historic drubbing, Mr. Mondello, in a flash of candor, said he was taking over a party that had hit rock bottom.

headline: Online: Bed Bouncers and Pool Leapers
text: Hotel Web site photographs don’t always reveal the whole picture. A wide-angle lens can make a small room look king-size and a pool look palatial. Enter HotelsByCity.net, a hotel reservation site, which started a “Hotel Blog” section in November filled with candid photos and videos on everything from beds to bathrooms.

headline: A Fake Bird Dispatched, and ‘O’ Fills the Void
text: IN Ossining, it’s good riddance Riverhawk, hello “O” as the high school tries again to settle on a nickname.

headline: A Slim Guidebook for Executing a Deposed Ruler
text: THE Ceausescus of Romania were dragged to their executions on Christmas Day 1989 with Nicolae singing “The Internationale” and Elena alternately directing her captors to hell and snapping at them, “I was like a mother to you.”

headline: Editors’ Note
text: An article in The Times Magazine on April 9 reported on the effects of laws that make all abortions illegal in El Salvador. One case the article described was that of Carmen Climaco, who is serving a 30-year prison sentence in El Salvador.

headline: Postcards From the Edge
text: Most parents try to shield their young children from harm, an elastic concept that covers not just imminent threats but painful knowledge. Yet even the most protective parent must one day reveal the hard truth that life ends. For Patty Dann, a writer whose books include the novel “Mermaids,” that wrenching task came sooner than any mother would wish.

headline: A Father’s Grief, a Father's Rage
text: ONE day this winter, on a pilgrimage that will be either blessedly cathartic or unbearably painful, a retired telecommunications worker and graphic artist named Dom Caruso will make his first visit to two gravesites at St. John’s Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens.

headline: Those Two ’80s Heroines, Tough as Toenails
text: ABOUT the time Cagney and Lacey were having their groundbreaking heart-to-heart talks in the ladies’ room of the precinct house, another pair of New York women were also meeting on the sly to kvetch: in the laundry room of a Greenwich Village brownstone.

headline: Season Slips Through Cowboys’ Fingers
text: SEATTLE, Jan. 6  Before he became a starting quarterback, a national celebrity and a tabloid regular, Tony Romo was the holder for field goals.

headline: Shaping Our Childhood Memories
text: THE ways we think we are affecting our children as parents and the actual impact we have are two different matters. Already I see evidence of this with my four. My richest memories of their childhood and their richest memories are not the same memories. They’ll say, “Remember that time, Dad...” and I don’t, even though I was there, and I’m in the story.

headline: In Reversal, Toys “R” Us Gives 3 Baby Prizes
text: Toys “R” Us yesterday reversed its decision and awarded a $25,000 savings bond to a baby born on New Year’s Day to parents who are not legal United States residents.

headline: So Many Millions, So Little Body Armor
text: THE current state of corporate ethics, and the governmental and public policy response to that state, are so bewildering, so upsetting, so impossible to understand except in terms of the famous phrase, “Follow the money,” that it makes my poor old head spin.

headline: Jumbo Bonuses: Dial Your Envy Down a Notch
text: It’s time to put the record Wall Street bonuses you’ve heard about in perspective. Yes, a few investment stars did reap tens of millions, topped by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who received $53.4 million.

headline: Correction: The Changing Face of the Suburbs
text: An earlier version of a chart with an article last Sunday about the changing demographics of the suburbs contained incorrect percentages for levels of education reported by the census in 2000 and 2005. In 2000, the proportion of the population over 25 with some college was 22.6 percent, not 28.1 percent. In 2005, the proportions in all groups were slightly higher than those reported: The proportion with less than a high school degree was 15.8 percent; the proportion with a high school degree was 27.7 percent; with some college, 23.7 percent; with a college degree, 19.3 percent; with a master’s degree, 9.1 percent; with a professional degree, 4.3 percent. The corrected chart can be viewed here.

headline: Daniela Nied and Stephen Somary
text: Daniela Desirée Nied and Stephen Johannes Somary were married on Monday evening at Blessed Sacrament Church in Manhattan by Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor. The Rev. Bernard McMahon took part in the ceremony.

headline: Kathryn Berger, Michael Herrington
text: Kathryn Lisa Berger and Michael Kelly Herrington were married yesterday by the Rev. Lynn E. Bourbeau, an interfaith minister, at the Castle on the Hudson, a hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: PIGEONS: The Fascinating Saga of the World’s Most Revered and Reviled Bird. By Andrew D. Blechman. (Grove, $24.) Consider the pigeon. Rather not? Well, reconsider, and do yourself a favor by reading Blechman’s charming book. For once, a subtitle that doesn’t exaggerate! For many of us, pigeons are just nuisances who foul the ground with their copious droppings. Yet the pigeon also inspires cults of rabid admirers who race them, breed them and show them off in pageants as bizarre as any snooty dog show. Blechman wittily traces the history of this gentle, intelligent, misunderstood bird — pigeon hatred, he shows, is a recent phenomenon — and journeys into its obsessive subcultures. He hangs out on Brooklyn rooftops with a die-hard who breeds “homers” (as racing pigeons are known) as if they were thoroughbreds, prepping them for a West Virginia-to-New York race called the Main Event. Then there is the world of dandified show breeds: Jacobins, among the oldest and most stylish, sport “a regal-looking mane of soft feathers, like Greta Garbo snuggled in a fur coat.” Blechman gives equal time to the haters, from avian exterminators to a pigeon-shooting club in Pennsylvania. Along the way, he offers plenty of revelations about pigeon habits. In fact, they’re rather tidy birds — it’s we pesky humans who make the urban poop problem worse by feeding them white bread, as processed flour makes for “rock-hard droppings.” Even those in the business of killing pigeons don’t think they’re that bad: “They’re pacifists,” an exterminator concedes. “They don’t mean any harm. They just want to eat and hang out.”

headline: Poets, Playhouses and Artists Are Among Grant Winners
text: NO one decides to become a poet for the paycheck. So when Steven Gehrke learned about a month ago that he had won a $20,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, he knew his bills would be paid next summer while he worked on his fourth collection of poems.

headline: Impressed by Threepeats? How About a 23-Peat?
text: WHEN Lisa Lally was in high school in Connecticut in the 1970s, she conducted fund-raisers for a service club called the Leaders. Once, the club sponsored an all-comers badminton tournament, and a woman — “tiny, but fierce-looking, with a big smile” — came along and entered, said Ms. Lally, now the athletic director at Miller Place High School in eastern Long Island.

headline: A House Museum That’s Part Serious and Part Sendup
text: YOU may think of your home as a work of art, but you might reconsider after seeing Filip Noterdaeme’s two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn Heights. Mr. Noterdaeme has transformed every inch of his fifth-floor walk-up into the Homeless Museum, Brooklyn, a conceptual art installation known as HoMu BKLYN.

headline: It’s Not the Manager. It’s the Liquidity.
text: MUTUAL fund managers are unfairly blamed for poor performance of their funds. The track record of the average manager doesn’t lag that of a simple buy-and-hold strategy because the manager is an awful stock picker. Instead, the underperformance results from unprofitable transactions that are forced by the buy-and-sell decisions of shareholders.

headline: Outside the Hedge Funds, Looking In
text: IT’S time for wise investors to start listening to Marx. But put away your college copy of “Das Kapital” because I’m talking about the well-known social theorist Groucho Marx, the man who famously said he wouldn’t want to belong to any club that would have him as a member.

headline: Cost Cutting
text: The Reality

headline: Where the Grass Is Greener
text: BEFORE their relocation to New York from Boston, Christoffer Eriksson and Muge Tuncel Eriksson assumed they could find a home almost as nice as their two-bedroom condominium, which overlooked Bunker Hill.

headline: For a Shuttered Marina, Some Regret, Some Relief
text: MICHAEL STONE could have been speaking for much of Inwood on Tuesday evening. Mr. Stone, a bearded, grizzled man dressed in several thick layers of clothing, was scavenging in the debris outside the Dyckman Marina, a now-shuttered boat basin that also housed a popular Caribbean restaurant and concert space on the Hudson at the western end of Dyckman Street.

headline: How ‘Ugly Betty’ Changed on the Flight From Bogotá
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Design for Everyone, Disabled or Not
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: The Common Application: Typo.com
text: JOAN RYNEARSON, an education consultant in the state of Washington, got a call last fall from a student who had been tooling around commonap.org for an eternity — five minutes — and couldn’t find application directions or lists of colleges or even a log-in page. “It wasn’t the right site, and it was very misleading,” Ms. Rynearson complains.

headline: Paul Verhoeven Goes to War One More Time
text: THERE are directors who are prone to controversy. And then there is Paul Verhoeven, a connoisseur of sex and violence whose four-decade career has played out against a more or less continual backdrop of condemnations and protests.

headline: Wares in Search of Warehousing
text: THERE is a warehouse shortage in New Jersey these days, if you can believe it. Citing a critical need for more facilities around the Port of Newark, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has called for the reclamation of brownfield sites to permit building as many as possible, as quickly as it can be done.

headline: Singing a New Song
text: Q: Your voice sounds startlingly unchanged in “An Other Cup,” your first pop album of new songs in almost 30 years, during which time you abandoned a world-class music career as well as the name Cat Stevens in order to reinvent yourself as Yusuf Islam, a pious Muslim who dressed in flowing robes and refused to pick up a guitar for religious reasons.

headline: Study Abroad: Border Crossing
text: IN the global age, study abroad is becoming a more integrated part of the curriculum. Some American colleges are even requiring that students travel to another country for coursework.

headline: Surrender and Survival in the Crucible of Battle
text: THE obvious novelty of Clint Eastwood’s “Letters From Iwo Jima” is that this quintessentially — you might even say iconically — American filmmaker has made a World War II movie from the Japanese perspective. This does not mean, of course, that he is on the side of the enemy, but his camera is very much at the side of the Japanese soldiers, and in their midst. Hewing to the visual and narrative conventions of ground-level combat realism, Mr. Eastwood’s film is less concerned with why they fight — they fight for the doomed, dubious cause of Empire, sometimes in the face of their own disillusionment, skepticism or indifference — than with how they fight. Which is to say, for the most part, how they are defeated and how they die.

headline: Can Foreign Markets Beat the U.S. Again?
text: THE best place to invest in 2006 was just about anyplace but the United States. Of the 24 stock markets in developed countries tracked by Morgan Stanley Capital International, only two, Japan’s and New Zealand’s, failed to match the 15.8 percent total return of Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index.

headline: The Week in Connecticut
text: Medicaid Shortfall Hurts Hospitals, Report Finds

headline: Barcelona: bubo and bubo bar
text: “Tourists come in and want to know, ‘Is it a jewelry shop?' ” says Carles Mampel, the 39-year-old award-winning pastry chef behind bubo and bubo bar. His establishment is actually a one-two punch of haute chocolatier and new-wave tapas bar near the Basilica Santa Maria del Mar, deep in Barcelona's El Born neighborhood, but “people eat with their eyes,” he says.

headline: In a Crowded Field, Newcomer Holds Its Own
text: YOU wouldn’t think Montclair needed still another mid-to-high-priced, bring-your-own-wine restaurant. When Passionné opened last May, it joined Blu, CulinAriane, Epernay, Raymond’s and at least half a dozen others chasing the attention of this town’s well-heeled, well-informed, wine-toting dining-out crowd.

headline: Correction: Moderate? Conservative? With Gerald Ford, Take Your Pick
text: An article last week about different interpretations of the presidency of Gerald R. Ford from across the political spectrum misstated the frequency with which Congress overrode his vetoes. Mr. Ford used his veto power 66 times and his vetoes were overridden 12 times. His vetoes were not “usually overriden.”

headline: Correction: Can Google Come Out to Play?
text: An article last Sunday about the campuslike atmosphere at Google’s New York offices misstated the surnames of three employees. The sales-staff trainer who is considered one of the best-dressed people in the office is Jane Risien, not Risen. The sales team member who brings M&M’s for the staff is James Tipton, not Tipon. And the sales operations specialist who organized an art show for a Thank God It’s Almost Friday gathering is Laura Garnett, not Garrett.

headline: Hoyas’ Defense Smothers High-Powered Irish
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — The Georgetown junior forward Jeff Green stood in the bowels of the Verizon Center and clutched a white plastic bag that contained his postgame snack.

headline: More, Please
text: AT Carnegie Mellon, newly admitted students can play the financial aid version of “Let’s Make a Deal.”

headline: No Golden Ticket, but More Than Candy
text: THE workers at Chocolate Bar can tell instantly which of the two types of chocolate eaters they’re dealing with when a new customer enters their Greenwich Village shop.

headline: Other Voices: When the Facts Need More Checking
text: Re “Truth, Justice, Abortion and The Times Magazine” (Dec. 31):

headline: A Prince on Flute and a Count on Guitar
text: BENEDIKT SCHACK, the tenor who created the role of Prince Tamino in Mozart’s “Magic Flute” in 1791, actually played the flute. So in the opera, when Tamino tames the creatures of the forest and later leads his beloved Pamina through the trials by fire and water, Schack, by all reports, played Mozart’s magical flute melodies himself. Has any Tamino since both sung and played? No one I can think of.

headline: Fatah Holds Rally in Gaza to Display Strength
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 7 — The Fatah faction of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, held a large rally today in a Gaza City sport stadium, marking Fatah’s 42nd anniversary with a show of strength and defiance after days of bloody clashes with the rival Hamas movement.

headline: One Way to Play the Mergers Boom
text: MERGERS and acquisitions have been booming, and investors looking for a way to profit from them have a simple solution at hand: they can invest in mutual funds that specialize in buying shares of companies that are being acquired.

headline: Dancing With the Stars
text: In June 1948, as Jack Kerouac was recovering from another of the amphetamine-fueled joy rides immortalized in “On the Road,” Freeman Dyson, a young British physicist studying at Cornell, set off on a road trip of a different kind. Bound for Albuquerque with the loquacious Richard Feynman, the Neal Cassady of physics, at the wheel, the two scientists talked nonstop about the morality of nuclear weapons and, when they had exhausted that subject, how photons dance with electrons to produce the physical world. The hills and prairies that Dyson, still new to America, was admiring from the car window, the thunderstorm that stranded him and Feynman overnight in Oklahoma — all of nature’s manifestations would be understood on a deeper level once the bugs were worked out of an unproven idea called quantum electrodynamics, or QED.

headline: A Cool Gadget Here, an A-List Chieftain There
text: WITH the end of the holidays comes a fresh start and new resolve to lead a loftier, healthier, simpler life. Maybe it’s time to tend the garden, take up the harpsichord or read Proust. Then, before you know it, everyone in the media business hops on planes to Las Vegas and swarms the Consumer Electronics Show, which starts today.

headline: Home Remade Overnight? Red Chair Team Was Here
text: New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: The Week Ahead: Jan. 7 - 13
text: THEATER

headline: Thinking in Colors and Textures, Then Writing in Music
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Detroit Puts on a Show, and It’s Playing for Keeps
text: MORE than ever this year, the Detroit automakers are taking a page from those old Mickey Rooney-Judy Garland musicals: facing disaster, the plucky youngsters decorated the barn and put on a show to save the day.

headline: Correction: Art Prices Are Rising, and So Are the Risks
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about art insurance misstated the location of the New England Brokerage Corporation that employs Brian Frasca, an insurance broker who gave examples of coverage for artwork. It is in Greenwich, Conn. — not Providence, R.I., where a different company of the same name is located.

headline: Independent Bookstores: Cozy, Friendly, Full of Surprises
text: NEW YORK has always been known as a city capable of sating any desire: for money, for high fashion, for companionship. But if you're just a bespectacled out-of-towner who suffers from simple book lust, its eclectic collection of independent bookstores can scratch your itch, too.

headline: Capitalist Punishment
text: Before we had radio, telephones, television, the Internet and iPods, we had books. Long books. Complicated books. Books that got read, their length and complexity notwithstanding, because before talk shows and chat rooms, what else was there to do?

headline: Alexis Chiang and Thomas Colvin
text: Dr. Alexis Shih-Wen Chiang, a daughter of Ning Chiang and Dr. George C. Chiang of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Orlin Colvin, the son of Ava Maria Colvin and Judge John O. Colvin of Arlington, Va. The bridegroom’s father, who is the chief judge of the United States Tax Court, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel.

headline: As Stores Offer Their Winter Sales, Hotels Near Them Do, Too
text: The phrase “shop till you drop” takes on new meaning this month when hotels offer places to collapse in after an exhausting day of sales shopping.

headline: Unconsumption
text: Freecycle

headline: The Music Is Sweet, the Words Are True
text: I’LL tell you what makes a good song,” Julie Wilson said before she left for a rehearsal the other day. “Truth. It comes from the heart.”

headline: Kochi, Kerala’s Friendly Gateway, Is No Backwater
text: THE best seller “1,000 Places to See Before You Die” includes as one of its don't-miss destinations the “staggeringly beautiful” backwaters of India's Kerala state. The book also says a stopover in Kochi, the gateway to these interconnected lakes, lagoons and canals, is a must. But a quick visit is hardly enough.

headline: Jews, Arabs and Jimmy Carter
text: This is a strange little book about the Arab-Israeli conflict from a major public figure. It is premised on the notion that Americans too often get only one side of the story, one uncritically sympathetic to Israel, so someone with authority and knowledge needs to offer a fuller picture. Fine idea. The problem is that in this book Jimmy Carter does not do so. Instead, he simply offers a narrative that is largely unsympathetic to Israel. Israeli bad faith fills the pages. Hollow statements by Israel’s enemies are presented without comment. Broader regional developments go largely unexamined. In other words, whether or not Carter is right that most Americans have a distorted view of the conflict, his contribution is to offer a distortion of his own.

headline: Amid the A.T.M.’s, Art Blossoms
text: COMPARED with a free toaster, the Ingres oil of the Dauphin riding a white horse back to Paris after the quelling of a peasant revolt was an unusual enticement coming from a bank.

headline: In Defending Robeson, Respect Ol’ Blue Eyes; Let Adopted Children Find Their Sense of Self; Beach Access and Property Taxes (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Our Hero Leapt Onto the Tracks and We Might Not
text: MAYBE some people are more hard-wired for heroism than others. Like, for example, Wesley Autrey, the man behind a stunning rescue last week in a Manhattan subway station.

headline: The Lure of Living Above It All
text: IT is a fine feeling to step into the elevator of an apartment building, press the button marked “PH” and take a ride to the top — or at least near the top. And at a time when the wealthiest New Yorkers are getting even wealthier, there are more buildings in Manhattan with many more of these elevator buttons that bespeak the privileges of penthouse living.

headline: Rewards Are Great for Sports Specialists; After Pataki’s 12 Years, Is New York Better Off? (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Preteen: Betwixt and Bedeviled
text: THE debate over how to educate young adolescents is about as stubborn and mercurial as a 13-year-old.

headline: A Teacher After All
text: BOTH my parents were teachers, and they saw teaching as the noblest profession. They never thought their only daughter would end up running a business. And it took a long time before they were proud of me for doing so.

headline: Three Golden Trumpets, Countless Gleaming Dreams
text: ONE day late last month, inside a reading room in the library at Queens College, a young visitor from Sweden named Erik Akerberg was handed a gold-plated Selmer trumpet with a small ding in the bell.

headline: All the Technology Needed for 100 M.P.G. (Batteries Not Included)
text: WHEN General Motors unwraps the Chevrolet Volt for the press today at the North American International Auto Show, it will be revealing much more than the latest fantasy from its styling studios.

headline: Totals
The Timely Death of Gerald Ford
text: THE very strange and very long Gerald Ford funeral marathon was about many things, but Gerald Ford wasn’t always paramount among them.

headline: Lauren Cutson, Andrew Janian
text: Lauren Beth Cutson, a daughter of Linda Rothfarb Cutson and Gary A. Cutson of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Michael Janian, a son of Roberta S. Janian and Keith R. Janian of Danvers, Mass. Rabbi Randy C. Fleisher performed the ceremony in the Graham Chapel at Washington University in St. Louis, from which the bride and bridegroom graduated and where they met.

headline: Barring Owners From Meetings
text: Q My condominium does not allow residents to attend board meetings. I understand why a board would not want residents present when common-charge arrears are discussed, but our board says residents may not attend any board meetings at all.

headline: The Doctor Is In
text: AMONG a cast of hospital patients recounting their injuries and treatments on a DVD playing in the president’s office of the NewYork-Presbyterian Healthcare System, Eugene Stolowski, a former New York firefighter, stands out. Mr. Stolowski recalls leaping from a burning building in the Bronx and plunging about 50 feet before he slammed into the ground. His voice trembling, he praises a team of NewYork-Presbyterian surgeons for sparing him from paralysis, even death, by reattaching his spinal column to his neck in early 2005.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.

headline: Once Jeered, Headbands Now Scoring Style Points
text: Cliff Robinson first started wearing a headband during basketball games nearly two decades ago, before it was a fashion statement. Robinson, now a 40-year-old power forward with the Nets, simply wanted to keep the sweat out of his eyes.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: Road Scholar is offering a new educational tour through Rwanda, a country both celebrated for its gorillas and shunned for its 1994 genocide. The 10-day trip, “Rwanda: Tracking the Mountain Gorilla,” will take small groups on hikes through the Virunga volcanoes to observe the gorillas (below). Other excursions include Akagera National Park and the Gisozi Genocide Memorial. The trip fee starts at $6,087 a person (www.roadscholar.org). ... Sandals Grande Antigua Resort and Spa is set to open its Mediterranean Village next month. The $70 million addition to the 19-acre resort complex in Antigua will have 180 ocean-view suites, a pool, four restaurants and 3,200 square feet of shopping space. Rates start at $675 a person per night (www.sandals.com). ... MTV has published three guides for young travelers. The guides — MTV Ireland, MTV Italy and MTV Europe — were written by 13 college-age travelers who will also be responsible for writing future guides on Spain, the United States, France and England. MTV podcasts are also available on www.frommers.com/podcast.

headline: Flighty Beethoven, Liberated Monteverdi and Brotherly Bach
text: BEETHOVEN: PIANO SONATAS NOS. 8, 19, 29 François-Frédéric Guy, pianist. Naïve V5023; CD.

text: North Babylon

text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Our Hometowns Pay for Charter Schools; The Ferry Alternative to New York City (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cinema Verbatim: Words on the Page
text: VOLVER

headline: Parker Is Highlight in Tennessee Victory
text: HARTFORD, Jan 6 — The clock was winding down and Tennessee looked as if it would win, but Candace Parker just wanted to make sure.

headline: In a Divided Israel, Angry Words or No Words at All
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 6 — Two of Israel’s most important relationships in the world are with the United States and Egypt. In the past 10 days, the Israeli government of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert has managed to embarrass both of them.

headline: Black Tie Optional
text: IN the unforgiving fluorescent light of Rosenfeld Hall, a dormitory on the periphery of Yale’s campus, students crouched in a hallway and quickly stuffed their clothes into plastic grocery bags. Shirts were left inside out, socks balled in pant legs. Giggling, they hurried into a basement storage room, where some 40 people stood around, under stone arches and gargoyles, wearing nothing but shoes.

headline: The Roads ... Not Taken
text: I am driving down a dirt road in the woods to a friend’s house. He didn’t say how many miles away his house was. He did say it was beautiful there, on the lake, so I suggested to E. that she come along, and she is sitting next to me, chatting. The car jerks and bucks on the rut-filled path. There aren’t any houses in view. I start looking for mailboxes and don’t see any. I can’t see any driveways leading to concealed houses either. It would appear that the road is quite isolated.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Backs Charges of Killing by Marines in Iraq
text: An American government report on the killing of 24 Iraqis, including several women and children, by marines in the village of Haditha in 2005 provides new details of how the shootings unfolded and supports allegations by prosecutors that a few marines illegally killed civilians, government officials said yesterday.

headline: Justice for the Poor
text: In our legal system, justice costs money, which means lots of poor people have to get along without it. Government has a critical obligation to provide adequate civil legal services for the poor, who would otherwise lack access to lawyers to resolve problems that could easily upend already tenuous lives, in areas like spousal and elderly abuse, child support, housing and disability issues.

headline: Rome, the Sequel
text: When a young millennium’s fancy turns to Empire, the fancy head for Rome. Thus I found myself one morning last October bumping along the old Appian Way on my way to Cinecittà, the Italian movie studio. An HBO production unit, installed for the past two years at Federico Fellini’s old dream factory, was filming the concluding episodes in the second (and final) season of “Rome,” a series on the history of the Roman Republic in the years before the imperial idea took hold. Who could pass up the chance to witness the last days of “Rome”?

headline: Debra Salz, David Finkelstein
text: Debra Faith Salz was married last evening to Dr. David Joel Finkelstein at the Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J. Cantor Anna Berman officiated.

headline: Setting the Bar on Earnings
text: THE flow of earnings reports will pick up this week, but the earnings themselves are expected to show a dip in growth from past quarters. Any impact on share prices may depend on investors’ expectations about those expectations.

headline: A Phantom Rebound in the Housing Market
text: HOUSING bulls took heart on Dec. 27, when the Commerce Department reported that sales of new one-family homes rose 3.4 percent in November from October. While the figure was still well below the rate of November 2005, it represented a recovery from the sharp declines of the summer.

headline: The Tamale Girl of Williamsburg
text: Elizabeth Reddin is a 32-year-old poet with saucer eyes and a rosy smile who stands nearly six feet tall without her roller skates. And last summer, on a whim, she became the tamale girl of Williamsburg.

headline: Stroller Maker Advises Parents Where to Push
text: Parents of young children vowing to venture out more in 2007 should log on to the Web site of Bugaboo, the Dutch company that designs strollers. At the beginning of next month, the “day trips” selections on www.bugaboo.com will be reintroduced with new features to mobilize even the most exhausted parents.

headline: Heroes Rush in, but What Would Average Joe Do?
text: A man falls from a subway platform, a toddler tumbles from a fire escape  two quintessential New York nightmares.

headline: See a Penny, Pick It Up and ‘Honey, Get the Glue!’
text: McKITTRICK, Calif., Jan. 4 — It began innocently enough, like most casual obsessions. Annie Moore dropped a penny into an empty coffee can. Clink.

headline: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’? No, Sir! (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Pretend Web Romance, Then a Real-Life Murder
text: CLARENCE, N.Y.  He told her he was a young marine, recently back from Iraq.

headline: After Pataki’s 12 Years, Is New York Better Off?; Battle Lines in the Fight to Protect Sunnyside; Long Island City: Happy to Be Unhip (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inside the list
text: HOLDING ON: At the start of last year — Sunday, Jan. 1, 2006 — the No. 1 novel here was “Mary, Mary,” a James Patterson production. The best-selling work of nonfiction was Frank McCourt’s memoir “Teacher Man.” Three books from that first best-seller list of 2006 are still clinging, like snow that won’t melt, to the nonfiction list in hardcover: “Marley & Me” (62 weeks), “The World Is Flat” (90 weeks) and “Freakonomics” (85 weeks). All of last January’s fiction best sellers have long vanished into the paperback aisle.

headline: War and Cheap Oil: A Second Look
text: For years, many conservationists argued that the government was subsidizing gasoline by spending billions of tax dollars to keep ships in the Persian Gulf and troops on the ground to assure the flow of oil.

headline: Rangel Says Encouraging Obama on ’08 Is No Big Deal
text: Are Charles B. Rangel’s loyalties mixed?

headline: Stone’s Diaries
text: Time passes, and what it passes through is people — though people believe that they are passing through time, and even, at certain euphoric moments, directing time. It’s a delusion, but it’s where memoirs come from, or at least the very best ones. They tell how destiny presses on desire and how desire pushes back, sometimes heroically, always poignantly, but never quite victoriously. Life is an upstream, not an uphill, battle, and it results in just one story: how, and alongside whom, one used his paddle.

headline: Will This Bull Ever Retire?
text: IF 2006 proved anything, it’s that aging bull markets don’t have to die simply because they’re old, or that they must quietly fade away.

headline: Weakness Is a Strength as the Colts Advance
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 6 — Even though Peyton Manning was not at his best Saturday, the Indianapolis Colts’ defense was superb.

headline: Abbas Asks Dissolution of Hamas Military Police
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 6  After two days of intense fighting between Hamas and his Fatah faction, the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, demanded Saturday that Hamas-run paramilitary police be integrated into Fatah-dominated security forces.

headline: Police Ignore Serial Killings in Delhi Slum, Exposing Unequal Justice for India’s Poor
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 6 — When Vandana Sarkar, an impoverished migrant worker, went to the police in October to report that her 20-year-old daughter was missing, she recalled Friday, officers laughed and said, “Why do you people have so many children if you can’t look after them?”

headline: The Wedding Economy
text: Los Angeles

headline: The Voice of America
text: In round numbers we have here, collected by Ted Widmer for the Library of America, 1,700 pages of orated words. Volume 1 is designated “American Speeches: Political Oratory From the Revolution to the Civil War.” There we weigh in with James Otis (his “Argument Against Writs of Assistance”) and end with Lincoln’s Second Inaugural Address (is there a stretch of forensic beauty to match this?). With understandable reluctance to be done with Lincoln, the editor, who served as a speechwriter in the Clinton administration, begins the succeeding volume with more Lincoln. His “Speech on Reconstruction” was delivered three days before John Wilkes Booth put an end to so much. The second volume is titled “American Speeches: Political Oratory From Abraham Lincoln to Bill Clinton.”

headline: The Imperial Presidency 2.0
text: Observing President Bush in action lately, we have to wonder if he actually watched the election returns in November, or if he was just rerunning the 2002 vote on his TiVo.

headline: Corrections: History and a Dog Run, in One Cozy Package
text: The “Living In” article last Sunday, on the Stuyvesant Square neighborhood, referred incorrectly to the Manhattan Comprehensive Night and Day High School. It is public, not private. The article also misstated the school’s hours. It is open 9 a.m. to 11 p.m. on Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Friday and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Sunday.

headline: Presenting the Arts to New Audiences
text: QUIET on the set,” bellows Charisse A. Brown, a statuesque actress with a dramatic upsweep of hair, as she paces back and forth in front of her eager young students. She praises one for reading without his script, then admonishes another for going out of character.

headline: Seas of Emotion
text: JOANNA SCOTT’S new story collection, “Everybody Loves Somebody,” boasts all the searing, raw eloquence of her previous books, with observations that boldly sacrifice prettiness for accuracy. A mother whose children are missing laments, “if only she had taken a knitting needle and stitched them to her, skin to skin.” A supercilious, “reptilian” maître d’ “smells faintly ... of bus exhaust.” A drunk old lady has a “fishnet face.”

headline: Modern Plans for a Harbor Village
text: SAG HARBOR

headline: Elizabeth Fox-Genovese, Historian, Is Dead at 65
text: Elizabeth Fox-Genovese, a noted historian and women’s studies scholar who roiled both disciplines with her transition from Marxist-inclined feminist to conservative public intellectual, died on Tuesday in Atlanta. She was 65 and had lived in Atlanta for many years.

headline: For American Investors, New Paths to South Africa
text: SOUTH AFRICA is a nation of contradictions. Crowded high-end malls, political stability and the country’s designation as host of the 2010 World Cup reflect a sense of optimism and progress. And yet 16 years after the end of apartheid, this nation of 45 million continues to grapple with widespread poverty and H.I.V., which affects about 12 percent of the population.

headline: Randolph Forgives, but Doesn’t Forget
text: Zach Randolph has the marks of a great young player. He has the gaudy statistics: 24 points and 10.3 rebounds a game for the Portland Trail Blazers. He has the gaudy contract: a six-year, $84 million deal signed in 2004.

headline: Where’s That Cabernet? Check the Virtual Cellar
text: JAMES CHARLTON owns about 400 bottles of wine, and he is beginning to lose track of his collection, which is split between his home in New York and his weekend retreat in Connecticut. So Mr. Charlton is considering a modern alternative to rummaging through wine racks and reading bottle labels: software that would let him keep tabs on his chardonnays and cabernets from a computer.

headline: Letters
text: A Single-Payer Path for American Health Care?

headline: Correction: Stung in the Search for Work
text: A column last Sunday on a day laborer who was arrested in Danbury misspelled the given name of one of several Yale Law School students who is representing him. She is Stacie Jonas, not Staci.

headline: When the Office Becomes Your Day Care Center
text: Q. Your baby sitter canceled at the last minute, leaving you no time to make alternative arrangements for child care. Should you bring your youngster to work?

headline: He’s Not Out of Cash, but Is Out of the Club
text: On the very same day that he left Home Depot last week with an exit package worth at least $210 million, Robert L. Nardelli walked away from another prominent position — without a cent.

headline: Drowned Poet Was Inspired by the Wilds
text: HUGH OGDEN’s voice resonated clearly last Wednesday on his answering machine at home in Glastonbury, three days after his body was found in Rangeley Lake in Oquossoc, Me.

headline: Ariella Hochsztein, Elliot Friedman
text: Ariella Aliza Hochsztein, a daughter of Giselle Dershowitz Hochsztein and Dr. Paul Hochsztein of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married today to Elliot Judah Friedman, a son of Barbara Macy Friedman and Dr. Harvey Y. Friedman of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Shmuel Goldin is to perform the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: Robert Fagles
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Chance to Save Social Security (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three Philosophies, Three Big Gains
text: MUTUAL funds made money across the board in the last quarter of 2006, in small- and large-cap stocks, and in growth and value shares. Some top-performing fund managers recently talked about some of their stocks and offered their thoughts about the year ahead.

headline: New Jersey Death Penalty (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Priorities for New York’s New Year
text: It’s easy for anyone to be overwhelmed by the ambitions of a new year. That goes for New York City, too, especially when a rosy budget forecast seems to promise unlimited opportunites. Here are some achievable goals that must not get lost.

headline: U.S. Selecting Hybrid Design for Warheads
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — The Bush administration is expected to announce next week a major step forward in the building of the country’s first new nuclear warhead in nearly two decades. It will propose combining elements of competing designs from two weapons laboratories in an approach that some experts argue is untested and risky.

headline: 36 Hours in Atlanta
text: FIRST, don't call it Hotlanta anymore. It's the ATL, the code for the teeming airport that is a fitting emblem for a city so transient it barely recognizes itself, where more than half the adult population is from somewhere else, and where every urban fad, from underground parking to savory ice cream, is embraced. A corporate stronghold, a Southern belle and a hip-hop capital, Atlanta wrestled with identity dysphoria as it searched for a new slogan (“Every day is an opening day,” accompanied by a new theme song by the hip-hop impresario Dallas Austin) and tried to name its newborn giant panda (Bling Bling was rejected). Major civic investments like the new, grandiose $220 million aquarium, a significant expansion of the High Museum of Art by the architect Renzo Piano, and the purchase of the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. add up to a high tide of enthusiasm, even in a city where optimism is liberally indulged.

headline: Making the Surge Work

Now imagine this has happened to someone in nearly every family on your block, and on the next block, and in the whole town.

headline: Shocks From the System
text: ALTHOUGH the New York State Department of Education bans corporal punishment, each year it uses taxpayer money to send dozens of children with emotional or learning disabilities to schools that use physically and mentally abusive forms of behavior modification. These include electric shocks, seclusion and sleep and food deprivation. Because these punishments are euphemized as “aversive therapy,” they have until recently stayed under the department’s radar.

headline: Happiness 101
text: One Tuesday last fall I sat in on a positive-psychology class called the Science of Well-Being — essentially a class in how to make yourself happier — at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va. George Mason is a challenge for positive psychologists because it is one of the 15 unhappiest campuses in America, at least per The Princeton Review. Many students are married and already working and commute to school. It’s a place where you go to move your career forward, not to find yourself.

headline: Coeds
text: In the beginning, American universities admitted men only. Women were deemed unfit for the rigors of higher education — insufficient blood to the brain, you know — and in need of teaching more suited to their jobs as mothers and wives. The rest is history. Today, women make up 58 percent of college enrollment. Their numbers started growing in the 1980s, though men still rule at the most elite institutions. The colleges and universities below, single sex at their founding, illustrate the path of coeducation. It’s a fuzzy path. A graduate school might have admitted women almost 100 years before the undergraduate program did. More recently, women’s colleges have been opening their doors to the opposite sex.

headline: Genesis of an Onstage Eden
text: No, it’s not a newfangled Pilates class. It’s a rehearsal for a family-friendly production of Arthur Miller’s 1972 play “Creation of the World and Other Business,” by the Playground Theater Company of Miami. Stephanie Ansin, the company’s co-artistic director with Oleg Kheyfets, said that Miller, in his recasting of the Book of Genesis, was “looking at God and Lucifer as human beings and raising questions about what is good and what is evil.” In this scene in the Garden of Eden — envisioned as a playground — the animals are being named by the Angel of Death (Jesus Quintero, at left), Adam (Meshaun Labrone Arnold, balancing on the ball) and the archangel Chemeul (Ricky Waugh).

headline: Little Asia on the Hill
