But striding through campus on his way to class at the University of California, Berkeley, Mr. Hu hears Mandarin all the time, in plazas, cafeterias, classrooms, study halls, dorms and fast-food outlets. It is part of the soundtrack at this iconic university, along with Cantonese, English, Spanish and, of course, the perpetual jackhammers from the perpetual construction projects spurred by the perpetual fund drives.

headline: With Us or Against Us
text: It is an old, and persistent, American affliction, an odd one for a democratic people: a weakness for dictators with charm and guile and a “modernist” veneer who rule exotic, dangerous lands. We may not know Bahrain but we can be friends with its king; we may not have known Persian ways, nothing, for instance, of the seminarian culture of Qum, but we knew Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, and our travelers and diplomats and journalists felt at home in his court. Jordan may be a realm apart, a place of poverty and a breeding ground of angry warriors of the faith, but young King Abdullah II and his queen, Rania, are fixtures on the international circuit. And now that we have extravaganzas like Davos, no land is truly foreign, the exotic rulers can rub shoulders with Oliver Stone and Angelina Jolie. They can all serve on panels together. Why bother learning Arabic, Farsi or Urdu, when the rulers of distant lands offer a shortcut for the voyeurs and the travelers.

headline: Ball State University
text: Sarah Robbins (left, as her avatar, Intellagirl) was already a "video-game-excited person" when she decided to conduct her section of English 104, a required writing course, in Second Life. Knowing the learning curve is steep, she put out a call last summer for interested underclassmen, and got 300 responses for 18 spots. Ms. Robbins doesn't use Second Life to impart textbook knowledge; she sends her students out to interact with other inhabitants to get them thinking and writing — "about our own identity, and respecting the identities of others, and exploring the look of our own avatar." A 500-word blog is due weekly. One day students dressed their avatars to look like pitchers of Kool-Aid (below) and traveled as a pack to observe reactions. Did they feel safer or bizarre? Another day, they switched genders by editing body form. "I gave them a big box of clothes to use," Ms. Robbins says. "The women in class all put on sort of dorky, unathletic clothing and became sort of intellectual-looking men. Men in the class all put on bikinis and had big guns." The women's alarmed reactions to the men's wardrobe choices provided fodder for that week's blog. "I wanted to break out of real-world learning," Ms. Robbins says.

headline: Harvard Law School
text: Last semester, Harvard Law offered "CyberOne: Law in the Court of Public Opinion," which explored public expression and new media. Only law students could enroll in the portion taught by Prof. Charles Nesson in a bricks-and-mortar classroom. But continuing-education students at Harvard Extension School could participate via Second Life. Some 40 avatars attended weekly "in world" classes and watched Professor Nesson's lectures on a large screen in the outdoor lecture pit adjacent to Austin Hall (above). Sessions were held outdoors because, "for people who are new to Second Life, navigating the indoors can be difficult," says Rebecca Nesson, the extension-school instructor who taught the course with, yes, her father. Harvard's island is open to the public, and nonstudents eavesdropped: the law-school lectures were downloaded at least 300 times a week, and many avatars at large sat in on her class (although not many law students showed up). Some nonstudent avatars even logged in to visit Ms. Nesson during her virtual office hours. This winter, Professor Nesson is moving his intensive trial-procedure class, "Evidence," into a newly built virtual courtroom where students can simulate cases. The public will be able to observe from a gallery.

headline: Pepperdine University
text: In past years, Bill Moseley had to communicate the old-fashioned way with his distance-learning class: text-based chat over the Internet. This year, his 19 graduate students convene on sandy Malibu Island, sometimes in a treehouse, sometimes in a coffee shop. Working in group projects from home bases in Arizona or Ohio, students in his education technology class create multimedia presentations. For an assignment inspired by Daniel Pink's book on steps to excellence, "A Whole New Mind," a wraparound wall (left) immerses viewers in images of the students' avatars.

headline: ‘The Crimson Portrait’
text: A MAN IN UNIFORM sat across from her. It was a hot afternoon, and the sunlight in the drawing room turned the metal buckle at his waist into a sharp bright square and made the gold buttons on his jacket perfect as coins. A stiff collar surrounded his soft neck. His face was indistinct, unaccustomed to giving orders. She guessed he had been called into the military from a minor profession in the city.

headline: ‘Wrestling with Gravy’
text: My parents battled through an acrimonious divorce right at the end of the war that supposedly made their generation the Greatest. They were almost central-castingly perfect opposites: Don Reynolds was short and fat, and at first meeting seemed like a hick from the dustbowls of Oklahoma and Texas; Edith Remick was a tall, dark-haired beauty, a refined and privately schooled graduate of Smith who had been brought up in Quincy, Massachusetts. She was given to upper-middle-class maladies like mild depression, frequently saw doctors for no apparent reason, and spent an inordinate amount of time resting at home. He was a whirlwind, she a lovely and fragile icicle. In the late thirties, he briefly owned part of a Quincy newspaper. One of his biggest advertisers was an upscale department store specializing in men's clothing, named Remick's. They met at a company picnic, and he swept her off her feet. She'd never seen anyone like him: such energy, such surprising smarts, such wild visions of the future. And such a sexual drive. I don't know whether he loosed her panties the very first night or was forced to wait till marriage-but I would bet the ranch, if I had one, that it was on his mind, raging, from the moment they met and every moment thereafter. He told her-and her family-that he intended to live in Quincy for the rest of their lives together. Within a month of their marriage, he sold his interest in the Quincy newspaper and announced that they were moving to Texas. He didn't ask her and hadn't forewarned her or anyone in the family; he just announced it, and off they went. Men could get away with things like that then. He then proceeded to hit the road in search of additional businesses. My sister, Nancy, was born in San Antonio in 1938, and the three of them moved to Fort Smith, Arkansas, where he established the Southwestern Publishing Company, a solely-owned enterprise that operated half a dozen small newspapers. I was born in February 1942, barely two months after the attack on Pearl Harbor, and Dad was drafted shortly after that. He grumbled about the army but finagled his way to Europe, where all the glamour was.

headline: ‘On “The Wealth of Nations”’
text: The Wealth of Nations is, without doubt, a book that changed the world. But it has been taking its time. Two hundred thirty-one years after publication, Adam Smith's practical truths are only beginning to be absorbed in full. And where practical truths are most important-amid counsels of the European Union, World Trade Organization, International Monetary Fund, British Parliament, and American Congress-the lessons of Adam Smith end up as often sunk as sinking in.

headline: ‘The Initials of the Earth’
text: From the snows of Kilimanjaro, Carlos looked into the jungle and yelled "Tarmangani!" three times, but neither Tantor the elephant nor Cheeta the chimpanzee nor the damned pigmies answered his call. Boredom overcame him, and he wished he had a Monopoly there, the game he'd gotten hooked on once he discovered the winning tactic: to buy up everything, Water Works, Electric Company, the railroads, Vermont, Illinois, Kentucky, where he'd build houses and hotels his opponents would land on, then they couldn't pay the rent, and they'd be ruined, go bankrupt, while he'd burst into stentorian laughter suddenly interrupted when he discovered an Apache girl watching him from the palm tree.

headline: ‘Next’
text: Division 48 of Los Angeles Superior Court was a wood-paneled room dominated by the great seal of the state of California. The room was small and had a tawdry feeling. The reddish carpet was frayed and streaked with dirt. The wood veneer on the witness stand was chipped, and one of the fluorescent lights was out, leaving the jury box darker than the rest of the room. The jurors themselves were dressed casually, in jeans and short-sleeve shirts. The judge's chair squeaked whenever the Honorable Davis Pike turned away to glance at his laptop, which he did often throughout the day. Alex Burnet suspected he was checking his e-mail or his stocks.

headline: ‘American Fascists’
text: I grew up in a small farming town in upstate New York where my life, and the life of my family, centered on the Presbyterian Church. I prayed and sang hymns every Sunday, went to Bible school, listened to my father preach the weekly sermon and attended seminary at Harvard Divinity School to be a preacher myself. America was a place where things could be better if we worked to make them better, and where our faith saved us from despair, self-righteousness and the dangerous belief that we knew the will of God or could carry it out. We were taught that those who claimed to speak for God, the self-appointed prophets who promised the Kingdom of God on earth, were dangerous. We had no ability to understand God's will. We did the best we could. We trusted and had faith in the mystery, the unknown before us. We made decisions - even decisions that on the outside looked unobjectionably moral - well aware of the numerous motives, some good and some bad, that went into every human act. In the end, we all stood in need of forgiveness. We were all tainted by sin. None were pure. The Bible was not the literal word of God. It was not a self-help manual that could predict the future. It did not tell us how to vote or allow us to divide the world into us and them, the righteous and the damned, the infidels and the blessed. It was a book written by a series of ancient writers, certainly fallible and at times at odds with each other, who asked the right questions and struggled with the mystery and transcendence of human existence. We took the Bible seriously and therefore could not take it literally.

headline: News Quiz: Final Passages
text: We’ve made this first quiz of 2007 rather manageable, we think. All items should come immediately to mind for most casual news hounds — or at least be easily traceable with a little sleuthing at Google. One item has a toe in the final days of 2006. The other two came post-New Year’s holiday.

headline: Much Ado About Nothing
text: I left the cineplex after seeing “Dreamgirls” with a new respect for “Chicago.” It’s not that I liked “Chicago” any better; it remains a movie I have no desire to see again. But having sat through “Dreamgirls,” I’m now able to appreciate the earlier movie’s curious virtue: it isn’t about anything, but it knows it. “Dreamgirls” also isn’t about anything, but doesn’t know it. This latest creation of director Bill Condon (he also adapted “Chicago” for the screen) takes itself very seriously.

headline: Let’s Start This Over
text: Subaru’s spokesman Michael McHale made it through the minefield of correctly pronouncing all the names of his company’s Japanese executives and guests at the company’s reveal of the redesigned 2008 Outback and Legacy, then handed off with a sigh of relief to Tom Doll, North American executive vice president.

headline: Audi Gets a Seal of Approval
text: Audi’s press conference at the 2007 Detroit auto show got some surprise starpower. The singer Seal stunned the assembled media and industry moguls present by making an unannounced appearance, prior to the unveiling of a 500-horsepower Q7 concept S.U.V.

headline: Happiness 101
text: Positive psychology, which is gaining popularity on college campuses, promises to take mild human pleasure and turn it into a profound state of well-being, D.T. Max writes in Sunday’s Times Magazine.

headline: Too Much Really Is Too Much
text: Continuing on with our theatrical reviews of the theatricality of the car debuts at the North American International Auto Show:

headline: The Libeling of a People Surges With a Vengeance
text: Diatribes against the Jews are shockingly crude in Arab television programs and newspapers. They are also shockingly commonplace, “the elevator music for the Arab world,” as David Ignatius, an international affairs columnist for The Washington Post, puts it in “Anti-Semitism in the 21st Century: The Resurgence,” a PBS documentary that is broadcast tonight. And that background noise has become more strident and pervasive over the last few years, spread by satellite television and the Internet throughout the Middle East and North Africa, with echoes reverberating deep into immigrant groups in Europe.

headline: Russian Crude Stops Flowing to Europe
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 8 — Russian crude oil stopped flowing to Western Europe through a major pipeline across Belarus, officials here and in Europe said.

headline: Slimmer Time in the Age of the Internet
text: Richard Stengel, the managing editor of Time, took his wife and kids out to dinner Friday night.

headline: Joe Economics
text: Prices are rising for the black sludge that helps make the world’s gears turn. If you think we’re talking about oil, think again. Petroleum prices have tumbled from their record highs. No sooner was there relief at the pump, however, than came a squeeze at the pot. That jolt of coffee that a majority of American adults enjoy on a daily basis has gotten more expensive and could go even higher this year.

headline: A Disputed A.P. Source Turns Up, but Bloggers Are Not Appeased
text: After weathering six weeks of criticism for quoting an Iraqi police captain whose existence had been called into question, The Associated Press had some relief last week when Iraq changed its story and acknowledged that, yes, Jamil Hussein did work there.

headline: Turnover and Loss Take Jets by Surprise
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 7 — When Jets receiver Jerricho Cotchery talked, were people listening? Could they see his dark eyes glistening?

headline: In Despair, Eagles Turn to Westbrook to Help Carry Them
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 — At halftime Sunday, the score was not knotted, but running back Brian Westbrook’s stomach was. The cramps would not dissipate, but neither would Westbrook’s determination to keep playing.

headline: Latest Plan Sets a Series of Goals for Iraq Leaders
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 — President Bush’s new Iraq policy will establish a series of goals that the Iraqi government will be expected to meet to try to ease sectarian tensions and stabilize the country politically and economically, senior administration officials said Sunday.

headline: Ex-Aide to Rowland Sentenced in Corruption Case
text: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 — A former aide to John G. Rowland, Connecticut’s former governor who resigned in 2004 before being imprisoned on corruption charges, was sentenced today to a year of home confinement and five years of probation for taking payoffs.

headline: Belichick’s Wisdom Equals Victory
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

headline: Taking Control of Electric Bill, Hour by Hour
text: Ten times last year, Judi Kinch, a geologist, got e-mail messages telling her that the next afternoon any electricity used at her Chicago apartment would be particularly expensive because hot, steamy weather was increasing demand for power.

headline: Queens Man Dies After Police Use Taser, Reports Say
text: A 38-year-old man went into cardiac arrest at his uncle’s home in Queens on Sunday afternoon after a struggle with police officers in which they tried to subdue him with a Taser gun, according to the police.

headline: For Parents, New Ways to Control the Action
text: By now most consumers have probably seen the television commercials from Apple Computer pitting a trim, slightly shaggy hipster, meant to represent that company’s Macintosh line, against a pudgy guy in a bad suit, meant to represent personal computers running Microsoft’s Windows operating system.

headline: Detroit Rethinks Sneak Peeks of Its Cars
text: It’s a time-honored Detroit tradition. Each year, in the weeks before Detroit automakers parade their hottest new designs in front of thousands of journalists at the auto show, carefully selected groups of reporters assemble for sneak previews.

headline: A $400,000 Tanning Booth
text: Introduced on Sunday: Rolls-Royce Phantom Drophead Coupé

headline: For Shockey, a Fast Start Winds Down With a Fizzle
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 — There was doubt last week whether Giants tight end Jeremy Shockey would play, but he started in Sunday’s 23-20 first-round playoff loss against the Philadelphia Eagles.

headline: There’s More to Consider Than a Tailspin
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Manhattan: Debate Over Security Funds
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, called on the Department of Homeland Security yesterday to abandon the use of peer review in deciding how to distribute money for high-risk urban areas, and to base financing decisions entirely on risk. On Friday, the secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff, said that the six highest-risk urban areas — including the New York metropolitan area — would receive 55 percent of the $746.9 million in urban area grants this fiscal year, while 39 other urban regions would get 45 percent. Mr. Schumer, at a news conference, maintained that given the higher risk of a terrorist attack, the New York area “would need at least 50 percent” of the 55 percent — a share that he conceded New York was unlikely to obtain.

headline: After Hevesi Ordeal, Officials Struggle With Travel Rules
text: One public official left her city car, driver and bodyguard in the city and hired a car service to take her to visit a friend in northern Westchester, and got lost. Two days later, the city car, driver and bodyguard arrived to take her from the friend’s home to Albany for the governor’s inauguration.

headline: Few Rules, but to the Fighters, Pure Sport
text: The two men circled each other, neither making any commitments. They were in a boxing ring in the Bronx, the exact location known to the promoter, the fighters and the roughly 100 spectators who were sitting in bleachers around them, completely quiet.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
text: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Newark: Robber Is Sentenced
text: A 19-year-old man, who is awaiting trial on charges of killing an Orange police officer last August, was sentenced to 14 years in prison on Friday for his role in an armed robbery that occurred before the officer’s killing, the authorities said. The man, Raynard Brown of Orange, pleaded guilty to robbery and weapon possession last year for his role in robbing a 34-year-old woman in Orange and stealing her cellphone. He is accused of fatally shooting Detective Kieran T. Shields on Aug. 7. He has pleaded not guilty.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Highbridge Hedge Fund Buys Stake in Louis Dreyfus Energy Business
text: The Highbridge Capital Management hedge fund will announce today that it has taken a major equity stake in the energy business of the Louis Dreyfus Group, the old-line commodities trading firm, in a deal worth about $1 billion.

headline: Eureka Moment: Caltech Wins a Game
text: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP)  Nobody understands the laws of probability better than the cerebral players at Caltech. After 207 consecutive losses, the Beavers finally won an N.C.A.A. men’s basketball game Saturday night  their first victory since 1996.

headline: Giants Put Up Fight, but End Up Losing in Familiar Fashion
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 — The ultimate downfall was swift and agonizing for the Giants, which made it a perfectly appropriate way to end the season.

headline: Addenda
text: Accounts

headline: Off-Duty Police Officer Killed at New Jersey Restaurant
text: An off-duty police officer in Paterson, N.J., was killed early yesterday at a restaurant there when a man shot him after he refused to give up his wallet, the authorities said.

headline: Conrad Black Twits an Author, Then Makes News by Apologizing
text: TORONTO, Jan. 7 — Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, has been relatively quiet lately as he awaits his trial this spring on fraud and racketeering charges in Chicago. But a literary spat and apology to the author of a book he reviewed critically put him back in the gossip pages last week.

headline: Old Spice Tries a Dash of Humor to Draw Young Men
text: CAN an agency known for offbeat campaigns that appeal to younger men, for brands like Nike, ESPN and Miller High Life, freshen the stodgy image of the Old Spice line of men’s grooming products?

headline: From the Mind of a TV Producer, Satellite Television in a Portable Box
text: LOS ANGELES — Rick Rosner is a self-described television junkie.

headline: Toyota Enters the Auto Show With a Swagger
text: DETROIT, Jan. 7 — If there is one word to describe how Toyota Motor has behaved in its 50 years in the American market, it is carefully — careful not to expand too fast or to appear brash in its goals, lest it stir up political resentment as it gathered market share at the expense of Detroit.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: CONFERENCE SEASON Three major consumer-oriented business conferences will be vying for headlines this week, with new product announcements from participating companies expected to be flying thick and fast. New cars, computers, televisions, electronic gadgets — there will be plenty for nearly any taste. The 2007 North American International Auto Show started yesterday in Detroit; press previews are through Tuesday and industry previews are on Wednesday and on Thursday. The auto show opens to the public on Saturday, through Jan. 21. The 2007 International C.E.S. (consumer electronics show) takes place on Monday through Thursday in Las Vegas. Apple’s Macworld conference opens on Tuesday in San Francisco. Among possible new products is a combination iPod and cellphone.

headline: Health Funds at Stake, Union Keeps Watch as Spitzer Plans Cuts
text: After Gov. Eliot Spitzer delivered the first two major speeches of his administration last week, attention shifted to the work of Paul Francis, the state’s new budget director, who is putting fine print to his boss’s proposals.

headline: In Hevesi’s Seat, Rising Potential for Party Split
text: ALBANY, Jan. 5 — Just days after being sworn in with a 19-gun salute, Gov. Eliot Spitzer is facing his first major political challenge — and it comes, perhaps surprisingly, from his fellow Democrats who control the State Assembly.

headline: Keeping Libraries Open (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Strikes Suspected Al Qaeda Target in Somalia
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — A United States Air Force gunship carried out a strike Sunday night against suspected Al Qaeda operatives in southern Somalia, a senior Pentagon official said tonight.

headline: Manhattan: Inaugurations, Reprised
text: Even though they were officially sworn in along with Gov. Eliot Spitzer last Monday in Albany, Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo held ceremonial inaugurations in New York City over the weekend, which were attended by relatives, local officials and other invited guests. Mr. Paterson’s was at 6 p.m. on Friday at Riverside Church; Mr. Cuomo’s took place yesterday at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Both officials were sworn in by their fathers: Basil A. Paterson, a former deputy mayor of New York City and secretary of state of New York, and Mario M. Cuomo, who was governor from 1983 to 1994. Aides said the ceremonies were financed with campaign money and not at public expense.

headline: For Journalists, Politics Not as Usual
text: ROSSLYN, Va. — The newsroom of The Politico, the (mostly) online news venture starting publication in two weeks, looks like a typical one — reporters tap on computers at adjacent desks while banks of televisions hum overhead. But unlike a standard daily newspaper, The Politico will be devoted to a single topic: national politics. Another big difference: It is hiring.

headline: Improbable Gators Consider the Possibilities
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., Jan. 7 — The Florida football team has labored this season without a reliable tailback. Its kicker hit only 30 percent of his attempts and none from beyond 33 yards. The Gators rank 118th out of 119 Division I-A teams in penalties, giving up 64 yards a game.

headline: More Zest From Cayenne
text: Introduced on Monday: 2008 Porsche Cayenne and Cayenne Turbo

headline: Iraq’s Escape Is Soccer, but Soccer Can’t Escape War
text: BAGHDAD — Anyone wanting to take a measure of the importance of soccer in Iraq needed only to be in the country during the national team’s recent march to the finals of the Asian Games, which were held in Doha, Qatar.

headline: In Trying Times, Papers Retreat From Washington
text: David Lightman, a Washington-based reporter for The Hartford Courant, knows how to grind it out, sometimes writing two or three articles a day. He is hustling even more than usual these days, now that his newspaper has cut its Washington bureau to one person from five.

headline: Seahawks Don’t Want Good Luck to Run Out
text: SEATTLE, Jan. 7  Pete Hunter was working as a loan officer 10 days ago, which is somewhat appropriate, considering that his new employer seems to be playing on borrowed time.

headline: ‘Titanic’ Director Joins Fox on $200 Million Film
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 — James Cameron, the director whose “Titanic” set a record for ticket sales around the world, will join 20th Century Fox in tackling a similarly ambitious and costly film, “Avatar,” which will test new technologies on a scale unseen before in Hollywood, the studio and the filmmaker said today.

headline: Ira D. Wallach, 97, a Philanthropist, Dies
text: Ira D. Wallach, a New York philanthropist who for many years was the chief executive of Central National-Gottesman Inc., the world’s largest private marketer of pulp, paper and newsprint, died on Saturday at the White Plains Hospital Center. He was 97 and lived in Scarsdale.

headline: Console Sales Beat Goals, Makers’ Early Reports Say
text: The most widely watched report on holiday video game sales is not due until Thursday, but early hints suggest that it may hold a few surprises.

headline: Quagmire of the Vanities
text: The only real question about the planned “surge” in Iraq — which is better described as a Vietnam-style escalation — is whether its proponents are cynical or delusional.

headline: Congress and Your Security
text: The new Congress is about to revisit some perilously neglected needs of homeland security, with Democrats determined to mandate inspection of all incoming sea cargo by 2012. This is an overdue protection that Republicans bottled up in the last Congress. The House, run now by the Democrats, plans swift passage of legislation requiring both stronger port security and the screening of all air cargo over the next three years.

headline: Ultimate Exile: A Gypsy Poet Expelled by Her People
text: To understand all is to forgive all, the French saying goes. In “Zoli,” a novel about the Gypsies of Eastern Europe, Colum McCann imagines a deeper, darker watchword for this immemorially wandering and persecuted people: to be understood, even in part, is to be violated and destroyed.

headline: Taliban Resume Their Attacks in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 7  The Taliban appeared to be resuming their campaign of violence after a week of quiet over the Islamic festival of Id al-Adha.

headline: Russia’s Extended Winter Holidays: A Binge of Drinking and Spending
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 7 — New Year’s has long been the favored holiday here, celebrated with Champagne and fireworks and gifts under the Christmas tree. Then there was Jan. 2, also traditionally a holiday. Now there is the 3rd and the 4th and the 5th.

headline: Gambler Shakes Up Land of Tutus and Leotards
text: The settled landscape of ballet in New York — dominated by the Balanchine-Robbins shrine at New York City Ballet and the bouquet of Latin and Slavic stars at American Ballet Theater — has been shaken by a minor earthquake.

headline: Tax Cuts Offer Most for Very Rich, Study Says
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 — Families earning more than $1 million a year saw their federal tax rates drop more sharply than any group in the country as a result of President Bush’s tax cuts, according to a new Congressional study.

headline: Some Northwest Residents See Trees Differently After Storm
text: SEATTLE, Jan. 7 — Douglas fir. Western hemlock. Western red cedar. They are trees the way Tiger Woods is a golfer and Ethel Merman was a singer and Richard Pryor was funny and Bill Gates is rich.

headline: A Fleeting Victory in Somalia
text: Newport, R.I.

headline: Working Harder for the Man
text: Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, began the new year with a pink slip and a golden parachute. The company handed him a breathtaking $210 million to take a hike. What would he have been worth if he’d done a good job?

headline: Hitchcock, Thrilling the Ears as Well as the Eyes
text: “I must get that damned tune out of my head!” exclaims the beleaguered Richard Hannay as he is chased across the Scottish Highlands in “The 39 Steps.”

headline: Testing the Testers
text: There is by now no doubt that there are serious problems with electronic voting machines: they fail to record votes, and even flip votes from one candidate to another. Election officials like to defend the machines by noting that they have been certified by independent testing labs. But the certification process has long been deeply flawed, and last week there was even more disturbing news  that the leading testing lab has been unable to meet the federal government’s standards.

headline: G.E. in Deal to Buy Oil and Gas Concern
text: General Electric agreed yesterday to acquire the oil and gas operations from Vetco International for $1.9 billion, people familiar with the situation said yesterday. The deal, which is expected to be announced today, is part of G.E.’s efforts to grow its energy business as the industry continues its boom.

headline: Hussein’s Voice Speaks in Court in Praise of Atrocities
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 8 - The courtroom he dominated for 15 months seemed much smaller on Monday without him there to mock the judges and assert his menacing place in history.

headline: Abbas Tells Party He’ll Proceed With Elections
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 7 — The Fatah faction of the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, held a large rally on Sunday in a Gaza City sports stadium, marking the group’s 42nd anniversary with a show of strength and defiance after days of bloody clashes with the rival Hamas movement.

headline: In the Old Neighborhood: Old Problems, New Life
text: Imagine trying to make a PG-rated “Wire.” That’s the tall order assumed by the producers of “Lincoln Heights,” an ABC Family drama about a middle-class black family moving into a former crack house.

headline: Cole Campbell, 53, Editor and Journalism Educator, Dies
text: Cole Campbell, one of the first newspaper editors to embrace the idea that journalism should help readers be engaged citizens, died Friday in Reno, Nev., when his vehicle flipped on an icy road.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Adm. William J. Fallon: An Experienced Naval Officer, and a Diplomat
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 — The Bush administration’s selection of a career naval aviator to be the top commander of American military forces across a region where they are engaged in two ground wars is, at first glance, odd.

headline: Addai Moves Colts’ Backfield to Forefront of the Offense
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 7  The emergence of running back Joseph Addai has helped the Indianapolis Colts overcome the loss of Edgerrin James.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Nobel Laureate Faults Turkey on Artists

headline: An Outbreak of Rift Valley Fever Kills Dozens in Kenya
text: A growing outbreak of Rift Valley fever has killed at least 62 people in northeastern Kenya since last month, and health officials fear that it could become much more widespread.

headline: Ruthanna Boris, Versatile Ballet Russe Dancer, Dies at 88
text: Ruthanna Boris, a versatile dancer and choreographer who was the first American ballerina to be a star of one of the prestigious Ballets Russes troupes of the ’40s, died Friday at her home in El Cerrito, Calif. She was 88.

headline: Queens: Child Found Dead in His Home
text: Paramedics pronounced an 11-month-old boy dead in his family's Laurelton apartment early yesterday after his family members discovered he was unconscious and called 911, the police said. The cause of the boy's death was unknown, pending the results of tests that might take two weeks to complete, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner. During the past week, the boy had been ill, the police said, and his mother, who is 15, had taken him to the hospital. The police said there was no sign of abuse or any other crime. Neighbors said the boy's mother and grandmother had moved into the basement apartment on 227th Street less than a year ago. One neighbor, Ricky Taggart, 46, said, "They seemed like they were doing the right thing, trying to make it and survive."

headline: For Gravitas or Levity, Try a Robert Frank Book
text: This summer, readers interested in American wealth will be able to pick up Robert Frank’s new book — and the other Robert Frank’s new book.

headline: China Says It May Be Flexible With Yuan
text: China may increase the flexibility of the yuan should the country’s trade surplus continue to expand this year, China’s central bank governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, said yesterday.

headline: Headhunters at Harvard May Pick a Woman
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 4 — Could Harvard be preparing to select a woman as its new president? A scientist? A female scientist?

headline: Totals
In Effort to Cut Murders, Newark Forms Police Drug Division
text: NEWARK, Jan. 8  Mayor Cory A. Booker and his police director announced the formation of a new narcotics division today to try to defeat a stubbornly high murder rate, firmly linking the trade in illegal drugs to the city’s persistent violence.

headline: To Get to Carnegie Hall, Play Bach or Pay Your $1
text: What does $1 buy in New York City? Generally speaking, not much. But that was the ticket price for a concert by the Bachiana Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. The event was intended to draw attention to Amazon rain forest conservation. It also drew more than the usual number of curiosity seekers, as evidenced by intermittent camera flashes before the concert and the boisterous children who trotted up and down the aisles.

headline: Caremark Rejects $26 Billion Offer
text: Caremark Rx Inc., the nation’s second-largest manager of pharmacy benefits, said yesterday that it had rejected a $26 billion unsolicited merger bid from Express Scripts Inc., choosing a lower offer from the drugstore chain CVS Corporation.

headline: As Newark Mayor Readies Crime Fight, Toll Rises
text: Two men were killed in a midday gun battle in a Newark housing project yesterday, less than 24 hours before Mayor Cory A. Booker was scheduled to reveal a new initiative against drugs and violent crime.

headline: Barber Leaves His Mark on Giants and Moves On to a New Career
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 — Tiki Barber watched helplessly from the sideline as David Akers attempted a game-winning field goal during the Giants’ wild-card game Sunday. As the ball sailed between the uprights, giving the Philadelphia Eagles a 23-20 victory, the Giants’ season and Barber’s 10-year career had come to a close.

text: Introduced on Sunday: Ford Interceptor design study

headline: Johnson Accepts Two-Year Offer
text: The Arizona Diamondbacks took the next step toward completing a five-player trade with the Yankees yesterday, agreeing to a two-year contract with pitcher Randy Johnson, one of Johnson’s agents, Alan Nero, said.

headline: Ex-Prosecutors Urge New Trial for Man Convicted of 2 Murders
text: The campaign to overturn the conviction of a Long Island man for the murders of his parents has gained a highly unusual group of supporters: 31 former federal, state and local prosecutors.

headline: Brooklyn: Accident Inquiry Begins
text: An investigation is under way into what caused a metal plate weighing thousands of pounds to fall and crush a worker to death on Saturday morning at the GMD Shipyard in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, a spokesman for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said yesterday. “We are conducting an investigation to determine whether any safety standards were violated,” said Ted Fitzgerald, the spokesman. The worker, Christopher G. Thomas, was killed after being crushed by the plate, which was being used to repair a barge in dry dock. Mr. Thomas was working beneath the barge when the plate came loose and crashed to the ground. His sister-in-law, Kathy McLean, 45, said yesterday that family members planned to meet with officials from GMD today.

headline: War Could Last Years, Commander Says
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 7  The new American operational commander in Iraq said Sunday that even with the additional American troops likely to be deployed in Baghdad under President Bush’s new war strategy it might take another “two or three years” for American and Iraqi forces to gain the upper hand in the war.

headline: For Today’s Daters, Update on ‘Which Twin Has the Toni?’
text: If you were ever of the mind that the character of Jack on “Will & Grace,” in all his shallowness, ditzy thinking and affinity for musical theater, amounted to a minstrelsy of homosexual life so unsettling that it diluted the show’s progressiveness to the intensity of a Shirley Temple, then you may find in “Gay, Straight or Taken?” the seeds of genuine advancement for American civilization. This new reality series, which has its premiere on Lifetime tonight, exists to dispute the idea that there is an infallible link between the connotations of someone’s sexual orientation and the orientation itself. And however dopey the show is in actuality — and it is awfully, awfully dopey — who could not applaud its instincts?

headline: Dear Diary
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Balms for Sadness: Salt, Grease, Sugar ...
text: Test subjects watching “Love Story,” the lachrymose 1970 romance, ate on average almost 125 grams of buttered, salty popcorn (the amount found in a medium-size bag at the movies) — about 28 percent more than did those watching “Sweet Home Alabama,” the 2002 fish-out-of-water comedy about a fashion designer going home to the rural South. The experiment, which involved 30 subjects watching each film over two days, was described in a paper in the January issue of the Journal of Marketing about the connection between people’s moods and the type and quantity of food they eat. The studies found that compared with happy people, people who are feeling unhappy eat larger amounts of foods they consider tasty, but unhealthy.

headline: Under Pressure, Pennington Falls a Few Plays Short
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 7 — Chad Pennington limped to the Jets’ buses after Sunday’s game, the gait of a man whose body was sore and tired.

headline: Bombs Signal a Turbulent Year for Thailand
text: BANGKOK, Jan. 6 — A string of lethal bombs that disrupted New Year’s celebrations here has signaled the start of a difficult year for Thailand as entrenched elites struggle for control of the country’s future.

headline: 30-Year Sentence in Subway Bomb Plot Case
text: A Pakistani immigrant was sentenced by Judge Nina Gershon this afternoon to 30 years in prison for his conviction in the plot to blow up the Herald Square subway station in 2004.

headline: Killing of Officer May Be Related to Robbery Surge
text: PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 8 — Investigators believe that the fatal shooting of a 23-year-old rookie police officer outside a fried chicken shop here early Sunday morning may be linked to a surge in robberies in Paterson, the police said today.

headline: A Personal Computer to Carry in a Pocket
text: The world of desktop computing is finally going mobile, and the shift can be seen in the explosive growth of wireless data for cellular carriers.

headline: Bush Picks Reagan Aide to Be White House Counsel
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — Fred F. Fielding, a White House counsel in the administration of Ronald Reagan, is about to become White House counsel in the administration of President Bush, Republicans close to the White House said today.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Daniel R. Raichel, 71, an Expert on the Characteristics of Sound, Is Dead
text: Daniel R. Raichel, a mechanical engineer and an expert on acoustics who studied how sound travels in symphony halls and across industrial workplaces and wrote a leading textbook on the subject, died on Dec. 22 in El Cajon, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Cadillac’s Plan: Less Edge for the Next CTS
text: Introduced on Monday: 2008 Cadillac CTS

headline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Backs New Members
text: Van Halen, the Ronettes, Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five, R.E.M. and Patti Smith will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame this year, in the 22nd annual round of honors, the organization announced this morning.

headline: Mr. Schwarzenegger’s Modest Idea
text: Guaranteed health care for children is the new political apple pie. No one can say he is against it, and it’s a sure applause line for politicians who want to show concern for reducing the number of uninsured in America. But special recognition is due California’s governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, who is reportedly ready to begin his new term with an actual proposal that his state insure all children. And by all, he means undocumented immigrants, too.

headline: New Warsaw Archbishop Quits Over Communist Collaboration
text: WARSAW, Jan. 7  The newly appointed archbishop of Warsaw, Stanislaw Wielgus, abruptly resigned on Sunday at a Mass meant to celebrate his new position after having admitted two days earlier that he had worked with the Polish Communist-era secret police.

headline: Biden Joins List of Presidential Contenders
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 — Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware on Sunday became the fourth Democrat to formally announce plans to run for president next year.

headline: Climate Change: No Time to Debate (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Louisville’s Petrino to Leave for the N.F.L. and the Falcons
text: When Coach Bobby Petrino signed a 10-year contract extension last summer at Louisville, he insisted that it include a million-dollar buyout as a sign of his commitment to the university.

headline: A Tale Spins Toward Peril, Steps by Subtle Steps
text: Kelley Donovan’s “It’s All Forgotten Now” stood out from its first moments for its precise and subtle shifts in dynamics. And this new work, presented by the Boston-based Kelley Donovan & Dancers on Friday and Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, steadily built to a quiet climax by means of those shifts alone.

headline: One More Brain Exercise (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tweaking a Few Lines (They’ll None of Them Be Missed)
text: Albert Bergeret and his New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players have been plying the Savoyard repertory for more than three decades — starting at a time when small operetta companies were plentiful in New York — and outliving all the competition. That isn’t how fans of this repertory, and even admirers of this company, would have wanted it; although the groups that flourished in the 1970s worked on tight budgets that barely allowed for makeshift sets and costumes, their combined activity kept the scene lively and the music on the stage.

headline: Losing Job and Pride, but Now Hoping for a Comeback
text: Nancy Harris wants to make a few things very clear.

headline: Big Overhaul of  Health Care Is Sought in Calif.
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 — Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed sweeping changes to California’s huge, troubled health care system today, including the requirement that all of the state’s 36 million residents have health insurance.

headline: Laurie’s Big Music Gig for the Littlest Rock ’n’ Rollers
text: At an invitation-only press preview on a recent Thursday, a swarm of lucky preschoolers rushed the stage at the first sight of the singer-songwriter Laurie Berkner, a guitar-strumming earth mother from “Jack’s Big Music Show,” on Noggin. Ms. Berkner and her band were appearing at John Jay College in Manhattan to welcome back Jack — the puppet host of a popular series that cleverly disguises music education as entertainment — for his second season. Melodious and cheeky, the show celebrates all manner of music making, be it surfer rock, Delta blues or zesty zydeco.

headline: After Many Years, It’s Rangel’s Turn at the Helm
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 — It is the committee that produced the Social Security and Medicare laws, that created the modern welfare state and reinvented it in the 1990s, that raised taxes and slashed them, again and again and again. No committee, arguably, has more power or attracts more lobbyists than the Committee on Ways and Means. House members sometimes wait for years for a seat on it, then for decades to rise in seniority.

headline: 50 Years Too Late, but Right on Time
text: On display at the G.M. exhibit: Holden Efijy design study

headline: Gas-Like Odor Permeates Parts of New York City
text: A strong odor permeated parts of New York City and nearby areas of New Jersey during the morning commute today, forcing several schools and companies to evacuate and interrupting traffic along some subway and train lines. Authorities investigating widespread reports of the smell, which some described as a gas-like odor, said it did not appear to be harmful.

headline: The British Like to Control TV With Their DVRs, Too
text: LONDON, Jan. 7 — An announcement from British Sky Broadcasting last week that it had sold more than two million digital video recorders demonstrated the international appeal of a technology that wrests control of television schedules out of the hands of broadcasters and into the homes of viewers.

headline: As Obesity Fight Hits Cafeteria, Many Fear a Note From School
text: BLOSSBURG, Pa. — Six-year-old Karlind Dunbar barely touched her dinner, but not for time-honored 6-year-old reasons. The pasta was not the wrong shape. She did not have an urgent date with her dolls.

headline: Planners Clash Over Transit Hub, and Riders Win
text: A truce has been called in the battle between form and function that erupted late last year over plans for the Fulton Street Transit Center, a new transportation hub in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Once Again, a Postseason Matchup for the Patriots Turns on a Defensive Play
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 7 — It was right there in the scouting report. When Jets quarterback Chad Pennington lines up under center, it often means a quick pass to the outside. And if a pass rusher cannot get to the quarterback, the report said, he should at least get his hands up to try to knock down a pass.

headline: Islamists Out, Somalia Tries to Rise From Chaos
text: KISMAYO, Somalia, Jan. 7 — Every Friday morning in this seaside town, the future of Somalia plays soccer on a bone-littered beach.

headline: Chevy Will Be Ready When the Batteries Are
text: Introduced on Sunday: Chevrolet Volt design study

headline: Student Binge Drinking (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tony Blair to Be Held to Account Onstage
text: PARIS, Jan. 7 — The Tricycle Theater in an unfashionable district of North London has just 240 seats but when it comes to tackling political issues it has found a way of being noticed: It gathers the real words of real people caught in real events and dramatizes them in what it calls verbatim plays.

headline: Finding Time on a Vacation to Collect a Pair of Titles
text: We have all heard the expression “busman’s holiday.” But why busmen? Why not golfers or doctors — or bridge professionals?

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Microsoft and Ford Combine Products
text: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 7 — Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, is using the Consumer Electronics Show here to highlight several new consumer-oriented products and to unveil a partnership with the Ford Motor Company to build Microsoft technology into several Ford models.

headline: Private Firms Lure Chief Executives With Top Pay
text: Robert L. Nardelli’s unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation and private jets is emerging elsewhere.

headline: And They’re Off …
text: If it were a race, Speaker Nancy Pelosi might say, “Democrats, start your engines!”

headline: Sensory Overload: Notes From Day 1
text: If you sit at a table at the Infiniti booth on the Cobo Hall show room floor for more than two minutes, somebody will come by and give you a plate with prosciutto-wrapped melon, edamame, and bruschetta. That hardly ever happens under normal circumstances, no matter how close you sit to an Infiniti.

headline: Eagles 23, Giants 20
text: The Eagles advanced to the next round of the playoffs after eliminating the Giants on Sunday.

headline: Bush Plans Big Push on Hill to Sell Iraq Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — The White House is planning an aggressive effort to sell Congress and the American public on President Bush's new strategy for Iraq, beginning with a prime-time address to the nation Wednesday night, a trip by the president to Fort Benning, Ga., to visit with troops on Thursday and appearances on Capitol Hill by the secretaries of state and defense.

headline: Me, Myself and I
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: B.C.S. Title Game Media Poll
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 6 – While waiting for Florida practice to end, I put together the remnants of my very informal and unscientific media poll. I sent e-mails to a variety of beat writers and college sportswriters around the country.

headline: Twenty Questions for Pete Thamel
text: Pete Thamel, the Times’s college football writer, is in Arizona to cover tonight’s national title game. The Fifth Downers sent him questions. He answered ‘em. Take a look-see:

headline: Caremark Rejects Express Scripts Offer
text: Caremark Rx, the nation’s second-largest manager of pharmacy benefits, said Sunday that it had rejected a $26 billion unsolicited merger bid from Express Scripts, choosing a lower offer from the drugstore chain CVS.

headline: Alliance Deal May Reshape Canadian Media Landscape
text: The potential sale of Alliance Atlantis Communications to CanWest Global Communications has cast a cloud over the growth prospects of two rival broadcasters, and could pressure them to do their own deal to keep pace in Canada’s consolidating media environment, The Globe and Mail reported. Astral Media and Corus Entertainment are each vying for Alliance’s stable of 13 specialty television channels, but the newspaper reported last week that CanWest, in concert with Goldman Sachs, are the clear front-runners to acquire its broadcast assets.

headline: R.I.M. Directors Leave Options Audit
text: Research In Motion said Friday that two board members will no longer be involved in the audit committee’s discussions regarding the company’s internal review of stock option grants. The two board members, Douglas Wright and Kendall Cork, who are also members of RIM’s compensation committee, decided to recuse themselves from such deliberations to avoid the appearance of conflicts of interest.

headline: Britain May Opt for a Light Touch in Hedge Fund Rules, Report Says
text: The Bank of England wants London-based hedge funds to agree to a voluntary code of conduct to encourage greater transparency and provide better governance in the contentious industry, The Guardian reported. Rather than go for heavy-handed regulation, which could push many out of their plush Mayfair offices and into other countries, British financial authorities are leaning toward the lighter touch of a voluntary code.

headline: Fox Rothschild Acquires Boutique Law Firm
text: Fox Rothschild, a New York law firm, has acquired a boutique law firm, Young Moriwaki and Greenfader. The acquisition comes just a few months after Fox Rothschild acquired a labor and employment boutique in New Jersey with more than 50 lawyers. Young Moriwaki & Greenfader has six attorneys and offices in Manhattan and Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: A Book Review and an Apology and Conrad Black in Headlines Again
text: Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, has been relatively quiet lately as he awaits his trial this spring on fraud and racketeering charges in Chicago. But a literary spat and apology to the author of a book he reviewed critically put him back in the gossip pages last week, writes The New York Times.

headline: G.E. to Buy Energy Company From Investment Firms
text: General Electric has agreed to buy Vetco Gray, a maker of oil and gas-drilling and production equipment, for $1.9 billion to profit from surging demand for energy exploration. G.E., the world’s second-biggest company by market value, is acquiring Houston-based Vetco from three private equity firms, the 3i Group, Candover Investments  and J.P. Morgan Partners.

headline: A Coming of Age for the Global Real Estate Market
text: For investors who have been missing out on the prolonged run-up in the shares of real estate investment trusts, or maybe jumped in only recently, the end may not be in sight: there are growing opportunities overseas, The New York Times reports. Some industry experts say that this is an opportune time to make a move into these nascent markets.

headline: Highbridge Buys Stake in Energy Business
text: The Highbridge Capital Management hedge fund said Monday that it had invested in the energy business of the Louis Dreyfus Group, the old-line commodities trading firm, forming a venture with an enterprise value of more than $1 billion. Highbridge Capital, a $17 billion hedge fund based in New York that is majority owned by J.P. Morgan Chase, said it had invested in Louis Dreyfus to gain more access to energy delivery and trading markets on its own.

headline: Time Warner Cable May Come to Market Without an I.P.O.
text: Shares of Time Warner Cable, the second largest cable company in the nation, could hit the market within the next few weeks, analysts said. But Time Warner may bring its cable unit to market without having to go through the costly and time-consuming process of an initial public offering.

headline: For Journalists, Politics Not as Usual
text: As many newspapers across the country are cutting their staffs and trimming back on Washington coverage, The Politico — the (mostly) online political news venture starting publication in two weeks — is finding younger journalists and some veterans who are willing to leave the once-secure confines of traditional print to join a start-up. And if The Politico succeeds, it could signal that the Web has become a more plausible alternative for mainstream journalists, says The New York Times. But, it notes, there are skeptics who say that the focus of The Politico is too narrow and that the marketplace too crowded with sources of political news.

headline: Taiwan Firm Sues Apple in Shuffle Skirmish
text: Luxpro, fresh from a legal victory against Apple Computer over whether its portable music players are ripoffs of Apple’s iPod Shuffle, is seeking $100 million in damages in the case.

headline: Mr. Moneyball Joins Board of Ellison’s NetSuite
text: NetSuite, a rising Silicon Valley company backed by the computer software mogul Larry Ellison, has scored Oakland Athletics General Manager Billy Beane as a director. The move represents a public-relations coup for NetSuite, an Internet-based maker of business management software preparing for an initial public offering later this year.

headline: Hedge Fund Has InFocus Board in Its Sights
text: A hedge fund, Caxton Associates, has raised its stake in InFocus, a provider of digital protection technology, in a move that might signal a proxy battle. Caxton said in a filing that it had raised its stake to 11.2 percent from 9.9 percent after discussions with InFocus management in the fourth quarter of last year had yielded unsatisfactory results.

headline: Will Tribune Managers Enter the Bidding Fray?
text: The announcement Thursday by two foundations with close ties to the Tribune that they had hired New York’s Blackstone Group to advise them as they consider alternatives for their combined 13.1 percent stake in Tribune stock, has put the focus on what role, if any, Tribune management will have in a possible deal for the media company.

headline: Equity Office Bondholders Pressure Blackstone for More Money
text: A group of Equity Office Properties Trust bondholders said Friday that they had received commitments from enough investors to block the Blackstone Group‘s tender offer for $725 million of their bonds. Investors owning a majority of bonds have agreed not to tender their securities, according to a statement from the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York. While Equity Office can still move ahead with the sale without approval from the bondholders, the group could force Blackstone to increase its offer, raising the $36 billion cost of what would be the biggest leveraged buyout ever.

headline: Highland Capital Raises Ruckus Over Delphi Plan
text: Delphi is facing objections to its bid for a six-month extension of its right to develop its bankruptcy-reorganization plan without interference from creditors or investors. Delphi, an auto parts supplier, said it needs the extra time to meet the terms of a “framework agreement” that proposes a $3.4 billion capital infusion from a pair of hedge funds and a private equity firm.

headline: Reed Elsevier Seen as Possible Takeover Target
text: Shares in the Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier rose Friday amid market speculation that the company is a takeover target of Wolters Kluwer, a smaller publishing house. But the companies have circled each other before and regulatory issues and size could prove an impediment to a deal.

headline: France’s Weinberg Capital Cooks Up Bakery Deal
text: Weinberg Capital Partners, a French buyout fund headed by the former head of luxury goods group PPR, Serge Weinberg, said Friday it had agreed to buy 60 percent of French baking equipment maker Sasa Industrie in a deal that values the group at 80.7 million euros ($106 million). The acquisition is the fourth by Weinberg Capital, which was founded in July 2005 by Mr. Weinberg, one of France’s highest-profile managers, and three partners, Guillaume d’Angerville, Henri Gagnaire and Philippe Klocanas.

headline: Private Firms Lure C.E.O.’s With Top Pay
text: Robert L. Nardelli’s unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation is emerging elsewhere. Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that the firms have bought out.

headline: At Electronics Show, A Cool Gadget Here, an A-List Chieftain There
text: With the end of the holidays comes a fresh start and new resolve to lead a loftier, healthier, simpler life. Then, before you know it, everyone in the media business hops on planes to Las Vegas and swarms the Consumer Electronics Show, which started Saturday. More than big awards shows or investment bank conferences and guru gatherings, C.E.S. has emerged as the Super Bowl of cluster-huddles, writes The New York Times’ Richard Siklos. And it has increasingly become a conference not just for tech aficionados, but for the heads of the media companies who create the content for said gadgets as well.

headline: State Farm Negotiating Gulf Claims Settlement
text: State Farm, the biggest home insurer in the nation, is in the final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, lawyers briefed on the talks said yesterday.

headline: Appeals Court Reverses Convictions of 2 Westar Energy Executives
text: An appeals court on Friday overturned convictions against two former executives of Westar Energy who were accused of “looting” the Kansas utility and said the most serious charges cannot be retried. The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit said the case against the former chief executive, David Wittig, and the former chief strategy officer, Douglas Lake, “hung by a thin legal thread,” based on claims that the men tried to hide their personal use of corporate aircraft from securities officials.

headline: Jumbo Bonuses: Dial Your Envy Down a Notch
text: It’s time to put the record Wall Street bonuses you’ve heard about in perspective. Yes, a few investment stars did reap tens of millions, topped by Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chairman of Goldman Sachs, who received $53.4 million. But these people were the exception, writes The New York Times’ Phyllis Korkki, pointing to data that show the average 2006 bonus in the New York securities industry was about $137,000, an increase of 15 percent from the year before.

headline: Viacom Selects President for MTV International Unit
text: In a series of appointments expected to solidify the management at Viacom, the company named Robert M. Bakish as president of MTV Networks International. He will report to William H. Roedy, who is global chairman of MTV Networks and has oversight of MTV’s international operation.

headline: Florida Wins B.C.S. Title
text: Florida shocked the college football world by blowing out top-ranked Ohio State to win the national championship on Monday night.

headline: HSBC Tries Tag-Team Approach
text: HSBC‘s chairman, Stephen Green, told The Financial Times he planned to run the bank as a ”double act” with the chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, who would lead its management team to deliver the strategy. In an interview in Monday’s edition of the newspaper, Mr. Green also said the bank, the biggest in Europe, did make mistakes but always moved to fix the problem. He detailed the division of labor between the post of chairman and the chief executive, calling it an evolution of the respective roles under his predecessor, John Bond.

headline: First Glances
text: A look at The 2007 North American International Auto Show.

headline: Bull Riding at the Garden
text: Meeting the judges, the bulls and the riders at Madison Square Garden's first top-tier professional bull-riding event.

headline: Ford C.E.O. Says Jaguar Not for Sale
text: Ford Motor‘s British luxury division Jaguar is not for sale, the chief executive, Alan Mulally, told reporters on the sidelines of an auto show on Sunday. Mr. Mulally, who became Ford’s chief execlutive in September, had earlier declined to rule out the sale of money-losing Jaguar and other premium brands in its portfolio.

headline: Citigroup Raises $3.3 Billion for Buyout Fund
text: Citigroup has raised $3.3 billion for private equity investments, highlighting the growing eagerness of Wall Street banks to take part in the high-risk, high-return boom in leveraged buyouts. The fresh pool of money, to be announced on Monday, exceeds the bank’s $2.5 billion target and includes commitments from clients and employees, as well as $1 billion of the bank’s own balance sheet. The fund, Citigroup Capital Partners II, will be used to strike deals in a variety of industries and regions alongside other private equity firms.

headline: NCR to Spin Off Teradata Unit
text: NCR, the world’s largest maker of automated-teller machines, said it would split into two public companies, spinning off its Teradata data warehousing business. The spinoff should be completed in six to nine months, separating their businesses into NCR’s banking and checkout systems and Teradata’s corporate data storage operations, NCR said in a statement Monday. J.P. Morgan Chase is serving as financial adviser in the move.

headline: United Surgical to Be Acquired by Welsh Carson for $1.8 Billion
text: United Surgical Partners International agreed Monday to be acquired by Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe, the buyout firm that helped create the surgery center operator, for $1.8 billion in cash. UNCN Acquisition, a unit of the New York private-equity firm, offered $31.05 a share for United Surgical, a 13 percent premium over Friday’s closing price.

headline: Forest Oil to Acquire Houston Exploration for $1.5 Billion
text: Houston Exploration agreed Sunday to be acquired by Forest Oil for $1.5 billion. A natural-gas driller, Houston Exploration had put itself up for sale after rejecting an unsolicited $62-a-share bid by a hedge fund, Jana Partners, last year. Jana Partners, the largest shareholder of Houston Exploration with a 14.7 percent stake, supports the transaction, Houston Exploration said.

headline: FIA Acts on New Role for Car Manufacturers
text: In keeping with the announcement in November by the International Automobile Federation and the Grand Prix Manufacturers Association that peace had broken out between the two groups, the FIA today announced the creation of a Formula One Manufacturers’ Advisory Commission.

headline: On The Trail of Bigger and Better Swag
text: One of the joys of covering the North American International Auto Show is comparing the swag that the various manufacturers hand out with or within their press kit materials after each event (fancy food and drink don’t count).

headline: Link Rolling in Our Time
text: The House of Many Doors weighed in big-time with Oscarnalia yesterday, and if you spent your Sunday watching football, you might want to catch up, now that you’re back at work and on the clock. The paper’s three film critics dissected pivotal moments in particular films: A.O. Scott looked at a potentially brutal moment in “Letters From Iwo Jima”; Manohla Dargis unpacked an intimate transaction amidst the mayhem of “Children of Men”; and Stephen Holden dissected the unforgettable pool scene in “Little Children.” In a year where all of the movies ran together on occasion for the Bagger, these pieces reminded him that great filmmaking can stop time.

headline: Sony Dips Its Toes Into Internet TV
text: The day when consumers can download content from the Internet directly to their TV may not be that far off. Last night, Sony announced a plan to sell a module that, when connected to their next generation of flat panel TVs, will allow customers to watch music, short videos, and other high-def content that’s streaming off the Internet.

headline: Taking the Grid Down
text: The Bagger stopped the “Four Seasons” for one of those schmoozy cocktails parties designed to make people warm and gooey about a particular project — in this case “United 93.” The Bagger stayed away from the very open bar, but tucked in some free groceries, as is his habit. He got a chance to talk to Paul Greengrass, the director, who emphasized that the film was a kind of partnership with the families who lost loved ones on that flight. “This was more than just another movie for those of us who were involved in making it,” he said, adding that he was happy to take time off from shooting “The Bourne Ultimatum” to help the film’s award prospects.

headline: Good to the Last Person
text: “Cheeky!” Sacha Baron Cohen said in a deep, genteel British accent to the young man in the front row who had just taken a photogrph of him. The Baguette was at a Q&A following a screening of “Borat” at the Lighthouse Theater on East 59th Street Saturday night. (The big mystery was how someone got a camera past the army of security guys, who combed backpacks, handbags and pockets.)

headline: Portugal Telecom Bid Is Expected after Buyout Firms Withdraw
text: Portugal Telecom, the country’s largest network operator, is expected to receive a $14 billion hostile bid from a rival, Sonae, this week, after a private-equity consortium dropped out of the running, The Financial Times reported Monday. That group, comprising Texas Pacific, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Blackstone Group, Cinven, Permira and Providence, was formed last March.

headline: Should Democrats Keep Committee-Chair Term Limits?
text: Are term limits for committee chairmen in Congress a bad thing? While guest-blogging at Ezra Klein’s eponymous site, Nicholas Beaudrot of Electoral Math wants to know why Nancy Pelosi is retaining one of Newt Gingrich’s ideas. “[I]t really seems odd to me to adopt Republican reforms that preceded the most insular, beholden-to-leadership Congress in the last century,” Beaudrot writes.

headline: The Hill: In the Shadow of a Veto
text: With the opposing party controlling Congress, it’s likely that President Bush may exercise his veto authority more often than he has in the past. (He has only vetoed one bill during his entire time in office.) The Associated Press’s Tom Raum takes a shot at guessing what he’ll strike down:

headline: Critical Mass
text: The Bagger was a little late to the New York Film Critics Circle Awards at the Supper Club, after spending some quality time with J.J. Abrams in a public interview for the House of Many Doors. So he was disappointed to find when he walked in that there was nothing but dessert on the table. As it turned out, only dessert was served, which improved his mood.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Hedge Fund Employee Over PIPEs Trading
text: A former employee of Spinner Asset Management, a $200 million New York hedge fund, has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of illegal short selling as part of trades in private investments. The former executive, Joseph Spiegel, paid a $110,000 fine and accepted a three-year ban for trades meant to hedge investments in private investments in public equity, or PIPEs. In December, the S.E.C. sued Edwin Buchanan “Bucky” Lyon IV of Gryphon, a Dallas-based hedge fund, for similar violations.

headline: East Coast-West Coast Continued
text: It turns out there are various camps — and plenty of camp — on the road to the statue. OscarWatch posts a scorecard so you can keep track of who is backing what.

headline: Credit Suisse Names Head of European M&A
text: A few months after announcing his resignation as HSBC‘s European head of investment banking, David Livingstone has resurfaced as Credit Suisse‘s head of mergers and acquisitions in Europe. Mr. Livingstone started his new position in Credit Suisse’s London office on Monday, the firm said. Susan Kilsby, who had been Credit Suisse’s head of European M&A since 2002, was named chairman of European M&A at the investment bank, Credit Suisse said Monday.

headline: The Gas Mystery
text: Updated 6 p.m.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Week in Review Editor Katy Roberts
text: Katy Roberts, editor of the Week in Review, answered reader questions.

headline: At Least He Didn’t Write About Yellowcake
text: The Washington Post editorial page, adopting a favorite tactic of the blogosphere, bashes the op-ed President Bush published last week in The Wall Street Journal. (It’s not a “Fisking,” but it’s close.) The editorial begins:

headline: Breaking: Gas Odor Overwhelms Manhattan
text: A powerful gas odor is affecting much of the West side of Manhattan this morning, reports New York 1 — and early-morning employees of The New York Times, who have personally described themselves as feeling a bit lightheaded, heachachy, and nauseous as the fumes waft through the 43rd Street headquarters.

headline: A Source of Stem Cells Without Controversy?
text: Scientists say they’ve found a new way to harvest stem cells without using human embryos. Describing them as “nearly as powerful as embryonic stem cells,” Reuters reports that the cells are capable of creating “muscle, bone, fat, blood vessel, nerve and liver cells in the laboratory.”

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Maria Antonelli, a partner at the Star Group, Cherry Hill, N.J., was promoted to managing partner. She continues as senior vice president and general manager at StarShipley, the Wilmington, Del., office of the Star Group.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today
text: Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware confirmed that he’ll be seeking the Democratic nomination for president during an appearance on NBC’s “Meet the Press” Sunday. “I’m going to be Joe Biden, and I’m going to try to be the best Biden I can be,” he said. “If I can, I got a shot. If I can’t, I lose,” he told Tim Russert, the host, adding that he would file formal papework by the end of this month.

headline: Bloomberg: Odor Is ‘Not Dangerous’
text: At a news conference, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said a small natural gas leak downtown was too minor to account for the pervasive odor “so it is obvious the smell is coming from something else.”“The city’s air sensors do not report any elevated level of natural gas,” he said, but he said officials were confident the odor was “not dangerous.”

headline: Quadrangle Announces Promotions
text: Quadrangle Group, an investment firm that focuses on media and communications companies, said Monday it had promoted several professionals in its private equity and distressed debt groups. Jeffrey Nordhaus, who joined the firm from Goldman Sachs in 2001, was promoted to managing principal from principal. Mr. Nordhaus leads several of Quadrangle’s investment sectors, including cable and leisure, the firm said.

headline: Best Buy Calls for New Venture
text: Look for In Advertising next week on Tues., Jan. 16, rather than Mon., Jan. 15, in honor of the Dr. King holiday.

headline: The War at Home: Glimpses at the New Strategy
text: The Times’s Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny preview President Bush’s new Iraq strategy, which includes a series of “benchmarks” that Iraqi leaders must meet:

headline: Has Fraud Followed I.P.O.’s to London?
text: The London Stock Exchange snagged more initial public offerings than the New York Stock Exchange in 2006, putting a dent in an otherwise impressive year for the NYSE Group, which runs the New York exchange. But there may be a downside for the L.S.E. as well: British regulators are fighting a 40 percent spike in business fraud, according to the New York Post. Citing a report by BDO Stoy Hayward, problems such as stock swindles and profit-rigging have cropped up in increasing numbers, costing at least $2.7 billion.

headline: Manhattan Smells Like Mercaptan
text: UPDATE: New York’s Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg just held a press conference updating the known wisdom on the odor situation in New York City and parts of New Jersey. (More about that on our Empire Zone blog.)

headline: How the Mighty Have Fallen
text: Remember Zenith? It used to be one of America’s premiere television brands, along with Magnavox and RCA. The company invented the remote control and was part of an early experiment in pay TV back in the 1960s. When every other company was bought up by overseas rivals, Zenith prided itself on the fact it was still American-owned and American-made.

headline: Everything Is Networking
text: Do you want to be able to send pictures, music and movies around the house, from one PC, TV or stereo to another? Many major consumer electronics companies are convinced you do, judging by the number of networkable products that were discussed at yesterday’s CES press conferences.

headline: LCD vs. Plasma: And the Winner Is…
text: LCD may be winning the battle of the marketplace, but the industry has long known that its technology has come up short in a number of areas, when compared to plasma’s overall picture quality.

headline: TV in Your Car…at 80 Miles Per Hour
text: The great thing about digital broadcast television is that the picture looks perfect. The bad thing about digital broadcast television is that when the signal is too weak, you get absolutely nothing.

headline: It Gets Angry When You Drop It
text: Maybe I’ve been attending these events for too long, but there wasn’t much that impressed me at yesterday’s Digital Experience, a nighttime show-within-a-show here at CES. There were ho-hum digital picture frames, high-def TVs, new mobile phones and plenty of companies about to ask regular people to do incomprehensible things with home networks.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: A New Vaccination Timetable
SAC’s (Teddy) Bearish Investment
text: Who says hedge funds can’t be warm and fuzzy? SAC Capital, the large and secretive investment pool run by Steven A. Cohen, made a regulatory filing Monday disclosing that the fund and its affiliates owned a 5 percent stake in Build-a-Bear Workshop, a publicly traded company that sells custom-made plush toys such as the “Taking Care of Business” bear, which comes complete with two-piece suit and black briefcase.

headline: When Worlds Collide
text: The New York Film Critics Circle is an intimate affair, but both the Bagger and the Baguette graced the scene. Their talents divide nicely: the Bagger sits in the back row and comes up with the occasional swipe while the Baguette actually works, engaging in conversation that rare and delicate species, the Movie Star, and carefully transcribing their words. Here’s what she found:

headline: Inside Tigger’s Furry Brain
text: The Walt Disney Co., which is hoping that “Apocalypto’s” violence won’t put off the kudos crews, is dealing with some alleged mayhem elsewhere in the kingdom. Tigger, generally a friendly sort, allegedly clobbered some kid.

headline: Maybe If I’m Really Still, They Won’t See Me
text: You know who has the worst job at the Detroit Auto Show? No, it’s not the German Shepherds at the Cobo Hall gates who have to sniff-test automotive journalists all day. It’s the poor saps tasked with driving concept cars during introductions.

headline: UBS Names Chief of U.S. Brokerage Unit
text: Teresa Mullett Ressel was appointed chief executive of UBS Securities, the United States broker-dealer unit of UBS, the securities firm said Monday. The promotion comes as UBS, based in Switzerland, has been rearranging the executive suite at its North American business.
