In her new role, Ms. Ressel will report to the recently named chief executive and chairman of UBS Group Americas, Robert Wolf.

headline: Something in the Air: Meanwhile, Out West …
text: It’s freaky Monday. In Austin, authorities cleared a full 10 blocks of the downtown business district early this morning after “dozens of birds were found dead in the streets,” according to the Associated Press.

headline: Praise for Apple
text: John Sculley, the former CEO of Apple Computer from 1983 to 1993, may have gotten the boot from Steve Jobs, but hey, no hard feelings. Mr. Sculley had nothing but praise for the company and his former colleague.

headline: Everything Must Not Go!
text: At the introduction for the 2008 Porsche Cayenne this morning, Peter Schwarzenbauer, Porsche Cars North America president and chief executive, launched into an unprompted diatribe. He made one thing very clear: Porsche has no intention of ever using sales incentives!

headline: Keeping Count of Silicon Valley’s Casualties
text: Is Silicon Valley getting a bit too ghoulish? Fred Wilson, a well-known venture capitalist, seemed to suggest as much as he criticized the “dead pool” on TechCrunch, a closely watched blog that focuses on the technology business. Mr. Wilson’s comments came soon after TechCrunch’s editor, Michael Arrington, wrote that the number of entries in his dead pool has been growing more quickly and “startup ranks are starting to thin.”

headline: Out of Sync
text: Ford’s announcement on Sunday of its relationship with Microsoft drew a lot of “oohs” and “aahs” when journalists learned the automaker would enable music players, phones and smart devices to work seamlessly with in-car systems. But the big pizzazz on the Cobo Arena screen drew reactions of “Huh? Why them?” from some suppliers who are already providing such systems to automakers, and who have been connecting Bluetooth devices to vehicles for several years.Mega-supplier Johnson Controls, Inc. is one of them.

headline: Mulally Rhymes With Sally
text: Ever since he was named Ford chief executive in September, Alan R.Mulally’s name has been twisted in a number of ways. Some have saidMulay-lly (as in daily); others Mu-lahlly (as in dolly.) On Sunday, the announcer at Ford’s noontime news conference seemed to pronounce it Mu-lelly, as if it rhymed with nelly.

headline: Office Real-Estate Market Feels Wall Street Effect
text: Flush with record-breaking bonuses, investment bankers and hedge funders are said to be driving up demand for all kinds of luxury goods, including expensive cars and multimillion-dollar apartments. (Whether or not that is true is another story.) Now, Bloomberg News suggests that Wall Street’s very good year could be raising prices in another area: office space rents. The cost of renting commercial space in Manhattan has jumped by as much as 35 percent, according to reports by two commercial brokers, which Bloomberg traces in part to the expanding financial-services sector.

headline: The Story of Skin
text: Dr. Nina Jablonski says the human canvas offers something different and deeply personal for a world where fashions are mass produced.

headline: Romney Dials for 2008 Cash
text: BOSTON — Could things be changing in the way presidential candidates raise money?

headline: The Story of Skin: Vanity
text: Modern anthropologist Nina Jablonski says the work of cosmetologists may signify a leap forward in overcoming the ageist bias of our primate ancestors.

headline: Eliot in the Elephants’ Den
text: Nixon goes to China? Daniel in the Lion’s Den? Eliot in the Elephant’s Den? Governor Eliot Spitzer paid a visit today to the private conference that Republican State Senators held before going into session today.

headline: Porsche 101
text: In my ongoing attempt to rate the theatricality and effectiveness of the press conferences here, we can report that, unlike many of the manufacturers, Porsche decided that its audience of journalists might actually like to know some facts instead of being entertained by inane skits that a high-school drama teacher would give a failing grade to.

headline: HDTV Heavy
text: You know that HDTV has arrived when even CNN and The Weather Channel are converting to the high-resolution format.

headline: For Skadden’s Deal Lawyers, a Year to Remember
text: When the time came to hammer out legal issues in last year’s megadeals, chances are someone from Skadden Arps Slate Meagher and Flom was there. The New York-based law firm came in first place both in the United States and worldwide as an adviser on announced mergers and acquisitions, as measured by the combined transaction value, according to Thomson Financial‘s rankings.

headline: Blogtalk: Something in the Air
text: Gas fears in the gossip-sphere. [Gawker]

headline: Gap Said to Hire Goldman to Consider Options
text: Gap, the struggling clothes retailer, has hired Goldman Sachs to consider “strategic alternatives” for the company, CNBC and other news outlets reported Monday. An unnamed source told Reuters that Gap hired the investment bank last month, but it was unclear exactly what the bank was hired to do. Gap would not comment on the reports, but its stock surged more than 7 percent Monday to close at $20.26 amid speculation it might be up for sale.

headline: That R2 Unit Is a Real Bargain
text: From the same trade show that told us Bluetooth earpieces looked fashionable…

headline: New York, Austin and Now, Miami …
text: Uncracking the third seal of urban Armageddon today, a package that was destined to be loaded onto a cruise ship in Miami was determined thought to contain plastic explosives. “The package was tested six times and each time it came back positive for C4,” reported The Associated Press.

headline: Odor Mystery Persists
text: The investigation into the odd odor, which has dissipated, continues.

headline: Analysis From Alex Smith
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. — Perhaps few people know the offense that Florida will run in the Bowl Championship Series title game better than the former Utah quarterback Alex Smith.

headline: B.C.S. Final Tonight
text: Quick programming note: Join us during the B.C.S. title game at 8 Eastern tonight. John Woods, a Nebraska fan (remember when the Cornhuskers used to play in these big games, John?), will provide live tracking and commentary.

headline: Spitzer’s Sense of Smell
text: Up in Albany today, Gov. Eliot Spitzer did not appear overly concerned about the smell that obsessed Manhattan this morning.

headline: Insurgent TV
text: Video originally aired on Al Zawra, a banned Iraqi satellite television station.

headline: It’s the End of the World as We Know It
text: Waiting to be interviewed on Japanese television on Sunday, a New York-based editor wondered aloud what he might say to explain the show to an Asian audience. A former P.R. rep standing nearby volunteered this succinct summary:

headline: Express Scripts Takes Aim at Caremark’s Board
text: After failing to win over Caremark Rx with words, Express Scripts is trying some stronger medicine. Like it promised, the prescription benefits manager said Monday it would nominate four directors to the board of Caremark, the rival company that spurned its unsolicited, $26 billion merger offer. Caremark instead chose a $22.2 billion bid from drugstore chain CVS, a transaction Caremark said would generate fewer legal problems.

headline: Another Cuomo Taps Hynes
text: This time it is the son, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who has asked Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, to provide a thorough review of the attorney general’s Medicaid Fraud Control Unit, known by it vaguely rude-sounding abbreviation, M.F.C.U.A news release from the attorney general’s office says that Mr. Hynes launched the first state M.F.C.U. in the nation, and that he will oversee a team of four specialists who have been asked to submit their recommendations to Mr. Cuomo on Feb. 15.

headline: Dysfunction Junction
text: The Albany Project has started a wiki — TAPopedia — that aims to be a “complete database of information about the dysfunctional NYS government.”

headline: Eliot Works the Other House
text: Soon after his meeting with Senate Republicans, Gov. Eliot Spitzer appeared, to a standing ovation, in the State Assembly as it began to get down to businesses.

headline: Kimberly-Clark May Draw Buyout Interest, Analyst Says
text: It would be a tall order, but consumer products giant Kimberly-Clark could be a good candidate for a leveraged buyout, according to credit-research firm GimmeCredit, MarketWatch reports. With a market capitalization of about $31.6 billion, Kimberly-Clark would rank among the largest buyout targets ever. Though it acknowledged that size could be a deterrent, GimmeCredit said Kimberly-Clark’s relatively low price-to-earnings ratio could attract buyout firms.

headline: Tales From the Crypt
text: The second day of my second year here and I just found out there was a basement. It’s the home of the “not ready for prime time exhibits.” It’s the auto show equivalent of the World’s Largest Ball of Twine or the Museum of Subway Odors.

headline: The War at Home: Bush and Congress
text: Well, it would seem that the first 100 hours agenda in Congress could use a stopwatch, with President Bush about to take the stage on Wednesday to tell the public about his way forward. All else on the agenda will become background material.

headline: What the Weatherman Knew
text: As a reader pointed out earlier today, the strength and duration of the mysterious gas-like odor in Manhattan – but not the odor itself – may have been caused by a weather phenomenon known as a temperature inversion.Inversions, which often occur when a warm front moves over a cooler, denser air mass, cause the temperature closer to the ground to be cooler and the air higher up to be warmer – a reversal of the usual pattern. Inversions can effectively trap pollutants and odors, preventing them from being dispersed upward.

headline: Springtime in January
text: If I had a nickel for every time someone asked me if I wanted to rethink our plan to build in Florida, in light of the pleasant weather we are experiencing in the Northeast, I would have had a lot of nickels.

headline: Amid the Loud Bugle Calls, the Workers are Awakened
text: There’s a little bit of everything down stairs at Cobo Hall. I intended to write about the good, the bad and the ugly at the Detroit Auto Show. But I didn’t count on was spending most of my time down in the basement watching the Changfeng Motors “Image Propaganda Film.”

headline: The Year of the Healthy American
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 1 column, “A Healthy New Year.”

headline: Additional Information for January 5 Column
text: Here are the information sources for my Jan. 5 column.

headline: Let the Iraqis Be
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 3 column, “A Hanging and a Funeral.”

headline: Blood Oil
text: “In America it’s bling bling, but out here it’s bling bang,” says Leonardo DiCaprio’s character in the movie “Blood Diamond,” explaining how diamonds on American fingers play a role in conflict and death in Africa. Thanks to this film, diamonds are the taboo commodity of the moment — “All who touch it are left with blood on their hands,” intones the voice-over in the preview.

headline: Another Puzzled Conservative
text: One of the most frustrating things about being a conservative these days is suffering from both sides in the debate about George W. Bush. As soon as one admits to being conservative, one is assumed to be a supporter of the administration. It takes a lot of effort to explain why almost nothing this administration has done is “conservative” by the standards of what conservatism has meant historically.

headline: The Senate on Ethics
text: Democratic Senators Russ Feingold of Wisconsin and Barack Obama of Illinois announced a series of proposals on ethics reform today, and trotted out for support several of the new Senate freshmen who campaigned (in part) on anti-corruption measures in the wake of the Abramoff lobbying scandal. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, in calling ethics reform the Senate’s first order of business, likened the breadth of the proposals to those passed after Watergate.

headline: Swag of the Day: Bongos
text: Don’t tell Matthew McConaughey, but right now Cobo Hall contains more bongo drums than you can shake a patchouli-scented tie-dyed Peter Tosh tee-shirt at. DaimlerChrysler is the party responsible for the bongo outbreak, having distributed the drums at the introduction for the Chrysler Nassau and Jeep Trailhawk concept S.U.V.s. Since I didn’t go to the press conference, I can only speculate on the relationship between bongos and the Nassau and Trailhawk, neither of which seem particularly geared toward hippies.

headline: Join the Toyota Marketing Machine
text: We all know that Toyota is on a roll in terms of strong sales, great profits and all around global domination of the car world. But now the Japanese auto giant has gone one step further, turning journalists and auto enthusiasts into marketing pawns for the new Toyota Tundra pickup.

headline: Bloomberg Criticizes Security Fund Distribution
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg criticized the way federal antiterrorism money is distributed, testifying today at a crowded Senate hearing that New York City had been shortchanged compared with other cities, given too little money for bioterrorism preparedness and denied financing to upgrade its communication systems.

headline: Bolivia Leader Lets Venezuela Send Soldiers, Angering Foes
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 8 — Political opponents of President Evo Morales of Bolivia have in recent days stepped up criticism of the country’s strengthening military relationship with Venezuela after Bolivian officials acknowledged that more than two dozen uniformed members of the Venezuelan military had recently entered the country without congressional approval.

headline: Movement to Change the Bowl System Starts at the Top
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 8 — San Francisco 49ers quarterback Alex Smith watched Boise State’s upset of Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl last week and again felt a pinch of regret.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Tuesday about Wal-Mart’s struggle to market a long-lasting, energy-saving light bulb known as a compact fluorescent lamp misstated the time period in which the retailer sold 40 million of the bulbs compared with about 350 million incandescent bulbs. It was from August 2005 to August 2006  not in 2005.

headline: Brown Returns to the N.B.A. With a Smile
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 — Larry Brown, whose dream job of coaching the Knicks turned into a nightmare last season and led to a hiatus from the N.B.A., resurfaced with the Philadelphia 76ers on Monday, looking relaxed, offering a smile and saying that he had no immediate plans to return to coaching.

headline: State Farm in Talks to Settle Gulf Claims
text: State Farm, the biggest home insurer in the nation, is in the final stages of settling hundreds of lawsuits over its payments for homes wrecked by Hurricane Katrina along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, lawyers briefed on the talks said yesterday.

headline: Manhattan: Former Union Leader Sentenced
text: The former manager of a pension fund for New York City’s main union of school bus drivers, who pleaded guilty last August to obstructing justice, was sentenced yesterday to five months in prison and five months of home confinement. Judge Kimba Wood of Federal District Court sentenced the former manager, Ann Chiarovano. The union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, has been placed in trusteeship, and Salvatore Battaglia, its president, has pleaded not guilty to federal charges of extortion, bribery and cooperating with the Genovese crime family.

headline: Borrowing Rose in November
text: Borrowing by United States households rose in November by the most in three months as Americans loaded up on credit card debt to purchase gifts at the start of the holiday shopping season.

headline: Common Sense on the Census
text: Last November, the director of the Census Bureau, C. Louis Kincannon, and the deputy director, Hermann Habermann, abruptly decided to quit, acknowledging tensions with their bosses in the Bush administration but giving no other details. Both men are statisticians who had served in their positions since 2002 and, before that, had decades of experience as civil servants.

headline: Text of Corzine’s State of the State Address
text: Following is the text of Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s State of the State address as prepared for delivery today in Trenton.

headline: New Congress, Older Look
text: The winds of change have blown through the 110th Congress, but only to a point. There are more women (90) and, obviously, more Democrats. But according to the Congressional Research Service, the average age of lawmakers in the new Congress is possibly the oldest in history. The average age of senators is 61.7 — two years older than in the previous Congress. The oldest senator is Robert C. Byrd, 89, Democrat of West Virginia, and the youngest is John E. Sununu, 42, Republican of New Hampshire. The average age of representatives is 55.9, with Ralph M. Hall, Republican of Texas, the oldest at 83, and Patrick T. McHenry, Republican of North Carolina, the youngest at 31. More demographics: there are more Protestants than any other religious affiliation, but Roman Catholics account for the largest single religious denomination.

headline: Albany: Bloomberg Aide Urges Judicial Overhaul
text: Citing an “unprecedented” crisis of confidence in the state’s judiciary, the New York City corporation counsel, Michael A. Cardozo, yesterday urged quick reform of the state’s judicial selection process at a State Senate hearing. Last year, a federal appeals court found that the nominating system for electing State Supreme Court justices was unconstitutional, and imposed an interim process of direct primary elections. Mr. Cardozo, representing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, suggested changes to the nominating conventions rather than the use of open primaries in choosing judicial candidates. He also urged that independent commissions be used to weigh Supreme Court candidates’ qualifications.

headline: Blasts From the Bebop Past of an Elusive Trumpeter
text: Disappearing acts are not uncommon in jazz, but Dizzy Reece is an extreme case. A Jamaican-born trumpeter who first made his name in London in the mid-1950s, Mr. Reece briefly enjoyed a reputation as a formidable voice in hard bop. He made four strong albums for Blue Note in the Eisenhower era, three with top-shelf American rhythm sections. But then came a period of struggle, followed by unexplained oblivion. For much of the last 40 years, Mr. Reece has essentially led a nonpublic life.

headline: Middle School: It's, Like, Awkward (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Germany: Manufacturing Orders Rise
text: Manufacturing orders rose for the first time in three months in November, led by an increase in demand for trucks and cars. Orders, adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation, rose 1.5 percent from October, when they declined 0.7 percent, the Economy and Technology Ministry said. The figure for October factory orders was revised up from an initially reported decline of 1.1 percent. Domestic orders gained 0.6 percent in November, and foreign orders rose 2.3 percent. Demand for consumer goods advanced 2.7 percent.

headline: Drew Is a Red Sox in Waiting ... and Waiting
text: J. D. Drew could not be reached for comment yesterday. He changed his telephone number or had a problem with his phone service, because the automated message said his number had been disconnected or was not in service.

headline: Two Elected to Hall of Fame; McGwire Misses
text: Cal Ripken Jr. was the iron man who played in 2,632 consecutive games, Tony Gwynn was the hitting machine who won eight batting titles and yesterday both were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in near-unanimous votes that reflected their standing within the sport. But their achievement was overshadowed by the voters’ rejection of Mark McGwire, a slugger who seemed like a modern-day Paul Bunyan before he fell into disrepute because of suspected steroid use.

headline: Retrofitting Operetta for a 21st-Century Crowd
text: Here’s a “Jeopardy!” answer: it’s a musical genre that features pointed, witty texts; catchy tunes; strong music; and cutting-edge visuals, presented in an intimate setting.

headline: Mazda’s Chapter Two Rakes the Garden
text: Introduced on Monday: Mazda Ryuga design study

headline: Nutrition: So Now You’re What Your Children Eat?
text: Adults who live with children eat more fat, and more saturated fat, than those who do not, according to a new study.

headline: South Korea: Samsung Forecast
text: The Samsung Electronics Company forecast record profit from consumer electronics this year, helped by television sales. Profit this year from the digital media division, including earnings from overseas affiliates, will probably exceed 1 trillion won ($1.1 billion) for the first time, Choi Gee Sung, president of the division, said in a statement. Samsung plans to sell 11 million L.C.D. televisions in 2007, up from 6.2 million units last year, the company said. Samsung, which is based in Suwon, South Korea, also forecast its shipments of plasma TVs to rise to 2.5 million units this year, compared with 1.3 million sets in 2006.

headline: Yet Another Worry for Those Who Believe the Glass Is Half-Empty
A Mother Helped the Homeless. Then She Joined Them.
text: It was like going through the looking glass. Not long ago, Brenda Francis, who had worked in shelters helping the homeless, found her world turned upside down when she and her teenage son, Bryant Dukes, were suddenly left without a home.

headline: Reins Off, French Retailers Rush to Buy TV Time
text: FRANCE may never be a nation of shopkeepers, but on television, at least, the country’s retailers are no longer getting a frosty reception.

headline: Spitzer Orders Sharp Cuts in Cost of Prisoner Phone Calls
text: ALBANY, Jan. 8 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer struck an early blow at the policies of his predecessor on Monday, sharply reducing steep Pataki-era charges that relatives and friends of inmates in New York State’s prisons have had to pay on collect telephone calls from them.

headline: Patriots, Hitting the Road, Will Run Into Tomlinson
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 8 — After the New England Patriots throttled the Jets on Sunday, 37-16, someone asked Patriots linebacker Tedy Bruschi if the Patriots took their game to another level during the playoffs.

headline: Mr. Noodle
text: The news last Friday of the death of the ramen noodle guy surprised those of us who had never suspected that there was  such an individual. It was easy to assume that instant noodle soup was a team invention, one of those depersonalized corporate miracles, like the Honda Civic, the Sony Walkman and Hello Kitty, that sprang from that ingenious consumer-product collective known as postwar Japan.

headline: Reagan Lawyer Ready to Return to White House
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — President Bush has chosen Fred F. Fielding as the new chief White House lawyer, adding to his team a longtime Washington legal hand and veteran of the post.

headline: Newark: Youth Worker Charged With Abuse
text: Investigators for the Essex County prosecutor have arrested an Irvington man who worked for a youth program financed by the state and charged him with molesting an 11-year-old girl whose family he befriended. The man, Lawrence Tyler, 56, worked for the Youth Advocacy Program, a private agency that has a state contract. He was arrested at his home late Friday night and charged with five counts of sexual assault and five counts of endangering the welfare of a child, said Mark Ali, director of the county’s Child Abuse Unit. Mr. Tyler had been working for the girl’s uncle, Mr. Ali said.

headline: A New Video Posted on Web Shows Hussein After His Death
text: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, Jan. 9 — A graphic new video of Saddam Hussein’s dead body, apparently taken shortly after he was hanged, was posted on the Internet on Tuesday by a group sympathetic to the former dictator.

headline: California Plan for Health Care Would Cover All
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 — Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Monday proposed extending health care coverage to all of California’s 36 million residents as part of a sweeping package of changes to the state’s huge, troubled health care system.

headline: Dance of the Continents
Yahoo Introduces Mobile Service Software
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 — After falling behind Google in Internet search and advertising, Yahoo is trying to remain No. 1 in the battle to deliver information and online services to mobile phones.

headline: 9/11 Associate Is Sentenced in Germany to 15 Years
text: FRANKFURT, Jan. 8 — A German court on Monday sentenced a friend of the Sept. 11 hijackers to 15 years in prison for being an accessory in the murders of 246 people aboard the commercial planes used in the terrorist attacks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Strands of Undesirable DNA Roam With Buffalo
text: MALTA, Mont. — The animals certainly looked like bison, with the characteristic humps and beards. But just to make sure, a pick-up truck slowly rolled up to them, and a bison wrangler shot a drug-filled dart into one of several calves.

headline: Louisville Looks to Tulsa to Fill Coaching Opening
text: Louisville is courting Tulsa Coach Steve Kragthorpe to replace Bobby Petrino as the Cardinals’ football coach.

headline: The Viennese Way (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Always Revealing, Human Skin Is an Anthropologist’s Map
text: In an era of academic hyper-specialization, Dr. Nina G. Jablonski has an amazingly broad résumé. At 53, she heads the anthropology department at Pennsylvania State University. She’s also a primatologist, an evolutionary biologist and a paleontologist.

headline: Hussein’s Voice Speaks in Court in Praise of Chemical Atrocities
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 8 — The courtroom he dominated for 15 months seemed much smaller on Monday without him there to mock the judges and assert his menacing place in history.

headline: Fissures Grow on Eve of Bush Speech on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- On the eve of President Bush’s planned speech on Iraq, both the White House and a prominent Democratic critic of the president said the United States was at a decisive moment, not just in Iraq but in American history.

headline: U.S. Warns Europe on Air Travel Emissions Rules
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 9 — A senior American diplomat warned the European Commission today against adopting rules that would impose emissions controls on all commercial flights to and within Europe.

headline: Push to End Use of Private Debt Collectors by U.S.
text: The national taxpayer advocate called on Congress today to repeal the authority it gave the Internal Revenue Service to use private debt collectors.

headline: Early Rout Is Challenge to Fox Team
text: Fox Sports’s first year of carrying Bowl Championship Series games has hardly been the happy collegiate football tortilla chip bash it intended when it acquired a four-year package of the Fiesta, Orange and Sugar Bowls, and the newly added national championship game, for $320 million.

headline: Kazakhstan: Prime Minister Steps Down
text: Prime Minister Daniyal Akhmetov resigned. Long considered an influential ally of the powerful president, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, who appointed him to the post in 2003, Mr. Akhmetov has lately come under public criticism from Mr. Nazarbayev for poor oversight of the economy. Mr. Nazarbayev, who has been Kazakhstan’s president since its inception as an oil-rich independent state in 1991, is known for frequently replacing members of his cabinet.

headline: Democrats Push for Changes to No Child Left Behind Law
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Democratic Congressional leaders on Monday called President Bush’s signature education law too punitive in its sanctions on public schools and pledged to increase educational spending, signaling the stance they will take this year in negotiations over the law’s renewal.

headline: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — The new Democratic majority in Congress is divided over how to assert its power in opposing President Bush’s plan to send more troops to Baghdad, as leaders explore ways to block financing for a military expansion without being accused of abandoning American forces already in Iraq.

headline: Paterson: Reward Offered in Officer’s Shooting
text: The Paterson police said yesterday that a reward for information about a man who fatally shot an off-duty police officer Sunday morning has been increased to more than $40,000 from an initial $1,000. The officer, Tyron D. Franklin, 23, was killed shortly after 1 a.m. in what the police said was a holdup at Broadway Fried Chicken. The extra money is being offered by a combination of foundations and private donors, the police said. Detectives have interviewed several witnesses and the police said yesterday that the shooting might be linked to a surge in robberies.

headline: The Ungulate Effect on an Ecosystem
text: In studies of the ripple effects of animals on an ecosystem, carnivores are the celebrities. Researchers have given the most attention to the impact these top predators have on the animals, plants and insects beneath them in the food chain, what’s termed a trophic cascade.

headline: McGwire Unlikely for Hall of Fame
text: When the results of Baseball’s Hall of Fame balloting are announced at 2 p.m. today, Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn will surely be smiling. Goose Gossage and Jim Rice have a chance to join them. But Mark McGwire is not likely to exhibit that same happy emotion.

headline: Exercise: Surfing, It Seems, Is Safer Than Some Sports
text: It may be safer to go surfing than to play college football, soccer or basketball, according to a six-year study of professional and amateur surfing competitions.

headline: Newark: A Former Mayor Admits Bribes
text: Joseph C. Scarpelli, left, the former mayor of Brick Township, pleaded guilty to bribery and conspiracy charges yesterday in Federal District Court, officials announced. Mr. Scarpelli, 67, admitted that he accepted and agreed to accept cash payments from an unnamed real estate developer, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Scarpelli said he received $5,000 in payments, Mr. Christie said. Mr. Scarpelli is free on $50,000 bail and faces 24 to 30 months in jail at sentencing, set for May 29.

headline: French, With a Twist of Wagner
text: It is hard to say why works that were once staples of the concert repertory lose popularity. A good example is César Franck’s Symphony in D minor. This once ubiquitous work was the focus of the conductor Leon Botstein’s concert with the American Symphony Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: More Races and Extra Day Are Added to Breeders’ Cup
text: Looking to expand the Breeders’ Cup and broaden its appeal, the organizers of the series announced yesterday that three races have been added to the event and that it will be held over two days.

headline: Bush’s Task: Thrusting New Strategy on ‘a Sovereign Nation’
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  It’s a refrain that President Bush and his top deputies have uttered many times over:

headline: Man Is Found Fatally Shot on Brooklyn Street
text: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot yesterday evening, two blocks from his home in Flatbush, the police said.

headline: Stern Likes His New Censor: Himself
text: Howard Stern, who today marks his first anniversary on satellite radio, wasted little time over that period before setting off on an expedition deep into the wild, forested territories of a medium patrolled by neither the Federal Communications Commission nor, apparently, his own employer.

headline: Restoring a Mud-Brick Tribute to a Departed Egyptian King
text: Before the great pyramids, ancient Egyptian kings left less grandiose monuments to themselves: fortresslike sanctuaries enclosed by mud-brick walls. Inside these mortuary complexes, people presumably gathered to worship and perpetuate the memory of their departed ruler.

headline: Home Court Helps Badger Guard Come of Age
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 8  The backyard court where Wisconsin guard Kammron Taylor learned his harshest basketball lessons is gone. Taylor’s father, Kenneth, took down the basket about three years ago, and it hangs, faded and rusty, inside their garage.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Jan. 1 about Gov’t Mule and Los Lobos, at the Beacon Theater, misstated the surname of a member of Los Lobos. He is Cesar Rosas, not Rojas.

headline: New York Given High Marks for Laws to Reduce Smoking
text: New York ranks second in the nation in the strength of its antitobacco laws, and New Jersey and Connecticut are also well above average, according to a report to be released today by the American Lung Association.

headline: When the Fur Flies
text: Increasing numbers of people are taking pets on business trips. But imagine the challenge when the animal is not the typical dog or cat.

headline: In Lobster Land, a Whale-Friendly Proposal
text: A threat to endangered North Atlantic right whales posed by dense arrays of lobster traps, lines and floating buoys off the coast of Maine could be greatly reduced without hurting profits if boats switch to fishing patterns that are the norm in nearby Nova Scotia, according to a study by Canadian and American researchers. The Maine lobster season is year-round, but Canadian lobstermen with far fewer traps have similar catches with a 180-day season, said the authors of the study, published in the journal Current Biology. They said Canadian lobster boats also had lower costs for fuel and bait. The executive director of the Maine Lobstermen’s Association told The Associated Press that almost all traps were set in waters not frequented by the whales.

headline: Indonesia: Boy Has Bird Flu; 6 Others Tested
text: A new human cluster of avian flu cases could be emerging in a suburb of the capital, Jakarta, according to Indonesian news reports. One case of H5N1 flu, the country’s 75th, was confirmed by the Health Ministry over the weekend; it was in a 14-year-old boy who had reportedly buried a flock of backyard ducks that died suddenly. He was alive but using a respirator to breathe. A local radio station and news outlets said six other people from the same town  at least three of them related to him  were hospitalized with flu symptoms in Jakarta, being treated with Tamiflu and awaiting test results. Indonesia has failed to get its poultry epidemic under control since it emerged in 2005.

headline: It’s Detroit, but Accents Are Foreign
text: DETROIT, Jan. 8 — The auto show in Detroit has always been something of a living time capsule. The cars may change, but the auto companies, their place in the universe, and the faces here always seemed to remain the same.

headline: Paying in Pollution for Energy Hunger
text: BAHARBARI, India — A toxic purple haze of diesel exhaust hangs over the rice and jute fields here in northeastern India, and bird songs are frequently drowned out by the chug-a-chug-a-chug of diesel generators.

headline: 31 Ex-Prosecutors Join Effort to Overturn 1990 Conviction of L.I. Man in Murder of Parents
text: The campaign to overturn the conviction of a Long Island man for the murders of his parents has gained a very unusual group of supporters: 31 former federal, state and local prosecutors.

headline: In Effort to Cut Homicide Rate, Newark Mayor Creates Narcotics Unit
text: NEWARK, Jan. 8 — Mayor Cory A. Booker and his police director announced the formation of a new narcotics division on Monday to try to reduce the city’s stubbornly high homicide rate, firmly linking the illegal drug trade to the persistent violence.

headline: White Plains: Group Says County Fails on Housing
text: A fair-housing group accused Westchester County yesterday of failing to pressure towns to accept more low-cost housing as a way to reduce racial segregation. In a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the group, the Anti-Discrimination Center of Metro New York, said the county had neither tracked towns’ efforts to bring in housing for lower-income people nor penalized those that did nothing. The group said the county was obliged, in return for federal funds, to take steps to “further fair housing.” Norma Drummond, the county’s deputy planning commissioner, denied the charges. She said that 751 units of low-cost housing had been built since 2000, often with county help, and that 1,174 more units were planned.

headline: At Jaguar, Out With the Old, In With the Bold
text: Introduced on Sunday: Jaguar C-XF design study

headline: A Rotten Smell Raises Alarms and Questions
text: It was the odor associated with natural gas  the telltale, unpleasant sulfur scent that typically signals a gas leak. But this time, it was lingering in many areas of Manhattan and northeastern New Jersey, coursing through buildings and leading to fears that it could ignite or that a dangerous chemical had been deliberately released.

headline: The Coming Escalation in Iraq (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kraft Takes a Charge for a Poor-Selling Coffee Machine
text: Kraft Foods said yesterday that weaker-than-projected sales of its Tassimo single-serve coffee-brewing machines led to a noncash charge of $245 million in the fourth quarter.

headline: Brooklyn Man, 38, Dies After Jolt From Police Taser
text: The day after a disturbed man died after being shocked with a Taser stun gun in Queens by a police sergeant, a city police official yesterday provided a fuller account of the moments before the man apparently went into cardiac arrest.

headline: Express Scripts Moves to Derail a Merger
text: EXPRESS SCRIPTS opened a proxy war in the pharmacy benefits industry yesterday, moving to derail the pending acquisition of its rival Caremark Rx by the drugstore chain CVS.

headline: Arrest of Activist Troubles Hartford Officials
text: HARTFORD, Jan. 8 — The arrest of a political activist and freelance journalist at the inaugural parade of Gov. M. Jodi Rell last week has raised questions about a state law enforcement list of people who pose potential threats to the government.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review on Thursday about the exhibition “South Bronx Contemporary: Longwood Arts Project’s 25th Anniversary,” at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, omitted a curator. The wall of art hung salon-style was organized by Edwin Ramoran under the title “Everyday Is Like Sunday”; it is not part of “Iconoclasm,” organized by Eddie Torres and hanging in the same room.

headline: Clearing the Air
text: Speaker Nancy Pelosi is poised to extinguish one of the last true perquisites of House service: the right to smoke just off the floor in an area known as the Speaker’s Lobby. Lawmakers and aides say they expect that Mrs. Pelosi will soon use the substantial powers of her new office to bar smokers from the lobby and force them outside. Opponents of smoking have complained about the practice for years. The impact of the change will be bipartisan; members of both parties regularly enjoy cigarettes and cigars as they relax in the lobby’s leather chairs between votes. The highest ranking smoker is Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio and the minority leader, who was perhaps anticipating the change when he headed to an outer balcony last week for a quick cigarette. Ever defiant, some smokers said they would still light up in their personal offices.

headline: An Escalation of American Blood
text: A surge in the number of troops in Iraq might have helped in 2003 or early 2004.

headline: Computers Join Actors in Hybrids On Screen
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 — James Cameron, the director whose “Titanic” set a record for ticket sales around the world, will join 20th Century Fox in tackling a similarly ambitious and costly film, “Avatar,” which will test new technologies on a scale unseen before in Hollywood, the studio and the filmmaker said on Monday.

headline: I’ll Have Fries and a Glass of Your Best Champagne
text: AT a recent wine tasting in Napa, Calif., my hosts made a tragic mistake: They served a big zinfandel with warm apple pie for dessert. The sweet pie stripped the fruit flavors from the wine, leaving us with mouthfuls of what tasted like tannic water.

headline: Many Chances to Be a Hero in New York
text: For the last week, New Yorkers have thrilled to the heroics of Wesley Autrey, Julio Gonzalez and Pedro Nevarez — profiles in courage, all. Mr. Autrey risked his life to rescue a young man who had tumbled from a subway platform into the path of an oncoming train. Messrs. Gonzalez and Nevarez caught a little boy who fell from a fourth-floor fire escape.

headline: Thailand Tightens Foreign Investment Laws
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 9 — Thailand pressed ahead today with a long-debated tightening of its foreign investment laws, ignoring warnings that the move could damage the country’s fragile economy at a time when it is already struggling to overcome the stigma of a recent military coup and a wave of bombings in Bangkok.

headline: Totals
Don't Play With Maps
text: Washington

headline: Iranian Leader Vows to Resist U.N. Sanctions
text: TEHRAN, Jan. 8 — Iran’s supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Monday that Iran would not back down from developing its nuclear program, despite sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Council last month.

headline: When 510 Horsepower Just Isn’t Enough, Go For 600!
text: Introduced on Tuesday: 2008 Dodge Viper SRT10

headline: Decisions on the Horizon
text: Don’t look for presidential announcements from Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton anytime soon, but stay tuned.

headline: Dispute Over Bus Fare Ends in Stabbing in New Jersey
text: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan 9 — It should have been just another routine bus ride. Passengers boarded the No. 34 bus on Monday evening at Newark’s Pennsylvania Station, paid their fare and sat down. But as the bus entered East Orange, en route to Montclair, an argument about a zone fare erupted between the driver and a passenger who eventually wound up with a knife in his shoulder.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about announcements by Sony and Microsoft regarding sales of their latest game consoles carried an incorrect dateline. The reporter was in San Francisco  not Las Vegas, where the announcements were made at the Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: Man Gets 30 Years in Subway Bomb Plot
text: A federal judge sentenced a 24-year-old Pakistani immigrant yesterday to 30 years in prison for plotting to bomb the Herald Square subway station in 2004, moments after the defendant apologized to the judge and prosecutors but blamed a police informer for his fate.

headline: Duke President Renews Call for District Attorney to Leave Case
text: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 8 — The president of Duke University renewed his call on Monday for the district attorney to step aside from the sexual offense case against three former lacrosse players and give control to an independent party “who can restore confidence in the fairness of the process.”

headline: A Rogue Wave Hits Nissan
text: Introduced on Sunday: 2008 Nissan Rogue

headline: Romania: a Bid for Dracula’s Castle
text: Dracula’s castle may sell for 60 million euros ($78 million) after the local government offered to buy the Transylvanian fortress to increase tourism revenue. The Brasov County Council in central Romania is in talks with a foreign bank on a 10-year loan for that amount to get back the castle from its current owners living abroad, Aristotel Cancescu, president of the municipality, said in a telephone interview. Built in 1212 by Teutonic knights, the castle was briefly used two centuries later by the Romanian ruler Vlad the Impaler, who inspired Bram Stoker’s legend of Count Dracula. The castle’s current owners are Dominic von Habsburg, an industrial designer who lives in New York, and his sisters, Elisabeth Sandhofer and Maria-Magdalena Holzhausen, who both live in Austria.

headline: Momofuku Ando, 96, Dies; Invented Instant Ramen
text: Momofuku Ando, who — to the delight of dormitory students and other kitchen-resistant customers worldwide — invented those small packets of preflavored dried noodles that require just a three-minute boil, died Friday at a hospital in Osaka, Japan. Mr. Ando, the founder of the Nissin Food Products Company, was 96.

headline: The Claim:  Hot Leftovers Should Cool at Room Temperature
text: THE FACTS What to do with leftovers? One common bromide is that leftovers stored in the refrigerator must be allowed to cool first at room temperature.

headline: Second Church Official Resigns in Poland
text: WARSAW, Jan. 8 — The Roman Catholic Church in Poland was in turmoil on Monday as a second prelate stepped down because of his Communist-era secret police ties, after Sunday’s resignation of this city’s archbishop over similar allegations.

headline: Newark: Hockey Arena to Be Named for Prudential
text: Newark’s new hockey arena will be called the Prudential Center under an agreement announced yesterday by the New Jersey Devils and Prudential Financial Inc., the Newark-based financial services company. Prudential will pay about $100 million over 20 years under the terms of the agreement. The 18,000-seat, $375 million arena is scheduled to open in the fall.

headline: Bronx: Search for Missing Baby
text: The police said they were searching yesterday for an infant boy whose mother reported him missing about 1:30 p.m. at Jacobi Hospital Medical Center. The woman, 28, whose identity was not released, first reported that a man had held a hard object to her back and abducted her son while she was outside the hospital, the police said, but they determined that there had been no abduction.

headline: Albany: More Teachers Meet State Requirement
text: The number of public school teachers who met the “highly qualified” standard required under the federal No Child Left Behind Law increased last year, Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, said yesterday. The law requires that teachers have at least a bachelor’s degree, meet state certification requirements and demonstrate knowledge in the subject they teach. State rules require teachers to have a degree in the subject they are certified to teach. In 2005-6, 4.9 percent of English classes in the state were taught by a teacher who failed to meet the requirement, compared with 8.7 percent in 2004-5, Mr. Mills said. The same statistic for math teachers dropped to 5.7 percent from 7.9 percent, he said.

headline: Buckeyes’ Big Return Is Quickly Forgotten
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 8 — The Ohio State Buckeyes took turns tackling one another in the back of the end zone, a dog pile that was as raucous as it was premature.

headline: Screen All Pregnancies for Down Syndrome, Doctors Say
text: For decades, pregnant women 35 and older have routinely been tested for chromosomal abnormalities that might affect their fetus, most notably Down syndrome. Younger women were tested much less often because the risk of birth defects was low and invasive procedures like amniocentesis carried risks of their own.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Alderman Arrested
text: A Chicago alderman who is running for re-election was arrested on federal bribery charges, the authorities said. Prosecutors say an undercover investigation revealed that the alderman, Arenda Troutman, accepted a $5,000 cash bribe and agreed to accept $10,000 more, as well as a $5,000 political contribution, in exchange for using her office to support zoning changes on behalf of a private developer  a developer that was, in fact, a fictitious entity set up as part of the investigation. Bond for Ms. Troutman was set at $10,000. She plans to plead not guilty, her lawyer told The Associated Press.

headline: Gap Is Said to Explore Selling Itself
text: Gap, the casual clothing chain that turned staples like T-shirts into must-have fashions and spawned scores of imitators that nibbled away at its business, is exploring a sale of the company, people briefed on the matter said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Strikes Insurgents in Fierce Battle in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 9 — More than 1,000 American and Iraqi troops, backed by Apache attack helicopters and F-18 fighter jets, battled insurgents all day Tuesday and late into the night in downtown Baghdad, in one of the most dramatic operations in the capital since the invasion nearly four years ago.

headline: Britain: Diana Inquest Judge Wants Ordinary Jurors
text: Lady Butler-Sloss, the judge presiding over the inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, said at a preliminary hearing that she had not yet decided whether to convene a jury to hear the case. But she said that in any case it would be “inappropriate” to empanel a jury made up of members of the royal household, as is the usual custom in deaths that involve the royal family. The inquest  whose purpose is to determine the identity of the deceased and the time, place and manner of death  has been delayed by, among other things, long investigations by France and Britain. In a report released last month, the British police concluded that the car crash that killed Diana in Paris in 1997 was a result of an accident caused by a drunk driver, and that it was not a murderous conspiracy. Lady Butler-Sloss said she hoped to schedule the full inquest for the beginning of May at the latest.

headline: Mysteries of the Brain and the Science of Sleep, Brought to Life in a Barn
text: EAST BURKE, Vt. — Amber Powers, 13, thought about sleep only when she didn’t get enough, which was most of the time. A trip to a remote barn here, however, left her spending many of her waking hours mulling over the time she spends sleeping.

headline: Remedies: Small Study Raises a Question About Echinacea
text: Some people take echinacea supplements in the hope that they will prevent or shorten colds, but a small study suggests that it may increase the number of intestinal bacteria associated with diarrhea, inflammatory bowel disease and an increased risk of colon cancer.

headline: Falcons Introduce Petrino as Their New Head Coach
text: The Atlanta Falcons are gambling that Bobby Petrino will have more success than recent college coaches who have jumped to the N.F.L. Petrino, 45, was introduced yesterday as the Falcons’ head coach after an impressive four-year run at Louisville.

headline: Past Time to Get Real on Iraq
text: We’ve been down this road before. This time, it has to be different.

headline: Killing Stirs Racial Concerns in North Woods of Wisconsin
text: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8 — Law enforcement officials said Monday that a Hmong hunter found dead Saturday in northern Wisconsin had been murdered after an “accidental meeting” between the victim and another small game hunter.

headline: Gergiev’s Opus: A New Concert Hall
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — When Daniel Barenboim announced almost three years ago that he would leave the Chicago Symphony, one reason he gave was that music directors of American orchestras have too many “nonartistic” responsibilities. Fund-raising is chief among them, but conductors are also expected to be community leaders, educators and shrewd business leaders.

headline: Bush Drops Plans to Nominate 3 U.S. Judges
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — In an apparent effort to lower the temperature in the fierce battle over federal judges — and in a concession to political reality — - President Bush said today that he was dropping plans to nominate three of his choices for the federal appeals courts who have been vigorously opposed by Senate Democrats.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief report on Thursday about Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a freshman New York State senator, in an article about the opening session of the State Legislature, misstated the number of new senators taking office and referred imprecisely to the historical significance of Ms. Stewart-Cousins’ election. Counting Ms. Stewart-Cousins, there are seven new senators; she is not the only one. She is one of a few candidates in recent years to have won by defeating an incumbent; more commonly, newcomers win by running for open seats.

headline: Dell Founder Wants to Offset Energy Consumption
text: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 9 — Michael S. Dell, who made his name building computers, has a new goal: planting trees.

headline: Leak Justifies Hype and Finishes With a Flourish
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 8 — Through the first 50 games of his college career, Chris Leak was a disappointment.

headline: Investigations Dim Luster of New Jersey Political Star
text: TRENTON, Jan. 8 — It has already been a long descent for State Senator Wayne R. Bryant.

headline: Married or Not, Gay Couple Are Ruled Legally Separated
text: A gay couple may have been mistaken in thinking they were legally married, but they still have to honor the terms of their separation agreement, which is the equivalent of any other type of contract, a judge in New York City has ruled.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about marines charged in the killing of 24 Iraqis in the village of Haditha in November 2005 misidentified the Pennyslvania hometown of one marine because of information provided by his lawyer. The marine, Lance Cpl. Justin Sharratt, is from Canonsburg, not Carbondale. (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 6 and Dec. 22.)

headline: Worried About Jobs (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paying the Price While Coaches Cash In
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.

headline: Conflict Over Oil in Belarus Recalls Ukraine’s Dispute With Moscow
text: Top stories from Russian newspapers today:

headline: Giants’ Choice: Sense or Sentimentality
text: The most symbolic moment of the Giants’ season came in the second half Sunday evening in Philadelphia, when Jeremy Shockey hurried over to Tom Coughlin on the sideline, yanked his headset receiver and shouted something in his ear.

headline: G.E. Is Said to Be Seeking a Buyer for Its Plastics Unit
text: In a move that has been expected for months, General Electric has begun shopping its plastics business to private equity funds, a person with knowledge of the details said yesterday.

headline: Barbs Traded in Nasdaq Bid for Exchange in London
text: LONDON, Jan. 8  Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange traded trans-Atlantic insults on Monday, as London exchange shareholders consider Nasdaq’s $5.3 billion hostile takeover offer.

headline: The Bevel Is in the Details
text: Introduced on Sunday: Nissan Bevel design study

headline: Bloomfield: Bus Driver Arrested in Stabbing
text: A New Jersey Transit bus driver was arrested last night, suspected of stabbing a passenger during a dispute over the fare, officials said. About 8:50 p.m. a passenger boarded the No. 34 bus, which runs from Newark to Montclair, and began to argue with the driver, a transit company spokesman said. The driver radioed a dispatcher requesting that the police be sent to the scene, but before they s arrived, Mr. Stessel said, the argument escalated, the passenger spit in the driver’s face and the driver responded by stabbing the man. The names of the driver and victim were not released last night. The victim was taken to University Hospital in Newark with injuries that were not life threatening, Mr. Stessel said. Officers from Bloomfield and New Jersey Transit were interviewing witnesses last night.

headline: G.M. Says It Is Losing Influence on Capitol Hill
text: DETROIT, Jan. 9 – General Motors still sells more cars than Toyota in the United States, but it says it’s seen as nothing more than an also-ran these days on Capitol Hill.

headline: Accord Falls Far From the Tree
text: Introduced on Monday: Honda Accord Coupe Concept

headline: Small and Fast Blaze Destroys Four Houses on Malibu Beach
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 — An unusually fast and furious brush fire destroyed four large seaside homes in Malibu Monday night and damaged at least two others, fire officials said.

headline: Love, Bludgeoned and Bent by the Camps
text: Martin Amis’s new novel, “House of Meetings,” tackles the same sobering material his 2002 nonfiction book “Koba the Dread” did: Stalin’s slave labor camps and the atrocities committed by the government during the failed “Soviet experiment.” The novel is everything that misguided earlier book was not. Whereas “Koba” weirdly mixed chilling, secondhand historical accounts of Stalin’s crimes with self-indulgent asides about Mr. Amis’s upper-middle-class life in England, “House of Meetings” is a powerful, unrelenting and deeply affecting performance: a bullet train of a novel that barrels deep into the heart of darkness that was the Soviet gulag and takes the reader along on an unnerving journey into one of history’s most harrowing chapters.

headline: Another Wound From War: Perversely Eroticized Power
text: Josh Fox, an esteemed member of the avant-garde theater world in New York, is a young playwright of ferocious passion who seems to consider himself a big pitchfork hurtling toward our most egregiously held cultural and political fictions. His themes — that Americans are anxious and alienated from one another, that estrangement breeds violence, and impulsivity, misfortune — lack the controversial effect that his visually elaborate stagings assume. And so it is to his credit that his latest piece, “You Belong to Me: Death of Nations, Part V,” produced by his International WOW Company, engages an idea with which his audience may not find easy and immediate sympathy.

headline: Separatists Blamed for Attacks in Northern India
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 8 — At least 67 people have been killed in the past four days in attacks in India’s troubled northeastern state of Assam. Most of the dead are Hindi-speaking settlers who migrated to the area for work decades ago.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,997 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: In Cobo’s Basement, the China Syndrome
text: Introduced on Monday: Changfeng Liebao CS7

headline: In ’05, Medical Bills Grew at Slowest Pace in 6 Years
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — Spending on health care in the United States increased in 2005 at the slowest pace in six years, mostly because of much slower growth in spending on prescription drugs, the government reported Monday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A Man in the News article on Saturday about Zalmay Khalilzad, President Bush’s choice to be ambassador to the United Nations, misidentified the first American ambassador to Afghanistan after the fall of the Taliban. It was Robert P. Finn  not Mr. Khalilzad, who succeeded Mr. Finn in the fall of 2003.

headline: Knicks Have a Surplus of Starters for a Change
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 8  With the anticipated return of Quentin Richardson and Nate Robinson for Wednesday’s game against the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks will be at nearly full strength in a season in which they have lost players to injuries and suspensions and often played better while shorthanded.

headline: Igawa’s Bronx Arrival Met With Tempered Expectations
text: The Yankees celebrated the arrival of a new left-handed strikeout king yesterday. His first name is pronounced K, as in the letter for strikeout on a scorecard, and he led the Japan Central League in strikeouts in three of the last five seasons.

headline: Agency Cancels Insurer’s Ads for George Washington Bridge
text: Geico’s gecko won’t be waving to drivers at the George Washington Bridge after all.

headline: Switzerland: UBS Names U.S. Official
text: UBS, the Swiss bank, said it had appointed Teresa Mullett Ressel, a former United States Treasury assistant secretary, to be the chief executive of its United States brokerage unit, UBS Securities. Ms. Ressel will maintain her role as chief operating officer for the company’s United States investment banking unit, UBS said. Based in Zurich, UBS hired Ms. Ressel in 2004 from the Treasury, where she was assistant secretary and chief financial officer.

headline: Heart Health: Study Links Alcohol to Lower Risk of Coronaries
text: Moderate alcohol consumption appears to pose little danger to men with high blood pressure, and may even reduce their risk of heart attack, according to a study published Jan. 2.

headline: Remembering a Saxophonist and His Undefinable Appeal
text: At Sunday night’s memorial service for the jazz saxophonist Dewey Redman, a lot of fellow musicians and friends came forward with suppositions about what made Mr. Redman special.

headline: Scientists Hope to Listen for Potential ‘Friends’ Elsewhere in the Universe
text: When it turns on in a couple of years, a field of what looks like oversized television antennas in western Australia will begin listening for gurgles of the early universe from billions of years ago.

headline: Mortgage Applications Up as Home Buyers See a Break in Rates
text: Low mortgage interest rates are buoying the housing market even as experts are debating whether the market has hit bottom.

headline: Letters
text: The Debate Over Diagnoses

headline: Romney Makes It Official and Asks for ’08 Cash in a Big Way
text: BOSTON, Jan. 8 — Presidential campaign fund-raising operations are usually run well out of public sight, reflecting their status as essential, if slightly unseemly, requirements for running for the White House.

headline: Girl Is Dead a Year, and Many Can’t Forget
text: Nixzmary Brown has been buried nearly a year, but as the criminal prosecution of her parents nears trial after months of missed deadlines and legal maneuvers, the case is stirring new passions.

headline: California: Sex Offender Back in Custody
text: A Superior Court judge in Contra Costa County ruled that Cary Verse, a convicted sex offender who was released in 2004 and who struggled to find housing amid community protests, had violated the terms of his release and must be returned to a mental hospital. The judge, John W. Kennedy, said Mr. Verse, 36, had committed “serious” violations of his release. Mr. Verse was recently taken into custody after the police stopped him for a traffic violation. He had a 14-year-old boy in his car, a breach of his release agreement.

headline: A Green Line in the Sand
text: Beersheba, Israel

headline: More Than 50 Die in U.S. Strikes in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 9 — More than 50 people were killed by American air strikes in Somalia on Sunday, most of them Islamist leaders fleeing in armed pick-up trucks across a remote stretch of the Kenya-Somalia border, officials of the transitional Somali government said today.

headline: Some Progress in Global Trade Effort
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — Trade envoys from the United States and Europe said on Monday that they had made progress in resolving differences to break an impasse on global trade negotiations, but they declined to say specifically where the differences had narrowed.

headline: All Is Not So Bad in the State of Denmark
text: Sweden has more blond beauties per capita, Italy and France have far better cuisine, and most of the free world can boast of better weather. But over the past 30 years, the citizens of Denmark have scored higher than any other Western country on measures of life satisfaction, and scientists think they know why.

headline: Manhattan: Diamond Club to Stay Put
text: In a setback for the developer Gary Barnett, the Diamond Dealers Club, a mainstay of the diamond district, has renewed its lease at its longtime home, 580 Fifth Avenue, near 47th Street. Mr. Barnett had hoped to lure the club to his planned 35-story tower on 47th Street, which he said would revitalize the city’s diamond and jewelry industry. In November, the developer got a $49.6 million subsidy package from the city, to the annoyance of the owners of 580 Fifth and other landlords. Jacob Banda, president of the diamond club, said yesterday that in the end he had doubts about whether Mr. Barnett’s tower would materialize. He said his landlord offered him a good deal on a 10-year lease, so he took it. Mr. Barnett insisted yesterday that his project was going forward, and he said the club had made “a major, major mistake.”

headline: U.N. Deputy Urges Pakistan to Curb Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 8  Pakistan should do more to restrict the activities of Taliban leaders in and around the border area with Afghanistan in keeping with a United Nations resolution that considers its leaders to be terrorists, the deputy chief of the United Nations mission in Afghanistan said here on Monday.

headline: Many on Easter Island Prefer to Leave Stones Unturned
text: RANO RARAKU, Easter Island — As remnants of a vanished culture and a lure to tourists, the mysterious giant statues that stand as mute sentinels along the rocky coast here are the greatest treasure of this remote place.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A Man in the News article on Saturday about Zalmay Khalilzad, President Bush’s choice to be ambassador to the United Nations, misidentified the first American ambassador to Afghanistan after the fall of the Taliban. It was Robert P. Finn — not Mr. Khalilzad, who succeeded Mr. Finn in the fall of 2003. (Go to Article)

headline: Discord Threatens to Split Earnhardts
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8  Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular and recognizable driver in Nascar, has made the No. 8 Budweiser Chevrolet equally as recognizable. But Earnhardt stopped short of guaranteeing he would remain in that race car after his contract with Dale Earnhardt Inc. expires at the end of the 2007 season.

headline: Swarming on the Corner
text: Q. Why do tiny flying insects form hovering masses in spring and summer?

headline: Mangini Says He Plans to Be Tougher in 2007
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Jan. 8 — In the second-floor meeting room where Eric Mangini was introduced as Jets coach 51 weeks ago, he addressed his players Monday for the final time this season.

headline: Australian Utility Giant Gets Buyout Offer From Managers
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 9 (Bloomberg News)  Alinta Ltd., Australia’s biggest energy transmission company, has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank Ltd. in what would be the country’s largest utility buyout.

headline: Bias Is Found in Food Studies With Financing From Industry
text: Research studies financed by the food industry are much more likely to produce favorable results than independently financed research, a report to be published today said.

headline: Hey, a Parking Space! But Which Way In?
text: WITH the row of parked cars in front of his shop looking altogether skewed, Barry Greenberg was bewildered. Some were parked front first, others had been backed to the curb, and every car was angled against the flow of one-way traffic on West 100th Street in Manhattan.

headline: Snapping Turtles Do Snap (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: In New York, No More Smell but Plenty of Talk
text: They could no longer smell it, but they could still talk about it.

headline: New Mobile Phone Signals Apple’s Ambition
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 — Steven P. Jobs introduced an Apple wireless phone today that he said would lead to a new synthesis of communications, video, music and computing.

headline: White House Gears Up to Sell Plan for Troop Increase in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — The White House is planning an aggressive effort to sell Congress and the American public on President Bush’s new strategy for Iraq, beginning with a prime-time address to the nation on Wednesday night, followed Thursday by a presidential trip to Fort Benning, Ga., and appearances on Capitol Hill by the secretaries of state and defense.

headline: Doctors Fault Designers’ Stance Over Thin Models
text: The response of American fashion designers to the problem of dangerously thin models on the runway is to propose educational reform and better working conditions. The response of eating disorder professionals is to suggest that those models should not be on the runways at all.

headline: That Charter Jet Is Available, but How Good Is the Pilot?
text: ONE of the many figures I can’t quite get my head around is $44 billion, which is one estimate of the amount of year-end bonus money said to have been distributed to the lucky folks rolling with the good times on Wall Street.

headline: John Sieburth, 79, Who Studied Various Types of Marine Life, Dies
text: John McN. Sieburth, a fiercely independent scientist whose research on turkeys led him to penguins, which in turn led him to help identify infinitesimal oceanic organisms that appear to be the most abundant on earth, died on Dec. 7 in West Kingston, R.I. He was 79.

headline: Surviving the Cold, or Even the Not So Cold
text: Three healthy, athletic young men were climbing on Mount Hood in Oregon last month when a severe snowstorm hit. One died of hypothermia from exposure; the search was ultimately called off for the other two.

headline: In Vacuum of Silence, Coughlin Sits Tight
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 8  The day after their first-round exit from the playoffs, Giants players were on the lower level of Giants Stadium, meeting with their coaches, perhaps for the last time. Upstairs, in the ground-level offices, the team’s management was addressing issues that would affect the franchise’s future.

headline: Congress Is Expected to Revisit Sentencing Laws
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — Federal sentencing laws that require lengthy mandated prison terms for certain offenses are expected to come under fresh scrutiny as Democrats assume control of Congress.

headline: At Universities, Plum Post at Top Is Now Shaky
text: David A. Caputo, the president of Pace University, has ricocheted from one crisis to another.

headline: No Negotiating With Separatists After Airport Attack, Spaniard Says
text: MADRID, Jan. 8 — The Socialist government of Spain will never again negotiate with the Basque separatist group ETA after a deadly attack on Madrid’s main airport terminal nine days ago, Interior Minister Alfredo Pérez Rubalcaba said Monday.

headline: A New Menu Item at the Road Kill Cafe
text: Introduced on Monday: Jeep Trailhawk design study

headline: Putin Considers Diverting Oil Around Belarus
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 — An unyielding President Vladimir V. Putin raised the possibility on Tuesday of diverting oil transit routes away from Belarus, a day after Moscow cut off pipeline deliveries of crude headed to Europe through the country.

headline: A Secretive Aerospace Company Sheds a Bit of Light on Its Rocket Program
text: Jeff Bezos finally gave the world a peek at his rocket.

headline: Bloomberg Picks Pataki Official to Run City’s Welfare Agency
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed former Gov. George E. Pataki’s social services commissioner yesterday to run the city’s enormous welfare agency, naming Robert Doar, who is considered conservative on some welfare issues.

headline: New DVDs: Walt Disney Treasures
text: The critic Leonard Maltin has been rooting through the Disney archives again, and a result is four more double-disc sets in the limited-edition “Walt Disney Treasures” series.

headline: House Democrats’ Security Bill Draws Doubts
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — House Democrats intend to fulfill a campaign promise this week by passing broad new antiterrorism legislation, but some Senate Democrats and the Bush administration object to security mandates in the plan, citing concerns about their cost and practicality.

headline: The Troubles of Sista P.
text: Kingston, Jamaica

headline: Recalling Rosemary Clooney, Fondly and Lyrically
text: Come gather round the kitchen table and soak in the showbiz tales of your wise and funny Grandma Rose: that describes the welcoming spirit of a typical late-career performance by the singer Rosemary Clooney, who died in June 2002. By that time, she had evolved from a demure ’50s “thrush” into an embracing, matriarchal force of nature. An audience became her extended family, encouraged to rest its collective head in her lap as she poured out musical bedtime stories for grown-ups. Though written by others, those stories, told in her voice, came across as nuggets of personal experience.

headline: Mayor Says City Risks Losing Grants for Security
text: New York City stands to lose access to a $1 billion pool of federal homeland security money to finance improved communications between public safety agencies because its system does not meet federal guidelines, according to a letter that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sent yesterday to Bush administration officials and Congressional leaders.

headline: Corzine Seeks Action on Property Tax Overhaul
text: Saying that property taxes in the state, the nation’s highest on average, are “the cork in the bottle that constrains New Jersey’s resources and attention,” Gov. Jon S. Corzine told legislators that they must complete the job they started to overhaul the property tax system.

headline: U.S. Moves Against Iranian Bank for Weapons Ties
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 – The United States, moving to raise pressure on Iran, today barred American financial institutions from doing any business with a major Iranian bank after concluding that it had been involved in illicit weapons programs.

headline: House Democrats May Aid Corruption Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The new Democratic House leaders are negotiating with federal prosecutors about complying with subpoenas related to former Representative Randy Cunningham’s corrupt sale of military contracts, potentially accelerating a dormant inquiry.

headline: NCR Says It Will Spin Off Its Data Management Business
text: Investors drove up the stock of the NCR Corporation, the largest maker of automated teller machines and airport check-in kiosks, yesterday after the company said it would spin off its data management business, Teradata, in what it expects to be a tax-free deal.

headline: Somebody Wake Up Aurora; She’s Missing a Lot of Debuts
text: Two more Auroras were given the magic wake-up kiss on Thursday and Friday at the New York State Theater in Peter Martins’s “Sleeping Beauty.”

headline: Chávez Moves to Nationalize Two Industries
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 8 — President Hugo Chávez signaled a vigorous new effort to assert greater control over Venezuela’s economy on Monday by announcing plans to nationalize companies in the telecommunications and electricity industries.

headline: Citigroup Cutback in Japan
text: Citigroup will shut about 270 consumer finance branches and 100 loan machines in Japan after a new local law capped the interest rate nonbank lenders can charge.

headline: U.S. Airstrike Aims at Qaeda Cell in Somalia
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — A United States Air Force gunship carried out a strike Sunday night against suspected operatives of Al Qaeda in southern Somalia, a senior Pentagon official said Monday night.

headline: Spitzer and Assembly Near Deal on How to Choose Comptroller
text: ALBANY, Jan. 8  The Spitzer administration and Democrats in the State Assembly are close to agreeing on how to review candidates for state comptroller, a politically charged selection process, state officials said on Monday evening.

headline: Elkan R. Blout, Scientist at Harvard, Dies at 86
text: Elkan R. Blout, a biochemist and top science administrator at Harvard whose career ranged from color film developing to the sharpening of research standards at the Food and Drug Administration, died Dec. 20 in Boston. He was 87.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Metropolitan Opera Manager Leaks ‘Ring’ Lineup

headline: Supreme Court Refuses Case Challenging Group’s Designation as Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 — The Supreme Court refused on Monday to intervene in the federal prosecution of seven Iranian refugees for providing financial support to an opposition group in Iran that the State Department has designated as a terrorist organization.

headline: After Aiding Prosecutors, Rowland Aide Gets Probation
text: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8  The deputy chief of staff to former Gov. John G. Rowland, who pleaded guilty four years ago to taking gold coins and other favors in exchange for steering state contracts, left the federal courthouse here on Monday richly rewarded, this time for his cooperation with prosecutors.

headline: Bronx Woman Charged With Murder of Baby
text: A 25-year-old Bronx woman who first claimed that her baby had been abducted on Monday then changed her story and led the police on a fruitless search for the child in the Bronx and Queens was charged with second degree murder this morning, the police said.

headline: Long-Term Global Forecast? Fewer Continents
text: Kiss the Mediterranean goodbye. Ditto the Red Sea and its wonderland of coral reefs and exotic sea life. And prepare for the day when San Francisco has a gritty new suburb: Los Angeles. Indeed, much of Southern California, including the Baja Peninsula, will eventually migrate up the west coast to make Alaska even more gargantuan.

headline: Belarus and Russia Dispute Cause of Oil Cutoff
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 8 — Supplies of Russian crude oil headed to European markets came to a halt overnight, officials said Monday, in the latest manifestation of rapidly deteriorating relations between Russia and Belarus.

headline: BMW 3 Series Flips Its Lid, the Hard Way
text: Introduced on Sunday: 2007 BMW 3 Series convertible

headline: U.S. Sub and Japanese Vessel Collide
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  An American nuclear-powered attack submarine has collided with a Japanese commercial vessel in the Arabian Sea. Initial reports from the area said there were no injuries and only slight damage, a Pentagon spokesman said Monday night.

headline: Memo Pad
text: MISHANDLED BAGS  Customer complaints in November about bags mishandled by domestic airlines rose to 6.32 percent per 1,000 passengers, from 5.04 percent in November 2005, the Transportation Department said. Of 20 airlines in the report, the five with the fewest complaints per thousand passengers were Aloha, Hawaiian, AirTran, Continental and JetBlue. The five with the most complaints were Mesa, SkyWest, American Eagle, Comair and Atlantic Southeast. A mishandled bag is one that was reported lost, delayed, damaged or subject to pilfering.

headline: Game Over: Florida 41, Ohio State 14
text: Check out our play-by-play commentary of the national championship game between Ohio State and Florida, as it was typed in LIVE:

headline: Is  the Big Ten Overrated? (And Where Does Boise State Belong?)
text: A reader named Bill wrote in during the live blog:

headline: Silicone Magic
text: Browse a selection of silicone kitchen tools in every shape and color imaginable.

headline: Emily Oster's Research on AIDS
text: In her research on AIDS, Emily Oster has come up with three main conclusions:

headline: In Poland, a Retreat From the City
text: Tour this Warsaw home shared by Kai Schoenhals, an American restaurateur, his wife and two children.

headline: $28 Million Homes
text: Tour palatial homes located in Wilson, Wyo., Sands Point, N..Y., and Pebble Beach, Calif.
