headline: The Economists' Web Sites
text: Ulrike Malmendier: http://www.econ.berkeley.edu/~ulrike/index.html

headline: Let’s Sleep on It
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Book to Tell Litvinenko’s Story
text: A friend and the widow of the former K.G.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko are collaborating on a book to be published by Free Press in May, "Death of a Dissident: Alexander Litvinenko and the Death of Russian Democracy." Alex Goldfarb with Marina Litvinenko will tell the story of Mr. Litvinenko and his career as a spy in the style of a political thriller. Mr. Litvinenko died of a high dose of the radioactive isotope polonium 210 in London in November, and before his death he accused the Russian government of poisoning him. Free Press is an imprint of Simon & Schuster. … The Sobol Award for Fiction, an online contest recruiting unpublished fiction writers, has been canceled, according to a statement on the contest's Web site (sobolaward.com). The statement said that an insufficient number of manuscripts were submitted. The promised prize for the winner of the contest, first announced in September, was representation with Sobol Literary Enterprises and a book deal with Touchstone, an imprint of Simon & Schuster. All entrants will be refunded the mandatory $85 entry fee, the statement said. The creators of the contest have endured criticism that the contest unfairly exploited unknown writers for money. … The Central Intelligence Agency has blocked Valerie Wilson from writing about her experience as an undercover officer for the agency in a new book, Newsweek reported. But the flagship imprint of Simon & Schuster is still planning to publish her book sometime this year. Adam Rothberg, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, declined comment.

headline: Polaris Puts $20 Million Into Heavy.com
text: The publisher of Heavy.com, an online answer to so-called lad magazines, has received a new $20 million cash infusion from top backer Polaris Venture Partners. The announcement of the funding round, Heavy’s fifth, comes about a year after Polaris provided $10 million to the company.

headline: Turnaround Expert Is Named Quiznos Chief
text: Quiznos, the sandwich shop chain, named Gregory D. Brenneman, a turnaround expert who is credited with revitalizing Burger King and Continental Airlines, president and chief executive on Monday. Mr. Brenneman’s private equity firm, TurnWorks, has also taken an equity stake in Quiznos, the company said, although it did not disclose financial details.

headline: Bear Stearns Said to Poach UBS Banker in Germany
text: Bear Stearns has poached the co-head of German investment banking at UBS to make him senior investment banker for Europe, a sign that Bear Stearns is pressing on with expansion in the region, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Lasik Surgery Company Will Buy a Rival
text: Advanced Medical Optics, a laser vision correction company, said yesterday that it would buy a rival, IntraLase, for about $808 million, gaining its competitor’s popular blade-free technology used during Lasik surgery. The cash deal, valued at $25 a share, represents a 12.5 percent premium over IntraLase’s closing price of $22.23 on Friday. Advanced Medical Optics said it expected to complete the acquisition early in the second quarter.

headline: Citigroup Makes Cutbacks in Japan
text: Citigroup will shut about 270 consumer finance branches and 100 loan machines in Japan after a new local law capped the interest rate nonbank lenders can charge. Citigroup increased its loan-loss reserves by $375 million and said costs related to the closings would total another $40 million. The actions will cut Citigroup’s fourth-quarter profit by 8 cents a share, a spokeswoman, Shannon Bell, said.

headline: Ex-Chief of Aspen Technology Accused of Inflating Revenue
text: The former chief executive of the software company Aspen Technology surrendered Monday to face charges that he inflated the company’s software revenues as he competed to become its chief executive. The executive, David L. McQuillin, 48, of Sudbury, Mass., was accused in Federal District Court in Manhattan of plotting to exaggerate the company’s software revenue from January 2001 to September 2002. In court filings, prosecutors accused Mr. McQuillin of trying to inflate the revenue while he was competing against the company’s other chief operating officer to become chief executive. He became chief executive in October 2002.

headline: G.E. Woos Private Equity in Plastics Auction
text: In a move that has been expected for months, General Electric has begun shopping its plastics business to private equity funds, according to The New York Times. Goldman Sachs, the investment bank that G.E. retained to find buyers, approached at least four equity groups, including Apollo Management, Bain Capital, the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, in a deal could be worth $10 billion, the report said.

headline: Black Engaged in Insider Trading, Prosecutors Allege
text: Conrad Black engaged in insider trading with the help of Toronto-based Brascan in 1998 to prop up the share price of Hollinger International, according to part of an expanded series of allegations by prosecutors in the United States Attorney’s office in Chicago. The filing alleges that Lord Black split profits from the trading with a group of associates and Brascan, and that he circumvented securities laws. Lord Black and three other former Hollinger executives face a variety of criminal charges over allegations they looted more than $80 million from the media company.

headline: Canada’s Imperial Metals Raises Bid for Rival
text: Imperial Metals raised its bid to acquire BcMetals on Monday by increasing its all-cash bid to about $43.2 million Canadian dollars ($36.7 million) in a move to woo shareholders considering a competing offer. Imperial increased its offer to $1.125 Canadian dollars a share and reduced the minimum tendering condition to 50 percent plus one.

headline: Yahoo Brings MyBlogLog into the Fold
text: Yahoo has purchased MyBlogLog, a social-networking site that aims to build communities among like-minded blog readers. Yahoo did not disclose what it paid for the Florida-based MyBlogLog, first launched in July, but the report put the price tag at a little over $10 million. Mybloglog also looks at reader behavior inside blogs, like what is being read and where readers go next, delivering information it can sell to web advertisers.

headline: Morgan Stanley Gets on Board US Airways Bid
text: US Airways Group said Monday that it has enlisted Morgan Stanley to join Citigroup in providing the financing for its hostile $8.5 billion bid for Delta Air Lines. US Airways, which made its unsolicited bid for Delta in November, said at the time that it had tapped Citigroup for a $7.2 billion debt package intended to provide the cash portion of its offer as well as to refinance the merged company. Delta management strongly opposes the bid, seeking instead to exit bankruptcy as a stand-alone company.

headline: Leader of Revived Fidelity Unit to Retire
text: Fidelity Investments said on Monday that Stephen P. Jonas, who engineered a makeover in less than two years as head of the investment management unit of the giant mutual fund firm, would retire at the end of this month. The news surprised analysts and investors, who said Mr. Jonas was the engine that drove Fidelity’s makeover, doubling the size of its United States team of equities analysts, appointing new fund managers at some critical portfolios, including the flagship Magellan fund, and overseeing the move to new offices in Boston. As one of the world’s largest investors, with more than $1.3 trillion in assets, Fidelity has often played a role in pushing for change in the industry, and changes within its executive ranks draw attention.

headline: ABN Amro Spins Off Biotech Venture
text: ABN Amro Capital, the private equity arm of the banking giant ABN Amro, has spun its life-sciences division off into an independent venture capital firm, Forbion Capital Partners, the new group said Monday, while announcing the close of a 200 million euros ($260 million) fund to take advantage of the company’s successful track record in a difficult sector.

headline: List of Golden Globe Nominees and Winners
text: Motion picture and television nominees and winners for the 64th annual Golden Globe Awards. denotes the winning nominee in each category.MOTION PICTURES:

headline: Home Depot to Review Nardelli’s Pay
text: Home Depot, the home improvement store chain, said Monday that its board would require that two-thirds of its independent directors approve any compensation granted to Robert L. Nardelli, the former chairman and chief executive. The decision, made last Thursday but not disclosed until Monday in a regulatory filing, follows an uproar over Mr. Nardelli’s pay.

headline: A Bud by Any Other Name
text: Anheuser-Busch has cut an importing and distribution deal with a Czech brewer — the same one it has been warring with for years over who owns the rights to the Budweiser trademark. Budejovicky Budvar and Anheuser-Busch have been fighting for almost 100 years in a country-by-country spat over the brand — and the deal will not stop that — but the two have now joined hands in a pact that will make the St. Louis-based brewer the importer of Czechvar, the name under which Budvar has been sold in the United States since 2001.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Asks S.E.C. To Delay New Trading Rules
text: The New York Stock Exchange is a little behind schedule, it seems. Its parent, the NYSE Group, requested Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission postpone the implementation date of Regulation NMS, a series of sweeping changes designed to update United States markets for new, rapid trading technologies, from Feb. 5 to March 5.

headline: Vodafone Gets Exclusive Look at Essar’s Books, Report Says
text: Vodafone will start examining Hutchison Essar‘s books on Tuesday as it mulls a bid of $18 billion to $19 billion for the company, India’s fourth-largest mobile phone operator, The Financial Times reported. The newspaper said Vodafone had appointed Ernst & Young to help it with the due diligence process. The report said that fifteen Vodafone executives flew to Mumbai over the weekend to undertake parallel due diligence on the operational side of the business.

headline: Is de Mol Looking to Take Back Endemol?
text: A Dutch billionaire, John de Mol, has taken a 5.15 percent stake in a television production company, Endemol, a business he founded in 1994 and sold to the Spanish telecom giant Telefonica six years later. The small holding in the company, which produces the “Big Brother” and “Deal or No Deal” television shows, was announced Monday by de Mol’s investment vehicle, Cyrte Investments, and could mark the first step in a campaign to regain control of the company.

headline: In Software, More Deals But Smaller Prices
text: Mergers and acquisitions in the software industry, once characterized by multibillion-dollar transactions, entered into a phase of “leftover consolidation” in 2006, a report from The 451 Group, a research firm, concludes. While the number of transactions increased 20 percent from 2005 to 947, the aggregate value of those deals dropped 20 percent to $27 billion. Many of last year’s software deals involved second-tier vendors and vertical-market specialists, the report said.

headline: Analysts Left Cold by Xerox Takeover Speculation
text: Xerox options trading surged Monday as trader speculation spread that Eastman Kodak could acquire the printer maker, options analysts told Reuters. But analysts downplayed the speculation, noting that such a transaction is unlikely to occur because film maker Kodak is less than half the size of Xerox by market capitalization and is in the midst of a restructuring following years of turmoil in its business.

headline: McAfee to Take Charges Related to Stock Options
text: McAfee, the security software developer, said late Monday that it expects to record charges of $25 million to $45 million over “several periods commencing with the fourth quarter of 2006″ related to the improper granting of stock options. In October, McAfee announced that it had discovered the improper accounting of up to $150 million in option grants, and Chairman and Chief Executive George Samenuk subsequently resigned.

headline: Barbs Traded in Nasdaq Bid for Exchange in London
text: Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange traded trans-Atlantic insults on Monday, as London exchange shareholders consider Nasdaq’s $5.3 billion hostile takeover offer. Nasdaq has been trying to take over the London exchange since March, but has failed to lure London executives to the negotiating table.

headline: Australian Energy Giant Receives Buyout Offer
text: Alinta, Australia’s biggest energy transmission company, has received a management buyout proposal backed by Macquarie Bank in what would be the country’s largest utility buyout. Alinta shares surged as much as 14 percent, valuing the company at 6.3 billion Australian dollars ($4.9 billion). Macquarie, Australia’s biggest investment bank, is advising the group and may take a stake in the buyout, Alinta said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

headline: Kirkland Opens Hong Kong Office to Pursue Asian Buyouts
text: Smelling buyout opportunities in Asia, the law firm Kirkland & Ellis announced Monday that it has opened an office in Hong Kong after receiving regulatory approval. The bureau will be led by David Patrick Eich, a partner specializing in private equity deals who played a key role in the the $10.2 billion buyout of Philips Semiconductors by a consortium of private equity funds.

headline: Investors Applaud NCR’s Spin-Off Plan
text: Investors appeared pleased with Monday’s announcement by NCR, the largest maker of automated teller machines and airport check-in kiosks, that it is planning to spin off its data management business, driving up the company’s stock. Shares of NCR rose as much as 7.1 percent, to $45.42, before falling back to close at $43.79, an increase of $1.39, or 3.3 percent, over Friday’s close, after NCR said it would spin off Teradata in what it expects to be a tax-free deal.

headline: Grasso Spars With New York Over Taxes
text: Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, whose pay package has been the subject of a legal battle, is getting hit on another front as well. The New York Post reports that the New York State Department of Taxation wants to impose a $1.8 million penalty on Mr. Grasso related to New York City tax returns it believes he should have filed in 2002 and 2003. The dispute, according to the Post, hinges on the location of Mr. Grasso’s main residence during that time.

headline: Gap Said to Explore Selling Itself
text: If Gap, the casual clothing chain, ends up putting itself on the block, the potential buyer may end up shelling out more than $18 billion, in a deal that could be one of the largest buyouts in retail history, according to The New York Times. The company’s current market value is $16.4 billion, but analysts expect that a buyer would have to pay more than $18 billion.

headline: To Charter or Not to Charter, That Is the Question
text: As Wall Street’s record $44 billion in bonuses begin to circulate, private jets and charter flights are one of the many luxuries industry watchers are betting will reap the benefits of all this ready cash. But before spending their money on a luxury charter service, bankers may want to asses the pros and cons of such travel.

headline: The Morning After
text: Some news and notes as you ponder that Boise State defeated Oregon State, which defeated U.S.C., which defeated Arkansas, which defeated Auburn, which defeated ……… Florida.

headline: Breaking: Damon Drinks Beer, Pays Cash, Tips Well
text: The Baguette admits she crushed on Matt Damon at the New York Film Critics Circle Awards ceremony. His Everyman routine — drinking a beer and talking to everyone, while Leo DiCaprio took off like he was fleeing a sinking ship — was endearing.

headline: Let Them Eat Cake, and Nothing Else
text: In his day job, the Bagger covers the rise and fall of MSM. He frequently suggests the sky is falling and often worries a piece the size of piano will hit his head. But nothing filled him with darker foreboding about the future of print media than walking into the New York Critics Circle Awards ceremony and finding that only dessert, not dinner, was served.

headline: Express Scripts Moves to Derail Caremark Deal
text: Express Scripts opened a proxy war in the pharmacy benefits industry on Monday, saying it would nominate four directors to the 11-member board of Caremark Rx, which has agreed to merge with the drugstore chain CVS. The Financial Times’s Lex column suggested that in rejecting Express Scripts’s unsolicited takeover offer, Caremark may be blinded by its vision of transforming the industry.

headline: Electronic Voting
text: Netroots has become a real force in real elections, so it is not surprising that some digital campaigning is underway for various films, including “Children of Men.” Reel Pop, a blog about on-line vid, shares a link to a homemade campaign document for the darkly wonderful film. So far, the document has been viewed over 40,000 times on YouTube.

headline: Stifel Financial to Buy Ryan Beck
text: Stifel Financial said Tuesday it had agreed to acquire Ryan Beck Holdings, a financial firm that postponed its initial public offering last summer. Stifel, which is based in St. Louis, will pay about $91.1 million in stock for Ryan Beck, a unit of a Florida regional bank, BankAtlantic Bancorp, and will additional payments if certain performance targets are met.

headline: The Golden Cheese Award
text: Companies that contribute swag to the Golden Globes gift suite are allowed two company representatives to heap the stuff on people who already have too much of it. But the folks at Bluetooth Wristwatch decided to play every angle and auctioned off one of their employee slots on eBay.

headline: Jumping the Gun, and Maybe, the Shark
text: The Director’s Guild Awards are a tidy affair. Five guys — yeah, it’s almost always guys — get nominated for directorial achievement and we all get a nice, vigorous stirring of the Oscar tea leaves. Come back about 1:00 p.m. and the Baguette will be putting up the results. In the meantime, the Bagger has rolled the Magic Eight Ball across the floor and come up with the following assessments.

headline: News Quiz: Accolades
text: O.K., we know this wasn’t exactly the toughest challenge — more of a scavenger hunt. But on the flip side, this was a banner week for contextualizing, that elusive tidbit that seems to regularly be ignored most weeks. In that sense, we’d dare play the Pollyanna and declare everyone an Egghead!

headline: Citing Sarbanes-Oxley Reins, Chairman Leaves Shutterfly
text: Shutterfly, an online photo service, said Monday that the chairman, Jim Clark, co-founder of Web pioneer Netscape Communications, had resigned. In explaining his departure, Mr. Clark said securities regulations, and more specifically the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, had “gone too far.” The harsh comments from one of Silicon Valley’s best-known entrepreneurs are likely to add to the debate about whether tougher laws are stifling innovation in the United States.

headline: Clearing the Air
text: Speaker Nancy Pelosi is poised to extinguish one of the last true perquisites of House service: the right to smoke just off the floor in an area known as the Speaker’s Lobby. Lawmakers and aides say they expect that Mrs. Pelosi will soon use the substantial powers of her new office to bar smokers from the lobby and force them outside. Opponents of smoking have complained about the practice for years. The impact of the change will be bipartisan; members of both parties regularly enjoy cigarettes and cigars as they relax in the lobby’s leather chairs between votes. The highest ranking smoker is Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio and the minority leader, who was perhaps anticipating the change when he headed to an outer balcony last week for a quick cigarette. Ever defiant, some smokers said they would still light up in their personal offices.

headline: New Congress, Older Look
text: The winds of change have blown through the 110th Congress, but only to a point. There are more women (90) and, obviously, more Democrats. But according to the Congressional Research Service, the average age of lawmakers in the new Congress is possibly the oldest in history. The average age of senators is 61.7 — two years older than in the previous Congress. The oldest senator is Robert C. Byrd, 89, Democrat of West Virginia, and the youngest is John E. Sununu, 42, Republican of New Hampshire. The average age of representatives is 55.9, with Ralph M. Hall, Republican of Texas, the oldest at 83, and Patrick T. McHenry, Republican of North Carolina, the youngest at 31. More demographics: there are more Protestants than any other religious affiliation, but Roman Catholics account for the largest single religious denomination.

headline: On the Hill: Homeland Security
text: House Democrats are pushing expansive plans for homeland security—maybe a little too big for the Senate and the Bush administration. From The Times’s Eric Lipton:

headline: The LCD Juggernaut–Not So Fast!
text: Panasonic, which has most of its eggs in the plasma TV basket, takes exception to the idea that liquid-crystal display TVs are going to dominate the big-screen HDTV market. Yoshi Yamada, chief executive of its North American operations, told me, “You are going to see a slow down in production of LCD and investment in LCD.”

headline: Black is the New Aluminum
text: Henry Ford supposedly said at the dawn of the automotive age, “You can have the car in any color you want, as long as it is black.”

headline: D.L.P. Is Not Dead
text: Texas Instruments says reports of the demise of its digital light processing technology are premature. “We believe DLP will be the third flat-panel technology,” John Van Scoter, TI’s senior vice president for DLP, told a small group of journalists over dinner last night.

headline: The War at Home: Hearts and Minds
text: When it comes to Iraq, the White House knows it has to win over hearts and minds—of the Congress and the American people, that is—if it wants to send more troops. President Bush reportedly made it clear to Republican senators yesterday that talk of a strategy involving escalation was true, and he’ll fill in the extra details Wednesday at 9 p.m.

headline: Samsung vs. Apple
text: Samsung has bested Sony as the No. 1 maker of TVs in the United States. Now the Korean company has set its target on another company known for great design and unassailable market share.

headline: The Trouble With Schwarzenegger’s Health Care Plan
Kennedy Tackles Troop Surge
text: Today, Senator Edward M. Kennedy will deliver a speech at the National Press Club. As recently as a week ago, the focus was expected to be on domestic policy – particularly health care – and other points of his agenda for the new Democratic Congress.

headline: The Readers’ Turn
text: From a reader: Instead of a 50-day layoff, how ’bout a playoff? (Editor’s note: Jesse Jackson couldn’t have said it better)

headline:
Getting to Know Wine?
The Only Thing to Fear Is Fear Itself
text: I’ve had my long rest, and while I know it’s getting annoyingly late to say so, Happy New Year!

headline: Blogs to Hannity: What About ‘Mystic River’?
text: Fox News’s Sean Hannity has launched a thousand blog discussions with the birthing of a segment called “Enemy of the State” on his new Sunday night program, “Hannity’s America.”

headline: And Baby Makes Five
text: Michael Lewis brings his “Dad Again” column, which had been about his second child, back to Slate for the birth of child No. 3: “It was up to me to prevent it, which is to say that it was only a matter of time before it happened.” Now a three-time veteran of the delivery room, Lewis offers this advice to expectant fathers:

headline: As Battle Looms, CVS and Caremark Add Advisers
text: Caremark Rx seems to be girding for a serious fight. The pharmacy benefits manager, which recently rejected a $26 billion takeover bid from its rival Express Scripts in favor of a deal with the drugstore chain CVS, has hired Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz as a legal adviser. Wachtell Lipton is well-versed in the art of the takeover feud, having advised Walt Disney as it sought to fend off Comcast‘s hostile bid (which was withdrawn) and drug giant Sanofi in its hostile offer for Aventis (which succeeded).

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Make Up Your Minds Already
text: Mitt Romney’s high-tech, highly public fund-raising blitz yesterday amounted to a de facto campaign kick-off after he formed an exploratory committee last week. In addition to raising $6.5 million, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts also won the endorsement of his fellow former Massachusetts governor, William Weld, despite Mr. Weld’s friendship with Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: The Candidates: Where They Stand on Iraq
text: As the nation awaits President Bush’s speech on Wednesday night outlining his new approach to Iraq, a sampling of announced or likely 2008 presidential candidates are staking out positions on a spectrum from hawk to dove.

headline: Buffalo: Abortion Provider's Killer Apologizes
text: A man convicted of killing a doctor who performed abortions as part of his practice apologized to the victim’s widow in Federal District Court yesterday, the first day of his trial on charges of violating a federal law forbidding forceful interference with reproductive services. The man, James C. Kopp, 52, who is acting as his own lawyer, told Lynne Slepian, whose husband, Dr. Barnett Slepian, was killed by a rifle shot from woods outside their suburban home on the evening of Oct. 23, 1998, “I respect you and your family.” Mr. Kopp, who spent more than two years as a fugitive in Mexico and France, is serving a sentence of 25 years to life after his conviction on state murder charges. If convicted in federal court, he faces a possible sentence of life without parole.

headline: Pinault Is Given 3 Weeks to Decide on Suez Bid
text: The French billionaire François Pinault has until Feb. 2, or about three weeks, to decide whether to bid for the water and energy utility Suez, France’s stock-market regulator said Tuesday. If his holding company, Artemis, decides against a bid, he must steer clear of making a bid for Suez for six months unless there are “significant changes in the environment, situation or shareholder structure” in the company.

headline: The Way We Were
text: Yesterday’s lingering odor was attributed in part to a temperature inversion settling over the New York region. Of course, that wasn’t the first time this has happened. Before the Clean Air Act, such inversions were linked to hundreds of deaths, as they trapped the deadly toxins from the city’s factories and other agents of pollution.

headline: The Surreal Life, Detroit Auto Show Edition
text: Across the street from Cobo, DaimlerChrysler throws a party each day of the auto show that begins at 4 p.m. and lasts till well past the witching hour. The venue is an old firehouse that’s temporarily turned into a pub, complete with a massive square bar that dominates the cavernous tiled room. And the drinks are priced just right for journalists: free.

headline: Gap Deal Would Face Many Hurdles, Analysts Say
text: Investors sent Gap‘s stock surging 7 percent on Monday amid reports that it might be considering a sale. But Wall Street analysts quickly pointed out some obstacles to an acquisition of the retail chain, whose casual fashions have been languishing on the racks in recent months. These include a generally lackluster demand for retail companies (as shown by last year’s failed auctions for Jones Apparel and Pep Boys) and Gap’s relatively small amount of real-estate assets, which could be used to defray the cost of a buyout.

headline: Back in Somalia, With al Qaeda’s Connection More Clear
text: SundayMonday’s attack in Somalia by a U.S. Air Force AC-130 gunship against suspected al-Qaeda members — a story that is only today beginning to take real shape — is something of a historic moment. As The Washington Post notes:

headline: Torch It
text: The strangest new material featured in a high-end vehicle at the Detroit Auto Show: burned wood.

headline: New York City ‘Subway Hero’ Gets Free Jeep
text: Thomas W. LaSorda, chief executive of Chrysler, and Jason Vines, vice president for public relations, have quietly arranged for the New York City “subway hero,” Wesley Autrey, to receive a new Jeep Patriot as part of Jeep’s ongoing “Everyday Heroes” program.

headline: Sending Mercenaries Into Darfur
text: Anne from New Jersey raised an interesting question: “You wrote in a recent column that President Bush could partly restore his legacy by establishing a no-fly zone over the Darfur region of Sudan. And, a few weeks before, you suggested that France, which maintains an airbase in Chad, could send military planes to strafe the Janjaweed, who, as groups of horsemen in the dessert, would be readily visible from the air.

headline: The DGA Announces Its Nominees
text: Michael Apted, president of the Directors Guild of America, announced today that the five nominees for outstanding directing achievement in a feature film are:

headline: The Return of Sean Patrick Maloney
text: The governor’s top deputy has a new top deputy.

headline: The Company They Will Keep
text: Politics will not play a role in the selection of a replacement for former Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. At least, that’s what the powers that be — Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, and Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno — said today.

headline: For Apple Chief, Gadgets’ Glitter Outshines Scandal
text: As Steve Jobs was preparing to take the stage at the MacWorld trade show to make his buzz-drenched annual keynote address, pundits were piling on to excoriate him for Apple‘s options-backdating scandal.

headline: What, No Odorama?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today that the source of the smell that wafted across Manhattan yesterday remained a mystery — and more a matter for entertainment than anything else.

headline: Kennedy: ‘George Bush’s Vietnam’
text: Senator Ted Kennedy spoke at the National Press Club this afternoon, detailing a resolution he plans to introduce today that would require Congress to vote on President Bush’s anticipated plan to send more troops to Iraq and any additional funding for those troops. In his speech, Mr. Kennedy, a Democrat from Massachusetts, called the Iraq war “George Bush’s Vietnam.”

headline: Cunningham Leaves 1199
text: A major development in New York politics. What does this mean, vis-a-vis Spitzer?

headline: Blogtalk: Dissent, Jodi and Joe
text: Connecticut state police are taking some heat for arresting a freelance journalist/law student/activist (or put more succinctly –- a blogger) at Gov. Jodi Rell’s inauguration parade last week.

headline: In Praise of Names
text: Coming up with a name is hard work. Just ask Gwyneth Paltrow—or, more accurately, just ask her daughter, Apple. Names, particularly creative names, are risky. On the topic of his son’s name, Magnus, Will Ferrell told Regis and Kelly, “We wanted to make sure he gets teased a lot.”

headline: The iPhone Rumors Are Right…Finally
text: OK, so after three years of being wrong, the rumor sites were finally right. Now there IS an Apple cellphone. Or, rather, will be one in June.

headline: Maybe It’s His Deep Pockets
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared this morning before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee and the hearing –- on implementation of the 9/11 Commission’s recommendations –- at times took on the appearance of a lovefest.

headline: Schumer’s Hidden Assets?
text: Or, maybe not.

headline: McGwire Haunted by His Own Silence
text: Members of the Baseball Writers’ Association of America, the body charged with voting new members into the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., settled on Cal Ripken Jr. and Tony Gwynn — both of whom were named on the necessary 75 percent of the 545 ballots cast.

headline: Tim Johnson’s Condition Upgraded
text: Senator Tim Johnson, the South Dakota Democrat who underwent emergency brain surgery in mid-December following a brain hemmorrhage, is making gradual improvement. His office announced today that his condition has been upgraded from “critical” to “fair.” Here’s what his office had to say in a press release:

headline: Flawed or Flawless
text: It may be a curiously extreme way to pose the question, but that phrase is the subtitle of a new “oral biography” of Rudolph W. Giuliani to be published Jan. 20.

headline: No More Middleman
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 5 column, “First, Do Less Harm.”

headline: 2008 Nuggets: South Rising
text: Senator John McCain has just signed on Alec Poitevint, currently the chairman of the Georgia G.O.P., to be his organization’s Southern co-chairman. The Atlanta Journal-Constitution’s Political Insiders have more:

text: Is New York City behind the curve on wireless Internet? Apparently. [The Politicker]

headline: Leggo My Ego
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 8 column, “Quagmire of the Vanities.”

headline: Tired of Taking It On the Chin
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 8 column, “Working Harder for the Man.“

headline: Creating a Heavier Footprint in Iraq
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Jan. 7 column, “Making the Surge Work.”

headline: Blogtalk: To Not Go Gently …
text: With the Democrats beginning their first 100 hours in control of Congress and with President Bush preparing to reveal his newest new strategy for Iraq, two streams joined this week to form a river of criticism and prediction on the conservative blogs.

headline: To Surge or Not
text: Much has been made in recent weeks of the Bush administration’s use of the term “troop surge,” to describe the option it is considering of sending more troops (say 20,000) into Iraq, presumably for a specified amount of time, with a mission to quell the sectarian violence that everyone agrees has been unrelenting.

headline: Moved to New Address
text: I’m blogging away this week, but you’ll find my posts at  this special trade-show address.

headline: Some Hands-On Time With the iPhone
text: Update: This post is from David Pogue’s initial look at the iPhone in January. For updated information, click on the following links:

headline: Two Stars Enter Hall; Steroid Cloud Stops 3rd
text: Mark McGwire hit 70 home runs in 1998 to shatter Roger Maris’s single-season mark of 61 and help restore popularity to a sport damaged by a strike that led to the cancellation of the 1994 World Series. But since then, McGwire’s image had been increasingly damaged.

headline: Les Moonves on the Digital Future of CBS
text: Early in his keynote speech this afternoon at CES, CBS chief Les Moonves said that the music business suffered from not listening to Internet audiences. He vowed that CBS would not hesitate to take risks, invest in start-ups and exploit online communities. “The place for any media company is right up front, ripping, burning and mashing up the new beat we are all marching to,” he said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Wednesday about prominent people who attended the funeral of former President Gerald R. Ford referred incorrectly to George Allen, Republican of Virginia. His Senate term ended at noon last Wednesday. At the time he arrived for the funeral, he was not a former lawmaker.

headline: Moving Ahead on Stem Cells
text: House Democrats are poised to push through a bill this week that would loosen President Bush’s restrictions on federal support of embryonic stem cell research. The bill will be opposed by legislators beholden to religious conservatives. Many are likely to cite a new study suggesting that broadly useful stem cells can be derived from amniotic fluid without destroying embryos to get them.

headline: Home Depot Board Faces New Outcry
text: Now that the board has ousted Home Depot’s chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, shareholders are expecting big changes at the home improvement retailing giant.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Dec. 19, about the financial problems that health plans for retired government workers are causing in some cities, misstated the amount that New York City intends to set aside in a trust fund to pay for its retired workers’ health care. It is $2 billion, which is to be paid over fiscal years 2006 and 2007 — not $2.2 billion, which is the city’s contribution to the trust fund in fiscal 2006 as well as its outlay for retiree health care in the same year.

headline: Slot Machines May Ring Where Steel Was Once Forged
text: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 4 — Since its coke ovens shut down for the last time in 1998, the mile-long Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant has been a rusty reminder of this small Lehigh Valley city’s proud industrial past. Trees have sprouted between the red bricks, and birds have nested in wire baskets in which steel workers once stored their belongings.

headline: Starting New Term, Chávez Defends Recent Moves
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 10 — President Hugo Chávez was sworn in to a new six-year term at a ceremony here today, calling Jesus Christ “the greatest socialist in history” and pledging to speed Venezuela’s metamorphosis into a socialist state.

headline: Earthy Cuban Sounds, Rendered With an Urban Complexity
text: If you’ve been curious about the state of new music in Cuba, Sequitur offered an answer of sorts in its program at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening. But it was an answer with an asterisk, for although the six composers on the program were all born in Cuba, and most began their musical training there, they live elsewhere now.

headline: Queens: Four Charged With Attempted Murder
text: Four young men from Queens have been charged with trying to kill a man in Woodside on Friday because they suspected him of spraying graffiti on the house of one member of the group, prosecutors said yesterday. The four — Ali Khan, 19, Aamer Khan, 18, Christian Diaz, 17, and Joseph Piazza, 18 — are charged with attempted murder and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said the group was riding in a Ford Explorer with the victim, Anthony Albaricci, 24, when one man looped a belt around Mr. Albaricci’s neck and began strangling him. Another stabbed Mr. Albaricci, while one slashed him with a razor. Aamer Khan, who was driving, turned and tried to shoot him with a pistol, Mr. Brown said. The Explorer crashed and Mr. Albaricci fled, only to be chased and beaten with a wooden chair by two of the teenagers, Mr. Brown said, while the other two ran him down with the Explorer.

headline: Investigators Start Work After Malibu Fire
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9  Investigators inspected the wreckage of five oceanfront homes in Malibu on Tuesday trying to determine the cause of a fast-moving fire the night before that destroyed them and damaged several others.

headline: Kidd Files for Divorce, Adding to a Trying Season for the Nets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 9 — The morning before he played the 900th N.B.A. game of his career, Nets point guard Jason Kidd felt compelled to address his personal life, and not for the first time. Kidd obtained a temporary restraining order against his wife, Joumana, on Monday and filed for divorce Tuesday, the latest chapter in a marriage whose turbulent moments have played out in public.

headline: Suspensions After Brawl Animated the Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 9 — Fists flew, mayhem reigned and the Knicks were sentenced to three weeks of unmitigated suffering for their transgressions. Wasn’t that the idea when the National Basketball Association penalized them for brawling with the Denver Nuggets last month?

headline: A Film Festival for a Jewish World That Spans the Globe
text: There is an old Jewish joke — the definitive old Jewish joke, perhaps — in which a man is stranded for years on a desert island. When his rescuers finally arrive, they discover that he has built not one synagogue, but two. Why? The answer is obvious: “This one I pray in every day, but that one, I wouldn’t go near it.”

headline: Hot Stuff
text: SILICONE kitchen tools have been lending a playful, psychedelic air to kitchens across the country, especially those where stark, sophisticated stainless steel had been the coin of the realm. The new tools appear in colors from electric green and royal purple to sweetheart pink and terra cotta and come in every shape imaginable.

headline: A Humble Grape That’s Had Its Day
text: IF there is a villain in the story of Madeira’s fall from grace, it is the tinta negra mole grape.

headline: Week’s Notables
text: CLUB In Spain, Deportivo Alavés, a club run by the mercurial American Dimitry Piterman, hired Fabri González as the club’s third coach of the season. Alavés, which was relegated from the top-flight La Liga last season, plays Barcelona today in a Round of 16 match in the King’s Cup. Last year Piterman bought a franchise, the San Francisco-based California Victory, that will begin play this season in the United Soccer Leagues First Division.

headline: Poor Hospital Practices Blamed for 2003 SARS Epidemic in Toronto
text: TORONTO, Jan. 9  A provincial commission investigating the SARS outbreak in 2003 reported Tuesday that poor hospital infection-control procedures led to the epidemic in the Toronto area that killed 44 people.

headline: House Passes Security Bill; Senate Stance Is Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Delivering on a major campaign promise, House Democrats used their new majority Tuesday to push through a bill that would write into law several remaining recommendations of the Sept. 11 commission.

headline: Bush to Propose Restoring Iraqi Factories to Create Jobs
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 9 — A new effort to revitalize Iraqi factories that make vegetable oil, fertilizer, road signs and sulfuric acid — among the world’s most outdated and decrepit — is expected to be at the center of the plan for the nation that President Bush will present Wednesday.

headline: Energy Standoff Between Russia and Belarus Intensifies
text: Top stories from Russian newspapers on Wednesday:

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening Soon

headline: Doctor Confronts the Human Drama’s Inevitable Finale
text: When it comes to confronting death, doctors are as much at a loss as the rest of us. They are in the business of saving lives, not ending them. By instinct and by training, they avoid what Pauline W. Chen calls “the final exam,” the emotional challenges posed by terminally ill patients. Death represents failure. It asks unanswerable questions. Perhaps most vexingly, it threatens to crack the hard professional shell of detachment that medical training puts in place. In modern American medicine, death is everywhere and nowhere at the same time.

headline: Tale of Armed Abduction Gives Way to Murder Charge
text: The 25-year-old woman delivered a lengthy video confession to the police, hesitating as she spoke, at times stoic, at other times tearful, slowly explaining the disappearance and death of her newborn son, investigators said yesterday.

headline: Free Will (or Is It?) (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The History of Crunchy, Revisited
text: WHEN the first mass-produced granola came on the market in the 1970’s, it was greeted with a touch of disbelief by many of us, as in, “how dare they?” If ever there was a homegrown food it was granola. Yet nostalgia isn’t the only reason we should honor its roots.

headline: Yes to Potholders, No to Floppy Pans
text: Here are silicone products I found to be good or bad, useful or not so useful, in tests over four days. These items contain no fillers and are available online and at kitchenware shops, including the Art of Cooking, Broadway Panhandler, Sur La Table and Zabar’s. Prices are approximate and may vary.

headline: A Hopeful Ponders Where to Plant Her Flag
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — Choices, choices. The Four Seasons in Georgetown or the Four Seasons in Midtown? A town full of political leaks or a town full of mysterious odors? Easy access to hundreds of gabby Democratic strategists or easy access to the one gabby Democrat who matters most (one’s husband, perhaps)?

headline: Well-Grounded Ethics Reform
text: The Senate’s new majority leader, Harry Reid, like most of his colleagues on both sides of the aisle, is an admitted frequent flier on posh lobbyist-provided corporate jets. So we were very pleased yesterday when he proposed legislation that would require senators to pay the full charter-flight fare if they wanted to ride in the style of a C.E.O.

headline: Agency Affirms Human Influence on Climate
text: President Bush has said it.

headline: Myanmar: U.S. Seeks U.N. Pressure on Repression
text: The United States introduced a Security Council resolution calling on the military rulers of Myanmar, formerly Burma, to begin a transition to democracy and release all political prisoners, including Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning opposition leader. China and Russia both oppose the move, but Alejandro D. Wolff, the acting American ambassador, said he hoped for a vote this week. Mr. Wolff said that the release of 2,831 prisoners announced last week had focused on petty criminals. “If you look at the facts,” he said. “you’ll find that there are more political prisoners today than there were a year ago.”

headline: New Serials: Now You See Them, Now You Don’t
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 — For the last several years, executives at other television networks have dreaded the annual debut of “24,” the Fox hit that, with its continuing storyline about a secret agent saving the nation unwinding from one episode to the next, is the ultimate serial drama.

headline: U.S. and Iraqis Hit Insurgents in All-Day Fight
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 9  More than 1,000 American and Iraqi troops, backed by Apache attack helicopters and fighter jets, battled insurgents all day Tuesday and late into the night in downtown Baghdad, in one of the most dramatic operations in the capital since the invasion nearly four years ago.

headline: Brooklyn: Case Against Ex-F.B.I. Agent Can Proceed
text: A retired F.B.I. supervisor accused of aiding in Mafia murders is not immune from prosecution in state court, a Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday. The retired agent, R. Lindley DeVecchio, 66, was charged with four counts of murder last March in State Supreme Court. Prosecutors say Mr. DeVecchio, who was responsible for managing confidential informants, played a role in four killings between 1984 and 1992 by giving information to the Colombo crime family. In April, Mr. DeVecchio’s lawyers sought to remove the case to federal court, arguing that the evidence was subject to federal grants of immunity and that his defense was based on federal law. But Judge Frederic Block ruled that Mr. DeVecchio had not presented a valid argument.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,998 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: First Flurries of the Year Seen in Central Park
text: Today, Jan. 10, a date which will live in meteorological history, snow flurries were glimpsed for the first time this winter in Central Park.

headline: Bush Drops Plans to Renominate 3 Judges
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — In an apparent effort to lower the temperature in the fierce battle over federal judges — and in a concession to political reality — President Bush said Tuesday that he was dropping plans to nominate three of his choices for the federal appeals courts who have been vigorously opposed by Senate Democrats.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Friday about Vincent Sardi Jr., who owned and managed the Broadway landmark Sardi’s restaurant for more than half a century, misstated the year in which he was on Okinawa as a member of the Marines helping to supervise a rest camp. It was 1945, after United States forces had taken control of the island, not 1943.

headline: House Votes to Raise Minimum Wage
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — The House overwhelmingly approved a $2.10-an-hour increase in the federal minimum wage this afternoon in a decisive vote that Democrats hailed as an overdue raise for low-income workers and a symbol of new leadership on Capitol Hill.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Directors Guild Announces Nominees

headline: Big Three Look Back to Past Glories and Dream of Muscle
text: DETROIT, Jan. 9 — One of the Ford Motor Company’s showcase concept cars is the imposing Interceptor sedan, with its big wheels and a burly front end that suggests an armor-plated battering ram.

headline: Three Recent Meals Point the Way to Fish in Red Wine Sauce
text: FISH served with red wine has long stopped being a culinary faux pas. But for this pairing I wanted the fish to be in red wine, not just with it.

headline: Two Places Where Readers Hold On to Their Bookstores
text: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.

headline: New York Tries to Think Outside the Sandbox
text: New York City, with its rich history of public playgrounds, is on the verge of a bold experiment in the way children play, one that could accelerate the trend away from monkey bars, swings and seesaws used by generations of city children.

headline: Blood Center Warns of Dangerously Low Supplies in New York Region
text: The New York region’s blood supply has dropped to a five-year low, prompting blood bank officials to warn yesterday of life-threatening shortages if donations do not increase.

headline: For Two, a Day of Recognition; For One, a Day of Reckoning
text: Mark McGwire seemed contorted with tension, his face flushed red, his eyes watering up on March 17, 2005, when he ducked the question of whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Democrats, Be Yourselves (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mother and Two Teenagers Make the Most of Cramped Spaces and Unlimited Goals
text: Life is tight in the small apartment. Tight physically. Tight financially. But there is still room for large aspirations.

headline: A Brighter Future for a Wine With a Past
text: AMERICANS these days drink wines from almost every state, continent and grape. Yet at one time they drank essentially only one: Madeira, a rich fortified wine from the Portuguese island in the Atlantic that gave it its name.

headline: Steroid Cloud Stops McGwire From Entering Hall
text: Cal Ripken was the ironman who played in 2,632 consecutive games, Tony Gwynn was the hitting machine who won eight batting titles, and yesterday both were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in near-unanimous votes. But their achievements were overshadowed by the voters’ rejection of Mark McGwire, a slugger who seemed like a modern-day Paul Bunyan before he fell into disrepute because of suspected steroid use.

headline: Dell Says Plant a Tree, Help the Environment
text: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 9 — Michael S. Dell, who made his name building computers, has a new goal: planting trees.

headline: The Good News (Really) About Voting Machines
text: In the summer of 2004, I attended a national meeting of state election directors, and one of the biggest laugh lines was how activists were demanding that electronic voting machines produce a paper record of every vote cast.

headline: Manhattan: Strategist to Leave Union
text: Jennifer Cunningham, the top political strategist at what is considered the state’s most politically powerful union — 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East — said yesterday that she was leaving the union to join a political consulting firm in New York City and a lobbying firm in Albany. Ms. Cunningham, a former deputy counsel to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, will become a partner at Knickerbocker SKD, a consulting firm. She will also be of counsel to Featherstonhaugh, Wiley, Clyne & Cordo, a lobbying and law firm in Albany. Ms. Cunningham said she would represent 1199 on many matters. She said she was leaving 1199 to spend more time with her 14-year-old daughter. “I don’t see it as leaving the union so much as changing the nature of my relations with the union,” she said. Dennis Rivera, 1199’s president, said, “We look forward to working with her for many years to come.”

headline: 2 U.S. Cities to Vie for Bid to Games
text: The United States will bid to be the host country for the 2016 Summer Olympics in either Los Angeles or Chicago, the United States Olympic Committee announced yesterday.

headline: Venezuelan Plan Shakes Investors
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 9 — Verizon Communications had been looking to lighten its exposure to Latin America for some time when it struck a deal in April to sell investments in three properties in Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Venezuela.

headline: Our Civil Liberties: Congress Must Act (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taken by the Tide
text: New Orleans

headline: St.-Émilions, Ripe From the Heat of 2003
text: THE 2003 vintage in Europe has been characterized as bordering on the bizarre. The weather was extreme, particularly in France, where a long, deadly August heat wave challenged winemakers.

headline: A Good Call in New York
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York set an important national example this week when he announced that the state corrections department would back away from a longstanding policy of charging prison inmates and their families more than six times the going rate for collect calls made from prison.

headline: Democrats Plan Symbolic Votes Against Iraq Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — Democratic leaders said Tuesday that they intended to hold symbolic votes in the House and Senate on President Bush’s plan to send more troops to Baghdad, forcing Republicans to take a stand on the proposal and seeking to isolate the president politically over his handling of the war.

headline: Two Upstarts Don Their Elders’ Laurels
text: HERE’S the epitome of a safe bet: Whenever the next Zagat Survey for New York City restaurants comes out, Gramercy Tavern and Union Square Cafe, the Danny Meyer mainstays, will be rated most popular. And in the survey after that, they’ll rule. They always do. They’re like a pair of preternaturally blessed prom queens in a high school where senior year never ends.

headline: Mayor Vows to Crack Down on New Orleans Violence
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9  Reeling from a spate of killings that threatens this city’s economic lifeline, tourism, officials gathered at the site of the year’s first murder Tuesday evening and promised to redouble crime-fighting efforts.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article and headline yesterday about the death of a disturbed man who apparently went into cardiac arrest after being shot with a Taser stun gun during a struggle with New York City police officers misidentified his borough of residence in some copies. He was from Brooklyn, not Queens.

headline: At the Temples of Food, an Outsider’s Look at the Sacred Texts
text: YOU won’t often hear this from people in the business of writing or talking about food, but it takes some nerve to tell other people what to eat. Yet apparently millions of us just love being nudged or browbeaten into particular chowlines by someone else with an air of authority, from weight-loss guru to restaurant reviewer.

headline: Johnson Happy to Be Back With the Diamondbacks
text: PHOENIX, Jan. 9 — Randy Johnson is delighted to be back in an Arizona Diamondbacks uniform, and he sounds eager to prove wrong the critics who believe he is washed up.

headline: An Author’s Vision of the Mean Streets of Mumbai
text: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 9 — A sweet Arts and Crafts bungalow with potted pansies and a puppy in the window seems an unlikely place to encounter a celebrated Indian author who possesses an intimate knowledge of what happens when a Mumbai gangster’s AK-47 meets up close and personal with an adversary’s skull.

headline: Thailand May Add Measures to Restrict Foreign Investment
text: Thailand warned yesterday that it might add further restrictions to foreign investors, ignoring warnings that the move was ill timed and damaging for a fragile economy already struggling to overcome the stigma of a military coup and the instability caused by recent bombings in Bangkok.

headline: Nets Overcome Their Off-Court Distractions
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 9 — The Nets have won four of five games, they are back atop the Atlantic Division and Vince Carter scored 32 points against his former team.

headline: Tiny Shoppers, Big Appetites
text: Kidfresh, a bright children’s food store on the Upper East Side, is the result of Matt Cohen’s light bulb. He said he was inspired to start the company because he had to fix lunches for his two young children. “There are lots of choices in prepared foods for adults, but for kids it’s mostly fast food or nothing,” he said.

headline: Wii Outsells PlayStation 3 in Japan
text: TOKYO, Jan. 10 — Japan is offering some of the first glimpses into the hotly contested market for new video game consoles, and the view so far doesn’t look good for struggling Sony and its much-touted PlayStation 3.

headline: Democrats Rush to Frame Political Debate Over Troops
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — “Cut and run” versus “stay the course” is so 2006.

headline: This Lexus Gets an F, and That’s a Good Thing
text: Introduced on Monday: 2008 Lexus IS-F

headline: Separatists Admit to Madrid Airport Attack but Stand by Cease-Fire
text: MADRID, Jan. 9 — The armed Basque separatist organization ETA said Tuesday that the “permanent cease-fire” it announced last March was still in effect, even as it formally claimed responsibility for the deadly bomb attack on Madrid’s main airport terminal 10 days ago.

headline: S.M.U. Faculty Complains About Bush Library
text: DALLAS, Jan. 9 — Intimates of President Bush have singled out Southern Methodist University as the likely site of his presidential library, but faculty members, complaining of being bypassed, are raising sharp questions about the school’s identification with his presidency.

headline: What’s Next for a Mysterious Stench? Theories, Punch Lines and Cyberspace
text: They could no longer smell it, but they could still talk about it.

headline: This Time, a True Strategy for Iraq? (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Florida Shows It Belongs by Winning Title With Ease
text: GLENDALE, Ariz., Jan. 8 — The Florida Gators navigated their way through a grueling Southeastern Conference schedule, mastering the art of winning ugly.

headline: Texas Speaker Wins Challenge and Keeps Post
text: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 9  Speaker Tom Craddick of the Texas House, an ally of the former United States House majority leader Tom DeLay, survived a strong challenge on Tuesday from a fellow Republican to win his third term in the leadership position on the first day of the 80th session of the Legislature.

headline: Jane Bolin, the Country’s First Black Woman to Become a Judge, Is Dead at 98
text: Jane Bolin, whose appointment as a family court judge by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1939 made her the first black woman in the United States to become a judge, died on Monday in Queens. She was 98 and lived in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: A Journey to Ethiopia, Citified Yet Authentic
text: THE modish, minimalist décor tips you off that things are a little different at Zoma, a new Ethiopian restaurant just north of Central Park on Fredrick Douglass Boulevard.

headline: Britain: Terrorism Warnings by E-Mail
text: The British security service known as MI5 is using e-mail to alert the public to changes in the security threat level. Internet users may register on MI5’s Web site to receive the electronic updates. On Nov. 9, the agency’s director general, Dame Eliza Manningham-Buller, said that Britain was facing as many as 30 terrorist plots and that terrorists might soon be using nuclear or biological weapons. Dame Eliza, who is retiring in April, has been more public than her predecessors in warning of suspected threats. In August, MI5 began posting details of the threat level, which is set by the government’s Joint Terrorism Analysis Center, on its Web site. The threat level has five tiers and is now at “severe,” the second highest, which means an attack is considered highly likely.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Jan. 1 about plans by the Walt Disney Company to introduce a revamped Web site at the Consumer Electronics Show referred incorrectly to the business relationship between Apple and Pixar Animation Studios. While Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, was once the majority shareholder in Pixar, Apple never owned the animation studio.

headline: AIDS Drug Study Offers Hope for Pregnant Women
text: Women can take the anti-AIDS drug nevirapine to protect their unborn children without endangering their ability to undergo life-saving antiretroviral treatment later on, a new study has found.

headline: All the Sensitive Noses Show Just How a City Has Changed
text: Basic science can explain how the latest mystery odor spread so far so fast on both sides of the Hudson River on Monday, but it cannot easily determine the source of the sulfurous smell. Nor can science account for the public panic and lingering suspicions, because those responses largely stem from fears and expectations.

headline: Banks Settle Claims in Auction Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (Dow Jones/AP)  A subsidiary of Deutsche Bank, the Bank of New York Company and the Wilmington Trust Company have agreed to pay a combined $1.6 million to settle claims in an investigation of the $200 billion auction-rate securities market.

headline: Savoring a Taste of Life in the Big Time
text: In the argot of the soccer world, they are known as minnows — clubs from the lower divisions who often change into giant-killers, waiting and dreaming of headline-grabbing upsets in domestic cup competitions.

headline: Wisconsin Defeats Ohio State in a Clash of Top-5 Teams
text: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 9  For one of the few times all game, Wisconsin fans at the Kohl Center turned oddly silent. A Badgers victory that 10 minutes earlier seemed assured was suddenly in peril, and many held their breath as Jamar Butler’s 3-point attempt to tie the score descended toward the cylinder in the final seconds.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart last Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about links between education and longevity misstated a correlation. People with more education are more likely — not less — to have had at least one alcoholic drink per month.

headline: Massachusetts Could Serve as a Guide in California’s Health Insurance Bid
text: BOSTON, Jan. 9 — In its drive to provide health insurance to nearly all its residents, Massachusetts has already signed up more than half of the poorest people who are eligible.

headline: Viewership Ranks 3rd for a B.C.S. Final
text: Florida’s 41-14 rout of Ohio State in the Bowl Championship Series national title game Monday night attracted an average of 28.8 million viewers to the Fox broadcast, making it the third-most-watched college football title game since the B.C.S.’s debut in the 1998-99 season.

headline: Gone, but Not Forgotten
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Kurdish Prisons (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Prohibits All Transactions With a Major Iranian Bank
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The United States, moving to raise pressure on Iran, on Tuesday barred American financial institutions from doing business with a major Iranian bank after concluding that it had been involved in illicit weapons programs.

headline: New Jersey Governor Calls for ‘Risks’ and ‘Dreams’ to Fix State’s Problems
text: TRENTON, Jan. 9  From leasing the New Jersey Turnpike to selling unions on the notion of shared sacrifice, Gov. Jon S. Corzine challenged legislators in his State of the State address on Tuesday to “risk more than others think is safe” and “dream more than others think is practical” to help ease the state’s considerable fiscal difficulties.

headline: Congress to Take Up Net’s Future
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Senior lawmakers, emboldened by the recent restrictions on AT&T and the change in control of Congress, have begun drafting legislation that would prevent high-speed Internet companies from charging content providers for priority access.

headline: The Future of Economics Is Not So Dismal
text: Chicago

headline: Light a Bulb, Save Earth (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Warsaw’s Enclave of Villas
text: Warsaw is densely covered with Communist-era housing projects, so finding a village-like setting just minutes from the bustling city center seems like an unattainable dream. But the city has its surprises, like Saska Kepa, a green enclave of villas across the Vistula River from downtown.

headline: China's Trade Surplus Sets Record
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 10 — China’s trade surplus in 2006 soared to $177.47 billion, far more than in any previous year on record, as the country’s exports continued to grow briskly, the Chinese customs administration announced this evening.

headline: Trading Math Class for Corsets and Minis
text: Six years ago a couple I know took their son, then 8, and daughter, 5, to a resort on the Isle of Elba, where, on the final night of their stay, the children participated in a talent show. Such was the resort staff’s understanding of talent that the little girls were asked to wear bathing suits and swoon over a 10-year-old playing a lifeguard, while the little boys removed the slickers they were wearing in a simulated striptease to the tune of “It’s Raining Men.” In a moment that left my friends feeling vaguely litigious, their son appeared onstage by himself to perform Tom Jones’s “Sex Bomb.”

headline: For a Boy Stumbling Over Words, a Dog Is the Ideal Reading Partner
text: THE PROBLEM Like many children, the little boy had learned to recognize common words from memory in kindergarten, and to sound out simple words — the first steps toward reading. Most children catch on fairly easily after this, figuring out how to use the meaning of words and sentences as a guide to greater fluency. But at age 9, when he was a third grader at a school in rural Massachusetts, this boy had never made that leap. While most children his age could read simple chapter books, he could not even read the short phrases in a picture book.

headline: Mayor’s Ultra-Secure Hot Line Gets Some Cold Sales Calls
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — It seems like a throwback to the cold war, a time when red telephones with direct lines to Moscow and leather briefcases with nuclear codes were grave symbols of international anxiety.

headline: Britain: An Increase in Profit at the London Stock Exchange
text: The London Stock Exchange, seeking to fend off a hostile takeover by the Nasdaq Stock Market, reported a 9.9 percent increase in third-quarter profit and forecast a “strong performance” in fiscal 2008. Net income rose to £31 million ($59.8 million) in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from £28.2 million a year earlier, the exchange said. Revenue increased 11 percent, to £89.9 million ($173.5 million). The third-quarter results “support the board’s rejection of Nasdaq’s offer, which significantly undervalues the business and the exchange’s unique strategic position,” the exchange’s chief executive, Clara Furse, said. “Our strong growth prospects will continue to enhance the quality of our markets.” The exchange, Europe’s biggest equity market, released its earnings about three weeks ahead of schedule and two days before Nasdaq’s offer to pay £12.43 a share expires.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the presidential campaign of Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, misidentified the home state of Mike Huckabee, another former governor who is also a prospective Republican candidate for president. He was the governor of Arkansas, not Arizona.

headline: Florida Had a Plan and Executed It
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., Jan. 9 — The moments all played out after Florida’s upset of Ohio State on Monday in the Bowl Championship Series title game as if they had been scripted.

headline: Warm Temperatures Chill the Ice Fishing Season
text: BUFFALO, Jan. 9 — For 20 years, Capt. Kevin Caffery traced Lake Erie’s frozen shoreline in the gathering twilight of late winter afternoons. From his helicopter, he scanned for parked cars belonging to ice fishermen. If the cars had not been retrieved, it could mean men were stranded miles offshore on shifting ice floes.

headline: A Playwright’s Horror Show of Cultural and Racial Identity
text: Thomas Bradshaw, the button-pushing writer of the new drama “Purity,” has become something of a downtown darling. Time Out New York called him a playwright to watch; Paper magazine named him one of the most beautiful people of 2006; and Margo Jefferson in this newspaper hailed his last play, “Prophet,” as a “satire with a vengeance.”

headline: A Procession of Penguins Arrives on Madison Ave.
text: NEVER mind what the Chinese calendar says. This is going to be the year of the penguin, at least on Madison Avenue.

headline: Revisiting a Relationship Defined by Its Silences
text: The best thing about “RiddleLikeLove (with a side of ketchup),” a one-woman show performed by Julie Fitzpatrick, is that not much happens onstage. That leaves you free to watch the American Sign Language interpretation being offered to the side, which gives the show a welcome extra dimension.

headline: Aints to Saints, Child to Man, a Family Affair
text: EUNICE, La., Jan. 9 — Since Hurricane Katrina, the resurgent New Orleans Saints may be America’s team, but they are not completely Louisiana’s team.

headline: Trade Deficit Improves for Third Straight Month
text: American manufacturers sold more goods like airplanes, cars and jewelry to foreign countries in November, helping to narrow the nation’s trade deficit with the rest of the world for the third straight month.

headline: New School Campus Is Approved for the Bronx
text: The New York City Council yesterday unanimously approved the construction of a $235 million campus with four secondary schools, a football field and basketball courts on old railyards in the South Bronx.

headline: Hard Times for Innovative School
text: A school is a fragile thing. That’s particularly so if it is small, homegrown and designed by an educator with an idiosyncratic vision.

headline: A Nation With a Long Memory, but a Truncated History
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 — History classes across the globe serve two purposes — they educate the young and they shape national identity. They also often sidestep controversy to avoid offense.

headline: Minor League Deal for Difelice
text: The Mets signed the journeyman catcher Mike DiFelice to a minor league contract yesterday. DiFelice, 37, was added to the Mets’ major league roster in August when the backup catcher Ramon Castro went on the disabled list because of a sore left rib cage. In 15 games with the Mets, DiFelice batted .080. Castro returned for the playoffs, and DiFelice was left off the postseason roster.

headline: Buying in Central America
text: When Steve Carl steps out of his three-bedroom beach house in Ambergris Caye in northern Belize, snorkeling at one of the largest barrier reefs in the world is just a short swim away and going to dinner means leaving footwear behind.

headline: Correction: Music and Food? The Pros Step In
text: An article last week about music in restaurants misstated the relationship between Muzak and ’Wichcraft restaurants. Muzak provided stereo equipment for a ’Wichcraft restaurant in San Francisco. It does not provide the chain with recorded music.

headline: Mayor Finds Friendly Ears on Senate Homeland Security Panel
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took his perennial pitch for more security money to Congress on Tuesday, but this year, for a change, lawmakers seemed poised to listen.

headline: Emissions Plan for Airlines Opposed by U.S. Diplomat
text: A United States diplomat warned the European Commission against adopting rules that would impose emission controls on all flights landing at European airports, a signal that Washington may take legal action if the measure became law. The diplomat, John R. Byerly, left, deputy assistant secretary of state for transportation affairs, called the proposal “unworkable and unlawful.” The plan would force foreign airlines flying in Europe to pay for carbon dioxide emissions. Under the proposal, airlines would have to meet emissions targets starting Jan. 1, 2011, for all flights landing within the 27-member European Union. Mr. Byerly’s comments came on the eve of two days of formal talks with European officials aimed at concluding an “open skies” treaty to open up the trans-Atlantic aviation market.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: In Cingular-Apple Deal, Only Phone Was Missing
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 — When Cingular executives went to the company’s board last year to get approval for a deal with Apple, they did so without so much as a prototype of an Apple phone to show the directors. The board signed off anyway.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart last Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about links between education and longevity misstated a correlation. People with more education are more likely — not less — to have had at least one alcoholic drink per month. (Go to Article)

headline: Today in Business
text: CHáVEZ PLAN DRAWS ALARM Investors reacted with alarm in the United States and throughout Latin America as they measured the impact of a plan by Venezuela’s president, Hugo Chávez, left, to nationalize critical areas of the economy. Flashbacks of past nationalizations during another turbulent era, in places like Cuba and Chile, helped drive down the Caracas stock exchange’s main index by almost 19 percent. [Page A1.]

headline: Just a Simple Taxi Ride (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Circuit in Europe Bedeviled by Heat Wave in the Alps
text: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 9  Another heat wave is wreaking havoc with the World Cup skiing circuit this week, and this time warm temperatures melting the snow in the Alps are threatening the most important races in the sport.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the energy efficient ways of the Japanese misstated the amount of energy consumed in Japan and the United States as measured in tons of oil per person. Japan consumed the energy equivalent of 2.8 tons of oil per person in 2004, not 2.8 million tons. Likewise, the United States consumed 5.4 tons of oil per person, not 5.4 million tons. The article also referred imprecisely to the output from a home fuel cell used by a Japanese homeowner, Kiminobu Kimura. The cell produces one kilowatt of power per hour; not one kilowatt per hour.

headline: Schwarzenegger Orders Cuts in Emissions
text: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 9 — Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Tuesday that he would ask regulators to require the state’s petroleum refiners and gasoline sellers to cut by 10 percent the emissions of heat-trapping gases associated with the production and use of their products.

headline: The Colts Say Manning Just Wants Perfection
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9 — Peyton Manning views the forward pass as an extension of his very being, the result of a life spent punching the clock in the family business.

headline: U.S. to Raise Royalty Rates for Oil and Gas Leases in the Gulf
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Bush administration, accused of failing to collect billions of dollars from companies that drill for oil and gas in federal waters, announced on Tuesday that it would demand higher royalties on all new deepwater leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: The Breakfast Wars
text: LAST Wednesday at a Starbucks in Times Square, Katie Voss, a nursing student, was drinking one of the chain’s new coffee creations, a cinnamon-flavored low-fat latte. Ms. Voss, who was visiting from Maryland, said she visits Starbucks every day — up to three times a day, in fact — but rarely eats anything.

headline: G.M. Officer Says Toyota Is Stronger in Washington
text: DETROIT, Jan. 9 — Toyota has not yet passed General Motors to become the world’s biggest carmaker, but Robert A. Lutz, G.M.’s vice chairman, says his company has fallen behind its rival in terms of clout on Capitol Hill.

headline: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — President Bush announced tonight that he was sending more than 21,000 American troops to Iraq to quell the sectarian violence there, as he conceded for the first time that he had provided neither enough troops nor enough resources to halt the country’s descent into chaos over the past year.

headline: Insurgents Battle Somali Forces in Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 10 — The capital of Somalia exploded in violence this morning after insurgents attacked a government barracks overnight and soldiers responded by sealing off large swaths of the city and searching house to house for weapons.

headline: Letters
text: Outfoxed by Sara Lee

headline: Judge Sends Public Defender to Jail
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9  The chief judge in the city’s juvenile courts had a top public defender arrested Tuesday in a bizarre escalation of a fight over changes in the city’s troubled program for representing indigent defendants.

headline: In Testing for Gifted Programs, a Few Knots
text: A new admissions process for highly coveted gifted-and-talented programs in the New York City elementary schools has been riddled with glitches, including last-minute notice of entrance exam dates in some areas, fraying the nerves of parents already frazzled about finding schools for their children.

headline: Recipe: Oven-Roasted Branzino With Hazelnut Picada
text: Oven-Roasted Branzino with Hazelnut Picada Adapted from “The Zuni Cafe Cookbook,” by Judy Rodgers (W.W. Norton, 2002)

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music column on Saturday about the View, a Scottish band from Dundee that made its American debut last week in New York, misstated the name of a Dundee suburb that one of its songs apparently refers to. It is Broughty Ferry, not Broughton Ferry.

headline: 3 Relatives of Plotter Are Held by Officials
text: The parents and sister of a man convicted of conspiring to bomb the Herald Square subway station were detained yesterday by federal immigration authorities, who have been seeking to deport them to Pakistan.

headline: Dow Jones Plans Layoffs at Newswires and Factiva
text: Dow Jones Plans Layoffs at Newswires and Factiva

headline: Educated and Healthy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:
