headline: Russia Considers Alternatives to Oil Pipeline Through Belarus
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 — An unyielding President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday raised the possibility of diverting oil transit routes away from Belarus, a day after Moscow cut off pipeline deliveries of crude oil headed to customers in Eastern and Central Europe through the country.

headline: Recipe: Crunchy Granola
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: At Yale, Renovation Puts Africa in Spotlight
text: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 3 — Fans of air, light and it-just-feels-right in architecture will find everything to admire in the revamped and revivified version of the Yale University Art Gallery’s Louis Kahn building. Post-Kahnian partitions have been pulled down, picture windows uncovered. Rangy Modernist space — the space of the future when the building opened in 1953 — unfurls in all directions.

headline: What’s on Wednesday Night
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) CHINA FROM THE INSIDE For all of China’s vaunted power, much of the country remains a mystery to the outside world. This four-part documentary travels from the Great Wall, temples in Tibet and the border areas of Muslim Xinjiang to courtrooms, newspaper offices and a women’s labor camp to paint of a portrait of its 1.3 billion people in all their contradictions. Tonight’s episodes look at the Communist Party, at 9; and the country’s women, who have one of the highest suicide rates in the world, at 10. The series continues on Jan. 17.

headline: Iwao Takamoto, 81, the Animation Artist Who Created Scooby-Doo, Dies
text: Iwao Takamoto, the artist who created the mystery-solving Great Dane, Scooby-Doo, among many other indelible cartoon characters, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Ex-Putnam Chief Settles
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (Dow Jones/AP)  The former chief executive of Putnam, Lawrence J. Lasser, will pay $75,000 to settle accusations that he failed to disclose that the investment company used fund assets to pay brokerage firms for preferred marketing agreements, regulators announced Tuesday.

headline: Defense Dept. Settles Suit on Database for Recruiting
text: The Defense Department yesterday announced changes in how it will treat information in an enormous military recruiting database.

headline: Big Names Competing for India’s 2¢-a-Minute Caller
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 9 — When Krishnadeo Prasad Verma calls you from his mobile phone, there is a flicker of a ring, then silence.

headline: The World Has Nearly Ended, but Movies Manage to Survive
text: A faux documentary with a twist, “Ever Since the World Ended” unfolds in and around an eerily depopulated San Francisco 10 years after a mysterious plague has decimated humanity. But instead of making a movie about the aftermath of a disaster, the filmmakers, Calum Grant and Joshua Atesh Litle, have tried something a little more clever and a lot cheaper: to envision what the first movie made after that disaster might look like.

headline: President of Paramount to Leave After Brief Term
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 — After a brief reign of two years, Gail Berman will be leaving her job as the president of Viacom’s Paramount Pictures unit, according to a film executive at the studio.

headline: Massachusetts: Commuter Train Kills 2 Workers
text: Two track workers were killed, and four were injured when a commuter train plowed into track maintenance equipment. The train, with 43 passengers, was headed to Boston from Lowell when it hit the equipment shortly before 2 p.m. Ten passengers were taken to hospitals with minor injuries, and no crew members were hurt. Scott Farmelant, a spokesman for Massachusetts Bay Commuter Rail, said the crew was performing routine track maintenance work.

headline: Mall REIT Warns That It Might Be Forced Into Bankruptcy
text: The Mills Corporation, the real estate investment trust known for off-price malls in outlying suburbs that combine entertainment and shopping, said yesterday that it was running out of cash and might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection, putting its shareholders at risk of losing their investment.

headline: Bush’s Troop-Increase Plan Is Expected to Draw Six Guard Brigades to Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — President Bush’s plan to increase troop levels in Iraq is expected to require the Army eventually to send as many as six National Guard combat brigades to Iraq, beginning in 2008.

headline: Wage Increase Could Hinge on Tax Cuts
text: As part of their 100-hour legislative blitz, House Democrats are expected to vote today to increase the minimum wage for the first time in a decade, to $7.25 an hour, in a move that economists say will raise pay for 13 million workers.

headline: Democrats Skeptical About Bush’s New Iraq Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Hours before President Bush’s speech on Iraq, Democrats carried out what amounted to a pre-emptive strike, with several top lawmakers voicing deep skepticism about whether the president’s vision is really “a new way” in Iraq.

headline: Calendar
text: Beer, With Cheese

headline: Off-Duty Correction Officer Kills Man in Traffic Dispute
text: An off-duty New York State correction officer fatally shot a man during a traffic dispute last night near La Guardia Airport in Queens, the police said. It was unclear how the dispute, which apparently began with a honked horn, escalated to gunfire.

headline: Manhattan: City Projects Surplus
text: New York City’s short-term fiscal outlook looks very bright because the local economy remains strong and tax revenues have been coming in at higher rates than expected, according to a report released yesterday by the city’s Independent Budget Office. The office projected a surplus of $2.1 billion for the 2007 fiscal year, which ends on June 30, and, assuming that that money is used to pay future expenses in advance, a surplus of $688 million for the 2008 fiscal year. The office said it expected deficits of $2.9 billion in fiscal 2009 and $2.7 billion in fiscal 2010, the last year of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s term — but added that those projected shortfalls were smaller than what the mayor’s Office of Management and Budget had projected.

headline: Recipe: Turbot Poached in St.-Émilion
text: Turbot Poached in St.-Émilion Adapted from Gordon Ramsay at the London

headline: Venezuela Inc.’s Hostile Takeover
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela  the very portrait of a modern Latin American strongman  is not content to exercise near-total political and military control of his country. Now he is tightening his grip on the Venezuelan economy. That’s bad news for foreign investors, but even more so for the Venezuelan people who will have to pay the price for an economy plagued by increasing inefficiency and corruption.

headline: Among His Official Duties, Keeping on Top of the 100-Hour Clock
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 — Rob Cogorno is busy watching the clock. And not just any clock.

headline: Brooklyn: Teenager Sought in Subway Stabbing
text: A 17-year-old boy was stabbed once in the chest by another teenager yesterday afternoon on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said. The victim, whom the authorities did not identify, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was listed in stable condition, the police said. The stabbing occurred about 3 p.m. aboard a Manhattan-bound J train that was stopped in the elevated Norwood Avenue station, near Fulton Street in Highland Park, officials said. Detectives were investigating whether it followed an argument between the two teenagers earlier in the day. Charles Seaton, a spokesman for New York City Transit, said that train service was suspended in the area through the early evening. A witness to the stabbing said that the dispute arose among members of separate gangs at a nearby school yesterday and that members of the gang agreed to take the fight off school grounds.

headline: Driver’s Letter to Yoko Ono Is Released, and Rebutted
text: When prosecutors arrested Yoko Ono’s chauffeur in December, they said he was a disgruntled, potentially violent employee trying to extort money from her.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The headline for a film review in Weekend on Friday about “Freedom Writers” misidentified the California city in which the movie is set. It is Long Beach, not Los Angeles.

headline: Two Views of Artists, Two Visions of the World
text: “I’m very careful not to have ideas, because they’re inaccurate,” the artist Agnes Martin says in Mary Lance’s touching documentary about her, but it’s a lie. Ms. Martin was full of ideas, and she dispenses them engagingly in the course of the film, “Agnes Martin: With My Back to the World,” made from 1998 to 2002.

headline: As Giants Wait, Mara’s on His Own for Tough Calls
text: The Giants’ president, John Mara, typically affable and approachable, increasingly avoided reporters as the team’s season deteriorated. He knew that tough decisions were coming, and that he was about to begin shaping his true legacy.

headline: I.R.S. Use of Private Debt Collectors Is Criticized
text: The national taxpayer advocate called on Congress yesterday to repeal the authority of the Internal Revenue Service to use private debt collectors.

headline: Apple Introduces Innovative Cellphone
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 — With characteristic showmanship, Steven P. Jobs introduced Apple’s long-awaited entry into the cellphone world Tuesday, pronouncing it an achievement on a par with the Macintosh and the iPod.

headline: In Poland, New Wave of Charges Against Clerics
text: KRAKOW, Poland, Jan. 9 — Poland was convulsed in finger-pointing and recrimination on Tuesday as more allegations of former secret-police collaborators among the Roman Catholic clergy members spilled onto the country’s front pages, sullying an institution that for decades was considered spotless in its fight against Communism.

headline: My Favorite Green Lump
text: Colstrip, Montana

headline: It’s Another Big Night in the City for the Isles
text: For all the dominance the Islanders have had over the Rangers in this season’s installment of their rivalry, they were not flexing it particularly proudly after last night’s 5-3 victory at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What You Get for ... $28 Million
text: Wilson, Wyo.

headline: Love Among the Ruins
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Pakistan: Plan for Border Mines Reconsidered
text: The Foreign Ministry said it had taken note of the statement this week by the United Nations deputy special representative in Afghanistan, Chris Alexander, that Pakistan and Afghanistan had to end their “war of words” over their border and said it would reconsider Pakistan’s announcement last month that it would lay mines along the border. The ministry said it agreed that blocking “undesirable elements” — a reference to the resurgent Taliban — from entering Pakistan was the responsibility of the forces operating on the Afghan side. President Hamid Karzai had voiced strong opposition to the plan for mines.

headline: Finding the Green in Building Renovation
text: It is a rare announcement for a new commercial office building these days that does not trumpet the new structure’s “green” features. In fact, nearly 5,000 buildings across the country, 90 percent of them new construction, are awaiting evaluation by the United States Green Building Council.

headline: Flavored With Flame and Stone
text: IT started with an offhand comment from Eric Ripert, the chef of Le Bernardin.

headline: Airstrike Rekindles Somalis’ Anger at the U.S.
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 9 — Somali officials said Tuesday that dozens of people were killed in an American airstrike on Sunday, most of them Islamist fighters fleeing in armed pickup trucks across a remote, muddy stretch of the KenyaSomalia border.

headline: Making Impressionism Move to a Ballet Beat
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — After carefully trolling the North Carolina Museum of Art’s “Monet in Normandy” exhibition, seeking inspiration for a new dance, the choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett ended up using a painting not in the show: Monet’s “Déjeuner sur l’Herbe.” That’s right, Monet’s — not Manet’s better-known 1863 painting of the same title, depicting a languid luncheon party of four, including unabashedly naked women, but Monet’s more decorous 1865-66 scene of a luncheon party of a dozen or so ladies and gentlemen, elegantly dressed.

headline: Ruling Seen as Giving an Edge to Challengers of Patents
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Supreme Court opened the door Tuesday to a category of patent lawsuits that a lower court had barred, issuing a decision that will probably shift power in the courtroom from bigger patent-owning companies to smaller start-up companies that rely on obtaining licenses for patented technology.

headline: Spitzer Office Finds E-Mail Can Be Revealing
text: ALBANY, Jan. 10  Gov. Eliot Spitzer made his name, in part, on indiscreet e-mails, as any number of executives who were pursued by the attorney general’s office in recent years can attest. Now his administration has sent out an indiscreet e-mail of its own: an e-mailed response to people seeking jobs as spokesmen was addressed to 227 other applicants, including many reporters and local and city government employees.

headline: Schwarzenegger’s Plan for Universal Care Draws No Universal Agreement
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 — When Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger took the oath of office last Friday, he called on legislators in Sacramento to set aside party loyalty in favor of “the Party of California.”

headline: Personal Shopper
text: New looks for a classic table.

headline: Currents
text: A new vacuum promises power without heft, the holidays are over but discount shopping isn't and more.

headline: Apple Waves Its Wand, Again
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 - Remember the fairy godmother in “Cinderella”? She’d wave her wand and turn some homely and utilitarian object, like a pumpkin or a mouse, into something glamorous and amazing, like a carriage or fully accessorized coachman.

headline: Saving a Broken Angel
text: Scenes from the Broken Angel, an eccentric building at 4 Downing Street in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, which the owners, and others, are trying to save from demolition.

headline: Clip-Ons Are Back
text: The return of clip-on earrings.

headline: Philharmonic Casts 'My Fair Lady'
text: The cast of the New York Philharmonic’s semistaged performance of “My Fair Lady” from March 7 to 10 has been announced: Kelli O’Hara (“The Pajama Game”) will play Eliza Doolittle, and Kelsey Grammer (“Frasier”) will play Prof. Henry Higgins.

headline: Ted Hughes Letters Go to Emory University
text: Emory University has acquired letters from Ted Hughes to Assia Wevill, his mistress during his marriage to Sylvia Plath. Mr. Hughes continued his relationship with Ms. Wevill after Ms. Plath’s suicide in 1963, but the two never married. The letters allow “unprecedented access to Hughes’s state of mind at a time of crisis in his personal and professional life,” said a statement from Stephen Enniss, the director of Emory’s Manuscript, Archives and Rare Book Library. The collection includes more than 60 letters from 1963 to 1969, sketches, diary entries and photographs. One letter implores Ms. Wevill to “burn all my letters.” A biography of Ms. Wevill, “Lover of Unreason,” by Yehuda Koren and Eilat Negev, was published in December.

headline: French National Library Recovers Stolen Manuscript
text: A 13th-century Hebrew Bible, stolen from the French National Library in the late 1990s, has been recovered after complex negotiations between French officials, Christie’s and a Brooklyn antiquities dealer, Yosef Goldman, who bought the leatherbound book from the auction house in 2000 for $368,000. Library officials said Mr. Goldman purchased the manuscript in good faith and had already resold it when its theft was discovered. France sued Mr. Goldman for the return of the book, but the case was later settled, with France reportedly agreeing to cover some of Mr. Goldman’s legal expenses. Michel Garel, the former chief curator of manuscripts at the library, was convicted last March of stealing the Bible and sentenced to a two-year suspended prison term and a fine of 400,000 euros ($520,000). He has appealed the verdict, and a ruling is expected this month.

headline: Philharmonic Chooses 'My Fair Lady'
text: “My Fair Lady” will be presented by the New York Philharmonic in four semi-staged performances in March.

headline: The Geodesic Dome
Home Depot Board Faces New Outcry
text: Home Depot‘s ousted chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, may not be the only one to walk the plank at the home improvement retailing giant. Some shareholder activists and corporate governance watchdogs are now turning their attention to the company’s board, criticizing Home Depot’s decision to allow three directors to remain even after reaching the mandatory retirement age of 72.

headline: Let the Iceman Come
text: Gear test with Ellen Miller, mountain running team manager.

headline: Dow Jones Plans Layoffs at Newswires and Factiva
text: Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, is planning to cut jobs at Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva to reduce overlap between the news groups. The number of positions to be eliminated will be announced at a company meeting Wednesday, and employees who will lose their jobs were to be contacted yesterday. The cuts follow Dow Jones’s purchase in October of the Reuters Group‘s 50 percent stake in the Factiva.com news database for $153 million.

headline: Deadline for Your Turn to Tell the Story
text: Today’s the deadline for “Your Turn to Tell the Story: The Darfur Genocide.”

headline: U.S. Prohibits All Transactions With a Major Iranian Bank
text: The United States, moving to raise pressure on Iran, on Tuesday barred American financial institutions from doing business with a major Iranian bank after concluding that it had been involved in illicit weapons programs. The move against Bank Sepah, announced by the Treasury Department, also affected North Korea, which American officials said had used the bank to facilitate payments to a North Korean group that exports missile technologies.

headline: Storm Clouds Gather as Congress Takes Up Net’s Future
text: The starting gun was fired in what could turn into a battle royale between major Internet players. Senior lawmakers, emboldened by the recent restrictions on AT&T and the change in control of Congress, have begun drafting legislation that would prevent high-speed Internet companies from charging content providers for priority access.

headline: Endemol Brings French Unit Back Into the Fold
text: Endemol, the TV production company behind “Big Brother,” agreed to buy its French unit from the Spanish company Telefonica for as much as 450 million euros. The deal could accelerate Telefonica’s effort to sell its stake in Endemol, analysts said.

headline: Vivendi and Deutsche Telekom Both Claim Victory in PTC Ruling
text: Vivendi and Deutsche Telekom both claimed victory Tuesday in their long-running dispute over ownership of the Polish mobile phone network PTC.

headline: Holland & Knight Hires Securities Lawyers From a Rival
text: A law firm, Holland & Knight said Monday that it had hired three lawyers from a smaller rival, Akerman Senterfitt, to join its securities and public companies practice.

headline: China Life Shares Surge in Shanghai Debut
text: The share price of China Life, the country’s No. 1 life insurer, soar Tuesday in its widely anticipated debut on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. China Life’s shares opened trading at 37 yuan ($4.74), up from the company’s initial public offering price of 18.88 yuan, and closed at 38.93 yuan.

headline: Rank Shareholders Approve Hard Rock Sale
text: Shareholders in the Rank Group have approved the $965 million sale of the Hard Rock cafes and associated businesses to the Seminole Tribe of Florida, despite a lawsuit from a spurned suitor that claims the sale process was unfair.

headline: Former U.S. Foodservice Executive Settles Fraud Charges
text: The former controller at U.S. Foodservice, a unit of the Dutch supermarket operator Royal Ahold, has agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to settle accusations that she participated in a fraud that overstated income by $700 million in fiscal 2001 and 2002, the Securities and Exchange Commission says.

headline: London Stock Exchange Reports Higher Profit
text: The London Stock Exchange, seeking to fend off a hostile takeover by the Nasdaq Stock Market, got some more ammunition yesterday when it reported a 9.9 percent increase in third-quarter profit and forecast a “strong performance” in fiscal 2008.

headline: Bahrain Royal Family Takes Stake in Formula One Team
text: McLaren Formula One‘s chairman, Ron Dennis, and a Saudi investor, Mansour Ojjeh, are selling half their stakes in the company to an entity owned by the Kingdom of Bahrain, which will hold 30 percent of the racing business.

headline: For Bidders, India’s 2¢-a-Minute Caller Is a Caller Nonetheless
text: The three-way struggle for the Indian mobile phone provider Hutchison Essar is emerging as one of the largest corporate takeover battles in Indian history. Hutchison could overnight become one of Asia’s largest companies if it fetches an expected valuation of $16 billion to $20 billion.

headline: Former Chief of Putnam Settles in Disclosure Case
text: The former chief executive of Putnam, Lawrence J. Lasser, will pay $75,000 to settle accusations that he failed to disclose that the investment company used fund assets to pay brokerage firms for preferred marketing agreements, regulators announced Tuesday.

headline: Banks Settle Claims in Auction Inquiry
text: A subsidiary of Deutsche Bank, the Bank of New York and Wilmington Trust have agreed to pay a combined $1.6 million to settle claims in an investigation of the $200 billion auction-rate securities market. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlements on Tuesday, the second set of settlements to grow out of an inquiry into the auction-rate bond market. In May, 15 brokerage firms agreed to settle accusations of violations in the same market.

headline: Cryptologic Buys Scandinavian Poker Brand
text: A Canadian gambling software firm CryptoLogic has agreed to pay up to 20 million Canadian dollars ($17 million) for the poker brand and related assets of Parbet.com, a popular Scandinavian online poker room.

headline: YouTube Is Back Online in Brazil
text: A Brazilian court said Tuesday that Internet service providers could allow Web surfers access to the popular video-sharing site YouTube, a day after they started blocking it because of a racy sex video featuring an MTV veejay and model and a Merrill Lynch banker. The move follows a hue and cry raised by devoted Brazilian YouTube fans over the loss of their favorite site.

headline: WetPaint Gets Fresh Funding
text: Wetpaint, a startup that provides hosting and tools for building wiki-based Web sites, said on Tuesday that it had raised $9.5 million in a second round of venture funding from Accel Partners. Wetpaint, which is aimed mainly at consumers building community-oriented sites, is one of several do-it-yourself Web site services that have emerged over the past two years.

headline: Japan’s Mizuho Plans to Merge Brokers, Report Says
text: Japan’s Mizuho Financial Group plans to merge two of its group brokerages next year to create the country’s fourth-biggest securities house by assets, Reuters reported. The merger of Mizuho Securities and Shinko Securities would create a full-service brokerage and investment bank with $260 billion of assets under management.

headline: Wachovia’s Evergreen Buys British Investment Firm
text: Wachovia‘s asset management unit, Evergreen Investments, agreed to buy a majority stake in European Credit Management, a privately held, fixed-income investment management firm based in London. European Credit has about $26 billion in assets under management, which would lift Evergreen’s international total to more than $280 billion.

headline: Goldman Said to Lead in Broadcasting Bid
text: The private equity arm of Goldman Sachs has taken the lead position in the bidding for Canada’s Alliance Atlantis Communications, according to The Globe and Mail. Goldman, which has has teamed up with CanWest Global Communications, is offering to pay the majority of the purchase price, with CanWest making a cash contribution of less than 20 percent of the value of Alliance’s specialty TV channels, the report said.

headline: The Contradictions of Tom Coughlin
text: Update: The Giants have decided to retain Coughlin and extend his contract one season, through 2008. “We are satisfied with how he planned to move forward and we remain convinced that he is the right man for the job,” the team co-owner John Mara told reporters.

headline: NYSE and Goldman Take Stakes in Indian Exchange
text: The NYSE Group and three other foreign investors have bought a 20 percent stake in India’s biggest stock exchange, the National Stock Exchange. It was the latest move in a wave of consolidation sweeping global exchanges.

headline: Facing Bankruptcy, Mills May Have to Sell
text: The Mills Corporation, the real estate investment trust known for off-price malls in outlying suburbs that combine entertainment and shopping, said yesterday that it was running out of cash and might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection, putting its shareholders at risk of losing their investment.

headline: Kodak to Sell Health Group to Onex
text: Eastman Kodak, the photography company, said Wednesday it plans to sell its medical imaging business to a subsidiary of a Canadian conglomerate, Onex, for up to $2.55 billion. Kodak said the move would help it focus on its consumer and professional imaging business.

headline: Quattrone to Take the Podium
text: Frank P. Quattrone, the former star technology banker from Credit Suisse whose years-long exile from the securities industry came to an end this fall, has been chosen to speak to a group of venture capitalists at an industry event. The New York Post notes that in doing so, Mr. Quattrone will join the ranks of Eliot Spitzer, the former New York attorney general who vigorously policed Wall Street.

headline: Loans to Hedge Funds Face Scrutiny
text: The financial regulators in the United States and several European Union countries have begun a joint investigation into whether banks’ prime brokerages are taking too many risks as they increase lending to hedge funds. Officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission, Britain’s Financial Services Authority, the New York Federal Reserve and several European agencies met last month to discuss whether a relaxation in credit standards could spark trouble down the road.

headline: President Bush’s Address to the Nation
text: The following is the prepared text of President Bush's address to the nation tonight, as released by the White House:

headline: NovaVision Scores $20 Million Third Round
text: NovaVision, a developer of neurological therapy technology, raised $20 million in a third round of funding, which it will use to expand its network of stroke and brain trauma treatment centers. Late-stage venture investor Chicago Growth Partners led the round.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Project Runway
text: While Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton takes “the best dressed” competition in New York, she’s also mulling over whether to base her campaign headquarters in New York or Washington and all but confirms that she’s made up her mind about another question.

headline: Cerberus Is Weighing a $38 Billion Offer for an Office REIT
text: Cerberus Capital Management is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, people involved in the discussions said last night.

headline: An Ideal Middle East?
As the Dust Clears, Assessing the Air Strikes in Somalia
text: There is some speculation today that American air strikes in Somalia may have taken out the Qaeda operative suspected of masterminding the 1998 bombings of the American embassies Kenya and Tanzania that killed 225 people, Fazul Abdullah Mohammed.

headline: Hush Tactics for the iPhone
text: I asked Steve Jobs if he knew of the work of Jeffrey Han, who’s been demonstrating his big “multi-touch” screen technology since at least August 2005. (I mentioned this similarity in my last blog post.)

headline: The Hill: The Clock is (Finally) Ticking
text: The clock keeping track of the first 100 hours of the House Democrats’ “New Direction” started at 12:57 p.m. yesterday. Or was it 1? or 1:30?

headline: US Airways Raises Delta Offer to $10.2 Billion
text: US Airways said Wednesday it had raised its bid to acquire Delta Air Lines out of bankruptcy to $10.2 billion in cash and stock, hoping to persuade Delta’s creditors to support its proposal over the stand-alone reorganization plan that Delta has endorsed.

headline: New Orleans Violence Boils Over
text: An already fragile social structure in the city’s poorest wards has been all but destroyed by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Bronx: Hospital Closing Blocked
text: A State Supreme Court judge has issued a temporary restraining order halting the state from proceeding with plans to close Westchester Square Medical Center in the East Bronx. The ruling last week by Justice Mary Ann Brigantti-Hughes, will remain in effect until a hearing on Jan. 29. Westchester Square is one of nine hospitals statewide that a state panel recommended be closed. Several other hospitals are seeking to reverse the commission’s decision.

headline: Making Granola
text: There are two reasons for making your granola. One: it tastes better. Two: it contains better ingredients. Mark Bittman demonstrates.

headline: ‘Prebuttals’ to Bush’s Address on the Iraq War
text: No need to wait for President Bush’s address to the nation tonight to find an opinion on it. The “prebuttals” are flourishing:

headline: Name That Would-Be Newspaper Baron
text: Even as newspapers struggle with declining readership and rising costs, the ranks of billionaires who might step in to buy them seems to be growing. Among those reported to be considering acquiring a newspaper are David Geffen, John F. Welch Jr. and Maurice “Hank” Greenberg.

headline: The War at Home: Looking Forward to ‘The Way’
text: Today is the first day of the rest of the Iraq war. President Bush will tell us the “way forward” during an address tonight at 9 p.m., even though most of his plan has already been leaked. Mr. Bush reportedly will call for 20,000 more troops (The Times has just reported that those troops would have a limited role, according to the White House). He will also unveil a major economic development plan and detail benchmarks the Iraqi government must meet (a plan that isn’t all that new, according to The Associated Press’s Tom Raum). The call for increasing troops marks the first time that Mr. Bush has acted counter to the advice of his top military brass.

headline: What Competition?
text: The nice thing about the National Board of Review, which filled Cipriani’s restaurant and then some last night, is that the competitive issues are settled and the program is not televised, so all the Hollywood wattage can unwind and enjoy themselves. The fact that they had several long hours, and 42 speeches, to do so may have bothered some — the Bagger, who has stamina issues, did not make it to the end — but the Baguette drank from the celebrity cup deep into the night.

headline: Fire’s Out in the Speaker’s Lobby
text: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the new speaker of the House, has just banned smoking in the Speaker’s Lobby, the room right outside the House chamber where reporters wait to tackle members and members go, err, went, for a smoking break. With studies showing the risks of secondhand smoke and a new restaurant smoking ban in Washington, D.C., Mrs. Pelosi’s press release said that “as Members of Congress, we must be held to a higher standard. We can no longer risk the health of colleagues, staff, pages, reporters and others who pass through the Speaker’s Lobby each day.”

headline: Where Protons Will Play
text: The new supercollider that is poised to shake up physics.

headline: Lebanon's Missing Curriculum
text: Students at a suburban school in Beirut, Lebanon, say their textbooks don't give them the full story about the country's recent history.

headline: Watch a Plasma TV…for Your Health
text: Did your mother tell you that watching too much TV would strain your eyes? Turns out she was right.

headline: It Can Be Too Early
text: I haven’t found many mashups and remixes of the cameraphone execution video yet, but “The Daily Show” did some credible sending up Monday night.

headline: Last Year’s Model?
text: The Apple cellphone is getting all the attention, but the company also announced a device that connects your TV to the Internet.

headline: Stem Cell Research: Deciding What Is News and What Isn’t
text: Making decisions about what scientific research is newsworthy is one of the toughest editing challenges at a newspaper. The controversy surrounding stem cell research makes the news judgments on those studies even more sensitive and difficult.

headline: Sneakernet TV
text: Although many companies were showing devices that promise to distribute entertainment content in our homes–anywhere, anyplace, any device, they all say–they probably won’t really get into our homes for a few more years, Claudio Sennhauser, a business development executive at Sandisk, told me.

headline: Get the Glow-Eye Out
text: I am not sure that Kodak intended to spill this, but during a demonstration of software that would recognize faces, a company representative revealed that it would be announcing later this year that it had developed a system to remove glow eyes from pet pictures.

headline: ‘Saddam Hussein Is Your Master, and the Master of Your Parents.’
text: With a new video of the dead Saddam Hussein now circulating online, where it is further inflaming tempers about his execution, a recent debate on Al-Jazeera suggests just where the ideological fault lines in Iraq may lie.

headline: Private Equity Firms Pay Up For Talent
text: The money pouring into private equity firms is making its way into the bank accounts of junior and midlevel employees, according to a report from Glocap Search and Thomson Financial. BusinessWeek.com cited the report, called “The 2007 Private Equity Compensation Report,” in Tuesday’s article about salaries in the financial-services sector. Hedge Fund Daily gave highlights from the report last month.

headline: Pelosi Puts Foot Down on House Smokers
text: It appears that Nancy Pelosi, the Democrat of California and newly elected Speaker of the House, will brook no jones in the Speaker’s Lobby just off the House floor — a spot where, according to The Associated Press, certain lawmakers have been known to take counsel with the demon tobacco.

headline: Should Amaranth’s Founder Get Another Chance?
text: Where, wonders Bloomberg News columnist Matthew Lynn, does Amaranth Advisors founder Nicholas Maounis get the gall? After presiding over the biggest hedge fund collapse in history, Mr. Maounis is reportedly looking for financial backers for a new investment fund, which he and some former colleagues would run.

headline: Word Up
text: Steven Spielberg, giving the introduction to Djimon Hounsou for best supporting actor at the NBR, recalled how his intense, angry appearance while in character as a slave in “Amistad” scared the other actors.

headline: Radio Report
text: Team Scorsese, a group of publicists and assistants, were waiting out front of Cipriani, a few sneaking a smoke with the Bagger, who is always quitting tomorrow. Mr. Scorsese was scheduled to be honored as best director by the National Board of Review.

headline: Dreamy Summit
text: The Bagger was out to lunch yesterday (and he’s not just talking about his picks for the DGA) at Michael’s, that Midtown dog run for media types.

headline: First Impressions: Lots of Them
text: Diner’s Journal has fallen behind. It has zipped through more restaurants than it has been able to account for, and it has wanted to account for more of those restaurants than it got around to doing. Such a lapse has prompted its author to avoid first-person pronouns in this paragraph and thus imply that Diner’s Journal is some entity for which no one individual has, or claims, responsibility. But enough of that:

headline: An E-Mail Goof
text: Eilot Spitzer made a name for himself building cases on indiscreetindiscrete emails of corporate executives. So it comes as quite a surprise that applicants for press jobs to his administration were sent back e-mails with the return addresses of other applicants.Michael Cooper talks to some of those applicants in this article.

headline: iPhone Pros and Cons
text: Steve Jobs said yesterday that he hopes Apple’s new iPhone will eventually garner one percent of the world-wide market. Judging by readers’ comments, enthusiastic commentary on Good Morning America, and a constant discussion of the phone’s features in the Consumer Electronics Show pressroom, he may very well meet that goal.

headline: As Le Mans Grows Richer, Will the U.S. Grand Prix Grow Poorer?
text: Although the news had already leaked out yesterday in L’Equipe, the French sports daily, and on many of the racing web sites, I decided to wait until some kind of photo became available before celebrating.

headline: Moonves Speaks, But Offers Few Hints on M&A
text: CBS is sitting on about $3 billion in cash, and with the hiring last November of new-media dealmeister Quincy Smith, everybody has been wondering what the company has in store. CBS Chief Executive Leslie Moonves offered little in the way of hints either during his keynote address Tuesday at the Consumer Electronics Show or in a backstage interview with paidContent’s Staci D. Kramer.

headline: Blogtalk
text: Dan Gerstein is back in the blogosphere, and he has written an essay about his work for the Lieberman campaign. His take is that the rational problem-solving wing of the party defeated the rage-driven polarizers. [Dangerous Thoughts]

headline: Analysts Say US Airways’ New Delta Bid Is Tempting
text: After crunching the numbers on US Airways‘ latest bid for Delta Air Lines, several equity analysts said Wednesday that it seemed to present a better payout for creditors than Delta’s standalone reorganization plan. Their estimates were slightly different, but three of them calculated that US Airways was offering at least $2 billion more than Delta would be worth if it emerged from bankruptcy on its own. Their analysis suggests that US Airways’ new offer, consisting of $10.2 billion in cash and stock, may get serious consideration from Delta’s creditors.

headline: Art Imitates, Interviews Life (and Vice Versa?)
text: In an era where some studies seem to indicate that parody news programs are just about as informative as the network news, it was inevitable that fact and fiction would merge.

headline: Visits Don't Always Lead to Adoption
text: Programs that allow children available for adoption to visit American families often lead to happily-ever-after, but sometimes end painfully.

headline: Bush and Congress: War of Words
text: The leadership on both sides of the aisle emerged from a meeting with President Bush this afternoon.

headline: Iraq Quotes From the Hill
text: Given that details of President Bush’s “new way forward” in Iraq have been surfacing for weeks, leading members of Congress have already begun heady debate over his proposals _ to be outlined in a national address at 9 tonight.

headline: National Board of Review Awards Gala
text: The Carpetbagger (a k a David Carr) goes to the National Board of Review Awards Gala to talk to the winners.

headline: More iPhone Fun Facts
text: If you just can’t wait to buy an iPhone from another cellular carrier, like T-Mobile, Cingular has a message for you: you’ll be waiting a long time, my friend.

headline: A Ride in a Gaming Chair
text: Honey, lower the shades and alert the neighbors. I’m about to play a video game.

headline: Suddenly Sarasota
text: I hate to interrupt the flow of this ongoing story about a dimwitted couple building their dream house, but could we talk for a minute about men?

headline: Rosie Perez on H.I.V.
text: Part of the "Love and Respect" campaign.

headline: Susan Sarandon on H.I.V.
text: Part of the "Love and Respect" campaign.

headline: Whoopi Goldberg on H.I.V.
text: Part of the "Love and Respect" campaign.

headline: Amanda Peet on H.I.V.
text: From the "Love and Respect" campaign.

headline: Blogtalk: A Pre-emptive Debate
text: As President Bush prepares to reveal his latest Iraq strategy tonight, the blogs can only wait, guess and bat the few leaked details in the air like a cat with a ball of yarn.

headline: Talking Baseball and Steroids
text: Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn discuss their selection to the Baseball Hall of Fame and the sport's steroid-abuse problems.

headline: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
text: Did President Bush in his speech to the nation on Wednesday night make a convincing case for sending more U.S. troops to Iraq?

headline: Group Weighs Rival Bid for Equity Office REIT
text: A consortium of investors is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, people involved in the discussions said last night.

headline: Grossman, Under Pressure, Faces Toughest Test
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 10  Rex Grossman is like a beleaguered politician whose approval rating keeps falling.

headline: It’s a Still Camera. No, a Camcorder. No Need to Choose Because It’s Both.
text: Many digital cameras shoot rudimentary video, and some camcorders take a shot at producing passable photographs. The Canon DC50 tries to do both well. Its five-megapixel sensor is equal in resolution to that of some midgrade cameras, and is actually bigger than those used by some photojournalists just a year or so ago.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.What is the best way to clean leather furniture?

headline: Bush’s Iraq Plan Meets Opposition From Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — President Bush’s top aides lobbied hostile lawmakers today on behalf of the administration’s new Iraq strategy, unveiling plans to add 92,000 soldiers and marines to the United States military and help Iraqis far beyond Baghdad’s city limits.

headline: Workers’ Pay: An Issue for the Rich (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York City’s Future Playground Gets a Nod From Present-Day Players
text: For all the fancy child-development theory and high-concept design behind the next-generation playground that the city unveiled this week, it did not take much explaining for the seesaw-and-swing crowd to decide that it seemed like a good idea.

headline: House, by a Wide Margin, Backs Minimum-Wage Rise
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — The House overwhelmingly approved a $2.10-an-hour increase in the federal minimum wage on Wednesday, in a vote that Democrats hailed as overdue and a symbol of new leadership on Capitol Hill.

headline: An Angel Is Pulled Closer to Earth
text: The stained-glass windows in the eccentric building at 4 Downing Street in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn are made from discarded salt shakers, ashtrays and coffee tables, bottles dug up in the backyard and the detritus of neighborhood car accidents. It is only from the inside that you can see the windows’ brilliant colors.

headline: Yvonne De Carlo, Who Played Lily on 'The Munsters,' Dies at 84
text: Yvonne De Carlo, a dark-haired Hollywood beauty who advanced from the chorus line to play Moses’ wife in a movie epic but who achieved her greatest popularity as Lily in the CBS television sitcom “The Munsters,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. She was 84.

headline: Bridling at Insulin’s Cost, States Push for Generics
text: As they examine their state health care budgets, 11 of the nation’s governors have identified one big-ticket item they think should cost less: insulin.

headline: Play to Learn
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: France Polishes Its Politesse
text: PARIS

headline: Duke Accuser Contradicts Herself in Interview
text: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 11 — In an interview last month with a district attorney’s investigator, the woman who has accused three former Duke lacrosse players of sexual assault contradicted critical evidence and parts of her earlier accounts, dealing a new blow to a faltering case.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a controversy over the arrest of a political activist, Kenneth Krayeske, during the inaugural parade of Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut, misstated his age and misstated the surname of his lawyer. Mr. Krayeske is 34, not 33, and his lawyer is Norman A. Pattis, not Potts.

headline: The Antiwar Movement (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Calendar
text: Setting the Stage

headline: Three Students and Van Driver Die in Fiery Crash in New Jersey
text: Three high school students and a school van driver were killed yesterday afternoon in Freehold Township, N.J., when the students’ Cadillac collided with the van about a mile from the campus and burst into flames, the authorities said.

headline: James Weeks, Ex-Times Co. Executive, Dies at 64
text: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Jan. 10 — James C. Weeks, a former president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Regional Media Group and a former publisher of The Press Democrat of Santa Rosa, died Monday in New York. He was 64 and had homes in Atlanta and Aspen, Colo.

headline: U.S. Governor Brokers Truce for Darfur
text: DAKAR, Senegal, Jan. 10  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan and leaders of several rebel factions in Darfur, the western Sudanese region, agreed Wednesday to a 60-day cease-fire in separate meetings with Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a former American ambassador to the United Nations, according to a statement by Mr. Richardson and Mr. Bashir.

headline: One Click, One Vote to Publish a Winner
text: Is there anything the American consumer isn’t allowed to decide?

headline: 46 New York City Schools Join List of Those Failing in Student Performance Standards Under U.S. Law
text: Forty-six New York City schools have been newly identified as failing under the federal No Child Left Behind law based on their students’ performance in the 2005-6 school year, the State Education Department said yesterday.

headline: Britain Won’t Follow U.S. in Adding Troops in Iraq
text: LONDON, Jan. 11 — Britain, America’s closest ally in Iraq, said today that it would not follow the United States in raising troop levels there and signaled that it would pursue its own planned handover of security responsibilities to Iraqi forces in the south.

headline: Bush’s Strategy for Iraq Risks Confrontations
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — By stepping up the American military presence in Iraq, President Bush is not only inviting an epic clash with the Democrats who run Capitol Hill. He is ignoring the results of the November elections, rejecting the central thrust of the bipartisan Iraq Study Group and flouting the advice of some of his own generals, as well as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq.

headline: Skull Provides Signs of When Humans Left Africa
text: From a new analysis of a human skull discovered in South Africa more than 50 years ago, scientists say they have obtained the first fossil evidence establishing the relatively recent time for the dispersal of modern Homo sapiens out of Africa.

headline: Grimacing and Barely Bearing It
text: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 10  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Wednesday that he was in pain. A lot of pain.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the World Business Briefing column last Thursday about the start up of Ironshore Insurance in Bermuda carried an incorrect credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not The Associated Press.

headline: NASA Schedules Flight to Update Space Telescope
text: The Hubble Space Telescope has a new, resonant date with destiny. NASA has set Sept. 11, 2008, as the target date for launching a mission intended to revitalize the telescope and keep it spaceworthy into the next decade, according to a planning document made public by nasawatch.com, an independent Web site.

headline: ImClone Shares Rise on an Erbitux Study
text: ImClone Systems said yesterday that its Erbitux cancer drug works as a first-choice treatment for bowel cancer. The company’s shares rose 5.3 percent.

headline: Residential Sales: New York and Miami
text: Manhattan

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: William Boyd Novel Honored

headline: Rights of Unions and Nonmembers Vie at Court
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — A case argued before the Supreme Court on Wednesday about how labor unions must handle the fees paid by nonmembers could turn out to be little more than a footnote to a long line of decisions about the respective rights of labor unions and dissident employees.

headline: Body Mass and the Student Body
text: Over the last three decades, the number of overweight children in America has tripled to 16 percent, so it would seem that anything that can help kids get to a healthy weight is worth considering. But schools aren’t helping if children think they’re being labeled as fat. That could be the effect of a program pioneered in Arkansas, which three years ago began measuring students’ body mass index  or B.M.I., a calculation based on weight and height  and then sending home what kids are calling “obesity report cards.” Pennsylvania and West Virginia do similar surveys, and about a dozen states, including New York, have bills to follow suit.

headline: Hard Work Helps Nets Tune Out Distractions
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 10  The Nets did not win the road game some of the players considered their best of the season  a 1-point loss to the Detroit Pistons on Dec. 26 that ended on a controversial call. Since then, the Nets have won four of six games and appear to be playing closer to preseason expectations.

headline: EBay Will Buy StubHub for $310 Million
text: EBay said yesterday that it had agreed to buy online ticket reseller StubHub Inc. for $310 million to bolster its share in the multibillion-dollar market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.

headline: Bail Set in Greece for Ex-Curator of Getty
text: ATHENS, Jan. 10 — Appearing before an investigating magistrate and prosecutors, Marion True, the former antiquities curator of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, was ordered on Wednesday to post $19,500 in bail pending trial on charges that she conspired to buy an ancient funerary wreath that prosecutors say was illegally removed from Greek soil about 15 years ago.

headline: Bruno Son Emerges as Key Link in Father’s Circle of Connections
text: GRAFTON, N.Y. — Pond View Way, a dirt road in this town of 2,125 residents, was completed late last year, but it is so new, and in such a remote location — eight miles west of the Vermont-Massachusetts border — that much of it does not appear on local maps.

headline: Totals
Cisco, Claiming Ownership of ‘iPhone,’ Sues Apple
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 — And now, iSue?

headline: G.M. Sees China, and the Chinese, in a Chevrolet
text: YANTAI, China — Yang Luzhou, who lives here in an industrial town facing North Korea across the bay, is about as far as can be from Americana.

headline: Home in the Ruins
text: New Orleans

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a secure telephone that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg uses in his Manhattan town house rendered incorrectly a quotation from him. The mayor said he had occasionally received calls on the secure line asking “did I want to subscribe to a particular magazine, buy an insurance policy or some other such ridiculous thing.” He did not say the callers asked “did I want to subscribe to a ridiculous magazine, buy an insurance policy or some other such particular thing.” (Go to Article)

headline: Wonder Where You Wander? This Mobile Phone Can Tell You
text: Thanks to cellphones, friends and relations can find you anywhere in the world. But can you find yourself? You can if you have the Pharos G.P.S. Phone 600, which has some advanced location-tracking features.

headline: Digital Billboard Up Ahead: New-Wave Sign or Hazard?
text: Their very name once told it all: a board to post notices or advertisements. But billboards are getting a makeover.

headline: 5 Iranians Detained at Consular Office
text: American forces backed by helicopters raided the Iranian consulate in the mainly Kurdish city of Erbil in northern Iraq before dawn today, detaining at least five Iranian employees in the building and seizing some property, according to Iraqi and Iranian officials and witnesses.

headline: Dolphins Get Head Start on the Hamptons Season
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Jan. 10  Despite the burst of colder weather on Wednesday, in the Hamptons it was the day of the dolphin.

headline: Back to 'Talking Smack' With Rosie, Donald and Barbara
text: If someone had to describe the feud between Donald Trump and Rosie O’Donnell to a television viewer whose power had been off the last three weeks, there are worse analogies than that of a WWE title bout, complete with a little off-camera brawling in the locker rooms and high-stakes ratings on the line.

headline: A Reversal of Fortune as Giants Keep Coughlin
text: The owners of the Giants and the man who coaches the team had differing perspectives after their meetings on Monday and Tuesday.

headline: The New Palette of Gansevoort
text: RUTH RO, an artist whose studio overlooks the intersection of Little West 12th Street and Washington Street, sees two ways to look at the state of the meatpacking district. You can bemoan the luxury whitewashing of the neighborhood’s once gritty character (and its sanguinary sidewalks), or you can view the change as a rebirth, bringing life to streets that once belonged to carcasses.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Jan. 3 about Teddy Kollek, the former mayor of Jerusalem, incorrectly rendered his birth name. He was Theodor Kollek, not Theodor Herzl Kollek. (Although he was named after Theodor Herzl, the founder of modern Zionism, he was not given a middle name, according to the Jerusalem Foundation, which he founded.)

headline: Queens: Election Fraud Alleged
text: A former aide to Jimmy Meng, the first Asian-American member of the State Assembly, has been charged with voter registration fraud, the Queens district attorney’s office said yesterday. Simon Ting, 42, of Flushing, who resigned after Mr. Meng chose not to run for re-election last year, submitted voter registration paperwork in 2004 for 36 people who did not live in Mr. Meng’s district. None of the people voted or attempted to vote in the 2004 election, prosecutors said. Mr. Ting was charged with offering a false instrument for filing and procuring false documents, and faces up to four years in prison if convicted.

headline: Unfilled City Manager Posts Hint at Future Gap
text: TECUMSEH, Okla. — Bent over a yellow 1969 Camaro Super Sport, David Johnson said he much preferred restoring muscle cars to solving his neighbors’ utility and garbage woes as Tecumseh’s city manager.

headline: Large Beasts, Mean Weapons and a Terrifying Judge
text: Many people believe that energy conservation is the way to deal with dwindling energy resources, but Capcom’s action game Lost Planet: Extreme Condition offers a different solution — kill house-size spiders and suck out their glowing orange blood to power advanced weapons that can be used to kill even bigger spiders.

headline: Um, Uh, Like Call in the Speech Coach
text: Whether to appear more confident, better organized or to stop the “ums,” entrepreneurs are realizing good voice and presentation skills can help them come into their own and even compete against larger competitors with big marketing budgets.

headline: Dodd Announces His Candidacy for President
text: Calling himself the “dark horse” in the crowded field of candidates, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, announced this morning that he is running for president.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend on Friday about a walk in the East Village with Robert Stone, who has a new memoir about the 1960s, “Prime Green,” misstated the history of Andy Warhol’s connection with the Polski Dom, or Polish Home, on St. Marks Place. The nightclub Warhol opened there, in 1966, was called Dom, not the Electric Circus. (The Electric Circus, not run by Warhol, opened at the site in 1967.)

headline: Phone Shows Apple’s Impact on Consumer Products
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 — Apple’s new iPhone appears to be the clearest statement yet of what Steve Jobs’s impact has been on consumer electronics.

headline: Accountant Pleads Guilty in KPMG Shelter Case
text: A California accountant pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiracy, tax fraud and obstructing a federal investigation, and pledged to help prosecutors as they conduct a widening criminal investigation of questionable tax shelters.

headline: The Real Disaster
text: President Bush told Americans last night that failure in Iraq would be a disaster. The disaster is Mr. Bush’s war, and he has already failed. Last night was his chance to stop offering more fog and be honest with the nation, and he did not take it.

headline: Rethinking Why Crazy Eddie Wouldn’t Be Undersold, and Other Mysteries
text: IT is common to see advertisements that offer to “meet or beat any price.” The most natural interpretation of such offers is that they signal strongly competitive behavior.

headline: Manhattan: Reducing Animal Euthanasia
text: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday that it would spend $2.4 million in an effort to reduce the euthanasia of stray animals in Austin, Tex.; Gulfport-Biloxi, Miss.; Philadelphia; and Tampa, Fla. Edwin J. Sayres, the president of the society, which is based in Manhattan, said it would commit $600,000 in each of the cities over three years to develop collaborations between public and private agencies.

headline: N.J. High School Mourns Students Killed in Crash
text: FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 11 — Grief came to school today at Freehold Regional High School as students mourning three students who were killed in an after-school automobile accident on Wednesday filed into a building staffed with grief counselors as well as teachers and administrators.

headline: Snow at Last, for Those Quick Enough to See It
text: Yesterday, Jan. 10, a date that will live in meteorological history, snow flurries were glimpsed in Central Park for the first time this winter.

headline: Room Service, Draw Me a Bath
text: IT used to be that free sample-size bottles of shampoo and conditioner, soap and a sewing kit were enough to make a guest giddy upon entering a hotel room. Then came the partnerships between hotels and high-end brands — Molton Brown, L’Occitane, Remède — that had guests salivating and fighting back thoughts of raiding the housekeeper’s cart.

headline: In Germany, a Hitler Comedy Goes Over With a Thud
text: BERLIN, Jan. 10 — Perhaps it was inevitable that the first German-made film comedy about Hitler would get a mixed reception in Germany — a country still haunted, six decades after the fall of the Third Reich, by the mystery of how this strange madman once held it in thrall.

headline: A Mideast Pawn, and a Father’s Agony
text: MITZPE HILA, Israel — Noam Shalit takes in the view of freezing rain and wind pounding olive groves of the Galilee outside his living room window and speaks of the danger of delay — more than half a year since the warm summer day when his son, Gilad, a young Israeli corporal, was captured by Palestinian militants in a cross-border raid and trundled into the Gaza Strip.

headline: Comedy Writer, Litigant, Frog Lover
text: A man is more than the sum of his eccentricities, but the equation for Jack Winter is particularly complicated. For someone who spent hours a day talking on the phone, had an enormous range of acquaintances and wrote a memoir (“The Answer to Everything,” self-published), he was, to many, an enigma.

headline: Dispute Erupts Over Flag Decals on the Lockers of Firefighters
text: The image still resonates in the minds of New Yorkers: three city firefighters raising an American flag over the smoldering ruins of ground zero. Now the flag, which has become inexorably tied to New York firefighters as symbols of courage since the 9/11 attacks, has become a wedge between the Fire Department and the city’s largest fire union.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a secure telephone that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg uses in his Manhattan town house rendered incorrectly a quotation from him. The mayor said he had occasionally received calls on the secure line asking “did I want to subscribe to a particular magazine, buy an insurance policy or some other such ridiculous thing.” He did not say the callers asked “did I want to subscribe to a ridiculous magazine, buy an insurance policy or some other such particular thing.”

headline: Keeping a Girl Off the Streets, and on the Road to Success
text: “She’s not going to be in the street, that’s for sure,” Geneva Burton said decisively as she nodded toward her granddaughter, Brittany Rivera, 14. There are drugs on the streets of their Bronx neighborhood, said Ms. Burton, 70. She lost her daughter to them and vowed not to lose her granddaughter, too.

headline: For $7.93 an Hour, It’s Worth a Trip Across a State Line
text: LIBERTY LAKE, Wash., Jan. 9 — Just eight miles separate this town on the Washington side of the state border from Post Falls on the Idaho side. But the towns are nearly $3 an hour apart in the required minimum wage. Washington pays the highest in the nation, just under $8 an hour, and Idaho has among the lowest, matching 21 states that have not raised the hourly wage beyond the federal minimum of $5.15.

headline: Storm Left New Orleans Ripe for Violence
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 — The storm of violence that has burst over this city since New Year’s Day can be traced in part to dysfunctional law enforcement institutions, aggravated by a natural disaster that turned the physical and social landscape of New Orleans into an ideal terrain for criminals.

headline: Kodak Selling X-Ray and Medical Image Lines
text: OTTAWA, Jan. 10  Eastman Kodak, as part of its struggle with the digital conversion of photography, said Wednesday that it would sell its X-ray film and medical-imaging equipment operations to an investment company, Onex of Toronto, for $2.35 billion in cash.

headline: And Today, Work Begins on First Wall
text: It looks like nothing more than a 22-foot-long, 4-foot-wide hole in the ground. But today, when a 180-foot-tall crane lowers a gigantic steel cage down into the trench, construction will begin on the first section of a $174 million wall more than 1,200 feet long.

headline: Shopping for a Villa, He Wound Up With a Village
text: Buonconvento, Italy

headline: Michigan: University to Comply With Ruling
text: The University of Michigan acceded to a federal appeals court decision and said it would immediately comply with the state’s new ban on affirmative action in public education, employment or contracting. The Michigan ballot initiative banning preferences based on race or gender passed overwhelmingly in November and was to go into effect on Dec. 23. But the University of Michigan, together with Michigan State University and Wayne State University, went to court seeking a six-month delay, on the ground that they were midway through an admissions cycle. A federal district judge granted the delay on Dec. 19, but on Dec. 29, a federal appeals court ordered immediate compliance.

headline: A Printer Meant to Produce Images That Last a Lifetime
text: Digital photographers and graphic designers with limited budgets will want to note Epson’s replacement for its venerable 1280 ink-jet printer, introduced in 2000. The Stylus Photo 1400, which will reach the market early next month, will cost the same as the older model  $400  and will still use six inks, but they will be Epson’s new Claria inks.

headline: Senator Dodd May Be Joining Democratic Race for President
text: HARTFORD, Jan 10 — Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, is to announce on Thursday morning that he is running for president, some of his friends say.

headline: Mets Are Near Multiyear Deal With Schoeneweis
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Jan. 10  The Mets were busy on two pitching fronts yesterday, welcoming an enthusiastic Pedro Martínez to the team’s minicamp to check on his rehabilitation from shoulder surgery while closing in on a multiyear contract with Scott Schoeneweis, a versatile left-handed reliever.

headline: Protecting Our Skin (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Bestows Medal of Honor on Fallen Marine
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — In April 2004, Cpl. Jason L. Dunham, a Marine Corps recruit from a small town in upstate New York, did something extraordinary: he threw himself on an exploding grenade to shield two men in his unit as they battled insurgents on a road in Iraq, losing his own life.

headline: Tax Cuts and Consequences
text: The tax system in the United States is supposed to mitigate inequality. But a recent report by Congress’s budget agency provides fresh evidence that Bush-era tax cuts have done more to reinforce inequality than to redress it.

headline: New Operas at the Met: What Works?
text: The Metropolitan Opera has to be discouraged by the mostly negative critical reactions to “The First Emperor,” Tan Dun’s ambitious opera, which had its world premiere at the house on Dec. 21. The good news for the Met, though, is that its run, through Jan. 25, is sold out, including this Saturday’s matinee, to be broadcast on radio and in high-definition screenings at more than 100 movie theaters around the world. Could opera companies have better proof that today’s audiences are hungry for new works?

headline: Spitzer Vote Tally Is Slightly Lower in Official Count
text: In last November’s election, which made Eliot Spitzer governor, the press and politicians made much of the size of his record victory. In the initial vote totals, based largely on unofficial election data and exit polls, Mr. Spitzer had about 70 percent of the vote.

headline: Police Detective in Fatal Shooting Is Questioned by Prosecutors
text: The undercover detective who fired the first of 50 shots at a car driven by a groom-to-be, killing him and wounding two friends, was questioned yesterday by Queens prosecutors investigating the shooting, the detective’s lawyer said.

headline: Giants Need Some Players Who Are Pillars
text: In the State of the Giants address yesterday by the team’s co-owners, John Mara and Jonathan Tisch, Mara mentioned how “the players we have spoken to overwhelmingly” supported retaining Tom Coughlin as coach. But the more serious issue is that none of those players resemble the locker-room pillars that made the Giants an elite pro football team in two glorious eras.

headline: Maureen Orcutt, Early Woman Golfer and Sportswriter, Dies at 99
text: Maureen Orcutt, one of the nation’s outstanding golfers for almost a half-century and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, died Tuesday in Durham, N.C. She was 99.

headline: A Shuffle at Paramount, and More to Come
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 — The resignation of the president of Paramount Pictures, Gail Berman, one of Hollywood’s highest-ranking female executives, carried a message this week for those with a stake in the success of her boss, Brad Grey: The turmoil is not over.

headline: China Says Its Trade Surplus in 2006 Climbed to a Record
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 10 — China’s trade surplus soared to a record $177.47 billion last year as exports continued to rise briskly, China’s customs administration announced Wednesday night.

headline: Inwood: Arrest in Robbery Attempt
text: A New Jersey man accused of being involved in a robbery attempt at an Inwood home in which a 9-year-old boy was shot through the eye has been arrested, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The man, Raseed Watson, 21, of Paterson, N.J., was extradited to Nassau County on Tuesday and arraigned yesterday on one count of first-degree robbery, the police said. The police said they believed that Mr. Watson fired the shot that injured the boy, John Henry Romano Jr., now 10, and expected to file additional charges against him. Investigators said Mr. Watson was one of three men who entered the Inwood home in September and engaged in a gunfight with the owner. A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested in the case in October, and a third suspect remains at large, the police said.

headline: Staten Island: More Bad Smells
text: A foul odor reported yesterday over Staten Island, particularly at Curtis High School and in New Brighton, was identified by fire officials and the Department of Environmental Protection as gas fumes. No injuries were reported, but students could be seen covering their noses and mouths. Unlike the odors over Manhattan and New Jersey on Monday, believed to be mercaptan, a chemical added to natural gas that smells like rotten eggs, the Staten Island smell is believed to be petroleum-based, said Charles Sturcken, spokesman for the environmental department. “The preliminary results in the field are that there is nothing hazardous in the air,” he said. After the first reports of the odor about 2 p.m., officials sampled the air along the waterfront across from an industrial area of Bayonne, N.J. The source of the odor was not determined.

headline: In 2 Pennsylvania Towns, Skepticism and Resignation
text: CLIFTON HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 11 — Hunched over a beer with a crowd of other veterans at the American Legion here, Rocco Polidoro, said he is sure of one thing: the President Bush’s plan to send some 20,000 more troops into Iraq will only make matters worse.

headline: Murcer Says Brain Tumor Is Malignant
text: Bobby Murcer, a former Yankees outfielder and their longest-serving current announcer, said yesterday that a tumor removed from his brain during surgery on Dec. 28 was malignant. He did not describe his prognosis.

headline: Apple Waves Its Wand at the Phone
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Judith Vladeck, 83, Who Fought for Women’s Rights, Dies
text: Judith P. Vladeck, a prominent labor lawyer and ardent advocate of women’s rights in the workplace, particularly on college campuses, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Transcript of President Bush’s Address to Nation on U.S. Policy in Iraq
text: Following is a transcript of President Bush’s address to the nation last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Barbaro Set Back by Damage to a Hoof
text: Barbaro was said to be resting comfortably last night after his months of slow, smooth recovery were interrupted by 36 hours of pain caused by damaged tissue in his left hind hoof.

headline: Goldman and Canadian Firm in Deal for 13 Cable Channels
text: OTTAWA, Jan. 10  CanWest Global Communications, a Canadian broadcaster and newspaper publisher, joined Goldman Sachs on Wednesday to buy Alliance Atlantis Communications, producer of “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation” and owner of 13 Canadian cable channels, for about 2.3 billion Canadian dollars (about $1.95 billion) in cash.

headline: Bush’s Speech Is Vindication for a General
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — After President Bush told the nation Wednesday night that he was ordering a rapid increase of American forces in Iraq, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki was not among the retired officers to offer instant analysis on television.

headline: A Discreet Voice Recorder for Your 275-Hour Podcast
text: Podcasters and others in need of audio recordings no longer need to stick a microphone in their subjects’ faces. The Olympus DS-50 voice recorder has a clip-on stereo microphone that will pick up both sides of a conversation.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart on the Street Scene page of Business Day last Thursday that listed the leading merger and acquisition advisers misstated the value of the deals in 2006. For Goldman, Sachs, the sector leader, it was $1.088 trillion, not $108.8 trillion. For the industry as a whole, the value of the deals was $3.805 trillion, not $380.5 trillion. A corrected chart can be found online.

headline: Democrats Plan to Fight Expansion of Troops
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — The new Democratic leaders of Congress on Wednesday accused President Bush of ignoring strong American sentiment against the war in Iraq and said they would build a bipartisan campaign against his proposed military expansion.

headline: Bid to Secure Baghdad Relies on Troops and Iraqi Leaders
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — With his new plan to secure Iraq, President Bush is in effect betting that Iraqi leaders are committed to building a multisectarian state, and his strategy will stand or fall on that assumption.

headline: Symbolic Vote on Iraq? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Who Belongs in the Hall? You Make the Call (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Promising Troops Where They Aren’t Really Wanted
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 10 — As President Bush challenges public opinion at home by committing more American troops, he is confronted by a paradox: an Iraqi government that does not really want them.

headline: Belarus Signals Resolution in Oil Dispute
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 10 — Belarus announced Wednesday that it had reached a compromise with Russia to end a dispute that had shut a Russian oil pipeline to Europe since Monday, but the Kremlin did not confirm any agreement.

headline: Carlo Ponti, Film Producer, Dies at 94
text: Carlo Ponti, the influential film producer whose vast body of work encompassed Italian realism, French New Wave and Hollywood fluff but who etched his name in popular legend by defying law and church to marry Sophia Loren, died on Tuesday in Geneva. He was 94.

headline: E.W. Scripps Explores Options for Its Newspaper Holdings
text: Newspapers may have lost their luster for yet another media company.

headline: AIDS Drug to Protect Fetus Is Safe for Infected Mothers, Study Finds
text: Women can take the anti-AIDS drug nevirapine to protect their unborn children without endangering their ability to undergo life-saving antiretroviral treatment later on, a new study has found.

headline: A Soak to Remember
text: RACHEL LANG said she is happy when she is drawing a bath and laying out the luxuries that symbolize pure enjoyment. Who isn’t? But what is unusual is that she does it for total strangers.

headline: A Whole Lot of Thinking Going On
text: SHORT of a “20 percent markup!” sign in the window, the owners of Project No. 8 have created one of the least inviting store facades in the city.

headline: A New Focus on Delta Air as Deal Bait
text: Delta Air Lines, in such dire straits a year ago that its chief financial officer called it “a company I’m not sure we could have given away,” is suddenly in great demand.

headline: Moving Down the Road to Recovery
text: I WAS injured on a nighttime run on Oct. 10. I had run nine and a half miles two days before, which was long for me. Then, the night of my injury, I got lost trying to check out a 10 kilometer course and ran way too far. By the time I got back to my car, my left forefoot ached. The next day I could barely walk.

headline: Threat and Harassment for New Jersey Town’s First Black Mayor
text: SOUTH HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 10 — Like a lot of mayors in small towns throughout New Jersey, Charles T. Tyson took office here on New Year’s Day with grand ambitions and little fanfare. But unlike most of them, Mr. Tyson started his term by trying to figure out who was threatening to kill him.

headline: Canada: Stomach Virus Sweeps Quebec
text: Dozens of hospitals and nursing homes in Quebec are struggling to contain an epidemic of viral gastroenteritis. The illness is suspected to be a new strain of the Norwalk virus and causes fever, vomiting and diarrhea. Montreal has been hit the hardest, with 29 health care institutions having reported outbreaks. At least eight players and one coach for the Montreal Canadiens hockey team have also contracted the illness. Officials said they expected the number of cases to increase.

headline: A Dance Fling to Salute the Soul Man
text: Dwight Rhoden’s hip and slinky “Chapters” has Broadway dance musical written all over it. The balance of the program presented by the Complexions Contemporary Ballet on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater was an up-and-down affair, with two of the most appealing dances coming from guest artists. But Mr. Rhoden, the company’s chief choreographer and its founder with Desmond Richardson, has a promising thing going in “Chapters,” which celebrates the music of Marvin Gaye.

headline: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
text: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the company’s $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.

headline: Still, the Question of Displaying the Names of 9/11
text: TO the dispute over how 2,979 victims’ names are to be inscribed and arranged at the World Trade Center memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg contributed an indisputable truth last month.

headline: Bombings Hit Philippines on Eve of Conference
text: CEBU, the Philippines, Jan. 11 — A series of terrorist bombings in the southern Philippines on the eve of the annual summit meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, has highlighted a growing need to address terrorism in the region, officials said today.

headline: Excerpts and Audio: The Pellicano Case
text: Following are excerpts of calls between the private eye Anthony Pellicano and Kirk Kerkorian’s lawyer, Terry N. Christensen, about a legal fight with Kerkorian’s ex-wife, Lisa Bonder Kerkorian, as transcribed by The New York Times. Digital recordings of the calls were turned over last year by prosecutors to defense lawyers as part of the discovery process. Prosecutors said the recordings were recovered from Pellicano’s computers. The recordings included date and time stamps placing them between March and May of 2002.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,002 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Clip-Ons Are Back. Fondling Allowed.
text: THERE was a time when young women wanted to be their mothers. Now it appears they want to be their grandmothers. The latest evidence? The resurrection of Grandma’s favorite touch: great big button earrings.

headline: On Display, the Video Frontier
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: A Veronica So Tall

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Celebration Continues, as Does Talk of Steroids
