text: A day after being elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn reflected fondly upon their careers during a news conference at a Manhattan hotel yesterday. But for the second consecutive day, the issue of steroids, and Mark McGwire, arose, following them like a tin can attached to a car.

headline: A Superpowered Defense, or a Chunk of Kryptonite at the Table?
text: As has been observed by many, if we all enjoyed X-ray vision, this game — not to mention life — would lose almost all of its appeal. But at the bridge table sometimes it is possible to play, or appear to play, as if one were blessed with Superman-style eyesight. The diagramed deal, which was played late last year on Bridge Base Online (www.bridgebase.com), gave East a chance to look as if he had just emerged from a phone booth with bulging muscles.

headline: Television That's Rude, Crude, Hilarious and Only on the Web
text: Spending eight hours in residence on Comedy Central’s MotherLoad, the “thousands of funny and free videos” now offered on the channel’s Web site, closed the case on something that’s been confusing me.

headline: Malden Mills Returns to Bankruptcy
text: Malden Mills Industries, maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, less than four years after an earlier reorganization, and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million.

headline: Nazi U-Boat Imperils Norwegians Decades After the War
text: FEDJE, Norway, Jan. 8 — World War II was edging to a close as Kristoffer Karlsen peered from this rocky outcrop off Norway’s coast and saw what he took to be a huge explosion some way out to sea.

headline: When It’s O.K. to Run Hurt
text: JUST before the end of last year, a prominent orthopedic surgeon was stretching to lift a heavy box and twisted his back. The pain was agonizing. He could not sit, and when he lay down he could barely get up.

headline: Eau de New York City
text: New Yorkers have spent the last few days getting sneering phone calls and e-mail from friends in distant places. Some recommended their favorite air fresheners or asked if we washed our socks. Others worried that this week’s big stink was a plot of some kind  perhaps terrorists, of course, since we always think that first now. But perhaps it was the work of somebody launching a fancy new oxygen atomizer: fresh air from the islands at only $5 a whiff.

headline: Trade Deficit Drops for Third Consecutive Month
text: American companies sold more goods like airplanes, cars and precious metals overseas in November, helping to narrow the trade deficit for a third consecutive month.

headline: Law Firm Employee Is Accused of Posing as Lawyer in Court
text: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 10  A man who prosecutors said had been representing clients of a prominent New York law firm for two years was arrested here on Wednesday and charged with impersonating a lawyer, state prosecutors said.

headline: Talk to Her (or Him)
text: MARGARET SHAPIRO of the Council for Relationships offered this script for hammering out design disagreements using ideas gleaned from a program developed by Dr. Howard Markman, director of the Center for Marital and Family Studies at the University of Denver:

headline: Getting Graphic With Vista
text: Getting Graphic

headline: Former Official Is Said to Be a Focus of Lobbyist Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — The former No. 2 official in the Interior Department has been notified by federal prosecutors that he will most likely be indicted for lying about his relationship with the corrupt lobbyist Jack Abramoff, people with knowledge of the investigation said Wednesday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the corporate takeover battle emerging in Asia for Hutchinson Essar, the telecommunications company, misstated its revenue in American dollars in some copies for the four quarters ended in June 2006. It was $1.58 billion — not $12.38 billion, which is the amount of revenue in Hong Kong dollars.

headline: Hurdles in Harvard Yard and the World Beyond
text: Louis Begley’s latest novel, “Matters of Honor,” is a kind of pale, male version of Mary McCarthy’s novel “The Group” — moved from Vassar to Harvard, from the class of 1933 to the class of 1950-something. It is also devoid of McCarthy’s biting, satirical wit and keen eye for social distinctions; none of its central protagonists emerges as a compelling or even believable individual.

headline: Small-Government Ideal (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wal-Mart Says Health Plan Is Covering More Workers
text: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation’s largest employer, is expected to announce today that the number of workers enrolled in the company’s health plan rose 8 percent last fall, the result of its introduction of cheaper insurance policies.

headline: Florida Adopts Plan for Mentally Ill Inmates
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 10  About 300 mentally ill inmates in county jails throughout Florida will eventually be moved to psychiatric hospitals and residential centers for treatment after state lawmakers agreed on Wednesday to an emergency spending measure.

headline: Firms Fret as Office E-Mail Jumps Security Walls
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10  Companies spend millions on systems to keep corporate e-mail safe. If only their employees were as paranoid.

headline: The Computer With a TV, and a Family's Virtual Bulletin Board
text: The notion of a computer at the heart of every home gets a little bump with the multitasking Hewlett-Packard TouchSmart PC, unveiled at the Consumer Electronics Show this week as part of the introduction of the Windows Vista operating system from Microsoft.

headline: Children’s Quality of Life Is on the Rise, Report Finds
text: Compared with a decade ago, America’s children appear to be marginally better off, according to a Census Bureau analysis. More are performing at grade level in school, more are taking lessons after class and on weekends and more parents  especially in black households  are imposing limits on television viewing.

headline: Green Is the Color of Coaches’ Parachutes
text: If Florida Coach Urban Meyer is the type of fellow to watch his money roll in, then he has had plenty to admire since he took the job in 2004, and even more since his Gators won the national championship Monday.

headline: Brooklyn: Arrest in Rape of Student
text: A man who works at an organization that collaborates with a school in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a teenage student, city school officials said. The man, Ivory Gordon, 24, of Brooklyn, was charged with rape, sex abuse and criminal sexual conduct, according to the office of Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools. The student, a girl attending the New Beginnings School, was assaulted several times on school premises and at Mr. Gordon’s home, according to Mr. Condon’s office. Mr. Gordon was suspended without pay on Monday from his job as a case manager at the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club’s Navy Yard clubhouse, said Joseph Patuleia, the organization’s executive director. He said the city ran New Beginnings in the clubhouse under a contract.

headline: Roberta Wohlstetter, 94, Military Policy Analyst, Dies
text: Roberta Wohlstetter, a military and foreign policy analyst whose work on the intelligence failures before the attack on Pearl Harbor was cited by the 9/11 commission, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: Big Mac’s Big Night
text: ON a September night in 1998, Mark McGwire hit his 62nd home run of the season, breaking Roger Maris’s record in front of a frenzied crowd in St. Louis. The moment was perfect.

headline: Europe Union Proposes Cleaner, More Competitive Energy Market
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 10  European Union officials on Wednesday challenged governments to loosen their grip on national energy sectors, calling for a fresh wave of competition and investment in infrastructure and technology to ease dependence on powerful exporters like Russia and to combat global warming.

headline: Knicks Look at the Sixers and See a Reflection
text: While unsure just yet where they are going, the Knicks got a long, hard look last night at where they have been. The team on the opposite bench lacked personality, direction and hope, and it was not so long ago that the Knicks suffered from a similar disease.

headline: Bush Adds Troops in Bid to Secure Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — President Bush embraced a major tactical shift on Wednesday evening in the war in Iraq when he declared that the only way to quell sectarian violence there was to send more than 20,000 additional American troops into combat.

headline: Jets’ Coaching Blueprint May Appeal to Dolphins
text: The Miami Dolphins are considering Brian Schottenheimer, the Jets’ offensive coordinator, for their head-coaching position left vacant when Nick Saban departed for Alabama. Yesterday they interviewed Schottenheimer, who is 33 years old, has never been a head coach and just finished his first season as a coordinator.

headline: Mideast Maps and Rorschach Tests (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush’s Plan for Iraq Runs Into Opposition in Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 President Bush’s call to increase the American military commitment in Iraq ran into intense Congressional opposition Thursday from Democrats and from moderate Republicans who expressed profound skepticism.

headline: A Tough Defense Lawyer Finds He’s in Need of One
text: Back in the 1980s, Paul W. Bergrin was a hard-hitting prosecutor in Essex County, N.J., who then became an assistant United States attorney in Newark.

headline: Uncruel Beauty
text: HADASS KANTOROWICZ is on the fence. “I eat less meat than I used to,” said Ms. Kantorowicz, a self-described tantric healer who stopped in last week at Organic Avenue, a vegan general store in downtown Manhattan. “I’m definitely a lot more conscious than I used to be.” While she appreciates the virtues of a meat-free diet, she stops short of embracing a vegan way of life, one that would ask her to forsake a croc-embossed bag or patent leather pumps. “And I’m not ready to wear hemp,” she confided.

headline: Opponents of Nevada Bomb Test Fault Impact Studies
text: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 10 — A twice-postponed nonnuclear bomb test in the middle of the Nevada desert may face additional legal challenges over its potential to propel dangerous radioactive particles from the soil into the air over four states.

headline: What's on Thursday Night
text: 10 P.M. (USA) NASHVILLE STAR Jewel and Cowboy Trent are hosts of the fifth season of this competition series in which the grand prize is a recording contract with Warner Music Group. Among the 10 contestants, chosen from 20,000 aspiring country musicians, are Angela and Zac Hacker, sibling competitors.

headline: The Fog Over Iraq
text: If the Democrats don’t like the U.S. policy on Iraq over the next six months, they have themselves partly to blame. There were millions of disaffected Republicans and independents ready to coalesce around some alternative way forward, but the Democrats never came up with anything remotely serious.

headline: 3 at Florida-Based Hedge Fund Accused of Misleading Investors
text: The three principals of the KL Group in West Palm Beach, Fla., a firm that operated many hedge funds that collapsed in early 2005, were indicted yesterday, accused of orchestrating an extensive fraud that raised more than $194 million from at least 250 investors.

headline: Drexel Claims a Spot on the Philadelphia Stage
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10  The Daskalakis Athletic Center, the Drexel Dragons’ cramped home gym, is a brisk four-block walk from the Palestra, the arena on the University of Pennsylvania campus that has been a basketball shrine for generations.

headline: Rutgers Can’t Get Shots to Drop Against Tough Syracuse Defense
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan 10  A young, rebuilding Rutgers team might have learned something Wednesday night. It probably is not going to win a jump-shooting contest.

headline: Bangladesh Leader Declares State of Emergency
text: NEW DELHI, Friday, Jan. 12 — The president of Bangladesh declared a state of emergency Thursday evening, suspending certain fundamental rights, imposing a nighttime curfew, and effectively postponing elections that were scheduled to be held in less than two weeks. He then resigned as the head of the caretaker government entrusted to run the polls, though he remains chief of state.

headline: Ivory Coast: U.N. Extends Mandate of Troops
text: The Security Council voted to keep a 12,000-strong force of United Nations and French peacekeepers another six months to help disarm militias, prepare for elections and monitor a buffer zone and fragile cease-fire between the government-run south and rebel-held north. The Council has twice extended the term of President Laurent Gbagbo, which ran out in 2005, in anticipation of elections but has authorized a political opponent, Charles Konan Banny, the prime minister, to organize the vote, an arrangement that Mr. Gbagbo has challenged.

headline: E-Mail Gaffe Publicizes Job Seekers in Albany
text: ALBANY, Jan. 10  Gov. Eliot Spitzer made his name, in part, on indiscreet e-mail messages, as any number of executives who were pursued by the attorney general’s office in recent years can attest. Now his administration has sent out an indiscreet e-mail message of its own: An e-mail response to people seeking jobs as spokesmen included the e-mail addresses of 227 other job applicants, including reporters and local and city government employees.

headline: A ‘Dream’ Government Goes Sour in Thailand
text: HONG KONG, Jan. 10 — When Thailand’s military-appointed government took office in October, it was hailed in the country as a dream team, with experienced Western-educated technocrats who had the rare quality of being “above politics.”

headline: House Bans Smoking, and Few Complain
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — Democrats banned smoking inside the House on Wednesday. Then they quickly congratulated themselves, squeezing as much symbolism out of the moment as they could.

headline: Estonia: Monuments to Soviet Soldiers to Go
text: Parliament voted to allow the relocation of war memorials and soldiers’ graves, a move critics have said was intended to eliminate Soviet-era monuments. The country’s ethnic Russians, joined by lawmakers and officials in Russia, have denounced the proposal, saying it was meant to remove the Bronze Soldier, a monument in the capital, Tallinn, to the Red Army soldiers who died in World War II, as well as other Soviet objects. For many in Estonia, absorbed into the Soviet Union during the war, the monuments symbolize occupation and totalitarianism.

headline: Irreconcilable Interiors: When Mates Don’t Match
text: SANDI SLONE and Bruce Ehrmann have been a love story for 25 years. She is a painter, he is a newspaper and television reporter turned real estate broker. They met in Harvard Square one afternoon — she had a show nearby, he was meeting a friend — and they have been together ever since. Where she is dainty and precise, he is expansive, voluble and quick to self-criticism. Their rapport is terrific, an affectionate, Nick-and-Nora-style back-and-forth, honed and polished to a glittering sheen.

headline: Solution Appears Near for Oil Tariff Dispute
text: Top stories from Russian newspapers on Thursday.

headline: Ex-Counsel to Settle Suit
text: Comverse Technology’s former general counsel, William F. Sorin, will pay $3.1 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations he conspired with the company’s former chief executive, Jacob Alexander, to backdate stock options.

headline: War’s Rorschach Test
text: Providence, R.I.

headline: Eagles' Andrews Loses Weight and Gains Finesse
text: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8  Each week, the Eagles’ players have a culinary ritual called Junk Food Friday. The problem, guard Shawn Andrews said, is that Junk Food Friday too often became Junk Food Saturday, Junk Food Sunday and Junk Food Monday.

headline: Kansas: City to Demolish Killer’s House
text: The mayor of a Wichita suburb said the city planned to tear down the house where Dennis Rader, known as the B.T.K. serial killer, lived for 25 years while he carried out a string of murders. The suburb, Park City, bought the house from Mr. Rader’s wife for just under $60,000 and plans to demolish it in the next month, Mayor Dee Stuart said. The property will be converted into an entry to an existing city park, Ms. Stuart said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about cellphones and other small devices that take on desktop computers’ functions referred incorrectly to four officials from Oqo, which makes a pocket-sized computer. While the four pictured are executives, only three were among its founders. Bob Rosin, second from right, is the senior vice president for marketing and alliances and joined the company later.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about a controversy over a national sweepstakes awarding a $25,000 savings bond to the first American baby born in 2007 gave an erroneous birth weight in some copies for a Chinese-American girl, born in Manhattan, who was disqualified because her mother was not a legal resident. The girl, Yuki Lin, weighed 6.5 pounds, not 6.5 ounces. (The sponsor of the sweepstakes, Toys “R” Us, has since reversed its decision and awarded Yuki and two other babies born shortly after midnight $25,000 each.)

headline: To Say ‘Bon Appétit,’ Oui or Non
text: PARIS

headline: God, Mom and Country: A Filmmaker’s Odyssey
text: You are a young documentary filmmaker with a reputation for capturing politicians’ antics. In a deliberate departure from politics, your latest film is a road trip into the world of evangelical Christians that includes a drive-through church, a Christian wrestling federation, a stand-up Christian comic, an evangelical Elvis and a biblical miniature golf course complete with the empty tomb of Jesus.

headline: Weapons Raids in Somalia After Violent Night
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 10 — Mogadishu exploded in violence on Wednesday morning after unknown insurgents attacked a transitional government barracks during the night and soldiers responded by sealing off large swaths of the city, searching house to house for guns.

headline: The Dome Gains Weight and Settles Down
text: BRUCE NELKIN decided in the 10th grade that he would someday live in a geodesic dome, after seeing a picture of one in a science book. “It looked like something out of ‘Star Wars,’ ” Mr. Nelkin said. “I thought it was the coolest thing I’d ever seen, and I said to myself, ‘When I grow up I’m going to build one of those.’ ”

headline: White House Is Opposed to New Bill on Stem Cells
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — The Bush administration jumped back into the bitter debate surrounding embryonic stem cell research on Wednesday, urging lawmakers to vote against House legislation to expand such research and calling for a new focus on scientific studies that would not harm embryos.

headline: Lawyer Gave Information to Kerkorian
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 — When Kirk Kerkorian’s longtime lawyer was indicted on wiretapping and conspiracy charges last February in the federal investigation of the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano, the billionaire investor was mentioned almost as an afterthought.

headline: Queens: Man Charged in Traffic Dispute
text: A man whose brother was shot and killed late Tuesday by an off-duty state corrections officer during a traffic dispute was charged yesterday with second-degree assault, the police said. The man, Leroi Kenner, 45, and his brother, Chris Kenner, 36, both of Queens, attacked the officer, Emilio Maldonado, 29, after he honked at them near La Guardia Airport when they failed to accelerate after their traffic light turned green, the police said. According to a witness, the police said, the men punched the officer in the face through an open car window. Then, realizing that he was an officer, they shouted, “Shoot the cop, shoot the cop.” According to the witness, the police said, one of the brothers reached for his waistband as if to retrieve a gun, and the officer shot once, striking Chris Kenner in the torso. He was taken to a Elmhurst Hospital Center, where he died. The investigation is continuing, but Officer Maldonado has not been charged. A spokeswoman for the Department of Correctional Services, Linda Foglia, said Officer Maldonado’s use of his weapon appeared to be proper procedure.

headline: To Counter Iran’s Role in Iraq, Bush Moves Beyond Diplomacy
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 — In promising to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, President Bush returned Wednesday night to a strategy of confrontation in dealing with Tehran, casting aside what had been a limited flirtation with a more diplomatic approach toward it.

headline: Chávez Begins New Term Vowing Socialism
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 10 — President Hugo Chávez was sworn in to a new six-year term at a ceremony here on Wednesday in which he described Jesus as “the greatest socialist in history” and pledged to speed Venezuela’s metamorphosis into a Socialist country.

headline: Residential Sales: New York
text: Manhattan

headline: Sales of Sony’s PlayStation 3 Fall Short in Japan
text: TOKYO, Jan. 10 — The first results are out in the hotly contested market for video game consoles in Japan, and so far, the results do not look too promising for Sony and its much-promoted PlayStation 3.

headline: Announcing a New Iraq Policy
text: Major topics of President Bush's address to the nation.

headline: The Ultimate iPhone Frequently Asked Questions
text: Wow. Predictably, the torrent — and I do mean torrent — of iPhone commentary from the citizens of the Web is practically outflooding spam this week. Most of it comes from people whose shirt fronts are practically drenched in drool. Plenty is negative and bitter.

headline: The Apple of Their Eyes
text: Judging from the first bunch of comments we got about the iPhone, Mr. Jobs has another hit on his hands.

headline: William Boyd Novel Honored
text: William Boyd’s “Restless” has won the new Costa prize for novels, previously known as the Whitbread Novel Award. Mr. Boyd, who won the Whitbread First Novel Award for “A Good Man in Africa” (1981), will receive £5,000 (about $9,700) and become eligible, with winners in four other categories, for the 2006 Costa Book of the Year prize, to be announced in London on Feb. 7. The awards honor books of the last year by writers based in Britain and Ireland. “Restless,” published in the United States by Bloomsbury, tells of an aging British woman who reveals to her daughter that she was a counterintelligence operative.

headline: Starbucks Backs a Book
text: Starbucks has made its second book selection, and it’s no Mitch Albom. “A Long Way Gone” by Ishmael Beah, a memoir of that first-time author’s life as a child soldier in war-ravaged Sierra Leone, will be sold in about 6,000 Starbucks stores beginning on Feb. 15, the company plans to announce today. Mr. Albom’s “For One More Day,” the sentimental novel that inaugurated the company’s book-sale program, has sold roughly 92,000 copies in Starbucks stores since going on sale on Sept. 26. Comparing the two titles, Ken Lombard, the president of Starbucks Entertainment, said “A Long Way Gone” was “opposite in terms of the type of book, but consistent with our overall strategy of quality books.” The company, he added, is “convinced our customers are going to love this.” Beginning next month, Mr. Beah will give readings at Starbucks in 10 cities. “A Long Way Gone” is published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

headline: Senator Barbara Boxer and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice
text: The following is the exchange between Senator Barbara Boxer and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice during the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Iraq.

headline: Not Steroids, But for Bonds, a Bitter Pill Is Uncovered
text: On the heels of home run slugger Mark McGwire’s snub by the Baseball Writers Association of America for his first ballot election to Cooperstown — largely due to swirling suspicions relating to steroid use during his career — The New York Daily News reports this morning that San Francisco’s Barry Bonds, who ranks No. 2 on baseball’s career home run list, tested positive for amphetamine use in 2006.

headline: Another Aircraft Odyssey for Warburg Pincus
text: For the second time since 2003, Odyssey Investment Partners is selling an aircraft parts maker to a rival buyout shop, Warburg Pincus. A Warburg Pincus portfolio company, TransDigm Group, said late Tuesday it would acquire Aviation Technologies, a Seattle parts producer, from Odyssey for $430 million in cash. Warburg Pincus bought TransDigm itself from Odyssey for $1.2 billion in June 2003, producing nearly a 300 percent gain on a $100 million equity investment for Odyssey in five years.

headline: Former Fastclick Executives Open Venture Capital Firm
text: Two former executives at an online advertising company, Fastclick, have launched Great Pacific Capital, a locally focused venture firm based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Managing partner Dave Gross, the founding chief executive of Fastclick, told The Deal.com the firm’s first fund, Great Pacific Capital Partners I, had not yet closed, but that it would be capped at less than $50 million. In addition to putting in their own money, Mr. Gross and co-founder Rusty Reed have tapped primarily individuals in the region for funds, although Mr. Gross said other high-net-worth individuals from elsewhere could contribute as well.

headline: New Chateaux for London Bankers?
text: Property in France, the United States and Italy is topping the shopping lists of bankers in London’s City this bonus season, with many putting down large deposits to reserve their second homes without even bothering to view the house, according to a report in The Guardian. About 51 percent of City bankers plan to invest in overseas property in 2007, according to a poll by Populus for the property agency PURE International, with France topping the list with 28 percent, followed by the United States with 21 percent.

headline: Icahn on Chiefs, Morons and Leased Jets
text: Earlier this week, several blogs and the New York Post picked up a funny and harrowing anecdote about the billionaire financier Carl Icahn that appeared in a profile in Avenue magazine: Aboard his leased aircraft, the activist investor (or “corporate raider” as he was known in the 1980’s) had just finished instructing Apollo‘s Leon Black on the virtues of leasing jets as compared to buying them when he saw smoke coming from the engine.

headline: The Unvarnished Reality of the Holocaust
text: The timing may be coincidental, but for perspective on the hanging of Saddam Hussein it would be difficult to do better than a viewing of “Verdict on Auschwitz,” a stark, emotionally draining documentary on the trial in Frankfurt of 22 defendants accused of being part of the Nazi death machine.

headline: Kerkorian Caught Up in Pellicano Wiretapping Case
text: Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor who controls MGM Mirage and led a failed bid to push General Motors into an alliance with Nissan and Renault, is more deeply involved in the federal case against the Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano than previously known, according to The New York Times. The Times has tapes of telephone conversations between Mr. Pellicano, who is currently in jail awaiting trial, and Mr. Kerkorian’s long-time lawyer that suggest that Mr. Kerkorian was aware that the private detective was listening in on his ex-wife’s conversations.

headline: Goldman and CanWest Win Alliance
text: CanWest Global Communications and the private equity arm of Goldman Sachs said late Wednesday that they had reached a deal to acquire Alliance Atlantis for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($2 billion). Under the terms of the long-anticipated takeover, CanWest will put down just 132 million Canadian dollars to gain control of the company’s specialty cable television channels valued at 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: Personal Foul on Belichick
text: For those who haven’t seen it, Bill Belichick has drawn criticism for mashing a camera into a photographer’s face while trying to reach Eric Mangini for their postgame meeting Sunday.

headline: Arcelor Mittal Won’t Force Dofasco Sale
text: the steelmaker Arcelor Mittal on Wednesday said it would not take legal action to force the sale of Dofasco of Canada to Germany’s ThyssenKrupp, leaving Dofasco’s ownership unchanged for now. During Mittal Steel’s contentious acquisition of Arcelor last year, the company pledged to sell the Dofasco unit to ThyssenKrupp if the merger was successful. But Arcelor, in a bid to stymie the Mittal bid, put 89 percent of Dofasco into a Dutch legal entity, called a stichting, to prevent its sale.

headline: Accountant Pleads Guilty in KPMG Shelter Case
text: A California accountant pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges of conspiracy, tax fraud and obstructing a federal investigation, and pledged to help prosecutors as they conduct a widening criminal investigation of questionable tax shelters. The accountant, Steven Michael Acosta, the fourth person in the inquiry to plead guilty, is a relatively minor figure in the investigation, which has led to the indictment of 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. The inquiry has also ensnared Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, and other banks, accounting, law and investment firms.

headline: Malden Mills Returns to Bankruptcy
text: Malden Mills Industries, the maker of Polartec cold-weather fabrics, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, less than four years after an earlier reorganization, and said it would be sold to the Gordon Brothers Group for $44 million. Gordon Brothers, a Boston-based firm that advises restructuring companies, will also assume an unspecified amount of debt. Any sale of the company, which employs 835 workers, is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court.

headline: Former Comverse Counsel to Settle Suit
text: Comverse Technology’s former general counsel, William F. Sorin, will pay $3.1 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations he conspired with the company’s former chief executive, Jacob Alexander, to backdate stock options. Mr. Sorin will forfeit $1.7 million in profit, plus $818,000 in interest, and will pay a $600,000 fine, according to an agreement filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. He played a “critical role” in backdating options at Comverse, the world’s biggest maker of voice-mail software, the agency said.

headline: Grassso Should Keep Pay, Lawyers Argue
text: Attorneys for the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso, argued Wednesday that Mr. Grasso had fulfilled his fiduciary duty to the exchange and should be allowed to keep his $187.5 million compensation package. “[He acted] as a reasonably prudent person would act,” Gerson A. Zweifach, a Washington D.C.-based partner at Williams & Connolly, who represents Mr. Grasso, said in oral arguments before a New York appeals court panel.

headline: Identity Theft Charge in H.P. Spying Case
text: A private investigator accused of posing as a journalist to read the reporter’s private phone records as part of the boardroom spying scandal at Hewlett-Packard was charged Wednesday with federal identity theft and conspiracy charges. The investigator, Bryan Wagner, is accused of using the Social Security number of the unidentified journalist to gain access illegally to the phone logs, according to the criminal charges filed by a United States attorney, Kevin V. Ryan, in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif.

headline: EBay Will Buy StubHub for $310 Million
text: EBay said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the online ticket reseller StubHub for $310 million to bolster its share in the multibillion-dollar market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events.

headline: 3 at Florida-Based Hedge Fund Accused of Misleading Investors
text: The three principals of the KL Group in West Palm Beach, Fla., a firm that operated many hedge funds that collapsed in early 2005, were indicted Wednesday, accused of orchestrating an extensive fraud that raised more than $194 million from at least 250 investors. The three, Won Sok Lee, Yung Bae Kim and his brother Jung Bae Kim, who was also known as John B. Kim, are accused of promoting the KL hedge funds as successful, when, in fact, some of the funds suffered losses every quarter of their existence.

headline: Group Considers $38 Billion Bid for Equity Office
text: The biggest leveraged buyout in history may get even bigger. A consortium of investors is considering making an offer worth more than $38 billion for Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust that is controlled by Samuel Zell, The New York Times reported. The bid may not happen, but if it does, it would challenge the record-setting deal that Equity Office and the Blackstone Group agreed to in November.

headline: Satellite Radio Merger Talk Gets a Lift from Citigroup
text: A possible merger of XM Satellite Radio Holdings and its rival, Sirius Satellite Radio, snagged another believer Wednesday when a Citigroup analyst raised her price target on XM. Shares of the company made a double-digit leap Wednesday after the analyst, Eileen Furukawa, lifted her 12-month price target on the company to $21 from $16 a share, telling clients that she believed a merger between the two companies could happen before the fall.

headline: Deephaven Adds Shine to Knight Capital
text: Doom and gloom surrounded hedge funds last year as lawmakers threatened increased regulation and several high-profile players were blown out, but at least one bright spot for fans of the unregulated pools of capital has emerged. A “stellar” fourth quarter by Deephaven Capital Management will likely incresae earnings of the broker Knight Capital Group, which owns the $4 billion hedge fund firm, according to an analyst’s report.

headline: Scripps May Spin Off Newspapers
text: Newspapers may have lost their luster for yet another media company. E. W. Scripps, the parent company of The Rocky Mountain News, The Commercial Appeal in Memphis and 18 other dailies, told an investor conference Wednesday that it was exploring separating its newspaper business from its more profitable cable television and syndication ventures.

headline: President Bush's Speech Analysis
A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
text: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the company’s $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.

headline: A New Focus on Delta Air as Deal Bait
text: In fighting off a hostile offer from one rival, it seems Delta Air Lines has been talking about linking up with another. As US Airways increased its unsolicited merger bid to $10.2 billion Wednesday, reports said that Delta has been holding talks with Northwest Airlines and United Airlines about a possible combination with either of those carriers, according to reports. Discussions between Delta and Northwest, both of which filed for bankruptcy the same day in 2005, have apparently been occurring regularly for weeks. A Northwest bid would probably be preferable to Delta managers because the two airlines’ route networks overlap less than with Delta and US Airways, leading to fewer grounded planes, if any.

headline: Kelso Gets Global Geophysical Stake
text: Kelso and Company is investing $140 million in Global Geophysical Services in a deal that is expected to give the buyout shop a substantial minority stake in the energy services business, Moody’s Investors Service said. Global Geophysical. which also has offices in Lima, Peru, Boumerdes, Algeria, and Buenos Aires, provides hydrocarbon reservoir location services to oil and gas exploration and production companies via three-dimensional seismic-mapping services.

headline: Software Maker Nimsoft Raises $10.3 Million
text: Nimsoft, a Norwegian infrastructure software maker, raised $10.3 million from JMI Equity of San Diego and Oslo-based Northzone Ventures. The company will use the venture funding to increase sales and marketing of products in the fast-growing service-level management market.

headline: Madison Dearborn Sells Pizza Chain
text: Madison Dearborn Partners has sold Peter Piper Pizza, a restaurant chain, to Acon Investments for an undisclosed price, TheDeal.com reported. Peter Piper said its annual revenue is expected to exceed $200 million in 2007.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Said to Be Near Cap in $16 Billion Fund
text: Contributing to a record-breaking fund-raising year in 2006, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has now closed on $16.1 billion for its newest buyout fund, according to LBO Wire. The New York-based buyout shop has yet to hold a final closing for the fund, KKR Associates 2006 Fund LP, which has a cap of $16.625 billion, the report said.

headline: Ameriquest Looks for Hedge-Fund Buyer, Reports Say
text: Ameriquest, the largest subprime mortgage lender in the United States, may be sold to a bond hedge fund as it and its competitors face an increasingly difficult business environment, reports said. J.P. Morgan Securities, which owns the lender, has approached several buyers recently, including Ellington Capital Management, a $4.5 billion fund with a specialty in hedging mortgage credit risk. Sources told The New York Post that Ellington executives have not yet decided if they want to receive an offering circular. A price has not been given.

headline: The War at Home: The Morning After
text: In the lead up to the president’s speech, there had been a lot of debate about the distinctions between “surge” and “escalation,” with opponents of President Bush’s expected troop increase arguing that “surge” misleadingly implied a short-term infusion. But when Mr. Bush spoke last night, he did not imply that the over 20,000 additional troops going to Iraq would be there briefly.

headline: AirTran Raises Midwest Offer to $345 Million
text: Just after US Airways bumped up its unsolicited bid for Delta Air Lines, AirTran Airways has applied the gas to its own efforts to acquire Midwest Air Group. AirTran, a discount airline based in Orlando, Fla., raised its bid 19 percent, to $345 million Thursday, making the offer directly to shareholders and putting pressure on Midwest Air’s management. Last month, Midwest rejected AirTran’s initial offer of $290 million as too low, and on Wednesday, the airline unveiled a plan to add routes and update its fleet to help convince shareholders it should remain independent.

headline: A Portrait of Lives Transformed by Trauma
text: “Abduction: The Megumi Yokota Story” is an engrossing nonfiction detective tale about the 13-year-old girl of the title, who vanished on the way home from school in Niigata, Japan, in 1977. But it also succeeds as a thumbnail review of a painful chapter of Asian history, and as a portrait of lives transformed by trauma.

headline: A Cry From Guantanamo
Living With Pain
text: After Lorraine Kipper fell behind in her rent, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund provided her with $300.

headline: IRS Digs Into Swag
text: Defamer points out that the IRS is not above rummaging around in gift bags when it comes to looking for loot. But this year, the tables at the Golden Globes will be laden with food, not tons of merch.

headline: The Hill: Congress vs. White House
text: Guaranteeing that the president’s speech will not be the last word on his new strategy, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has been summoned to the Capitol today, and she is scheduled to appear before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this morning and the House Foreign Affairs Committee this afternoon.

headline: Heavy Lies the Crown
text: Gail Berman, Brad Grey’s handpicked president of Paramount Studios, is out and the studio has announced an executive overhaul.

headline: Pellicano: The Sequel
text: It’s sort of hard to get worked up about the implications of various pre-Oscar awards when a real-life drama seems deeper and darker than most of the movies out there.

headline: Coughlin Caricature
text: Tom Coughlin is the first coach to lead the Giants to two straight playoff appearances since Bill Parcells. He is a hard worker and a good man.

headline: EMI Group Said to Dismiss Its Music Chief
text: In an unexpected shakeup, the British music giant EMI Group has sacked its recorded music chief, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company, according to executives briefed on the plan.

headline: Turner Warms Up to Solar Venture
text: Following on a pledge by California’s governor to increase solar-energy production, the outspoken billionaire Ted Turner has partnered with Dome-Tech Solar of New Jersey to create a solar-energy venture to address the state’s power needs. Mr. Turner and Dome Tech intend to make the venture, DT Solar, one of the biggest solar power system integrators in California. Financial terms of the venture were not disclosed, but Dome-Tech’s chief operating officer told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Turner “won’t be a passive partner.”

headline: Picking Apart Bush’s New War Plan
text: “President Bush’s latest plan for Iraq has the feel of an overdue high school book report,” says the Los Angeles Times editorial page. “It looks nice, reads well and is persuasive in parts. If only he had handed it in on time.” Its editorial concludes:

headline: Julius Baer Sells Fixed-Income Unit in M.B.O.
text: The management of Julius Baer‘s fixed income investment boutique in London bought the $9 billion unit, less than two years after Julius Baer bought it when it acquired the global asset management operation from UBS. The division, now Augustus Asset Managers, will continue running hedge funds for Julius Baer and intends to expand in the United States. The first task for the unit and its new nonexecutive chairman, Howard Carter, will be to right a listing ship in which its two flagship funds generated anemic returns in 2006.

headline: Bush’s Belligerence Toward Iran and Syria
text: Several writers think President Bush buried the lede in his address to the nation last night. “We will interrupt the flow of support from Iran and Syria,” Bush said midway through the speech. William M. Arkin, who writes the “Early Warning” blog for The Washington Post, says this was the real news of the night: “If there’s anything in the President Bush’s remarks tonight that we didn’t already know or didn’t anticipate him saying militarily about Iraq, it is his evident willingness to go to war with Syria and Iran to seek peace.”

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Dodd In, All the Way
text: Senator Chris Dodd has held the status of potential presidential candidate for years. So now that he’s finally decided to go for it, he’s going straight for it, skipping the exploratory committee to directly file as a candidate with the Federal Election Commission. He announced the move earlier today on “Imus in the Morning,” and later today he’ll head to Iowa, and then to South Carolina on Sunday.

headline: A Tough Audience for a New Plan in Iraq
text: Reactions to the President’s plan to send 21,000 more troops in an attempt to settle a still roiling Iraq — a gambit that was fleshed out a bit this morning in a press conference held by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Robert Gates — were developing across the land, and across the globe today.

headline: Will Bondholders Play Spoiler in Blackstone Deal?
text: In a deal valued at $36 billion, quibbling over $100 million or so may seem absurd. But that is just what is happening in the background as Blackstone Group tries to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust in what would be the largest leverage buyout in history. A group of Equity Office’s bondholders, including insurance giant American International Group, say they are being shortchanged under a proposed debt buyback that would facilitate the sale. And at least one analyst points to the dispute as one of the reasons that Equity Office may be put back in play.

headline: Democrats Pick Denver as Convention Site
text: It’s not exactly a “New York: Drop Dead” kind of moment, but the Democratic National Committee has decided to hold the party’s 2008 nominating convention in Denver, according to Democrats familiar with the decision, heading West in rejecting a bid from New York to hold it there.

headline: Dems Choose Denver
text: That will be the site of the next Democratic convention, as New York lost its bid to host amid Bloomberg’s concerns about raising money for it.

headline: Albany: Full Ban on Smoking in Dorms
text: The State University of New York’s trustees adopted a policy yesterday banning smoking in all dormitories on all SUNY campuses starting July 1. The policy will affect the remaining 9 percent of SUNY residence hall beds where smoking is currently permitted, primarily at Stony Brook, Morrisville and Buffalo State, according to a statement issued by the university board.

headline: E-Mail Goof Postscript
text: The Spitzer administration sent this e-mail out to all the job-seekers who were inadvertently outed when their e-mail addresses were shared with other job-seekers:

headline: Video: He Types for a Reason
Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "The Scene," "You Belong to Me" and "Purity."

headline: Democrats Pick Denver for ’08 Convention
text: It's not exactly a "New York: Drop Dead" kind of moment, but the Democratic National Committee has decided to hold the party's 2008 nominating convention in Denver, according to Democrats familiar with the decision, heading West in rejecting a bid from New York to hold it there.

headline: The Van Picks Up Speed
text: Could “Little Miss Sunshine” be this year’s “Crash”? Jeffrey Wells offers a  theory to back up that view. This time of year, the plot not only thickens, it morphs by the hour.

headline: Knock, Knock, Microsoft. It’s SanDisk
text: Despite the Redmond, Wash., giant’s famously deep pockets and well-documented commitment to the success of its first digital music player, the Zune, Microsoft has so far failed to fire the imagination of the buying public since the player’s release last fall. I overheard a litany of disparaging remarks (“It’s kinda clunky,” for example) from would-be consumers shuffling past a Zune display at the Consumer Electronics Show yesterday.

headline: Espionage Tip in Canada: Don’t Keep the Change
text: Not only will those Canadian coins jam up the soda machine, now it appears they may be tracking your movements. At least that’s a warning that came down from the Defense Department to American contractors, who were told to be on the lookout for Canadian change embedded with tiny radio transmitters.

headline: Six Flags to Sell Seven Parks
text: Six Flags said Thursday that it had agreed to sell seven of its amusement parks for $312 million, and the news sent its stock on quite a ride. Shares of Six Flags, which is struggling with falling attendance at its parks, surged 9 percent in late-morning trading after the deal was announced. Six Flags was the subject of a bitter proxy battle in 2005, which resulted in a former ESPN executive, Mark Shapiro, being named chief executive. Since then, the company has sought to make its parks more family-friendly and to pay down some of its debt.

headline: Soares and Cuomo, Part II
text: Attorney General Andrew Cuomo is moving quickly to claim the mantle of a corruption fighter, offering details at a morning press conference today on his plans to work closely with Albany County District Attorney David Soares on cases involving state officials.

headline: Romney Adds Key G.O.P. Aide
text: Former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney has snagged another highly regarded Republican operative for his presidential campaign as the fight among the presidential campaigns for brains and bodies slogs on.

headline: Mr. Craigslist at City Hall
text: Craig Newmark may be one of the most important players in New York’s apartment rental market, but admits that most of what he knows about it he learns from watching re-runs of Seinfeld.

headline: U.S. Official: Somalia Air Strikes Miss Their Marks
text: Updating the murky and chaotic story of American air strikes in Somalia, BBC News is reporting that an unnamed “top U.S. official” is now saying that none of the major al Qaeda targets in that country are thought to have been killed.

headline: Who’s Worried About Iraq?
text: Oil prices were falling fast before President Bush added tough talk on Iran to his speech last night, in ways that had commentators wondering if a military confrontation loomed.

headline: Club Rules: Another View of G.E.’s Plastics Auction
text: Is Goldman Sachs being unusually careful to avoid group bids as it shops General Electric‘s plastics unit to potential buyers? PE Week Wire’s Dan Primack says no. And he argues that The Wall Street Journal got it wrong earlier this week when it suggested that the sale process shows the influence of a recent Justice Department investigation into so-called club deals.

headline: Families of Troops React to Bush Speech
text: Around the country, the wire services and local newspapers sought out the families of U.S. troops to get their reactions to President Bush’s speech Wednesday. Here’s a sampling:

headline: The iPhone Up Close
text: An inside look at Steve Jobs's speech at the Macworld convention.

headline: An Uncertain Somalia
text: The Times's Jeffrey Gettleman explains the challenges facing the Somali government after two weeks of violence.

headline: Whither Private Equity? Fortune Asks Dealmakers
text: If a substantial number of private-equity deals do not eventually “crash and burn,” it would be “a complete historical aberration,” Steve Rattner of Quadrangle Group tells Fortune magazine, offering a completely reasonable but rather dire observation for the magazine’s 2007 outlook piece. Fortune asked players such as Mr. Rattner and the Carlyle Group‘s David Rubenstein to assess where things stand. Mr. Rubenstein repeated what seems to be a favorite phrase of his, telling Fortune, as he told the Financial Times in December, that private equity is “the face of 21st-century American capitalism.”

headline: Blogtalk
text: Rather than get out of politics, Tom Suozzi may seek a third term as Nassau executive. [Capitol Confidential]

headline: Teaching an Old Fuel New Tricks
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 10 column, “My Favorite Green Lump.”

headline: The Ultimate iPhone Frequently Asked Questions
text: Wow. Predictably, the torrent — and I do mean torrent — of iPhone commentary from the citizens of the Web is practically outflooding spam this week. Most of it comes from people whose shirt fronts are practically drenched in drool. Plenty is negative and bitter.

headline: The Ultimate iPhone Frequently Asked Questions
text: Video: The iPhone Up Close

headline: eBay’s Latest Deal Looks Expensive, Analyst Says
text: EBay is paying a rich price for the online ticket vendor StubHub, Bear Stearns analyst Richard S. Peck suggests, writing in a research note that the deal “could be dilutive to eBay’s valuation.” His comments come as eBay is still trying to convince Wall Street that its $2.6 billion acquisition of the Internet-phone service Skype in September 2005, a deal whose final price tag could eventually hit $4.1 billion if bonuses are paid, was worth it.

headline: Writer’s Guild Finds Funny Bone
text: The writers have spoken, or typed. In any case, they have voted and the Writers Guild Award nominees are out. Among them: “Borat” and “Thank You for Smoking” showed up in the adapted screenplay category; “Little Miss Sunshine” was cited as one of five original screenplay nominees. For a complete list of nominees, click here.

headline: Tilting at Yahoo With a Web Site and Wiki
text: Eric Jackson is not happy that Yahoo has lost more than a third of its market value over the past year. But since he holds fewer than 1,000 shares of the Internet giant, he lacks the muscle of big-time activist shareholders such as Carl Icahn, Nelson Peltz or Ralph Whitworth, who have wrested concessions from the likes of ImClone Systems, Wendy’s International and Home Depot in recent months. Still, Mr. Jackson hopes to use the Internet to consolidate the anger of other small shareholders, attempting to become what TheStreet.com’s Vishesh Kumar describes as a “virtual activist investor.”

headline: Beckham to U.S.: Do You Care?
text: We take a short break from talking about football to talk about … football. The kind that has a professional team in Los Angeles.

headline: Blogtalk: The Speech
text: President Bush’s speech last night calling for 20,000 additional troops to help secure Iraq scored with the bloggers along predictable partisan lines.

headline: Editorials Elsewhere
text: Here’s a smattering of editorial opinions published today and Wednesday in newspapers around the country, including some in early primary states and others near military bases that will be deploying additional troops to Iraq.

headline: Wynn Sues Insurer Over Pierced Picasso
text: The Picasso painting that nearly inspired hedge fund billionaire Steven Cohen to shell out $139 million has inspired something else: a lawsuit. Casino mogul Stephen Wynn, who accidentially poked a silver-dollar-size hole in the painting shortly after agreeing to sell it to Mr. Cohen, has sued insurer Lloyd’s of London over the damaged painting, called “Le Reve.” If the deal with Mr. Cohen had gone through, it would have been the most-expensive sale of a work of art in history. (What Mr. Wynn reportedly said after discovering he had torn the painting is not fit for a family blog.)

headline: Portion Patrol
text: Some of the comments in response to a recent post about a book called “The Skinny” surprised me, because they took exception to diners who deliberately don’t finish the food on their plates and to restaurants that don’t scale portions down so that every morsel is guaranteed to be eaten.

headline: Debating Troop Increases on Guantánamo’s Anniversary
text: Even as President Bush and his Cabinet set about trying to sell the idea of increasing troop levels in Iraq to a reticent public and a sometimes-hostile Congress today, protesters at the site of another touchstone in what critics consider to be the mishandled war on terror — the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba — rallied for its closure.

headline: Senator Johnson: Health Update
text: The office of Senator Tim Johnson released an update on his condition this afternoon, saying the South Dakota Democrat was being moved to an inpatient rehabilitation unit at George Washington University Hospital, where he has been hospitalized since undergoing brain surgery last month.

headline: Do You Get What You Pay For?
text: A bottle being filled directly from a barrel of Brouilly, Cru du Beaujolais, at Chez Denise in Paris. (Ed Alcock for The New York Times).

headline: Spitzer Intervenes in LI Race
text: The race for Michael Balboni’s Long Island Senate seat continues to percolate.

headline: Post-Katrina Rejections Get Expensive for Insurance Companies
text: Sounding what must feel, at the very least, like a moral victory, if not quite yet a financial one (given that appeals are guaranteed) for families across the hurricane-ravaged Gulf Coast, a jury awarded $2.5 million in punitive damages to a couple in Mississippi who sued State Farm Fire and Casualty, after the company denied their post-Katrina claim.

headline: The National Board of Review, Continued
text: The Baguette stayed up too late on Tuesday, the night of the National Board of Review Awards, so she is only now getting around to reporting on her conversation with Pedro Almodovar, whose “Volver” won for best foreign film.

headline: Battle Lines Being Drawn
text: It’s been a weighty day of debate over the war in Iraq, with hearings on Capitol Hill replete with Bush administration officials and senators and representatives announcing their positions, and in many cases denouncing President Bush’s just-released plan to add nearly 22,000 troops in the field in Baghdad and the Anbar province.

headline: Still the Most Powerful Form of Protest
text: Great lessons can still be learned from the work of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. — not just for Americans but for people staging protests in other countries.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Black Tiger'
text: A. O. Scott of The New York Times reviews a colorful Thai western that is a loving pastiche of classic film genres.

headline: The Good Old-Fashioned Playground
text: New York City planners, blessed with a patch of prime real estate, an infusion of private funding and the participation of a hot architect, have hatched a plan to endow Lower Manhattan with a play space that will feature no swings, slides or monkey bars (“too dangerous,” as a New York Times story put it). Instead, this “bold experiment” in child-development-theory-made-real will have low wooden ramps, “zones” of sand and water, and enchanting, innovative playthings like foam blocks and gaskets.

headline: Accounting Games
text: Companies are still playing games when they do their financials, and auditors are still allowing them to be played.

headline: Duke Accuser Contradicts Herself and Says 2, Not 3, Attacked Her
text: Defense lawyers for three Duke lacrosse players made public a new account from the woman who has accused them of sexually assaulting her. She said two players, not three as she had originally alleged, attacked her in the bathroom at a team party in March. She also gave a new version of the timing and revised some of the men’s descriptions.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about a proposal by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to extend health care coverage to all of California’s residents misstated a requirement for insurers. They would have to contribute 85 percent of premiums to health care services, not 85 percent of profits. The article also referred incorrectly to the precedent for universal coverage. California would be the fifth state, not the fourth, to try near universal coverage. (Besides Maine, Massachusetts and Vermont, Hawaii has also tried.)

headline: Southeast Asians Consider Pact Against Terrorism
text: CEBU, the Philippines, Jan. 11  Ten Southeast Asian countries meeting here are hammering out a regional antiterrorism agreement, officials said Thursday, the day after a series of terrorist bombings in the southern Philippines underscored the need for such a measure.

headline: German Leader’s Status Grows as Voice of Europe
text: BERLIN, Jan. 11 — When Angela Merkel was sworn in 14 months ago as Germany’s chancellor, the first woman to hold the post, she seemed less a phenomenon than a fluke — squeaking into office amid predictions that her government would be hobbled by internal problems and might soon collapse.

headline: Where You’ll Find a Small-Town Feeling on the Big Island
text: LIKE many visitors to the Hawaiian Islands, Donna Rehling was smitten right away with the lush landscape, temperate breezes, indigo ocean and, of course, the near-perfect weather year-round. She even invested in a time share on Maui 14 years ago, so she and her family could revel in it all at least once a year.

headline: Knicks Are Not Among Webber’s Choices
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 11  Isiah Thomas could not hide his warm feelings and deep appreciation for Chris Webber  as a player, as a person and as a figure who could change the N.B.A.’s playoff landscape this spring.

headline: New York Loses Out to Denver in Quest for the ’08 Democratic Convention
text: DENVER, Jan. 11  The Democratic Party chose Denver over New York on Thursday as the site for its next national convention, capping months of debate about which city had better logistics, deeper pockets and a more compelling backdrop to frame the party’s message.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Skull Supports Theory of Human Migration
text: From a new analysis of a human skull discovered in South Africa more than 50 years ago, scientists say they have obtained the first fossil evidence establishing the relatively recent time for the dispersal of modern Homo sapiens out of Africa.

headline: Russian Billionaire Detained in Prostitution Ring Inquiry
text: PARIS, Jan. 11  Mikhail Prokhorov, a billionaire often described as Russia’s most eligible bachelor, was detained during an investigation into a suspected international prostitution ring operating at an upscale ski resort, a French prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: Steve Krantz, 83, Maker of TV Mini-Series, Dies
text: Steve Krantz, a producer and writer who pushed his wife, Judith, into starting her first novel at 48, then turned her signature “sex and shopping” best sellers into television mini-series, died on Jan. 4 in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Negotiating Lower Drug Prices
text: From all the ruckus raised by the administration and its patrons in the pharmaceutical industry, you would think that Congressional Democrats were out to destroy the free market system when they call for the government to negotiate the prices of prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries. Yet a bill scheduled for a vote in the House of Representatives today is sufficiently flexible to allow older Americans to benefit from the best efforts of both the government and the private drug plans.

headline: Exchange Turns Into Political Flashpoint
text: WASHINGTON, Jan 12 — A passing exchange during a Senate hearing on Thursday turned into a political flashpoint overnight as Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat, and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice accused one another of insensitivity in comments about motherhood and the war in Iraq.

headline: Hackensack: Lawsuit in Police Shooting
text: The family of a 45-year-old man who was fatally shot last year by a New Jersey Park Police officer filed a wrongful-death suit yesterday in State Superior Court. The suit names the officer and several colleagues, the State of New Jersey and the Park Police. The man, Emil Mann, a member of the Ramapough Mountain Indians, had been at a barbecue in the woods of Mahwah on April 1 when the officer, Chad Walder, shot him twice without justification, the suit alleges. Officer Walder, who has said he fired in self-defense, and two other officers also delayed getting medical help to Mr. Mann, the suit says. A lawyer for Officer Walder, Robert Galantucci, said the shooting was justified. No criminal charges have been filed in the case, and the Bergen County prosecutor’s office has said the investigation is still open. Mr. Mann, who grew up on the mountain where he was shot, lived in Monroe, N.Y., and had three children.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article Wednesday about efforts by Massachusetts to extend health care coverage to all residents reversed the names in some copies of two people who helped an immigrant from Bangladesh sign up for insurance. Feroza Bashar, a translator, was at right, and Goretti Macedo of Cambridge Health Alliance was at left.

headline: Administration Offers Plan to Ease Rules on Asylum
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  After months of pressure from lawmakers, conservative groups and advocates for immigrants, the Bush administration announced plans on Thursday to seek legislation that would provide relief to thousands of refugees and asylum seekers who have been inadvertently denied refuge because of antiterrorism laws.

headline: State Farm Told to Pay Gulf Claim
text: A federal jury ordered State Farm insurance yesterday to pay a $2.5 million penalty for refusing to cover damages to a Mississippi couple’s house that was destroyed in Hurricane Katrina, throwing into question settlement talks intended to resolve hundreds of lawsuits filed after the 2005 storm.

headline: Demand Outpaced Supply for New Game Consoles
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 — The Xbox 360 outsold the Wii, which outsold the PlayStation 3.

headline: Iraq Dominates World Politics, Not Markets
text: As Washington squares off over Iraq, with President Bush warning of disaster if the United States withdraws and Democrats saying that another 20,000 troops will not reverse what has gone wrong, two questions come to mind:

headline: Bush Threatens Veto of Medicare Drug Bill, but a Senator Is Seeking a Middle Ground
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — President Bush threatened on Thursday to veto legislation that would require the government to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies to obtain lower drug prices for Medicare beneficiaries.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture on Sunday of members of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, who protested the unseasonably warm weather by refusing to take a winter swim, carried an incorrect credit in some copies. It was by Andrea Mohin of The New York Times.

headline: Gun-Slinging Cowboys in Colorful Thailand
text: There may be crazier movies than “Tears of the Black Tiger,” Wisit Sasanatieng’s Thai cowboy melodrama of betrayal and forbidden love, but I can’t think of one that is quite so mad about its own craziness. What is most startling is not Mr. Sasanatieng’s compulsive, fetishistic assembly of bits and pieces of the movie past; this kind of pastiche has, over the past decade and a half, gone from novelty to cliché. The source of the movie’s seductive appeal lies less in its vivid fakery — the mock vintage-Technicolor hues, the musical and visual quotations, the miasma of camp hanging in the air — than in its disarming sincerity.

headline: 5th Defendant Pleads Guilty in Shelter Case
text: A former accountant pleaded guilty yesterday to one felony count of lying to federal investigators as part of a widening criminal inquiry into questionable tax shelters.

headline: New Law in Poland Is Aimed at Former Secret Police Agents
text: PARIS, Jan. 11  Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski of Poland on Thursday promised a new law that would take aim at former secret police agents, excluding them from serving in numerous public posts and leaving many of them with reduced or no pensions.

headline: G.I.’s in Iraq Raid Iranians’ Offices
text: ERBIL, Iraq, Jan. 11  American troops backed by attack helicopters and armored vehicles raided an Iranian diplomatic office in the dead of night early Thursday and detained as many as six of the Iranians working inside.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about separatist rebel attacks in the northeast Indian state of Assam misstated its precise location. Assam borders several other Indian states and the kingdom of Bhutan; it does not border Myanmar.

headline: Hussein Cousin Says He Ordered Executions
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 11  In the Baghdad courtroom where Saddam Hussein was sentenced to die in November, new testimony on Thursday featured a startling admission by his cousin Ali Hassan al-Majid, known to Iraqis as Chemical Ali.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the difficulty in filling city manager jobs misspelled the surname of the longtime manager of Charlotte, N.C., who announced her retirement. She is Pam Syfert, not Seyfert.

headline: House Passes Bill Mandating Drug Price Negotiations
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Defying a veto threat, the House today passed legislation requiring the government to negotiate with drug manufacturers to obtain lower drug prices for Medicare beneficiaries.

headline: On the Speed Channel, the Lead Roles in a New Show Are Played by 2 Toyotas
text: TOYOTA feels the need ... the need for speed — Speed Channel, that is, as the automaker and cable network join forces for an unusual program in which the Toyota FJ Cruiser plays a starring role.

headline: In TV Land, Barber Is Able to Run Free
text: A fantasy about the future employment of the in-demand former Giants running back Tiki Barber.

headline: As States Innovate, Schwarzenegger Blurs Lines
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 — So, who is Arnold Schwarzenegger anyway?

headline: Sugarbush Tries to Regain Its Buzz
text: THERE once was a mountain they called the Aspen of the East. It had boundless terrain, lavish dining, a pulsing nightlife and a clientele of gossip-page celebrities. Every Friday evening in winter, a chartered Greyhound bus called the Sugarbush Special would pull away from Park Avenue and the onboard party would be rocking by the time the bus rolled out of Manhattan.

headline: Letters: Nuclear Past and Present
text: To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in “Strange Love” (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins, the once formidable planes are a shell of their former selves, their sawed-off fuselages lying sadly in the dust. What used to be terrifying has somehow become poignant, as if a great epoch had ended. I suppose we can find cathartic relief in the mummification of a Titan II missile, but this may be cold comfort. The United States has spent more than $5 trillion on nuclear weapons since 1940, and judging from the current administration’s Nuclear Posture Review, which was made public in 2002 and calls for a complete revitalization of the country’s nuclear infrastructure, this spending is far from done. Don’t be fooled by moth balls. Old nukes are like old rock stars  they never go away. Jeff Porter

headline: No. 1 Gophers Keep Them on the Pond
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 11 — The pull that the University of Minnesota men’s hockey program exerts on many of the state’s top high school players is such that after Erik Johnson and Kyle Okposo were selected first and seventh in the N.H.L. draft in June, both chose to delay their pro careers in favor of playing for the Gophers.

headline: Make Them Fight All of Us
text: I’ve heard the president’s surge speech, and I have a reaction, an observation and some advice.

headline: A 2-Month Debate on Iraq, Capped by ‘the Big Push’
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — Even before the November elections, President Bush and his national security adviser, Stephen J. Hadley, were informally discussing what Mr. Hadley was calling “the big push” — whether it made sense to make a show of increased American force in Baghdad to take back the city.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the media company E.W. Scripps, and the possible sale of some of its newspapers, misattributed a quotation explaining the reason for the strategy. It was the chief financial officer Joseph G. NeCastro — not the chief executive Kenneth W. Lowe — who said: “Clearly the most advantageous route is to separate the newspaper business in some fashion.”

headline: The Westin St. Maarten Dawn Beach Residences and the Star Tower
text: The Westin St. Maarten Dawn Beach Residences

headline: Shiite Radicalism Could Fuel Wider Violence, Official Warns
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The nation’s top intelligence official said Thursday that the spiraling violence in Iraq, along with Iran’s ascendancy in the Middle East, had led to a rebirth of Shiite Islamic radicalism that could fuel sectarian violence and destabilize nations across the region.

headline: Meditation Retreats Calm Those Jangled Nerves
text: FINDING calm and clarity is a tall order for frenzied urbanites, but there’s help — in the form of guidance, serenity and natural beauty — at meditation retreats. Buddhist, yogic or eclectic, most provide anxious beginning meditators with instruction and practice. Several are scheduled around the country in the next few weeks.

headline: In the Company of Eakins
text: PHILADELPHIA — In art, as in love, you don’t always know what you’ve got until it has one foot out the door. Thomas Eakins’s “Gross Clinic,” as great as any American painting of the 19th century, was about to leave Philadelphia but will now stay in the city that has always been home to it.

headline: Friends, Romans, Countrymen, Lovers, Haters, Murderers, Barbarians ...
text: On the season premiere of HBO’s “Rome,” decline, fall and foul-smelling Visigoths seem just around the corner. It’s true that the upheaval that followed Caesar’s assassination in 44 B.C. made life bleak and oppressive, but it was centuries before the empire turned really rotten to its core.

headline: Tears Are Shed at the White House for a Marine’s Bravery in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — In April 2004, Cpl. Jason L. Dunham, an ordinary recruit from a small town in upstate New York, did something extraordinary: he threw himself on a grenade to shield two men in his unit as they battled insurgents on a road in Iraq.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,005 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Bush Speaks and Base Is Subdued
text: FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 11 — President Bush came to this Georgia military base looking for a friendly audience to sell his new Iraq strategy. But his lunchtime talk received a restrained response from soldiers who clapped politely but showed little of the wild enthusiasm that they ordinarily shower on the commander in chief.

headline: Like Them or Loathe Them, Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
text: SOMETIMES it feels as if there is a red state-blue state divide when it comes to hedge funds.

headline: Nice Night for a Norse Shout-Along (Bring Devil Horns)
text: They came to the B. B. King Blues Club & Grill on Wednesday night: two groups of traveling musicians, one from Sweden and one from Norway, both playing traditional Scandinavian music for an audience of connoisseurs. Religious sagas were retold, ancient Norse runes were evoked, festive costumes were worn. Who says Americans don’t appreciate world music?

headline: AT&T Prepares to ‘De-Brand’ the Cingular Wireless Name
text: One of the biggest “de-brandings” in advertising history is to begin Monday when AT&T, now the sole owner of Cingular Wireless, starts changing all Cingular marketing to adopt the AT&T name.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Connections column on Monday, about music in the films of Alfred Hitchcock, misspelled the surname of a composer who worked with him. He was Miklos Rozsa, not Rosza.

headline: Risk-Assessment Plan Is Withdrawn
text: The Bush administration yesterday withdrew a proposal to change the way federal agencies assess environmental hazards, health threats and other risks, after an expert panel declared that it was so scientifically flawed that it “could not be rescued.”

headline: Pork, Peanut Butter and Security
text: Making his umpteenth pitch to Congress to provide more security money for New York City, Mayor Michael Bloomberg stated the obvious when he said that money to defend against terrorism should be divvied up based on an assessment of risks, not “spread across the country like peanut butter.” After all, his testimony to the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee echoed one of the key recommendations of the 9/11 Commission. The mayor estimated that more than $3 billion had been distributed in this lunatic way to date.

headline: Giving Up a Republican Future to Work for a Democrat
text: MICHAEL A. L. BALBONI, the man who might have been New York’s next Republican governor, or maybe Republican attorney general, is instead the man who gave up his Senate seat and any dibs on being a Republican candidate for statewide office, to run the homeland security team for Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a Democrat he barely knows. They are strange bedfellows, but they both say the politics involved are nonpartisan.

headline: The Physical Pain of Spinal Disease Eclipses Poverty’s Mental Anguish
text: The dozen or so old cookie jars, all that remain of a collection, glisten on the living room shelves, each alive in its bright details: the fiery red of Lucille Ball’s hair, Howdy Doody’s ruddy cheeks.

headline: Texas: Two Parades for King Day
text: A federal judge in Houston has ruled that two competing organizations must both be allowed to hold parades on Monday in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A lawsuit filed by the Black Heritage Society challenged a city ordinance that allows only one parade per day downtown, alleging infringements on freedom of expression. The city revised the ordinance in 2005, in part to deal with a continuing dispute between the society and the M.L.K. Grande Parade group, which had been given the parade permit. The city said it would review the ordinance before to returning to court in March in an effort to resolve the issue.

headline: Forstmann Is Leader of the Pack at IMG
text: The financier Teddy Forstmann beckoned one of his public-relations executives to hold up a recent issue of Global People, a magazine published by People’s Daily, the Chinese Communist Party’s leading official newspaper.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend last Friday about Complexions Contemporary Ballet, which is at the Joyce Theater this week, misstated the date its engagement ends. It is Sunday; it did not end yesterday.

headline: Executive Who Stirred Up Volkswagen Will Step Down
text: FRANKFURT, Jan. 11 — Wolfgang Bernhard, the hard-charging executive who pared costs at Volkswagen but ruffled the feathers of its labor unions and chairman, will leave the company as part of a broad shake-up of its managing board, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Defense Chief Warns Against Failure in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told senators today that Iraqi government officials seem committed, finally, to meeting their obligations to secure their own country, and that an American failure there would be a setback of historic proportions.

headline: Murder Trial Paints Portrait of a Family Torn by Strife
text: Wearing a black velvet coat and a patterned blouse, the 86-year-old mother of the dead woman looked birdlike and frail as she walked to the witness stand.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit filed by a pension fund over the proposed merger between Caremark RX and CVS misstated the amount of exit pay that Caremark’s chief executive, Edwin M. Crawford, would receive if a rival bid was accepted. If Express Scripts succeeds in its rival bid, Mr. Crawford would receive $57.6 million to $62.4 million, not an estimated $48 million.

headline: Bush’s Plan for Iraq Runs Into Opposition
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 President Bush’s call to increase the American military commitment in Iraq ran into intense Congressional opposition Thursday from Democrats and from moderate Republicans who expressed profound skepticism.

headline: New Strategy Vindicates Ex-Army Chief Shinseki
