text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — After President Bush told the nation on Wednesday night that he was ordering a rapid increase of American forces in Iraq, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki was not among the retired officers to offer instant analysis on television.

headline: Correction: Strange Love
text: A picture credit with an article last Friday about visits to Atomic Age sites misstated the photographer’s given name. He is Jeff Topping, not Jess.

headline: Doctors Stay Optimistic on Barbaro
text: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 11  A day after it was announced that Barbaro had had a setback in his recovery from the painful hoof disease laminitis, his condition remained largely unchanged Thursday, but his surgeon was cautiously optimistic.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about possible campaign headquarters for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misidentified one of the places she has considered home. It is Washington, D.C., not Washington State.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Athens Is Attacked
text: ATHENS, Jan. 12 — An antitank grenade was fired into the heavily fortified American Embassy here just before dawn today. The building was empty, but the attack underscored deep anti-American sentiment here and revived fears of a new round of homegrown terror.

headline: Manhattan: 2 Stabbed Outside School
text: Two teenage boys were stabbed yesterday outside Landmark High School and the Coalition School for Social Change, which share a building on West 58th Street, the police said. They were attacked by a group of 11 other teenagers, the police said. The victims, both 16, were not identified. One was stabbed in the thigh, the other in the lower back, the police said, but both were in stable condition yesterday at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital. The stabbings apparently followed a dispute on Wednesday between two girls who attend school there, the police said.

headline: Concerns of Dashed Hopes From Promised Miracles
text: It was a day of promised miracles in the House of Representatives. Almost every other lawmaker who spoke during the debate on the stem cell bill told of a close relative with a deadly affliction whose cure depended on generating new human embryonic stem cell lines.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about the popularity of penguin characters among marketers, misidentifed the agency that created a holiday commercial for Coca-Cola, based on information supplied by Coca-Cola. The agency was Berlin Cameron United, which previously worked for the company — not Wieden & Kennedy, the current agency. The article also misspelled the surname of a founder of Club Penguin, a Web site for children. He is Dave Krysko, not Krisko.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Scalpel and Palette
text: These are the places visited by Michael Kimmelman on his Eakins tour. Except St. Charles Borromeo Seminary, they are all in Philadelphia.

headline: Explosion Hits U.S. Embassy in Athens
text: ATHENS, Friday, Jan. 12 — A powerful explosion, reportedly caused by a rocket, rocked the American Embassy in Athens Friday morning.

headline: Winter? What Winter?
text: THE final New Hope & Ivyland Railroad steam locomotive of the day had just lurched out of New Hope, Pa., station last Sunday afternoon, leaving Ed Hoy hunched at his desk in the ticket office to crunch the numbers from an unusually warm and profitable weekend.

headline: After a Struggle to Escape Comes an Effort to Adjust
text: “God Grew Tired of Us,” a sober, uplifting documentary that follows the resettlement in the United States of three young men uprooted as children by the civil war in Sudan, is the softer, Hollywood-sanctioned version of an earlier documentary, “The Lost Boys of Sudan.” A National Geographic production, directed by Christopher Quinn and narrated by Nicole Kidman in her loftiest A-student elocution, “God” won both the Grand Jury Prize and the Audience Award at the 2006 Sundance Film Festival. How could it not? Handsomely photographed and inspirational, but not cloyingly so, it is the rare contemporary documentary that doesn’t leave a residue of cynicism and outrage.

headline: Theater Listings
text: TWAINATHON Samuel Langhorne Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, made a famous declaration after his obituary was published in 1897. “The report of my death was an exaggeration,” Twain said, and he went right on living for nearly 13 years.

headline: Bonds Is One Problem Baseball Can’t Escape
text: Barry, Barry, Barry. There you go again. This time it isn’t flaxseed oil but amphetamines. You can’t get yourself suspended for using flaxseed oil; you can get people laughing at you for saying that’s what you thought you used, but suspended, no. Greenies, however, will get you suspended if you test positive a second time.

headline: For Police Involved in Fatal Shooting, Talking May Be Risky
text: The decision by four of the five police officers involved in the killing of an unarmed Queens man to voluntarily speak to prosecutors, giving investigators their version of events for the first time, poses certain risks for both sides, lawyers and legal experts say.

headline: A Psychedelic Boat Trip Down a Sea of Ambiguity
text: “Fluke,” which ran at Performance Space 122 in April, reopened yesterday and continues through Jan. 28 at Collapsable Hole, 146 Metropolitan Avenue, at Berry Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 388-2251. Following are excerpts from Jason Zinoman’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 29; the full text is here.

headline: High-Toned Scats and Purrs by a Low-Profile Jazz Singer
text: The jazz singer Nancy King has a fairly deep voice, a comfortable, well-worn purr. But during every song she sang in her late set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, whether she was improvising while singing lyrics or scatting, she jumped an octave.

headline: Seven Hours in a Swirl of Jazz With a French Accent
text: The NYC Winter Jazzfest, now in its third year, carries off a small thing on a large scale. A profusion of small things, actually: well over a dozen separate acts in 40-minute sets, spread out over all three stages of the Knitting Factory. In essence the event conspires to produce the sensation, not common enough in New York jazz circles, of plunging into an enveloping atmosphere. All it asks of its patrons is a dash of curiosity, a dose of patience and the will to trudge repeatedly up and down several flights of stairs.

headline: Rock/Pop Listings
text: POP

headline: Mexico: Troops to Acapulco
text: President Felipe Calderón continued a crackdown on drug cartels and sent more than 1,000 soldiers into the Pacific resort town of Acapulco and other areas of Guerrero State. The deployments follow similar operations in the states of Michoacán and Baja California involving 10,000 troops and agents since Mr. Calderón took office in December.

headline: Russia: Arrest in Killing of Central Banker
text: The General Prosecutor’s Office announced the arrest of what it called the organizer of the killing of Andrei A. Kozlov, the first deputy chairman of Russia’s central bank, in September. The office declined to identify the suspect, but the man’s lawyer told Russian news agencies that he was Andrei Y. Frenkel, the director of two banks that Mr. Kozlov shut down last year over accusations of money laundering and other irregularities. Mr. Kozlov’s killing, which came a month before the killing of the journalist Anna Politkovskaya, raised alarms about the safety of prominent reformers. Arrests have been rare in contract-style murders.

headline: 3,000 Tests for Amphetamines, but Only Bonds Is in the Spotlight
text: The statement was not a direct admission of guilt. But the 64 words attached to Barry Bonds’s name last night will probably be viewed as an acknowledgment by the embattled 42-year-old outfielder that he indeed tested positive for amphetamines at some point in 2006, thus raising questions about his status for 2007.

headline: Ex-Investigator for H.P. Is Expected to Plead Guilty
text: A former Hewlett-Packard private investigator is expected to plead guilty today to federal charges that he posed as a reporter to get phone records for the company’s internal investigation of boardroom leaks.

headline: Bristol Finds Alliances, and Perhaps a Suitor
text: THE drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb brings to mind that vacant colonial for sale down the street. In real estate parlance, both are expensive and might seem to need too much tender loving care.

headline: Correction: A Revised Edition
text: A picture caption with an article last Friday about the writer Maya Angelou’s part-time home in New York misstated the number of its rooms. It has 12 rooms  not 18, which is the number of rooms in her home in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline: Where Covering a Wedding Can Bring Death Threats
text: The north of Mexico is under siege. Gang wars for control of the drug market and cocaine routes to the United States took at least 2,000 lives in Mexico last year, most of them in border states. Serious journalism is also a victim.

headline: Mexico: Vatican Punishment Asked for Priest
text: The leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in Mexico have asked the Vatican to defrock the Rev. Nicolás Aguilar, a priest with a long history of sex-abuse allegations who has evaded prosecution for nearly two decades. Cardinal Norberto Rivera, the archbishop of Mexico, along with two other high-ranking bishops, sent the request in late December to a special ecclesiastical committee in the Vatican charged with investigating sexual abuse by priests. The decision came after new reports about Father Aguilar’s case. Although wanted in Los Angeles since 1989 on 19 counts of sexually molesting children, he continued to work as a priest in Mexico. He has been accused of similar crimes in Mexico in the 1990s, including the brutal rape of an alter boy in 1994.

headline: Britain Signals Plans to Reduce, Not Increase, Troop Levels in Iraq
text: LONDON, Jan. 11 — Britain, which had been America’s closest and most pliant ally in Iraq, said Thursday that it would not follow the United States in raising troop levels there and signaled that it would proceed with plans to hand over security responsibilities to Iraqi forces in the south.

headline: In Texas, Monarchs Flutter and Admirals Alight
text: MEXICAN blue wing butterflies defy stereotype. They prefer shade to sunlight. They are dark, not bright. They seek tree bark, rather than blooms. And they are one of the reasons Mel and Maris Midgley traveled from Gloucestershire, England, to southern Texas and the Lower Rio Grande Valley.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: She Solves the Crime but Remains a Mystery
text: When it comes to the writing and reading of mystery series, certain rules of the road apply. Each novel features a stellar main character, possibly with a cast of devoted sidekicks. These books are cranked out at regular intervals. They’re also read in sequence by readers who are as compulsive as the authors, so that it is unthinkable to pick up a current title without wading through the earlier ones. Unthinkable, that is, unless an established but not yet mainstream writer like Carol O’Connell blows this whole orderly process out of the water.

headline: Coughlin Fires His Defensive Coordinator
text: Part of the deal that allowed Giants Coach Tom Coughlin to keep his job was the promise to the team’s owners that he would make changes. The status quo, following an 8-8 record and a first-round playoff exit, was not good enough.

headline: Hire by the Contract Now, Risk a Big Regret Later
text: The new heads of Exxon Mobil, PepsiCo and Pfizer don’t have one. Nor do the chief executives at Citigroup, General Electric and Procter & Gamble. And some corporate governance experts say shareholders are better off as a result.

headline: Golden State Gamble
text: A few days ago. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger unveiled an ambitious plan to bring universal health insurance to California. And I’m of two minds about it.

headline: Prosecutor Asks State to Take Over Duke Case
text: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 12 — The district attorney has asked the state attorney general to take over prosecution of the sexual offense and kidnapping case against three Duke University lacrosse players, an official involved in the case said today.

headline: Stepping Up the War: Will the Bush Plan Work? (13 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Greenwich: Concession Dispute Over
text: The operators of the coffee concession at the Old Greenwich train station have reached an agreement with town officials in which they will vacate that stand in exchange for an assurance that the town would try to help them keep their other stand at the Riverside station, officials said yesterday. The operators, Greg and Mary Maher, a married couple who have had the Old Greenwich stand for some years, were told in December that they had to leave after Adam Fairbanks, a 23-year-old Greenwich man who is blind, invoked laws giving the blind preference at running government-owned concessions.

headline: New U.N. Chief Steps Gingerly Into the City
text: Nobody mentioned parking tickets.

headline: In Obliging Waco, Dr Pepper Is the King
text: YOU step off the plane, rent a car and notice a gun club off the side of the airport access road. Fifteen minutes later, with a stranger’s shotgun in your hand, you’re merrily blasting away at clay pigeons across a poplar-lined field within site of the control tower. Welcome to the Wild West as it’s lived in the old cowboy town of Waco, Tex. — hospitable, liberating and as broad as the dry, grassy plains around town.

headline: All About Ego, Showbiz and a Little Black Dress
text: Blondes don’t come any more toxic than Clea, the weapon of mass destruction accessorized with “it” bag and alpine heels who lays waste to a seemingly solid marriage in “The Scene,” Theresa Rebeck’s sharp-witted, sharp-elbowed comedy about the savage economies of sex and show business in contemporary Manhattan.

headline: Democrats in Senate Fail to Block Bill on Ethics
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — After campaigning for months on a promise to tighten ethics rules, Senate Democratic leaders tried unsuccessfully Thursday to block a measure that would shine a light on the shadowy practice of earmarking federal money for lawmakers’ pet projects.

headline: Police Dog Is Seriously Injured During Pursuit
text: After the life, or at least the career, of one of New York’s finest was imperiled in the line of duty yesterday, police officials and reporters gathered inside a Manhattan hospital, awaiting news from doctors.

headline: Britain: Jury Selection in Failed 2005 Bomb Plot
text: Jury selection began in the trial of six men accused of conspiring to murder in the attempted bombings in London on July 21, 2005, when explosives failed to detonate. The trial is expected to open with prosecution evidence next week. The accused men are Ibrahim Muktar Said, Ramzi Mohamed, Yassin Hassan Omar, Hussain Osman, Manfo Asiedu and Adel Yahya.

headline: Rangers, Listless Then Resilient, Fall Short
text: The comeback sprang from almost nothing last night; there was no outward sign that the Rangers had hit rock bottom and were plotting their way back into a game that seemed disastrous.

headline: Stem Cell Bill Sails Through the House
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to broaden federal support for embryonic stem cell research, stepping up a confrontation with President Bush over a thorny scientific and ethical issue that Democrats hope to capitalize on in the next election.

headline: Manhattan: Prostitution Sentence
text: The operator of an escort service in TriBeCa was sentenced to a year and a half to three years in prison yesterday for money laundering and attempted promotion of prostitution. Judge Daniel P. FitzGerald sentenced the operator, Jason Itzler, 39, under the terms of a plea agreement. “I’ve grown up, I’ve matured, I’ve learned a lot,” Mr. Itzler, who once proclaimed himself to be “King of all Pimps” in an interview with New York magazine, told the court. “I will never run an escort agency again.”

headline: Spitzer Names 11 to Top Posts; Some Key Spots Remain Open
text: ALBANY, Jan. 11  Gov. Eliot Spitzer named 11 members of his administration Thursday, including veterans of the Clinton White House, members of policy research groups, and two of the Democrats who ran unsuccessfully last year to succeed him as the New York State attorney general.

headline: Rise in Child Abuse Reports Has Family Court Reeling
text: The surge in child abuse and neglect reports in the year since Nixzmary Brown was killed has overwhelmed judges and lawyers in New York City Family Court, government officials and lawyers for children testified at a City Council hearing yesterday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: The South Rises in the Northeast
text: THE SOUTH RISES

headline: Devastating Criticism on Iraq by Both Parties
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  From the very first remarks, the tone was set: courteous, serious  and devastating.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about separatist rebel attacks in the northeast Indian state of Assam misstated its precise location. Assam borders several other Indian states and the kingdom of Bhutan; it does not border Myanmar. (Go to Article)

headline: Bombers Strike, and America Is in Turmoil. It’s Just Another Day for Jack Bauer.
text: It’s morning again on “24,” and Day 6 is looking bleak. Among other things, teams of suicide bombers are blowing up buses and subway cars all across the United States.

headline: A Soccer Star Heeds Lure of Hollywood
text: David Beckham has never been simply a sports star. He is a brand, and one who briefly lived at the spot where fashion, celebrity and soccer met. The soccer component of that equation has eroded, but his star power still reverberates worldwide, so much that Major League Soccer has lured Beckham to Los Angeles.

headline: Duke Accuser Contradicts Herself
text: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 11 — In an interview last month with a district attorney’s investigator, the woman who has accused three Duke lacrosse players of sexual assault contradicted critical evidence and parts of her earlier accounts, dealing a new blow to a faltering case.

headline: Newark: Transit Director Leaving
text: George D. Warrington, executive director of New Jersey Transit, said yesterday that he would step down at the end of March to “pursue other opportunities.” Mr. Warrington has spent more than three decades in transportation and started at New Jersey Transit when it was formed in 1979. After working his way up to manager in charge of rail operations, he took jobs at the New Jersey Department of Transportation and later Amtrak, where he became president in 1998 and oversaw the introduction of the Acela Express. Mr. Warrington returned to New Jersey Transit in 2002. Under his tenure, ridership reached record highs and multilevel trains were introduced. Gov. Jon S. Corzine will appoint his successor.

headline: In Surprise Move, British Bank Lifts Rate
text: LONDON, Jan. 11  The Bank of England surprised investors on Thursday and raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent, to head off rising inflation amid a boom in the housing market and strong economic growth.

headline: In Pennsylvania, President’s Plan Draws Mixed Responses and Hardens Opinions
text: CLIFTON HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 11 — Hunched over a beer with a crowd of other veterans at the American Legion here Thursday, Rocco Polidoro was sure of one thing: President Bush’s plan to send some 20,000 more troops to Iraq would only make matters worse.

headline: Bush’s Iraq Plan, Between the Lines
text: PRESIDENT BUSH has presented a new strategy for the war in Iraq that he feels can reverse the country’s drift toward large-scale civil war. The new plan focuses on stabilizing Baghdad by adding thousands of American troops with newly expanded powers to take on Shiite as well as Sunni rebels. It also includes a limited increase in United States forces in Anbar Province, and calls for Iraqi forces to take formal control of the security mission in November. The president was refreshingly candid, saying that “where mistakes have been made, the responsibility rests with me.”

headline: Second Man Sentenced in Killing of Reporter
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The second of two men convicted in the killing of a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced to 65 years in prison today.

headline: Klein Says Privatizing Not Planned for Schools
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein flatly denied yesterday that he would hire private managers to run city schools, but he did not rule out a wide role for outside groups in advising and supporting networks of schools.

headline: Maureen Orcutt, 99, Golf Champion, Dies
text: Maureen Orcutt, one of the nation’s outstanding golfers for almost a half-century and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, died Tuesday in Durham, N.C. She was 99.

headline: Florida: Chemical Substance Found on Envelopes
text: The outside of two envelopes delivered to the Palm Beach County Courthouse held a white powdery substance that tested positive for tellurium, a chemical hazardous to the liver and central nervous system, the authorities said. The chemical did not pose a threat because it was not airborne, but five people who came in contact with the envelopes were decontaminated, said Teri Barbera, a spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County Sheriff’s Office, which was investigating the origin of the substance.

headline: Newark: Man Guilty in Fatal Crash
text: An Old Bridge man was convicted of vehicular homicide and manslaughter in State Superior Court yesterday for a 2004 crash in Newark that killed two sisters, said Christopher Iu, an Essex County assistant prosecutor. The man, Kevin McGrath, 43, hit the sisters, Venessa Pereira, 19, and Maressa Farias, 13, both of Newark, as they walked into the street. Mr. McGrath, who was driving 50 miles per hour in a 25 m.p.h. zone, told investigators that he had fallen asleep behind the wheel.

headline: An Updraft for the Airlines
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — A good mood can be infectious, and W. Douglas Parker, chief executive of US Airways, with a sunny disposition and a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta Air Lines, has helped make the airline industry feel better about itself again.

headline: Military Eases Its Rules for Mobilizing Reserves
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Pentagon announced steps Thursday to make more reservists available for duty in Iraq and Afghanistan by changing the policies that govern how often members of the Army National Guard and Reserve can be mobilized.

headline: Wal-Mart Chooses New Ad Agencies
text: For the third time in less than three months, Wal-Mart Stores has made major decisions affecting the advertising agencies that handle its giant marketing assignments.

headline: Mets Say Mota Saga Is a Thing of the Past
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Jan. 11 — An assortment of Mets players and front-office officials were on hand Thursday in the Dominican Republic, as the organization presented a $25,000 donation to Esperanza International, which assists families in starting small businesses.

headline: Sensitivity and a Surprise for ‘La Traviata’ at the Met
text: What might have been just a routine revival of Franco Zeffirelli’s extravagant 1998 production of Verdi’s “Traviata” turned out to be an affecting performance thanks to the inspired work of two South Korean-born artists and a stalwart American baritone who saved the day.

headline: New York City Property Values Jump 19 Percent
text: Defying fears of a cooling real estate market, the total value of all New York City property jumped 19 percent, to $802.4 billion this year from $674.1 billion last year, officials announced today. The increases were greatest in Brooklyn and the Bronx and among apartment buildings and commercial properties.

headline: Massachusetts Rescinds Deal on Policing Immigration
text: BOSTON, Jan. 11  Gov. Deval L. Patrick said Thursday that as expected, he had rescinded a new agreement between Massachusetts and federal officials that empowered the state police to arrest illegal immigrants on charges of violating immigration law.

headline: Carter Center Advisers Quit to Protest Book
text: ATLANTA, Jan. 11  Fourteen of the city’s business and civic leaders resigned from the Carter Center’s advisory board on Thursday to protest former President Jimmy Carter’s recent criticisms of Israel and American Jewish political power.

headline: Inquiry Planned in Poland Over Secret Police Ties
text: PARIS, Jan. 12 —The church leadership of Poland called today for all the country’s bishops to be investigated for past ties to the secret police.

headline: Harvard Outlines Plans to Expand Campus Across the Charles River
text: BOSTON, Jan. 11  Harvard University released details on Thursday of a multibillion-dollar plan to expand from Cambridge across the Charles River to the Allston neighborhood of Boston. The university wants to transform more than 200 acres into a second, more modern, Harvard Square, with retail space, academic buildings, athletic and cultural facilities and student housing.

headline: Radical Reads
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Totals
Revisiting Issue, U.N. Chief Clarifies Death-Penalty Stance
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 11  Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, sought Thursday to change the impression he left in his first public utterance as United Nations head last week about his position on the death penalty.

headline: Times Co. to Cut Jobs in New England
text: The New York Times Company is offering a voluntary buyout plan to newsroom and business-office employees in its New England Media Group as part of an effort to cut 125 jobs at The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, according to memorandums sent yesterday by the head of the group and the editor of The Globe.

headline: In an Unforgiving Kingdom, the Tyranny of the Strong
text: Go on, rouse yourself to watch “The Best of Nature — 25 Years” on Sunday night. It’s the 25th anniversary of this august and spectacular series, which since 1982 has featured some of the greatest nature cinematography on earth. You can make time for a highlight reel.

headline: Tales of the Urban Jungle and a Forest Full of Music
text: Is it blasphemous to suggest that in the world of urbane American child rearing there simply seems to be too much love between parents and teenagers? Too much trading of Ugg boots and playlists, too much consensus on Bob Dylan, David Sedaris and gnocchi? When precisely did the taste for rebellion expire?

headline: Steve Jobs Walks the Tightrope Again
text: Apple’s new iPhone appears to be the clearest statement yet of what Steven P. Jobs’s impact has been in the world of consumer electronics.

headline: A Setback for Prosecutors in the ‘Enron of Kansas’ Case
text: It was called the Enron of Kansas.

headline: Art in Review
text: ROBERT IRWIN Who’s Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue3 PaceWildenstein 545 West 22nd Street, Chelsea  Through Feb. 3

headline: After Adjustment, the Ravens’ Offense Makes Up Ground
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md., Jan. 11 — It was the price to be paid last season for leaving the house.

headline: In Downtown New Orleans, Thousands March Against Killings
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11  Thousands of residents here, mostly whites, marched through downtown on Thursday in a show of anger over recent killings and local officials’ ineffective response.

headline: Fun With Studio Crafts: When the Traditional Gets Quirky
text: Who but the California funk ceramicist Robert Arneson (1930-92) could turn the mother of the 16th-century painter and printmaker Albrecht Dürer from a figure of pathos into a witty incarnation of worldly wisdom? His satirical take on the dour 1514 drawing by Dürer is but one of the quirky, provocative, funny and sometimes gorgeous things to be found in “One of a Kind: The Studio Craft Movement,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: The $250,000 Question
text: WHAT kind of second home can you get these days for $250,000? It depends on where you’re looking.

headline: Belarus Learns That Days of Wine and Roses Are Over
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 11 — President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus appeared to be the last leader in the old Soviet neighborhood to realize that he was dealing with a different Russia.

headline: Head of MTV Networks Leaving
text: In another management change at Viacom, Michael Wolf, the president and chief operating officer of MTV Networks, is leaving the company.

headline: NATO Says Afghan Clash May Have Killed Scores of Rebels
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 11  Afghan and NATO troops clashed with a large group of insurgents crossing from Pakistan into eastern Afghanistan in the early morning hours on Thursday. NATO said up to 150 insurgents might have been killed in the fighting.

headline: New Jersey Says Clerics Aren’t Required to Unite Gay Couples
text: Allaying the fears of some clergy members, the New Jersey attorney general announced yesterday that the state would not require clerics to unite same-sex couples in civil unions.

headline: Grooming a Weatherman for His TV Debut, and Hoping He Doesn’t Bite the Host
text: Chuck the groundhog waddled out of his open carrier and onto the desk in the tiny reception office in the Staten Island Zoo. He walked onto the phone and stepped on a few buttons. A house line rang. “Thank you for calling the Staten Island Zoo,” the female voice said on the speaker. “You have reached the director’s office.”

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Going Commercial
text: WHO Jason Goldwater, 35, of Las Vegas, an associate creative director at an advertising agency and a co-owner of a waxing salon, shown with his wife, Bree Goldwater, 34, also a co-owner of the salon

headline: Revamping of EMI Begins With Management Shake-Up
text: In an unexpected shake-up, the British music giant EMI Group has fired its chief of recorded music, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company, according to executives briefed on the plan.

headline: Coping With Grief, and the Causes of a Fatal Crash
text: FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 11  Patrick Cornell had already been to the morgue. A few minutes later, he planned to visit the scene of the fiery collision that claimed the life of his mother, Ruth A. MacArthur, and three students from Freehold Borough High School.

headline: Somalia’s Clashes Move to Doorstep of New Rulers
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 12 — More violence exploded in Somalia’s capital today, and this time it was right at the doorstep of the newly-installed government.

headline: Wake Up Your Computer
text: With great computing power comes great responsibility. Unsecured computers hurt their owners by exposing them to identity theft and stolen passwords. But they can also be conscripted as foot soldiers in a destructive online army: At best, it inconveniences all users by spewing noisome spam. At worst, it generates large-scale attacks on the Web sites of companies and even governments that can shut down networks at enormous cost.

headline: In Traffic’s Jam, Who’s Driving May Be Surprising
text: It’s a common enough thought among city drivers inching through traffic: Everyone around me came from the suburbs, making my life miserable. But it’s wrong, because more than half the drivers who crowd into Manhattan each workday come from the five boroughs.

headline: Who Needs Objects? Rev Up the Flashing Sign, and Run the Video
text: In an object-craving moment in American art — has there ever really not been one? — it’s good to see SculptureCenter go a little way in the other direction. Its winter lineup of nine installations includes video, sound, a zine, two light shows and a mural. It may be worth noting that the most object-intensive work is also the least interesting.

headline: Albany: Brodsky Makes Ethics Pledge
text: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky told lawmakers yesterday that if he was chosen as the next state comptroller, he would issue an order prohibiting people and businesses who do business with the state pension fund from making political contributions to candidates for comptroller. Mr. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, is one of several assemblymen vying to succeed Alan G. Hevesi, who resigned last month. Mr. Hevesi and other past comptrollers took large donations from people and businesses who earned big fees from the pension funds. Another candidate, Assemblyman Joseph D. Morelle, resigned as chairman of the Monroe County Democratic Committee to focus on the race, which will be decided by the Legislature after a panel screens the applicants.

headline: American Soccer Takes a Bold Gamble on a Boldface Name
text: It was the night of Aug. 12 that Dave Checketts was enlightened to the magnetic appeal of Posh Spice’s significant other. David Beckham entered a game in Salt Lake City for Real Madrid and, as Checketts recalled, “Thousands of flashbulbs went off.”

headline: Senator Dodd of Connecticut Announces Bid for Presidency
text: HARTFORD, Jan. 11 — As he formally announced his candidacy for president on Thursday, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut said he saw himself as the “dark horse” in the expanding Democratic field, an “unknown quantity with experience.”

headline: Neo-Splendor in American Wing
text: NEO-SPLENDOR

headline: In Bangladesh, State of Emergency and Election Delay
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 11 — The president of Bangladesh declared a state of emergency on Thursday evening, suspending certain fundamental rights, imposing a nighttime curfew, and effectively postponing elections that were scheduled to be held in less than two weeks. He then resigned as the chief of the caretaker government entrusted to run the vote.

headline: Voters Who Take Chances on Politicians May Get a New Way to Test Their Luck
text: TRENTON, Jan. 11  The next time a New Jersey resident steps into a voting booth and hopes to pull the lever, think of a one-armed bandit.

headline: Just a Bunch of Kids Who Kidnap and Kill
text: “Alpha Dog” is a true-crime story inspired by a pipsqueak thug improbably named Jesse James Hollywood, who once reigned over a modern Sodom and Gomorrah in — you know it — Los Angeles.

headline: A Familiar Face Returns, Bringing Hope That Another Follows
text: The marquee atop Yankee Stadium yesterday told motorists there were 33 days until pitchers and catchers report for spring training. Reversing the calendar would show it has been 34 days since the Yankees agreed to contract terms with Andy Pettitte.

headline: Canadian Court Rules Lesbian Partner Is a Parent
text: OTTAWA, Jan. 11  Last week, a 5-year-old Ontario boy became a member of a larger family. An appeals court ruled that he has three parents: a father and two mothers.

headline: Crude Oil Falls Further, Gratifying Consumers More Than Investors
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 11 — Oil prices sank on Thursday to the lowest level in 19 months, providing potential relief to consumers. But investors in energy stocks may wish for a cold spell after they see the fourth-quarter earnings of their stocks in the next few weeks.

headline: Despite Distractions, Kidd Leads the Way in Nets’ Unlikely Victory
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 11 — Jason Kidd, 33, had played nearly 43 minutes against the Chicago Bulls and still was relentlessly pursuing Kirk Hinrich, a point guard who is seven years younger.

headline: Nets Hanging On to Their Core, for Now
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 11  The unpredictability of the Nets’ play this season may have made the job of their president, Rod Thorn, more difficult.

headline: Picassos’ Theft Contributes to Mystery of Eccentric Collector’s Art Trove
text: When the colorful Manhattan gadfly known as William M. V. Kingsland died in March, leaving an unexpected trove of important art in his Upper East Side apartment, a mystifying art world caper began to unfold.

headline: U.S. Preparing for Trials of Top Qaeda Detainees
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Bush administration has set up a secret war room in a Virginia suburb where it is assembling evidence to prosecute high-ranking detainees from Al Qaeda including the man accused of being the mastermind of the September 2001 attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, government officials said this week.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Is There an Actor In the House?

headline: Preparing for Farm Bill Cuts, or Not
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 — With a costly war in Iraq, mounting budget deficits and record-high crop prices, administration officials said this week that farmers should expect to receive smaller agricultural payments in this year’s Farm Bill.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Fatal Raid Linked to Lies for Warrant in Drug Case
text: ATLANTA, Jan. 11  A narcotics team that shot and killed an elderly woman while raiding her home lied to obtain the search warrant, one team member has told federal investigators, according to news reports confirmed by a person familiar with the investigation who requested anonymity.

headline: Costco Bias Suit Is Given Class-Action Status
text: A federal judge granted class-action status yesterday to a lawsuit filed on behalf of more than 700 female workers at Costco Wholesale claiming that the retailer had systematically discriminated against women seeking jobs as managers.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about digital technology that rotates advertiser images on highway billboards, carried incorrect estimates from the Outdoor Advertising Association of America on the number of billboards that are expected to be converted to digital in the next 10 years. It is 4,000, not 90,000.

headline: Agents Say Fast Audits Hurt I.R.S.
text: Top officials at the Internal Revenue Service are pushing agents to prematurely close audits of big companies with agreements to have them pay only a fraction of the additional taxes that could be collected, according to dozens of I.R.S. employees who say that the policy is costing the government billions of dollars a year.

headline: Suspect Arrested in Murder of Central Bank Official
text: Top stories from Russian newspapers on Friday:

headline: People
text: People

headline: In Baghdad, Bush Policy Is Met With Resentment
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 11 — Iraq’s Shiite-led government offered only a grudging endorsement on Thursday of President Bush’s proposal to deploy more than 20,000 additional troops in an effort to curb sectarian violence and regain control of Baghdad. The tepid response immediately raised questions about whether the government would make a good-faith effort to prosecute the new war plan.

headline: Blair Urges Britain to Stay Aggressive Abroad
text: LONDON, Jan. 12 — As he seeks to define his legacy and stamp his imprint on the future, Prime Minister Tony Blair urged his successors today to maintain the warlike foreign policy that he promoted, sending troops into battle in Africa and the Balkans, Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: On the Market
The Prozzos Meet Alona
text: Marino and Debbie Prozzo hosted 7-year-old Alona Malyovana over the holidays, falling head-over-heels for a Ukranian orphan they may be unable to adopt.

headline: Smooth Move
text:
At home
with Marc
Newson,
an industrial
designer
who has
always been
ahead of
the curve.

headline: Streep to Star in Film Version of ABBA Musical
text: Meryl Streep will take on the role of a mother with a rebel streak when she stars in the film version of the international hit musical “Mamma Mia!,” Reuters reported.

headline: Analysis: Bush's Iraq Plan, Between the Lines
text: Below, I’ve selected a number of important phrases from the address that beg for more detailed discussion, and included my own analysis of the validity and practicality of what the president seems to have in mind.

headline: Is There an Actor in the House?
text: Todd Weeks, who plays Hugh Voysey in the Atlantic Theater Company’s production of “The Voysey Inheritance,” left the show for a few days this week after his father died suddenly on Monday. There were no understudies; either performances would have to be canceled or someone familiar with the play would have to jump into the role.

headline: Stomping His Way to Brotherhood
text: Brotherhood is powerful. That’s the message of “Stomp the Yard,” a strange and at times strangely compelling mix of black fraternity recruitment video and inspirational tale about a hip-hop boy in a stepping world.

headline: The Human and the Animated, Shrunk to Size
text: In the latest wowzer merging of the real and the fabricated, “Arthur and the Invisibles” takes actual human actors and, through a complex process involving Slim-Fast and a Maytag dryer, shrinks them to the size of bacteria so they can interact with the microscopic beings who live in your backyard along with Rick Moranis and his family.

headline: For Many M.B.A.’s, Dream Job May Be Just That
text: What do business schoolers want these days? A job in private equity, apparently. But their dreams of high payouts may not come true, according to BusinessWeek, which reports that there are fewer private equity jobs out there than one might think. While many of the biggest funds will hire about 20 percent more M.B.A.’s this year, there are about five candidates for each job available, the magazine said. And the positions typically go to those with experience.

headline: Executive Who Stirred Up Volkswagen Will Step Down
text: Wolfgang Bernhard, the hard-charging executive who pared costs at Volkswagen but ruffled the feathers of its labor unions and chairman, will leave the company as part of a broad shake-up of its managing board, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Carter and His Critics: The Skirmishes Continue
text: As Brenda Goodman reports this morning, 14 members of the Carter Center Board of Councilors, a “leadership advisory group that serves to promote understanding of and support for The Carter Center,” the human rights organization founded by former President Jimmy Carter, resigned their posts this week in protest over views expressed by Mr. Carter in his book, “Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid.”

headline: 5th Defendant Pleads Guilty in Shelter Case
text: A former accountant pleaded guilty Thursday to one felony count of lying to federal investigators as part of a widening criminal inquiry into questionable tax shelters. The former accountant, Michael Grandinetti, entered his plea before Judge Thomas P. Griesa in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Grandinetti, 49, is expected to serve as a witness for the prosecution in a mammoth tax shelter case against 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG. Mr. Grandinetti, a resident of the Northern Mariana Islands, a United States territory in the Pacific, becomes the fifth person to plead guilty and agree to cooperate with prosecutors in the inquiry, which has also ensnared major accounting firms, banks, law firms and investment boutiques.

headline: Ex-Investigator for H.P. Is Expected to Plead Guilty
text: A former Hewlett-Packard private investigator is expected to plead guilty Friday to federal charges that he posed as a reporter to get phone records for the company’s internal investigation of boardroom leaks. The former investigator, Bryan Wagner of Littleton, Colo., will plead guilty to identification theft and conspiracy in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., said his lawyer, Stephen Naratil.

headline: French Optics Giant May But Cooper Companies
text: A French optics company, Essilor International, might acquire a United States contact lens maker, the Cooper Companies for 2.1 billion euros ($2.7 billion), brokerage Oddo Securities said in a research note this week. Essilor has been on an acquisition spree in recent years, snapping up prescription lens laboratories in North America, Europe and India.

headline: A Setback for Prosecutors in the ‘Enron of Kansas’ Case
text: After two men won their appeal to have their convictions overturned in a case referred to as the Enron of Kansas, The New York Times takes a look at the latest in a recent series of setbacks for the government in white-collar cases. In September 2005, David C. Wittig, a former star investment banker, and his lieutenant, Douglas T. Lake, were convicted of looting the company they ran, Westar Energy of Topeka, the largest electric utility in Kansas. Mr. Wittig was sentenced to 18 years in prison, and Mr. Lake, 15 years. But last Friday, a federal appeals court overturned the convictions of the two men on all 40 counts – most of which cannot be retried.

headline: A Genial C.E.O. Provides an Updraft for the Airline Industry
text: Despite robust resistance by Delta Air Lines management and employees to US Airways’ unsolicited $10.5 billion bid for the rival carrier, there may be one positive outcome everyone can agree on. A good mood can be infectious, and W. Douglas Parker, chief executive of US Airways, with a sunny disposition and a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta, has helped make the airline industry feel better about itself again, writes The New York Times’ Jeff Bailey.

headline: Sun Life Buys Genworth Unit
text: Canada’s Sun Life Financial said on Thursday it would buy Genworth Financial‘s group benefits business in the United States for $650 million. Sun Life, Canada’s third largest insurer by market value, said the acquisition would expand its business in the United States. A Morgan Stanley analyst, Ken Zerbe, said in a research note that the deal appeared to be positive for Sun Life, which had been “a sub-scale player” in the United States group insurance market and was searching for a chance to bulk up.

headline: Former Siemens C.F.O. Questioned in Corruption Scandal
text: Prosecutors looking into charges of corruption at Siemens said Thursday that they were investigating the company’s former chief financial officer, Heinz-Joachim Neubürger. Mr. Neubürger was questioned Tuesday, the Munich state prosecutor Christian Schmidt-Sommerfeld said.

headline: China Stocks Top $1 Trillion
text: China’s stocks have surpassed $1 trillion in value after indexes more than doubled last year and the government encouraged the domestic listing of state-owned companies like Industrial & Commercial Bank of China. The combined value of shares listed on the stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen rose to $1.01 trillion, making mainland China the world’s 10th biggest equity market, according to data compiled by Bloomberg News.

headline: Nasdaq Extends Bid for London Exhange
text: The Nasdaq stock market on Thursday extended by two weeks the deadline for shareholders to accept its offer to buy the London Stock Exchange after the New York bourse got a tepid response. The Nasdaq bid for the London exchange was to have ended Thursday, but it said the new deadline would be Jan. 26. The Nasdaq, which is offering 12.43 pounds ($24.22) a share for the London exchange, said it had received acceptances from investors holding 0.61 percent of the exchange’s shares outstanding.

headline: Vengence Is Mine, Saith the Executive
text: While many chief executives and other high-level managers cite challenges, passion for their industry and even money as their motivating forces, BusinessWeek takes a look at a little mentioned engine that pushes executives to perform: revenge. Examining some high-profile spats, as well as some lesser-known battles, the magazine reminds us of how sweet getting even can be.

headline: V.C. Investment in Clean Tech Up 78% in 2006
text: For clean technology start-ups, a year definitely made a difference. Venture capitalists poured $2.9 billion into clean technologies, including energy, in 2006, representing a 78 percent increase over the year before. The Cleantech Venture Network on Thursday published investment data for 2006, reflecting a surge in investment in technologies related to energy generation, storage, recycling and waste, and transportation.

headline: Goldman’s Alliance Stake May End in an I.P.O.
text: The combined television assets of CanWest Global Communications and Alliance Atlantis Communications could be spun off in a multibillion-dollar public offering four years from now under one of several scenarios set out in CanWest’s $2 billion deal with its financial partner, Goldman Sachs, to buy the business, The Globe and Mail reported. The specifics of how the private equity arm of the New York investment banker will cash out on this week’s blockbuster takeover of Alliance are not yet public, but the pact with CanWest includes a limited number of outcomes, including an I.P.O.

headline: Ritchie Capital Sells Financing Unit to BlueCrest
text: Ritchie Capital Management has sold its start-up finance business to BlueCrest Capital, a hedge fund firm partly owned by the British industry giant Man Group, MarketWatch reported. In a letter to investors cited by MarketWatch, Bluecrest said it had bought the finance vehicle, Ritchie Technology & Life Sciences, for an undisclosed price.

headline: Cinema Ad Group Aims High in I.P.O.
text: National CineMedia, the advertising network for theater chain operators, on Thursday outlined plans to offer 38 million shares at $18 to $20 apiece in a bid to raise about $722 million in its initial public offering. The planned I.P.O. raises the number of offerings set to kick off in the $500 million to $1 billion range, joining theater chain AMC Entertainment, Time Warner Cable and MetroPCS, a wireless broadband provider. The I.P.O. backlog in the United States stands at a healthy level of 104 deals expected to raise $16 billion, down from 106 deals expected to raise $17.4 billion in the year-ago period, according to Dealogic.

headline: CVC and Macquarie Said to Eye Chinese Lumber Firm
text: CVC Asia Pacific and Macquarie Bank may offer to buy the Sino-Forest Corporation, the largest foreign-owned lumber company in China, according to Bloomberg News. An acquisition of Sino-Forest, which has a market capitalization of $1 billion, would give the buyout firms control of a wood-products maker that increased sales 34 percent annually between 1994 and 2005. Shares in Sino-Forest, which is based in Toronto, are poised for the biggest weekly gain since September 2005.

headline: Why Hedge Funds Aren’t Going Away
text: Whether you’re among those who believe that hedge funds are Satan (much of the news media and the Connecticut attorney general) or savior (hedge fund employees and investors), it looks like they’re here to stay, writes The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson. The money continues to flow into hedge funds. Hedge Fund Research, a Chicago-based research firm, estimates that $110 billion flowed into new funds through November. A study released by Deutsche Bank yesterday surveyed investors who represent $900 billion of the total $1.4 trillion in the industry and predicted that $110 billion will flow into the sector in 2007.

headline: Bristol Finds Alliances, and Perhaps a Suitor
text: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb brings to mind that vacant colonial for sale down the street. In real estate parlance, both are expensive and might seem to need too much tender loving care. The company’s leaders all but announced it was for sale last September. Four months later, though, no potential suitor has emerged – at least not publicly. Instead, Bristol-Myers has entered several comparatively small deals, including one yesterday in which it announced a $1.35 billion partnership with the British company AstraZeneca to develop two diabetes compounds.

headline: Banks Answer Need for Charity Advice
text: Spurred on by Warren E. Buffett’s June announcement that he would hand most of his $40 billion fortune to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, philanthropy is increasingly attracting cash infusions from hedge fund managers, real estate moguls and technology entrepreneurs, Bloomberg News reports. And this year, Wall Street bankers and traders sharing more than $36 billion in bonuses may help drive the donations up even more.

headline: This (Naughty) Message Will Self-Destruct in 30 Seconds
text: Real life may have taken a cue from “Mission: Impossible,” albeit a little too late for those like one-time investment banking star Frank Quattrone who found themselves in hot water over undeleted e-mails. The New York Post writes of new e-mail that self-destructs in just seconds, with no traces left. The vanishing text and video are the brainchild of a small e-mail provider, BigString of Redbank, N.J., founded a year ago by a former Wall Street dot-com trader and several dot-com survivors from the late 1990’s. Data can be timed to vanish after just three readings, for example, or in just 30 seconds or as long as several weeks or more.

headline: Zebra Snaps Up WhereNet
text: Zebra Technologies said Thursday it had agreed to buy WhereNet, bolstering its position in an up-and-coming technology known as radio frequency identification. Zebra, which primarily makes printers that spit out bar code labels, will pay $126 million in cash for the privately-held WhereNet, based in Santa Clara, Calif. Analysts believe that radio frequency identification — RFID for the cognoscente — will one day supplant bar code technology in supply chain tracking.

headline: Mystery Investor Sells Off $131 Million Esprit Stake
text: An unidentified institutional shareholder last night sold 1.02 billion Hong Kong dollars ($131 million) worth of shares in Esprit Holdings, the second placement in the fashion retailer in less than four months. The sale came on a day when Esprit’s share price turned higher again after six days of mainly declines and could suggest that more shareholders are getting nervous about the current weakness in the market and are taking the opportunity to secure some profit on days of strength.

headline: After Brief Hospital Stay, Kozlowski Returns to Prison
text: The former chairman of Tyco International, Dennis Kozlowski, returned to prison Thursday after being hospitalized, according to a prison spokeswoman. Mr. Kozlowski is currently being housed in the Mid-State Correctional Facility’s infirmary in New York, after being treated for an undisclosed ailment. Mr. Kozlowksi is serving a sentence of 8-1/3 to 25 years after being found guilty in June 2005 of looting the company.

headline: Revamping of EMI Begins With Management Shake-Up
text: In an unexpected shake-up, the British music giant EMI Group has fired its chief of recorded music, Alain Levy, ahead of a broad reorganization aimed at reviving the flagging company. The sudden move, announced Friday, follows a series of setbacks at EMI, including a string of failed merger negotiations with a rival, the Warner Music Group, and the poor sales performance of the pop star Janet Jackson.

headline: Snarky Annotation Not Required
text: From a press release:

headline: Forstmann Is Leader of the Pack at IMG
text: Forstmann Little‘s Teddy Forstmann has said that IMG, the sports, fashion, entertainment and media marketer, would be one of his last big acquisitions. To sell it at the steep profit he envisions, Mr. Forstmann has overhauled the ingrained agent culture nurtured in Cleveland by its founder, Mark H. McCormack, and is running it like a profit-driven, even obsessed, property.

headline: Pulse
text: The choice of glamorous pack rats, strewing riches at your feet and more.

headline: Fearing Beheading, Gibson Ducks Mexican Premiere
text: Okay, that’s a little excessive, but it is a true known fact that Mel Gibson will attend a private screening of his movie in Mexico, but skip the public premiere.

headline: McDonald’s May Serve Up Boston Market Sale
text: After spinning off its Chipotle Mexican Grill business last year, the fast-food giant McDonald’s is considering putting its Boston Market restaurant chain up for sale, The Chicago Tribune reported. Employees of Boston Market, whose menu includes chicken dinners, were told about the potential sale Thursday, a McDonald’s spokeswoman told the Tribune.

headline: The Hill: 20 Hours Later
text: After six years with only one veto, we can now see two possible presidential vetoes on the horizon after just a week of Democratic control in Congress.

headline: Casino Pulls Up to the Table
text: Is it just the Bagger, or is it pretty darn swell that the America Cinema Editors chose “Casino Royale” and its ace, Stuart Baird, as one of the five best-edited dramatic films of 2006? In a heady group that included “The Departed,” “The Queen,” “United 93” and “Babel,” the spy snuck in. Was the blond Bond the crowning cinematic achievement of the year? Nah, but you try making making a cartoon character seem fresh and contemporary.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Looks to Shop in 2007
text: Marsh & McLennan‘s chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, will look to acquisitions to help the financial-services company grow in 2007 as it tries to recover from an aggressive investigation by the former New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer. The company is looking to go to market after completing a possible $3.9 billion sale of its Putnam Investments unit to the Power Corporation of Canada, The Telegraph reported. “Our first priority is growth as opposed to a share buy-back,” Mr Cherkasky told the paper.

headline: The Bagger Takes a Beatdown
text: Dave Poland hopped in his ’96 Huffy and delivered a fairly righteous beatdown of the Bagger for suggesting that there might be a connection between Gail Berman’s departure from Paramount and the failure of “Dreamgirls” to soar past the competition in the awards season. Watching two bloggers go at it has all the aesthetic value of watching “Freddy vs. Jason” — you wish they’d hurry up and slice each other to ribbons before falling down an elevator shaft together.

headline: El Gordo Speaks, and Then Some
text: OscarWatch has a lengthy, lucid interview/profile, by Sasha Stone, with Guillermo del Toro, director of “Pan’s Labyrinth.”

headline: Unit of Germany’s Merck Said to Attract Buyout Firms
text: The German drugmaker Merck KGaA has attracted interest in its generic drugs unit from Cinven, Permira and the Texas Pacific Group, people familiar with the matter told Reuters. Merck — no relation to the United States company of the same name — said last week it was considering selling the business, valued at more than 4 billion euros ($5.2 billion), as it retrains its focus on higher-revenue branded products. Merck declined to comment, as did Permira and Cinven, while Texas Pacific was not available to comment, Reuters said.

headline: The Question of the Hour, or At Least the Next 30 Seconds
text: “I was wondering how far the three of you would be willing to go to help very small movies — and I mean really small,” he said. “Like if somebody put the best movie you’ve ever seen on YouTube, would you put it on your Top 10 list?” — from a panel of critics at Makor in New York that included David Edelstein (New York Magazine), Owen Gleiberman (Entertainment Weekly) and Stephanie Zacharek (Salon), hosted by The Reeler.

headline: A Left-Handed Hammer?
Fact-Checking the President
text: There’s a new “truth squad” report on President Bush’s Iraq speech by www.factcheck.org, a terrific non-partisan group that regularly tries to reel people back to reality. It says that the facts that Bush included in his speech are largely accurate, but that he omitted inconvenient ones. Then it looks at Dick Durbin’s Democratic response and comes to the same conclusion. Check it out.

headline: Senator Clinton Heads to Iraq, Afghanistan
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton left last night for Iraq and Afghanistan on a four-day trip to meet with United States military commanders and troops to­ further ground herself on the war as she prepares for a likely presidential bid.

headline: This is Classified!
text: Or it was. Back in 1999, the U.S. military conducted a secret report on what a military intervention in Iraq would look like, and what should be done to minimize the risks. Documents about the effort, conducted by Centcom and called Desert Crossing, were recently declassified and can be found on line at the National Security Archive — and they make fascinating reading.

headline: Plus Ca Change
text: Bob Edgar, the head of the National Council of Churches, has written a fascinating account of another attempted “surge.”

headline: On the Road With Hillary
text: Hillary Clinton is off to Iraq and Afghanistan. The details are here.

headline: A New Campaign Against Gitmo Lawyers
text: The Bush administration appears to have decided that it’s time to kill all the lawyers — or at least time to pressure big business into refusing to pay legal fees to law firms that represent detainees at Guantanamo Bay.

headline: Dolan Family Raises Offer for Cablevision
text: Cablevision Systems‘s controlling family, the Dolans, said Friday that they had raised their offer to buy out the public shareholders of their cable television empire to $30 per share in cash, up from the $27-per-share cash offer they presented in October. In a press release, the family said their latest proposal valued Cablevision’s equity at $8.9 billion and implied a total entreprise value of $20.1 billion. The Dolans said the bid was their “best and final offer” and would expire on Jan. 17.

headline: Modern Game Consoles: Glorified Sex Machines?
text: Techsperts are deconstructing a report from a Dallas/Fort Worth television station, which held up Nintendo’s popular Wii and other gaming consoles as potential mother lodes of smut for little Johnny and Susie.

headline: Tranquil Vientiane
text: Get off the beaten tourist track with a visit to Laos's relaxed capital, which can be a tonic for those who have been hopscotching across the region.

headline: Evercore Adds Co-Head of Private Equity
text: The Investment bank Evercore Partners said Friday it had hired James Matthews as a senior managing director to co-lead its private equity business, which makes investments in midsize companies. He will oversee the group alongside the senior managing director Neeraj Mital. Mr. Matthews, previously a general partner at the private equity firm Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe, will bring expertise in the business-services and “mature technology” sectors, Evercore’s co-chief executive, Austin Beutner, said in a news release.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Politics and Friendship
text: Senator Christopher Dodd of Connecticut has long supported his home-state colleague, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. He lobbied for Mr. Liberman’s nomination as the Democratic Party’s vice presidential candidate in 2000 and, some say, stayed out of the 2004 presidential primary in deference to Mr. Lieberman, who was briefly a candidate.

headline: Equity Office Bondholders Agree to Revised Buyback
text: At least one of the Blackstone Group‘s headaches seems to have gone away. Late Thursday, dissident bondholders of Equity Office Properties Trust relented and said they would accept the company’s debt buyback, part of Blackstone’s $36 billion buyout of the trust. The bondholders, including the insurance giant American International Group, said that they would accept a revised offer by the Jan. 18 deadline, even though it fell short of their initial demands.

headline: Placing Ads Anywhere and Everywhere
text: In an attempt to break through to consumers, advertisers have started to migrate from traditional media to almost anywhere outside the home with a little blank space.

headline: Can a Garage Space Be Rent-Stabilized?
text: Q When a tenant living in a rent-stabilized apartment rents a parking space in the building’s garage, is the garage rent subject to stabilization, too?

headline: What Keeps Lloyd Blankfein Up at Night?
text: What keeps Lloyd Blankfein up at night? The trouble with being at the top of your game is that there is so much room to fall. That may be why Forbes’s profile of Goldman Sachs, like some other recent media coverage, tends to characterize the giant securities firm as beset by potential peril. Once you are on a pedestal, everyone wonders what will knock you off, and when.

headline: New Orleans Violence Boils Over
First Impressions: Fig & Olive (downtown)
text: There’s something a bit different going on here. The proprietors of this new, downtown branch of Fig & Olive, an Upper East Side café, have taken the kind of location, big-box format, hyper-segmented menu and booming lounge soundtrack usually associated with this city’s Asian mega-restaurants and wed it to Mediterranean cuisine.

headline: The War at Home: ‘Pivot Point’
text: Robert M. Gates, the new secretary of defense, and Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were in front of the Senate Armed Services Committee this morning.

headline: Northwest Files Basic Reorganization Plan
text: Northwest Airlines filed its bankruptcy reorganization plan on Friday, expecting to emerge from bankruptcy sometime in the second quarter this year. In a filing with federal bankruptcy court, the carrier said that its shares, which are currently trading over the counter, would be canceled, and its unsecured creditors will not be paid in full.

headline: Proxy Season Preview: Pay in the Crosshairs
text: Last year was a contentious one for corporate governance and shareholder proposals. What will 2007 bring? Institutional Shareholder Services, one of the main proxy advisory firms, has issued its 2007 Proxy Season Watch List, which offers some clues. One notable statistic: There are 39 shareholder proposals so far that would link executive pay more closely to a company’s performance, compared with just 17 such proposals in last year’s proxy season.

headline: Who’s to Blame?
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Jan. 11 column, “The Fog Over Iraq.”

headline: A Roof Over New Orleans’ Head
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 11 column, “Home in the Ruins.“

headline: Readers Have Say on Saban, Role of College Sports
text: Andrew Zimbalist wrote an article for The Times last Sunday in which he argued that:

headline: More on Black
text: I had mentioned a few days ago that every TV frame now seems to be glossy black.

headline: Taking a Flyer
text: Helen Mirren and Meryl Streep sat still, sort of, for EW’s big Oscar thingie. They return fire on one of the age-old H-wood questions.

headline: A Cry for Help
text: While the rest of you were sleeping the sleep of the wicked, Anne Thompson of the Hollywood Report snapped awake wondering what had happened at the BAFTA’s –that’s the British Academy of Film and Television Arts to you civilians. She pointed out that because Oscar ballots are due tomorrow, the BAFTA’s will probably have significant impact.

headline: Hit and Miss: Cars of the Detroit Auto Show
text: The media preview is over, but the North American International Auto Show opens to the public on Saturday. Here is a breakdown of the hits and misses of the sohw, as I see them. What do you think?

headline: Best and Worst of Show
text: The C.E.S. is winding down, so now it is time for the reflecting and summing up.

headline: Is ‘Little Miss Sunshine’ a Used Car?
text: Writing in the Bagger comments section, John surfs around and comes across some eerie parallels between “Little Miss Sunshine” and the shining cinematic achievement of “National Lampoon’s Family Vacation”:

headline: Radio Deal Looks Like a ‘Take-Under,’ Analyst Says
text: The Dolans, who just raised their bid to take Cablevision Systems private, may not be the only media-owning family compelled to reach deeper into their pockets. At least one stock analyst is questioning whether the Mays family and their bidding partners are offering enough cash to shareholders of Clear Channel Communications, the nation’s largest network of radio stations.

headline: Farewell to the D
text: My first Detroit auto show is behind me. If I were to give someone else advice on how to plan for the show, the first thing I would say is, don’t bring gym clothes. First of all, journalists at the show have less free time than an Industrial Revolution-era mill worker. And second, you tend to get so wrapped up in what you’re doing that you don’t even have time to eat, let alone hit the elyptical trainer. Call it the NAIAS diet.

headline: The Professor Responds
text: Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of Economics at Smith College, responds to the letters from readers (from the previous post):

headline: The Myth of the Suburban Driver
text: This article  from the front page today is a must-read for anyone who ever wondered where all those cars on the city’s streets come from. Hint: Not New Jersey.

headline: Counting the Days Bush Stays at Camp David
text: Mark Knoller, the longtime White House correspondent for CBS Radio, keeps such good records of President Bush’s travels that the White House often refers inquiries to him. But Mr. Knoller, who reports today that the president has officially spent 365 days — a full year — at Camp David, now finds himself in a little record-keeping tiff with the commander in chief.

headline: Looking for Exploited Children in All the Wrong Places?
text: Meanwhile, speaking of pornography, the always-interesting Los Angeles Times reports today that the F.B.I. has been conducting raids of adult-film studios in the steamier parts of the San Fernando Valley — on the hunt, it seems, for exploited children.

headline: Money-Money-Money-Mon-ey. Money!
text: The Spitzer administration has released salaries for the governor’s top political appointees and commissioners. Aspiring pols can find out how much government service really pays, below the jump:Titles/salaries below presume senate confirmation.Commissioner salaries are statutory.

headline: First New Hampshire Debates Set (No Kidding)
text: Enter April 4 and April 5 on your political calendar.

headline: We Win a Case!
text: I just heard that the U.S. District Court has in effect tossed out the libel case against the New York Times for articles that I wrote about the anthrax case. The case was brought by Dr. Steve Hatfill, the person that the Justice Department described as a “person of interest” in the case. In more technical terms, the judge said he would grant our motion for summary judgment, meaning that the case won’t go to trial.

headline: China Needs to Embrace Its Feminine Side
text: This came down the pike this morning, but is worth highlighting: A national report in China indicates that the country could face a rather staggering gender imbalance over the next 15 years, with as many as 30 million more men of marriageable age than women by 2020.

headline: Seduced by an Airport, and a Hotel
text: Now that my wife is done making fun of me — and all I can say in my defense about her comments posted last time is, well, ah, nothing — we return to our regularly scheduled story.

headline: Blogtalk
text: A thought for the Dr. King holiday, and background on Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a Somali-born former member of the Dutch parliament, who will be honored on Monday at the Congress for Racial Equality’s “Living the Dream” banquet. [The Daily Politics]

headline: Blogtalk: The Boxer-Rice Slugfest
text: Several blogs on the center to the right are hammering California Senator Barbara Boxer for the childless, family-less remarks she made to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Thursday. Some are demanding apologies. (Full transcript and audio excerpts of the Boxer-Rice exchange)

headline: Bird Flu Persists in Indonesia
text: Avian flu continues its spread across Indonesia. This two-part series explains one country's failure to control a disease that remains a threat to become a pandemic.

headline: Bird Flu in Indonesia - Part 2
text: A variety of factors, both cultural and economic, help explain Indonesia's failure to stamp out avian flu, which remains a threat to become a pandemic.

headline: Art World Luminaries Recall Marcia Tucker
text: Marcia Tucker, the influential curator and founder of the New Museum, was remembered yesterday at a memorial service as a woman whose insatiable curiosity and ability to ignore her fears led her to alter New York’s museum landscape and become a mentor to a generation of curators and artists.

headline: The Bride Became Debt-Free
text: IF you stopped to name some recent innovations that had enhanced your quality of life, a few things might come to mind  Netflix, leave-in hair conditioner and the proliferation of those big cheap boxes of clementines. But would any financial services top your list?

headline: NATO’s Afghan Struggle: Build, and Fight Taliban
text: SPERWAN GHAR, Afghanistan — The road that cuts through the heart of Panjwai district here tells all that is going wrong with NATO’s war in Afghanistan.

headline: In London, a Peek at New York Playgrounds Ahead
text: LONDON, Jan. 12  At some point in its long history, St. Stephen’s stopped being just another playground and, like a hospital that metamorphoses into a medical center, became St. Stephen’s Play Project.

headline: Tenants Sue Agency Over Brooklyn Project
text: Forest City Ratner Companies, the developer of the planned $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, has insisted during the long public debate over the project that it will do anything to ensure that displaced residents will not be left out in the cold.

headline: Highway Walker Struck by 2 Cars
text: A man walking along a westbound lane of the Grand Central Parkway near La Guardia Airport last night was hit by two cars and killed, the police said.

headline: A Taste of U.S. Family Life, but Adoption in Limbo
text: TERRYVILLE, Conn. — During the two weeks that Marino and Debbie Prozzo welcomed a Ukrainian orphan in their home, they fell head over heels for a 7-year-old child they may never be able to adopt.

headline: In Reversal, Senate Endorses Plan on Disclosing Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Senate Democratic leaders on Friday embraced a proposal to shed light on the murky practice of Congressional earmarks, reversing themselves after trying to block an almost identical measure the day before.

headline: Imagining, and Reimagining, the Globe
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Of all the debates about Shakespeare, it is perhaps second only to the enduring controversy over the identity of the author himself: what exactly did the Globe Theater, where many of his plays were first performed and his troupe resided, look like?

headline: An Out-of-Towner Arrives to Show She’s Kept the Faith
text: In American cities outside New York, modern dance thrives by the grit of individuals like Jean Isaacs, who has lived in San Diego since 1970 and has devoted much of her life to spreading its faith. So her choreographic output, judging from a performance by her San Diego Dance Theater at Danspace Project on Thursday, is fairly traditional, with few surprises in her highly structured, emotionally wrought dances.

headline: For Human Eyes Only
text: LeIpzig, Germany

headline: Sounds to Accompany an Outdoors of the Imagination
text: The Kitchen was where the wild things were on Thursday night. Eighth Blackbird, the new music sextet based in Chicago, offered an aural feast for the imagination with works from “Strange Imaginary Animals,” their new disc on the Cedille label.

headline: Bruno Bought Stock With Campaign Funds
text: Over the past six years, State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, has invested hundreds of thousands of dollars from two campaign accounts that he controls in at least four Albany-area companies, which have all had personal business dealings with him, a review of state campaign finance records shows.

headline: Fire Officials Relax Position on Lockers
text: The New York Fire Department, under threat of a lawsuit from the city’s largest fire union, has sent a memo to city firehouses stating that firefighters may post American flags and Mass cards memorializing fallen colleagues on their lockers.

headline: Nice Phone, Mr. Jobs, But ...
text: IS there anyone who introduces products with more panache than Steven P. Jobs? Let me rephrase that: has there ever been anybody in the history of marketing to introduce products with the sheer, dazzling showmanship of the legendary Apple chief executive?

headline: Banks Gone Wild
text: Lexington, Ky.

headline: Student Gets Some Help From a Sympathetic Mother
text: Jill Rappaport had just finished talking to her son, Alex, who is a freshman at Duke University, when she read an article about Steguer Wilson, a young man from the Bronx adjusting to his first semester at Hunter College.

headline: Safe-Haven Laws Fail to End Discarding of Babies
text: Their lives ended almost as soon as they began. And every time their tiny bodies were found, in Dumpsters, garbage cans or, in the case of a newborn girl in Queens last fall, on the conveyor belt of a recycling plant, dismay and bewilderment followed.

headline: Rights Group Says Conditions in China Worsen as Olympics Near
text: BEIJING, Jan. 12  Human rights conditions in China deteriorated last year even as China sought to portray itself as an increasingly open, modern society ahead of the 2008 Olympics, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Friday.

headline: Passing Exchange Becomes Political Flashpoint
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — A passing exchange during a Senate hearing on Thursday turned into a political flashpoint overnight as Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat, and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice accused one another of insensitivity in comments about motherhood and the war in Iraq.

headline: Totals
At Marist, Passing First Has Pro Scouts Taking a Second Look
text: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — Jared Jordan was in the fourth grade when his parents moved from the suburbs of Hartford into the city, to a neighborhood known as the West End. Until that time, Jordan’s entire basketball repertory consisted of a long-range jump shot. Then he began showing up at playgrounds where he was not only one of the smallest players on the court, but also one of the few white players.

headline: Bringing Disparate Ethnic and Cultural Worlds Together
text: As high-concept programs go, it would be hard to beat the one the Chiara String Quartet brought to Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening. Under the title “Mestizaje: Harmony of Differences,” the group offered works in which disparate musical, ethnic and cultural influences mingle (the meaning of the Spanish word in the title, at least as the quartet is using it). The program’s two halves were listed as “acts,” with the stage bathed in red light during the performances and dark between them.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a Supreme Court argument in a labor case from the state of Washington misidentified the type of workplace at issue, in which employees who choose not to join the union must pay fees to support the union’s collective bargaining. It is an agency shop — not a union shop, in which all employees must actually join the union.

headline: Marionettes, a Saxophone and a Battle to the Death
