text: “The Rapture Project,” an eccentric show with marionettes and an oompah band, is inspired by a strand of Sicilian puppet theater most popular in the 19th century, and any 19th-century Sicilians in the audience will no doubt find it quite enjoyable. Everybody else will be mystified more often than not.

headline: BP Names Its Next Chief; Succession Pace Stepped Up
text: LONDON, Jan. 12 — The beleaguered energy giant BP unexpectedly named a successor on Friday for its chief executive, John Browne, and said Mr. Browne would step down more than a year earlier than expected.

headline: When the Ravens Play Defense, It Is a Bruising in Disguise
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md., Jan. 12 — Linebacker Bart Scott had just been handed a bottle of Tabasco sauce as a trophy for being the media-friendliest of the Ravens when he began waving it in the air.

headline: The Shock of College (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Catch a Falling Star
text: The planned departure for Los Angeles of the British soccer star and tabloid darling David Beckham grabbed headlines and kicked off a fresh round of soccer optimism. Once again, boosters could claim that what the rest of the world calls football would finally hit the big time in the United States — for a mere $250 million over five years.

headline: Round Up the Usual Lawyers
text: No one who has followed President Bush’s policies on detainees should be surprised when a member of his team scorns American notions of justice. But even by that low standard, the administration’s new attack on lawyers who dare to give those prisoners the meager representation permitted them is contemptible.

headline: Landy, Astro and Beyond: Searching for the Right Signal
text: If an opponent opens one strong no-trump, what are your partnership’s intervening options?

headline: A High-Wire Act Shows Up, With Feet on the Ground
text: One of the main reasons that the conductor Kurt Masur, a Teutonic taskmaster, was brought to the New York Philharmonic in 1991 was to instill much-needed discipline after Zubin Mehta’s erratic 13-year tenure as music director. Mr. Mehta, a dynamo on the podium, was capable of brilliance. But too often, his performances back then were all flash and no substance. The consensus was that the playing of the Philharmonic had grown careless and coarse during the Mehta era.

headline: New York Judges’ Pay (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Black Churches Hungering for Musical Talent
text: In the early summer of 2005, the Rev. Douglas Slaughter went searching for a church musician to hire. He had all too much experience in such quests and their futility. During a dozen years as pastor of Second Baptist Church in Aiken, S.C., Mr. Slaughter had already gone through the recruitment routine four times.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Dec. 29 about Edwin Edwards, the banker who helped bring a currency trading scandal at Citibank to light, gave an erroneous name in some copies for the investment bank for which he later worked. It was Stephens Inc., not Stephen Inc.

headline: Cablevision Buyout Bid Is Raised
text: The Dolan family, the controlling shareholders of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, yesterday increased their bid for the company by about $1 billion, to $8.9 billion, from their October offer.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A news analysis article yesterday about a bill on stem cell research passed by the House misstated one of its provisions. The measure would allow scientists receiving federal funds to use embryonic stem cells from surplus embryos generated in fertility clinics, after the cell lines had been derived by others using nonfederal funds. The federally supported scientists would not derive the cell lines themselves.

headline: Wielding Kitchen Knives and Honing Office Skills
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 — Steve Jakosa, leader of the Emerald Palace cooking team, took off his apron and sat down to enjoy his dinner when the bad news came. His team’s Mongolian beef had lost.

headline: Sweden’s Lightning Rod in a Storm Over Assimilation
text: STOCKHOLM

headline: 2 Missing Boys Are Found Near St. Louis
text: When the police entered an apartment near St. Louis yesterday looking for a 13-year-old boy who had disappeared 60 miles away on Monday, they found him and a bonus: another Missouri teenager who had been missing for more than four years.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Ballet at the Barricades

headline: House Democrats Propose Cut in Student Loan Rates
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — House Democrats on Friday unveiled a bill that would cut interest rates on federally subsidized loans to college students by half over the next five years.

headline: My Father Was a New York Jet, and I Don’t Give a Darn
text: I WOKE up my 9-year-old son, Harrison, on New Year’s Eve morning with a gentle nudge, a chocolate doughnut and a pair of media credentials for the New York Jets’ final regular-season game. Harrison had recently suffered a nasty bout with pneumonia, and although the doctor said his lungs had mostly cleared, he coughed as he blinked open his eyes.

text: To the Editor:

headline: House Democrats Pass Bill on Medicare Drug Prices
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Defying a veto threat, the House on Friday passed a bill to require the government to negotiate with drug manufacturers to obtain lower drug prices for Medicare beneficiaries.

headline: A Lot of Uncertainty, Except on Wall Street
text: UNCERTAINTY is usually bad news in business, and there was plenty of uncertainty this week. But stocks rallied nonetheless, suggesting investor optimism, in part because of acceleration of the sustained fall in energy prices.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map in some copies last Saturday with an article about the death of a 13-year-old boy who was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train in Queens showed two branches of tracks in Rego Park that no longer exist.

headline: Grenade Hits U.S. Embassy in Athens
text: ATHENS, Jan. 12 — An antitank grenade was fired into the heavily fortified American Embassy here on Friday just before dawn. The building was empty, but the attack nonetheless underscored deep anti-American sentiment here and revived fears of a new round of homegrown terror.

headline: A History Lesson That Sprays Scorn Liberally
text: Over the last few years, George W. Bush has probably been the most frequently portrayed character in New York theater — unless Donald H. Rumsfeld has edged him out. An entire genre of Bush-bashing shows has even emerged, defined by broad parody, cutting one-liners and a disdain for the notion of fair and balanced. These shows, easily spotted by punchy, willfully unsubtle titles like “Bush Is Bad” and “Bush Wars,” serve a psychological purpose as much as an artistic one. The world has gone mad, they imply, so come and vent with us.

headline: Columbia Uses Hot Shooting and Late Run to Top Princeton
text: The early signs indicated this might not be a typical basketball season for Columbia, where losing had become a tradition. But a couple of perennial Ivy League powers still stood in the Lions’ way. Doesn’t the Ivy League always come down to Penn and Princeton, with Columbia straggling far behind in the standings?

headline: Republicans on Panel Back President’s Plan, Masking Divisions
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Republicans on the Senate Armed Services Committee came to the defense of President Bush on Friday, lending support to his decision to send more troops to Iraq and hoping to head off a Senate resolution criticizing the plan.

headline: Judge Rejects Defamation Suit Against The Times
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  A federal judge on Friday dismissed a suit against The New York Times by a former government scientist who said he was defamed by a series of columns about the deadly anthrax mailings in 2001.

headline: Correction
text: An article yesterday about the Iraqi government’s response to plans by President Bush to deploy additional troops referred incorrectly to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s absence from the government’s news conference. Mr. Maliki was never scheduled to speak; it was not that he “failed to appear.”

headline: Holiday on Monday: Martin Luther King’s Birthday
text: NEW YORK

headline: Bolivia: Morales Calls for Calm
text: Street protests continued in the city of Cochabamba as President Evo Morales ordered the army and the police to guard the airport, bridges and public buildings. Mr. Morales asked his supporters to refrain from “vengeance” after they clashed with supporters of Cochabamba State’s governor, Manfred Reyes Villa. Two people were killed and dozens wounded in clashes this week between groups armed with machetes, bats and rocks, and protesters set fire to the governor’s colonial-era palace. The battles erupted after Mr. Reyes Villa joined governors from eastern provinces in pushing for greater political autonomy from the central government.

headline: Three More Faces of Aurora, and of Her Prince
text: On paper, the “Sleeping Beauty” tale known today is simple, even silly: a harmless delight for children. It’s only in the telling that this Tchaikovsky story ballet can become a classic.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart on Jan. 2 with the continuation of a front-page article about Wal-Mart’s struggle to market an energy-saving light bulb known as a compact fluorescent lamp referred incompletely to mercury emissions in comparing two light bulbs. The emissions — 2.4 milligrams from the fluorescent lamp and 10 milligrams for an incandescent bulb — occur at a coal-powered plant generating the electricity needed for the bulbs. The bulbs themselves do not emit mercury.

headline: Polish Church to Check Ties to the Secret Police
text: PARIS, Jan. 12 — The Roman Catholic Church leadership of Poland called Friday for all of the country’s bishops to be investigated for past ties to the secret police.

headline: With Ousters, EMI Group Is Said to Be Packaging Itself for Sale
text: Love is not all you need. Not if you are the EMI Group, the British music company, whose best-selling album on the Billboard chart is “Love,” a remixed set of songs from the Beatles’ decades-old catalog.

headline: Rice Says Bush Authorized Iranians’ Arrest in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — A recent series of American raids against Iranians in Iraq was authorized under an order that President Bush decided to issue several months ago to undertake a broad military offensive against Iranian operatives in the country, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Friday.

headline: A Move With More Bends Than Beckham’s
text: Juan Pablo Montoya is 31, just like David Beckham, and is bringing his game to the United States, just like Beckham. Therein the comparison ends.

headline: Wilson Hulme, 60, a Curator and Passionate Stamp Collector, Is Dead
text: Wilson Hulme, an energetic promoter of the stamp collecting hobby and philatelic curator of the Smithsonian’s National Postal Museum in Washington, died on Wednesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 60.

headline: Martin D. Kruskal Dies; Mathematician Was 81
text: Martin D. Kruskal, a mathematician whose wide-ranging research touched on astrophysics, nuclear fusion and the soliton, a unique form of wave that he helped describe in the 1960s, died Dec. 26 in Princeton, N.J. He was 81.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A television review on Jan. 2 about “Dirt,” on FX, referred incorrectly to the channel. It is a basic cable channel, not a premium one.

headline: Wine Tastings Loosen Up. Butter Pecan With That Cabernet?
text: Andrew Sia wanted to find a sommelier who would lecture to his wine tasting club, but was not sure he could afford it. Then there was the matter of the ice cream.

headline: Writers Scrutinize Big Mac and Themselves
text: In an article that ran Wednesday — the day after he and his fellow baseball writers emphatically rejected Mark McGwire’s candidacy for the Hall of Fame — the Toronto Globe and Mail columnist Stephen Brunt recalled a news conference the St. Louis Cardinals called for their outsized slugger the first day of spring training in 1999, six months after he obliterated the single-season home run record.

headline: Pentagon Sees Move in Somalia as Blueprint
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Military operations in Somalia by American commandos, and the use of the Ethiopian Army as a surrogate force to root out operatives for Al Qaeda in the country, are a blueprint that Pentagon strategists say they hope to use more frequently in counterterrorism missions around the globe.

headline: Blair Urges Britain to Pursue an Aggressive Foreign Policy
text: LONDON, Jan. 12 — As he seeks to define his legacy and stamp his imprint on the future, Prime Minister Tony Blair on Friday urged his successors to maintain the warlike foreign policy that he promoted, sending troops into battle in Africa and the Balkans, Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Correction: For the Record

headline: Argentine Ex-President Charged With Rights Abuses
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 12 — Acting at the request of Argentine officials, the Spanish police on Friday detained María Estela de Perón, the former president of Argentina and the widow of the founder of the ruling party, as part of a broadening investigation by the Peronist government of Argentina into past human rights abuses there.

headline: Interpreting the Beatles Without Copying
text: Lately I’ve been wondering why, as a more than casual Beatles fan, I’m not interested in note-perfect covers by Beatles tribute bands, even though, as a classical music critic, I happily spend my nights listening to re-creations — covers, in a way — of Beethoven symphonies and Haydn string quartets. What, when it comes down to it, is the difference?

headline: In Europe and Elsewhere, Bush’s New War Strategy Is Greeted With Skepticism
text: LONDON, Jan. 12 — Whatever the impact of President’s Bush’s new strategy for Iraq in Baghdad or in Baquba, it has won few converts across a worried world, where dismay and hostility toward the American expedition have grown while support trickles away.

headline: Wal-Mart Chooses Ad Agencies Yet Again
text: For the third time in less than three months, Wal-Mart Stores has made major decisions affecting the advertising agencies that handle its giant marketing assignments.

headline: Russia Cuts Belarus Oil Duty
text: After a political dispute that shut down an important oil pipeline to Europe, Russia’s prime minister, Mikhail Y. Fradkov, announced that Russia had agreed to lower significantly an export duty on oil to Belarus. Russia had imposed a duty of $180 per ton on oil shipped to Belarus, but agreed to lower it to $53 after the conflict prompted a halt in supplies to Europe through the Druzhba, or Friendship, pipeline, according to news accounts. Belarus on Wednesday agreed to drop a tit-for-tat fee it had imposed in response to Russia’s new duty, causing Russia to close the pipeline. Belarus has refined subsidized Russian oil and resold it at significant profit. Belarus will continue to receive a subsidy, but Mr. Fradkov said the new agreement, which appeared to end the dispute between the countries, would still raise $1 billion for Russia.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the World Briefing column on Friday misstated the given name of a banker arrested on suspicion of ordering the killing of the deputy of Russia’s central bank. He is Aleksei Y. Frenkel, not Andrei.

headline: Nelson Gets His Wish and Retires as a Yankee
text: At 3:26 p.m. yesterday, the Yankees sent out a news release welcoming back Jeff Nelson as a non-roster invitee to spring training. At 3:53, they sent another release announcing Nelson’s retirement.

headline: U.S. Official Sees Opening for Revival of Trade Talks
text: GENEVA, Jan. 12 — The United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, said Friday that she was optimistic the collapsed Doha trade negotiations could be restarted, but added that there were still obstacles to a revival of the talks.

headline: Second Man Sentenced in Killing of Ex-Reporter
text: The second of two men convicted in the killing of a retired reporter for The New York Times was sentenced to 65 years in prison. The man, Percey Jordan Jr., 43, was convicted of first-degree murder in October. He faced a maximum of life without the possibility of parole for the attack on the reporter, David E. Rosenbaum, last January. Mr. Jordan’s cousin Michael C. Hamlin, who was sentenced to 26 years for his role in the death, testified that Mr. Jordan had struck the former reporter over the head with a pipe while he took his wallet. Last week, Mr. Hamlin was sentenced after pleading guilty late last year to second-degree murder.

headline: What's on Saturday Night
text: 10 P.M. (HBO) LOUIS C. K.: SHAMELESS With a season of “Lucky Louie,” his adult sitcom, behind him, Louis C. K. takes the stage at the Henry Fonda Theater in Los Angeles for an evening of stand-up, in which, as his people put it, he’ll cover “everyday subjects near and dear to his heart, tackling issues that others have been too ashamed to address.” Now what could that mean?

headline: Looking Defenseless, Knicks Take Step Backward
text: The scoring gap between the Charlotte Bobcats and the Knicks was considerable last night, as was the gap between the Knicks’ defensive effort and their attempted explanations for it.

headline: Chinese Court Upholds Conviction of Peasants’ Advocate
text: BEIJING, Jan. 12  A Chinese court on Friday upheld the conviction of and lengthy jail sentence for a leading advocate for peasants’ rights despite widespread criticism that he was unjustly made a target by corrupt local officials.

headline: Insight or Hindsight? Ask Saints About Colston
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12  Of the 255 players selected in last year’s N.F.L. draft, only three were taken after receiver Marques Colston of Hofstra. He flirted with becoming Mr. Irrelevant, the dubious honor given to the last player drafted. In the local football parlance, it was a “Who dat?” moment.

headline: Where Courtly Manners and Vital Energy Meet
text: ANTWERP, Belgium, Jan. 12 — Belgium is better known for contemporary dance — Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, Wim Vandekeybus and Jan Fabre are among its international exports — than for ballet, and it is probably better known for beer than for any kind of dance. But the country does possess a first-rate classical company, the Royal Ballet of Flanders, based in Antwerp, the Flemish-speaking home of diamonds and fashion design.

headline: Yury Golubev, 64, a Founder of Yukos Oil, Dies
text: Yury A. Golubev, a founder of Yukos Oil, the former energy giant once led by Mikhail B. Khordokovsky, died sometime last weekend in London. He was 64.

headline: Robert Anton Wilson, 74, Who Wrote Mind-Twisting Novels, Dies
text: Robert Anton Wilson, an author of “The Illuminatus! Trilogy” — a mind-twisting science-fiction series about a secret global society that has been a cult classic for more than 30 years — died on Thursday at his home in Capitola, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Reporters Tail a Killer Croc
text: “Primeval,” which opened yesterday without having been screened in advance for critics, is one of several recent movies to bill itself as “inspired by true events.” So was this review, though in both cases “inspired” may be too strong a word.

headline: Prosecutor Asks to Exit Duke Case
text: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 12 — The district attorney in the Duke lacrosse sexual assault case asked the state attorney general on Friday to take over the troubled prosecution, saying he faced a conflict of interest because of ethics charges filed against him by the state bar, officials involved in the case said.

headline: Doctor’s Killer Tries to Make Abortion the Issue
text: BUFFALO, Jan. 12 — There is no dispute over how Dr. Barnett Slepian died. Yet eight years later his confessed killer — who is already serving 25 years to life in prison for murder — is on trial for a second time.

headline: Spitzer Backs a Democrat From Nassau for the Senate
text: MANHASSET, N.Y., Jan. 12 — First, Gov. Eliot Spitzer created a vacancy in the State Senate, then on Friday he ventured down from Albany to try to fill it.

headline: 2 New Bids for Freedom Put Prosecutor on Defensive
text: Kenneth Mark Taub stands more than six feet tall with a meaty neck and good wrestling shoulders. He has a well-disciplined goatee, a withering baritone and a law degree from St. John’s University, which he puts to good use leading homicide prosecutors through the cage-fighting match known as State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

headline: The Sounds of Mexico Hit New York Airwaves
text: On Thursday morning, commuters in New York tuning in to the Spanish-language station WZAA-FM 92.7 might have heard an unusual traffic report, describing conditions not on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, but on the Santa Monica and Hollywood Freeways, clear across the continent.

headline: Official Attacks Top Law Firms Over Detainees
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — The senior Pentagon official in charge of military detainees suspected of terrorism said in an interview this week that he was dismayed that lawyers at many of the nation’s top firms were representing prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and that the firms’ corporate clients should consider ending their business ties.

headline: What’s on Monday Night
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 64TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Warren Beatty (right), who has earned 12 Golden Globe nominations over the years for roles in films including “Reds,” “Bugsy,” “Bonnie and Clyde” and “Splendor in the Grass,” will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement at this annual event honoring the best in film and television as chosen by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. Presenters include Cameron Diaz, Sarah Jessica Parker, Rachel Weisz, Salma Hayek, Felicity Huffman, Justin Timberlake, Reese Witherspoon and Ben Stiller. Lorraine Nicholson, the daughter of Jack Nicholson and Rebecca Broussard, is the 2007 Miss Golden Globe.

headline: Spy Case Comes to U.S. as Agency Urges Testing

headline: AOL, Now Focused on Free, Sells Its Paid Music Service
text: After six years of trying to build an online music service, AOL agreed yesterday to sell its AOL Music Now to Napster. Napster will pay $15 million to add AOL’s 350,000 subscribers to its own 566,000.

headline: Property Values in New York Show Vibrancy
text: As the nationwide property market cools, real estate in New York City is showing surprising vibrancy, with estimated market values jumping by 19 percent in 2006, double the increase from the previous year, city officials said yesterday.

headline: Sun’s Chief Doesn’t Fear the Snarky

McNealy, there was a great deal of skepticism about whether he could bring the company back. Perhaps more than any other computer maker Sun has been a victim of the dot-com Internet collapse.

headline: Stormy Outlook as Gonzales Faces Senate Democrats
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, who has faced controversy throughout his two-year tenure, is likely to enter an even stormier phase next Thursday when he appears before the Senate Judiciary Committee for the first time since control fell to the Democrats.

headline: Death of a Shark Leaves Scientists Grasping
text: ATLANTA, Jan. 12 — To those who questioned the propriety of keeping the giant whale shark in captivity, the philanthropist Bernie Marcus liked to say that in his aquarium here, the shark, the world’s largest fish, would also be the world’s most pampered.

headline: Abu Dhabi Is to Gain a Louvre of Its Own

headline: Another Chance to Help

headline: Oil Companies Attack Legislation Aimed at Tax Incentives

headline: The Changing Times Take the Fox Out of the Fox Hunt

headline: Correction: 36 Hours London
text: The 36 Hours column on Dec. 31 about London referred imprecisely to the term “Cool Britannia.” While it was used in the news media and advertising and was associated with the early years of Prime Minister Tony Blair’s Labor government, Mr. Blair did not use it as a nickname for London.

headline: One Mother’s Sad Mission, a State’s Shame
text: THE question comes up nearly every time Mariann Hudak displays the plastic bag containing her daughter Lori’s effects. The coroner’s office returned $6, a bracelet and a ring Lori was wearing when a drunken friend crashed their car into a pole on Post Road in Fairfield. Mrs. Hudak hears the question when, as a victim advocate for Mothers Against Drunk Driving, she shows convicted drunken drivers and ashen high school students the color photographs of 21-year-old Lori dead in the mangled car.

headline: Among Troops and Families, Mixed Reaction to American Expansion in Iraq

The corporal is part of the infusion of troops being poured into Iraq under President Bush’s new plan, and as he weighed his coming departure at Galloping Gertie’s, a soldier-thick watering hole outside Fort Lewis, Wash., he was brimming with confidence.

headline: Equal Cheers for Boys and Girls Draw Some Boos
text: WHITNEY POINT, N.Y. — Thirty girls signed up for the cheerleading squad this winter at Whitney Point High School in upstate New York. But upon learning they would be waving their pompoms for the girls’ basketball team as well as the boys’, more than half of the aspiring cheerleaders dropped out.

headline: Art of the Deal
text: De Kooning once grudgingly praised the art dealer Leo Castelli by declaring, “That son of a bitch, you could give him two beer cans and he could sell them.” Sure enough, after the impish Jasper Johns responded to this taunt by making a pair of Ballantine Ale empties, Castelli sold the 1960 work to the collectors Robert and Ethel Scull. This classic of Pop art is now in a German museum.

headline: Conquer and Convert
text: A work of historical fiction couldn’t ask for better bones than the adventures of a real-life conquistadora. The heroine of Isabel Allende’s latest book, a 16th-century Spanish woman who sailed to Peru and trekked south with the expedition that claimed vast lands for Charles V, faces the same perils as the soldiers around her — along with a few extras, like unwanted sexual advances.

headline: Scientists Detect Variant Gene in Alzheimer’s Disease
text: A variant gene involved in Alzheimer’s disease has been detected through study of Dominican families living in Upper Manhattan, scientists are reporting.

headline: Correction: And a River, Such as It Is, Runs Through It
text: The Jersey column last Sunday incorrectly described the course of the Saddle River. It joins the Passaic River below the Great Falls in Paterson; it does not form part of the falls.

headline: Katherine Murray-Vergata, Clifford Cohn
text: Katherine Murray-Vergata, the daughter of Patricia Murray of Brooklyn and the late Frank Vergata, is to be married in Manhattan this evening to Clifford David Cohn, a son of Joan Cohn and Dr. Peter F. Cohn of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Alan Rabishaw, a cousin of the bridegroom, is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton at Battery Park.

headline: Connecticut, Where Puritans Live
text: Many Connecticut residents experienced the annoying necessity this past Christmas Eve and New Year’s Eve of having to act like bootleggers in order to serve alcohol at parties. Those who had not planned ahead were forced to drive to border states to purchase wine, beer and other spirits. The reason? This year, both days, normally among the strongest for liquor sales, fell on Sundays, when it is illegal to sell alcohol in Connecticut.

headline: Lesson for Corzine: Tax Relief Is Not Simple
text: TRENTON

headline: Just Dump Him Already
text: You know that woman friend of yours who has been inexplicably, miserably, annoyingly hung up on the wrong guy for years — or has it been a decade? You know who I mean: she’s smart, funny and attractive. Lots of men — even desirable ones — fall for her, although she never seems to like any of them. Or else, just when she begins to notice their existence, he steps back into the picture, pulling her focus away once more. She’s the friend to whom you had to issue a ban on ever mentioning his name in your presence again, and then broke it repeatedly because she seemed so desperately in need of advice (which she promptly ignored). Well, she’s the heroine of a very funny novel, “Him Her Him Again the End of Him” by the former “Saturday Night Live” writer Patricia Marx. Unfortunately, he’s in here, too.

headline: Doodles à la Carte
text: IT is a cool, cloudy day in late fall as Sam Gross and Gahan Wilson, both in their 70s and regular contributors of cartoons to The New Yorker, stroll side by side up Seventh Avenue. After a quick Tuesday morning meeting with Bob Mankoff, the magazine’s cartoon editor, they and a handful of other New Yorker cartoonists have set out for lunch; more men than women, most in their 70s, each week they are a slightly different bunch.

headline: All Together Now
text: “Take me out with the crowd,” goes the old baseball song. “I love this crowd,” repeats the classic stand-up comic. Every lecturer knows: the larger the group, the more they become an event for themselves, heightening the attention, the laughs or the emotions. At our national political conventions, people wear silly hats and bob up and down to music so stupid it is a parody of music, in order to “demonstrate” a political feeling. Participating in a demonstrative crowd gives joy, as being a mere spectator cannot. Even in a culture where recorded performance has become central, people crave the live event, largely for that group joy.

headline: When Dream Cars Are Powered by Pipe Dreams
text: DETROIT

headline: After All That Turmoil, the Giants Now Seem Likely to Stay the Course
text: The much-speculated overhaul of the Giants’ football operations, after a disappointing 8-8 season and a first-round playoff loss last Sunday to the Philadelphia Eagles, did not occur.

headline: Young Players Race to the Top, but the Over-30 Set Holds On
text: A popular misconception about chess is that older players are better because they are more experienced.

headline: TV Dramas Rip the Cover Off Magazines
text: KRISHTINE DE LEON, one of six interns picked to star in an MTV reality series set at Rolling Stone, expected an office out of “Almost Famous,” the 2000 movie about the early-1970s heyday of the rock music magazine. “The type of place where people were doing copious amounts of drugs to get their stories in on time, hobnobbing with lots of celebrities, no real rules,” she said.

headline: Correction: Holiday on Ice in St. Petersburg, With a Shot of Vodka on the Side
text: An article on Dec. 31 about winter events in St. Petersburg, Russia, referred incorrectly to the Seventh Symphony of Shostakovich. He composed part of it as shells fell on the city (then known as Leningrad); he did not conduct it. The article also referred incorrectly to meters in taxis there. Taxis typically have meters, but they are not always used.

headline: Modernist No More: Home by Famous Architect Is Razed
text: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 13 — A Modernist house designed by the renowned architect Paul Rudolph and at the center of a highly public dispute over its demolition was being torn down Saturday, despite a last-minute effort by the state attorney general to save it.

headline: The Best We Can Hope For
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Germans Push Europe on Holocaust
text: BERLIN, Jan. 13  Germany wants to use its European Union presidency to push through legislation that would make denying the Holocaust punishable by stiff prison sentences in all 27 of the union’s member states.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Dec. 28, about Gerald Ford during World War II, incorrectly described a ship he saw hit by a Japanese torpedo during the Battle of Leyte Gulf. The ship, the cruiser Canberra, was American, not Australian.

headline: Maryland Hands Clemson Its First Loss, and Dreams Start Anew
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 13  A big chunk of the hardwood floor that Maryland played on en route to winning the N.C.A.A. championship in 2002 is attached to a wall inside the Comcast Center. The Terrapins walk past the floor on their way to practice. The junior forward James Gist said he stares at it and thinks about bringing the university another title.

headline: Andrée Finkle and Carter Worth
text: Andrée Jill Finkle was married last evening to Carter Braxton Worth in New York. The Rev. Christiane M. Lang performed the ceremony at Brick Presbyterian Church.

headline: Jordan Chattman, Joseph Shumofsky
text: Jordan Deanna Chattman, a daughter of Renee L. Chattman and Sanders M. Chattman of North Caldwell, N.J., is to be married this evening to Joseph Bruce Shumofsky, a son of Linda Lang Shumofsky and Dr. Edward Shumofsky of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Norman Patz is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J.

headline: Nicole Quenqua, Sean Adler
text: Nicole Quenqua and Dr. Sean Adler were married on Friday in a civil ceremony at the New York City Municipal Building. Blanca Martinez of the City Clerk’s office, officiated. Last evening they had a Jewish ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: The Week in Connecticut
text: Senator Dodd Gets Off the Sideline

headline: Pushback
text: “We were too weakened, and had too many problems, to really push back,” said Brent Scowcroft, recently recalling the early days of the presidency of Gerald Ford.

headline: Money Doesn’t Talk
text: AFTER months of eyeing a black Chanel tote at Saks Fifth Avenue, Shalla Azizian was ready to splurge. Instead of charging the $2,000 bag to a credit card, Ms. Azizian, a lingerie boutique owner in Manhattan, discreetly plunked down a stack of crisp bills she brought for the purchase.

headline: Penn Proves Too Much for Columbia
text: As fans filed into Levien Gymnasium last night, they could hardly contain their excitement. The prospect of Columbia beating Princeton and Penn on consecutive nights was almost too much to handle. But the Lions were already halfway there.

headline: The Latest New Wave
text: As luxury condos and waterfront development are redefining Williamsburg, the longtime hipster central of Brooklyn, the dining scene is as hot as ever. These restaurants have all opened in the past year.

headline: How to Catch a Falling Dollar (and Even Make a Profit)
text: THE dollar fell against many currencies in 2006, and many Wall Street analysts are predicting more of the same this year.

headline: Rio Dances Into New Year Despite Violence
text: THE drug traffickers who rule many of Rio de Janeiro’s slums may have been hoping, in part, to scare people away from the city’s famous New Year’s Eve celebration on Copacabana Beach. But the coordinated acts of violence they committed on Dec. 28, which killed at least 20 people and made news worldwide, were upstaged by two forces apparently more powerful: a steady drizzle that kept some revelers away and a concert by the Black Eyed Peas on Ipanema, the next beautiful beach over.

headline: And Diggity Makes Three
text: NO one gets it right the first time. Even the second apartment that a novice New Yorker inhabits is often a mistake — tiny, or stinky, or in a dull part of town. But after that, either you wise up and start to figure out what you need in order to feel at home in this city, or there’s a good chance you never will, and the next place you live will be somewhere far away from here.

headline: Bollywood Glitz in a Times Square Debut
text: Roopam Jain craned for a view of the celebrities on Friday night, jostling with dozens of other fans. He called his wife by cellphone, warning that she was about to miss the grand arrivals.

headline: Breaking the Power Brokers
text: ALBANY is infamous for its disdain for democracy. In fact, what’s been going on for years in the capital would be better called a triocracy because all important decisions that affect the third-largest state in the country are made by three people: the governor, the Senate majority leader and the Assembly speaker.

headline: Tunisia Says Suspects in Gun Battle Had Blueprints of Embassies
text: PARIS, Jan. 13 — More than two dozen Islamic extremists involved in a deadly gun battle with the Tunisian police earlier this month had blueprints of foreign embassies and documents identifying foreign envoys as targets, the Tunisian interior minister said Friday.

headline: For Many, King’s Birthday Is Just Another Workday
text: In the 21 years since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday became a national holiday, the embrace it has received from employers has been less of a bear hug than a polite handshake followed gradually by an arm around the shoulders.

headline: Tennessee Says Top Defender Is No Longer Enrolled
text: Demetrice Morley, one of more than two dozen high school athletes who exploited loopholes in National Collegiate Athletic Association rules to qualify for a football scholarship, is no longer enrolled at the University of Tennessee.

headline: Come to Our Club. Or Not. Whatever.
text: IF the owners of the Anchor, a lounge on Spring Street in the West Village that opened two weeks ago, were hoping to create something other than a downtown hot spot, they seem to have taken all the necessary precautions.

headline: Rustic Streams Hiding Complicated Traditions
text: ‘RIDER ON THE PLAINS’: MUSIC BY VIRGIL THOMSON AND CHARLES FUSSELL

headline: Spoleto Premieres to Include One by Philip Glass
text: Look for a number of American premieres at this year’s Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C. (May 24 to June 10). “I think we stretched ourselves further than ever with this year’s program,” said Nigel Redden, the festival’s general director, mentioning that the lineup includes more dance (Swan Lake, Rubberbandance) and jazz events (the pianist Ahmad Jamal) than in previous years.

headline: Alison Yaeger and Todd Krueger
text: Alison Marcia Yaeger, the daughter of Ellen Hope Yaeger of Cortland Manor, N.Y., and Franklin Elliot Yaeger of Putnam Valley, N.Y., was married last evening to Todd Krueger, a son of Barbara and Sheldon Krueger of Del Mar, Calif. Rabbi Mel Hecht officiated at the Bali Hai Golf Club in Las Vegas.

headline: Editors' Choice
text: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

headline: Getting Good Habits Started Early
text: New Rochelle

headline: Fraud Cases Are Rising, F.B.I. Says
text: MORTGAGE fraud has continued its climb over the last year, according to new statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, despite increased attention from the financial industry and law enforcement agencies.

headline: It’s Not Easy Staying Green
text: ONCE I floated through life in a haze of good fellowship. I believed in recycling and saving the planet; I wasn’t an activist out on the barricades or sitting at the top of a threatened redwood tree, but I certainly supported the people who were. I recycled back in the days when going to the recycling center meant a 20-mile round trip. I used cloth napkins and unbleached paper towels. I didn’t use disposable coffee filters. I shopped with string bags to keep plastic out of the landfill and embarrassed my daughter by packing her school lunch in reused bread bags. I bought my cleaning products at the health food store, refilling bottles to save on packaging.

headline: Children’s Books
text: When Russell Freedman won the Newbery Medal for his photobiography of Abraham Lincoln in 1988, he rewarded himself with a trip to China. The many nonfiction books he has written since then are devoted primarily to American subjects, but Freedman continues to be fascinated by Asia. He wrote about Confucius in 2002 and now, with the Russian-born illustrator Bagram Ibatoulline, he has produced a splendid new book, “The Adventures of Marco Polo.”

headline: When Money’s Involved, the Truth Can Take a Beating
text: Correction Appended

headline: Spanish Prime Minister Takes Political Heat After Airport Attack by Basque Group
text: MADRID, Jan. 12 — At his year-end news conference on Dec. 29, Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero proclaimed that the peace initiative he had started with the Basque separatist movement ETA months before was making progress.

headline: All Quiet at Ridge Hill
text: A battle between Yonkers and its neighbors over Ridge Hill Village, the $600 million residential, retail and commercial project the city wants to build near its border with the Town of Greenburgh, has gone quiet.

headline: Charities Try to Keep Up With the Gateses
text: Correction Appended

headline: So You Think a Hold and a Kick Are a Snap?
text: Snap. Hold. Kick.

headline: Hmong, Shaken, Wonder if a Killing Was Retaliation
text: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 12 — As with most unsolved killings, there are more questions than answers about why Cha Vang, a Hmong immigrant from Laos, was shot to death while hunting squirrels in the deep woods north of here last weekend.

headline: An Investment in Legal Services; Gratefully Received, Suddenly Rescinded (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Plan for Iraq Swells ’08 Intrigue
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 — On Friday morning, as the capital was enmeshed in a debate over President Bush’s decision to send thousands more troops to Iraq, no one was more obviously searching for an alternate plan than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the New York Democrat and likely candidate for president.

headline: You Can’t Go Home Again, but You Can Win There
text: Baltimore

headline: Johanna Francis and William Stroever
text: Johanna Bess Francis, the daughter of Anne V. Francis and David M. Francis of Newtown, Conn., is to be married today to William Wallace Stroever, a son of Karen A. Stroever and Bruce W. Stroever of Long Valley, N.J. The Rev. Donald Delaney, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony in the Chapel of De La Salle and His Brothers at Manhattan College in Riverdale, the Bronx.

headline: Out of Bounds, Within Limits in Silverton, Colo.
text: CHANCES are you're not good enough to ski Silverton Mountain — or to ski it with grace, anyway. Don't take this personally: This six-year-old, vertigo-inducing backcountry “ski area” in the San Juan mountains of southwest Colorado that scoffs at niceties like slope grooming (and running water, but we'll get to that) has a way of quickly separating, with the deftness of a croupier, the rippers from the gapers, the noobs and the one-and-done's (but we'll get to them, too). Acre for acre, it's the most challenging lift-skiing in North America.

headline: Bush’s Legacy vs. the 2008 Election
text: DURING the midterm elections, a question nagged at Republicans who agreed to follow the White House script on the Iraq war: Does the president care more about his legacy than the party’s in pushing his course?

headline: Rookie Blues
text: Don’t ask me how it happened, but a gang of great old guys nearly hijacked the American crime novel last year. I’m thinking of lone avengers like Michael Connelly’s aging homicide detective, Harry Bosch, bringing belated justice to a cold case he might have botched in “Echo Park,” as well as precinct-house saints like the Oracle, wising up the rookie cops in Joseph Wambaugh’s “Hollywood Station.” And how about those old lions who came roaring out of retirement in new novels by George Pelecanos and John Lutz?

headline: Crepes, Scones and Buttery Bread
text: Sometimes Simon’s Marketplace in Chester seems like the center of the local universe, it’s so full of people shopping for specialty foods, buying takeout items and noshing. Although the general store’s space is ample, there are just 24 seats for eating-in. They are often full, with people munching savory or sweet crepes, house-made scones, sandwiches and other goodies made by four full-time chefs.

headline: U.S. Sounds Out Britain’s Plans in Iraq
text: LONDON, Jan. 14—Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates met with Prime Minister Tony Blair tonight on the first stop of a weeklong trip to Europe and the Middle East aimed at winning support for the White House plan for stabilizing Iraq.

headline: New York’s Kindest
text: WHEN Cesar Rodriguez’s stepdaughter missed several weeks of first grade in the spring of 2005, he convinced an investigator from the city Administration for Children’s Services that his wife, pregnant with her sixth child, was simply overwhelmed. After he agreed to get the older children to school on time, the investigator arranged to buy the family a crib, a stroller and a high chair. And then she closed the case.

headline: Does Abe Foxman Have an Anti-Anti-Semite Problem?
text: In certain precincts of the Jewish community, a person who insists that the sky is falling, despite ample evidence to the contrary, is said to gevaltize — a neologism derived from the famous Yiddish cry of shock or alarm. The word is sometimes applied to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, known as Aipac, the hard-line and notoriously successful pro-Israel lobby. But in the world of Jewish leaders, one man stands alone in the annals of gevalthood — Abraham Foxman, director of the Anti-Defamation League and scourge of anti-Semites of high estate and low, in Hollywood and Tehran, on campus and in the tabloids.

headline: Rebekah Dopp, Theodore Calabrese
text: Rebekah Evangeline Dopp is to be married today to Theodore Steven Calabrese in the chapel of the Hackley School in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie Harry Cohen, an interfaith minister, is to officiate.

headline: A Tepid Winter Warms Some Wallets
text: THE recent warm weather in the Northeast might not have been great for makers of winter coats, but the economy and markets could be poised for a small fillip. Benefits of the balmy days may extend from poor families to big-time investors, but are they just borrowing present prosperity from the future?

headline: Coveted, Whether Stone-Clad or Bare Brick
text: FOR a time after Mona Thong and her husband, Robert Stamicar, moved to Brooklyn from Toronto in 2004, they lived on Montgomery Place in Park Slope, perhaps the most sought-after location in the neighborhood, if not all of Brooklyn. The street is an immaculate ensemble of bay windows, elegantly angled rooftops, understated columns and brownstone facades, ending in a flourish at Prospect Park.

headline: On Bended Knee, With Questionnaire in Hand ...
text: A FIELD NOTES column on Dec. 17 (“Marriage Is Not Built on Surprises”) and an accompanying list posted at nytimes.com (“Questions Couples Should Ask, or Wish They Had, Before Marrying”) addressed the fact that many who marry are oblivious to important things about their partners.

headline: A Centenarian With Starkly Youthful Looks
text: THE old General Motors Building, at the southeast corner of 57th Street and Broadway, was recently wash-water gray but is now suddenly gleaming white, as it was when it was put up in 1909 in the heart of Automobile Row for the Demarest and Peerless auto manufacturers.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: Poor Mary, Queen of Scots. The infant ruler cried on her coronation day. Her second husband murdered her adviser in front of her. And later, she was imprisoned for 19 years by Queen Elizabeth I (her first cousin), who then sentenced her to death. Even Mary’s beheading was full of drama, requiring three swings of the ax. The Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh, where Mary lived, prayed and  most scandalously  saw her adviser killed, is now inviting the public to take a gander at her private chambers, as well as those of her murderous husband, Lord Darnley. New additions to the chambers, which reopened last month after a six-year restoration, include an oak-paneled oratory and a 17th-century portrait of Mary (below), painted by an unknown artist, which hung at Windsor Castle for 300 years (www.royalcollection.org.uk). ... Tomorrow, the Langham Hotel in London is scheduled to open a swanky bar, Artesian. Named after a 360-foot-deep artesian well that once provided water for the property, this watering hole specializes in rum and was designed by David Collins, who also created the modern looks behind the Blue Bar at the Berkeley and Claridge’s Bar at Claridge’s Hotel (www.langhamhotels.com). ... Wanderlust, a company based in Oakland, Calif., is offering a new getaway from March 3 to 9, called “A Winter’s Moon Over Yosemite Valley.” Scheduled so that participants will be able to visit Yosemite National Park during a full moon, the seven-day tour includes round-trip tickets aboard a vintage streamliner train (all meals and beverages included), a one-night predeparture stay in Oakland, two nights at the Ahwanhee or Yosemite Lodge and three nights of lodging, as well as dinner and a show, in San Francisco. Rates start at $1,995 a person. For more information, call (877) 625-1717 or visit www.wanderlustevents.com. .... Starting Feb. 15, all Delta flights (www.delta.com) from La Guardia Airport in New York to Chicago will land at Midway Airport instead of O’Hare. Midway is closer to downtown Chicago, which should cut down on travel time. ... Globetrotters reluctant to share private information on borrowed computers might be interested in RoboForm2Go. The software, which is designed to be carried around in a U.S.B. drive, organizes passwords, address books and banking and credit card information. It can be downloaded from www.roboform.com for $39.95. HILARY HOWARD

headline: Holiday Tomorrow Martin Luther King’s Birthday
text: NEW YORK

headline: A Time to Grieve, and to Forge a Bond
text: I RECEIVED an e-mail message not long ago from a young woman who asked me not to use her name. She wasn’t looking for attention. She just wanted to share.

headline: Rice Backs Mideast Moderates, but Offers No Plan
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and her Israeli counterpart declared their mutual backing on Saturday for a bilateral diplomatic strategy that would support moderate political leaders across the Middle East, but after a first evening of talks here offered little new to push ahead any agreement with the Palestinians.

headline: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno and Conan O’Brian
text: JAY LENO

headline: With City Watching, the Saints Carry On
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 — The New Orleans Saints advanced to the National Football Conference championship game for the first time Saturday, providing a sense of renewal for both a long-hapless team and a hurricane-battered city.

headline: The Two Sides of the Chargers: The Thunder and the Flash
text: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 13 — The first time Shawne Merriman went to a high school football practice, the coaches asked him what position he played.

headline: Art House to Get a Campus
text: PLEASANTVILLE

headline: Up Front
text: To most readers, Robert Pinsky is familiar as a former poet laureate of the United States, the author of an acclaimed translation of Dante’s “Inferno” and the creator of the Favorite Poem Project, which invited ordinary people to submit poems with particular meaning to them, along with personal commentary. This week, in his review of Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Dancing in the Streets: A History of Collective Joy,” Pinsky considers the cultural importance of Carnival, rock concerts and other celebratory mass events — phenomena not as far from the world of poetry as it might seem. “The emotional force of mass gatherings has profound importance,” he explained in an e-mail message. “I think we are desperate for something to counterbalance performances, great though they may be, that we experience electronically. We crave something else, something more personal as well as communal.” The public readings sponsored by the Favorite Poem Project, he says, “are among the most interesting group events I have witnessed: less performance than participation, and with a spirit hard to name, but unforgettable, and generated not just by each reader or poem, but by everyone there, together.” Click here for his review.

headline: More on Carry-On Rules for Liquids
text: I got a supply of clear plastic bottles clearly marked 100 milliliters from a drug store, as you advised on Dec. 17, but had a problem with them when I went through security at Bradley International Airport (Hartford/Springfield). It seems the bottles must have a commercial label indicating the contents. I don’t know if this is a local interpretation. I have not run across this at other airports since then, like Cincinnati, Chicago and Seattle, where nobody even looked at the contents of my clear plastic quart-size zip-top bag. — Mary Gorman, Bloomfield, Conn.

headline: The Overlook
text: Bosch has found the radiation victim’s Toyota in an alley not far from the overlook, and inside it, many objects associated with Stanley Kent’s murder, particularly the cesium. In the process, however, Bosch, too, has been exposed to the radiation.

headline: Infant Is Dead in Harlem After Shaking
text: A 20-year-old woman was being questioned last night in connection with the death of her 2-month-old son at their home in Harlem, the police said. The woman told detectives that she had shaken her son because he would not stop crying, according to the police.

headline: Correction: Check In, Check Out: Hotel 17
text: The Check In/Check Out column last Sunday about Hotel 17 in Manhattan misstated its neighborhood. The hotel, at 225 East 17th Street, is east of Union Square; it is not on the Lower East Side.

headline: In Rematch of Championship, Maryland Is No Match for Duke
text: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 13  The 2006-7 season began as one long victory parade for the Maryland women’s basketball team. After stunning the Duke Blue Devils in the N.C.A.A. championship game last April, the Terrapins have held the No. 1 spot in the national polls since November with an 18-game winning streak.

headline: ‘Starship Troopers’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Online Giving Increases
text: More and more people are donating online to The New York Times Neediest Cases campaign. As of Dec. 31, 2006, with more than a month left in the campaign, the number of online donors, 2,240, had already exceeded last season’s total. Data comes from NYCharities.org , which processes the online donations. Sixty-seven percent of online donors are New Yorkers, while the remaining 33 percent represent 36 states. They have many reasons for giving, but they are all moved to do so. Some of their letters are below.

headline: Newly in the Minority, G.O.P. Shows Signs of Division on Iraq and Domestic Policies
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13  After years of rock-solid party discipline and fealty to President Bush, Congressional Republicans have suddenly fractured in their new role as members of the minority, with some prominently deserting the White House on Iraq and others bolting from their leadership on popular domestic issues.

headline: Correction: A Bagel-Shaped Hole on an Unexpected Strip
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about complaints by Upper West Side residents that they cannot find superior bagels on West 72nd Street referred incorrectly to the status of a bagel store on West 72nd between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues. The store, 72nd Street Bagel, is open for business — not defunct.

headline: Life Goes On. And Then, Once Again, It Doesn’t.
text: FREEHOLD, N.J.

headline: Davidson Finds His New Voice in Leading Blues
text: Half a season has passed, but for viewers of Rangers games on the MSG Network, it’s still strange not to hear John Davidson’s commentary. After 21 years of analyzing Rangers games and games on other networks, Davidson left in June to become the president of the St. Louis Blues.

headline: Building a Stairway to Paradise, for Your Beloved Pet
text: FOR nearly 15 years, A. R. LaMura has cared for Sandy, a mixed-breed terrier he found on a loading dock, as if she were his own child. Sandy has a waterbed to sleep on, an array of bandanas to adorn her neck and gets treats like doggie ice cream and Omaha steaks.

headline: My Doctor the Lobbyist
text: My ob-gyn phoned, urging my support for a ballot measure requiring parental notification for teenage girls seeking abortions. I subsequently received calls from two antiabortion organizations asking me to support the measure. I suspect that my doctor gave them my number. Is that legal of her? Ethical? Kristin Fidler, Portland, Ore.

headline: The Clock Is Ticking for Winter Travelers
text: MORE than a year ago, the federal government decided it was going to require just about everyone entering the United States to present a passport  even American citizens coming back from trips just across the border. Confusion ensued  travel companies and border cities protested, start dates were pushed back, and air and sea requirements were broken up and put on different timetables. On Jan. 23, the first of the requirements is becoming reality. If you’re jetting off to Mexico or the Caribbean, you’ll need to pack a passport along with that bathing suit.

headline: Opening Hearts and Checkbooks to Ease the Woes of Strangers
text: For each person whose life has been eased by money provided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, there is a donor who has been moved to make a difference. For some, donating to the Neediest Cases is part of a tradition of giving. More and more often, that tradition is carried out online.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

headline: In Angel Falls, Venezuela, a Forest of Islands
text: THE wooden canoe, a curiara in the language of my Pemón Indian guides, winds through the rapids of the Carrao River in southeast Venezuela. A drizzle lets up as the sun rises, revealing the misty escarpments of Auyan-tepui. Then, abruptly, the tepui — a Pemón word for the majestic sandstone mountains in this wide swath of jungle and savanna — comes into magnificent relief. It is easily one of the most impressive sights I've ever encountered.

headline: Man Fatally Shot at Brooklyn Apartment Complex
text: A man was fatally shot in Brooklyn late Friday while walking along a courtyard behind one of the buildings in the apartment complex where he lived, the police said yesterday.

headline: The American Way of Equality
text: Income inequality is on the rise. The rich are getting better at passing their advantages on to their kids. Lifestyle and values gaps are widening between the educated and uneducated. So the big issue is: Will Americans demand new policies to reverse these trends — to redistribute wealth, to provide greater economic security? Are we about to see a mass populist movement in this country?

headline: A Family That Kept On Growing
text: CORAM, N.Y.

headline: Fin-de-Siècle Admen
text: New Brunswick

headline: For Desperate Souls, a Last Chance No More
text: A suicidal New Yorker picks up the phone. He dials the number of the city’s oldest crisis-intervention hotline, HelpLine, in a last-ditch effort to save himself. Instead of a concerned counselor, what he hears at the other end is a recorded voice saying: “You have reached HelpLine. Due to extenuating circumstances, this program is no longer in operation.” The voice then refers callers to 311 or 911.

headline: The Making, and Unmaking, of a Child Soldier
text: Sometimes I feel that living in New York City, having a good family and friends, and just being alive is a dream, that perhaps this second life of mine isn’t really happening. Whenever I speak at the United Nations, Unicef or elsewhere to raise awareness of the continual and rampant recruitment of children in wars around the world, I come to realize that I still do not fully understand how I could have possibly survived the civil war in my country, Sierra Leone.

headline: Out of Africa: Cotton and Cash
text: Lira, Uganda

headline: A Real-World AIDS Vaccine?
text: Last month, scientists invented the AIDS vaccine. Missed it? Perhaps that’s because you were still seeking the vaccine fantasy: the magic bullet, the impenetrable shield that finally pitches this disease into the trash bin, the shot that will end not only the AIDS epidemic but our anxiety about the AIDS epidemic as well.

headline: Lights, Camera, Honey Cookies: A Soap Opera, Greek Style
text: Film crews seem to blanket New York these days, and on a balmy afternoon early this month, one of them was shooting in a most unlikely place: the concrete backyard of a two-story brick house on 23rd Street in Astoria.

headline: Children’s Books
text: The great art of etiquette was invented to translate the incoherent jumble of human feelings to which we are all subject into something more presentable.” So says Judith Martin, a k a Miss Manners, our greatest living philosopher, and it is no mistake that this definition sounds very much like child-rearing. Babies are born rude, and it is their keepers’ duty to transform them from loud houseguests making outrageous demands at all hours of the night to charming people who might make some babies themselves. Etiquette is both method and model for this transformation, and teaching presentable behavior to one’s chattel is thus a noble endeavor.

headline: For Top Executives, a Need to Be Aware of the Nearest Exit
text: Being a chief executive has many perks, but job security is not one of them, especially now. A record total of 1,478 chief executive departures were announced last year at United States-based companies, 12 percent more than in 2005.

headline: Correction: Elegant Surprises on Both Sides of the Rio Grande
text: A picture caption on Dec. 31 with an article on restaurants in El Paso, N.M., and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, misstated the name of a restaurant in Ciudad Juárez. As the article noted, it is Martino, not Marino.

headline: Private Equity Deals? Join the Club
text: PRIVATE equity firms have been teaming up in leveraged buyouts of larger publicly traded companies. Justin B. Wender, president of Castle Harlan, a private equity firm in New York that specializes in retailing and restaurants, analyzed the trend in a recent conversation. Here are excerpts:

headline: British Interiors
text: “Nationality and class have been replaced by lifestyle,” a new manifesto declares. “People find their place in the world through intelligence and taste.” The author of this treatise is Ian Schrager, better known as a hotelier than as a political theorist — and, on closer inspection, his proclamation proves to be a sales brochure for a condominium project. One suspects that luxury apartments aren’t quite the solution to class struggle Marx had in mind.

headline: Charter Schools: Don't Believe the Hype (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alyssa Feinsmith, Matthew Grodin
text: Alyssa Feinsmith, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Feinsmith of Cherry Hill, N.J., is to be married this evening to Matthew Lawrence Grodin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Grodin of Aurora, Ohio. Rabbi Joshua Skoff is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton Cleveland.

headline: Victory for Ortmeyer and the Rangers
text: If Jed Ortmeyer needed any reminder of how far he has come this season, he received it yesterday the instant he slid a penalty shot past Boston goalie Tim Thomas and sealed a 3-1 victory over the Bruins.

headline: It’s All Happening Downstairs
text: WHAT with the vast, labyrinthine subway system, building superintendents who live in basement apartments and businesses squeezed into microscopic spaces down narrow stairs, New Yorkers may spend more time underground than anyone else in America, with the possible exception of fallout-shelter inspectors.

headline: He’s in the Bunker Now
text: PRESIDENT BUSH always had one asset he could fall back on: the self-confidence of a born salesman. Like Harold Hill in “The Music Man,” he knew how to roll out a new product, however deceptive or useless, with conviction and stagecraft. What the world saw on Wednesday night was a defeated Willy Loman who looked as broken as his war. His flop sweat was palpable even if you turned down the sound to deflect despair-inducing phrases like “Prime Minister Maliki has pledged ...” and “Secretary Rice will leave for the region. ...”

headline: Swiss Tax Deals Lure the Superrich, but Are They Fair?
text: PARIS, Jan. 13 — In the dark of winter, the French rock ’n’ roll icon Johnny Hallyday has abandoned France to settle in a snow-dusted mountain chalet, joining a scattered flock of superrich tax refugees in serene Switzerland.

headline: New High in ’06 on Borrowing for Pet Projects
text: ALBANY, Jan. 13 — For months, the state capital has been consumed by talk of state and federal investigations into the legislative pet projects known as member items.

headline: Now, Big-Name Retail Chains Will Take the Other Boroughs, Too
text: They have saturated much of Manhattan so completely that their ubiquity has become fodder for jokes on television. Now chain stores are rapidly spreading into parts of New York City that had long been left to local merchants.

headline: Uninviting or Idyllic? A Redesign Airs Old Disputes
text: For admirers of the Soldiers’ and Sailors’ Monument at 89th Street and Riverside Drive, the grand old days seem to be coming back. The Memorial Day ceremonies at the 105-year-old monument, which had petered out by the 1990s, have been revived. And Gale Brewer, the City Council member who represents the area, has committed $650,000 in city money to a redesign of the potholed asphalt plaza south of the monument, with its three Civil War-era cannons.

headline: Losing Iraq, One Truckload at a Time
text: Fort Benning, Ga.

headline: The Week on Long Island
text: Suffolk Seeks Ways to Ease School Taxes

headline: Anytown, Online
text: BEFORE the days of the printing press, town squares served as the main forum for exchanging community news and gossip. Now comes the virtual town square.

headline: Bode Miller’s Dazzling, All-Out Run Wins the Lauberhorn Downhill
text: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 13  Bode Miller won the Lauberhorn downhill Saturday, crashing across the finish line to become the fourth American man to win in the event’s colorful 77-year history.

headline: Colts Push Onward in Playoffs, Advancing 3 Points at a Time
text: BALTIMORE, Jan. 13 — The Indianapolis Colts, the team of Peyton Manning and the franchise that once had the legendary quarterback Johnny Unitas, probably never thought they would rely on a formula like this to win in the playoffs: Let the defense stop the opponent, have the place-kicker score all the points, and hope the offense does not make too many mistakes.

headline: Notes for a Soul Mate
text: AH, the sweet sound of personal regrets, of squandered talents, of if onlys, of what might have beens. It is a siren song to which no one is immune, a fantasy ballet in which you are always prima, in which your dying swan always draws unprecedented applause.

headline: Connecting the Global Warming Dots
text: If thought of as a painting, the scientific picture of a growing and potentially calamitous human influence on the climate has moved from being abstract a century ago to impressionistic 30 years ago to pointillist today.

headline: When Those Blue Chips Aren’t Made in the U.S.A.
text: MANY investors have been heeding market strategists’ advice to reduce portfolio risk by putting more money into stable, high-quality, dividend-paying stocks.

headline: Correction: The Doctor Is In
text: An article last Sunday about the NewYork-Presbyterian Healthcare System referred incorrectly to the history of hospitals that was chronicled in “The Care of Strangers: The Rise of America’s Hospital System,” by Charles E. Rosenberg. The number of hospitals in the United States grew from only two in 1800, according to the book; there were not only two in the early 1900s. And a census of hospitals in 1909, not 1920, showed more than 4,300 hospitals housing more than 420,000 beds.

headline: Snug and Warm on Restaurant Row
text: EMME of Capri, on Stamford’s restaurant row (Summer Street), is so small you may pass it so quickly you’ll have to backtrack.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: Bush and Cheney Rebuff Critics of Iraq Troop Increase
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 — President Bush, facing sharp and widespread opposition to his plan to send more troops to Iraq, insists that he has the authority to do so even without the approval of Congress.

headline: Designing a Starter Town House With a Twist
text: WHEN Andrew C. Friedman, a Manhattan architect known for his elaborate (and expensive) classical residences, chose a nondescript little brick and fake-stone building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn to redesign, he already knew the kind of urban couple he imagined there — and they were very different from his usual clients.

headline: Amber Fields of Bland
text: Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Elation Greets Recovery of 2 Boys After Abduction
text: UNION, Mo., Jan. 13 — On Thursday evening, they were captives in the same tiny two-bedroom apartment in suburban St. Louis. Abducted four years apart, William Ownby and Shawn Hornbeck were freed on Friday, and they smiled sheepishly on Saturday as their families held back-to-back news conferences to discuss their boys’ astonishing rescue.

headline: They Say We Have Too Many Lawsuits? Tell It to Jack Cline
text: Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Conducting Electricity, and Idolatry
text: AS the sixth cycle of “American Idol” begins on Tuesday, the show’s producers say they expect that at some point during the season something will go wrong. Indeed they are counting on it: “There’s kind of a train-crash mentality,” an executive producer, Ken Warwick, said.

headline: A Nomad Finds a Home
text: AFTER finishing law school, Isabel Hidrobo found herself in a string of temporary living situations. She spent four unsettled years moving among shares and sublets.

headline: Picking Up the Pieces
text: It was surreal how disconnected President Bush was the other night, both from Iraq’s horrifying reality and America’s anguish over this unnecessary, mismanaged and now unwinnable war. Indeed, most Americans seem far ahead of the president. They understand that what the country urgently needs is for Mr. Bush to chart a way out of Iraq that also limits the chaos that will be left behind.

headline: Meow
text: Fashion’s fascination with spotted cats has a new canvas this winter, the handbag. In exotic patterns, some unknown in nature, most are printed or stenciled on fabric or calfskin and, thankfully, the real thing is as rare as a snow leopard. A few women are spotted from hat to shoes, and the occasional dog wears cat’s clothing, too.

headline: Jets Assistant to Leave for Notre Dame
text: Corwin Brown, the Jets’ defensive back coach for the past three seasons, will become the defensive coordinator at Notre Dame, according to published reports.

headline: House of the Setting Sun
text: It’s bad form, probably, to wish ill of the aged, but golly it would be gratifying to load all of the geezers in Tim Sandlin’s new comic novel onto a spaceship and blast them into orbit around some other planet.

headline: Hotels Go Hi-Tech to Help Their Guests Get Out and About
text: The latest trend among upscale hotels is no longer amenities that keep guests inside the hotel (WiFi, plasma screen TVs, DVD players) but rather gadgets encouraging them to leave.

headline: Southeast Asians Agree to Trade Zone
text: CEBU, the Philippines, Jan. 13 — The Association of Southeast Asian Nations made progress toward its goal of economic and political integration at a summit meeting here on Saturday, but it was sidetracked by tensions over how to deal with Myanmar, which has come under fire for its poor human rights record.

headline: Nice and Ambitious: Either, Neither or Both?
text: THE POWER OF NICE

headline: Two Media Superstars Head for Warmer Climes
text: LONDON

headline: Celebrating a Chinese Heritage, With Nods to New York
text: JAMES KAPLAN, the chief executive of Tai Ping, a high-end carpet company based in Hong Kong, knew exactly what he didn’t want when he began to think of a United States headquarters and flagship showroom. There would be no piles of smelly rugs on the floor and no pushy sales representatives, and the space wouldn’t be in a building with other rug wholesalers. When architects and designers stepped into the new showroom, they might not know immediately what was for sale, but they would know it was luxurious.

headline: Saints Give City Reason to Cheer
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 — It seems the more blows New Orleans absorbs, the more it turns its affections toward the Saints.

headline: Organic David, Organic Goliath
text: At the back of the Fourth Street Food Co-op, past the rotting floorboards, cardboard boxes of gold blush apples, and bins of green mung beans and dried mangoes, Dion Workman, a composer from Williamsburg, was pouring bags of goji berries into a new glass display jar.

headline: In Politics, Friends for Vintners?
text: Since politics in Albany and Washington inevitably have an impact on vintners, 2007 is likely to see changes that will ultimately affect how consumers — local, state and national — perceive Long Island wines.

text: To the Editor:
