It was nearly a full-time job for Jagr, staying on the ice for double shifts or jumping out early, all for a few precious seconds without Devils forward Jay Pandolfo hounding him.

headline: Even Free, the Price Wasn’t Right
text: Yum Brands, the fast-food conglomerate, wanted to buy property for a Taco Bell in Norfolk, Va., on the site of a former appliance store.

headline: France: Now There Are Three
text: René Riffaud, one of just four known surviving French veterans of World War I, died at the age of 108, according to the national veterans office. His existence was unknown to the authorities until last year, when he emerged from obscurity to claim veteran status under pressure from relatives. Nationwide commemorations are expected at the death of the last member of the group.

headline: White House Says Judiciary Will Monitor Spy Program
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Bush administration, in what appears to be a concession to its critics, said today it will allow an independent court to monitor its warrantless electronic-eavesdropping program.

headline: As Raids on Afghan Border Increase, U.S. Military Seeks More Troops
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 16 — Attacks by militants crossing into Afghanistan from Pakistan have tripled since September along portions of the border, a senior American intelligence official said Tuesday, prompting calls for a greater effort by Pakistan to curb the influx and a larger deployment of American and other NATO soldiers here.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in the Itineraries pages of Business Day yesterday about finding places to eat while traveling for business misstated the name of a Web site that offers restaurant information. It is www.fodors.com, not www.fodor.com.

headline: Record Year Followed by Record Deal
text: The sale of the 41-story skyscraper at 666 Fifth Avenue for $1.8 billion  a record price for an office building in Manhattan  closed last week, and the deal is symbolic of the red-hot demand from big investors for commercial properties.

headline: Israeli and Syrian Citizens Wrote Plan for Returning Golan Heights
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16 — Prominent private citizens from Israel and Syria drafted a document in secret, unofficial talks that calls for returning the Golan Heights to Syria and offers a possible outline for peace negotiations, one of the participants said Tuesday.

headline: John W. Simpson, 92, Dies; Pioneer of Nuclear Power
text: John W. Simpson, a former top executive and engineer for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation who played a major role in developing the nation’s first commercial nuclear power plant and its first nuclear-powered submarine, the U.S.S. Nautilus, died Jan. 4 near his home on Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 92.

headline: Britain: Terrorism Suspect on the Run
text: The government said a terrorism suspect had absconded after being served with what is known as a control order, a form of house arrest that would require him to report daily to the police, surrender his travel documents and reside at an address known to the authorities. The man was not identified by name, but John Reid, the home secretary, said he “had recently been radicalized and wanted to travel abroad for terrorism-related purposes.” Mr. Reid said the man was not seen as “a direct threat to the public in the United Kingdom.”

headline: As Trial Begins, Cheney’s Ex-Aide Is Still a Puzzle
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 — Paradox seems to define I. Lewis Libby Jr., who remains a bit mysterious even to close colleagues. He is the White House policy enforcer who also wrote a literary novel; a buttoned-down Washington lawyer who likes knocking back tequila shots in cowboy bars and hurtling down mountains on skis and bikes; and a 56-year-old intellectual known to all by his childhood nickname, Scooter.

headline: Naomi Pleads Guilty to Tossing Phone at Maid
text: Naomi Campbell apologized yesterday for hitting her maid in the head with a cellphone, but said it was an accident.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 6 about White House efforts to find a new chief counsel misstated the working status of Laurence H. Silberman of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, who was considered a contender for the job. On Nov. 1, 2000, he took senior status, which allows a judge to continue to serve while handling fewer cases than a judge in active service; he has not retired. (President Bush has since named Fred F. Fielding to be the White House counsel.)

headline: NBC’s ‘Today’ Is Expected to Add a Fourth Hour
text: Meredith Vieira won’t appear on it at all, and Matt Lauer will make only an occasional cameo, if that, but NBC is expected to announce formally today that it will expand “Today,” its morning-program empire and the most profitable program on television, to a fourth hour, beginning at 10 a.m. on weekdays next fall.

headline: Gay Lawyer’s Suit Accuses Firm of Bias
text: An associate at one of the country’s most prestigious law firms, Sullivan & Cromwell, filed a state lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday accusing the firm of a systematic campaign of discrimination and retaliation against him because of his sexual orientation.

headline: The Food Pyramid Takes Its Show on the Road
text: New Run at the Dietary Guidelines

headline: J.P. Morgan’s Income Soared in 4th Quarter
text: Net income at J.P. Morgan Chase soared by 68 percent in the fourth quarter, the company reported today. Record-high profits in its investment-banking advisory businesses and vast improvement in its trading results were the reasons, the company said.

headline: Senate Passes Disclosure Measure
text: The Senate voted 98 to 0 to require public disclosure of the sponsors of pet projects known as earmarks, attaching the provision to broader ethics legislation. The vote came on an amendment sponsored by Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, that is similar to a provision approved by the House on Jan. 5. It would prevent lawmakers from anonymously inserting special projects or tax breaks for companies into spending legislation.

headline: Court Vacates Term of Algerian in Bomb Plot
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16  A federal appeals court on Tuesday vacated the 2005 sentence of an Algerian man convicted of plotting to bomb Los Angeles International Airport.

headline: Recipe: Black-Skinned Chicken Soup
text: Adapted from Yvonne Wong

headline: Achieving His Goal, Reese Gazes Even Higher
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 16 — Jerry Reese, standing on a raised platform and sandwiched between bright spotlights and a backdrop of Giants logos, laughed when he considered just how it was that he got here.

headline: Family Life and Other Hazards as Refracted in a Jaundiced Eye
text: “The Vietnamization of New Jersey,” Christopher Durang’s 1977 satire of the arrogant American character, the hypocrisy of middle class family life, consumerism and the branding of just about everything, seems, in retrospect, to have been about more than all that. What seems clear now is that it embodied, as well, a particular prescience about where late-20th-century television would head — or perhaps it even informed that direction.

headline: Finding Faith, and Responsibility, After Making a New Start
text: When William McKinney showed up at church one Sunday more than a decade ago, he said he was open to anything that would help him make a fresh start.

headline: Opposition to Bush’s War Plan Is Mounting
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — A prominent Senate Republican joined senior Democrats today in sponsoring a resolution against the Bush administration’s troop buildup in Iraq. But the White House said it would not let its hands be tied.

headline: Comptroller Raises $524,000 in Undeclared Bid for Mayor
text: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. raised nearly $524,000 in the last six months, giving him a sizable lead in fund-raising among the potential 2009 mayoral candidates, according to campaign finance disclosures released yesterday.

headline: Immigrant Centers Inspected
text: A federal inspection of 5 of the nation’s 325 immigrant detention centers found that most did not provide timely and responsive health care and sometimes failed to comply with the government’s standards of disciplining, classifying and housing detainees. The audit by the Department of Homeland Security also found a rape of a detainee in one center and a failure to provide access to legal services in another. Three centers did not translate handbooks into Spanish and other languages. Homeland security officials said the study was too small to be representative of the country’s detention centers.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about a gun battle on Jan. 3 between the police and Islamic extremists in Tunisia misstated the name of a militant Islamic political party that has risen in popularity as part of a religious resurgence across North Africa. The party, based in Egypt, is the Muslim Brotherhood, not Islamic Brotherhood.

headline: Bloomberg Plans to Cut New York’s Property Taxes
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is proposing to cut property taxes by roughly 5 percent and eliminate the city sales tax on clothing and footwear as New York enjoys the bounty from its booming economy and real estate market, city officials said yesterday.

headline: Budget Reform Pact Augurs a More Transparent Albany
text: ALBANY, Jan. 16 — It sounds logical enough: New York State should be required to pass balanced budgets. The budget should not include blank checks to state officials, in the form of giant lump sums to be divvied up later in secret. And lawmakers should have to explain the fiscal impact of the changes they make to the budget.

headline: $300,000 Homes
text: Tour a condo on the Gulf Coast of Alabama, a farmhouse near Maine’s Acadia National Park and a loft in Portland, Ore.

headline: Microsoft's Radical Redesign
Fedora Style
text: Old hat? Not on a young head.

headline: Obama Statement on Iraq
text: The following is a statment released by Senator Barack Obama's office Wednesday.

headline: Lighting Your Way
text: Gear test with Paul Romero, adventure racer.

headline: Regulators Are Examining Commerce Bank
text: Commerce Bancorp, which calls itself “America’s most convenient bank,” rattled investors Tuesday after it disclosed that federal regulators were investigating the bank’s real estate deals with executives. Shares of Commerce fell 8.3 percent, or $2.89, to $31.83, after the bank said the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve were conducting an inquiry. Commerce has become one of the fastest-growing banks in the nation, thanks in part to its extended branch hours, and has made an aggressive and successful push into New York’s crowded banking market. Commerce, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said, “The scope of the investigation will include but not be limited to transactions with its officers, directors and related parties, including transactions involving bank premises.”

headline: Icahn Takes Aim at Drug and Housing Companies
text: Carl C. Icahn is at it again. The billionaire investor has set his activist sights on two new targets, building stakes in the companies because he believes the shares are undervalued. Mr. Icahn now has a 14.57 percent stake in WCI Communities, a developer of housing in Florida, and has increased his holdings in Telik, an unprofitable developer of cancer and diabetes drugs, to 9.92 percent.

headline: Ex-Owner at Refco Charged in Fraud Case
text: A former owner of Refco, the commodities brokerage firm, was charged Tuesday in a fraud that cost investors more than $1 billion in losses, prosecutors said as they also added charges against the former chief executive and chief financial officers of the firm. Tone N. Grant, 62, of Chicago, a former owner of Refco, was charged with bank fraud and money laundering along with the former chief executive, Phillip R. Bennett, 58, of Gladstone, N.J., and the former finance chief, Robert C. Trosten, 37, of Sarasota, Fla.

headline: Gerson Lehrman Under a New York Inquiry
text: The battle to be Wall Street’s top matchmaker is getting messier. The New York State attorney general’s office is investigating whether employees at Best Buy, Circuit City and the credit card processor First Data improperly provided nonpublic information to hedge fund traders, according to media reports.

headline: Goldmans Sachs Agrees to Acquire Insurance Broker
text: The buyout unit of Goldman Sachs has agreed to acquire the insurance brokerage firm USI Holdings for about $1.4 billion including debt. The Goldman unit, GS Capital Partners, will pay $17 a share, USI said Tuesday. The offer represents a 21 percent premium over the average closing share price in the 30 days before Oct. 24, the day USI announced that it had formed a committee to review a possible takeover. USI is based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

headline: 2 Years in Prison for Ex-Software Executive
text: The former general counsel at Computer Associates, Steven Woghin, was sentenced on Tuesday to two years in prison for his role in a scheme to increase the software maker’s quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts, prosecutors said. At a hearing in Brooklyn, Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court also sentenced Mr. Woghin to three years of supervised release. Several former executives at the company, now known as CA, including the former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, have pleaded guilty to criminal charges.

headline: Ex-Fund Trader Sentenced to Probation
text: A former Millennium Partners mutual fund trader who pleaded guilty to improper trading in 2003 avoided a prison term after cooperating with a New York State investigation of the mutual fund industry. The former trader, Steven Markovitz, 44, was sentenced to five years’ probation Tuesday after pleading guilty to violating New York’s General Business Law, a felony, by trading in mutual funds from late 2001 to July 2003 after markets had closed.

headline: Two Charged in Payments From Wagers on Internet
text: Two founders of a company that processes Internet gambling transactions were arrested and charged with laundering billions of dollars in gambling proceeds, federal prosecutors announced Tuesday. The charges were filed against John David Lefebvre, 55, and Stephen Eric Lawrence, 46, who founded the company, Neteller, in 1999, in two criminal complaints unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Monday, Michael J. Garcia, a United States attorney, said in a statement.

headline: G.M. Discloses Talks for Deal in Malaysia
text: General Motors has been in talks with Proton Holdings, the Malaysian carmaker that is looking to sell a stake, G.M.’s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said Tuesday night. “There have been conversations, not extensive,” Wagoner told reporters after a speech in Dearborn, Mich., last night. “It’s very early to handicap the potential outcome.” G.M. is interested in Proton because it is underrepresented in Malaysia, Southeast Asia’s largest auto market. G.M., the world’s largest automaker, is focusing growth on 11 emerging markets, including Malaysia, India and China, as its domestic sales shrink, Mr. Wagoner said.

headline: Landry’s Fields Offer for Smith & Wollensky
text: Landry’s Restaurants said Tuesday that it had made a $64.4 million offer to buy the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, whose original steakhouse is a New York City institution and a favorite of the likes of Warren Buffett. Smith & Wollensky, whose shares soared 45 percent, to $7.29, said it had formed a special committee to review the $7.50 per share offer. Shares of Landry’s, which operates the Landry’s Seafood House, Chart House and Rainforest Cafe restaurants, also got a boost, rising more than 2.5 percent to $31. The Smith & Wollensky Group operates its namesake steakhouses as well as Maloney & Porcelli, Post House, Park Avenue Cafe and Quality Meats.

headline: Norwest Outsources $20 Million to Adventity
text: Norwest Venture Partners has invested $20 million in India-focused Adventity, which provides high-end research and analytics to the investment banking, mortgage and financial services industries. The investment closes the second round of financing for Adventity and marks the first funding received from an institutional source. Based in New York, most of Adventity’s operations are in India. With more than 2,000 employees, Adventity serves several global investment banks, management consulting firms and some of the largest hedge funds. The funding is one of several investments by Norwest in second-generation services, or business processes that are not traditionally outsourced.

headline: E-Mail Start-Up Gets Cash to Take on Microsoft
text: Going head-to-head with Microsoft is a risky business strategy, but investors in a mail server technology developer, PostPath are confident enough to give the company an additional $15 million. The Series C financing for PostPath closed in late December and was led by a new investor, Jafco Ventures. Two previous investors Matrix Partners and Worldview Technology Partners also participated in the financing, which brings the company’s total funding to $30 million. PostPath has developed a Linux-based exchange server that integrates fully with Microsoft’s own Exchange server.

headline: Historians Appeal ‘Da Vinci Code’ Case
text: The two historians who lost their plagiarism case against the British publishers of the best seller “The Da Vinci Code” by Dan Brown turned to the Court of Appeal in Britain yesterday in an effort to reverse their loss in a case that also saddles them with a legal bill of more than $2 million, The Associated Press reported. Lawyers for the historians, Michael Baigent and Richard Leigh, argued that the “vast amount of skill and labor” they expended in writing their book “The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail,” first published in 1982, is “protectable.” They contend that Mr. Brown stole significant parts of it for his novel. Both books are based on the theory that Jesus and Mary Magdalene married and had a child, and that the bloodline continues to this day. In April, Justice Peter Smith ruled that Random House had not breached the copyright of “The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail,” and Mr. Baigent and Mr. Leigh were ordered to pay 85 percent of Random House’s legal bill, estimated at $2.6 million. In a statement, Random House expressed regret “that more time and money is being spent trying to establish a case that was so comprehensively defeated in the High Court.”

headline: EMI and Baidu in Chinese Duet
text: The Chinese search engine Baidu.com and EMI Music are teaming up in an Internet venture that will let users listen to streaming music free, adding to Baidu’s growing entertainment business. Under the terms of the the venture, announced Tuesday, EMI will make its Chinese pop music available on Baidu’s Web site. Baidu, which has more than 60 percent of China’s online search market, has been expanding entertainment offerings in an effort to compete with Web sites that combine search with entertainment and games, financial analysts say.

headline: Time Runs Out on Bid for N.B.A.’s Grizzlies
text: The Memphis Grizzlies are back on the block after a deadline passed for a group led by a former Duke University player, Brian Davis, to assemble a $252 million deal. The window for the Grizzlies Acquisition Holdings, Mr. Davis’s acquisition vehicle, to negotiate exclusively for the 70 percent stake owned by a Chicago billionaire, Michael Heisley, expired on Monday. Mr. Heisley, a turnaround specialist , told the Memphis Commercial Appeal that the team is still for sale — to Davis, to the team’s local minority-share investors or to someone else making an “acceptable” offer for the team, which has the NBA’S worst record. ‘He wasn’t able to get all of his financing together,’ Mr. Heisley told The Deal. ‘He was able to get some of it. If Mr. Davis comes up with the money, we’ll sell him the team.’

headline: Court Lifts Hurdle to E.ON’s Bid for Endesa
text: A Spanish court lifted the final injunction Tuesday to an offer by the German utility E.ON for Endesa of Spain, a potentially groundbreaking merger that has become one of Europe’s longest-running takeover battles. The court’s decision allows E.ON to move forward with its 36.5 billion euro, or $47.1 billion, bid for Endesa, which is also being pursued by Gas Natural, another Spanish energy concern. That combination is backed by the Spanish government, which would like to see the creation of a national energy champion. Meanwhile, a Spanish building conglomerate, Acciona, has also steadily built up a 21 percent stake in Endesa, but it has not moved to secure full control.

headline: Dresdner and Gazprom team Up on Emissions Venture
text: Gazprom’s banking unit has set up an emissions trading venture with Dresdner Bank to take advantage of the growing market for securities linked to greenhouse-gas quotas under the Kyoto Protocol, the companies said Tuesday. The company, Carbon Trade & Finance Sicar, will invest in projects that earn emissions credits by reducing pollution, and will trade the credits and securities linked to the credits.

headline: Millennial Media Rings Up $6.3 Million in Funding
text: Millennial Media, a mobile-advertising services company started by a former Verizon executive, has received $6.3 million in Series A funding, CNet News.com reported. The funding comes from Bessemer Venture Partner, an investor in companies such as Blue Nile, Skype and VeriSign; Columbia Capital, an investor in Mobi, Nextel and XM Satellite Radio; and Acta Wireless.

headline: Fearing a Fire Sale, Mills Investors Offer to Lend a Hand
text: Two major shareholders of Mills each offered a plan to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the troubled shopping-mall developer to help it pay off heavy debt and stave off potential bankruptcy. The hedge fund Farallon Capital Partners proposed a $499 million recapitalization plan for Mills, while the Israeli real estate firm Gazit-Globe offered a new, $1.8 billion version of an offer it made last year.

headline: Currents
text: What home may look like if you're unusually tall or wide, a muscular design in the marble and more.

headline: As Fast as Merill Can Make It, O’Neal Is Is Spending It
text: As Merrill Lynch prepares to announce Thursday what analysts expect will be its most profitable year ever, its chief executive will continue to spend those record-breaking profits to make acquisitions to stay competitive, Bloomberg News said. The chief, E. Stanley O’Neal, is expected to eye investments in commodities and mortgage-bond trading in efforts to catch up with Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers, respectively.

headline: Gay Lawyer Accuses Top Firm of Discrimination
text: An associate at one of the country’s most prestigious law firms, Sullivan & Cromwell, filed a state lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday accusing the firm of a systematic campaign of discrimination and retaliation against him because of his sexual orientation. The associate, Aaron B. Charney, 28, asserts in the lawsuit, filed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, that several partners in Sullivan & Cromwell’s highly regarded mergers and acquisitions practice subjected him to “lewd and illegal conduct,” beginning in the fall of 2005. He is seeking a jury trial and unspecified compensatory and punitive damages.

headline: Even Free, the Price Wasn’t Right
text: In an unusual tale of a real-estate acquisition, Yum Brands, the fast-food conglomerate, wanted to buy property for a Taco Bell in Norfolk, Va., and the owner offered to give it away. On one condition.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Reclaimed or antique, a stump can be used as an end table.

headline: Wednesday Morning Excerpts
text: The weekend of football wouldn’t be complete without some analysis from Gregg Easterbrook in Tuesday Morning Quarterback . Click here for the full column. Here are a few excerpts:

headline: Deja-Vu: Cablevision Board Rejects Offer by the Dolans
text: The board of Cablevision Systems rejected an $8.9 billion offer Tuesday to sell the company to the Dolans, its founding family. The rebuff was a rare example of a board standing up to and denying a request by a controlling shareholder. The rejection by the board, which set up a special committee to review the Dolans’ proposal, is the second time it has refused to sell the company to the family.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Regulators Fine Specialists
text: The regulatory arm of the New York Stock Exchange said Tuesday that it had fined seven specialist firms a combined $2.8 million for trading violations. NYSE Regulation said that the specialists violated the so-called “firm quote” rule. The rule requires specialist firms execute buy or sell orders that are presented to them at prices that are at least as favorable as the N.Y.S.E.’s published bid or offer at the time the orders enter the N.Y.S.E.’s electronic-display book. The specialists also were censured.

headline: Day of Reckoning for Former Cendant Chief
text: The final chapter in one of the longest-running sagas of corporate crime is scheduled to conclude Wednesday in a Connecticut courtroom. Walter Forbes, the blue-blooded former chairman of Cendant, is set to be sentenced for his role in a $252 million accounting fraud that was exposed nearly a decade ago. At the time, the Cendant fraud was the largest on record, and its exposure in April 1998 wiped out $14 billion of the company’s market capitalization, nearly half its total, in a single day.

headline: Encore Buys Anadarko Wyoming Properties
text: The oil and gas producer Encore Acquisition said on Wednesday that it would pay $400 million in cash to buy oil and natural gas properties in Wyoming from Anadarko Petroleum. The properties include the Elk Basin Unit and the Gooseberry Unit in Park County, Wyo., and Encore expects them to generate about $50 million in cash flow a year in 2007 and 2008. The transaction is expected to close in March, Encore said.

headline: Brady vs. Manning Column Contest
text: No self-respecting blog would miss a chance to address a debate that has been brewing for years, especially with the Patriots and the Colts meeting Sunday.

headline: Tribune: All Dressed Up and No One to Bid?
text: Tribune, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, the Los Angeles Times and Newsday, appears to have thrown a takeover party where no one showed up. With the deadline for final bids today, the private-equity firms that have been meeting with Tribune’s management and looking over its financial records for the past several months do not plan to submit final offers, according to The New York Post.

headline: The Nuremberg Hangings — Not So Smooth Either
text: Before we set aside the topic of Iraq’s botched hangings, which continue to cause a fair bit of consternation there, a reader reminds us to flash back to 1946, and the conclusion of the trials at Nuremberg, in which 11 high-ranking Nazi officers were ultimately condemned to death by hanging. One of them, Hermann Göring, managed to finish himself in his cell with a cyanide capsule just hours before the execution was to take place, but the others took their trip to the gallows.

headline: EADS May Seek Funding to Buoy Airbus
text: The European aerospace giant EADS, the parent company of Airbus, said on Tuesday it might ask shareholders for permission to go to the financial markets to raise funds. “The question is whether it is possible that we will ask the AGM for authorization to go to the market,” EADS’ finance chief, Hans Peter Ring, said at a press conference. “The answer is ‘yes’, it is possible.”

headline: As Tomlinson Looks Back, the Patriots Look to the Colts
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 17 — New England Coach Bill Belichick is apparently worried about getting to the Super Bowl again, not about LaDainian Tomlinson's feelings.

headline: J.P. Morgan Reports A Record 4th-Quarter
text: Helped by gains from investment banking and trading, J.P. Morgan Chase posted a profit of $3.91 billion, or $1.09 a share, for its fourth quarter of 2006, capping its most profitable year ever. The numbers were up from $2.64 billion a year earlier, exceeding the $2.64 billion from a year ago and beating analysts’ expectations of 94 cents a share. J.P. Morgan’s windfall arrives as other Wall Street rivals like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley boasted of similarly outsized returns.

headline: Colts Confident of Solving Brady
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 17 — Tom Brady has an impeccable reputation for postseason heroics. But when the Colts beat the Patriots in November, Brady threw four interceptions. And when the Patriots beat the Chargers last week, Brady was picked off three times.

headline: Cerberus Drops Out of Equity Office Bidding Group
text: Cerberus Capital Management dropped out of a consortium considering a rival offer for the Equity Office Properties Group, according to news reports. The group, which still includes Vornado Realty Trust, Barry Sternlicht’s Starwood Capital and Leon Bluhm’s Walton Street Capital, has been scrambling to put together an offer for Equity Office that would top its agreement last year to be sold for $36 billion to the Blackstone Group. Without Cerberus, it is unclear whether the consortium will be able to mount an offer.

headline: Bears' Grossman Turns Defensive
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan 17 — The person at the lectern looked like Rex Grossman, but when he started answering questions Wednesday at Halas Hall, his bearing became so wooden it was as if he was a puppet and somebody was throwing his voice.

headline: G.E. Near Deal for Abbott’s Diagnostic Unit
text: General Electric was near a deal last night to buy the medical diagnostic unit of Abbott Laboratories for more than $5 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

headline: Shrimp and Eggs
text: The Times food columnist Mark Bittman pairs shrimp and eggs in a delightful new brunch recipe.

headline: Once More Into the Breach, My Friends
text: The Bagger, at the behest of his betters, gasped out a last bit of Globes prose before hitting security at LAX. Just. One. More. Copy. Inch. Out. Of. The. Globes. Must keep typing.

headline: The War at Home: ‘Cracked Egg’
text: In a signal of how seriously the Bush administration is taking the task of quelling public doubts about the new ‘way forward,’ President Bush himself ventured over to PBS’s “The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer.” Here’s what he told the show’s host on the possibility of success:

headline: A Handicapping Handicap
text: For those of you who haven’t had your fill of prognostication, Kristopher Tapley turns over the upcoming guild awards with a stick and makes some picks at InContention.

headline: Mr. Ed’s Peculiar Brother
text: Jeffrey Wells talks about what happens when man and horse bond in new ways. “Zoo” will get a long look and a few stares when it premieres at Sundance. The film has a nickname that the Bagger, who works for a family newspaper, has somehow forgotten.

headline: Portrait Etched in Acid
text: Dan Klores has a day job spinning and pinning reporters as one of New York’s heavyweight flacks, if there is such a thing. But what he really wants to do is direct, and so he has. “Crazy Love,” is Klores’ fourth film, this time about one of the most obsessive relationships in the history of humankind. The Reeler talks to him about the film, his third outing as filmmaker at Sundance, and a play he has written in his spare time.

headline: A Different Boardroom Dance
text: There is a boardroom dance whose steps are known by most directors of companies with controlling shareholders.

headline: In Search of That Elusive New York Angle
text: New York magazine does a mega heave on Sundance, which includes pointing out that a walk up Main Street in Park City when the festival is at its height may seem like an average night in the Village. All the usual suspects will be here.

headline: Incoming
text: When the Bagger checked into his Sundance condo — well, he did it at three different places before someone actually gave him a key — the locals seemed friendly and correctly surmised that he wasn’t here to ski. Except that he is. One day this week the Bagger will take his inimitable downhill style — think bean-bag chair on skis — up to the top of the hill and see if Newton’s Laws will once again pull him to the bottom.

headline: Macabre Math on Iraq’s Death Toll
text: Blogger Marc Cooper finds a way to put the United Nations’ new tally of 2006 Iraqi war deaths – more than 34,000 – in perspective. “On a per capita basis,” he writes, “this death toll would add up in the U.S. to nearly 400,000 dead per year.”

headline: Bear Stearns Seeks to Expand — Literally
text: Bonus-flush investment bankers may be preparing to spend on pricey new real estate, and now it appears at least one of their companies will, too. Bear Stearns is close to signing a deal to drastically expand its midtown Manhattan location, The New York Observer reported Wednesday. After acquiring 240,000 square feet in two leases signed last year, the investment bank is looking to buy an additional 104,000 square feet at its 237 Park Ave. offices, the Observer said, citing three sources close to the deal. If completed, it would be the largest New York City lease of 2007 thus far.

headline: Clinton on Iraq … and Obama
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, just back from Iraq and Afghanistan, appeared this morning on NBC’s “Today” show, among others, and was to hold a news conference this afternoon about the trip with fellow travelers, Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana and Congressman John McHugh, Republican of New York.

headline: On the Hill: Spousal Privilege
text: The Senate voted 98-0 for a bill that would require public disclosure of earmark sponsors.

headline: Deconstructing Obama
text: Barack Obama’s pre-announcement of his 2008 presidential campaign took the form of a five-minute video biography. In his own video analysis, John Dickerson of Slate dissects the ad, pointing out how the announcement emphasizes the Illinois senator’s biography, his popularity and his experience as an underdog and de-emphasizes his short Senate record. One black-and-white photo, showing the young Obama in a black turtleneck and leather jacket, Dickerson says, “appears to be the cover picture from his first jazz album.”

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Historic Field
text: The 2008 Democratic field could turn out to form “one of the most historic and compelling races ever,” writes The Washington Post’s Dan Balz in an analysis, referring to the potential candidacies of Senators Barack Obama, who just formed an exploratory committee, and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Judy Keen of USA Today tries to answer Mr. Obama’s “Does he have enough experience?” question. The Fix profiles Mr. Obama’s inner circle.

headline: Text of the Resolution on Iraq Introduced by Joseph R. Biden, Carl Levin and Chuck Hagel
text: The text of the resolution on Iraq introduced Wednesday by Senators Joseph R. Biden of Delaware and Carl Levin of Michigan, both Democrats, and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, a Republican:

headline: The Short-er List
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced their short list for the Best Foreign Language Film award, choosing 9 films from the 61 submitted for consideration. In alphabetical order by country they are:

headline: Manhattan: Train-to-Plane Use Sets Record
text: A record number of passengers used trains to connect to Kennedy International Airport and Newark Liberty International Airport last year, officials at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Roughly 4 million people rode the train to Kennedy, an increase of about 15 percent over 2005, officials said; 1.6 million took the train to Newark Airport, a jump of about 8 percent.

headline: Newark: Man Charged in Fatal Shooting
text: An East Orange man already in custody on charges of setting his uncle on fire was charged with murder on Tuesday in the fatal shooting of a clothing store owner on Jan. 3, the police said yesterday. The man, Lamar A. Tidwell, 24, is charged with walking into the Clothing Wholesale and Retail Urban Warestore on Main Street and shooting the owner, Allen Cuff, 34. The men had argued a week earlier, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant Essex County prosecutor. Mr. Tidwell also faces weapons charges in that case. On Saturday he was charged with attempted murder; the authorities said he set fire to his uncle, Richard Burns, 54, in Mr. Burns’s apartment in East Orange after an argument. Mr. Burns suffered injuries over 22 percent of his body and was in critical condition yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. Mr. Tidwell is being held in $1 million bail at the Essex County jail.

headline: A House They Could Call Their Own
text: Money from the Neediest Cases fund is helping a familiy of nine move from a shelter, where they've lived for four years, and into a new apartment.

headline: Testing a Missile Shield for Airliners
text: A FedEx flight took off from LAX yesterday with a little something extra attached to its belly: an anti-missile system.

headline: Reader Responses
text: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt’s Jan. 17 column on the cost of the war in Iraq:

headline: The Latest Investment-Banking Bonus: A Life
text: Investment banks have long been known as the preserve of hundred-hour weeks, where leaving the office only to change clothes is considered a badge of honor. But according to Fortune, Wall Street is discovering that some of its best people don’t believe that being chained to the office is a mark of greatness — and are leaving for saner pastures. Now, Lehman Brothers and its rivals are turning to “return to work” recruitment programs to lure those employees back. The draw: lighter schedules and less travel.

headline: Mills to Be Sold to Brookfield for $1.35 Billion
text: Teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, it appears Mills has found its white knight. The developer of 38 malls throughout the United States said Wednesday morning that it had agreed to a $1.35 billion buyout by Brookfield Asset Management. Mills has struggled to repay loans that it took out as its business has shriveled and it bled cash. Last week, it said that it could be forced into bankruptcy over a loan from Goldman Sachs Mortgage that would come due at the end of March.

headline: The Accents Beyond the Plate
text: Do race and ethnicity play roles in the hiring and promotion of restaurant workers? Should they?

headline: Map: ‘No-Freedom Zones’
text: Online mapping seems to be all the rage lately for New York sites seeking to score political points and encourage activism. Yesterday it was a mashup of hospital closings in the city.

headline: Ex-Cendant Chairman Sentenced to 12 Years
text: The former chairman of Cendant, Walter Forbes, was sentenced Wednesday to 12 years and seven months in prison and ordered to pay $3.275 billion in restitution for leading the largest accounting fraud of the 1990’s. In October, a jury found Mr. Forbes guilty of conspiracy to commit securities fraud and two counts of making false statements in a massive fraud scheme that cost the travel and real estate company and its investors more than $3 billion. He was found not guilty of a fourth count, securities fraud.

headline: The End Is Nearer, Say Atomic Scientists
text: The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, which 60 years ago began keeping tabs on humanity’s temporal distance from self-annihilation with the concept of a “Doomsday Clock,” apparently found things sufficiently dire to nudge the minute hand forward two clicks, indicating that we are now “five minutes to midnight” — or Doomsday.

headline: As Districts Turn to Exotic Finances, Banks Reap Rewards
text: Cash-strapped public school districts and other local governments are increasingly making bets on arcane financial derivatives, often in hopes of quickly raising needed funds. But sometimes, as Bloomberg News recounts, those bets go awry. The schools suffer, but the financial firms clean up.

headline: Craig Johnson for …Something
text: Several readers have pointed out that Craig Johnson, the Democratic candidate for the vacant seat the State Senate, has a new campaign Web site.

headline: Speculating About the Energy Speculators
text: While some pundits may blame instability in the Middle East for the recent volatility of oil, and others may decry the machinations of Opec, BusinessWeek speculates that another party may be to blame as well: speculators. As hedge funds, investment banks and other institutional players crowd into the energy market, their trades could be magnifying otherwise small movements in prices and increasing volatility, Peter Fusaro of the Energy Hedge Fund Center told the magazine.

headline: Marty’s World
text: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president and potential mayoral aspirant, was in the spotlight this afternoon, introducing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the start of the mayor’s State of the City address, at the New York City Technical College in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Pulling a Fast One
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 15 column, “The Texas Strategy.”

headline: Vornado-Led Group Offers $52 a Share for Equity Office
text: A consortium of three real estate companies offered $52 a share for Equity Office Properties Trust after the market’s close Wednesday, stirring up what could be the most expensive buyout contest on record. The three companies — Vornado Realty, Starwood Capital and Walton Street Capital — hope to wrest control of Equity Office, the nation’s largest office-building manager and owner, from the Blackstone Group, which offered a record $36 billion in November, based on a $48 a share bid.

headline: Sinking Ever Lower
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 15 column, “Descending to New Depths.“

headline: Anna Maria, at Last
text: One of the things everyone in our family loves about my co-blogger (and wife) is that she has the ability to solve almost any problem. Even the world’s most obnoxious yellow lab knows this. He has a special sound he lets out when he has a problem — the pig ear has wedged itself under the couch — Buster yips and the trouble goes away.

headline: Radio Hosts Sacked for Wii Water Contest
text: Just to update the case of Jennifer Strange, who died of water intoxication last Friday after participating a contest sponsored by a local radio-station in Sacramento that required contestants to drink copious amounts of water in an attempt to win a Nintendo Wii game console. (We’ve had quite a heated debate in our forums on the issue of culpability here.)

headline: Who’s Going to Pay for All of This?
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 12 column, “Make Them Fight All of Us.”

headline: Help Wanted
text: Position: Payroll administrator

headline: ‘Subway Hero’ Returns
text: Wesley Autrey ought to have his own reality-television show.

headline: Fox Attending State of the Union
text: From the “Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner” Department: Michael J. Fox, the actor, Parkinson’s Disease patient and advocate for embryonic stem cell research, will be in the Capitol gallery when President Bush delivers his State of the Union address next week.

headline: Party of Two
text: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman’s critics frequently enjoy referring to him as a member of “the party of one.” His supporters created the Connecticut for Lieberman party solely so he could run in the general election after losing the Democratic primary last August.

headline: Senator Clinton and Iraq
text: After a trip to Iraq, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke out across Washington to stake out her position on the issue.

headline: The Price of Oil in Texas
text: In the history of accidents, the March 2005 explosion at BP’s Texas City, Tex., oil refinery might have been another Exxon Valdez — a catastrophe that changed the way we perceive and regulate the industry. But the BP disaster hasn’t captured the public’s imagination the way the 1989 Alaska oil spill did, even though the explosion killed 15 people and injured 180 more. Yesterday James Baker, the fix-it man for both the Iraq war and BP’s safety record, released a 374-page report on how BP’s corporate culture contributed to the disaster.

headline: Expert Ties Ex-Player’s Suicide to Brain Damage From Football
text: Andre Waters, the former N.F.L. player who committed suicide last fall, sustained at least 15 concussions during his playing career. After his death at the age of 44, tests revealed that Mr. Waters’s brain resembled that of an octogenarian Alzheimer’s patient.

headline: How Gentlemen Disagree
text: A few weeks ago, I singled out an especially poorly written, hostile e-mail from a 15-year-old named Josh to support my theory that in the Internet age, civility is an endangered species.

headline: The Elusive Altar
text: If all the world were south of 96th Street, what a happy place it would be! If all the world were south of 96th Street, then we could greet with unalloyed joy the news that after decades of social change, more American women are living without husbands than with them.

headline: A Ghastly Toll: 34,000 Iraqi Dead (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Justices Scrutinize Death Penalty in Texas
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — The Supreme Court on Wednesday resumed its long-running effort to monitor the use of the death penalty in Texas, hearing arguments in three cases that put the strains and internal contradictions of the court’s capital punishment jurisprudence fully on display.

headline: Beauty of a String Trio, Free of Distractions
text: Surely some conspiracy theorist can explain what unnatural sequence of events prevented the string trio from becoming one of the most frequently heard ensembles, rather than the oddity it is. The configuration — violin, viola and cello — is perfectly balanced and symmetrical, its seamless range from soprano to bass untroubled by a top-thickening second fiddle or the distraction of a piano. And you’d think string players would form trios by the dozen just to have Mozart’s E-flat Divertimento in their active repertory.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about a record set in 2006 for the amount of borrowed money the New York Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki committed to pet projects included an erroneous reference from David Catalfamo, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, to a museum that Mr. Catalfamo defended as a worthwhile investment. It is the Natural History Museum of the Adirondacks in Tupper Lake — not the Adirondack Museum, which is in Blue Mountain Lake.

headline: With Arrest of DJ Drama, the Law Takes Aim at Mixtapes
text: In the world of hip-hop few music executives have more influence than DJ Drama. His “Gangsta Grillz” compilations have helped define this decade’s Southern rap explosion. He has been instrumental in the careers of rappers like Young Jeezy and Lil Wayne. He appears on the cover of the March issue of the hip-hop magazine XXL, alongside his friend and business partner T.I., the top-selling rapper of 2006. And later this year DJ Drama is scheduled to make his Atlantic Records debut with “Gangsta Grillz: The Album.”

headline: After Falling Behind Early, Blake Quickly Regains Place
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 18 — The mentoring program in American tennis has its limits, as Alex Kuznetsov discovered soon after breaking James Blake’s serve twice at the beginning of their second-round match at the Australian Open.

headline: Newark: Former Keyport Mayor Admits Taking Bribes
text: The former mayor of Keyport pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to accepting $24,000 in bribes from contractors seeking city construction work, federal prosecutors said. The former mayor, John Merla, 45, admitted accepting the payments while in office in 2003 and 2004, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Merla was one of 13 Monmouth County officials arrested in February 2005 as part of a corruption investigation by federal agents. He is scheduled to be sentenced on May 8 and faces up to 30 months in prison.

headline: Universal Plans to Hire Top Executive of Film Rival
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 — Universal Pictures has raided 20th Century Fox and hired away the animation executive who oversaw the hit “Ice Age” movies, a move intended to fill a void left when Paramount acquired DreamWorks and replaced Universal as distributor of animated films like “Over the Hedge.”

headline: California: $1 Billion in Citrus Losses
text: California’s citrus industry may have lost close to $1 billion after freezing weather devastated oranges and lemons still maturing on the tree, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said after touring some of the state’s growing regions. As much as 75 percent of the orange crop was damaged, according to the Department of Food and Agriculture, which oversees the state’s $31.8 billion agricultural industry.

headline: Death 31 Years After Shooting Leads to a Murder Indictment
text: Jose Rivera and Juan Cortes were drinking and gambling on a street corner in the South Bronx late in the steamy afternoon of Aug. 2, 1974. But alcohol, heat and a game of craps turned out to be a dangerous combination, and the men soon fell into an argument about a roll of the dice.

headline: TJX Says Customer Data Was Stolen
text: The TJX Companies, the retailer that operates the T. J. Maxx and Marshalls discount clothing chains, has joined the ignominious list of companies that have had sensitive customer financial data pilfered by identity thieves.

headline: As the Skeptics Ask Why, Obama Asks Why Not?
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — There is always, it seems, a fresh new face breezing into a presidential race, offering himself as the person to change the tone, eliminate the vitriol and transform the old ways of politics.

headline: Street Kata
text: STREET KATA

headline: Speaking Chic to Power
text: LAUDING someone for their style on Capitol Hill is a lot like celebrating the best surfer on Florida’s Gulf Coast — it’s all relative, and some would argue irrelevant. Washington has never embraced fashion (nor, for that matter, has the fashion world embraced Washington), and for understandable reasons. In political circles, fashion is a loaded term, smacking of frivolity and vanity.

headline: Border Agent Kills Immigrant; Mexican Government Protests
text: BISBEE, Ariz., Jan. 17 —A Mexican immigrant was shot and killed on Friday by a Border Patrol agent in Arizona, prompting an investigation by federal authorities and condemnation from President Felipe Calderón of Mexico.

headline: A Bit of Bidding Subterfuge From the Inner Poker Player
text: When is bridge like poker?

headline: Don’t Like the Dancing Cowboys? Results Say You Do
text: Most online advertisements are becoming less obtrusive and more tailored to the interests of individual Web users. Among the stubborn holdouts are the two-stepping cowboys, frisky rooftop dancers and weird tattoos in ubiquitous Web banners from LowerMyBills.com.

headline: Politics and the Corruption Fighter
text: In its secretive purge of key United States attorneys, the Bush administration is needlessly giving comfort to any number of individuals now under federal investigation. Most prominently, there is Representative Jerry Lewis, the California Republican whose dealings as appropriations chairman have been under scrutiny in the continuing investigation of lawmakers delivering quid pro quo favors for contractors and lobbyists.

headline: Neutralizing Arenas Is Not Enough as Butler Dunks the Knicks
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Before the Knicks’ game on Wednesday night, they vowed that Gilbert Arenas would not beat them with his scoring. He did not. He beat them by not taking the game-winning shot.

headline: After Iraq Trip, Clinton Proposes War Limits
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday called President Bush’s plan to send more troops to Iraq “a losing strategy” and proposed placing new limits on the White House’s conduct of the war.

headline: Court to Oversee U.S. Wiretapping in Terror Cases
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — The Bush administration, in a surprise reversal, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to give a secret court jurisdiction over the National Security Agency’s wiretapping program and would end its practice of eavesdropping without warrants on Americans suspected of ties to terrorists.

headline: Shifting Strategy, Maserati Finally Adds an Automatic
text: Introduced on Monday: Maserati Quattroporte Automatic

headline: A Fed Adviser Plans to Leave
text: Vincent Reinhart, one of Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke’s top advisers on interest rates, is planning to leave the central bank.

headline: Hollywood Rethinks Its Ratings Process
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 — Stung by a low-budget documentary that assailed the movie ratings system last year, motion picture industry officials are vowing to make the system more transparent to filmmakers and more accessible to parents.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about intestinal operations that a Spanish newspaper said had been performed on Fidel Castro referred incorrectly to peritonitis, a serious condition that the newspaper said had afflicted Mr. Castro after one of the operations. Peritonitis is an inflammation of the lining of the abdominal cavity, called the peritoneum; it is not an inflammation of the stomach lining. (Go to Article)

headline: Spitzer Taps Hospital Executive for Health Post
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has turned to Dr. Richard F. Daines, the chief executive of St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, to be the new state health commissioner.

headline: Apple Profit Rose 78% in Quarter
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17  Apple Inc., sweeping past even optimistic analyst expectations, delivered $1 billion in profit for its first quarter, based largely on the Christmas performance of its iPod music player business.

headline: Lieberman’s Party, but Someone Else’s Fight
text: HARTFORD, Jan. 17  Senator Joseph I. Lieberman’s critics frequently enjoy referring to him as a member of “the party of one.”

headline: Brooklyn Artist, Held Hostage, Is Beaten to Death
text: A Brooklyn artist was found fatally beaten in his apartment on Tuesday after his son held him and others hostage for more than six hours, the police said yesterday.

headline: Behind the Scenes, Three Towers Take Shape
text: FOSTER Maki Rogers,” it says on the doors leading to an 11th-floor design studio overlooking ground zero.

headline: Some TV Contestants Feel More Equal Than Others
text: LONDON, Jan. 17 — It began predictably enough as yet another television plunge into the choreographed world of faded celebrity, a familiar cocktail of the incompatible and the incorrigible, lubricated with booze and braggadocio, on “Celebrity Big Brother.”

headline: Top Wives Urge Barriers on Web to Child Abuse
text: PARIS, Jan. 17 — Their husbands may not always agree on issues like the Iraq war and global warming, but when Bernadette Chirac, Laura Bush, Lyudmila Putin and Suzanne Mubarak met here on Wednesday to discuss the fight against child pornography and pedophilia, they seemed safely on the same page.

headline: Trenton: Couple Accused of Money Laundering
text: A New York couple were arrested yesterday and charged with money laundering and receiving stolen property for using slot machines in Atlantic City to launder embezzled money, said Stuart Rabner, the New Jersey attorney general. The woman, Jamine Alabre, 26, of Westbury, and her companion, Mathurin Ambroise, 33, of Queens were indicted by a New Jersey grand jury this week. The couple are charged with laundering $500,000 in stolen cash through Atlantic City casinos from January to October 2005, prosecutors said.

headline: Spitzer Is Set to Name Health Chief, Officials Say
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer will name Dr. Richard F. Daines, the chief executive of St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, to be the new state health commissioner, according to several executives in the hospital industry.

headline: Quarrel Stalls Movement of Ethics Bill in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  It is an open secret that many members of Congress from both parties would be relieved to scuttle proposed changes in ethics rules. After all, the changes tend to limit the personal perks and political advantages of their positions.

headline: Mellon Financial Reports 14% Higher Profit
text: Mellon Financial, the investment manager that is being acquired by Bank of New York, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 14 percent on an increase in fees for overseeing hedge funds and mutual funds.

headline: Newly Released
text: This month’s new releases include novels by two writers better known for nonfiction, Richard A. Clarke and Anthony Swofford. There’s also a novel set in the icy climate of Lapland, and, in nonfiction, a look at the Hartford public schools and the legal battle to end segregation there.

headline: Curb Sought on Fannie Mae Regulator
text: Fannie Mae’s former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, asked a federal appeals court yesterday to bar the company’s regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him.

headline: Grand Old Apothecary, Version 2.0
text: I AM a traumatized consumer. Like many Americans, I have spent my entire life so bombarded by salesmanship and advertising that I have become cautious and rattled from all of it. If someone offers me help when I walk into a store, I want to implode into a tiny dot and disappear. I usually say, “No I’m just looking thank you so much!” even when I know exactly what I am looking for because I’m frightened that saying yes will mean I will be spritzed with a noxious tonic and forced to buy it along with a Mitch Albom book and a life insurance policy.

headline: Regulators Fault Con Ed Over Queens Blackout
text: In a devastating condemnation of Consolidated Edison, state regulators have concluded that a failure to adequately maintain, operate and oversee its electrical network was “the overriding cause” of the nine-day blackout that paralyzed western Queens last July.

headline: Warriors and Pacers Look for Lift From Trade
text: It is halfway through the season, and just the right time for struggling teams to reinvent themselves.

headline: Bills on Climate Move to Spotlight in New Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — The climate here has definitely changed.

headline: Rivals Offer $38 Billion for a REIT
text: The gloves have come off in buyouts.

headline: Orbital 360 Rocket Workout
text: ORBITAL 360 ROCKET WORKOUT

headline: Suspect in Kidnapping May Be Linked to 1991 Abduction
text: POTOSI, Mo., Jan. 17  The investigation of a suburban St. Louis man accused of kidnapping widened Wednesday as law enforcement officials pursued links between him and a 1991 abduction.

headline: The Mayor and His Tax Cuts
text: Michael Bloomberg was elected mayor five years ago after a self-financed campaign in which he shunned the politician label. So it was particularly striking to see his turnaround become all but complete in his State of the City speech yesterday, when he offered up a crowd-pleasing promise to cut taxes by $1 billion. It was an undeniable moment of political triumph, but it was less clear that it was a triumph for prudent governance.

headline: Thomas Lyson, 58, Cornell Sociologist Who Studied Rural Towns, Dies
text: Thomas A. Lyson, an influential sociologist at Cornell who argued that rural towns and small farms could survive economically by selling locally produced goods to regional markets, died on Dec. 28 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 58.

headline: Bring Back Gas Rationing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Islamists Held Trying to Flee From Somalia Into Kenya
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 17 — Several Somali Islamist fighters and possibly some of their leaders were arrested trying to escape into Kenya, Kenyan authorities said Wednesday, raising the possibility of a sticky asylum issue.

headline: What’s on Thursday Night
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) SCRUBS All the hospital’s a Broadway stage when a woman checks into Sacred Heart complaining of hearing incessant music. Stephanie D’Abruzzo, an original cast member of the Tony Award-winning “Avenue Q,” plays the patient with singing in her ears; Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx, who wrote the show’s music, composed the songs for this episode.

headline: Why the Strongest Armies May Lose the Newest Wars
text: Right now in Iraq the mightiest army on earth is being fought to a standstill by insurgents using rocket-propelled grenades, rifles and improvised roadside bombs. This should not come as a surprise. In nearly every respect the war in Iraq fits a new paradigm of conflict that has been operative since the end of World War II, although military and political leaders have been slow to recognize it. Until they do, conventional armies, applying conventional wisdom, will continue to misapply their power and risk defeat at the hands of seemingly inferior enemies.

headline: A 12th Dallas Convict Is Exonerated by DNA
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 17 — A 50-year-old Dallas man whose conviction of raping a boy in 1982 cost him nearly half his life in prison and on parole won a court ruling Wednesday declaring him innocent. He said he was not angry, “because the Lord has given me so much.”

headline: S.M.U. Chief Says Bush Library Would Be a Boon for the Campus
text: DALLAS, Jan. 17 — The president of Southern Methodist University told professors on Wednesday evening that the university would benefit if it became the site of President Bush’s presidential library.

headline: Retired Generals Criticize Bush’s Plan for Iraq
text: A panel of retired generals told a United States Senate committee today that sending 21,500 additional troops to Iraq will do little to solve the underlying political problems in the country.

headline: Gates Backs Generals’ Afghan Distress Call
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 17 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that American and NATO military commanders in Afghanistan, worried about a resurgent Taliban insurgency, had asked for additional troops and that he was sympathetic to the request.

headline: 2 Motel Owners Are Indicted Over Fire That Killed 3 People
text: NEWARK, Jan. 17 The owners of a motel where a fire killed 3 people and injured 14 others who were trapped because exit doors were reported to have been illegally locked were indicted on manslaughter charges on Wednesday and accused of ignoring safety regulations.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Posts 68% Rise in Earnings
text: JPMorgan Chase & Company reported a 68 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, ending 2006 on a high note that showed record profits for its investment banking advisory businesses and vast improvement in its trading results.

headline: Shiite Fighters Are Arrested, Iraq Says
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 17 — Facing intense pressure from the Bush administration to show progress in securing Iraq, senior Iraqi officials announced Wednesday that they had moved against the country’s most powerful Shiite militia, arresting several dozen senior members in the past few weeks.

headline: Ian McEwan’s True Tale Led Him to a Long-Lost Brother
text: LONDON, Jan. 17 — He is known as an author of dark and tangled tales in which love sometimes endures and sometimes does not. But Ian McEwan, one of Britain’s best-known novelists, has now found himself as a player in a true story that might have sprung from his own imagination.

headline: ReganBooks to Shut Down After Firing of Its Creator
text: HarperCollins, the publishing company, announced yesterday that it planned to close ReganBooks, the imprint created by Judith Regan, the editor who was fired last month after public outcry over a book and television deal with O. J. Simpson. The imprint will close March 1.

headline: Rooting Around Grandma’s Basement in Cyberspace
text: SOME years I receive nothing.

headline: Art Buchwald, 81, Columnist and Humorist Who Delighted in the Absurd
text: Art Buchwald, who satirized the follies of the rich, the famous and the powerful for half a century as the most widely read newspaper humorist of his time, died Wednesday night in Washington. He was 81.

headline: The Suspect in 3 Murders and 8 Rapes Blended In
text: BUFFALO, Jan. 17  The man sitting at table 35, a booth in the back of the restaurant, made the same impression on Rebecca Klauk last Saturday that he had left on countless other people who encountered him over the years: respectable but wholly unremarkable. He just blended in.

headline: House Votes to Void $14 Billion in Oil Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The House voted this evening to rescind $14 billion worth of tax breaks and subsidies for oil drillers and channel the money into a fund that would finance renewable energy projects and new technologies for conserving energy.

headline: Hair Regimens Fit for the Jungle? Putting Unruly Locks to a Big Test
text: HOURS before leaving on a 17-day trip to Vietnam and Cambodia over the holidays, I visited the hairdresser.

headline: Help, I’m Surrounded by Jerks
text: CERTAIN mortals have the power to sink hearts and sour moods with lightning speed. The hysterical colleague. The meddlesome neighbor. The crazy in-law. The explosive boss. A mélange of cantankerous individuals, they are united by a single achievement: They make life miserable.

headline: Ukraine: Premier’s Ally Dies of Hunting Wound
text: Yevhen Kushnaryov, a deputy leader of the pro-Russian Party of Regions and a close ally of Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, died of a gunshot wound suffered while hunting on Tuesday. Mr. Kushnaryov was shot under circumstances not yet fully explained. Ukrainian news agencies said he was with a group that had just finished a boar hunt when a wolf appeared, prompting at least one unidentified hunter to fire and strike Mr. Kushnaryov.

headline: Taking Power, Sharing Cereal
text: Washington

headline: Graphic Accounts
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: German Leader Vows to Revive Constitution for Europe
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 17 — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany set two daunting tasks for herself on Wednesday in her new role as European Union president, saying she wanted to save the bloc’s faltering constitution and revive stalled global trade talks.

headline: Betty Trezza, 81, Pioneer of Women’s Baseball, Is Dead
text: Betty Trezza, who at 17 escaped her job as a Garment District embroiderer to play women’s professional baseball and went on to smack a memorable championship-winning hit, died Tuesday in the Brooklyn house where she was born. She was 81.

headline: Two Backs, One Ball, No Problem for Saints
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 — Like many landmark moments in the history of this city, the phone call came just after the minestrone soup and just before the redfish.

headline: Nudge Here, a Challenge There
text: The pianist Kenny Barron has a brisk but unostentatious technique and a deceptively casual way with a phrase. He conveys a number of things clearly in his playing; what comes across over all is the quiet hum of effortless erudition. Within his playing you can hear a digest of mainstream jazz piano traditions, with bebop as the root. You can also hear the measured tension of an expert nudging himself toward a challenge.

headline: Taliban Detainee Says Rebel Chief Hides in Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 17 — The Afghan Intelligence Service announced Wednesday that it had detained a Taliban spokesman, who said in a videotape released with the announcement that Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, was hiding in Pakistan.

headline: Gale-Force Storm Hits Europe, Leaving 7 Dead
text: FRANKFURT, Jan. 18  A howling gale churned through the British Isles and Northern Europe on Thursday, killing at least nine people, uprooting trees, shattering windows, flooding beaches and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights at airports from London to Frankfurt.

headline: Bob Zawoluk, 76, a Star for St. John’s Basketball, Is Dead
text: Bob Zawoluk, an all-American center at St. John’s in the early 1950s who became the university’s longtime career scoring leader, and then endured a troubled life far from the basketball spotlight, died Jan. 9 in Spring Valley, N.Y. He was 76.

headline: Second Drop in Cancer Deaths Could Point to a Trend, Researchers Say
text: The number of cancer deaths in the United States has dropped for the second year in a row, the American Cancer Society reported yesterday. The finding suggests that the small drop reported last year — the first in more than 70 years — was real, possibly the start of a continuing decrease and not merely a statistical fluke, researchers said.

headline: Camaro Convertible: The Other Shoe Drops
text: On display at the General Motors exhibit: Chevrolet Camaro convertible

headline: The Virtuoso and the Star: A Study in Contrasts
text: A singer I know used to collect batons from every conductor he worked with. He was once greatly amused when a conductor he hadn’t thought much of presented him with a stick that was warped and appeared to be broken: a reflection, the singer said later, of the conductor’s abilities.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,012 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,878,126.62

headline: Maryland: Governor Sworn In
text: Martin J. O’Malley was sworn in as governor in a ceremony in Annapolis that included a surprise guest, Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California, a Maryland native. Mr. O’Malley, a Democrat, was mayor of Baltimore for nearly two terms. He pledged to make good on a campaign promise to finance school construction, announcing this week plans to direct $400 million in state money toward that goal in his first year as governor. Other priorities include making health care more affordable and accessible, reducing energy costs and restoring of Chesapeake Bay. He replaced a Republican, Robert L. Ehrlich Jr.

headline: Pictures With Sharper Detail in Shadow and in Light
text: Dynamic range is the ability to capture details even in a scene’s darkest shadows and its brightest highlights, and it has always been an issue in photography.

headline: In Which We Reach Southern California in a Season of Strange Weather
text: It was a fitting end to the trip — a 15-mile traffic jam snaking over Cajon Pass and down into the refrigerated depths of Southern California, where avocados were freezing on the bough and sprinkler-soaked lawns had iced over by morning. The day before we left, it was 70 degrees at home in upstate New York.

headline: Delay Denied on Tax Accounting Rule
text: Correction Appended

headline: Cost of Fuel Skews Earnings at Airlines
text: The AMR Corporation earned a surprise fourth-quarter profit and Southwest Airlines said yesterday that net income fell, demonstrating how fuel-pricing decisions dictate carriers’ finances even when planes are full and fares are rising.

headline: Knicks Show Improvement, but Will It Save Thomas?
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 18 — A half-season of diligent progress cannot be undone in 2.2 seconds, but Isiah Thomas’s grim expression and grave tone made it seem so Wednesday night.

headline: Political Opinions Complicate Screening for Libby Jurors
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The difficulties of seating a jury for the perjury trial of Vice President Dick Cheney’s former chief of staff were evident on Wednesday as more prospective jurors expressed criticism of the Bush administration.

headline: In Sweeping Schools Vision, Big Risks for Mayor
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday effectively doubled his bet that the nation’s largest school system is capable of unprecedented improvement, wagering the education of the city’s nearly 1.1 million students and his own legacy on a far-reaching decentralization plan that puts enormous pressure on principals to raise student achievement.

headline: China Tests Anti-Satellite Weapon, Unnerving U.S.
text: China successfully carried out its first test of an anti-satellite weapon last week, signaling its resolve to play a major role in military space activities and bringing expressions of concern from Washington and other capitals, the Bush administration said Thursday.

headline: Fed Chief Sends Warning on Budget
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 – The chairman of the Federal Reserve warned today that looming deficits in the Social Security and Medicare programs posed long-term threats to the nation’s economy.

headline: Myanmar Accuses Democracy Advocate of Tax Evasion
text: SINGAPORE, Jan. 18 — It was an imaginative new twist in the periodic verbal salvoes fired by the military government of Myanmar against the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi: A state-run newspaper accused her today of evading taxes on the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize and other awards she has won for her work.

headline: Grasso Weighs in on Cost of Spitzer Suit
text: Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that the costs involved in a lawsuit challenging his compensation might have exceeded $100 million, almost equal to the amount the New York attorney general is seeking to recover.

headline: Crude Oil Prices Fall to Lowest Level Since 2005
text: Crude oil prices fell sharply today to their lowest levels since May 2005, and briefly fell below the psychologically important $50-a-barrel level, after the United States government reported a significant rise in crude stockpiles.

headline: White House Retreats Under Pressure
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — The Bush administration’s abrupt abandonment on Wednesday of its program to eavesdrop inside the United States without court approval is the latest in a series of concessions to Congress, the courts and public opinion that have dismantled major elements of its strategy to counter the terrorist threat.

headline: Ex-Official of Red Cross Is Charged With Fraud
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 — A former California accounting executive at the Orange County Chapter of the American Red Cross was indicted Wednesday on federal embezzling charges, adding to concerns raised by watchdogs over the financial management of the Red Cross and some of its chapters.

headline: Grand Jury Looking at Katrina Insurer
text: A grand jury in Mississippi began hearing testimony yesterday on possible criminal charges against State Farm for its handling of claims after Hurricane Katrina, people close to the proceedings said.

headline: Sales Tax Cut in City May Dim Allure of Stores Across Hudson
text: PARAMUS, N.J., Jan. 17  For years, shoppers from New York City have played a game of retail arbitrage, traveling to the many malls in northern New Jersey, a state where there is no tax on clothing and shoes.

headline: Terror Warning Startles Russians
text: A summary of the top news in Russian papers on Thursday.

headline: New Jersey Court Revives a Merck Suit
text: A lawsuit against Merck that seeks medical monitoring for former users of the painkiller Vioxx was revived yesterday by a New Jersey appeals court.

headline: Old Hat? Not on a Young Head
text: BRAD PITT may be striving mightily to downplay his heartthrob image — he even sported gray stubble and crow’s feet in “Babel” — so this probably is not going to help. The truth is that probably no male star today has the power to ignite a fashion trend like Mr. Pitt can. With the help of the trend-setting costume designer Michael Kaplan, he did it with the retro-70s hip-length leather jacket in “Fight Club.” Now he has done it with the fedora.

headline: Felled Trees in East Hampton: A Prank’s Toll, or a Beaver’s Lunch?
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Steven Niggle was duck hunting on Scoy Pond in the Northwest Woods here when he did a double take at a tree with a ring chewed out of its lower trunk. Then he found several more gnawed-up trunks around the pond, some merely stumps with a pointy, chewed up tip, others with trees still partially attached, either fallen or leaning.

headline: Payday Loans Are a Scourge, but Should Wrath Be Aimed at the Lenders?
text: When a lion achieves alpha male status, one of his first acts is to kill all unrelated cubs in the pride. Is that a bad thing?

headline: Purging Bloat to Fashion Sleek Software
text: Life has a funny symmetry, don’t you think? When you’re born, you’re short, toothless and bald. You spend the first part of your life gaining height, teeth and hair — and the last part losing them again.

headline: Here Comes Rhymin’ Kelso and the Dancin’ ‘Scrubs’ Gang
text: There is something about the urgent pace of technological progress that, no matter how welcome, seems to navigate our tastes in historical reverse. It didn’t seem long before the fashion for vacuum-cooked salmon redounded to another fad for meatloaf and macaroni and cheese. The arrival of sleek, heat-retaining microfibers never sent fur on its way, it only seemed to heighten a demand for everything ermine, sable and pouffy. YouTube certainly exists in no small part to indulge our nostalgic affinities. And television, for its part, has displayed a recent interest in what some have long considered entertainment’s hoariest form, the musical.

headline: Iran’s President Criticized Over Nuclear Issue
text: TEHRAN, Jan. 18 — Iran’s outspoken president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, appears to be under pressure from the highest authorities in Iran to end his involvement in the country’s nuclear program, a sign that his political capital is declining as his country comes under increasing international pressure.

headline: Not a Front-Runner, but Moving Ahead in Polls
text: The transformation, on vivid display in a studio inside ABC News’s Washington bureau on Sunday morning, was arresting. There was Representative John P. Murtha, a Pennsylvania Democrat whose criticisms of the Bush administration’s policies in Iraq had long ago earned him a reputation as little more than a gadfly, now being interviewed about his threats to withhold money for additional troops in his new capacity as chairman of the subcommittee on defense appropriations.

headline: New Strain of Bird Flu Found in Egypt Is Resistant to Antiviral Drug
text: A strain of avian flu that is resistant to the antiviral drug oseltamivir has been isolated from two family members in Egypt, the World Health Organization said yesterday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Tuesday, about “T. S. Eliot,” by Craig Raine, included an erroneous reference in the book to the site where 14,000 people turned out in Minnesota to hear Eliot speak in 1956. It was Williams Arena at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, not a baseball stadium in that city.

headline: Foiled Daredevil Fares Better in Court
text: If you have parachute training and an urge to jump off the Empire State Building  or the Brooklyn Bridge  there may be nothing wrong with it, a New York City judge ruled yesterday.

headline: Time Inc. Lays Off Nearly 300
