text: Time Inc. said today it will cut nearly 300 jobs at its top magazines, including its most profitable title, People, which is shutting down its bureaus in Washington, Miami, Chicago and Austin, Texas.

headline: Barclays Pays Record Price to Put Name on Nets’ Arena
text: Setting a record price for the naming rights to an American indoor sports arena, the British bank Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the Nets’ planned future home in Brooklyn. The arrangement could double the old record of $185 million for 20 years that Royal Philips Electronics paid to name Philips Arena in Atlanta in 1999.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A television review in Weekend on Jan. 5 about the new reality show “Living With Ed,” on HGTV, misidentified the car that Ed Begley Jr. drives. It is a Toyota converted to run on electricity, not a Volkswagen.

headline: American Woman Was Killed After Visit to Sunni Office
text: An American woman who was killed here on Wednesday had just left the headquarters of a prominent Sunni political party, where she had been teaching a class on democracy, when her convoy of vehicles was ambushed by gunmen.

headline: Lifestyle and Body Mass (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making Money in Multiples
text: FAST fashion collections like those of Karl Lagerfeld, Stella McCartney and Isaac Mizrahi have brought good design to the masses, but what have they brought to designers?

headline: Bridgewater: Missing Student’s Body Found
text: The body of a missing New York college student was found in a lake here yesterday, two days after he disappeared, the Connecticut state police said. The student, Joseph Zahornacky, 22, who lived in Shelton, Conn., and was a student at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., was reported missing on Monday night, just hours after he told relatives that he was on his way back to school from La Guardia Airport, the police said. Mr. Zahornacky had just returned from a visit to his girlfriend in California. On Tuesday night, the authorities said, the police found his 2000 Jeep Cherokee in Lake Lillinonah, the same body of water where they discovered his body about 11 a.m. yesterday. Lt. J. Paul Vance of the state police said that detectives were awaiting the results of an autopsy. Mr. Zahornacky’s brother Michael said the police told him that they did not suspect foul play. He described his brother as an avid guitarist and surfer, and said he was one of four siblings.

headline: A Seat for the Jet Cockpit in Your Game Room (No Need to Buckle Up)
text: There’s nothing like being in the middle of the action in a good video game. Serious fans of flight-simulator programs can now grab their force-feedback joysticks and practically climb right into the cockpit. The HotSeat Flight Sim gaming chassis, available in three models, brings both a Dolby 5.1 six-speaker surround sound system and a comfy chair to the stimulating experience of simulated flight.

headline: Scientists Recreate 1918 Flu and See Parallels to Bird Flu
text: Scientists infected monkeys with a virus that caused the 1918-19 influenza pandemic and said in the Jan. 18 issue of the journal Nature that it caused an illness like that suffered by patients with the bird flu now spreading in Asia.

headline: A Mobile Work of Art Is Missing an Ironworker
text: Perhaps the most famous construction crew in the city’s history is down a man.

headline: Some Bling for Your Blog
text: PASTOR BOB HYATT acknowledges that his widget fixation may be getting a little out of control.

headline: Gonzales Testifies on Eavesdropping  Changes
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales was lectured on Capitol Hill today by senators who were only partly mollified by the Bush administration’s concession to allow judicial oversight of its electronic-eavesdropping program.

headline: Bank of Japan, in a Split Vote, Decides to Hold Rates Steady
text: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 18 — The Bank of Japan, the nation’s central bank, kept borrowing rates unchanged on Thursday in an intensely scrutinized decision, apparently concluding that the economy was too weak to bear a rate increase.

headline: Bank of Japan Decides to Hold Rates Steady
text: TOKYO, Jan. 18 — The Bank of Japan, the nation’s central bank, kept borrowing rates unchanged in an intensely scrutinized decision today, concluding that the economy was too weak to bear a rate hike.

headline: Antiques Dealer Sues to Bar Homeless From Sidewalk
text: A Manhattan antiques dealer has filed a lawsuit against a small group of homeless people claiming that they are disrupting his business by using the sidewalk outside his high-end East Side store as a urinal, a spittoon and an occasional dressing room, according to the suit and the dealer’s lawyer.

headline: In Death as in Life, a Personalized Space
text: SACRAMENTO

headline: Bloomberg Seeks Further Changes for City Schools
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg laid out ambitious new plans yesterday to overhaul the school system by giving principals more power and autonomy, requiring teachers to undergo rigorous review in order to gain tenure and revising the school financing system that has allowed more-experienced teachers to cluster in affluent areas.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Florida

headline: NBC President Says Ratings Are Gaining Momentum
text: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 17 — Even in the face of what he acknowledged will likely be another tsunami of ratings from Fox’s “American Idol,” which again set a viewership record on Tuesday night, Kevin Reilly, the president of NBC Entertainment, said here on Wednesday that his network had established significant momentum this season and had regained its status as the network of what he called “quality programs.”

headline: Appeals Court Rules for Wal-Mart in Maryland Health Care Case
text: When Maryland legislators passed a first-of-its-kind law in 2006 forcing Wal-Mart Stores to spend more on employee health care, the measure was held up as a model for other states grappling with mounting Medicaid bills.

headline: The Route From Research to Start-Up
text: HARTMUT NEVEN came from Germany to the University of Southern California a decade ago to lead research efforts in computerized face and object recognition. The aim was to create a tool for the military and law enforcement agencies to identify enemies and suspects as well as for airlines and other companies to check passengers and visitors.

headline: Airbus Predicts Operating Loss for 2006
text: PARIS, Jan. 17  Airbus warned Wednesday that major production delays on its twin-deck A380 jet would probably push it to an operating loss for 2006, despite a record number of deliveries.

headline: Ravaged by Fires, Australian State Warns of Hot Weather’s Danger
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 — Australia’s second-most-populous state, Victoria, is in the grip of one of the worst bush fire seasons in recorded history, and the state’s government has issued warnings that with more hot weather on the way the situation is likely to get worse before it gets better.

headline: House Smoking Ban (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Lost Voice of Protest
text: On the evening of the fourth of April, 1967, one year to the day (almost to the hour) before his assassination, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. walked into Riverside Church in Manhattan and delivered a speech that was among his least well known, yet most controversial.

headline: Balanchine and Stravinsky, Reunited
text: Stravinsky was arguably the most important composer for dance in the 20th century, beginning with a 1910 commission from Serge Diaghilev to score Michel Fokine’s “Firebird.” Although Stravinsky wrote only four scores for ballets by George Balanchine, the two artists had a long and mutually fruitful working relationship.

headline: Some Signs of Economic Resilience Seen
text: A tight labor market is pushing up many workers’ wages, consumers are spending more at their local shopping malls and the skid in the housing market is easing in some areas of the country.

headline: House Cuts Interest Rate for Some College Loans
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  House Democrats on Wednesday pushed through legislation cutting the interest rate on federally subsidized loans to college students, drawing on large bipartisan support despite opposition by the White House.

headline: Subaru Parks Its Styling in the Middle of the Road
text: Introduced on Sunday: Subaru 2008 Legacy 3.0 R Limited sedan and Outback

headline: On Kue, Kia Shows Its Passionate Side
text: Introduced on Monday: Kia Kue design study

headline: Brought to You by ... (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: President Calls for Genetic Privacy Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — President Bush on Wednesday urged Congress to pass long-stalled legislation to safeguard genetic privacy, a measure experts say would encourage millions of Americans to undergo testing that could lead to prevention and treatment of cancer and other diseases.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about a dispute between Wendy P. McCaw, the owner of The Santa Barbara News-Press in California and the newsroom staff misspelled the name of the city where Don Murphy, the former deputy managing editor of the paper, has taken a job. It is San Luis Obispo, not San Louis Obispo. The credit for a picture of Ms. McCaw misstated the given name of the photographer. He is Paul Wellman, not Paula.

headline: Fraternal Twins in the Showroom
text: DETROIT, Jan. 17 — Inside the cavernous Cobo Convention Center where the Detroit auto show is held each year, it’s easy to lose your way among the hundreds of new models.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Says Rules Bar Satellite Radio Merger
text: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Kevin Martin, said yesterday that the two satellite radio companies, Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio Holdings, would not win approval of a merger under current regulatory rules.

headline: The Netherlands: Chip Supplier Soars
text: ASML Holding, maker of the most expensive machines in chip fabrication, said fourth-quarter profit quadrupled on demand for semiconductors used in iPod music devices and mobile phones. Net income jumped to a record 205.5 million euros ($265.7 million), or 0.42 euro a share, from 51.6 million euros, or 0.11 euro a share, a year earlier, ASML said. Sales surged 95 percent, to a record 1.07 billion euros. The company said orders would be “healthy” in the first quarter and revenue would gain this year. Demand for Apple iPods and Motorola phones has spurred shipments of ASML’s $18 million machines to clients like Samsung Electronics, Intel and Texas Instruments. ASML is based in Veldhoven, the Netherlands.

headline: A Spy Program in From the Cold
text: Of the many ways that President Bush has trampled civil liberties and the balance of powers since the 9/11 attacks, one of the most egregious was his decision to order wiretaps of Americans’ international calls and e-mail without court approval. It was good news, then, when the administration announced yesterday that it would now seek a warrant from the proper court for that sort of eavesdropping.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about intestinal operations that a Spanish newspaper said had been performed on Fidel Castro referred incorrectly to peritonitis, a serious condition that the newspaper said had afflicted Mr. Castro after one of the operations. Peritonitis is an inflammation of the lining of the abdominal cavity, called the peritoneum; it is not an inflammation of the stomach lining.

headline: He Writes the Songs, He Spans the Decades, He Inspires the Karaoke
text: “I’m 95 years old and I look great, right?” That was Barry Manilow at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, telling a fib  maybe, if we’re honest, telling two fibs  and earning another big ovation.

headline: Taming Frizz and Setting Curls Free
text: GROWING up, I yearned to have lustrous straight hair that I could wear parted in the middle and let swing down my back, like Marcia Brady of “The Brady Bunch” or Laurie Partridge of “The Partridge Family.”

headline: Measure in Senate Urges No Troop Rise in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 — The Senate set the stage on Wednesday for a direct clash with President Bush over the war, with two senior Democrats and a prominent Republican introducing a symbolic measure to declare that the administration’s plan to send additional troops to Iraq runs counter to the national interest.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music column on Saturday about a new album by the Smithereens (“Meet the Smithereens!”) that reproduces the song lineup and much of the arrangements on “Meet the Beatles!” misidentified the Smithereens’ lead guitarist, whose solos were compared to George Harrison’s. Although Pat DiNizio does play guitar in the band, it is Jim Babjak who plays lead.

headline: Stand Up, Ask Questions, Be Upbeat
text: MANY specialists on coping with difficult people suggest strategies specific to their behavior types.

headline: A Family of Nine, Buffeted by an Injury, Remains Intact
text: Christmas presents came a few days late for the Fardan-Daniels children. On Dec. 28, Nadine Bosson, a social worker, took gifts to the Brooklyn shelter where the family was living.

headline: Mets Won’t Trade Future, So Present Must Wait
text: The telephone calls keep coming, so Mets General Manager Omar Minaya keeps listening. But trading away premium talent for a modest starter is not going to happen. So Minaya has resisted all comers, and will take a chance that the enigmatic Jorge Sosa and seven other candidates will ultimately produce three capable starters for the last three spots in the rotation.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the N.B.A. roundup in some copies last Thursday, about the Toronto Raptors’ 90-77 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, misstated the team that Toronto tied for the lead in the Atlantic Division as a result. It was the Nets, not the Knicks.

headline: An Unmarried Woman, on Her Own (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Iraqis Answer Global Critics by Tackling Troubling Issues
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 17  Iraqi political leaders stepped up efforts to persuade the world that they were tackling the country’s thorniest problems on Wednesday, highlighting crackdowns on militias, pressing for more rapid arming of Iraqi troops, and underlining progress on a national oil law and new examples of reconciliation with former Baathists.

headline: Changes in Top Leadership Are Expected at Channel 13
text: After two decades under the same leadership, the New York public television station WNET, Channel 13, is planning a change at the top. Under a succession plan to be voted on today by the board of WNET’s parent, Educational Broadcasting Corporation, William F. Baker, the chief executive officer, will step down in February 2008, to be replaced by Neal Shapiro, the former president of NBC News.

headline: Ex-Convict Testifies in Sentencing Trial of Detectives’ Killer
text: At 27, Shabucalik Geralds can recall nine years in and out of federal prisons, selling drugs on probation a month after his release, firing guns at people 8 or 10 times and ordering two other shootings. Many of his crimes have gone without punishment, for he has proven more valuable to prosecutors as a serial cooperator.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Granddaughter, Sprouting

headline: Appeals for Delayed Travelers
text: The Department of Homeland Security is setting up a new, simplified way for travelers to file an appeal if their journey is disrupted by security queries. The new system will allow travelers who have been denied or delayed boarding an airplane or entering the United States, or have been subjected to more intense searches or questioning by a department official to question why they were the target of such scrutiny. The new system, called the Traveler Redress Inquiry Program, will allow the person to file and track the status of the claim online and is scheduled to start late next month.

headline: A Way to Lose the Headset and Still Make Cheap Skype Calls
text: Netgear’s Dual-Mode Cordless Phone with Skype  or the SPH200D for short  mixes plain old landline communications with cutting-edge Internet calling.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announces cultural plans for New York, China denies admission to “The Departed” and more culture news.

headline: Expert Ties Ex-Player’s Suicide to Brain Damage
text: Since the former National Football League player Andre Waters killed himself in November, an explanation for his suicide has remained a mystery. But after examining remains of Mr. Waters’s brain, a neuropathologist in Pittsburgh is claiming that Mr. Waters had sustained brain damage from playing football and he says that led to his depression and ultimate death.

headline: ‘Mermaid’ Approaches, So ‘Beauty’ Will Close
text: Beauty was no problem; ’twas actually fish that killed the beast.

headline: Shaky ‘Studio 60’ Is Counting on Romance to Rouse Ratings
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 — Aaron Sorkin has a new pitch for all those viewers who did not fall in love last fall with “Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,” his behind-the scenes look at a late-night comedy show.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary last Thursday about Roberta Wohlstetter, a military and foreign policy analyst, misstated the surname of her mother and reversed the middle name and surname of her father. Her mother was Elsie Morgan, not Morris. Her father was Edmund Morris Morgan — not Morgan Morris.

headline: The Titans Return, Carrying Lacrosse Sticks
text: Casey Powell made a big mistake bringing his wife to New York to watch him play Saturday night in the first lacrosse game ever at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Hard, Easy or Just Right?
text: N.F.L. TRAINING

headline: As Tomlinson Looks Back in Anger, the Patriots Look Forward to the Colts
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 17  New England Coach Bill Belichick is apparently worried about getting to the Super Bowl again, not about LaDainian Tomlinson’s feelings.

headline: Pentagon Aide Regrets Stance on Law Firms for Detainees
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  A senior Pentagon official apologized on Wednesday to the lawyers of Guantánamo Bay detainees for suggesting that corporations should consider severing business ties with law firms that represent the detainees.

headline: Is It Spring? Winter? What’s a Flower to Think?
text: IT’S that time of year again: mail order catalogs are pouring in, and Web sites are saturated with color images of gorgeous plants that never get eaten by insects or ravaged by disease. I’m dreaming of Fresca strawberries, an everbearing variety that will produce fruit all summer, if I start the seeds 16 weeks before my last frost date (kitchengardenseeds.com; (860) 567-6086).

headline: Russia: Sakhalin Production Increases
text: Exxon Mobil said output from its $17 billion Sakhalin Island development in the Pacific off Russia jumped 40 percent in the last month. Oil and natural gas production from the Sakhalin-1 development has risen to the equivalent of more than 200,000 barrels of crude a day, according to Stuart McGill, senior vice president. Exxon, which operates and owns a 30 percent stake in the project, expects output eventually to reach the equivalent of 317,000 barrels a day. Production at Sakhalin-1 was about 160,000 barrels a day in early December, a Bear Stearns analyst, Nicole Decker, said in a Dec. 13 note to clients after an analysts’ lunch with Exxon’s chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson. Exxon began producing crude from the Chayvo field off Sakhalin Island’s ice-choked coastline in October 2005. Exxon’s partners in Sakhalin-1 are a Japanese group known as Sodeco, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India and the state-run Russian oil company Rosneft.

headline: Plan Will Allow 911 and 311 Lines to Accept Digital Images
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who built his fortune on innovations in information technology, announced a plan yesterday that will allow emergency 911 call centers and the popular 311 service line to receive digital photos and videos from callers.

headline: The Reckoning: Ralph Rucci at F.I.T.
text: COMMENTATORS on the designer Ralph Rucci tend to vigorously defend him, as though there may be some doubt about his talent.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 4 about Delores Pryce, a Queens woman whose youngest daughter has health problems and who received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help pay an electricity bill, referred incorrectly to New Alternatives for Children, a program that helps families with medically fragile children. (The error was repeated in an article on Jan. 5 about Dorcas Acheampong, a Bronx woman who received help from the fund to help pay her rent.) Although it is a member agency of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, it is not run by the federation.

headline: G.E. May Buy Abbott’s Diagnostic Unit
text: General Electric is near a deal to buy Abbott Laboratories’ medical diagnostics unit for as much as $5 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about the appearance of a new island as a result of glacial melting in Greenland referred incorrectly to a region where another such island has appeared. Svalbard, off Norway, is an archipelago, not an island.

headline: The Museum as Outdoor Movie Screen
Take an Internet Call and Some Notes, or Just Doodle
text: You can’t put the world in your pocket, but you can put the Web there, with Nokia’s N800 Internet tablet, which is about the size of a paperback (3 by 6 by ½ inch). Like the earlier N770, it lets you browse the Internet, send and receive e-mail and instant messages, download audio and video and get R.S.S. feeds. The N800 adds a Web cam for videoconferencing and a microphone for Internet phone calls.

headline: Democrats Say House Energy Bill Will Pass
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  House Democrats, brushing aside objections from the Bush administration, said on Wednesday that they had ample votes to pass a bill on Thursday that would eliminate $14 billion in subsidies and tax breaks for oil companies and channel the money to renewable-energy projects.

headline: Owner of Outlet Malls Agrees to a Buyout
text: One week after disclosing that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection, the Mills Corporation, the owner of suburban outlet malls around the country, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for $1.4 billion by Brookfield Asset Management.

headline: Governor Is Challenged on Ethics by Bruno
text: ALBANY, Jan. 17  The honeymoon may be coming to an end. Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader, accused Gov. Eliot Spitzer on Wednesday of being hypocritical for championing campaign finance reform while headlining a $25,000-a-couple fund-raiser later this week for the state Democratic Party.

headline: Happy Hours
text: Washington

headline: Iraqi Factories, Aging and Shut, Now Give Hope
text: RAMADI, Iraq, Jan. 16 — Inside a huge shuttered factory on the gritty western fringes of this outlaw desert town, thousands of ornate porcelain sinks, toilets and other fixtures sit in row after row next to the automated ovens and assembly lines that once churned out the products but lie silent under a thin film of yellow desert dust.

headline: Operating Costs Are Imperiling Disaster Fund
text: The federal government’s biggest program to help people rebuild after natural disasters is on the verge of running out of operating money because of budgeting problems at the agency that runs it, the Small Business Administration.

headline: North Korea and U.S. Envoys Meet in Berlin
text: BERLIN, Jan. 17 — Seeking to revive stalled negotiations to end North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, the United States held “substantive” talks with North Korean diplomats here on Tuesday and Wednesday, said the chief American envoy, Christopher R. Hill.

headline: Offline Options for Backup
text: Q. What are the alternatives for backing up a computer’s data if you don’t want to use an online service?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about a meeting between the United States trade representative, Susan C. Schwab, and the head of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, misstated the date of Mr. Lamy’s discussion with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain about the restart of global trade negotiations. It had already been held, on Jan. 9; it was not scheduled for Tuesday.

headline: For a Media Room Away From Home, a Remote for the Laptop
text: Even seasoned business travelers need a bit of downtime. The Interlink ExpressCard Media Remote lets an average laptop act like a media center, complete with a couch-potato-worthy remote control.

headline: Casting Blame for Looting in Trial of Getty Ex-Curator
text: ROME, Jan. 17 — In a move that seemed to gratify prosecutors, lawyers for a former curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles who is on trial here asked on Wednesday that the court admit as evidence a letter in which the curator railed against her former employer.

headline: Publisher Drops Novel About Mantle
text: “7: The Mickey Mantle Novel,” a frequently salacious fictional account of the late Yankee’s life, was canceled yesterday by its publisher, HarperCollins, slightly more than a month before it was to be released.

headline: New Chief Looks to U.S. for Peacekeeping Support
text: Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, asked President Bush and members of Congress during a two-day trip to Washington to lift a cap on spending for peacekeeping that limits the United States’ contribution to 25 percent of the total cost, which he said produced an annual shortfall of $200 million. The United States is the biggest contributor to peacekeeping and used to pay 27 percent, but Congress imposed the 25 percent cap in 2005 in response to instances of sexual abuses by peacekeepers. Mr. Ban said he had stressed that “while there was a time when the relationship between the United Nations and the United States was not easy, it is time now to look for better days.”

headline: Calendar
text: Winter Antiques Show

headline: Queens: Man Charged With Murder and Assault
text: A Ridgewood man has been charged with murder and assault in the shooting of two men outside a nightclub in Woodside three months ago, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Victor Gavalo, 24, of Stephens Street, was awaiting arraignment on the charges last evening in Queens Criminal Court. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said that Mr. Gavalo was charged with shooting the men on Oct. 1 as they sat in a car outside Club Phenomenon, which was shuttered last month under the public nuisance abatement law. The dead man was Ernesto Salgado, 22, of Sunnyside; the wounded man’s identity was not released. NEW JERSEYNEWARK: MAN CHARGED IN FATAL SHOOTING An East Orange man already in custody on charges of setting his uncle on fire was charged with murder on Tuesday in the fatal shooting of a clothing store owner on Jan. 3, the police said yesterday. The man, Lamar A. Tidwell, 24, is charged with walking into the Clothing Wholesale and Retail Urban Warestore on Main Street and shooting the owner, Allen Cuff, 34. The men had argued a week earlier, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant Essex County prosecutor. Mr. Tidwell also faces weapons charges in that case. On Saturday he was charged with attempted murder; the authorities said he set fire to his uncle, Richard Burns, 54, in Mr. Burns’s apartment in East Orange after an argument. Mr. Burns suffered injuries over 22 percent of his body and was in critical condition yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. Mr. Tidwell is being held in $1 million bail at the Essex County jail.

headline: Digital Music Up 80% but Shy of Lost Revenue
text: LONDON, Jan. 17  Sales of digitally distributed music rose about 80 percent worldwide in 2006 but failed to make up for falling sales of compact discs, a trade group said Wednesday.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.When shopping online, I often see newsletters or blogs with design advice. Are any worth reading?

headline: A House Built Around a Tower of Books
text: Boston

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Two Seek Large Stake in Tribune
text: As the deadline for bids for the Tribune Company came and went yesterday, the team of Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle made an audacious $500 million offer to help refinance the company while becoming its largest shareholder.

headline: Crew Sensed Trouble Seconds Before Crash
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Seventeen seconds before the crash last August of a Comair flight that took off from the wrong runway in Lexington, Ky., the co-pilot made an odd comment, the first indication that the crew knew something was wrong.

headline: New Questions Raised in Bonds Investigation
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 — In December 2003, Barry Bonds testified before the grand jury investigating the Balco steroid scandal. That grand jury expired without indicting him. Bonds’s case was hauled over to a second grand jury, which focused on whether he had perjured himself before the first grand jury. In July 2006, that grand jury also expired without an indictment. A third grand jury continued the investigation.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about General Electric’s purchase of Smiths Group’s aerospace business misstated G.E.’s percentage of ownership of Smiths GE Detection, a joint venture between the companies. G.E. will own 36 percent, not 46 percent.

text: Photos from productions at the 2007 Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater.

headline: Spontaneity and Pizazz
text: The images by Martin Munkacsi and Henri Cartier-Bresson at the International Center of Photography complement each other, highlighting modernism at its peak between the world wars.

headline: ‘Spamalot’ in Quest of Oliviers
text: The London production of the Broadway hit musical "Monty Python's Spamalot" led the field with seven nominations, including best new musical, when the competitors for the Laurence Oliviers, Britain's foremost theater awards, were announced yesterday.

headline: ‘Coram Boy’ Is Broadway Bound
text: The acclaimed English National Theater production of "Coram Boy" is to open on Broadway at the Imperial Theater on May 2, after previews beginning on April 16.

headline: G.E. May Buy Abbott’s Diagnostic Unit
text: General Electric is near a deal to buy Abbott Laboratories‘ medical diagnostics unit for as much as $5 billion, according to The New York Times. Acquiring the Abbott business, which makes and sells glucose monitoring systems, blood test kits and other chemically based diagnostic tools, would enable G.E.’s health care unit to expand its growing stable of diagnostic products and services.

headline: Delay Denied on Tax Accounting Rule
text: The board that establishes accounting rules decided unanimously yesterday not to postpone a rule that requires companies to take a new, more stringent approach to reporting uncertain tax positions on their financial statements. The Financial Accounting Standards Board denied a request from Tax Executives International, which represents corporate tax officers, to delay the new rule, which takes effect this year. The rule, known as Fin 48, requires companies to examine and document their tax positions, evaluating whether those positions are likely to withstand a challenge by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Raines Seeks Curb on Fannie Mae Regulator
text: Fannie Mae’s former chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, asked a federal appeals court Wednesday to bar the company’s regulator from ruling on a lawsuit seeking more than $84 million in penalties against him. James B. Lockhart, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, “has prejudged the charges” against him “and cannot serve as the impartial decision maker that due process requires,” Mr. Raines said in a filing with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. On Dec. 18, the agency sued Mr. Raines; a former chief financial officer, J. Timothy Howard; and Fannie Mae’s former controller, Leanne G. Spencer, for more than $215 million, citing their roles in profit overstatements of $6.3 billion from 2001 until mid-2004.

headline: Not Playing in a Theater Near You
text: These days, the cosmopolitanism of international filmmaking is matched by the parochialism of American film culture.

headline: Barclays Pays Record Price to Put Name on Nets’ Arena
text: It looks $400 million is the going rate these days to buy naming rights for the play grounds of professional sports teams, at least when investment banks are anteing up. Setting a record price for the naming rights to an American indoor sports arena, the British bank Barclays has agreed to pay nearly $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the New Jersey Nets’ planned future home in Brooklyn, according to press reports. The deal follows Citigroup‘s November agreement to shell out $20 million a year over 20 years to have its name attached to the structure replacing Shea Stadium, the most expensive stadium rights deal in the United States.

headline: Beacon Capital to Put More Properties on the Block
text: Less than three weeks after selling Boston’s John Hancock Tower and other office buildings for about $3.2 billion, Beacon Capital Partners is moving to capitalize on the still-hot commercial real estate market by putting an even larger portfolio of properties in the city on the block, according to The Boston Globe.

headline: Volkswagen Executive Confesses in Corruption Case
text: Volkswagen‘s former personnel chief may get a suspended sentence and a fine in exchange for a confession on breach of trust charges, the judge at his trial over a corruption scandal at the automaker said Wednesday. The former executive, Peter Hartz, is charged with 44 counts of breach of trust in the case, which has shone an unsavory light on the cozy relationship between the company’s management and labor representatives.

headline: R.I.M. Releases More Data on Stock Options
text: Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, released additional preliminary financial results, but gave investors no better sense of the size of the earnings restatement the company would make after a review of its stock option grants to employees. In filings with Canadian and American securities regulators, Research in Motion repeated its earlier warning Tuesday that it could restate more than $45 million in earnings dating back to 1997, and again did not indicate an upper limit.

headline: Apple’s Stellar Results Help Options Medicine Go Down
text: Apparently, nothing effaces the stigma of a scandal like a billion-dollar profit, as BusinessWeek, looking at Apple‘s recent sales figures, points out. Buoyed by record sales of 21 million of its signature iPod digital media players, Apple reaped that billion-dollar bottom line on revenues of $7.1 billion in its fiscal first quarter. Net income surged 78 percent in the period that includes the year-end holiday season, yielding per-share profit of $1.14, Apple said Wednesday.

headline: Goldman Said to Be Backing Lionsgate Slate
text: Lionsgate is putting the finishing touches on a $210 million financing pact led by Goldman Sachs, according to Variety, in a sign that private equity and hedge fund money continues to pour into Hollywood, despite mixed results on those investments in 2006. The deal apparently provides backing for 23 films, excluding, among other projects, the “Saw” movie franchise. Variety said that Lionsgate will receive a distribution fee of 15 percent — on the high side for deals that cover slates of films — showing just how the mini-studio has impressed Wall Street with its track record and its model of modestly priced films.

headline: MTV Hooks Up with Campus Start-Up
text: Viacom‘s MTV Networks announced Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire RateMyProfessors.com. The site, which allows college students to share information on the performance of college professors, has more than 6.6 million ratings on more than 900,000 college professors and is visited by more than 10 million college students, according to MTV Networks. RateMyProssors.com will become a part of MTV Network’s mvtU.com, a 24-hour online college channel that covers campus news, music and videos for college students, as well as a campus television production company.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Says Rules Bar Satellite Radio Merger
text: Has the fat lady sung for a possible merger between Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio Holdings? The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Kevin Martin, said Wednesday that the two satellite radio companies would not win approval of a merger under current rules. Speculation has ramped up in the last few weeks over the possibility of such a deal, which has long been championed by a slew of market watchers, as well as Sirius executives. And last week XM officials were apparently showing signs of enthusiasm themselves at a Citigroup entertainment and media conference.

headline: Universal Poaches Fox Executive for Animated Venture
text: Universal Pictures has raided 20th Century Fox and hired away the animation executive who oversaw the hit “Ice Age” movies, a move intended to fill a void left when Paramount acquired DreamWorks and replaced Universal as distributor of animated films like “Over the Hedge.” Universal has lured Christopher Meledandri, the president of 20th Century Fox Animation, with a deal to initially finance a new company run by Mr. Meledandri, whose animated and live action films would be exclusive to Universal, according to press reports. The plan calls for the firm to ultimately be financed by outside investors.

headline: Chandlers Make Competing Bid for Tribune
text: Tribune Company’s largest shareholder, the Chandler family, has submitted a bid to buy the company and spin off some of its broadcast and entertainment operations in an offer that values Tribune at $7.6 billion.

headline: Canadian Cable Company Begins Share Sale
text: The Canadian cable operator Cogeco Cable said Wednesday it is issuing 4.5 million of its surging subordinate voting shares at 38.50 Canadian dollars ($32.77) each for a total of 173.25 million Canadian dollars ($147.47 million). The net proceeds of the bought deal, underwritten by a syndicate including Scotia Capital, GMP Securities, BMO Nesbitt Burns and CIBC World Markets, are to be used to repay debt and for general corporate purposes.

headline: L.S.E. Doubles Down to Win Shareholder Loyalty
text: The London Stock Exchange stepped up its defense against the 2.7 billion pound ($5.3 billion) bid from it rival, Nasdaq, with the promise that it will give up to 250 million pounds back to shareholders. This is more than double the amount that had been expected in the City of London, and the L.S.E. is hoping it will be enough to persuade its investors to remain loyal and reject the offer, The Guardian reported.

headline: Broadcom Probe May Focus on Founders
text: As federal investigators ramp up their examination of stock option practices at Broadcom, the chip maker, they are likely to put a spotlight on Henry T. Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, the billionaire founders of the company, legal experts told The Los Angeles Times. Broadcom disclosed last month that the Securities and Exchange Commission had elevated its inquiry to a formal investigation, an action that gives the agency the power to subpoena documents and testimony.

headline: Allianz to Buy Out European Stakes for $13.5 Billion
text: The German insurer Allianz said it is offering 10.5 billion euros ($13.5 billion) to buy out the stakes it does not already own in France’s AGF and Germany’s Allianz Leben as it tries to get a better grip on its wide array of European operations. Allianz said the deals would strengthen its position in Europe and in growth markets, simplify its ownership structure and lift earnings per share in 2008.

headline: Merrill to Pour $4 Billion into Real Estate Venture
text: Merrill Lynch plans to invest up to $4.15 billion in a property development partnership with the Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings, Reuters reported. Merrill Lynch’s Japan arm and SBI have agreed to create a special-purpose company to buy land and build condominiums and commercial properties, intending to sell the developments on to real estate funds and other investors, the report said.

headline: Citigroup and Goldman Invest in Indian Software Firm
text: Citigroup and Goldman Sachs will invest a total of $52 million in software firm ICSA of India, the company said on Wednesday. Citigroup would pay $30 million for a 14 percent stake, which will be made up of new shares and 284,000 convertible warrants. Goldman would buy $22 million of foreign currency convertible bonds.

headline: Brightcove Uploads $59.5 Million in Funding
text: An Internet video company, Brightcove, said Wednesday that it had received $59.5 million in funds from dozens of investors, including The New York Times Company. The company, one of dozens of video-sharing start-ups trying to take on Google’s YouTube also took in funding from AllianceBernstein, Brookside Capital, and Maverick Capital.

headline: Equity Office: Sharper Elbows in Buyout Battles
text: With the unprecedented amount of cash sloshing around in private equity’s pockets, it may have been inevitable, but the gloves have come off in buyouts. Late Wednesday, a group of investors offered $38 billion for the nation’s largest office landlord, setting off the biggest buyout battle since the landmark fight for RJR Nabisco nearly two decades ago. The upstart bid for Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust that was founded by Samuel Zell, tops a $36 billion deal that Equity Office had reached with the Blackstone Group in November. Either bid would win the crown as the largest buyout ever, surpassing last summer’s $33 billion deal for HCA.

headline: Hedge Funds Boost Knight Capital’s Profit
text: Knight Capital Group, the second-largest trader of Nasdaq-listed stocks, said fourth-quarter profit increased 13 percent as it handled more shares and fees rose from its Deephaven hedge funds. Net income rose to $47.4 million from $41.9 million a year earlier, while revenue increased 29 percent, to $260.1 million. Deephaven Capital Management produced $27.4 million in pretax profit from asset-management fees, compared with $6.6 million a year earlier. The hedge funds had $4.2 billion under management as of Dec. 31, up from $2.9 billion a year earlier.

headline: Top 10 Responses (So Far)
text: We appreciate all the responses so far, and we’re also taking note of those who put in a little extra effort for contest purposes (see post below). The readers’ sports columnist contest will remain open until the kickoff of Colts-Pats on Sunday at 6:30 p.m. Eastern. So feel free to join the Manning-Brady debate, and you can also send in comments judging fellow contestants.

headline: The Doomsday Clock — and Schlock
text: This just in from the Royal Society and the American Association for the Advancement of Science: The world will end in 2157.

headline: An All-Volunteer Army
text: A day before the festival, volunteers were being trained all over the place. The process seemed to involve surgically implanting a chip into their buttocks briefings on significant logistical issues and a reminder that it is credentials, and not rhetoric, that determines entrance into various hot venues. The Bagger listened for a while and tried to fathom what goodness lurked in people’s hearts that they would volunteer to assist a crowd that is steeped in prerogative and entitlement. “Friendly but firm” was the mantra driving the indoctrination

headline: iSundance
text: Those of you who have an interest in the festival, but not in being part of the crush of 50,000 people, can always skip the queue and take in some of the films and many of the panel discussions on iTunes. (There are also streams available at www.sundance.org/watch). The Bagger, who watched “Good Will Hunting” on his iPod in the airplane on the way out here — he likes to think of Matt and Ben as his little friends who live in a box — thinks that watching films on a tiny little screen with headphones is perfectly acceptable behavior. And on a computer screen, it’s a fine way to pass the time until that freak of a boss returns from another one of those endless lunches.

headline: For $600 More, You Can Buy the Movie
text: The Bagger doesn’t know from tickets at Sundance — he’s sure they’re around here somewhere — but apparently anything with a whiff of heat will cost you both lots of money and some of your dignity. According to cinematical, if you want to go to “Black Snake Moan” and don’t have tickets already, it will cost you $345 bucks. That’s seems to be the going price of social currency within a small, temporary community.

headline: Merrill Posts $2.3 Billion 4th-Quarter Profit
text: Helped by gains from trading and buyouts, Merrill Lynch said its fourth-quarter profit surged 68 percent to $2.35 billion, or $2.41 a share, from $1.39 billion a year earlier. The results, which exceeded analysts’ estimates, fall in line with the record profits other Wall Street firms have shown over the past year, as mergers and acquisitions activity has risen to new heights.

headline: Dead, Not Dead
text: The Hollywood Reporter suggests that the ancient film ratings system is in for an overhaul.

headline: Grim Fairy Tale
text: Dave Poland, over at Movie City News, tells an L.A. fairy tale, which means that the characters who symbolize Betrayal, Arrogance and Deceit end up running a marathon on the Stairmaster. The Bagger didn’t understand it all — allegory is often lost on him — but it seems that sometimes showbiz people are not always straightforward when it comes to taking and giving credit.

headline: On the Ground Reporting
text: Unlike the Bagger, who has been letting that yucky newspaper work get in the way of his one true love — blogging night and day for your consideration — indieWIRE showed up early and often. They have a nice bit on the button of the moment: “Focus on Film.”

headline: Sundance Folkways
text: The Bagger caught a break last night at Sundance. Instead of her annual contribution to the March of Dimes, a kindly movie exec took him to a private dinner where the cool people go in Deer Valley, above Park City. The food was really good, the people were indeed beautiful, and the Bagger did a fair job of pretending he had seen the movies everyone was talking about. He was, however, in a hurry to get back to the condo to practice his one authentic skill — typing. But there were not one, but two, Hummers in his way. (The Bagger, who did not get the memo about proper automotive accessories at Sundance, was driving his father’s Oldsmobile.) The scenario involved well-fed, well-wined people backing huge metal objects up a steep, snow-encrusted driveway. Driver number two failed after repeated efforts and then pronounced his vehicle out of gas. He used the incline and a bit of dicey navigation to get the behemoth down to the bottom of the drive and the Bagger made his escape. This opening ceremony of out of the way, the Bagger thought, your’re in.

headline: On the Hill: Ethics Changes Stalled
text: Late last night, Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, tried to hold a vote on ethics changes. It was blocked. He charged Republican malfeasance. But Republicans said they would block the ethics bill unless it contained the presidential line-item veto, which they said would allow the president to cut out individual earmarks stuck into a bill. The Democrats hope to get the bill through today, but if it doesn’t happen, there could be a sizeable nonpartisan coalition of secretly relieved lawmakers. Our favorite quote from the floor on Wednesday was uttered by Senator Trent Lott, the minority leader:

headline: Has Rice Been Wronged?
text: Noting that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has lately seemed “constantly perturbed when not downright angry,” Kathleen Reardon, a professor of management at the University of Southern California and the author of “It’s All Politics,” questions whether the bond between President Bush and Condoleezza Rice may be weakening. Blogging at The Huffington Post, Reardon says the president “seems to be putting distance between the two of them. He has given more praise and nods of approval lately to Joe Lieberman than he’s given to her.”

headline: Gay Slurs at ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ — Can’t We All Just Get Along?
text: Joining Michael Richards, who blew a fuse on stage late last year and began spewing racial slurs like a Grand Wizard, and before him, Mel Gibson, who saw in a police traffic stop an opportunity to call the world’s Jews out for their prolific war mongering, we now have “Grey’s Anatomy” star Isaiah Washington, who’s drawn the ire of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.

headline: Flashback: The Blackout
text: With winter finally upon us — and temperatures in the 20’s — the July blackout in Queens might seem like a distant memory. But a blistering report from state regulators on Con Ed’s role in the ordeal brought it all back today.

headline: The War Like It’s 2008
text: Iraq has already become a central issue in the burgeoning 2008 race, and it’s extremely evident on Capitol Hill.

headline: Ode to the R.I.A.A.
text: Ever since I phased out my career as a Broadway arranger and conductor, I've tried to keep my toe in the showbiz world in my own peculiar way: I write new, tech-industry lyrics to old melodies.

headline: All of a Sudden, Warrants for Wiretapping
text: Bloggers on both the right and left express confusion over the Bush administration’s surprise announcement that it has given a secret court jurisdiction over the National Security Agency’s wiretapping program. At the National Review Online, Mark Levin says the move “goes to the heart of the White House’s credibility.” “For the Bush administration to argue for years that this program, as operated, was critical to our national security and fell within the president’s Constitutional authority, to then turn around and surrender presidential authority this way is disgraceful.”

headline: After 20 Seasons, Testaverde Has a Shot at First Super Bowl
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 18 — If the New England Patriots beat the Indianapolis Colts and advance to the Super Bowl, it will be a milestone for their 43-year-old backup quarterback, Vinny Testaverde, who has never reached the Super Bowl in 20 N.F.L. seasons.

headline: Colts' Manning Keeps Quiet
text: Colts quarterback Peyton Manning has been noticeably quiet this week in Indianapolis, opting to address the news media only once — at a huge news conference scheduled for Friday afternoon. So it has fallen to the rest of the Colts to guess how Manning will be judged after Sunday's game against the Patriots.

headline: Dolans Look to Malone after Second Cablevision Bid Rejection
text: Shortly after the rejection of their $8.9 billion second offer for Cablevision, the cable company’s ruling Dolan family might be looking to John Malone for some solace, The New York Post reports. Unnamed sources said that the failed bid poses an opportunity for the two sides to talk about selling part or all of the network’s Rainbow Media, home to the AMC and IFC channels, to Mr. Malone’s Liberty Media. As it previously reported, the Post said that the Dolans could use cash from the transaction to make a third run at Cablevision.

headline: Dunn and Others Offered Pleas in Hewlett-Packard Case
text: The California attorney general’s office has offered plea bargains to Patricia Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, and four other defendants, offering them the chance to accept a misdemeanor charge each for their role in a spying scandal at the company, The San Jose Mercury News reported Thursday. But federal prosecutors will continue with their own case, which the Mercury News said could endanger those deals through “double jeopardy” provisions in California’s penal code. (State attorneys are discouraged from pursuing cases in which defendants have been acquitted or convicted in federal court.)

headline: Inch by Inch, Taking Democracy Online
text: The Pew Internet and American Life Project released its first report on the 2006 elections and the extent to which the Internet played a role in the transaction of politics. Seems it was a banner year — and if Lee Rainie, the organization’s grand poo-bah and co-author of the report is to be believed, the 2008 election cycle may well prove something of a tipping point.

headline: Mayor Defends Con Ed, Again
text: The New York State Public Service Commission’s report [text in pdf] on Con Ed’s role [press release] in the nine-day Queens blackout urges that the utility pay $9.3 million in penalties — a number that could be far higher if the Public Service Commission launches what is known as a “prudence proceeding,” which could result in hefty fines.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "The Scene," "Fluke" and "Toys in the Attic."

headline: Phillycars.com
text: An ad for Phillycars.com, a Web site intended to offer a Philadelphia-focused alternative to auto-shopping sites like Cars.com and Vehix.com.

headline: Phillycars.com
text: An ad for Phillycars.com, a Web site intended to offer a Philadelphia-focused alternative to auto-shopping sites like Cars.com and Vehix.com.

headline: We Land Where Others Fly
text: Still trying to be on vacation, but now that the topic lurches to lonelygirl, I had to share some fan fiction recommended by a reader.

headline: J.P. Morgan Is Ready to Spend
text: After pulling in record-breaking profits for 2006, J.P. Morgan Chase‘s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, wants to celebrate with a shopping spree. “If something comes up, we’re prepared at this point to take a look,” Mr. Dimon said on Wednesday.

headline: Ode to the R.I.A.A.
text: Ever since I phased out my career as a Broadway arranger and conductor, I’ve tried to keep my toe in the showbiz world in my own peculiar way: I write new, tech-industry lyrics to old melodies.

headline: John Hall and Kiryas Joel
text: In an article on one of the state’s tighter congressional upsets in November, The Forward looks at the debt that John Hall, the Orleans frontman turned freshman congressman, owes to the Satmar Hasidic leaders of Kiryas Joel.With the backing of Mayor Abraham Wider, Mr. Hall won 88 percent of the village’s vote — and defeated incumbent Sue Kelly. “The rabbis basically hand out pieces of paper and tell people how to vote,” a Hall spokesman says. “They have a history of wanting to vote with winners.” (Eliot Spitzer also got their endorsement.)

headline: More on Pet Projects
text: Last weekend, we reported on the mountain of discretionary capital projects — critics would call most of it pork — that former Gov. Pataki and the legislature divvied up in the waning days of the Pataki administration.

headline: For a Senator, Hedge Funds Are Close to Home
text: Joseph Biden has more than a passing familiarity with hedge funds. As a Democratic senator and a longtime member of that body’s judiciary committee, the Delaware native participated in hearings last year on issues ranging from regulation to naked short-selling.

headline: Tech Companies Get Serious About Global Rights Issues. But Where’s Cisco?
text: It looks like after years of hollering, civil rights groups have nudged some technology companies into a dialogue over how to avoid stomping on human rights, freedom of speech, privacy and other concepts that aren’t considered quite so precious in some countries where the Western companies are aggressively doing business.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Traders Back Suit Against Exchange
text: A lawsuit filed by former New York Stock Exchange seatholders against the exchange has gotten some backing, The New York Post reported Thursday. Filed by Allison Wey, the wife of an N.Y.S.E. broker with Bear Wagner Securities, the $4.5 million suit claims that at a breakfast in February of 2005, Mr. Thain denied the exchange was considering a merger or a public offering. The Weys then sold their seat for $1.54 million the next month. (The N.Y.S.E. eventually merged with the Archipelago electronic exchange, creating one of the world’s largest exchanges with a current market capitalization of $16 billion.)

headline: Bruno Ramps Up Spitzer Attack
text: So much for the honeymoon.

headline: Blogtalk
text: Schumer in his boxers: “a terrifying mental image”? [Owen Kellogg]

headline: Taking Marriage Off the Pedestal
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Jan. 18 column, “The Elusive Altar.”

headline: Did Hedge Funds Fall, or Just Stumble?
text: Is it possible that hedge funds, the media stars du jour, may have lost a little of their shine lately? Data from two reports suggests that may be the case — at least, temporarily. Bloomberg News writes of a new study by Hedge Fund Research showing that hedge fund inflows dropped 64 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006. And a separate report by Spectrem found that among the wealthiest investors, investment in that $1.3 trillion asset class dropped by more than 10 percent.

headline: Heeding Dr. King’s Call
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 18 column, “The Lost Voice of Protest.“

headline: Mehlman Says Goodbye
text: In his farewell speech to Republicans attending the annual G.O.P. winter meeting, the national party’s outgoing chairman, Ken Mehlman, reflected a bit on the losses sustained by his party in the midterm elections and encouraged, even at times goaded, members on moving forward in different ways.

headline: G.E. Buys Abbott’s Diagnostics Unit for $8.13 Billion
text: General Electric will buy Abbott‘s laboratory diagnostics business for $8.13 billion in cash, the two companies announced Thursday afternoon. The acquisition will strengthen G.E.’s own burgeoning diagnostics business as it absorbs the Abbott units. The sale does not include Abbott’s lucrative molecular diagnostics and glucose monitoring businesses.

headline: Reconstruction Hurdles in Lebanon
text: Many in Lebanon believe the current political crisis is slowing efforts to rebuild areas heavily damaged in last summer's war with Israel.

headline: Art Buchwald: A Celebrity for Death
text: Buchwald surprised friends and doctors alike as he turned his "deathbed" into a lively social circuit. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

headline: Art Buchwald: His Political Satire
text: In 1962, Buchwald gave up his comfortable expat life to chronicle Washington politics. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

headline: Art Buchwald: The Herald Tribune Years
text: Landing a column at The Herald Tribune took all of the young Buchwald's wit and charm. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

headline: Art Buchwald: I Just Died
text: Art Buchwald was one of the great American humorists. He delighted in skewering the powerful and the pompous. (Producer: Brent McDonald | Reporter: Tim Weiner)

headline: Consumer Reports Pulls Child Car Seat Report
text: Consumer Reports has withdrawn a bombshell report the magazine published earlier this month that suggested that many of the child car seats currently on the market performed badly at speeds just barely above the government test standard for child safety seats of 30 miles per hour.

headline: Green Light
text: Will Mark Green have a second career in television?

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Mafioso'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "Mafioso," which has been re-released after more than 40 years.

headline: CSpan: Back on the Road Again
text: CSpan announced today that its campaign bus, following the 2008 Like It’s Today approach, will be back on the road again, beginning Sunday.

headline: The Waif From Ipanema
text: My post on changing body fashions in Brazil prompted readers to raise and debate an excellent question: Why do women suffer to look like skeletons even when men don’t want them to?

headline: Another Hat in the Ring
text: The deadline is near for those New Yorkers who wish to be apply for the state comptroller’s job, and some interesting candidates are already popping out of the woodwork. Among them: Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a leading black money manager and philanthropist who two years ago donated $50 million to institutions and individuals working towards racial equality.

headline: First 100 Hours, or Something, Come to a Close
text: House Democratic leaders, flanked by new members, waxed triumphant today as they prepared to pass the last “six for ‘06” measure during the “first 100 hours.” Of course, as has been much examined in the press and much derided by the Republicans, it wasn’t actually 100 hours in the way that, you know, human beings experience the passing of time. And it wasn’t even 100 hours from when the 110th session of Congress opened. But, whatever, they passed ‘em pretty quickly.

headline: Senate Ethics Impasse Broken
text: Update at 9:15 p.m. or so: The Senate passes ethics bill, 96-2.An amendment to create an independent office of Public integrity was defeated.This is without the amendment Republican Senator Judd Gregg and other G.O.P. senators wanted that would have given a president veto power over line items. Under an agreement reached earlier tonight, that will come up next week with the minimum wage legislation.

headline: Is It Finally Time for Tax Reform?
text: The idea of tax reform has been off the table for a long time. Republicans used it effectively as a political issue when they were out of power, but once they got control of Congress they lost interest in the subject. It was too easy to enact every tax cut they wanted without worrying about how it was messing up the tax code.

headline: An Epidemic of Misunderstanding About Children’s Mental Health
text: Roy Richard Grinker, a professor of anthropology at George Washington University, whose 15-year-old daughter is autistic, has just come out with a new book that calls into question what we’ve come to know as the autism “epidemic.” It’s called “Unstrange Minds,” and it makes the argument that the dramatic rise in the incidence of autism in the past few decades is mostly – if not entirely – the result of more and better diagnoses. In other words, in the not-so-distant past, autism as a wide-ranging diagnostic category (a “spectrum disorder”) simply didn’t exist, and it certainly wasn’t consistently measured.

headline: Arriving for Sundance
text: The Carpetbagger (a k a David Carr) arrives for the Sundance Film Festival for the first time and asks the veterans for some advice.

headline: A Bombing in Baghdad
text: Witnesses at a wholesale vegetable market described how three bomb explosions killed at least 10 people and wounded 30. The Times's Damien Cave reports.

headline: Maine City Bans Smoking in Cars Carrying Children
text: Bangor, Maine’s second-largest city, is banning smoking in cars if children are present. The ordinance has delighted some and angered others, leading to complaints about invasion of privacy and even threats to boycott the city.

headline: Approach Boss With Caution
text: PHOENIX — On a scale of one to 10, with 10 being the most volatile personality, Jonathan G. Ornstein, chief executive of the Mesa Air Group, cheerfully admitted, “I used to be an 11.”

headline: Giants Hope Gilbride Can Animate Manning
text: The power structure of the Giants, from the team president, John Mara, to the new general manager, Jerry Reese, to Coach Tom Coughlin, took turns recently expressing a general disappointment in the development of quarterback Eli Manning. Each stated an urgent goal of making him better.

headline: Very Strange and Very Naked
text: I have seen the Glorious Future.

headline: A Chance to Save Their Skin
text: BABY boomers are so last century.

headline: Heaven and High Water in South Carolina’s New Wilderness
text: ONE moment, the paddler was sliding through a narrow passageway between an ancient bald cypress and a towering tupelo gum tree. The next, the upturned yellow hull of his kayak was all any of us could see.

headline: White House Shifting Tactics in Spy Cases
text: In a four-paragraph letter on Wednesday announcing that the Bush administration had reversed its position and would submit its domestic surveillance program to judicial supervision, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales used one phrase three times. A secret court, he said, had fashioned a way to allow the program to be monitored by the judiciary without compromising the need for “speed and agility.”

headline: Art in Review
text: NEW YORK CERAMICS FAIR

headline: Police Shooting Led Mayor to Bolster Review Board
text: Concerns about police-community relations following the Sean Bell shooting prompted the Bloomberg administration to examine the board that investigates claims of police abuse  a review that led the mayor to announce an increase in funds for it during his State of the City speech, city officials said.

headline: Queens: Officer Hurt in Hit-and-Run
text: A police officer was injured last night in a hit-and-run involving a sport utility vehicle that he had stopped in Jamaica, the police said. The S.U.V., a black GMC Yukon, dragged the officer 30 feet to 122nd Avenue and Sutphin Boulevard about 8:30 p.m., they said. It then fled north on Sutphin Boulevard. The vehicle was found abandoned about an hour later on 139th Street. The officer, Sgt. John Pagnotta, 40, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. Investigators said that they had identified the vehicle’s owner and were looking to question him.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by an appeals court to strike down a Maryland law that required companies like Wal-Mart to spend more on employee health care misidentified the state’s attorney general, who has two weeks to appeal. He is Douglas F. Gansler — not J. Joseph Curran Jr., whom Mr. Gansler succeeded earlier this month.

headline: Economy Seems to Be Holding Its Own, but Inflation Risk Persists
text: The economy seems to be shaking off a slowdown brought on by the precipitous drop in housing, the latest economic data suggested yesterday.

headline: Nino and His Oh-So-Present Memories of Underdevelopment
text: In “Mafioso,” Alberto Lattuada’s incomparable, half-forgotten 1962 crime comedy-travelogue (and then some), the divisions between northern and southern Italy are drawn in vivid, almost cartoonish relief. The hero, played by the great Italian comic actor Alberto Sordi — an irrepressible mixture of clown, blowhard and matinee idol — scrambles to reconcile the contradictions between his life in Milan and his Sicilian roots, an identity crisis that is clearly not his alone.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Independence at the Hammer
text: INDEPENDENCE

headline: Departing Chief Warns G.O.P. on Outlook for 2008 Races
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Ken Mehlman, the departing chairman of the Republican National Committee, warned on Thursday that his party would suffer even more devastating losses in 2008 than it did in 2006 if it did not reach out to minorities and address voter concerns about ethics.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the crime and discontent that has accompanied prosperity for some in the Chinese city of Guangzhou referred incorrectly to the city’s economic development. It has reached $7,800 per capita gross domestic product — not per capita income. (Go to Article)

headline: The Races Will Go On (With Imported Snow)
text: The International Ski Federation yesterday gave a green light to the coming World Cup ski races in Kitzbühel, Austria, where organizers used a fleet of helicopters this week to import more than 100,000 cubic feet of snow from higher elevations.

headline: Reforming Health Care (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Russia Considers Ban on Election Protests
text: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Friday.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: Time to Aid Our Own (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Explosion of Antiques, Uptown and Down
text: A selection of antiques events this weekend in Manhattan, including the two major shows reviewed today:

headline: Housing Cost Takes a Bigger Leap Upward
text: The cost of putting a roof over one’s head in the New York metropolitan region rose faster last year than at any other time since Edward I. Koch was mayor, the federal Labor Department reported yesterday.

headline: Reforms for Movie Ratings
text: The motion picture industry has announced that it is reforming its movie ratings system, which has been sharply criticized by moviemakers and by a recent hard-hitting documentary. The reforms are not perfect, and some details remain sketchy, but they are an important step toward making the movies rating more transparent and fair.

headline: People
text: People

headline: Four Singers, Playing Cards, Breaking the Rules of Opera
text: Robert Ashley has never worried that the works he calls operas bear little resemblance to the traditional variety, and there’s no reason he should start now. Far more than Philip Glass’s operas, which are considered revolutionary for their stripped-down narratives and vocal lines that are ritualistically repetitive rather than flighty and virtuosic, Mr. Ashley’s works jettison the standard operatic yardsticks.

headline: Groups Offer Health Plan for Coverage of Uninsured
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  A broad coalition of business and consumer groups, doctors, hospitals and drug companies laid out a major proposal on Thursday to provide health coverage to more than half of the nation’s 47 million uninsured by expanding federal benefit programs and offering new tax credits to individuals and families.

headline: State Farm to Pay $1 Million to Settle Gulf Claim
text: On the eve of trial, State Farm agreed yesterday to pay an estimated $1 million to settle a lawsuit by a Mississippi Gulf Coast resident whose house was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. The settlement came a week after a jury ordered the insurer to pay $2.5 million in punitive damage to a homeowner with a similar case.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded: $7,031,850.29

headline: A Middle Ground for Stem Cells
text: Washington

headline: Secretary General Orders Audits of U.N. Programs
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 19 — Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, called today for outside examination of all United Nations activities after a published report that the United Nations Development Program in North Korea was making unaccountable payments in hard currency to local staff members and the Pyongyang government.

headline: Cost of Corn Soars, Forcing Mexico to Set Price Limits
text: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18 — Facing public outrage over the soaring price of tortillas, President Felipe Calderón abandoned his free-trade principles on Thursday and forced producers to sign an agreement fixing prices for corn products.

headline: With Democrats in Control, New York Awaits More Aid
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  With Congress in the hands of their fellow Democrats, lawmakers and other officials from the New York metropolitan region are seeking to rewrite many of the aid formulas to funnel tens of billions of additional dollars to the region in the coming years.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Innovator and Master, Side by Side
text: In 1932 the young Henri Cartier-Bresson, lately returned from Africa, saw a photograph of African children charging into waves on a beach. “I must say that it is that very photograph which was for me the spark that set fire to fireworks,” he recalled years later. “I couldn’t believe such a thing could be caught with the camera. I said, ‘Damn it,’ took my camera and went out into the street.” What Cartier-Bresson produced during the next few years, as the curator Peter Galassi once wrote, became “one of the great, concentrated episodes in modern art.”

headline: Putting Hitler on the Couch, and Finding Bees
text: The wise beekeeper does not wear dark clothing, lest it pick up light-colored pollen. Italian bees are gentler and more chic than the Austrian variety. The mating box, capping fork and spur-wheel embedder are essential tools for apiculture. And all power in the beehive rests with a treacherous but fragrant bitch.

headline: After 42 Hours (or So), House Democrats Complete 100-Hour Push
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — House Democrats met the goals of their 100-hour legislative offensive with plenty of time to spare on Thursday, claiming that their successes proved they could govern.

headline: More Room to Pirouette at Lincoln Center Studios
text: To the untrained eye, they may just be dance studios  albeit spanking new ones  with the requisite barres, mirrors and sprung floors. But to those who have followed Lincoln Center’s ambitious, sometimes torturous, redevelopment project over the last eight years, they are a milestone: the first piece to be completed.

headline: Surging and Purging
text: There’s something happening here, and what it is seems completely clear: the Bush administration is trying to protect itself by purging independent-minded prosecutors.

headline: Correction: The $250,000 Question
text: An article last Friday about $250,000 second homes around the nation misstated a lake open to the public near Victorville, Calif., a popular second-home area. It is Silverwood Lake, which is in a state recreation area, not Lake Arrowhead, which is private.

headline: Unlikely Pairing, on and Off Court, Helps Energize Nets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 17 — Mikki Moore and Hassan Adams are separated by nine years in age, eight inches in height and eight seasons in N.B.A. experience. They were born on opposite coasts of the United States.

headline: A Warning From the Garden
text: Well, so much for our daffodils! They all bloomed in our front yard last week. They now form a nice bright yellow cluster at the bottom of our driveway. Temperatures of 65 degrees in Washington in January will do that. Frankly, daffodils in January do brighten up the lawn. Maybe next year we’ll try for roses in February.

headline: The Raid on Raters
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about a positive drug test by Barry Bonds misstated the number of random drug tests allowed under an agreement between Major League Baseball and the players association. In addition to testing players on each 40-man roster, the agreement provides for 600 random tests, not 580.

headline: Italy: Hungarian Move by Bank
text: Intesa Sanpaolo, the Italian bank, offered to buy shares in its Hungarian unit, Inter-Europa Bank Nyrt, also known as IEB. Intesa Sanpaolo, which owns 84.7 percent of IEB, which is based in Budapest, offered 4,074 forint ($21) a share, it said.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Spitzer and Corzine Appeal for Antiterrorism Aid
text: HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan 19 — Warning that it would be a “grave mistake” to further reduce antiterrorism financing to the nation’s busiest urban center, Govs. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey pressed the Bush administration today for a substantial increase in federal money to improve security for the region’s highways and mass transit lines.

headline: AT&T Plans ‘Unity’ Strategy for Free Calls
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 — Only weeks after closing its deal for BellSouth, AT&T is embarking on an ambitious strategy to show customers the benefit of its owning 100 million phone lines.

headline: Endorsement for Voting Machine Labs
text: The National Institute of Standards and Technology has recommended approval of two laboratories for testing electronic voting machines under a new federal oversight program. The institute, part of the Commerce Department, said SysTest Laboratories and iBeta Software Quality Assurance, both of Colorado, were the first to pass examinations, and the federal Election Assistance Commission is expected to grant them full accreditation. Voting machine experts have long been concerned about possible conflicts of interests, because the testing laboratories are paid by the companies that make the machines. When the oversight program started last summer, the commission found serious deficiencies at Ciber Inc. and held up the company’s request for temporary certification. Officials said Ciber was still fixing those problems. Ciber and three other companies — Wyle Laboratories, InfoGuard Laboratories Inc. and BKP Security Labs — have also applied for full accreditation.

headline: Perhaps Thinking of Legacy, Bush Has Rice on the Move
text: LONDON, Jan. 18 — Two years from the end of his second term, President Bush — perhaps with his legacy in mind — sent his secretary of state to try to restart moribund peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians and to create a foundation of Muslim support for the administration’s new strategy in Iraq.

headline: Welterweight Bialystock Treads Softly on Big Shtick
text: Max Bialystock is many things — a stinking liar, a crook, a shameless noodge, a stud muffin for the elderly and infirm. And of course a big fat Broadway producer. But a mensch he is not.

headline: Flexing Muscle, China Destroys Satellite in Test
text: China successfully carried out its first test of an antisatellite weapon last week, signaling its resolve to play a major role in military space activities and bringing expressions of concern from Washington and other capitals, the Bush administration said yesterday.

headline: Vatican Meets to Discuss Relations With China
text: ROME, Jan. 19 — The Vatican began two days of closed-door meetings today on the church’s relations with China, which have soured because of a dispute over the right to appoint bishops.

headline: Partial Demolition Planned for a Reminder of Sept. 11
text: The only architectural vestige of the World Trade Center complex still standing aboveground, the “survivors’ stairway,” would be largely demolished under a proposal by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

headline: Beneath the Glitz, a Middle-Class Aspen
text: WHEN Don Bird is on vacation or traveling away from his Aspen home, if someone asks him where he lives, he will answer, “Colorado.” If pressed to be more specific, he might admit that he lives in the mountains, but he will do anything to keep from confessing that he lives in Aspen.

headline: Reverberations, No Charge
text: “Ten Saturdays with Buxtehude,” a free series of organ recitals by John Scott, begins tomorrow at 4 p.m. at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue, at 53rd Street. Other concerts in the series, all at 4 p.m., will be on Feb. 3, 10, 17 and 24; March 31; April 28; and May 12, 19 and 26.

headline: Coke Executive to Resign Post
