text: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its marketing chief, Mary E. Minnick, would leave the company, a month after the company promoted its international chief, Muhtar Kent, to chief operating officer.

headline: Germany: Media Mogul Demands Redress
text: Deutsche Bank and its former chief executive, Rolf E. Breuer, are facing damage claims of 1.4 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from the media mogul Leo Kirch for comments made in 2002 about the creditworthiness of Mr. Kirch’s media group. “The claims have no substance, and we’ll vigorously counter any legal action,” a Deutsche Bank spokesman, Ronald Weichert, said. The bank received a letter from Mr. Kirch’s lawyers demanding it pay the money by Jan. 30 or face a lawsuit, Mr. Weichert said. The dispute stems from a 2002 Bloomberg television interview in which Mr. Breuer said the financial sector was not prepared to provide new loans for Mr. Kirch’s company. The company collapsed a few months later.

headline: Israel Transfers $100 Million to Abbas
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 — Israel transferred $100 million in tax revenues to the office of Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas as part of a plan to bolster him and keep money out of the hands of the Hamas government, officials said today.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Relocating, and Reclaiming a Mentor’s Legacy
text: NOT to nitpick, but somebody who worked for Ralph Nader in his Nader’s Raiders consumer advocate heyday and votes for him whenever he runs for president better be making a legitimate segue back to the New York City rental scene. Henriette Mantel, who has been in Hollywood the past 13 years and is about to release “An Unreasonable Man,” an Oscar-short-listed documentary about Mr. Nader and his devastating feud with the Democratic Party, swears that she is. Nothing under the table for her.

headline: The Rules Are Different, but a Rivalry Remains
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18 — When the Indianapolis Colts stepped into a bitterly cold New England night three years ago, after their last appearance in an American Football Conference championship game, Tony Dungy had words of consolation.

headline: Time Inc. Cutting Almost 300 Magazine Jobs to Focus More on Web Sites
text: In a broad retrenchment, Time Inc. announced yesterday that it would cut nearly 300 employees at its top magazines, including the most profitable publication, People, as it moves to invest more in its Web sites.

headline: Text of Letter to Secretary of Homeland Security
text: Following is the text of the letter that Govs. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Jon S. Corzine sent today to the secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff:

headline: U.S. May Cut Troops in Iraq by Summer, General Says
text: TALLIL AIR BASE, Iraq, Jan. 19 — Gen. George Casey, the top American commander in Iraq, said today that the additional troops being sent to Iraq could begin to be withdrawn by late summer if security conditions improve in Baghdad.

headline: Homelessness, Abuse, Illnesses and Theft Yield to Perseverance
text: For one couple, perseverance in the face of grinding living conditions is slowly leading to a better life.

headline: Deadly Wind and Rain Storm Sweeps Europe
text: FRANKFURT, Jan. 18 — A howling gale churned through the British Isles and Northern Europe on Thursday, killing at least nine people, uprooting trees, shattering windows, flooding beaches and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights at airports from London to Frankfurt.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Art Buchwald, Whose Humor Poked the Powerful, Dies at 81
text: Art Buchwald, who satirized the follies of the rich, the famous and the powerful for half a century as the most widely read newspaper humorist of his time, died Wednesday night in Washington. He was 81.

headline: Stock Market in London Fights Nasdaq With Buyback
text: LONDON, Jan. 18  Clara Furse, chief executive of the London Stock Exchange, wants to keep its unwelcome suitor, Nasdaq, at bay  and now she has put money on it.

headline: Continental Reports a 40% Narrower Loss
text: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it narrowed its fourth-quarter loss by 40 percent as it flew more passengers and increased fares.

headline: Strong Merger Market Aids Merrill Lynch’s 68% Profit Rise
text: Merrill Lynch, the nation’s largest brokerage house, capped a record earnings season for the major brokers yesterday by announcing a 68 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit.

headline: I.B.M. Sales Beat Forecasts on Software and Services
text: I.B.M. reported quarterly profits and revenue yesterday that slightly surpassed Wall Street estimates, lifted by strong software sales and a solid performance from its big services unit.

headline: What’s on Friday Night
text: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) MS. ADVENTURE Rachel Reenstra will be the first to admit that she’s no expert when it comes to animal behavior, although she does have a master’s degree in spiritual psychology and some experience in the proverbial jungle. In the premiere of her series, Ms. Reenstra tries to glean insight into the world of human relationships by delving into animal relationships, starting with some basic instincts — or are they? — involved in parenting.

headline: Decorative Tradition, Laced With Bursts of Eccentricity
text: Art fairs can put some fairly magnificent obsessions on display, where they function like traps. Step into a booth, and an unfamiliar area of visual culture suddenly exerts an irresistible force, changing your life.

headline: Iraq Signals Changes in Protocols With Iran
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 18  Iraq is carrying out an extensive review of its diplomatic protocols with Iran and may place new restrictions on them, the Iraqi foreign minister said in an interview on Thursday, after Iranian military officials and diplomats were picked up in three separate American actions here.

headline: A Light Bulb Goes on, and China Starts Thinking ‘Alternative Energy’
text: ON the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been “alternative energy” and “China.” Are the two worlds about to collide?

headline: Newark: Rape Charge for City Official
text: A city housing official was charged with two counts of rape and one count of official misconduct yesterday after the authorities said he forced his way into the apartment of a woman and assaulted her. The official, Albert Foster, 44, of Somerset, who works as a Section 8 housing inspector, surrendered to the police yesterday, said Paula T. Dow, the Essex County prosecutor. Investigators said Mr. Foster was inspecting a Chadwick Avenue apartment building on Dec. 14 when he attacked a 31-year-old woman who lives there. After the assault, the victim contacted police, Ms. Dow said. Mr. Foster was being held at the Essex County jail yesterday afternoon. Information on bail was not immediately available.

headline: Global Battle Against Measles Is Said to Save 2.3 Million Lives
text: Vaccinators scaled Himalayan peaks in Nepal, waded through Cambodian paddy fields, canoed up the Congo River and rode camels across Somalia’s hinterlands in an effort to immunize children against measles. New data released yesterday documents the scale of their success: the global campaign against measles has saved 2.3 million lives since 1999, mostly in Africa.

headline: Shares Fall on Technology Sales Forecasts
text: Stocks fell for the second consecutive day, buffeted by declining oil prices that sent energy shares down and by sales forecasts from technology companies that fell below analysts’ estimates.

headline: Prosecution Rests in Seeking Death for Killer of Detectives
text: Retired detectives with red eyes and untucked shirts faced the men’s room wall and wiped their faces with brown paper towels. Back in the courtroom, the convicted man covered his eyes. In the front row, his mother, sister and cousins fell together and sobbed.

headline: Overhaul of Schools Would Let Teachers Rate Principals
text: Pressing the case for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s latest round of changes to the city school system, Chancellor Joel I. Klein detailed yesterday how the new powers being granted to principals would be accompanied by new evaluations of them: teachers for the first time would rate their supervisors.

headline: Celebrating the Hard Stuff
text: IN 1955, a handful of mineral enthusiasts (O.K., call them rock geeks) from the Tucson Gem and Mineral Society got together to show off specimens from their personal collections at a local elementary school. From this small beginning, the annual Tucson Gem and Mineral Show has grown into the largest event of its kind in the country, a mega-celebration for rock lovers and a curiously mesmerizing attraction for spectators who don’t know staurolite from Styrofoam. As many as 25,000 people are expected at this year’s show Feb. 8 to 11 in the Tucson Convention Center.

headline: In Baghdad, Pressing to Meet, With Iraqi Help, Pentagon’s Own Standard for Force Levels
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  When Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus assumes his duties as the new American commander in Iraq, he will be guided by a new military doctrine on counterinsurgency that makes the security of the population a chief objective.

headline: Never Mind the Age, Listen to the Numbers
text: If you look as fresh and unbowed as Rita Moreno at 75, you may as well flaunt your age. For her birthday, she announced at Tuesday’s opening-night show of “Little Tributes,” her breezy new cabaret act at the Cafe Carlyle, her husband presented her with a bound copy of The New York Times from the day she was born, Dec. 11, 1931. On the front page was a story about Alphonse XIII, the recently deposed ruler of Spain. In show business Bing Crosby was the new kid on the block; the paper cost 2 cents then.

headline: Ney Is Sentenced to 30 Months in Prison
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — Former Congressman Bob Ney was sentenced to 30 months in prison today for accepting tens of thousands of dollars in illegal gifts in return for using his legislative influence to help his benefactors.

headline: Top Blair Aide Arrested in Fund-Raising Inquiry
text: LONDON, Jan. 19 — The police arrested and questioned a senior aide to Prime Minister Tony Blair today in what seemed a widening inquiry into allegations that political leaders traded high honors for campaign contributions made as loans.

headline: All Together: Let’s Go, Jack! Let’s Go, Jill! (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Patron Saint of Sensible Sneakers
text: Went to the mall this week and purchased my first pair of Starburys, white low tops with many air holes in the front, paper balled up inside, the nickname of a wealthy N.B.A. player printed in the arch, and all for the unbelievably discounted price of $9.98.

headline: North Korea and U.S. Differ on Nuclear Arms Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 19 — The North Korean Foreign Ministry said today that it had reached a “certain agreement” with Christopher Hill, the lead American negotiator, during talks in Berlin this week over its nuclear arms program.

headline: Manhattan: City Unemployment Drops
text: New York City’s unemployment rate dropped to 4.3 percent in December, the second-lowest level in the 30 years that extensive records have been kept for the city. The jobless rate, which is adjusted by the State Labor Department to account for seasonal fluctuations, was 4.5 percent in November after hitting a low of 4.1 percent in October. The number of private-sector jobs in the city increased by 45,500, or 1.5 percent, in 2006, the Labor Department reported. New York State’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 4 percent in December, down from 4.2 percent in November. Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the data “suggest that the economy may have decelerated a bit” at the end of last year.

headline: France: Royal Ruffled by Aide and Partner
text: Ségolène Royal, the Socialist presidential candidate, suspended one of her two spokesmen for a month after he said she “has only one flaw”: her longtime partner and the father of their four children, François Hollande, who is the leader of the Socialist Party. The aide, Arnaud Montebourg, made the comment on a television program on Wednesday evening. When the audience reacted with silence, he quickly added, “It was a joke.” Last week, Mr. Hollande suggested that taxes be raised for the middle class, an idea Ms. Royal promptly brushed aside. The new strains on her campaign came as her rival on the right, Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy, outpaced her in two recent opinion polls.

headline: Officials Say They’ll Break Up Latino Gang in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 — The authorities said Thursday that they would dismantle a Latino gang that has been accused of racially motivated violence, including the shooting death last month of a 14-year-old black girl.

headline: Ambush Kills an American Teaching Democracy to Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 18 — An American woman killed here on Wednesday when gunmen fired on her convoy of vehicles was ambushed just minutes after leaving the headquarters of a prominent Sunni Arab political party, where she had been teaching a class on democracy, party members said Thursday.

headline: Small but Sufficient
text: WHO Wyndi Gundrum-Cooper, 47, a real estate agent from Ocean Isle Beach, N.C.

headline: When the Visitors Are From Home
text: Most concerts presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center rely on players from the organization’s standing roster. The society’s International String Quartet Series, on the other hand, usually offers a steady supply of visiting groups. But at a recital by the Daedalus Quartet on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, the society had it both ways: Daedalus, founded in 2000, is part of the organization’s CMS II program for young musicians. But it also enjoys a busy career independent from its work at Lincoln Center.

headline: Miner’s Shacks, Mansions and the Real-Life West
text: FOR most Americans, Montana signifies the mythical West, a place to dream of buying a working ranch or a mountain hideaway. And Red Lodge is one of those places where Montana real estate fantasies can come true, and fairly cheaply.

headline: Queens: Guilty of Crack House Murder
text: A South Ozone Park man was convicted yesterday of robbing a man inside a crack house in Jamaica and shooting the man’s stepson to death during a subsequent confrontation, prosecutors said. The man, Timmy Lee Walker, 33, was convicted of murder, kidnapping and robbery in State Supreme Court, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Walker robbed James Hubbard, 48, at gunpoint on Sept. 5, 2004, while the men were in the crack house on 140th Street. About an hour later, Mr. Hubbard; his stepson, Tony Brunson, 22; and another man rushed into the house, and Mr. Walker shot Mr. Brunson to death, Mr. Brown said. The other two men subdued him until the police arrived, he said. Mr. Walker faces up to 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced on Feb. 8.

headline: You Watch This Art. You Should Also Watch Out.
text: When books or paintings become too dizzying, you can walk away until you’re ready for more. But performance art keeps coming at you, ready or not. Though audience members can practice some form of pacing, much of the work’s effect depends on the artist’s skill in knowing how much is too much, or when too much is just enough.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary last Friday about Maureen Orcutt, an outstanding golfer starting in the 1920s and one of the first women to become a sportswriter, attributed a distinction to her erroneously. She is not a member of the World Golf Hall of Fame.

headline: A Mouthful and an Earful (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Maine City Bans Smoking in Cars With Children
text: BANGOR, Me. — Tonya Henderson will have to be more careful where she lights up her Marlboros.

headline: Jury Spares Driver in Smuggling Deaths Case
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 18 — The truck driver who carried 19 illegal immigrants to their deaths in his suffocating trailer in 2003 was spared execution on Thursday and sentenced instead to life in prison without parole.

headline: U.S. Dominance in Space Challenged by China’s Test
text: BEIJING, Jan. 19 — China’s apparent success in destroying one of its own orbiting satellites with a ballistic missile signals that it intends to contest American military supremacy in space, a realm many here consider increasingly crucial to national security.

headline: Read This Flyer
text: Here is information about the events mentioned in this article. All take place at Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 840-2824.

headline: Senate Passes Vast Ethics Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — The Senate on Thursday overwhelmingly passed sweeping changes to ethics and lobbying rules, overcoming bipartisan reluctance to ban many of the favors that lobbyists do for lawmakers and to illuminate the shadowy legislative practice of earmarking money for special projects.

headline: Retelling Shakespeare With an Abundance of Tenors
text: If the main characters in Rossini’s “Otello” were not named Otello, Desdemona and Iago, most of the audience would never guess that this opera is based on Shakespeare’s tragedy. The story is bowdlerized into a generic drama of romantic intrigue, jealousy and revenge.

headline: A Personal Toll to Setting Aside the Umbrella
text: Ever since Citigroup said it was considering whether to retire its ubiquitous red umbrella logo, the mostly muted reaction has been surprising. For years, many in New York and beyond complained that the giant umbrellas affixed to many of the company’s buildings cast a tacky glow.

headline: Editor of Turkey’s Armenian Paper Is Killed
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 19 — The editor of Turkey’s only Armenian-language newspaper was assassinated today on an Istanbul street.

headline: Classroom Distinctions
text: IN the past year or so I have seen Matthew Perry drink 30 cartons of milk, Ted Danson explain the difference between a rook and a pawn, and Hilary Swank remind us that white teachers still can’t dance or jive talk. In other words, I have been confronted by distorted images of my own profession — teaching. Teaching the post-desegregation urban poor, to be precise.

headline: Florida: Not-guilty Pleas in Boot Camp Death
text: Seven former guards and a nurse charged in the death of a 14-year-old boy at a boot camp in Panama City in January 2006 have pleaded not guilty. The guards and the nurse were charged in November with aggravated manslaughter in the death of the boy, Martin Lee Anderson. A security videotape from the camp showed the guards covering Martin’s mouth, forcing him to inhale ammonia and striking him repeatedly after he stopped running on his first day at the camp. The nurse is seen on the tape watching the guards. The defendants face up to 30 years in prison if convicted.

headline: To Execute, or Not to Execute? That Is the Uneasy Question
text: There is no reason for you to recognize the name Gerhard Arthur Puff, but it looms rather large right now in New York jurisprudence.

headline: No Clear-Cut Path for Tribune’s Board
text: When members of the Tribune Company board assemble this weekend to review bids for the company, they will have a lot to consider but not much to be happy about.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: To Simplify, Allianz Will Acquire All of French Unit
text: FRANKFURT, Jan. 18  Allianz, the largest insurer in Europe, announced Thursday that it would buy out the minority shareholders of its French subsidiary AGF for $12.6 billion, another step in a drive by Allianz’s chief executive, Michael Diekmann, to reduce the complexity of his company.

headline: A Coalition for Firm Limit on Emissions
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Ten major companies with operations across the economy — utilities, manufacturing, petroleum, chemicals and financial services — have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A television review in Weekend last Friday about “24” misstated the method the president’s sister uses to destroy personnel files sought by the F.B.I. She deletes them from a computer; she doesn’t shred them.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about the New Orleans Saints’ financial situation gave the wrong day for the team’s playoff game last week against the Philadelphia Eagles. The game was played on Saturday, not Sunday.

headline: Russian, American-Style, and a Loner on a Quest
text: Hard to say what ballets fit into what categories on Wednesday night in “Tradition and Innovation,” the catch-all title of the second of 10 themed programs to be presented by the New York City Ballet during its winter season at the New York State Theater. Tradition was possibly best represented by Mauro Bigonzetti’s “In Vento,” a hit from last spring’s Diamond Project festival, and George Balanchine’s “Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2,” with Balanchine’s “Mozartiana” holding the fort for innovation.

headline: Fed Chief Warns That Entitlement Growth Could Harm Economy
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Warning against complacency over the federal deficit, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that recent positive trends on the budget were a “calm before the storm,” masking a long-term danger posed by looming deficits in Social Security and Medicare.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart on Tuesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the slowdown in the condominium market mislabeled the top line of the scale showing the number of condos for sale. It is 25,000, not 30,000. A corrected graphic can be found online.

headline: Springfield, U.S.A., My Second Home
text: AS an actor, I never set out to work in the same place for decades. I certainly never intended to log hours in a fictional hospital among chiseled doctors and sultry patients. But playing a trusty orderly on “Guiding Light” — the longest-running soap opera in history — has been a ritual spanning my entire adult life.

headline: Decorative Arts Galleries Offer Worthy Complements to the Armory Show
text: DECORATIVE ARTS GALLERIES

headline: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
text: As the court-appointed guardian and self-described fixer of some of America’s most wayward companies, Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator, is considered a pillar of corporate ethics and governance.

headline: Ron Carey, Comic Actor, Dies at 71
text: Ron Carey, the pint-sized, round-faced comic best known as the unjustifiably cocky Police Officer Carl Levitt on the long-running television situation comedy “Barney Miller,” died Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 71.

headline: Germany: Bavarian Leader Leaves the Stage
text: Edmund Stoiber, a leading conservative powerbroker and an ally and irritant to Chancellor Angela Merkel, said he would step down in September as Bavaria’s prime minister and leader of the Christian Social Union, a sister party of Mrs. Merkel’s Christian Democrats. Mr. Stoiber, the governor of Bavaria, Germany’s largest state and its economic powerhouse, for almost 14 years, had been under attack from within his party as opinion polls showed his and the party’s ratings sinking. Last month, he was forced to accept the resignation of his chief of staff after a party member critical of Mr. Stoiber accused the aide of snooping on her private life. The polls also shook Mrs. Merkel’s party, which relies on the muscle of the Bavarian conservatives in federal elections.

headline: Pentagon Revises Its Rules on Prosecution of Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — The Pentagon on Thursday unveiled its new courtroom rules for prosecuting prisoners held as terrorists, allowing military tribunals to consider hearsay evidence and testimony obtained through coercion, but not torture.

headline: Rebuke in Iran to Its President on Nuclear Role
text: Correction Appended

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about a 1906 Maxfield Parrish painting of Old King Cole, which was removed from the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan for its first extensive cleaning since the 1950s, misidentified the man who commissioned it and whose face is believed to have been the model for the king’s. He is John Jacob Astor IV — not John Jacob Astor, his great-grandfather.

headline: Lights-Out Science
text: The Museum of Natural History isn’t the only museum to offer sleepover programs. All are popular; campers are advised to book early.

headline: Keeping Their Distance, but Still Playing for the Homeland
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 18 — It has been a rough week for Serbia’s image in the tennis world, with scores of young Serbian fans brawling with their Croatian counterparts in the usually more sedate alleyways of the Australian Open on opening day.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Jan. 11 by The New York Times Regional Newspapers about James C. Weeks, a former president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Regional Media Group, incorrectly described his postgraduate education. He was a graduate of the Program for Management Development at the Harvard Business School — not a recipient of a master’s degree in marketing from the University of Florida, where he earned his undergraduate degree. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his wife. She is Toney Weeks, not Toni.

headline: What's in a Name? $400 Million
text: When the Nets were a goofball franchise, it was impossible to imagine their owners consorting with a global financial power like Barclays. But the Nets aren’t laughable anymore, and yesterday, their principal owner, Bruce C. Ratner; some of his investors, like the rapper Jay-Z; and a few of their players were at the Brooklyn Museum to announce that Barclays will pay a record $400 million over 20 years to put its name on the team’s new arena. “Barclays is saying Brooklyn is the place to be,” Ratner said at a luncheon in the elegant Beaux-Arts Court, accompanied on a platform by Jason Kidd, Vince Carter, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern. (Ratner’s company is the development partner on the new headquarters for The New York Times.)

headline: A Place Where Hope Dies, and a Boy Who Escapes
text: A dark fairy tale from Russia, “The Italian” — more on that title in a moment — pulls you into a richly atmospheric, persuasively inhabited world teeming with foundlings and pathos. Directed by Andrei Kravchuk, making his feature debut, from a screenplay by Andrei Romanov, the film pivots on a 6-year-old stray, Vanya (the wonderful Kolya Spiridonov), who lives in an institution easily meriting that well-worn adjective Dickensian. Overcrowded and brutally underfinanced, it is the kind of place in which hope dies slowly but surely, vanishing a little more with each new birthday. It is a holding pen for young bodies with very old souls.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Campaign Finance Case
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The Supreme Court stepped back into the debate over campaign finance regulation today, announcing an expedited review of a ruling last month that substantially narrowed the application of a major provision of the McCain-Feingold federal campaign law.

headline: Archdiocese Set to Announce Church Closings
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is set to announce today its final list of parishes that will close as part of a far-reaching reorganization plan, bringing to an end a decision-making process that has dragged on for more than five years and trapped many parishioners in uncertainty.

headline: Con Ed May Face Millions in Penalties After Panel’s Finding That It Bungled Blackout
text: Consolidated Edison now faces the prospect of $9.3 million in penalties and tens of millions of dollars in additional sanctions as the result of a scathing state report into its handling of the nine-day blackout in Queens that left 174,000 people without power last summer.

headline: Ordeal by Appliance: Weekend Home Tales
text: FOR some people, the most elusive aspect of owning a vacation home that sits beyond big-city borders isn’t finding the time to enjoy it. It’s finding someone to service the deluxe appliances inside.

headline: Study on Nicotine Levels Stirs Calls for New Controls
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  A Harvard study concluding that cigarette makers have for years deliberately increased nicotine levels in cigarettes to make them more addictive led to renewed calls Thursday for greater federal oversight of the industry.

headline: Small Area Has Big-Time Talent
text: If a high school basketball team wanted to put an easy game on its schedule, it would be well-advised to stay out of northern New Jersey.

headline: Williams Shakes Off Rust, Powers Herself to the Fourth Round
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 19 — It was an unexpected joy ride on the relearning curve for Serena Williams in the third round of the Australian Open.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 4 about heart-valve problems linked to two drugs for Parkinson’s disease misstated the year that one of them, Permax, added a black-box warning label, the strongest warning required by the Food and Drug Administration. It was 2006, not 2003.

headline: Consumer Reports Retracts Article on Car Seats
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Consumer Reports magazine today retracted an article on infant car seats, published two weeks ago, that said most of them had failed side-impact crash tests.

headline: A Report Brings Back Memories of Living in the Dark
text: Just days before Dan Glasser’s future in-laws flew in from San Diego last summer, he and his fiancée made the rounds of butcher and seafood shops in their Queens neighborhood, gathering fresh fish, shrimp and prime cuts of steak.

headline: Bush’s Reversal on Wiretapping (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain: Reins Tighten on BBC Financing
text: The BBC said it might have to cut back on the creation of television shows and other programming after the government awarded it less public financing over the next six years than it had requested. The BBC’s license fee, which every British household with a television is required to pay, will rise to £148 ($290) in 2012, from £131.50 last year. The fee will generate more than £20 billion ($39.4 billion) for the BBC over the six years, about £2 billion less than the BBC had requested, the broadcaster said. “We now face not just a tight settlement but daunting investment challenges in distribution, infrastructure and technology that risk diverting money away from content creation,” said Mark Thompson, above, the director general of the BBC.

headline: Apology Not Accepted
text: Correction Appended

headline: Jury Selection in Libby Trial Moves Slowly Because of Bias
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The task of seating a jury for the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. did not get easier Thursday when a majority of the candidates interviewed were disqualified, mainly because they expressed deep distrust of the Bush administration and the Iraq war.

headline: Manhattan: Heroin Ring Arrests
text: Three people have been extradited and charged with participating in an international heroin-smuggling operation, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The three, Yaya Yahayai, 50; Henry Sichone, 42; and Andrew Sarpong, 33, are charged with involvement in a smuggling operation that bought heroin in Thailand and moved it through various routes to cities in the United States, including New York, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said the ring recruited couriers who smuggled heroin by swallowing it or using false compartments in suitcases.

headline: Sundance Dream Most Notable for an Absence
text: PARK CITY, Utah

headline: The Good, the Bad and the Bush Baby: New Low on ‘Idol’?
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 — The season-opening episodes of “American Idol” are notorious for their auditions by untalented performers and the catty comments of the judges, particularly Simon Cowell, whose one-liners have been known to deflate the most confident of hopefuls.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Iraqi Draft Law on Oil Revenue Appears Close
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 19 — After months of tense bargaining, a cabinet-level committee has produced a draft law governing Iraq’s vast oil fields that would distribute all revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers in exploration, development and awarding of major international contracts.

headline: Wall Street Is Betting on the Farm
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 — Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures.

headline: Correction: In Texas, Monarchs Flutter and Admirals Alight
text: An article last Friday about observing butterflies in the Lower Rio Grande Valley misstated the trees that are hung with Spanish moss there. Many indigenous trees, including species of elm and ash, have Spanish moss there, but oaks are not among them.

headline: Law Firms Are Urged Not to Force Retirements
text: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association is calling on law firms to end the practice of mandatory retirement for partners.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the crime and discontent that has accompanied prosperity for some in the Chinese city of Guangzhou referred incorrectly to the city’s economic development. It has reached $7,800 per capita gross domestic product — not per capita income.

headline: Consumer Reports Retracts Article on Car Seats
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Consumer Reports magazine on Thursday retracted an article on infant car seats, published two weeks ago, that said most of them had failed side-impact crash tests.

headline: Unfettered Debate Takes Unflattering Turn in Michigan Supreme Court
text: In a recent series of written dissents, Justice Elizabeth A. Weaver of the Michigan Supreme Court has accused four of her colleagues of “bully tactics,” “abuses of power and grossly unprofessional conduct” and trying to censor her.

headline: China: Intel Considers Building Chip Plant
text: Intel is considering building its first semiconductor factory in Asia in the northeastern Chinese city of Dalian. China’s central government has approved the project, said Gao Fujun, assistant counsel at the Dalian Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Bureau. An Intel spokesman, Mark Miller, said the company was in talks with several governments about its next chip factory. The company won approval to build a factory in the Dalian Economic and Technological Development Zone, Mr. Gao said. Intel has assembly and testing plants in Shanghai and Chengdu.

headline: Williams, in Comeback, Ousts Petrova
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 19 — It was quite a journey to victory for Serena Williams in the third round of the Australian Open.

headline: G.E. Agrees to Buy an Abbott Laboratories Unit
text: The General Electric Company reached an agreement yesterday to buy part of the diagnostic-equipment unit of Abbott Laboratories for $8.13 billion to expand its line of testing devices.

headline: Feminism’s Fictional Powerhouse
text: “Jane Eyre” may not be the first feminist novel, but it is certainly one of the most enduring. There have been at least 20 movie and television versions of Charlotte Brontë’s gothic love story, even more than of “Emma” or “Pride and Prejudice.”

headline: White Plains: Man Charged With Rape
text: A Manhattan man has been named in a 23-count indictment accusing him of kidnapping and raping a 12-year-old girl in Westchester County on Dec. 28, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, William Davis, 46, of 126th Street, is charged with rape, kidnapping and predatory sexual assault, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester district attorney. Mr. Davis is scheduled to be arraigned today. Ms. DiFiore said Mr. Davis is accused of luring a Brooklyn girl into his car by identifying himself as a police officer, taking her to Westchester and raping her.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Movie details with a film review of “Arthur and the Invisibles” in Weekend last Friday included an erroneous running time provided by the distributor and referred incorrectly to the movie’s rating. The film is 94 minutes, not 102, and it is rated PG; it is not unrated.

headline: Grace Notes: To Be Young and in Paris in 1968
text: “Regular Lovers” was shown as part of the New York Film Festival in 2005. Following are excerpts from the review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 24, 2005; the full text is here. The unrated film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

headline: Senators Demand Details on New Eavesdropping Rules
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — Lawmakers demanded more information on new rules for governing a domestic surveillance program on Thursday, a day after the Bush administration announced that it had placed the National Security Agency eavesdropping under court supervision.

headline: O Brave New World That Has Such Gamers in It
text: This week it’s likely that thousands of people cut school, called in sick and otherwise turned away from the real world so they could be among the first adventurers to traverse the Dark Portal and battle the demons of the Burning Legion in the broken world of Outland.

headline: The Setai, New York, and the Trump Ocean Resort, Baja, Mexico
text: WHAT Metropolitan residential building.

headline: Tell the Troops
text: It is bad enough for troops in Iraq to learn that their tours of duty have been extended. It is terrible for them to have to hear about it from loved ones at home rather than from their military commanders.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Personal Shopper column yesterday in House & Home, about the Americana at the Piers antiques show (55th Street and 12th Avenue), gave incorrect dates for the show. It will be open tomorrow and Sunday; it does not open today.

headline: The Iraq War and the Trillion (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cuisine Is Strictly Cajun, but Loyalty Is to Da Bears
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 — Like Mike Ditka, who coached the Chicago Bears to the Super Bowl and the New Orleans Saints to more misery, Jimmy Bannos has close ties to both cities that will be represented in Sunday’s National Football Conference championship game.

headline: A Rapper, Backed Up by Brass
text: What do you get for the guy who has everything? You give him a sparkly evening to redefine American popular song, of course. But unless the guy is a brilliant performer and a born bandleader, you might want to add some accessories to that gift: a bunch of rehearsals, a merciless musical director.

headline: Amid Chaos, Young Somalis Struggle to Get By
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 18 — A week ago, Yoonis Issay Alin was riding around in the back of a pickup, part of a squad of tough-looking guys with big trucks and big guns.

headline: Parents of 9/11 Victims Torn From Grandchildren
text: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.  Five years after their father was killed at the World Trade Center, two little girls, ages 7 and 5, sat crying in a car parked at the curb of their grandparents’ home here one December day, refusing to go inside for a court-ordered visit. It was a painful family tableau rooted in a hundred tangled details, but one overriding and uncontested reality: 9/11.

headline: A U.S. Civilian in Baghdad: Standing Out, Even in Death
text: CLEVELAND, Jan. 18  Andrea Parhamovich always stood out.

headline: House Votes to Rescind Oil Drillers’ Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 — House Democrats easily passed legislation on Thursday that would rescind $14 billion in tax breaks and subsidies for oil drillers and reserve the money to develop alternative energy projects and conservation technologies.

headline: Bulldozers Hit the Beach in Los Cabos
text: IS Los Cabos the next Cancún?

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Big Brother’ Tumult Continues

headline: Albany: Student Lender Investigated
text: The New York attorney general’s office is looking into certain methods of student loan marketing by Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest lender to students, the lender said yesterday. The company disclosed in a regulatory filing that Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo had requested information and documents relating to “preferred lender lists” used by colleges and universities. A spokesman for Sallie Mae, Tom Joyce, said the company was cooperating with the request. “We are confident that once the attorney general’s staff has reviewed our marketing practices,” he said, “they will agree that they are in the best interest of students and schools.” Some loan companies have criticized preferred-lender lists, contending that college officials steer students to particular lenders in exchange for payments or other benefits. The federal Education Department is also considering regulating the lists.

headline: Parents Believe Abducted Son Was Abused
text: Appearing yesterday on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” Craig and Pam Akers said they believed that their son, Shawn Hornbeck, had been sexually abused during the four years he was allegedly held captive in a suburban St. Louis apartment by Michael Devlin.

headline: A Producer for All Seasons (Also Juggles)
text: A HUNGRY producer shivering in the snow outside a theater, handing out flyers to his latest event, is a far less glamorous image than that of a flamboyant impresario, flanked by chorus girls, holding court in a cloud of cigar smoke. But on many nights, rain or shine, outside a Broadway theater is where you’ll find Scott Siegel, a producer, writer, critic and aspiring show business entrepreneur, leafleting one of four events he puts on each year at Town Hall.

headline: Movie Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Gates Says U.S. Has Few Options to Halt Iran’s Atomic Plans
text: MANAMA, Bahrain, Jan. 18  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday played down the possibility of American military action against Iran but said it was not the right time for diplomatic engagement, either.

headline: Organ Fanfare for Buxtehude. Who?
text: MEMO to Moravian College students: Come back.

headline: Nowhere to Turn for Shelter
text: In the long and sordid story of Hurricane Katrina, a new low may be approaching. In Louisiana alone, tens of thousands of displaced families who rely on the government to provide trailers or rent will lose their temporary housing next month — unless the Bush administration extends the standard 18-month time limit for their federal aid.

headline: As College Grows, a City Is Asking, ‘Who Will Pay?’
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — For most of the last 40 years, this eclectic seaside city and its University of California campus have lived in relative harmony. With its beaches, bistros and relaxed intellectual vibe, Santa Cruz has long held an allure for those seeking a mellower college experience, a place where hiking trails, yoga mats and surfboards are as common as backpacks filled with books.

headline: Government Forces in Sri Lanka Take Key Town
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 19 — Thousands of civilians waving white flags fled from heavy fighting in eastern Sri Lanka today as government forces captured a strategic coastal town from rebel forces after an extended siege.

headline: Lawmakers Wary of Talks With Iran and Syria
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The head of the bipartisan advisory group that urged a change in the American approach to Iraq insisted today, in the face of skepticism from Congressional leaders, that the United States should engage Iran and Syria diplomatically as it moves to reduce its role in Iraq.

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
text: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 18 — It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at the Ford Motor Company.

headline: Venezuela Wants Trade Group to Embrace Anti-Imperialism
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18  South American leaders began gathering here on Thursday for discussions focused on a single, contentious issue: should the Mercosur trade group continue to emphasize economic integration, as Brazil and Argentina prefer, or transform itself into a political alliance with an “anti-imperialist” tint, the path President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela favors?

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Uneasy at First, Mets Embrace Their New Orleans Connection
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 — A woman wearing a pink cowboy hat covered in rhinestones walked down Bourbon Street on Wednesday night and spotted a character with equally outrageous headgear.

headline: Nepal: Rebels Disband Their Government
text: Prachanda, the leader of the Maoists, said that the rebels would scrap the parallel state of courts and government units they ran in rural areas under their control, another significant step in ending the country’s protracted civil war. Earlier this week, former rebels took their seats in a new interim Parliament.

headline: Shanghai Bribery Inquiry Ensnares Big Firms
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 19 — The Shanghai police have detained 22 people in a bribery investigation that has ensnared some of the world’s biggest companies, including McDonalds, Whirlpool, McKinsey and ABB, according to reports in the state-run news media.

headline: Burmese Daily at Odds With Democracy Advocate
text: SINGAPORE, Jan. 18  A state-run newspaper in Myanmar on Thursday accused the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of tax evasion for spending the money she won for the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize and other foreign awards outside the country.

headline: Night of the Iguanas (and Dinosaurs and Whales) in the Museum Wilds
text: These days “A Night at the Museum” is one of the hottest tickets in New York. But don’t be misled. This is not the hit movie in which Ben Stiller plays a security guard at a fictionalized American Museum of Natural History, only to discover that the fossils and specimens come to life at dusk, racing and rampaging through the galleries. This is a real overnight at the actual museum, and the racers and rampagers are not Tyrannosaurus rex skeletons and bloodthirsty barbarians, but kids.

headline: Archdiocese  to Shut 21 N.Y. Parishes
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced today that it is closing 21 parishes as part of a far-reaching reorganization plan, bringing to an end a decision-making process that has dragged on for more than five years and trapped many parishioners in uncertainty.

headline: A Talking Head Meets His Comic Doppelgänger, and Sparks Fail to Fly
text: The exchange was billed as the ultimate cable news vs. fake news smackdown: Stephen Colbert, who pretends to be a Bill O’Reilly-esque television pundit on his comedy show, “The Colbert Report,” was a guest on Mr. O’Reilly’s show on Fox News last night, and Mr. O’Reilly appeared on Mr. Colbert’s mock talk show on Comedy Central.

headline: Free-Spirited Innocence, With a Hint of Menace
text: Mark Morris began the sold-out nine-performance run of the Mark Morris Dance Group Wednesday night by accepting a WQXR American Gramophone Award (WQXR is owned by The New York Times Company), which pays tribute to individual excellence in music. “Music is a song and a dance,” Mr. Morris said, quoting the late composer Lou Harrison. “Enjoy the show.”

headline: Perspectives on Womanhood, in a Dialectic of Desire
text: “Good Girl/Bad Girl,” Maude Maggart’s must-see new cabaret show, begins with a smirking musical question, written in the 1920s: “How could Red Riding Hood/Have been so very good/And still kept the wolf from the door?” The song goes on to comment with a raised eyebrow: “Father and mother she had none/So where in the world did the money come from?”

headline: Treasure Hunt for Grown-Ups With Money
text: Mature is the word in the trade for fairs like the Winter Antiques Show, though time-honored, even venerable, would be closer to the mark. The show, which opens today, has been around forever (well, since 1955). It delivers substantial, sometimes spectacular retail; always has. Dealers and clients alike return, like swallows to Capistrano, year after year. So if solid tradition, rather than Art Basel Miami Beach-style blowouts, is what you want in a fair, this one’s for you.

headline: St. Benedict’s Basketball Plays Two
text: NEWARK, Jan. 18 — There were two home teams in the St. Benedict’s Preparatory School gymnasium Thursday night. One was wearing its white home jerseys, trimmed in maroon and gray, and playing the Kima School from Washington. The other St. Benedict’s team was wearing street clothes and cheering from the stands.

headline: The French Know Where 007 Acquired His Savoir-Faire
text: PARIS, Jan. 18 — James Bond has never seemed fascinated by the French, but the French certainly are fascinated by James Bond.

headline: With Onion and Pickle, Please
text: The Onion, the humor Web site, has weighed in on Manning-versus-Brady, and seems to have the A.F.C. championship game figured out.

headline: The Forecast
text: We’ve concentrated on Patriots-Colts. It’s a more compelling matchup, and the survivor will be expected to win the Super Bowl.

headline: Greek Revival by the Gasworks
text: A burgeoning neighborhood in Athens attracts a cultured crowd.

headline: A Time Traveler in Shanghai
text: Exploring the line between old China and new China in this global city's shops, restaurants and museums.

headline: Traders Take a Bow
text: On Wednesday night, the biggest star of the first annual Trader Monthly Awards Reception was not any of the winners. It was a $369,000 car.

headline: Wall Street Is Betting on the Farm
text: Wall Street commodity funds that have been investing heavily in energy futures are now loading up on agricultural commodities like corn and livestock futures. The flood of investment has raised concerns among grain traders and agricultural producers that speculative money is gaining an undue influence over their markets, which help set the prices of raw commodities for a host of consumer food products, according to The New York Times.

headline: As Tribune Board Reviews Offers, Analysts Scratch Their Heads
text: When members of Tribune board assemble this weekend to review bids for the company, they will have a lot to consider but not much to be happy about. The company received at least two firm bids by Wednesday’s deadline, one from the Los Angeles team of Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle, and another from the Chandler family, the company’s largest shareholder. A third potential bidder, the Carlyle Group, has expressed interest but only in Tribune’s television group. The company also owns 11 papers, including The Los Angeles Times.

headline: Law Firms Are Urged Not to Force Retirements
text: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association is calling on law firms to end the practice of mandatory retirement for partners. In a strongly worded report that is to be released Friday, the committee concluded that “mandatory retirement – requiring a partner to leave the firm upon reaching an arbitrary age – is not an acceptable practice.”

headline: Bank of New York’s Profit Beats Expectations
text: The Bank of New York Company, one of the nation’s largest trust banks, reported an increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday on strength in its corporate trust business, depositary receipts and global custody services. The New York-based bank said net income totaled $1.79 billion, or $2.36 a share, in the October-December period, up from $405 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Bidding for ElkCorp Heats Up
text: The bidding for the roofing products maker ElkCorp heated up Thursday, with the Building Materials Corporation of America raising its bid to $865.2 million, topping a $834 million offer by a private equity firm, the Carlyle Group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Building Materials said it had raised its offer for ElkCorp to $42 a share in cash, from an earlier $40. Earlier in the day, Carlyle said it had started a tender offer on its previously disclosed bid of $40.50 a share.

headline: How China Is Going Green
text: On the vanguard of venture capital, the buzzwords of late have been “alternative energy” and “China.” Are the two worlds about to collide? Seed investors are financing, or considering financing, start-ups in China that are developing equipment for wind and solar power, clean water and food alternatives and technology to promote energy efficiency. While this may seem to be an arbitrary combination of two of the hottest trends in venture capital – sort of like the first person who mixed peanut butter and chocolate – there is a growing number of investors who believe that the potential reward in China is worth the tremendous risk.

headline: Shell Mulls Boosting Offer for Canadian Unit, Report Says
text: Royal Dutch Shell is dangling the prospect of a 15 percent-plus bump in its offer to buy oil patch subsidiary Shell Canada for C$7.7 billion ($6.6 billion), if minority shareholders agree to support its takeover bid, The Globe and Mail reported. Apparently frustrated in its attempts to drum up interest in a 40-Canadian-dollars -a-share offer made in October, and fearing a nasty takeover battle, Royal Dutch has been quietly meeting with the biggest shareholders in its Calgary-based offspring in recent weeks, the report said. Money managers in Toronto and Calgary told the newspaper that the parent company is holding out the promise of $46 to $48 a share if institutions agree to commit their shares.

headline: Buyout Firm Reaches for Mace
text: Mace Security International, which owns a chain of car washes and makes the namesake pepper spray, has received an unsolicited $45.8 million buyout bid from a California-based private equity firm. The offer of $3 a share by Kelly Capital Management was disclosed in a regulatory filing yesterday and Mace said its board was reviewing the offer. While shares of the company soared on the news, Mace’s two largest shareholders, Lawndale Capital Management and Ancora Capital, said the offer seemed too low.

headline:
We Have a Winner…
‘Your Turn': The Darfur Genocide
text: Last month I launched a contest for readers to submit their own writing about Darfur, using my reporting or other source materials. I called it “Your Turn” and thought I would be inundated with earnest newspaper columns from college journalists. Instead, most entries were letters, essays or poems.

headline: Firms Band Together for Emissions Market
text: Ten major companies, including industrial giants like General Electric, DuPont and Alcoa, have banded together with leading environmental groups to call for a firm nationwide limit on carbon dioxide emissions that would lead to reductions of 10 to 30 percent over the next 15 years. Besides adding pressure on Congress to act, one of the group’s major goals is the creation of a market in which allowances to emit carbon dioxide could be traded in a way that achieves the greatest reduction at the lowest cost.

headline: As Fund Grows, Providence Cuts Fees
text: Providence Equity Partners is gearing up to play with the big boys. The media buyout specialist is looking to triple its fund size, and, in doing so, has agreed to cut its carried interest, or percentage of the fund’s profits, to 20 percent from 25 percent, according to press reports. The firm promised at the outset to do so if the new fund exceeded its initial $8 billion soft target, The Deal.com reported. And now it is now raising up to $12 billion, after recently holding a first close at $8 billion. The move puts Providence among $10 billion-plus mega-funds raised by the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: What’s In a Name? $400 Million
text: After the announcements of the twin $400 million naming-rights deals inked by British bank Barclays, for the Nets new arena, and Citigroup, for the Mets new stadium, the Jets and the Giants must be salivating as they look over the next year to sell the naming rights to their $1.2 billion stadium in the Meadowlands. They professional football teams have hired the Wasserman Media Group to handle the transaction, and yesterday, Jeff Knapple, the president of WMG Marketing told The New York Times: “We’ve watched with a keen eye toward what the Mets and the Nets have done. It’s an indication of the power of the New York marketplace and its position in the nation and the world.”

headline: From Ethics Overseer to Hedge Fund Boss
text: The leap into hedge funds by Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator, is making waves. As the court-appointed guardian and self-described fixer of some of America’s most wayward companies, Mr. Breeden, who also oversaw Securities and Exchange Commission from 1989 to 1993, is considered a pillar of corporate ethics and governance. Now he trying to become another paragon – that of savvy investor in troubled companies. And in the coming months he will face his first major test: taking on the Applebee’s International restaurant chain in a proxy fight.

headline: Times Looks Set to Keep Boston Paper
text: Dampening the hopes of some investors, analysts, and potential bidders The New York Times Company seems to be in no hurry to sell The Boston Globe. The Times’ chief executive, Janet L. Robinson, said Thursday that the company remains committed to the New England market and The Globe, despite the financial difficulties roiling the newspaper and traditional media in general.

headline: After Inquiries, Ford Official Decides to Skip Company Jet
text: It’s goodbye Gulfstream, hello Airbus for Mark Fields at Ford Motor. Mr. Fields said Thursday that he would voluntarily give up the use of the company’s private jets for his weekend trips home to visit his family in Florida after media scrutiny over his flights, a common perk among executives, raised eyebrows because of billions of dollars in losses last year at Ford. Instead, Mr. Fields, who is president of the Americas region for the auto company, will fly commercial.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Sarbanes-Oxley Problem
text: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act might be meant to guard against massive white-collar scandals, but the resignation of a high-profile tech veteran suggests the law may also be restricting efficiency atop Silicon Valley’s corporate ladder, CNet News.com suggests. Earlier this month, venture capitalist and Netscape founder Jim Clark announced his departure from the board of directors at photo-printing site Shutterfly, where he served as chairman. In his resignation letter, he cited “the constraints imposed by Sarbanes-Oxley” as one of the primary reasons for departure.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Buy CNL Hotels in $6.6 Billion Deal
text: Morgan Stanley, the biggest real estate investor among Wall Street firms, agreed to buy CNL Hotels & Resorts Inc., adding eight luxury hotels and resorts throughout the U.S. in a transaction worth $6.6 billion. The move comes amid a hot market for hotel acquisitions, which booked a 38 percent jump in 2006 to reach $70 billion. Morgan Stanley Real Estate will pay $20.50 for each CNL share and assume CNL’s debt. CNL, based in Orlando, Florida, will also sell 51 properties to Ashford Hospitality Trust for about $2.4 billion as part of the takeover.

headline: After Dulcet Tones, Australian Cleric’s Fiery Rhetoric Stirs Controversy
text: The comments of an influential Australian Muslim cleric, revealed in a British TV documentary earlier this week, are fueling outrage, with authorities down under investigating whether the the cleric had broken anti-terrorism laws, according to various reports.

headline: Pinault Move Makes Vinci Shares Pop
text: Shares of Vinci, the world’s biggest construction company, rose to a record after activist investor Francois Pinault bought a 1 billion euro ($1.3 billion) stake, prompting speculation he may seek to acquire the company. The stock jumped 6.4 percent to 104.9 euros, the most in seven months, and was trading at 103.3 euros as of 11:36 a.m. in Paris, giving a market value of 24.2 billion euros.

headline: Citigroup Profit Falls in 4th Quarter
text: Citigroup said on Friday that fourth-quarter profit fell from a year earlier, when it took a one-time gain, although the company benefited from growth in investment banking. Net income for the New York-based company fell to $5.13 billion from $6.93 billion a year earlier, when Citigroup recorded a $2.1 billion gain from selling its asset management business.

headline: Citadel and NBC Get Together on Ion Bid
text: In a bid to salvage its stake in the family friendly TV network formerly known as Paxson Communications, NBC Universal has found a buyer willing to pony up about $70.5 million to help it take the ailing company private. Hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, which, like NBC is a major investor in the company now called Ion Media Networks, is offering to buy out its common shareholders for $1.41 a share in cash.

headline: Giuliani Hires a Rove-Linked Consultant
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani has hired Olsen & Shuvalov, a prominent Texas consulting firm with ties to Karl Rove, to assist his presidential exploratory committee with fundraising, voter outreach, and development of his political message, according to campaign officials.

headline: Can I Get a Receipt for That?
text: How cold are mornings at Sundance? The Bagger was out shooting video in cheap gloves, with foot warmers in his cheap boots, and his extremities soon turned into four different flavors of snow cone. The Bagger quickly found one of those upscale sportswear shops and got a vigorous cashectomy for real cold weather boots and mittens.

headline: Just Plain Good?
text: Wouldn’t you know that the year the Bagger finally gets to Sundance is the year that the stars who generally dapple the event decide to take a pass? The Hollywood Reporter suggests that while this may be a fine year for film, a lot of the wattage stayed home. The story also notes that the commercial side of the festival may not sparkle either.

headline: The Ghost of This Machine
text: indieWire, which is all over Sundance to very excellent effect, talks to Rory Kennedy about “Ghosts of Abu Ghraib”, a hard look at what America is doing to others in the name of keeping the rest of us safe.

headline: Hunting Big Game
text: Geoffrey Gilmore, the co-director of Sundance, explains to Zoom In Online, which is running a lot of video about the festival, how audiences here tend to mistake the tree for the forest, or more specifically, the tusk for the elephant.

headline: Selling Iraq’s Oil
text: -Mary Duenwald

headline: Lotto Films
text: The game at Sundance is to suss out the must-see film and see it before anyone else so you can see them and talk about it. Peter Ranier of the Christian Science Monitor, a film fest vet, said that it can be a bit of a game — sometimes those in the know will terrorize their colleagues by going bonkers about a film that is no longer screening.

headline: Radically Good Manners
text: One of the Bagger’s colleagues sent him a bit from the Q & A following the “Chicago Ten” screening. The Bagger would thank him by name, but he’d probably just get the guy jammed up at work. Here’s what the Bagger missed when he ran for one of the buses.

headline: Redford Whispers, Time’s Up
text: The Bagger was thrilled to actually see a film at Sundance, in this case, the premiere of “Chicago 10,” the mashup of animation and archival material that serves as a modern tutorial on four days in recent American history when a major city turned into a police state, and a fairly brutal one at that.

headline: Pinault Rules Out Bid for Suez
text: Francois Pinault on Friday dashed speculation that he would make a run for the utility Suez, but the French billionaire said he would seek alternatives to its proposed merger with Gaz de France. In a statement from his holding company, Artemis, Mr. Pinault said the conditions were not right for a Suez bid. “Artemis remains convinced that an alternative solution to the merger can be found in the interests of the market and will continue to examine the possibility of such an operation,” Artemis said.

headline: Fortress Aims for $634 Million in I.P.O.
text: Taking another step toward making history as the first public hedge fund, New York’s Fortress Investment Group said that it may raise as much as $634.3 million in its initial public offering. In a regulatory filing, Fortress said that it plans to sell 34.3 million shares for $16.50 to $18.50 a piece, with the fund’s principals controlling 78 percent of the firm after the sale.

headline: China on Space Missile: Nothing To Worry About, If We Did It
text: One thing seems clear from today’s coverage of China’s recent display of missile muscle: it happened. From Bill Broad and David Sanger in today’s Times:

headline: Against Manning, Patriots Put the Pressure on Their Pass Rush
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 19 — Harassing Peyton Manning with a consistent pass rush is a top priority for the New England Patriots.

headline: Bears Banking on the Cold Against the Saints
text: Some of the Bears players grumbled this week about the fact that there were 6,000 empty seats at Soldier Field for their second-round playoff game last weekend against the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: On the Hill: End of an (Ever So Brief) Era
text: With the passage of the “first 100 hours” and major ethics legislation, a brief period of bipartisanship may also have passed. Republicans in the House were mad because, they say, the Democrats muzzled them during their initial blitz of legislation, and G.O.P. and Democratic leaders in the Senate played the blame game over what had stalled the ethics bill.

headline: Debate on China’s Place in Space
text: Did China blow up a weather satellite this week in response to America’s greater weapons capability in space? Jeffrey Lewis, blogging at ArmsControlWonk.com, says he doesn’t believe so, because the American space weapons programs have been “mostly talk,” not supported by real budgetary support.

headline: The Secret Race for Comptroller
text: When the popularly-elected State Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, resigned late last year – leaving the choice of his successor to the State Legislature – state officials pledged to conduct an open and public process to select his replacement.

headline: Fidelity Will Oppose Clear Channel Buyout, Report Says
text: Clear Channel Comunications‘ largest shareholder, Fidelity Investments, plans to oppose the radio networks’ $19 billion buyut as too low, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing an unnamed source. Fidelity, which held an 11 percent stake as of Sept. 30, is seeking a higher price than the $37.60 that two buyout firms — Thomas H. Lee Partners and bain Capital Partners — offered last November.

headline: Ney Sentenced to 30 Months
text: On the heels of the Senate passing wide-ranging lobbying and ethics legislation last night, a federal judge sentenced former Congressman Bob Ney to 30 months in prison in the wake of the Jack Abramoff corruption scandal that heavily influenced the new push for reforms to break the ties between lobbyists and lawmakers.

headline: More Car Seat Fallout, Plus: What Was the Alternative, Anyway?
text: Updating now the news from Thursday that Consumer Reports had pulled its widely circulated study from two weeks ago suggesting that many child car seats on the market today may be unsafe at moderate speeds. Seems some of Consumer Reports’ tests — specifically the side impact tests — may have been grossly overstated, according to the Nation Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Can a Building Change Its Rules About Dogs?
text: Q My building went co-op 20 years ago, and we have always been allowed to have pets. But this month, the new board of directors adopted a change to the house rules that now states owners’ dogs can weigh no more than 50 pounds.

headline: Regilding the Golden Guy
text: “It’s a very warm and I would say soothing feeling,” Juliette Binoche said in her lilting French accent when the Baguette asked her what it felt like to win an Oscar. Ms. Binoche won a best supporting actress award in 1996 for “The English Patient,” which was nominated for 12 Oscars and won nine, including best director for Anthony Minghella.

headline: Losers Go to Harvard?
text: Dad, what happens to politicians when they lose?

headline: Equity Office Fight Suits Zell Just Fine
text: The battle for Equity Office Properties Trust may turn ugly — but from Samuel Zell’s perspective, it’s beautiful all the same. The founder of the REIT has seen the value of his stake in the company climb to $825 million as a group of three real estate companies offered a $38 billion bid earlier this week, The New York Post reported Friday.

headline: Virtually Correct Still Means Correct
text: Not so long ago I wrote a post extolling chenin blanc wines, particularly those from the Loire Valley, which I love. I mentioned in passing that I had been hearing very good things about South African chenin blancs, and I offered a link to the South Africa entry in the Epicurious wine dictionary.

headline: Chandler Bid Packs Big Payments for Tribune Executives
text: If Tribune is sold to the Chandler family, some executives could walk away with compensation totaling an estimated $269 million, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the family, which formerly owned the Times, notes a change of control payments. While it does not say how many executives would be eligible, the paper says that Tribune’s chief executive, Dennis J. FitzSimons; publishing president, Scott C. Smith; and broadcasting president, John E. Reardon, are among those eligible if they are dismissed within three years of a Chandler takeover.

headline: Layoffs Hit the N.Y.S.E. as Specialists Are Squeezed Out
text: Wall Street executives and office types may be enjoying record bonuses right now, but those who work the trading floor have increasingly little to celebrate. The New York Post reported Friday that Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs have laid off even more floor workers at the New York Stock Exchange, as the market increasingly moves to electronic trading via its so-called hybrid-trading system. Lehman laid off six and Goldman nine on Thursday, the paper said, adding that both laid off an unknown number of marketers who sell floor-trading screens and execution services.

headline: Blogtalk: When I First Met Rudy…
text: The Politicker quotes some first impressions of Rudy Giuliani from people interviewed for a new biography.

headline: Reid Stands Between Bush and Iran
text: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, drew a battle line with President Bush on Iran today during a joint appearance with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the Democrats’ leader in the House. As part of the Democrats’ runup to Mr. Bush’s address to the nation on Tuesday night, Mr. Reid reminded the commander in chief that his power does have limits when it comes to military engagement.

headline: Shooting of Outspoken Editor Tests Turkey’s Democratic Mettle
text: Hrant Dink, a prominent Turkish-Armenian editor who was convicted of insulting Turkey’s identity under a controversial law that has been a stumbling block in its bid for membership in the European Union, was shot dead outside his newspaper office in Istanbul today.

headline: A New Consultant for Giuliani
text: Over at our national sibblog, The Caucus, Patrick Healy reports that Rudy Giuliani has hired Olsen & Shuvalov, a prominent Texas consulting firm to assist his presidential exploratory committee. Mr. Giuliani seems to be expanding his inner circle, which is still dominated by people who worked for him at City Hall. Olsen & Shuvalov, a communications and political strategy firm in Austin, Texas, grew out of the old Karl Rove & Company direct-mail marketing firm. When he joined the Bush campaign in 1999, Mr. Rove sold the assets to two of his former employees and no longer has any official ties to it.

headline: Hedge Fund Cries Foul in Openwave Proxy Contest
text: Harbinger Capital Partners declared victory in its battle against Openwave Systems on Friday, but said that the wireless software maker was taking action to thwart shareholders. The activist hedge fund, which owns more than 10 percent of the wireless software maker, said that it expects to win a seat on Openwave’s board, based on a preliminary count of votes at a shareholder meeting.

headline: You type. I type. Why bother with handwriting?
text: On the off chance you haven’t started preparations, don’t forget: Only four days until National Handwriting Day!

headline: Another Firm Settles in Market-Timing Inquiry
text: The mutual fund Fred Alger Management has agreed to pay $40 million to settle charges leveled against it by former New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer during his investigation of fraudulent mutual fund market-timing schemes, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday. Alger allowed such trading from 2000 to 2003, according to the S.E.C.

headline: The Candidates for Comptroller
text: Let’s get ready to comp-trol! The State Senate has released the list of 19 comptroller candidates, though the Assembly claims one candidate had a problem with his application, according to the Senate release. Some extra candidates may have applied only to the Assembly.

headline: Valleywag’s Denton Tells Doerr: Retire Now
text: L. John Doerr, one of the big names at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, is a legendary investor, according to Valleywag’s Nick Denton. So legendary that Mr. Denton uses the phrase twice within 15 words. But, the Gawker media emperor concludes in an editorial, now is the perfect time for the veteran venture capitalist to retire.

headline: War of Words Without End
text: Well, not that anyone is naive about the ever-growing divide between Democrats and President Bush over the war in Iraq and his new plan to send more troops into battle.

headline: All Night Long for Mountain Dew
text: The most requested ad of the day, from AdForum.

headline: Nipping Global Warming in the Bud
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 19 column, “A Warning From the Garden.”

headline: McCain Powers Up His Media Team
text: Senator John McCain has enlisted the core players of President Bush’s advertising team, adding them to what was already a group of bare-knuckled political advertising strategists working for his nascent campaign.

headline: Defining a Dream Home
text: This morning I received an e-mail reminding me about the HGTV Dream Home 2007 Giveaway, which got me thinking: What exactly are the ideal characteristics of a dream home?

headline: Raikkonen’s Red Tank
text: I’m a bit late on this, but I found it to be one of the most baffling and yet possibly enlightening bits of news of the week – or the year. Reuters yesterday sent out a story quoting the German magazine Sport Bild which said that Mario Illien, of the McLaren-Mercedes Ilmor engine fame, said that Ferrari will have to build a car as strong as a tank to withstand Kimi Raikkonen’s driving style.

headline: Blogtalk
text: Ben Smith has posted a spreadsheet of pork projects organized by zip code. [Room 8]

headline: Rest Easy: Overt Religious Symbols Permitted for British Airways Employees
text: The Lede will be closed for business on Monday and Tuesday next week, but we leave you with this little tidbit to tide you over until then:

headline: Vows: Brooke and Seth
text: After Brooke Lippmann met Seth Christian, she decided to enlist her friends' help in pursuing him.

headline: The Week That Was
text: At week’s end, we’d be remiss if we didn’t mention some newsworthy items that keep popping up on our screen, but have failed to make the Caucus blog, until now.

headline: The Conversation: 2006 Highlights
text: Excerpts from Times reporter Calvin Sims's interviews, including Larry Kramer, Elie Wiesel, Calvin Butts, Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, and Ruth Reichl.

headline: Elderly Organ Donors (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Justices Revisit Campaign Finance Issue
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The Supreme Court stepped back into the debate over campaign finance regulation on Friday, announcing an expedited review of a ruling last month that substantially narrowed the application of a major provision of the McCain-Feingold federal campaign law.

headline: A Product of the U.N. System
text: Benon Sevan no longer works for the United Nations. But his indictment on federal corruption charges stemming from his long maladministration of the Iraqi oil-for-food program points to a continuing problem in the U.N. appointments system that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon needs to tackle without further delay.

headline: Belarus: Leader Warns of Hard Times
text: Confronted with higher natural gas and oil prices after a New Year’s confrontation with Russia, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said that energy conservation had become a national security priority. Belarus long enjoyed discounted prices for energy from Russia, subsidizing its industries and generating profits from the refining and export of gasoline and other oil products. Russia more than doubled the price of natural gas  $100 per cubic meter, compared with $46  beginning Jan. 1. Belarus imposed a retaliatory fee on the transit of oil, but backed down last week after Russia turned off its main oil pipeline through Belarus, disrupting supplies across Europe. Mr. Lukashenko appeared to be bracing the country for austerity as energy-saving measures are adopted. “The next three, four years will not be an easy time,” he said, according to Interfax, “but we will have to bear it.”

headline: Sex and the Single-Minded
text: How to get a job in Washington, that balmy, bipartisan town: Direct an organization that opposes contraception on the grounds that it is “demeaning to women.” Compare premarital sex to heroin addiction. Advertise a link between breast cancer and abortion — a link that was refuted in 1997. Rant against sex ed. And hatch a loony theory about hormones.

headline: Vatican and China Open Talks on Improving Ties
text: ROME, Jan. 19  The Vatican began two days of meetings on Friday over the church’s relations with China, which have soured because of a dispute over the right to appoint bishops.

headline: Sri Lanka: Thousands Flee Fallen Rebel Town
text: Thousands of civilians waving white flags fled from heavy fighting in the east of the country as government forces captured a strategic town held by the separatist Tamil Tigers after weeks of fierce fighting. The town, Vakarai, on the northeastern coast, is a main link between the northern and eastern areas controlled by the rebels. “Since dawn, 6,000 to 8,000 people have been moving on foot, by tractor and by sea,” a United Nations spokeswoman, Ola Clinton, said. “They were waving white flags and handkerchiefs.” She said that as fighting intensified in recent weeks, 25,000 people had already fled Vakarai, and she estimated that another 2,000 to 2,500 civilians remained, with food in short supply.

headline: Extra Innings Exclusively on DirecTV
