text: Major League Baseball is close to announcing a deal that will place its Extra Innings package of out-of-market games exclusively on DirecTV, which will also become the only carrier of a long-planned 24-hour baseball channel.

headline: Advice for Invaders (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Leading Senator Assails Bush Over Iran Stance
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — The new chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Friday sharply criticized the Bush administration’s increasingly combative stance toward Iran, saying that White House efforts to portray it as a growing threat are uncomfortably reminiscent of rhetoric about Iraq before the American invasion of 2003.

headline: ‘Post-’
text: It may seem odd to celebrate a prefix. After all, it isn’t even a whole part of speech. It does for a word, visually, what a big cigar does for a small man. But even as prefixes go, “post-” is unusually adaptable. It signifies transcendence, surpassing, moving past, leaving behind, and yet it does all these things while remaining attached to the very thing the prefix is leaving in the dust.

headline: Western Companies Caught Up in Chinese Bribery Inquiry
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 19 — The police have detained 22 people in a bribery investigation that has ensnared several large companies, including ABB, McDonald’s, McKinsey & Company and Whirlpool, according to reports on Friday in the state-run news media.

headline: Don’t Call. Don’t Write. Let Me Be.
text: The fears of the direct marketing industry came true. Once a do-not-call list was created, people did register, in droves.

headline: Armenian Editor Is Slain in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 19 —A prominent newspaper editor, columnist and voice for Turkey’s ethnic Armenians who was prosecuted for challenging the official Turkish version of the 1915 Armenian genocide, was shot dead as he left his office on a busy street in central Istanbul on Friday.

headline: China Shows Assertiveness in Weapons Test
text: BEIJING, Jan. 19 — China’s apparent success in destroying one of its own orbiting satellites with a ballistic missile signals that its rising military intends to contest American supremacy in space, a realm many here consider increasingly crucial to national security.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about Muhammad Ali’s 65th birthday, rendered incorrectly an antiwar quotation from him in the 1960s. He said, “I ain’t got no quarrel with them Vietcong” — not “I got nothin’ against them Vietcong.”

headline: Senior Aide to Blair Is Arrested in Graft Inquiry
text: LONDON, Jan. 19  The police arrested and questioned a senior aide to Prime Minister Tony Blair on Friday in what seemed to be a widening inquiry into allegations that political leaders had traded high honors for campaign contributions made as loans.

headline: U.N. to Audit Its Activities After Reports on North Korea Program
text: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 19  Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, called Friday for outside examination of all United Nations activities after a published report that the United Nations Development Program in North Korea was making unaccountable payments in hard currency to local staff members and the North Korean government.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the chief executive of the Mesa Air Group referred incorrectly to the company’s revenue for the years 2002 through 2006. It was in billions, not millions. A corrected graphic can be found online.

headline: Easy Does It, the Next Stop Is a Killer. No, It Really Is.
text: “The Hitcher” isn’t shy about declaring its intentions. The opening image is of a jackrabbit crossing a desert highway and being pulped by a car. Soon after, the vacationing young hero, Jim (Zachary Knighton), asks his girlfriend, Grace (Sophia Bush), to hold the wheel of his 1970 Oldsmobile 442 so he can hang out of the driver’s side window and clean a splattered bug off the windshield. Message: Roadkill comes in all shapes and sizes.

headline: Bush to Visit Democrats’ Retreat
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Who says bipartisanship is dead? President Bush has accepted an invitation from House Democrats to travel to Williamsburg, Va., in February to speak at their annual issues conference, a move that might have been unthinkable a few short months ago, when Republicans ran Capitol Hill.

headline: Richard A. Musgrave, 96, Theoretician of Public Finance, Dies
text: Richard A. Musgrave, an economist who has been called the father of modern public finance, died Monday in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 96.

headline: The Quicksand of Debt (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Two Brothers in a Gumbo of Bayou and West Africa
text: Tarell Alvin McCraney, a third-year student at the Yale School of Drama, is one of the few playwrights in the Under the Radar festival who is actually under the radar — but not for long.

headline: New Warnings on Climate Change
text: The main international scientific body assessing causes of climate change is closing in on its strongest statement yet linking emissions from burning fossil fuels to rising global temperatures, according to scientists involved in the process.

headline: Showbiz Exporter Scores Goal
text: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 19 — Simon Fuller has achieved remarkable success in Britain as an entertainment executive and manager, chiefly in the recording industry. But clearly he has finally found the area of his true business acumen: export.

headline: Could the Contract Be Defeated? The Software Oracle Knows
text: When you play in a tournament that gives out deal records, under every board you see the highest contracts that each side can make in the five strains, assuming the play is double-dummy  everyone knows where the cards lie. (This is done using Bill Bailey’s Deep Finesse software.) Competitors in the Flight A/X Pairs last Saturday at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., were surprised to see that there was a way to defeat three no-trump by South in the diagramed deal. What leads by West work?

headline: Senators to Offer Centrist Proposal on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — Senator John W. Warner of Virginia is drafting a proposal on Iraq policy with two Senate centrists in an effort to provide an outlet for lawmakers uneasy with President Bush’s troop buildup but unwilling to back a toughly worded resolution opposing the new strategy.

headline: Senate Measure Puts Spotlight on Fund-Raising
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — Of all the new rules passed in Congress’s recent ethics overhauls, the most sweeping is a barely debated provision in a Senate bill passed Thursday night that could alter one of the most time-honored campaign fund-raising practices in Washington.

headline: Coliseum Will Fall, Taking Grand-Scale Philosophy With It
text: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19  There are rooftop soirees and a city-sponsored official watching spot. One art gallery has scheduled an open-microphone night to encourage people to share their memories. People from near and far are making plans to witness the implosion, though the whole spectacle is expected to last less than 20 seconds.

headline: Comfort Food Is in at London Theater Buffet
text: LONDON, Jan. 19 — It is the eve of destruction, although everyone is pretending it is not. Hitler is on the horizon, storm troopers are in the wings, and betrayal has replaced friendship as the common social coin. So whom would you choose as your musical dream date for this Götterdämmerung moment: the chaste nun-in-training who loves nature and children, or the sexy nightclub singer who loves a cabaret?

headline: 3 From the Bush Advertising Team Join McCain’s ’08 Advisers
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — Senator John McCain of Arizona has enlisted strategists from President Bush’s advertising team to work on the senator’s nascent drive for the Republican presidential nomination, aides with his campaign exploratory committee said Friday.

headline: A Punch Line in Detroit, Milicic Finds a Niche in Orlando
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 19 — The screaming blond streaks in Darko Milicic’s thick black hair have long since faded. He is back to his natural color.

headline: Testimony to Be Heard on Shooting by the Police
text: A Queens grand jury that will weigh evidence in the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man on his wedding day in November will begin hearing testimony next week, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,014 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: An Unthinkable Crime, Until Someone Finally Thought of It
text: Three crumpled dollars and two quarters, tugged from the pocket of a puffy coat on a cold night, brings four hot chicken wings with French fries or fried rice. The most expensive dish on the restaurant’s menu is No. 71, the lobster meat chow mein, at $8.95 a quart.

headline: Insurgents Attack Palace in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 19  Insurgents blasted Somalia’s presidential palace with heavy explosives on Friday night, Somali officials said, but it appeared that no one was hurt.

headline: Denny Doherty, 66, Mamas and Papas Singer, Dies
text: Denny Doherty, a founding member of the 1960s folk-pop band the Mamas and the Papas, died yesterday at his home in Mississauga, Ontario. He was 66.

headline: Totals
Giant Does Not Blame Bonds for Link to Positive Drug Test
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19  This should have been a feel-good event, part of a fanfest weekend being staged by the San Francisco Giants. Maybe some softball questions from reporters and some home run responses from the 14 Giants players who were taking part.

headline: Figuring Out the P.E. Ratio of Steve Jobs
text: APPLE’S share price leaped to a record after the company unveiled its latest device to be hailed as the coolest thing ever, but investors are factoring more into their decision than a best guess on the number of iPhones Apple will sell.

headline: A Trip Off the Beaten Path (for Everyone Involved)
text: With Broadway and Theater Row and the Villages beckoning, sometimes New York theatergoers need to remind themselves: it’s not the location, it’s the writing and the acting. West 21st Street may not be a theater hot spot, but “The Dirty Talk,” a delicious two-hander playing at Center Stage there, is as rewarding a trip off the beaten path as you’ll make.

headline: Draft Law Keeps Central Control Over Oil in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 19 — After months of tense bargaining, a cabinet-level committee has produced a draft law governing Iraq’s vast oil fields that would distribute all revenues through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers in exploration, development and awarding major international contracts.

headline: Seeing Results in Darfur (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brodeur Goes About His Business: Winning
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 19  His 35th birthday is less than four months away, and the Devils’ Martin Brodeur is beginning to sound like a goaltender who has been around a while. He says he now appreciates recognition much more.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with a front-page article on Jan. 9 about the naming of Fred F. Fielding as the chief White House lawyer misspelled the surname of a woman, whose husband was killed in the Sept. 11 attacks, who spoke to Mr. Fielding at a meeting of the Sept. 11 commission when he was on that panel. She is Beverly Eckert, not Ecket.

headline: Unhappy Quarterback Has Razorbacks Reeling
text: Coming off its best season in nearly 20 years, Arkansas is embroiled in a controversy involving the heralded quarterback Mitch Mustain that has bitterly divided Razorbacks fans.

headline: What’s on Monday Night
text: 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK Well, that’s one way to save your life. The show picks up where it unexpectedly left off: with Michael (Wentworth Miller) and Lincoln (Dominic Purcell) forming a tenuous alliance with Kellerman (Paul Adelstein), who turned his gun on Mahone in revenge for ruining his life. Tonight, the threesome heads to Montana to track down Terrence Steadman, the president’s brother — and the man Lincoln was framed for murdering. Meanwhile, T-Bag insinuates himself into the Hollander household. And Bellick finds out what life is really like on the other side of the bars.

headline: Muti Takes the Reins, a Classicist at His Core
text: The conductor Riccardo Muti grabbed international headlines in 2005 when he resigned as music director at La Scala Opera in Milan, expressing displeasure with working conditions and attitudes. But this exacting 65-year-old maestro, one of the towering musicians of our time, has always worked well with the New York Philharmonic. He is back with the orchestra for two programs over the next two weeks, and the first concert on Thursday night was predictably excellent, though in unpredictable ways.

headline: The Guilt-Free Corporation
text: THE notion that the corporation should apply its assets for social purposes rather than for the profit of its owners — the shareholders — is an irresponsible use of assets,” argues the venture capitalist Betsy S. Atkins.

headline: Trade Deficit Stubbornly Defies the Dollar’s Slide
text: Jessica Heyman’s breakfast in Paris last month was nothing out of the ordinary: a modest repast of eggs, coffee and a side salad with her husband, Jonathan Podwil, at the popular Café de Flore. But the bill was memorable — 46 euros, or about $60, at the current exchange rate. Five years ago, when the dollar was strong, the same bill would have amounted to $42.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about a move by Bangor, Me., to ban smoking in cars where children are passengers misstated the population ranking of the city. Bangor is the third largest city in Maine, not the second. (Portland is the largest, followed by Lewiston.)

headline: Lessons for Living Found in Views of the Last Judgment
text: “Eschatology” is not exactly your everyday word. If you had read every word of this newspaper every day for the last five years, you would have encountered it fewer than 20 times. Half those times were somehow referring to fundamentalist religious beliefs about the final battles between good and evil, the coming of Jesus (or other messianic figures), the Last Judgment and the eternal assignment of the saved and the damned to heaven or to hell.

headline: Israel Releases $100 Million Withheld From Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 — Israel transferred $100 million in Palestinian tax revenues to the office of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, as part of a plan to bolster him and keep money out of the hands of the Hamas government, Israeli officials said Friday.

headline: Flames Flare Over Naked Shorts
text: UNSUSPECTING readers of certain stock message boards may be forgiven for believing they have stumbled into a flame war among 14-year-old boys. But the increasingly vicious online dispute actually involves, among others, the chief executive of a publicly traded corporation and a longtime business journalist.

headline: Pennsylvania Governor Pushes Health Plan
text: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 — Gov. Edward G. Rendell arrived here Friday to rally support for his plan not only to extend health insurance coverage to the state’s 760,000 uninsured adults, but also to cut billions of dollars in heath care costs and ban smoking in restaurants, bars and workplaces.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the baseball roundup on Thursday about the status of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative steroids investigation misstated the number of men who have pleaded guilty and been sentenced in the case. It is five, not four. The article also gave an outdated academic position for Peter Keane, who commented on the outlook for the case. He is a law professor at Golden Gate University School of Law in San Francisco; he is no longer the dean of the law school.

headline: At Murder Trial, Both Sides Portray Abusive Marriage
text: It was a surprising killing for the neighborhood, hidden behind the doors of a dignified town house in the same orbit as Gracie Mansion and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where affluence is high and the crime rate is low.

headline: In the N.F.L., Violence Sells, but at What Cost?
text: By the time I reached him late Thursday afternoon, Gene Upshaw had already read the article in The New York Times about Andre Waters, the Philadelphia Eagles safety who committed suicide in November after years of battling depression. One neuropathologist said the condition might have been related to the concussions that Waters sustained as a professional football player.

headline: Pacers’ O’Neal Must Now Adjust to Roster Changes
text: MIAMI, Jan. 18 — Jermaine O’Neal’s head is spinning from the wholesale changes the Indiana Pacers made in this week’s trade that sent his friends Al Harrington and Stephen Jackson to the Golden State Warriors.

headline: A Colossus Blocks the Colts’ Path to a Title
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 19 — When snow flurries briefly fell Friday, it created a home-team dream tableau, the white flakes dusting buildings bathed in blue light as if the town had ordered up the weather, along with pep rallies and towering banners, to cheer on the Colts in the American Football Conference championship game.

headline: Parents and 3 Children Found Slain in Burned Home
text: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 19 — A family of five — two adults and three children — was found slain in its house in a working-class section of Dutchess County early Friday after firefighters responded to a blaze that gutted the home, the authorities said.

headline: State Farm Settles One Hurricane Katrina Suit
text: On the eve of trial, State Farm agreed yesterday to pay an estimated $1 million to settle a lawsuit by a Mississippi Gulf Coast resident whose house was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. The settlement came a week after a jury ordered the insurer to pay $2.5 million in punitive damage to a homeowner with a similar case.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about the successful online ad campaign for LowerMyBills.com, misspelled the given name of a blogger who commented on the ads. He is Rogers Cadenhead, not Roger.

headline: A Final Adventure for the Consummate Animal Hunter
text: Probably no creature in the history of the animal kingdom ever needed the image-enhancing public relations services of, say, a Hill & Knowlton, as much as the stingray that attacked and killed Steve Irwin off the Great Barrier Reef in Australia in September. Of all the naturalists to choose to make a victim! Mr. Irwin, of course, had gained celebrity engaging with unwieldy and lethal reptiles as if they were, on a scale of fearsomeness, roughly equivalent to a table of society matrons at tea.

headline: An Enigmatic Wild Card in Lebanon’s High-Stakes Politics
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon

headline: Metaphysical Ruminations, Glowing With Winter Light
text: Jazz is the nominal domain of Fred Hersch, the ferociously prolific pianist and composer who sidelines as a first-class accompanist. But in all of his work, jazz invention and lyrical fancy are tethered to an analytical mind that bows to the structure and balance of formal, notated music; chaos is not allowed.

headline: Extension Granted to Hurricane Victims
text: The federal government will allow the 110,000 families still living in trailers because of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita to stay through August, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency said. The housing program had been scheduled to expire at the end of February, and some community groups had been expecting FEMA to start issuing eviction notices as early as next week. The six-month extension, announced by Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, also applies to displaced families living in apartments paid for by FEMA.

headline: Furor Over 12-Year-Old Actress’s Rape Scene
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 — Dakota Fanning will turn 13 next month, and she has a short answer for anyone who questions her decision to play a 1950s girl who gyrates in her underwear, wakes up as her naked father climbs into her bed, demands that a prepubescent boy expose himself to her in exchange for a kiss and, finally, is raped by a teenager who lures her with tickets to an Elvis concert:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about the “Brain Games” exhibition at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, misstated the days the museum is open. It is open Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., not Tuesdays through Fridays.

headline: Writers’ Picks (and Pans) at the Show
text: Members of the team that covered the 2007 North American International Auto Show for The New York Times were hardly in agreement on their favorite (and least favorite) cars. Here are their choices:

headline: Playing Across the River, Jefferson Appears Right at Home
text: By the time the Nets make their scheduled arrival in Brooklyn for the 2009-10 season, Richard Jefferson could be the team’s marquee player. Only 26, he already has a mixture of panache and intellect that is worthy of the sheen the Nets hope to have in their new arena in Atlantic Yards.

headline: Czech Republic: Vote Ends Stalemate
text: Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek’s newly appointed coalition cabinet narrowly won a critical vote of confidence, ending a political stalemate that had left the country without an active government since elections last June. Those elections left the 200-seat Parliament evenly divided between rival coalitions. The deadlock was broken when two legislators from Mr. Topolanek’s opposition broke ranks and backed his cabinet in the vote. But Mr. Topolanek warned that the political crisis might not be over if the continued partisan split made it impossible for the new government to act effectively.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 8 P.M. (AMC) JEREMIAH JOHNSON (1972). An ex-soldier, played by a scruffily golden Robert Redford, opts out of civilized society in the 1850’s to live alone in the Colorado wilderness, where he unwittingly violates an Indian burial ground and loses his wife and adopted child to vengeance. Will Geer plays the trapper who teaches Johnson how to survive in this stark meditation on the American West, directed by Sydney Pollack. Parts of the film were shot northeast of Provo, Utah, near the ski area Mr. Redford eventually bought and named “Sundance,” after his character in “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.”

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Jan. 2, about coastal shipping, misstated a provision of the Merchant Marine Acts. The acts bar non-American ships from loading and unloading merchandise at consecutive American ports; they do not prevent such ships from calling on consecutive ports.

headline: Two Are Sentenced for Fraud Involving Trading of Stocks
text: Two former traders at the New York Stock Exchange were each sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and fined $250,000 for improper stock trading.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: There’s Money in Global Warming

headline: Have Magic Powers, Will Investigate. Hey, It’s a Living.
text: The hero of “The Dresden Files,” a new series on the Sci-Fi Channel that will make its debut tomorrow night, is Harry Dresden, and if his name reminds you of someone, his profession, wizardry, should confirm your suspicions of where inspiration for him might have been drawn.

headline: Madison Avenue Calling
text: People often say they do not like advertisements, but that may change if the ads start lowering their cellphone bills.

headline: 2 Men Are Found Dead in Brooklyn Garage Where Fire Broke Out
text: Two men were found dead yesterday evening in a garage in Brooklyn that was damaged by a fire, officials said.

headline: China’s Muscle Flex in Space
text: China spread alarm and consternation among space powers when it destroyed one of its own satellites last week with a missile fired from the ground, thus becoming the first nation in more than two decades to successfully test an antisatellite weapon. This aggressive show of force puts a wide range of United States military and intelligence satellites at risk and holds the danger of starting an arms race in space. Too bad the Bush administration’s own bellicose attitudes  and adamant refusal to consider an arms control treaty for space  give it scant standing to chastise the Chinese. The administration needs to reverse course promptly and join in talks aimed at banning further tests or use of antisatellite weapons.

headline: Pataki Will Soon Lose State Security Detail
text: ALBANY, Jan. 19  Former Gov. George E. Pataki will soon give up the taxpayer-provided security detail he has enjoyed since leaving office at the end of last year, a spokesman said on Friday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: 21 Parishes Face Shutdown in New York
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday issued a final list of 21 parishes that will close, ending a wrenching period of uncertainty for thousands of parishioners, some of whom had waited for several years to learn the fate of their church.

headline: Georgia: Illegal Workers Found at Military Sites
text: Twenty-four illegal immigrants were arrested on Wednesday after trying to enter Fort Benning to do construction work, Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said. All but three are facing federal charges of identity theft, use of fraudulent documents or re-entering the United States after deportation. In Nevada, the authorities said, two illegal immigrants employed as masons were arrested on Thursday at Creech Air Force Base in Indian Springs. In Virginia, immigration agents on Thursday arrested Richard Eversole, 58, an American citizen, and Juan Martínez, 24, a Mexican, on federal harboring charges, accusing them of hiring illegal immigrants to work on a construction project at the Quantico Marine Corps Base, and leasing apartments for the men.

headline: G.E. Says Profit Rose 11%, but Its Shares Still Fall
text: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings in 2006 were up 11 percent, buoyed by favorable tax rates and strong performance in several industrial and finance units.

headline: General Sees Summer Deadline for Troops
text: TALLIL AIR BASE, Iraq, Jan. 19 — Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the top commander in Iraq, said Friday that the additional troops being sent to Iraq under President Bush’s new plan to stabilize the country could begin to be withdrawn by late summer if security conditions improve.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A film column on Jan. 10 about the New York Jewish Film Festival misidentified the voice-over featured in the animated short “Chronicles of a Professional Eulogist.” While the film is based on interviews with a rabbi who is the stepfather of the writer’s wife, the voice is that of Jonathan Milder, not the rabbi.

headline: Archives of Spin
text: Louisville, Ky.

headline: Student-Loan Company Is Allowed to Keep Subsidy
text: The Bush administration reached an accord with a student loan company that will let it keep $278 million in subsidies that the inspector general of the Education Department found improper, the department said yesterday.

headline: The Marriage Ideal and Unwedded Bliss (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Election Could Decide Serbia’s Role in Europe
text: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 19 — While six years of democracy in Serbia have given its people ample opportunities to vote — in four presidential elections, two parliamentary elections and a nationwide referendum — many complain that the country has seen little change.

headline: Patent Trial Near, Bristol-Myers Counts on Resilience
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 19 — Bristol-Myers Squibb staggered, but the drug maker has remained on its feet.

headline: Seton Hall Drops Game After Losing a Starter
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 19  Seton Hall announced a heaping portion of bad news before Friday night’s game against Georgetown. Its starting center and tallest player, the 6-foot-10 Grant Billmeier, is out for the season.

headline: Warm Days and Hard Times in Snowmobile Land
text: CHESTER, Vt., Jan. 18  For 24 winters, Bev and Butch Jelley, owners of the B&B Mobil station here, have provided legions of snowmobilers with fuel and chili. But this year the kitchen is quiet, and the snowmobiles are nowhere to be found.

headline: Education Officials Faulted
text: State education officials in Georgia mishandled their part in Reading First, a $1-billion- a-year federal program intended to teach low-income children to read by third grade, a report by the federal Education Department’s inspector general found. The report said officials set unwarranted restrictions on local districts, creating “the appearance of preferential treatment” for a handful of programs. The state also failed to protect against conflict of interest, hiring the author of one program competing for use in Reading First schools to screen grant applications submitted by districts. Kathy Cox, the state school superintendent, said several of the audit’s findings had been remedied.

headline: Candidates for State Comptroller Line Up
text: ALBANY, Jan. 19  The strange race to become the next comptroller of New York State began in earnest on Friday as at least 18 candidates took the first step toward being considered by submitting their résumés to the State Legislature.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 6 about a police officer in Madison, Conn., who is accused of stealing lobster meat and shrimp from a local seafood restaurant, referred incorrectly to the town’s location. Madison is 20 miles east — not south — of New Haven.

headline: Police in Chase Injure Woman Crossing Street
text: A woman crossing the street in Newark yesterday afternoon was struck and injured by a marked police car chasing robbery suspects, the authorities said.

headline: Just Call It Airport Insecurity (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nets Grab the Victory and First Place
text: By perception and by record, the Knicks and the Nets spent three months converging on each other — the Knicks rising to meet the Nets’ apparent decline. When they finally met last night, the gap proved narrow indeed.

headline: Blockbuster Marries Stores to Internet
text: Netflix has upped the ante in its push to outwit its chief competitor, Blockbuster. This week, Netflix, which rents movies by mail, introduced a service to deliver movies and television shows directly to PCs as streaming video. Blockbuster is fighting back and plans to roll out its own digital distribution service. John F. Antioco, 57, the chairman and chief executive of Blockbuster, spoke recently about the challenge from Netflix and the shifting marketplace, new programs that address those shifts and how Oscar buzz is good for business. Following are excerpts:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Dec. 29 about concessions that investors in oil and gas fields have given the Russia government misspelled the name of one gas field involved. (The error also appeared in articles last year on Nov. 8, Oct. 11, Sept. 23 and March 22, as well as Feb. 22, 2005, and Oct. 28, 2004.) It is Kovykta, not Kovytka.

headline: A Soft Landing and a Push on Global Warming
text: BUOYED by encouraging economic news, the stock market bobbed near a record high this week. Congress acted to rein in oil drillers’ subsidies, and some of the country’s biggest companies joined traditional foes to address some of the country’s thorniest problems.

headline: A Democratic Bangladesh (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: You, Too, Can Be an Energy Trader Right in Your Heated Home
text: IT is not enough that in contrast to our parents we have to shop for our phone service, our cable service, our retirement plans and our health provider. Now many of us can become energy traders in our spare time.

headline: Mother Flees to America, Only to Face New Struggle
text: There were two moments when life changed forever for Jennifer Coello.

headline: The Biggest Man on Campus
text: Dallas

headline: They May Be Automatons, but They Sure Have Heart
text: They say you mellow with age. Trisha Brown’s new “I love my robots” certainly supports that thesis. In her 70th year, Ms. Brown, the innovative high priestess of postmodernist dance for four decades or so, has created a work of irresistible charm and silliness. It had its world premiere performance on Thursday night by the Trisha Brown Dance Company at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University as part of Peak Performances@Montclair, the college’s avant-garde performing arts series.

headline: States Study Marketing of Lilly Pill
text: Stepping up government investigations into Eli Lilly’s marketing of its best-selling drug Zyprexa, state prosecutors in Illinois and Vermont have demanded that the company turn over information about the way it promoted the medication.

headline: In a Teenager’s Plight, the Forgotten History of the ‘Charity Girls’
text: The writer Michael Lowenthal was reading through Susan Sontag’s essay “AIDS and Its Metaphors” when he first stumbled across a brief mention of the “charity girls.” He knew, he said, that he had to write a novel about them.

headline: Aide to Militant Shiite Cleric Held After U.S.-Iraqi Raid
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 19  A senior aide to the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr was detained here in a joint American-Iraqi raid before dawn on Friday, Iraqi and American officials said, in the latest high-profile arrest of a Shiite militia member.

headline: Up Quarter Ends Rough Year for Citigroup
text: Citigroup reported fourth-quarter results yesterday that were good. The only problem was that its competitors have done so much better.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Thursday about the sale of naming rights for the Nets’ planned home in Brooklyn referred imprecisely to the arena’s anticipated cost. Although the price will indeed exceed $550 million, the latest cost projection has raised it to about $637 million. The article also referred incompletely to a park planned atop the arena. It will be a private open space for the complex; it will not be a public park.

headline: Jordan: King Will Seek Nuclear Program
text: In an interview with the Israeli daily newspaper Haaretz, King Abdullah II said Jordan wanted to develop a peaceful nuclear program. With the comments, Jordan joined Egypt and several Persian Gulf states that have announced intentions to develop peaceful nuclear programs. The king’s statement was widely seen as a continuation of the political posturing of Arab leaders who have grown fearful that the West will fail to halt Iran’s nuclear ambitions. Last month, members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, made up of Iran’s Arab neighbors, agreed to begin a study into developing a nuclear research and development center somewhere in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Virginia: Church Claims Ownership of Property
text: The Episcopal Diocese of Virginia has announced that it intends to “recover or secure” the property of 11 churches that voted in December to leave the Episcopal Church and affiliate with an Anglican archbishop with whom they share conservative views on homosexuality and scripture. Many of the congregations had hoped to retain their property by reimbursing the diocese, but now both sides are preparing for a legal battle. The presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, Katharine Jefferts Schori, said in a statement, “While individuals have the right and privilege to depart or return at any time, congregations do not.”

headline: Challenging Mount Hood a Month After a Tragedy
text: MOUNT HOOD, Ore. — A month after a climber was found dead in a snow cave right below Mount Hood’s 11,237-foot summit and the search was abandoned for his two climbing partners, a hardy sense of normalcy has returned to the mountain’s climbing scene. Two recent breaks in winter storms, including one last weekend, have drawn back many climbers who prefer a winter-snow-blanketed Hood to its gravelly summer form.

headline: Two Governors Appeal for Antiterror Aid
text: HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan 19  Warning that it would be a “grave mistake” to further reduce antiterrorism financing to the nation’s busiest urban center, Govs. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey pressed the Bush administration on Friday for a substantial increase in federal money to improve security for the region’s highways and mass transit lines.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a strain of avian flu found in Egypt that is resistant to oseltamivir, the chief weapon against the virus, misspelled the name of another drug that remains effective against it. It is zanamivir (sold as Relenza), not zanamir. (Go to Article)

headline: H.P. Chief Defends Timing of Stock Sale
text: The chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd, told Congressional lawmakers that his sale of company shares on Aug. 25 was “totally unrelated” to the fact that he was questioned the same day about an ill-fated internal investigation.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a strain of avian flu found in Egypt that is resistant to oseltamivir, the chief weapon against the virus, misspelled the name of another drug that remains effective against it. It is zanamivir (sold as Relenza), not zanamir.

headline: Fighting the Taliban (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: I Want My Howard Stern and Oprah
text: On Wednesday, I was in the middle of a long phone conversation with Craig Moffett, the Wall Street analyst who follows broadcasting for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. His purview includes the country’s two satellite radio companies, XM and Sirius. Although Mr. Moffett is more positive on XM than Sirius, he sounded a little sheepish when I asked him whether he was bullish on the sector.

headline: Tribune Board Members Consider Bids
text: A special committee of Tribune Company board members met for several hours today in Chicago without reaching a decision about the company’s possible sale. But the committee indicated in a statement that it was weighing not only bids from outsiders but whether Tribune management might take action itself, possibly either buying the company or conducting some other transaction to increase the value of its shares.

headline: The Ballad of Bushie and Flashy
text: WASHINGTON

headline: This Emperor Has Clothes (but Says He Doesn’t)
text: Who would have imagined that watching a stranger undress could ever be tedious?

headline: Class Divide in Chinese-Americans’ Charity
text: As a schoolteacher in New York’s Chinatown in the 1960s, when the government’s war on poverty seemed focused on blacks and Latinos, Virginia Kee noticed that many of her Asian pupils were too poor to pay $2 for a class trip. To connect community needs with public money, Ms. Kee helped found what is now the Chinese-American Planning Council, one of the largest social service agencies for Asians in the country.

headline: Clinton’s Announcement Makes Waves in ’08 Field
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s entry into the 2008 presidential contest this morning set off rounds of e-mail and conference calls among both her allies and opponents, some of whom were shaking their heads that a major political event was happening at 9:30 on a Saturday morning.

headline: World View Podcast
text: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

headline: Kids Play on Our Behalf (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Curt Dempster, 71, Artistic Director of Ensemble Studio Theater, Dies
text: Curt Dempster, a founder and the artistic director of the Ensemble Studio Theater, a New York institution that has served as an incubator for thousands of new American plays, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartment in Greenwich Village. He was 71.

headline: All Japanese, and Very Naked
text: I have seen the Glorious Future.

headline: San Francisco Police Are Criticized in Wake of Fight Involving a Yale Singing Group
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 — Investigators from the San Francisco Police Department are expected to travel to Connecticut this weekend to interview victims of a New Year’s Day street fight here that left several Yale University students injured and the department once again fending off criticism.

headline: Ney Is Sentenced to 2½ Years in Abramoff Case
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Former Representative Bob Ney, the only member of Congress to admit guilt in the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal, was sentenced Friday to two and a half years in prison, longer than had been requested by the Justice Department.

headline: With His Game on the Rise, Roddick Roars Past Safin
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 20 — Anyone who has taken a marathon flight from the United States to Melbourne — “Eight movies and you’re there” an Australian once said — could sympathize with Jimmy Connors as he sat courtside Friday night, having arrived a few hours earlier.

headline: Reform, Finally, in the Senate
text: The Senate has finally passed credible reforms of its shabby ethics code, reining in lawmakers’ more egregious quid pro quo dealings with their fund-raising cohorts in the lobbying industry. The Republican minority had second thoughts about how its transparently obstructionist tactics would look to constituents. And an overwhelming majority then approved the first serious anticorruption strictures since the Watergate era, banning gifts, entertainment, travel and other inducements that lobbyists and their employers use in greasing privileged access to lawmakers and their staffs.

headline: New Favor for a Name That Straddles Cultures
text: For the first time in a generation, the most popular name for newborn Hispanic boys in New York City is an ethnic one: Angel.

headline: Bush Comments on Agents Who Shot Suspected Drug Dealer
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  President Bush waded this week into the furor surrounding two former border patrol agents who were each convicted and sentenced to more than a decade in prison in the shooting of a suspected Mexican drug dealer in Texas.

headline: A Home That Once Was
text: Past and present views of Miriam DePalma's childhood house outside of Havana.

headline: On Leadership
text: Tom Brady criticized his teammates and supported Bill Belichick in a news conference last month.

headline: Hillary’s In
text: Six years after making history by winning a United States Senate seat as First Lady, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is expected to announce announced this morning that she is taking the first formal step toward seeking the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, according to Democrats familiar with her decision.

headline: New Political Best-Seller List
text: It’s a new month, and a new year, but some political books that ranked high on last month’s list continue to hang in there, especially Senator Barack Obama’s book, still at No. 1.

headline: Thinking About You by Norah Jones
text: Music Video: "Thinking About You" by Norah Jones, her first single from her new album, "Not Too Late," due for release Jan. 30.

headline: ‘I’m in to Win’
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced this morning that she was taking the first formal step to seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, The Times’s Patrick Healy reports.

headline: Magazining on the Head of a Pin
text: Los Angeles magazine plumbs the implications of Oscar blogging in L.A. It’s not on the stands yet, but Jeffrey Wells at Hollywood Elsewhere– or some pal of his –– scanned it in so he could write about it while mad-blogging the proceedings here at Sundance. It’s only of interest to true obsessives, so the Bagger read every word.

headline: They’ve Got the Valley Covered
text: For people who want to go deep on Sundance, The Reeler is doing a ton of sharp reviewing and reporting.

headline: Heeding the Call, Even When It Doesn’t Come
text: Winona Ryder was about to head into the crush of a pre-screening party for “The Ten.” “I’m a little nervous, because I fall in love with a puppet and I have to play it totally straight,” she said. Beyond that, not having seen a final cut, she did not want to do a lot of talking about the film. But she did say she had a great time making it.

headline: Elements of Style
text: The Bagger has taken a righteous pounding in the comments section of yesterday’s postings. The correspondents pointed out that the Bagger was grammatically impaired, a sloppy writer and suggested he might have mailed in his report from Sundance.

headline: Brother-Sister Act
text: Earlier in the evening, “The Savages” played at the Eccles Theater, a much larger venue. The place was jammed, in part because its director,Tamara Jenkins, made the much-liked “Slums of Beverly Hills” and is a graduate of the Sundance Institute. Folks also showed up in droves because Philip Seymour Hoffman and Laura Linney star in the film. They play siblings who come together — barely, at first — to take care of a demented father who never took much care of them. Afterward, the actors said that the movie felt like one long scene – in a good sense.

headline: Ten Times the Effort
text: Attending a film festival, especially one with the endless possibilities of Sundance, may be just a bit of fun for some folks, but the pros — the Bagger is a newbie so he doesn’t count — treat it like a bloodsport. The point is not just to see most of the hot movies, but to see them first. It’s a brutal pastime.

headline: Style at Sundance
text: At the Sundance Film Festival, your style boils down to your boots. The Carpetbagger (a k a David Carr) investigates.

headline: 2008 Like It’s All Weekend: Clinton and Brownback and Richardson
text: Today’s news is some of the biggest of the whole primary season, and yet it is perhaps the least surprising. People have been talking about the possiblity of Hillary Rodham Clinton someday running for president since, gosh, maybe when she was appointed by her husband, then-President Bill Clinton, to fix the health care system in the mid-1990s.

headline: Talking to Iran
text: To comment on Sunday’s column about Iran, hit the comment button below and fire away….

headline: Notes On Update 0.1.0.4
text: We’re drawing ever closer to a V1 release of Times Reader. Thanks to your feedback we have been able to discover and fix some of the application’s weak points as well as several annoying bugs. Below is a list of some of the major changes that you will find in the 0.1.0.4 build.

headline: Journey Through War
text: Follow The Times's Jeffrey Gettleman during his recent two-week journey through war-torn Somalia.

headline: One-Armed Bandits, Working for the Public
text: YONKERS

headline: Is There a Post-Abortion Syndrome?
text: Early on a windy Saturday morning in November, Rhonda Arias drove her Dodge Caravan past a Wal-Mart at the end of her block and onto the Interstate. She was beginning the 50-mile drive from her house in southwest Houston to Plane State Jail, where she is, as she puts it, an “abortion-recovery counselor.” To Arias, that means helping women at the prison who have had abortions to understand how that procedure has stained them, and how it explains what has gone wrong in their lives. The prisoners’ abortions, she told me, “have a great deal to do with their pain.”

headline: Gordimer and Said
text: To the Editor:

headline: Refugees Find Hostility and Hope on Soccer Field
text: CLARKSTON, Ga., Jan. 20 — Early last summer the mayor of this small town east of Atlanta issued a decree: no more soccer in the town park.

headline: Once Given Up for Dead, Comcast Defies Its Obits
text: THREE years ago, with the cable television industry in the doldrums, the Comcast Corporation’s chairman, Brian L. Roberts, approached Mel Karmazin, then the president of Viacom, with a modest proposal: give Comcast the right to show programming from such Viacom properties as CBS and MTV on the cable company’s channels so it could have a leg up on its rivals.

headline: In Buffalo, Detectives Celebrate Arrest in a Cold Case After Many Years of Frustration
text: BUFFALO, Jan. 20  Notes on the student’s murder filled more than a thousand typed pages. For years, six detectives worked the case full time, alongside dozens of other investigators. The telephones rang with tips 10 times a day, and more often after the case was profiled on the television program “Unsolved Mysteries.”

headline: Living in the Wake of an Accident; Value Judgments Regarding Adoption; A Virtual Town Square Reinvents Community (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: He Uses Blood to Get Under Your Skin
text: JAN FABRE knows that not everyone shares his passion for blood. For years this Belgian artist, director, writer and choreographer has been a provocateur in Europe, stunning and seducing audiences with his inventive creations, including some drawings for which he used his own bodily fluid.

headline: The Reform Window
text: Sometimes in politics, as in other vital matters, there occurs just the right combination of will, power and urgency to make real progress. Such a moment has arrived in Albany. The matter at hand is reforming the way Albany does business. All the key players are in alignment. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, still riding his electoral landslide, promises a new day in Albany. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat like Mr. Spitzer, says that his half of the Legislature is ready, again, to vote on many desperately-needed reforms. And Senator Joseph Bruno, the Republican leader of the other half, finds himself in trouble with investigators and thus in dire need of a few positive headlines.

headline: With Jefferson on His Side
text: CAMERON SINCLAIR is no sentimentalist. “My grandmother once told me, ‘Only fools rely on luck,’ ” he said.

headline: An Ex Takes the Spot
text: Although he knows I still have strong feelings for him, my ex-boyfriend applied for a training program at my workplace. May I ask my supervisor to prevent this? The company has many other offices around the nation where he could train without it being at my emotional expense. — name withheld, AUSTIN, TEX.

headline: Great Neck Students and Their Cars; Folk Arts Programs, Far and Wide (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Norah Jones, Now in Her Own Words
text: A LOCAL musician couldn’t ask for a more appreciative audience than the petite, black-haired woman in blue jeans who was one of about two dozen people at Marion’s Marquee Lounge on the Bowery a few Mondays ago. As the guitarist Tony Scherr led a trio through his bluesy, slightly skewed songs, she tapped her foot, giggled at his stage patter and vigorously applauded his solos. Every few tunes, she whispered, “I love this song!”

headline: Local Officials Are Cool to Corzine’s Tax Plan
text: TRENTON

headline: The Week in New Jersey
text: Bills Would Track Sex Offenders’ Web Use

headline: A Wrenching AIDS Tale Spanning Two Continents
text: There’s a simple moment in the Off Broadway hit “In the Continuum” that speaks far more eloquently than any government statistics could about the AIDS crisis in Africa. Abigail Murambe, an announcer on Zimbabwe’s state-run television channel, is trying to flag down a jitney after learning that she is HIV-positive. Shooing away the street urchins pestering her for money, she says: “Go away, you kids! Where are your parents?”

headline: Expecting? Make That Angst-Ridden
text: WHAT to expect when TV characters were expecting once meant glowing, knowing moms and jittery dads building toward a very special episode, complete with a requisite madcap race to the hospital.

headline: Fifth Avenue Mirage
text: AT 141 Fifth Avenue, a gleaming copper dome seems to rise above the turn-of-the-last-century facade, rich in Beaux-Arts detail, as homey curtains hang in the windows.

headline: The Need to Think Onstage Is Driving Mr. Daisey
text: THE lights went up too early, the cramped theater was swelteringly hot and Mike Daisey, looking a bit nervous alone onstage, could see himself sweating profusely in the mirror on the wall behind the audience. It was going to be one of those shows.

headline: Soul-Searching by Missouri Suspect’s Neighbors
text: KIRKWOOD, Mo., Jan. 19 — For more than four years, the residents of the South Holmes Apartments here in this quiet suburb of St. Louis lived alongside Shawn Hornbeck and the man who is accused of being his kidnapper and captor, Michael Devlin, a pizzeria manager.

headline: Big Media’s Crush on Social Networking
text: I WAS wandering around recently in Second Life, the much-ballyhooed online virtual world, and had a nice chat with one of its “residents.” But at the end of the talk he (or perhaps she; you never really know in these digital dioramas, where anyone can create an identity and just about anything else) asked if he could add me to his “friends” list and thereby keep tabs of my comings and goings in the online world. “Sure,” I replied, not because I was yearning to keep in touch but because it just struck me as rude to turn down such an invitation.

headline: What Was Once Theirs
text: FOREIGNERS almost never show up on the ragged streets of the old town across the bay from Havana. But there was a knock recently on the front door of the battered yellow house in Guanabacoa that is home to Marielena and Francisco, a working-class couple, and outside stood an American.

headline: Life in the Fast Lane
text: CLEAR, a private service that prescreens travelers for a $100 annual fee, has come to Kennedy International Airport. To benefit from the Clear Registered Traveler program, which is run by Verified Identity Pass, a person must fill out an application, let the service capture his fingerprints and iris pattern and present two forms of identification. If the traveler passes a federal background check, he will be given a card that allows him to pass quickly through airport security.

headline: Who Is This Child? And What Will He Be Next?
text: MY son, at age 8½, changed his name to Penguin S’ Ice, and he has kept that name for almost a year now, un-bratty in his corrections, but adamant.

headline: From a Mental Hospital, a Cinematic Mexico
text: IN 1925 Martín Ramírez (1895-1963), the great self-taught draftsman, left his small ranch in the Jalisco region of Mexico for work in the promised land of the United States. He never returned to his wife and four children back home, spending more than three decades confined to psychiatric hospitals after being picked up off the streets of California in 1931: jobless, homeless, confused and unable to communicate in English.

headline: None (but Me) Dare Call It Treason
text: At first Dinesh D’Souza considered him “a dark-eyed fanatic, a gun-toting extremist, a monster who laughs at the deaths of 3,000 innocent civilians.” But once he learned how Osama bin Laden was viewed in the Muslim world, D’Souza changed his mind. Now he finds bin Laden to be “a quiet, well-mannered, thoughtful, eloquent and deeply religious person.” Despite being considered a friend of the Palestinians, he “has not launched a single attack against Israel.” We denounce him as a terrorist, but he uses “a different compass to assess America than Americans use to assess him.” Bin Laden killed only 3,000 of us, with “every victim counted, every death mourned, every victim’s family generously compensated.” But look what we did in return: many thousands of Muslims dead in Afghanistan and Iraq, “and few Americans seem distressed over these numbers.”

headline: Astonish Me
text: No one was more excited than I was when Maureen Corrigan of National Public Radio’s “Fresh Air” described Alice McDermott’s new novel as “astonishing.” Several years ago, overwhelmed by the flood of material unleashed annually by the publishing industry, I decided to establish a screening program by purchasing only books that at least one reviewer had described as “astonishing.”

headline: Neighbors’ Scowls Place a Dog Spot in Peril
text: Chelsea, a young wheaten terrier, bounded in unleashed abandon across the fenced-in yard, sending pebble gravel flying in all directions, and threw herself on top of a slimy tennis ball.

headline: Blue Jays Are Trying to Stay With the Big Boys
text: By slipping ahead of Boston in last season’s final week, Toronto enjoyed its best division finish since winning successive World Series in 1992 and ’93. For a dozen years the Blue Jays had finished no better than third in the American League East. Now only the Yankees finished ahead of them. Where do they go from here?

headline: Thai Army Officers Held in Bombings
text: SINGAPORE, Jan. 20  Authorities in Thailand detained 15 people, including some military officers, in connection with a string of bombings that killed three people and disrupted celebrations on New Year’s Eve, the police said Saturday.

headline: Karen Bernard, Jonathan Reiter
text: Karen Anne Bernard and Jonathan Charles Reiter were married last evening at the Carlyle in New York. Justice Lewis J. Lubell of State Supreme Court in White Plains officiated.

headline: The Socialist Senator
text: When Bernie Sanders visits a high-school class, as he does regularly, students don’t hear a speech, a focus-grouped polemic, a campaign pitch or, heaven forbid, practiced one-liners. Nor, in all likelihood, do they hear Sanders tell stories about his family, childhood or some hardship he has endured. He makes no great effort to “connect” emotionally in the manner that politicians strive for these days, and he probably doesn’t “feel your pain” either, or at least make a point of saying so. It’s not that Sanders is against connecting, or feeling your pain, but the process seems needlessly passive and unproductive, and he prefers a more dynamic level of engagement.

headline: What’s the Coolest Way to Accessorize an iPod? Buy It a Car.
text: APPLE’S iPod seems to be everywhere. We can attach them to our home stereos and stick them into portable devices to bring them into our bedroom, kitchen and even the bathroom. With cases that clip to a shirt pocket and Velcro holders that wrap around an arm, it is hard to imagine a place where an iPod can’t go.

headline: Naming Rights and Wrongs Across Time Zones
text: What would Walter O’Malley have thought about the $400 million naming rights for a sports arena atop the railroad station near Downtown Brooklyn, where he once feinted at building a ballpark?

headline: The Fornicator
text: At times in Walter Mosley’s “sexistential” new novel, “Killing Johnny Fry,” it’s unclear whether his hero, Cordell Carmel, is meant to be a lover or a big-game hunter. One of his conquests is described as bellowing “like some large woodlands creature in ecstasy over the wild” and flopping “like a mackerel on the deck of a fishing boat.” Manly and active to a fault, the descriptions Mosley favors for both Cordell’s physical equipment and his talent with it might have been plucked from “The Boys’ Big Book of Phallic Metaphors.” Cordell compares himself to “a bullet” entering “the well-oiled chamber of a gun” and “a giant cruise ship coming into a port that was way too small.” All that’s missing is for Cordell to drop his drawers and have one of his partners inquire, “Is that the Chattanooga Choo-Choo?”

headline: ‘My’ Yard? Ha! The Turkeys Run the Place Now
text: WESTON

headline: Yoon Im and Jamie Kane
text: Yoon Kyong Im and Dr. Jamie Andrew Kane were married on Monday evening at the Hotel Punta Islita in Guanacaste, Costa Rica. Marcelo Galli, a lawyer, officiated.

headline: Rusty Bridge, Great Views and Soon, a Walkway?
text: Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

headline: When Is a Building a Rubik’s Cube?
text: SOMETIMES, developers and architects say, the biggest design problem with a new Manhattan residential building is figuring out how it will fit onto its lot. Two luxury condominiums, one planned for East 51st Street and the other for East 13th, are currently presenting a challenge.

headline: The Overlook
text: Instead of going to the hospital to get checked out, Bosch, along with Walling, has gone back to the Kent house, where Bosch has convinced her that the terrorist angle was meant to distract, the crime being a classic one of sex and murder: Alice Kent had conspired with Walling’s partner to kill Stanley Kent. Except the partner wasn’t Brenner, as Bosch had been thinking.

headline: Arizona Is Latest Pac-10 Team to Regret Trip to Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 — The Arizona Wildcats gave themselves less than two hours Saturday to board a bus at Pauley Pavilion, negotiate Interstate 405 southbound, check in at Los Angeles International Airport and hop a flight to Tucson.

headline: The Hungry Stroller
text: Less than a square mile in area, NoHo, short for north of Houston, is a stroller’s paradise, with wide cobblestone streets and few cars. Though zoning rules have limited the types of businesses that can occupy ground floors, restaurants are trickling in, broadening the food options.

headline: On the Air, the Voice of Sunni Rebels in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 20 — The video starts with a young American soldier patrolling an Iraqi street. His head is obscured by leaves, so a red target is digitally inserted to draw the viewer’s eye. A split second later, the soldier collapses, shot. Martial music kicks in, a jihadi answer to John Philip Sousa. The time and place of the attack scrolls at the bottom of the screen.

headline: Bush Administration, Under Criticism, Warns Iraq to Fulfill Its End of the Bargain
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  President Bush and his top advisers, after nine days of unrelenting criticism from Congress, are warning the Iraqi government that continuing funding for an American troop increase and other elements of Mr. Bush’s new Iraq strategy will be contingent on Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s delivery on promises to quell violence, senior administration officials said in recent interviews.

headline: More Doors for the Great Outdoors
text: Dalton, N.H.

headline: Correction
text: An essay in the special “Lives They Lived” issue on Dec. 31 about the geologist Marie Tharp referred incorrectly to a past admissions policy of her alma mater, the University of Michigan. Women were eligible for admission to its geology department as early as 1870, not starting after World War II began.

headline: A Proposal to Ban Spanking Sparks Debate
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 — As a general rule, legislators tend to begin their attack on bills once they have actually been written. But not much proposed legislation involves the backsides of children.

headline: The Street Corner Trap
text: For years now, it has been common knowledge that many of the harsh drug laws enacted in the 70s and 80s not only do not work, but have an unfair impact on minorities. That is especially true of a 1987 New Jersey law setting up 1,000-foot zones around schools where anyone convicted of a drug crime would automatically be sentenced to extra time in prison.

headline: Stroke and Scram
text: ON Saturday, Dec. 16, three actresses in their 20s ventured out to Herald Square with a video camera and a surreptitious mission: to approach unsuspecting pedestrians from behind and gently stroke their hair without their knowledge. They filmed one another’s efforts, which for the most part succeeded in failing to attract notice from various hair pettees, bar a few suspicious looks.

headline: A Movie House’s Happy Ending
text: Bantam

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Editors' Choice
text: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

headline: After Finding Trouble, Johnson Hoping to Find Brees
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 20 — On Sunday at Soldier Field, the Chicago Bears are counting on a defensive tackle who weighs 300 pounds and goes by the name Tank to storm the New Orleans Saints’ backfield and seize the moment.

headline: Armenian in Istanbul
text: There is a moral putrescence peculiar to the denial of genocide. Yet denial’s practitioners are all around us. The Sudanese government calls the butchers of Darfur “self-defense militias.” The Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, dismisses the Holocaust as “myth.” In an official government report, the Turkish Historical Society describes the slaughter of more than a million Armenians between 1914 and 1918 as “relocations” with “some untoward incidents.”

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: Hang Up! Tehran Is Calling
text: One of the most worrying parts of President Bush’s Iraq strategy doesn’t have anything to do with Iraq. It’s the way he’s ramping up a confrontation with Iran.

headline: Keeping Tabs on Accidental Wanderers
text: ON a dark, rainy evening last fall, a 78-year-old man with Alzheimer’s headed out the front door of his home in Morris County, N.J., and started walking toward a grocery store. His frantic wife, having walked downstairs and realized he was gone, called the Morris County Sheriff’s Office to report him missing. Twelve minutes after officers arrived at the house, they found him almost three miles from his home.

headline: With Field-Goal Accuracy on the Rise, Are Kickers Too Good?
text: Place-kickers in the N.F.L. have never been this good, and they are becoming better every season.

headline: A Child’s View of Play: Leave It to Us Kids! (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Sale: Fit for an Army and Long as a City Block
text: PATERSON, N.J.

headline: In Jackson, Wyo., an Art Scene Pushes Beyond the Old Frontier
text: THE town of Jackson has long been known for cowboys, moose and mountains — a shorthand for the American frontier that has been immortalized in countless wildlife and landscape paintings. And in Jackson's town square, you can find showrooms like the Trailside Galleries and the Legacy Gallery, whose large spaces exhibit mounted bronzes of bears and oil paintings of snowy owls taking off in flight.

headline: Tackling Taxes
text: As targets of suburban loathing and despair, property taxes get all the attention, particularly in Westchester, whose property taxes are among the highest in the nation. But there are many other tributaries flowing into the sea of taxes in which New Yorkers float.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Behind a Player’s Depression

headline: Brooke Lippmann, Seth Christian
text: Brooke Ashley Lippmann, the daughter of Jessica Lippmann and Larry Lippmann of Katonah, N.Y., was married last evening to Seth Michael Christian, the son of Deborah Christian and Edward P. Christian of Nantucket, Mass. Rabbi Lewis Mintz officiated at the New York Palace hotel.

headline: Is a ‘Mansion Tax’ Deductible?
text: Q Is the 1 percent “mansion tax” imposed by New York State on a house that costs $1 million or more deductible on the buyer’s federal income tax return?

headline: City Hires Coordinator of Food Policy
text: The city has hired Benjamin Thomases, an advocate for the poor, as its first food policy coordinator, officials confirmed Friday.

headline: Mexico Sends 4 Kingpins to Face Trial in the U.S.
text: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 — Breaking with longstanding practice, Mexico extradited four major drug traffickers to the United States late Friday and sent a signal that the country’s newly elected president, Felipe Calderón, is serious about cooperating with his northern neighbor to dismantle cartels.

headline: Rough Treatment for 2 Journalists in Pakistan
text: My photographer, Akhtar Soomro, and I were followed over several days of reporting in Quetta by plainclothes intelligence officials who were posted at our respective hotels. That is not unusual in Pakistan, where accredited journalists are free to travel and report, but their movements, phone calls and interviews are often monitored.

headline: Another Tasty Addition to a Restaurant Family
text: Coromandel in Orange is the third in the Coromandel family of Indian restaurants in this area. The first is in Darien, the second in New Rochelle, N.Y. (The same owners also have Dakshin, in Stamford, and Kolam, in Newtown).

headline: Damaged Ship Spilling Cargo Off British Coast
text: A damaged and listing cargo ship was spilling fuel and cargo containers into stormy seas off the southwest coast of England, near Devon, British officials said tonight. Some of the containers held hazardous materials.

headline: Once at Risk of Dropping Out, Now Making College Plans
text: You can hear the pride in Estefania Esquilin’s voice: “My teacher, she said that I’m her inspiration. I did what I had to do in such a short amount of time. My teacher used me as an example to the other classes.”

headline: As East Harlem Develops, Its Accent Starts to Change
text: Inside a wooden shack set in a garden on East 117th Street, a group of Puerto Rican men, many of them in their 70s and 80s, are playing a spirited game of dominoes on a rainy winter afternoon. A painting of a woman wearing a burgundy shawl over a flamenco-style dress hangs on a wall, and in the garden, tomatoes, peppers, corn and culantro, an herb used in Caribbean cooking, grow in the summer.

headline: 3 Charged With Assault on Officers
text: Two off-duty police officers were injured, one of them critically, when three people attacked them early yesterday after a car accident on the West Side of Manhattan, the police said.

headline: The Mexican Experience: La Gran Manzana’s Homey Side
text: IT was a challenge to find a genuine Mexican meal in New York City 15 years ago, in part because it was a challenge to find a genuine Mexican.

headline: When Food and Rent Compete
text: Every Thursday, the line forms at the door of the 164 Wilson Food Pantry in Richmond Hill, one of Stamford’s poorest neighborhoods, for the pantry’s weekly dispersal of groceries to the needy. But the fourth Thursday of the month is usually the toughest, says Joyce Gumbus, the pantry’s coordinator. That is when people who struggle to make a Social Security check or a disability check last generally run out of money, and the line winds around the building. Instead of the usual 150 to 200 people who need help, sometimes 300 to 400 show up.

headline: The Noncompete Clause: Balk at Your Own Risk
text: Q. You’ve been offered a new job, and your prospective employer wants you to sign a noncompete agreement, but the document makes you uneasy. What should you do?

headline: Bush to Urge New Tax Plan for Health Care Coverage
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  President Bush intends to use his State of the Union address Tuesday to tackle the rising cost of health care with a one-two punch: tax breaks to help low-income people buy health insurance and tax increases for some workers whose health plans cost significantly more than the national average.

headline: On Renewing New Haven
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Lonely Hearts
text: For some of us, self-deprecation is the olive in the martini of romance. It’s that little something extra — a blast of salt and texture in a pool of cool velvet. The practice of demoting oneself has a counterintuitive power: it takes a truly secure person to self-flagellate. But in “They Call Me Naughty Lola,” a highly jaunty collection of personal ads from The London Review of Books, the intense self-deprecation among lovelorn Brits is less like an olive resting comfortably at the bottom of a martini glass and more like a peacock that has set itself on fire to flag down passing motorists. One ad runs, “Official greeter and face of Dalkeith Cheese Festival, 1974, seeks woman to 50 who is no stranger to failure, debt-consolidating mortgages and wool.” Another states: “Your buying me dinner doesn’t mean I’ll have sex with you. I probably will have sex with you though.” A third comes from the pen of a woman able to “start fires with the power of her premenstrual tension.”

headline: Forget the Airport. Give Us Better Trains!; Value Judgments Regarding Adoption (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Border, Signs of Pakistani Role in Taliban Surge
text: QUETTA, Pakistan — The most explosive question about the Taliban resurgence here along the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan is this: Have Pakistani intelligence agencies been promoting the Islamic insurgency?

headline: The Turntables That Transform Vinyl
text: LONG-PLAYING records are gathering dust in the homes of many music lovers, who hope to hear their contents one day on a CD player or iPod.

headline: Funny Girl
text: Q: The opening credits of your new television sitcom, “The Sarah Silverman Program,” include a scenic glimpse of a cemetery plot, as your voice explains that your parents are both deceased. Is that actually true? No. They’re both pretty retired.

headline: Amsterdam: Mövenpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre
text: THE BASICS

headline: Correction: The Music Is Sweet, the Words Are True
text: An article on Jan. 7 about the lyricists’ art misstated a word in a Stephen Sondheim lyric for the song “Pretty Little Picture.” The line goes “And the boat and the boy and the bride are away,” not “And the boat and the buoy and the bride are away.”

headline: Shushing the Baby Boomers
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Blinding Ourselves in Space
text: You don’t have to be a space or climate expert to recognize that this country’s ability to track climate and environmental changes from space is heading in the wrong direction. At a time when concerns about global warming are rising, the Bush administration is sharply reducing the number of satellites that can measure the impact of rising temperatures and a host of other environmental trends.

headline: Totals
Insurance for Travelers Who Have Reached a Certain Age
text: I am having a problem finding travel insurance for my 82-year-old mother-in-law who lives in Moscow and is planning to visit us in Switzerland. Because of her age, and the fact that she has had a heart problem, her Russian travel insurance may not be adequate. She would be staying with us for four to six weeks. Can you help?

headline: ‘American Speeches’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Moby-Dinner
text: The flesh was red — maroon almost — and shot with sinew. Pinching it between my wooden chopsticks, I hesitated as the woman watched me and leered. Deep brown soy sauce and acid green wasabi clung to the limp piece of sashimi, giving it a rainbow cast. The woman’s stare was still on me. Her eyes widened.

headline: How Long Can the Hotel Industry Stay in High Gear?
text: THE hotel industry has made a stellar comeback since bottoming out about five years ago, with occupancy and room rates rising sharply nationwide. Analysts expect another strong year in 2007, though they caution that the opening of hotels planned when the industry began its expansion may cool off the market.

headline: Army Says Improper Orders by Colonel Led to 4 Deaths
text: Army investigators say that Col. Michael D. Steele, a decorated combat veteran and brigade commander in Iraq, issued improper orders to his soldiers that contributed to the deaths of four unarmed Iraqi men during a raid in May, according to military documents.

headline: Mother of Victims Killed by Police Car Questions Handling of Inquiry
text: UPPER TOWNSHIP, N.J. — At least five people saw the New Jersey State Police car as it sped along Stagecoach Road one night in late September. One witness guessed it was going 80 miles an hour; another described it simply as a “white streak.”

headline: From Last-Minute Write-In to Mr. Mayor
text: Ogdensburg

headline: Correction: TV Dramas Rip the Cover Off Magazines
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about depictions of celebrity magazines in television series and novels referred incorrectly to Absolute magazine, whose former editor in chief, Andrew Essex, discussed the portrayals. It is not exclusively for holders of American Express black cards, known formally as the Centurion card; Absolute is aimed at affluent readers in general. (Centurion, The Magazine, is published exclusively for customers with black cards.)

headline: Vatican Urges ‘Dialogue’ With China to Rebuild Ties
text: ROME, Jan. 20  The Vatican issued a measured statement on Saturday on its future relations with China, saying it wanted a “respectful and constructive dialogue” to rebuild diplomatic ties but still noting the “suffering” of Chinese Catholics.

headline: In Gas-Plant Plan, a Weighty Silent Voice
text: AT the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission hearings this month on Broadwater Energy’s proposed floating natural gas plant in Long Island Sound, opponents seemed to be addressing a man who was not there.

headline: With Loss, Rangers Limp Into Break
text: A gloom descended on the Rangers late in a 3-1 loss to Atlanta yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, where the crowd melted away and the team limped into the All-Star Game break with the momentum of a stalled car.

headline: Prosecutor in Apple Case Joins Law Firm
text: Christopher J. Steskal, a lead prosecutor of a federal task force investigating the backdating of stock options at Apple Inc. and other companies, is leaving his San Francisco post to join a law firm, the United State Attorney’s office in San Francisco confirmed late Friday.

headline: Dad’s Motorcycle Diary
text: I FIRST noticed the rusting motorbike, which was chained to a fence at Peters Field, on Second Avenue between 20th and 21st Streets, in the summer of 2005. That was when I, a former rock drummer and window cleaner turned stay-at-home dad, began taking my 1-year-old daughter, Annika, to the Augustus St. Gaudens Playground a block away.

headline: Correction: Kochi, Kerala’s Friendly Gateway, Is No Backwater
text: An article on Jan. 7 about Kochi, India, referred incorrectly to flights on Delta Air Lines between New York and Kochi. It does not offer service to Kochi.

headline: Announcement Sends Race Into High Gear
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s entry into the 2008 presidential contest yesterday set off rounds of e-mail messages and conference calls among both her allies and opponents, some of whom were shaking their heads that a major political event was happening early on a Saturday morning.

headline: Iran’s President Continues to Press Nuclear Issue
text: TEHRAN, Jan. 21 — Iran’s internal battle over President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s defiant rhetoric on Iran’s nuclear program continued to simmer on Sunday, with the president repeating his vow to ignore international sanctions and a moderate daily newspaper warning of Iran’s increasing isolation.

headline: Tech Shares Fall as Earnings Disappoint
text: Technology earnings reports that failed to meet Wall Street’s expectations pulled down the Nasdaq composite index last week, but the Dow Jones industrial average managed a small gain.

headline: Senate Newcomer Is Designated to Encounter President Bush Yet Again
text: Washington

headline: Looking for My Father in Las Vegas
text: They are all gone now. I don’t think about them much anymore, except, fleetingly, at this time of year, late January. They would have loved it, the buildup to the Super Bowl, an exhilarating time for men like themselves, those shadowy figures from my childhood.

headline: Kansas Senator Announces Bid for Presidency
