text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 — Declaring himself a proud conservative before a crowd of cheering supporters waving American flags, Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, on Saturday announced his candidacy for president.

headline: Vast Pipelines in Amazon Face Challenges Over Protecting Rights and Rivers
text: URUCU, Brazil — In theory, the issue is a simple one: Brazil needs more sources of energy to keep its economy humming, and huge reserves of gas and oil are in the Amazon jungle. Problem solved.

headline: Sniffing Out the Truth
text: THE mysterious odor that blanketed Manhattan on Jan. 8 remains, well, a mysterious odor. Last week, officials in New York and New Jersey gave up on finding the source of the smell.

headline: Residential Conversions Revitalize River Town
text: ALTON, Ill.

headline: A Taste of Portugal, Fresh, Simple and Flavorful
text: SITTING in Docas in downtown Ossining on a late December evening, we luxuriated in the restaurant’s atmosphere. Warm, soft Portuguese rolls had just hit the table. The menu and most of the conversation around us was in Portuguese. Our glasses were filled with a wonderful house-made sangria and a carbonated pineapple juice from Portugal that is a terrific, less sugary alternative to soda.

headline: Alice’s Adventures in Gymnastics
text: Wonderland is one loony labyrinth in “Lookingglass Alice,” the Lookingglass Theater Company of Chicago’s gravity-defying, if at times stubbornly earthbound, version of Lewis Carroll’s 19th-century children’s classics “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” and “Through the Looking Glass.” Adapted and directed by David Catlin, it is now on stage at the McCarter Theater in Princeton.

headline: The Pitcher, the Singer and the Bricklayer
text: It’s a tough time of year for Joe Gaeta.

headline: Where Religion Meets Real Estate, a Developer and a Town Face Off
text: POMONA, N.Y.

headline: Jeeps Go Forth and Reproduce
text: WITH its four-wheel-drive franchise under assault from all sides, DaimlerChrysler’s Jeep division has responded by sending new recruits into battle. But to the horror of some Jeep traditionalists, not all of these new models can climb every mountain and ford every stream.

headline: Correction: Alexis Chiang and Thomas Colvin
text: A report on Jan. 7, about the Chiang-Colvin wedding, misstated the bridegroom’s given name. He is Timothy Colvin, not Thomas.

headline: Free of Frat Parties, Neighbors Still Worry
text: Setauket

headline: Why Wait Until May?
text: The sign may say Cinco de Mayo, but at this Hillsdale diner you can enjoy authentic Mexican food all year long.

headline: Polarities
text: Lately, fashion in New York has been a high-wire act. The seasons have been changing so fast you would think winter and spring were running a marathon. Temperatures spiraled to near 70 as January got under way, then plunged to 19 on Wednesday morning. Women scrambled to keep up with nature’s high jinks, first stripping down, left, for spring’s surge. On Monday, daffodils, quince, snowdrops and forsythia were in bloom in Central Park. Then, two days later, winter sprinted ahead, and women bundled up to resemble the polar bear window at the decorator Linda Horn’s antiques shop on the Upper East Side. On Friday, snow coated the park and capped the daffodils.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: FILM

headline: Mr. Chips Goes to Congress
text: We’re in bipartisan nirvana. Bills are passing through the House 356 to 71 and through the Senate 96 to 2. Nancy Pelosi is aglow, and this week President Bush will trot out a State of the Union speech so conciliatory in tone it’ll sound like Gandhi on Quaaludes.

headline: In Close-Knit Town, ‘Horrific’ Killing of Family Rattles the Residents
text: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 20 — Even as it expands with new housing and new businesses, this Dutchess County town remains an old-fashioned community, where people pay good money — $129.99 — for a rocking chair at Cracker Barrel and the only thing menacing about the place is its name.

headline: Mr. and Mrs. Natural
text: VALLÉE DU Vidourle, France

headline: Why Backdated Options Might Be Contagious
text: DIRECTORS of corporations often form a tight-knit community, serving at more than one company and creating what are known as interlocking boards of directors. As a result of this chumminess, corporate practices that otherwise might remain confined to just a few companies can spread quickly.

headline: Value Judgments Regarding Adoption; Diocese of Bridgeport, Are You Listening?; Drunken Driving in ‘Cheever Country’ (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Small Businesses Get Bigger
text: MITCHELL GOSS is a very busy businessman. So busy running his small but growing digital-age business that he did not have time to hunt for the loan he needed to continue expanding.

headline: True or False: Lies Are Hard to Prove
text: Proving perjury, the central charge against I. Lewis Libby, whose trial began in Washington last week, can be an uphill fight. To win a perjury case, a prosecutor must convince a jury not only that the defendant said something false under oath about a significant point but also that the falsehood was more than an innocent error produced by poor memory. To be perjury, the false statement has to be a knowing lie.

headline: Wake Up and Smell the ‘Odorous Air Contaminant’
text: Four years ago or so, about two weeks after Hy Chabbott’s trouble with city government started, he was in line at the bank when another customer said he smelled coffee. “That’s me,” said Mr. Chabbott, who spends most of his days in the roasting plant of the 167-year-old Gillies Coffee Company, of which he is an owner.

headline: In Shanghai, Balancing the Past, the Future and a Budget
text: IN Shanghai, the present does not exist. Want the past? Stroll along the Huangpu River and gaze at the stretch of Greek temple banks, Neo-Classical-style skyscrapers and Art Deco hotels. This is the Bund, a relic of Shanghai's golden age, built a century ago by the international coterie of businessmen who had transformed a river town into the richest port in Asia.

text: Music and Dance

headline: The Week in Connecticut
text: Commuter Group Says Improvements Are on the Way

headline: Melanie Thernstrom, Michael Callahan
text: Melanie Thernstrom and Michael Callahan were married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York. The ceremony was performed by Cynthia Baughman, the bride’s best friend, who became a minister of the Rose Ministries for the event.

headline: A Tenor Cashes in on His Money Notes
text: IT’S ancient history, but the Sicilian tenor Marcello Giordani makes it a point of honor to acknowledge the crisis. His career got off to a promising start in Spoleto, Italy, with Verdi’s “Rigoletto” in 1986. He was 23, and he had plenty going for him: musicality, easy high notes, a handsome face, a good physique. And he was tall — a godsend to leading ladies.

headline: Son of Dogs Playing Poker
text: FEW ideas have caused as much academic navel-gazing as kitsch. An unfathomable amount of highbrow ink has been spilled in the name of explaining why so many people prefer paintings of dogs playing poker to the masterworks of Abstract Expressionism.

headline: Busiest Runways, Most Delays: The Tao of Flying
text: In total metro area population, Atlanta barely breaks the Top 10. But it is No. 1 at the airport: Atlanta can brag that it had the most takeoffs and landings in the United States for 2006.

headline: Retreat and Cheat
text: President Bush’s warrantless wiretapping program was once deemed so vital to national security that it could not be subjected to judicial review. Last week, the White House said it was doing just that.

headline: Jazz Education; ‘Dutchman’; Charles France; David Byrne; Lyricists and Their Art
text: JAZZ EDUCATION

headline: The Underdog Days of Winter
text: Las Vegas

headline: The Home That You Can’t Call Your Own
text: WHEN most people consider the pain of moving, they think of the actual move: cardboard mountains, insubordinate packing tape, back strain and bewildered children.

headline: Beauty in the Eye of the Renter
text: FOR Richard E. Waits, leading the life of an itinerant performer meant always being someone’s roommate.

headline: Clinton’s Success in Presidential Race Is No Sure Thing
text: Compared with the other Democrats who plan to run for president in 2008, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is the most battle-tested, has the biggest fund-raising network and can walk into the job with a unique set of skills and perspectives gleaned from eight years in the White House as first lady.

headline: Racial Subplot on British ‘Big Brother’ Grabs Nation and Ratings
text: LONDON, Jan. 20 — So, finally, it was over and it ended, of course, in tears. By an overwhelming majority, the viewers voted to expel Jade and keep Shilpa.

headline: Indecent Exposure
text: Durham, N.C.

headline: Overnight Fire Erases a Block in Elizabeth; Dozens Are Left Homeless
text: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 20 — A 10-alarm fire spread by blasts of winter wind gutted a city block of apartment buildings and businesses early on Saturday, leaving nearly 50 people homeless, the authorities said.

headline: A Stylish Ride to Hydraulic Hell
text: WHAT WAS IT? The Citroën SM of 1970-75, the front-wheel-drive offspring of a French-Italian marriage. Fewer than 13,000 were made before the fuel crisis killed the market for fast coupes.

headline: When Friends Buy a House Together
text: IT is not unusual, real estate lawyers and brokers say, for people to consider pooling resources with friends or family members when buying property.

headline: Chinese New Year Is Bargain Time in Hong Kong
text: Even though you might think that Hong Kong would be crowded during the Chinese New Year — the two weeks after the start of the lunar calendar — it is quite empty because many residents desert the island for vacation. (The one exception: Disneyland, now 16 months old, which was so packed last year it had to shut its doors to day-trippers from the mainland.)

headline: For the Bold, Bargains Near a Harborside Park
text: THE factors luring homeowners like David Gonzalez into Bridgeport — a city whose persistent problems with crime, corruption and decay have at times subjected it to derision — offer strong evidence that those problems might be conquerable after all.

headline: Heidi Pechter, Monte Sichelman
text: Dr. Heidi Rochelle Pechter, a daughter of Phyllis Yantz Pechter and Marc S. Pechter of Weston, Fla., was married last evening to Dr. Monte Reid Sichelman, a son of Janet L. Sichelman and Dr. Alan K. Sichelman of Tarpon Springs, Fla. Rabbi Norman S. Lipson performed the ceremony at the Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center in Aventura, Fla.

headline: Three Generations, All on the Same Block
text: FROM her bedroom window in Chelsea, Virginia Manning, 8, can monitor the six elderly koi that live in her backyard pond. While aquaculture is new to her family, Virginia is the third generation to live on this block of West 19th Street. Her mother, Sarah Edwards, grew up in a town house a few doors down, where Virginia’s grandmother still lives. Her father, Paul Manning, grew up on Long Island, but his parents once lived in Chelsea, too.

headline: The Orange Meets Economics 101
text: At one bodega in Brooklyn on Friday, a big, thick-skinned navel orange cost 99 cents. In other parts of the country, that price might seem steep. But within a couple of weeks, it could be a bargain. The culprit: a citrus-killing freeze that hit California, which supplies 95 percent of the nation’s navel oranges in the winter.

headline: Low Prices Abound on the High Seas
text: LOOKING for a cheap Caribbean getaway? With bookings up at many resorts, deep discounts are hard to find on land — but there are plenty out at sea. Weak demand for Caribbean sailings is leading many cruise lines to slash prices — as low as $189 for some three-night cruises — in an effort to spur sales.

headline: Connecticut’s Diaspora
text: The young are leaving Connecticut in droves. According to the Connecticut Economic Resource Center, between 1990 and 2000, we lost a larger percentage of 18- to 34-year-olds than any other state, 23 percent, or more than 200,000 people.

headline: Correction: War and Cheap Oil: A Second Look
text: An article on Jan. 7 about the effect of the Iraq war on the price of oil in the Middle East attributed an incorrect statistic to James A. Placke, an oil expert, about the amount of oil currently being produced by Iraq. He said production was expected to average 1.85 million barrels a day for 2006; he did not say 1.5 million barrels.

headline: Laurie Sternberg, Joshua Sherwin
text: Laurie Jane Sternberg and Joshua Manning Sherwin were married last evening at Max of Eastman Place, a restaurant in Rochester. Rabbi Harold Kudan, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

headline: The World Is Watching. Not Americans.
text: This month the National Society of Film Critics picked its winners for 2006 — one of the last such bodies to do so. (The Iowa and Central Ohio critics would weigh in a few days later.) The announcement of the Society’s awards followed a month of frenzied balloting by various Circles and Associations in New York, Los Angeles and just about every city, state and region in between, an annual festival of critical self-assertion — a protest against irrelevance, perhaps — before the big Oscar show on Feb. 25.

headline: Is Greed Good?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bankers Trust: The Building Known for Its Ziggurat Top
text: THE ziggurat-topped Bankers Trust Building of 1912, at the northwest corner of Wall and Nassau Streets, is one of New York’s most picturesque skyscrapers, in part because of its contrast to the short J. P. Morgan & Company headquarters of 1914 diagonally across the intersection.

headline: Twin Cornerstones Catapult the Patriots to Amazing Heights
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 19 — A few weeks after the 2000 N.F.L. draft, Robert K. Kraft, the Patriots’ owner, left his office and passed a tall young man carrying a pizza box under his arm.

headline: New Orleans of Future May Stay Half Its Old Size
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20  The empty streets, deserted avenues and abandoned houses prompt a gnawing question, nearly 17 months after Hurricane Katrina: Is this what New Orleans has come to  a city half its old size?

headline: Early Start on a Fast Track
text: I GREW up in a small middle-class neighborhood of St. John’s in Newfoundland. My first job, at 16, was working at Tim Horton’s, which is like Dunkin’ Donuts in the United States. I had to be there at 5 a.m. The franchise owner had two locations. One store made doughnuts and the other made muffins. I carried the baked goods between the two, made coffee and waited on customers. I made minimum wage, which was $4.75 Canadian at the time.

headline: New Books Detail Offbeat Subjects About Tourism
text: If the idea of taking a guided tour through a former war zone — Sarajevo, Belfast, Cambodia or Rwanda — or visiting the scene of devastation from a natural disaster — New Orleans after Katrina or Thailand after the tsunami — appeals to you, get the Lonely Planet’s latest guide, “The Bluelist 2007” ($19.99).

headline: Chasing Spring: An American Journey Through a Changing Season
text: By Bruce Stutz Scribner, 239 pages, $24 hardcover

headline: Boogie Till Dawn
text: NIGHT life present is always on the verge of becoming night life past. So for its own sake, it is good that Love, an unassuming West Village club around the corner from Babbo, thrives on being a bit of living, kicking history. It is an amalgam of references: the black lights and Day-Glo graffiti rainbows, suns and ankhs of the ’60s and ’70s, the rage-all-night ethos of the ’80s, and the house music and D. J. worship of the ’90s.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Blue-Collar Workers
text: THE Super Bowl, the highlight of the National Football League season, is the very model of a 21st-century media, marketing and entertainment mega-event. It commands a huge audience (an average 90.7 million viewers tuned in to last year’s Super Bowl), attracts enormously lucrative commercials ($2.6 million for a 30-second spot this year), and will feature Prince as the performer during its halftime extravaganza.

headline: Site Calculates Risk Factors for Travelers
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20  A middle-aged male pedestrian is four times as likely, on any given trip, to be killed by a car as is an elementary school student, according to a new interactive Web site that lets people compare travel risks.

headline: Correction
text: An article about the Chevrolet Volt electric car on Jan. 7 gave the incorrect Web site of the California Cars Initiative, an advocate of such cars. It is CalCars.org, not Calcars.com.

headline: Measure for Measure
text: Here’s a tip. When deciding whether to buy an academic book marketed to a general audience, flip to the acknowledgments to look for tell-tale phrases like this one: So-and-so “deserves special mention for his indispensable advice and counsel as I turned my dissertation into a book.” Beware! Vestigial Dissertation Syndrome alert! Common symptoms include turgid prose and microscopic narrowness of topic. So after finding that tip-off in the acknowledgments of “The Averaged American,” by Sarah Igo, I braced myself for a slog.

headline: The Iraq Crackup (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Race to Fill Senate Seat Has Parties at Full Throttle
text: MINEOLA, N.Y., Jan. 20  It is a campaign for a single State Senate seat in the Long Island suburbs, a district that ranges from the grand estates of Old Westbury to working-class Elmont  and that has always sent Republicans to Albany.

headline: Public Parks and Private Schools
text: In a city of gaping economic disparities, public parks have long been the great equalizer. New Yorkers take pride in their egalitarian green spaces, which are open to everyone. But acreage has always been at a premium, and public money cannot keep pace with the costs of upkeep and improvements. Over the years, the city has thus come to depend on private donations to fill the gaps.

headline: Correction: Where Money’s No Object, Space Is No Problem
text: An article last Sunday about the new Seattle sculpture park misstated the year another institution, Benaroya Hall, home to the Seattle Symphony, opened. It was 1998, not 2002.

headline: Corrections
text: A credit on Jan. 7 for a cartoon by Daryl Cagle, about the death of newspapers, omitted the publication and syndicate for Mr. Cagle’s work. His cartoons appear on MSNBC.com and are distributed by CagleCartoons.com.

headline: The Sound and the Fury
text: HEATHER MILLSTONE had a bucolic childhood, living with her parents in suburban Rockville, Md., in a peaceful home that bordered a farm. That idyllic setting, however, didn’t last.

headline: Anatomy of Misery
text: Paula Spencer, a widowed working mother in north Dublin, has an exhausting job and four kids to fret about. At 47, she’s still a “good-looking woman” who makes time to keep abreast of popular trends: taking in the odd White Stripes or Coldplay concert, Googling her name on the Internet, contemplating yoga and nursing the hope of one day meeting a suitable partner — like Joe, a retiree in a Nike hoodie whose wife left him for another woman.

headline: Love, and Death, Is in the Air
text: ROB JETT, a 51-year-old Brooklyn birdwatcher who maintains a blog called Citybirder, has long been fascinated by the red-tailed hawks living in Prospect Park.

headline: The Reform Window
text: Sometimes in politics, as in other vital matters, there occurs just the right combination of will, power and urgency to make real progress. Such a moment has arrived in Albany. The matter at hand is reforming the way Albany does business. All the key players are in alignment. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, still riding his electoral landslide, promises a new day in Albany. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat like Mr. Spitzer, says that his half of the Legislature is ready, again, to vote on many desperately-needed reforms. And Senator Joseph Bruno, the Republican leader of the other half, finds himself in trouble with investigators and thus in dire need of a few positive headlines.

headline: Soups, Stews and Salads
text: Even though this winter has been less than frigid, soup is still a draw at Kozy Kettle in Huntington Village. Shoppers, parents with strollers and local business people line up at the counter at this spare, self-service cafe for fresh salads ($2.35 to $7.49), wraps ($6.99) and a weekly selection of 15 soups.

headline: Unassuming Steakhouse Is the Real Deal
text: KINDERKAMACK ROAD is the spine of north-central Bergen County — an 11-mile strip of commercial and residential miscellany connecting at least half a dozen mini-downtowns like that of Park Ridge, which go by in a blink if you hit the traffic lights correctly. Who would figure that one of those anonymous-looking converted frame houses, wedged between a funeral home and a diner, would hold a terrific New American steakhouse?

headline: Shareholders? What Shareholders?
text: CAREMARK RX is a large pharmaceuticals benefits manager. Generally, this means that it makes money by denying benefits of various kinds, especially prescriptions, to patients and employees, thus supposedly saving money for employers and keeping a big chunk of that money for itself. (I know this is an oversimplification, but it’s basically true.)

headline: Pick One
text: In 1977, whenI was 9, my father and I moved away from the protected Maryland suburbs of Washington — and away from his latest wife, my latest stepmother — to my grandmother’s apartment in inner-city Baltimore. I had never seen so many houses connected to one another, block after block, nor so many people on streets, marble stoops and corners. Many of those people, I could not help noticing, were black. I had never seen so many black people in all my life.

headline: Psycho Analyst
text: If I were a snob, a liar, a drunk, a philanderer, an anti-Semite, a violent bully, a poseur and a menace to the vulnerable, I would want Linda Hopkins to write my biography.

headline: Inside the List
text: QUITE FAR OFF: When Robert Stone’s third novel, “A Flag for Sunrise,” was published in the fall of 1981, he made a $5 bet with his publicist that the book would not make the Times best-seller list. But lo, it came to pass. On Nov. 22, 1981, “A Flag for Sunrise” stood at No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list — the first time one of Stone’s books had appeared here. (It was sandwiched between Martin Cruz Smith’s “Gorky Park” and Paul Erdman’s “Last Days of America.”) Stone never had to cough up the $5, however. In the next issue of the Book Review, the following note ran under the best-seller rankings: “Last week Robert Stone’s ‘A Flag for Sunrise’ was reported in ninth place on the hardcover fiction list. This was the result of a computer error. The actual sales of the novel placed it quite far off the list.” Quite far off the list — did they have to rub it in? “Well,” Stone told me earlier this month, “I got to be on top of the world for a week.” It’s too soon to tell if Stone’s new book, the memoir “Prime Green,” will appear here.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Chairs With Airs: On Arty Streets, a Cluster of Hip Furniture Stores
text: The ABC Carpet and Home store, yards from the Brooklyn waterfront, has been closed for about a year now, but people moving into the new 33-story J Condominiums up Jay Street need not fret about finding that perfect new sofa.

headline: Confronting the Post-Bond Predicament
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Clinton Enters ’08 Field, Fueling Race for Money
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton jumped into the 2008 presidential race yesterday, immediately squaring off against Senator Barack Obama and the rest of the Democratic field in what is effectively the party’s first primary, the competition for campaign donations.

headline: Beatrix Potter’s Life Becomes a Lake District Travelogue
text: Even though it might not be a box-office hit in the United States, Renée Zellweger’s recent film, “Miss Potter,” is giving the Lake District of England, the region where the majority of the movie about the children’s book author Beatrix Potter, right, was filmed, a much-needed boost in tourism.

headline: Coach vs. Coach, Progressive vs. Dictator
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Kristina Daugirdas and Nicholas Bagley
text: Kristina Binderis Daugirdas, a lawyer for the State Department, was married last evening to Nicholas John Bagley, a clerk at the United States Supreme Court. Judge Stephen F. Williams of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, for whom the bride was a law clerk, officiated at the Newberry Library in Chicago.

headline: Riders on the Storm
text: Riders on the Storm

headline: Colombian Government Is Ensnared in a Paramilitary Scandal
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia, Jan. 20  The government of President Álvaro Uribe, the largest recipient of American aid outside the Middle East, has found itself ensnared in a widening scandal as revelations surface of a secret alliance between some of the president’s most prominent political supporters and paramilitary death squads.

headline: What You Can’t Smell Will Kill You
text: London

headline: 36 Hours in Cancún
text: BEYOND the seaside curtain of megahotels, theme restaurants and jam-packed beaches that have made Cancún, Mexico, a spring break mecca, there lies an idyllic, veiled city. It is a Cancún apart, which offers tranquil sunsets and shaded parks for post-college beachgoers who have outgrown cavernous nightclubs and wet T-shirt contests. This is a Cancún, where brass bands parade through the public square, waves crash against vacant shorelines and the friendly women at corner food stands will teach you how to make a perfect quesadilla.

headline: Online Music, Then and Now
text: To the Editor:

headline: You Are What You Expect
text: Are you an optimist or a pessimist? Put so starkly, the question has a fatuous ring. Unless you are in the grip of a bipolar disorder, you are probably optimistic about some things and pessimistic about others. Optimism tends to reign when people are imagining how their own plans will turn out. Research shows that we systematically exaggerate our chances of success, believing ourselves to be more competent and more in control than we actually are. Some 80 percent of drivers, for example, think they are better at the wheel than the typical motorist and thus less likely to have an accident. We live in a Lake Woebegon of the mind, it seems, where all the children are above average. Such “optimism bias,” as psychologists have labeled it, is hardly confined to our personal lives. In fact, as Daniel Kahneman, a Nobel laureate in economics, and Jonathan Renshon argue in the current issue of Foreign Policy, it may help explain why hawkishness so often prevails at the national level. Wasn’t the Iraq war expected by proponents to be “fairly easy” (John McCain) or “a cakewalk” (Kenneth Adelman)?

headline: Hyderabad, India
text: HYDERABAD, one of India's largest cities and the capital of Andhra Pradesh state, has long been appreciated for its Islamic minarets, Hindu temples, British colonial architecture and centuries-old pearl markets. But now, helped by an influx of global software and financial companies like Microsoft and UBS, Hyderabad is a happening city, buzzing with coffee bars, stylish restaurants, bouncer-at-the-door clubs and sophisticated boutiques.

headline: Up Front
text: In his review of Dinesh D’Souza’s “Enemy at Home,” Alan Wolfe makes the assumption that he is one of those D’Souza has in mind when he speaks of “decent liberals.” If not, Wolfe should be, because over the years he has made a name for himself as the man editors turn to when they want a temperate, reasoned discussion of a hot-button issue from a slightly left-of-center perspective. As a result, he appears again and again in publications like The New Republic, Commonweal, The New Yorker and The Wall Street Journal. A list of his books, articles and reviews runs to 25 pages; his byline has appeared 21 times in The Book Review alone.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: Want to mingle with literati on your next vacation? Rosewood Hotels & Resorts might be able to help. Its Hot Type Author Series invites well-known writers to discuss their work with guests at selected resorts. Next in the series is Adam Gopnik, a staff writer at The New Yorker and author of “Through the Children’s Gate: A Home in New York” (2006). Mr. Gopnik is scheduled to visit Caneel Bay, A Rosewood Resort in the United States Virgin Islands, from Friday to Jan. 31. Rates there start at $450 (www.rosewoodhotels.com). ... For those who prefer their intellectual stimulation while on a cruise, Regent Seven Seas Cruises is offering a cruise with PBS personalities and other guests from May 12 to 23. The 11-night Alaskan voyage is scheduled to feature Gwen Ifill, moderator and managing editor of “Washington Week,” on PBS; Scott Simon, the host of “Weekend Edition Saturday,” on National Public Radio; Ric Burns, the documentary filmmaker; Charlie Cook, editor and publisher of The Cook Political Report; Scott Ellis, a theater director; and David Lee, a television writer, director and producer. Rates start at $3,998; (www.ptvatsea.com). ... Last month, the Peninsula Hong Kong hotel introduced a fleet of 14 custom-designed Rolls-Royce Phantoms, below, as one of its services. Guests can make reservations to take one to and from the airport for about 850 Hong Kong dollars, $109, at $7.95 Hong Kong dollars to the United States dollar, one-way or 1,500 Hong Kong dollars round-trip. Guests can also rent them for about 1,100 Hong Kong dollars an hour. There is a two-hour minimum (www.hongkong.peninsula.com). ...Travelers who want to shop for designer luggage at competitive prices can visit www.luggagepoint.com, a new Web site that also provides baggage requirements for airlines. ... Ruaha National Park in Tanzania is preparing to become the largest national park in Africa as it absorbs the almost 5,800 square miles of the Usangu Game Reserve (www.tanzaniaparks.com).

headline: The Mysteries of Kabul
text: AN icy wind blasted in our faces as we trudged up a rocky slope on the southern outskirts of Kabul, the war-shattered capital of Afghanistan. Around us rose a moonscape of treeless, dun-colored hills, broken by clusters of mud-walled squatter huts. I squinted into the sunlight, looking east toward the earthen citadel of Bala Hissar, a stronghold from the time of the Silk Road to the post-Soviet wars. High above us, another wall of mud brick and stone — a fragment of the ancient rampart of Kabul, constructed before the arrival of Islam in a futile attempt to defend the city against invaders from Arabia and Central Asia — snaked along the ridgeline.

headline: A Hudson Valley Artist Rediscovers a Forgotten Past

It begins with a map of Peekskill in 1800, listing the names of families that lived there. This establishes a broader context for the show, which traces several generations of African-Americans who have lived in the Hudson Valley for the past 230 years.

headline: The News From Little Rock
text: Historians of the civil rights era have long recognized the impact of the press on the character and pace of the movement. From William Bradford Huie’s graphic 1955 interview with the unrepentant killers of Emmett Till to the televised images of Bull Connor’s attack dogs snapping at young demonstrators in the streets of Birmingham to the eyewitness accounts of the beatings of voting rights marchers in Selma, Ala., the power of the pen and the camera has been memorable. Until now, however, no one has offered an in-depth analysis of how and why the news media came to play such an important role in the struggle for racial justice.

headline: Beauty and the Blizzard

headline: Yo Quiero Marry Carla

I assumed that it was a tradition in his native Uruguay. In retrospect, I might have been confusing “Uruguay” with “medieval Europe.”

headline: A True Friend and a Good Writer
text: “I’m the father of two robins,” E. B. White writes to his stepson in 1964 from his farm in Maine. The baby birds had been orphaned, “and without really thinking about what I was doing I casually dropped a couple of marinated worms into their throats as I walked by. ... This did it. They took me on with open hearts and open mouths, and my schedule became extremely tight.” He has fed these robins a formula of “hamburg, chicken mash, kibbled worm and orange juice” for several days from a “yellow bamboo stick, split at one end, like a robin’s bill.” And now the birds “come streaming at me from bush and tree, trying for a landing on shoulder or cap, usually overshooting me in the fog and bringing up against a wall. This exhausts them and me.” Next, says White, he will have to “hop about on the lawn with my head cocked to one side, to show them how to get their own living.”

headline: Hope You Saved Your Glow Stick
text: LONDON

headline: Miler Is 6 Years Older and 3 Seconds Better
text: Six years ago, in the New Balance Games at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan, Alan Webb ran 3 minutes 59.86 seconds in the invitation mile. It was the first time a high school miler had broken four minutes, and, as Webb recalled, it was exciting.

headline: Bears 39, Saints 14, Final
text: Review the play-by-play commentary of Saints-Bears as it was typed in LIVE:Postgame: It wasn’t an artistic success, but the Bears are going to the Super Bowl.The Bears forced four turnovers and their offense was opportunistic enough in a 39-14 victory over the Saints. The oft-criticized Rex Grossman was good enough when it counted and Thomas Jones was impressive when he was in there. Aside from a big drive at the end of the first half, the Saints always looked a little defensive on offense. The lack of a rushing game hurt the Saints. Reggie Bush had four attemps for 19 yards. Deuce McAllister had six carries for 18 yards. Even though Drew Brees passed for 354 yards, he was never able to get comfortable in the pocket.The numbers were not impressive for Grossman. He was 11 for 26 for 144 yards and a touchdown, but he is now a Super Bowl quarterback.

headline: The Week Ahead: Jan. 21 - 27
text: THEATER

headline: Dropping the Curtain on ‘Vagina Monologues’
text: St. John's University, one of the country's largest Roman Catholic universities, has decided not to allow Eve Ensler's "Vagina Monologues" to be performed on campus.

headline: The Public Theater Collaborates With Stanford
text: Stanford University and the Public Theater in New York have announced a long-term partnership that includes an annual residency program at Stanford for playwrights developing work for the Public, joint commissions for one playwright a year, and three annual fellowships for Stanford undergraduates and graduates with the artistic staff of the Public.

headline: Correction: The Reel and the Real
text: An article last Sunday about a surge in attendance at the American Museum of Natural History since the release of the film “Night at the Museum” referred incorrectly to an artifact at the museum. The museum has a cast of bones from the Peking man fossils — not an actual skull of a Peking man. Most of the Peking man fossils were lost during World War II.

headline: Correction: Pastries, and Particle Physics
text: An article last Sunday about a monthly series of talks by Columbia University science professors at an Upper West Side restaurant incorrectly described two eighth graders in the audience. They were Sarah Friedhoff, a 13-year-old girl, and Miguel Alonso-Lubell, a 13-year-old boy — not two boys.

headline: Bruce McLaren Film Gathering
text: With the announcement at the A1 Grand Prix in Taupo, New Zealand of the plans to make a film about Bruce McLaren, the founder of the Formula One team of same name, there was a meeting of several important drivers and other people associated with or related to Bruce McLaren.

headline: N.F.C. Championship
text: Led by their defense and the clutch play of quarterback Rex Grossman, the Bears defeated the Saints to advance to their first Super Bowl since 1985.

headline: The Word on the Snowy Street
text: If you want to read somebody who is actually seeing a lot of films at Sundance, you might want to look in on Anthony Breznican, USA Today’s designated cool hunter here. And if you are looking for opinions, some based in reality, you might check out Dave Poland.

headline: Warmth After a Little Help
The Other Half
text: By some mistake of bureaucracy or taste, the Bagger was invited to a small, swanky dinner put on by Netflix and the Creative Coalition, the nonprofit organization where Hollywood parks and occasionally uses it conscience. The Bagger would tell you who was there, but then he would have to Taser you. Kidding. It was a mix of political types like Eric Alterman of the Nation and Lawrence O’Donnell, who these days blogs on “The Huffington Post,” along with studio and movie people, like Daniel Battsek of Miramax, Hal Sadoff of ICM and Robert Rosen, dean of the theater, film and tv school at U.C.L.A. Kyra Sedgwick and Kevin Bacon were also in attendance.

headline: ‘The Best Seat in the House’
text: Please don't get me wrong. Living with paralysis is not like the disease-of-the-week TV-movie in which the Robert Urich character, having wrestled his demons to the ground for two commercial-filled hours, bravely gets off the floor and Frankenstein-walks across the room while his wife weeps and prays in the corner. I wish it had worked out that way, but it didn't. Paralysis is an often painful and confusing process that takes way more than two hours to get a handle on, and unlike a TV potboiler, the outcome is always in doubt. Just when you think it's time to bring up the music and roll the credits after a small victory-boom!-something untoward happens and you're reeling again. Sometimes you're lost, sometimes you're not, but you're never quite out of the woods.

headline: ‘False Self: The Life of Masud Khan’
text: Masud Khan's childhood home was in Montgomery (now Sahiwal), an area in the northwest part of the United Provinces of India known as the Punjab. The land had been conquered by the British in the latter half of the nineteenth century after a savage conflict in which Khan's father and uncles were allied with the British. After the conquest, his family continued to maintain close military ties: of his eight half-brothers, seven would have celebrated careers in the Indian and then the Pakistani army. In the West, Khan claimed, probably accurately, that his was the first generation in which there had not been a murder. He told a friend: "In my country, life is very cheap. I could have men disposed of for a mere five hundred rupees-that is how we might deal with difficult situations. My people do not feel Judeo-Christian guilt: my people feel vengeance."

headline: ‘The Castle in the Forest’
‘They Call Me Naughty Lola’
text: This ad may not be the best lonely heart in the world, nor its author the best-smelling. That's all I have to say. Man, 37. Box no. 7654.

headline: ‘The Enemy at Home’
text: THE REASON AMERICA'S "war on terrorism" is imperiled is that there is no clear sense of who the enemy is. Is Al Qaeda the problem? A network of terrorist groups operating through the Al Qaeda "franchise"? State-sponsored terrorism? Weapons of mass destruction in the hands of hostile states? Or is Islamic fundamentalism to blame, since it appears to be the incubator of terrorism? Or is the West facing a very old enemy, Islam itself?

headline: ‘Letters of E. B. White’
text: (Elwyn Brooks White was born in Mount Vernon, New York, on July 11, 1899, the youngest of the six children of Samuel and Jessie Hart White. Mount Vernon was a quiet, leafy suburb in the early years of the new century, and Elwyn, sometimes called "En," grew up in a child's paradise of backyards and skating ponds, bicycles and pets. He attended public schools, where he got good grades, and he did some writing for the Oracle, the high school paper. White himself can best supply the details and introduce the characters, and the following introduction is, therefore, in his own words.-Ed.)

headline: ‘The Race Beat’
text: The winter of 1940 was a cruel one for Gunnar Myrdal, and spring was shaping up even worse. He was in the United States, finishing the research on the most comprehensive study yet of race relations and the condition of Negroes in America. But he was having trouble reaching conclusions, and he struggled to outline and conceptualize the writing. "The whole plan is now in danger of breaking down," he wrote the Carnegie Foundation, which was underwriting his project.

headline: Everything is New Again
text: In a race that has more left turns than the Indy 500, the Producer’s Guild shuffled the Oscar cards again (I’m trying to come up with a third metaphor to mix into this sentence) by choosing “Little Miss Sunshine” as their movie of the year. This final scrambling of the Oscar race should make the homestretch run a happy car wreck.

headline: You Mean They Have Movies Here Too?
text: As the Bagger has mentioned in previous Sundance posts, amid all his blogging, reporting, video-making and party-going, something often seems to be missing here: Moviegoing. And then, once more, he was standing in a queue and heard someone talking about how fabulous “Delirious” was and someone else talking about John Cusack’s amazing performance in “Grace is Gone.” Oh yeah, movies.

headline: A Primer on Raising Movie Money
text: Tamara Jenkins, the director of “Slums of Beverly Hills” and now, “The Savages,” which continues to kick up nice comments all over Park City, on getting Fox Searchlight to buy the film before it was shot – in effect financing the movie:

headline: Why We Travel
text: “Each step was difficult; I felt powerless; I had a headache. But when I reached the top, the sickness and the pain were gone, and I was just happy my whole family had made it.”

headline: 36 Hours in Cancún
text: In this Cancún, you'll find vacant shorelines, friendly women at food stands and tranquil vistas instead of wet T-shirt contests.

headline: 2008: Senator Clinton Casts a Long Shadow
text: You would’ve thought Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was in the room on some of the news shows today, given how much her presidential exploratory announcement on Saturday dominated and infused interviews with other potential 2008 contenders. What a difference a few days makes, as she pretty much shoved aside Senator Barack Obama’s exploratory announcement last Tuesday.

headline: Correction: Online: Bed Bouncers and Pool Leapers
text: A brief report in the In Transit column on Jan. 7 about HotelsByCity.net carried incorrect information from a blogger on the site who posted a photograph of the singer Lindsay Lohan. She was standing beside a pool with Harry Morton, the Hard Rock heir, at an unidentified hotel in Maui — not at a Hard Rock Hotel. (Hard Rock Cafe International has no hotels in Maui.)

headline: Fish, Into Quarterfinals, Will Face Ex-Housemate Roddick
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 21 — The first man into the quarterfinals of this year's Australian Open on Sunday was the unseeded Mardy Fish, which was quite an achievement considering the former state of his forehand and of his left wrist.

headline: FINAL: Patriots 34 at Colts 38
text: Review the play-by-play commentary of the AFC championship game between New England and Indianapolis, LIVE, as it happened at the RCA Dome.

headline: YouTube's Growing Influence
text: M dot Strange's first feature, "We Are The Strange," came to Sundance with a  huge YouTube audience. The Carpetbagger sits down with him.

headline: All the Presidents’ Libraries
text: When I arrived at Duke to take up a faculty position in the fall of 1985, I found a campus still polarized to some extent by the 1981 controversy over whether the university should be the site of the Richard Nixon library and museum. Nixon was a 1937 graduate of the law school at Duke, in Durham, N.C., and the offer of his papers was received positively by then president (and lifelong Democrat) Terry Sanford. But a significant number of faculty members opposed the plan, and the heated discussions that followed established a pattern of argument that would reappear whenever a university was proposed as the location of a presidential library.

headline: Taking the Middle Schoolers Out of the Middle
text: A slump in learning among early adolescents has prompted a movement to get rid of middle schools entirely, Elissa Gootman writes.

headline: Can the Bears Make It a Game?
text: O.K., time to look ahead. Can the Chicago Bears make it a competitive Super Bowl?

headline: To Critics, It’s Just Pork; Others See Democracy
text: ALBANY, Jan. 21 — To some people, member items — the grants that lawmakers award, with little debate and much secrecy, to community groups and pet projects back in their home districts — symbolize the worst of New York’s political culture. Member items have gone to fix the roof of a hunting club near Albany, help finance a pro-wrestling hall of fame in Schenectady and, most infamously, open a cheese museum in the city of Rome.

headline: An Insurance Policy for Low Airfares
text: FARECAST, the Internet start-up that made waves last year by predicting ticket prices for air travelers, is putting its money where its mouth is.

headline: Unabomber Wages Legal Battle to Halt the Sale of Papers
text: Nine years after he began serving a life sentence for the Unabomber crimes, Theodore J. Kaczynski is fighting to reclaim more than 40,000 pages of his writings and correspondence so he can preserve them in their rawest form for the public to read.

headline: Fair Housing, Free Speech and Choosy Roommates
text: Gene Kavenoki wanted to rent out a spare bedroom in his West Hollywood apartment and he had a few requirements.

headline: M dot Strange Finds a Way at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — In the daunting hierarchy of the Sundance Film Festival, with its hype machine, big stars and indie royalty, a young movie maker named M dot Strange would seem to have little chance of gaining much attention.

headline: Turkish Gunman Said to Confess to Killing Armenian Editor
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 21 — A teenage Turkish gunman arrested in connection with the killing of an ethnic Armenian journalist has given prosecutors an extensive confession, Turkish news agencies reported Sunday. They said he explained how he plotted the killing and how he stalked the victim and shot him directly from behind three times in the neck and head on a crowded Istanbul street.

headline: In Austin, Echoes of a Distant War in an Opera’s American Premiere
text: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 20 — The state capital of Texas takes great pride in a live music scene that cherishes tradition while also valuing innovation. The city is a hotbed of both roots music and experimental rock; classical music, by comparison, claims a considerably smaller share of attention. Austin Lyric Opera has long been overshadowed by older, larger, better-financed companies in Dallas and Houston.

headline: Your MasterCard or Your Life
text: Americans are increasingly living in a house of cards  credit cards.

headline: U.S. Envoy Upbeat About New Korea Talks
text: BEIJING, Monday, Jan. 22 — The chief American envoy to talks on North Korea’s nuclear weapons program said Monday morning that he hoped a new round of six-nation negotiations would get under way shortly, and he expressed cautious optimism about prospects for reaching a settlement.

headline: Before the Flood
text: San Francisco

headline: Tribune Co. May Reject Outside Bids
text: The Tribune Company, which had put itself on the market, indicated over the weekend that it might reshape its future without outside help.

headline: Pfizer to Lay Off 10,000 Workers
text: The drug giant Pfizer said today that it would lay off 10,000 workers and close several manufacturing and research sites in an effort to bolster earnings hurt by the loss of patent protection on certain drugs and setbacks in developing new products.

headline: Agency That Harbored ‘Saatchi 17’ to Close
Taking Middle Schoolers Out of the Middle
text: When John Smith, a swaggering sixth grader at one of New York City’s growing collection of kindergarten- through eighth-grade schools, feels lost, he heads downstairs to the colorful classroom of his former third-grade teacher, Randi Silverman, for what she calls a “Silverman hug.”

headline: A Friendship Muddled by Attraction
text: “A Beautiful View,” a play by the talented writer and director Daniel MacIvor that is part of the Public Theater’s Under the Radar festival, is a remarkable achievement in incongruity. Purely experimental in form, it is romantic in substance and cozy in impact, without gloom or hard angles.

headline: Showdown Looms in Congress Over Drug Advertising on TV
text: Drug advertising aimed at consumers, a fast-growing category that reached $4.5 billion last year, will face hard scrutiny in the new Congress, according to industry critics in both the House and Senate.

headline: Curry’s Biggest Test Must Wait Until Heat’s O’Neal Is Healthy
text: MIAMI, Jan. 21 — Eddy Curry now knows he can score 20 points nearly at will, that he can carry the Knicks for weeks at a time, that he can dictate an opponent’s game plan. But the learning curve for a newly dominant young big man is long and jagged. And his evolution cannot be complete until he has faced the ultimate big-man test.

headline: North Caldwell, N.J.: Man Is Charged With Arson and Sexual Assault
text: A New York City man was arrested yesterday and charged with setting his estranged wife’s house on fire and trying to sexually assault and kill her, the authorities said. The man, Jesus M. Reza, 36, was charged with attempted murder, sexual assault, arson and burglary, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor.

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Vision of Rebuilding Lebanon Wanes
text: BINT JBAIL, Lebanon, Jan. 16 — In August, Mohammed al-Seyed watched with some pride as tractors driven by Hezbollah men rolled in to begin scooping away the rubble and debris of a month of war with Israel, while engineers and others set to work.

headline: Tighter Passport Rules for U.S. Citizens Start Tuesday
text: A United States citizen flying home today from a ski jaunt in Canada, a beach break in Mexico or a honeymoon in Jamaica can flash a driver’s license or a birth certificate at airport customs officials and walk on through.

headline: Amid Accounting Inquiry, a Greenwich Pastor Resigns
text: The pastor at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich, Conn., resigned after an investigation found that he had maintained secret bank accounts with church funds and could not document how he spent more than $500,000 from those accounts, church officials said yesterday.

headline: Floyd Is Close to Signing With the Cubs
text: The free-agent outfielder Cliff Floyd is close to signing a one-year contract with the Chicago Cubs, a person with direct knowledge of the contract confirmed yesterday.

headline: Learning From Lauren: Smells Like Teen Spirit, Looks Like Hard Work
text: For three years MTV has tried to get viewers to fall in love with Lauren Conrad, the star of the docusoaps “Laguna Beach” and “The Hills.” Wary, watchful, cheerless Lauren with the many-layered cosmetics: audience adoration has always seemed unlikely.

headline: Hawkish Gates Sees More Force as Leverage
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  Less than a month after Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates took office, his imprint on American military strategy is beginning to show.

headline: Anatomy of an Insult: ABC Is Stung by an Actor’s Anti-Gay Slurs
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 — Executives at ABC and its parent, Disney, are mulling the future of the actor Isaiah Washington, a star of the hit series “Grey’s Anatomy,” after Mr. Washington last week publicly used an anti-gay slur for the second time in roughly three months, a Disney executive said Friday.

headline: In Live Bacteria, Food Makers See a Bonanza
text: The fastest way to consumers’ hearts may be through their troubled stomachs.

headline: A Boss Takes to His Blog to Deny, Then Confirm
text: Blogging by a chief executive can be tricky business.

headline: A Red Cat’s Journey, Enhanced by iTunes
text: Over the course of his career that has spanned four decades, the guitarist and producer Ry Cooder has recorded with groups from the Rolling Stones to the Buena Vista Social Club. But he hasn’t been prolific as a solo artist recently, mostly because he has had trouble capturing the sound he wanted on a compact disc. On his new album, he achieved that sound with a little help from an unlikely source: Apple’s iTunes program.

headline: Totals
China to Revamp 4th Bank in Preparation for Offering
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 21 — China said over the weekend that the last of four big state-owned banks would be financially restructured to prepare it for a public stock listing.

headline: Rush of Entries Gives ’08 Race Early Intensity
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — Two years before the next president is inaugurated and a full year before the first vote is cast, the contest for the White House is off to a breathtakingly fast start, exposing an ever-growing field of candidates to longer, more intensive scrutiny and increasing the amount of money they need to remain viable.

headline: After Years of Instability, an Illness Is in Check and a Mother Reconnects With a Son
text: Margaret Silvestri stopped getting out of bed altogether when her son was about 11 years old. She had been experiencing symptoms of depression for years, but this was a breakdown. Her son, Mark Silvestri, called relatives for help.

headline: Congress’s Challenge on Iraq
text: President Bush’s refusal to come up with a serious policy on Iraq means that the Democrats will have to goad him toward one. Congress needs to do more than just oppose the latest ill-conceived military escalation. It needs to insist that American troops are not captive to the destructive policies of an Iraqi government for which sectarian revenge counts for more than national unity and civil peace.

headline: Damaged Ship Off Britain Spills Fuel and Cargo
text: ROME, Jan. 21 — A damaged and listing cargo ship was spilling fuel and cargo containers into stormy seas off the southwest coast of England, near Devon, British officials said Sunday night. Some of the containers held hazardous materials.

headline: Gold-Plated Indifference
text: President Bush’s Saturday radio address was devoted to health care, and officials have put out the word that the subject will be a major theme in tomorrow’s State of the Union address. Mr. Bush’s proposal won’t go anywhere. But it’s still worth looking at his remarks, because of what they say about him and his advisers.

headline: Princeton to Hold the Line on Tuition Next Year, but Other Costs Will Rise
text: For the first time in 40 years, Princeton University will not raise tuition for the next academic year, the university announced yesterday. Tuition will remain $33,000, but room and board costs will jump.

headline: In One Play, Bush Shows Talent and Inexperience
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 21 — The New Orleans Saints rookie Reggie Bush received the pass from quarterback Drew Brees and kept running. He froze Chicago Bears safety Chris Harris along the sideline, then cut toward the middle of the field, shifted into high gear and peeled away from his pursuers.

headline: Poland Makes Witch Hunting Easier

headline: James Hillier, 91, Dies; Co-Developed Electron Microscope
text: James Hillier, a physicist and inventor who helped develop an early and commercially successful electron microscope for RCA and then found ways to apply it for medical research, died last Monday in Princeton, N.J. He was 91.

headline: ‘Idol’ Judge Says She’s Healthy and Sober
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 — Paula Abdul, the “American Idol” judge whose strange behavior in recent televised interviews has been the subject of widespread speculation, said Saturday that she was healthy and sober and had not been under the influence of drugs while working to promote the show.

headline: After All That Goodness, a Sudden Fall From Grace
text: Before she set a toe on the red carpet at the Golden Globes last week, Angelina Jolie’s carefully molded image as humanitarian and mom was already showing some cracks. The Internet had been flooded with reports, picked up from European interviews, that she had called her biological daughter “a blob” with less personality than her two adopted kids, and had criticized Madonna’s adoption of a baby boy from Malawi. Women’s Wear Daily reported she was being difficult about designs from St. John, the staid company whose ads she appears in and whose conservatively elegant gown she wore to the Globes.

text: More than four times as many households downloaded videos from file-sharing networks as they did from centralized services like iTunes in the third quarter of 2006.

headline: U.S. Toll in Iraq Is 27 for Deadly Weekend
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 21 — The United States military said that two marines died Sunday in western Iraq and that an additional seven service members died Saturday. The deaths brought the weekend toll to 27 and made Saturday the third-deadliest day for United States forces since the war here began.

headline: Case of the Paralegal Who Played a Lawyer Raises Many Questions
If Clinton Should Win, Who Would Take Her Place?
text: The choice — if it had to be made — would be two years away, but Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s decision to run for the White House in 2008 has already touched off some early speculation about who would succeed her in the Senate if she wins.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: DAVOS, ANYONE? The annual World Economic Forum will take place Wednesday through Sunday in Davos, Switzerland, drawing political and business leaders — plus a celebrity or two — to brainstorm solutions to world problems. Among the top issues on the agenda are climate change and the role of emerging markets. Klaus Schwab, right, the founder and executive chairman of the forum, said he hoped that this year’s conference would address a “schizophrenic world” in which there are both broad prosperity and tremendous risks from many directions.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,014 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

headline: In Another Plot Twist, Williams Is a Contender
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Jan. 22 — Few would have imagined, perhaps not even Serena Williams, that when the second week of the Australian Open began, she would still be in contention for the title and the defending champion, Amélie Mauresmo, would not.

headline: Antonina Tumkovsky, 101, Dies; Teacher Who Trained Future City Ballet Stars
text: Antonina Tumkovsky, an influential teacher at the School of American Ballet who trained future stars of the New York City Ballet and other dancers for 54 years, died on Friday at the Tolstoy Foundation Nursing Home in Valley Cottage, N.Y., where she lived. She was 101.

headline: A Single Securities Regulator Is Approved
text: The NYSE Group and NASD have won approval from brokerage firms to form a single regulator for the United States securities industry, overcoming opposition from a group of small firms.

headline: Big Labels Offer Free Music to College Students
text: In one more attempt to counter music piracy, major music labels have agreed to support a service that will offer free music downloads — with some substantial restrictions — to any college student.

headline: British Scavenge From Stricken Vessel
text: LONDON, Jan. 22 — Ignoring health warnings and threats of prosecution, hundreds of people foraged among containers washed from a stricken cargo vessel on the southern English coast on Monday, hauling off booty that included BMW motorcycles, shoes, diapers, beauty cream and carpets.

headline: Faith in Quick Test Leads to Epidemic That Wasn’t
text: Dr. Brooke Herndon, an internist at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, could not stop coughing. For two weeks starting in mid-April last year, she coughed, seemingly nonstop, followed by another week when she coughed sporadically, annoying, she said, everyone who worked with her.

headline: Nets Will Lose Jefferson for 6 Weeks
text: The Nets will be without Richard Jefferson, their starting small forward, for about six weeks after he has arthroscopic surgery today to remove loose fragments from his right ankle.

headline: Marquette Hands Pitt a Rare Loss at Home
text: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 — Marquette point guard Dominic James wore dark blue knee-highs Sunday afternoon to warm his legs, not because he was trying to make a fashion statement. But his team’s play definitely made an impression.

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce Workers’ Networking Software
text: And you thought social networking was all about text-messaging among bored teenagers.

headline: Coaches Bet in Big Spots, and Players Make Them Look Wise
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 21 — For a trip to the Super Bowl, Bill Belichick and Tony Dungy were willing to take chances.

headline: Election Ad Aggravates a Racial Divide in Atlanta
text: ATLANTA, Jan. 21 — The nastiness of the 2006 campaign season has largely died away, forgotten amid the swearing-in ceremonies and gavel transfers of a new political landscape. But in this normally resilient city, one 30-second radio advertisement for a relatively obscure county race has lingered uncomfortably in people’s minds.

headline: Three More Senators Say They Oppose More Troops in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Three senators offered a new resolution today against President Bush’s Iraq policy, in which they declared their opposition to Mr. Bush’s plans to increase the American troop force there by 21,500.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Alumni to Lead a CNBC Monthly Magazine
text: As cable news becomes increasingly combative and opinionated, the financial news network CNBC is pushing in the other direction, introducing an hourlong monthly newsmagazine, “Business Nation.”

headline: Antagonists Last Summer, Spitzer and Suozzi Learn to Be Friends for the Party
text: It was like Muhammad Ali making nice with George Foreman. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi, who threw jabs at each other during last year’s Democratic primary for governor, were all smiles last week when they both attended a $25,000-a-couple private fund-raiser for the state Democratic Party.

headline: North Bellmore, N.Y.: Two Killed in Accident
text: Two people were killed and a third was critically injured when their Honda Accord careered off the Southern State Parkway near Newbridge Road in Nassau County just before 2:30 a.m. yesterday, according to the New York State Police. The driver, Juan Benitez, 22, of Brentwood, and a 16-year-old female front-seat passenger, whose identity was not disclosed, were pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. A 17-year-old male passenger, whose identity was also not disclosed, was ejected from the back seat and sustained a head injury. He was in critical condition late yesterday at Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, the police said. The cause of the accident remained under investigation yesterday, the police said.

headline: Democratic Governor of New Mexico Joins Race
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico said on Sunday that he intended to run for the Democratic nomination for president, joining a growing field that includes Senators Hillary Clinton of New York (since Saturday) and Barack Obama of Illinois (since Tuesday).

headline: Clock Ticking, Speechwriters for Bush Seek Perfect Pitch
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — Most Americans think of President Bush as the commander in chief. His speechwriters have another name for him: the editor in chief.

headline: Aging at Home (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shirley, N.Y.: Woman Dies in House Fire
text: A woman died yesterday morning in a house fire, the Suffolk County police said. The woman, Delores Hutt, 57, was trapped in an upstairs bathroom during the fire at a house on Saint George Drive West, in Shirley, Long Island, the police said. According to the police, Ms. Hutt’s sister, Dorothy Landau, was making tea about 4:30 a.m. when she saw flames coming from a blanket on the couch. An investigation continued yesterday, but the police said the fire did not appear to be suspicious.

headline: Leader of Somali Islamists Surrenders
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 22 – The second highest member of Somalia’s defeated Islamist forces, a man described as a moderate Muslim and potential peacemaker, surrendered to Kenyan authorities and is staying at a hotel in Nairobi, Western diplomats and Somali officials said today.

headline: Princeton Won’t Raise Tuition in Coming Year
text: For the first time in 40 years, Princeton University will not raise tuition for the coming year, the university announced yesterday. Tuition for the 2007-2008 academic year will remain at $33,000, its current level.

headline: Libby Trial to Display Changed Reporter-Source Relations
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — As the perjury and obstruction of justice trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. unfolds over the next few weeks, the ways in which the case has vastly reshaped relations between reporters and high government officials will be on vivid display.

headline: Newark: Airport Security Official Resigns
text: Gerard Grandinetti, the federal official in charge of overseeing and hiring 1,100 airport screeners at Newark Liberty International Airport, has resigned. Ann Davis, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Security Administration, confirmed yesterday that Mr. Grandinetti resigned on Friday, citing personal reasons. Last week The Newark Star-Ledger reported allegations that some job candidates for senior management posts had received questions in advance that were on a test for prospective employees. After the allegations, officials canceled the test and started an internal investigation. Mr. Grandinetti could not be reached for comment.

headline: How Daisy Mae’s Charm Finds a Home at the Met
text: Kristin Chenoweth made a zany entrance onto the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday evening, outfitted in a New York Mets baseball shirt and cap, waving a banner and pretending to be a ditsy sports fan arriving late for a game.

headline: Ogunleye Keeps Heat on the Saints
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 21 — As Chicago Bears defensive end Adewale Ogunleye walked out of Soldier Field on Sunday and into the snowy, cold night, he said in his baritone: “Suntan lotion. Get your suntan lotion.”

headline: Hedge Funds and Insider Trading
text: A truism of investing is that to beat the market consistently, an investor must either take above-average risk or trade on inside information. That inevitably casts a cloud over hedge funds, which exist to beat the market. Many fail, sometimes spectacularly so. But many succeed. The question is, How?

headline: Changes in Mellencamp Country
text: “People say I sold out,” John Mellencamp said, explaining his decision to license a song for a Chevrolet commercial. “No, I got sold out. Sometime during the ’90s record companies made the decision that us guys who had been around for a long time and had sold millions of records and were household names just weren’t as interesting as girls in stretch dresses.”

headline: For Sale: Hussein’s Riviera Villa
text: GRASSE, France — Tucked in the hills outside this small southern French town, high among the terraced olive groves, sits a peaceful stone Mediterranean villa once acquired for the family of Saddam Hussein.

headline: Boot Camps Gaining Popularity With Korean Parents, Not Kids
text: POHANG, South Korea — Spitting plumes of white smoke, a wave of South Korean amphibious assault vehicles lands on the freezing cold beach.

headline: Grossman Puts Struggles Behind Him and Repays Coach’s Faith
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 21 — With fog and doubt shrouding Soldier Field on Sunday, Bears Coach Lovie Smith kept unbending faith in his quarterback. A lead had shrunk. The Bears and quarterback Rex Grossman, backs to the end zone, faced another in a season’s worth of uh-oh moments.

headline: Injured Officer Leaves Hospital
text: Three suspects accused of attacking an off-duty police officer, gravely injuring him, were ordered held without bail yesterday.

headline: An Internet Video Partnership From 2 Lions of Old Media (Eisner and Jann Wenner)
text: Michael D. Eisner and Jann Wenner, who once successfully joined in saving a celebrity magazine, are about to reunite in the world of Internet video.

headline: In Raw World of Sex Movies, High Definition Could Be a View Too Real
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 — The XXX industry has gotten too graphic, even for its own tastes.

headline: Olympics Are Still a Dream for Some Female Athletes
text: Starting with the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, British Columbia, both men and women will win medals in ski cross, a somewhat gladiatorial freestyle event that was conceived in the 1990s.

headline: Industrial Bank of China Plans Sizable Share Sale in Shanghai
text: Industrial Bank of China, partly owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, may raise up to 21.25 billion yuan ($2.74 billion) from a Shanghai share sale, making it the second-largest domestic initial public offering by a mainland Chinese bank.

headline: Iran’s Leader Stands by Nuclear Plans; Military to Hold Exercises
text: TEHRAN, Jan. 21 — Iran’s internal battle over President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s defiant rhetoric on Iran’s nuclear program continued to simmer on Sunday, with the president repeating his vow to ignore international sanctions and a moderate daily newspaper warning of Iran’s increasing isolation.

headline: As His Character Pursues Fugitives, an Actor Breaks Out Too
text: “Prison Break” prides itself on over-the-top plot twists and belief-beggaring coincidences.

headline: Fame Waits at the Wire
text: The bugler sounded his call. A bone-numbing chill rushed through the paddock, tearing into the jockey’s silks and biting at his skin.

headline: Newark: Man Dies From Burns
text: A man who the police say was set on fire after an argument on Jan. 12 died on Saturday, the authorities said. The man, Richard Burns, 54, was hospitalized at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston after suffering burns to more than 22 percent of his body, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor. Mr. Burns’ nephew, Lamar A. Tidwell, 24, was charged with setting the fire, and Mr. Loriquet said a charge of murder would probably be filed against him today.

headline: In Another Plot Twist, Williams Is a Contender
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Jan. 22 — Few would have imagined, perhaps not even Serena Williams, that when the second week of the Australian Open began, she would still be in contention for the title and the defending champion Amélie Mauresmo would not.

headline: Toy-Size Sculptures That Play With Adult-Size Emotions
text: In classic examples of William King’s sculptures, the figures have arms like I-beams, legs like stilts and heads that are barely there. Sometimes they stride or sit with a kind of stiff American nonchalance, like Giacomettis conceived by John Cheever. Just as often they gesticulate emphatically. They’re frustrated, furious, ecstatic, having some kind of fit. Children probably think these figures in particular, with their long, goofy clodhopper shoes, are fun. Adults may be less easily charmed, sensing what it’s like, emotionally, to be in those shoes.

headline: Mary Stolz, Who Wrote Novels for the Young, Is Dead at 86
text: Mary Stolz, a noted author for children and adolescents whose novels earned critical praise for the seriousness with which they took the problems of young people, died on Dec. 15 at her home in Longboat Key, Fla. She was 86.

headline: Illinois Seeks to Privatize Its State Lottery
text: The State of Illinois is seeking to privatize its state lottery system, hoping to attract as much as $10 billion from private investors interested in an operation with 800 retail outlets and 2005 revenue of about $650 million.

headline: The Clinic Is Open
text: Companies are proving that when it comes to health care, you can re-teach old dogs an old trick. On-site health clinics in the workplace, which had been disappearing since their peak in the 1970s, are staging a comeback. Corporations are waking up to the fact that healthy employees are more productive, while sick workers are a drag on the bottom line. And they’re trying to do something about it.

headline: Nuances Illuminate Tales From Stringed Storytellers
text: Music is a kind of narrative. Some performers take it on like a good story, moving through its plot points. The Takacs Quartet, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, took on narrative in a poetic sense, expanding the action to pick up the nuances and subplots. The effect was music expressed not in clear black-and-white lines but in washes of sound color accruing to — and enhancing — the outlines of the work.

headline: BA Cabin Crews Plan Brief Strike
text: British Airways cabin crews plan a three-day strike starting Jan. 29, after the Transport and General Workers’ Union failed to reach an agreement over sick leave, pay and staffing.

headline: Categorized, Compared and Displayed: Social Ills as Museum Specimens
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 — If I ever need to be committed, I could do worse than end up someplace like the Medfield Insane Asylum of a century ago. There — judging from the photos of that Massachusetts institution now displayed at Harvard University’s Arthur M. Sackler Museum — I would have a good chance of sleeping on starched linen, walking on spotless floors and rarely bumping into fellow inmates. The elite private rooms of the McLean Hospital are still more appealing, offering in 1903 the coziness of Victorian living rooms. And even insanity might not be too high a price to pay for the draperies, lace and furnishings promised by a photograph of the Lunatic Asylum for Men in Ghent, Belgium.

headline: In Chicago, an Inhospitable Blend of Snow and History
text: Chicago

headline: Cracking Down on Mixtape CDs
text: Not long before Christmas, Jeff Baker, the chief of police of Morrow, Ga., a small town just south of Atlanta, and one of his officers were walking through a local shopping mall when they happened to pass a kiosk hawking rap music CDs. One in particular caught their attention.

headline: After Struggle, Patterson Finds Touch for Storm
text: The clock was winding down, and the game was on track to be a case of more of the same for St. John’s and the junior guard Avery Patterson. The Red Storm, which led by 8 points midway through the second half yesterday, had frittered away its lead, and Patterson was struggling. A fifth consecutive loss seemed to be a foregone conclusion.

headline: Trends on Social Issues (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gap’s Chief Executive Resigns
text: The axe finally fell on Gap’s embattled chief executive, Paul S. Pressler, who stepped down today after the clothing retailer’s third dismal holiday shopping season.

headline: Gambling Subpoenas on Wall St.
text: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to at least four Wall Street investment banks as part of a widening investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry, according to people briefed on the investigation.

headline: New CDs
text: THE SHINS “Wincing the Night Away”   (Sub Pop)

headline: Out of the Cradle, Endlessly Talking About the Family
text: John Sedgwick is part of a venerable Massachusetts family with connections to both George Washington’s Congress (the politically ambitious Theodore Sedgwick) and Andy Warhol’s Factory (Edie). He believes that this lineage has shaped his destiny. He cites manic depression as the trademark Sedgwick ailment, but his new book reveals other traits as well. The Sedgwicks have long struggled with their sense of privilege and worried as much about status as about sanity.

headline: In Role Reversal, New England Fades With Game on the Line
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 21 — The locker room was quiet, players spoke in hushed tones, and the New England Patriots felt as empty as many of their past victims.

headline: One Concert, Multiple Bands and a New Life for a Dead Classic
text: Even in their absence, the Grateful Dead can pack a hall. On Saturday night, the World Financial Center’s Winter Garden was filled to capacity for the first night of the American Beauty Project: various groups performing all the songs on “Workingman’s Dead.” (Sunday’s concert covered “American Beauty,” the other album the Dead released in 1970.) None of the Dead were on the bill; the aura was enough.

headline: When John Meets Al
text: Four major bills have recently been offered in the Senate calling for mandatory controls on carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas. And last week, 10 big companies, including General Electric, Alcoa and progressive utilities like PG&E of California, joined in an informal coalition to press Congress and President Bush for action.

headline: Group Formed to Support Linux as Rival to Windows
text: Linux, the free operating system, has gone from an intriguing experiment to a mainstream technology in corporate data centers, helped by the backing of major technology companies like I.B.M., Intel and Hewlett-Packard, which sponsored industry consortiums to promote its adoption.

headline: Heroic Teachers, on Screen and Off (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Death Toll in Iraq Hits 27 for Weekend
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 21 — The United States military said that two marines died on Sunday in western Iraq and that an additional seven service members had died on Saturday. The deaths, in addition to those announced on Saturday, brought the weekend toll to 27 and made Saturday the third-deadliest day for United States forces since the war here began.

headline: Manhattan: Hoboken Councilman Charged With Drunken Driving
text: A Hoboken city councilman has been arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said yesterday. The councilman, Christopher Campos, was stopped on the West Side Highway near 43rd Street in Manhattan just after 3 a.m. on Saturday for running a red light, the police said. Officers administered a Breathalyzer test to Mr. Campos because they smelled alcohol, the police said, adding that he failed the test. Mr. Campos spent the night in jail and was arraigned and then released.

headline: A Reporter and Potential Juror Says She Can Be Impartial, to a Point
text: Jury selection in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. — who has been charged with perjury and obstruction of justice for his role related to the investigation of the outing of a C.I.A. operative — has been taking far longer than expected. Mainly that is because so many of the potential jurors have expressed strong negative feelings about the Bush administration, the Iraq war and Vice President Dick Cheney, for whom Mr. Libby once served as chief of staff.
