headline: In This Rivalry, Manning Takes Role of Winner
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: U.S. Tries to Interpret China’s Silence Over Test
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — Bush administration officials said that they had been unable to get even the most basic diplomatic response from China after their detection of a successful test to destroy a satellite 10 days ago, and that they were uncertain whether China’s top leaders, including President Hu Jintao, were fully aware of the test or the reaction it would engender.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Manhattan: Call to Monitor Investment Decisions
text: Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat, left, a Manhattan Democrat, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to create an 11-member investment review commission to monitor certain investment decisions made by the state comptroller’s office. The office is the sole trustee of the state’s Common Retirement Fund, which provides pension, death and disability benefits to public employees. Mr. Espaillat, chairman of a task force of black, Hispanic and Asian-American state lawmakers, said the commission would focus on social investment goals for the fund, like promoting economic development in urban and rural areas that are struggling economically.

headline: New Somali Government Faces the Age-Old Problem of Clans
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 18 — Fifteen men and one woman sat on the floor of a sunlit room. It was hot. Many people were sweating. The elders of the Ayr clan had called a political meeting, and very quickly it was clear that their attitudes toward the nation’s newly empowered transitional government were unanimous — and bitter.

headline: Court Rules Against Sentencing Rules in Calif.
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that California’s system of sentencing criminals is unconstitutional because it gives judges some authority that really belongs to jurors and thus deprives a defendant of a fair trial.

headline: Sri Lankan Military Battles Rebels at Sea
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Jan. 21  A fierce battle erupted off Sri Lanka’s northern coast on Sunday when two clusters of Tamil Tiger rebel boats, including suicide craft, attacked a ship carrying food supplies.

headline: Using the Newsroom to Represent Honesty
text: AT a time when many deem newspapers to be going the way of hair tonic, tail fins and land lines, Madison Avenue still uses reporters and editors as role models for consumer behavior — to a point.

headline: Safely Back Home in Louisiana, Playing It Safe
text: We all know of the destruction caused by Hurricane Katrina in 2005. Apart from its far more serious consequences, the Louisiana Bridge Association premises were severely damaged. The club had to relocate temporarily to the American Legion Hall in Harahan. But in October it reopened at 2709 Edenborn Avenue, Metairie, eight miles from downtown New Orleans.

headline: Bush Expected to Make Call for Improved Fuel Economy
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 — There is widespread anticipation, inside government and outside, that President Bush will call for better fuel economy in his State of the Union address on Tuesday.

headline: Bulletin! Washington Post Decides to Go for the Satirical
text: In what might be taken as a sign that The Washington Post believes in keeping its enemies close, the paper will sell local advertising for the humor weekly The Onion and print and distribute it in the Washington area.

headline: U.S. Financial Sector Is Losing Its Edge, Report Says
text: Adding to a chorus of concern that the United States is losing its edge as the leading financial center, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release a report today urging the country to take a series of steps to improve its legal and regulatory environment.

headline: Colts Overcome Brady and Patriots to Reach Super Bowl
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 21 — To reach the Super Bowl, to finally fill in the blanks on the glittering résumés that lacked postseason glory, even the Indianapolis Colts conceded it was only appropriate that they would have to vanquish their greatest tormentors.

headline: Clinton Opens Her Campaign With Health Insurance Plan
text: With a 4-year-old girl clutching her hand, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began her newborn presidential campaign yesterday at a Manhattan health care clinic, announcing legislation that would significantly expand federal health insurance for Americans under age 18.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Washington Bureau Chief Philip Taubman
text: Philip Taubman, Washington bureau chief for The Times, answered reader questions during the week of Jan. 22.

headline: What’s Past Is Prologue
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Harsh Winter for the Calves
text: The cycle of ranch birth exposes tangled emotions and ambivalent impulses that go far beyond the elements.

headline: Figuring Out the P.E. Ratio of Steve Jobs
text: Apple‘s share price leaped to a record after the company unveiled its latest device to be hailed as the coolest thing ever, but investors are factoring more into their decision than a best guess on the number of iPhones Apple will sell. Ultimately they are putting a price on the brilliance and creativity of Apple’s designers and engineers and especially on its founder and chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.

headline: Swift Founder to Take Company Private
text: The founder of Swift Transportation, Jerry C. Moyes, plans to buy the company for $2.74 billion. Mr. Moyes, who founded Swift more than 40 years ago with his father and brother, announced a deal Friday to pay $31.55 a share in cash to take the company private. His group, which includes family members, will also assume $332 million in debt.

headline: A Single Securities Regulator Is Approved
text: The NYSE Group and NASD have won approval from brokerage firms to form a single regulator for the United States securities industry, overcoming opposition from a group of small firms. Sixty-four percent of members of NASD approved combining its regulatory operations with those of NYSE to create a single watchdog, NASD said in a statement Sunday. NASD, a private-sector provider of financial regulatory services with 5,058 brokerage firms, said almost 83 percent of eligible members voted during a 33-day election period.

headline: Industrial Bank of China Plans Sizable Share Sale in Shanghai
text: The Industrial Bank of China, partly owned by a unit of HSBC Holdings, may raise up to 21.25 billion yuan ($2.74 billion) from a Shanghai share sale, making it the second-largest domestic initial public offering by a mainland Chinese bank. Industrial Bank plans to sell up to 1.33 billion class A shares at between 15 yuan and 15.98 yuan each to investors, the company said in a statement Sunday. The sale would top the Bank of China’s 20 billion yuan offer in June 2006 and would be second only to the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China’s sale of 46.6 billion yuan last year.

headline: China to Revamp 4th Bank in Preparation for Offering
text: China said over the weekend that the last of four big state-owned banks, the Agriculture Bank of China, would be financially restructured to prepare it for a public stock listing. Three of the largest banks sold shares in 2005 and 2006, offerings that raised more than $40 billion and were among the most successful initial public stock issues anywhere.

headline: Prosecutor in Apple Case Joins Law Firm
text: Christopher J. Steskal, a lead prosecutor of a federal task force investigating the backdating of stock options at Apple and other companies, is leaving his San Francisco post to join a law firm, the United State Attorney’s office in San Francisco confirmed late Friday.

headline: Caremark Shareholders’ Bitter Pill
text: Caremark Rx‘s proposed merger with CVS, and its rejection of a higher offer from Express Scripts, is a case where a company’s management has put themselves totally ahead of the stockholders, Ben Stein argues in a column in The New York Times.

headline: Why Backdated Options Might Be Contagious
text: Directors of corporations often form a tight-knit community, serving at more than one company and creating what are known as interlocking boards of directors. As a result of this chumminess, corporate practices that otherwise might remain confined to just a few companies can spread quickly. That appears to have been the case with the backdating of stock options, according to a new statistical study of publicly traded American companies.

headline: Big Media’s Crush on Social Networking
text: An invitation to join someone’s online social networking circle is fast becoming the new handshake among Internet savvy business folk, writes The New York Times’s Richard Siklos, who describes himself as an antisocial networker. But, he notes, the level of engagement that social networking demands raises questions about politesse when navigating the seas of staying in touch.

headline: Star-Struck on the Soccer Field, and in the Boardroom
text: Major League Soccer’s deal for David Beckham, whose salary with bonuses could exceed the entire payroll of the rest of the league, shows an overwhelming faith in star economics, where the leading lights of an industry wield disproportionate influence, according to The New York Times.

headline: Big Game? An Enron Survivor Hunts for Riches
text: The South Pacific islands of Papua New Guinea, where canned mackerel occasionally serves as currency and cannibalism was once on the menu, are a long way from the corporate jungles where Enron was born.

headline: H.P. Chief Defends Timing of Stock Sale
text: The chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Mark V. Hurd, told Congressional lawmakers that his sale of company shares on Aug. 25 was “totally unrelated” to the fact that he was questioned the same day about an ill-fated internal investigation. The sale of 100,000 shares of Hewlett-Packard was made during a scheduled window for trading by executives, Mr. Hurd wrote in a letter dated Dec. 21 that he sent to the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat. On the same day the trade was completed, Mr. Hurd was interviewed by lawyers from the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati. The lawyers were looking into techniques used by Hewlett-Packard to identify the source of boardroom leaks.

headline: Flames Flare Over Naked Shorts
text: Unsuspecting readers of certain stock message boards may be forgiven for believing they have stumbled into a flame war among 14-year-old boys. But the increasingly vicious online dispute actually involves, among others, the chief executive of a publicly traded corporation and a longtime business journalist.

headline: Business News for the Saucy (and Internet Savvy) Set
text: Tuning into the demand for for saucy, tongue-in-cheek treatment that financial news gets on the net via blogs like Valleywag.com, Dealbreaker.com and the like, a band of video producers and wannabe stars are pooling their talents and cheap digital cameras to create Wallstrip, a daily online television show examining top-performing stocks, BusinessWeek writes.

headline: Two Former N.Y.S.E. Traders Sentenced for Fraud
text: Two former traders at the New York Stock Exchange were each sentenced Friday to six months in prison and fined $250,000 for improper stock trading. The two traders, Michael J. Hayward and Michael F. Stern, former managers at Van der Moolen Specialists USA, were each convicted of securities fraud at a trial in July, part of a crackdown on illegal trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Sears C.F.O. Resigns
text: Sears Holdings‘ chief financial officer resigned Friday after less than four months on the job, the latest in a string of high-level executive changes as billionaire Edward Lampert searches for ways to make money on one of his biggest, and most challenging, investments. The executive, Craig Monaghan, plans to leave at the end of January and return to Florida where his family lives, according to an announcement from the Hoffman Estates-based company. William Crowley, chief administrative officer and chief financial officer before Mr. Monaghan’s arrival, will assume the C.F.O. role while Sears looks for a replacement.

headline: Online Gambling Underwriters Face Subpoenas in U.S.
text: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to at least four Wall Street investment banks as part of a widening investigation into the multibillion-dollar online gambling industry, The New York Times reported. The subpoenas were apparently issued to firms that had underwritten the initial public offerings of some of the most popular online gambling sites that operate abroad. The Times said that the banks involved in the inquiry include HSBC, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Kleinwort, these people said.

headline: One to Go
text: Facts and links on the morning after the conference championship games:

headline: Chicago’s Hancock Center Changes Hands
text: Another iconic Chicago tower changed hands Friday with the closing of the approximately $385 million sale of Chicago’s third-tallest skyscraper, the John Hancock Center. The buyer is a joint venture of hometown real estate firm Golub & Company and Whitehall Street Real Estate Fund, an affiliate of New York-based Goldman Sachs.

headline: Bacon’s Six Degrees of Charitable Giving
text: Actor Kevin Bacon has finally embraced the fact that he’s connected to most of the rest of the world by just six degrees, and he’s parlaying the concept to help humanity. SixDegrees.org, a play on the popular, tongue-in-cheek “Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon” game based on the performer’s career, hopes to be more than just a social-networking site, but rather a site that motivates the public to be more charitable.

headline: Canadian Banks Chided for Timid Approach to China
text: China wants Canadian banks to abandon their timid approach to the Asian market of 1.3 billion consumers and instead step up investment there, the Canadian finance minister, Jim Flaherty, said Sunday, passing on advice that he underlined should be heeded. “One of the things I heard from officials in China is that our financial services sector – particularly our banks – have probably been too conservative, not aggressive enough, in the China market,” Mr. Flaherty said during a conference call with reporters at the end of a week-long trip to Beijing and Shanghai.

headline: Providence Equity to Open Offices in Asia
text: Providence Equity Partners said it would open offices in Hong Kong and New Delhi to support its growing investment activities in Asia. Andrew Rickards, chief executive of the investment bank N.M. Rothschild & Sons in Asia, will become a managing director at Providence in Hong Kong and will lead the firm’s Asian investments, Providence said.

headline: Is Big Brother Ruckus Bad for Business?
text: It seems that the brouhaha surrounding the treatment of a Bollywood actress on the British version of “Big Brother” is not doing British business any favors. Richard Lambert, director-general of an employers’ organization, the CBI, has waded into the row over alleged racism on Channel 4’s “Celebrity Big Brother” by describing the program as “complete crap” and “unhelpful” to British firms trying to establish themselves in India. The Guardian reported.

headline: Google in Talks to Buy Internet Ad Firm, Report Says
text: Google is in talks to acquire Adscape Media in a move to expand beyond its traditional Internet search advertising business and into video games, according to The Wall street Journal. A deal for Adscape, a closely held San Francisco firm whose technology allows for the placement of ads over the Web in video games, could be reached as early as this week, the report said.

headline: Salary.com Prices I.P.O.
text: Salary.com, which provides on-demand compensation management products, set its planned initial public offering Friday at 5 million shares for an estimated price of $8 to $10 each. The company said in an amended Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the underwriters, Thomas Weisel Partners, William Blair & Company, Needham & Company, Wachovia Securities, and Pacific Crest Securities, have the option to buy an additional 750,000 shares to cover over-allotments.

headline: Credit Suisse Eyes Big Buyback and and Other Deals
text: The Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s second-largest bank, plans a record share buyback and will seek takeovers after selling its Winterthur insurance unit for 12.3 billion Swiss francs ($9.8 billion). The bank plans to buy back as much as 8 billion Swiss francs of stock over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion Swiss francs for “bolt-on acquisitions” in areas including wealth management, the bank said in a presentation to investors today. Credit Suisse last month completed the sale of Winterthur to France’s Axa.

headline: Bidders Circle Apax’s Moelnlycke Health Care
text: The Blackstone Group and Sweden’s billionaire Wallenberg family are the leading bidders for Moelnlycke Health Care, which may be sold for as much as 3 billion euros ($3.9 billion), according to Bloomberg News. The report said that Apax Partners, the buyout shop that acquired Moelnlycke, a maker of surgical products, two years ago, is considering whether to drop a planned initial public offering and pursue a sale after receiving offers that value Moelnlycke at 2.5 billion euros to 3 billion euros.

headline: Stoke Raises $20 Million
text: Stoke, a provider of networking hardware and software, said Monday it had raised $20 million in a Series C funding round led by led by DAG Ventures. Previous investors including Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital also participated in the round, Stoke said.

headline: Citigroup to Buy ABN Amro Mortgage Unit
text: Citigroup agreed to buy ABN Amro Holding‘s ABN Amro Mortgage Group for an undisclosed amount to strengthen its presence in mortgage origination and servicing in the United States. Citigroup will acquire about $9 billion in net assets and the mortgage group’s $224 billion mortgage-servicing portfolio, the bank said on Monday. The mortgage group is unit of ABN Amro’s LaSalle Bank.

headline: U.S. Financial Sector Is Losing Its Edge, Report Says
text: Adding to a chorus of concern that the United States is losing its edge as the leading financial center, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release a report Monday urging the country to take a series of steps to improve its legal and regulatory environment. If not, the report warns, it could lose 4 to 7 percent of the global financial services market over the next five years.

headline: A Boss Takes to His Blog to Deny, Then Confirm
text: Blogging by a chief executive can be tricky business. Some executives, like Jonathan I. Schwartz of Sun Microsystems, pull it off with aplomb. Others, like Jason Goldberg of the online recruiting company Jobster, have had more difficulty. Last month, Mr. Goldberg took to his blog to knock down rumors that Jobster was in trouble. “Everybody’s all a speculating. A lot of falsehoods are being bandied about,” he wrote on Dec. 22. He said that revenue was up 30 percent, and he vowed to drive the company to profitability in 2007. Amid rumors of pending layoffs, he assured the staff that there would be no news until after the new year.

headline: Tribune May Reject Outside Bids
text: The Tribune Company indicated over the weekend that it might reshape its future without outside help. On the auction block since last fall, the company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and other media properties, received three bids last week for all or part of the company.

headline: Sundance East Prospers
text: The Reeler points out that, so far, NYC is finishing in the money at Sundance. Hometown boy and BMOC Dan Klores has a doc, ”Crazy Love,” that will be coming, soon or not, to a theater near you, by virtue of Magnolia’s interest in exploring the commercial possibilities of a love that has a name, but very little in the way of precedent.

headline: Krawcheck to Lead Citigroup’s Wealth Management Arm
text: Sallie L. Krawcheck, the chief financial officer of Citigroup, will become head of the banking giant’s wealth-management division. The move, which Citigroup announced in a news release early Monday, comes several weeks after the bank announced a management shake-up that seemed to quiet speculation on Wall Street that Ms. Krawcheck was planning to resign from the firm.

headline: An Expanding ‘World’
text: Every few years it seems there is a report out of South Korea, where gaming is practically a national religion, about some young man who sat down to play an online PC game, didn’t get up for a few days, and literally keeled over dead.

headline: Political Agitation and a Missing Person
text: The choice of “Chicago 10” as the hood ornament for this year’s Sundance comes in for additional spanking from Hollwood Elsewhere. The blog also runs a cast and crew photo from the premiere of “Waitress,” a sweet movie that grows in depth and texture as it unfolds. Between the photo and the film the murder of director Adrienne Shelly seems all the more affecting.

headline: Trying Not to Be Roadkill on the Schuylkill
text: Remember the jingle "Baseball, hot dogs, apple pie and Chevrolet"? A musical campaign for a new Web site offers a version that could be called "Phillies, cheese steaks, scrapple and all kinds of cars."

headline: Prepping for Bush Speech
text: The White House is getting ready for what would, under normal circumstances, be the most important speech of the year (though some would argue that his “way forward” in Iraq speech has already supplanted the State of the Union address). President Bush will address a joint session of Congress — a less friendly one than usual — Tuesday evening.

headline: Cushman to Sell Banker’s Trust Building for $325 Million
text: Cushman & Wakefield has sold the former Banker’s Trust building at 14 Wall St., with its iconic pyramid top, as office space for $325 million, The New York Post reported. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that the real estate firm approached John Zamir of Capstone Equities about buying the building, which was not then for sale. Its current owners bought the building, with 1 million square feet of space, for $215 million in 2005 with the intent of making it residential. Those plans have long since stalled.

headline: How to Tell Clinton From Obama
text: -Mary Duenwald

headline: M Dot Dot Dot
text: The Bagger spent some time doing a video interview of M dot Strange, the guy behind the animated feature, “We are the Strange.” Its idiosyncratic visual vocabulary and 8-bit soundtrack had Sundancers jogging for the exits, but M dot, as the Bagger has come to think of him, could care less. To find out why, check out this thought from the Bagger about the changing nature of the movie biz. Or you can always check with the man hisself.

headline: State Street to Buy Currenex for $564 Million
text: State Street, the institutional investors service provider, said on Monday it would buy the Currenex electronic foreign exchange trading platform for $564 million. Founded in 1999, Currenex serves banks, hedge funds and other active traders and has offices in New York, Chicago, London, Singapore and Redwood City, Calif.

headline: What About the Awakened-by-Seemingly-Meaningless-Events Genre?
text: The RiskyBiz blog pointed us to Richard Corliss’s piece in Time, in which he gives Sundance the back of his hand for being too predictable — too conformist in its noncomformity.

headline: And After That, He Invented the Internet
text: “But for me, as much of a fan of awards season as I always was, the business of Oscar started with the birth of Movie City News in 2002.” — Dave Poland, editor of Movie City News, in an annotation of the Los Angeles magazine piece on Oscar bloggers.

headline: Supporting Data
text: The Bagger is pulling out tomorrow to cover the Oscar nominations on Tuesday, and he had a thought about what seems like just one more stutter step on the way to the real deal. Actually, it was someone else’s thought, but he will just pick their pocket and keep moving.

headline: Gross Points
text: There was happy news for the makers of “Grace is Gone,” the film about a newly widowed character, played by John Cusack, who can’t bring himself to tell his two girls that their mother is not coming back from Iraq. Variety reported that the Weinstein Company bought the film for $4 million in negotiations that went through the night to the early morning.

headline: This is the Hill. This is the Hill on Drugs.
text: Side effects may include irritation, drowsiness and nausea. But with a $4.5 billion spent on direct-to-consumer drug advertising last year, someone is clearly benefiting from the effort to win over consumers. Congress is likely to conduct its own clinical trials, so to speak, on the matter.

headline: Congress and Bush in the Week Ahead
text: For the first time since President Bush took office, a Democratically controlled Congress will be the audience for his State of the Union address and the reception is likely to be noticeably different.

headline: Bombing at a Baghdad Marketplace
text: A pair of bombs killed at least 75 people in a crowded Baghdad marketplace, capping a weekend in which at least 27 U.S. service members died.

headline: First, Let’s Remove All the Lawyers
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 19 column, “Surging and Purging.”

headline: Some Hillary What Ifs…
text: Time for some more speculation about what happens if Hillary proves the doubters wrong by returning to the White House and giving up her Senate seat:

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Apres Clinton, Le Deluge
text: We are drowning in news about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. So are the other candidates, including Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico. And Senator Clinton isn’t just resting on the flood of press coverage. Her campaign is taking an aggressive approach. Her pollster sent a memo to reporters saying that the campaigns of Senator Barack Obama and John Edwards are “stalled or failing.” Nonetheless, many Democrats are worried about her general election prospects.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Kiran Advani joined Zapwater Communications, Chicago, as group director. She had been running her own media relations and specialty-marketing agency and before that managed public relations and special events for the Terra Museum of American Art, Chicago.

headline: Carlyle Matches Rival Bid for ElkCorp
text: The Carlyle Group has raised its offer for ElkCorp, a maker of roofing products, to $42 a share, matching a competing offer from the Building Materials Corporation of America and extending a months-long battle for ElkCorp.

headline: One-Man Assault on Citadel Ends in Quiet Retreat
text: An unusual lawsuit involving a secretive hedge-fund chief has come to a fittingly enigmatic finale. Last June, a Florida man claiming to be the mentor of Kenneth C. Griffin accused him of defrauding him and illegally breaking their partnership to form Citadel Investment Group, a hedge fund that now oversees more than $12 billion in assets.

headline: Editor's Note
text: A review on Jan. 14 about "The Man Who Would Not Shut Up," by Marvin Kitman, and "Culture Warrior," by Bill O'Reilly, incorrectly attributed an anti-Semitic euphemism to Patrick J. Buchanan, whose populism was compared to O'Reilly's. Neither the reviewer, Jacob Heilbrunn, nor the editors of the Book Review have found evidence that Buchanan has ever denounced "rootless cosmopolitans." Some of Buchanan's ideological opponents have used the phrase in characterizing his views, and the reviewer wrongly assumed from their writings that Buchanan had used it himself.

headline: Tapping the Stuff Dreams Are Made Of
text: The academy and its TV partner, ABC, are scheduled to start  their annual campaigns to encourage viewers to watch the Academy Awards show.

headline: Senator Clinton Calls for Federal Help for Sick 9/11 Workers
text: Targeting President Bush for the first time in her new role as presidential candidate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton attended a news conference at Ground Zero this morning and called on the White House to seek funding to cover the health needs of ill first responders who worked at the Twin Towers during 9/11.

headline: Out and About: Bistro Cassis
text: The other night I did something unusual.

headline: Conquering the Burning Crusade
text: Wednesday, Jan. 31 FINAL THOUGHTS

headline: In Stock Sales, UBS Narrows Gap With Goldman
text: “You would have thought,” one fund manager recently opined to Bloomberg News, “it would be a U.S. bank that’s nipping at Goldman’s heels.” But you would have thought wrong: It is Zurich-based UBS that appears to be doing the nipping. And if the bank keeps up its pursuit of the Chinese market, UBS may surpass Goldman Sachs as the top dog of global stock sellers, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: A.F.C. Championship
text: Quarterback Peyton Manning led the Colts over the Patriots in the biggest comeback in championship game history.

headline: Co-Head of Goldman’s Distressed Debt Unit to Retire
text: Mark McGoldrick, the London-based co-head of Goldman Sachs’ Special Situations Group, will retire for personal reasons, Bloomberg News reported Monday. His New York-based partner, Stephen McGuinness, will assume control of the whole unit, a Goldman spokesman said. Mr. McGoldrick, 47, earned the investment bank $500 million last year after Goldman sold a stake in Accordia Golf, a company it formed to run a set of failed Japanese golf courses.

headline: Will Citi Woo Bank of America’s Outgoing C.F.O.?
text: Monday’s announcement that the Citigroup chief financial officer, Sallie Krawcheck, is getting a new assignment at the firm quickly ignited speculation about who might succeed her. One name that kept popping up was Alvaro G. de Molina, who announced in December that he would step down as Bank of America‘s chief financial officer, telling The New York Times’s Eric Dash that he was “looking for something that will be more impactful.”

headline: 6 Billion Degrees of Separation
text: This one ranks right up there with some of the best Stunts the Internet Makes Possible, so I thought I’d give it a little digital ink:

headline: Will Blackstone Raise Its Equity Office Bid? Speculation Abounds
text: The Blackstone Group is apt to fight back in the bidding war over Equity Office Properties Trust by raising its $36 billion bid, Reuters reported Monday, citing “industry sources.”

headline: The Gentle Soul of a Dictator
text: Forest Whitaker, who already has a Golden Globe for his role as Idi Amin in “The Last King of Scotland,” is on everyone’s list to receive a best actor Oscar nomination tomorrow

headline: Travelport Said to Consider Orbitz I.P.O.
text: Less than six months after leaving the public markets, the travel Web site Orbitz.com may be contemplating a return trip.

headline: More on Darfur
text: I just started to tap out the headline on this blog software, and as soon as I had typed the word “more” it offered up: “More Bad News From Darfur.” I guess I used that as a previous headline. Maybe I should autoprogram my F6 key to type that out, because it’s certainly a refrain.

headline: Bidding War for Child Art
text: “My Kid Could Paint That,” the story of a four-year-old girl whose abstract paintings made others look at her as a prodigy — before authorship of the work was challenged, sold here early this morning to Sony Pictures Classics for just under $2 million for world rights, according to Tom Bernard, co-president of Sony Pictures Classics(A & E has limited broadcast rights). There was much back and forth throughout the night, and much standing by, but eventually Mr. Bernard and his co-president, Michael Barker, won the competition.

headline: Looking in the Mirror at the Caremark Chief’s Strategy
text: In an attempt to put the brouhaha over Caremark‘s proposed deal with CVS in context, TheStreet.com’s Melissa Davis offers a history lesson. Edwin M. Crawford, the chief of Caremark, was at the center of another health-care merger more than a decade ago that in many ways mirrors what’s happening now. Although he is considered a “turnaround king” who has steered Caremark to solid returns during his tenure, Ms. Davis writes, Mr. Crawford has at least one black spot in his past.

headline: Looking for Health Care and Finding Fool’s Gold
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 22 column, “Gold-Plated Indifference.”

headline: Additional Notes on 1/22 Column, “Gold-Plated Indifference.”
text: As is often the case, I couldn’t fully explain my views in the space available. So I’d like to explain at a bit more length why I’m so opposed to the direction Bush is going.

headline: More Clinton Staff Assignments
text: Three hard-working New Yorkers are taking on some weighty assignments for Hillary ’08.

headline: Congress’ First Report Card
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Jan. 21 column, “Mr. Chips Goes to Washington.”

headline: Paying the Balance for Life
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 22 column, “Your MasterCard or Your Life.“

headline: Alaska Air May Become Takeover Target, Analyst Says
text: Thanks to its smallish size and its location on the West Coast, Alaska Air could make an attractive takeover candidate if airlines start merging, according to a Credit Suisse analyst, Daniel McKenzie. Mr. McKenzie initiated coverage of the airline with an “outperform” rating. Despite the dominance of larger carriers, he wrote, Alaska Air holds strong market positions in a number of routes and has a solid balance sheet that is second only to that of Southwest Airlines.

headline: The Mystery of the Private-Equity Populists
text: Why are so many billionaires speaking out lately about income inequality and the plight of the middle class? Trend-mongering is part of it, to be sure. But Slate’s Daniel Gross also sees something else at work: fear that the hoi-polloi are mad as hell, and soon won’t take it anymore. Should the middle class face continued hardship — while “economic royalists” like Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group keep growing richer — the free trade of goods, services and capital will lose political support. And who else does that hurt?

headline: Blogtalk
text: Everybody talks about the weather, so why isn’t Mike Bloomberg doing anything about it? [Wonkster]

headline: Gap’s Chief Resigns After a Poor Fourth Quarter
text: Gap‘s chief executive, Paul Pressler, resigned Monday following a miserable holiday shopping season that hurt the retail chain’s fourth quarter profit.

headline: The State of Our Energy Policy
text: This is what I wish President Bush would say about energy in his State of the Union message:

headline: Procrastinate Now!
text: Here’s an even better way to put off work than reading my blog. You can take an on-line survey to measure how much of a procrastinator you are.

headline: Kingston? That’s So Downstate.
text: Where is the line between upstate and downstate New York?

headline: Your Invitation to Mingle With Bono
text: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Hillary Clinton
text: Senator Clinton of New York announced her bid on Jan. 20.

headline: War at Home: Another Senate Resolution
text: Several leading Republican senators, led by John W. Warner of Virginia, the former chairman of the Armed Services Committee, proposed their own language for a resolution today against President Bush’s plan to send 21,500 more troops to Iraq.

headline: Barack Obama
text: Senator Obama's announcement was one of the first Web videos to be widely distributed.

headline: The View From 1,650 Meters
text: World leaders and corporate chiefs will spend the next few days in Davos debating issues that affect billions of people — the global economy, climate change and energy, just to name a few — in what the World Economic Forum describes as an attempt to set the global agenda.

headline: Moguls Arrive, One Eye on the Sky
text: As well as a flurry of corporate bigwigs and policy makers, Davos can expect some snow later this week, if weather forecasts prove correct. Considering the unusually balmy winter the Alps is having this year, that is likely to be happy news for the conference’s many skiing aficionados and especially for one mogul in particular: publishing executive Hubert Burda, who for several years has organized an invitation-only ski race to coincide with the annual conference.

headline: Do You Believe in Magic?
text: Research indicates that the appetite for so-called magical thinking is rooted in the circuitry of the brain, Benedict Carey writes in today’s Science Times. This helps explain why even people who fashion themselves skeptics cling to odd rituals that seem to make no sense, like lucky numbers and special game-day clothing.

headline: Bronx: Teenager Charged With Two Murders
text: A Bronx teenager was indicted on murder charges yesterday in two deaths, including the contract killing of a drug dealer as part of a turf war over drug sales, the Bronx district attorney’s office announced. The teenager, Alan Brown, 18, is charged with shooting Shawron Hughes, who prosecutors said was a drug dealer, as Mr. Hughes was driving in Fordham on July 7, 2005. Mr. Hughes lost control of his car, which struck and killed a bystander, Wellington Contrera. Mr. Hughes, who was shot in the head, did not die until Oct. 19, 2006. Prosecutors said that Mr. Brown had been hired by Terrance Degraffenreid, 33, to kill Mr. Hughes for $2,000. A second man, who has not been identified and who the authorities said was still at large, was also involved in hiring Mr. Brown, prosecutors said. Mr. Degraffenreid faces first-degree murder and other charges, prosecutors said, and a third man, Duane Heath, 19, faces conspiracy and weapons charges.

headline: Letters
text: Pap Tests and Annual Exams

headline: Williams Hangs on to Advance to Semifinals
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 23 — Shahar Peer did not make it easy, tracking down big shots that others might not have bothered to chase and rallying from a 4-1 deficit in the third set. Serena Williams did not make it easy on herself, struggling with her movement and timing and never looking entirely comfortable.

headline: Libby a Scapegoat, His Lawyer Tells Jurors
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  In his opening statement today, the chief defense lawyer for I. Lewis Libby Jr. set the stage for a nasty bout of finger-pointing in the Bush administration, asserting that Mr. Libby, the vice president’s former chief of staff, had been made a scapegoat to protect the president’s longtime political strategist, Karl Rove.

headline: Ford Shows a Hybrid Car With 2 Modes: Electric or Electric
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — Move over, gas-electric hybrid. Ford has a new entry, the electric-electric hybrid.

headline: Limits on Prison Suits Are Eased
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — Twelve years ago, Congress passed a law intended to make it harder for prisoners to file lawsuits challenging prison conditions as illegal or unconstitutional. On Monday, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a federal appeals court had overstepped its bounds by making prisoner lawsuits even harder to file than Congress intended.

headline: Jerome Robbins: One Toeshoe in Bach, the Other in Kern
text: Jerome Robbins choreographed two of his late ballets to Bach in the first few months of 1994, and both were on the third themed program of the New York City Ballet’s winter season, “Jerome Robbins: An American Icon.”

headline: Eye on the Sky
text: Q. The optical Large Synoptic Survey Telescope is supposed to measure dark matter. Since dark matter is invisible, how can an optical telescope see it?

headline: Rehabilitating Robert Moses
text: FOR three decades his image has been frozen in time. The bulldozing bully who callously displaced thousands of New Yorkers in the name of urban renewal. The public-works kingpin who championed highways as he starved mass transit. And yes, the visionary idealist who gave New York Lincoln Center and Jones Beach, along with parks, roads, playgrounds and public pools.

headline: No Smokers, but Watch the Skies
text: It is illegal in this city to light up a cigarette in a bar because the secondhand smoke can be hazardous, and you never know. Someone across the room might end up with cancer in 25 or 30 years.

headline: Icahn Backs Three for Cyberonics Board
text: WASHINGTON, Jan 22. (Reuters)  The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said on Monday that he planned to back three nominees by Metropolitan Capital Advisors to the board of Cyberonics, a medical device maker under investigation for its stock options dating practices.

headline: Supreme Court Limits Judges’ Sentencing Power
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — The Supreme Court invalidated California’s criminal sentencing law on Monday, ruling that the 30-year-old statute gave judges authority that the Constitution places with juries.

headline: A Radical Step to Preserve a Species: Assisted Migration
text: The Bay checkerspot butterfly’s story is all too familiar. It was once a common sight in the San Francisco Bay area, but development and invasive plants have wiped out much of its grassland habitat.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the Pentagon’s new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantánamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administration’s original plans for the commissions. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unconstitutional.

headline: Suit Challenges Rent Jumps in Complexes MetLife Sold
text: The $5.4 billion sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village was hailed by Wall Street and the real estate industry as a bountiful coup for its owner, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

headline: Outsiders Console the Underdogs
text: “Nobody wants you, but we want you,” Murray Lightburn of the Dears sang on Friday night at Webster Hall, heedless of the contradiction. The Dears have a mission. They are determined to console underdogs and befriend the alienated, and they stayed steadfastly on message throughout their set.

headline: Restatement by Take-Two Over Problems With Options
text: Take-Two Interactive Software, maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, said yesterday that it let its former chief executive, Ryan A. Brant, “control and dominate” improper options backdating that began when the company went public in 1997.

headline: Small Wonders: Understanding the Way of the Warrior Sperm
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The first thing that David E. Clapham of Harvard Medical School wants me to know as we meet for breakfast on a recent morning is that he’s “not a sperm specialist.”

headline: Meat Processor Considering a Buyout
text: Swift, the beef and pork producer, said yesterday that it was considering a possible buyout after receiving “unsolicited inquiries” during the last six months.

headline: General Petraeus’s Opening Statement
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — Following is the opening statement by Lieutenant General David H. Petraeus this morning before a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on his nomination to be the commander of U.S. forces in Iraq, as recorded by Federal News Service.

headline: Watching the Energy Watchdog
text: A scathing report from the state’s Public Service Commission about last summer’s electrical blackout in western Queens took some well-deserved shots at Consolidated Edison. The utility certainly failed spectacularly as it left 174,000 people sweltering in the dark for as long as nine days. But the report ignored a critical part of the problem: the commission itself, which has been incompetently monitoring the energy monopoly.

headline: An Alternative to Long Irons, and It’s Legal
text: CARLSBAD, Calif. — In the early days of the 1999 golf season, two engineers from TaylorMade began showing up at tournaments with a golf club shaped like a weeding tool. The club was made from small, expensive pieces of titanium and tungsten, and by many accounts, it was ugly.

headline: Making Sense of Time, Earthbound and Otherwise
text: More than three weeks have passed since the great Waterford disco ball dropped over Times Square, and most of us are taking 2007 in stride. The time is flying by, just as it does when we’re having fun, approaching a deadline or taking a standardized test on which our entire future depends, though not, oddly enough, when we ourselves are flying, especially not when we are seated in the last row, near the bathrooms.

headline: Never Too Early for Pollsters
text: Let the hypotheticals begin. Conventional wisdom may say Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York is the Democrats’ prohibitive front-runner. But a Newsweek poll released over the weekend, which otherwise shows the candidates tightly bunched, indicates that former Senator John Edwards, below, is the only one to beat the top two potential Republican candidates in head-to-head matchups. The poll shows that Mr. Edwards, of North Carolina, Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama of Illinois all would beat Senator John McCain of Arizona by a few percentage points. But Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor, would narrowly defeat Senators Clinton and Obama while losing to Mr. Edwards, 45 percent to 48 percent. But the numbers are all close and fall within the poll’s margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

headline: For the Record
text: In last Friday’s editorial about the administration official who urged corporations to punish lawyers for representing Guantánamo detainees: Charles Stimson is a deputy assistant secretary of defense, not state.

headline: Colts Take Cue From Balanced Dungy
text: Now for a pause in Indianapolis’s Super Bowl party.

headline: Hoboken: Councilman’s Lawyer Cites Lapse in Judgment
text: In a statement released yesterday, the lawyer for a Hoboken councilman charged on Saturday with drunken driving in Manhattan said his client “realizes this was a lapse in judgment and admits he made a mistake.” The councilman, Christopher Campos, 30, left, who is also a prosecutor in West New York, was charged with driving while intoxicated after he ran a red light on the West Side Highway at 43rd Street about 3 a.m., the police said. Yesterday, his lawyer, Francis S. Cutruzzula, released a statement in which he said Mr. Campos acknowledged that he had made a mistake “and wants to assure everyone that this will never happen again.” A spokesman for David Roberts, the mayor of Hoboken, said that the mayor was “supportive” of Mr. Campos and did not believe that the councilman would need to resign. Mr. Campos did not respond to requests for comment yesterday.

headline: Ruling’s Effect on California Inmates Is Probably Modest
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22  The Supreme Court decision on Monday that invalidated California’s criminal sentencing law would probably affect only a small slice of the state’s convicted felon population.

headline: New Scanners for Tracking City Workers
text: The Bloomberg administration is devoting more than $180 million toward state-of-the-art technology to keep track of when city employees come and go, with one agency requiring its workers to scan their hands each time they enter and leave the workplace.

headline: Partial Bailout Offered in Book Bankruptcy
text: Small publishers left reeling by the major book wholesaler Advanced Marketing Services’ bankruptcy filing last month received a rare bit of good news yesterday.

headline: Individualists, Straddling Cultures and Exporting Ideas
text: World music performers often present themselves as emissaries from a single exotic country. But at the fourth annual Globalfest, a world-music showcase with a dozen acts at Webster Hall on Sunday night, many of the musicians cited dual origins: Cape Verde and Lisbon for Sara Tavares, Colombia and New York City for Lucia Pulido, Cambodia and Los Angeles for the band Dengue Fever, Mexico and Minneapolis for Lila Downs. These are not traditional musicians; they are individualists who happily blend and straddle cultures.

headline: At Princeton, a Parody Raises Questions of Bias
text: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 — Belda Chan, a senior at Princeton University, was stunned when she encountered an article in broken English in the annual joke issue of the student daily parodying an Asian-American student who had filed a civil rights complaint against Princeton.

headline: 2 Car Bombs Kill Scores at Packed Market in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 22 — Two powerful car bombs ripped through a market in central Baghdad on Monday, turning an area crowded with shoppers and commuters into one of the worst scenes of carnage since the war began.

headline: Spanking Is Wrong (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sharpe Is a Showman on the Set and Off
text: Reggie Bush was well on his way to an 88-yard touchdown Sunday when Shannon Sharpe sprung as if catapulted from his chair on the set of CBS’s “The NFL Today” and sprinted to a television screen that stands nearly 9-by-15 feet.

headline: Subpoenas Sought Against 2 Times Reporters
text: A defense lawyer in the case involving Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private eye accused of masterminding a long-running wiretapping ring, called yesterday for two New York Times reporters to be subpoenaed to find out who leaked them recordings of conversations and other evidence in the case.

headline: Another Weekend of Death in Iraq (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hezbollah Strike Brings Beirut to a Virtual Halt
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23 — An opposition protest turned violent today as thousands of Hezbollah supporters blocked roads leading into Beirut, burning tires and cars and clashing with government loyalists. The escalation brought the Lebanese capital to a virtual standstill and heightened fears that the nearly two-month long political crisis could burst into sectarian conflict.

headline: Nicotine Manipulation Confirmed
text: Any doubts that the tobacco industry has surreptitiously raised the nicotine content of cigarettes should be laid to rest by a study from researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health. They confirmed last year’s discovery of the nicotine increase by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and went on to identify how the tobacco companies designed their cigarettes to accomplish this.

headline: And No More Catalogs! (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thousands Mourn Slain Editor in Istanbul
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 23 — Huge crowds of mourners, including senior Turkish and Armenian officials joining for a rare display of unity, poured into the heart of Istanbul today to bid farewell to Hrant Dink, the Armenian-Turkish journalist who was shot and killed on the street in front of his newspaper’s offices last week.

headline: Et Tu, George?
text: Maybe George W. Bush is the education president after all. Whatever one thinks of his No Child Left Behind initiative, he has made the classics powerfully resonant today.

headline: Bush, at Low Point in Polls, Will Push Domestic Agenda
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — Carrying some of the worst public approval ratings of any president in a generation, President Bush is heading into his State of the Union address on Tuesday night seeking to revitalize his domestic agenda but facing stiff resistance over the initiatives the White House has previewed so far.

headline: Global View of U.S. Worsens, Poll Shows
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The global view of the United States’ role in world affairs deteriorated significantly again last year, according to a poll of more than 26,000 people in 25 countries.

headline: Chicago Fed Chief to Retire in August
text: Michael H. Moskow, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, confirmed yesterday that he would retire Aug. 31, leaving a fourth high-level opening at the central bank.

headline: Father of Dead West Bank Girl Seeks Peace With Israelis
text: ANATA, West Bank, Jan. 22 — Even as Bassam Aramin mourns his 10-year-old daughter, killed last week during a clash between stone-throwing Palestinian youths and the Israeli police, he says he wants to talk to Israelis about making peace.

headline: Citigroup to Buy ABN Loan Unit
text: Citigroup agreed to buy the United States wholesale mortgage unit of the Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding for undisclosed terms, the companies said yesterday.

headline: ‘Supreme Conflict’
text: Even as more commentators on both the left and the right are using the adjective “incompetent” to describe the administration of George W. Bush, historians like Douglas Brinkley, Sean Wilentz and Eric Foner have begun to argue that Mr. Bush is in contention for the title of worst president in history, citing reasons like the metastasizing war in Iraq, a ballooning deficit, the mishandling of Hurricane Katrina and a widening credibility gap.

headline: Ethiopia Troops Begin Somalia Exit, General Says
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 23 — The Ethiopian troops who helped install Somalia’s fledging government in Mogadishu, the capital, earlier this month began to pull out today, officials said.

headline: In Arab Capital of U.S., Ethnic Divide Remains
text: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 19 — After the longtime mayor, Michael A. Guido, died of cancer here in December, a flock of Arab-American candidates stepped forward in the hopes of claiming City Hall.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Probation and Fines for Paris Hilton

headline: Amnesiacs May Be Cut Off From Past and Future Alike
text: In the movies amnesia is bizarre, and thrilling. The star is usually a former assassin or government agent whose future depends on retrieving the bloody, jigsaw fragments that restore identity and explain the past.

headline: My Face, My Frizz (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Serbia Vote Could Lead to Coalition of Democrats
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Jan. 22 — Two leading democratic parties emerged Monday as the groups most likely to form a government in Serbia, despite a first-place showing for a nationalist party in the parliamentary elections on Sunday.

headline: Showcasing Talents for Those Who Write the Checks
text: Jazz — or what people can get away with calling jazz — is crucial to the world of American midsize theaters and subscription performing-arts audiences. So jazz becomes extra dynamic for a week in New York around the time of the annual conference of the Association of Performing Arts Presenters. Besides the panels and performances at the New York Hilton, the conference’s home base, clubs around town set up dozens of showcases last week. The biggest was Winter Jazzfest, which took over the Knitting Factory on Saturday night.

headline: Britain: BBC in Talks With YouTube
text: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBC’s programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material.

headline: Bears Coach Smith Reflects on His Roots
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 22 — The mentor and the protégé spoke briefly by telephone Monday. Nothing groundbreaking there. Bears Coach Lovie Smith keeps in touch with Tony Dungy, the Indianapolis Colts’ coach, who gave him his first N.F.L. job more than a decade ago.

headline: Roddick Will Try to Make Semis Interesting for Federer
text: MELBOURNE -- Roger Federer was sitting comfortably, legs crossed, after vanquishing Tommy Robredo in less style than usual in the quarter final round of the Australian Open Tuesday. He was talking just a little wistfully about how great it had been to watch a five-set match the night before when Rafael Nadal’s staying power had gotten the better of Andy Murray’s brain power.

headline: New DVDs:  ‘Films of Kenneth Anger’ and ‘Samurai Classics’
text: FILMS OF KENNETH ANGER, VOLUME 1

headline: Pfizer, Hurt by Rival Drugs, Will Lay Off 7,800
text: Pfizer said yesterday that it would cut 7,800 workers, close several manufacturing and research sites and overhaul its business practices in hopes of coping with competition from cheaper generic drugs and setbacks in developing new products.

headline: The Claim: Drinking Tea Reduces Stress.
text: THE FACTS Some call it nature’s tranquilizer, able to smooth away stress and lift the spirits. But are the stress-reducing powers of tea fact or fiction?

headline: Memo Pad
text: NOT A BAD YEAR FOR AIRLINES  After $35 billion in net losses from 2001 to 2005, the domestic airline industry is expected to earn about $4 billion in 2007 and to report earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion for 2006, the Air Transport Association said. But the Champagne corks are not popping yet. John Heimlich, the trade association’s chief economist, noted that despite cost cutting, reduction in capacity and a decrease in the number of aircraft types flown, “debt levels remain high, leaving airlines vulnerable to fuel spikes” and other risks like a recession, natural disaster or another significant terrorist attack.

headline: Corrections
text: A news analysis article on Sunday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential prospects misstated the results of a recent Washington Post/ABC News poll and erroneously attributed the incorrect number to a statement by her campaign. Mrs. Clinton led Senator Barack Obama in the preference poll of likely Democratic primary voters by 41 percent to 17 percent; she did not hold a 41 percentage point lead over Mr. Obama. The campaign’s statement correctly reflected the polling data; it did not contain the incorrect percentage. (Go to Article)

headline: Under Fire, Gap Chief Steps Down
text: For the last two weeks, the son of Gap’s founders and the board’s chairman, Robert J. Fisher, conducted a series of secret conference calls with fellow directors.

headline: Brazil: Air Controllers Share Collision Blame
text: Government investigators looking into the cause of the midair collision over the Amazon in September that killed 154 people aboard a civilian airliner said for the first time that air traffic controllers were partly to blame. Previously, the authorities had assigned responsibility solely to the two American pilots of the other plane, an executive jet that managed to make an emergency landing without loss of life. The controllers “should have adopted emergency procedures” when the smaller plane could not be located on their radar screens, “but that was not done,” said Renato Sayão, the chief investigator.

headline: Britons Harvest Ship’s Bounty, From BMWs to Bibles
text: LONDON, Jan. 22  Hundreds of people foraged among containers washed from a stricken cargo vessel on the southern English coast on Monday, ignoring health warnings and threats of prosecution and hauling off booty that included BMW motorcycles, shoes, diapers, beauty cream and carpets.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Plain Speaking and Singing on Copland’s Family Farm
text: Aaron Copland worried about the durability of “The Tender Land,” his opera about a traditional, humble, rural 1930s family suspicious of outsiders and their morals. But it seems uncannily relevant: contemporary America is still often touted as a place whose small-town heartland, inhabited by plain-spoken, wary and conservative folk, is framed by cities teeming with deviants and elitists.

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View of Ski Trails’ Perils
text: While a ski trail can provide plenty of enjoyment (at least when there is enough snow to cover it), from an environmental standpoint it is a scar on the landscape. This is especially true for trails constructed below the tree line, where large patches of forest must be clear-cut to make way for skiers.

headline: All Around the Town, Piano Recitals With a Difference
text: The most obvious way to freshen a classical music program is through novel programming. The pianist Wu Han and the cellist David Finckel have proved adept at this so far as music directors of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. The title they devised for the society’s program on Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall might have been trite — “Pianos/Pianists: A Celebration of the Keyboard” — but the concept was imaginative.

headline: Eagles Assistant Joins the Giants
text: The Giants, whose championship hopes this season collapsed when their defense collapsed, turned to their bitter rivals, the Philadelphia Eagles, for a new defensive coordinator.

headline: Bank of America Profit Rises 47%
text: Big gains in equity investments buoyed Bank of America’s earnings in the fourth quarter, which were up 47 percent from the same period in 2005, the bank reported today.

headline: Albany: Increased Disclosure for Legislative Grants
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said yesterday that all future recipients of so-called member items — grants that lawmakers steer to community groups and pet projects in their home districts — would be required to meet detailed new disclosure requirements before the money was disbursed. The recipients would have to reveal any potential conflict of interest with the lawmaker. Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that such conflicts would not necessarily prevent groups from receiving money, but that the new requirements would lend transparency to what has been a highly secretive process. “When people don’t know, people get suspicious,” Mr. Cuomo said.

headline: Helicopter Crashes in Baghdad and 5 Are Killed
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 23 — Five members of a private security detail protecting an American convoy were killed on Tuesday when their helicopter came under attack and plummeted to the pavement through a tangle of electrical wires in one of Baghdad’s most dangerous neighborhoods.

headline: Shutting Doors Where a Drug-Making Giant Began
text: Pfizer is closing the plant in the borough where it was born.

headline: A Career in Letters, 50 Years and Counting
text: Robert Loomis has never been fired. He’s never been lured away from his job as an editor at Random House by a higher salary. His name doesn’t pop up in gossip columns. He has never been caught up in a plagiarism scandal.

headline: On the Scales: For Obese Children, Increased Risks in Surgery
text: The risks associated with the growing problem of obesity among young people may be extending to the operating room table.

headline: Barbaro Loses to Rivals at the Eclipse Awards
text: Barbaro might have been the story of 2006 in thoroughbred racing, but he was neither the Horse of the Year nor the 3-year-old champion. With his career cut short because of the fractured hind leg he sustained during the Preakness Stakes, voters for the Eclipse Awards decided he did not accomplish enough on the racetrack to merit any championship honors.

headline: Abbé Pierre, 94, French Priest Who Aided the Homeless, Dies
text: Abbé Pierre, who in the 1950s as a gaunt priest with a crook-handled cane and a profoundly persuasive passion mobilized France to attend to its homeless, then kept pressing his crusade until he became known as the country’s moral compass, died yesterday in Paris. He was 94.

headline: Records of Arrests at ’04 Convention Can Be Released
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that hundreds of city records, including documents, videotapes and testimony, can be made public in connection with lawsuits brought by people arrested during the 2004 Republican National Convention.

headline: Iran Bars Inspectors; Cleric Criticizes President
text: Correction Appended

headline: Springtime for Ethanol
Debate Grows in Iran Over Nuclear Program
text: Correction Appended

headline: 88 Killed as Car Bombs Devastate Busy Baghdad Market
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 22 — Two powerful car bombs ripped through a market in central Baghdad on Monday, turning an area crowded with shoppers and commuters into one of the worst scenes of carnage since the war began.

headline: Italy: French Bank Reduces a Stake
text: Crédit Agricole, the French bank, sold a 3.6 percent stake in Intesa Sanpaolo for 2.51 billion euros ($3.23 billion), complying with a requirement by Italy’s antitrust authority. After the sale, Crédit Agricole, which is based in Paris, still has shares representing about 5.8 percent of the capital and 5.5 percent of the voting rights of Intesa, which is based in Milan. Crédit Agricole was ordered on Dec. 20 by the Italian antitrust regulator to reduce its stake in the Italian bank.

headline: Keeping Up With Nigeria
text: IN the last six months, media coverage, Congressional hearings, lawsuits by private citizens and a scathing report by the Interior Department’s inspector general have exposed a litany of failures in the department’s management of oil and gas leases on public lands and waters.

headline: For Worse and for Better: Documenting an Obsession
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 — There are no electric cars in “Crazy Love.” No presidential candidates. No cautionary tales about eating too much fast food and no penguins. Instead this latest offering from Dan Klores, the longtime New York publicist turned documentarian, looks squarely at something many of his peers have avoided of late: simple human emotions.

headline: Do You Believe in Magic?
text: A graduate school application can go sour in as many ways as a blind date. The personal essay might seem too eager, the references too casual. The admissions officer on duty might be nursing a grudge. Or a hangover.

headline: Parcells Tells the Cowboys He Is Retiring From Coaching
text: IRVING, Tex., Jan. 22  Bill Parcells dutifully kept regular office hours, even as he kept the Dallas Cowboys in the dark for the past 15 days.

headline: Lack of Budget Could Hurt Nuclear Energy Revival, Official Says
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  The senior member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission warned on Monday that the failure of Congress to pass a detailed budget for the current fiscal year could damage the nuclear renaissance that the government tried so hard to encourage with the energy bill of 2005.

headline: Bridgeport: Choir Director Admits Possession of Pornography
text: The former music director of Christ Church in Greenwich pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to possession of child pornography, a charge that carries a maximum penalty of 10 years. Assuring the court that he would check himself into a medical center pending sentencing, the former director, Robert F. Tate, was released after posting a $500,000 bond secured by rental property he owns in Stamford and the pledge of several supporters who agreed to cover the balance. Prosecutors told the court that they confiscated electronic materials that contained 150 to 300 sexually explicit images of young children from Mr. Tate’s housing at the Episcopal church. Asked by Judge Alan H. Nevas whether he was pleading guilty because he was guilty, Mr. Tate, 64, said that “sad to say, I am.” A woman whose husband co-signed the bond, Evelyn Bausman, told a reporter that she believed Mr. Tate’s admission of guilt. Asked then why she stood by him, she said, “Well, we’re all sinners.”

headline: Manhattan: Ex-Guard Sentenced for Sex With Inmate
text: A former federal prison guard was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday for having sexual contact with an inmate and making false statements to investigators, prosecutors said. The former guard, Nicholas Defonte, 49, of Staten Island, was sentenced to 18 months in prison, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said Mr. Defonte had sexual contact with the female inmate while he supervised the kitchen at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan in 2001. A jury in April acquitted Mr. Defonte of two counts of sexual abuse, but convicted him of sexual activity with an inmate.

headline: Somali Islamists’ No. 2 Leader Surrenders in Kenyan Capital
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 22 — The second in command of Somalia’s defeated Islamist forces has surrendered to the Kenyan authorities and is staying at a hotel in Nairobi, Western diplomats and Somali officials said Monday.

headline: Bush Calls for Increase in Renewable Fuels
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — President Bush, vowing to reduce the nation’s thirst for foreign oil, called tonight for a huge government-mandated increase in renewable fuels — mainly ethanol — and tougher mileage standards for cars and light trucks.

headline: Switzerland: Bank Plans a Share Buyback
text: The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss bank, will use proceeds from the sale of its Winterthur insurance unit to buy back a record amount of stock and make money-management acquisitions. The bank plans to repurchase as much as 8 billion francs ($6.4 billion) of shares over three years and has set aside 3.5 billion francs for possible takeovers in the United States, the Middle East and Asia. “We have the requisite resources to grow our business, while at the same time returning capital to our shareholders,” the chief executive, Oswald J. Grübel, told investors in Zurich. Credit Suisse completed the sale of Winterthur to Axa of France for 12.3 billion francs last month.

headline: Shuffle or Sharpie? Harrison Takes the Points
text: By the way, Marvin Harrison is going to the Super Bowl, too.

headline: On Web, Voters Question Clinton Directly
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton strived for an Oprah moment yesterday night, the third of her presidential campaign, by sitting in a fake living-room set and fielding questions on a live video Webcast about her vote for the Iraq war (if she had known then), universal health care (still wants it) and her favorite movies (“The Wizard of Oz,” “Casablanca” and “Out of Africa”).

headline: Corrections
text: A news analysis article on Sunday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential prospects misstated the results of a recent Washington Post/ABC News poll and erroneously attributed the incorrect number to a statement by her campaign. Mrs. Clinton led Senator Barack Obama in the preference poll of likely Democratic primary voters by 41 percent to 17 percent; she did not hold a 41 percentage point lead over Mr. Obama. The campaign’s statement correctly reflected the polling data; it did not contain the incorrect percentage.

headline: Bush Revives Some Past Proposals, but Breaks Little New Ground on Domestic Issues
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — President Bush delivered a domestic agenda to Congressional Democrats on Tuesday that was, in large part, modest and a reiteration of past proposals. Where he did break ground — on health care — his initiative was quickly dismissed by leading Democrats and seemed unlikely to form the basis of bipartisan action.

headline: A Daughter Proves She’s of the Same Stripe
text: In the early hours of a quiet morning in May 1986, Mickey Crowley jumped out of bed to answer the doorbell at his home in Centereach on Long Island.

headline: An Old Cholesterol Remedy Is New Again
text: Perhaps you heard it? The wail last month from the labs of heart researchers and the offices of Wall Street analysts?

headline: Love Ya, Really, From Way Over Here
text: Talk about phoning it in. President Bush’s opposition to abortion is well known, but every Jan. 22, when opponents of abortion descend on Washington to protest on the anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade, the president manages to be out of town, addressing protesters by telephone, not in person.

headline: The Vroom of the Engines, the Pride of the Clubs
text: AT times some behaved like gossipy girls, eyeing a rival clique as they passed by.

headline: N.J. Transit Proposes 10 Percent Fare Increase
text: The outgoing head of the New Jersey Transit system proposed today a 10 percent fare increase for the nation’s largest statewide public transit system.

headline: From Pakistan, With Jihad
text: To learn why a resurgent Taliban is fighting American and NATO troops to a military draw in Afghanistan, you have to go to the frontier region on both sides of the Pakistan-Afghanistan border.

headline: New Jersey Senate Passes Two Bills Meant to Cut Costs
text: TRENTON, Jan. 22  The New Jersey State Senate passed bills on Monday intended to save money by consolidating local governments and by taking away portions of pensions of public officials convicted of corruption.

headline: What’s on Tuesday Night
text: 9 P.M. (Major Networks) STATE OF THE UNION 2007 President George W. Bush addresses Congress and the nation. Analysis follows.

headline: Israel’s President to Be Indicted in Rape Case
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23 — Israel’s attorney general plans to indict the country’s president, Moshe Katsav, on charges of rape and other sexual offenses, the Justice Ministry announced today.

headline: Manhattan: Student Dies in Fall From Roof
text: A 21-year-old Hunter College student was killed yesterday in a fall from the rooftop of a 20-story college building on East 67th Street near Lexington Avenue, the police said. The student, Anton Frolov of Brooklyn, had been escorted from the roof moments before by security guards responding to an alarm that sounded when he went outside, the police said. But minutes later, he went back outside, the police said, and fell before the guards returned. The police said they were investigating the possibility that he had jumped. The student’s landing was so loud that 911 callers reported the sound of gunfire or an exploding bomb, the police said. David Sanchez, 45, a custodian in the building, said, “I was inside on the first floor taking care of the trash when I heard a big bang, like a really loud noise.”

headline: In the Vortex of Baghdad, Staying Put This Time
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 22 — Two blocks from the new American outpost in Ghazaliya, one of Baghdad’s most dangerous neighborhoods, a fight was raging. Shiites were battling Sunnis, the latest skirmish in a sectarian war that has left this area a wasteland.

headline: Fighting Drug Abuse (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bach’s Strolls and Puzzles in All Keys, Major and Minor
text: The two books of Bach’s “Well-Tempered Clavier” contain an immense amount of music. Their 48 preludes and fugues touch not only on every major and minor key, twice, but also on just about every way an 18th-century musician might have conceived and executed either form.

headline: Canadian to Remain on U.S. Terrorist Watch List
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — Despite a Canadian inquiry that cleared a Syrian-born Canadian citizen of any terrorist ties, the Bush administration has formally refused a Canadian government request that it remove the man, Maher Arar, from the terrorist watch list, saying that the United States has secret information justifying his inclusion.

headline: E. Howard Hunt, Watergate Figure, Dies at 88
text: E. Howard Hunt, a cold warrior for the Central Intelligence Agency who left the spy service in disillusion, joined the Nixon White House as a secret agent and bungled the break-in at the Watergate that brought the president down in disgrace, died today in Miami. He was 88.

headline: Five New Satellites With a Mission of Finding a Source of Color in Space
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — NASA will soon launch a fleet of five spacecraft in hopes of solving the mystery of how the greenish auroras above the Earth’s poles suddenly burst into shimmering multicolor lights.

headline: Report Accuses Belfast Police of Collusion in Gang Killings
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 22  Northern Ireland’s police ombudsman, in a report on Monday, accused the province’s police force of collusion with at least one loyalist Protestant gang in a number of killings and attempted killings and serious drug crimes.

headline: Yonkers: City Agrees to Bronx River Cleanup Plan
text: The City of Yonkers has agreed to end its four-year opposition to a state plan to clean up the city’s discharge of sewage into the Bronx River, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The settlement, approved earlier this month by a State Supreme Court justice in Westchester County, calls for the city to pay $2.2 million for a study to identify sources of pollution and then to promptly clean up the sites identified by the study.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 4 and Wounds 23 in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 22  A suicide bomber rammed his explosive-laden car into a military convoy near Mirali in the restive North Waziristan tribal region on Monday, killing 4 people and wounding 23, witnesses said.

headline: Record Labels Contemplate Unrestricted Digital Music
text: CANNES, France, Jan. 22 — As even digital music revenue growth falters because of rampant file-sharing by consumers, the major record labels are moving closer to releasing music on the Internet with no copying restrictions — a step they once vowed never to take.

headline: Police Tied to Murder of Russian Journalist
text: MOSCOW, Jan 23 — Police officials in Chechnya are under criminal investigation for a possible role in the murder of Anna Politkovskaya, the prominent Russian journalist, a New York-based media rights group said here today.

headline: Louisiana: Congressman to Run for Governor
text: Representative Bobby Jindal, Republican of Louisiana, said he would enter the 2007 governor’s race, his second attempt at winning the office. Mr. Jindal will be running against a weakened incumbent, Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco, a Democrat. Ms. Blanco defeated Mr. Jindal by four percentage points in 2003, but her standing was damaged after Hurricane Katrina. Mr. Jindal, 35, has also been the secretary of the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals and an assistant secretary at the federal Department of Health and Human Services in the Bush administration.

headline: Veteran of Lebanon Campaigns Is Set to Lead Israeli Army
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 22 — A former infantry officer who commanded Israeli troops against Hezbollah in southern Lebanon for many years was appointed Monday as the Israeli military’s new chief of staff.

headline: General Calls Iraq Situation ‘Dire’
text: “The situation in Iraq is dire,” Lt. Gen. David Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee today. But he said the planned increase in troop levels and new tactics should enable American and Iraqi forces to provide security in Baghdad.

headline: Detention Is Urged for African TB Cases
text: LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP)  A team of doctors has recommended forcibly detaining people in South Africa who refuse treatment for a drug-resistant form of tuberculosis, an extreme measure meant to keep the infected away from others to curb the spread of the disease, according to a paper published Monday in an international medical journal.

headline: Expect Havoc Near Brooklyn Bridge, but It’s Just for a Movie
text: Do not be alarmed, the police warned New Yorkers yesterday, should they see Army and Coast Guard helicopters or police and military vehicles swarming near the Brooklyn Bridge tonight. It’s just a movie: in this case, a film starring Will Smith about the last human in New York.

headline: State Farm Settles Katrina Claims in Mississippi
