text: State Farm, the nation’s largest home insurer, reached an agreement today with Mississippi officials to pay hundreds of millions dollars to thousands of homeowners in the state who have been unable to rebuild in the nearly 17 months since Hurricane Katrina swept across the Gulf Coast.

headline: A Humorist Illuminates the Blessings of Hospice
text: As the self-described “man who would not die,” the humor columnist Art Buchwald was a strange bedfellow with the hospice movement. But in the months between the end of his extended hospice stay and his death from kidney failure on Wednesday at age 81, Mr. Buchwald was a living testimonial to the benefits of hospice care.

headline: Bloomberg’s School Push (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: European Trade Negotiator Sees Some Hope
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 22 — The European Union’s chief trade negotiator said Monday that efforts to restart stalled global trade talks were showing new vigor. But he sought to discourage expectations that a breakthrough could come during a meeting of trade ministers this week alongside the Global Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Here, There and in Iowa
text: One of the striking things about the 2008 presidential campaign is the number of stages it is being played on at once. Take today in Washington, for example, where things will be happening on two fronts. The afternoon brings a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee, a platform that could display the sharply contrasting views on Iraq of Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York. The evening brings the president’s State of the Union address, which many Democrats — notably Mrs. Clinton — view as providing an opportunity to tee off to advance their own presidential campaigns.

headline: State Panel to Scrutinize 17 Hopefuls for Comptroller
text: ALBANY, Jan. 22 — If only Flavor Flav had thrown his oversize clock into the ring, it might have made a good reality television show.

headline: In the Background, You Just May Hear the Past
text: When you listen to the songs of Michael Franks, a creator of impressionistic pop-jazz pastels, there is always the question of how to frame his exquisite, whimsical miniatures. On 16 albums recorded over more than three decades, the most common solution has been to present them as smooth jazz. But if you pay close attention to the lyrics of songs like “The Cool School,” a nostalgic ode to the jazz cats of the 50s and early 60s on his newest album, “Rendezvous in Rio” (Koch), you will realize that Mr. Franks’s heart belongs to a purer musical era.

headline: Manhattan: Call for Aid to 9/11 Workers
text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer and Representatives Carolyn B. Maloney, Jerrold L. Nadler and Vito J. Fossella held a news conference at ground zero yesterday to urge President Bush to provide money for monitoring and treating rescue workers, volunteers and firefighters who became ill after helping with the 9/11 cleanup and recovery. “This is an issue that demands attention from the president and the Congress,” Mrs. Clinton said, adding, “I believe this is a moral responsibility.” Last month, officials warned that federal money set aside for treating the workers would run out in a few months. To draw attention to the issue, several of the lawmakers said they had invited 9/11 first responders and some of their relatives as their guests for the president’s State of the Union address tonight.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,022 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: 2 Nations Seek American Antimissile Defense
text: BERLIN, Jan. 23 — The United States will start formal negotiations this year with Poland and the Czech Republic on the deployment of an antimissile defense system meant to protect them from possible attacks by rogue states or terrorist groups, government officials said today.

headline: Armenian Editor’s Death Leads to Conciliation
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 22 — The killing of an Armenian-Turkish editor in Istanbul last week and the sorrow it has generated within Turkey are leading to rare conciliatory gestures between Turkey and Armenia, historic enemies, and to calls for changes in laws here defending Turkish identity.

headline: Consequences: Gun Ownership Linked to Higher Homicide Rates
text: States with the greatest number of guns in the home also have the highest rates of homicide, a new study finds.

headline: A Note to Women Travelers: Be Too Cute to Leave Behind
text: MOST frequent travelers like their passports, with all those exotic stamps. But the passport photo is another matter. Many people hate theirs. Mine, for example, looks like Dick Cheney after two hard days in a drizzly duck blind.

headline: Death Knell May Be Near for Public Election Funds
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — The public financing system for presidential campaigns, a post-Watergate initiative hailed for decades as the best way to rid politics of the corrupting influence of money, may have quietly died over the weekend.

headline: Grand Jury Weighs Case of a Killing by the Police
text: A Queens grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday in the police shooting of Sean Bell, an unarmed black man who was killed in a hail of police bullets on his wedding day in November.

headline: The 2008 Race Heats Up Early (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Shuffle Roils Waters at Citigroup
text: Citigroup shuffled its management ranks yesterday for the second time in a little more than a month in a shake-up that raises questions about the bank’s ability to turn itself around.

headline: Libby Jury Seated; Arguments May Start Today
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — The judge in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. seated a jury of nine women and three men on Monday who are expected to spend a month or longer hearing the case against Vice President Dick Cheney’s former top aide.

headline: Allied Is Asked to Remove Management
text: Greenlight Capital, the hedge fund, asked the Allied Capital Corporation in a letter yesterday to replace senior managers after the indictment of an executive at an affiliated company.

headline: Berkeley Township: Body Found in Woods Is Identified
text: A young woman found dead on Sunday under a pile of trash has been identified as Illeana Hess, 17, of Toms River, Thomas F. Kelaher, the Ocean County prosecutor, said yesterday. Ms. Hess was last seen alive by her father on Dec. 31 at her home on Morris Avenue and had been reported missing, said Capt. Jeff Harper of the Ocean County Prosecutor’s Office. Ms. Hess’s body was discovered near 3 p.m. Sunday by a man scavenging through garbage in a wooded area near Dover Road. The body showed no signs of trauma, Captain Harper said. He added that because Ms. Hess was buried under trash, “it appears she was put there.” Her death is considered suspicious, he said, and a toxicology report is pending.

headline: Acquisition Ban Lifted at Career Education
text: The Career Education Corporation, which operates more than 80 campuses in the United States and overseas, said yesterday that the Education Department lifted a ban imposed in June 2005 that limited acquisitions and expansion.

headline: Two Power Plants Win a Lawsuit, and Property Taxes Rise Drastically in Several Towns
text: GARNERVILLE, N.Y.— Barbara Bodnar, a retired nurse having lunch one recent afternoon at Sparky’s Diner in this Rockland County hamlet of 9,000 people, saw her annual property tax jump $7,200 in the fall. David Clark, the owner of REC supply, a hardware store in Haverstraw, said his taxes doubled. Danny Li’s rose 93 percent — and seven neighbors put their houses up for sale.

headline: Chemical Insecurity
text: The new Democratic leadership in Congress has a chance to finally do what the Republican Congress and the Bush administration failed to do after Sept. 11: to protect the nation’s chemical plants from an attack. Lawmakers should stop the Homeland Security Department from adopting new regulations that would block state and local governments from doing more to protect their residents and should pass a federal law with teeth.

headline: Vatican City: John Paul II Pondered Quitting in 2000, Aide Says
text: As his health grew worse, Pope John Paul II discussed with top aides the possibility of resigning in 2000, Cardinal Stanislaw Dziwisz, his personal secretary for 40 years, says in a new book. Among those he consulted was Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, who became Pope Benedict XVI after John Paul died in 2005. John Paul “came to the conclusion that he had to submit to God’s will, that is, to remain as long as God wanted,” Cardinal Dziwisz wrote in the book, called “A Life With Karol,” the pope’s given name.

headline: Florida Acts to Lower Home Insurance Cost
text: MIAMI, Jan. 22 — Struggling to fulfill a campaign promise made last fall by virtually every Florida lawmaker, the Legislature approved a series of measures Monday that would reduce home insurance rates — modestly, for the most part — by having the state take on billions of dollars in additional insurance risk.

headline: A Dose of Maturity for a California Protest
text: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 22 — It is not every day that tree-sitters are older than the tree, but on Monday three environmental activists with a combined age of 247 climbed into an oak tree here for an hour to protest a hotly contested building plan.

headline: The Mystery of the Chinese Baby Shortage
text: McLean, Va.

headline: Mayors Urge Crackdown on Illegal Guns
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — Mayors from some of the nation’s largest cities gathered here today to urge Congress to crack down on the sale of illegal firearms. But their expanding coalition, led by Mayors Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston, has begun to encounter resistance among some advocates for gun owners.

headline: Outsider to His Kin, but a Ghost No More
text: Their flight from Los Angeles had arrived nearly three hours late, but travel fatigue couldn’t keep Maria Ramirez-Miller, her six daughters and a granddaughter from scampering out of their Manhattan hotel rooms and onto West 53rd Street on Friday around midnight.

headline: Europe Encouraging Clean Energy Industry
text: PARIS — The cloudy Welsh coast may seem an odd choice for making solar panels, especially for a bigwig like Robert M. Hertzberg, a Californian who has hobnobbed with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger. But a commitment by European governments to helping out “clean energy” entrepreneurs is creating a more welcoming environment than America, where erratic support, a lackluster market for taking companies public, along with more onerous financial rules, have given pause to some start-ups and investors.

headline: REIT to Consider Another Takeover Bid
text: Equity Office Properties, which agreed in November to be bought by a private equity company, the Blackstone Group, for $36 billion, including debt, said yesterday that it would begin discussions with a rival group that has offered to top that price.

headline: Bush Offers Broad Goals  for Last 2 Years
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — President Bush sketched out a wide-ranging international and domestic agenda tonight, including energy proposals meant to end the country’s dependence on foreign oil, in his first State of the Union address to a Democratic-controlled Congress and the last before the country turns its attention more fully to the presidential election in 2008.

headline: Thousands of Abortion Opponents Rally on Mall
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — They marched down Seventh Street on Monday chanting, singing and eventually flooding onto the Mall to show disapproval on the 34th anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision that legalized abortion.

headline: Grisly Details Bared as Serial Killing Trial Begins in Canada
text: NEW WESTMINSTER, British Columbia, Jan. 22 — The murder trial of the man accused of the largest number of serial killings recorded in Canada began here on Monday with grisly details of how the police found the dismembered hands and feet and severed heads of women on his pig farm.

headline: Fighting Depression Since 12, She Has a Tailor-Made Job
text: The pain weighs heavily on her. It always has. “I was depressed from very, very young,” said Heather Eicholz, a case manager at a social service agency on Long Island.

headline: In Douglass Tribute, Slave Folklore and Fact Collide
text: At the northwest corner of Central Park, construction is under way on Frederick Douglass Circle, a $15.5 million project honoring the escaped slave who became a world-renowned orator and abolitionist.

headline: Spitzer Picks Pennsylvanian to Spur Upstate Economy
text: ALBANY, Jan. 22  Gov. Eliot Spitzer poached one of Pennsylvania’s top economic development officials on Monday to give him a similar job in New York as part of Mr. Spitzer’s effort to rebuild western New York’s stagnant economy.

headline: The Knicks Look Bad, and Marbury Feels Worse
text: MIAMI, Jan. 22 — Disaster took on many forms for the Knicks on Monday night. Had a 28-point first-quarter deficit been the worst of it, they might have left South Florida feeling grateful.

headline: All Breast Cancer Patients Are Not Treated the Same
text: When women with low incomes or low levels of education start chemotherapy for breast cancer, they routinely get insufficient doses, a new study suggests. That may be one reason they are less likely to survive the disease than other women.

headline: Suicide Bomb Targets NATO Base in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 23 — A suicide bomber wearing a vest full of explosives blew himself up at the entrance of a NATO base in the southeastern province of Khost today, killing as many as 10 people, officials said.

headline: Quartet’s Harmonic Voices, Pleasure Clearly Understood
text: In 1562 the Council of Trent recommended that church Masses be written with singing “constituted not to give empty pleasure to the ear, but so that the words may be understood clearly by everyone, and that thus the hearts of listeners may be drawn to the desire of heavenly harmony.”

headline: With Two Deals Stalled, Joke Never Gets Started
text: You would think that when the Red Sox won the 2004 World Series, it would have liberated their fans, enabled all of them to smile and laugh.

headline: Key Republican Senator Offers Bipartisan Call to Reject Bush Plan for More Troops in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 — Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, one of Congress’s leading authorities on the military, presented a bipartisan proposal on Monday that soundly rejected President Bush’s plan to send more American troops to Baghdad and urged the administration to find a new course in Iraq.

headline: Nascar Adds Two Drivers to the Chase
text: CONCORD, N.C., Jan. 22  The field for the annual Chase for the Nextel Cup will expand this year to 12 drivers from 10, one of several adjustments to the points and playoff systems announced Monday.

headline: Recognizing a Sacred Bond Sometimes Obscured
text: I carry the card in the glove compartment of my car. It is not a Valentine’s card from my wife, or a graduation card from my mother. It is a simple greeting card, with a cheerful watercolor of wildflowers, sent to me by a patient I cared for after moving to Memphis.

headline: Study Says Tapping of Granite Could Unleash Energy Source
text: The United States could generate as much electricity by 2050 as that flowing today from all of the country’s nuclear power plants by developing technologies that tap heat locked in deep layers of granite, according to a new study commissioned by the Energy Department.

headline: Illinois Is Putting Lottery on Block for Quick Payoff
text: The state of Illinois yesterday took the first steps in selling its state lottery system, hoping to attract as much as $10 billion from investors who, in return, would own a monopoly that could turn out to be the biggest jackpot yet.

headline: Regional Carrier to Become a Unit of Northwest
text: Northwest Airlines will take control of Mesaba Airlines, the bankrupt regional carrier, in a step toward its own exit from bankruptcy.

headline: A Turbulent Life Is Described by the Family of a Killer
text: Robert Earl Barnes was holding a 40-ounce bottle of Colt 45 when the big marble ashtray came crashing down, according to one witness. Mr. Barnes’s wife, Cheryl Wilson, was at the other end of the ashtray. The children watched the shards disperse across his skull. Depetra was 10, Ronell 1, and the youngest about a month old. Mr. Barnes lifted a finger to his hairline.

headline: Sun Microsystems Will Use Intel Chips
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 — Sun Microsystems and Intel, two technology companies that have rarely found themselves on the same side of the aisle, announced a deal on Monday for Sun to use Intel chips in some of its computer servers, a setback for the rival chip maker Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: Scrambling to Get Hold of a Passport
text: The new requirement that Americans use a passport when they fly between the United States and any point in the Western Hemisphere has significantly increased demand for passports, testing the processing capabilities of federal offices, travel industry officials say.

headline: House of Style (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Yankee Chef With a Mexican Flavor
text: ON a train from Dublin to Shannon recently, I struck up a conversation with an elderly man sitting across from me.

headline: Tapping the Stuff Dreams Are Made Of
text: AS another Oscar season gets under way, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences faces a conundrum: Is what we have here a failure to communicate, or is this the beginning of a beautiful friendship?

headline: Back to a Future Unmade: Glittering, Playful Varèse
text: In the 1920s and 1930s and in the 1950s Edgard Varèse wrote music of the future. It was the same future that the spires and silvery arcs of the Empire State and Chrysler buildings were pointing to, streamlined and shining, later outlined in visions of flying cars and mechanized houses and space travel. But that future never came; and seen from the vantage point of the future that happened instead, those visions can seem both farsighted and slightly, wistfully dated. So can Varèse’s music.

headline: Screening: Making a Case for Early Testing for Skin Cancer
text: If doctors began a broad screening program for early signs of melanoma, they might find any number of cases soon enough to save lives. But would it be worth the cost?

headline: White Doctors, Black Subjects: Abuse Disguised as Research
text: The most notorious medical experiment in American history was surely the Tuskegee syphilis study, in which 400 black men with syphilis were left untreated for 40 years, from 1932 until 1972, so government doctors could study the course of the disease. The experiment ended only because a journalist exposed it, igniting a firestorm of public outrage over its racism and cruelty. By then, as many as 100 of the men had already died of syphilis.

headline: Police May Get an Academy That Can Fit All Its Recruits
text: The newest crop of New York’s finest stepped into the crisp Manhattan night, another day at the police academy behind them. Briskly, they crossed the academy’s plaza, where new recruits assemble in tidy formations each day. Their hair was neatly shorn. Their shoes were polished to a high shine. They were silhouetted by a moldering mountain of garbage, piled high to the left of the academy’s front door on East 20th Street.

headline: Facing a Congress With a Decidedly New Look
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — The first two words of the evening were evidence of how much has changed here: “Madam Speaker,” came the introduction.,“the president of the United States.”

headline: A Sleepy City on the Steppe Fears Hordes of High Rollers
text: KAPCHAGAI, Kazakhstan — The town’s chief administrator sat next to an office window overlooking rows of dilapidated four-story, Soviet-era apartment buildings in this grim industrial town. As he looked down at the rooftops, he considered the potential impact of dozens — perhaps even hundreds — of casinos and thousands of gaming arcades setting up shop in this region.

headline: Aging:  Study Questions Limits on Sedatives for Elderly
text: When federal and state officials began trying to limit sedative prescriptions for the elderly nearly two decades ago, the expectation was that doctors would see fewer hip fractures in their frail patients.

headline: Orbitz’s Parent Company Hires Adviser for Possible Offering
text: Less than six months after leaving the public markets, the travel Web site Orbitz.com may be contemplating a return trip.

headline: A Trial to Remember
text: Who knew that 12 angry Americans could be so easy to come by — and a jury so difficult to assemble? “It took us all day to get six jurors qualified,” Judge Reggie M. Walton lamented last Thursday, after a contentious afternoon of voir dire in the Scooter Libby trial. Judge Walton had hoped to have seated his panel by then; selection took twice as long as expected. Opening arguments are scheduled for today, not the sort of trailer you would normally run before a State of the Union address.

headline: Hospitals and Their Workers Reach a Pact on Health Care
text: Hospitals in New York City and the largest health care union have agreed on a new contract that bails out the union’s ailing health care benefits fund, officials said yesterday.

headline: Macao Surpasses Las Vegas as Gambling Center
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 23 — Macao surpassed the Las Vegas Strip to become the world’s biggest gambling center in 2006, measured by total gambling revenue, according to industry analysts and government figures released today.

headline: Ending the Curse of Cursive
text: At long last, National Handwriting Day has arrived. And with your help, we have some data to answer the great question of the day.

headline: Waiting for the Sun
text: The Bagger will be “in position” as they say, fortifying himself with gratis bagels and coffee at Academy headquarters on Wilshire Blvd in Los Angeles, and awaiting the Oscar nomination press conference. Assuming he doesn’t perish from all the excitement, he will bring you news and some quick analysis at 9:00 a.m., with video and futher deconstruction later in the day. Please talk amongst yerselves in the meantime.

headline: Got Yogurt?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Excerpts From the State of the Union
text: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address on the State of the Union, as released by the White House.

headline: A Groovy Italian Village
text: Calcata, north of Rome, is home to all kinds of artists.

headline: 36 Hours in Madrid
text: Spend a weekend in a city that is fast-forwarding to the 21st century.

headline: China Confirms Test of Anti-Satellite Weapon
text: BEIJING, Jan. 23 – The Chinese government confirmed today that it had conducted a successful test of a new anti-satellite weapon, but said it had no intention of participating in a "space race."

headline: Davos in the Papers: Google, Trade Talks, Dark Rooms
text: The World Economic Forum in Davos has yet to start and already reports are surfacing about the first deal to be announced there. The Guardian wrote Monday that the British Broadcasting Company was in talks with Google to make programming available through a branded channel on YouTube, the video site the Internet giant bought last year for $1.65 billion.

headline: More Deals Likely in Storage Sector, Report Says
text: Isilon‘s successful initial public offering could inspire other midrange data-storage companies to make a similar move, The 451 Group suggests in a report. The firm also predicts that other storage companies will get snapped up by acquirers such as Hewlett-Packard, Sun, or even longer shots such as Microsoft or fresh-out-of-bankruptcy SGI.

headline: Endemol Leaves Disney Cold, Report Says
text: A source told Reuters in no uncertain terms that Walt Disney is not interested in buying Telefonica‘s 75 percent stake in the TV producer Endemol. The cryptically worded message: “We are not interested in it,” the source said. Disney was touted on Monday as possibly being interested with Endemol co-founder John de Mol in forming an alliance to repurchase the Dutch production house.

headline: Partial Bailout Offered in Book Bankruptcy
text: Small publishers left reeling by the bankruptcy filing of the book wholesaler Advanced Marketing Services last month received a rare bit of good news on Monday. The Perseus Books Group announced that it was offering to acquire the distribution contracts of about 150 book publishers who employ Publishers Group West, a subsidiary of Advanced Marketing Services, as their book distributor. Perseus promised to pay 70 cents for every dollar owed to the publishers, an amount that could total $20 million if all the publishers accepted the deal.

headline: Illinois Is Putting Lottery on Block for Quick Payoff
text: The state of Illinois took the first steps in selling its state lottery system yesterday, hoping to attract as much as $10 billion from investors who, in return, would own a monopoly that could turn out to be the biggest jackpot yet. The sale, which may occur as early as the spring, would not be the first privatization of public property – both Chicago and Indiana have recently earned billions of dollars by signing long-term leases with private companies to run toll roads. But the proposed lottery sale is almost certain be one of the largest privatizations of a state-run program, and it raises concerns that states, some of them critically short of cash, are selling valuable assets that could otherwise provide consistent streams of revenue.

headline: Democratic Response of Senator Jim Webb to the President’s State of the Union Address
text: Good evening.

headline: Mesaba to Fly Under Northwest’s Wing
text: Northwest Airlines will take control of Mesaba Airlines, the bankrupt regional carrier, in a step toward its own exit from bankruptcy. Mesaba will become a unit of Northwest under an agreement with Mesaba’s parent, Mair Holdings, the companies said Monday. Northwest, Mair’s largest shareholder, will sell its stake back to Mair for $35 million in exchange for Mesaba’s shares now held by Mair. Mesaba will get a claim of $145 million against Northwest that it will sell to pay off its creditors.

headline: Hedge Fund Asks Allied to Dump Management
text: Greenlight Capital, the hedge fund, asked Allied Capital in a letter Monday to replace senior managers after the indictment of an executive at an affiliated company. In the letter, Greenlight accused Allied of knowingly making unlawful loans through Business Loan Express. Greenlight said it sent Allied directors a letter requesting that the “the present management team” be replaced.

headline: Acquisition Ban Lifted at Career Education
text: The Career Education Corporation, which operates more than 80 campuses in the United States and overseas, said Monday that the Education Department lifted a ban imposed in June 2005 that limited acquisitions and expansion. The Education Department said eight months ago that it was satisfied with the results of a financial audit review at Career Education that prompted the restriction. The company’s founder, John Larson, retired in December.

headline: Icahn Backs Three for Cyberonics Board
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said on Monday that he planned to back three nominees by Metropolitan Capital Advisors to the board of Cyberonics, a medical device maker under investigation for its stock options dating practices. Mr. Icahn holds a 9.77 percent stake in Cyberonics, which is scheduled to have its annual stockholders meeting on Feb. 1, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Company management is trying to have shareholders re-elect three directors; Metropolitan Capital wants to replace all three.

headline: Restatement by Take-Two Over Problems With Options
text: Take-Two Interactive Software, maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, said Monday that it let its former chief executive, Ryan A. Brant, “control and dominate” improper options backdating that began when the company went public in 1997. The compensation committee abdicated its responsibilities for the grants and failed to maintain proper controls, the company said in a regulatory filing. Take-Two will restate results from 1997 to 2003 to reflect options costs.

headline: Nasdaq Forecasts Earnings Pressure at L.S.E.
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market on Tuesday told shareholders of the London Stock Exchange that growth forecasts for the British market are ambitious and warned that customers will demand further price cuts, pressuring earnings. In a letter to the exchange’s shareholders, Nasdaq also criticized the British exchange for refusing to discuss a takeover, even though its chief, Clara Furse, has said a deal could be a positive move.

headline: Venture Capitalists Favored Tech Last Year
text: Venture capital investments in high-tech and life sciences start-ups climbed 12 percent to $25.5 billion in 2006, from $22.7 billion the prior year, according to the MoneyTree survey released Monday. The increase marked the third consecutive year of higher outlays for the firms that supply financial fuel for the nation’s entrepreneurial economy. Last year’s venture capital investment level was the highest since 2001, the last big financing year before the dot-com bust.

headline: China Mobile Dials Up Deal for Paktel
text: China Mobile, already the world’s largest mobile phone company, is making its first overseas acquisition by buying a majority stake in Paktel, a mobile phone company in Pakistan, for $284 million. China Mobile agreed to buy an 89 percent stake in the company, which is owned by Millicom International Cellular of Luxemberg.

headline: Publicis Denies Aegis Bid Rumors
text: Publicis, the advertising group, has denied market speculation that it is preparing a bid for the British media group Aegis. Publicis, which is finalizing a $1.3 billion deal to acquire the North American new media group Digitas, said that the rumors were “groundless.”

headline: Judge Won’t Block Nardelli’s Pay
text: A Georgia state judge on Monday refused to block the severance pay of Home Depot‘s former chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, but gave plaintiffs time to gather more information in the case. “On the injunction, I’m going to deny it with the proviso that I may consider it at a later date,” Judge Craig Schwall of Fulton County Superior Court said at a hearing. He said it would give lawyers for shareholders who sought to block the exit pay 60 days to depose company directors and compile more information.

headline: Attorney General Shake-Up May Delay Options Inquiries
text: The recent shake-up in the United States Attorney’s office in San Francisco could lead to delays in the office’s wide-ranging backdating investigation, according to The San Jose Mercury News. The turnover, which includes the departure of a United States Attorney, Kevin Ryan, comes as the government’s scrutiny of options backdating at Apple appears to be heating up. Federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission officials interviewed Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, last week as part of that investigation, the newspaper said.

headline: Cemex Extends Rinker Bid
text: Cemex, the world’s third-largest cement maker, extended its $11.7 billion hostile takeover bid for Australia’s Rinker Group by two months while it waits for U.S. regulatory approval. Cemex’s $13-a-share offer for Australia’s biggest building materials company will now end March 30, the Monterrey, Mexico-based company said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Tuesday.

headline: Shell Ups Bid for Canadian Unit
text: Royal Dutch Shell, Europe’s biggest oil company, raised a bid to buy out its Canadian unit by 13 percent to 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion) to gain increased production from oil sands. Shell, which owns 78 percent of Shell Canada, raised its bid to 45 Canadian dollars a share, from an offer of 40 Canadian dollars a share made in October.

headline: Carlyle Plans Focus Share Sale
text: Carlyle Group‘s Asian arm is poised to realize a huge gain on an investment in China’s electronic advertising market. Carlyle is preparing to sell 10 million of the 22.5 million ordinary shares it owns in Shanghai-based Focus Media Holdings, China’s biggest purveyor of advertising on flat-panel television screens in upscale office buildings, hotels, airports and similar settings, according to a recent Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Candover Wins Race for Spanish Theme Park
text: A British buyout firm, Candover, beat two rivals Apax Partners and CVC Capital Partners in the the auction for a Spanish theme park operator, Parques Reunidos, with a pitch The Deal.com said was worth more than 900 million euros ($1.2 billion). Candover bid in a consortium with a British operator of trailer parks and family holidays, Bourne Leisure, which is taking a substantial minority stake in the business.

headline: Profit Jumps at BofA, Wachovia
text: Bank of America and Wachovia, two of the nation’s largest banks, said Tuesday that their profits rose sharply in the fourth quarter compared with the same period a year earlier. Results at both banks were helped by major acquisitions in 2006. Bank of America, which bought the credit-card giant MBNA last year, said its net income rose 47 percent, to $5.26 billion, in the fourth quarter. Wachovia, which picked up Golden West Financial, said its fourth-quarter profit increased 35 percent, to $2.3 billion.

headline: New Shuffle Roils Waters at Citigroup
text: The management shuffle at Citigroup, the second shake-up in a little more than a month, raises questions about the bank’s ability to turn itself around, The New York Times says. The ouster of Todd S. Thomson, as head of global wealth management, and the shift of Sallie L. Krawcheck from the post of chief financial officer to that of Mr. Thomson, comes amid years of lackluster operating results and a languishing stock price under its chief executive, Charles O. Prince III. And it now leaves Citigroup looking to fill two significant executive posts.

headline: Clowns and Princes
text: (A spin around the league as I ponder who deserves to win the Manning-Brady column contest — announcement on Wednesday)

headline: For Your Comments on ‘Et tu, George?’
text: In his Tuesday column Nick wrote that we should go the classics to find better analogies than Vietnam for the situation in Iraq. Are there other classics beyond “Moby-Dick” or the “Aeneid” that you think would be appropriate analogies for President Bush and Iraq?

headline: Equity Office to Consider Another Takeover Bid
text: Equity Office Properties, which agreed in November to be bought by a private equity company, the Blackstone Group, for $36 billion, including debt, said Monday that it would begin discussions with a rival group that has offered to top that price. Equity Office, the nation’s largest office landlord, with 585 buildings in 24 metropolitan areas, also said it would open its books to the challengers, a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust.

headline: Congress Remains Wary of Airline Mergers
text: Congressional lawmakers fear a merger between US Airways and Delta Air Lines would trigger wider consolidation and leave consumers with less service and higher fares. But interviews with key members, their staff, lobbyists, and consultants ahead of Wednesday’s Senate Commerce Committee hearing on the hostile proposal found no consensus in Congress that lawmakers should oppose the $10.5 billion deal.

headline: AOL Co-Founder Starts Up Medical Site
text: Steve Case, the co-founder of America Online, launched a Web service on Monday to provide medical information and help with insurance to customers. The site, RevolutionHealth.com, will provide ratings for doctors, hospitals and different treatment options. Co-founders of the site include the former Secretary of State Colin Powell, Hewlett-Packard‘s former chief executive Carly Fiorina, Fannie Mae‘s former chairman Franklin Raines and a venture capitalist, Jim Barksdale, Mr. Case said.

headline: New Bankruptcy Law Aids American Express
text: American Express, the financial and travel services company, reported Monday that stronger holiday shopping and a reduction in bankruptcy write-offs helped lift fourth-quarter profit by 24 percent. The company reported a profit of $922 million, or 75 cents a share, for the quarter, compared with $745 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased 13 percent, to $7.21 billion from $6.38 billion.

headline: S.E.C. Is Silent on H.P. Proxy Fight
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission declined to take a stand on Monday on a request from Hewlett-Packard to exclude from its proxy ballot a proposal from some shareholders that would give them more power to nominate directors.

headline: As Gap’s C.E.O. Leaves, Buyout Firms Circle
text: Gap‘s decision to push out its chief executive, Paul S. Pressler, clears the way for potential buyers to install their own C.E.O. at the struggling retail chain, The New York Times reports. Mr. Pressler stepped down Monday after Gap’s third dismal holiday shopping season in what the company described as a “mutual” decision. Several private equity groups have approached Millard S. Drexler, the former chief executive who was ousted to make way for Mr. Pressler, about running the company after a sale, a person briefed on the matter told The Times. But Mr. Drexler, whose runaway success at J. Crew has haunted Gap’s board, has told the investment firms that he has no interest in returning to Gap, this person said.

headline: Edinburgh Fringe Director to Leave After 8 Years
text: The director of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Paul Gudgin, intends to leave after eight years, the BBC reported.

headline: Time Inc. Magazines Auction Lures More Bidders
text: As the deadline to submit second-round bids for 18 Time Inc. titles expired Monday, up to six companies have emerged as competitors, The New York Post reported. Among the likely bidders are Sweden’s Bonnier Publications; the Quadrangle Group backing a former Wenner Media executive; Boston Ventures, supporting a former Time Inc. executive vice president; Intermedia Advisors; and Active Media in conjunction with Windpoint Partners. Also in the hunt for at least some of the titles is Elevation Partners, the private-equity firm founded by Roger McNamee and the U2 frontman Bono.

headline: Is This Thing On?
text: We are inside the auditoriium at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and there are two figures on stage. Both are life-size Oscars, mute golden neuters whose eyes seem to follow the Bagger where ever he goes. In a matter of minutes, more will be revealed, except, perhaps, their gender.

headline: Spitzer Joins Call to Streamline Wall Street Rules
text: As New York’s attorney general, he was one of the most ardent defenders of heightened securities regulation. As the state’s new governor, however, Eliot Spitzer may be backtracking, or at least that is the suggestion of Tuesday’s article in The New York Post. Joining Sen. Chuck Schumer and New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday as they presented a new plan to streamline regulations, Mr. Spitzer said that he will do what it takes to keep Wall Street at the top of global finance.

headline: Text and Audio
text: Correction Appended

headline: Moses’s Impact on New York
Oscar Nods
text: The Oscar nominations are in. Dreamgirls” got the most –eight. “Babel” was right behind, with seven. The best picture choices are “Babel,” “The Departed,” “Letters From Iwo Jima,” “Little Miss Sunshine” and “The Queen,”

headline: Oscar Nominees and Winners
text: Nominees for the 79th Annual Academy Awards.

headline: Waiting for Tonight
text: The Caucus Question of the Day: Fill in the blank: The state of the union is _______. Elaborate in our comments section below.

headline: Bush’s State of Approval
The Big List of the Big Nod
text: Here, for all the Bagger’s fellow Oscar Ninnies, is the complete list of the 79th Annual Academy Award nominations.

headline: The War at Home: Bipartisan Questions
text: First up this morning is a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee, where Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton, two of the leading 2008 potential contenders, are likely to take turns questioning the president’s policies in Iraq. The hearing is devoted to considering the president’s nomination of Army Lt. Gen. David Petraeus to be general and commander of the Multi-National Forces-Iraq.

headline: Clinton, Obama and the African American Vote
text: “Mystery Pollster” Mark Blumenthal combines the two most recent ABC News surveys on the 2008 primaries and discovers an interesting data point: “Clinton led Obama among blacks by a 53 percent to 27 percent margin. Her lead over Obama is smaller (35 percent to 17 percent) among white Democrats.”

headline: A Dreamgirl’s Nightmare
text: Experienced Oscar hands will tell you that its best to watch for who is not there when the nominations are announced and this morning provided a whopper. Despite the nomination of two of supporting actors, “Dreamgirls,” the one film confected to order for the Oscars, is not going to the big show in the best picture category. The picture got eight nominations to “Babel’s” seven, but with the best pic, the Bagger is telling you it’s not going. For a complete list of nominess, click here.

headline: Here, There and in Iowa
text: One of the striking things about the 2008 presidential campaign is the number of stages it is being played on at once. Take today in Washington, for example, where things will be happening on two fronts. This morning brings a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee, a platform that could display the sharply contrasting views on Iraq of Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York. The evening brings the president’s State of the Union address, which many Democrats — notably Mrs. Clinton — view as providing an opportunity to tee off to advance their own presidential campaigns.

headline: Policy Grit Replaces Glitter at Davos
text: The World Economic Forum theme seems especially apt this year. As the conference begins discussing “the shifting power equation” on Wednesday, some of the brightest lights from previous years won’t be on hand to contribute their views. Who’s out? Former President Bill Clinton, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Angelina Jolie, for starters. Who’s in? Nguyen Tan Dung, the prime minster of Vietnam.

headline: Did Someone Say ‘Climate Change?’
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The first thing I noticed as the bus approached Davos for this year’s World Economic Forum was how green and beautiful the hillsides are. There are patches of snow, but it looked like a magnificent spring.

headline: Davos Dialogue: Climate Change
text: As part of our effort to open up the World Economic Forum and move the discussion beyond the confines of Davos, we are asking readers to weigh in on some of the big questions being addressed at this week’s conference. We encourage you to share your views in what we are calling Davos Dialogue.

headline: Clinton in New Hampshire, and the Party
text: This just in:

headline: Building Materials Re-Raises ElkCorp Bid
text: In a quick turnaround, the Building Materials Corporation of America raised its offer for ElkCorp, a roofing products maker, to $43.50 a share, ElkCorp said in a regulatory filing. The increased offer extends a months-long battle with the Carlyle Group, which raised its offer to $42 on Monday, matching Building Materials’ previous bid. ElkCorp had previously recommended that shareholders accept the Carlyle offer.

headline: The iToaster, the iWatch and the iRon?
text: Fake, Photoshopped “photos” of secret, upcoming Apple products are nothing new, of course; fake photos of the iPhone have been kicking around the Web for years.

headline: VF Sheds Intimate Apparel Business
text: The VF Corporation said Tuesday that it would sell its intimate apparel business to Berkshire Hathaway‘s Fruit of the Loom for $350 million in cash as it focuses on more profitable businesses like outdoor clothing. VF, which owns Wrangler jeans and North Face outerwear, said the unit booked more than $800 million in revenue in 2006. It expects the deal to close in the first quarter of 2007, and that it would take a loss of $45 million from the loss of the unit. VF plans to use the proceeds to fund a share buyback this year.

headline: The Oscar Nominees
text: Photos of some of the films and actors nominated for the 2007 Academy Awards.

headline: Not on the Official Schedule: Parties Galore
text: Scoring an invitation to the World Economic Forum is a coup in itself. Even tougher, though, is getting on the list for the dozens of exclusive soirees that participants host themselves here at Davos. Perhaps the hottest ticket this year is a private breakfast Saturday morning hosted by Bill and Melinda Gates. Mr. Gates, Microsoft‘s founder, and his wife will have a fireside chat about philanthropy with Tom Friedman of The New York Times acting as moderator.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Campaign Cash and Nukes
text: With all this effort to reduce the role of money in politics on the Congressional level and past battles over campaign finance reform, is the country headed back in the other direction when it comes to public financing? Both The Times’s David D. Kirkpatrick and The Washington Post’s Dan Balz and Matthew Mosk see it as a distinct possibility. It could take at least $50 million by the end of 2007 to be seen as credible now, and more like $100 million to have a real shot.

headline: Washington’s Hedge Fund Shuffle
text: For Slate’s Daniel Gross, there is no mystery behind the influx of former politicians into the world of hedge funds. “Hedge funds can make you filthy rich,” he states.

headline: Yeowsir
text: “Dreamgirls” is out. So what’d the Bagger tell you? Oh yeah, he said that the day it premiered in New York it would win everything. And while it was nominated for almost everything — eight nods in all — it didn’t make the Big Five lineup, so this is a crushing result for Paramount/Dreamworks The rest of the best picture stuff went as planned, but the slot that everyone thought would go to “Dreamgirls” went to “Letters From Iwo Jima.”

headline: $700,000 Homes
text: A five-bedroom home in the Outer Banks region of North Carolina, a condo in Minneapolis, Minn., and an island retreat off the coast of Washington State.

headline: Did Someone Say ‘Climate Change’?
text: Where are the snows of yesteryear? That is a question that many attendees of this year’s conference are pondering as they arrive in Davos and notice that the scenery looks a lot less wintery than in previous years. Coincidentally or not, the strange weather comes as Davos has put the issue of climate change high on its agenda, scheduling 17 sessions to discuss it.

headline: Blowback on Bloomberg’s Gun Stance
text: Mayor Bloomberg is facing some blowback down in Washington today as he pushes his gun control agenda.

headline: The Long Island Ad War
text: Time for the latest jab in the hotly contested Long Island Senate race.

headline: National Strike in Lebanon
Lobbyists Ask for Delay on N.Y.S.E. Data Fees Ruling
text: Regulators should hold off on ruling how the New York Stock Exchange charges for its market data until questions about its new status as a for-profit group are resolved, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets association, a Wall Street lobbying group, has asked. The NYSE Group, which owns the exchange, is preparing to charge fees for access to ArcaBook, the real-time market data system the exchange picked up when it merged with Archipelago Holdings last year. Among the offerings the market is planning is real-time share-price data to Web sites like Google and CNBC, in return for a flat fee.

headline: The Oscars Are Coming!
text: The Carpetbagger goes behind the scenes to cover this year's Oscar nominations.

headline: Davos Moment: How to Talk Like a C.E.O.
text: Participants at the forum always talk about “Davos Moments” — those only-at-Davos experiences in which, for example, you find yourself washing your hands in the bathroom with former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres on one side and rock musician Peter Gabriel on the other.

headline: More on Global Warming
text: DAVOS, Switzerland —  It is not just the politicians in the United States who are unconcerned about global warming.

headline: When a Stake Is Not a Stake
text: Consider what happens when a hedge fund buys stock in a company — giving it voting rights in various matters of importance to all shareholders — but then uses other investments to reduce or cancel out the economic risk associated with the holding. Paul Atkins, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission, said this common situation could raise concerns as some corporate-governance groups seek to give shareholders greater influence in a proxy vote. He told The Financial Times that hedge funds “have used financial derivatives to influence the voting for acquisitions but where they don’t have the economic interest.”

headline: I Cudda Been a Comptroller
text: Sitting in the back of Hearing Room B, where the marathon screening of 17 would-be state comptrollers went by rather slowly, was the man who started it all: J. Christopher Callaghan, the little-known Republican candidate who blew the whistle on former Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi’s misuse of staff, but who still lost the election.

headline: For Would-Be British Bankers, What Not to Wear
text: Those who thought that American investment bankers were clothes horses — recall those who dress like Patrick Bateman of “American Psycho” — may be in for a surprise, according to Reuters. British financiers are even more concerned about their appearance. Bankers in the City of London are every bit the peacock, according to one of their female colleagues. In fact, she told the news service, “they may care more than women.”

headline: Little Big Man
text: Mark Urman, president of theatrical distribution at ThinkFilm, on the nomination of Ryan Gosling for actor in a leading role for the “Half Nelson,” a little movie that played big:

headline: Vanessa Redgrave in Drag?
text: Screenwriter Peter Morgan was in Sundance with the producer of his new film, “Longford,” when he called the Baguette to chat about receiving anAcademy Award screnwriting nomination for “The Queen,” which bagged six nominations in all.

headline: How Does it Feel?
text: Alan Arkin, last seen at the Oscars in 1968 for his role in “The Heart is a Lonely Hunter,” is not about to make a big deal about it this time around.

headline: Random, Wonky Thought
text: Best picture wins are usually pulled along by a best actor nomination,but that will not be the case this year. Of all the lead actors andactresses in the best picture nominees, only Hellen Mirren in “The Queen”was nominated

headline: The New Name is Also-Ran
text: “If you are frontrunner, you don’t want to be called the frontrunner because then they all want to take you down,” said Sasha Stone, editor of OscarWatch, recalling some wisdom an Oscar publicist shared with her. Like any sensible person, she watched the nominations in her jammies. The Bagger joined the scrum and he has to say the pre-announcement scrambled eggs were a bit too al dente for his taste.

headline: Red Wine With Fruit?
text: I don’t really know what came over me, as I don’t ordinarily think of pairing wine with fruit. But having just polished off a substantial portion of my wife Deborah’s excellent home-made lasagna, I was ready for the perfect dessert: a juicy, sweet-and-tart clementine. Clementines are so dicey – you never know whether you’re going to get a luscious one perfectly in balance or end up with a mouthful of pith. Often they come in sealed crates, so you can’t weigh them individually in your hand, looking for heaviness in one of the time-honored methods for assessing citrus fruit.

headline: Close Encounter
text: Helen Mirren on her new reign as an Oscar nominee:

headline: Bringing Home ‘The Departed’s’ Bacon
text: “I was completely surprised and I’m thrilled,” Mark Wahlberg told the Baguette about his best supporting actor nomination for “The Departed.” “It made my parents and a lot of people very happy, very proud.

headline: Bitttersweet Triumph
text: Penelope Cruz, speaking by phone to the Baguette,on the joy of being one of the five nominated lead actresses, and the sadness that “Volver,” the film she starred in by her friend Pedro Almodóvar, did not get nominated in the foreign film category:

headline: Leaving the Labrynth for the Sunshine
text: “I am exploding with delight,” Guillermo del Toro said with characteristic exhuberance about receiving a best foreign language film nomination for “Pan’s Labyrinth.”

headline: Court Rules Parmalat May Sue Citi in New Jersey
text: A New Jersey state court has rejected Citigroup‘s bid to dismiss a $10 billion lawsuit accusing it of helping former management at Italian food company Parmalat commit fraud. The decision, by Bergen County Superior Court Judge Jonathan Harris, dismisses Citigroup’s claim that New Jersey is the wrong venue.

headline: Remembering Not to Forget
text: Paul Greengrass, the director of “United 93,” in a call from Britain, where he is shooting “The Bourne Ultimatum,” was pleased, but hardly celebratory, over his Oscar nomination as a director.

headline: Going Over the Top and Staying There
text: The Bagger has no biases when it comes to the awards, of course, but he did think that “Little Children” was criminally — oh, he takes that back for the second time today, its just a statue — sadly, ignored. Its star wasn’t however, and the Baguette got to take the call from a delirious Kate Winslet:

headline: Super Freak
text: “I’m calling to freak out over the phone,” was the phone message Jackie Earle Haley left the Baguette about his nomination in the supporting actor category for his nuanced portrayal of a convicted sex felon.

headline: Blogtalk
text: Mike Bloomberg prints out his Web reading. [Fishbowl DC]

headline: The Queen’s Hegemony
text: “The Queen” was kind of hanging around the best picture crowd for much of the awards season, but most of the handicappers felt that Miramax would have to settle for a best actress win. Now, however, with the race wide open, nothing seems impossible.

headline: God’s Mighty Hand
text: Stephen Hawkings, er, Frears, has a simple theory about his nomination for directing “The Queen”: “I think it proves the existence of God. A favorable wind got behind this film and has just blown it along. It has been extraordinary.”

headline: Bush Speech Excerpts
text: While much of the detail in President Bush’s State of the Union address tonight has been briefed and written about, the White House has just released a few excerpts from the speech itself.

headline: Clinton Locks Up Top Fundraiser
text: Hassan Nemazee, who was New York finance chief for the Kerry ’04 campaign, and who is also an old friend of Senator Joe Biden, said this afternoon that he has decided to raise money and offer economic policy advice to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the 2008 campaign.

headline: Not Your Average Republican Presidential Candidate
text: The other day, I went by to visit Congressman Ron Paul, Republican of Texas. My first “real” job in Washington was working for him when he was initially elected to Congress in 1976, and I wanted to see how he was doing. Little did I realize when I made the appointment that I would be talking to a candidate for president.

headline: BlogTalk: Plame Blame Game and S.O.T.U. Scripts
text: The liberal blogs are giddy over the opening arguments by I. Lewis “Scooter” Libby’s defense lawyer at the former Cheney aide’s trial for perjury and obstruction of justice.

headline: Google’s High-Octane Mixer
text: As politicians and moguls stream into Davos, some of them arrive with a discreet black envelope in their luggage. It contains an invitation to what has consistently been one of the conference’s hottest events: the party hosted by Web search giant Google.

headline: Second Chances: Babouche
text: How is that that proprietors can pour so much money — and, one can assume, so much hope — into a restaurant, then let a series of questionable decisions and avoidable mistakes trip them up?

headline: Bites in San Francisco
text: The New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman makes scones at Tartine Bakery in San Francisco.

headline: Pataki Seeks a ‘Way Forward,’ Too
text: Rudy Giuliani is heading to the New Hampshire north country on Friday, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and a hefty portion of the national political press corps are pakking to Des Moines for her town hall-style meeting on Saturday. But if you’re in D.C. Friday and find yourself wondering — “where has that other New York presidential wannabe been?” — head over to Georgetown University at 11 a.m.

headline: Violence in Beirut
text: The Times's Michael Slackman explains the complicated struggle for power in  Lebanon.

headline: Caucus Readers on the State of the Union
text: Thanks to everyone who answered The Caucus Question of the Day.

headline: Where’s Pataki?
text: Former Gov. George E. Pataki has not been much heard from since leaving office on New Year’s Day. He has taken out office space in his hometown of Peekskill, N.Y., and has hired a few fundraising advisers to a political staff that mostly left the governor’s office with him.

headline: A Break in the Ranks
text: SEIU Local 32BJ is going against its larger brother, SEIU 1199, and endorsing Democrat Craig Johnson in the Long Island Senate race. No more details are available, but an announcement is expected tomorrow. The union represents about 60,000 “property service” workers in the state–janitors, doormen, security guards, etc.

headline: Rehabilitating Robert Moses
text: Three exhibits featuring the work of Robert Moses,  one of New York  City's premier builders, will open in the coming weeks.

headline: SOTU: The Daily Durbin?
text: Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois will not be rushing toward the television cameras after the State of the Union address tonight.

headline: The Fashion Police at the Capitol
text: There is, of course, high security in the Capitol tonight. But in addition to the typical metal detectors, the authorities are on on the lookout for offensive clothing.

headline: Caucus Survey: The State of Us
text: O.K., readers of the Caucus. President Bush has concentrated on a few critical issues for his address tonight.

headline: Bush Text
text: The full advanced text of President Bush’s speech has finally been released.

headline: Senator Webb’s Rebuttal
text: Senator Jim Webb, the Democrat newly elected from Virginia, a Vietnam veteran and a former Navy secretary, was chosen to give the Democrats’ rebuttal to President Bush’s speech.

headline: Madame Speaker
text: At the beginning of his speech and in a nod to bipartisanship, President Bush acknowledged twice, perhaps even three times, the moment that has brought a woman, Nancy Pelosi, to the seat of House speaker for the first time.

headline: State of the Seating Chart 2008
text: The eyes of all members of Congress were aimed toward the front of the House chamber when President Bush began his State of the Union address. None, perhaps, were trained more enviously than those of the gaggle of senators – Democrats and Republicans alike – who aspire to be delivering the address in three years.

headline: 7 Speeches, All in One Place
text: Taken together, President Bush’s seven State of the Union messages add up to nearly 35,000 words. Which words show up all the time? Which ones are conspicuously absent? Use our new tool to search all seven speeches simultaneously and see how the words stack up. Here’s one example: In 2002, the president mentioned Iraq a grand total of….. two times. Tonight, he used the word 34 times. You can go ahead and chart how often he said Iraq through the years.

headline: Confirm My Judges, Please
text: In a moment fraught with partisanship, Republicans stood and cheered as Democrats frowned in the House chamber when President Bush, mindful of past Democratic filibusters against his judicial nominees, said this:

headline: Divided We Stand, or Sit
text: You only had to watch whether Speaker Nancy Pelosi joined Vice President Cheney on her feet in standing ovations to figure out which passage of President Bush’s speech was being delivered.

headline: State of the Applause, Part 2
text: Speaker Nancy Pelosi indeed set the tone of whether most of her fellow Democrats would – or would not – applaud after specific lines of President Bush’s speech.

headline: Getting That Photo-Op
text: As President Bush walked down the center aisle to exit the chamber, cameras were able to pick up little bits of his exchanges with the lawmakers who crowded around, asking him to sign their programs. Representative Michele Bachmann, a new Republican member from Minnesota, maintained a death grip on the president’s shoulder, even while he turned away to talk to others, until he posed for a picture with her.

headline: Obama, Giuliani on the Speech
text: Senator Barack Obama, interviewed by Anderson Cooper on CNN right after President Bush’s speech, called the administration’s logic and policy “flawed” on the Iraq strategy. And he said what was striking to him in the last few weeks was the “near-unanimity” with which lawmakers would prefer to see a drawdown in Iraq, and redeployment, as opposed to an increase of troops.

headline: Building Middle-Earth: ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Online
text: In 1955, shortly after “The Lord of the Rings” was published, J. R. R. Tolkien began to worry his creation had become a “vast game” for some readers. This was not good, he wrote, even “for me, who find that kind of thing only too fatally attractive.”

headline: Rivals CNN and Fox News Spar Over Obama Report
text: A disputed report on the Web site of a conservative magazine about Senator Barack Obama’s childhood schooling kicked off a pointed exchange this week between the rival cable news networks CNN and Fox News, when CNN seemed to make an overt effort both to debunk the report and to question the quality of Fox News’s journalism.

headline: Putin Visit to India Highlights Enduring Alliance
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 — India has a new nuclear accord, booming trade and an ever closer partnership with the United States, but it will celebrate a much older friendship at the country’s annual Republic Day display of military pomp this week: President Vladimir Putin of Russia will be the guest of honor.

headline: For the Record
text: A chart with the Political Action column yesterday listing the estimated federal pensions of former lawmakers who have been convicted of crimes misstated the party affiliation of former Representative James Traficant of Ohio. He was a Democrat, not a Republican.

headline: General Says New Strategy in Iraq Can Work Over Time
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus, President Bush’s new choice as the top commander in Iraq, told senators on Tuesday that the new military strategy to secure Baghdad can work, and that he had asked that the additional troops the administration promised be deployed as quickly as possible.

headline: After the Last Lap, It’s Time for SAT Prep
text: On a cold, drizzly evening, the copper-colored track inside the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan was as inviting as a crackling fireplace. Hundreds of sprinters and middle-distance runners from public and private high schools were taking wintertime practice, cantering around the indoor track with the exuberance of youngsters taking still-sprouting bodies to once unimaginable peaks.

headline: What’s a Pound of Prevention Really Worth?
text: Arthur Agatston, the South Beach diet doctor, came to town last week and, in between bites of filleted fish, he was trying to persuade me that his patients rarely have heart attacks anymore.

headline: Returning to New York, Forcefully
text: It is mystifying that the Mexican pianist Jorge Federico Osorio does not have more of a presence in the New York concert world. Having won several competitions in the early 1970s, he waited until 1997 to make his New York recital debut. He hasn’t been back much since, but his recordings of Spanish and Mexican music have attracted notice, and on Monday evening he played a hefty, colorful program at Alice Tully Hall that reinforced the impression he made a decade ago.

headline: Stirring Many Ingredients Into a Strangely Blended Brew
text: When books or paintings become too dizzying, you can walk away until you’re ready for more. But performance art keeps coming at you, ready or not. Though audience members can practice some form of pacing, much of the effect depends on the artist’s skill in knowing how much is too much, or when too much is just enough.

headline: Our Father, the Nazi Zealot: A Family Grapples With Its Burdens and Blind Spots
text: The Nazis ruled Germany for 12 years and inflicted their cruelty on other European nations for around 7. Coming to terms with what Hitler and his followers did has been a much longer project — involving Jews, Germans, other Europeans and just about everyone else in the world — and it is unlikely to end anytime soon. Like many other films and books, “2 or 3 Things I Know About Him,” a new documentary directed by Malte Ludin, examines the impact of Nazism on a single family, in this case the family of a high-ranking member of Hitler’s government. But if it tells, in Mr. Ludin’s words, “a typical German story,” the movie also offers an unusually matter-of-fact picture of the private and public effects of ordinary evil.

headline: Life or Death? Jurors Hear About Killer’s Past, and Future
text: In a courtroom in Brooklyn, a jury heard testimony yesterday on the primacy of maternal love, the duration of breakfast service in the federal prison system, the role of diligence in scholastic performance, the stature of the Mexican Mafia gang and a discourse on certain political trends guiding New York City social welfare policy in the latter part of the previous century.

headline: A Cap on Property Taxes May Have a Few Loopholes
text: TRENTON, Jan. 23 — On paper, Gov. Jon S. Corzine may well get what he wants from the Legislature: a bill limiting annual increases in revenues from local property taxes to 4 percent.

headline: Giuliani Is Expected to Sell One of His Three Businesses
text: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently taken steps to sell the biggest division of his consulting business as he considers running for the presidency, according to a person with detailed knowledge of the firm’s plans.

headline: China's Leader to Visit Sudan and Seek End to Darfur Conflict
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24 — President Hu Jintao of China will visit Sudan in early February and press for a diplomatic solution to the conflict in that country’s western Darfur region, Chinese officials announced today.

headline: Against Roddick, Federer May Truly Be Tested
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 24 — Tommy Robredo of Spain had been vanquished in less style than usual. Andy Roddick was up next in the semifinals, and Roger Federer was sitting comfortably, legs crossed. He spoke a bit wistfully about how great it had been to watch a five-set match the night before, when Rafael Nadal’s staying power got the better of Andy Murray’s brain power.

headline: What if Israel and Syria Find Common Ground?
text: ISRAEL’S newspapers are rife with reports of a peace agreement secretly forged between Israeli and Syrian negotiators. Though both the Syrian and Israeli governments have denied any involvement in the talks, past experience shows that such disavowals are often the first indication of truth behind the rumors.

headline: China Confirms Space Test; Denies Intent to Intimidate
text: BEIJING, Jan. 23  The Chinese government publicly confirmed Tuesday that it had conducted a successful test of a new antisatellite weapon but said it had no intention of participating in a “space race.”

headline: Greek Tragedy Wears a New, Brash Mask
text: Sophocles’ “Women of Trachis” is packed with sex, gore, desperation and verbal beauty. If it isn’t staged very often, one reason is that the plot hinges on a twist that is hard to swallow today. Why would Deianira, Heracles’ adoring and sensible wife, believe that such a glaringly suspicious character — a centaur that Heracles shot for trying to rape her — would then want to help the couple stay together by giving Deianira a magical love potion?

headline: Changes Sought at Children’s Psychiatric Hospital
text: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan 23  For months, Connecticut’s psychiatric hospital for children has been buffeted by criticism. Employees say it is unsafe and complain that their opinions are dismissed, and others worry that the children remain in custody far too long.

headline: Kerr-McGee Is Found Liable in Lawsuit Over Oil Royalties
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — A federal jury in Denver agreed Tuesday with a former top auditor for the Interior Department that the Kerr-McGee Corporation had cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties on oil it produced in publicly owned coastal waters.

headline: Wendy’s Shifts Ad Agencies, Dropping McCann
text: Wendy’s International is unexpectedly changing advertising agencies after working since August 2002 with two New York agencies that are part of the McCann Erickson Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Manhattan: New Helicopter Service for East Side
text: The first scheduled helicopter service to New York area airports from the East Side in two decades is set to begin next month, aviation officials said yesterday. The helicopter company, U.S. Helicopter Corporation, which provides eight-minute flights from the Downtown Manhattan Heliport to Kennedy International Airport and Newark Liberty International Airport, said it would add service to those two airports from the city-owned East 34th Street Heliport on Feb. 5. The East Side heliport, like the downtown heliport, will have security screening overseen by the federal Transportation Security Administration that will allow passengers to bypass the security lines at the airports. The one-way fare will be $169.

headline: Chinese President Wants Inquiry Into Reporter’s Murder
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24 — In a rare response to a criminal incident, President Hu Jintao of China has ordered a speedy investigation into the murder of Lan Chengzhang, a reporter for the China Trade News, according to the semioffical China News Service.

headline: Canada: Bid for Shell Canada Shares Is Raised
text: After an earlier offer received a cool reception from minority shareholders, Royal Dutch Shell increased its bid for the portion of Shell Canada it does not own to 45 Canadian dollars ($38.10) a share from 40 Canadian dollars. The new offer values the 22 percent of Shell Canada not held by the parent company at 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion). About 150,000 barrels of Shell Canada’s daily production of 230,000 barrels comes from oil sands projects in Alberta rather than conventional sources. When it made its opening bid in October, Royal Dutch Shell said that full control of Shell Canada would allow it to increase its reported reserves. An accounting problem forced the parent company to lower its reserve levels in 2004. The higher bid still may face difficulty since some Canadian fund managers have said recently that they are looking for a price near 50 Canadian dollars a share.

headline: More Marketers Are Grabbing the Attention of Players During Online Games
text: CASUAL game sites have learned how to play the ad game.

headline: Haggis, Updated: Less Offal, Tastes Great
text: IF there can be said to be a haggis season, we’re smack in the middle of it. Demand for the Scottish national dish — a large sausage of innards boiled inside a lamb’s stomach, which is to say, something very much like an inside-out sheep — begins to heat up around St. Andrew’s Day, at the end of November. It peaks tomorrow night when Scottish organizations around the world will celebrate the birthday of the poet Robert Burns.

headline: Mexico: Cemex Extends Bid for Australian Company
text: Cemex, the concrete maker, extended its $11.7 billion hostile takeover bid for the Rinker Group of Australia by two months while it waits for regulatory approval in the United States. Cemex’s $13-a-share offer for Rinker will end March 30, Cemex said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange yesterday. Cemex wants to buy Rinker because of its business in the United States, which is focused on Florida, Arizona and Nevada. The deal would make Cemex, which is based in Mexico, the world’s biggest concrete maker.

headline: Five American Security Employees Killed in Baghdad Helicopter Attack
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 23  Five members of a private security detail protecting an American convoy were killed Tuesday when their helicopters came under attack, and one plummeted to the pavement through a tangle of electrical wires in one of Baghdad’s most dangerous neighborhoods.

headline: You May Kiss the Chef’s Napkin Ring
text: THE person taking your reservation is the first to put you in your place.

headline: A Village That Was Reborn Isn’t Eager to Be a Brand Name
text: KATONAH, N.Y.

headline: Texas: Penalty in Case of False Gas-Mileage Booster
text: Attorney General Greg Abbott filed an agreed judgment against a Dallas company that was marketing a mothball-like product as a gas-mileage booster. The company, BioPerformance, sold its product with a claim that putting a couple of the pills into an automobile fuel tank could increase gas mileage 30 percent. The state’s investigation revealed that the product had no such power and that its main ingredient was naphthalene, used in making mothballs. The state also found that the company developed a pyramid scheme that drew in about 50,000 people nationwide and ran up some $28 million in sales. The judgment provides $7.3 million in restitution to affected consumers.

headline: The Best Place for Middle Schoolers (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Renovating in Historical Districts
text: Renovations are never easy. And renovating a home in a designated historical district makes the task even more formidable.

headline: Big Bank Stops Effort to Change Law Limiting Growth
text: Bank of America’s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said yesterday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 8 in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 23  A suicide bomber wearing an explosive vest blew himself up Tuesday at the entrance to a NATO base in the southeastern province of Khost, killing 8 to 10 people, officials said.

headline: Britain: Crackdown on Scavengers of Stricken Cargo Ship
text: After looters continued to carry away motorcycles, engine parts, alcohol and other goods from containers on a Devon beach after a cargo ship foundered and was grounded off the coast, the authorities said they would prosecute anyone who did not report and return the items. “Frankly, the scenes were despicable,” Mark Rodaway, an official at the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, said at a news conference. He said looters had compounded damage to the beach while making it harder for coastal officials to deal with issues like contamination from 200 tons of heavy fuel said to have leaked from the ship, the Napoli. Environmentalists said 1,100 oil-covered birds  about 900 guillemots and 200 gulls  had already washed up on shore.

headline: Senate Panel Opposes Troop Increase in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — One day after President Bush implored Congress to give his Iraq strategy a chance to succeed, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a resolution today denouncing the White House’s plan to send more troops to Baghdad, setting up the most direct confrontation over the war since it began nearly four years ago.

headline: Armenian-Turkish Unity at Slain Editor’s Funeral
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 23 — More than 50,000 mourners, including senior Turkish and Armenian officials in a rare display of unity, poured into the heart of Istanbul on Tuesday to bid farewell to Hrant Dink, the Turkish-Armenian journalist who was gunned down outside his offices last week, a death that many Turks hoped would be a catalyst for change.

headline: Dear Graydon ...
text: TO: Graydon Carter, grayisgood@vanityfair.com

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the Pentagon’s new rules for military commissions to try prisoners held at Guantánamo, Cuba, on terrorism charges, misstated the reasons cited by the Supreme Court when it struck down the Bush administration’s original plans for the commissions. And a correction in this space yesterday repeated the error. The court ruled last year in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld that the initial procedures established for the commissions were unauthorized by federal statute and violated international law. It did not rule that the commissions themselves were unconstitutional.

headline: This Emperor Does Have Clothes (but He Says He Doesn’t)
text: Who would have imagined that watching a stranger undress could ever be tedious?

headline: Israel to Indict President on Sex Charges
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23  The attorney general of Israel plans to indict President Moshe Katsav on charges of rape and other sexual offenses, the Justice Ministry announced Tuesday, in what would be the most serious criminal case involving a senior Israeli official.

headline: Germany: Suitor Abandons Bid for Scania
text: Man dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid for the Swedish truck maker Scania after opposition emerged from Volkswagen, Scania’s largest shareholder, and will seek a friendly merger instead. Man, Volkswagen and Scania “see the industrial logic behind a combination” of the three businesses, but such a combination is not possible under the existing offer, Man said. A combined Man and Scania, the Swedish truck maker, would surpass DaimlerChrysler and Volvo as Europe’s No. 1 maker of heavy vehicles. Volkswagen, based in Wolfsburg, Germany, said it wanted to wrap its Brazilian truck unit into a Scania-MAN combination to compete with DaimlerChrysler and Volvo. Man is based in Germany.

headline: Bloomberg’s Leadership (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Man Dies in Fall, Second Fatality at Brooklyn Shipyard in January
text: A shipyard worker died yesterday after falling at least 25 feet in a fuel barge at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the police said, the second fatality this month at a work site operated by GMD Shipyard Corporation.

headline: Profit at Sun Microsystems Stirs Hope of Turnaround
