text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23  After years of losses, Sun Microsystems returned to profitability last quarter, while Advanced Micro Devices swung to a loss, providing evidence that the road to recovery in the technology industry is a bumpy one.

headline: Clash Pits Hezbollah Against Rule in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23 — Thousands of supporters of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, which is seeking to bring down the pro-Western government, clashed with government supporters and blocked highways leading into Beirut, the capital, on Tuesday, raising fears that the political crisis might lead to open sectarian conflict.

headline: Libby’s Lawyers Question Witnesses’ Recollections
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Prosecutors in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., paraded a roster of former government officials before the jury today to testify that they had informed Mr. Libby about the identity of a C.I.A. operative, Valerie Wilson, before he spoke with reporters.

headline: Deep Brown, Sweet and Rich, Onion Soup Provides Perfect Harmony
text: DARK brown, rich with a hint of sweetness. Altbier fits that description. So does onion soup. And the two can certainly be in harmony.

headline: Plan Seeks to Change New York School Financing
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein today laid out the first specifics of his ambitious plan to change the school financing system in New York City so that schools of similar sizes and student demographics get roughly the same amount of city tax dollars per student.

headline: Belarus Asks Russia to Pay for Land Used by Pipelines
text: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers on Wednesday.

headline: Once Around the Block, James, and Pick Me Up After My Nap
text: The cars gather in front of the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan about 8:30 a.m. In the front seats sit hired drivers (nobody uses the term chauffeur anymore). The cars are mostly big and mostly black luxury-edition sport utility vehicles like the Mercedes GL-Class or the GMC Yukon Denali. They fill the lanes in front of the Y’s entrance on Lexington Avenue, often two or three rows deep.

headline: Chechen Police Under Scrutiny in Journalist’s Killing, Group Says
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 23 — Some police officials in Chechnya are under criminal investigation for a possible role in the killing of Anna Politkovskaya, a prominent Russian journalist, a New York-based news media rights group said here on Tuesday.

headline: Text: Statement of Ronell Wilson in Murder Trial
text: Following is the text of the statement Ronell Wilson read in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in the sentencing phase of his murder trial:

headline: Love of Learning: Which Children Have It Most
text: Which children like school the most? Asians and girls and the children of parents who are married, make the most money, have advanced academic degrees and live in the suburbs of the Northeast.

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ Leads in Oscar Nominations but Is Snubbed for Best Picture
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 23 — Everything went as planned for “Dreamgirls,” a perfectly confected Oscar machine. Great cast, showstoppers that stopped the show, and a wonderful back story in Jennifer Hudson, the washed-out “American Idol” turned movie star. And it was all propelled by hype-filled rollout, plenty of strong reviews and, finally, widespread belief that it was the favorite in the best-picture throwdown.

headline: Asian Rival Moves Past Las Vegas
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 23 — Macao surpassed the Las Vegas Strip to become the world’s biggest gambling center in 2006, according to industry analysts and government figures released Tuesday.

headline: Clijsters and Sharapova Are Out of Sorts, but in the Semifinals
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 24 — The champion on the way out beat the champion on the way back, and now Kim Clijsters will face Maria Sharapova in the semifinals of the Australian Open.

headline: ‘The State of Our Union Is Strong; Our Cause in the World Is Right’
text: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Bush’s State of the Union address as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript: nytimes.com/washington.

headline: Officer Who Epitomized Ills of Ground Zero Workers Dies
text: A former New York City police officer died of a lung disease last night, hours before his son attended the State of the Union address to draw attention to the plight of 9/11 rescue workers like him who became ill after they were exposed to toxic dust at ground zero.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts last Wednesday about NBC’s plans to extend the “Today” program to a fourth hour attributed an erroneous distinction to the show. “Nightwatch” on CBS, which had its premiere in 1982, ran for four hours on weekdays. “Today” will not be the first such weekday program of that length on major broadcast networks.

headline: A Hostage Who Stayed a Few Steps Ahead
text: On the night of Jan. 21, 1998, Stanley N. Alpert was heading home in Greenwich Village with pleasant thoughts on his mind. The next day he would turn 38. By chance, he had struck up a conversation with an attractive woman on the subway, and it looked as if a date were in the cards. As he walked, he mused, and as he mused, he failed to notice two armed men closing in on him from behind. Before he knew it, he was in the back seat of a new Lexus, about to experience the most terrifying 25 hours of his life.

headline: Serving the U.N. (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Shift in Power, Starting With ‘Madam Speaker’
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — The first two words of the evening on Tuesday were evidence of how much has changed here: “Madam Speaker,” boomed Congressional escorts, “the president of the United States.”

headline: Quiet Cover for a Vital Brew
text: BROWN is not exactly the color of excitement. To achieve a hint of glamour, brown must adopt more seductive aliases, like chestnut, cocoa or cafe au lait. Unaltered, brown might as well be plain vanilla, the blah-est of moods, the Charlie Brownest of the ordinary. “Brown shoes don’t make it,” Frank Zappa sang in a more cutting assessment of this most defenseless of colors.

headline: Manhattan: Union Leader Wins Re-Election
text: Lillian Roberts was overwhelmingly elected to a new three-year term as executive director of District Council 37, the city’s largest union of municipal workers, the union announced last night. The union’s 327-member delegate assembly, in weighted voting, elected Ms. Roberts with 83,486 votes, while the challenger, Charles Ensley, president of the union local representing social workers, received 37,503 votes. In her race three years ago, Ms. Roberts eked out a victory over Mr. Ensley. After three years in which the executive board often clashed with Ms. Roberts, her slate swept all 20 contested seats on the board yesterday, giving her firm control.

headline: For the Record
text: An obituary and headline on Thursday about Betty Trezza, a pioneer of women’s professional baseball, misstated her age. She was 81, not 82.

headline: Libby Defense Portrays Client as a Scapegoat
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  I. Lewis Libby Jr., the vice president’s former chief of staff, was made a scapegoat by White House officials to protect the president’s longtime political adviser, Karl Rove, Mr. Libby’s lawyer asserted in his opening statement on Tuesday.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded: $7,109,434.83

headline: Videotaping the Apocalyptic Intersection of Abu Ghraib and Las Vegas
text: Imagine all the decadence, incoherence and insanity of Times Square jammed into a black-box theater and you get some sense of what you’re in for with Big Art Group’s “Dead Set #3,” at the Kitchen as part of the Under the Radar festival.

headline: A Maleficent Obsession? Could Be More Than Heaven Allows
text: “You’ve got to change your brand of men.”

headline: To Deliver Their Remarks, Democrats Opt to Put a Fresh Face Front and Center
text: Correction Appended

headline: Making Music Speak for Those Without a Voice
text: Aspiring classical musicians struggling to find work and established professionals with well-paying positions in major orchestras may seem to live in different worlds. But young or old, student or master, most musicians understand that the art they practice is capable of reaching, and even changing, people profoundly.

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
text: Southern Shores, N.C.

headline: 9/11 Families Offer New Plan for Memorial Names
text: Far from having been settled last month behind closed doors at the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, the three-year-old battle over the arrangement of victims’ names at the 9/11 memorial escalated today to television and the Internet.

headline: Bush Seeks Vast, Mandatory Increase in Alternative Fuels and Greater Vehicle Efficiency
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — Vowing to reduce the nation’s thirst for foreign oil, President Bush called on Tuesday for a huge government-mandated increase in renewable fuels — mainly ethanol — and tougher mileage standards for cars and light trucks.

headline: Knicks Go From the Heat to the Frying Pan
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 23 — On the afternoon that followed the most disturbing night of their season, only two developments could have soothed the Knicks: a positive report on Stephon Marbury’s knee or an N.B.A. edict canceling the rest of their games this week.

headline: Manhattan: Lawyer Fails to Appear at Murder Trial
text: A judge presiding over a murder trial in State Supreme Court held a lawyer in contempt yesterday and fined her $1,000 after she failed to appear on behalf of her client, Paul Cortez, for the second straight day. Jury selection was supposed to begin Monday in the trial of Mr. Cortez, 25, who is charged with murdering Catherine Woods, 21, a dancer, in her Upper East Side apartment in 2005. Justice Carol Berkman said Mr. Cortez’s lawyer, Laura Miranda, sent the court a fax on Monday, saying that she had to go to Puerto Rico to take care of her sick mother. “For what illness, I do not know,” Justice Berkman said. The fax said Ms. Miranda’s co-counsel, Dawn Florio, had had a death in the family. The judge said Ms. Miranda had been absent without leave from her courtroom before. “Well, I suppose we may as well adjourn this matter until tomorrow and see whether indeed she reappears,” the judge said.

headline: Texas City Takes Step to Ease Ban on Renting to Illegal Immigrants
text: DALLAS, Jan. 23 — The City Council of a Dallas suburb has revised its proposed ban on renting apartments to illegal immigrants to allow landlords to rent to families with mixed citizenship or residency status.

headline: Return of the Drug Company Payoffs
text: Two excessively lenient court decisions have allowed the manufacturers of brand-name drugs to resume the underhanded practice of paying generic competitors to keep their drugs off the market. It is a costly legal loophole that needs to be plugged by Congressional legislation.

headline: A Call for $1 Billion to Cut City Class Size
text: ALBANY, Jan. 23  The head of New York City’s teachers’ union implored state lawmakers on Tuesday to reserve at least $1 billion of new state education spending to reduce class sizes.

headline: Poles and Czechs to Talk With U.S. About Missile Defense System
text: The United States will start formal negotiations this year with Poland and the Czech Republic on deploying ground-based antimissile defense systems in the countries, government officials said. The decision was made despite weak public support in each country and strong opposition from Russia. The United States says the system is intended as protection against a possible attack from the Middle East, not Russia.

headline: Ryszard Kapuscinski, Polish Writer of Shimmering Allegories and News, Dies at 74
text: Ryszard Kapuscinski, a globe-trotting journalist from Poland whose writing, often tinged with magical realism, brought him critical acclaim and a wide international readership, died yesterday in Warsaw. He was 74.

headline: State of the Union: Another Take
text: Randy Newman, the singer, songwriter and composer, performed this song at Carnegie Hall in 2006. It will be released soon online. This is an abridged version.

headline: Sri Lanka: Report Accuses Government of Collusion in Child Soldiers
text: Human Rights Watch accused the government of colluding with Karuna, a renegade faction of the Tamil Tiger rebels, in rounding up children to fight against their former comrades. While the Tigers have long been accused of conscripting child soldiers, the rights group said the government was implicated in some of the same abuse by using the renegade group as a “proxy force.” The government denied both charges. Its report, based on interviews with parents and children, said that Karuna operated with impunity in government-controlled areas and that its abductions of hundreds of boys and young men were carried out in areas with a heavy military presence.

headline: What’s on Wednesday Night
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) RHINOCEROS Virtually unchanged over 25 million years, the rhinoceros once roamed the earth in millions. Today, it is one of the planet’s rarest animals, with three of the remaining five species headed toward extinction. This “Nature” special follows rangers through the savannahs of South Africa, the grasslands of India and the jungles of Indonesia to examine efforts to protect rhinos from poachers and relocate them to new habitats, and peers into a fertility lab at an American zoo to find out about attempts to breed them in captivity. It also zooms in on some startling behavior in the rhinos’ natural environments, including a nursery full of mothers and calves and a charge from an angry bull.

headline: Williams Not Willing to Give Up Pinstripes
text: There is no spot on the Yankees’ roster for Bernie Williams, who is uncomfortable as a free agent after 16 seasons in New York. Williams does not want to retire, yet he does not want to leave the Yankees.

headline: One Steel Cage Up, and Many More to Follow
text: It was hard to believe that the 70-foot-long steel cage lying rigidly on the ground yesterday at the World Trade Center site was about to become a “50-ton Slinky,” in the words of Steven Plate, the director of priority capital programs at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Big Insurer Will Pay 640 Katrina Claims
text: In a move that is expected to jump-start rebuilding along the Mississippi Gulf Coast, State Farm Insurance said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with state officials to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to owners of homes along the coast that were wrecked by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Iraq Parliament Finds a Quorum Hard to Come By
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 23 — Mahmoud al-Mashhadani, the speaker of Parliament, read a roll call of the 275 elected members with a goal of shaming the no-shows.

headline: Big Question Unanswered in Scandal
text: For the fourth time in less than two years, Clarence Norman, the disgraced former head of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, sat in a courtroom yesterday, watching prospective jurors file in to sit in judgment of him.

headline: A Commercial Landlord’s Biggest Sale May Be Itself
text: For several years, Equity Office Properties, the huge commercial portfolio assembled by the Chicago real estate magnate Samuel Zell, lagged other publicly traded office landlords.

headline: Biotech Psoriasis Drugs Hit a Cost Ceiling
text: Are biotechnology companies reaching the limits of how much they can charge for their drugs? One sign of that is the sluggish sales of drugs for psoriasis.

headline: On Snowbound Plains, Grim Fight to Save Calves
text: TOWNER, Colo., Jan. 17 — The temperature outside was 10 degrees and falling as calf No. 207, just one hour old, lay on the floor of the warming shed, wheezing and fighting for life.

headline: The State of the Union
text: The White House spin ahead of George W. Bush’s seventh State of the Union address was that the president would make a bipartisan call to revive his domestic agenda with “bold and innovative concepts.” The problem with that was obvious last night  in six years, Mr. Bush has shown no interest in bipartisanship, and his domestic agenda was set years ago, with huge tax cuts for wealthy Americans and crippling debt for the country.

headline: Two Long Island Boys Find Their Parents Shot to Death at Home
text: Two Long Island boys returning home from school yesterday discovered that their parents had been killed in what investigators believed was a double homicide, the Nassau County police said.

headline: Invest in Cancer Research (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Off the Menu
text: Whither Montrachet?

headline: ’60s Prejudice and Capitalism as a Big Blond Metaphor
text: “Dutchman,” the poet Amiri Baraka’s controversial 1964 race play, has always seemed an unwieldy and ineffective boxing glove jabbing at the malignancies of American capitalism, the kind of artless art James Baldwin had in mind 15 years earlier when he derisively coined the phrase “protest fiction” in The Partisan Review. The white person who goes to see this is supposed to leave feeling like a viper sent off to repent; the middle class African-American is meant to go home regarding any embrace of prosperity as weak, self-negating and lethal, both politically and spiritually.

headline: Newark: New Buses to Be Purchased, Complete With Cameras
text: New Jersey Transit yesterday approved the purchase of 1,145 buses to replace its aging fleet over the next six years. At a cost of $409.9 million, the buses will begin to arrive later this year and be equipped with multiple closed-circuit cameras that can digitally record passengers and drivers, the agency said. The cameras are activated by the driver or in the event of an accident, and officials said the cameras would lead to increased security. Roughly 200 buses will be delivered each year, and the agency said the new fleet would be more accessible to handicapped passengers and have stricter emission standards.

headline: For the Record
text: The Market Gauges chart in Business Day on Saturday for the snapshot of Schlumberger, the energy services company, provided incorrect market and financial results. The stock, trading under the ticker symbol SLB, closed at $61, not $14.98. It had a 52-week high of $74.75, not $15.37, and a 52-week low of $54, not $9.57. The price/earnings ratio was 20.27, not 35.7, and the market cap was $72.12 billion, not $3.8 billion. The 12-month E.P.S. was $3.01, not $2.56, with a yield of 1.15 percent, not 2.2 percent.

headline: Minimum Wage Bill Suffers Setback in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Prospects for an increase in the minimum wage suffered a setback today in the Senate, where a move fell short, at least for now, to raise the minimum by $2.10 an hour without tax breaks for small businesses

headline: Reworking the A-List
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 23 — The World Economic Forum convenes its annual conference here Wednesday with the theme “Shaping the Global Agenda: The Shifting Power Equation.” To judge by the names on the guest list — and those not on it — the phrase aptly reflects the turnout at this high-altitude huddle.

headline: The President and ‘Moby-Dick’ (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 52 Mayors Unite to Curb Illegal Firearms
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Mayors from some of the nation’s largest cities gathered on Tuesday to urge Congress to crack down on the trade of illegal firearms. But the mayors’ efforts, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston, generated a small protest by advocates for gun owners and dealers.

headline: Blogging for Property Sales
text: Just as Web listings transformed international real estate a decade ago, new Internet tools are making even more information available — and not just from real estate agents.

headline: EBay Profit Rises 24% on Strong Holiday Business
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 — EBay, the Internet auction giant, has scored at least a temporary victory over the mounting pressures facing its business.

headline: Profit Down, Outlook Up at Yahoo
text: Yahoo closed the books on a tough year yesterday, reporting that its sales rebounded in the fourth quarter from an especially sluggish third quarter and promising investors that it would soon turn on technology that it hoped would close the widening gap with Google.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the waning reliance of presidential candidates on public financing for campaigns included an outdated reference to Michael E. Toner, who said the 2008 election will be the most expensive in American history. As of Jan. 1, Mr. Toner is a commissioner of the Federal Election Commission. He is no longer its chairman, his position in 2006.

headline: Last Stalwart in Klein’s Top Ranks Is Going
text: As longtime veterans of the New York City school system departed in droves in recent years, especially from the top leadership ranks where Chancellor Joel I. Klein has favored outsiders from the corporate and legal worlds, one stalwart remained in the inner circle: Rose Albanese DePinto, a lifelong city educator who for most of the 1990s was principal of William Cullen Bryant High School in Queens, Mr. Klein’s alma mater.

headline: Lisa E. Goldberg, 54, Foundation President, Dies
text: Lisa E. Goldberg, president of the Charles H. Revson Foundation, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 54.

headline: Scientists Build Memory Chip as Small as Blood Cell
text: Scientists have built a working memory chip that is roughly the size of a white blood cell — about 1/2000th of an inch on a side.

headline: Recipe: Onion Soup With Pretzel-Cheese Dumplings
text: Time: 11/2 hours, plus 1 hour's infusing

headline: Strict Vegan Ethics, Frosted With Hedonism
text: ISA CHANDRA MOSKOWITZ, a vegan chef, does not particularly like to talk about tofu. Ditto seitan, tempeh and nutritional yeast.

headline: Newark: Transit Officials Propose Fare Increase
text: New Jersey Transit officials yesterday proposed a 10 percent fare increase for bus and train passengers. The officials said the increase would help close a $60 million deficit in the agency’s proposed $1.5 billion budget. The agency’s board must first vote on the proposed increase, which would take effect in June if approved. Hearings will be held in February and March to give the public a chance to comment. The agency last raised bus and rail fares in July 2005. New Jersey Transit provides about 857,000 passenger trips each weekday on 240 bus routes, 3 light rail lines and 11 commuter rail lines, the agency said.

headline: Red Storm Makes Its Last Shot Count
text: After two poor months, St. John’s has had two very good days.

headline: Starstruck Mets Fan Fined for Impersonating Reporter
text: The twin passions in the life of Ryan Leli intersected last August when the San Diego Padres came to Shea Stadium to play the New York Mets.

headline: The Price of Security (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Carpetbagger
text: David Carr reports on this year’s Oscar nominees, with reactions from many of those nominated:

headline: State Leaders Ready to Merge 2 Ethics Panels
text: ALBANY, Jan. 23  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders are expected to announce an agreement on Wednesday to combine two state commissions that look into lobbying and ethics, merging them in a bid to centralize investigations into corruption, people with knowledge of the discussions said.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Greece Seeks Cancellation of Christie’s Auction

headline: It’s a Deal: You Like Me and I Like Me Too
text: Forget about false modesty, not to mention its nonfalse counterpart. Jamie Foxx came to Madison Square Garden on Monday night to celebrate his favorite singer, his favorite actor, his favorite comedian, his favorite sex symbol and his favorite storyteller, who all happen to share his name. Near the end, Mr. Foxx morphed into Ray Charles  only to thank himself for doing such a good job playing himself in “Ray.”

headline: At Brandeis, Carter Responds to Critics
text: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 23 — In his first major public speech about his controversial book “Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid,” former President Jimmy Carter told an audience at Brandeis University on Tuesday that he stood by the book and its title, that he apologized for what he called an “improper and stupid” sentence in the book and that he had been disturbed by accusations that he was anti-Semitic.

headline: Murdoch Said to Join Tribune Bid
text: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for the Tribune Company — Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post.

headline: A State of the Union Tableau for the History Books
text: It was the annual State of the Union address, but the tableau looked more like a moment of reckoning on “Judge Judy.” Behind the president, the new speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, sat — and occasionally stood to clap — a mint green weathervane of the mood in the room.

headline: New York Public Hospitals Fear Proposed Medicaid Changes
text: New York City’s public hospitals and clinics would lose billions of dollars over the next few years under changes President Bush proposes to make to Medicaid  far more than his plan would cost other parts of the country, according to local and state officials.

headline: With DNA From Exhumed Body, Man Finally Wins Freedom
text: AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 23 — Roy Brown, who spent 15 years in prison on a murder conviction and uncovered evidence while there that linked another man to the crime, was released from prison on Tuesday after DNA tests on the other man’s exhumed body matched saliva on a nightshirt at the crime scene.

headline: Cheesy Pasta, Redressed
text: THERE was a time when pasta dishes dressed with just cheese, cream or milk were popular, at least with me and my family, but today they seem stodgy and fat. Although these popular standbys almost always feature a strong hit of black pepper, they don’t contain acidity or real spice, and seem one-dimensional despite the strong flavors. They’re also almost always white, beige and yellow, not exactly a stunning color combination for what for us was often a weeknight main course.

headline: A Case of Hearing Without Listening
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Suns Work Hard to Make Their Games Look That Fun
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — Playing in perpetual fast-forward, the Phoenix Suns have become the blur that cannot be beat.

headline: A Relative Bargain in a Corner of the Village
text: In New York City’s sizzling commercial real estate sector, one of the rare submarkets where the statistics appear relatively weak is Hudson Square. In this wedge of the West Village, the office vacancy rate was 18.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006, compared with a rate of 6.7 percent for Manhattan as a whole, according to figures compiled by Cushman & Wakefield.

headline: For the Record
text: An obituary on Jan. 12 about the producer and writer Steve Krantz misspelled the surname of his surviving sister. She is Sunny Onish, not Ornish.

headline: 8 Arrested in 1971 Killing of San Francisco Police Officer
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 — Eight men, including seven described as members of the radical Black Liberation Army, were arrested on Tuesday on charges of murdering a police officer here in 1971 and waging a violent five-year battle against the police and federal authorities.

headline: After Getting Family Out of Shelter, Mother Has a New Challenge: Paying the Rent
text: In March, necessity moved Carmen Laureano and her two daughters from Florida to New York City.

headline: Follow the Money All the Way to the Kitchen
text: I’M in Utah, freezing,” the chef Michelle Bernstein said over her cellphone.

headline: Corrections
text: The DealBook column on Jan. 14 in Sunday Business, about what some chief executives say during takeover battles, referred incompletely to the position of Delta Air Lines and its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, on merger proposals. As the column noted, Delta has rejected a takeover offer from US Airways and says that it wants to come out of bankruptcy as an independent airline. Yet it has also been privately talking with Northwest Airlines. While Mr. Grinstein had not publicly commented on reports of the talks with Northwest until yesterday, he had indeed said that Delta had a fiduciary duty to consider all alternatives, including mergers. (Go to Article)

headline: Martin Luther Al-King?
text: It’s hard to know what’s more disturbing: the barbaric sectarian murders by Sunnis and Shiites in Iraq, or the deafening silence with which these mass murders are received in the Muslim world. How could it be that Danish cartoons of Muhammad led to mass violent protests, while unspeakable violence by Muslims against Muslims in Iraq every day evokes about as much reaction in the Arab-Muslim world as the weather report? Where is the Muslim Martin Luther King? Where is the “Million Muslim March” under the banner: “No Shiites, No Sunnis: We are all children of the Prophet Muhammad.”

headline: For N.H.L.’s Top TV Producer, Big Picture, Small Screen
text: John Shannon is watching.

headline: Smokers Welcome: Try This at Home
text: WINTER does strange things to grill lovers cooped up in city kitchens. They start daydreaming about smoldering hardwood.

headline: A World Champion, Meissner Now Seeks National Title
text: In some ways, the United States Figure Skating Championships seem to be in a full post-Olympic-year swoon.

headline: Man Convicted in Police Killings Offers Apology
text: A man who was convicted of killing two undercover detectives read an apology today in the sentencing phase of his trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: A Healthy, Well-Regulated Wall Street
text: A healthy financial sector is crucial to the economic well-being of this country and to New York City in particular. And it is true that Wall Street is facing ever stiffer competition from financial markets like London’s and Hong Kong’s. But beware of the doomsayers who argue that American markets are in free fall and — not incidentally — contend that looser regulations are the only way to save them.

headline: In Kiffin, Raiders Are Putting Young Face in Tough Job
text: At 3 months old, Pressley Kiffin already looks to be in the market for silver makeup, metal spikes and a Darth Vader mask.

headline: In Venezuela, Chavismo Is Dissected by Fans and Foes
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  “You and I know that, as some people say, I’m only a lieutenant colonel, I’m not a summa cum laude doctor,” President Hugo Chávez casually told a few million viewers of his Sunday talk show, “Hello President.” “I modestly contribute a few ideas.”

headline: Correction: An Italian Spot, Larded With Drive
text: A review last Wednesday of the restaurant Porchetta in Brooklyn misstated an ingredient in a chicken dish. They are cannellini beans, not cannelloni beans.

headline: In Address, Bush Insists U.S. Must Not Fail in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — President Bush tried to resuscitate his ailing presidency Tuesday night, using his State of the Union address to present a modest agenda of energy and health care proposals while warning an increasingly assertive Congress against undercutting his new Iraq strategy.

headline: Robinson’s Relevance Spans the Decades
text: Since it is still football season, the eye could not help but notice a fleet, powerful running back from U.C.L.A. flickering on the video screen, accelerating down the left sideline and then instinctively veering back toward the middle, right past three hapless defenders rushing the wrong way.

headline: The Oscar Nominees
text: BEST PICTURE

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup last Wednesday about reaction to the star player David Beckham’s decision to leave Real Madrid for the Los Angeles Galaxy misstated the given name of Real Madrid’s president. He is Ramón Calderón, not Raúl.

headline: E. Howard Hunt, Agent Who Organized Botched Watergate Break-In, Dies at 88
text: E. Howard Hunt, a cold warrior for the Central Intelligence Agency who left the spy service in disillusionment, joined the Nixon White House as a secret agent and bungled the break-in at the Watergate that brought the president down in disgrace, died Tuesday in Miami. He was 88.

headline: Move Over Silicon Valley, Here Come European Start-Ups
text: MUNICH, Jan. 23 — A technology and media conference being held here this week provided ample evidence that Silicon Valley’s dominance of Internet-style technology innovation is waning.

headline: In Pittsburgh, a Music Director to Replace Three Conductors
text: Two seasons ago the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra announced it was moving in a “bold new direction” by hiring three conductors, rather than following the lone music director model that dominates American orchestras.

headline: Nepal: U.N. Creates New Political Mission
text: The United Nations Security Council voted to set up a mission to oversee a disarmament and cease-fire accord between the government and former Maoist rebels and plan elections of a constitutional assembly in June. The vote creates a force of military monitors, police and civil administration teams and poll watchers, which was requested by each sides and will last a year.

headline: Senators Say Resolutions on Troop Plan Should Merge
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Senate critics of President Bush’s troop buildup in Iraq suggested Tuesday that competing resolutions opposing the plan should be merged in an effort to attract the largest bloc of senators in a strong statement of Congressional dissent.

headline: Fresh Faces Give U.S. Team a Boost and a Win
text: The youth of America served Bob Bradley well.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy misstated the name of the university whose president, former Senator Bob Kerrey, commented on campaign donors. It is the New School, not the New School University.

headline: Youth to Be in Spotlight at N.H.L. All-Star Game
text: DALLAS, Jan. 23 — The National Hockey League trotted out Oscar-style surroundings for its first All-Star Game festivities in three years, with a red carpet, paparazzi, fans clamoring for autographs behind barricades, a television interviewer, cheerleader escorts and an honor guard tapping hockey sticks on the cold cement in salute.

headline: Israeli Prime Minister Urges President to Resign
text: HERZLIYA, Israel, Jan. 24 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert called this evening for President Moshe Katsav to resign after the Israeli attorney general announced his intention to indict Mr. Katsav on criminal charges including rape, abuse of power, obstruction of justice, fraud, sexual harassment and breach of trust.

headline: China: One-Child Policy Spurred Gender Gap
text: China’s top population official said that a worsening gender imbalance had been complicated by population control efforts and that it would take 15 years to redress. The official, Zhang Weiqing, head of the National Population and Family Planning Commission, said 118 boys were born for every 100 girls in China in 2005, largely because of a preference for male offspring, which has driven many families to abort female fetuses under the one-child policy.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,023 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Ethiopian Forces Start Leaving Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 23  The Ethiopian troops who helped install Somalia’s fledging government in Mogadishu, its capital, began to pull out Tuesday, officials from each country said.

headline: Around the Clock, Beethoven Magnified
text: Never has listening to the Ninth Symphony of Beethoven required so much attention.

headline: For the Record
text: A Classical Music entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure incorrectly described “Decasia,” being performed Thursday through Saturday at Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts. The concert consists of a score by Michael Gordon and a film by Bill Morrison, not a video. The entry also omitted information about advance tickets. They are available only through ticketmania.com, not at the center.

headline: Nymex Abandoning Plans for British Futures Market
text: LONDON, Jan. 23 — Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a lonely champion of open-outcry trading, is cutting its last ties to an ill-fated plan to set up a trading floor in Britain.

headline: E-ZPass for Passports? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Governor and Lawmakers Offer Ethics Bill
text: ALBANY, Jan. 24 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders announced a package of sweeping changes to existing ethics policies, but they were greeted coolly by civic groups who have long pushed for such changes.

headline: Contributor to Gossip Column Won’t Be Charged
text: Federal prosecutors have decided not to file charges against a former freelance contributor to The New York Post’s Page Six gossip column after an investigation into whether he had demanded payments for favorable coverage, a lawyer for the contributor said yesterday.

headline: Gimme an Oil Change and a Tankful of Ribs
text: TO get to Mo Gridder’s BBQ, go to the Bronx, then head to Hunts Point Avenue. Drive east under the Bruckner, through the more residential part of Hunts Point, where I spied a stroller tangled in barbed wire atop a rusted fence, where tied-together sneakers hung slung over tree branches overhead and where a wizened, weathered Chihuahua, loitering outside a bodega, eyed passers-by with suspicion.

headline: A Promise on Immigration Now a Problem for Spitzer
text: In his campaign for governor, Eliot Spitzer repeatedly expressed support for the licensing of all New York drivers regardless of their immigration status. Now expectations are running high among those urging the governor to change policies that deny licenses to 250,000 drivers in the state, most because they cannot prove they are legal immigrants.

headline: Kerry Bows Out of 2008 Race
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 – Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who narrowly lost the presidency to George Bush in 2004, announced today that he would not proceed with a second bid for the White House because he preferred to use his position in the new Senate majority to press for an end to American involvement in Iraq.

headline: Queens: 2 Dead, and Murder-Suicide Is Suspected
text: A 30-year-old man and his 21-year-old female companion were found fatally shot yesterday in an apartment in Sunnyside. The police believe the man shot the woman before turning a gun on himself. The woman’s mother, who lived with her daughter in the apartment on 49th Street, discovered the two shot in the head about 7 p.m. A .22-caliber gun was found near the man, whose name was not immediately released pending family notification, the police said. The woman, Gabriella Alcivir, had requested a restraining order against the man after she said he assaulted her in September, a law enforcement official said. But the two had since reconciled, the official said.

headline: Pucker Up and Smile: A Bottle Full of Surprises
text: Here is a taste of sunshine just when you need it. The kitchen at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), is preparing preserved lemons, but with a bright, palate-pleasing departure from the salt-cured Moroccan recipe. It uses Meyer lemons, which are sweeter than regular lemons, and cures them not just with salt but also with a touch of sugar, then bathes them in olive oil.

headline: Bush Revives Some Past Proposals and Offers a New Initiative on Health Insurance
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 — President Bush delivered a domestic agenda to Congressional Democrats on Tuesday that was, in large part, modest and a reiteration of past proposals. Where he did break ground — on health care — his initiative was quickly dismissed by leading Democrats and seemed unlikely to form the basis of bipartisan action.

headline: Tennessee Court Orders Return of Girl, 7, to Biological Parents
text: NASHVILLE, Jan. 23 — Almost eight years after a Chinese couple living in Memphis placed their daughter into what they thought was temporary foster care, the Tennessee Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered that she be returned to her biological parents.

headline: As Her World Turns, Lonelygirl15 Seeks New Thrills
text: Lonelygirl15 wants a career. She’s considering becoming a forest ranger but lacks the stomach for herd-thinning. Teaching aerobics is another option, but she’s worried she’s too smart for that.

headline: Dedication to Douglass
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: The most ordinary household objects — even drawer pulls or measuring cups — can seem exotic when they are purchased in a foreign marketplace.

headline: Currents
text: Getting the makeup table ready for its close-up, home and garden supplies, carefully pruned and more.

headline: New In the Loo
text: New high-end urinals.

headline: Holocaust Denier Deniers
text: More than 100 Iranian artists and intellectuals signed a statement condemning a Holocaust conference, largely given over to Holocaust deniers, that was sponsored by the Iranian government in Tehran in December. The statement, which appears in the forthcoming issue of The New York Review of Books and on its Web site (nybooks.com), begins by acknowledging “our diverse views on the Israeli-Palestinian question.” It condemns the conference’s “attempt to falsify history” and pays “homage to the memory of the millions of Jewish and non-Jewish victims of the Holocaust,’’ as well as “other victims of crimes against humanity across the world.” Azar Nafisi, the author of “Reading Lolita in Tehran,” who helped to create the statement with Roya and Ladan Boroumand, the founders of a human-rights group in Iran, said in a telephone interview that many people could not voice their objections to the conference inside Iran for fear of reprisals, but that “we felt that as Iranians, we should make a statement” that the conference “should not come out in our names.”

headline: Physical Culture
text: Gear test with Martinique Davis and Erik Aura, ski patrollers.

headline: Global Warming? Whatever.
text: Speaking of climate change — and at this year’s World Economic Forum, they are — the springlike weather in Davos took a wintery turn as the conference began, as The New York Times’s Mark Landler told us in this update:

headline: Profit Down, Outlook Up at Yahoo
text: Yahoo closed the books on a tough year Tuesday, reporting that its sales rebounded in the fourth quarter from an especially sluggish third quarter and promising investors that it would soon turn on technology that it hoped would close the widening gap with Google.

headline: Is Silicon Valley’s Dominance Fading?
text: With New York’s dominance as the world’s financial center being threatened by the likes of London and Hong Kong, some are beginning to wonder if Silicon Valley is next on the hit-list of American corporate mainstays. A technology and media conference being held in Munich this week provided ample evidence that Silicon Valley’s dominance of Internet-style technology innovation is waning, according to The New York Times. The gathering, Digital Life Design, has become a showcase for a range of European entrepreneurs who have taken the start-up culture pioneered in Silicon Valley as a template and are successfully transplanting it across the Atlantic.

headline: Bank of America Tones Down Deposit Cap Stance
text: Bank of America‘s chairman and chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Tuesday that the company was backing away from a quiet lobbying effort to change a federal law that could prevent it from making major acquisitions. Just weeks after agreeing to initiate discussions with lawmakers to raise the possibility of lifting the 10 percent federal deposit cap, Kenneth D. Lewis told The New York Times that he had told bank representatives to “back off” from those plans.

headline: Nymex Abandoning Plans for British Futures Market
text: Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a lonely champion of open-outcry trading, is cutting its last ties to an ill-fated plan to set up a trading floor in Britain. The commodities market has quietly applied for “derecognition of exchange” with British regulators, traders in London said.

headline: Kerr-McGee Is Found Liable in Lawsuit Over Oil Royalties
text: A federal jury in Denver agreed Tuesday with a former top auditor for the Interior Department that Kerr-McGee had cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties on oil it produced in publicly owned coastal waters. The decision, reached by the jury after deliberations of about four hours, is a vindication for the auditor, Bobby L. Maxwell. He became a whistle-blower and sued Kerr-McGee as a private citizen after top officials at the Interior Department ordered him to drop his audit findings.

headline: Sam Zell’s I-Told-You-So Moment
text: The battle over Equity Office Properties is sweet vindication for its founder, Samuel Zell, who has long argued that Wall Street has not given his company the respect it deserved. Many analysts have been scornful, or at best skeptical, of the Chicago real estate magnate’s strategy of creating a national brand of office buildings scattered among 37 metropolitan areas. But the bidding war by Vornado Realty Trust and the acquisition-hungry private equity firm Blackstone Group seems to be showing them up.

headline: Man Drops Hostile Bid for Scania, Offering Honey Instead
text: Man dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid for the Swedish truck maker Scania after opposition emerged from Volkswagen, Scania’s largest shareholder, and will seek a friendly merger instead. Man, Volkswagen and Scania “see the industrial logic behind a combination” of the three businesses, but such a combination is not possible under the existing offer, Man said.

headline: The Davos Quiz
text: Whether you have followed World Economic Forum since it began in 1971 (as the Davos Symposium) or tuned in more recently (maybe the celebrity-focused Forum panel called “Star Power and Social Change” piqued your interest), we encourage Davos Diary readers to try their hand at our Davos trivia quiz. There’s no prize for getting all five questions right, other than a virtual pat on the back from the Davos Diary crew.

headline: Warner and Sony Back Asian Music Venture
text: The Warner Music Group and Sony BMG have signed a deal to develop technology for distributing music downloads and multimedia entertainment to wireless customers throughout China and other Asia-Pacific markets. The two music companies are investing an undisclosed amount in Access China Media Solutions, a partnership created by Tokyo-based Access and Melodeo of Seattle. Western companies looking to enter China’s music market have had to navigate piracy-laden territory and the deal represents the music major’s efforts to encourage the growth a legitimate music business.

headline: Broadcom Faults Chief in Options-Backdating Scandal
text: Broadcom said Henry T. Nicholas III, its co-founder and former chief executive, bore “significant responsibility” for improperly backdated stock options that led it to disclose $2.2 billion in unreported expenses on Tuesday. The computer-chip maker restated earnings to take the huge noncash charge, the largest reported so far by any of the nearly 200 companies caught up in the scandal over manipulating the timing of option grants.

headline: Eisner and Wenner Team up for Celebrity TV
text: Michael Eisner and Jann Wenner, who once joined forces to save a celebrity magazine, are about to reunite in the world of Internet video. Wenner Media and Veoh Networks announced a partnership Monday between Usmagazine.com, the Web site for Wenner’s Us Weekly, and Veoh.com, a video-sharing Web site and a competitor of YouTube.com, to create a celebrity entertainment channel on Veoh. Mr. Wenner leads the privately owned Wenner Media, while Mr. Eisner, the former chief executive of Walt Disney, is a major investor in Veoh and brokered the deal.

headline: Internet Capital Faces Battle With Hedge Fund
text: Internet Capital Group, whose market value eclipsed that of General Motors during the dot-com boom, may face a proxy fight with an activist hedge fund that is taking issue with company’s management. Mason Capital Management, a New York-based hedge fund, said it had increased its stake to 9.5 percent from 8 percent and might seek board seats at Internet Capital.

headline: College Students Get the I-Banking Pitch
text: For undergraduates majoring in business, intersession — the time after January exams, but before the commence of the second semester — is apparently not the hibernating, beer-guzzling extravaganza that their less-finance minded peers appear to be enjoying. At least some of the college students gearing up for a career in banking use the vacation to get a head start on the competitive summer internship process with a whirlwind tour of some of New York’s most prestigious investment banks, according to BusinessWeek, which sent a reporter along with the students to check out the pitches the banks are giving. Advil, it seems, is a necessary component.

headline: Wrigley’s Doubles Its Pleasure With a Chocolate Buy
text: Wm. Wrigley Jr., the world’s largest chewing-gum maker, agreed to buy 80 percent of Russia’s A. Korkunov for $300 million in its first acquisition of a chocolate company. Closely held A. Korkunov, which was founded in 1999 by a pair of entrepreneurs, makes bonbons and chocolate bars and is Russia’s seventh-biggest chocolate maker. It had 2006 sales of $100 million, Chicago-based Wrigley said.

headline: American Airlines Parent to Raise $500 Million in Share Sale
text: AMR plans to issue and sell 13 million shares of stock, an offering that would bring the parent of American Airlines about $500 million based on its offering price Tuesday of $38.70 a share.The company plans to use some of the proceeds to help pay off debt. Underwriters Credit Suisse, UBS and Merrill Lynch will also have a 30-day option to purchase an additional 1.95 million shares to cover any overallotments.

headline: Yankee Candle Shareholders Say Yes to a Buyout
text: Madison Dearborn Partners‘ $1.4 billion buyout of Yankee Candle moved one step closer to completion Tuesday after Yankee stockholders formally voted to accept the private equity firm’s all-cash $34.75-a-share proposal.

headline: Microsoft Caught Trying to Buy Wikipedia Tweaks
text: Microsoft has apparently run afoul of the editors of the communal online reference Wikipeda, the people’s encyclopedia where anyone can edit entries on any topic, but where the overall integrity of the site is policed by an army of volunteer overseers who attempt to weed out destructive, trivial and agenda-driven entries and changes.

headline: Black and Co-Defendants to Be Tried Together
text: Conrad Black will be tried along with co-defendants when his criminal trial begins in Chicago next month, and “appropriate” instructions will be given to the jury to avoid “spill-over guilt,” the judge presiding over the case has ruled. Judge Amy St. Eve said that “because the counts are properly joined and because defendants have failed to establish any prejudice that would require severance, the court denies their respective motions to sever.”

headline: Kraft Serves Up Cream of Wheat to B&G
text: Kraft Foods said Tuesday it would sell its hot cereal business, including the popular Cream of Wheat products, to a subsidiary of B&G Foods for $200 million. “Our decision to sell Cream of Wheat is part of a broader effort at Kraft to focus our portfolio,” Rick Searer, president of Kraft’s North America commercial segment, said in a statement.

headline: Williams-Sonoma Denies Hiring Goldman to Explore Options
text: Williams-Sonoma, the owner of kitchenware stores and the Pottery Barn home decor retail chain, denied Tuesday it had hired Goldman Sachs or any other investment bank to explore strategic options, calling it an “absolutely incorrect” rumor. Williams-Sonoma, whose shares rose more than 3 percent in after-hours trading following a Reuters report that the company had hired the investment bank, said in a statement it generally does not comment on market speculation, but it felt compelled to do so in this case because “this rumor is absolutely incorrect.”

headline: Newbridge to Take Controlling Stake in Taiwan Insurance Firm
text: The buyout firm Newbridge Capital agreed to take control of Union Insurance of Taiwan, part of the troubled Rebar Asia Pacific Group, for $100 million, Union Insurance said. Union will use the money to increase its capital, and Newbridge, which will receive at least 50 percent of the company’s stock in exchange, would become its controlling shareholder after the deal, Union Insurance said.

headline: New York and Tokyo Exchanges Said to Be Near Deal
text: The Tokyo and New York stock exchanges are in the final stages of alliance talks and may come to an agreement as soon as the end of the month, the head of the Tokyo exchange told The Wall Street Journal. Taizo Nishimuro, president of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, said the two exchanges may make an announcement on their tie-up details after a planned two-day trip to New York starting next Tuesday.

headline: Goldman and Morgan Eye Dominion Bid, Report Says
text: The investing arms of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are working on a $15 billion private-equity play for the oil-and-gas assets of the utility company Dominion Resources, The Wall Street Journal reported. Goldman and Morgan are said to be part of a consortium that includes the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, Warburg Pincus, First Reserve and the Carlyle Group and its affiliate Riverstone Holdings. The Journal said that it may end up bidding against a rival consortium, made up of Blackstone Group, Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which is also exploring an offer.

headline: New York Observer Owner Mulls New Jersey Paper
text: The New York Observer‘s owner, Jared Kushner, could be just weeks away from making a decision about bankrolling a free weekly newspaper in New Jersey. “A final decision will be made by the end of February or early March,” Mr. Kushner’s spokesman, Howard Rubenstein, told The New York Post, adding that Mr. Kushner has been encouraged by the initial reaction to the proposed paper.

headline: Times Shareholder Unhappy Over Vote Rebuff
text: The New York Times Company shareholder Morgan Stanley Investment Management, which has been pushing for changes in the voting structure of the Times, said the publisher rebuffed its effort to let investors vote on a proposal to scrap rules that cement family control of the company. Morgan Stanley Investment Management, owner of more than 10 million Times shares, said in a letter to the board that a vote would have let investors express their views on the company’s performance and governance.

headline: Will Murdoch Breathe Life into Tribune Auction?
text: Yet another media mogul has reportedly entered the fray for Tribune, Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, whose holdings include Fox News and The New York Post. Mr. Murdoch’s goal, according to The New York Times, is to gain a stake in Newsday, the Long Island newspaper in Melville that is owned by Tribune, so that he can combine its back-office functions with those of the money losing Post as a way to cut costs.

headline: Owner of Lavalife Said to Seek Buyer
text: Vertrue, which runs the matchmaking Web site Lavalife, has hired an investment bank, Jefferies Broadview, to help sell the company, The New York Post reported, citing sources close to the deal it did not identify.

headline: We Have a Winner
text: Thanks for your patience as I procrastinated in choosing a winner. Now all of you know why I’m in the newspaper business. Without deadlines, I’m convinced I would never leave my couch. (If you’re about to blow deadline at a newspaper, you get yelled at, and that somehow does the trick.)

headline: Giuliani Is Expected to Sell His Investment Bank
text: the former Mayor of New York Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently taken steps to sell the biggest division of his consulting business as he considers running for the presidency, according to a person with detailed knowledge of the firm’s plans. The sale of the division, Giuliani Capital Advisors, a boutique investment bank, is being pursued to prevent its clients’ activities from being used against Mr. Giuliani in a heated political campaign, said that person, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Delta, US Air Executives to Testify on Airline Mergers
text: The Senate will hear testimony about the effects of potential airline mergers Wednesday morning, as the takeover feud between US Airways and Delta Air Lines comes to a possible head. Top executives of both airlines will field questions from lawmakers about US Airways’ unsolicited $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta — which Delta has opposed — as other players continue to try to influence the endgame.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Puts $700 Million Into Sun
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts announced a $700 million investment in Sun Microsystems, a maker of computer servers, and said it would take a seat on Sun’s board. The Financial Times called the investment “one of the most striking deals yet in a wave of transactions that has brought private equity money into the tech industry.” But a Sun executive said Tuesday that the company has no intention of going private.

headline: Some Early, Smart Money?
text: “And guess what? I think ‘Letters From Iwo Jima’ wins this Best Picture race.” — Kris Tapley at InContention, a guy who actually makes phone calls on the way to pronouncing. He reports, he decides.

headline: Live from Davos: Day 2
text: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland, home of the annual conference of the World Economic Forum. Wall Street chief executives and private equity kings are here aplenty: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of J.P. Morgan Chase, Charles Prince of Citigroup, Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone Group and David Rubenstein of Carlyle Group, just to name a few. Several panels on this week’s agenda should provide some interesting grist for dealmakers, including “Is Bigger Better in Private Equity?” and “The M&A Landscape: Developing the 2007 Heatmap.”

headline: A Taboo Link
text: If you thought there was something missing in the energy section of the State of the Union address, there’s a new Web site to fill in the gap.

headline: The  Splits
text: The Bagger remains torn between two worlds. Later on, you will see videos that make it appear that he is still at Sundance, but like all television, even Web TV, that is a lie. He stacked a few up while he was there and they will be doled out to justify his expenses.

headline: Discovering Cold Fusion
text: Every once in a while here at the moveable feast that is Bagger HQ — he is currently at Le Meredien hotel in L.A., awaiting permission to stop typing — things get so quiet that the Bagger begins shouting down the blog, “Haaaalooooooo.” Nothing but echo. Or sure, there are a few comments here and there, but the Bagger often senses they are made out of pity, just to let him know that you are there for him, man. He sees the robust comment sections of other blogs and wonders what they have that he doesn’t. He wonders what makes the noisy, exotic birds of the forest pipe up. Oh yeah, real news.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Power Vacuums, C.E.O. Pay, Shrimp
text: Who’s in charge here? That seems to be a question that more people are asking, on a global scale, heading into this year’s conference in Davos.

headline: Dreams, Unfulfilled
text: The Bagger made a fool of himself bragging early on about a “Dreamgirls” sweep. By the time this Oscar is over, that’s going to cost him some money on a bet he made with a wily industry vet. And say what you want about Nikki Finke, she serves up some mighty tasty crow.

headline: Tempest in a Coffee Cup
text: A Chinese television news anchor, Rui Chenggang, has brought his campaign against the Starbucks coffee shop in Beijing’s Forbidden City to Davos.

headline: Not Exactly a Slam Dunk, Mr. President
text: Opinionland is unimpressed with President Bush’s State of the Union address. “It is always tempting to take the State of the Union address seriously,” begins The Los Angeles Times editorial page, before explaining why this particular address was particularly unserious.

headline: Most Horrible Sound in the World
text: A professor at Britain’s Salford University, Trevor Cox, claims to have reached a new plateau in the understanding of human hearing and acoustics, based on a year of input from of over a million online test subjects: Vomiting is the worst sound ever.

headline: Bush’s Plan: A View From the 2008 Crowd
text: As the Senate Foreign Relations Committee begins considering resolutions opposing President Bush’s plan to increase troop levels in Iraq by 21,500, many of the potential 2008 presidential contenders have weighed in with their own positions. At this juncture, here’s how they stand:

headline: Webb’s Winning Reply
text: After turning their collective thumb down for President Bush’s performance at the State of the Union, the nation’s political-theater critics give an approving thumbs-up, way up to the Democratic response delivered by Virginia’s new senator, James Webb. The New Republic’s Michael Crowley says it was the best Democratic speech of the past two and a half years. “That response could do for Webb something akin to what Barack Obama’s 2004 convention speech did for the Illinois senator,” Crowley writes at The Plank. “Maybe not on quite the same scale. But I can’t think of another Democratic speech since Obama’s that was half as good.”

headline: Ugly Bears and Bulls
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Can the “Goldilocks Economy” — one that is not too hot and not too cold — endure? And can any literary allusion be stretched any further?

headline: Sabadell of Spain Buys a Florida Bank for $175 Million
text: Banco Sabadell of Spain said on Wednesday it had agreed to buy TransAtlantic Bank if Florida for $175 million, following other Spanish banks already in the United States.

headline: The War at Home: A Disagreement Over How to Agree to Disagree
text: Right now, there are two competing Senate resolutions expressing disapproval of President Bush’s new Iraq strategy to send more troops to Baghdad. Sponsors of the original bill are hoping to merge the two to present a united front against the president. But sponsors of the newer, milder bill, including Senator John Warner, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, are saying not so fast.

headline: War at Home: Senate Begins Iraq Debate
text: Keep an eye on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today – the White House surely is – as the first Congressional resolution on President Bush’s Iraq policy takes shape.

headline: Senator Clinton: ‘I Know What It Takes to Run The Country’
text: It is Day 5 of her presidential campaign, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has shown near-total poise and confidence in public thus far, with nary an uncertain note about pursuing the most powerful job in the world.

headline: Hail to the Chef
text: The restaurant Alain Ducasse at the Essex House isn’t around anymore, but if you went before it closed at the turn of the year, you may remember the following details:

headline: A (Nearly) Bear-Free Zone
text: Practitioners of the dismal science were anything but on Wednesday, as several prominent economists offered their outlooks in a Davos session called “Update 2007: The Global Economy.” As The New York Times’s Floyd Norris told us, even the most pessimistic member of the panel expressed only mild concern about the possibility of a worldwide economic downturn.

headline: Reader Responses
text: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt’s Jan. 24 column on the economics of illness prevention:

headline: A Graceful John Cusack
text: The Carpetbagger talks with John Cusack at the Sundance Film Festival about his new film, "Grace is Gone."

headline: State of the Union Lullaby
text: Bloggers left and right are debating whether Sen. John McCain, the maverick Republican from Arizona and 2008 presidential hopeful, was nodding off during the President’s State of the Union address last night, or merely perusing papers in his lap — a copy of the speech, perhaps.

headline: Full Nelson
text: Ryan Gosling, whose extraordinary portrayal, in “Half Nelson,” of an idealistic school teacher who is also a crack addict earned a best actor nomination, said by telephone that his family was over the moon.

headline: Solving a Video Chat Problem
text: So many products that I review fall into the category of, “Solutions to problems nobody really has,” that it’s a delight to find something that solves a real problem that’s been driving a lot of people crazy.

headline: New York Senators and the White House
text: Here’s a history lesson — with help from an attentive reader who is a fan of New York political trivia.

headline: Home Depot’s New C.E.O. to Receive $8.9 Million
text: Home Depot may pay its chief executive, Frank Blake $8.9 million this year, less than the $39.7 million it paid his predecessor, Robert Nardelli, who was ousted this month amid criticism of his compensation. Mr. Blake, who took over Jan. 2, received a base salary of $975,000. He will get the rest if he meets the board’s profit and stock performance goals, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: New Hampshire vs. the Democratic Party
text: Another showdown is brewing. This time, it’s between the Democratic National Committee and the whole state of New Hampshire.

headline: Obama’s Religion and Schooling
text: For the past several days, charges and rumors — which appear to have been debunked — have been flying around that Senator Barack Obama attended a radical Muslim school as a child in Indonesia.

headline: While the Senator Dozed
text: John McCain is a very dignified sleeper. He’s one of those who can probably stay upright, mouth in a neat, thin line, while in an airplane seat. And even wake refreshed. Is this a POW thing? Or a Senate thing?

headline: From Tony Blair to Bill Gates
text: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin reports from the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Renting in Paradise
text: We’ve had friends who rented a house in Cape Cod that was advertised as “steps to the beach.” They discovered that “forced march to the beach” would have been more accurate. (Although, technically, 4,000 steps does qualify as “steps.”)

headline: Law-Firm Salary Watch: Who Else Will Go Higher?
text: Once again, the top New York law firms are leapfrogging each other to recruit talent by raising salary offers for first-year associates. The latest bump-up has attracted a lot of attention in legal circles, and raised some questions as well. For example: Will California firms follow? And what about the New York offices of California-based firms? Some of them are expected to come up with the extra cash — particularly the ones that consider themselves competitors with top firms either nationally or in New York.

headline: The State of the Presidency
text: Some of the country’s best political minds have put the State of the Union speech on the couch for a probing analysis.The Caucus Question of the Day: Based on last night’s address, what’s your diagnosis of the Bush presidency? Let us know in the comments section below, and if you have a prescription, we’d be especially interested in that, too.

headline: 2008: Kerry Not Running
text: In these days when everyone and their brother seems to be running for president, someone today decided that he was not: Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who lost to President Bush in 2004.

headline: Tech Companies and Global Rights: Cisco Responds
text: We have an update on our post last week about a union of technology companies, academics and human rights groups seeking to develop a set of principles for Western businesses operating in countries where it has proven all too easy for them to become — or at least appear to become — accomplices to regimes that repress free speech, privacy and other basic rights.

headline: Edwards Appeals to Congress With Ad
text: John Edwards may have left Congress, but he doesn’t necessarily want Congress to forget about him.

headline: Ethics Day in Albany
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the legislative leaders rolled out their ethics reform plan at a press conference this morning to something of a mixed response from civic groups who have long pushed for change.

headline: Valleywag: ‘Steve Jobs Is in Jeopardy’
text: Steve Jobs may have briefly distracted everyone from the options-backdating scandal at Apple by waving the iPhone around at MacWorld, but Valleywag is offering what it calls a “reality check,” in which it lists five reasons it thinks that Mr. Jobs “is in jeopardy, more serious than has been acknowledged.” Others have made similar warnings, but Valleywag’s comes one day after Bloomberg News reported that investigators from both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department questioned Mr. Jobs last week.

headline: After A.I., Tune In to A.C.!
text: Nick is going to be on CNN’s Anderson Cooper 360 Wednesday at 10 p.m. Eastern. The story is about Nick’s recent trip to Cambodia and his search for Srey Mom, a teenage .

headline: Superpowers and Blogger Power
text: This year’s overarching theme at Davos — the “shifting power equation” — apparently means many things to the throngs gathered here. For some, it crystallized a growing concern that established institutions are losing power. Rogue states and nonstate actors threaten disorder on the global stage, which could take the form of weapons proliferation, terrorism or the spread of AIDS and other deadly diseases. These threats “create an environment in which the things we treasure cannot prosper,” Richard N. Haas, the president of the Council on Foreign Relations, said in a panel Wednesday called “The Shifting Power Equation: Geopolitics.”

headline: Ethics Front-Runner — and ‘Maverick’
text: Eliot Spitzer and the executive director of the Lobbying Commission, David Grandeau, have had their dust-ups in the past, and one of the big questions in the ethics overhaul announced today is the future of Mr. Grandeau.

headline: War at Home: Resolution Passes Senate Panel
text: As you may have heard, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in a 12-9 vote, passed a nonbinding resolution this afternoon opposing President Bush’s plan to increase troop levels in Iraq by 21,500.

headline: Ad Attacks Mayor’s 9/11 Memorial Plan
text: The three-year battle over the arrangement of victims’ names at the 9/11 memorial escalated today with the release of a TV ad denouncing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan for the arrangement of victims’ names at the memorial.The family groups have their own plan for the arrangement of the names that would include more information about where the victims worked and where they died, as well as the ranks of uniformed rescuers. It would also included their ages.

headline: Climate Change?
text: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin offers an overview of Day 1 at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: A Buyout Consortium — for Charity
text: Buyout firms often pool their resources together to make astronomical takeover offers for companies. But now it seems many of the biggest names in private equity are forming a consortium for a different reason. Reuters reports that about 800 people from throughout finance are stopping by London Wednesday evening to raise money for the Private Equity Foundation, a new nonprofit aimed at funding charities. Among those involved are top figures from the Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital, Permira Advisors and Texas Pacific Group, many scheduled to appear at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Merkel of Germany Says ‘Nein’ to Protectionism
text: Addressing an audience of world leaders and top executives, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany opened this year’s Davos conference with a wide-ranging speech that touched on climate change, trade talks and hedge funds, among other topics. Ms. Merkel offered up her views on globalization, which carry special resonance because Germany this year took over the rotating presidency of the Group of Eight, the leading industrialized nations, which will hold a summit meeting in June.

headline: The Private Equity Squeezeout
text: The boom in private equity will end either when big deals start to collapse or when banks start putting the squeeze on loans. So goes the conventional wisdom, according to Dan Primack of PEHub. But he sees a different end game: strategic buyers will crowd buyout firms out of the market. Both stockholders and strategic buyers, Mr. Primack believes, are already starting to see private equity offers as being too low.

headline: Looking for a Leader
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 24 column, “Martin Luther Al-King?”

headline: Kerry Bows Out Officially
text: From the Senate floor, Senator John Kerry officially announced this afternoon that he would not attempt another bid for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Apologies to Murray Hill
text: Readers who responded to my post about the restaurant Babouche — and to my statement, within it, that Murray Hill is a restaurant tundra — are right: that statement was sloppy, too broad and unfair.

headline: Tijuana’s Police Take Up Arms … With Slingshots
text: The police in Tijuana, Mexico, having been stripped of their firearms by federal officers earlier this month, have begun patrolling the streets with slingshots in a demonstration of their plight, according to news reports earlier this week.

headline: Is Income Inequality Really a Problem?
text: With Democrats back in charge of Congress, it is not surprising that we are seeing a revival of interest in the issue of income inequality. In his response to President Bush’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, Senator James Webb, Democrat of Virginia, complained that corporate C.E.O. compensation has risen from 20 times that of the average worker 40 years ago to 400 times today. Such obscenely large payouts may result from nothing more than the operation of Adam’s Smith’s invisible hand, but even many conservatives are wary of defending it that way.

headline: Airline Executives Discuss Mergers at Senate Hearing
text: The fight over US Airways‘ proposed $9.8 billion takeover of bankrupt Delta Air Lines moved on Wednesday to Capitol Hill, where lawmakers questioned the top executives of both companies about what the deal would mean for consumers. US Airways’ chairman, W. Douglas Parker, defended the proposed bid, telling the Senate Commerce Committee that lower costs and operational efficiencies would cut fares in “dozens of new markets” for passengers. But Delta’s chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, said fares would not go down because the two airlines directly compete in many markets.

headline: Can Polyester Save the World?
text: Clothes are a large and worsening source of the carbon emissions that contribute to global warming because of how they are both produced and cared for, concludes a new report from researchers at Cambridge University titled “Well Dressed?”

headline: For Rent: Pataki’s N.H. Office
text: A Boston Globe political blog notes that former Gov. George E. Pataki quietly packed up his Manchester, N.H., political action committee office in recent months and moved it to Peekskill, where he lives. He was one of the first presidential maybes to open up a New Hampshire office to some fanfare. The office is now listed on Craigslist. [The Primary Source]

headline: All-American Author and Eater
text: The author Jim Harrison talks about writing, cooking and life on the land.

headline: Giants-Broncos, Super Bowl XXI
text: Welcome to the first episode of Classic Times rewind, a periodic look at how The Times has covered Super Bowls. We’re starting with the 1987 Super Bowl because Bill Parcells said this week that he was through with coaching, and he might have even meant it this time. This game was his first Super Bowl triumph.

headline: Planes, Strains and Automobiles
text: The Times's Micheline Maynard speaks with Ford C.E.O. Alan Mulally about how his experiences at Boeing are shaping his approach to Ford's challenges.

headline: New York City School Chief Outlines a Financing Plan
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday laid out the first specifics of his ambitious plan to change the school financing system so that schools of similar sizes and demographics get roughly the same amount of city money per student.

headline: Conoco Posts First Decline in Earnings Since 2002
text: ConocoPhillips posted its first profit decline in four years yesterday after fuel prices dropped.

headline: Ford Loses Record $12.7 Billion in ’06
text: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 25 — The Ford Motor Company had the worst year in its history in 2006, losing $12.7 billion and suffering sharp erosion of its share of the United States auto market.

headline: Plush Animals With a Key to Enter Their Web World
text: A stuffed animal doubles as the key to a Web site with Webkinz, a collectible toy that has been enjoying some playground buzz lately.

headline: Putin in India: Visit Is Sign of Durability of Old Ties
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 — A new nuclear accord, booming trade and an ever closer partnership with the United States notwithstanding, the guest of honor this week at India’s Republic Day ceremony, an annual display of military pomp, will be a symbol of New Delhi’s newest old friend: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Angry Dispute Erupts Among Iraqi Lawmakers
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 25 — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s presentation of a new Baghdad security plan to the Iraqi Parliament on Thursday broke down in bitter sectarian recriminations, with Mr. Maliki threatening a Sunni Arab lawmaker with arrest and, in response, the Sunni speaker of Parliament threatening to quit.

headline: AT&T Posts 17% Rise in 4th-Quarter Earnings
text: Capping a whirlwind year of merging and rebranding that has come to characterize the telecommunications business, AT&T reported a 17 percent increase in quarterly profits today driven by a sizable increase in wireless subscribers.

headline: Urging Teenagers to Rein in Careless Drivers
text: DRIVING with passengers is generally safer than driving alone, at least for adults, studies have found. But if the driver and passengers are teenagers, the risk of a fatal crash rises. Add more teenagers and the risk goes up more.

headline: Senate Panel Rejects Bush’s Plan for Iraq
