text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — One day after President Bush implored Congress to give his Iraq strategy a chance to succeed, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a resolution on Wednesday denouncing the plan to send more troops to Baghdad, setting up the most direct confrontation over the war since it began nearly four years ago.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: A front-page article on Jan. 5 about the tendency of criminal suspects in New York City to give revealing and usually damaging statements to the police, despite their right to remain silent, included excerpts from the statement of James Barbour, a Broadway actor accused of sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl. According to his statement, Mr. Barbour told the police that he had lain on a bed with the girl and that they had kissed.

headline: Linda Harrison’s Egg and Gruyère Polenta
text: Slightly adapted from a recipe in “Splendid Fare” by Albert Stockli (Knopf, 1970) Time: About 35 minutes

headline: Online Nordic Banking Theft Stirs Talk of Russian Hacker
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 — Word has started spreading in Sweden about the discovery last week of a $1 million online banking theft traced to a Russian hacker who goes by the sobriquet “the Corpse.”

headline: Knicks Avoid Rout, but Not Another Loss
text: A cruel sort of familiarity came over the Knicks last night, as they stared at the wrong end of a lopsided score and watched another star player limp away. A few more games like this could destroy their morale, if not their season.

headline: Donors Pledge $7.6 Billion for Lebanon
text: PARIS, Jan. 25 — Led by Saudi Arabia and the United States, more than 30 countries and agencies pledged $7.6 billion in aid for Lebanon today in a bold bid to try to prop up the government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora.

headline: Chinese Leader to Visit Sudan for Talks on Darfur Conflict
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24  Chinese officials announced Wednesday that President Hu Jintao would visit Sudan in early February and would seek a diplomatic solution to the conflict in the country’s western Darfur region, which the United States has described as genocide.

headline: SAP Plans New Venture for Serving Small Clients
text: BERLIN, Jan. 24  SAP, the biggest maker of business management software, said Wednesday that it would invest as much as $520 million over two years on an organization aimed at smaller business clients.

headline: Bloomberg and Council Change Arts Financing
text: Declaring that they had wearied of their annual dance over arts financing, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council announced yesterday that they would make more money available to arts groups, award it on a merit basis and widen a peer-review process to level the playing field.

headline: Debate Renewed: Did Moscow Free Estonia or Occupy It?
text: TALLINN, Estonia, Jan. 23 — The Bronze Soldier stands in a small park near Tallinn’s lovely Old Town, staring mournfully at the snow-covered earth, helmet in hand. An inscription in Russian and Estonian says simply, “To the fallen of the Second World War.” It is far less conspicuous, as war monuments go, than the furor its fate has caused.

headline: Boom! And an Impersonation Requires No Punch Line
text: Frank Caliendo, a short comic impressionist with a giant head and cherubic face (his descriptions), stood in his dressing room at CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman” studying his lines and waiting to become John Madden.

headline: Queens: Man Convicted in 2003 Killing
text: Tony Sexton, 37, of Jamaica, was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for killing Maria Rogers, 57, his fiancée’s mother, in 2003, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Ms. Rogers objected to Mr. Sexton’s moving into her home, and that after an argument on Feb. 14, 2003, Mr. Sexton bludgeoned her to death. He said Mr. Sexton then put her body in a garbage bag, placed the bag in her car and abandoned the vehicle about a mile away. Mr. Sexton faces up to 27 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, Mr. Brown said.

headline: Vatican City: Pope Condemns Sex in Media
text: Pope Benedict XVI condemned as a “perversion” any entertainment that romanticizes violence or trivializes sex, especially animated cartoons and video games meant for children. “I appeal to the leaders of the media industry to educate and encourage producers to safeguard the common good, to uphold the truth, to protect human dignity and promote respect for the needs of the family,” the pope wrote in a brief address on the media and children.

headline: Strong Profit at Corning Lifts Shares by Nearly 11%
text: Shares of Corning, the biggest maker of glass for liquid-crystal displays, rose sharply yesterday after the company posted a fourth-quarter profit that surpassed analysts’ estimates.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article yesterday, about Israeli-Syrian relations, misidentified the Bush administration’s label for Syria in 2002. Syria was described as a “rogue state”; it was not part of the original “axis of evil.”

headline: It’s Tough for the Opposition When a Player Is in the Zone
text: If you would like to start with a test, look only at the West hand in the diagramed deal and the auction. What would you lead against six hearts?

headline: EBay Beats the Estimates for 4th-Quarter Earnings
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24  EBay, the Internet auction giant, has scored at least a temporary victory over the mounting pressures facing its business.

headline: Plain Cellphones Can Overachieve, With a Little Help
text: IF you have an ordinary cellphone — the type that you got free, or cheaply, when you signed up for service — you might envy those with phones that are also personal digital assistants, like BlackBerrys, Treos, Sidekicks and Windows smartphones.

headline: Pakistani Premier Faults Afghans for Taliban Woes on Border
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 24 — Pakistan’s prime minister, Shaukat Aziz, acknowledged Wednesday that people sympathetic to the Taliban were active in the frontier regions near the border with Afghanistan. But he insisted that the root of the problem was the Afghan government’s weak authority, not Pakistani support of the Taliban.

headline: More Ethics Charges Brought Against Official in Duke Case
text: The North Carolina State Bar filed a second, more serious round of ethics charges yesterday against the district attorney in Durham, N.C., accusing him of “systematic abuse of prosecutorial discretion” in the sexual assault case against three former members of the Duke University lacrosse team.

headline: Council Panel Interrogates Kelly on Police Treatment of Blacks
text: City Council members questioned Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday for more than three hours on diversity in the Police Department, standards for undercover operations and perceptions of the police’s unequal treatment of black New Yorkers.

headline: Pair Pleases the Crowd, but Not the Judges
text: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 24 — After the last turn in their short program at the United States Figure Skating Championships Wednesday night, Naomi Nari Nam jumped into the arms of her pairs partner, Themi Leftheris, celebrating their program. The cheers raining down on them turned to boos when their score was finally announced.

headline: A Toy That Sends Grown Men Into Orbit
text: IN the 1960s, when a toy inventor named Sol Friedman used to wake up at night with ideas that sent him running to what his family called his “mad scientist’s lab,” he could not have predicted the effect his actions would have on a generation of men.

headline: Dressing Up Bryant Park
text: THIS week, just when it finally turned cold, the skating rink in Bryant Park was dismantled to make way for the tents of Fashion Week. You could almost hear the echoes of rosy-cheeked children hissing, “Awww, fashionistas.”

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Italy Recovers Rare Marbles

headline: N.F.L. and Union to Strengthen Steroid Testing
text: The National Football League and its players union said yesterday that they had agreed to strengthen the league’s testing program for performance-enhancing drugs, including increasing the number of tests and adding endurance-boosting EPO to the list of banned substances.

headline: Dispute Threatens Trial of Khmer Rouge Leaders
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 25 — _ The Cambodian judges were on one side and the foreign judges on the other this week, in a dispute that captures a decade of difficulties in bringing to trial the last surviving leaders of the murderous Khmer Rouge.

headline: Hiking Club Spreads a Little Bit of Charlie on Every Peak
text: TUCSON, Jan. 24 — Richard Kane stood on a large outcropping at Chimney Rock in the Santa Catalina Mountains northwest of here one day recently. He was holding an open prescription bottle and thinking about Charlie Whitmore, his hiking buddy who died in 2005.

headline: A Halting Plea for Mercy, Heavily Edited
text: Ronell Wilson said he was sorry.

headline: A Laptop Designed to Take a Licking and Keep on Ticking
text: “All terrain” is not usually a designation associated with things as delicate as hard drives and high-speed memory chips. Dell, however, is betting that its Latitude ATG D620  the ATG stands for All-Terrain Grade  can change that.

headline: Visitors Come Calling, With Enthusiastic Friends in Tow
text: The Aspen Santa Fe Ballet usually arrives in New York with a full complement of home-base admirers, and they were out in force on Tuesday night when the company opened its third season at the Joyce Theater. Their excited adulation has a tinge of wonderment that might charm the most cynical of New York dance fans. “They raise the bar, and then they jump over it,” one audience member from Aspen, Colo., said of the company on Tuesday night.

headline: Howard Stern Is Heard (Briefly) on Free Radio
text: Howard Stern, whose satellite radio show is typically available only to subscribers willing to pay $12.95 a month, has sworn that he will never return his morning show to the free commercial airwaves.

headline: Helmut Wimmer, 80, Painter With Planetarium for a Canvas, Dies
text: Helmut K. Wimmer, whose vivid depictions of twirling planets, glowing comets, pulsing nebulas and space-bending black holes awed thousands of visitors craning their necks under the dome of the old Hayden Planetarium for more than 30 years, died on March 20, 2006, near his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded: $7,133,110

headline: John W. Lavelle, Staten Island Assemblyman, Dies
text: John W. Lavelle, the assemblyman for the 61st District and chairman of the Democratic Party on Staten Island, died on Wednesday. He was 57.

headline: Two Who Were in Foster Care Make Providing Stable Home a Priority
text: Stephanie Robinson Davis and Randy Davis are young parents just starting out. There can be a lot to learn, but in the Davises’ house, they already know that their children come first.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about Yahoo’s quarterly earnings misstated the reason given for the departure of the company’s chief operating officer, Daniel L. Rosensweig, which was announced last month. He resigned; he was not fired.

headline: Queens: Real Estate Broker Charged
text: ADDENDUM APPENDED

headline: A Stream of Movies, Sort of Free
text: If there’s one sure thing about the future, it’s that it always takes longer to arrive than you think it will.

headline: Smoking Ban at Casinos May Be Eased
text: Smokers will still be able to light up at Atlantic City casinos if a compromise measure introduced in the City Council last night gets final approval in two weeks.

headline: McDonald’s Says Latest Results Are Strongest in 30 Years
text: In the four years since McDonald’s began a program to reinvent itself, the world’s largest restaurant chain has introduced several menu items, like chicken wraps, premium coffee, apple slices and Asian salads.

headline: Man in Family Slain at Home Was Drug Dealer, Police Say
text: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 24  A man who was killed last week in his home here, along with his wife and three young sons, was a low-level crack cocaine dealer and user, state police officials said Wednesday.

headline: France: Traders Fined in Bond Sale
text: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorité des Marchés Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecommunications-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.

headline: Yanks Hope to Get a Jump in China
text: The Yankees are coming, the Yankees are coming. That’s what the Chinese are shouting in China today because the Yankees are heading there in their latest international exploration. Vasco da Gama and Magellan had nothing on them.

headline: Britain: Economic Growth Picks Up
text: The British economy grew at the fastest rate since 2004 in the fourth quarter as the financial-services boom in London created jobs and pushed house prices to a record. Gross domestic product increased 0.8 percent from the previous three months, the most since the second quarter of 2004, the Office for National Statistics said. The annual growth rate increased to 3 percent from 2.9 percent. Accelerating growth in the economy drove inflation to the highest in 10 years in December, prompting the Bank of England to raise its benchmark rate in January.

headline: Red Sox Owner Close to Deal to Join Roush Racing Team
text: CONCORD, N.C., Jan. 24  A deal that would make John Henry, the Boston Red Sox’ principal owner, a key investor in Roush Racing, a top Nascar team, is nearing completion.

headline: Mets Reward Randolph With $5.65 Million Extension
text: There was once a time when no one wanted to hire Willie Randolph. He was interviewed 12 times for managerial openings, and 12 times he was turned down. One team, however, took a calculated chance, and now the Mets will not let Randolph go.

headline: Smuggler’s Plot Highlights Fear Over Uranium
text: TBILISI, Georgia, Jan. 24 — Last January, a Russian man with sunken cheeks and a wispy mustache crossed into Georgia and traveled to Tbilisi by car along a high mountain road. In two plastic bags in his leather jacket, Georgian authorities say, he carried 100 grams of uranium so refined that it could help fuel an atom bomb.

headline: Series of Sordid Corruption Charges Nears Its Nadir in Israel
text: HERZLIYA, Israel, Jan. 24  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert called Wednesday for President Moshe Katsav’s resignation, after Israel’s attorney general announced his intention to indict Mr. Katsav on criminal charges including rape, abuse of power, obstruction of justice, fraud, sexual harassment and breach of trust.

headline: Soldier Pleads Guilty to Killing Two Unarmed Iraqis
text: FORT CAMPBELL, KY., Jan. 25 - An Army infantryman received an 18-year prison sentence today after pleading guilty to killing two unarmed Iraqis during an assault northwest of Baghdad last May.

headline: Home Sales Figures Signal a Slowing Market
text: Sales of existing homes declined 0.8 percent in December, according to the National Association of Realtors, a sign of further slowing in the nation’s once-effervescent housing market.

headline: Brooklyn: Arrest in Brooklyn Crash
text: Jiankai Huang of Alexandria, Va., was arrested yesterday after crashing his car into a pickup truck and a van and hitting three pedestrians in Brooklyn, the police said. Mr. Huang, 29, was charged with driving while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and driving with a suspended license, the police said. They said that Mr. Huang was driving east on 65th Street at 8:15 a.m. when he hit the truck, which was heading north on Fort Hamilton Parkway, and then the van, which was stopped at a red light. The three injured pedestrians, a woman of 26 and two boys, 13 and 11, were hospitalized, the police said. Mr. Huang’s passenger, a 20-year-old woman, was hospitalized with head injuries, and the other drivers for evaluation, the police said.

headline: Budget Office Forecasts Drop in U.S. Deficit
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office predicted on Wednesday that the federal budget deficit would shrink again this year and could actually swing into a surplus in 2012 — but only if President Bush’s tax cuts expire in 2010.

headline: Cedar Grove: Rescue Effort Unsuccessful at House on Fire
text: A woman died in a house fire early yesterday despite her husband’s efforts to save her, said Jeff Cartwright, director of the Essex County prosecutor’s arson task force. Prosecutors would not identify the woman, but neighbors said the single-family house at 60 Montclair Avenue belonged to Nick Fierro, 79, and his wife, Marge, 73. Mr. Cartwright said the fire was not considered suspicious. The woman’s husband was treated for smoke inhalation at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge and released, a spokeswoman said. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: For Nash, 3 M.V.P.’s Can’t Take Place of Title
text: Steve Nash wants no part of the debate. Nash, the Phoenix Suns’ point guard, is a top contender to win his third consecutive Most Valuable Player award, which would make him only the fourth N.B.A. player to accomplish the feat.

headline: Love Is Up Against the Wall, So Now It’s Time to Fight
text: “Estimated Time of Arrival” is not one play but five, a series of thin comic vignettes presented over the course of an economical 90 minutes that prize the sort of love consumed by its own inertia. Our sympathies are toward the couple who can’t get out of the ring, the kind who break plates and scream into the night and fail to see in all their ostensible passion the dull routine to which they’ve been condemned.

headline: Big States’ Push for Earlier Vote Scrambles Race
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  As many as four big states  California, Florida, Illinois and New Jersey  are likely to move up their 2008 presidential primaries to early next February, further upending an already unsettled nominating process and forcing candidates of both parties to rethink their campaign strategies, party officials said Wednesday.

headline: The State of the Union, and of the President (11 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Manhattan: Guilty Plea in Defrauding of Priests
text: Robert Riggio of Manhattan, who was charged with defrauding more than 60 priests over several years, pleaded guilty to wire fraud in Federal District Court yesterday, prosecutors said. Mr. Riggio, 60, faces up to 40 years in prison when he is sentenced in April, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said that Mr. Riggio stole more than $200,000 from 2004 to 2006 by calling priests with bogus pleas for help and requests for money. The funds often came from the priests’ personal savings, Mr. Garcia said. Mr. Riggio was arrested in September after he asked for money from an F.B.I. agent posing as the niece of a priest who had been defrauded, Mr. Garcia said.

headline: Bush Proposes Broadening the No Child Left Behind Act
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24—The Bush administration called on Wednesday for an array of changes to the president’s signature education law. The proposals would give local school officials new powers to override both teachers’ contracts and state limits on charter schools in the case of persistently failing schools.

headline: Murder Victims Moved to Long Island for Safety of Suburbs
text: SYOSSET, N.Y., Jan. 24  In the 18 years since Jaspal and Geeta Singh arrived in New York from India, they prospered, had two sons and managed to join the wave of South Asians leaving behind New York City’s immigrant neighborhoods for more comfortable swaths of central Nassau County.

headline: $48 Million Paid to Merrill’s Chief
text: Merrill Lynch’s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing .

headline: Study Says Many Firms Cheat New York Workers’ Comp System
text: A new study estimates that employers cheat New York State’s workers’ compensation system by not paying $500 million to $1 billion a year in required insurance premiums, forcing other employers to pay higher premiums.

headline: N.F.L. Reverses a Trend in Penalties
text: The number of penalty flags thrown in the N.F.L. declined 20 percent this season compared to a year ago, a drop that reversed a trend that had taken hold in recent seasons.

headline: Kerry Will Not Enter Presidential Race
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who narrowly lost the presidency to President Bush in 2004, announced Wednesday that he would not proceed with a second bid for the White House, saying he preferred to use his position in the new Senate majority to press for an end to American involvement in Iraq.

headline: Acquisitions Bolster General Dynamics
text: General Dynamics, the largest maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose on acquisitions. Sales missed analysts’ estimates.

headline: Closing the Revolving Door
text: The United States is paying a heavy price for the mandatory sentencing fad that swept the country 30 years ago. After a tenfold increase in the nation’s prison population  and a corrections price tag that exceeds $60 billion a year  the states have often been forced to choose between building new prisons or new schools. Worse still, the country has created a growing felon caste, now more than 16 million strong, of felons and ex-felons, who are often driven back to prison by policies that make it impossible for them to find jobs, housing or education.

headline: Once a Poor Student, Coach Is Now a Stickler for Academics
text: PURCHASE, N.Y., Jan. 23  Not long ago, a freshman was kicked off the Manhattanville College men’s basketball team because of poor grades. Now he is the head coach.

headline: What’s on Thursday Night
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) FRIENDS OF GOD: A ROAD TRIP WITH ALEXANDRA PELOSI In 2000, Ms. Pelosi, a daughter of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, created “Journeys With George,” in which she spent 18 months on the road with George W. Bush as he campaigned for the presidency. In this new documentary, Ms. Pelosi traversed the country for a year in search of personal encounters with some influential members of the evangelical community — from Joel Osteen, the most-watched television minister in America, to Ron Luce, the founder of Battle Cry, a Christian conert tour that has drawn 2 million young people to its events. She also visited with the Rev. Ted Haggard before he stepped down as president of the National Association of Evangelicals, the largest evangelical group in the country, after accusations of buying illegal drugs from a male prostitute and paying him for sex.

headline: For the High-End Bathroom, Something Unexpected
text: AMONG the features of the new 6,000-square-foot, $3 million entertainment wing in Kevin Scherer’s home in Plano, Tex., are two bars, a theater, a video game room, a shuffleboard table and a golf simulator that projects images of top courses onto a big screen.

headline: New Offer Made for Control of Apn Media
text: An Irish media tycoon, Tony O’Reilly, has renewed an attempt to take complete control of APN News and Media of Australia. Mr. O’Reilly, who already owns 40 percent of APN, teamed his Independent News and Media, which is based in Dublin, with the Carlyle Group, the buyout group in Washington, and Providence Equity Partners, an investment firm in Providence, R.I. His group bid 3.4 billion Australian dollars ($2.65 billion) for APN. Mr. O’Reilly first teamed with Providence to buy the rest of the media group in October. Those talks were abandoned in November. APN owns regional newspapers in Australia and New Zealand and operates 125 radio stations in the two nations, with Clear Channel Communications.

headline: Moving It All to Vista
text: Q. When the time comes, how can I move all of my bookmarks, music and other files from my old computer to a new Windows Vista PC?

headline: Relatives’ Groups Use TV and Internet to Call for More Details With Names on 9/11 Memorial
text: Far from having been settled last month behind closed doors at the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, the three-year battle over the arrangement of victims’ names at the 9/11 memorial escalated yesterday to television and the Internet.

headline: Childhood Poverty Is Found to Portend High Adult Costs
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Children who grow up poor cost the economy $500 billion a year because they are less productive, earn less money, commit more crimes and have more health-related expenses, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Officer Charged in Car Crash That Injured Woman and Child
text: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24  An off-duty police officer was charged with drunken driving after critically injuring a woman and her 2-year-old child on the Pulaski Skyway, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Residential Sales: New York
text: Manhattan

headline: Newark: Shooting Leaves Man Dead and Woman Hurt
text: A man was killed and a woman seriously injured yesterday afternoon in a shooting in the South Ward, the authorities said. Police officers responding to a report of shots fired around 3:15 p.m. on Shaw Avenue near Route 78 found a 23-year-old man dead near a tan sport utility vehicle, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant prosecutor with the Essex County prosecutor’s office. A woman nearby, who had been shot several times, was taken to University Hospital, where she was in critical condition last night. Neither was identified yesterday. The homicide was Newark’s 10th this year.

headline: Long on Rhetoric, Short on Sorrow
text: President Bush showed what he does well at the beginning of the State of the Union ceremony when he graciously acknowledged and introduced Nancy Pelosi as speaker of the House of Representatives. He seemed both generous and sincere, and it was the right touch for a genuinely historic moment.

headline: Calendar
text: The Story of Moses

headline: With Health Care Topic A, Some Sketches for a Solution
text: Start with the children and work up from there. For corporate America and Washington policy experts, that seems to be the emerging consensus about how to begin tackling the problem of the 47 million people in this country without health insurance: Start with the more than 8 million uninsured children.

headline: Scientists Tie Part of Brain to Urge to Smoke
text: Scientists studying stroke patients are reporting that an injury to a specific part of the brain, near the ear, can instantly and permanently break a smoking habit, effectively erasing the most stubborn of addictions. People with the injury who stopped smoking found that their bodies, as one man put it, “forgot the urge to smoke.”

headline: Greek Terror Group Claims It Bombed Embassy
text: ATHENS, Jan. 25 — A Greek terror group claimed responsibility for the attack on the United States embassy in Athens two weeks ago, saying in a five-page proclamation published today that the attack was an “act of retaliation” against American military involvement in Iraq, Afghanistan, the Middle East and Somalia.

headline: Mississippi Man Arrested in Killing of 2 Blacks in ’64
text: ATLANTA, Jan. 24 — A 71-year-old man was arrested Wednesday in Mississippi on federal kidnapping charges stemming from the 1964 killing of two black teenagers who were tied to trees, whipped and drowned.

headline: Long-Lost Trove of Music Connects Brazil to Its Roots
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 24 — From the mid-1930s onward, the American ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax led expeditions into the Deep South, searching for authentic blues and folk singers. Thanks to those efforts, Muddy Waters and Woody Guthrie made their first recordings and a template for American popular music was set.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article yesterday about events surrounding President Bush’s State of the Union speech misquoted his opening remarks. He said, “And tonight I have the high privilege and distinct honor of my own as the first president to begin the State of the Union Message with these words: ‘Madam Speaker.’ ” He did not say, “Tonight, I have the high privilege and distinct honor to begin a speech with the words ‘Madam Speaker.’ ” (Go to Article)

headline: The Math Rookie Is a Girl, a Big Problem for the Geeks
text: Maybe there was a time when exaggerated high school-speak was amusing, but as the avalanche of “awesome” and “totally” in “Victoria Martin: Math Team Queen” buries you, you are hard pressed to remember when it was. The early ’90s? Perhaps the ’80s?

headline: Sorrow and Reflection in Killer’s Housing Project
text: Everything feels colder here, on a forbidding patch of brick and glass on Staten Island’s northeast side, just blocks from the harbor. The rest of the island, the vistas of suburban lawns and town houses, could be another planet.

headline: Of Gay Sheep, Modern Science and Bad Publicity
text: Charles Roselli set out to discover what makes some sheep gay. Then the news media and the blogosphere got hold of the story.

headline: China Strains to Fit Migrants Into Mainstream Classes
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24 — It seemed like an ordinary day earlier this month at the Jianying Hope School for migrant children here, with fidgety students settling down in their modest classrooms as their teachers prepared for the day’s lessons.

headline: Redesigned Toyota Pickup to Cost More Than Rivals’ Trucks
text: DETROIT, Jan. 24 — Toyota is putting its reputation as a premium automaker to a test by pricing its redesigned pickup, the Tundra, several thousand dollars higher than comparable trucks made by General Motors and Ford.

headline: Can Polyester Save the World?
text: WOKING, England

headline: Rough (but Silly) Justice and Striking (Also Silly) Moves
text: When the judge in a murder case pronounces a defendant not guilty, I doubt that confetti streams from the ceiling. I also suspect that the prosecutor is rarely a foul-tempered teenager who carries a whip and curtsies when she presents compelling evidence. But if trials were as entertaining in the real world as in Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney Justice for All, it might be worth jury duty just see it all firsthand.

headline: Researchers Go Molecular in Design of a Denser Chip
text: Scientists have built a memory chip that is roughly the size of a white blood cell, about one-2,000th of an inch on a side.

headline: Hedge Fund Chiefs, With Cash,  Join Political Fray
text: Lisa Perry loves Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Blackstone Makes New Offer for Equity Office
text: The bidding war for Equity Office Properties Trust, one of the nation’s largest commercial landlords, escalated today when the Blackstone Group offered $54 a share in cash, or $38.3 billion, for all of Equity Office’s stock.

headline: Incomes and Inequality: What the Numbers Don’t Tell Us
text: The growing inequality in wealth and income has led many people to question whether the contemporary American economy is rigged in favor of the rich. While there is little doubt that the gap between the wealthy and everybody else has widened in recent years, the situation is not as unfair as some of the numbers seem to imply.

headline: Albany: New Head of Long Island Power Authority
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer appointed the Suffolk County executive’s chief deputy, Kevin S. Law, left, the new chairman of the Long Island Power Authority yesterday. Mr. Law succeeds Richard M. Kessel, who headed the agency under Govs. Mario M. Cuomo and George E. Pataki. Mr. Kessel is expected to take on the vacant post of chief executive officer for several months and then retire. Mr. Law is then expected to succeed him as the chief executive officer, at which point a new chairman will be appointed.

headline: Bonus Pay by Medicare Lifts Quality
text: Paying a hospital to do the right thing is a lot harder than it looks.

headline: Instead of Dollars, Some of the Squabbling Is Cut Out of Early Budget Negotiations
text: The annual New York City budget dance, a stylized ritual that has varied little over the past decade, took a different step forward yesterday. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in another sign of his good will toward the City Council, agreed to dedicate money to parks, child care and arts programs in the preliminary budget he plans to present today  instead of making the Council fight for those dollars as in the past.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Oregon

headline: Siemens to Buy Software Maker
text: Siemens, the German engineering company, agreed yesterday to buy the software maker UGS for $3.5 billion, including debt, and separately announced plans to spin off its VDO automotive unit.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: A Sarah Bernhardt Drama

headline: Breakthrough for González Means Early Exit for No. 2 Nadal
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 25 — Tommy Haas and Fernando González took radically different paths to their upsets at the Australian Open on Wednesday.

headline: What a View to Behold, and It’s Really Something
text: YOU can see the progress of construction at the Freedom Tower.

headline: First-Time All-Stars Put Their Stamp on Game
text: DALLAS, Jan. 24 — Alex Ovechkin did not waste time in breaking down the race to become the National Hockey League’s most valuable player. All he had to do was look to the seat next to him, which was occupied by Sidney Crosby.

headline: Testimony by Former Cheney Aide Hurts Libby
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — A former spokeswoman for Vice President Dick Cheney gave testimony in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. today that directly contradicted Mr. Libby’s version of events during a crucial period that is at the center of the perjury case against him.

headline: Crochet Undergoes an Upgrade
text: DUMBO, the nickname for the neighborhood Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, sounds like an acronym made up by a developer. But there’s nothing prefab or Disney-esque about the place.

headline: Breaking the Clinch
text: Iraq is at the beginning of a civil war fought using the tactics of genocide, and it has all the conditions to get much worse. As a Newsweek correspondent, Christian Caryl, wrote recently from Baghdad, “What’s clear is that we’re far closer to the beginning of this cycle of violence than to its end.” As John Burns of The Times said on “Charlie Rose” last night, “Friends of mine who are Iraqis  Shiite, Sunni, Kurd  all foresee a civil war on a scale with bloodshed that would absolutely dwarf what we’re seeing now.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: The Shepherd, the Sea Nymph and the Big Rock, Abridged
text: This can be short. Certainly the opera is.

headline: Mayor’s Budget Plan Includes $2.9 Billion Surplus
text: With New York City’s treasury flush with unexpected revenue from an extraordinary surge in its real estate market, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg projected today a $2.9 billion surplus in his $60 billion budget plan, allowing him to grant $1 billion in tax cuts and set aside $1.9 billion for future expenses.

headline: Several Casualties Reported in Beirut Clashes
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon Jan. 25 — Violence erupted in Beirut today for the second time in three days, as a lunchroom altercation at a Beirut university escalated into rioting and gunfire.

headline: ‘Office’ Songs in the Unhip Keys of Life and Karaoke
text: If a song is popular now, don’t expect to hear it on “The Office” until late next year.

headline: Hershey Earnings Decline as Mars Cuts Into U.S. Market Share
text: The Hershey Company’s fourth-quarter profit fell 9.9 percent, trailing analysts’ estimates, after sales at the company, the largest United States candy maker, declined for the first time in three and a half years.

headline: Queens: Conviction in Police Officer’s Shooting
text: Lasana Philbert, 23, has been convicted in State Supreme Court of assault on a police officer for wounding Officer Christopher Wiesneski in 2005 by grabbing his gun during a struggle, causing it to fire, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. Prosecutors said that Officer Wiesneski had to retire as a result of his wound. Mr. Philbert, of Cambria Heights, faces up to 15 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, Mr. Brown said.

headline: Stem Cell Research: When Does Life Begin? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mendy Samstein, 68, Dies; Championed Civil Rights
text: Mendy Samstein, who left graduate school to put himself in the forefront of the fight for black voting rights in Mississippi, enduring bombings and beatings in the crucial summer of 1964, died yesterday at his home in New Lisbon, N.Y. He was 68.

headline: Returning to the Spy World to Uncover a Political Plot
text: In his first book, “Overworld,” Larry J. Kolb told a dizzying, spy-studded story of his lifelong adventures as the son of a senior United States intelligence official. It was an amazing account, almost too much so, filled with events far too strange for fiction. And it was packed with guest stars, from Muhammad Ali to Ronald Reagan. For a man who had lived so much of his life in the shadows, Mr. Kolb used this book to cast an improbably bright light.

headline: In a New Joint U.S.-Iraqi Patrol, the Americans Go First
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 24 — In the battle for Baghdad, Haifa Street has changed hands so often that it has taken on the feel of a no man’s land, the deadly space between opposing trenches. On Wednesday, as American and Iraqi troops poured in, the street showed why it is such a sensitive gauge of an urban conflict marked by front lines that melt into confusion, enemies with no clear identity and allies who disappear or do not show up at all.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article yesterday about events surrounding President Bush’s State of the Union speech misquoted his opening remarks. He said, “And tonight I have the high privilege and distinct honor of my own as the first president to begin the State of the Union Message with these words: ‘Madam Speaker.’ ” He did not say, “Tonight, I have the high privilege and distinct honor to begin a speech with the words ‘Madam Speaker.’ ”

headline: A Dance-Party Niche in the Cruise Industry
text: Three years ago, Jason Beukema, a tour manager at a travel agency in Atlanta, thought he was just doing his friends a favor in organizing a group vacation.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,044 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Wendy’s Shifts Work to Three Agencies
text: Wendy’s International is unexpectedly changing agencies after working since August 2002 with two New York agencies that are part of the McCann Erickson Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Wendy’s spends about $300 million a year on local and national advertising in major media.

headline: Donors Gather to Help Lebanon’s Government
text: PARIS, Jan. 24 — After 50 days of Syrian- and Iranian-backed protests that culminated in Tuesday’s daylong standoff in Beirut, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and officials from more than 30 other countries are gathering here to see if they can inject enough money into the Lebanese government to prop up the pro-Western prime minister, Fouad Siniora.

headline: Jim Harrison’s Mesquite Roasted Doves
text: Time: 5 minutes

headline: Moment of Opportunity in Somalia
text: Thanks to an unusual and probably fleeting set of events, Somalia has a chance to return to the community of law-abiding and legitimate states. For a country that dissolved years ago into chronic clan warfare and became a way station for international terrorists, that would be an enormous gain  and an enormous gain for the rest of the world.

headline: Bush Goes on the Road to Sell His Health Plan
text: LEE’S SUMMIT, Mo., Jan. 25 — In what could be the opening salvo in a new partisan debate over his domestic agenda, President Bush urged Congress today to consider his new health care proposal and indicated he was ready for a fight.

headline: Effort to Move on Minimum Wage Bill Falters in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Bloomberg) — Senate Republicans rejected an effort by Democrats to pass minimum-wage legislation without breaks for small businesses on Wednesday, setting the stage for a potential impasse with the House, where lawmakers are demanding a “clean” bill.

headline: Ex-Officials Testify They Informed Libby of the Identity of a C.I.A. Operative
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Prosecutors in the perjury trial of the former White House aide I. Lewis Libby Jr. paraded a roster of former government officials before the jury on Wednesday to testify that they had informed him about the identity of the C.I.A. operative Valerie Wilson, contrary to Mr. Libby’s claim that he had learned about her weeks later from reporters.

headline: Iraqi Official Offers Terms From Militia to Avoid Fight
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 24  An Iraqi official authorized to speak on behalf of field commanders for the country’s most powerful militia has approached Western military officials and laid out a plan to avoid armed confrontation, senior Iraqi and American officials said this week.

headline: At the Libby Trial, Hints of Intrigue and Betrayal
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — The assertion by lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. that White House aides had sacrificed him to protect Karl Rove, the senior political adviser, appears to be based primarily on Mr. Libby’s own sense that the administration had failed to defend him adequately as the C.I.A. leak case unfolded.

headline: Federer Overwhelms Roddick
text: MELBOURNE -- When the reinvigorated Andy Roddick stepped on court Thursday to face his longtime tormentor Roger Federer, the consensus at the Australian Open was that spectators were in for a special evening.

headline: An Orchestra in Transition Tackles an Unfinished Work
text: Corporate success does not necessarily mean mutual admiration between worker and management. Some orchestras do best while actively disliking the person conducting them, but that is usually a short-term transaction. The Philadelphia Orchestra and its music director, Christoph Eschenbach, played Bruckner very well at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night with the full knowledge that Mr. Eschenbach will complete his contract next season and leave. His tenure has been too startlingly short to avoid the conclusion that players wanted him to go, and no news other than boilerplate press releases indicate that Mr. Eschenbach goes willingly.

headline: George Wein Sells Company That Produces Music Festivals
text: George Wein, the producer of music festivals including the JVC-sponsored jazz festivals in New York and Paris and the Newport festivals of jazz and folk music, announced yesterday that he had sold his company, Festival Productions Inc.

headline: U.S. Picks an Inauspicious Time to Restart Mideast Talks
text: HERZLIYA, Israel, Jan. 24  It would be hard to imagine a less promising moment for the United States to restart serious Palestinian-Israeli peace negotiations.

headline: State Leaders Agree on Plan to Merge 2 Ethics Commissions and Tighten Lobbying Rules
text: ALBANY, Jan. 24 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders announced a package of sweeping changes to state ethics policies on Wednesday, but the measures were greeted with a mixed response from civic groups that have long pushed for even broader changes.

headline: A TV Family Bound by Blood and a Band
text: “The Naked Brothers Band,” an ebullient mock documentary about a kids’ rock band, is both a movie and a new series on Nickelodeon and a tween fantasy in which no one over 18 has much sense. The brothers have a classic bubble-gum sound, live in a very 21st-century video world and are the real-life offspring of entertainers from two television shows that had baby-boomer appeal.

headline: Energy Rhetoric, and Reality
text: For six years, off and on, President Bush has been talking about the need for alternative fuels and conservation to make the country less beholden to unreliable sources of foreign oil. Yet all he has to show for it is a growing dependence on foreign oil, a growing climate problem and an increasingly cynical public. Mr. Bush talked the same game on Tuesday night, offering several impressively specific goals. But whether these new pledges turn out to be as empty as the old ones depends on his capacity for follow-through, and history is not encouraging.

headline: 4th Major Hub for Air Traffic Moves Ahead
text: The plan to create a fourth major airport that could relieve crowding and delays in the metropolitan region will take a leap forward today, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

headline: Weight and Diabetes Are Focus of Health Foundation Grants
text: A health foundation created by New York State announced its first grants yesterday, devoting considerable attention to obesity and resulting problems like diabetes, and to asthma. It also addressed other ills as disparate as alcohol abuse and lack of dental care.

headline: Political Meddling With Justice
text: The federal investigation into Congressional corruption is approaching a crucial deadline and potential dead end. Feb. 15 is the last day on the job for United States Attorney Carol Lam of San Diego, the inquiry’s dedicated prosecutor, who is being purged by the Bush administration.

headline: ABC TV Star Is Seeking Counseling After Epithet
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 — Isaiah Washington, the “Grey’s Anatomy” star who twice used an anti-homosexual slur against one of that show’s co-stars, is seeking counseling for behavioral issues at the suggestion of his employers, the ABC television network and Touchstone Television, both part of the Walt Disney Company.

headline: House Restores Some Voting Rights to Congressional Delegates
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 — The Democratic majority in the House restored limited floor voting rights to the Congressional delegates from the District of Columbia and four territories on Wednesday after a rancorous debate with echoes of the days before the Republicans won the majority in 1994.

headline: A Culture of Faith, Devoted Yet Complex
text: There is a God, and he punishes those who overreach on television.

headline: Israeli Panel Approves President’s Leave
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 25 — An Israeli parliamentary committee today approved President Moshe Katsav’s request to suspend himself for three months, as prosecutors prepare a case against him that could include charges of rape and other kinds of sexual misconduct.

headline: When Resolutions Fail, the Exercise Enforcers Step In
text: JUDY McMILLIN used to be a perennial quitter. Every January, gym-going would become her new favorite hobby, and then, poof, she would abandon it. “I just did not grow up exercising or enjoying it,” said Ms. McMillin, 57, a homemaker in Dallas.

headline: Bush Makes Sales Pitch for Proposal on Energy
text: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 24  President Bush made a big deal about ethanol, the fuel derived from plants, in his State of the Union address Tuesday night. Wednesday morning, he got up close and personal with it, poking his head through stalks of corn and wheat while scientists for DuPont gave him a crash course in ethanol production in a tour of their research greenhouse here.

headline: Energy Research on a Shoestring
text: GOLDEN, Colo. — Thirty years after it was founded by President Jimmy Carter, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory at the edge of the Rockies here still does not have a cafeteria.

headline: Balancing Act: Wins and Fatherhood
text: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 24 — The latest phase of Tiger Woods’s life has brought him to a new and unfamiliar place, where the quest for titles on the PGA Tour has been joined by the anticipation of his first child.

headline: Strike a Pose: A Show Pony Choreographs His Obsession
text: Last year the choreographer Trajal Harrell was hit with an intense dose of post-performance depression. It wasn’t that his dance, “Before Intermission,” was badly received (it wasn’t), but that after months of rehearsal and a two-night run at the Kitchen, it was over. Around the same time he also observed how his nondance friends were progressing in their lives: getting married, having babies, buying homes.

headline: On the Aegean, Stone and Steel Surrender to the Breeze
text: Assos, Turkey

headline: A Life Lived in Fear, but Not Half Bad
text: BENNINGTON, Vt.

headline: What’s Behind the Surplus? Taxes
text: The good news for New York City’s budget stems partly from the large taxes New Yorkers must swallow when buying property in the city’s booming real estate market: the city, along with the state, is collecting a record amount in transfer taxes from the sale of residential properties, and those sales have been booming.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.What can I do to disguise an ugly steel door?

headline: It’s Roundball 2, Square Jaw 1
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Facing Strike Threat, British Air Cancels 1,300 Flights
text: LONDON, Jan. 25 — British Airways said Thursday that it was canceling 1,300 flights from London for two days next week because of a planned strike by its cabin-crew workers.

headline: Hezbollah Won’t Topple the Lebanese Government, Its Leader Says
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon Jan. 24 — Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s leader, said Wednesday that Lebanon’s opposition movement had decided to stop short of toppling the government of Fouad Siniora, fearing civil strife. He warned, though, that Hezbollah and its allies would continue to ratchet up the pressure on Mr. Siniora in coming weeks and vowed not to back down on their demands.

headline: The Irish, Young in ‘Old Europe,’ Strain Schools and Housing
text: DROGHEDA, Ireland — Moving to a newly built seaside housing development north of Dublin seemed an obvious decision for Katrina Dooley and her partner.

headline: For the Good of the Herd
text: Washington

headline: Glasses Make the Nerd
text: IT’S sad, but true: the only people who truly appreciate the fine-tuning it takes to get nerd style right are the fervently hip. Also sad but true: the long, thin rectangles edged in black plastic or silver wire, which have bridged the noses of so many architects and others who long to be seen as cerebral, have lost their edge. Perhaps that is why old-school 1950s glasses are making a comeback at fashionable spectacle shops like A. R. Trapp, Selima Optique and Myoptics.

headline: China: Economy Grew 10.7%. in 2006
text: China’s economy grew 10.7 percent in 2006, closing in on Germany as the world’s third largest, fueled by investment in manufacturing and a boom in exports. Gross domestic product expanded to 20.94 trillion yuan ($2.69 trillion) after growing 10.4 percent in 2005, Xie Fuzhan, chief of the National Bureau of Statistics, said in Beijing. China’s economy expanded at more than twice the global average as record exports swelled foreign-currency reserves to more than $1 trillion. Premier Wen Jiabao wants to increase consumer spending to reduce the country’s reliance on shipments overseas and avoid igniting investment bubbles.

headline: Dallas Suburb Amends Its Ban on Renting to Illegal Immigrants
text: DALLAS, Jan. 24 — The City Council of a Dallas suburb has revised its proposed ban on renting apartments to illegal immigrants to allow landlords to rent to families with mixed citizenship or residency status.

headline: Police Won’t Use $140 Million Radio System
text: For more than 10 years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been working to correct a major hindrance to police work in the subway system: a radio network that keeps transit officers underground from talking with officers patrolling the streets above.

headline: Home Depot Chief’s Pay in 2007 Could Reach $8.9 Million
text: Home Depot may pay its new chief executive, Frank Blake, $8.9 million this year, less than the $39.7 million it paid his predecessor, Robert L. Nardelli, who was ousted this month.

headline: Conflict Case at Hospitals Is Settled
text: Under pressure from the Connecticut attorney general, a consulting group owned by some of the country’s most influential hospital executives agreed yesterday to stop selling marketing advice to vendors who do millions of dollars in business with nonprofit hospitals across the nation, including their own.

headline: How E.T. Might Phone Home, if Home Had a G.S.M. Network
text: The Palm Treo 750 is a Windows Mobile smartphone with a global agenda. The 5-ounce phone, which uses Cingular’s cellular and wireless broadband networks in the United States, can connect in most countries that use the G.S.M. standard.

headline: Official Ready to Re-examine Law Shielding Turks’ Identity
text: ISTANBUL, Jan. 24 — Foreign Minister Abdullah Gul called Wednesday for changes in a controversial law that penalizes insults against Turkish identity.

headline: An Electronic Watchdog Will Follow You to a New Home
text: Those who rent their homes are just as vulnerable to burglars as homeowners, but they are less likely to have burglar alarms. And who can blame them? What renter wants to pay to install a system that has to be left behind in a move, or be locked into a monitoring company’s contract that is longer than the lease?

headline: Pleasures of the Hard-Worn Life
text: PATAGONIA, Ariz. — Jim Harrison, author of rugged, outdoorsy books like “True North” and “Legends of the Fall,” is tough on vehicles. His current ride is a much-abused Chevy Tahoe that every day is pounded over terrain most S.U.V.’s experience only in commercials: splashing through creeks, lurching down hills, bouncing over rock-strewn dirt roads in the back country of southern Arizona, where Mr. Harrison and his wife, Linda, spend the winter months in an adobe casita on the Sonoita Creek. The shock absorbers are so overstressed they’ve gone a little spongy.

headline: Barons Before Bedtime
text: ONE of Bradley Ziegler’s favorite days is the day after Christmas, when the bargain bins at Toys “R” Us and Wal-Mart are filled with marked-down DVDs and GameCube games. As he has done for the past two years, Bradley will pick up an armful of $3.99 games and movies and then auction them for up to 10 times that on eBay to regular customers from Kentucky to Cyprus.

headline: At Sundance, Art and Journalistic Ethics on Trial
text: Amir Bar-Lev sat on a bench at The Art Is In, a gallery in Park City, Utah, looking at a series of very energetic acrylic abstract paintings with titles like “Ocean” and “Lollipop House.” Mr. Bar-Lev, who knows and likes the artist, chatted with Mark Weiler about their respective favorites in the showing of six pieces that was held during the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: A Word From Our Sponsor
text: WHEN Clinique made its debut in 1968, the cosmetics brand altered America’s beauty landscape by using scientific language and clinical iconography at a time when highly perfumed, elaborately packaged creams dominated department stores.

headline: James Farley, 76, Consultant Who Headed Insurance Firm, Dies
text: James B. Farley, an executive who moved seamlessly between the worlds of management consulting and corporate America, died on Saturday at his home in Gulf Stream, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Williams Reaches Finals in Australia
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 25 — After two years of waiting and not much playing, Serena Williams is back in a final, and it happens to be in a Grand Slam tournament.

headline: 7 Megapixels and a 7X Zoom in a Rather Small Package
text: Casio’s 7-megapixel EX-V7 packs an inordinate number of features into its diminutive 2.4-by-3.8-by-1-inch body. The 7X zoom lens is long enough to catch action across the soccer field.

headline: Help the Homeless (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Far From Hollywood
text: PARIS

headline: In Unusual Move, Hu Demands Inquiry After Journalist’s Death
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 24  In a rare response to a criminal incident, China’s president, Hu Jintao, has ordered a speedy investigation into the killing of a journalist who was beaten to death recently while investigating conditions in an illegal coal mine, the semiofficial China News Service reported on Wednesday.

headline: The New Hollywood
text: The iconic Los Angeles neighborhood seems to have finally achieved a comeback.

headline: A More Perfect Union?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Weather Strikes Again
text: The practical effects of climate change continue to be the issue du jour here, if only because the weather seems to be making everyone’s trip to Davos difficult. The British opposition leader, David Cameron, arrived late Wednesday for a climate chnage dinner after his journey from London was disrupted by bad weather. Mr. Cameron said he had even tried to beat the delays by riding to Heathrow on the back of a motorcycle. Britain has been at the forefront of the climate change debate, but may have problems coping with hostile weather patterns.

headline: Helping Europe Grow
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The aging of Western Europe is a continuing concern, leading to worries that there will not be enough workers to support generous public pension policies.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: "Frost/Nixon," the new Peter Morgan play about the series of interviews David Frost, the British talk show host, conducted with former President Richard M. Nixon, has set its Broadway dates.

headline: Stephen King’s Midnight Madness
text: Every week comic book fans look forward to Wednesdays, the day new issues go on sale. On Feb. 7, one of those comics will be the first issue of a new seven-part series based on the Stephen King novel “The Dark Tower,” from Marvel Entertainment. To commemorate the event, almost 150 comic book retailers across the country will begin selling the issue at the stroke of midnight. A list of participating stores can be found at www.marvel.com/news/comicstories. Fans who flock to Midtown Comics in Manhattan will see a couple of special guests: Peter David, who writes the dialogue for the series, and Jae Lee, the book’s artist. The store will open for one hour.

headline: Fine Lines
text: Images from the Martin Ramirez retropective at the American Folk Art Museum.

headline: Siemens to Buy Software Maker
text: Siemens, the German engineering company, agreed Wednesday to buy the software maker UGS for $3.5 billion, including debt, and separately announced plans to spin off its VDO automotive unit. Siemens said it would retain a majority stake in VDO, which makes electronic systems that help deploy air bags. The purchase and spinoff would accelerate an overhaul started by the chief executive, Klaus Kleinfeld. He shed the company’s mobile phone unit and is combining the communications network division with that of Nokia.

headline: Acquisitions Bolster General Dynamics
text: General Dynamics, the largest maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, said Wednesday that fourth-quarter profit rose on acquisitions, but sales missed analysts’ estimates. Profit from continuing operations climbed 16 percent, to $463 million, or $1.13 a share, from $398 million, or 98 cents, a year earlier, the company said.

headline: Teaming With Carlyle, Irish Media Mogul Revives APN Bid
text: The Irish billionaire Tony O’Reilly revived his 3.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.97 billion) takeover offer for APN News & Media, Australia’s fourth-largest media company, after luring the Carlyle Group to his buyout group. The bidders, led by Mr. O’Reilly’s Independent News & Media, offered 6.05 Australian dollars a share for the 60 percent of APN it does not already own. But shares of the publisher of the New Zealand Herald closed unchanged at 6.15 Australian dollars Thursday, signaling the group, which includes Providence Equity Partners, may have to increase its offer.

headline: Nestle Frosts its Ice Cream Unit With Eskimo Pie
text: Nestle, the maker of Haagen-Dazs ice cream, agreed to purchase the Eskimo Pie and Chipwich ice-cream brands from CoolBrands International to increase its share of the global market. Nestle paid $18.9 million for the brands through a unit in the United States, Dreyer’s Grand Ice Cream Holdings.

headline: TD Banknorth Post 50% Rise in Fourth Quarter Profit
text: TD Banknorth, the U.S. consumer banking unit of the Toronto-Dominion Bank, said fourth-quarter profit rose 50 percent on increased deposits from its purchase of Hudson United Bancorp. Net income climbed to $83.4 million, or 36 cents a share, from $55.6 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier.

headline: The Death of Trade: Greatly Exaggerated?
text: Behold the good tidings of Davos: That wave of protectionism you heard about is a mirage.

headline: Caremark Makes Its Case for CVS Deal
text: The pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx on Tuesday sent a letter to its shareholders urging them to vote for its pending merger with the drugstore operator CVS. Caremark says in the letter that the proposed $21.2 billion buyout by CVS will deliver immediate value to shareholders and has a high probability of being completed in about a month.

headline: At H-P, More Spying Allegations Fly
text: Hewlett-Packard is once again at the center of a cloak-and-dagger brouhaha. A former Hewlett executive accused by the company of stealing trade secrets is now saying that he was instructed by the company’s management to spy on a rival, Dell, CNet News.com reported. Karl Kamb, Hewlett’s former vice president of business development and strategy, was named as a defendant in a federal lawsuit filed by the computer maker in 2005 alleging that he used trade secrets to launch a rival flat-screen TV company of his own while still on the payroll.

headline: Amaranth Returns Chunk of Capital to Investors, Report Says
text: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last year after losing more than $6 billion in energy markets, has returned more than half of its remaining capital, MarketWatch reports, citing a letter the firm sent to investors earlier this month. Almost 55 percent to 60 percent of the firm’s capital as of Sept. 30 was returned during the fourth quarter through investor redemptions and withdrawals, Amaranth’s founder, Nick Maounis, wrote in the letter obtained by MarketWatch. Apparently favorable market conditions allowed Amaranth to sell a swath of its remaining positions without incurring large losses.

headline: Endesa Earnings Turns Up Heat in Takeover Scramble
text: Endesa, the target of a 36.5 billion euro ($47.4 billion) takeover battle, beat its 2006 profit forecast and laid out profit estimates for the next three years including a higher goal for 2009, days before the German utility E.ON and Gas Natural were to make their final offers. Net income was 2.95 billion euros, or $3.82 billion, topping the 2.9 billion euros that Endesa forecast in July, according to preliminary earnings reported in a filing Wednesday. The strong earnings puts pressure on the bidders to table richer offers.

headline: Delphi in Deal With Hedge Fund Consortium
text: Delphi said it had signed an agreement for an investment of up to $3.4 billion by a bloc of funds that will take a controlling stake in the auto parts maker as it emerges from bankruptcy. The bankruptcy court overseeing Delphi’s reorganization approved the equity investment plan earlier this month over the objections of the hedge fund Highland Capital Management, which offered a rival $4.7 billion reorganization plan. Delphi said Tuesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had signed the agreement cleared by the court with investors led by Appaloosa Management and Cerberus Capital Management last Thursday.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Hedge Funds, Iran, Snow
text: There was much ado in the press about German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s speech at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday, with several reports focusing on her stance on hedge funds. Ms. Merkel said proposals to shed more light on hedge funds’ operations would be a priority for her leadership of the Group of Eight industrial nations this year. “We want to minimize the systemic risks in international capital markets and to raise their transparency — above all, I see the need to catch up with hedge funds,” she said.

headline: Shell Canada Investors Vow to Fight Royal Dutch
text: Disgruntled minority shareholders of Shell Canada threatened Wednesday to fight on in court if Royal Dutch Shell succeeds in buying out its Canadian subsidiary at $45 a share. Royal Dutch controls 78 percent of Shell Canada and wants the rest because of its position in the booming Alberta oil sands. Shell Canada outlined Wednesday even more ambitious plans for its exploitation of the resource.

headline: Buyout Shop Takes Mattress Firm
text: Mattress Firm is getting new owners. J.W. Childs Associates, a Boston-based private equity firm, and members of Mattress Firm’s senior management team are acquiring the company from majority shareholder Sun Capital Partners.

headline: I.B.M. Selling Printer Unit to Japanese Firm
text: The Japanese office equipment maker Ricoh will buy I.B.M.‘s digital commercial printer operations for about $700 million in April, the Nikkei reported. The acquisition, Ricoh’s largest ever, will make the firm the No. 1 player in the growing market for devices used by companies to print contracts and other documents quickly and in large volumes, the report said.

headline: Bank of America Board Greenlights Buyback
text: Bank of America on Wednesday said its board of directors authorized the repurchase of up to 200 million additional common shares, and will allow management to spend $14 billion over the next 12 to 18 months to buy back stock. The No. 2 U.S. bank said it has 63 million shares remaining under a 200 million share buyback program authorized last April. Bank of America’s market capitalization is more than $200 billion.

headline: LA Landlord Raises $400 Million in I.P.O.
text: Meruelo Maddux Properties, the largest landlord in downtown Los Angeles, raised $400 million Wednesday in an initial public stock offering intended to capitalize on investors’ widespread demand for commercial real estate. Meruelo Maddux sold 40 million shares at $10 each, well below the $12 to $14 a share the company was seeking. The stock was to begin trading Thursday on Nasdaq under the symbol MMPI.

headline: GLG and Deutsche Fined by French Regulators
text: GLG Partners, a European hedge fund manager, and Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, were fined by the French market regulator for trading abuses stemming from a convertible bond sale in 2002. The regulator, the Autorité des Marchés Financiers, fined GLG 1.2 million euros ($1.6 million) for using privileged information before a convertible bond sale by the telecom-equipment manufacturer Alcatel in December 2002, the regulator said. The agency fined Deutsche Bank 300,000 euros for not abiding by rules when sounding out investors before the sale, according to the report.

headline: Adelphia Ruling to Delay Time Warner Cable Offering
text: The opening of Time Warner Cable shares on the public market faces yet another delay after a federal judge on Wednesday blocked Adelphia Communications, the cable television company, from moving ahead with its $15 billion plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection. The judge granted a request by an 11-member bondholder group, which includes Lehman Brothers and Bank of America, to appeal the Jan. 3 order approving the reorganization plan which they say undervalues their claims.

headline: Merrill Chief Pocketed $48 Million in 2006
text: Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said Wednesday in a regulatory filing. Mr. O’Neal received $700,000 in salary for 2006, a cash bonus of $18.5 million and stock valued at $28.8 million. The previous year, Merrill gave Mr. O’Neal $37 million in salary and bonuses.

headline: Hedge Fund Money to Play Role in Political Races
text: Hedge fund money, which now exceeds $1 trillion, has emerged in the last several years as a potentially powerful force in politics, as underscored by the significant role it is playing in the presidential aspirations of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. says. During the 2006 election cycle, executives who work at the 30 biggest hedge funds made $2.8 million in contributions to political candidates or party committees, almost double the amount in 2000.

headline: Greenberg Invests in China Buyout Fund
text: Maurice R. Greenberg’s Starr International will take a 50 percent stake in a 1 billion yuan ($129 million) private-equity fund to invest in Chinese companies. In the first confirmed investment in China since he was ousted from the American International Group, Mr. Greenberg’s company will invest alongside state-owned Citic Securities, China’s biggest publicly traded broker. During his tenure at AIG, Mr. Greenberg, who ran the insurance giant for 38 years before getting the boot, won the first insurance license in China for an overseas company since the country’s communist revolution in 1949.

headline: Ethnic Eats: Queens
text: A tour of this borough's global tables.

headline: Sun and the Kohlberg Edge
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ recent deal to invest $700 million in Sun Microsystems shows how Kohlberg, a giant private equity firm, got special access to a public company the average Joe cannot hope for, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Rarely Seen Sea Monster Captured, Then, Following Script, Dies
text: Yet another rare-freaky sea creature has made a rare-freaky video appearance — courtesy Japanese marine researchers — before being promptly declared dead.

headline: Bush Plan May Support Clean Tech
text: Venture capitalists may have a new ally in their rush to invest in clean technologies: President Bush. As the president outlined an aggressive plan to reduce gasoline use by 20 percent within a decade through a mandatory fuels standard in his State of the Union speech, several V.C.’s said that their investments in ethanol and other environmentally friendly fuels could pay off — and help the United States meet that goal. Companies like Khosla Ventures invested more than $2.9 billion in clean tech in 2006, according to the Cleantech Venture Network.

headline: American Stock Exchange Hires Adviser
text: The American Stock Exchange said Thursday it had hired the investment bank Morgan Stanley to advise it on a demutualization plan, which would convert it to a for-profit corporation, as well as “potential strategic future initiatives.” Demutualization could be a step toward an initial public offering of the exchange.

headline: Blackstone Raises Equity Office Bid to $38.3 Billion
text: The Blackstone Group increased its offer for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, or $54 a share, in cash, escalating the stakes in the pitched battle for the country’s largest office landlord. The new offer trumps a rival $37.6 billion, $52-a-share bid by a real estate consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust made earlier this month. Analysts and industry watchers had expected the private equity giant to top the Vornado group’s bid, as the agreement it reached with Equity Office last November — for $48.50 a share — allowed Blackstone to match rival offers. If completed, the offer would set a record for a leveraged buyout.

headline: Clinton Promises Health Care Plan
text: A day after saying that she would take on health care again, despite the political problems it caused her in the 1990s, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday evening that she would soon propose a plan “about how we get to universal coverage.”

headline: 3i Targets U.S. With New Investment Team
text: The 3i Group, a private equity and venture capital firm based in London, said Thursday that it had formed a new division and opened a New York office as part of a plan to increase its investments in United States companies. The firm said its U.S. Growth Capital team will typically make investments of $20 million to $200 million in privately owned companies.

headline: Fantasy and Farce From Far, Far Away
text: Aliens offer a cure for earthling ennui in "From Other Worlds," a limp sci-fi comedy with fewer laughs than a meeting of Abductees Anonymous. When Joanne (Cara Buono), a despondent wife and mother, develops a fascination with dead fish and a fan-shaped skin blemish, she naturally suspects an otherworldly cause. Grappling with blackouts and an unreliable Brooklyn accent, she heads for a U.F.O. support group at which neighborhood losers vie for the extraterrestrial-sighting record and, apparently, the title of Most Unfortunate Hair.

headline: Conservatives Upset With Bush’s Speech
text: Conservatives felt President Bush’s speech left a lot to be desired, topic-wise.

headline: The Bagger in Fifty Years
text: BoingBoing points to a blogger with a few miles on him who thinks about how many miles he has to go.

headline: My Point, and I Do Have One
text: Okay, it was a long few days and the Bagger just wanted a little him-time. So he plopped on the hotel bed and hit the remote in an effort to get away from the Oscars. And there was Ellen DeGeneres with some freaky fitness guy who advised her to eat nothing but air, flax seed and free-range twigs so he could fit into her Oscar hostess frock. Yeow. And then she started mating with a Pilates ball as part of the regimen.

headline: Cardinal Health Selling Unit to Blackstone for $3.3 Billion
text: Cardinal Health, a provider of products and services to the health care industry, said Thursday it had agreed to sell its pharmaceutical technologies and services business to the Blackstone Group for $3.3 billion.

headline: Buyout Showdown Wows Davos Dealmakers
text: As many of the world’s buyout kings were gathered in Davos, Switzerland, to mix with leaders and moguls at the World Economic Forum, their attention turned to an audacious move by someone in their midst. Stephen Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group, who was seen casually roaming the halls of the convention center earlier in the day showing little sign of what was to come, and his firm announced Thursday that they had raised their bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to $38.3 billion, including debt, making the biggest leveraged buyout in history even bigger. Blackstone increased its offer to $54 a share from its previous bid of $48.50, leapfrogging a $52-per-share offer from a rival bidding group led by Vornado Realty Trust.

headline: My Kid Could Write That
text: The Bagger has reverted to writing on dead trees of late, including this piece today on “My Kid Could Paint That,” directed by Amir Bar-Lev, which premiered at Sundance to instant acclaim and was bought for just under $2 million by Sony Pictures Classics.

headline: Odds Are
text: OscarWatch points us to some odds for the Big Show. Best picture race looks tight, but Kate Winslet at 25-to-one for best actress? That ain’t right even if it’s right.

headline: A Loud Outcry Against Genocide
text: Like Atom Egoyan's 2002 fiction film "Ararat," the documentary "Screamers" takes as its jumping-off point the 1915 massacre of Armenians by the Ottoman Turks. Unlike Mr. Egoyan, however, the director Carla Garapedian has a wider agenda: to show how continued refusal to acknowledge the genocide, by the United States and Britain as well as by Turkey, has given governments all over the world courage to instigate their own versions of ethnic cleansing.

headline: An Audio  Labyrinth
text: Now that Guillermo Del Toro’s “Pan’s Labyrinth” has been nominated for best foreign film, El Gordo has become El Rey, or at least a prince. And boy, can the guy talk. The funniest man in film. Hear him talking more, ah, stuff, than a landlord on rent day in his interview with Terry Gross on “Fresh Air.”

headline: Money Talks
text: The Bagger wishes he was still in Park City, pretending that celebrities are his friends, but he is instead at a hotel in Los Angeles, pretending that the doormen are his running buddies. “Good evening, Mr. Bagger.” “Hey Rico, what’s up with your bad self?” “Good night, Mr. Bagger.”

headline: One Degree
text: Last Saturday night, the Bagger went to a couple of parties at Sundance – one held by the Creative Coalition and the other by Entertainment Weekly – and at both of them ran into Kyra Sedgwick and Kevin Bacon. He wrote a story about them in New York a while ago and has since pretended that they know each other. The couple plays along.

headline: Obama’s Race Problem
text: Debra Dickerson, author of “The End of Blackness,” concurs with Stanley Crouch: “Obama isn’t black,” she writes in Salon. She continues:

headline: The Heartbreak of Cheap Labor
text: "China Blue," a heartbreaking and meticulous documentary about life inside a blue-jeans factory in China, reveals more than we may care to know about the provenance of our most beloved item of clothing. Employing smuggled equipment and outright deception, Micha X. Peled and his crew infiltrate a plant owned by Guo Xi Lam, a former police chief who is clearly proud of his success. "We are happy to make the jeans for the whole world," says his beaming sales manager, while clients like Wal-Mart suggest the factory is well on its way.

headline: Scania’s Profits Shore Up Bargaining Position with MAN
text: Shortly after a German competitor dropped its hostile bid, the Swedish truck maker Scania reported healthy profits for last year, giving it a position of strength to negotiate a better deal, the Financial Times reported Thursday. The German company, MAN, dropped its 10.3 billion euro ($13.4 billion) hostile bid earlier this week and instead proposed a friendlier alliance. But one of Scania’s largest shareholders, the Investor holding vehicle of Sweden’s Wallenberg family, insisted that the company could “stand alone.” Scania posted an operating income of 8.75 million krona, up 28 percent for the year.

headline: On the Hill: Minimum Wage Hike Faces Tough Going
text: The minimum wage hike is facing some difficult terrain in the Senate. Democrats unsuccessfully tried to pass the bill without tax breaks for small businesses, which Republicans sought to offset the impact of paying higher wages.

headline: Anyone-Webb in ’08!
text: One day after the State of the Union, the “Jim Webb for Vice President” bandwagon started rolling, launched by this Tapped post by Michael Tomasky, editor at large of The American Prospect. At The Plank, The New Republic’s Jason Zengerle seconds Tomasky’s motion. He writes:

headline: A Wake-Up Call to Microsoft's PR Team
text: From the January 1, 2007, edition of The New York Times:

headline: Deutsche Bank Buys Stake in Private Equity Firm
