text: Deutsche Bank will acquire a minority stake in a boutique asset management firm specializing in private-equity investments, the investment bank said Thursday. Deutsche Bank’s alternative-investment arm will pay an undisclosed sum for the interest in Aldus Equity, which manages more than $3 billion. The two will work together to create private-equity fund of funds products, Deutsche’s press release said. Both firms expect the deal to close in the first half of 2007.

headline: War at Home: G.O.P. Under Pressure
text: With the anti-surge vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee falling along party lines, (Senator Chuck Hagel the lone Republican in favor), several G.O.P. senators have still expressed reservations about the president’s plan to increase troop levels in Iraq. And because many more Republican senators are up for re-election in 2008, low public opinion over the war in Iraq places them in a far more difficult space than their Democratic counterparts.

headline: Saving the Nation Through Procreation
text: The aging of Western Europe is a continuing concern, leading to worries that there will not be enough workers to support generous public pension policies.

headline: ABC to ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ Star: Physician, Heal Thyself
text: Isaiah Washington, the “Grey’s Anatomy” star, has struggled recently with a certain anti-gay epithet, which has twice tumbled quite audibly out of his mouth in reference to fellow cast member T.R. Knight, who is gay — first on the set of the hit ABC show, and then again during a press conference after the Golden Globes last Monday.

headline: Who’d Expect Otherwise?
text: DAVOS, Switzerland —  Chinese banks have, in the past, earned a reputation for not being completely open about how many bad loans were on their books. And there have been some cases of corruption.

headline: Shelly: Pick My Guy
text: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver told the Buffalo News that the next comptroller should be one of his five Assembly colleagues–a number that fell to four this morning after Gov. Spitzer appointed Alexander “Pete” Grannis to Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation.

headline: Davos Gadget Gets a Silicon Valley Tweak
text: Even the hackers show up in Davos.

headline: Time Inc. to Sell Magazines to Swedish Publisher
text: Media conglomerate Time Warner will sell 18 magazines to the Swedish publishing company Bonnier Group, Bonnier said in a press release Thursday. The magazines to be sold include Field & Stream, Outdoor Life and Yachting.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: Primary Frenzy
text: With big states like Florida, New Jersey, California and Illinois looking to move up their primaries to shortly after New Hampshire’s, will it be a whole new nominating world? The Times’s Adam Nagourney examines how the calendar could complicate candidates’ strategies.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Dutchman," "Women of Trachis" and "The Dirty Talk."

headline: The Downside of Banking Bonuses
text: As on Wall Street, bankers in London got huge year-end bonuses. But over there, the bankers’ former spouses may end up getting big shares of those bonuses — and possibly future bonuses as well. One British lawyer advises bankers and hedge-fund executives: “Don’t get married.”

headline: Ford Still Loves Girls and Football
text: Harold Ford Jr., the former Tennessee congressman and unsuccessful candidate for Senate last year, took over as chairman of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council today.

headline: Crying Pols
text: Another video microgenre hits the Internets: Career politicians getting choked up.

headline: Who’d Expect Otherwise?
text: Chinese banks have, in the past, earned a reputation for not being completely open about how many bad loans were on their books. And there have been some cases of corruption.

headline: A Chat With Ted Leonsis
text: The Carpetbagger talks with Ted Leonsis at Sundance about film-antrophy and his first film, 'Nanking.'

headline: Claudia Schiffer Breaks a Glamour Embargo
text: Looking for Angelina Jolie or Brad Pitt on the conference grounds? Not this year.

headline: Busy Morning in Hillaryland
text: Senator Clinton just walked out of a private meeting with the Rev. Al Sharpton, who is comparison shopping among likely 2008 candidates, sitting also with Senators Obama, Dodd, and Biden today.

headline: Pernod Is Absolutely Interested in Swedish Vodka
text: France’s Pernod Ricard is interested in buying Swedish state-owned vodka Absolut when it comes up for sale, while talks on acquiring the Stolichnaya brand outside Russia continue, the company said on Thursday. When asked at a briefing in London if Pernod was interested in buying Vin & Sprit‘s Absolut, managing director Pierre Pringuet said “yes.” Absolut, known for its long-running, pun-filled ad campaign, is the world’s second-bestselling vodka after Diageo’s Smirnoff. Analysts have valued the brand at more than $4 billion.

headline: Streaming Movies
text: Netflix has rewritten the rules of the online movie-rental game.

headline: Net Pioneer Settles Into ‘Nerd Paradise’
text: Having been a player in one of the most dramatic stories of the dot-com boom and bust, Joe Kraus seems happy to be safely ensconced at the Internet giant Google. Mr. Kraus founded Excite, which went from a university-sponsored search engine to (as Excite@Home) one of the biggest names in the Internet business before its spectacular crash and burn at the turn of the latest century. He went on to found JotSpot, a maker of collaboration software that Google acquired in October.

headline: Kristof on Anderson Cooper 360
text: NYTimes.com footage of the columnist's most recent trip to Cambodia was included in a Jan. 24 segment on CNN's Anderson Cooper 360.

headline: Seven or Eight Days in Paris (But Who’s Counting?)
text: The spring haute couture collections have opened. At Dior, John Galliano has recreated the dove-gray look of the salon, with a pair of enormous chairs to remind us of his capacity to distort reality. Sure, the clothes evoked “Madame Butterfly,” but in their sugary colors and their playfulness (tailored jackets that morph into origami birds), they also told the story of Galliano’s 10 years at Dior. He had the girls walk among the guests, so that you could touch the clothes, and he had all the top girls, including Shalom Harlow and Jacquetta Wheeler, who at one point was having so much trouble negotiating some steps in her enormous dress that I thought one of the ushers might have to perform a fireman’s lift.

headline: A Wake-Up Call to Microsoft’s PR Team
text: From the January 1, 2007, edition of The New York Times:

headline: Researchers Say Prehistoric Extinctions in Australia Were Man’s Work, Not Nature’s
text: Sticking with the theme of bizarre prehistoric creatures today, we turn our attentions to the marsupial lion — one of several critters known collectively as Australia’s once-plentiful “megafauna” that vanished from the planet roughly 45,000 years ago.

headline: Paradise Lost: Hedge Funds Flee from Island Tax Haven
text: Nearly half of the 49 hedge funds that had their headquarters in the Virgin Islands have left in the past two years. It’s not the heat or the bugs that sent them packing, but the Internal Revenue Service. A set of new laws and regulations have dashed the hopes of people who had counted on their Virgin Islands address cutting their tax bills by 90 percent. The I.R.S. suspects “rampant fraud,” according to a Bloomberg News account of the situation on St. Croix and other islands.

headline: Civil War, or War Against Civilians?
text: There has been great debate in recent months about whether the conflict in Iraq can accurately be called a civil war. Iraqi Vice President Adil Abdul Mahdi offered his view Thursday in a panel discussion at Davos chaired by Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.

headline: Blogtalk: Question Time
text: Is Al Sharpton “very happy” that his hometown senator is running for president? [The Caucus]

headline: How to Top It Off
text: First of all, the responses to my last post on unusual food and wine matches has been fascinating. Thank you! While I do like good dark chocolate, I am not really a chocolate lover, so I’ve never really wondered about what wine, or whisky, to drink with it. But I was especially intrigued by Brooklynguy’s suggestion of a simple grilled hanger steak with a good Savennières, as I love Savennières and steak, but have never tried them at the same time. But I can see it intellectually and, more important, I started to salivate thinking about it.

headline: From Kerry to Obama
text: Less than 24 hours after Senator John Kerry announced that he would not enter the 2008 presidential race, some of his prominent contributors are joining the camp of Senator Barack Obama.

headline: The Softer Side of Surging
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s Jan. 25 column, “Breaking the Clinch.”

headline: Eye to Eye With Bush, Democrats Too Shy
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 25 column, “Long on Rhetoric, Short on Sorrow.“

headline: Bill Miller on Luck and the End of ‘The Streak’
text: Bill Miller, the legendary stock picker who manages the Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund, says he is often asked whether, on some level, he is relieved that his streak — 15 years of besting the Standard & Poor’s 500 — is over. “The answer is no,” he wrote in his latest letter to shareholders of the fund, which ended 2006 up 5.9 percent, far below the 15.8 percent gain in the S&P. He goes on to suggest that it is actually a silly question.

headline: Redefining Reality
text: Readers respond to Frank Rich’s Dec. 10 column, “The Sunshine Boys Can’t Save Iraq.”

headline: A Hot-Button Issue Cools Down
text: Readers respond to Frank Rich’s Dec. 17 column, “Mary Cheney’s Bundle of Joy.”

text: Doritos will air this example of user-generated advertising.

text: Doritos will air this example of user-generated advertising.

text: Doritos will air this example of user-generated advertising.

headline: Bush on Free Health Care Benefits
text: While President Bush was promoting his health initiatives at a roundtable at St. Luke’s Hospital in Lee’s Summit, Mo., today, he kind of forgot how many workers now pay for their health care benefits. (See the line we’ve boldfaced below.)

headline: And Then There Were Three?
text: This is getting interesting. The three wise men (as former state comptrollers H. Carl McCall, Ned Regan and former city comptroller Harrison J. Goldin have come to be known) have spoken, and they found only three of the many candidates who applied to be comptroller qualified for the job – and none of the three are from the Legislature.

headline: What the Democrats Didn’t Say (en Inglés)
text: The Democratic rebuttal to President Bush’s State of the Union address sounded quite different in Spanish — and not just because of the language.

headline: Calvin Trillin Gets Parked
text: The author of the first parking novel test drives the first car that parks itself.

headline: The Conversation: 2006 Highlights II
text: Excerpts from The New York Times reporter Calvin Sims' interviews, including John Yoo, Orhan Pamuk, Neil deGrasse Tyson, Antonio Maria Costa and Luke Visconti.

headline: Colleges Regroup After Voters Ban Race Preferences
text: With Michigan’s new ban on affirmative action going into effect, and similar ballot initiatives looming in other states, many public universities are scrambling to find race-blind ways to attract more blacks and Hispanics.

headline: Trying to Imagine a Woman in the White House
text: Is America ready to elect a woman president?

headline: Buy Vista, Surf Free
text: Man, talk about a good deal.

headline: Classical Music for Six Strings
text: ANDRÉS SEGOVIA, widely known as the father of modern classical guitar, may have explained its sophisticated appeal better than anyone else. “The guitar is a small orchestra,” he said. “It is polyphonic. Every string is a different color, a different voice.”

headline: Anchor’s Ties to Citigroup Attract Scrutiny
text: Late last year, an executive from Citigroup phoned an official connected with CNBC, the cable business news channel. According to people with knowledge of the call, the Citigroup executive made it clear that Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, would not be permitted to fly on Citigroup’s corporate jet again.

headline: A Fearless Fighter, Gone (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Long Island, More Are Priced Out of the Housing Market
text: GARDEN CITY, Jan. 24 — In 2000, 60 percent of the homes sold on Long Island could be classified as “affordable” for families earning up to $100,000 a year, under the old rule of thumb that buyers should spend no more than 2.5 times their income on places to live.

headline: In Lower Manhattan, the Echo of the Yiddish Stage Endures
text: REAL estate agents have a knack for investing any Manhattan neighborhood with romance, no matter how harsh or dowdy its past. The bloodstained meatpacking district in recent years has assumed a sudden charm. Then there's the Lower East Side, which has become a cradle to luxury condos after spending decades as a place where immigrants of all stripes strived to get to, then sought to leave as quickly as possible — a kind of perpetual springboard to a better life.

headline: Theater Listings
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Russia, Europe Split Over Human Rights Court
text: A summary of top stories in Russian newspapers on Friday.

headline: From Unread to in Demand, Thanks to ‘Utopia’
text: ONE of the hottest books in New York appears on no best-seller list.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a chip deal between Sun Microsystems and Intel and its effect on an Intel rival, Advanced Micro Devices, rendered incorrectly a quotation from a research note by an analyst with Stifel Nicolaus, Cody Acree. He wrote, “Now A.M.D. has missed the last two quarters”  not that “Intel” has missed the last two quarters.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about Carmen Laureano, a Bronx woman who received money for clothing and furniture from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the subject of the picture in some copies. She was Luz Rivera, Ms. Laureano’s 12-year-old daughter, not Ms. Laureano.

headline: After Two Tough Years, Williams Shows She’s Not Done Yet
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 26 — It was the morning before Serena Williams’s most unexpected Grand Slam final, and she was sitting in a chair in the Australian sun for an interview, speaking slowly, laughing frequently and enjoying the sharpest turn for the better in a career full of switchbacks.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Jan. 14 about wealthy foreigners moving to Switzerland and negotiating tax breaks incorrectly described a formula used for determining a lump sum tax payment. The immigrants negotiate an annual payment based on five times the monthly rental value of their Swiss homes. They do not make a one-time payment based on the value of their Swiss homes. (Go to Article)

headline: Presidents Ford (as in Harrison) and Freeman Show the Way
text: Hollywood and national politics scrambled for our attention this week. They drew special interest from some in this city, graced as it now is with almost as many potential presidential candidates as Naomi Campbell has tantrums.

headline: Mondrian South Beach and One Steamboat Place
text: Mondrian South Beach

headline: Court Finds State Agency Miscalculated Housing Need
text: TRENTON, Jan. 25  The state agency set up to ensure that municipalities meet court-mandated requirements to provide low- and moderate-income housing has used faulty methods in calculating housing needs in the state, a Superior Court appellate panel ruled on Thursday.

headline: New Rocket Is Progressing, NASA Reports
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — The new rocket that will replace the space shuttle for carrying crews to the International Space Station is on schedule and within weight guidelines, NASA officials said Thursday.

headline: Multiplying the Payoffs From a Super Bowl Spot
text: HERE is a lesson in new math, Madison Avenue style: The most expensive advertising buy of the year may turn out to be something of a bargain.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article by The Associated Press last Friday about the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic misidentified the winner of the Texas Open in September. It was Eric Axley  not Justin Rose, who shared the lead in the Chrysler Classic at one point, but is still seeking his first PGA Tour victory.

headline: Iraq Leader and Sunni Officials in Clash on Security
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 25 — Iraq’s Shiite prime minister and Sunni lawmakers hurled insults at one another during a raucous session of Parliament on Thursday, with the prime minister threatening a Sunni lawmaker with arrest and the Sunni speaker of Parliament threatening to quit.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Delays Limit Robust Sales at Microsoft
text: Microsoft yesterday reported strong sales for its latest quarter and a profit that slightly surpassed Wall Street estimates, but its financial results were muddled by the late arrival of important new products.

headline: Distinguishing the Remarkable From the Merely Old
text: AS de facto custodian of everything within the built city that bears sprucing up and saving for posterity, Robert B. Tierney, chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, is instantly miffed when a photographer gives his office the once-over and offhandedly remarks that there is nothing in it worth preserving on camera. Well, maybe him. But only if he puts on the silly paper party hat crowned by a cartoonish depiction of the Chrysler Building sitting on the bookcase next to two  likewise ceremonial  hard hats from Lincoln Center and the High Line.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Aug. 31 about a decision by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to give some priests accused of child sexual abuse the choice of leaving the priesthood or moving to supervised housing in Westchester County  an option that was later canceled  misstated the jurisdiction of the archdiocese. It covers Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx in New York City, and seven other downstate counties  not all of New York City and five other downstate counties. The error was discovered recently by a reporter reviewing The Times’s archives.

headline: Suspended Guard Wants to Return to Notre Dame
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 26 — Kyle McAlarney, the starting point guard for Notre Dame before he was arrested last month for possession of marijuana and suspended from the university, notified Coach Mike Brey on Friday morning that he intended to return to the program.

headline: Queens Now Has Less Feta, More Jellyfish
text: LIKE most New York immigrant stories, mine started with a long trip, a small apartment in a humble neighborhood and hope for a better life. Sure enough, I graduated from the little apartment to a bigger one, and then a house. I got a better job and a better life. But 27 years later, the neighborhood remains the same: Astoria, Queens.

headline: Groups Head to Capital to Step Up Antiwar Drive
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — Tens of thousands of demonstrators are set to arrive in the capital this weekend for a major antiwar march, staging the first of several protests intended to persuade the new Democratic-controlled Congress to do more than simply speak against President Bush’s Iraq policy.

headline: When It Comes to Parcells, Never Say Never, Ever
text: Over the telephone, a voice said, “Coach Parcells is calling.”

headline: A Convenient Truth
text: Melbourne, Australia

headline: What’s on Friday Night
text: 8 P.M.(Turner Classic Movies) PARIS WHEN IT SIZZLES (1964). Paris isn’t just for springtime. Tonight, TCM takes a winter break in the City of Light, starting with this William Holden and Audrey Hepburn vehicle about a boozy writer who has two days to deliver a script to a Hollywood producer and hires a temporary secretary to help him get the job done. They fall in love, but of course. At 10, Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron trip the light fantastic to a luscious Gershwin score in the grand musical “An American in Paris” (1951). And at midnight, Alec Guinness and Vernon Gray play a Scottish father and son who visit the city and tumble into mild infatuations — the son with an older woman, the father with a girl — in “To Paris, With Love” (1955).

headline: Reality Check for a Generation That Knows Best
text: Viewers who complain that the auditions on this season’s “American Idol” are too cruel are missing the point.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about Senator John Kerry’s announcement that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2008 incorrectly described what he called “a botched joke” he told before the November midterm elections. In telling the joke, which was assailed as an attack on American troops fighting in Iraq, Mr. Kerry not only dropped a word from his prepared remarks, but he also rephrased his opening sentence extensively and omitted a reference to President Bush. Mr. Kerry’s aides said that the prepared text read: “Do you know where you end up if you don’t study, if you aren’t smart, if you’re intellectually lazy? You end up getting us stuck in a war in Iraq. Just ask President Bush.” What he actually said: “You know, education, if you make the most of it, you study hard, you do your homework and you make an effort to be smart, you can do well. If you don’t, you get stuck in Iraq.”

headline: Presidential Libraries (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sometimes Pulp Fiction Emphasizes Pulp Over Fiction
text: “F.B.I.! F.B.I.!” Blam blam blam blam. “[Expletive]. [Expletive].” Blam blam blam. Spurt of blood. Plot twist. “F.B.I.! F.B.I.!” “[Expletive].” Blam blam blam blam blam. “[Expletive].” “F.B.I.!” “Hotel Security!” Blam. Exploding skull. Guy sits on a chain saw. Montage. [Expletive]. Plot twist. Roll credits.

headline: How Transfer Taxes Work
text: The good news for New York City’s budget stems partly from the taxes New Yorkers must pay when buying property in the city’s booming real estate market. The city, along with the state, is collecting a record amount in transfer taxes from the sale of residential properties, and those sales have remained strong.

headline: Aid Conference Raises $7.6 Billion for Lebanese Government
text: PARIS, Jan. 25 — Led by Saudi Arabia and the United States, international donors from more than 30 countries on Thursday pledged $7.6 billion in aid for Lebanon, in a bold effort to try to prop up the government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora.

headline: Seeing Future of Britain, and Blair, in the Snow
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25  As a subplot to the annual rite here of the World Economic Forum, there is what might be billed as the Little Britain show, or, perhaps more diplomatically, Britain’s big picture writ small in the snows of Switzerland.

headline: Randolph Gets Expensive as Mets’ Expectations Rise
text: Coffee, gasoline and real estate cost a small fortune in New York. And now, the Mets have learned, so does a manager with two years of experience.

headline: Mayor Sees $3.9 Billion Surplus Fed by Booming Real Estate Market
text: With New York City’s treasury flush with unexpected revenue from an extraordinary surge in the real estate market, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg projected yesterday that the city would have a $3.9 billion surplus to carry over into its $57.1 billion budget next fiscal year, allowing him to cut taxes and set aside money for future expenses.

headline: Gains in Wireless Customers Help Lift AT&T’s Earnings 17%
text: Capping a whirlwind year of merging and rebranding that has come to characterize the telecommunications business, AT&T reported a 17 percent increase in quarterly profits yesterday driven by a sizable increase in wireless subscribers.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about sharp spikes in property taxes in northern Rockland County, N.Y., stemming from a settlement of $275 million that several municipalities and a school district agreed to pay to a power company as compensation for tax overcharges, misidentified the state agency that deregulated electric utilities in the 1990s. It is the Public Service Commission  not the New York State Power Authority, which is an electricity producer.

headline: Ask Science
text: Natalie Angier answered readers’ questions regarding her first column for Science Times, about the nature of time.

headline: In Clue to Addiction, Brain Injury Halts Smoking
text: Scientists studying stroke patients are reporting today that an injury to a specific part of the brain, near the ear, can instantly and permanently break a smoking habit. People with the injury who stopped smoking found that their bodies, as one man put it, “forgot the urge to smoke.”

headline: Bush Backs Force Against Iranians in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- American soldiers will do what they must to protect themselves from Iranian agents operating inside Iraq, the White House said today, following a report that President Bush had authorized the killing of Iranian agents.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Illinois: Bias Claimed in Contest
text: A woman who won a car in a contest sponsored by a Spanish-language radio station is suing the station and its parent company, saying they withheld the car from her because she is an illegal immigrant. The woman, Maribel Nava Alvarez, filed suit in late November in Chicago against the local station, WLEY 107.9 FM, and the Spanish Broadcasting System, said her lawyer, Robert M. Romero. The suit, only now being reported in English-language news media, alleges breach of contract because the station refused to give Ms. Alvarez the Corvette she won in a raffle at a fair on July 4, 2005, Mr. Romero said. In a statement, the station and its parent company said they could not give Ms. Alvarez the car because they were unable to verify the tax-reporting information required by the Internal Revenue Service in awarding prizes valued at more than $500.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Jan. 14 about wealthy foreigners moving to Switzerland and negotiating tax breaks incorrectly described a formula used for determining a lump sum tax payment. The immigrants negotiate an annual payment based on five times the monthly rental value of their Swiss homes. They do not make a one-time payment based on the value of their Swiss homes.

headline: Nokia Net Up 19%, Topping Estimates
text: Nokia, the maker of mobile phones, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 19 percent, beating analysts’ estimates, as a push into emerging markets drove handset sales to a record.

headline: Meissner Thrives in Starring Role
text: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 25 — Though Kimmie Meissner has had time to get used to the role as the top American figure skater since she won a world title last year, she said the pressure that goes with being the favorite at the United States Figure Skating Championships hit her only this week.

headline: Hotel in Pakistani Capital Is Bombed
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 26 — A man blew himself up today outside a major hotel used by government officials and foreign dignitaries, killing himself and a security guard, police and security officials said. Three other people were wounded.

headline: Knicks Are Depleted as Heat's Stars Return
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 25 — The Miami Heat defeated the Knicks handily Monday without Shaquille O’Neal and Dwyane Wade. On Friday, the teams will meet again, but this time it may be the Knicks who are short-handed.

headline: A Game? No, It’s a Life.
text: AT this time of year there isn’t a lot to do in Warroad, Minn., a little town at the southwestern end of the Lake of the Woods, just a few miles from the Canadian border. There is no movie theater, the one bowling alley closed a while ago and the nearest shopping mall is in Grand Forks, N.D., two and half hours away across a windswept plain. You can snowmobile, but the snowfall has been a little skimpy so far this winter. Or you can ice fish, though until just a couple of weeks ago, when the temperature finally plunged to double digits below, it might have been unwise to drive a pickup out onto the lake.

headline: Once Upon a Time in a Very Familiar West
text: Archetypes and symbols solemnly parade through “Seraphim Falls,” a handsome, old-fashioned western of few words and heavy meanings that unfolds with the sanctimonious grandeur of a biblical allegory. In this drama of pursuit, revenge and forgiveness, set in 1868, Pierce Brosnan and Liam Neeson are soldiers who fought on opposite sides of the Civil War and are now engaged in a life-and-death chase that takes them from the Ruby Mountains of Nevada to a final showdown in the desert.

headline: G.I. Gets 18-Year Prison Term for Killing 2 Captive Iraqis
text: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Jan. 25  An Army infantryman received an 18-year prison sentence on Thursday after pleading guilty to killing two unarmed Iraqis during an assault northwest of Baghdad last May.

headline: Spitzer to Outline Plans for Cuts in Health Spending
text: ALBANY, Jan. 25 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer will preview his first executive budget in a speech on Friday afternoon, laying out his plan to rein in Medicaid and other health care spending, setting the stage for a battle with politically powerful health care providers and unions.

headline: Love Means Always Having to Say You’re Sorry
text: “Breaking and Entering,” the latest film by Anthony Minghella, climaxes in a welter of apologies. Everyone in London, it seems, has cause for remorse — the burglar, the philanderer, the seamstress, the budding gymnast — and for my part I regret that I lost count of the number of times the words “I’m sorry” were uttered on screen.

headline: The Name Is ‘Power’ and It Fits
text: MONTREAL, Jan. 23 — The narrow stone building on Victoria Square here has an unusual dark green door with prominent brass handles and hinges. But no signs on its exterior or anywhere in the marble lobby behind it indicate that it is the headquarters of the Power Corporation of Canada, one of the country’s largest financial services companies and Quebec’s pre-eminent newspaper publisher.

headline: No Frivolity: Davos Tries Fewer Stars
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 25 — Snow was not the only thing in short supply as moguls and world leaders rolled into this ski resort town this week.

headline: A Year After Her Olympic Fall, Winning Is Jacobellis’s Revenge
text: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 25 — Competitors cannot keep pace with her on the snowboardcross course, but shaking questions about her famous fall at the Winter Olympics has been more vexing for Lindsey Jacobellis.

headline: Salvadoran’s Death in Iraq Leaves His Mother Fuming
text: SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 21  From her hillside home in western El Salvador, Herminia Ramos sobbed and sobbed the other day as she recalled her fallen son.

headline: Spitzer Names 2 Members of His Environmental Team
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer nominated Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis of Manhattan yesterday to be the new commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, a sprawling agency that in recent years has lost hundreds of employees who handle critical matters like dam safety inspections and pollution permit reviews.

headline: Teaneck: Bus Hits and Kills Pedestrian
text: A man was struck and killed last night by a New Jersey Transit bus turning left from Teaneck Road onto State Street, the Teaneck police said. The man, whose identity was not immediately released, was declared dead at the scene around 8:30 p.m. The police said that the death appeared to be an accident and that they did not expect charges to be filed.

headline: When Money Talks, Do Voters Lose? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trying to Get Inside the Lives of Children in Urban Poverty
text: It’s virtually impossible for a mainstream journalist, in print or on film, to explore poverty without sounding condescending, and it’s certainly impossible for Diane Sawyer. Her treacliness works against the good intentions of “Waiting on the World to Change,” a “20/20” segment tonight on ABC that looks at some particularly impoverished young lives in Camden, N.J., one of the country’s most distressed cities.

headline: Building Boom May Mean Jobs Can’t All Be Filled, Report Says
text: Amid one of the biggest building booms in New York City’s history, the construction industry may soon have trouble finding enough young workers to fill all the jobs, a leading industry group said yesterday.

headline: British Airways Cancels Flights as Strike Nears
text: LONDON, Jan. 25 — British Airways said Thursday that it was canceling 1,300 flights from London for two days next week because of a planned strike by its cabin-crew workers.

headline: Calling Blue: And on That Farm He Had a Cellphone
text: Stephen Colbert, listen up. If any minority lifestyle is overrepresented in the early education of children in the United States, it’s farm life.

headline: Consumer Reports Apologizes for Botched Tests
text: Just a few weeks after an alarming report on the safety of infant car seats in Consumer Reports magazine that it later admitted was a result of botched tests, the magazine sent letters of apology yesterday to its readers and promised an investigation.

headline: A No Vote on Senate Raises Just Might Count
China Says Its Economy Grew by 10.7% in 2006, With Little Inflation
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 25 — In the last 30 years, no major economy in the world has grown at the speed of China’s, and no other country has been able to do it year after year, for over a decade.

headline: Why Iraq’s a Mess: Just Count the Ways (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Daniel Stern, Short Story Writer, Dies at 79
text: Daniel Stern, who sifted through his careers in jazz and symphonic music, advertising, movies and academia for psychic grist for the bittersweet, tightly crafted novels and short stories that were his crowning achievement, died Wednesday in Houston. He was 79.

headline: Ex-Cheney Aide Contradicts Libby
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — A former spokeswoman for Vice President Dick Cheney gave testimony in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on Thursday that directly contradicted Mr. Libby’s version of events during a crucial period that is at the center of the perjury case against him.

headline: Bush Pushes Health Care Plan
text: LEE’S SUMMIT, Mo., Jan. 25 — President Bush urged Congress on Thursday to consider his new health care proposal and indicated he was ready for a fight.

headline: New India Accords With Russia Include More Nuclear Power Plants
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 — India sealed a wide-ranging package of agreements with Russia on Thursday, the first day of a summit meeting intended to demonstrate that their longstanding relationship had not deteriorated as a result of India’s growing engagement with the United States.

headline: Secrecy Is at Issue in Suits Opposing Spy Program
text: The Bush administration has employed extraordinary secrecy in defending the National Security Agency’s highly classified domestic surveillance program from civil lawsuits. Plaintiffs and judges’ clerks cannot see its secret filings. Judges have to make appointments to review them and are not allowed to keep copies.

headline: Time Comes to a Standstill in a Courtroom Journey
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — The most politically charged criminal trial in the capital in nearly two decades crackles to life each morning in a bland sixth-floor courtroom with a stopped clock.

headline: Eloquent Tongues but Anguished Irish Hearts
text: Quite a few languages are spoken in Brian Friel’s play “Translations.” There is a fair amount of Latin and Greek. Gaelic makes frequent appearances. And English is of course the play’s official lingua franca.

headline: North Korea: U.N. Stops Projects and Cash
text: The United Nations Development Program agreed to cease $1.7 million in new projects in North Korea until completion of what Alejandro D. Wolff, the acting United States ambassador, called a “real, full, thorough, independent, investigative audit” and to end direct payments in hard currency to local staff members and vendors and recruitment through the North Korean government. The $2.7 million in programs that will go forward are those that directly benefit the people of North Korea, officials said. The action followed complaints from the United States and Japan that some money could be diverted to the government, a claim that North Korea dismissed as “ridiculous and nonsense.”

headline: A Triangle Equal to the Sum of Its Hoops
text: THE gentle hills of the Triangle region of North Carolina are spangled with the prim brick McMansions of migrant techies lured by opportunity and temperate weather — almost any day is good for squeezing in 18 holes. Out on the wandering back roads, tall pines still cast thin shadows, turning a sunny-day drive into a sparkling strobe-light show. Just roll down the window to air out your soul. The Triangle, bounded by the cities of Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill, is an easy place to live and an even easier place to visit. Refill your sweet-tea glass and sit a while.

headline: Drug That Treats Vision Problems May Increase Stroke Risk
text: Use of Genentech’s new eye drug, Lucentis, might raise the risk of stroke, according to a letter the company has begun sending to doctors.

headline: Food Pantry Needs Help, Even Holiday Fruitcake
text: FREEPORT, N.Y., Jan. 24 — That cellophane-wrapped holiday gift food package with the 12 different cheeses and three tins of paté. And that two-ton fruitcake. And the unopened Whitman’s Sampler. You could live without the calories contained in those gestures of good will from the season just passed — and people at the emergency food pantry here are willing to help.

headline: Afghan Lawmaker Is Killed in Shooting
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 26 — A member of Afghanistan’s Parliament was gunned down while he was walking from his home to a mosque for Friday prayers, officials said.

headline: Beirut University Dispute Escalates Into Rioting, Killing 4
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25 — Violence erupted in Beirut on Thursday for the second time in three days, as an altercation in a university cafeteria escalated into rioting and gunfire.

headline: Greece: Militants Claim U.S. Embassy Attack
text: The leftist guerrilla group known as Revolutionary Struggle claimed responsibility for the rocket attack on the American Embassy in Athens two weeks ago, saying it was in retaliation for the “criminal U.S. war on terrorism.” The claim was made in a five-page statement to the weekly newspaper Pontiki. Since September 2003, Revolutionary Struggle has claimed responsibility for a number of attacks, including bombings at a courthouse and police station and an assassination attempt against the culture minister. In its statement, the group warned: “There is no doubt that the American Embassy would be the first building we would wreck. The second would be Parliament.” It singled out Foreign Minister Dora Bakoyanni and Public Order Minister Vyronas Polydoras as “praetorians” of the American administration.

headline: Outspoken Catholic Pastor Replaced; He Says It’s Retaliation
text: In his last Mass as pastor at the inner-city parish in Detroit where he had served for 23 years, Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. Gumbleton told his parishioners that he was forced to step down as pastor because of his lobbying efforts on behalf of the victims of sexual abuse by members of the clergy, a stance that put him in opposition to his fellow bishops.

headline: Watching a History Lesson That’s Told Through Tango
text: Miguel Angel Zotto re-entered New York society on Wednesday when his company, Tango X 2, performed for the first time in a decade at City Center. The group, formed in 1988, presented “Su Historia,” a two-act show tracing the company’s history and paying homage to Mr. Zotto’s tango heroes.

headline: Jack Kerouac, in His Cups, on a Tear and on TV
text: “No Great Society,” which opened at Performance Space 122  in February, reopened last night and runs through Feb. 11 at the New York Theater Workshop’s Fourth Street Theater, 83 East Fourth Street, East Village; (212) 239-6200. Following are excerpts from Jason Zinoman’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 11; the full text is online here.

headline: Hartford: Senate Health Care Plan
text: Democratic leaders of the State Senate offered a $450 million plan yesterday to increase publicly financed health care programs for the uninsured. The plan would make 140,000 uninsured people eligible for programs like Medicaid and insurance plans for children. It would leave an estimated 260,000 residents without health insurance, but Donald E. Williams, the Senate president, said it was a “first step” toward a universal health care program.

headline: Bush to Seek More Aid for Afghanistan as Taliban Regroups
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 25 — President Bush plans to ask Congress for $10.6 billion in aid for Afghanistan, primarily to beef up the country’s security forces, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Thursday.

headline: More Willful Indifference
text: Mark Foley fled his seat in the House of Representatives last September when his sexual approaches to teenage pages finally reached the news media after years of a shameful cover-up in the halls of Congress. Now it turns out that the F.B.I. was just as phlegmatic about the scandal as Mr. Foley’s Republican colleagues. An inspector general’s report excoriates F.B.I. agents for brushing aside “troubling” evidence of the lawmaker’s flirtatious message-writing, and then falsely blaming their inaction on the watchdog group that tried to alert the government in the first place.

headline: A Convocation of the Visionary and Disenfranchised
text: Now in its 15th round, the robust extravaganza known as the Outsider Art Fair might almost be called Establishment. To be sure, compared with uptown fairs it’s still a little short on amenities: no carpets, no-frills booths, a loosey-goosey layout. But this annual event at the Puck Building has longevity and staying power, and its now-classic artists — among them Henry Darger, Bill Traylor, Joseph E. Yoakum, Adolf Wölfli, Scottie Wilson, Howard Finster, James Castle and Elijah Pierce, to name a few — keep returning. (Martín Ramírez, who is starring uptown in a major retrospective at the American Folk Art Museum, appears here, too, at several dealers’ booths.)

headline: Fun When It Freezes
text: WHO Doug Kolner, 47, owner of a biotech manufacturing company and commodore of the Four Lakes Ice Yacht Club

headline: Gold Rush Mentality at a Hustlin’ Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah, Jan. 25 — Midway through this year’s Sundance Film Festival, the festival sent out a news release that underscored why so many now swarm around this mountain resort town every January without a ski lift ticket: several films that were first shown here had been nominated for Academy Awards, including “Little Miss Sunshine.” It was, said the director of the festival, Geoffrey Gilmore, “refreshing” that the academy had recognized “the quality of the storytelling and the talent of the actors in independent films that originally premiered” here.

headline: Fearing Protectionism, in India
text: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: Israeli Panel Approves Suspending President in Sex Scandal
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 25 — An Israeli parliamentary committee on Thursday approved President Moshe Katsav’s request to suspend himself for three months as prosecutors prepare a case against him that could include charges of rape and other sexual misconduct.

headline: G.M. Holds Results and Plans Big Restatement
text: DETROIT, Jan. 25 — General Motors said Thursday that it expected to post a profit for the fourth quarter but that it would delay reporting the results because its finance arm needs more time to complete calculations.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,053 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: From a Rough, Nomadic Childhood to Young Motherhood
text: Mirza Norales remembers waiting for her mother to pick her up from the emergency room as midnight approached one summer night in 2000, but she never came.

headline: Making Car of Tomorrow With Robotics of Today
text: CONCORD, N.C., Jan. 25 — For all the technology that goes into stock-car racing, Nascar remains a labor-intensive competition, as each race car chassis is welded together by hand. That will change this year when Evernham Motorsports becomes the first Nextel Cup team to use robotics to aid in building racecars.

headline: Some Pieces of Church Silver Don’t Go Gently to the Auction Block
text: It is often controversial when an American church sells its antique church silver, as reaction to a Christie’s sale of early American silver shows once again. Its Jan. 18 auction included 14 pieces of church silver consigned by the First Church in Salem of Salem, Mass., all of which sold.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Two picture captions on Sunday with an article about the transformation of East Harlem from a Puerto Rican enclave to a more heterogeneous neighborhood misidentified the location of buildings being renovated or constructed. They are on 117th Street, not 116th.

headline: At Last, Red Sox Will Sign Drew
text: The Boston Red Sox and outfielder J. D. Drew have resolved issues surrounding his five-year, $70 million contract, and Drew’s signing is expected today, The Boston Globe reported yesterday.

headline: A Friendly Face With a Foul Mouth That Sings
text: Bridget Everett is, without a doubt, the life of the party. Whether it’s a party you’d be interested in attending — or one you’d instantly flee in search of Xanax — depends on your affection for big-boned, loudmouthed, dirty-talking girls with attitudes stretching from here to Kansas.

headline: Acceptance Notices Sent, Mistakenly, to 2,700 University Applicants
text: Oops. The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill sent e-mails to 2,700 undergraduate applicants earlier this week, congratulating them — mistakenly — on their admission to the school.

headline: Tour Rookie Ties Course Mark and Best PlayStation Score
text: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 25  It is a bold golfer who can upstage Tiger Woods in his first tournament round of the year, but Brandt Snedeker has vowed to make inroads into Woods’s television time.

headline: Seeking Edge in China, Yankees Put Baseball First
text: The Yankees consider themselves the most driven team in a competitive sport, so their push to boost baseball in China is not purely altruistic. They believe there is talent to be cultivated in China, and when future prospects have a choice of where to sign, the Yankees want their brand and reputation to stand out.

headline: Letters: Second-Home Appliances
text: To the Editor: Gadzooks! “Ordeal by Appliance: Weekend Home Tales” (Jan. 19) implies that only the wealthy with remote second homes have problems with appliance repair. Remember, lots of Americans with only one home live in equally remote areas. The problems you nicely detail are common to all of us: appliances don’t last as long as they once did, hi-tech features exacerbate the problem, service is slow and decidedly low-tech. The rich, at least, are able to return home to their maids and housekeepers for solace. David Pevear Houston

headline: Outside In
text: The American Folk Art Museum’s transporting exhibition of the scroll-like drawings of the Mexican artist Martín Ramírez (1895-1963) should render null and void the insider-outsider distinction.

headline: EMI Merging Record Labels and Ousting Capitol’s President
text: EMI Group, the flagging British music conglomerate, reorganized its American unit yesterday by merging the operations of its two main record labels and ousting the president of Capitol Records, the bigger of the two.

headline: A Mystery Heard on Radio: It’s Stern’s Show, No Charge
text: Howard Stern, whose satellite radio show is typically available only to subscribers willing to pay $12.95 a month, has sworn that he will never return his morning show to the free commercial airwaves.

headline: Showing Young Skiers That ‘Really Cool’ Athletes Wear Helmets
text: FIVE years ago, Dr. Robert Williams, a Vermont pediatrician and critical care specialist, lay in his own hospital’s intensive care unit after a nasty mountain biking accident. Dr. Williams had a variety of serious injuries, including internal bleeding, but he had not sustained a head injury.

headline: United Way’s Top Executive Says He Will Retire in the Summer
text: Lawrence Mandell, president and chief executive of the United Way of New York City, stunned the staff of the organization yesterday by announcing that he would be retiring in June.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: A Return Trip to a Faraway Place Called Underground
text: Time is forever. Love is the goal. Art is what you are, not what you do. Many young artists and poets in California in the 1950s and ’60s felt and lived this way. And a traveling band of them, trailing a cloud of marijuana-fragrant air, has arrived at the Grey Art Gallery in “Semina Culture: Wallace Berman & His Circle.”

headline: Rules Dispute Imperils Khmer Rouge Trial
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 25 — The Cambodian judges were on one side and the foreign judges on the other this week in a dispute that captures a decade of difficulties in bringing to trial the last surviving leaders of the murderous Khmer Rouge.

headline: What a Teacher Needs (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Students Get 5-Year Sentences in Seton Hall Fire
text: NEWARK, Jan. 26 — Two former Seton Hall students were sentenced today to five years in prison after they admitted that they set a fire in a dormitory that killed three students and injured several others — an act one of them called “a prank that got out of hand.”

headline: A Tough Quarter for Some Drug Makers
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday and ImClone Systems said its profit was lower than expected; both companies cited increased competition for their biggest drugs.

headline: Old San Juan, for the Young
text: PUERTO RICO is a lush island, 100 by 35 miles, outlined by long stretches of white beach, which, for most tourists, are reason enough to visit. But on a recent trip with my husband and three children, I was struck by how much the island offers in addition to its coastline. As we discovered an array of historical sights and opportunities for natural adventures, I quickly concluded that giving up my beach chaise — at least part of the time — was a smart move.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded: $7,213,701.25

headline: Federer Finds New Ways to Torment Roddick
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 26  When the reinvigorated Andy Roddick stepped onto the court Thursday to face his longtime tormentor Roger Federer, the consensus was that it was going to be a special evening at the Australian Open.

headline: Bronx: Boy Dies After Night in Container
text: A 2-year-old boy was found dead in his Kingsbridge home yesterday after spending the night trapped inside a plastic storage container that he had climbed into during a hide-and-seek game with his siblings, the police said. The boy’s mother, whom neighbors identified as Rosa Lopez, discovered the 2-year-old, Anthony Pena, unconscious around 5 a.m., the police said, and he was pronounced dead when medics arrived at the apartment, at 3034 Albany Crescent. Ms. Lopez told the police that she put Anthony, his 6-year-old brother and his 3-year-old sister to bed about 9 p.m. on Wednesday, the police said. The siblings are believed to have shut the container with their brother inside, the police added. No charges have been filed. Neighbors reported hearing loud noises and fighting coming from the apartment during the night. The medical examiner is expected to conduct an autopsy today.

headline: New Yorkers Feel an Unusually Frigid Day
text: So you don’t like how frigid it is today in New York because you’ve gotten used to practically balmy, all but snow-free winter days. Well, don’t run out yet to buy a new heavy parka.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Hollywood, the Sequel: Less Shabby, More Chic
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 — For decades, tourists deposited themselves at one of the most famous intersections in America — Hollywood and Vine — and looked around in puzzlement, wondering what exactly they were supposed to be seeing.

headline: 2nd Republican Enters Race for Presidency
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — Representative Duncan Hunter, Republican of California, announced his bid for the presidency on Thursday in Spartanburg, S.C., then boarded a motor home to tour the state, where he hopes to gain support from a conservative electorate.

headline: Wal-Mart Settles U.S. Suit About Overtime
text: The United States Labor Department announced yesterday that Wal-Mart Stores had agreed to pay $33.5 million in back wages plus interest to settle a federal lawsuit that accused the company of violating overtime laws involving 86,680 workers.

headline: State Senate Approves Creating a Comptroller in New Jersey
text: TRENTON, Jan. 25  New Jersey could, for the first time, have a state comptroller with broad powers to audit and conduct performance reviews of state agencies, authorities, local governments and school districts under a bill that was narrowly approved by the Senate on Thursday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture credit with an article on Sunday about criticism of the pace of an investigation into a crash in which a New Jersey State Police car struck a minivan in September, killing two teenage sisters, misidentified the source of one of two photographs. Only the picture on the right, of a memorial to the victims, was by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times. The other picture, of the victims and their mother, was provided by the family.

headline: Manhattan: Prostitution Arrests at Scores
text: Seven people were arrested on prostitution charges at Scores West Side, a Chelsea nightclub, after an undercover operation on Wednesday night, the police said yesterday. Several dancers at the club engaged officers in sexual conversation and said sexual acts could be performed in rooms rented inside the club, the police said. The operation followed a complaint of prostitution at the club. Four women were arrested on charges of prostitution, and one woman and two men were charged with permitting prostitution, the police said. Mark Bederow, a lawyer for all seven, said his clients pleaded not guilty during their arraignments yesterday.

headline: Option to Rent: Great New Jersey Views, Many Lanes, Tollbooths Included
text: TRENTON, Jan. 24 — The New Jersey Turnpike has long been the subject of song and an object of scorn. And now Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who earned a reputation as a shrewd negotiator on Wall Street, is thinking seriously about leasing it out, banking on the hope that it and two other toll roads could fetch as much as $30 billion and hold the key to solving some of the state’s nagging fiscal difficulties.

headline: Mama Was a Rolling Stone
text: To a certain kind of aesthetic traditionalist there is certainly no more alienating set of words in the artist’s vocabulary than the phrase “mixed-media performance.” Such an individual hears those words and fears, more often than not justifiably, the very worst — indulgence, discord, facile earnestness. The mixed-media performer can be prone to masquerading platitude (war is trying; love, unattainable; materialism, rampant) as position. And in delivering the masquerade in several formats —with instruments, computer monitors, acrobats — the performer is suggesting that a mere barrage of images will compensate for all crimes of intellectual ambition committed.

headline: Artistic Revival Takes Root Amid Relics of Copper Mines
text: BUTTE, Mont.  This is the city that copper built, in the mountains atop the Continental Divide.

headline: Canada Reaches Settlement With  Torture Victim
text: OTTAWA, Jan. 26 — Maher Arar, the Canadian software engineer who was detained by American officials in 2002 and deported to Syria, where he was kept captive for nearly a year and regularly tortured, will receive more than 10.5 million Canadian dollars ($8.9 million) in compensation from the Canadian government, under a settlement announced today.

headline: Sharpton Goes to Washington to Talk to Party’s ’08 Hopefuls
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — The Rev. Al Sharpton, a man who says he knows a well-tailored suit from a fake, went to the United States Senate on Thursday to do some comparison shopping, meeting separately with four Democrats who are seeking the 2008 presidential nomination to discuss civil rights.

headline: A Familiar Rembrandt at a Formidable Price
text: A Rembrandt portrait of the Apostle St. James the Greater, his hands clasped in prayer, sold at Sotheby’s yesterday for $25.8 million. The winning bid was taken by Takako Nagasawa, a Sotheby’s representative in Asia, who was acting on behalf of a client identified by Sotheby’s only as a “non-American old-master painting collector.”

headline: Louisiana: Federal Officials Pledge Help on Crime
text: Responding to an increase in violent crime in New Orleans, the Department of Justice announced it would assign agents to the Police Department “around the clock” to help identify cases that could be prosecuted by federal officials. In other federal efforts to help beleaguered local law enforcement officials, the department also said it would send more agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, expand the authority of Drug Enforcement Administration agents and extend financing for six additional federal prosecutors temporarily posted to the city.

headline: John Lavelle, 57, New York Assemblyman, Dies
text: John W. Lavelle, the assemblyman for the 61st District and chairman of the Democratic Party on Staten Island, died Wednesday. He was 57.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Reich and Rollins Win Polar Prize

headline: Women Pay for a Chance to Play
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22 — They certainly looked like professionals, even if they weren’t.

headline: Colleges Regroup After Voters Ban Race Preferences
text: With Michigan’s new ban on affirmative action going into effect, and similar ballot initiatives looming in other states, many public universities are scrambling to find race-blind ways to attract more blacks and Hispanics.

headline: Renewal, in Real Estate and in Culture, for Ancient People
text: ROME, Jan. 25 — As a boy, in October 1943, Pacifico Disegni watched from his window as two German trucks hauled people from the ghetto in Rome, a city where Jews have lived for 2,000 years.

headline: The President’s Risky Health Plan
text: The new health care proposals announced by President Bush this week purport to tackle the two toughest problems confronting the American health care system: the rising number of uninsured Americans and the escalating costs of medical care.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about changes in the National Football League’s testing program for performance enhancing drugs misstated the mandatory suspension for a player who fails a second drug test. It is eight games, not one year.

headline: Ford Chief Sees Small as Virtue and Necessity
text: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 25 — Just 10 months ago, William Clay Ford Jr. vowed that his auto company, despite its mounting losses, would “reclaim our legacy” in the American car market and “emerge stronger than we’ve ever been.”

headline: Running on Empty
text: Sorry to repeat myself, but I have the same reaction to this year’s energy proposals in the State of the Union that I had to last year’s. President Bush had the opportunity to launch America on a transformative new path for clean, efficient power. He had a chance for a “Nixon to China” moment — as the Texas oilman who leads us into a greener future. Instead, he gave us “Nixon to New Mexico” — right direction, but not nearly far enough.

headline: Judge Urges U.S. to Drop Plan to Seek Death Penalty in Case
text: A federal judge, at the close of the death penalty trial of a convicted drug trafficker with ties to the rap music industry, called the government’s effort to seek his execution “absurd” and a waste of money and urged prosecutors to ask their Justice Department superiors in Washington to abandon the endeavor.

headline: Blackstone Raises Ante in Battle for Equity Office
text: The biggest leveraged buyout ever got bigger yesterday.

headline: People
text: People

headline: Amgen Finds Anemia Drug Holds Risks in Cancer Use
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  Amgen, the biotechnology company, said Thursday that its anemia drug Aranesp increased the risk of death when used to treat certain cancer patients, a finding that will probably raise more questions about it and similar drugs.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart in Business Day last Friday about recommendations by industry and environmental groups on how to limit greenhouse emission misstated a goal of the coalition. The group wants to cut greenhouse emissions to 20 to 40 percent of current levels by 2050, not 60 to 80 percent of current levels.

headline: Grading the Principal (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New England Lakes Area as a Back-to-Basics Getaway
text: FEW souls roamed the normally busy byways of Ossipee, N.H., earlier this month, as 65-degree temperatures and a complete lack of snow beset this mountainous, lake-rich territory near the Maine border. A tiny group of young snowboarders in T-shirts rode the sole lift running at the King Pine Ski Area in nearby East Madison. But Main Street in Center Ossipee was empty, and Ossipee Lake itself seemed uncertain whether to keep its scrim of ice.

headline: Manhattan: Drug Gangs Broken Up, Police Say
text: The Police Department announced yesterday that it had dismantled two drug organizations that were selling crack cocaine and marijuana in Washington Heights. One group was operating out of eight apartments in the Polo Grounds Houses, on Eighth Avenue near 155th Street, the police said. The other group, a subset of the Bloods street gang known as the Best Out, was earning about $10,000 a week from street-level sales in the same area, the police said. Officers began investigating the two groups last year, the police said. In raids yesterday, the police arrested more than two dozen people and seized cash, narcotics and two .22-caliber revolvers.

headline: Nets Lose Close One, Again
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 – For the third game in a row, the Nets lost by 1 point on their opponent’s final shot, this time falling to the Los Angeles Clippers, 102-101, at the Staples Center. The Nets are now 0-3 on their five-game trip out West, and they have yet to win a road game against a Western Conference team this season.

headline: Debate in India: Is Rule on Yoga Constitutional?
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 — Hollywood celebrities swear by it. Yuppies the world over have fallen on their knees to embrace it. Now, the question of whether public school students in India should be required to take up the sun salutation, or “surya namaskar” as the common yoga exercise is known in Sanskrit, has engendered a legal and political row in this country, revealing lingering questions about how secularism is practiced and challenged in Indian politics.

headline: Rodolfo and Mimi Soar Again
text: Not many tenors these days excel in the full-bodied, lyric Puccini and Verdi repertory once owned by the likes of Carlo Bergonzi, Giuseppe Di Stefano and Luciano Pavarotti. The closest we have may be the Italian tenor Marcello Giordani, who took over the role of Rodolfo on Wednesday night for the first of four final performances in the Metropolitan Opera’s current revival of Puccini’s “Bohème.” His Mimi was the Chilean soprano Cristina Gallardo-Domâs, which united the stars of the Met’s acclaimed Anthony Minghella production of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly.”

headline: Manhattan: New Post for Public Schools
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday announced the creation of a new administrative position: chief executive for parent engagement, charged with ensuring a “greater level of collaboration with parents and community groups that serve them.” The chief executive, who is expected to be named this spring, will report directly to the chancellor. The announcement came at Mr. Klein’s testimony at a City Council hearing, at which he was questioned on plans to change the school system.

headline: Schumer to Democrats: Challenges Ahead
text: New York’s senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, was a chief architect — along with Representative Rahm Emanuel in the House — of the Democrats’ 2006 campaign strategy that helped lead to their take-back of Congress in November, persuading incumbent Democrats in red states not to retire; countering Karl Rove’s much ballyhooed Republican machine with a hefty war chest and aggressive on-the-ground tactics of their own; and perhaps most important, recruiting and backing candidates (like Jon Tester in Montana, Bob Casey in Pennsylvania and James Webb in Virginia) who could compete in red-leaning states.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: On Being Partisan
text: American politics is ugly these days, and many people wish things were different. For example, Barack Obama recently lamented the fact that “politics has become so bitter and partisan” — which it certainly has.

headline: Park, He Said
text: IT was only a matter of time before someone was able to spot the test driver deep within me. O.K., test parker: I was asked if I would do a road test of the self-parking device on the new Lexus LS 460 L. Although I like to think that I was being perceived as a laconic man with steel nerves and steady hands, I suspect that the invitation had something to do with my authorship of “Tepper Isn’t Going Out,” which is considered by most scholars to have been the first parking novel. It might even have had something to do with the fact that in 1964 I was the founding co-editor of Beautiful Spot: A Magazine of Parking, which I’ve seen referred to as a one-issue publication even though we prefer to say that the second issue hasn’t come out yet. (We’ve had some production difficulties.)

headline: Immigration Raid Draws Protest From Labor Officials
text: An immigration raid at a huge North Carolina pork-packing plant provoked protests yesterday from union officials, who said the company, Smithfield Foods, had collaborated with the authorities searching for illegal immigrants to discourage its workers from organizing.

headline: A Rocky Mountain Road to Happily Ever After
text: The Chamber of Commerce of Boulder, Colo., should be over the moon about the portrait of that city presented by the warm and fuzzy romantic comedy “Catch and Release.” It appears to be a clean, prosperous bohemian paradise where everyone is happy 90 percent of the time; even visitors from big, bad Los Angeles quickly mellow.

headline: Days of Decision in Ulster
text: The militant Irish republican Gerry Adams and the fire-breathing unionist preacher Ian Paisley have long symbolized the irreconcilable extremes of Ulster politics. But over the next few days, they have the chance to lead the province into a new era of democratic self-rule.

headline: Extra Innings Throws a Curve, and Fans Cry Foul
text: Jeanette Bottone cried last week when she heard that the Extra Innings package of major league baseball games that she has diligently watched on cable since 2002 was about to migrate to DirecTV in April.

headline: Tremors at the Door
text: Wall Street’s big bet on risky mortgages may be souring a lot faster than had been previously thought.

headline: Nets Take Two Steps Back After a Big Step Forward
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  The Nets squandered double-digit leads in the fourth quarter and lost each of their first two games of their trip out West, a reflection of their inability to maintain a steady course this season.

headline: Sharp Decline in Union Members in ’06
text: Union membership dropped sharply last year in the United States, as the percentage of manufacturing workers in unions fell below the percentage of American workers in unions for the first time in modern history.

headline: Pork Producer Says It Plans to Give Pigs More Room
text: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 — The world’s largest pork processor said on Thursday that it would phase out confinement of pigs in individual gestation crates over the next decade, a move animal welfare advocates said would end one of the cruelest practices in the agriculture industry.

headline: Suspension Over, Albert Pirro Is Readmitted to Practice Law
text: After a federal conviction and suspension of his law license, Albert J. Pirro Jr., the husband of the former Westchester district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, was readmitted to practice law in New York this week, the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court said yesterday.

headline: NATO Allies Wary of Adding Troops in Afghanistan
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26 — America’s European allies remained noncommittal about sending additional troops to Afghanistan today, even as the Bush administration sought to inject new energy into the NATO mission against the Taliban by offering more American soldiers and money.

headline: State Panel Selects 3 Likely Comptrollers
text: ALBANY, Jan. 25  Setting up a potential showdown with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a panel charged with picking the next state comptroller went against Mr. Silver’s wishes in naming three finalists on Thursday, none of them members of the State Legislature.

headline: About Those Fears of Wall Street’s Decline ...
text: A LOT of smart people have spent a lot of time talking to a lot of important people about whether the financial services sector is becoming less competitive.

headline: Art in Review
text: STEPHEN G. RHODES  Recurrency Guild & Greyshkul 28 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 10

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Queens: Community Center Audit
text: The city is considering legal action against employees of a Queens community center after an audit revealed that they received $178,530 in questionable payments, officials said. The audit, released yesterday by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., was ordered after suspicions of financial irregularities at the center, the Pomonok Neighborhood Center in Flushing, surfaced in 2005. The center has city and state contracts to provide after-school programs, housing assistance and other services. According to the audit, the center’s youth program director may have padded the time sheets for himself, his daughter, his live-in companion and her son, who were hired in violation of rules against nepotism. The audit also questioned salary payments to 27 other people.

headline: Lessons at Princeton (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Caliendo, Madden, Sandomir and Cosell
text: For those who read Richard Sandomir’s article on Frank Caliendo but haven’t seen Caliendo’s impersonations of John Madden and others, click on the YouTube link.

headline: Bears-Patriots, Super Bowl XX
text: Welcome to another episode of Classic Times Rewind. This selection, on Super Bowl XX in 1986, should make Bears fans happy. They’ve been a little cranky lately about their team being considered underdogs against the Colts. That wasn’t a problem against the Patriots, of course, and the Bears are back in the Super Bowl after a 21-year absence.

headline: This Land: Here Lies Sitting Bull...
text: Stand before the monument of the world-famous Native American and wonder, along with the rest of the Dakotas: Is Sitting Bull here?

headline: Do Co-op Candidates Have to Give Notice?
text: Q Is there a law that says that someone who wants to run for office on a co-op board must give notice before the annual shareholders’ meeting? Recently, at our annual meeting, a shareholder was told she could not run because she did not tell the president before the meeting that she wanted to.

headline: Federer and Roddick
text: A pause during a football dead spot to ask this question:

headline: A Showdown on Ice
text: For two small towns in northwest Minnesota, hockey is not just a sport, it's a way of life.

headline: Put Me In, Coach
text: Choose your team colors and have a field day. Shoulder pads optional.

headline: Spyker on the Heals of Ferrari and McLaren…
text: …in the luxury car market, that is…

headline: The Sounds of Music
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Pulse
text: Digital puppetry, a new holistic canine grooming, what Manuela Testolini Nelson is wearing now and more.

headline: The Making of 'Lily'
text: A behind-the-scenes look at how a dress is made at Lanvin.

headline: The Davos View on Iraq
text: I’ve been running around the World Economic Forum here in Davos and haven’t had much of a chance to post here. Sorry about that.

headline: Tremors at the Door for Subprime Mortgage Lenders
text: The once booming market for home loans to people with weak credit – known as subprime mortgages and made largely to minorities, the poor and first-time buyers stretching to afford a home – is coming under greater pressure. The evidence can be seen in rising default rates, increasingly strained finances at mortgage lenders and growing doubts among investors. Now, Wall Street firms, which had helped fuel the growth in the market by bankrolling and investing in subprime mortgage lenders, have begun to pinch off the money spigot.

headline: EMI to Merge Record Labels
text: EMI Group, the flagging British music conglomerate, reorganized its American unit Thursday by merging the operations of its two main record labels and ousting the president of Capitol Records, the bigger of the two. The moves were the most notable so far in a worldwide revamping that started two weeks ago, when EMI, which releases music from acts including Coldplay and Norah Jones, forced out the global chief of its music division.

headline: The Name Is ‘Power’ and It Fits
text: As the Power Corporation closes in on a $3.9 billion deal with the Marsh & McLennan Companies to acquire its Putnam Investments Mutual Fund unit, The New York Times takes a look at one of Canada’s largest financial services companies and Quebec’s pre-eminent newspaper publisher.

headline: Ex-NBC Official Charged in Theft
text: Federal authorities have arrested a former treasurer of the media conglomerate NBC Universal on charges of stealing more than $800,000 to finance private jet flights, liquor and a vacation home. The former treasurer, Victor Jung, is charged in the indictment with two counts of wire fraud, according to the statement from the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. He pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in Manhattan and was released on a $250,000 bond. “He plans to vigorously defend himself against these charges,” Mr. Jung’s lawyer, Christopher Brennan, told Reuters.

headline: Icos Shareholders Approve Eli Lilly Deal
text: Shareholders of Icos approved a $2.3 billion buyout offer on Thursday from Eli Lilly, a deal that would combine the companies behind the impotence drug Cialis. The transaction is expected to close on Jan. 29. ICOS said 77 percent of the shares that were voted in a special meeting favored the takeover.

headline: The New Media World, According to Eisner
text: Former Walt Disney Chairman and Chief Executive Michael Eisner has been exercising his deal-making skills since leaving the Mouse House more than a year ago. Through his investment vehicle Tornante, which is backed by the $1 billion he pocketed during his tenure at Disney, Mr. Eisner has been trying his hand at new media. He bought Team Baby Entertainment, which makes sport-themed DVDs for children, and, most recently, purchased in a a stake in YouTube challenger Veoh Networks.

headline: Lay and Others Dropped from Enron Suit
text: A judge granted a request by former shareholders and investors suing Enron to drop several individuals and firms, including Enron’s late founder, Kenneth L. Lay, from the lawsuit. The regents of the University of California, the lead plaintiffs in securities litigation against Enron and several banks, asked for the dismissals last year. Judge Melinda Harmon of the U.S. District Court approved the request Wednesday in the class-action lawsuit.

headline: Midwest Board Urges Shareholders to Fly Alone
text: Taking a page out of Delta Air Lines management’s playbook, the board of Midwest Air Group has recommended shareholders reject a buyout offer worth $345 million by AirTran Holdings, saying that it would be better off alone. The Milwaukee-based parent of Midwest Airlines said Thursday the board unanimously recommended that shareholders reject the revised $13.25-per-share offer and not tender their shares to AirTran.

headline: On One YouTube Competitor, All Joking Aside
text: One of the gazillion online video start-ups trying to take on YouTube has apparently come up with an new angle: serious thought. Instead of humorous videos of people dancing around their living rooms in their underpants, FORA.tv offers clips from a V.I.P. dinner the night of the State of the Union address, a talk by former President Jimmy Carter on C-SPAN and a presentation on global warming by a quantum physicist, CNEt News.com says.

headline: From Davos, NYSE Chief Says Tide Will Turn on Private Equity
text: John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, offered up some sobering words Friday about the explosive rise of private equity, which has swept many publicly traded companies off of the world’s major exchanges. He said, in effect: They’ll come back to us.

headline: Time Warner Elects Motorola Chief and Its Own President to the Board
text: Motorola Chairman and Chief Executive Ed Zander and Time Warner President and Chief Operating Officer Jeffrey Bewkes have both been elected to join Time Warner’s board, the company announced Thursday. Richard Parsons, Time Warner’s board chairman and C.E.O., credits Mr. Bewkes with helping him turn around Time Warner and leading the AOL transition, while Mr. Zander brings mobile communications expertise to the table.

headline: Macquarie Buys Dallas Publisher
