text: American Consolidated Media, a Dallas-based publisher of 40 local newspapers in Texas and Oklahoma, said Thursday that it has agreed to be acquired by Australia’s Macquarie Media for $80 million. The privately held newspaper group, whose owners include founder Jeremy Halbreich, BancBoston Ventures and Halyard Capital and Arena Capital Partner, will receive either cash or stock from the buyer, a subsidiary of Macquarie Bank.

headline: Canadian Grain Company Ups Offer for Rival
text: Saskatchewan Wheat Pool added a cash component to its C$700 million ($591 million) hostile offer for Agricore United late Thursday in a move to persuade Agricore shareholders to back a proposed merger of Canada’s two biggest grain handlers. Under the new bid, Agricore shareholders may receive C$11.33 in cash or 1.3601 SaskPool shares or any combination of the two.

headline: Credit Suisse Said to Overhaul Bonus Plan
text: Credit Suisse has revamped its stock-based bonus plan in an attempt to retain staff earning more than $100,000 a year, Financial News reported. The new plan will affect more than 25 percent of the firm’s employees, mostly those working in the investment banking unit, the report said.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Kinder Buyout, on One Condition
text: Pipeline giant Kinder Morgan‘s plan to go private through a $22 billion management-led buyout cleared a major regulatory hurdle Thursday when the Federal Trade Commission gave its blessing after settling antitrust issues that the agency said could have fueled higher gasoline prices in the Southeast. The F.T.C. approved the buyout on the condition that the Carlyle Group and Riverstone Holdings, two of the investment firms participating in the deal, become passive investors in Kinder Morgan competitor Magellan Midstream Partners.

headline: Many Who Can Invest in Hedge Funds Don’t
text: There’s no question that hedge funds and private equity investments have dominated the business headlines for the last year. But, asks Fortune, does that mean that individuals are actually flocking to these high-risk, high-return funds? The, answer, says the magazine: Not as much as you might think. It cites a recent study that shows that 40 percent of millionaire investors surveyed had no allocation whatsoever in alternative investments, including private equity, hedge funds and commodities.

headline: Eddie Bauer Buyout Delayed Due to Accounting Glitches
text: Eddie Bauer said Thursday that it delayed a shareholder meeting to vote on a $286 million buyout plan after finding tax accounting errors. The errors, which cover 2005 and earlier years, relate to the determination of deferred tax assets and goodwill on its balance sheets, arising from the treatment of leasehold improvements. In November, Eddie Bauer agreed to a buyout by private-equity firms Sun Capital Partners and Golden Gate Capital for $286 million, plus the assumption of $328 million in debt.

headline: Schwab C.F.O. to Step Down
text: Discount brokerage Charles Schwab said Thursday that its chief financial officer since 1999, Christopher Dodds, will retire on May 18. Mr. Dodds, who is 47, joined the company in 1986. He will be succeeded by senior vice president and treasurer Joseph Martinetto. Forbes.com notes that Mr. Dodds is just the latest finance chief at a Wall Street firm to leave the post behind.

headline: Lazard Chief’s Stock Rises
text: Lazard awarded Chairman and Chief Executive Bruce Wasserstein $18 million in restricted shares, 80 percent more than a year earlier, after the stock rose 48 percent in 2006, according to a federal filing. Mr. Wasserstein, received 359,425 shares on Jan. 23, when the stock closed at $50.08, the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission said. He can sell half of the shares on March 31, 2010, and the other half a year later.

headline: Equity Office Bids May Go Higher, Analysts Say
text: As the biggest leveraged buyout ever got bigger Thursday when the Blackstone Group increased its bid for Equity Office Properties Trust to a whopping $54 a share, market watchers fell over themselves trying to guess if a consortium led by Vornado Realty Trust would be forced to up its bid. But even more than that, analysts and other industry watchers, who can sometimes take a been-there-done-that attitude toward bidding battles, seemed on the edge of their ringside seats, caught up in the high-stakes (and high-price) war for the nation’s largest office landlord, with nearly 600 buildings across the country.

headline: Morgan Stanley and Swedish Group Buy Healthcare Firm
text: Investor, the holding company of the Swedish billionaire Wallenberg family, teamed up with Morgan Stanley to buy Moelnlycke Health Care for 2.85 billion euros ($3.7 billion) including debt. Stockholm-based Investor and Morgan Stanley will buy the maker of surgical gloves from London-based Apax Partners. Investor said it is financing the purchase mainly with debt

headline: About Those Fears of Wall Street’s Decline …
text: What has become of the Sheriff of Wall Street? In what the New York Times’ Jenny Anderson describes as “an interesting about-face,” Eliot Spitzer, the newly-elected governor of New York, has added his voice to the growing battle cry that New York risks losing its pre-eminence if the Sarbanes-Oxley Act is not amended and litigation not curtailed. Interesting, Ms. Anderson says, because the enforcer turned laissez-faire governor was not long ago a prosecutor blazing through Wall Street’s boardrooms and ridiculing regulators for not cracking down enough.

headline: Anchor’s Ties to Citigroup Attract Scrutiny
text: The connection between the ouster of Todd S. Thomson, long viewed as a possible future chief executive of Citigroup, and his relationship with Maria Bartiromo, the popular CNBC anchor, has been the talk of the financial services community since the banking giant announced this week that Mr. Thomson would be leaving the company. Much ink has been spilled on reports of Citigroup executives being pushed off overseas flights on the corporate jet so that Mr. Thomson could fly alone with Ms. Bartiromo, expensive dinners at Daniel and other juicy tidbits.

headline: Delta Creditors May Ask US Airways to Extend Deadline
text: Delta Air Lines‘s creditors may ask US Airways Group to extend the Feb. 1 deadline on its hostile takeover bid as they study competing plans for the bankrupt carrier’s future, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources. The nine-member unsecured creditors committee is split between those favoring a quicker payback of their claims through a US Airways merger and those benefiting more if Delta stays independent, the unnamed sources said. An extension would give the creditors panel more time to debate US Airways’ merger plan as well as Atlanta-based Delta’s bid to leave bankruptcy as a stand-alone airline by mid-2007. Kelly Sullivan, a spokeswoman for US Air, said that the committee has not asked for an extension of the deadline.

headline: Industrial Bank Wins Record I.P.O. Subscriptions
text: Industrial Bank, a midsize Chinese lender, attracted a record 1.16 trillion yuan ($150 billion) in subscriptions to its Shanghai initial public offering, reflecting the current mania for Chinese stocks.

headline: Nasdaq Will Not Raise L.S.E. Offer
text: Nasdaq said it will not raise its 2.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion) offer for London Stock Exchange, as the clock runs down on the bid. The U.S. stock market said Friday that the L.S.E. has not responded to its offer, and now “there is now insufficient time to effect any revision of the final offers via constructive dialogue.” Nasdaq had previously said it would only consider raising the bid if the British market’s board recommended the offer by Jan. 27. But the L.S.E. has repeated rejected the offer as inadequate.

headline: KB Home Says It Faces S.E.C. Options Inquiry
text: KB Home said Friday that the Securities and Exchange Commission has launched a formal investigation into how it granted stock options to employees. The homebuilder’s chief executive, Bruce Karatz, stepped down in November after it was disclosed that he received favorably dated option awards.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Second Life, W.T.O. Talks, C.E.O. Pay
text: Virtual world Second Life is a hot topic at the World Economic Forum this year, according to The Independent. Indeed, even the forum’s founder and chairman, Klaus Schwab, has his own avatar, or virtual identity, and Reuters is conducting interviews with major players at Davos at its virtual bureau in the Second Life realm.

headline: The War at Home: Modes of Objection
text: President Bush is meeting with House Republicans today in Cambridge, Md., at their annual retreat. White House officials said he would cover a broad range of issues, but he also is expected to try to garner broader support for his troop-increase plan for Iraq. (Meanwhile, CNN is reporting this morning that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is leading a delegation on a trip to Iraq.)

headline: Filmfest in Room 777 Brought to You by an IBM Laptop
text: You don’t have to be in Sundance these days to enjoy a moody, serio-comic film school short. Now if the Bagger can just get some popcorn from room service, he’ll be all set.

headline: Davos Diary
text: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin offers an overview of Day 2 at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: This  American Television Show
text: indieWIRE brings us news from off the movie grid, but still very much worth knowing. Showtime will be bringing “This American Life,” the home of the best stories on radio, to a television screen near you.

headline: Davos Tries Fewer Stars
text: There has been some grumbling on the ground here at Davos about this year’s celebrity-free (or nearly so) approach. “The no-celebrity thing was a big mistake,” one of the world’s largest financiers, who asked for anonymity, told The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin at a party sponsored by Forbes. “The celebs added a sense of energy and spice to the forum.”

headline: The Best Sundance Ever
text: French director Luc Bresson, he of “La Femme Nikita,” brought “Angel-A,” his new film, to Sundance and called it “a very pleasant experience.”

headline: Posting the Mortem
text: All of the crows are coming off the wire, caw-cawing about how the parade float that was “Dreamgirls” wound up in a muddy ditch. No one really knows why it didn’t get nominated for best picture, but it may be some consolation to its backers that they saved the $10 million or so they would have spent flogging the film for an award that, it’s now clear, it wouldn’t have won, even if it had snuck in as the fifth nominee.

headline: Smoke, Mirrors & the Size of Women
text: Spain will, for the first time, be standardizing its clothing for women. Seems until now, it was something of a crapshoot when shopping for a blouse in, say, Barcelona — where as BBC News points out today, a European size 40 in one shop (roughly a size 10 in the United States) could mean something completely different in another.

headline: Where it All Began
text: Defamer points us to The Smoking Gun, which has uploaded, from a copy of the script, the scene from “Hounddog” that kicked up all the fuss.

headline: Inside the Burning Crusade
2008 Like It’s Today: Race and the Race
text: Don’t limit your presidential campaign because of race, Harold Ford Jr. advised Senator Barack Obama. Some speculate that race contributed to Mr. Ford’s defeat in the Tennessee Senate election. Mr. Obama told The Chicago Tribune that he’s not sweating race, when it comes to wooing the black vote.

headline: Five Not-So-Easy Pieces
text: Without “Dreamgirls,” the little juggernaut that couldn’t, Oscar Ninnies have been staring at the revised Final Five: “Babel,” “The Departed,” “Little Miss Sunshine,” “The Queen” and “Letters From Iwo Jima.” Which one will win for best picture?

headline: Outsourcing the War
text: Too many private contractors in Iraq; What Andrew Jackson didn’t say; Want to help the poor? Forget minimum wage.

headline: Bush’s Disastrous Omission
text: Do you know what it means to miss New Orleans? President Bush does, after omitting the subject of the Crescent City’s post-Katrina catastrophe entirely in his State of the Union address. “Congress and the nation heard nothing, zilch, nada, not a single, solitary word about New Orleans, the Gulf Coast and the devastation that remains from the worst natural disaster in United States history,” writes Washington Post columnist Eugene Robinson. “A disaster that happened on his watch.” Robinson continues:

headline: Marsh Chief May Withdraw Putnam from Sale
text: Marsh & McLennan‘s chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, might yet throw a wrench into the insurance brokerage giant’s plans to sell its Putnam Investments unit. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Cherkasky said that he is keeping all options on the table — even backing away from selling the unit to Canada’s Power Corporation. Mr. Cherkasky told Reuters: “It is always complicated. It is a terrific company. … At the same time, if someone had the structure of a deal and the certainty for our shareholders, we would be interested. It is about weighing a number of factors.” Several analysts said they see an effort by Marsh to negotiate better terms from Power; specifics of that deal have not been publicly disclosed.

headline: France’s Lyonnais to Kick Off I.P.O.
text: France’s top soccer club, Olympique Lyonnais, plans to raise up to 103 million euros ($132.9 million) through the country’s first soccer-based I.P.O. soon, the Financial Times reported Friday. The Lyons-based club said that it hopes to sell up to 4.24 million new shares at 21 euros to 24.40 euros apiece. At the top end of the range, the I.P.O, would value parent company OL Group at 331 million euros, the paper said. The company’s two top shareholders, Chief Executive Jean-Michel Aulas and the French movie company Pathé, will retain control of the team.

headline: Court Dismisses Claims of Additional Spying by H.P.
text: A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard by a former executive who claimed the computer maker obtained his phone records illegally. H.P. has accused Karl Lamb of stealing trade secrets to start up his own flat-panel display company. Mr. Lamb’s lawsuit briefly re-raised the specter of pretexting, or the obtaining of personal information under false pretenses. Former H.P. executives, including ex-chairwoman Patricia C. Dunn, still faces charges that they authorized private investigators to pretext board members and reporters in the course of a leak investigation.

headline: NYSE Chief Says Tide Will Turn on Private Equity
text: John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, offered up some sobering words Friday about the explosive rise of private equity, which has swept many publicly traded companies off of the world’s major exchanges. He said, in effect: They’ll come back to us.

headline: The Pushback
text: Assemblyman — and passed-over comptroller candidate — Joseph D. Morelle was up on Fred Dicker’s radio show this morning, and between what he’s saying, and what various members told us last night, you can get a pretty good sense of the Assembly’s talking points about yesterday’s selection of three finalists for the comptroller’s job, none of them state lawmakers.

headline: The Web Cuts Both Ways
text: The expanding reach of the Internet has allowed communities such as MySpace to flourish, but it has also created a global platform for extremists and terrorists to spread their views. That was one of the themes to emerge from a Friday session called “Who Will Shape the Agenda?”, whose panelists included media magnate Rupert Murdoch and Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein.

headline: Gremlins Crack Copy Protections … Again
text: Demonstrating once again that even the best anti-copying schemes can succumb to the ravages of dedicated scofflaws who don’t quite subscribe to the same philosophy regarding intellectual property as, say, the movie and recording industries, a renegade programmer going by the name muslix64 has figured out a way to bypass the encryption on high-definition DVD’s and on another type of high-density optical media disc, known as Blu-ray.

headline: More From Vanguard Chief John Brennan
text: In October, investments in mutual funds passed the $10 trillion mark, according to the Investment Company Institute. The mutual fund company, Vanguard in Valley Forge, Pa, has more than $1.1 trillion of that amount under management.

headline: Bush on Congress and Anti-Surge Moves
text: In a brief Q & A at the White House this morning, President Bush thanked the Senate for unanimously confirming Army Lt. Gen. David Petraeus as his new commander of United States forces in Iraq.

headline: Spinning Google and YouTube Into Gold
text: Riding two of the Internet’s big success stories, Google and YouTube, venture capitalist Michael Moritz of Sequoia Capital took the No. 1 spot on Forbes’s latest Midas List, an annual ranking of the top 100 dealmakers in technology and the life sciences.

headline: Concerns Over Ethics Reform
text: Albany Wonk Watch!

headline: Real Technology, Dismal Movie
text: I saw the Harrison Ford movie “Firewall” in a hotel room the other day. The moviegoing public at IMDB.com (Internet Movie Database, the Internet’s headquarters for movie ratings) gave it an average rating of only 5.8 out of 10, which is shockingly low for IMDB. “Ford has a loooooooooooong, boring resume of playing dull bourgeois men who are attempting to find their misplaced wives or prove they didn’t kill someone; ‘Presumed Innocent,’ ‘Frantic,’ ‘The Fugitive,’ this,” writes one commenter.

headline: As Housing Slumps, Deal Talk Builds
text: Consolidation may be coming among publicly traded homebuilders as the housing market continues to sink, according to an article in BusinessWeek. As if to reinforce the point, the Commerce Department on Friday reported that sales of new homes last year fell by the largest amount in 16 years, though sales rose by a better-than-expected 4.8 percent in December.

headline: War at Home: Hoyer’s Turn to Talk
text: This is probably going to be a fairly heavy weekend of anti-war speeches and protests, with more than the usual pundits weighing in. With President Bush promoting his way forward, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi touching down in Baghdad, and several 2008 potential contenders on the road, the war of words is heating up.

headline: Show Us Your Carbon
text: Chief executives at Davos are ballyhooing the time and resources they devote to fighting climate change. But investors at the World Economic Forum say they want to see more evidence that these titans of industry will be able to turn a profit in a warmer — and more heavily regulated — world.

headline: The Other Breakfast of Champions — Now Even Easier
text: Whether necessity truly gave birth to this invention is an open question, but at least one molecular scientist in Durham, N.C., apparently felt the traditional coffee-and-a-doughnut breakfast was just too much of a time-suck.

headline: F1 on About.com – and Yours Truly
text: I wanted to let you know that as of today, a project that I have been working on for the past couple of months went live on the web: I have become the Formula 1 Guide at About.com. I think the two sites fit nicely together: In addition to this anything-goes F1 blog, the IHT web site runs my stories that appear in the newspaper. The About.com F1 space is also a reference site with links to information and above all, original content written by me, the Guide, specifically for that site. It has several other features as well, including a blog and a forum, so if you don’t see something here, you may see it there – and vice versa. Actually, the best way to understand it, is to go and check it out at http://formula1.about.com – so I’ll stop talking about it here!

headline: After the Gold Rush
text: The last time the Bagger saw his colleague Manohla Dargis at Sundance, she was speed walking to what was probably her fourth film of the day. (A Sundance vet, she ignores the transport system, which zips along with all the speed of a dark examination of the human soul by a first-time filmmaker.) Today, she teases apart the good, the bad and the downright ugly, and finds a few that were worth the walk. Oh yeah, and an empty box.

headline: How Our Kids Spent Our Winter Vacation
text: Alison and I thought we were renting a house in the tiny town of Anna Maria, Fla., to have a chance to relax, soak up some sun on a deserted beach, and read a few novels.Silly us.

headline: Can Tech and Private Equity Make a Happy Couple?
text: The recent increase in private-equity deals in the technology sector raises what the Red Herring calls a “fundamental question”: Is private equity “good for an industry in which research and development, capital investment, and recruiting and retaining top talent are critical elements for long-term success?” It sounds like begging the question. Private equity players — “rightly or wrongly,” the Herring says — have a reputation for working against all those elements in one way or another, at least in the way they normally operate (piling on debt, slashing costs and taking a big payday for themselves upon their quick-as-possible exit).

headline: Perella Lures 2 Morgan Stanley Bankers, Report Says
text: In potentially another coup for Joe Perella, his boutique investment bank has snatched two high-level bankers from his old stomping grounds at Morgan Stanley, Reuters reported Friday. The newswire said that Perella Weinberg Partners had poached Scott Bruckner, who was co-head of the European technology group, and Arnaud Dassy, an executive director on the telecom team. Mr. Bruckner was to have transferred to New York from London to take the helm of the East Coast technology team.

headline: It’s My Party …
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 26 column, “On Being Partisan.”

headline: Getting Off the Ground
text: As part of the U.S. effort to make the Iraqi military independent, American advisors are working with veteran Iraqi helicopter pilots.

headline: Taking the Lame Duck to Task on Energy
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 26 column, “Running on Empty”.

headline: Shandling Spars With Baldwin
text: An excerpt from "Not Just the Best of the Larry Sanders Show," featuring a sparring scene between Garry Shandling and Alec Baldwin.

headline: Credit Check
text: There’s big news in the little world of Oscarville. The producers’ wing of the Academy Awards had some nasty math to work through last night, and the Bagger just got an e-mail from the Academy announcing that it will credit only one person as the producer of “The Departed,” while “little Miss Sunchine” will have three.

headline: Nasdaq Extends Deadline for L.S.E. Bid
text: In what is its really, truly, final offer, Nasdaq said Friday that it would extend its deadline for London Stock Exchange shareholders to accept its 2.7 billion pound ($5.3 billion) merger offer. That bid will now expire Feb. 10, pushed back from Feb. 1. Earlier Friday, the U.S. exchange said that it would not raise the price it was offering for its British counterpart. Now, Nasdaq cannot raise its offer unless the L.S.E. agrees, or if it comes in response to another party. The U.S. exchange already owns almost 30 percent of the L.S.E.; but under British law, if this deal fails it must wait six months before it can bid again.

headline: A Polite Protestor (Virtually) Barges In
text: Demonstrators are usually kept far from the action at the World Economic Forum in Davos, where security measures include barricades and barbed wire.

headline: Spitzer: Choose From the Three
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, cornered for a moment in the capitol’s cafeteria, has this to say about the comptroller process:

headline: Midnight on the Rue Cambon
text: I leave the Valentino show (dreamy white dresses in Robert Ryman textures) and go with my driver, Bernard Alloux, to Chanel. It is cold, nearly 10 p.m., and the lights in the house are ablaze. Two models are ahead of me at the door. Karl Lagerfeld is still doing fittings, and the show is in 24 hours. For once I am glad Lagerfeld is running late. The studio won’t be as crowded with editors. Andre Leon Talley and Michael Roberts, of Vanity Fair, will be there. But everyone else will be at Giancarlo Giammetti’s buffet dinner for Valentino, or tucked into their beds at the Ritz.

headline: In the Living Room
text: Dries van Noten has opened a new boutique, at 7 Quai Malaquais, and apart from a few meals, I can’t think of a better reason to come to Paris. The place is gorgeous, so unlike a store — with one room done as a kind of salon and another as a library, and without any pretense — that I think executives at LVMH across the Seine should pay attention.

headline: Armani at the Moderne
text: Giorgio Armani’s Privé show, at the city’s modern art museum, starts almost an hour late, and probably that’s because he has invited 600 people and arranged to have Katie Holmes and Cate Blanchett in his front row. The collection was inspired by India, with jewels and scimitars worked into the Italian silks, and everyone says it is Armani’s best. Afterward, there is a dinner. Armani has placed himself between Holmes (in a sari-like green dress) and Blanchett (glamorous in a tight-fitting black suit, her hair in a flip). An English editor whispers that Armani will be dressing Blanchett for the Oscars. “She had her fitting this afternoon,” the editor says and rushes off.

headline: Friends and Foreigners
text: Alber Elbaz, the Israeli-born, American-trained designer at Lanvin, received the Légion d’Honneur today in a small ceremony at the Ministry of Culture. After the red ribbon was pinned on Elbaz’s chest, he said he no longer knew where he belonged — not in Israel, not in America, and, he admitted with a smile, he had doubts about France. He then offered that he belonged to the world of women. Yet, wherever Elbaz has gone in his career he has had the support of two men: Ralph Toledano, the Chloé chief executive, who hired him years ago at Guy Laroche; and Pierre Bergé, who put him at Yves Saint Laurent. They attend his Lanvin shows, and they were in the crowd today.

headline: Google Guys Aren’t Writing Off Old Media
text: The sight of Larry Page and Sergey Brin is enough to strike fear into a newspaper editor’s heart. After all, the giant Internet company they founded, Google, has become a powerful force for democratizing the distribution of news, blogs and other forms of information, a trend that has left many in the industry bracing for the day when the print newspaper is dead.

headline: Spitzer on Health: Let’s Save ‘Billions’
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer delivered a healthcare policy address today ahead of his executive budget—which comes out Wednesday—calling for an overhaul that would “save taxpayers billions of dollars.”

headline: Where’s the Decider?
text: Goodbye, decider. Hello, decision-maker.

headline: Memorial for Disabled Vets
text: Gary Sinise, the actor/musician known widely for his iconic role as Lt. Dan Taylor in “Forrest Gump,” was in Washington today to celebrate the planned construction of a new memorial that would recognize 3 million disabled military veterans.

headline: BofA and Countrywide Said to Discuss Alliance
text: Bank of America and Countrywide Financial have held discussions about an “alliance” that could eventually lead to an acquisition of Countrywide by Bank of America, The Financial Times reported Friday afternoon, citing unnamed sources. Such a deal would create the biggest mortgage lending group in the United States, joining Bank of America’s size and Countrywide’s significant lending business. Analysts said a Countrywide buyout could cost BofA about $30 billion.

headline: Pentagon Debuts a Non-Lethal Ray Gun
text: The Defense Department has, for more than a decade, been quietly working on a non-lethal crowd dispersal weapon that is best understood in comic book terms: yes, it is, in form and function, a heat ray, and apparently it works pretty darn well — that is, if making people feel momentarily like they’re on fire, so they’ll skedaddle, is the objective.

headline: Pataki: If Iraqis Stand Up, Then We’ll Stand Up
text: New York’s former governor staked out his own space in the middle of the Iraq debate today.

headline: Cerberus May Pull Out of Delphi Deal, Report Says
text: Facing heat from the United Auto Workers over proposed pay cuts, hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management may withdraw a planned $3.4 billion investment in Delphi, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Cerberus, which agreed last month to lead an investment in the bankrupt auto parts maker, has been wrangling with the U.A.W. since then. If discussion stall, Delphi can ask a bankruptcy judge to void the union’s contract, potentially leading to a strike that would cripple Delphi’s biggest customer, General Motors.

headline: Movie Pitches From Sundance
text: The Carpetbagger solicits movie pitches at the Sundance Film Festival and tries to 'hit the slopes' before leaving town.

headline: A Hedge Fund By Any Other Name…
text: Fairly or not, hedge funds have a bit of a reputation problem in some circles. They are often used as cultural shorthand for fast, risky money. Just this week, German Chancellor Angela Merkel referred to hedge funds a “headache” in a speech to the World Economic Forum in Davos.

headline: HOWJADOTHAT?
text: From time to time on this blog, I’d like to show you how something is done, in the hopes of better explaining the creative process. Not long ago in New York, over lunch with the now-pinned Alber Elbaz, we got to talking about the trouble with futurism. At the spring 07 shows in Milan and Paris, futurism was suddenly the buzz word. But, as Elbaz pointed out, tomorrow is actually a difficult place to reach.

headline: Blogtalk: A General Approval
text: As several states consider the merits of moving up their presidential primaries, as candidates declare themselves viable a year and 10 months before Election Day and voters wade through a historic field of potential presidents, blogs have no shortage of topics to ponder and insights to provide. And then of course there’s Iraq.

headline: Vows: Amanda and Duncan
text: Amanda Boyd found out that Duncan Yin was thinking about proposing to her when he was over an hour late to pick her up from the train station.

headline: Davos Diary
text: Follow The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Giuliani, in New Hampshire, Discusses Iraq, but…
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, ardent supporter of President Bush, the Iraq war and the president’s recent decision to send more troops to Baghdad, may have opened just a sliver of daylight between himself and the president tonight, in his first New Hampshire appearance since the November election. At the very least, he showed something less than the absolute confidence about the increase in troop strength that emanates from the White House, referring repeatedly to the prospect that more soldiers will not lead to success.

headline: Suicide Bomb Erases a Fading Vestige of Joy in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 26  There used to be two great joys on Fridays for Iraqis in Baghdad: browsing the ancient bookshops, and exploring the Ghazil animal market, home to an extraordinary array of creatures.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture in some copies on Sunday about a 10-alarm fire that gutted a block of buildings in Elizabeth, N.J., carried an erroneous credit. It was by Aaron Houston for The New York Times, not Colin Archer of The Associated Press.

headline: In Game of Risk and Reward, Tour Rookie Is a Good Bet
text: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 26 — In two days at the Buick Invitational, Brandt Snedeker has become a favorite of the grandparents and the gamblers.

headline: Taking Another Global Step, Minaya Leads Group to Ghana
text: On a continent teeming with untapped potential, on a sandy field that doubles as a soccer pitch, a cadre of baseball officials and former players hope to discover the next breeding ground for major league talent. But first, they have to teach its children how to play.

headline: A Fund Giant Not Fretting About No. 1
text: In October, investments in mutual funds passed the $10 trillion mark, according to the Investment Company Institute. The mutual fund company Vanguard, based in Valley Forge, Pa, has more than $1.1 trillion of that amount under management. Last year, Congress passed the Pension Protection Act, which aims to encourage savings for education and retirement. For instance, the tax benefits for 529 plans, due to expire in 2010, are now permanent, as are the recent increases for yearly individual retirement account and 401(k) contributions.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the death of a shipyard worker at the Brooklyn Navy Yard misstated the given name of a spokesman for the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration who said the accident was being investigated. He is John Chavez, not Juan.

headline: Carlos Lezama, 83, Dies; Shaped West Indian Parade
text: Carlos Lezama, who as president of the West Indian American Day Carnival Association transformed a Brooklyn block party into the city’s largest parade, with millions of spectators lining two miles of Eastern Parkway each Labor Day to enjoy throbbing steel-pan bands, ostrich-plumed dancers and fantastical floats, died on Monday. He was 83.

headline: Episcopal Leader Taking Over Newark’s Flock
text: NEWARK, Jan. 26 — When the Rev. Mark Beckwith becomes the 10th bishop to lead the Episcopal Diocese of Newark on Saturday, parts of the service will be read in English, Spanish, French, Korean and Malayalam, an Indian language, to reflect the tongues spoken by the diocese’s 27,600 parishioners.

headline: Daffy Does Doom
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Trying to Keep Divinity ...
text: Depending on the day at her Methodist seminary, Jennifer Wilsford wants to be either a parish minister or a professor. Her seminary, for its part, has tweaked its curriculum, brings in speakers and tries to hold her hand through the logistics of ordination  all designed to nudge Ms. Wilsford and other seminarians toward the pulpit.

headline: NATO Allies Wary of Sending More Troops to Afghanistan
text: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26 — America’s European allies on Friday remained noncommittal about sending additional troops to Afghanistan, even as the Bush administration sought to inject new energy into the NATO mission against the Taliban by offering more American soldiers and money.

headline: ‘Hate Crime’ of Beatings Divides a Campus
text: GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 26  In this business-minded Southern city that looks more like a sprawling suburb, Guilford College stands out like a hippie commune, a Quaker liberal arts school where students call professors by their first names and regularly stage antiwar protests.

headline: Tennessee: Man Killed in Building Collapse
text: One construction worker was killed and another injured when a one-story brick building collapsed in Nashville, the police said. The workers  Richard Whiteshield, 57, of Clewiston, Fla., who was killed, and John Kemper of Hendersonville, Tenn., who was injured  were part of a crew that was using a jackhammer to dig up a gas main to the building, which was being demolished, said Kristin Mumford, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Police Department. The building, in the city’s Berry Hill neighborhood, had been closed for some time, said Kim Lawson, the deputy fire chief.

headline: Deadly Suicide Bomber Attack at Hotel in Pakistan’s Capital
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 26  A suicide bomber blew himself up outside a Marriott hotel here on Friday afternoon, killing himself and a security guard, the police and security officials said. At least five other people were wounded.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Jan. 9 about Momofuku Ando, the founder of the Nissin Food Products Company and the inventor of instant ramen, misstated his national origin. He was born in Taiwan during the Japanese occupation of Taiwan to Taiwanese  not Japanese  parents; he became a Japanese citizen after World War II.

headline: Eye Drug Might Raise Risk of Stroke, Genentech Says
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26  Use of Genentech’s new eye drug, Lucentis, might raise the risk of stroke, the company said Friday.

headline: If Beauty Is Only Skin Deep, Look Really, Really Hard
text: Rhinos don’t enjoy the household privileges of dinos and hippos. They make no claims of cuteness. They don’t smile broadly on mugs, T-shirts and the bedsheets of toddlers; they don’t pervade the work of Sandra Boynton. Surely it can’t be that rhinos are the scariest of the three: nearly all of those big beasts can get ugly, and none would make good pets.

headline: Feeling Healthy and Ready, Webb Takes Aim at the Mile
text: In 2001, Alan Webb broke the high school indoor and outdoor records for the mile and became the first prep runner to run a sub-four-minute mile indoors. Then came six years of occasional fast times interrupted by too few good races and too many injuries and illnesses.

headline: Judge Puts Settlement on Katrina in Question
text: A federal judge in Mississippi, citing the need for more information, has rejected  at least temporarily  a settlement by State Farm Insurance that was expected to provide several hundred million dollars to help policyholders rebuild homes destroyed by Hurricane Katrina 17 months ago.

headline: Sights Set on Title, Meissner Is All Smiles
text: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 26 — Watching Kimmie Meissner practice her long program Friday afternoon, it was impossible to tell that she was less than a day from the finale of the United States Figure Skating Championships. She glided through her program, fell trying a few jumps, but picked herself up and skated back to her coach with a smile.

headline: One NATO Is Not Enough
text: Carlisle, Pa.

headline: Reserved Seats, and Tone, as a New Defense Chief Meets the Press
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates held his first Pentagon press conference on Friday, and it was nothing like those of his predecessor, Donald H. Rumsfeld.

headline: Nasdaq Holds Firm on a Bid for London Stock Exchange
text: LONDON, Jan. 26  Nasdaq said on Friday that it did not plan to raise its offer for the London Stock Exchange, just before a deadline to do so, damping investors’ expectations. Investors have until Feb. 10 to tender their shares for a deal, but any changes in the bid would have to happen this weekend unless a rival bidder emerges.

headline: Five Arrested in New Jersey in Illegal Sales of Painkillers
text: TRENTON, Jan. 26  Five people have been arrested on charges that they ran a drug ring that had sold more than $20 million worth of painkillers, or one million pills, law enforcement officials in New Jersey announced on Friday.

headline: A Rocker Who’s Come to Terms With Time
text: Bob Seger is 61, with gray hair and glasses. But he still goes to work in a T-shirt and bluejeans.

headline: BMW Reports Record Sales; Porsche Posts Revenue Drop
text: BERLIN, Jan. 26 (Bloomberg News)  BMW, the German carmaker, posted record sales last year with new versions of the 3 Series car and X3 sport utility vehicle. Revenue at a German rival, Porsche, dropped for the first time in 14 years as demand for the Cayenne sport utility vehicle slumped.

headline: The Dangers of Swinging for the Fences
text: There was once a pharmaceutical company that could do no wrong. It had the best-selling drug in the world. It saturated the airwaves with its ads, and swarmed doctors’ offices with its army of good-looking sales representatives. It had mastered the art of turning drugs into blockbusters. It made many billions in profits. Wall Street analysts loved it.

headline: Pakistan and the Taliban (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Your Toes, Blokes, 2 Highnesses Coming — Charles and Camilla
text: It has been just over a year since their Wellington boots last sloshed about on these shores, and it’s not as though that trip — billed as their first official overseas tour since being married in April 2005 — came off so smashingly that they, or an adoring American public, ought to be crying out for another.

headline: Not Much Market for Worry Beads in the Executive Suites
text: To chief executives, the threat of global warming seems very real in Asia, but not in the United States or Russia.

headline: At Rice, a Scorer’s Patience Is Starting to Pay Off
text: HOUSTON, Jan. 26 — When Morris Almond chose to attend Rice four years ago over such traditional basketball powers as Indiana, Notre Dame and Virginia, everyone seemed to have the same quip.

headline: Change Comes, Gradually, to the San Francisco Opera
text: Significant changes are happening in America’s opera landscape as new directors take over some of the country’s major companies. But in a field in which artists are booked several years in advance, it takes a while for season programs to reflect those changes.

headline: Riding Perseverance to Finals in Australia
text: For Asha Price, watching from afar as her youngest sister made a remarkable run at the Australian Open has been a nerve-racking, eye-opening experience.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Weekend on Jan. 19 about the film “Waitress,” which was shown at the Sundance Film Festival, misidentified the role played in “Mission: Impossible III” by Keri Russell, the star of “Waitress.” She was a protégée of Tom Cruise’s character, not his love interest. (That role was played by Michelle Monaghan.)

headline: A Saxophonist Known for New Ideas Meets an Organist From the Old School
text: The saxophonist Greg Osby is one of the most specific writers and arrangers in jazz. He makes small-group music that can be aslant with odd or long meter, and serenely played; it’s not battering or superexpressive, but glows within its own tight structure. Always, he comes with a grid.

headline: Relatives of Dorm Fire Victims Lash Out
text: NEWARK, Jan. 26  Anger, at once therapeutic and corrosive, along with memories still tender and painful were in the air of a crowded courtroom on Friday.

headline: Williams Shocks Sharapova to Win in Australia
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 27 — It has been two weeks of turning back the clock for Serena Williams, and under a closed roof during Saturday’s Australian Open women’s final, she completed her astoundingly quick trip back to dominance against the top-seeded Maria Sharapova.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A map last Saturday showing parishes affected by the reorganization plans of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misidentified a Bronx parish scheduled for closing. It is St. Anthony’s at 4505 Richardson Avenue, in the northern part of the borough — not St. Anthony’s at 1496 Commonwealth Avenue, in the central Bronx. A corrected version of the map can be found at www.nytimes.com/2007/01/20/nyregion/20churches.html.

headline: What Can Money Buy?
text: SEVERAL news reports, all relying on anonymous sources, have suggested that the Federal Communications Commission will soon announce a settlement with four major radio broadcasters over payola.

headline: Curfew Is Lifted in Beirut, but Tension Lingers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26  Lebanese Army soldiers reinforced checkpoints and maintained a heavy presence in tense neighborhoods in Beirut on Friday, lifting a rare nighttime curfew that had been imposed to stop the worsening violence between pro- and antigovernment crowds.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart yesterday with an article about declining union membership gave outdated information on the states with the highest and lowest membership in 2006. The top states were Hawaii (24.7%), New York (24.4%), Alaska (22.2%), New Jersey (20.1%) and Washington (19.8%); the bottom states were Texas (4.9%), Georgia (4.4%), Virginia (4.0%), and North and South Carolina (both with 3.3%). The chart listed the 2005 rankings. (As the article noted correctly, the national average is 12 percent, based on 2006 figures.) (Go to Article)

headline: An Open Job Opens a Rift in Albany
text: ALBANY, Jan. 26 — It took less than a month for Gov. Eliot Spitzer to find himself on the precipice of an all-out political war with the man he replaced as the top Democrat in New York State government, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

headline: Operetta and Weill in Front; Moving Shadows in Back
text: A silhouette of old lace blows across a screen above the stage, tangling with the shadows of the performers singing below. Then the shadows free themselves of the singers and begin to dance, as if giving life to the dreams in the music.

headline: A Breadwinner Rethinks Gender Roles
text: WHEN my son was born last fall, my husband and I had a plan. After a short maternity leave, I would continue to work, and he would quit his job to take care of the baby.

headline: At Lawmakers’ Retreat, G.O.P. Plots a Comeback
text: CAMBRIDGE, Md., Jan. 26 — President Bush tried to rally House Republicans on Friday as the lawmakers hunkered down on the Eastern Shore and struggled to come to grips with their new minority status and the challenge of the continuing war in Iraq.

headline: A New Wave Now Knits for the Rebellion of It
text: In 2000 the GetCrafty.com Web site offered a pattern for a crocheted skull (not for the faint of heart, or needle), recasting traditional “women’s work” for the post-riotgrrrl era. That same year groups of women and the occasional sensitive guy began gathering on Sundays to swap ideas and patterns in an organization called the Church of Craft.

headline: At Ease, Mr. President
text: Evanston, Ill.

headline: Illegal Sublets Put Private Eyes on the Case
text: The house was one of those stucco numbers that grow in the suburbs like crab grass. The woman in question was a cagey brunette suspected of chiseling her landlord. She had a rent-regulated apartment in Manhattan that she seemed to be subletting illegally for twice what she was paying, while sleeping in the stucco house just outside the city.

headline: Tokyo Cuts Aid, and Hinterland Withers in Japan
text: YUBARI, Japan  Buried in chest-deep snow, History Village sprawled across a valley here, undisturbed by the tourists it was supposed to attract.

headline: In Fighting Disorder, Family Stays Vigilant
text: Norma Turner, 14, is her mother’s daughter. Her mother, Kareen Brown, held a recent portrait of the two of them, which showed their striking resemblance. The same eyes, same face, same tendrils of hair, the same happiness shines out of the picture.

headline: Touching a Nerve: Carter at Brandeis (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s on Monday Night
text: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) NORA ROBERTS’ ANGELS FALL Heather Locklear plays Reece Gilmore, the sole survivor of a Boston restaurant massacre, who moves to a remote Wyoming town in the hope of rebuilding her life in this adaptation of a novel by Ms. Roberts. But one day, while hiking alone, she witnesses a murder — though no one can find evidence of a crime when they return to the scene. As more strange events start to occur, Reece begins to question her sanity. Now only Brody (Johnathon Schaech), her new love, believes in her.

headline: Chemical Security: How the Industry Sees It (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Black Teenagers Convicted in Beating of 3 White Women
text: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 26 — A juvenile court judge found nine black teenagers guilty Friday of beating three young white women with pumpkins, newspapers and a skateboard last Halloween in an attack that has shined a spotlight on racial tensions here.

headline: Yes, She Has a Sweet Tooth, but She’s a Major Carnivore
text: Interspecies mating is always a challenge, particularly when one species likes to eat the other. In the lupine love triangle “Blood & Chocolate,” a reluctant Romanian werewolf named Vivian (Agnes Bruckner) spends her days making chocolates in a Bucharest candy store. If her customers could see how she celebrates the full moon, they would think twice before letting her handle their macaroons.

headline: Bush Defends Moving Against Iranians Who Help Shiites Attack U.S.-Led Forces in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 — President Bush and his senior aides on Friday justified American actions against Iranian operatives inside Iraq as necessary to protect American troops and Iraqis, and said they would continue as long as Tehran kept up what they called its support for Shiites involved in sectarian attacks.

headline: Adrenaline on Display at Sports Convention
text: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 26 — Wandering the teeming halls of the San Diego Convention Center on Friday afternoon, the former professional surfer Peter King said of the goings-on at an action sports trade show, “I’d say it’s a lot more fun than a Dell computer convention.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about the Juilliard School’s Focus Festival misstated the surname of the festival’s longtime director. He is Joel Sachs, not Cohen.

headline: Turning 60, and Doing So With 1,500
text: Not every Wall Street titan can celebrate his birthday in a place that holds 1,500 people. Unless, of course, that titan is Stephen A. Schwarzman, who is on the verge of clinching the biggest buyout deal ever.

headline: In Battle to Bring in Catch, an Imaginative Angler Learns to Win by a Neck
text: Casting a fly properly is among the most beautiful movements in all of sport. Landing a hooked fish, on the other hand, has all the elegance of attempting a limbo dance on a roller coaster. Having a friend or guide net your fish is often the more practical approach.

headline: Mexico’s Latest War on Drug Gangs Is Off to a Rapid Start
text: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25  If any image can sum up President Felipe Calderón’s first eight weeks in office, it would be the sight of him dressed in military fatigues addressing troops he had sent into the state of Michoacán to corral narcotics traffickers.

headline: In New Batch of 9/11 Calls, Confusion and Courage
text: The city yesterday released 19 recordings of telephone calls made to 911 operators from the World Trade Center on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: At Churches Set to Close, Faithful Dig In for Battle
text: A week after the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York released its final list of 21 parishes to be closed as part of a broad reorganization, some parishioners are digging in for a battle, enlisting help from parishioners in the Boston Archdiocese who successfully resisted some church closings there with round-the-clock sit-ins.

headline: Driving the Precious Little Darlings (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Official Proposes ‘Drafting’ Poll Workers to Ease Problems
text: CINCINNATI, Jan. 26 — The chronic shortage of election workers in Ohio could be solved by requiring residents to work at the polls the way they fulfill jury duty, the newly elected secretary of state says.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: In Last Three Games, Nets Are Missing the Point
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 — The Nets’ margin of error over the past three games can essentially be measured in three possessions and 3 points. The resulting burden has manifested itself in blank stares, mumbled answers and an unusually quiet locker room.

headline: Porn Filmmaker Finds Out a ‘K’ Can Be Owned
text: The cast was entirely Israeli. The script was entirely in Hebrew. The film was entirely treif.

headline: Democrats Try to Increase Leverage Over Iraq Policy
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  Representative Steny H. Hoyer, the House majority leader, said Friday that Congress might consider legislation revising the authorization it gave President Bush in 2002 to use military force in Iraq.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 12 about Staten Island Chuck, a groundhog being prepared for his first Groundhog Day duty by commuting home with his trainer on weekends, included an outdated reference to the train system that Chuck travels on. Since 1994, it has been called the Staten Island Railway, not Staten Island Rapid Transit.

headline: New Permits for Mass Bike Rides
text: The New York Police Department has adopted rules that require parade permits for bicyclists and others who take to the streets in groups of 50 or more for processions, races and protests.

headline: Donald E. Osterbrock, 82, Who Studied the Cores of Galaxies, Dies
text: Donald E. Osterbrock, an astronomer and historian of science who studied the birth of stars and luminous clouds of gas at the core of galaxies outside the Milky Way and wrote an influential textbook about the subject, died on Jan. 11 in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 82.

headline: In Top Shape, González Aims to Topple Federer
text: MELBOURNE, Saturday, Jan. 27 — Roger Federer has already snuffed out the hopes here of one longtime foil who thought that his improved backhand, soaring confidence and new American coach might help him break the habit of losing to the world’s No. 1 player.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 9 P.M. (Hallmark) TROY (2004). Pump me up: Brad Pitt flexes his muscles as the warrior Achilles in this action-heavy historical drama from Wolfgang Petersen, adapted by David Benioff from “The Iliad” by Homer and other sources, about the assault on Troy by Greek forces. The glossy cast includes Orlando Bloom as Paris, Diane Kruger as Helen, Brendan Gleeson as Menelaus, Eric Bana as Hector, Brian Cox as Agamemnon, Sean Bean as Odysseus and Peter O’Toole as Priam.

headline: Mr. Bush’s Oil Security Blanket
text: One of the stranger and so far unexplained items in President Bush’s energy program is his proposal to double the capacity of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to 1.5 billion barrels, over the next 20 years. The proposal carries a $65 billion price tag  one of several reasons Congress should question Energy Secretary Samuel Bodman closely when he comes looking for the money.

headline: Is Dividing Iraq Our Best Way Out? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Colorado: Ranchers Getting Loans
text: Farmers and ranchers in storm-plagued areas of southeastern Colorado who lost livestock in recent back-to-back blizzards will be able to obtain low-interest emergency loans of up to $500,000 from the United States Agriculture Department, federal officials said. As many as 10,000 head of cattle may have been killed by the storms, but the final count remains uncertain because many animals remain buried in snow. Losses are also mounting from the deaths of weakened animals. President Bush signed a declaration this month qualifying parts of Colorado, Kansas and Nebraska for federal disaster relief.

headline: Art From Russia With Love (C’est Français, Naturellement)
text: LONDON — The British have long conceded that the French invented the art of love. London, then, might offer the most receptive audience for “The Triumph of Eros: Art and Seduction in 18th-Century France,” a show that demonstrates through paintings, engravings and sculptures how the French turned loving into an amusing pasttime.

headline: O.K., Financial Planners, Grab a Calculator and Let’s Get Started
text: The only way to know whether you have saved enough for retirement is, when you suck in your last breath, for someone to show you your bank statement.

headline: Flamenco That Finds Its Fit in a Space Between Two Styles
text: Not everyone wants to perform pure traditional gypsy flamenco. A grass-roots genre of flamenco Latino has sprung up in New York in recent years. The program presented by Andrea Del Conte Danza España on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo fits somewhere between those styles, but never created the crucial flamenco feeling of an internal fire reaching up into the soul from the core of the earth.

headline: Countdown to the Census
text: The accuracy of the census is determined in the planning stages, and planning for the 2010 count is already imperiled. The dangers fall into two categories: money (too little) and politics (too much). The new Congress will have to manage both vigilantly.

headline: Romania’s King Without a Throne Outlives Foes and Setbacks
text: BUCHAREST, Romania

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Oprah’s New Reading Recommendation

headline: Labor Union, Redefined, for Freelance Workers
text: Herding freelancers is a bit like herding cats. Both are notoriously independent.

headline: The Bait-and-Switch White House
text: We often wonder whether there is a limit to the Bush administration’s obsession with secrecy, its assault on the rule of law, its disdain for the powers of Congress, its willingness to con the public and its refusal to heed expert advice or recognize facts on the ground. Events of the past week suggest the answer is no.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart yesterday with an article about declining union membership gave outdated information on the states with the highest and lowest membership in 2006. The top states were Hawaii (24.7%), New York (24.4%), Alaska (22.2%), New Jersey (20.1%) and Washington (19.8%); the bottom states were Texas (4.9%), Georgia (4.4%), Virginia (4.0%), and North and South Carolina (both with 3.3%). The chart listed the 2005 rankings. (As the article noted correctly, the national average is 12 percent, based on 2006 figures.)

headline: Finding a Famous Pair’s Intensity and Sensitivity
text: Four men, their backs to the audience, stand in a line upstage at the beginning of George Balanchine’s “Agon.” Then they turn, and Stravinsky’s bright fanfare of trumpets heralds the start of the ballet that, in Balanchine’s words, used history as “the takeoff point.”

headline: Ex-Executive of Computer Associates Receives Prison Sentence
text: A former executive with Computer Associates who pleaded guilty to securities fraud and who prosecutors said was instrumental in the prosecution of the company’s former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced to seven months in prison and seven months of home detention.

headline: Offering Help for Former Foster Care Youths
text: DETROIT — When current and former foster children formed a group to help youths who had turned 18 and were “aging out” of the system, one of the first things they did was hold a luggage drive.

headline: U.N. Plan Paves Way for Kosovo Independence
text: PARIS, Jan. 26 — The United Nations mediator Martti Ahtisaari presented his proposals for the final status of Kosovo on Friday, most likely setting the tiny war-torn territory on its way toward independence.

headline: Picking New York’s Comptroller
text: New York’s Legislature is expected to choose a replacement soon for Comptroller Alan Hevesi, who resigned after pleading guilty last year to a felony. To inject some quality control into a process that could have been all political horse-trading, legislative leaders and Gov. Eliot Spitzer set up an excellent vetting process. Three former comptrollers  two Democrats and a Republican  screened candidates and were asked to pick up to five finalists.

headline: U.N. Atomic Chief  Cites Iran Enrichment Plan
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 26  The head of the United Nations nuclear inspection agency said Friday that Iranian officials had told him that they planned to begin installing equipment next month in an industrial-scale plant to enrich uranium.

headline: Woman Killed by Husband Provoked Family, Son Says
text: The son of an Upper East Side landlord accused of killing his wife in 2005 by stabbing her testified on behalf of his father yesterday, telling the story of a marriage that unraveled into madness.

headline: Sgt. Preston, Where Are You? Dog Sledding Isn’t Easy
text: I MOUNTED the runners of a dogsled on Eden Mountain in northern Vermont, bracing for my first solo mush. The sun sparkled on a snow-covered field framed by stands of sugar maple, beech, birch, spruce, pimlock and pine. A few yards away, my wife, Alison, and my son, Harrison, stared at me with disbelief.

headline: Chinese Pipa Joins Russian Strings
text: Why a Russian string orchestra spent two hours playing Japanese and Chinese music at Zankel Hall on Thursday has one obvious answer. Everyone is across the street from everyone else these days and sends instant cultural messages back and forth. Differences remain. If Toru Takemitsu’s movie music is the last word in restrained elegance, the Moscow Soloists executed it sounding like 17 fine young performers who sort of play together.

headline: X Games Veteran Is More Motivated, Not Mellowed, With Age
text: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 26 — He was born for speed. In November 1968, his father sped a Camaro containing his mother through the San Diego night to a hospital, where Shaun Palmer was born. And so began a wild ride for one of the most accomplished and versatile action-sports athletes.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about a pointed exchange between CNN and Fox News over a Web site report that said Senator Barack Obama had attended an Islamic school or madrassa in Indonesia as a child referred imprecisely to madrassas. While some teach a radical version of Islam, most historically have not. (Mr. Obama’s office has said the report is untrue.)

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,060 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Arena Fit for Quinnipiac’s Ambition
text: Last Saturday, New Haven Coliseum, once home to the popular but long ago dismantled Knighthawks of the American Hockey League, was demolished in favor of downtown redevelopment.

headline: For TV’s Trixie, the Honeymoon Lives On
text: It is 5:01 p.m. and Joyce Randolph, a k a Trixie Norton, is holding forth in the downstairs bar at Sardi’s, sipping her favorite formulation of the White Cadillac, Dewar’s and milk. “I think it does your stomach good,” she is saying. “The Scotch. The milk.”

headline: Intel Says Chips Will Run Faster, Using Less Power
text: Intel, the world’s largest chip maker, has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for a new generation of faster and more energy-efficient processors.

headline: Assembly Condemns Denial of Holocaust
text: The General Assembly adopted a resolution condemning the denial of the Holocaust, with only Iran, which was the host to a conference last month that cast doubt on the existence of the Holocaust, disassociating itself from the measure, which was drafted by the United States, co-sponsored by 103 countries and agreed to by consensus. Hossein Gharibi, the delegate from Iran, said that Israel exploited the sufferings of Jews as a cover “to commit new genocide and crimes” against the Palestinians. Dan Gillerman, the ambassador of Israel, responded, “While the nations of the world gather here to affirm the historicity of the Holocaust with the intent of never again allowing genocide, a member of the Assembly is acquiring the capabilities of carrying out its own.”

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $7,363,501.28

headline: Crawford’s 52 Points Tie 5th-Best Knick Mark
text: When you are as hot, as brilliant and as close to perfect as Jamal Crawford was last night, the record shattering does not end at the final buzzer. An hour after Crawford lit up the Madison Square Garden scoreboard and the Miami Heat, he picked up his cell phone.

headline: Pataki Opposes More Troops Unless Iraqis Do Their Part
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 —Former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican who has steadfastly supported President Bush’s Iraq policies, said on Friday that he would oppose Mr. Bush’s plan for sending more troops to Baghdad unless Iraqi leaders took clearer steps to build a nonsectarian government.

headline: 2 Face Charge of Murder in Deaths of 5
text: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 26  One week after a couple and their three young sons were killed in their home here, the New York State Police announced on Friday that they had arrested two men, one a close family friend, and charged them with second-degree murder.

headline: Lyman Wynne, 83, a Leader in Research on Mental Illnesses, Dies
text: Dr. Lyman C. Wynne, a psychiatrist and psychologist whose research helped lay the foundation for family-based therapies for mental disorders, died on Jan. 17 in Bethesda, Md. He was 83.

headline: Dan Christensen, 64, Painter of Abstract Art, Dies
text: Dan Christensen, an abstract painter best known for his unfettered use of color in various styles, including Color Field painting and lyrical abstraction, died last Saturday in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 64.

headline: Spitzer Sees Health Savings; Hospitals Call Them Cuts
text: ALBANY, Jan. 26 Gov. Eliot Spitzer said on Friday that he would seek billions of dollars in Medicaid and health care cost savings when he unveils his first executive budget on Wednesday.

headline: Fashion Rituals and Runway
text: As any nature show will demonstrate, mammals use several methods for marking their territory.

headline: Gap Is in Need of a Niche
text: In the fall of 2004, Gap put on a splashy ad campaign called, “How do you wear it?” with Lenny Kravtiz and Sarah Jessica Parker. It featured the pair dancing in customized Gap jeans — his with metal studs down the seam; hers with a waist-to-cuff velvet ribbon.

headline: Giuliani Is Cautious as He Weighs ’08 Decision
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who developed a national reputation for decisive and reassuring leadership after 9/11, now faces the odd challenge of having to reassure some supporters that he can be decisive about a very different issue: running for president.

headline: Costs Increase for Building N.F.L. Stadium
text: Nothing seems to come cheap these days, particularly new athletic stadiums.

headline: Ono’s Driver Complained About Stress on Recording
text: Yoko Ono’s chauffeur was so stressed by his job that eight of his teeth fell out because he was grinding them at night, according to court papers filed by his lawyer.

headline: Cracking the Books for Financial Aid to College
text: As the price of a degree at a private college shoots toward the cost of a Lamborghini, parents and grandparents are looking for a leg up as well as to correct mistakes that could cost them dearly when applying for need-based financial aid.

headline: Washington and Detroit Share Some Issues
text: ENERGY and health policy dominated the news this week, both directly, in the form of President Bush’s State of the Union address, and indirectly, in the huge loss at the Ford Motor Company last year. Ford’s problems were attributed largely to the flagging sales of its gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles and the crushing burden of providing health care to its employees and retirees.

headline: Canada to Pay $9.75 Million to Man Tortured in Syria
text: OTTAWA, Jan. 26  Maher Arar, the Canadian software engineer who was detained by American officials in 2002 and deported to Syria, where he was jailed and regularly tortured, will receive 11.5 million Canadian dollars ($9.75 million) in compensation from the Canadian government, under a settlement announced Friday.

headline: Best-Seller Big Bang: When Words Started Off to Market
text: “I hate publishing!” Alfred Tennyson complained as he assembled his poems for London publication in 1842. Among his gripes was having to chase down pirated American versions of his verse, while trying to earn his keep from books and magazines. But those earnings came far more easily to him than to today’s poets. “In Memoriam” sold 25,000 copies in England in less than two years; in 1864 “Enoch Arden” sold 40,000 copies in just a few weeks.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article by The Associated Press last Saturday about a fatal stabbing at the Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School in Massachusetts misstated the school’s location. It is in Sudbury, not Framingham.

headline: Italian Romanticism From a Rarely Heard Source
text: Riccardo Muti’s streamlined readings of the Russian and German repertory are an acquired taste (though one worth acquiring), and his relatively rare forays into American repertory have been well meaning, if unpersuasive. But there is no one to touch him in Italian music, and that was what he brought to the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening, the start of his second week of subscription programs with the orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Luxury by the Fraction
text: THE good life can be acquired in limited pieces. What works for vacation homes and private planes — fractional ownership — is rapidly becoming available for pleasure boats and wineries.

headline: What’s on Sunday Night
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) RHINOCEROS Virtually unchanged over 25 million years, the rhinoceros once roamed the earth in hordes. Today, it is one of the planet’s rarest animals, with three of the remaining five species headed toward extinction. This “Nature” special follows rangers through the savannahs of South Africa, the grasslands of India and the jungles of Indonesia to examine efforts to protect rhinos from poachers and relocate them to new habitats, and peers into a fertility lab at an American zoo to find out about attempts to breed them in captivity. It also zooms in on some startling behavior in the rhinos’ natural environments, including a nursery full of mothers and calves and a charge from an angry bull.

headline: Venezuela: U.S. Envoy Says Bags Are Packed
text: Diplomatic relations with the United States appeared to become more fragile as William Brownfield, the American ambassador, responded to a threat of expulsion from President Hugo Chávez by saying, “My bags are always packed and ready.” Mr. Brownfield, in a visit to Maracaibo, also emphasized that he hoped to avoid further confrontation and to focus instead on issues of political and economic importance to both Caracas and Washington. Mr. Chávez, who has threatened to expel Mr. Brownfield before, said on Thursday night that he could declare the ambassador “persona non grata” if he continued to comment on such issues as Venezuela’s plan to nationalize companies controlled by foreign investors.

headline: A Contrarian View: Save Less and Still Retire With Enough
text: Could it be possible that you are saving too much for your retirement?

headline: Young Lovers, a Vespa and a Frolic by Rossini
text: If Rossini had been in the audience on Thursday night at the Harry de Jur Playhouse, he would surely have found the stylish and witty new production of “Il Signor Bruschino” by the Gotham Chamber Opera as cheekily funny as everyone else did.

headline: ‘Get Organized Now’ Month? Maybe in the Red States
text: Donald Keyser, the Asia expert and former senior State Department official, was finally sentenced to prison this week. Among other things, Mr. Keyser confessed to keeping more than 3,000 sensitive documents — 3,559 to be exact, ranging from the classified to the top secret — in his basement. His wife had pointed this out to him. I’m going to go out on a limb here: in the history of the world, no one has ever been happy to be told to clean up his room.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Saturday about complaints by some nonprofit groups of a class divide in philanthropy among Chinese-Americans misstated the given name of the executive director of the Ong Family Foundation, which makes annual grants to such groups, including the Chinese-American Planning Council, a social service agency. The executive director is Nelson Louis, not Norman. The article also misstated the association that Mr. Louis and Danny Ong Yee, the foundation’s founding trustee, once had with the council. They are former staff members; they did not attend the council’s child-care programs as children.

headline: Defending a Slam Again, Only This Time It’s Grand
text: In Thursday’s column you had the chance to pick West’s opening lead against a small slam. Now you can select something against a grand slam, seven spades. What would be your choice?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Jan. 19 about the humor columnist Art Buchwald misspelled the place of residence in Virginia of one of his surviving children, and a correction in this space yesterday misidentified that survivor. The town is Culpeper, not Culpepper. And it is Connie Marks Buchwald who lives there  not Joel Buchwald, who lives in Washington.

headline: In the Tennessee Senate, a Historic Shift of Power
text: NASHVILLE, Jan. 26 — Over the last year, members of the Tennessee legislature have witnessed a number of updates. Plasma televisions that broadcast legislative sessions now line corridors in Legislative Plaza, where many lawmakers have their offices. Smoking has been banned from the building although the two activities it used to cloud, lobbying and political arm-twisting, remain.

headline: Bravely Setting Out to Mock Others
text: I can’t say that I was surprised to learn that “Epic Movie” would not be screened in advance for critics, but I must say that my feelings were a little bit hurt. A crude, scatological parody of a handful of big-budget, inexplicably popular movies from the past two years — what would be more likely to warm a critic’s withered, cynical heart?

headline: Flair and Flash, Not Frumpiness
text: Long viewed as the domain of grandmothers, needlework has undergone an image makeover in the last decade. Snowboarders, the old torchbearers of alt.culture, have embraced crocheting, making beanies to wear on the slopes; coffeehouses and subways are filled with fashion-conscious types busily knitting or doing needlepoint. And contemporary artists like Andrea Zittel, Lisa Anne Auerbach, Orly Genger and Jim Drain and the Forcefield collective have given crafts a coolly conceptual edge.

headline: Fighting Between Hamas and Fatah Continues
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 — At least two more Palestinians were killed in Gaza today in continuing fighting between fighters loyal to Fatah and the Islamic Hamas movement, which has been celebrating its victory a year ago over Fatah in legislative elections.

headline: New York Won’t Replace Voting Machines by the Fall
text: New York officials have given up on replacing the state’s aging voting machines by the fall elections, and some would like to put off buying new electronic voting systems until after the 2008 presidential election, state officials said yesterday.

headline: Carpet Cleaner
text: This weekend, the Bagger will again sublimate his by-now sour soul and battered ego by crawling onto the red carpet, this time at the Screen Actor’s Guild Awards, which given the free-for-all in the Oscar hunt, seems to have some implications beyond the usual festive time had by all. He likes the wide-open vibe of the awards and that glitzerati always seems to be on their funnest behavior. But when it comes to carpet duty, he never knows what to say to the attendees. “Love your work” is fine and all, but it always brings a version of the same retort, which is a version of, “Well, I don’t know yours, but my publicist asked me to imitate a human being tonight, so here we are.”

headline: Women’s Australian Open Final
text: Serena Williams proved she is once again a force to be reckoned with after defeating Maria Sharapova.

headline: Correction: The Week in New Jersey
text: A report in The Week column last Sunday, about the availablility of season tickets for Rutgers University football games next season, carried incorrect information from the university about the number of people on a waiting list for the tickets. It is 1,600, not 9,600.

headline: Correction: Works to Touch by Artists Who Can't See
text: An article last Sunday about an exhibition by blind artists misspelled part of the name of the college in Hartford where it is being held. It is Capital Community College, not Capitol.

headline: Keeping Track of Steve Ballmer
Correction: Badillo’s World, One Tenement’s Tale and Eau N.Y.C.
text: A review of New York books on Dec. 31, in appraising “Water- Works: The Architecture and Engineering of the New York City Water Supply,” referred incorrectly to the origin of the octagonal logo used by JPMorgan Chase & Company. Ivan Chermayeff, who designed the logo with Tom Geismar, said the design was intended to be distinctive and geometric; he said the design was not related to a New York water provider that was the forerunner to JPMorgan Chase & Company. The logo was not intended to resemble a cross-section of a wooden water pipe, and any such resemblance was not the decisive factor in the selection of the logo from several proposed designs.

headline: Correction: Chairs With Airs: On Arty Streets, a Cluster of Hip Furniture Stores
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about furniture stores in Dumbo, Brooklyn, misstated the context of a quotation by Robert Siewert, the manager at Wonk, one of the stores. When Mr. Siewert said, “This building, before they started getting kicked out, was mostly artist studios,” he was referring to a building at 68 Jay Street, where his store is located — not to the nearby J Condominiums.

headline: Correction: F.Y.I.
text: A report in the F.Y.I. column last week about a luminaire at Verdi Square misstated the given name of the director of art and antiquities for the Department of Parks and Recreation, who commented on the luminaire’s history. He is Jonathan Kuhn, not John.

headline: It’s Up, It’s Good, Maybe Too Good
text: We received quite a few responses to John Branch’s article last Sunday on rising field-goal accuracy and what the league should do, if anything, about it. (I pasted his article on the bottom of this file.)

headline: Soros Likes Obama, Is Worried About Leverage
text: George Soros, the billionaire former hedge fund manager, met with a group of reporters over lunch today — he paid the check — and offered views on everything from markets to American politics to Bill Gates as a philanthropist.

headline: Perilous Journey
text: Mexico has taken measures to slow the flow across its southern border, but much remains to be done.

headline: Lies, Fallacies and Truths
text: Lawrence Summers, the former U.S. Treasury Secretary and Harvard University president, delivered some harsh criticism of the way globalization has been pitched to the public. Making the intellectual case for free trade and then simply “paying off” some of the losers in globalization, Mr. Summers said, will not work for world leaders trying to sell the current round of global trade talks to a skeptical polity.

headline: Powerful Women and Their Admirers
text: Heads of state, ministers and chief executives were among those who attended a Forbes–Ernst & Young co-sponsored Powerful Women reception here at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

headline: Asia Takes Lessons, and Teaches Some Too
text: Call it the third-mover advantage.

headline: The Password Is… Everywhere
text: There is no more coveted party than the Google Party in Davos.

headline: Green For a Day?
text: Climate change is one of the big topics at this year’s World Economic Forum, so it is no surprise that delegates are parading their green credentials. But the worthies and grandees at Davos should watch out: There are watchdogs about.

headline: George Soros Backs Obama (But Hedges His Bets)
