text: George Soros, the billionaire former hedge fund manager, met with a group of reporters over lunch on Saturday — he paid the check — and offered views on everything from markets to American politics to Bill Gates as a philanthropist.

headline: Crowd Turns Out for Blair’s Not-Quite-Farewell
text: For Tony Blair, it was a valedictory Davos moment — his final appearance at the World Economic Forum as Britain’s prime minister after almost 10 years in office (but probably not his last time at the conference). Despite his poor ratings and limited political shelf-life at home, Blair still packed the auditorium with listeners Saturday as he addressed three main issues: climate change, trade and Africa.

headline: Father of the Bride
text: Hail Mary, did Jean-Paul Gaultier have a Jesus hallucination?

headline: Clinton Packs a Crowd in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — If it’s turning into a battle of who can score the biggest early Democratic primary crowds, let the record show that Senator Hillary Rodham Cinton from New York at least matched –- and may have beat – Senator Barack Obama from Illinois at her rally here this morning, compared to the turnout Mr. Obama drew in New Hampshire last month.

headline: In Her Own Time, Like Her Spouse
text: DES MOINES — It’s called Clinton Time. It’s a reference to Bill Clinton’s notorious habit of being late to every campaign event, caused by his desire to linger behind to shake every hand, grant every request for an autograph.

headline: Clinton: The X Factor
text: DES MOINES — The conversation and themes of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s town hall visit can be boiled down to one word thus far: Women.

headline: Happy Birthday, Cognitive Dissonance
text: So these five hundred social psychologists walk into a ballroom. They sit through a symposium entitled “Cognitive Dissonance Theory Celebrates 50th Birthday.” Afterwards there is birthday cake for everyone – two birthday cakes, actually. One is chocolate; one’s white. Neither looks particularly better than the other.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Jan. 28
text: Well, in keeping with announcements that seem to pop up on the Sunday news shows, word has it that former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee may say on NBC’s “Meet the Press” that he’ll file exploratory papers for a 2008 bid for the Republican nomination as early as Monday. He’s the lead guest; the schedule for Tim Russert’s program otherwise includes Senators David Vitter and Chuck Schumer as well as former Bush speechwriter Michael Gerson.

headline: Your Ideas for Darfur
text: In my Sunday column, I invite readers to send me ideas for addressing the crisis in Darfur, at DarfurSuggestions@gmail.com. Those can be ideas for helping people or for pressuring the Sudanese government. You’re also welcome to post those suggestions here — and to comment on other people’s suggestions or on my column itself.

headline: Big Dreams Under G.M.’s New Tent
text: ONE of the most intriguing concept cars of recent years was never seen at an auto show. In fact, it was banned from them — by the company that created it.

headline: Dale Noyd, Vietnam Objector, Dies at 73
text: Dale E. Noyd, who as a decorated Air Force captain and fighter pilot attracted worldwide attention in the 1960s as a conscientious objector who objected to only one war, the one in Vietnam, died Jan. 11 in Seattle. He was 73.

headline: Bitter Spirits
text: In daily life, obsessive, all-consuming, world-annihilating rage is not a healthy emotion, but for horror fiction it’s mother’s milk. In horror, very bad things have to happen to people — or, at the least, to impend ominously — and the perpetrators of those atrocities tend to be in extraordinarily foul moods, especially when, as in the case of ghosts and zombies, they have recently risen from the dead. They always wake up cranky.

headline: Biden Encourages Debate Over Iraq Troop Increase
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that no more than 20 senators would voice support for the president’s troop increase in Iraq when the Senate debates resolutions opposing that plan.

headline: Recently Published
text: THE GREAT KISSER

headline: Paperback Row
text: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

headline: Jets Along the Hudson
text: Turning Stewart International Airport in New Windsor into the New York metropolitan area’s fourth major air hub is a bold proposition that sets the mind racing at the grand possibilities, though it can also prompt a sinking feeling when one remembers the many ways that big ideas can fall flat.

headline: Judging Goalies, Ranking Brodeur
text: Martin Brodeur has been the rock-solid foundation of the Devils since his rookie season in 1993-94, when he backstopped them to the second overtime of an unforgettable Game 7 against the Rangers in the conference finals. Now, with his name engraved on the Stanley Cup three times to ease the memory of Stéphane Matteau’s series-winning goal that wild night at Madison Square Garden, Brodeur is having what may be the best season of his career.

headline: Inside the Minds of Your Employees
text: WITH all the targeted marketing out there, and the customer satisfaction surveys and opinion polls that companies seem to offer at every turn, you might think that employers could get a handle on which employee benefits are most popular among their workers.

headline: For a Pavilion With a Past, Grumbling Over the Future
text: IN the heyday of the New York Left, the limestone pavilion at Union Square Park’s north end was a common backdrop for hundreds of Socialist, Communist and labor union demonstrations, its columned arms seeming to embrace the swelling crowds. Until the 1980s, it also served as a bandstand and an unofficial play space.

headline: New Lords of the (Downtown) Dance
text: WHEN Cathy Edwards stepped down as artistic director of Dance Theater Workshop last summer, experimental dance lost a general. Ms. Edwards had the essential ingredients of a good curator: experience and guts. She put a slew of young artists on the map in her outstanding 2005-6 season, and her daring curatorial choices showed her to be as creative and imaginative as many of the artists she booked. Others in the field took note.

headline: These Kids Never Say ‘Yech!’
text: ON Saturdays at Paradou, a small French restaurant in the meatpacking district, the bed-headed brunch crowd slogs in after noon, ready for mimosas. The morning crew is rowdier: a gaggle of apron-wearing children, mostly under 5, who come for the Mini Chef cooking lessons.

headline: With Lines Like These, Who Needs Words?
text: Introduced on Sunday: Lamborghini Murciélago LP640 Roadster

headline: 3 Killed as Hamas and Fatah Fight On
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 — At least three more Palestinians were killed Saturday in Gaza in continuing battles between fighters loyal to Fatah and Hamas, which has been celebrating its victory a year ago over Fatah in legislative elections.

headline: Hate the House? Then Renovate
text: LOVE the neighborhood, hate the house. That is a common enough complaint from both current homeowners and prospective homeowners.

headline: Hey Now: It’s Garry Shandling’s Obsession
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Between A.F.C. and N.F.C., Parity Is Only a Six-Letter Word
text: The Chicago Bears won one more game than the Indianapolis Colts in the 2006 regular season. The Bears outscored their opponents by 172 points, and the Colts outscored theirs by 67. The Bears won the National Football Conference championship in a blowout, while the Colts needed a late comeback to beat New England in the American Football Conference title game.

headline: They Are Refugees. Who Are We? (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Whose Iran?
text: The Mahestan mall in South Tehran is sometimes called “the honeycomb” of the Basij, the Iranian youth militia, because it is here that Basijis, as the militia members are known, buy and sell banners for the Shiite festival of Ashura, as well as religious books and posters. Somber, bearded young men in collarless shirts linger over tea behind stands selling tapes of religious singers — cult celebrities who belt out tear-jerking laments for the martyrdom of Hussein and make a small fortune performing at memorial services. Omid Malekian, a 28-year-old employee of a Tehran petrochemical refinery and the son of a carpenter, was shopping at Mahestan on Dec. 16, the day after Iran’s elections for city councils and for the Assembly of Experts, the 86-member clerical board that will select the next supreme leader should anything happen to the current leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. In the 2005 presidential election, Malekian voted for the winner, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and when I asked if he was happy with the president, he answered frankly.

headline: A Chevy in Saturn’s Orbit
text: Introduced on Tuesday: 2008 Chevrolet Malibu

headline: Red Carpet Syndrome
text: It is late January. The year is still fresh. So why do you feel so stale?

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Going, Going, Gone?

headline: You Listening to Me?
text: You have just written your first book, “Positively American: Winning Back the Middle-Class Majority One Family at a Time,” in which you try to produce a functional platform for the famously unfocused Democratic Party. What do Democrats stand for? No one has a good answer. I felt anguish about that. I felt a burning need to have us thinking beyond the immediate.

headline: Pfizer’s Birthplace, Soon Without Pfizer
text: When the morning shift ends and the afternoon light thins, workers stream out of the Pfizer pharmaceutical plant on Flushing Avenue in Brooklyn.

headline: Don’t Feed the Poets
text: I recently wandered through my home library in Montana and rediscovered Karl Shapiro’s “Bourgeois Poet” (1964), a book of prose poems I first read during the vile winter of 1966. My wife and I had moved back to northern Michigan, after I’d left behind a good job in Boston on the promise of my first book of poems, “Plain Song,” having been accepted by Norton. I don’t recall what shape I expected the promise to arrive in: I ended up trimming Christmas trees and working construction for two and a half bucks an hour. Our rented house was only $35 a month, but it was drafty, the furnace was faulty and frequently the place couldn’t be brought up to 55 degrees. All of these numbers can actually describe a life.

headline: Saving Lebanon
text: It is good that international donors have pledged $7.6 billion to help rebuild Lebanon after last summer’s devastating Israeli air strikes. The democratically elected government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora needs all the help it can get. Clashes between Shiite supporters of Hezbollah and the government’s mainly Sunni supporters threaten to overwhelm Mr. Siniora’s fragile coalition.

headline: Up Front
text: “The only really bold thing I’ve ever done,” Thomas Mallon insisted in a recent telephone conversation, “was to give up tenure at Vassar and start trying, in my mid-30s, to live the kind of life I might have had in my 20s.” Although his aim was to be a novelist (his first, “Arts and Sciences,” was published in 1988; his seventh, “Fellow Travelers,” is due in May), it was literary journalism, not novel-writing, that set him free from the constraints of academic prose. Mallon’s informed but accessible style, evident in his cover review of Claire Tomalin’s biography of Thomas Hardy, has been a feature of his contributions to the Book Review, The New Yorker, The Atlantic Monthly and other publications for the past 20 years — and in “Doubting Thomas,” the column he wrote for GQ magazine through much of the 1990s.

headline: The Curse of Geography in the ’08 Race
text: CALDWELL, N.J.

headline: Correction
text: Last week’s Photo-Op carried an incorrect date. The photograph was taken Jan. 11, not Jan. 16.

headline: Police Say Escapee Took Road Paved With Good Intention
text: NASHVILLE, Jan. 27 (AP)  It has all the makings of a country song: an escaped prisoner, his terminally ill mother, a Wal-Mart truck, Nascar and a Nashville singer’s tour bus.

headline: Making a Good System Better
text: New York’s campaign finance system has been a model for cities seeking ways to insulate politicians from special interest money while shoring up public confidence in the political system. But this enviable system is hardly free of loopholes, and gaming it has become commonplace. With Mayor Michael Bloomberg, the City Council and the Campaign Finance Board having expressed a desire to strengthen the program, this seems an especially auspicious time for reform.

headline: Raining E-Blows on Egos
text: THEY pour into your e-mail in-box, as explicit as they are relentless, with subject lines too shameful to share with colleagues. Enlarge your penis! Shrink your waistline! Enhance your sex life! Delete, delete, delete.

headline: In Two Tongues, Trying to Close a Learning Gap
text: Ossining

headline: Tech Stocks Are Back (With Caveats)
text: FOR the first time since the Internet bubble burst at the start of this decade, technology stocks really matter — even to investors who are wary of them.

headline: Cushy Flights and Fancy Victuals When the Nets Go on the Road
text: The perks of flying charter for the Nets extend beyond the cozy seats and the flexible schedule.

headline: A Jail Break, but Not to Fear
text: The Bronx House of Detention was reduced to little more than a mountain of rubble by last week. A high-reach excavator clawed ferociously at the last of its steel beams, adding them to a heap of brick and stone.

headline: With Leading Scorer on Bench, Irish Help Erase Cruel Memories
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 27 — The banner hanging above the Notre Dame basketball team’s bench shows that the last time the Irish reached the N.C.A.A. tournament was in 2003. Since then, Notre Dame has endured a long string of close calls, cruel losses and trips to the National Invitation Tournament.

headline: Truly Indie Fans
text: WHEN Douglas Martin first saw the video for Nirvana’s “Smells Like Teen Spirit” as a teenager in High Point, N.C., “it blew my mind,” he said. Like many young people who soothe their angst with the balm of alternative rock, Mr. Martin was happy to discover music he enjoyed and a subculture where he belonged.

headline: Alexandra Ostrow, Richard Bruskoff
text: Alexandra Hille Ostrow, the daughter of Marjorie Grossman and Eric B. Ostrow, both of New York, was married last evening to Richard Michael Bruskoff, the son of Ilene D. Helfand of Boca Raton, Fla., and Dr. Bruce Larry Bruskoff of Gladwyne, Pa. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in New York.

headline: Toy Story
text: The (variously) one-eyed, one-horned, purple, red and green people eaters called Uglydolls are among the most successful of a new wave of vinyl, plastic and plush “designer toys.” Originally conceived by the New York design school graduates David Horvath and Sun-Min Kim, the Uglydoll line has grown into a monstrous franchise with dozens of iterations, collected (ostensibly for their kids) by baby boomers, like me, who have yet to fully embrace maturity. Uglydolls are, however, but one brand among scores — if not hundreds — of patently quirky and deliberately unsightly toy/object characters that have exploded into a minor global phenomenon.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Mission Unaccomplished
text: HILLARY CLINTON has an answer to those who suspect that her “I’m in to win” Webcast last weekend was forced by Barack Obama’s Webcast of just four days earlier. “I wanted to do it before the president’s State of the Union,” she explained to Brian Williams on NBC, “because I wanted to draw the contrast between what we’ve seen over the last six years, and the kind of leadership and experience that I would bring to the office.”

headline: Mollie Hanna, Thomas Lang
text: Mary Anne Hanna, a daughter of Mary Anne Duffy Hanna and Howard William Hanna III of Pittsburgh, was married last evening to Thomas Justin Lang, a son of Aimee J. Lang of Deerfield, Ill., and Richard A. Lang of Chicago. Rabbi Emanuel Baum officiated at the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh. The Very Rev. Drew Morgan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

headline: In the East End, Riesling Legacy
text: AT a tasting in 1984 at the International Wine Center, a wine school in Manhattan, Peter M. F. Sichel, a seasonal South Fork resident, pointed to a bottle labeled Vin de l’Ile Blanc and said, “Try that.” Mr. Sichel, then a major figure in Germany’s wine industry (he has since retired), has a masterly understanding of whites. I tried it, and was charmed.

headline: Here Come China’s Women (and One Rising Star Is Just 12)
text: For decades, the best women in chess came from Eastern Europe, partly a result of state support of chess. But since the Soviet Union’s collapse, while Eastern European men have maintained their place among the elite, the women have slipped. Of the top 10 active women, half are from Eastern Europe.

headline: Home Rule, High Taxes
text: Just about everyone in the New Jersey Legislature knows that a major reason for high property taxes in the state is the existence of so many municipalities (566), school districts (616) and hundreds of other governmental units in a state relatively small in area.

headline: Bistronomy
text: If in Paris a friend tells you that he’s taking you to a Basque rugby pub in the opposite-of-bustling Seventh Arrondissement, don’t whimper about wanting to try somewhere on your list of Places to Go — Le Comptoir, say, or Le Sensing. He’s taking you to L’Ami Jean, and soon you will be grateful.

headline: For Sailors: St. Vincent and the Grenadines
text: St. Vincent and the Grenadines is an archipelago of 32 islands and cays at the southern end of the Caribbean. With relatively calm waters, a steady breeze and short distances between anchorages, the islands have long been a draw for the sailing and yachting crowds. But it's become more popular in the last year or so, thanks to increased marketing efforts and expansions by charter companies. Barefoot Yacht Charters, www.barefootyachts.com, one of the longest running operators in the islands, organized about 400 sailing trips last year, up 45 percent from 2005. Prices for staffed yachts vary widely depending on the size and amenities. A 47-foot, air-conditioned catamaran with a two-person crew and accommodating six guests costs about $9,660 for seven nights. A week-long charter of a 126-foot sailboat that can accommodate 12 guests will run about $64,000. Footloose Sailing Charters, www.footloosecharters.com, a 12-year-old company based in Florida, opened a new base on the island of St. Vincent in October and is offering 10 percent off five-day May charters booked by Feb. 5.

headline: Where Dignitaries Spoke, Bad Beams and Frail Walls
text: The words “Republican Club” remain in arched black letters above the four-columned entrance to the Colonial Revival structure in the Richmond Hill neighborhood in Queens, but the building’s paint is peeling badly.

headline: The Whole Audience Sits in One Chair, the Cast in the Other
text: INSPIRATION can come in the most unlikely places. For the writer and performer Nancy Bannon it arrived while she was riding in an elevator on the Upper East Side about five years ago. She was wearing grungy sweats and carrying a yoga mat when a dapper fellow in a business suit got on. She felt intimidated by his more formal attire; he looked uncomfortable as well, eyes darting as he pressed himself into a corner. Both of them, she realized, were awkward in such a tiny space, and their responses turned the elevator ride into a miniature drama.

headline: Hanging Pictures: An Art in Its Own Right
text: THE higher math of hanging pictures has always escaped me. The measurements of the space on one wall and two or four or seven pictures require a kind of visual algebra that I have no aptitude for.

headline: Correction: Where Money’s No Object, Space Is No Problem
text: The credits on Jan. 14 for two pictures with an article about the new Olympic Sculpture Park in Seattle were reversed. A photograph of the park at night was by Benjamin Benschneider, and a photograph of Alexander Calder’s “Eagle” was by Paul Macapia.

headline: A People’s Food Takes a Step Up in Cape Town
text: WITH its brightly painted houses and Muslim melting pot, the Bo Kaap neighborhood of Cape Town may not seem like a foodie's delight. It was settled in the 17th century by slaves from India, Malaysia and other southeast Asian countries, who became known as Cape Malays. And their food, odd fusion dishes like bobotie (curried beef with egg custard) and sosatie (a Mediterranean-style kebab marinated with Indian curry), was largely regarded as working-class fare.

headline: In the Wee Hours, Worship and More
text: AT 10 o’clock on a recent Thursday night, the corner of 53rd Street and 13th Avenue in the heart of Borough Park was bustling with traffic. In this neighborhood, an ultra-Orthodox stronghold for the past decade, a sea of religious Jews clad in traditional black and white garb scurried in every direction for late-night prayer, shopping or something to eat. This corner of Brooklyn never sleeps, or so it seems.

headline: Bernie Williams’s Future Still Unclear
text: Not breaking from the laid-back demeanor that has made him a calming presence in the Yankee locker room for 16 years, Bernie Williams said yesterday that he was not sure what he would do if he could control his future.

headline: A Lovely Parting Gift for Her Ex-Employer
text: In her first public appearance since her well-publicized firing as Wal-Mart’s top advertising executive, Julie Roehm resurfaced at the Reuters Newsmakers panel discussion on Super Bowl advertising in Times Square on Wednesday, and she quickly demonstrated that she had lost none of her ability to deliver pithy, quotable remarks.

text: An article on Jan. 14 about a new spate of films with ensemble casts, misstated the year “The Towering Inferno,” another ensemble film, was released. It was 1974, not 1977.

headline: A Mechanic’s Laptop Makes Manuals All but Obsolete
text: WHEN Donny Seyfer started fixing cars a couple of decades ago, a mechanic could still count on his internal database — a well-developed blend of observation, experience and instinct — to diagnose most breakdowns. The worn-out brushes in a dead starter or a short circuit in a sparkless ignition distributor would eventually be revealed to a mechanic who carefully dug through the clues.

headline: New Direct Flights From the United States to Greenland
text: I am planning a trip this May from Detroit to Nuuk in Greenland. Air Greenland serves Nuuk, via Copenhagen, but I hear that the carrier will start direct flights from Baltimore in May. I am unable to get confirmation of this from any source, including Air Greenland. If it is true, how do I book a flight? —Elsa M. Shartsis, Huntington Woods, Mich.

headline: Experts See Peril in Bush Health Proposal
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 — With his proposal to uproot a tax break that has been in place for more than 60 years, President Bush has touched off an impassioned debate over the future of the employer-based system that provides health insurance to more than half of all Americans.

headline: Faith at Work
text: I answered an ad for a job as a data-entry clerk at a faith-based charity, but I stopped filling out the application when it said I could not work there unless I signed a “statement of faith,” affirming that I had evangelical Christian beliefs. Isn’t this religious discrimination? — Janet Lama, Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Preventing Drowning Deaths
text: This past Wednesday, a task force appointed by the Department of Environmental Protection met for the first time to draw up a plan for reducing drowning deaths in state parks. This is a serious problem in this state: in the last eight years, 21 people have drowned while swimming in Connecticut state parks. A strategy for dealing with it should be put in place by Memorial Day.

headline: Spotting Freelancer Conflicts: A Solution With Problems
text: THE ability of The New York Times to maintain its ethical standards among its far-flung outside contributors continues to be a major concern of mine. As these freelancers fill column after column at a lower cost than full-time reporters, readers have a right to expect that editors ensure the integrity of that journalism.

headline: Totals
For Foodies: Anguilla
text: For many years, foreign chefs — many of whom were brought in to run the kitchens of Anguilla's high-end resorts — dominated the culinary scene on this northernmost of the Leeward Islands in the Lesser Antilles. But over the last several years, local chefs who trained at those same resorts have been opening their own restaurants and adding new twists to traditional dishes.

headline: A Guest Encounters Happiness, and a Bit of Babyland
text: I’D met the happily married man several times, always at one of the parties Doug gave in his loft in TriBeCa, but we never got to know each other very well. He was alarmingly kind, and of course married, but for some reason, his happily married wife and I didn’t remember each other. Could be because Doug’s loft seems to be the size of a football field, and when you are in a space the size of a football field, you usually don’t get to know the people on the other side unless you have a pair of binoculars.

headline: A Holocaust Commemoration Both Somber and Hopeful
text: DAVID WROE is a bit too British to rhapsodize about his good fortune, but he will let on that he never expected a career in New Jersey to get this good.

text: BOSTON, Jan. 27  Tirunesh Dibaba, a 21-year-old Ethiopian, likes running in Boston, and who can blame her?

headline: Journeys to the Center
text: Jules Verne’s “Journey to the Center of the Earth,” a survey of mid-19th-century geological controversies thinly disguised as a ripping yarn set in a dinosaur-inhabited subterranean realm, was a best seller when it was first published in France in 1864. Five years later, an upstate New York alternative healer named Cyrus Teed had a vision revealing that the earth is hollow and that we’re all living on its concave inner surface. He eventually renamed himself Koresh, and established a thriving colony of hollow-earthers in the wilds of Florida. Then, in 1871, “The Coming Race,” by Edward Bulwer-Lytton, in which the narrator discovers an advanced civilization underground, helped give rise to dozens of science-fiction novels in which travelers penetrated the icy polar realms and descended into a well-lighted netherworld via a whirlpool or tunnel.

headline: The Faint Hoofbeats? That’s the Dark Horse
text: WASHINGTON

headline: For Hermits: Marie-Galante
text: Marie-Galante, one of the larger islands of the Guadeloupe archipelago, is a throwback to a bygone era. Nineteenth-century windmills dot the island and ox-drawn carts, once the chief means of transportation on the island, are not an uncommon sight even today. On Sundays, there are draught ox competitions and cock fights according to Luigy Ssosse, a representative of the Guadeloupe Committee of Tourism.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on the front page of today’s Travel section, referring to the 36 Hours column on Madrid, misidentifies the building shown. It is the library of the Reina Sofía Museum, not the Mercado Fuencarral, a boutique shopping center.

headline: The 10-Point Caribbean Escapes Plan
text: WITH more than 30 major islands to choose from — from the lush wilderness of Dominica to the desertlike terrain of Curaçao — the Caribbean can be almost all things to all people. Want a back-to-nature hiking experience? You got it. Want to be pampered in a five-star resort where the staff-to-guest ratio runs at two to one and the toughest decision you will make each day is whether to have a hot stone or an ayurvedic massage? No problem. Or do you just want to chill at a place where there’s no TV, no cellphone service and where dinner is no more elaborate than the catch of the day? Consider it done.

text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: You Can Teach a Spy a Novelist’s Tricks
text: E. Howard Hunt Jr., who died last week at 88, is best remembered as the man who helped plan and bungle the 1972 Watergate break-in. An ex-C.I.A. officer with a background in dirty tricks, sabotage and other skulduggery, Mr. Hunt was particularly qualified to be a “security consultant” for President Richard Nixon. In 1954, he helped overthrow the government of Guatemala, and he was later involved in the Bay of Pigs fiasco.

headline: Middle Relievers Are Moving Front and Center
text: In an effort to raise the performance standards of their bullpens, teams have raised the standard of living for the pitchers who populate those bullpens. The more important they are perceived to be, the more money middle relievers are earning.

headline: Meissner, Helped by Early Lead, Holds on for Title
text: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 27 — Her long program Saturday was not the triumphant performance Kimmie Meissner had hoped for, but after holding on to win the women’s title at the United States Figure Skating Championships, she could not stand still. She bounced in place, shifted from one skate to the other and clasped her hands to keep them still. She could not stop smiling.

headline: Evidence From Bite Marks, It Turns Out, Is Not So Elementary
text: FIFTEEN years ago, Roy Brown, a hard-drinking man with a criminal record, was convicted of stabbing, beating, biting and strangling a social worker in upstate New York. The case rested largely on one piece of forensic evidence: bite marks on the victim’s body that the prosecution’s witness, a local dentist, said matched Mr. Brown’s teeth.

headline: Three Singular Brooklyn Buildings, Each With a Second Chance
text: IN the 1890s, Louis Seitz built three singular apartment houses in Brooklyn: the Imperial, at Pacific Street and Bedford Avenue; the Alhambra, at Nostrand Avenue and Macon Street; and the Renaissance, at Nostrand and Hancock Street.

text: CAIRO

headline: A Warm Coat for a Woman With Endless Stories to Tell
text: Sally Mae Jenkins is full of stories. In a breathless rasp, she recalls traipsing through the woods of her native South Carolina, running from snakes and getting into dicey escapades with her 13 brothers and sisters. Then she talks of having a daughter at 17, only to lose her 25 years later. Each reverie is delivered in her thick-as-molasses Southern accent and punctuated with “Lord have mercy!”

headline: Putting It Together: The Artist as Deal Maker
text: SCOTT LATHAM is one of the country’s highest-paid commercial real estate brokers. But in the early 1980s, he was a struggling artist, exhibiting his paintings — when he was lucky — alongside more prominent artists like Keith Haring or Jean-Michel Basquiat in group shows.

headline: Coming-of-Rage
text: The year 1956 will be remembered in British history mainly for two events, both fatal in their different ways. In the autumn, Anglo-French forces invaded and briefly occupied Egypt in the debacle known as the Suez Crisis, which called time on British imperialism and saw off a prime minister. A few months earlier, at the Royal Court Theater on the edge of Chelsea, John Osborne’s “Look Back in Anger” had its first performance. Osborne was 26, a member of the generation that would oppose Suez, and the attitudes of his first major play and the astonishingly irreverent and fluent invective of its young protagonist, Jimmy Porter, captured a disenchantment in postwar English life that had never been seen on stage before. It shattered the well-bred conventions of English theater — to a large extent killed them off — and in the wider world became a symbolic text for people who wanted a different kind of Britain; one that, for example, would not have bombed Suez. Osborne, thanks to an alert theater press office, became the first “Angry Young Man.” Kenneth Tynan wrote famously in his review, “I doubt if I could love anyone who did not wish to see ‘Look Back in Anger.’ ” Mary McCarthy, the play’s early American champion, compared Jimmy Porter to Hamlet, who had also “declared war upon a rotten society.” Arthur Miller thought it the only modern British play worth seeing.

headline: A Serialist Island Thrives in a Sea of Minimalism
text: IN 1988 the composer Charles Wuorinen was profiled in The New York Times on the occasion of his 50th birthday. The article, “Wuorinen’s Bleak View of the Future,” written by the music historian Joan Peyser, painted a grim picture of Mr. Wuorinen’s fortunes. The thorny, demanding style of serialist modernism for which he had long been known was being eclipsed by Minimalism, and the Group for Contemporary Music, the influential ensemble he helped found in 1962, faced financial crisis.

headline: First You Clear the Table
text: Almost anybody who has ever done anything big knows that the first step involves clearing the desk. Or maybe the kitchen table. And New York’s lawmakers, with Gov. Eliot Spitzer as the new executive, clearly have some heavy scouring to do. Besides budget reform, which Mr. Spitzer signed into law last week, the next step is a series of changes the governor has labeled a “dramatic, significant, fundamental step forward” in ethics reform.

headline: 7 Months, and Still No Rate Cut

text: An Art entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report gave an incomplete title for an exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design. It is “Radical Lace and Subversive Knitting,” not “Lace and Subversive Knitting.”

headline: With Fort Closing, Towns Ponder a 1,126-Acre Windfall
text: WHEN Gerald J. Tarantolo, the mayor of Eatontown, N.J., places a price tag on the 452 acres of land his town hopes to acquire when Fort Monmouth closes, he is not exaggerating.

headline: The Recycled City
text: Chris Abani has done an end-run around the immigrant novel. In two previous books, Abani, who was born in Nigeria, traced a path from third world to first: “GraceLand,” his bustling novel set in Lagos, closed with a young man’s departure for the United States; his novella “Becoming Abigail” followed the title character from Nigeria to London. Abani now teaches at the University of California, Riverside, and his strange new novel is set in Los Angeles. Rather than adopting the perspective of a newcomer, though, he gives us Black, a mural artist raised in California, the son of a Nigerian father and a Salvadoran mother. Black was called Obinna as a boy, but after his father went missing in Vietnam, he lost his name along with any connection to his African ancestry.

headline: Higher Price Tags in Montauk
text: MONTAUK, the hamlet on the end of Long Island’s South Fork, has been a rustic un-Hampton summer destination for more than 50 years. But two new projects suggest that Montauk may be heading for year-round status, and the recent sale of a former celebrity retreat has also put a spotlight on the hamlet.

headline: 36 Hours in Madrid
text: POOR Madrid. Stuck in the middle of Spain, the city has long been perceived as the provincial, sleepy sister to Barcelona. Even today, you can see little girls dressed exactly as their mothers were, in 1940s-style dresses and matching topcoats. But that is precisely Madrid's charm. As the city fast-forwards into the 21st century — with designer hotels that rival any international city's, a sleek new airport terminal designed by Antonio Lamela and Richard Rogers and non-tapas bars that flirt with minimalist décor — Madrid is still the country's political and cultural capital. It remains, as Ernest Hemingway wrote, “the most Spanish of all cities.”

headline: In the Right Place at the Right Time
text: IT was shortly after he appeared on the television show “Queer Eye for the Straight Guy” that Jeff Berman decided he couldn’t continue sharing an apartment near Battery Park with four roommates.

headline: The Long Road to Energy Independence
text: President Bush never used the phrase “energy independence” in his State of the Union address last week, and it is just as well. His program for cutting gasoline demand is ambitious in scope, but modest in effect, according to experts.

headline: Thomas Hardy’s English Lessons
text: When Thomas Hardy drew his first chancy breaths inside a Dorset cottage in 1840, Wordsworth had yet to become England’s poet laureate. By his ninth decade, still writing, Hardy enjoyed listening to the wireless with his dog, Wessex, and had seen the silent-film adaptation of his own “Tess of the D’Urbervilles.” The author’s life span seems somehow even vaster than it was, a match for the cosmically long view Hardy took of his fictional characters, fate’s playthings set in motion on a “blighted star.”

headline: Radio Days
text: In the late 1940s and early 1950s, broadcasting experts predicted that the advent of television would kill off radio. Many of them didn’t especially want it to survive, since it could only hold back the acceptance of TV. In fact, the radio those experts knew didn’t survive. By the mid-1950s, the national networks that had dominated since the ’20s had all but evaporated, replaced by more than twice as many local stations. Television took over presenting broadcast drama and comedy, variety shows and in-depth news.

headline: Bombing Kills 14 Pakistanis
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 27 — At least 14 people were killed, most of them policemen, and several others were wounded Saturday in what appeared to be a suicide bombing here shortly before a Shiite religious procession was to come through, the police said.

headline: Homegrown, and (Partly) Newman’s Own

headline: The Budget Illusion
text: In the State of the Union speech, President Bush said that the budget deficit had been cut in half from 2004 to 2006. Not quite. The deficit declined, but not by half, from $412 billion to $248 billion. If you measure it as a percentage of the economy, Mr. Bush was off by an amount equal to about $15 billion.

headline: Former Party Boat Partly Sinks in Bay
text: The authorities are investigating the partial sinking yesterday of a paddleboat in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, that once was used for party cruises.

headline: The First Dance
text: On the first night of December, an unseasonably cold one in the Ozarks, the boys and girls of John Brown University primped in their zoot suits, suspenders, waistcoats, spats, faux-hawks, pompadours, knee-length pleated skirts, nylons, snoods and inch-high black heels and marched through snow drifts to their gymnasium in the Walton Lifetime Health Complex, one of northwest Arkansas’s monuments to the Wal-Mart family’s generosity. Inside, the gymnasium was decorated with rows of Christmas lights strung overhead across the width of the basketball court, from one railing of the mezzanine jogging track to the other. The occasion, which would last from 8 p.m. to 11 p.m., was a dance, the first of its kind at this small, nondenominational Christian college.

headline: Suburban Squall
text: “It’s the cooking, the cleaning, the crying!” wails Oscar in “The Odd Couple” when Felix has pushed him too far. In Rachel Cusk’s latest novel, it’s the cooking, the cleaning and the fact that beyond one’s own snarled household a million other women are doing the same. Her characters are quietly going berserk. Arlington Park isn’t the end of the world; it’s just suburbia. But, with a little exaggeration, the two become interchangeable.

headline: Israel May Have Violated Arms Pact, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON, Jan 27 — The Bush administration will inform Congress on Monday that Israel may have violated agreements with the United States when it fired American-supplied cluster munitions into southern Lebanon during its fight with Hezbollah last summer, the State Department said Saturday.

headline: Calcata, Italy: Where Newcomers Gave an Old Town a Second Life
text: WHETHER you arrive in Calcata by car or by one of the buses from Rome, it is impossible to remain unfazed when the village first comes into sight. Perched high atop a cake-shaped stump of tan volcanic rock — studded with a diminutive chess-piece castle and fringed by a dense forest — the fortified village plays on the travelers’ collective myth of the quintessential Italian hill town.

headline: If Driving Is a Pain, Here’s Your Balm
text: YOU will never read a truly enthusiastic review of the Lexus ES 350. This is less a reflection of the car than of the people who write auto reviews.

headline: Looking for the Angry Populists in Suburbia
text: IN his confrontational response to President Bush’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, Senator Jim Webb of Virginia said that he was going to focus on only two topics. One, as everyone knew it would be, was Iraq.

headline: Delight in Science, Then and Now
text: GROWING up, I loved math and science. My father was a history professor who became a college administrator. He encouraged me to go for the biggest challenge.

headline: Correction: Holiday on Ice, With a Shot of Vodka on the Side
text: An article on Dec. 31 about winter events in St. Petersburg, Russia, referred incorrectly to the Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan, the city’s holiest shrine. It housed the Historical Museum of Religion and Atheism during the Soviet era. It was not mockingly called the Museum of Atheism.

headline: Correction: N.F.L. Salaries
text: An article last Sunday about the lack of job security for professional football players misstated the average salary of an N.F.L. player. It was $1.4 million in 2005, the most recent figure available, not $1.3 million a year.

headline: A Gentle Touch Develops Into a Winning One
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 26 — Engulfed by grief thicker than any fog, Colts Coach Tony Dungy did not lose sight of his purpose. Within hours of learning of the suicide of his 18-year-old son, James, in December 2005, Dungy and his wife, Lauren, consented to have their son’s eyes harvested for donation in Tampa, Fla.

headline: The U.S. Is Losing Market Share. So What?
text: LAST week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Senator Charles E. Schumer released a report that warned of New York’s decline as a global financial capital. To remedy this dire state of affairs, the report, by the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, suggested solutions as diverse as easing regulation on publicly held companies and changing visa requirements so investment banks can more easily recruit foreign math whizzes.

headline: Crunch Time for the Tunnel
text: The proposed New Jersey to Manhattan commuter rail tunnel, widely regarded as vital to the economy of both New York and New Jersey, is moving into a critical period that could decide whether or not it actually gets built.

headline: Consider Your Citrus Options
text: One of winter’s luxuries is a sweet, seedless navel orange. But this month in California, where most of the nation’s eating oranges are grown, navels met with a killing frost. Although West Coast citrus will be fleetingly available as the last survivors are shipped, orange eaters will have to look beyond the Golden State for their vitamin C.

headline: 100 Hours
text: On a hot day in July last year, Nancy Pelosi, then the House Democratic leader, took a gang of reporters to a gas station near the Capitol. At that spot, with the gasoline pumps as a backdrop and the price of fuel skyrocketing, and with the Democratic senator Charles Schumer and the congressmen Rahm Emanuel and Ed Markey in tow, the future speaker launched a campaign with a slogan that fizzled but a phrase destined to have a delayed impact.

Then there are pockets like the small Japanese restaurant scene around Second and Third Avenues in the 40s, a short walk from the United Nations for visitors, immigrants and anyone else craving sushi, noodles, grilled meat and fish.

text: The nuanced 2006 sauvignon blanc from Blue Grove Hill, the second label of Capaia, a new producer in Philadelphia, South Africa, is cosmopolitan.

headline: Virulent TB in South Africa May Imperil Millions
text: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 27  More than a year after a virulent strain of tuberculosis killed 52 of 53 infected patients in a rural South African hospital, experts here and abroad say the disease has most likely spread to neighboring countries, and some say urgent action is essential to halt its advance.

text: WHEN I last had fondue, it was at a bustling place in Geneva, where the supercilious waiter knew we were tourists and treated us accordingly. I declared then that I wouldn’t be craving bread dunked in melted cheese for a very long time.

headline: A State Senate Endorsement
text: The sudden vacancy in the 7th State Senate District has caused both parties to leap in with guns blazing. headline: Correction: Dueling Banjos, Gospel Harmonies, Arabesques and Electric Eels
text: A review last Sunday of Tony Trischka’s album “Double Banjo Bluegrass Spectacular” in the Playlist column misidentified a guest banjoist, Alison Brown. She is formerly of the group Union Station; she is no longer a member.

headline: For Families: Aruba
text: Finding the perfect island to satisfy everyone on a family vacation can be quite a challenge. The kids are tired of the beach by noon and need something else to do. Dad wants to golf all morning and lie on the beach all afternoon. And Mom just wants to retreat to the spa. Plus, any place that requires changing planes is too much of a hassle, and if you or your spouse want any chance of watching the sunset in peace, a resort without a babysitting program is out of the question.

headline: With Reese Hoffa
text: Reese Hoffa, the fourth-best shot-putter in the United States in 2005, burst past the others last year. He won the world indoor title with the year’s longest indoor put (72 feet 6½ inches) and was ranked first in the world by Track and Field News. Hoffa, 29, graduated from the University of Georgia. About 6 feet and 305 pounds, he propels the shot with a fast, low line drive. On Friday, with the Madison Square Garden lights dimmed, with all other competition stopped and the music almost deafening, Hoffa will try to win the Millrose Games title for the third straight year. FRANK LITSKY

headline: Assimilating Circumstances
text: I’ve taught English as a second language for eight years, and I’m no slouch. I’ve taught in Korea and in New York City’s Chinatown. I’ve taken on classrooms of 50 high-school boys at a time. I wouldn’t have guessed that one slim Afghan girl would represent my most difficult challenge.

headline: Carter Gets 40 and Support, Letting Nets Exhale
text: DENVER, Jan. 27 — High point totals are a common occurrence for Vince Carter, but they are not the true mark of his dominance. That is typically measured by how inclined he is to shun jump shots for a taste of the rim.

headline: The Hard Rain That’s Falling on Capitalism
text: You may be a businessman or some high-degree thief, They may call you doctor or they may call you chief But you’re gonna have to serve somebody, yes indeed You’re gonna have to serve somebody, Well, it may be the devil or it may be the Lord But you’re gonna have to serve somebody.Bob Dylan, “Gotta Serve Somebody”

headline: It’s Night. Shall We Snorkel, Cycle or Hike?
text: WHEN night falls in New York or Paris, one goes clubbing or bar hopping. In a Texas park, the choices include bat detecting; in the Channel Islands of Britain, full-moon tidal treks; and in St. Louis, candlelight museum prowls.

headline: Looking in the Toolbox and Seeing Art
text: For four decades, John Hechinger ran a hardware and home supplies chain founded by his father in 1911. In 1978, as part of an expansion, he moved the corporate headquarters to suburban Washington, D.C. Soon after, he began collecting art to humanize the somewhat sterile building. Believing in the relationship between the tools his company made and the work that artists produced, he hoped the art would inspire his workers.

headline: Plan to Revive Trade Talks Is Offered in Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 27  Leading trade ministers on Saturday embraced an unusual game plan for reviving trade talks, saying they would try to hash out details on technical issues, rather than first agreeing on the broad outlines of an accord.

headline: For Budget Travelers: The Dominican Republic
text: A wide swath of all-inclusive resorts and relatively low-cost flights makes this country, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, the best option for the bargain-seeker.

headline: Paper, Plastic or Cooler?
text: Homemade fresh mozzarella ($7 a pound) is the big attraction at Massimo Italian Delicatessen in Kenilworth. “I make it at least twice a day,” said Massimo Clemente, known as Max. “We also prepare our own marinara sauce” ($4.25 a quart, plain; $4.50 with meat).

headline: Subaru Parks Its Styling in the Middle of the Road

headline: One Man’s Ode to Indianapolis, Indiana
text: One year in college, Norbert Krapf lived in Halas Hall, never giving much thought to the dormitory’s being named for the great Papa Bear of Chicago, George Halas, or that large men inhabited the hall in July and August.

headline: Pain Artist
text: Among the many perverse diversions and delights of Jesse Kellerman’s unnerving new thriller, TROUBLE (Putnam, $24.95), are his clinically detailed descriptions of all the variables that could drive a third-year medical student like Jonah Stem crazy. The sleep deprivation from putting in 16-hour days, six days a week, might do it alone. But compounding that constant assault on the nervous system are the abusive egomaniacal surgeons, the disgusting scut work on the colorectal ward and the staggering psychic misery of observing all the human suffering. That Kellerman maintains such a grimly hilarious perspective on his subject is its own twisted tribute to the survival instincts of writers who go down to the depths to entertain their readers. In Jonah’s words, when he finds himself on the psych wing: “You had to laugh. If you didn’t, you’d drown.”

headline: In Mexico City, Regional Flavors Unchanged by the Big City
text: THOUGH the regions of Mexico retain their very distinct cuisines, Mexico City acts like a food processor, puréeing ingredients until you can't tell what went into the final mix. There are places like Fonda El Refugio, a classic old-style, semiformal restaurant, and the wonderfully authentic El Bajio, now with four outposts, considered by many to have the best food in Mexico City; both pick and choose favorite dishes from around the country. Then there is Izote, which features Patricia Quintana's fabulous, decidedly modern and slightly internationalized cuisine. There are scores of brightly colored restaurants serving food so oriented to tourists' palates that they might as well be north of the border. And then there are literally hundreds of places with cheap, good and rarely distinguished food.

headline: Hart Crane’s Bridge to Nowhere
text: Before Hart Crane’s leap into the Caribbean that fatal April noon in 1932, he folded his jacket over the ship’s rail with impeccable manners. Striking out into the glassy sea, he was seen no more, dying younger than Byron but older than Shelley. Not being a seagoing breed, poets rarely die by water — Shelley drowned in a sudden squall; but he had written 1,500 pages of poetry, while Crane left only two very short books and the shards of a third. The hope for a homegrown American epic that died with him has never entirely revived.

headline: Agents of Angst
text: RENÉE MIZRAHI suspects that the first real estate agent she worked with deliberately didn’t tell her that a building was only 49 percent owner-occupied.

headline: Step Into the Attic. Enter the Jazz Age.
text: In the spring of 2004, a tall and trim 31-year-old real estate developer and investor from Harlem named Ed Poteat received a call from a broker about a hot deal in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

headline: The Choices Become Highly Personal
text: BUYING or selling an apartment or house can never be a simple transaction because it involves both emotions and finances. This is your home, after all, and the choices are very personal.

headline: An America Where Much Was Left Unsaid
text: There’s an autumnal air surrounding “The Cocktail Hour,” A. R. Gurney’s 1988 play, and not just because of the necklace of orange and brown leaves encircling the Long Wharf stage. The play deals with a waning world. Two, in fact.

headline: For Gays, Read the Fine Print
text: THE news earlier this month about how a New York court treated the dissolution of a gay relationship demonstrates how far gays have come in the struggle for marriage equality and how far we have yet to go. The court held that a separation agreement between two men was binding even though they were not married.

headline: With Gold in Reach, Jacobellis Falls Again
text: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 27  In a stunning repeat of her performance at the Winter Olympics, Lindsey Jacobellis had to settle for a silver medal Saturday after falling just before the finish during the snowboarder X final at the Winter X Games.

headline: Devon Beddard and Scott Caraher

Caraher and James C. Caraher of Chicago. The Rev. Philippa A. Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

headline: For Vandals, an Ironic Target: Street Artists
text: The block of Williamsburg’s North Sixth Street between Kent and Wythe Avenues has long been a sort of street-art gallery. Not long ago, a life-size head and torso of the children’s character Waldo perked up a corrugated-metal fence there, for instance, and beside it was a delicate mauve drawing of a sword-wielding woman with flowers for eyes. The caption read, “Flower Face Killah: Fierce Warrior.”

headline: Air Support
text: In the early morning of Jan. 18, 2002, a Canadian Pacific Railway train carrying hazardous chemicals derailed just outside Minot, N.D., spilling roughly 240,000 gallons of anhydrous ammonia into a woodsy neighborhood on the outskirts of town. The resulting toxic cloud grew to some five miles long, two and a half miles wide and 350 feet high, enveloping the homes of approximately 15,000 people. Confused and afraid, thousands of Minot residents turned on their radios to get public warnings and instructions on how to stay safe.

headline: Midnight at the Oasis
text: Around the time of the War of Independence, America’s main contact with the Middle East consisted in trading Caribbean rum for Turkish opium. It’s hard not to wish, reading the epic story of this 230-year relationship, now usefully condensed into a single well-researched volume, that things could have remained as simple as the swapping of your recreational poison for mine.

That move, police officials said, led to the hiring of a Hispanic woman and an Asian-American man, both New York City police officers.

headline: After Times of Grief and Doubt, a Tennis Ace Is Hungry Again
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 28 — The Australian Open was to begin in four days, and Serena Williams was so upset about the state of her game that she had locked herself in her hotel room after losing early in a low-level tennis tournament in Hobart, Tasmania.

headline: Connecticut’s Gambling Habit
text: Connecticut does not need the neon flash of the Las Vegas Strip to make money from gambling. Consider: Nevada, with its scores of casinos, took in tax revenue of about $1 billion last year. But Connecticut’s State Treasury took in $718 million from the lottery and just two Indian casinos.

headline: Correction: In Angel Falls, Venezuela, a Forest of Islands
text: The Explorer column on Jan. 14 about Angel Falls in Venezuela, misidentified the type of airplane flown by Jimmie Angel, who survived a crash landing there in the 1930s. It was a radial-engine monoplane — not a turboprop, which was not developed until the 1940s.

text: "HAND me a cigarette ..., lover,” Martha says to her conquest Nick in the second act of Edward Albee’s “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” The stage directions then read: “He lights it for her. As he does, she slips her hand between his legs.”

headline: For Hevesi Prosecutor, ‘One Standard of Justice’
text: ALBANY, Jan. 27  P. David Soares, the Democratic district attorney here, has clashed at various points in his two years in office with the mayor, the police chief, the sheriff and the County Legislature. He has assailed the war on drugs as a failure that “provides law enforcement officials with lucrative jobs” and called prison building an American “economic development strategy.”

headline: The Pluses and Pitfalls of Job-Seeking at Work
text: ON the surface, it seemed like the perfectly executed job search. Every day, a 40-year-old saleswoman based in New York would scan Internet job boards like Monster, HotJobs and CareerBuilder and would send e-mail messages to contacts and potential employers. She faxed her résumé and checked online trade news. In short, she did everything she could to find a more fulfilling job than the one she had held for seven years.

text: TAPACHULA, Mexico — Four Salvadoran men in jeans and T-shirts trudged along the railroad tracks under a hot sun, their steps carrying them steadily toward a fuzzy but seductive dream.

headline: Inside the List
text: POP/LIT: What would you rather write this year, if you could: a great, lasting pop song or a strong but unmemorable novel? That question came up at dinner, in a loud downtown restaurant, about a decade ago. I was there, as were two novelists: one has gone on to win major awards and become well known, the other hasn’t but deserves to. It was late; there were wine bottles; you could still smoke inside. I’d thrown out the question after hearing something good — was it “(Don’t Go Back to) Rockville”? — on the sound system. But these guys went at the question as if their lives depended on it. The debate quickly ratcheted up from the fundamental worth of, say, Brian Wilson’s work versus J. D. Salinger’s to Beethoven’s versus Tolstoy’s. I can’t remember who won. But punches were on the verge of being thrown. And I dimly recall thinking I should hide the pointy silverware.

headline: Rangel and Others Condemn Bush Medicaid Plan
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel and a number of city officials urged President Bush yesterday to reconsider a proposed change to Medicaid that could cost the city’s public hospital network millions of dollars in annual financing.

headline: Boy on the Bus
text: In this tender, slender, fictionalized memoir, Wendell Berry adds another chapter to his continuing account of rural life in Kentucky. The novel’s town of Port William, as his elderly narrator explains, looking back to his childhood during World War II, is “the nucleus, the navel, of the country that was most intimately home to me then and has been home to me all my life, even in the years when I did not live in it. It is my motherland, the mold I was cast in.”

headline: Parting Ways in Iraq
text: During the summer of 1995, Edward Joseph was serving as a U.N. peacekeeper in Bosnia. He was asked to help Muslim women and children flee from an area near Srebrenica, where 7,000 Muslims had already been slaughtered by Serb forces.

headline: Now You, Too, Can Enter the World of 007 Finance
text: COMPARED with button-down stock jockeys at Fidelity or T. Rowe Price, hedge fund managers may be the James Bonds of the financial world. They have a reputation for being secretive risk takers who use an array of specialized financial weaponry like derivatives and short-selling. (No license to kill, of course, though their lightly regulated funds do allow managers tremendous, nonlethal latitude.)
