headline: Clinton Calls on Bush to ‘Extricate’ U.S. From Iraq
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Jan. 28 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called today for President Bush to “extricate our country” from Iraq by the time he leaves office in 2009, and she also said she knew enough about “evil and bad men” to protect the country from its enemies.

headline: Summers for Teenagers That Enhance Résumés
text: There was a time when teenagers could spend the summer doing nothing more challenging than working at a camp or filing papers at Dad’s office and still get into Harvard. No more. Now they had better be polishing their résumés. Luckily, they can do it in places that give them a taste of adventure and offer a break from home.

headline: Building ‘Green’ a Luxury? Not at All, Habitat Shows
text: HARTFORD

headline: Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico Remind Travelers: No Passports Needed
text: With new rules now in effect requiring that all United States residents carry a passport when they return from the Caribbean, Mexico or Canada, tourism officials in Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands are busily reminding American travelers that they can still visit those islands without a passport.

headline: With Apologies, Nuclear Power Gets a Second Look
text: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: San Francisco: Tartine Bakery
text: In a city known for bakeries, bread and breakfasts, the scene just continues to get better. For whatever reason — gold miners ate big breakfasts? the hills build morning appetites? the sea air? — San Francisco has always had breakfast food worth traveling for. (The corned beef hash at Campton Place about 20 years ago was as interesting as any dinner entree served locally at the time.)

headline: Preserve the Record, However Odious (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is the Fix Worse Than the Problem?
text: CONGRESS has a new idea about how to rein in executive pay. Trouble is, the plan will squeeze midlevel workers, even as they need to save more money for retirement. And it won’t even dent top executives’ takes.

headline: Michelle Walter, Cyrus Hadidi
text: Michelle Lynn Walter, the daughter of Linda G. Walter and Robert L. Walter of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday at the One & Only Ocean Club on Paradise Island in the Bahamas to Cyrus Stephan Hadidi, the son of Grazyna Anna Hadidi and Nasser Hadidi of Colfax, Wis. The Rev. Franklin Knowles, a Methodist minister, signed the marriage license, and the Rev. Brian Scott, an Evangelical Lutheran minister and the brother-in-law of the bridegroom, led a religious ceremony.

headline: Knicks Seek Meaning After an Amazing Night
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 27  The Knicks are trying to figure out how to harness the mysterious forces that led Jamal Crawford to make 16 straight shots on his way to scoring 52 points Friday night in a 116-96 victory against the Miami Heat.

headline: Deer Hunters Spotted, and Neighbors Fret
text: For the last decade, the management of the Staten Island Golf Practice Center, off Chemical Lane in the Rossville neighborhood, has watched a group of deer steadily grow in number, grazing peacefully at the end of the driving range.

headline: 24 Rolls of Toilet Paper, a Tub of Salsa and a Plasma TV
text: SHOPPING at Costco often goes something like this: Customer comes to buy bulk necessities like toilet paper and dish detergent. Customer buys those items, as well as a pack of giant muffins, three cashmere sweaters and a power tool.

headline: In Law School, Obama Found Political Voice
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 — The peers who elected Barack Obama as the first black president of the Harvard Law Review say he was a natural leader, an impressive student, a nice guy. But in the 1990 Revue — the graduating editors’ gleeful parody of their elite publication — they said quite a bit more.

headline: Up These Stairs, You Walk With Keith Haring
text: IN an old convent on the Upper West Side, students at the Ascension School go about their ordinary business, attending classes on art or dance. But if they take the stairway to reach their destination, they will pass by something decidedly out of the ordinary: a bold mural, spanning three floors and 85 feet, by the artist Keith Haring.

headline: Lift a Wee Dram All Over Town
text: IF your knowledge of Scotch begins with Johnnie Walker and ends at “on the rocks,” a weekend spent tasting expensive single malts at whiskey bars around the city might seem pointless, even intimidating.

headline: Minneapolis: The Chambers Minneapolis
text: Rather than cloning the original art-filled Chambers boutique hotel in New York, the Midwestern outpost, which opened in September, strikes an independent profile in a gallerylike compound fashioned from two neighboring pre-1910 brick low-rise office buildings with a a courtyard-cum-lounge in between. Interiors and exteriors showcase the estimable contemporary art collection of the owner, the Minneapolis developer Ralph Burnet, helping to increase Minneapolis's emerging stature as the artiest town on the prairie.

headline: Joy Chang and William Schaaf
text: Joy Sandy Chang, a daughter of Tzen-Yuan Chang and Loh-Yi Chang of Greenville, S.C., was married in Manhattan last evening to William Sheehan Schaaf, the son of Nora Schaaf and Homer D. Schaaf of New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

headline: What Lies Beneath
text: Somewhere off the coast of Vietnam in the mid-15th century, in a stretch of cantankerous ocean where typhoons raged and pirates plied their trade, the Dragon Sea claimed a kitchen girl who cowered in the galley of a junk. The ship groaned and buckled, and as it sank the icy seawater thundered through the galley. Eventually “the girl’s struggles stopped. ... Life faded from her eyes as around her the water grew dark with depth.”

headline: Video Game Tests the Limits. The Limits Win.
text: PARK CITY, Utah

headline: In HoJo Land, the End of a 49-Year Stand
text: Waterbury

headline: In Brooklyn and Queens, Two Killings in Two Hours
text: A 34-year-old woman was stabbed to death by her companion at a Queens playground late Friday, the police said.

headline: Rookie Leaders Hear Rustle of Woods’s Footsteps in Grass
text: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 27  After two rounds of watching a rookie play the big room at the Buick Invitational, Tiger Woods finally cleared his throat Saturday on the South Course at Torrey Pines. For more than four hours, Woods elbowed his way past competitors and made a steady climb up the leader board until he had whittled a seven-stroke deficit to two.

headline: If the Time Is Right, Oil and Water Can Mix
text: BEDFORD, N.Y.

headline: The George W. Bush Library: Scholarly Mecca or $500 Million Oxymoron?
text: The news reports that President Bush’s representatives seem to be closing in on a deal to put a half-billion-dollar presidential library and policy institute at Southern Methodist University in Dallas has inspired the predictable lame jokes and references to “The Pet Goat.”

headline: From the Flats to the Pinnacle, Smith Savoring the Ride
text: BIG SANDY, Tex., Jan. 23 — Lovie Smith was a million miles from here when he realized just how far he had come.

headline: Courageous Decision at Life’s End; Embracing Diversity of Many Kinds (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gone but Hardly Forgotten, an Idol Isn’t Buried Yet, Either
text: AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 24 — More than a month after the death of the legendary soul singer James Brown, his body still has not been laid to rest, a circumstance that has dismayed his friends and bewildered residents here in the town that has honored him as a native son.

headline: Corrections
text: Editors’ Note

headline: Transit Effort Seeks Train Track Safety
text: Transit officials announced the formation of a task force yesterday to improve safety along unfenced tracks on the Metro-North Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road.

headline: Nonprofit Groups Draw a Line at Some Donors
text: In the wake of the 2004 tsunami that devastated shorelines around the Indian Ocean, the relief group Doctors Without Borders won plaudits for its decision to halt fund-raising for the disaster once it had collected enough donations to accomplish the mission it had set for itself.

headline: Three Courses for $25, All Night, Every Night
text: IT’S like Restaurant Week all year long at Gabrielle’s Brasserie in Rockville Centre. This appealing spot, formerly 22 North Park under the same owners, changed its name, its chef and its menu in late November. It now offers a three-course dinner for $25 that is sure to be a hit with patrons who love good food but don’t want to break the bank every time they eat out. That price includes everything on the menu: no exceptions, no supplements. It is offered all night — not just during “early bird” hours — every night of the week. It was even in place on New Year’s Eve.

headline: A) Sexy, B) Loud or C) Dreamy? Try D) All of the Above.
text: IMAGINE a time before alternative country. Before Americana and roots rock. Picture a corner office, sometime in the early ’80s, with record executives scratching their heads over how to market a talented singer, songwriter and guitarist from Louisiana named Lucinda Williams. Was she country? Folk? Blues? The answer of course was (and is) all of the above. A three-time Grammy winner, Ms. Williams will release “West,” her eighth studio album, on Feb. 13. A tour is scheduled to begin soon after, including a stop at Radio City Music Hall on March 23. Ms. Williams, 54, shows no signs of getting any less sexy with her lyrics or her taste in music. She recently spoke by phone with Winter Miller about what she’s listening to now.

headline: I Saw a Playhouse, My Daughter Saw a Jail
text: MY year-old grandson, Leo, wraps his arm around my neck as we leave the diner in Barre, Vt., where his mother, Anna, and my wife are having breakfast. Because Leo will not stop throwing utensils across the table, I offer to take him to a nearby hardware store to explore an environment where he cannot wreak as much havoc.

headline: Correction: Indie Rock’s Patron Saint Inspires a New Flock
text: An article on Jan. 14 about David Byrne and his song cycle based on the life of Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, misidentified the ethnicity of a singer in the production. Ganda Suthivarakom is of Thai-Chinese descent; she is not Filipino.

headline: The Maestro of Spaghetti Westerns Takes a Bow
text: ROME

headline: Big Cats
text: There are all sorts of books about lions. Accounts of lions who come to stay are always popular, as Joy Adamson discovered when she wrote “Born Free” and its sequels. These books succeed because the idea of sharing one’s life with such a creature is, at some deep level, very appealing. Then there is writing in which lion imagery is used to make a point about the human rather than the leonine situation. In such a context, the lion is symbolic of vigor, of the masculine, of the untamable. Indeed, so burdened are lions with symbolism that it’s surprising they manage to stagger even a few paces, let alone spring at their prey.

headline: At March, Worshipers Brace to Fight Closing of a Church
text: Scores of parishioners of a Catholic church in East Harlem took to the streets yesterday to protest its imminent closing, while an activist from Boston warned of a “tough fight” of vigils, lawsuits and prayers.

headline: Drug Running Helped to Feed a Bingo Habit
text: BISBEE, Ariz., Jan. 27 — Playing bingo might seem a more likely pastime for a grandmother than running drugs, but a jury found that Leticia Villareal-Garcia did one so she could afford to do the other.

headline: Atlantic City Casinos Reap Anti-Blight Funds
text: Seven years after New Jersey legalized gambling in 1977, state lawmakers created an agency called the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority to redirect some casino revenue to blighted areas in Atlantic City and across the state.

headline: Seeing Red Over the Cable Bill
text: Q I am a rent-regulated tenant in a co-op. For the last 20 years or so, the building has negotiated a bulk rate for cable services at prices that are considerably lower than the provider’s retail rates.

headline: Cut and Run
text: Boston

headline: Mortar Strike Hits Girls’ School in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 28 - The girls had just finished taking an exam at a school in the Sunni Adil neighborhood, and were gathering in an inner courtyard today when a mortar suddenly landed between them.

headline: For Adventurers: Dominica
text: Situated between the French islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique in the eastern Caribbean, Dominica (pronounced dom-in-EEK-ah) is the largest and most mountainous of the Windward Islands, with an area of nearly 290 square miles. More than half of it is covered with tropical forests offering a range of outdoor adventures. Hikers, bikers and horseback riders can explore more than 300 miles of trails that wind across valleys, past waterfalls and up mountains reaching heights of nearly 5,000 feet. There are three national parks, more than 365 rivers and streams, and at least 40 dive sites just offshore.

headline: From Tech Workers to Nurses, an Employee’s Market
text: UNEMPLOYMENT is low and the job market is strong, according to surveys. But just where are the jobs in 2007?

headline: College Booster Bias Is Delaying Minority Hiring
text: The boosters of inequity, the true power brokers of college football, feel safe staring down at a football field and seeing their reflection in the skybox glass.

headline: U.S. Citizens Killed in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 27 — Two Americans, including an elderly woman, were shot to death on Saturday afternoon by carjackers in Nairobi, the capital, according to American and Kenyan officials.

headline: A Backyard Mayan Temple May Be Doomed
text: Katonah, N.Y.

headline: Editors' Choice
text: FICTION AND POETRY | NONFICTION

headline: Saudi Officials Seek to Temper the Price of Oil
text: Saudi Arabia, which benefited immensely from record oil prices last year, has sent signals in the past two weeks that it is committed to keeping oil at around $50 a barrel — down $27 a barrel from the summer peak that shook consumers across the developed world.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: FILM

headline: Hearing Things. The Wrong Kind of Things.
text: IT happens all the time. In 2005 Till Fellner, an Austrian pianist then rising quickly, canceled an appearance in the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center because of illness. A cold? The flu? A sprained finger?

headline: Safe or Not? It Depends on Whom You Ask
text: IN the days after Bangkok’s New Year’s Eve blasts, which killed three people and came on the heels of a military coup, many travelers seemed confused about how to respond. Some travelers appeared unfazed; one Briton hurt in the bombings, Paul Hewitt, quickly told reporters, “I can’t see why this would deter me from coming back.” Expatriate friends of mine wrote that Bangkok seemed normal, and they planned to spend New Year’s Day engaged in one of Thailand’s favorite activities, cellphone shopping.

headline: Correction
text: A review on Jan. 7 about “American Fascists: The Christian Right and the War on America,” by Chris Hedges, referred incorrectly to American Veterans in Domestic Defense, a group that conducted a traveling exhibit of a Ten Commandments monument banned from the judicial building in Montgomery, Ala. The group and its tour are in fact mentioned in the book.

headline: Pamela Flood and Kenneth Morrison
text: Pamela Vanessa Flood was married yesterday to Kenneth Maxwell Morrison at Wyndham Sugar Bay, a resort on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr. officiated, assisted by his wife, the Rev. Dr. Lakeesha Walrond. Both are Baptist ministers.

headline: Awaiting the Day When Everyone Writes Software
text: BJARNE STROUSTRUP, the designer of C++, the most influential programming language of the last 25 years, has said that “our technological civilization depends on software.” True, but most software isn’t much good. Too many programs are ugly: inelegant, unreliable and not very useful. Software that satisfies and delights is as rare as a phoenix.

headline: Gentlemen of the Road
text: Chapter 1: On Discord Arising From Excessive Love of a Hat

headline: For Golfers: Jamaica
text: For years, golf was scarce in the Caribbean, where strict development rules and lack of fresh water posed major challenges. But thanks in part to a new breed of salt-tolerant turf grass, known as paspalum, golf courses have been springing up on many islands in recent years. Anguilla got its first golf course in November. Barbados, which has a total of seven courses, played host to the World Golf Championships for the first time last month. And the Dominican Republic, with a new Jack Nicklaus-designed course, Punta Espada, and half a dozen other courses planned, is quickly gaining notice among golfers as a hotspot to tee-off.

headline: A New Castro?
text: Policy analysts and pundits have been predicting for some time that the so-called unipolar moment, in which the United States stands unchallenged as the sole superpower, will soon come to an end. The debacle in Iraq has hastened this reckoning and sharpened the anxieties about America’s role in the world — perhaps especially among those who believe that the United States is a benign hegemon and that the real choice is between a Pax Americana and anarchy. But it is the recent conduct of Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s firebrand president, that offers the starkest evidence yet of the changed circumstances that American policy makers are starting to confront around the world.

headline: In Culver City, Calif., Art and Food Turn a Nowhere Into a Somewhere
text: IT'S a warm weekend evening and it looks as if a hipster convention has descended upon Culver City. On La Cienega, the sidewalk teems with the spillover from the opening of a video installation at the LAXart gallery. At Mandrake, a bar a few doors down, the D.J. plays the White Stripes while artists in distressed denim ignore the Werner Herzog movie playing in the background.

headline: On Iran, Bush Faces Haunting Echoes of Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 — As President Bush and his aides calibrate how directly to confront Iran, they are discovering that both their words and their strategy are haunted by the echoes of four years ago — when their warnings of terrorist activity and nuclear ambitions were clearly a prelude to war.

headline: Amanda Boyd, Duncan Yin
text: Amanda Morley Boyd and Duncan An-Shea Yin were married last evening in Brooklyn. The Rev. Ron Sala, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Palm House of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Protest Focuses on Iraq Troop Increase
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 — Tens of thousands of protesters converged on the National Mall on Saturday to oppose President Bush’s plan for a troop increase in Iraq in what organizers hoped would be one of the largest shows of antiwar sentiment in the nation’s capital since the war began.

headline: World View Podcast
text: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

headline: Grim Harvest
text: Organ transplants are at once the most amazing and frustrating of medical miracles. A new kidney or heart can cure someone who would otherwise die or, even in less than ideal circumstances, extend life and improve well-being. The surgical skill and pharmaceutical innovation required to make transplantation work are wonders of human ingenuity.

headline: Marooned
text: Overdue at a friend’s house for dinner, I parked the minivan in the garage and urged my daughters to get out of the car and into the house, where my wife and the baby sitter were waiting. I reached into the back seat to help my 6-year-old, Gracie, expedite her exit. Which is when she hit me in the face with the beads.

headline: A Choice for Darfur
text: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: As Authentic as They Come
text: There are diners and there are diners, but few like White’s Diner in Bridgeport, which has been owned for 30 years by the same couple — Greg and Linda Cerminara, with Greg in charge of the cooking. They kept the name White’s (for the original owner, who opened the diner around 1935), and over time the place has become a local institution.

headline: A Clean Way to Be Naughty
text: AS sinful pleasures go, breakfast in bed ranks as one of the least wicked — slothful and slightly gluttonous, but not exactly worthy of ecclesiastical condemnation. Yet people routinely deny themselves this minor indulgence, often for one of two reasons: they either feel guilty about being so lazy, or they fret about food particles falling between their sheets.

headline: The Week in Westchester
text: Village Seeks to Hold Election Despite Lawsuit

headline: New York’s Public Schools
text: New York lawmakers and the State Board of Regents are rightly nervous about the school reforms recently announced by Mayor Michael Bloomberg. The third package of reforms to hit the nation’s largest school system in five years, this one radically alters funding formulas and guts the existing management structure — roiling a system already struggling to digest earlier changes.

headline: For Clubgoers: Trinidad and Tobago
text: Just off the tip of Venezuela, Trinidad and Tobago is a small dual-island nation where three distinctive musical sounds — steel pan drum, calypso and soca — evolved. Calypso, a lilting style of Afro-Caribbean music, developed as a means of communication between African slaves. Soca is a modern form of calypso with an up-tempo beat. Half a century ago, Trinidadian percussionists invented pan by hammering out the ends of discarded oil drums. Today, visitors will find musicians practicing at so-called panyards throughout Port of Spain, the capital, especially in the weeks leading up to the island’s winter Carnival, which begins just after Christmas and runs into February.

headline: A Few Raindrops Fall on the Big-Money Collector Car Auctions in Arizona
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: A Blog Offers Insiders’ Guides to Paris
text: When in Paris, do as the Parisians do. At www.voiceofacity.com, a new blog, 10 Paris residents give visitors their insiders’ guides to the City of Light. Published by Eurostar, the company that runs the Channel Tunnel trains between Paris and London, visitors to the site can check out the voices of After8 (a 28-year-old night-life lover and graphic designer), Mama Gilda (a 40-something mother of two), and PutYourFlareOn (an American “marketing goddess” living in Paris). Others might prefer to listen to King Negrito, described as a 23-centimeter-tall leather bear that frequents the trendy parts of Paris.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: If a civilized game of croquet — complete with understated players swinging polished mallets on a manicured lawn — makes you want to scream “Anarchy!” and dive into the nearest body of water, then perhaps you’d prefer a round of extreme croquet. In addition to its traditional croquet lawn, the Somerset on Grace Bay in the Turks and Caicos (www.thesomerset.com) is now offering extreme croquet on the beach. The biggest difference between traditional versus extreme croquet is the terrain; the extreme course shifts from short grass on flat land to beaches and hills, and on occasion, mud and water. Traditional croquet rules apply to the Somerset extreme course, with a few variations, including a ball being fair play if it’s whacked into the water, each player having to complete his turn within 10 seconds, and an arm wrestling match that determines who starts the game. Reservations: (649) 946-5900. ...This month, Zagat Survey published its first New Orleans guidebook since Hurricane Katrina devastated the city in 2005. The 2007 Best of New Orleans edition includes 390 restaurants, 94 night spots, 29 attractions and 18 hotels. For top food and service in a restaurant, August won top billing; Galatoire’s received the title of most popular restaurant; and Hansen’s Sno-Bliz ranked No. 1 in the best buy category. The Windsor Court was named top hotel (www.zagat.com). ... On Feb. 20, the Grand Hotel Kempinski Geneva is set to unveil 230 rooms in time for the 77th International Motor Show in March. The hotel, on the lakefront and formerly known as the Noga Hotel, is undergoing a refurbishment that will include 200 additional rooms and conference facilities, all of which are scheduled to open in May (www.kempinski.com).

headline: Preaching From the Ballmer Pulpit
text: RUNNING a storied enterprise like Microsoft — software heavyweight, geyser of cash, corporate icon — is about much more than energy and commitment, says Steven A. Ballmer, the company’s chief executive. It is all but a calling, an article of faith.

headline: If Memory Serves
text: “NEW YORK CITY is beautiful!”

headline: The Week Ahead: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3

headline: Clinton, in Iowa, Vows to ‘Renew the Promise of America’
text: DES MOINES, Jan. 27 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began her presidential campaign road show on Saturday by making an appeal along gender lines, telling a crowd of 2,800 Iowans that she faced a “double standard” as a female candidate, yet hoped voters would look past “stories about my clothes and hair” to help her make history.

headline: Lysacek Dazzles His Way to the Men’s Title
text: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 27 – Evan Lysacek charged into his long program at the United States Figure Skating Championships, landed the first quad jump of his career – to go with eight triple jumps – and brought the Spokane Arena crowd to a thunderous celebration in winning his first national title Saturday night.

headline: Federer Makes It Look Easy, Winning 10th Grand Slam
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 – At least there is history for Roger Federer to play against, because for the moment, no man is much of a match.

headline: By the Seat of Their Pants
text: The design for a Levi’s pocket, first used 133 years ago, has become the biggest legal battleground in U.S. fashion.

headline: C.E.O.’s Drive On Thin Ice
text: What do the world’s most discriminating people do for fun here, when they’re not listening to Bono talk about debt relief? There’s skiing, of course, but the real thrill seekers sign up for the Audi Safe Driving Course (a.k.a. spinning out in really expensive cars on a sheer ice course).

headline: Giuliani Visits New Hampshire
text: In a visit to the bellwether state, former Mayor Giuliani courted New Hampshire Republicans and seemed to come closer than ever to declaring a presidential run.

headline: Hillary Clinton Goes to Iowa
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took her presidential campaign to Iowa for the first time.

headline: Sundance Denouement
text: The Bagger posted an item yesterday afternoon that “Grace Is Gone” had won the Grand Jury Prize, based on information from a very reliable source. Oops. It is nice to be first, but better to be right.

headline: Trapped Inside a Movie
text: The Toledo Blade reminds readers that the Battle of Iwo Jima was more than a subject for two films this year, running interviews with Robert Lauer, 86, and Thomas Maloney, 85, two American soldiers who survived the battle. The men watched “Letters From Iwo Jima” with a Blade reporter and talked about their experiences.

headline: Turn Around, Look at Me
text: Driving up La Cienega in Los Angeles, the Bagger saw a billboard with the by-now iconic image of the three Dreamettes facing their audience, with their backs to the viewer.

headline: Is This Thing On?
text: The Bagger got up and ran the length of his body just to make sure he is in shape for the carpet at the Screen Actor Guild awards later today. Amidst the hullabaloo, which may or may not signify much for the Oscars, the cast of the “Mary Tyler Moore” show will be reuniting for the first time since television still had tubes in them.

headline: A Heroic Disaster
text: THERE is evidently something in the British character that relishes a really solid military reverse. Many more hearts, among the island race, are set pounding by the gallant fiasco of the Light Brigade than even by Waterloo or Trafalgar. George MacDonald Fraser has made a fortune out of chronicling the numberless heroic drubbings to which, from Afghanistan to Zululand, British armies have been subjected. Nobody can quite decide whether the Somme in 1916 was a victory or a defeat, because some things indeed do lie too deep for tears.

headline: Why We Travel
text: "My wife says, ‘We travel to all these places around the world, and there’s so much beauty here in the United States.’"

headline: ‘Arlington Park’
text: All night the rain fell on Arlington Park.

headline: ‘Dragon Sea’
text: THE FALKLAND ISLANDS were a lonely place in which to grow up, and young Mensun Bound was often left to his own devices. With only a few hundred settlers scattered across Britain's desolate outpost in the South Atlantic, there were not many other children his age. Whenever the bitter winds and slashing sleet allowed, Mensun would walk over the beaches and low-lying hills, all featureless save for sheltering penguins and windblown huddles of sheep, to sit on the westernmost rocks and watch the sea.

headline: ‘John Osborne’
text: I may be a poor playwright, but I have the best view in England-  John Osborne at home in Shropshire

headline: Romney Appeals to Core Audience
text: Fresh off a trip to Iowa, Mitt Romney came to Washington on Saturday night to face another contingent that he needs to court as he seeks the Republicans’ presidential nomination in 2008. As the post-dessert course at the National Review Institute’s Conservative Summit dinner, the former Massachusetts governor sought to clarify his views on social issues — a subject that has become of considerable concern among conservative Republicans in recent weeks.

headline: Los Angeles Steps Up Antigang Efforts
text: Growing violence among blacks and Latinos has brought renewed promises from the city to reverse a surge of gang violence.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: If readers have been considering picking up a little conversational Hindi, they would probably do well not to begin with the sample list of words in the Jan. 7 review of “Sacred Games,” a novel by Vikram Chandra that sprinkles untranslated Hindi throughout its English text. Indian readers pointed out that while most of the Hindi terms in the review were innocuous, several were in fact obscene — suitable for Chandra’s tough-guy characters, no doubt, but not for the Book Review, where editors failed to check the meaning of the words in the novel’s glossary.

headline: Plot Points
text: Some small stuff that looms large in Baggerville. Item one: It is raining on and off in Los Angeles and you’d think a plague of locusts had been let loose. Never mind that it rains so infrequently here that the roads get slick because they are paved with exhaust residue; the ability of people here to find ambient moisture personally offensive leaves the Bagger deeply amused.

headline: 2008: Huckabee, Biden, Clinton, Hunter, Dodd
text: So, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas — of Hope, Ark., mind you — announced his presidential ambitions today on NBC’s “Meet the Press”:

headline: The Actor’s Workout
text: The Bagger just had a very close encountere with a life-size version of the so-called “Actor,” the statue that the Screen Actors Guild gives out to the winners. He doesn’t want to spoil anything for you in terms of tonight’s broadcast, but let’s just say that unlike his pal Oscar — the Bagger thinks they work out at the same gym — the Actor has been doing some serious reps on the Stairmaster. Withoiut getting into a lot of specifics, howerver he can say that the backside of the actor brings new meaning to the phrase, “Buns of steel.” Same principle, but a far more gilded look.

headline: Davos 2007 in Review
text: Politicians, tycoons and big thinkers climbed into limousines, trains and private planes on Sunday as this year’s World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, came to an end.

headline: Tale of Two Clinton Campaigns
text: Hillary Clinton's message during her trip to Iowa reflected lessons learned from her 2000 Senate race in New York.

headline: Early Warning
text: The red carpet set was in the midst of being struck,the show is not five minutes old, and Helen Mirren has her first award of the night — one more to add to her growing collection.

headline: To Resign or Not to Resign?
text: Under what conditions should one resign? I ask the question in the context of the resignation from the Carter Center of 14 members of its board of councilors. (The full board numbers more than 200.) The reason they give is disagreement with the assertions made by President Carter in his new book, “Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid,” which argues that Israel bears a large share of the responsibility for the failure to achieve peace in the Middle East. In a letter to the former president, the resigning councilors declared that while the center they admired and supported “has always played the useful and constructive role of honest broker and mediator between warring parties,” the former president’s new book showed him to be abandoning his “historic role of broker in favor of becoming an advocate for one side.” That side is of course the Palestinian side, and it is that side’s views – complete with assertions of fact the letter writers find “false” and even “malicious” – that are now, they assert, being voiced by Carter.Originally I had thought to include this controversy in last week’s post on the controversy at Southern Methodist University over whether the George W. Bush library and museum should be housed on its campus. I argued (on Jan. 22) that those protesting the library because they were outraged by Bush’s policies made the mistake of conflating the question of the ethics of his administration with the question of whether the records of that administration were a valuable addition to a campus’s intellectual resources. The university (this or any other), I said, does not have a social or moral agenda that might lead it to reject materials because it disapproves of the values they embody. Universities have only an academic agenda (made up in equal parts of teaching and research), and being faithful to it does not require, and indeed precludes, making moral or political judgments on public figures. Therefore, I concluded, faculty members have no reason to be in a situation of estrangement from their university just because it welcomes the archives of a president whose actions they deplore.

headline: Reading His Reviews
text: Eddie Murphy took the male actor in a supporting role award and this time when he stepped up to the mic, he was all honey and hosannas, as opposed to his borderline crabbiness at the Globes. He thanked everybody but the janitor in a speech that was short on bluster and long on graciousness. The SAG win signals abiding support among the actors, by far the biggest guild in Academy. This man will not be stopped.

headline: Overheard
text: Helen Mirren and Jeremy Irons exited the interview room together after a nice little speech on the intrinsic value of awards.

headline: And Then There’s That
text: Back in the press room, Eddie Murphy, when asked if he was disappointed that “Dreamgirls” had not been not nominated for best picture, paused before answering.

headline: Speaking of  Déjà Vu
text: Helen Mirren, accepting her second award of the night, this time for female actor in a leading role, used almost the same speech, thanking the writers, “because without those words, none of us could do what we do.” Guess that bore repeating.

headline: Little Miss Juggernaut?
text: For most of the night, the cast of “Little Miss Sunshine” sat still and smiled while others picked up the hardware. Alan Arkin, who the Bagger picked to win, did not, and neither did the funny, frothy Abigail Breslin. But at the end of the night, when everyone was rushing to finish the show on time, the bright yellow lvan pulled up to the stage and drove away with the best ensemble award.

headline: A Story Going Forward
text: It is easy to overestimate the value of a backstory when it comes to awards, because voters, no matter what the role, tend to react what they see on the screen.

headline: The Queen Reigns
text: Helen Mirren, speaking in the press room, on her second award of the night, this time, for her lead role in “The Queen” — she was also had a two-fer at the Globes — and probably not her last of the season: “Déjà vu is funny, I am not saying it took my by surprise, but it took me by something. It has been kind of a tsunami effect.”

headline: Women Feeling Freer to Suggest ‘Vote for Mom’
text: For a long time women seeking high office were advised to play down their softer, domestic side. But today, many political strategists say, motherhood and a focus on children can become one more political asset to be showcased.

headline: Women Feeling Freer to Suggest ‘Vote for Mom’
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 — Some women were struck by the politics of maternity practiced by Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in recent weeks, the imagery and stagecraft that highlighted their roles as mothers and/or grandmothers.

headline: West African Religion Lends a Spiritual Framework to a Jazz Exploration
text: “I hope you know this is a rehearsal,” said Cassandra Wilson near the close of her first set at the Stone on Saturday night. “No, seriously,” she added. “We just got together today.”

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ Banked on Best Picture, and Lost
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 — Oscar theorists all have their notions about the failure of “Dreamgirls” to get a best picture nomination last week, despite eight other nominations for Academy Awards and an all-out drive by its backers for top honors.

headline: Russia Turns to Spin to Redefine Itself and Reassure the West
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 28 — Russia’s elite players came to the World Economic Forum high in the Swiss Alps with a mission. At a meeting as much about posturing and politics as it is about business and trade, Moscow’s emissaries were here to say loudly that their country was not the bully its detractors depicted it to be.

headline: Yes, Tonal. Have a Problem With That?
text: It seems strange, so many decades after the postwar avant-garde first gathered in Darmstadt, Germany, how often the words unabashedly and tonal are still linked. Given that composers now enthusiastically write in wildly diverse idioms, calling a piece “unabashedly tonal” seems almost as odd as referring to a work as “bashfully dissonant.”

headline: Blog Traffic Grows, and It’s Mostly Male
text: Over the last few years, as newspaper Web sites have started to maintain blogs, there have been plenty of setbacks. A Washington Post blog was shut down last January after commenters flooded it with vitriol, and the author of a Los Angeles Times blog was caught commenting on his own posts under a pseudonym.

headline: Barbaro Faces a New Peril After Surgery
text: Barbaro’s long, difficult convalescence has taken a significant turn for the worse after a risky operation was performed on his shattered right hind leg.

headline: Will Bush’s Health Plan Work? (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hubble Telescope Loses Its Survey Camera
text: The Hubble Space Telescope is flying partially blind across the heavens because of a short circuit in its most popular instrument, the advanced camera for surveys.

headline: At Davos, the Squabble Resumes on How to Wire the Third World
text: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 28 — Here in the Swiss mountains at the World Economic Forum, the annual conclave of world leaders, concerns over a growing digital divide this year have taken a back seat to the challenge of climate change.

headline: Contemporary Dominance Secure, Federer Is Now Measured by the Ages
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 — At least there is history for Roger Federer to play against, because for the moment, no man is much of a match.

headline: In the Buzz of Club Activity, a Cluster of Singleton Queens
text: Players in duplicate tournaments win only master points, no prizes. And they strive to attain the rank of life master. You must gain 300 points, at least 50 being silver points, which can be won only in sectional tournaments. Earlier this month the Greater New York Bridge Association ran a “STaC” — for Sectional Tournaments at Clubs — week. These pair events were played simultaneously in the clubs across the city.

headline: Money Trail Often Murky in Small-Town Courts
text: As court clerk in the western New York village of Perry, Ruth Milks was in a prime spot to see the kind of big money that moves through the state’s smallest courts. Her husband was the village justice, and Mrs. Milks — a former justice herself — collected the fines and fees.

headline: City That Loves Mass Transit Looks to the Sky for More
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 28 — The view from the new silver spheres strung across the sky here will not always be as stunning as it was on this sunbeam weekend: Mount Hood regal in the late light, Mount St. Helens a mystery in the distance, the downtown skyline sharp but self-effacing, smart enough to know its place amid mightier peaks.

headline: Readers Call Newspapers. These Are Their Stories.
text: To respond to the challenge posed by digital media, newspaper executives are being told to listen to their readers. The San Francisco Chronicle is doing just that: It is posting some of the voice mail messages left for reporters and editors as audio files on its Web site, SFGate.com.

headline: A Free-Market Economist, Up by His Bootstraps
text: Milton Friedman, arguably the most influential economist of the 20th century, died in November at 94, and today the world is commemorating him. In celebration of what has officially been named Milton Friedman Day, universities, political institutes and online discussion groups around the country will conduct debates and pay tribute to his legacy.

headline: Friends Proclaim Innocence of Actor Going on Trial in Dancer’s Killing
text: Paul Cortez’s friends see him as a victim of slapdash police work, in which a young man who rose out of a poor neighborhood in the Bronx is the usual suspect. He is, they say, a shining example of the success of programs designed to send gifted but poor children to the best private schools.

headline: ‘Man Down’: When One Bullet Alters Everything
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — Staff Sgt. Hector Leija scanned the kitchen, searching for illegal weapons. One wall away, in an apartment next door, a scared Shiite family huddled around a space heater, cradling an infant.

headline: Manhattan: Sex Offenders Study
text: Of the 2,114 sex offenders who live in New York City and are listed in the state’s publicly available database, 85 percent live within five blocks of a school and 32 percent within two blocks of a school, according to a report released yesterday by Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Queens and Brooklyn. Mr. Weiner’s staff used mapping software to analyze records from the database, which was expanded in July and lists Level 2 and Level 3 sex offenders, who must register for life. (Sex offenders are assigned a risk level from 1 to 3 based on the nature of the crime, the victim’s age and an offender’s prior record.) Though there is no law that restricts where a sex offender may live, Mr. Weiner has pushed for action. In addition to seeking federal aid to study and monitor sex offenders, Mr. Weiner called for requiring offenders to notify the authorities if they have profiles on social-networking Web sites like MySpace, and if they live near schools, to submit to monitoring using global positioning satellite technology.

headline: Any Little Gems? Who Cares? Sundance Is a Hot Brand Now
text: Before it was a brand, a media circus and an adjunct of Hollywood, the Sundance Film Festival was exhilarating, a blast. It was also small.

headline: One Paper Hopes Fans of Politics Will Pay Up
text: Part of the news media’s job is to make information from people in high places more accessible to the masses. Now one newspaper has decided to restrict access to its own content, and it hopes to make some money by doing so.

headline: G.O.P. Senators Criticize Iraq Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 — Republican allies of the White House argued on the Sunday news programs that resolutions critical of President Bush’s new Iraq plan being considered by the Senate would embolden insurgents and demoralize American troops.

headline: 23-Month Campaign
text: In the old days, presidential races were one-year events. John F. Kennedy announced his candidacy on Jan. 2, 1960, and was elected that November. Earlier this month, would-be candidates who were still deciding whether to run in 2008 were being accused of reckless delay. Presidential campaign pundits were saying that if Senator Hillary Clinton had waited another minute to announce, Senator Barack Obama would have locked up every New Hampshire county committee member and hedge fund billionaire.

headline: No Pumpkin and No Dancing Broom, but Cinderella Still Finds Love
text: NEWARK, Jan. 26 — When an obscure Russian company comes to town for a one-off performance of a classical ballet, you never know what to expect. The latest example was the State Ballet Theater of Russia, the touring name of the Voronezh State Theater of Opera and Ballet, a group formed in 1961. Its presentation of Vladimir Vasiliev’s “Cinderella” at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center departed liberally from the program’s synopsis, based on Nikolai Volkov’s 1940s libretto.

headline: Weighing the Consequences of Telling Others the Truth
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Kirstein, Youth and All Those Mice Who Made Good
text: It has been said that there would have been no New York City Ballet without Lincoln Kirstein. On Saturday night the company presented “Tribute to Kirstein,” a prelude of sorts to its season-long homage in the spring, on the centenary of his birth.

headline: Harnessing the Web to Sell Online Security
text: THIRTY percent of Internet users still do not trust technology enough to buy something online. But will they use the Web to buy security software?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 21 about Mexico’s extradition of drug traffickers to the United States incorrectly described a November 2005 decision by Mexico’s Supreme Court that cleared the way for the extraditions. The court ruled that extraditions could proceed if the accused faced a possible life sentence without parole, which Mexican courts had previously held violated the country’s constitution. The court did not overturn the prohibition on extraditions in which the accused would face the death penalty. (None of the accused drug traffickers extradited on Jan. 19 face the death penalty, Justice Department officials say.)

headline: Lady Tar Heels Exact Revenge While Remaining Undefeated
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 28  At the Final Four in Boston last April, the North Carolina women’s basketball team saw a night full of promise dissolve into a disquieting mess.

headline: A Survivor of Polio Fights Unrelenting Pain With Faith, and a Good Night’s Rest
text: In high school, Laurence Cantore’s nickname was Romeo.

headline: Feeding Frenzy for a Big Story, Even if It’s False
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Jeffrey T. Kuhner, whose Web site published the first anonymous smear of the 2008 presidential race, is hardly the only editor who will not reveal his reporters’ sources. What sets him apart is that he will not even disclose the names of his reporters.

headline: Levi’s Turns to Suing Its Rivals
text: United States Patent and Trademark No. 1,139,254 is not much to look at: a pentagon surrounding a childlike drawing of a seagull in flight.

headline: 3 Men Killed and 9 Are Hurt in Brooklyn and Bronx Disputes
text: Three men were killed and nine others were injured in about two hours yesterday morning in three disputes in Brooklyn and the Bronx, the police said.

headline: Shiite Cult Aimed to Kill Top Clerics in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 29 — The gunmen who battled Iraqi and American forces near Najaf on Sunday were members of a Shiite cult that planned to storm the city during a religious festival and kill the nation’s top Shiite clerics, Iraqi officials said today.

headline: Chinese Children and Adoption (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Totals
New CDs
text: CLAP YOUR HANDS SAY YEAH

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,061 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

headline: New School Bus Routes Confuse New Yorkers
text: George A. Bonanno, a Manhattan professor, was startled to learn that under New York City’s new school bus routes that took effect today he would have to deposit his two children at separate bus stops about a mile apart, at different times, only so they could be ferried to the same elementary school.

headline: Its Wild Heart Broken, a City, Like Its Eagles, Rebuilds
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 24 — No matter how high the office towers and condominiums get in this fast-growing city, those who live here still cling to the laid-back way of life that draws so many to Canada’s west coast, where spandex and a yoga roll are as common a sight as a suit and briefcase.

headline: Sounds of the Past Echo in Miami
text: Lombardi, Namath, Swann, Bradshaw, Montana, Young and Elway. Each famous and familiar name put his imprint on a Super Bowl in Miami, where XLI will engrave another name into pro football history Sunday night.

headline: Scientists Gather to Finalize Climate Report
text: PARIS, Jan 29 — Scientists from across the world gathered here today to hammer out the final details of an authoritative report on climate change that is expected to project centuries of rising temperatures and sea levels unless curbs are placed on emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.

headline: Iranian Reveals Plan to Expand Role in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — Iran’s ambassador to Baghdad outlined an ambitious plan on Sunday to greatly expand its economic and military ties with Iraq — including an Iranian national bank branch in the heart of the capital — just as the Bush administration has been warning the Iranians to stop meddling in Iraqi affairs.

headline: Barbaro Is Euthanized After Struggle With Injury
text: Barbaro, who rocketed to a six-and-a-half-length victory in the Kentucky Derby last May but sustained a catastrophic injury two weeks later in the Preakness Stakes, was euthanized early this morning in Pennsylvania.

headline: Man Sold Drugs to Two Accused in His Death, Friend Says
text: FISHKILL, N.Y., Jan. 28 — Manuel A. Morey kept his drugs in a lockbox under his bed, his friend said. When his three young boys were asleep, the people he sold cocaine to could use drugs in any room of his two-story house on Route 82. When the boys were awake, his customers had to go to the bedroom and close the door, or head to the basement.

headline: In Opera’s Famous Pair of One-Acts, Tenor Doubles His Workload
text: The traveling sideshow of “Pagliacci” added a strongman act to its clowns, acrobats and derailed theatrical entertainments on Friday night. Salvatore Licitra was scheduled to sing Leoncavallo’s Canio at the Metropolitan Opera, while Frank Porretta would be Mascagni’s Turiddu in “Cavalleria Rusticana.” On Thursday Mr. Porretta reported in sick. Rather than let a cover singer be called for, Mr. Licitra said he would sing both operas.

headline: On a Trip Through History, Students Join Freedom Riders
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 28 — More times than he remembers, La’Markus Cook has traveled south on Interstate 65 from Nashville, where he attends American Baptist College, to his home outside Montgomery, Ala. But never, he said, as he did this weekend.

headline: Bronx: Man Found Dead in Room
text: A 53-year-old man was found dead yesterday morning in his small room inside a nine-story building run by a nonprofit group in Morrisania, the police said. The man, whom the authorities did not identify, was killed by blunt trauma to the torso, the police said. The killing occurred shortly before 4 a.m. at a building, known as Webster House, at 1075 Webster Avenue, the police said. The building is run by the group, Volunteers of America, under an agreement with the city. Residents said the man, who they said was named Thomas and was also known as Mac, was found lying with the door to his room open. “I heard rumbling and fighting,” said Umberto Sanchez, who lives in a nearby room. A spokeswoman for Volunteers of America referred calls to the city’s Department of Homeless Services. Nobody at that agency could be reached yesterday.

headline: Egyptian Paper Accuses Iranians of Complicity in Envoy’s Death
text: CAIRO, Jan. 28  A front-page article in Egypt’s semiofficial state newspaper on Sunday accused Iranian intelligence of involvement in the 2005 killing of Egypt’s ambassador to Iraq.

headline: Girls’ Friendship, Renewed Choreographically
text: Two young girls are best, best friends. They grow up, grow apart, then rediscover their friendship as adults. Oh, and one of them is Claire Danes.

headline: Nasty Fall at Games Isn’t Keeping Kildow Down
text: KITZBÜHEL, Austria, Jan. 28 — It has been almost a year since Lindsey Kildow had one of the ugliest Olympic downhill crashes since Hermann Maier flew upside down into worldwide fame at the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan. She returned to competition a few days later, but was badly bruised and failed to win a medal.

headline: 250 Are Killed in Major Iraq Battle
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — At least 250 militants were killed and an American helicopter was shot down in violent clashes near the southern city of Najaf on Sunday, Iraqi officials said.

headline: Feminist Art Finally Takes Center Stage
text: “Well, this is quite a turnout for an ‘ism,’ ” said the art historian and critic Lucy Lippard on Friday morning as she looked out at the people filling the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater at the Museum of Modern Art and spilling into the aisles. “Especially in a museum not notorious for its historical support of women.”

headline: Finding Consolation in a Consolidation
text: ALBANY — David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, has been reading fine print lately.

headline: 3 Weeks to Pitchers and Molinas
text: The energetic, young children scampered along a bumpy dirt infield, chased baseballs around an outfield that was missing almost as much grass as it contained and sidestepped a leaning light tower that was a miniature Tower of Pisa. Still, to them, this tattered field in Vega Alta, P.R., is hallowed ground.

headline: Restless Quick-Draw McGraws
text: Impatience is a virtue, and an organizing principle, for Deerhoof, the San Francisco band that headlined at Irving Plaza on Friday night.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Novelty Rules the Box Office

headline: Gump Worsley, 77, Hall of Famer Who Won Four Titles, Is Dead
text: Gump Worsley, the pudgy but agile Hall of Fame goaltender who spent a decade with the Rangers, played on four Stanley Cup championship teams with the Montreal Canadiens and was among the last goalies to play without a mask, died Saturday in Beloeil, Quebec. He was 77.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC BAROMETERS Two critical economic events are scheduled to take place this week. First, on Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to meet and issue its decision on short-term interest rates; expectations are that the federal funds rate will remain at 5.25 percent. Investors have been hoping that rates would be lowered, but positive economic reports last week about new home sales and big factory orders have made that less likely. On Friday, the government is expected to report on unemployment for December, with forecasters predicting an increase of 140,000 jobs.

headline: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Vocal Minority Wants the Stock Tables Back
text: In an effort to survive industrywide financial straits, many newspapers have made cuts both large and small, reducing newsroom staff, paper sizes and even the daily printed stock listings that are readily available online. But after torrents of reader complaints, two major papers said last week that they would restore some of those listings.

headline: Congress, the Constitution and War: The Limits on Presidential Power
text: President Bush doesn’t seem to care that Congress wants a bigger role in guiding the Iraq war. Talking about his plan to send in 20,000 additional troops, he said on “60 Minutes” that he knows Congress can vote against it, “but I’ve made my decision and we’re going forward.”

headline: Ex-Bush Aide Contradicts Libby on C.I.A. Agent
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — The former White House spokesman Ari Fleischer today contradicted the account of I. Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheney’s former chief of staff, on when Mr. Libby first learned the identity of a C.I.A. agent.

headline: The Sum of All Ears
text: For those hoping for real action on global warming and energy policy, the State of the Union address was a downer. There had been hints and hopes that the speech would be a Nixon-goes-to-China moment, with President Bush turning conservationist. But it ended up being more of a Nixon-bombs-Cambodia moment.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Trims Its Profit Forecast
text: Deutsche Telekom, Europe’s largest telephone company, cut its forecast for profit this year as competition in Germany intensifies and the dollar’s decline against the euro erodes revenue in the United States.

headline: Respect Is Nice, but Principals Want a Raise
text: Alejandro Soto, the principal of Intermediate School 184 in the South Bronx, is willing to accept the wider authority Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants to give to school leaders. He is willing to weather further reorganization of the school system. He is willing to be held responsible for his students’ scores and to face the scrutiny of outside evaluators and surveys of parents.

headline: The Prince, in the City, Dribbles and Scores
text: Prince Charles and Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, were a bit later than expected in arriving at the gymnasium of the Harlem Children’s Zone yesterday, where two teams of seventh and eighth graders were nearing the end of a basketball scrimmage.

headline: Skiercross a Great Place to Bump Into Olympians
text: ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 28  Added to the Winter X Games 10 years ago as an appeal to youth, skiercross has instead come to be dominated by retired Alpine racers creating a second act to their competitive careers.

headline: Liz Renay, Cult Film Star and Stripper With Mob Connections, Dies at 80
text: Liz Renay, a boisterous, buxom cult film actress who worked as a stripper, wrote several books and got a little too close to some mobsters in the late 1950s, leading to a three-year prison term, died last Monday near her home in Las Vegas. She was 80.

headline: Death Upstate Renews Phone-Tower Controversy
text: An accident on Thursday that resulted in a Brooklyn man freezing to death while he and his wife were trapped in their car for 32 hours has renewed the discussion for cellphone service along a mountainous stretch of highway in Adirondack Park.

headline: Hasbro Severs Relationship With Grey After 30 Years
text: Hasbro is ending its relationship with Grey Worldwide in New York after 30 years by consolidating the creative account for its toys and games at Uproar, an agency in Dallas and New York that specializes in campaigns aimed at children and teenagers.

headline: Giants to Name Palmer as Quarterbacks Coach
text: In trying to create a brighter future for quarterback Eli Manning, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin continues to reach into his own past.

headline: The City That Never Walks
text: FOR the past two decades, New York has been an inspiration to other American cities looking to revive themselves. Yes, New York had a lot of crime, but somehow it also still had neighborhoods, and a core that had never been completely abandoned to the car. Lately, though, as far as pedestrian issues go, New York is acting more like the rest of America, and the rest of America is acting more like the once-inspiring New York.

headline: The True State of C.S.I. Justice
text: Modern DNA testing is steadily uncovering a dark history of justice denied. More than 190 DNA exonerations in 18 years show ever more alarming patterns of citizens, wrongly convicted, suffering in prison. Consider the eight felons finally exonerated through DNA challenges in New York State in just the last 13 months. Or the 12 people who had to fight long and hard to prove their innocence in Dallas County, Tex., alone in the past five years. New York and Texas are, in fact, the leading states in yielding these hard-fought exonerations. This is hardly a credit to their justice systems since the victories are won by dedicated pro bono lawyers, not by state monitors charged with finding injustice.

headline: Iraqi Forces in Fierce Battle With Gunmen
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — Iraqi forces backed by American helicopters and tanks battled hundreds of gunmen hiding in a date palm orchard near the southern city of Najaf on Sunday, exchanging fire for 15 hours in what appeared to be one of Iraq’s deadliest battles in years, Iraqi officials said.

headline: Miles and Decades Away, Quiet Queens Neighbor Is Linked to a Violent Era
text: On Aug. 29, 1971, two armed men, members of the Black Liberation Army, walked into a San Francisco police station.

headline: Queens Officer Stops Fight and Shoots One Assailant
text: An off-duty police lieutenant interrupted two men beating a third on a corner in Jackson Heights, Queens, early yesterday, and shot and wounded one of the assailants, the police said.

headline: In Los Angeles, Antigang Efforts Start on the Street
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 — At twilight on Friday, in the heart of the territory of the latest notorious Los Angeles gang, a woman in a passing car calls out a tip to Officer Dan Robbins, sending him racing toward a corner and a man he believes is a member of the 204th Street gang.

headline: Billboards That Know You by Name
text: Each day, it seems, marketers go further in their quest to deliver messages so engaging and personalized that one cannot help feeling special. The latest step will be seen today in four cities when Mini USA begins delivering custom messages to Mini Cooper owners on digital signs the company calls “talking” billboards.

headline: Courts Turn to Wikipedia, but Selectively
text: When a court-appointed special master last year rejected the claim of an Alabama couple that their daughter had suffered seizures after a vaccination, she explained her decision in part by referring to material from articles in Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia.

headline: Suicide Bomb Kills 3 in Bakery in Israel
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 — After nine months without a suicide bombing in Israel, a Palestinian walked from Egypt across the open desert border, hitched a ride from a suspicious Israeli motorist and then blew himself up today inside a bakery in the Red Sea resort town of Eilat, Israeli officials said.

headline: Tech Barons Take on New Project: Energy Policy
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 — President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valley’s technology investors.

headline: Silicon Valley Rebounds, Led by Green Technology
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 — After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology.

headline: Acting Governor Gets Permanent Portrait in Trenton
text: TRENTON, Jan. 29 — Richard J. Codey’s son Kevin thought the bright smile was just right. His wife, Mary Jo, agreed but suggested that his teeth were not quite as white in reality.

headline: A Public Memorial
text: For a while, it seemed as if the emotional issue of how to place the names of the dead at the 9/11 memorial had finally been resolved. And for nearly everyone, including most of the 9/11 families, it has, thanks to a compromise engineered last month by Mayor Michael Bloomberg. But a small group of victims’ families has regrettably decided to mount a public campaign against the compromise.

headline: Marilyn Horne Puts Her Protégés on Parade in Song
text: The standing ovation came before a note of music had been sung. The Marilyn Horne Foundation’s annual gala recital is supposed to focus on song, but it also focuses on Marilyn Horne. Looking radiant in gold lace, apparently undaunted by a year’s struggle with cancer, she played host to Friday evening’s event at Zankel Hall, a night after giving a master class there, with every bit of her star flair. And at her first entrance the audience stood, with applause and shouts of “Brava,” to greet her.

headline: In Politics, the Camera Never Blinks (or Nods)
text: BEYOND its fulfillment of a constitutional requirement, the president’s annual State of the Union address has come to provide much pomp. It’s a prime-time gala where Washington’s best and brightest gather for an evening in the media spotlight, and where the nation tunes in with varying degrees of interest, cynicism or boredom at the bloated spectacle of it all.

headline: Shell Hits Baghdad Girls’ School, Killing 5 Students
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 28 — The girls had just finished taking an exam and were gathering in an inner courtyard at a school in a mainly Sunni section of western Baghdad on Sunday when a mortar shell crashed down.

headline: In Iowa, Candidate Clinton Takes a New Tack, and Talks
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Jan. 28 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was in a Cedar Rapids living room crammed with Iowa voters on Saturday night when a voice from the back asked why the Clintons were such polarizing figures in American politics. The room grew still, except for the crackle of the fireplace.

headline: Opposition Party Barred From Regional Vote
text: A summary of the leading articles in Russian newspapers on Monday.

headline: N.Y. Officials Seek $50 Million to Upgrade Courts
text: ALBANY, Jan. 29 — New York State’s top court officials plan to ask the Legislature for at least $50 million over five years to upgrade the state’s threadbare system of town and village courts, more than five times the amount they had previously discussed, the state’s chief administrative judge said today.

headline: A Serbian Region Unravels With Its Textile Industry
text: LESKOVAC, Serbia — The crumbling factory walls and idle smokestacks that dominate this town are replicated across Eastern Europe: symbols of once proud industrial centers that fell into decline almost as soon as the Berlin Wall came down.

headline: At a Position Known for Greatness, Pretty Good Can Be Enough
text: MIAMI, Jan. 28 — On one side of the field Sunday will be a quarterback who completed more passes this season than Joe Namath in 1968, for more yards than Roger Staubach in 1977, at a higher percentage than Johnny Unitas in 1970.

headline: Ex-Arkansas Governor Joins Race for G.O.P. Nomination
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas announced Sunday that he was forming a presidential exploratory committee, mounting an underdog campaign for the Republican nomination with “a message of hope and optimism for restoring America.”

headline: With Quad, Lysacek Gives U.S. Men a Lift
text: SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 28  With his spectacular performance in the long program at the United States Figure Skating Championships on Saturday night, Evan Lysacek did far more than wow a crowd and a set of judges to win a national title. He helped the men’s field upstage the women’s, a rarity in a sport in which tiny girls generally dominate the spotlight.

headline: New York Investor Plans to Buy Air America
text: Air America Radio, the liberal network that filed for bankruptcy in October, said today that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell itself to Stephen L. Green, the chairman of a New York office real estate investment trust.

headline: Bernie Friedkin, 89, a Pro Boxer Who Fought Ex-Champs to Draws, Is Dead
text: Bernie Friedkin, a native of Brownsville, Brooklyn, who was known as Schoolboy and who as a professional boxer in the late 1930s and early ’40s battled many of his opponents to a draw — including three former lightweight champions — died Jan. 18 in Brooklyn. He was 89.

headline: Beyond a Shadow of a Doubt, Nights Are Noir in Fog City
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 — The orange and blue neon lights of the Castro Theater shone blurrily on the damp asphalt beneath the crisscrossing catenary wires of the streetcars. The words on the marquee in the Friday night gloom, read: “Marsha Hunt: In Person.”

headline: Google Halts ‘Miserable Failure’ Link to President Bush
text: It has been a bad month for anti-Bush snarkiness.

headline: Brooklyn: Council Endorsement
text: Representative Yvette D. Clarke, a Brooklyn Democrat who resigned from the City Council after she was elected to Congress in November, endorsed Mathieu Eugene yesterday to succeed her on the Council. Mr. Eugene, a Haitian immigrant who runs a youth recreation center in Flatbush, faces 12 other candidates in a special election on Feb. 20. At a news conference, Ms. Clarke’s mother, Una S. T. Clarke, an influential former councilwoman, and the Haitian-American Association for Progressive Action, a political group, also endorsed Mr. Eugene. His main rivals for the seat include Jesse E. Hamilton III, a Democratic district leader with support from several unions; Jennifer N. James, a political activist who raised money for Ms. Clarke’s Congressional race; and Wellington Sharpe, who runs a child care company.

headline: At Last, Television Ratings Go to College
text: For decades, Nielsen Media Research has affixed the same value to every college student watching television while away at school: zero. As a result, industry executives have complained for years that shows appealing to a younger audience have been underrated.

headline: Hollywood Parables, Retold and Rehashed
text: Tonight a show about disappointment begins just right.

headline: Tale of Survival Quickly Turns Into Lesson on Fragility of Life
text: The news out of Kennett Square, Pa., is not promising.

headline: Hollywood Monster Rampage: Art vs. Egos
text: David Mamet’s “Bambi vs. Godzilla” takes its title from a two-minute animated short (actually “Bambi Meets Godzilla”) in which the monster crushes the innocent little fawn. This would make a fine metaphor for the way the film business treats artists if it didn’t mean miscasting Mr. Mamet in Bambi’s role. As the lacerating essays in this uneven but icily hilarious collection make clear, he is far better suited to stomping on Tokyo.

headline: Rivera to Step Down as President of Powerful Union
text: Dennis Rivera, the president of New York’s largest health care union as well as its most politically powerful union, announced today that he would be stepping down, but not without issuing a broadside against Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s planned cuts in health care spending.

headline: Saudi King Invites Palestinian Factions to Talks
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 — King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia called Sunday on the rival Palestinian factions to hold emergency talks in the holy city of Mecca in the latest bid to halt some of the worst ever Palestinian internal fighting.

headline: More Than Antiwar
text: Washington

headline: Manhattan: Power Line Proposal
text: Elected officials from Manhattan and the Bronx urged Consolidated Edison yesterday to reconsider plans to install a 9.5-mile underground electric transmission line that would extend from Yonkers, along Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx, under the Harlem River and into Inwood, in northern Manhattan. In a statement, the officials said the power line would “have a severe negative impact on vital neighborhood services and residents’ overall quality of life” and identified an alternative route that they said would be less disruptive. Michael S. Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman, said that the line was essential to expand the capacity of the networks serving the area and that the proposed route was the most feasible. The State Public Service Commission is expected to decide the issue shortly.

headline: Sinn Fein Endorses Plan for Ulster Police Reforms
text: DUBLIN, Jan. 28 — Sinn Fein, the main Catholic republican party in Northern Ireland, voted Sunday to endorse the police force in the divided province, opening the way toward restoring local rule through a government shared by Protestants and Catholics.

headline: Officer in Jersey City Faces Stiffer Charge
text: A 2-year-old injured in Jersey City, when a vehicle driven by an off-duty police officer struck his mother’s car, died and the officer, who was out on bail on drunken driving charges, now faces manslaughter charges and was being sought by the police last night, officials said.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Clock Expires as Comeback by Knicks Falls Short
text: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 28 — On the play that essentially decided the game, Knicks guard Stephon Marbury did everything right defensively. He stepped around a high screen set by Ruben Patterson, Milwaukee’s muscular forward, and forced the right-handed guard Mo Williams to dribble left.

headline: Citigroup and CNBC Cozy Up
text: Commerce runs on the favor bank. That is simply how things work when the body shop owner notices that your car is running a little loud and sends you to his pal Ricky the muffler guy, or when big drug companies play nice with friendly doctors. When it comes to business, it’s a natural reflex to favor those who favor us.

headline: Nets’ Tinkering Keeps Reserves on Their Toes
text: DENVER, Jan. 28  Bostjan Nachbar said he must have heard the message 1,000 times. Mikki Moore said he was hearing it before he even arrived in New Jersey.

headline: Manhattan: Rent-to-own Stores
text: Rent-to-own stores charge exorbitant prices for televisions, appliances, mattresses and other items and disproportionately take aim at black, Hispanic and low-income consumers who have limited access to credit, according to an investigative report that the City Council released yesterday. A 1986 state law exempted rent-to-own companies from small-loan usury caps; and under the law, because the stores retain legal title to rented items until the final payment is made, the product can be repossessed if a payment is missed. Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, introduced a bill in Congress last year that would force the industry to disclose more information about prices and hidden fees, and to abide by state limits on interest and financing charges. Assemblyman J. Gary Pretlow, a Westchester Democrat, introduced a similar bill last year in the Legislature. The Council members who released the report — Maria del Carmen Arroyo of the Bronx and Leroy G. Comrie and Eric N. Gioia of Queens — said they supported both bills. Officials at Rent-A-Center of Plano, Tex., the country’s leading rent-to-own operator, did not respond to e-mail and phone messages requesting comment.

headline: Spitzer to Tie School Funds to Performance
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York said today that he would allocate more money to the state’s public education system in his 2008 budget proposal, but he said the increased spending would be tied to better results from schools, educators and students.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Wendy Arnon joined the Omnicom Media Group, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, as managing director at the Direct strategic business unit. She succeeds Tom Benelli, who left to pursue other endeavors, the agency said. Ms. Arnon had been senior vice president and media director at G2 Direct and Digital, New York, part of the Grey Global Group unit of the WPP Group.

headline: Monumental Questions
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Spin Around League
text: A look at what others are writing about:

headline: Citigroup Shells Out $1.13 Billion for Egg
text: Citigroup, moving to bolster its consumer business in the United Kingdom, said Monday it would buy Egg, the online bank, from the British insurer Prudential for 575 million pounds ($1.13 billion) in cash. Prudential, Britain’s second largest insurer, has been reviewing its underperforming British operations since last summer.

headline: Two Drug Giants Said to Consider Merger
text: Sanofi-Aventis and Bristol-Myers Squibb could announce a friendly merger deal in the next few weeks to create the world’s largest pharmaceuticals company, according to an unsourced report from the French financial newsletter La Lettre de l’Expansion. The report said a premerger deal was thought to have been signed last week.

headline: Once Rivals, European Banking Groups Become Band of Brothers
text: Four of Europe’s national lobbying groups for the investment banking industry, hoping to coordinate their responses to issues before European legislators and international regulators, plan to create a joint body called the European Forum of Securities Associations, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Altria Expected to Announce Kraft Spin-Off This Week
text: The Altria Group will formally announce its plan to spin off its Kraft Foods unit Wednesday, according to The Financial Times, marking the end of a 20-year era marked by tobacco litigation. Altria, which acquired Kraft in 1988 for $13.1 billion cash, will release details of what will be one of the largest tax-free corporate spin-offs on the day it reports fourth-quarter earnings, The newspaper said. It added that Altria is likely to spin its 88.6 percent stake in Kraft by giving its shareholders 1.46 billion Kraft shares.

headline: Deals Ahead for Traffic-Optimization Firms?
text: Riverbed Technology parlayed its ability to help speed up network traffic into last year’s hottest initial public offering. What is next for the remaining vendors? A report from The 451 Group concludes that others are more likely to join the growing list of trade sales.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Achilles Heel
text: Deutsche Bank  has a problem in equities that is not going away soon enough, says Bloomberg News. While the bank, Germany’s largest, earned more revenue last year trading bonds than any competitor except Goldman Sachs, income from stocks rose at the slowest pace of the 10 biggest securities firms, Bloomberg says, citing company reports and analysts’ estimates. Two years after he started his revamp of the equities division, the managing director, Anshu Jain, is still searching for the winning hand in the United States and a golden touch with hedge funds.

headline: Texas Pacific Preps J.Crew Offering
