text: After J.Crew‘s impressive initial public offering last summer, the Texas Pacific Group is gearing up again to sell a big part of its stake in the retailer in a move that The Deal.com estimates will bring the buyout shop’s return to seven times its original investment nine years ago.

headline: Tech Stocks Are Back (With Caveats)
text: For the first time since the Internet bubble burst at the start of this decade, technology stocks really matter – even to investors who are wary of them. Tech has turned in the worst performance of any group of stocks over the past five years, but investment managers are more bullish on tech than they are on any other segment of the economy, according to a survey by the Russell Investment Group.

headline: Mayfield Fund Cements China Venture
text: The Mayfield Fund of Menlo Park, Calif., raised a $200 million early-stage venture fund dedicated to investment in China, formalizing a two-year relationship with China’s GSR Ventures to become a general partner in GSR Ventures II. GSR Ventures II will be a Menlo Park- and Beijing-based fund to succeed GSR Ventures I, a $75 million Beijing-based fund in which Mayfield was a limited partner.

headline: Now You, Too, Can Enter the World of 007 Finance
text: Compared with buttoned-down stock jockeys at Fidelity or T. Rowe Price, hedge fund managers may be the James Bonds of the financial world. They have a reputation for being secretive risk takers who use an array of specialized financial weaponry like derivatives and short-selling. (No license to kill, of course, though their lightly regulated funds do allow managers tremendous, nonlethal latitude.)

headline: 3i Walks Away from Countrywide After Rebuff
text: A British buyout shop, the 3i Group, doesn’t seem to be having much luck lately closing deals on its home turf. On Friday 3i walked away from its proposed acquisition of the British real estate concern, Countrywide, after shareholders rejected its 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) offer, without further raising its 490 pence a share bid. The private equity shop’s offer garnered 57.8 percent of votes at the extraordinary meeting, falling short of the 75 percent needed under British takeover rules. On Jan. 18, a British support services group, Enterprise, also rejected a 528 million pound offer from 3i Group, arguing the proposal undervalued the company.

headline: Greenlight Files Suit Claiming Loan Fraud
text: Greenlight Capital, a hedge fund that has been locked in a dispute with Allied Capital, filed a lawsuit on behalf of the United States alleging that Allied’s Business Loan Express unit submitted fraudulent loan documents to the Small Business Administration. Last week, after a former executive at Business Loan Express was indicted in Michigan, Greenlight called on Allied to replace its management team.

headline: Sterling Stops By Fairway to Pick Up a Stake
text: Sterling Investment Partners has agreed to buy a majority stake in Fairway Markets, one of New York City’s best-known food institutions, in a deal that The Deal.com reports is worth about $150 million. CapitalSource Finance is providing $87 million of debt financing, and Sterling is putting in about $50 million of equity, The Deal said. Fairway’s managers will retain a significant stake. From its roots as a produce market on the city’s Upper West Side, the chain has morphed to become a much larger, specialty food purveyor to the city’s foodies, offering fresh fruits and vegetable and gourmet fare.

headline: Gap Is in Need of a Niche
text: As buyout firms cast an eye over Gap and the retailer’s interim chief executive, Robert Fisher, passes out memos to improve business, The New York Times looks at at the anachronism that is the Gap: a single chain, selling only its own brand, with one point of view, chasing shoppers from birth to death. Mr. Fisher passed out a memo last week entitled “How we’ll be great again,” according to The New York Post. But retail analysts, it seems, have their own list of how the struggling chain could bring back its cachet. First, they told The Times, the chain could start by shrinking. Next, its should experiment with brands. And finally, they said, Gap could focus on a narrow group of consumers, and tailor clothing to meet their needs.

headline: SunPower Executive Accused of Insider Trading
text: As SunPower announced explosive growth in the fourth quarter Thursday, the solar-power company also disclosed that a senior-level employee is under federal scrutiny for actions he took while working for a former employer. Peter Aschenbrenner, currently vice president of marketing, has been accused of playing a role in the bankrupt AstroPower‘s “allegedly improper recognition of revenue,” and regulators accuse him of insider trading, according to SunPower’s amended quarterly filing.

headline: Comcast’s Web of Ventures
text: Comcast‘s venture-capital arm, Comcast Interactive Capital, is helping the company create an ecosystem of businesses that advance new cable technologies and, if all goes well, boost Interactive Capital’s bottom line. The Philadelphia Inquirer takes a look at the venture, which backs about six to eight start-ups a year with initial investments ranging from $2 million to $10 million.

headline: For Web 2.0 Start-Ups, the Fat Lady Is Waiting
text: The scores of Web 2.0 start-ups trying to hit the MySpace–YouTube jackpot may be living on borrowed time, says BusinessWeek. The magazine predicts that 2007 will be the make-or-break year for these businesses and to make it, they are going to have to put their money where their mouths are. That means raising significant money to spend on nuts and bolts.

headline: Proxy Adviser Gets Behind Blackstone in Equity Office Bid
text: The Blackstone Group‘s $38.3 billion bid for the Equity Office Properties Trust won another supporter Sunday when a proxy adviser, Institutional Shareholder Services, said it had recommended that its shareholders vote for the buyout shop’s proposed merger, dealing a blow to a rival offer from a group headed by Vornado Realty Trust.

headline: Monotype Imaging Files for Stock Offering
text: Monotype Imaging Holdings, a maker of text-imaging software, filed with regulators Friday for an initial public offering of as much as $135 million in stock. Monotype, a former unit of Agfa, is backed by a private equity firm, TA Associates.

headline: Silicon Valley Rebounds, Led by Green Technology
text: After five years of job losses, Silicon Valley is hiring again. The turnaround coincides with a huge increase of investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology. In Silicon Valley, investment in clean technology – from alternative energy products, like solar panels and hybrid cars, to the use of nanotechnology to solve environmental problems – went from $34 million in the first quarter of 2006 to $290 million in the third quarter, according to an annual report released Sunday by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network, a research organization in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Management Group to Take Laureate Education Private
text: Laureate Education, a for-profit operator of universities, said Sunday it had agreed to be acquired for about $3.1 billion by a group led by its chairman, Douglas L. Becker. The buyout group also included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the hedge fund SAC Capital.

headline: Indonesian Oil Giant May Hold I.P.O. in 2008
text: Pertamina, Indonesia’s state oil company, said it might be ready for an initial public offering by the end of 2008 after weeding out corruption and improving accounting procedures. It would have a market value of $30 billion, making it the biggest stock on the Jakarta Stock Exchange, the company’s president, Ari Soemarno, said last week.

headline: A One-Time Denim King Turns to the Courtroom
text: Levi Strauss is becoming a leader in a new arena: lawsuits. The company, once the undisputed king of denim and now a case study in missed opportunities, has emerged as the most litigious in the apparel industry when it comes to trademark infringement lawsuits, firing off nearly 100 against its competitors since 2001. That’s far more than General Motors, Walt Disney or Nike, according to an analysis by a research firm, Thomson West.

headline: Citigroup and CNBC Cozy Up
text: Ah, the corporate jet. Like $6,000 shower curtains and the nickname Kenny Boy, the corporate jet lives large in the public imagination, writes The New York Times’ David Carr. And it may be the reason, he suggests, that the ethically questionable relationship between Maria Bartiromo, the popular anchor on the business news channel CNBC, and the ousted Citigroup executive, Todd S. Thomson, has garnered so much attention.

headline: Credit Suisse Eyes Trust Banks in U.S.
text: A Credit Suisse private-banking executive said his firm is interested in buying a trust bank in the United States, Financial News reported. The investment bank could use funds from the recent sale of its insurance unit, Winterthur.

headline: Tech Barons Take on Energy Policy
text: President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valley’s technology investors. These venture capitalists, backers of giants like Google and Genentech, have traditionally been free-market advocates, favoring ideas and innovation over government intervention. Now they are heading to Washington on a crusade to influence energy policy because they have a big stake in the outcome.

headline: Former CA Executive Is Sentenced
text: A former executive with Computer Associates who pleaded guilty to securities fraud and who prosecutors said was instrumental in the prosecution of the company’s former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced to seven months in prison and seven months of home detention. The executive, Ira Zar, the former chief financial officer, pleaded guilty in 2004 and has cooperated with authorities in the prosecution of Mr. Kumar and the company’s former sales chief, Stephen Richards.

headline: Tribune Management Mulls Bid of Its Own, Report Says
text: Tribune‘s top management team is talking with private-equity companies about crafting a new deal to restructure the company and will likely begin discussing its ideas with the company’s special board committee Saturday in Chicago, The Chicago Tribune reported. The newspaper said that the media company’s board has decided that the two offers tabled for the company by the Chandler family, Tribune’s largest shareholder, and the Los Angeles billionaires Eli Broad and Ron Burkle are too low.

headline: Barbaro, a Champion
text: Before his accident, Barbaro’s résumé summoned memories of Affirmed, Seattle Slew and Secretariat.

headline: News Quiz: Memorials
text: Good morning good readers of The Lede! Yes, yes, we’ve received your letters alerting us to the fact that we skipped the quiz last week — even though we had promised one the week before. Well, we apologize for that, but listen: does the term “fly-by-night operation” mean anything to you people? Yeah, it’s sorta like that.

headline: The Hard Rain That’s Falling on Capitalism
text: Bad corporate behavior, including avaricious management-led buyouts and options backdating, is undermining the trust that is the bedrock of capitalism, Ben Stein writes in The New York Times. Among the offenses that Mr. Stein sees being perpetrated are backdating and management buyouts, both of which he says fleece shareholders.

headline: Private Equity Stirs Canada’s Record Mergers Boom
text: Foreign buyers have stoked the biggest mergers-and-acquisition boom in Canada ever, snaring once untouchable Canadian trophy companies such as Inco, Dofasco, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts and Four Seasons Hotels. According to Thomson Financial, the value of mergers and acquisitions involving Canadian companies soared to $230 billion last year, nearly doubling the action a year earlier. The biggest player: private equity firms.

headline: Which of These Things is Not Like the Other?
text: The red carpet is a test of reporting fortitude. Physical challenges, plus an absence of meaningful stakes, makes it place where your soul can come in for some wear and tear. View the videohere. “This is kind of a young person’s game, isn’t it?” said someone he knows, giving a long stare at the Bagger’s crow’s feet. Just then, the Bagger spotted Todd Field, the director of “Little Children” and perhaps the only person less qualified by disposition to be on the carpet than he. The Bagger gave him a beseeching look from behind the hedge and Mr. Field came over. They each played their part, the Bagger offering inane questions and Mr. Field doing his best to answer. They shared a moment of complete nothingness and mutual understanding. The beast, such as it is, must be fed.

headline: North American Paper Companies to Merge
text: Abitibi-Consolidated of Canada and Bowater of the United States said Monday that they would merge, creating the third-largest paper company in North America. The combined entity would have annual revenue of about $7.9 billion, the companies said.

headline: Mixed Bagger
text: The Bagger had the wisdom to see “Little Miss Sunshine” coming. Then again, he also picked Alan Arkin and Peter O’Toole to win the honors actually awarded to Eddie Murphy and Forest Whitaker. Of course, he picked Helen Mirren and Jennifer Hudson too, which was bold and unexpected of him, right?

headline: Data Machine
text: At the Globes, the Bagger sat next to this guy who opened up file after file on his laptop and kept going all night long, every once in a while piping up to ask a question. A few of us sitting by him watched him pound away and asked, “Who is that guy?” Turns out it’s Greg Hernandez from the Los Angeles Daily News and, well, the dude likes typing.

headline: A Growing Aversion to Ticker Symbols
text: Everyone, it seems, is hopping on the buyout bandwagon these days. Even the big public companies once thought untouchable are now wistfully talking about the success of firms like the Blackstone Group, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his DealBook column. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Blackstone’s Stephen A. Schwarzman — whose firm has now offered $38.3 billion to take Equity Office Properties private — told Mr. Sorkin that the head of a major public company confided that he wished he could go private.

headline: The Van Refuels
text: Closer readers of the blog, all four of you not counting blood relations, know that the Bagger is a heatseeking missile when it comes to free groceries. So you will be unsurprised to learn that he made it into the gala thrown by People magazine after the Screen Actors Awards, even though media types were not especially welcome. Let’s just say that he knew a guy who knew a guy who knew a guy. The beef Wellington was dainty but satisfying and what exactly is not to like about those little hamburgers that are all the rage?

headline: Merrill Lynch to Buy First Republic
text: Merrill Lynch said Monday it would acquire the First Republic Bank, a bank that specializes in serving wealthy individuals, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock. Merrill said its offer for San Francisco-based First Republic represented a price of $55 a share, or 44 percent more than First Republic’s closing stock price on Friday. The deal would be Merrill’s largest acquisition in almost 10 years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: 70 Years of Music
text: Photographs of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, from past to present.

headline: The War at Home: “Existential Conflict”
text: In an interview with Newsweek, Vice President Dick Cheney defended the decision to invade Iraq but predicted a very, very long haul:

headline: On the Hill: Slicing the Pork
text: When it comes to earmarks, the difference between pure pork and legitimate spending can be awfully subjective. But with President Bush’s call to cut such spending in half and a deadline to approve a new appropriations bill to fund the federal government looming on Feb. 15, Congress had better figure it out soon. Democratic leaders also wrote a letter to Mr. Bush asking him to cooperate on adopting “fiscally responsible policies,” including giving a more accurate account of the costs of wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Congress: One-Stop Spending Bill
text: First it was the 100-hour blitz. Now those House Democrats plan to do a whole year’s worth of work in one day.

headline: Davos 2007 in Review
text: Tycoons, politicians and big thinkers climbed into limousines, trains and private planes on Sunday as this year’s World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, came to an end. Among dealmakers and corporate executives there, the push to go private was a major topic of discussion. Strolling out of a session called “Is Bigger Better in Private Equity?” Blackstone Group‘s Stephen Schwarzman told DealBook an anecdote about how the chief executive of an unnamed company worth more than $125 billion recently remarked, “Geez, I wish you could buy us, but we’re too big.” Amid all this talk about going private, John Thain, chief executive of the NYSE Group, predicted that the tide would eventually turn and companies would make their way back to the public markets.

headline: Subscribe to the Videos!
text: OK, so this is totally great: my weekly Times videos are now available on YouTube AND from the iTunes Store. For free!

headline: Stephen Schwarzman’s Big Bash
text: Not every Wall Street titan can celebrate his birthday in a place that holds 1,500 people. Unless, of course, that titan is Stephen A. Schwarzman, who is on the verge of clinching the biggest buyout deal ever. Then this would be the moment to keep thinking big, writes The New York Times’ Landon Thomas Jr.

headline: From the Print World
text: In today’s Empire Zone column, David Grandeau of the state Lobbying Commission wonders if the overhaul that would merge his panel would ultimately give him some stong new powers, at least in the short term, to take on lobbying violations.

headline: Guess It Finally Froze Over
text: News flash: Krugman and WSJ agree; A country music backtrack on the war?; Habeus what?

headline: SAG Awards
text: David Carr catches up with Forest Whitaker and other stars on the red carpet at this year's Screen Actors Guild Awards.

headline: For Relaxing Times, Make It Suntory Time
text: Tommy Lee Jones takes his coffee canned. Or so he’d have you believe in the camp-o-kook ads he’s been doing in Japan.

headline: Sudan Snubbed for African Union Post. Will a Peacekeeping Plan Hold?
text: The African Union decided today that John Kufuor, the president of Ghana, would be next to hold the rotating chairmanship of the union, snubbing Sudan for a second year, and resisting what looked like a bargaining chip for Sudan’s president, Omar al-Bashir, who signaled that he was owed the slot.

headline: Post-Enlightenment Enemies of Pure Evil
text: Johns Hopkins historian David A. Bell, who has written a new book, “The First Total War: Napoleon’s Europe and the Birth of Warfare as We Know It,” takes to the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times to argue that the attacks of Sept. 11, in the context of the broad sweep of military history, just weren’t that big of a deal. “As an instance of mass murder, the attacks were unspeakable, but they still pale in comparison with any number of military assaults on civilian targets of the recent past, from Hiroshima on down,” Bell writes. “Even if one counts our dead in Iraq and Afghanistan as casualties of the war against terrorism, which brings us to about 6,500, we should remember that roughly the same number of Americans die every two months in automobile accidents.”

headline: Mars Photos
This Campaign Thinks Pink
text: An organization that has fought breast cancer for 25 years is marking its anniversary with a new name and a new logo as well as a new campaign that demonstrates a new attitude.

headline: Merrill Analyst Turns Cautious on Cowen
text: Shares of the Cowen Group have risen nearly 30 percent from last year’s initial public offering, but Merrill Lynch analyst Guy Moszkowski is concerned that there may be little upside left. On Monday, Mr. Moszkowski cut his rating on Cowen to “neutral” from “buy,” writing that, at Friday’s close of $20.70, the investment bank’s stock had topped his $18 price target. He also said that Cowen’s merger advisory business looks weak, especially in the fourth quarter of 2006.

headline: GOP Money Edge on Long Island
text: Steve Zissou, the tortured undersea explorer bent on finding the shark that ate his best friend,* has donated $250 to Long Island Senate candidate Craig Johnson.

headline: LinkedIn, Social Network for Suits, Gets Funding
text: Venture capitalists have infused $12.8 million into LinkedIn, a Web site that allows users to create online networks of business contacts. The funding comes as last year’s flood of investments in social-networking startups — it seems all of Silicon Valley hopes to back the next YouTube or MySpace — has many in the industry wondering when the shakeout will begin.

headline: Davos Diary
text: Andrew Ross Sorkin reports.

headline: Montoya’s Daytona 24-Hour Victory
text: Although this is news that everyone has certainly heard or read by now, I just could not let it pass without some kind of a photo celebration and comment. After poking fun at Juan Pablo Montoya’s Nascar debut, here’s some history with the Colombian’s victory in the Daytona 24-hour race yesterday.

headline: What, Me? Oldest Living Person? No, Not Me. Please …
text: Being recognized as the world’s oldest living person is something of an honor — at least as measured by the competititive spirit that often seems to underlie the quest for the most super of planet’s supercentenarians.

headline: Rivera Leaves, Too
text: Recenty, the powerful heath care union Local 1199/SIEU lost its political director, Jennifer Cunningham. Now comes word that the union’s longtime leader, Dennis Rivera, a major force in state politics, is taking a job with the national union.

headline: Private Times: Imagining a Newspaper Buyout
text: For months, certain outside investors have criticized the New York Times Company over its two-tiered stock structure. If the Sulzberger family, which controls the Times, ever decides that they have had enough of such badgering, they might conceivably try to take the company private. Slate’s Daniel Gross considers such a hypothetical and concludes that the publisher is “an excellent target for a management-led buyout.”

headline: Hooray! Sudan Loses AU Election….
text: The African Union just announced that it has chosen John Kufuor, president of Ghana, to lead it for the coming year. That means that Omar al-Bashir, the genocidal president of Sudan, lost his bid to win the job. As I wrote in Sunday’s column, it had seemed that Bashir might get the job, and I’m glad that African leaders came to their senses and realized that would have been a catastrophe for Africa’s image.

headline: Jet Use Leaves Bad Taste With Applebee’s Investor
text: Earlier this month, DealBook noted that Richard C. Breeden, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was already “making waves” during his short tenure as a hedge-fund manager. On Monday, footnoted.org’s Michele Leder continued the maritime theme, noting Mr. Breeden’s latest attack on Applebee’s International and writing that “it didn’t take him long to find his sea legs.”

headline: My Plane’s Bigger Than Your Plane
text: A couple of people are interested in buying A-380’s as personal planes, according to a Bloomberg report. Airbus calls it a “flying palace.”

headline: Air America Finds a Buyer
text: Air America Radio, the liberal talk radio network, said Monday that it had reached a tentative agreement to be sold to Stephen Green, the founder of SL Green Realty, a deal that could breathe life into the bankrupt venture. The network also said that longtime marquee host Al Franken would leave next month.

headline: Mapping Ozone
text: With ozone polluting cities around the world, scientists are using low-cost balloons as one way to map and target ozone hot spots.

headline: Bristol Shares Jump Amid Merger Speculation
text: Shares of the drug giant Bristol-Myers Squibb, which has been the subject of takeover speculation for months, soared to near a three-year high Monday after a French financial publication said it might be close to merging with Sanofi-Aventis. The report did not name its sources, and both companies declined to comment. Nevertheless, shares of Bristol-Myers, which sells the blockbuster anticoagulant drug Plavix, were up 4.6 percent to $27.41 in late-afternoon trading, giving it a market capitalization of nearly $54 billion.

headline: A  Little Town All Our Own (for the Week)
text: Part of the reason we had so much fun during our Christmas vacation had to do with where we rented.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: New Yorkers’ Weekend in Iowa, NH
text: A Des Moines Register Iowa Poll shows 68 percent of respondents think the country is ready for a black president, 55 percent a woman and 40 percent a Hispanic.

headline: Tijuana Police Are Packing Heat Again
text: The police in Tijuana, Mexico, having worked the last three weeks without weapons, have obtained their firearms back after they had been seized by federal troops sent to address the city’s lawlessness.

headline: Maria Who?
text: Business journalists, myself included, have been fascinated by the Maria Bartiromo-Citigroup story, which David Carr discussed in today’s Times. When I was in Davos at the World Economic Forum last week, it was a major topic of coversation. Government officials and business leaders asked me if she would keep her job. Some were amazed when I said I thought she would.

headline: The Dukes of Hazzard
text: Rei Kawakubo’s Comme des Garçons show, on Saturday, featured four men who played various roles in London of the ’60s and ’70s. One was called Sebastian Horsley, a self-described “middle-aged loser poncing around in make-up, fixing up drugs.” He headed up the tailored section. Of course, to most of the people in the room these men meant nothing. I don’t suppose they minded or noticed the blank looks of incomprehension. And, anyway, you get enough of those at an ordinary fashion show. But I don’t know. I think I know what people would think if, in 20 years time, I put on a pair of platforms and ponced down a runway: old bag.

headline: Bon Mot Dept.: Figures of Speech
text: On Saturday, on my way into the Raf Simons show at Bercy, the big sports stadium, I decided to kill a few moments at a hockey game that was going on next door. It was strange that two completely different male experiences were taking place just a few meters apart: the dark, esoteric venue of the Simons show and the crowded, bright, boisterous world of the competitive arena. As I stood watching the players chase the puck, my friend Klaus Stockhausen, the fashion director of German GQ, came in with his editor-in-chief, Manuel Frei.

headline: Romney: Clinton’s Wrong About Bush
text: COLUMBIA,S.C. — Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts seeking the Republican nomination for president, has no shortage of criticism of the way the war in Iraq has been handled. And he questions whether President Bush was sending enough troops in, and dispatching them quickly enough, to accomplish the stabilization of Bagdad.

headline: Return to Haifa Street
text: Accompanying a U.S. nighttime patrol, Damien Cave of The Times witnessed a deadly gun battle with Iraqi militants. Warning: contains graphic content.

headline: Seeking Better Energy Policy in Cornfields
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his Jan. 29 column, “The Sum of All Ears.”

headline: Celebrating the Right to Protest
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s Jan. 29 column, “More Than Antiwar.“

headline: Prodigiously Prodigal: Men’s Fashion in Paris
text: Everything has simmered down since the couture shows ended and the boys took over. Twice a year this happens, in January and July, and twice a year I am reminded of what a nervous wreck women make things. The men seem to have such minimal expectations, and more fun. It’s like the perfect date. On Friday night, I went backstage to say hello to John Galliano before his men’s show. He was in his private dressing room have his hair curled into long ringlets. “The guys are great,” he said. “They arrive on their skateboards. No cars, no dramas. I saw some of them taking a nap earlier.”

headline: The Week Ahead
text: International Herald Tribune managing editor Alison Smale looks ahead at the  events occurring worldwide this week.

headline: Readers React
text: I was enormously pleased to see the many comments to the post on Wednesday that essentially invited diners to share their thoughts on my article in that day’s Dining section about the way some self-regarding chefs and restaurants behave.

headline: Blogtalk
text: In his education speech today, Governor Spitzer skipped  the paragraph that was nice to Assembly Speaker Silver. [The Daily Politics]

headline: Clinton to Bush: Meet the Son of 9/11 Hero
text: In a letter that’s sure to draw the attention of New York tabloids and others, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton released a missive to President Bush today on behalf of one of her young guests for the president’s State of the Union address one week ago: Ceasar Borja Jr.

headline: The Growing Chorus of Antiwar Conservatives
text: In many ways, the war in Iraq is looking more and more like the last days of the Vietnam War. It is becoming increasingly clear that the situation is hopeless and the administration’s strategy is incapable of achieving victory. Yet the president insists that additional resources can still turn the situation around. Although he has little credibility left, many continue to support him in some vain hope that the sacrifices of our soldiers can somehow be vindicated and given meaning.

headline: Death of a Racehorse
text: A topic that is on many minds today.

headline: VoteVets Aims at G.O.P. Senators
text: VoteVets.org, the group who sponsored controversial ads aimed at vulnerable G.O.P. incumbents last year, is back at it. This time, it is attacking Republican senators from purplish states who have expressed opposition to President Bush’s troop increase but have declined to support the original, harsher Senate resolution condemning the plan.

headline: You’re Weird. I’m Elvis.
text: I went to Memphis this past weekend seeking a scientific understanding of Graceland. I was there for a meeting of social psychologists, and I wanted to drag a few a few of them out to Elvis Presley’s home so they could explain its appeal.

headline: Dave Barry and More Fun With Cities
text: Continuing today’s theme of sparring between cities ….

headline: City Bashing: Chicago vs. Indianapolis
text: Chicago has a history of picking on Indianapolis. From a 1982 edition of Time Magazine:

headline: Clinton-Romney Ping-Pong
text: Here’s an update to our earlier item about Mitt Romney, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Iraq. The ever-rapid Clinton war-room spotted the item about Mr. Romney, saying he disagreed with Mrs. Clinton’s demand that President Bush extricate the United States from Iraq before he leaves office, and issued a rapid response.

headline: Barbaro Is Euthanized After Struggle With Injury
text: The eight-month effort to nurse Barbaro back to health after he sustained a catastrophic injury in the Preakness Stakes came to an end on Monday morning, when doctors euthanized the horse. Barbaro’s owners said it had become clear that he could not live without pain after a setback over the weekend.

headline: “Sunday Morning” on the Web
text: Each year, I write and report about six TV segments for “CBS News Sunday Morning.” From a pure satisfaction standpoint, they’re some of the juiciest bits of my career. Not only am I allowed to infuse technology stories with my own brand of cornball humor, but the segments are long enough—six, eight, even nine minutes long—to delve into a story far deeper than they can on, say, the evening news.

headline: Social Entrepreneurs
text: If you have comments on my Tuesday column on the power of social entrepreneurs, post them here. I’d particularly welcome any thoughts on individuals or groups that are particularly making a difference and could serve as models for others. If you can, include links so others can find out more information.

headline: Senators at Louisiana Hearing Criticize Federal Recovery Aid
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29  Three United States senators sounded off on Monday about the slow pace of recovery from Hurricane Katrina at a hearing in the French Quarter, criticizing federal officials for perceived inequities in aid to Louisiana and for imposing rules that are halting government assistance.

headline: Raid at Hells Angels Club Leads to Dispute Over Arrest
text: A member of the New York chapter of the Hells Angels plans to file suit against the city contending that he was illegally taken into custody after a search of the motorcycle club’s East Village headquarters on Monday.

headline: Verizon Profit Drops 38%, but Wireless Shows Growth
text: Profit at Verizon Communications fell 38 percent in the fourth quarter, after one-time charges, but the company reported yesterday that it had narrowed the gap with AT&T Wireless in the race for new long-term subscribers.

headline: 2 Witnesses in Queens Killing Cite Pause Amid 50 Police Shots
text: Two men celebrating at a bachelor party for Sean Bell in November emerged from a grand jury in Queens late yesterday and said they had testified that the many bullets fired by the police came in two bursts.

headline: Do-Gooders With Spreadsheets
text: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: Former Press Secretary Dispels Many Illusions
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — As White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer was the omnipresent television face of government power, the confident insider who spoke for President Bush and seemed to know everything but reveal only what he chose.

headline: Explosion Destroys Gas Station in West Virginia
text: Four people were killed and five injured today in an explosion at a gasoline station and convenience store near Ghent in southern West Virginia.

headline: Take a Stand Even if It Means Not Getting a Seat
text: NOTHING gives your principles a workout like a business trip. Taking a stand for your beliefs isn’t easy when you’re outside of your comfort zone, but the rewards can be significant.

headline: The Police Will Kick Off the Grammys
text: The Police, who leapt from the British punk scene to become one of the world’s biggest rock acts before breaking up in 1984, will reunite for a performance to kick off the 49th Grammy Awards on Feb. 11.

headline: 2 Plan a Production Company
text: Gail Berman and Lloyd Braun, two Hollywood executives who formerly ran network entertainment divisions, have created a company to produce entertainment for television, films and the Internet.

headline: At Risk: Some Cancers May Be Tied to Family Size
text: A new study suggests that having many siblings may increase the risk for certain stomach cancers and that younger siblings may be more at risk than older ones.

headline: Recalling a Literary Family, and Phobias
text: As he notes in his remarkable new memoir, “Wish I Could Be There,” the composer Allen Shawn suffers from a veritable rainbow of phobias: “I don’t like heights,” he writes. “I don’t like being on the water. I am upset by walking across parking lots or open parks or fields where there are no buildings. I tend to avoid bridges, unless they are on a small scale. I respond poorly to stretches of vastness but do equally badly when I am closed in, as I am severely claustrophobic. When I go to a theater, I sit on the aisle. I am petrified of tunnels, making most train travel as well as many drives difficult. I don’t take subways. I avoid elevators as much as possible. I experience glassed-in spaces as toxic, and I find it very difficult to adjust to being in buildings in which the windows don’t open.”

headline: Symantec to Buy Software Tracker
text: Symantec, a maker of computer antivirus products, will buy Altiris for about $1.03 billion to gain programs that track corporate software use.

headline: In Survival Mode, 2 Newsprint Makers Merge
text: OTTAWA, Jan. 29  Two leaders of the struggling North American newsprint industry, Abitibi Consolidated and Bowater, announced on Monday that they would merge through a stock-based transaction.

headline: One Horse Dies
text: Why should we feel so much grief at the loss of one horse? After all, this is a world in which horses are sacrificed again and again for the sport of humans. Barbaro was euthanized yesterday, eight months after he shattered his right hind leg at the start of the Preakness Stakes. After an injury like that, most racehorses would have been put down minutes later. But every race is a complex equation  a balance of economics, athleticism, equine grace and conscience. Conscience often comes in last, but not in this case. Barbaro’s owners gave that horse exactly what he had given them, which is everything. It was the very least they could do, and yet it seemed truly exceptional in a sport that is barbarous as often as it is beautiful.

headline: Fed Has Yet to Set Target on Inflation
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — When Ben S. Bernanke took over as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board one year ago this week, he brought with him a long-held conviction that the central bank should be more explicit about its goals and less personalized than it had been under Alan Greenspan.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Indian Actress Wins on Show After Racial Taunts

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: A Star Player, a Video and a Suspension
text: O. J. Mayo, a West Virginia high school senior considered the country’s best guard prospect since LeBron James, has been suspended and is not expected to play tonight in a national showdown game.

headline: Senators Assert Right to Block Bush on Iraq
text: Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee began laying the constitutional groundwork today for an effort to block President Bush’s plan to send more troops to Iraq and place new limits on the conduct of the war there, perhaps forcing a withdrawal of American forces from Iraq.

headline: F.A.A. Review Is Expected on Pilots’ Age at Retirement
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Airlines and pilots’ unions expect the Federal Aviation Administration to announce Tuesday that it will review its rule requiring airline pilots to retire at age 60, now that the International Civil Aviation Organization has raised the age to 65.

headline: Traces of Ancient Village Found Near Stonehenge
text: New excavations near Stonehenge have uncovered hearths, timbers and other remains of what archaeologists say was probably the village of workers who erected the brooding monoliths on Salisbury Plain in England.

headline: In High School Football, Crunch Time Can Be Literal
text: A bellow of Southern pride, tinny in a cellphone speaker, sounds at the bedside of a sleeping teenager. It’s “Sweet Home Alabama.” This is morning in Hoover, Ala., home of sublime high school football, as well as of MTV’s pious reality series “Two-a-Days,” which begins its second season tonight. The song is a wake-up call.

headline: Labor Leader Is Parting, With a Shot
text: Dennis Rivera, the president of New York’s largest health care union, announced yesterday that he would step down, but not without issuing a surprisingly pointed broadside against Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s planned cuts in health care spending.

headline: Trenton Assembly Votes to Ease State’s Property Tax Burden
text: TRENTON, Jan. 29  A half-year after legislative leaders and Gov. Jon S. Corzine vowed to provide relief for the highest property tax rate in the nation, the Assembly voted on Monday evening to give a 20 percent credit to most homeowners and to put a 4 percent cap on future local property tax increases.

headline: Suicide Attack Is First in Israel in 9 Months
text: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Jan. 30 — After nine months without a suicide bombing in Israel, a Palestinian walked from Egypt across the open desert border, hitched a ride from a wary Israeli motorist and then blew himself up on Monday inside a bakery in the Red Sea resort town of Eilat, Israeli officials said.

headline: The Importance of Knowing What the Doctor Is Talking About
text: How often have you left a doctor’s office wondering just what you were told about your health, or what exactly you were supposed to be doing to relieve or prevent a problem? If you are a typical patient, you remember less than half of what your doctor tries to explain.

headline: To Ban the Bomb, Sign the Peace
text: Washington

headline: Chinese United by Common Goal: A Hot Stock Tip
text: BEIJING, Jan. 29 — “Irrational exuberance” has no exact Chinese translation, but no explanation seemed necessary in the bustling lobby of GF Securities. Grungy-looking college students, office workers, retirees and even a pregnant woman in suede boots all jostled into the brokerage on a recent morning, eager to buy stocks and buy them now.

headline: In a Bakery Window, Shades of Miss Havisham
text: WHEN are they going to change the cakes? La Villita, a Mexican bakery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has become a familiar presence on the corner of Bedford Avenue and Grand Street, with its curious window display of cakes.

headline: Big Plan for Small Courts: Seeking Money to Fix Them
text: ALBANY, Jan. 29  New York State’s top court officials plan to ask the Legislature for at least $50 million over the next five years to revamp the state’s threadbare system of town and village courts  more than five times the amount they had previously discussed, the state’s chief administrative judge said during legislative testimony on Monday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 19 misstated the history of the performance in New York of “Il Signor Bruschino,” by Rossini, which the Gotham Chamber Opera is performing through Saturday. The Gotham Chamber Opera’s production is the first professional staging of the work in New York since 1933, not the first staging since then. (The error was repeated in a Week Ahead entry in Arts & Leisure on Jan. 21, in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday and in a review of a performance on Saturday.)

headline: Missteps by Iraqi Forces in Battle Raise Questions
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 29 —Iraqi forces were surprised and nearly overwhelmed by the ferocity of an obscure renegade militia in a weekend battle near the holy city of Najaf and needed far more help from American forces than previously disclosed, American and Iraqi officials said Monday.

headline: A Faith-Based Fuel Initiative
text: In 1975, after the oil embargo, Congress approved the most successful energy-saving measure this country has ever seen: the Corporate Average Fuel Economy system, known as CAFE, which set minimum mileage standards for cars. Within 10 years, automobile efficiency had virtually doubled, to 27.5 miles per gallon in 1985 from just over 14 miles per gallon in 1976.

headline: Following the Tracks of a Killer Mountain Beetle
text: In early September, Jesse Logan, a 62-year-old insect specialist with a knack for mathematics and a deep love for the Western landscape, gazed across a rolling meadow 10,400 feet high in the rugged Wind River Range in Wyoming.

headline: Lifting Ligeti With the Force of an Organ
text: A passer-by glancing through a rear window of the sanctuary at St. Thomas Church on Sunday evening might not have noticed anything amiss. The pews were filled with people whose heads were bowed in concentration, eyes closed tight; a few faces were turned heavenward in amazement or rapture.

headline: Staten Island Assemblyman Is Mourned by Top Politicians
text: Many of the state’s leading politicians flocked to Staten Island yesterday on a cold, blustery morning to pay their respects to John W. Lavelle, the 61st District assemblyman and the chairman of the borough’s Democratic organization, who died of a stroke last week at 57.

headline: Canada’s Good Example
text: Canada set an important example of decency when it offered a formal apology and compensation worth millions of dollars to a Syrian-born Canadian citizen who was a victim of President Bush’s use of open-ended detention, summary deportation and even torture in the name of fighting terrorism.

headline: Boom Market for Lebanon’s Soothsayers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a land racked by sectarian tension and political instability, men like Michel Hayek have become Lebanon’s unlikely political players.

headline: Letters
text: Lollygags and Sidereal Days

headline: Bryant Suspended for Tonight’s Knicks Game
text: Kobe Bryant was shocked and subdued this morning after he arrived at Madison Square Garden for the Los Angeles Lakers’ shoot-around only to learn he would not be playing there tonight.

headline: Rewriting the Room Service Menu
text: For all that hotels have done to make their bedding more luxurious, their décor more stylish and their lobbies smell better with a signature scent, one area that hasn’t gotten much of a makeover is the in-suite dining experience, otherwise known as room service.

headline: CNet Restatement Goes Back to 1996
text: CNet Networks, an online publisher of technology news and reviews, has restated earnings going back to 1996 to reflect $105.7 million in costs for backdated stock options.

headline: A New Nuclear Warhead (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gates, in London, Promotes Vista to Europeans
text: LONDON, Jan. 30 — Bill Gates, co-founder and chairman of Microsoft, marked the consumer release of the new Vista operating system with a low-key event today in a small auditorium at the British Library in London.

headline: The World’s a Mess, and It’s All Your Fault
text: Warning: Your reading of this newspaper may be hazardous to someone’s health. (Don’t worry — not yours.) Equally fraught with danger is the casual reach for that morning coffee, the purchase of a new pashmina, a night out at the theater.

headline: 22,000 Slots Are Added for City Help With Rent
text: The Bloomberg administration intends to give out 22,000 new federal housing vouchers to help low-income New Yorkers rent apartments on the private market over the next two years, officials said yesterday. To do that, officials are temporarily reopening the waiting list for the program, called Section 8, to nonemergency applicants for the first time in 12 years.

headline: Manhattan: New Air Route to Open
text: Travelers looking for an easier path to western Ireland will soon have a new option, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. Starting on May 27, Flyglobespan, a low-cost carrier based in Scotland, will run three weekly direct flights between Kennedy International Airport and Ireland West Airport Knock in County Mayo for as little as $259 each way, including tax. The new route, approved by the federal government after Mr. Bloomberg’s urging, is intended to boost Irish tourism to New York.

headline: Daunted by the Subway? Try It in a Wheelchair
text: From Michael Harris’s house in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, it is a seven-block walk to the nearest subway station.

headline: Glen Tetley, 80, Pioneering Choreographer, Dies
text: Glen Tetley, an American choreographer long popular in Europe whose pioneering fusion of ballet and modern dance challenged taboos and rattled purists but influenced major companies worldwide, died on Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 and also had homes in New York and Rome.

headline: Senate to Consider Minimum Wage Bill With Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — The Senate is expected to clear the way on Tuesday for an increase in the minimum wage that Democrats and some Republicans agree is overdue.

headline: First the Wait for Microsoft Vista; Now the Marketing Barrage
text: Microsoft’s power in the technology industry, some analysts insist, is waning. It faces a host of rivals from a reinvigorated Apple on the desktop to Web-based challengers like Google, delivering services and software online.

headline: After Marketing Frenzy, a Tame Release for Vista
text: Twelve years ago, Microsoft introduced its new operating system, Windows 95, in a frenzied marketing blitz that was unlike anything the computer industry had ever seen.

headline: F.A.A. to Propose Raising Pilots’ Retirement Age
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The head of the Federal Aviation Administration said today that the agency would propose allowing airline pilots to fly until they are 65 years old, dropping a 47-year requirement that they retire at 60, to bring the United States in line with international practice and to help maintain safety.

headline: Europe Resists U.S. Push to Curb Iran Ties
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — European governments are resisting Bush administration demands that they curtail support for exports to Iran and that they block transactions and freeze assets of some Iranian companies, officials on both sides say. The resistance threatens to open a new rift between Europe and the United States over Iran.

headline: A Debut and a Fervent Violinist
text: The concert by the Hamburg Symphony at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night had the makings of an event. The orchestra, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary with an American tour, was playing for the first time in New York. On the podium was Andrey Boreyko, its 49-year-old Russian music director, whose star is on the rise. Robert McDuffie, a popular, respected American violinist, was the soloist.

headline: A Lively Market, Legal and Not, for Software Bugs
text: Microsoft says its new operating system, Windows Vista, is the most secure in the company’s history. Now the bounty hunters will test just how secure it is.

headline: Ashura Attacks Leave Dozens Dead in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 30  Women dressed in black had just set out large cauldrons to cook the traditional feast on the holy day of Ashura, a simple meal of rice and lamb in a tomato-based sauce. Children crowded around the pots as men wailed in a ritualistic mourning ceremony and guards scanned the crowd at the Shiite mosque in Baquba for would-be killers.

headline: Bush Directive Increases Sway on Regulation
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — President Bush has signed a directive that gives the White House much greater control over the rules and policy statements that the government develops to protect public health, safety, the environment, civil rights and privacy.

headline: Prospect of Womb Transplant Raises Hopes and Red Flags
text: The telephone calls and e-mail messages started streaming in just hours after the first news articles reported that a uterine transplant might be in the works. One caller was a 25-year-old Alabama woman who was born without a uterus. Another was a 33-year-old Illinois woman who had a hysterectomy at 24.

headline: Citigroup to Buy Online Bank in Britain to Expand Retail Presence
text: Citigroup agreed yesterday to buy Egg Banking, a British online bank owned by Prudential P.L.C., for $1.13 billion, the latest in a series of small deals to expand its retail presence abroad.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,065 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Palestinian Factions Try to Observe New Truce
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 - After five days of clashes in the Gaza Strip, Palestinian factions today mostly observed the latest cease-fire, although one Hamas member was shot dead.

headline: U.S. Ally and Foe Are Trying to Avert War in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 — In an unusual collaboration that could complicate American policy in the region, Iran and Saudi Arabia have been mediating an agreement to end Lebanon’s violent political crisis.

headline: ... And I Want to Thank That Same Bunch. Again.
text: As the awards season lumbers toward the Oscars, you can almost envision what might happen when the Academy Awards are finally given out on Feb. 25. Forest Whitaker will fumble for words and mumble; Eddie Murphy will robotically deliver his list of industry thanks; Jennifer Hudson will work in a hokey use of the word “dream”; and Helen Mirren will pay tribute to the actual queen. Because this season has already brought three televised awards shows without a single surprise in the acting categories, the winners’ acceptance speeches have been hemmed in by an unusual problem: The same old people to thank and too many opportunities to do it.

headline: Brooklyn: City Cancels Golf Course Deal
text: Parks Commissioner Adrian Benepe canceled an agreement yesterday under which East Coast Golf was to pay the city a minimum of $9.6 million in fees over 20 years to renovate and operate a golf course in Marine Park. The cancellation, effective in a month, came after William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller, raised concerns about the company’s president, Domenick Logozzo, and his financial relationship with Craig Marino, whom federal prosecutors have described as a soldier in the Colombo crime family. Mr. Marino was one of 10 people indicted in March on federal racketeering and conspiracy charges. According to prosecutors, Mr. Logozzo lent Mr. Marino and his father money and a car but has not been implicated in any criminal activity in the indictment. Calls to Mr. Logozzo’s place of business were not returned yesterday.

headline: Hazards: Antidepressant Linked to Fractures in Older People
text: Daily use of a common class of antidepressant may double the risk of fracture in people older than 50, a Canadian study reports.

headline: A Day Without Guns ...
text: Twenty years ago, the Florida Legislature cravenly decided to allow “law abiding” citizens to carry concealed weapons merely by declaring their preference for self-defense. Then last July, at the prodding of the gun lobby, the current crop of state lawmakers proved they could be even more corrupt and cowardly than their predecessors by deciding to make the list of gun-toting Floridians a secret.

headline: Too Young for This: Facing Cancer Under 40
text: In July 2005, Jeff Carenza and his girlfriend were enjoying a getaway weekend in Miami when food poisoning landed them both in the hospital. Blood tests showed that Dr. Carenza, then 29, had iron-deficiency anemia.

headline: Nickelodeon Begins a Web Site Focusing on Interactive Play
text: Nickelodeon, the popular children’s cable network, is pushing hard into the online world with Nicktropolis.com, a new Web site that will let its young users enter their own world of Internet activities.

headline: Memo Pad
text: SHOELESS IN RENO? Unisys plans to open its first Registered Traveler program kiosk at the Reno-Tahoe International Airport in mid-February. But it is unlikely that the program will initially offer shoe-scanning technology, said Larry Zmuda, the company’s partner for homeland-security-related business. In an interview, Mr. Zmuda said the major concern for Unisys was ensuring the program’s “predictability” for members, who will undergo a federal background check and pay an annual fee to receive biometrically encoded I.D. cards and access to a special lane for expedited passage through the security checkpoint. Mr. Zmuda cited early snags with shoe-scanning technology being tested in Orlando by Verified Identity Pass, which already operates a Registered Traveler program called Clear at Orlando and four other airports. The Clear shoe-scanning technology, developed by General Electric Security, was intended to detect traces of explosives and suspicious metal, and to allow most travelers to pass through Clear lanes without having to remove their shoes. But the scanner rejected an unexpectedly high number of travelers’ shoes in Orlando, requiring members to remove their shoes just as they would at regular checkpoints. Mr. Zmuda said Unisys, which plans to be operating in 6 to 10 airports within a year, will probably offer only a special lane for the I.D. cards in Reno while the company continues to study options that will provide more benefits. Steven Brill, the founder of Verified Identity, has said that not having to remove shoes is the biggest potential benefit sought by customers. But Mr. Zmuda said that “all of our survey data” show that not having to remove laptops from cases is the biggest benefit sought by potential members.

headline: Carter’s Long 3 at Buzzer Sends Nets Home Happy
text: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 29 — For all the heartache the Nets suffered in the early part of this five-game Western trip, vindication came in the sweetest form Monday night.

headline: September in January: School Bus Changes Sow Confusion
text: George A. Bonanno, a Manhattan professor, was startled to learn that under new city school bus routes going into effect yesterday, he would have to take his two children to separate bus stops about a mile apart, only so they could be ferried to the same elementary school.

headline: When Reporters Chose Sides: Spain Looks Back at Its Civil War
text: MADRID — It was “the golden age of foreign correspondents,” the historian Hugh Thomas wrote, a period in the late 1930s when the literary elite descended on Spain armed with a lust for adventure and belief in a cause.

headline: Mental Abilities: Folic Acid May Improve Thinking Skills
text: Folic acid dietary supplements significantly improve thinking skills that tend to decline with normal aging, a Dutch study has found.

headline: Father Weeps as He Recalls Learning of Dancer’s Killing
text: The father of a young woman who came to New York from Columbus, Ohio, to pursue a career as a dancer, but ended up with her throat slashed in her Upper East Side apartment, broke down and sobbed yesterday as he told jurors in State Supreme Court how he had learned of his daughter’s death.

headline: Starkest Choice for Jurors: Mercy or Death
text: And then there was nothing left to say.

headline: New Vaccine for Cervical Cancer Could Prove Useful in Men, Too
text: The new vaccine against human papillomavirus, which became available last summer, could potentially prevent thousands of cases of cervical cancer. But doctors hope the vaccine will be able to prevent a less well-known, but potentially fatal, disease in gay men, anal cancer. The same strains of HPV cause both cancers.

headline: Politics Could Scuttle Raising Pay for House Members
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The annual raise for members of the House is on the verge of being eaten up in political payback.

headline: Baseball: Cooperate, or the Bogeyman Will Get You
text: Bud Selig and George J. Mitchell, his chief steroids investigator, have unleashed the threat of Congress on Major League Baseball. However, Henry Waxman, the chief bogeyman, apparently is not ready to speak publicly about what he might be prepared to do if Mitchell’s investigation does not satisfy him.

headline: Spitzer’s Education Agenda Promises Aid Increase
text: ALBANY, Jan. 29  Gov. Eliot Spitzer declared on Monday that he would propose a major increase in state aid for New York’s public schools in his first budget and would seek vastly expanded oversight of local school districts, including wide powers to remove school boards or force the dismissal of superintendents for repeated failures.

headline: Not All Sports Icons Are Created Equal
text: There are more than a dozen buildings on Nike’s campus named for famous endorsers like Tiger Woods, Michael Jordan, Mia Hamm, Ken Griffey Jr., Pete Sampras, Lance Armstrong and John McEnroe.

headline: Bears Hope Takeaways Lead Them to a Title
text: MIAMI, Jan. 29  If the Chicago Bears win the turnover battle Sunday, they believe they will win the Super Bowl.

headline: Killer of 2 N.Y. Detectives Is Sentenced to Death
text: A jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn this evening sentenced Ronell Wilson to death for killing two New York City detectives.

headline: Tyson Returns to Profit
text: Tyson Foods, the meat processor, reported yesterday that it made its first profit in a year on improving beef and pork sales and the closing of plants to save money.

headline: Admiral Calls for ‘New and Different’ Approach in Iraq
text: The admiral who has been nominated to be the next head of the United States Central Command said today during a Senate confirmation hearing that a “new and different” course of action was needed in Iraq and he warned about Iran’s “support” for terrorism beyond its borders.

headline: Economist Wants Business and Social Aims to Be in Sync
text: Dani Rodrik, a trade economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, received his introduction to the idiosyncrasies of globalization while growing up in Turkey.

headline: Highway Exhaust Stunts Lung Growth, Study Finds
text: A new study suggests that children who grow up within a third of a mile of a freeway may be sustaining permanent respiratory problems.

headline: Mountain Glaciers Melting Faster, U.N. Says
text: The melting of mountain glaciers around the world continues to accelerate, the World Glacier Monitoring Service reported. According to the United Nations Environment Program, a partner with the service, surveys of 80 glaciers in mountain ranges around the world show they lost, on average, about two feet of ice thickness in 2005. Comprehensive data from 2006 were not yet available, the United Nations said, but since that year was one of the warmest on record, the accelerated shrinking is believed to be continuing. Since 1980, 30 reference glaciers in nine mountain ranges have lost, on average, the equivalent of more than 30 feet of ice thickness, the United Nations said. In a statement, Achim Steiner, executive director of the environment program, said the ice loss resulted from human-induced global warming.

headline: After 8 Hours on the Taxiway, You Might Want a Bill of Rights
text: THE air traffic system around Dallas basically snapped on Dec. 29.

text: To the Editor:

headline: State Is Investigating Lobbyist About Source of Contributions
text: ALBANY, Jan. 29  The state lobbying commission is investigating whether an Albany lobbyist masked the source of some of his clients’ political contributions by charging the clients for appearing at fund-raisers and then making campaign donations in his own name, according to court papers filed here Monday.

headline: Japan: Factory Output Rose to a Record in December
text: Japan’s factory output in December rose more than expected, to a record, fueled by higher overseas demand for automobiles and machinery. Industrial production climbed a seasonally adjusted 0.7 percent, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said in Tokyo. In the labor market, Japan’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 4.1 in December, slightly more than the 4.0 percent that was expected. In a sign of an improving employment market, the jobs-to-applicant ratio was 1.08 in December, meaning 108 jobs were available per 100 applicants.

headline: Eye on Cosmos Is Lost to Short Circuit on Hubble
text: The Hubble Space Telescope is flying partly blind across the heavens, a result of a short circuit on Saturday morning in its most popular instrument, the Advanced Camera for Surveys.

headline: Art Fowler, 84, Who Coached for Yankees Again and Again, Is Dead
text: Art Fowler, who became George Steinbrenner’s sixth, ninth, 17th and 26th Yankees pitching coach in a turbulent baseball pairing with his often hired and fired manager and drinking buddy Billy Martin, died yesterday in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 84.

headline: Dash of Success Spices Up Gould’s Neighborhood
text: GURNEE, Ill., Jan. 23  If Robbie Gould, the Chicago Bears’ place-kicker, was feeling the heat, he did not show it. Two days after kicking three field goals against the New Orleans Saints to help the Bears reach Super Bowl XLI, Gould was standing over a gas stove, stirring the alfredo sauce that was simmering in a pot.

headline: Queens: Wounded Teenager Is Charged
text: A 17-year-old who was shot on Sunday when he tried to grab an off-duty police officer’s pistol during a struggle in Jackson Heights was charged yesterday with attempted third-degree robbery, the police said. The teenager, Edwin Guaman, remained at Elmhurst Hospital Center last evening, the police said. The officer, Lt. Jose Jacome, a 16-year veteran assigned to the 110th Precinct, came upon Mr. Guaman and another man early Sunday beating a third person who was yelling that he was being robbed, the police said. Lieutenant Jacome identified himself as a police officer and tried to stop the robbery, the police said. It remained unclear yesterday whether the shot was accidental and who fired it, the police said.

headline: Odd Dish for a Diet
text: As former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas heads to Iowa this week in his quest for the Republican presidential nomination, one piece of his platform may be unique: his weight loss.

headline: Pursuing Happiness, Greeks and Turks Find One Another
text: ATHENS — A short decade ago, a blink in the centuries of bad blood between Greeks and Turks, there was “no way” a Turkish store could have opened at a fancy mall in Athens. So said Elena Kanellopoulou, 60, as she meandered through Athens’ first megamall, stopping a few steps from an upscale women’s shop with a clock in the display window showing the time in Istanbul.

headline: Rumors Fly About Bristol, Lifting Stock
text: Ever since Bristol-Myers Squibb named an interim chief executive last fall, the market has been primed for a takeover of the drug company. So yesterday, all it took was one rumor printed as fact to incite a buying frenzy.

headline: Williams and Federer Look to Stay on the Right Path
text: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29 — It was a cool summer night Down Under, and Serena Williams, the new women’s champion at the Australian Open, was sitting in the stands under a floppy hat watching Roger Federer carve up Fernando González in straight sets in the men’s final.

headline: Baquet Rejoins Times as Washington Bureau Chief
text: Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, effective March 5.

headline: Playing Mozart and His Pal, Funky Funky, uh, Mozart
text: Duke Ellington’s quip that there are only two kinds of music — good and the other kind — was apposite on Saturday night at Merkin Concert Hall in a concert celebrating Mozart’s 251st birthday. The uninitiated might have heard two kinds of music, classical and jazz. But in Ellington’s terms there was only one: excellent.

headline: Digging Past the Familiar to Find Beethoven Treasures, Some Knotty and Some Nice
text: Beethoven’s three most famous piano sonatas have names. You know what they are. The more-than-casual listener will identify three, arguably four more, also with poetic titles attached. Add to these the last three sonatas, which no one interested in this composer’s late period will have avoided. This leaves 22 Beethoven piano sonatas that, aside from music students, hardly anyone knows at all.

headline: 6-Month Home Detention for Executive
text: A former executive at Computer Associates was sentenced to six months of home detention yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiracy charges in connection with a scheme to bolster the company’s quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

headline: Poison Begets Poison
text: Poison Begets Poison

headline: Agency Says Higher Casualty Total Was Posted in Error
text: For the last few months, anyone who consulted the Veterans Affairs Department’s Web site to learn how many American troops had been wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan would have found this number: 50,508.

headline: Family Copes With a Disease It Well Knows Can Be Fatal
text: She lost Joey to asthma shortly before he was to turn 11 — a searing memory for Earline Sierra, who recalls that as her son was having another of his many asthma attacks, “he was talking to me, and he turned blue, and he stopped breathing.”

headline: Battle Pits Patent Rights Against Low-Cost Generic Drugs
text: NEW DELHI, Jan. 29  The supply of low-cost generic versions of cancer and AIDS treatments for the developing world could be blocked if Novartis wins a legal challenge to India’s patent law, patients’ rights groups have contended.

headline: In Queens Blackout, Report Finds Some Fault With Regulators
text: The staff size at the New York State Public Service Commission declined by nearly one-third under the Pataki administration, and the reduction contributed to a failure by the agency to adequately monitor Consolidated Edison’s performance, according to a report to be released today by a State Assembly task force.

headline: Turks Arrest 47 on Suspicion of Terror Links
text: TRABZON, Turkey, Jan. 29  In simultaneous operations carried out in five Turkish cities on Monday, the police arrested 47 people suspected of being Islamic militants, including the leader of Al Qaeda in Turkey, the semi-official Anatolian news agency reported.

headline: Using Quickness, Colts’ Freeney Is Spinning Into Control
text: Dwight Freeney remembers trembling as he stood on the manicured grass, so anxious he could barely focus on his target.

headline: Merrill to Buy First Republic, Seeking to Add Wealthy Clients
text: Merrill Lynch said yesterday it had agreed to buy the First Republic Bank for $1.8 billion in cash and stock to gain clients with an average net worth of $20 million.

headline: Mad About Mary
text: Once upon a time, asking about someone’s children was like talking about the weather. Then again, once upon a time talking about the weather was also like talking about the weather — not a portal into the political or the apocalyptic. But that’s another story. The point is that children made for the kind of paltry social currency you could exchange with your in-flight neighbor, back when the only other option might have been: “As you’re carrying that knife and wearing full camouflage, is it safe to conclude that the vegetarian meal is mine?” Then came children as designer accessories and politically charged pawns, appendages and admissions statistics.

headline: Bonds and Giants Complete a Deal Worth $15.8 Million
text: Almost two months after Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants agreed on the financial part of a one-year, $15.8 million contract, the two sides finally completed the remaining aspects of the deal last night. So Bonds will return to San Francisco for 2007, needing 22 home runs to break Hank Aaron’s career record of 755.

headline: Barbaro’s Desperate Fight for Life Gripped a Nation in Anguish
text: We fretted over this horse as if we all had a piece of him. The news media covered him like a saddle, from the moments after he shattered his right hind leg last spring in the Preakness Stakes. The country seemed to pause for reflection, and in many cases for prayer, with every bulletin from Kennett Square, Pa., where Barbaro was nursed for the past eight months and was finally euthanized yesterday in a medical surrender to the harsh realities of thoroughbred racing.

headline: Veterinarian Says Goodbye to a Patient
text: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 29 — In the minutes before an overdose of an anesthetic was given to Barbaro on Monday morning to terminate his life, Dr. Dean Richardson took a moment to say goodbye. For Richardson, the surgeon who worked so hard to save Barbaro’s life and who developed an emotional attachment to his famous patient, it was a final, and intensely poignant, moment.

headline: G.M. Shifts Saturn Ad Account to Deutsch
text: General Motors, once reluctant to change agencies on its principal brands, is doing so again for the second time in four months.

headline: Bobby Ross, Citing Lack of Energy, Retires at 70
text: Bobby Ross, who improved Army’s football program in his three years as the coach but could not produce a winning season, retired yesterday at 70. He will be succeeded by Stan Brock, an N.F.L. offensive lineman for 16 years and Ross’s offensive line coach at Army.

headline: Reporter Disputes Libby in Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A former New York Times reporter testified today that I. Lewis Libby Jr. disclosed the identity of a C.I.A. agent to her more than two weeks before Mr. Libby has said he learned of the agent’s identity.

headline: World Scientists Near Consensus on Warming
text: PARIS, Jan. 29 — Scientists from across the world gathered Monday to hammer out the final details of an authoritative report on climate change that is expected to project centuries of rising temperatures and sea levels unless there are curbs in emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.

headline: Deborah Orin-Eilbeck, 59, Political Reporter, Dies
text: Deborah Orin-Eilbeck, the Washington bureau chief and a columnist for The New York Post, died on Sunday at a hospital near her home in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: When the Simple Solution Is the Right One
text: I had run way too far for my level of training, and I knew it. But I had gotten lost, and the fastest way back to my car was to run. The next day, my left forefoot hurt so much I could hardly walk, so I did just what you might expect — I checked the Internet to see what sort of injury I might have and what to do about it.

headline: As Airlines Surge, Pilots Want Share
text: Now it’s the pilots’ turn.

headline: A Country’s Cultural Centerpiece Comes Calling
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 — The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, celebrating its 70th anniversary, is one of the burnished centerpieces of Israeli cultural life, a distinguished institution that resonates powerfully with the Jewish diaspora whose sympathy and support remain so important to this small Jewish state.

headline: Computer Gets It Wrong in Medical Admission Test
text: When Daniel Sonshine, a senior at Brown University, took the Medical College Admission Test on Saturday, he was asked to read a passage on robotic fish in the verbal reasoning part of the exam. Then he was presented with a series of questions about songbirds.

headline: Mattel Profit Rises 2.6%
text: Mattel Inc., the world’s largest toy maker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit unexpectedly rose 2.6 percent on holiday sales of Barbie dolls and Fisher-Price toys.

headline: Robert Drinan Dies at 86; Pioneer as Lawmaker Priest
text: The Rev. Robert F. Drinan, the first Roman Catholic priest to become a voting member of Congress, and the first congressman to call for the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 86.

headline: No Snow, No Mush
text: An annual dog sled race across the Pyrenees and taking in Spain, France and Andorra was canceled because of a lack of snow. “It’s the first time in its 17 years of existence that it has ever been canceled,” Cristina Lopez, the event’s spokeswoman, told Reuters. About 50 teams from eight countries had signed up to participate.

headline: Robert Wilson, Beckett and a Celebrity From the Neck Up
text: A long-anticipated encounter between two giants of avant-garde theater is currently taking place in New York City — not on a stage but at an art gallery.

headline: No Offense, but ...
text: President Bush says he had no intention of offending members of the other party when he said in his State of the Union address, “I congratulate the Democrat majority.” In an interview yesterday, Juan Williams of NPR asked Mr. Bush about dropping the “ic,” something the president does regularly, to the intense annoyance of many Democrats.

headline: Bronx: Man Is Charged in Fatal Attack
text: A man has been charged with fatally stabbing a fellow resident of an apartment building run by a nonprofit group in Morrisania, the police said yesterday. The man, Lee Ruffin, 29, of the Bronx, was charged with murder, the police said. He is accused of repeatedly stabbing an unidentified 53-year-old man shortly before 4 a.m. on Sunday at Webster House, at 1075 Webster Avenue, the police said. The building is operated by Volunteers of America under an agreement with the city.

headline: Transportation Chief Takes a CUNY Post
text: New York City’s transportation commissioner, Iris Weinshall, is leaving her post to become a vice chancellor of the City University of New York, officials said yesterday.

headline: Looking to the Hudson for Rockland’s Water Needs
text: STONY POINT, N.Y., Jan. 24  There was a time not long ago when the Hudson River was little more than a convenient dump site, a river so heavily used and contaminated that a state commission once referred to it as New York’s open sewer. But Rockland County residents may soon be drinking its water.

headline: Child Care: Ear Tubes Not Found to Affect Development
text: Inserting tubes in children with persistent fluid in the ear does not lead to better developmental outcomes as the children age, a new study reports.

headline: Jersey City: Officer Surrenders After Officer’s Boy’s Death
text: A Jersey City police officer who had been sought on a manslaughter charge in a drunken driving case surrendered to prosecutors yesterday, the authorities said. The officer, Kevin Freibott, 38, of Red Bank, was charged with drunken driving and assault by automobile after critically injuring a 2-year-old boy and his mother on Jan. 23, the police said. Prosecutors upgraded the charges to manslaughter after the boy died on Saturday night, but Officer Freibott could not be found, they said. John A. Young Jr., Officer Freibott’s lawyer, said the officer moved his family on Sunday morning to another location after receiving “disturbing calls” at his home. “He was never a fugitive,” Mr. Young said. “He wasn’t running. His family is here. His children are here. He wasn’t going anywhere.”

headline: Tethers to the Senate
text: The senators eyeing the White House — there are six or seven, depending on whether one counts Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska — face a scheduling problem that does not torture their non-Senate rivals. Because of the Senate’s close partisan divide, most members are reluctant to miss votes to hit the campaign trail.

headline: Waving the Flag at Bunny Ranch
text: It’s high time that the Department of Homeland Security investigated “Hannity’s America.”

headline: Oh, the Rivalry! And That’s Off the Field.
text: RENSSELAER, Ind., Jan. 24 — The happy couple, Indianapolis Colts fans, bounded into the tattoo shop on the main square of this small city, unaware they had just crossed into enemy territory.

headline: A League of Their Own
