headline: Japan: Fury Over Minister’s Comment on Women
text: An uproar over a cabinet minister who called women “baby-making devices” sent Prime Minister Shinzo Abe scrambling to control damage to his already falling popularity. In Parliament, Mr. Abe said the remark by his health minister, Hakuo Yanagisawa, left, was “inappropriate” and said he had reprimanded him. Mr. Yanagisawa also apologized for the remark, made Saturday at a political rally while calling on women to reverse Japan’s declining birthrate by bearing more children. The remark was the second recent slip of the tongue by a member of Mr. Abe’s administration. Last week, the defense minister, Fumio Kyuma, said President Bush “made a mistake” in attacking Iraq, contradicting Tokyo’s official pro-Washington stance. An opinion poll released yesterday by the newspaper Mainichi Shimbun showed Mr. Abe’s approval has fallen to 40 percent, down from almost 70 percent when he took office in September.

headline: Air America to Be Acquired by New York Investor
text: Air America Radio, the liberal network that filed for bankruptcy protection in October, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to be acquired by Stephen L. Green, the chairman of a real estate investment trust specializing in office buildings.

headline: Views of a Neighbor
text: The instruments aboard NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, now in the third month of its scientific mission, have taken expansive global images, like a downward look at Mars' north polar region and colorful close-ups. The orbiter's high-resolution camera was able to spot not only where the Opportunity rover is exploring, but even its tracks in the sand. Elsewhere, the sharper-than-ever images have revealed large boulders in areas that previously looked smooth, which led NASA to reconsider the landing site for its Phoenix mission, scheduled to set down in 2008.

headline: In the Rockies, Pines Die and Bears Feel It
text: Jesse Logan retired in July as head of the beetle research unit for the United States Forest Service at the Rocky Mountain Laboratory in Utah. He is an authority on the effects of temperature on insect life cycles. That expertise has landed him smack in the middle of a debate over protecting grizzly bears.

headline: In Connecticut, World’s Oldest Woman Dies at 114
text: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 29 — To say Emma Faust Tillman lived a full life would be an epic understatement.

headline: Non-Celebrities on the Web, Seeming to Make Non-Pitches
text: THE commercials are rambling musings by the comedian Demetri Martin that seem to have little to do with the product, Microsoft’s new Windows Vista operating system.

headline: Headstrong or Pigheaded, Carter Paces the Irish
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 29  Russell Carter has been thrown out of basketball practice at Notre Dame for a variety of reasons the past four years. There has been bad body language, a lack of interest in defense and a few confrontations with Coach Mike Brey, who laughingly refers to the incidents as “good theater for the players and staff.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about “China Blue,” a documentary about life inside a bluejeans factory in China, referred incorrectly to its clients. Levi Strauss does not buy jeans from it.

headline: Totals
Can Humanity Survive? Want to Bet on It?
text: Sixty years ago, a group of physicists concerned about nuclear weapons created the Doomsday Clock and set its hands at seven minutes to midnight. Now, the clock’s keepers, alarmed by new dangers like climate change, have moved the hands up to 11:55 p.m.

headline: Baby Found Dead in Bronx Trash Chute
text: The body of an infant girl was discovered yesterday afternoon at the bottom of a trash chute in a Bronx apartment building, the police said.

headline: Harvard Analysis Casts Doubt on Works Said to Be Pollocks
text: A yearlong scientific analysis by the Harvard University Art Museums of three paintings discovered in 2003 and considered to be possible works by Jackson Pollock has found that some of the pigments used in the paints were not patented or commercially available until long after Pollock died in 1956.

headline: ‘House,’ Already Strong, Gets a Boost
text: LOS ANGELES — Even after a couple of weeks of giddy two-hour ratings for “American Idol” on Tuesday nights, the Fox network has no trepidation in turning to a drama to follow “Idol” at 9 this Tuesday, because the drama in question, “House,” is already the strongest scripted hour that Fox has to offer.

headline: Moore Looking to Shed Journeyman Tag as a Net
text: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 29  Road games are often a homecoming for Nets center Mikki Moore.

headline: An Effort to Get More Fans to Meet the Mets
text: For more than an hour, five of the Mets’ better-known players had been posing for photographs, signing autographs, shaking hands and exchanging high-fives, when Judi Millar made a slightly less common request of Tom Glavine. Her co-worker Paul is a huge Braves fan and, well, it would mean a lot to him if you said hi, she told Glavine. Millar handed Glavine her cellphone.

headline: A Researcher for Microsoft Is Reported Missing at Sea
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  The Coast Guard is searching for a computer scientist from Microsoft who left for a daylong sailing trip off the coast of San Francisco on Sunday and did not return.

headline: Serial Child Molester Receives Maximum Term in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  A man who the authorities said had sexually abused hundreds of young boys in several states was sentenced Monday in a California courtroom to 152 years to life in prison for molesting two 12-year-olds.

headline: Francis Returns, and So Do Questions and Doubts
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 29  Steve Francis reappeared at the Knicks’ training center Monday morning, and for the second time in a year, he joined a team in disarray, with no clear sense of where or how  or if  he fits in.

headline: After 8 Months Filled by Hope, Setback Ends Barbaro’s Battle
text: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 29 — In eight months of waiting for Barbaro’s shattered bones to heal, the horse’s owners and his veterinarian said they had not seen the Kentucky Derby-winning colt become so uncomfortable that he would refuse to lie down and rest. Until Sunday night.

headline: Ex-Bush Aide, in Testimony, Disputes Libby
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — Ari Fleischer, the former White House press secretary, recounted to a jury on Monday his experience at an unusual lunch on July 7, 2003, during which he said that I. Lewis Libby Jr. passed on detailed information about the identity of a Central Intelligence Agency operative.

headline: The Claim: The Pill Can Make You Put On Weight
text: THE FACTS Quick weight gain may be among the birth-control pill’s most dreaded side effects. But how much does it really add to your waistline?

headline: Peace on Earth
text: Why bet against doomsday? I give a few reasons in my “Findings” column today (about my wager against a prophet of doom, Martin Rees). If you’d like more cause for cheer, take a look at Edge, the Web site dedicated to a “third culture” bridging the gap between scientists and other intellectuals.

headline: Health Literacy Test
text: How many of these words can you read aloud and pronounce correctly, each within five seconds? Start with the first column, reading down. Skip those you cannot read.

headline: Profit Slips at Sony on Losses for PlayStation 3

text: A weekend in Aspen, a town that looks to its past to define its future.

text: Spring 2007s dueling personalities  and the beauties who embody them.

headline: Readers Respond With a Library of Ideas
text: Last week, Nick wrote that we should go the classics to find better analogies than Vietnam for the situation in Iraq. This blog asked readers what other classics beyond Moby-Dick or the Aeneid that they thought would be appropriate analogies for President Bush and Iraq.

headline: The Midnight Train to Strasbourg
text: With the arrival of a high-speed train, this Alsatian city may become a weekend destination for partygoers.

headline: Do You Know Your Health I.Q.?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Jews of Cuba
text: A small group, of 1,500 Jews works to keep tradition alive on the island.

headline: Shakespeare in the Park
text: Those crazy Veronese lovebirds have scheduled a date in Central Park this summer.

headline: Boost in London Ticket Sales
text: For London theaters it was a very good year, Reuters reported.

headline: There’s a Lot Happening ‘On the Ground’
text: This blog has become a hive of activity in the last week and, since the following post is so long, here’s a recap of what’s going on here. We don’t want things to get lost or forgotten.

headline: Cyberonics Capitulates in Proxy Battle
text: Metropolitan Capital Advisors won its proxy battle for control of Cyberonics, a maker of medical devices, on Monday when, days before its annual shareholder meeting, the company said it had appointed three directors backed by the dissident shareholders.

headline: MBIA to Pay $75 Million in Settlement
text: MBIA, the large insurer of municipal bonds, has agreed to pay $75 million to settle civil securities-fraud charges by federal and New York State authorities over what they said was a sham $170 million transaction in 1998, the company and regulators announced Monday.

headline: Giants-Bills, Super Bowl XXV
text: (Classic rewind: How The Times covered Super Bowl XXV. Where were you when Scott Norwood missed his 47-yard field-goal attempt wide right?)

headline: Strange Buyout-Fellows: Henry Kravis and Steven Cohen
text: SAC Capital Partners, the giant hedge fund managed by Steven Cohen, grew to prominence by making fast trades for quick profits. In recent years, it has sometimes taken larger positions in companies and held them longer, occasionally even playing the role of activist investor. Now it has teamed up with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, a veteran of the relatively long-term business of private equity investing, as well as a slew of other firms in the $3.1 billion, management-led buyout of Laureate Education, which runs campus-based and online universities.

headline: CNet Restatement Goes Back to 1996
text: CNet Networks, the online publisher of technology news and reviews, has restated earnings going back to 1996 to reflect $105.7 million in costs for backdated stock options. The company also amended a million stock options granted to executives to reflect market prices. Shelby W. Bonnie, the former chief executive, agreed to reprice 700,000 unexercised shares, the company said on Monday.

headline: Hedge Fund Pans Northwest’s Bankruptcy Plan
text: A hedge fund that owns 5 percent of Northwest Airlines is calling for the bankrupt carrier to meet with shareholders to develop a reorganization plan that returns their investment. “To start, the company must agree to give its stockholders a voice in the bankruptcy,” said Jeffrey Altman, founder of the hedge fund, Owl Creek Asset Management, in a letter to Northwest dated Jan. 26. Under its reorganization plan, Northwest will cancel existing stock and current shareholders are expected to receive nothing.

headline: 2 Producers Without A Home Hang Their Own Shingle
text: Gail Berman and Lloyd Braun, two Hollywood executives who formerly ran network entertainment divisions, have created a company to produce entertainment for television, films and the Internet, according to press reports. No details of the partnership have yet been announced, but The New York Times reported that the duo has been meeting with potential partners in Hollywood and seeking office space.

headline: Symantec to Buy Software Tracker
text: Symantec, a maker of computer antivirus products, will buy Altiris for about $1.03 billion to gain programs that track corporate software use. Altiris shareholders will receive $33 a share in cash, 22 percent more than Altiris’s closing price of $27.14 on Friday. The purchase price includes about $200 million Altiris has in cash on hand and short-term investments.

headline: 6-Month Home Detention for Executive
text: A former executive at Computer Associates was sentenced to six months of home detention yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiracy charges in connection with a scheme to bolster the company’s quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts. Judge I. Leo Glasser of Federal District Court sentenced David Kaplan, former senior vice president for finance, at a hearing in Brooklyn. Mr. Kaplan was also ordered to serve three years of supervised release

headline: Tesoro to Buy Shell Refinery
text: Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it would sell its Los Angeles refinery and related assets to Tesoro. Tesoro will pay $1.63 billion, plus the value of oil inventory at closing. Tesoro’s chief executive, Bruce A. Smith, said the purchase would give Tesoro earnings growth even as it faces flatter gasoline margins.

headline: 2 Former Cendant Executives Spared Prison Sentences
text: Two former executives of Cendant were spared prison time on Monday for their roles in an accounting scandal that cost the company and its investors more than $3 billion. One of them, Anne Pember, 47, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy in 2000, was sentenced to two years’ probation and 200 hours of community service. The other, Casper Sabatino, 54, a former accountant who admitted wire-fraud charges and cooperated with federal prosecutors, was sentenced to two years’ probation.

headline: I.B.M. Gobbles Up Softek
text: I.B.M. has agreed to buy Softek Storage Solutions, which provides software for data storage management, for an undisclosed amount. Softek will become part of the storage and data services unit of IBM Global Technology Services.

headline: HealthSouth Sells Outpatient Division
text: HealthSouth, seeking to focus on its inpatient business, said Monday it sold its outpatient rehabilitation division to privately held Select Medicalfor about $245 million in cash. Investors cheered the sale of the division, which some analysts said fetched about 20 percent more than expected.

headline: Shareholder Information Goes Online
text: Companies issuing information to shareholders will at last be allowed to use the Internet as a legal method of delivery beginning July 1, 2007, according to new rules published by the Securities and Exchange Commission last week. Under the current rules, proxy materials and annual reports must be delivered in hard-copy form unless a shareholder specifically requests electronic delivery.

headline: Rumors Fly About Bristol, Lifting Stock
text: Ever since Bristol-Myers Squibb named an interim chief executive last fall, the market has been primed for a takeover of the drug company. So on Monday, all it took was one rumor printed as fact to incite a buying frenzy. A report in the French weekly La Lettre de L’Expansion said that Bristol-Myers had signed a premerger agreement to join forces with Sanofi-Aventis, a significantly larger French company, in a deal that would close this year.

headline: Steel Makers Prepare to Duke It Out Over Corus
text: The furnaces are stoked for a red-hot finish to the sale of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus Group, The Deal.com says India’s Tata Steel and its Brazilian rival Cia. Siderúrgica Nacional, are preparing to face off in a 10 hour, nine-round auction that begins Tuesday. The battle could spark offers dramatically higher than the 5.78 billion pounds ($11.33 billion) already on the table, according to The Deal.

headline: British Venture Capital Investor Raises Record Biotech Fund
text: A British venture capital investor, Abingworth, has raised Europe’s largest ever life sciences venture fund, worth 300 million pounds ($589 million), according to The Guardian. The news is a boon for the industry’s start-ups, which, according to the paper, have been lamenting the lack of venture capital funds for biotech firms in Britain.

headline: News Corp. Puts Cash Into Roo’s Pocket
text: The News Corporation is investing $1.3 million in an Australian Web video company, Roo, which provides technology for distributing and syndicating video content. News Corporation will initially take a 5 percent stake in the company, which already powers video services for several News Corporation Web properties, and an additional 5 percent if News Corporation reaches various revenue targets through Roo’s products and services.

headline: Former Coca-Cola Employee Denies Trade Theft
text: A former Coca-Cola aide said at her federal trial on Monday that, although she routinely took copies of company documents and e-mails home, she did not conspire to steal and sell trade secrets about the beverage company to its chief rival. “No. We never talked about anything like that whatsoever,” Joya Williams said when asked if she planned with two other defendants to steal and sell Coca-Cola documents to PepsiCo.

headline: NASD Fines Bank of America $3 Million
text: Bank of America was fined $3 million by the NASD Monday to settle charges it failed to follow rules designed to stop money laundering in its handling of accounts held by a single family. While the NASD did not identify the family, Reuters said that the accounts are identical to those held by Dallas billionaire Sam Wyly and his brother Charles, as described in an August 2006 report, “Tax Haven Abuses: The Enablers, the Tools and Secrecy,” by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

headline: United Bankshares Takes Premier for $200 Million
text: United Bankshares , a Charleston, W.Va., banking company, said Monday it agreed to buy Premier Community Bankshares for about $200.7 million to add more deposits in Virginia and the Washington, metropolitan area. Premier shareholders will receive 0.93 of a United share, equivalent to $33.73 based on Friday’s closing prices, or $34 in cash for each of their shares, with 50 percent to 65 percent paid in stock.

headline: Behind the Scenes of the Battle for Delta
text: Will another billion dollars make the difference between a stand-alone airline and a willing merger partner? That’s what US Airways may find out this week after some behind-the-scenes negotiating with Delta Air Lines creditors. According to press reports, US Air was asked over the weekend by some Delta creditors to again raise its $9.87 billion bid. The pro-merger creditors, which include a group of hedge funds, reportedly suggested that the airline raise its offer by $2 billion. US Air has been frustrated because the official creditors committee in Delta’s bankruptcy, the only party that can force Delta to allow due diligence by US Airways and otherwise get the merger talks started, has been silent.

headline: Providence Equity Said to Raise $12 Billion Fund
text: Providence Equity Partners raised $12 billion for its biggest-ever fund to buy media and communication companies, Bloomberg News said, following reports that the buyout shop had outstripped its original target of $8 billion. Highlighting increasing amount of cash coursing through the private equity industry, the latest fund would be three times bigger than the $4.25 billion Providence Equity collected in 2004.

headline: Texas Pacific One of 11 Bidders for Alitalia
text: Shares of Alitalia, Italy’s largest airline, jumped as much as 4.9 percent as a plan to sell the state’s stake in the unprofitable carrier attracted 11 possible bidders, including the Texas Pacific Group and UniCredit. The stock gained as much as 5.4 cents to 1.15 euros ($1.49) a share and was up 3.4 percent in Milan, valuing Rome-based Alitalia at 1.57 billion euros ($2 billion). Texas Pacific, which is part of a consortium buying Qantas Airways Ltd., Australia’s biggest carrier, said it would invite Italian and foreign investors to join an eventual offer to buy the company.

headline: Quattrone Takes the Stage, but Act II Remains a Mystery
text: What Frank P. Quattrone’s next act will be has become a parlor game among industry watchers. Is the former technology banker teaming up with former Credit Suisse colleagues to start an investment firm? Is he planning a tech-focused buyout shop? Will he join some of his biggest Silicon Valley supporters in venture capital?

headline: News Quiz: Laurels
text: Good morning, gang. No need to dilly-dally. Here are the answers to yesterday’s quiz:

headline: BAA Plans Mammoth Asset-Backed Bond Sale
text: BAA, the world’s biggest airport operator, will pledge at least $15.7 billion of assets from Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted to back a sale of bonds in the largest deal of its kind. BAA will sell the securities in March or early April to pay for debt that funded its takeover last year, according to Michael Wilkins, head of infrastructure finance at Standard & Poor’s. Bloomberg News said that BAA’s deal would exceed the record $12 billion of bonds and loans that Japan’s richest man, Masayoshi Son, issued last October to fund the acquisition of the cellphone operator Vodafone K.K. by pledging the company’s assets, income and shares as security.

headline: Shares of Kraft Foods Expected to Fall After Spinoff From Altria
text: The Altria Group is expected to announce the terms of the long-awaited spinoff of its stake in Kraft Foods on Wednesday, and several analysts said they expected Kraft’s shares to decline in the near term. Altria owns more than 88 percent of Kraft, the largest maker of food products in the United States, and is expected to disburse shares among Altria shareholders.

headline: Excerpt: 'On the Road in America'
text: Lara Abou Saifan, the series's production assistant, and cameraman Guy Livneh have a discussion about Israelis while visiting the Hamptons.

headline: Stock-Picker Showdown: Blodget vs. Cramer
text: Henry Blodget has some harsh words for James Cramer, the popular market pundit who hosts CNBC’s “Mad Money” show. Writing in a column for Slate, Mr. Blodget, the former Internet analyst, calls Mr. Cramer “perhaps the worst thing to happen to the financial security of average Americans since the crumbling of the Social Security system”. And that’s before he really gets going.

headline: On the Hill: Pay Raise Threat
text: Democrats are pushing Republicans to put their, um, mouths where their money is by threatening to block the annual congressional pay raise until legislation to increase the minimum wage is passed.

headline: Little Miss Hit and Miss
text: Scott Feinberg argues both for and against “Little Miss Sunshine” as a best picture winner. And when he finally runs out of hands, he decides the van’s on a roll that may not stop.

headline: Motorola Says Icahn Will Seek Board Seat
text: Motorola, Carl Icahn is calling.

headline: A Fine Wrestler and a Very Natty Dresser
text: The British version of GQ ranked men “shaping the fabric and direction of the nation” and put Sacha Baron Cohen at number 19, just behind Prince William.

headline: Tethers to the Senate
text: The senators eyeing the White House — there are six or seven, depending on whether one counts Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska — face a scheduling problem that does not torture their non-Senate rivals. Because of the Senate’s close partisan divide, most members are reluctant to miss votes to hit the campaign trail.

headline: Hanoi Jane’s Back and Rocking
text: Presidential spokesman Tony Snow is a huge fan of Jane Fonda, who has been nominated seven times for a best actress Oscar, and won for “Klute” and “Coming Home.” “You know, I mean, it’s nice to see Jane Fonda in front of a camera again,” Mr. Snow said of her appearance at an antiwar rally held on Saturday. The Bagger followed the rally closely and is glad that Ms. Fonda, 69, chose not to reprise her photo–op mounted on an anti-aircraft gun or her time doing the tomahawk chop as a Braves fan.

headline: No Offense, but…
text: President Bush says he had no intention of offending members of the other party when he said in his State of the Union address, ”I congratulate the Democrat majority.” In an interview yesterday, Juan Williams of NPR asked Mr. Bush about dropping the ”ic,” something the president does regularly, to the intense annoyance of many Democrats.

headline: Odd Dish for a Diet
text: As former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas heads to Iowa this week in his quest for the Republican presidential nomination, one piece of his platform may be unique: his weight loss.

headline: The Defeated: Where Are They Now?
text: Where do former lawmakers end up after being voted out of office? Farhana Hossain of The Times Washington bureau took a look at the paths taken by politicians who lost some of the most contested races in 2006. Here’s what she found:

headline: The Song  That Never Ends
text: The Bagger is in the smoking cage at LAX, an extremely crowded exterior “patio” surrounded by high bars. The last time the Bagger lent out this many ciggies, his jail name was “Pop Tart.” Not that he is complaining; the tobacco ceremony means that he is going home for the first time in almost three weeks.

headline: The War at Home: Nothing But Hearings in Sight
text: The Capitol is about Iraq today.

headline: Go Ahead, Front-load the Primaries
Battle Over the AIDS Memorial Quilt
text: The creator of the AIDS Memorial Quilt is locked in a legal tug of war with the quilt’s caretaker.

headline: Give the Hamburger Back to Wichita
text: Who invented the hamburger? Earlier this month, The New York Times’ Jennifer Medina explored whether the Edison of edibles hailed from Texas or New Haven, Conn. (Yale historian Andy Horowitz cast his vote for New Haven in the Times.) On the op-ed page of the Los Angeles Times, Josh Ozersky – online food editor for New York magazine and author of a forthcoming book, “Hamburgers: A Cultural History” – settles the debate: They’re both trying to hamburgle one of the claims to fame of Wichita, Kan. Ozersky writes:

headline: Wake Me When Davos Is Over
text: Michael Lewis is too busy for Davos, but he isn’t too busy to complain about it. “Examine the public statements extruded by the World Economic Forum any year and you’ll find the same warmed-over prudence, the same dreary feeling that someone is about to punctuate the nebulous tedium with a proposal to create a commission,” Lewis writes in his Bloomberg News column. He adds:

headline: The Schumer Book (No, He’s Not Running For President)
text: At Steve Rattner’s party in Manhattan last night to celebrate Senator Charles Schumer’s new book, “Positively American: Winning Back the Middle Class Majority One Family at a Time,” probably the best bit of ribbing belonged to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who urged the crowd to buy on Amazon.com to help the book’s ascent toward No. 1.

headline: The ‘Insufferable’ Schumer?
text: For the inside word on last night’s book party for Chuck Schumer at Steve Rattner’s apartment, here’s Pat Healy’s take.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: New Ohio Poll and Cash Reports
text: Even though she has higher negative ratings, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is ahead of Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain in Ohio, the ultimate swing state, according to a new Quinnipiac Poll.

headline: Global Climate Panel’s First Report Looks Dire, but Wait for Part 2
text: Tidbits of the much-anticipated report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change have trickled out over the last week or so — ahead of its official Friday release — and experts on the outside have dickered over whether the findings were spot-on. An early sense that the report would estimate rises in sea levels not quite as dramatic as had been predicted in the past, for instance, caused some chatter — and charges that the panel had failed to include the recent melt-off of large chunks of Greenland and Antarctica.

headline: Teacher Lands in Headlines With Bid for Alitalia
text: An Italian high school aviation teacher earning 1,200 euros ($1,500) a month became a minor celebrity in Italy on Tuesday by slipping through a fake plan to buy the ailing airline Alitalia as a protest against years of mismanagement, Reuters reports.

headline: Keller’s Announcement on Baquet and Taubman
text: Following is Executive Editor Bill Keller's memo to the newsroom this morning.

headline: Birth Video
text: A good-sized chip of Greenland has broken loose, and when Dennis Schmitt discovered it in 2005, it was probably the world’s newest island. Earlier this month, my colleague John Collins Rudolf illuminated climate change, snow-and-ice physics, and Greenland’s new cartography here.

headline: Feingold Tugs on Iraq Purse Strings
text: Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin is leading a hearing today in the Judiciary Committee about a topic that makes many of his fellow Democrats squirm: using the power of the purse to bring an end to the Iraq war.

headline: A Look at the Libby Trial
text: From witness to witness, the interplay between the Bush White House and the press has taken center stage at the trial of I. Lewis Libby.

headline: Analyst Cuts Rating on Clear Channel Stock
text: Another analyst is advising caution to shareholders of Clear Channel Communications  as the radio giant continues to seek support for a proposed $18.7 billion buyout. Jonathan Jacoby of Banc of America Securities on Tuesday cut his rating on Clear Channel to “neutral” from “buy,” writing that, even in the most optimistic scenarios, there is little room for the stock to continue rising. The downgrade comes amid reports that some major Clear Channel shareholders, including mutual-fund giant Fidelity, will vote against the $37.60-per-share offer to take it private.

headline: Survey: Young Muslims in Britain Are More Politicized. Blame Multiculturalism?
text: Results of a survey released yesterday by the Policy Exchange, a center-right British think tank, are causing a bit of a stir — chiefly for findings suggesting that 37 percent of young Muslims age 16 to 24 would prefer to live under Shariah law, the strict Muslim codes that govern every area of life, from prayers to style of dress.

headline: Bruno’s Budget Worries
text: Eliot Spitzer’s first budget hasn’t even been unveiled yet (that happens tomorrow) but the skirmishing has already begun with Senate Republicans. At a press conference this morning, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said he had concerns with much of what the governor has already said about the budget.

headline: $3.9 Million Homes
text: Tour a house on Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island, a log home in the Vail Valley in Colorado and a 20-acre estate in Napa, Calif.

headline: Static Clouds Time Warner Cable Offering
text: The long-awaited listing of shares in Time Warner Cable — the United States’ No. 2 cable provider after Comcast — could be delayed until March because of the legal wrangling in Adelphia Communications‘ bankruptcy case. That is one of the possibilities considered by Bear Stearns analyst Spencer Wang, who wrote in a research note Tuesday that, if the internecine battles among Adelphia’s creditors continue, Time Warner could decide to try a traditional initial public offering as opposed to floating the stock through a court-approved reorganization plan.

headline: Comptroller Rumblings
text: We caught up with Joseph L. Bruno, the GOP majority leader in the Senate, this morning at a conference of state county executives, when he was asked about the comptroller’s fight now underway. He briefly, and characteristically, addressed the angels-on-the-head-of-a-pin question now dominating the comptroller selection process, to wit: Were the three wise men supposed to pick precisely five finalists for the job, or up to five finalists?

headline: (Almost) 107 Men and Women in a Room
text: The Assembly Democrats just filed into their conference room to decide, behind closed doors, what to do about the comptroller situation.

headline: Smoking PIPEs and Getting Burned
text: Private investments in public equities, known as PIPEs, can be a valid source of financing for publicly traded companies. But they also have a controversial reputation, in part because of their susceptibility to stock manipulation. Forbes’ Nathan Vardi — in an article colorfully headlined “Sewer Pipes” — describes some particularly troubling examples. This week’s magazine offers a litany of cases of hedge-fund managers involved in PIPEs who allegedly duped investors, ran afoul of regulations and were convicted of fraud. “When it comes to dicey partners, though, few are as accomplished as the Grins,” Mr. Vardi writes.

headline: Wall Streeters Make Crain’s Under-40 List
text: Nasdaq‘s head of trading services and the co-head of Merrill Lynch‘s United States financial institutions group were among the Wall Street up-and-comers highlighted in this year’s “40 Under 40″ list from Crain’s New York Business. The weekly newspaper said the winners were selected by Crain’s editorial staff, which “closely scrutinizes each applicant, and leverages their comprehensive, multidisciplinary knowledge of New York’s business, culture and politics.”

headline: And You Thought That Rest-Area Men’s Room Was Repulsive
text: Citing estimates that put the cost of cars slamming into deer on American roadways at $1.4 billion a year, including property damage and bodily injury — not to mention the 200 human deaths each year from such crashes — officials and researchers from a number of states are pooling their resources to find ways to keep deer off the highway.

headline: Lebanon's Soothsayers
text: Clairvoyants have become Lebanon's unlikely political players as the country is racked by sectarian tension and political instability.

headline: Is Wall Street Really Losing Its Edge?
text: The people who are warning that New York is losing its dominance as a global financial center because of overregulation make up “a chorus of Cassandras,” James Surowiecki writes in the latest issue of The New Yorker. The article’s skeptical stance echoes Jenny Anderson’s Insider column in last week’s New York Times, in which she suggested there was some “undue panic” over the flight of companies to overseas markets.

headline: No White Smoke
text: The Assembly Democrats just took a brief break from their closed-door conference, where they are trying to figure out what to do about picking a comptroller.

headline: A Pre-Super Bowl Wardrobe Malfunction?
text: How cold is it in Chicago? Well, here’s an answer to that question you won’t hear every day: It’s cold enough to crack a giant fiberglass football helmet off the head of a bronze lion.

headline: A Sense of Place
text: Call it a Russian River Valley wine, not a cabernet sauvignon, says Appellation America. (Lars Klove for The New York Times ).

headline: Are Jobs Easy to Get?
text: One thing that changed after Sept. 11, 2001 is that it became a lot harder to persuade Americans that the employment situation looks good.

headline: Blogtalk: Evil Men and Wounded Democrats
text: Over the weekend Hillary Clinton made a joke about “evil men,” President Bush caught heat for his State of the Union reference to the “Democrat Party,” and the Iraqi Army fought a fierce battle with Shiite militants, a battle the president held as an example in the development of Iraqi soldiers. Today these topics, and new revelations about the battle, gave blogs lots of prime material.

headline: Baker and Hamilton on Troop Increase
text: James A. Baker 3d testified before the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee today amid speculation that he would criticize the troop increase proposed by President Bush, with whose family Mr. Baker has long been allied. Though he did not endorse the new strategy, the Iraq Study Group co-chairman did not condemn the plan, either.

headline: The Upside-Down Grill
text: New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, reintroduces the broiler.

headline: Our Secret Stash of Oil
text: Last week, in his State of the Union address, President Bush proposed to spend $65 billion from the government’s general fund to double the size of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. For most Americans, the reserve, where 700 million barrels of oil have been stored since the late 1970s, is mostly an article of faith: Few know that it’s located deep underground in four sites on the Gulf Coast, and because those sites are considered vital to national security, hardly anyone has seen it. But it’s time to take a closer look at the reserve’s purpose, its usefulness and its cost. Before we invest another $65 billion in this underground bank of oil, we should ask ourselves what we’re really getting for the money.

headline: Games That Sell While Others Languish
text: The Nintendo Wii, which uses an innovative wireless controller to translate the players’ motions onto the screen, has upset the order of the video game world. In electronics stores and elsewhere, there are growing signs that the Wii has taken the lead in buzz and sales over another new console, the Sony PlayStation 3, which offers new superlatives in processing power and graphics.

headline: For Hungary’s Avant-Garde, a Memorial and (Almost) a Birthday
text: Joel Sachs does nothing by half measures, it seems. Last year Mr. Sachs, the director of the Juilliard School’s annual Focus! festival and a mainstay of New York’s new-music scene, felt it was time to present a series devoted to contemporary Hungarian music. Soliciting the advice of colleagues was not enough, nor was traveling to Budapest: Mr. Sachs, according to his program note, spent July learning Hungarian.

headline: Senate Adds Tax Breaks as It Moves Ahead on a Wage Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to move ahead on a bill to increase the minimum wage, signaling that the measure is likely to pass this week.

headline: Tata Steel Buying Corus for $12 Billion
text: BANGALORE, India, Wednesday, Jan. 31 — When the bidding was over, Tata Steel stepped away as the winner in a heated battle for its European rival, the Corus Group, topping an offer from Brazil’s Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional. Tata agreed to at least pay $12.2 billion for Corus.

headline: Times Sharply Drops Value of New England Papers
text: The New York Times Company said today that it was writing down by $814.4 million the value of its New England newspapers, The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, which have suffered from sluggish advertising and a migration of readers to the Internet.

headline: Honesty in Elections
text: On Election Day last fall in Maryland, fliers were handed out in black neighborhoods with the heading “Democratic Sample Ballot” and photos of black Democratic leaders  and boxes checked off beside the names of the Republican candidates for senator and governor. They were a blatant attempt to fool black voters into thinking the Republican candidates were endorsed by black Democrats. In Orange County, Calif., 14,000 Latino voters got letters in Spanish saying it was a crime for immigrants to vote in a federal election. It didn’t say that immigrants who are citizens have the right to vote.

headline: Not-So-Strange Bedfellow
text: Here’s a little foreign policy test. I am going to describe two countries — “Country A” and “Country B” — and you tell me which one is America’s ally and which one is not.

headline: Bryant Barred for One Game After Hard Hit
text: In slow motion on computer screens around the country, especially in the N.B.A. offices, flashed the supposed Los Angeles crime scene from last weekend.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Jan. 13 about the writer Harold L. Humes misstated the time frame during which he served as campaign manager for Norman Mailer. He was the manager for Mr. Mailer’s aborted campaign for mayor of New York in the early 1960s, not in 1969. (Joe Flaherty was the manager of the campaign in that year.)

headline: Barbaro’s Plight Shined a Light on Advances
text: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 30 — Even after enduring eight months of searing emotions, the people most involved in attempting to save the Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro said the costly and complicated effort was a worthwhile pursuit.

headline: A Threat to Defy Spitzer on Comptroller Selection
text: ALBANY, Jan. 30 — Democratic lawmakers were leaning on Tuesday toward reneging on the deal they made with Gov. Eliot Spitzer and choosing one of their own as state comptroller — a stance that drew a furious reaction from the Spitzer administration.

headline: Iraq’s Refugees
text: To calculate the price that Iraqis have paid for the American misadventure in their country, you have to deal in big, round, horrifying numbers. Civilians killed last year: 34,000. Driven from their homes within Iraq: 1.8 million. Fled to other countries: an additional 2 million, and growing. The number of Iraqis who have found refuge in the United States is easier to pin down. This country has admitted a grand total of 466 Iraqi refugees since 2003.

headline: Manning Handles Questions as Easily as a Pass Rush
text: Miami

headline: Reyna Joins M.L.S., and Says He Hopes Others Will Follow
text: Claudio Reyna said it was time to come home.

headline: The Endlessly Maddening (for Liberals) Case of Ralph Nader
text: Early in the documentary “An Unreasonable Man,” it is noted that Ralph Nader is more likely to be remembered for his 2000 presidential campaign than for the decades of advocacy that preceded it. And the movie, an admiring but hardly uncritical portrait of Mr. Nader, confirms this suspicion by devoting nearly half of its more than two-hour running time to the 2000 election and its aftermath.

headline: G.M. Changes Agencies, Assigning Saturn to Deutsch
text: General Motors, once reluctant to change agencies on its principal brands, is doing so for the second time in four months.

headline: Lost Souls, and Puppets, in a Tour of the Afterlife
text: Walk into a New York theater at random and you have a decent chance of encountering a story about sex and its consequences, or a parody of some pop-culture phenomenon, or a tale of war and power. You have very little chance of encountering a play that looks beyond the earthly realm to the spiritual one. Life after death? Puh-lease; don’t be so unfashionable.

headline: Bush Promotes His Free Trade Initiatives
text: EAST PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 30 — With Democrats making the case that his economic policies have benefited the rich more than the middle class, President Bush struck back on Tuesday, in the first of back-to-back speeches promoting what the White House characterizes as 41 consecutive months of economic growth.

headline: For a Nation of Debaters, One Court to Rule Them All
text: A four-part program on PBS about the Supreme Court does not have to be boring, or so I believed as I sat down to watch a review copy of “The Supreme Court,” which begins tonight.

headline: U.P.S. Profit Is Up; Slower Growth Seen
text: United Parcel Service Inc. reported a 7.5 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, but said that profit growth would slow this year.

headline: A Hotel Room With Views of 5 Couples’ Relationships
text: “Room 314” cracks open the door of an anonymous hotel room where, at different times, five couples navigate critical moments in their relationships. But whether dealing with unrequited love, suicidal depression or what appears to be a booty call gone awry, no one is permitted to check out without a dose of self-knowledge. You certainly don’t get that at a Holiday Inn.

headline: New Products and Demand in Emerging Markets Fatten Profits at P.& G. and Colgate
text: Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive reported profits yesterday that exceeded analysts’ estimates on consumer demand for new razors and soap and increased sales to emerging markets.

headline: Vista Arrives With Limited Fanfare
text: Twelve years ago, Microsoft introduced a new operating system, Windows 95, in a frenzied global marketing blitz that was unlike anything the industry had ever seen.

headline: Megastores March Up Avenue, and Paris Takes to Barricades
text: PARIS, Jan. 30 — There was a time when the Champs-Élysées stood for grand living, high style and serendipity. With the Arc de Triomphe on one end and the Tuileries Gardens on the other, you could discover an underground jazz band at midnight and down oysters and Champagne at dawn.

headline: Expert Parking (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Icahn Seeks Board Seat at Motorola
text: Motorola, Carl C. Icahn is calling.

headline: Florida Gators on Top of Supercharged SEC
text: The basketball was a blur as it was passed among the Florida Gators. They were looking for the best shot, not merely a good shot. Open 18-footers were surrendered for open 10-footers, and Florida shot 58 percent in a rout of host Auburn last Saturday.

headline: Sally Mann Portrait in Which She’s the Star
text: Sally Mann came to the world’s attention in the early 1990s with her book and exhibition “Immediate Family,” a series of luminous, haunting photographs of her young children, Emmett, Virginia and Jessie, that evoked the languid anxiety of preadolescence, the sense of somnolent August days soon to vanish with the coming winds of maturity, sex and longing.

headline: Legislators Tell Coast Guard to Revamp Rebuilding Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Frustrated by reports of ships with cracking hulls, design flaws, cost overruns and construction delays, lawmakers demanded Tuesday that the Coast Guard’s leadership overhaul its $24 billion effort to rebuild its fleet or risk the program’s cancellation.

headline: Cheney and Critics: No Love Lost (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Italian Countryside, Just as Imagined
text: PERUGIA, Italy — Unlike many Americans who decide to follow their dream of restoring an abandoned Italian house in the countryside, Douglas Andrews knew exactly what he was getting into.

headline: To ’08 Hopefuls, Media Technology Can Be Friend or Foe
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — Some of the nation’s most enduring memories of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton — memories she would happily erase — were etched on television more than a decade ago: She didn’t stay home and bake cookies in her marriage. She wasn’t “some little woman, standing by my man, like Tammy Wynette.” The headband. The hairstyles.

headline: Raid at Hells Angels Club Leads to Dispute Over Arrest
text: A member of the New York chapter of the Hells Angels plans to file a suit against the city contending that he was illegally taken into custody after a search of the motorcycle club’s East Village headquarters on Monday.

headline: Jurors Can’t Be Excluded by Nationality, Judge Says
text: A federal magistrate judge has ruled that excluding prospective jurors because of their national origin is no more justified than barring them because of their race or sex.

headline: Biden Unwraps His Bid for ’08 With an Oops!
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 — In an era of meticulous political choreography, the staging of the kickoff for this presidential candidacy could hardly have gone worse.

headline: Nintendo’s Wii,  Radiating Fun, Is Eclipsing Sony Machine
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 — Some of the video game industry’s smartest minds thought that couch potatoes wanted richer graphics and more challenging virtual worlds. It turns out that a lot of potatoes simply wanted to get off the couch.

headline: Reporter Who Was Jailed Testifies in Libby Case
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — Judith Miller, a former reporter for The New York Times, testified Tuesday as a witness for the prosecutor who had put her in jail for 85 days, recounting details of her once-confidential interviews with I. Lewis Libby Jr.

headline: Brooklyn: Worker Killed in Fall
text: A day laborer doing tile work at a Brooklyn construction site died yesterday after he lost his bearings and fell four stories through an open elevator shaft, officials said. The man, whose identity was not immediately known, was pronounced dead at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center at 11:18 a.m., an hour after the accident, the police said. The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the city’s Buildings Department are investigating. A Buildings Department spokeswoman, Kate Lindquist, said that a stop work order was issued because no guardrails were in place, as required, around elevator openings. A superintendent at Nesher Construction, the general contractor, said that the victim worked for a subcontractor and that protective plywood had been in place over “all the elevator openings” at the start of work.

headline: Accord on Increasing Pell Grants
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The maximum federal grant for middle- and low-income students to attend college would increase for the first time in four years under a catchall spending bill that House and Senate Democrats agreed to on Tuesday.

headline: Manhattan: Waiters Sue Steakhouse
text: Four employees of the Old Homestead steakhouse in Chelsea filed a lawsuit yesterday in Federal District Court charging the restaurant with improperly operating a tipping pool, and with denying them minimum and overtime wages. The plaintiffs charge that the restaurant, at 56 Ninth Avenue, deprived its waiters of more than $1 million in income over the past six years. The suit, filed by Louis Pechman of the law firm of Berke-Weiss & Pechman LLP, claims Old Homestead operated a tipping pool for employees and managers who were not eligible to receive tips. According to federal and state labor laws, only those employees connected with the actual serving of food and beverages are eligible for participation in a tip pool. Marc Sherry, who owns the restaurant, said he was unaware of the suit and declined to comment.

headline: Second Schmertz for Millrose Hall
text: Of the 35 members in the Millrose Hall of Fame, all but one are renowned athletes. The only exception is Fred Schmertz, the meet director for 41 years. Now, Schmertz will be joined by his son, Howard, 81, who succeeded him and directed the Millrose Games, the world’s most celebrated indoor track and field meet, for 29 years, until 2003.

headline: From Arms to Art
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Two years ago, when the Noisette Company began its $3.5 million transformation of an abandoned warehouse at the shuttered United States Navy shipyard here, there were few takers for the 14 artists’ studios under construction.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Jan. 14 about A. I. Bezzerides, who wrote several novels that were adapted for films, omitted part of the title of one film and misidentified its director. The title is “On Dangerous Ground,” not “Dangerous Ground,” and the director was Nicholas Ray, not James Dassin.

headline: Essay Linking Liberal Jews and Anti-Semitism Sparks a Furor
text: The American Jewish Committee, an ardent defender of Israel, is known for speaking out against anti-Semitism, but this advocacy group has recently stirred up a bitter and emotional debate with a new target: liberal Jews.

headline: Songs From Sweden by Way of Britain and Two Epochs
text: Peter Bjorn and John kept flipping between two eras — the Merseybeat mid-1960s and the new wave early 1980s — during their sold-out set at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night. Both were times of crisp, upbeat, tuneful pop-rock: the first bright-eyed and fresh, the second more knowing and self-conscious. Peter Moren (on guitar), Bjorn Yttling (on bass) and John Eriksson (on drums) don’t set out to revolutionize their chosen styles, only to give them a brisk, smart workout.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Dec. 18 about Herbert Gursky, an astrophysicist who studied the sources of X-rays from outside the solar system, referred imprecisely to some of these sources. A distant star he discovered is in the constellation Scorpius, not Scorpio, and the star was designated Scorpius X-1, not just Scorpius. The first recorded example of a black hole, which he and others discovered in 1971, was designated Cygnus X-1 or Cygnus XR-1  not just Cygnus. The errors were pointed out on Dec. 19 in an e-mail message that was misdirected within The Times. The correction was further delayed for research.

headline: 4 Killed in Gas Explosion Near West Virginia Resort
text: An explosion at a store near a West Virginia ski resort yesterday killed four people and injured five others, the authorities said.

headline: Google Posts Sharp Rise in Sales and Profits
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 — Continuing its blockbuster growth, Google this afternoon reported a sharp rise in both sales and profits in the fourth quarter.

headline: The Interest Was There, but Not the Money
text: Kobe Bryant’s only Madison Square Garden appearance of the season was nullified yesterday by a suspension. Had the Knicks managed their payroll better, Bryant sightings at the Garden might not be so rare.

headline: Taking a Two-Century Voyage Through the Music of France
text: There’s something unfairly disarming about an all-French vocal recital. Both the language and the way French composers have woven music around it are so inherently seductive that, given a singer who has internalized both, resistance  or even detatchment  is futile. This repertory has always been high ground for the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, and for her recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening she and her pianist, Malcolm Martineau, explored it in an unusual way.

headline: Opening the Gates at an Army Base
text: PICATINNY ARSENAL, N.J., Jan. 24 — This huge military base in Morris County boasts that it has developed and deployed virtually all the lethal weaponry currently used by the United States Army. Now, the base will become a generator of revenue for itself by turning some of its vast real estate holdings into a high-tech research and development park.

headline: What You Get for ... $3.9 Million
text: Portsmouth, R.I.

headline: Summer Rentals: The Forecast Is Calm
text: The summer rental market used to be fairly predictable on the southern coast of Maine.

headline: Harrison Opens Up on the Field, Not Off It
text: MIAMI, Jan. 30  Close to the end of the hour, Marvin Harrison was perched on the edge of his seat, asking all the questions.

headline: Senate Allies of Bush Work to Halt Iraq Vote
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — The Bush administration’s allies in the Senate began a major effort on Tuesday to prevent a potentially embarrassing rejection of the president’s plan to push 20,000 more troops into Iraq.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about the extravagant 60th-birthday party planned for Stephen A. Schwarzman, a founder of the Blackstone Group, referred incorrectly to Katharine Graham’s presence at Truman Capote’s Black and White Ball, the New York social event of 1966. Mrs. Graham was the guest of honor; she was not simply one of Mr. Capote’s guests.

headline: An Ode to All the Magnificent Horses (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mystery Freight Train Out of Queens? It May Soon Be a Familiar Sight
text: EASTPORT, N.Y. — Gritty freight trains may be a familiar sight out West and in cowboy movies, but in Queens and Brooklyn and the neat suburbs of Long Island, they are a roaring, sooty cause for a big double take.

headline: Bidding War for Roofing Products Maker Is Over
text: ElkCorp, a maker of roofing and building products, said yesterday that it planned to accept a bid for the company from Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group.

headline: N.Y. Stock Exchange Chief Determined to Go East
text: The Village People sang “Go West.” John Thain, the chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, seems determined to go east.

headline: Iran May Have Trained Attackers That Killed 5 American Soldiers, U.S. and Iraqis Say
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 30 — Investigators say they believe that attackers who used American-style uniforms and weapons to infiltrate a secure compound and kill five American soldiers in Karbala on Jan. 20 may have been trained and financed by Iranian agents, according to American and Iraqi officials knowledgeable about the inquiry.

headline: Scientists Criticize White House Stance on Climate Change Findings
text: Under its new Democratic chairman, Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform took on the Bush administration’s handling of climate change science yesterday, and even the Republicans on the panel had little good to say about the administration’s actions.

headline: Deal Struck on Claims of Nazi Era
text: After nearly 10 years of struggling to have a big Italian insurance company pay claims on life insurance policies sold to victims of the Holocaust, lawyers who say they represent most of the victims are giving up the fight.

headline: Staten Island: Woman Shot Dead in Her Car
text: A woman was fatally shot in the head as she sat in the driver’s seat of her car last evening at a park-and-ride lot near Pleasant Plains Avenue, the police said. The woman, Jean Kane, 58, was declared dead on arrival at Staten Island South Hospital, the police said. An officer who was nearby heard the shot shortly before 6 p.m. and arrived at the scene to find Ms. Kane’s body slumped in her four-door gray Volkswagen. Investigators say that someone probably drove up to Ms. Kane’s car, got out, shot her through a window and drove away.

headline: A Soviet Agricultural Success: Vast Greenhouse Complex
text: MOSCOW, Jan. 29 — In a city starved for winter light, little could seem more out of a place than this: on a day dimmed to gray by a canopy of clouds, Russian workers in short sleeves picking green lettuce and fresh herbs, all while illuminated by brilliant light.

headline: Christie’s to Raise Its Fee
text: Taking a leaf from its rival Sotheby’s, the auction house Christie’s plans to raise the commission it charges buyers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: Lottery Numbers

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about an auction of silver that had been owned by the First Church in Salem, in Massachusetts, attributed an erroneous distinction to the church. The Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan, founded in 1628, is the oldest continuously operating Protestant congregation in the United States  not the First Church in Salem, which was founded a year later.

headline: Democrats’ Spending Plan Would Raise Some Budgets
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Bloomberg News)  Education, veterans’ health care, international AIDS relief and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are among the government programs that would receive more money this year under a spending plan released Tuesday by House Democrats.

headline: Dead Officer’s Son Asks Bush to Increase Aid to 9/11 Workers
text: After meeting with President Bush today, the son of a former police officer who died last week from an illness that may have been linked to his rescue work at the World Trade Center on 9/11 said Mr. Bush had assured him that he wanted to expand federal financing for the medical needs of people injured at ground zero.

headline: Fighting Eases on First Day of a Cease-Fire by Gaza Factions
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30  After five days of clashes in the Gaza Strip, Palestinian factions on Tuesday mostly observed the latest cease-fire, though one Hamas member was shot dead.

headline: Wall Street Finds a Lot to Like About Tobacco
text: There are plenty of reasons cigarettes would seem to be a terrible business.

headline: Murder Trial Hears Account of Marital War’s Last Fight
text: An Upper East Side man testified at his murder trial yesterday, describing what he saw as his wife’s decade-long mental breakdown and admitting that he grabbed a knife and stabbed her in the kitchen of their home.

headline: Cooking Under Pressure, That’s Reality
text: THE final two contestants on “Top Chef” didn’t get this far on character or charm.

headline: Big Trouble for a Small-Town Ingénue
text: As sopranos age, it is natural to expect their voices to mature, to grow darker and thicker. Karita Mattila is now 46. And, as her riveting portrayal of the title role of Janacek’s “Jenufa” on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera made vibrantly clear, Ms. Mattila’s artistry is maturing.

headline: A Changing Battle on AIDS Is Reflected in a Quilt
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 — It has been 20 years since Cleve Jones started the AIDS Memorial Quilt here, painting the name of a friend who had died from the disease on a simple piece of fabric.

headline: Bing Devine, Builder of World Series Winners, Dies at 90
text: Bing Devine, who transformed the St. Louis Cardinals and the Mets into World Series champions in the 1960s in a career spanning seven decades as a baseball executive, died Saturday in St. Louis. He was 90.

headline: A Little Bit of a Bad Thing Can Be Good
text: Forgive that older gentleman in Malibu, Calif., if he was not among the millions mesmerized by “American Idol” last night. For one thing, it was his 85th birthday, and he might have had better things to do. For another, this notion of singers so wincingly bad that you can’t turn away? Been there. Done that. About 40 years ago.

headline: Knicks Inject the Garden With a Buzz and a Win
text: The Los Angeles Lakers missed Kobe Bryant’s other-worldliness, fans at Madison Square Garden missed his showmanship and the Knicks, for once, did not miss the golden opportunity that was handed to them.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Friday about efforts by public colleges to attract minority students misstated the name of the organization headed by Roger Clegg that opposes racial preferences. It is the Center for Equal Opportunity, not the Council for Equal Opportunity.

headline: ESPN and the Tennis Channel Strike Deal on TV Rights
text: ESPN and the Tennis Channel agreed yesterday to share the rights to televise the French and Australian Opens, an arrangement that will bring a far higher profile to the Tennis Channel, which has 10 million subscribers.

headline: Britain: Top Blair Fund-Raiser Arrested Again
text: The Labor Party’s chief fund-raiser, Lord Levy, was arrested as part of an investigation into whether the party elevated people to the House of Lords in exchange for loans. It was the second time that Lord Levy, left, a close ally of Prime Minister Tony Blair, has been arrested in the inquiry; he has not been charged with a crime. The police have arrested three others, none of whom have been charged, in their investigation, and have spoken to more than 90 people, including Mr. Blair and Michael Howard, the former leader of the Conservative Party. A spokesman for Lord Levy said he “completely denies any allegations of wrongdoing whatsoever.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the future of relations between Turkey and Armenia following the funeral for Hrant Dink, a Turkish-Armenian newspaper editor killed in Istanbul on Jan. 19, misidentified the issue between the two countries that Turkey has said should be examined by a governmental history commission. It is the 1915 Armenian genocide — not the political status of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that Armenia claims but that Turkey recognizes as part of Azerbaijan. (Go to Article)

headline: Fed Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged today, as it has since last June, and it signaled that it will continue its holding pattern for some time to come.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,070 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: A Top Editor Returns to Times to Lead Washington Bureau
text: Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, effective March 5.

headline: Once a Dream Fuel, Palm Oil May Be an Eco-Nightmare
text: AMSTERDAM, Jan. 25  Just a few years ago, politicians and environmental groups in the Netherlands were thrilled by the early and rapid adoption of “sustainable energy,” achieved in part by coaxing electrical plants to use biofuel  in particular, palm oil from Southeast Asia.

headline: Mary Cheney Publicly Defends Her Pregnancy
text: Mary Cheney, the lesbian daughter of Vice President Dick Cheney, today for the first time publicly defended her decision to become pregnant and asserted that same-sex couples are equally capable of raising children as heterosexual couples.

headline: Ukraine: Pro-West Foreign Minister Quits
text: Boris I. Tarasyuk, the foreign minister, resigned after a constitutional dispute over his post. Mr. Tarasyuk has been a close ally of President Viktor A. Yushchenko and the most vocal proponent of leading Ukraine closer to the European Union and NATO. Parliament voted to dismiss him in December and later moved to remove the president’s power to appoint ministers overseeing foreign and defense matters, a move a weakened Mr. Yushchenko declared unconstitutional. Mr. Tarasyuk, in televised remarks reported by news agencies, said he resigned after a court hearing in the dispute was postponed. Mr. Yushchenko’s office declared that he would appoint a successor.

headline: Carter Harman, 88, Composer, Music Critic and Record Producer, Dies
text: Carter Harman, a composer, music critic, author and record producer, died on Jan. 23 in Stowe, Vt. He was 88 and lived in Waterbury, Vt.

headline: Mixed News for Wolves
text: The Interior Department’s decision on Monday to remove the gray wolves that inhabit the western Great Lakes region from the endangered species list represents yet another triumph for the much-maligned Endangered Species Act. First listed in 1974, when their numbers had dwindled to the low hundreds, the wolf population there now numbers about 4,000, thanks almost entirely to the act’s prohibitions on hunting and trapping. State and tribal governments will now be responsible for keeping their numbers at healthy levels.

headline: 50 Iraqis Die as Holiday Brings Spasm of Sectarian Killing
text: BAGHDAD, Jan. 30 — Women dressed in black had just set out large caldrons to cook the traditional feast on the holy day of Ashura, a simple meal of rice and lamb in a tomato-based sauce. Children crowded around the pots as men wailed in a ritualistic mourning ceremony and guards scanned the crowd at the Shiite mosque near Baquba for would-be killers.

headline: Kellogg Profit Falls 5% as Wheat Cost Rises
text: The Kellogg Company, the largest United States cereal maker, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 5.2 percent as wheat costs soared and the company spent more on advertising.

headline: Israeli Court Convicts Ex-Minister in Sex Scandal
text: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31  An Israeli court convicted Haim Ramon, a former justice minister, today on charges that, while in office, he forcibly kissed a young female soldier. The outcome in the highly publicized case has added to the cloud of scandal surrounding the country’s leadership.

headline: After Shooting, Amish School Embodies Effort to Heal
text: NICKEL MINES, Pa., Jan. 30 — Nearly four months ago, a milk delivery-truck driver lined up 10 girls in a one-room schoolhouse in this Amish farming community and opened fire, killing five of them and wounding five others before turning the gun on himself.

headline: Judge Puts Mayo Back in Big Game
text: A West Virginia judge ordered an injunction yesterday that allowed the high school basketball star O. J. Mayo to play last night in a game featuring two of the country’s top teams.

headline: Her Deadly Illness Becomes Her Family’s Struggle
text: The quinceañera photo hangs high up on the living room wall: Wanda Reynoso, at 15, in a sparkling white dress and a tiara, radiant against the pink backdrop.
Chefs on the Move

headline: 12 New Yorkers Among Finalists for National Science Prize
text: As a first grader, Kathryn Blair Friedman was so allergic to wheat, peanuts and sesame that she had to settle for carrots whenever her schoolmates celebrated class birthdays with cupcakes.

headline: State Farm Is There, Right by the Backboard
text: ALTHOUGH it seems that the only thing Madison Avenue is doing this week is making commercials for the Super Bowl, marketers are still finding ways to fill other sports spaces with advertising. If you doubt that, look up the next time you attend a college basketball game or watch one on television, and study the framework behind the backboard.

headline: American Road Trip Through Arab Eyes
text: “On the Road in America” looks, on first viewing, like the sort of television show that Al Jazeera and MTV might produce if they could be coaxed together in front of an editing terminal. A 12-part reality series, currently being broadcast throughout the Middle East, “On the Road” features a caravan of young, good-looking Arabs crisscrossing America on a mission to educate themselves and the people they encounter along the way.

headline: Molly Ivins, Populist Texas Columnist, Dies at 62
text: Molly Ivins, the liberal newspaper columnist who delighted in skewering politicians and interpreting, and mocking, her Texas culture, died today at her home in Austin. She was 62.

headline: Killing Puts Focus on Corruption in Chinese News Media
text: SHANGHAI, Jan. 30 — Lan Chengzhang sat in a car outside the office of a mining company while a colleague ventured inside to make inquiries.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Athens Protest Seeks Return of Elgin Marbles

headline: Economy Sped Up at End of 2006
text: The economy gained speed in the final three months of 2006, as Americans shrugged off the slump in the real estate market by spending more money on everything from computers to food.

headline: The Human Rights of a Disabled Child (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yahoo Planning to Add 100 Web Sites for Entertainment
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Jan. 30  Yahoo said Tuesday that it planned to build individual Web sites around 100 entertainment “brands” this year that would pull together content from Yahoo’s sprawling array of online properties.

headline: Hobbled by Disappointing Sales and a Loss at the Game Unit, Sony’s Profit Drops 5%
text: TOKYO, Jan. 30 — The dip in Sony’s quarterly earnings released early Tuesday underscores what many analysts call the biggest single challenge now facing the recovering Japanese electronics conglomerate: the shaky start of its long-awaited PlayStation 3 game console.

headline: Bears’ Anderson Likes Being in a Rush
text: MIAMI, Jan. 30 — As a rookie, Mark Anderson of the Chicago Bears has never played against Peyton Manning. Anderson hopes to introduce himself on Sunday. Because when Anderson meets quarterbacks, they often end up lying on the ground.

headline: U.S. Judge Ends 20-Year Case to Deport 2 Tied to Terrorists
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30  Chastising the government with poetry and blunt language, an immigration judge on Tuesday ended 20-year-old deportation proceedings against two of eight men who had been accused of ties to a Palestinian organization classified as a terrorist group.

headline: Two Donations, Deep in Tradition, Given to Neediest Cases Campaign
text: As the current campaign for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund entered it final days, two large donations from two different groups were being tallied yesterday.

headline: Libby’s Lawyers Question Reporter’s Memory
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 – A lawyer for I. Lewis Libby Jr. tried to portray a former New York Times reporter today as having a “fuzzy” memory of her conversations with Mr. Libby about a C.I.A. agent whose husband was a critic of the Bush administration.

headline: White House to Release Details on Eavesdropping
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31— Bowing to bipartisan pressure from lawmakers, the Justice Department announced today that it was turning over to select members of Congress secret documents detailing the National Security Agency’s domestic eavesdropping program.

headline: Choice for No. 2 at State Dept. Defends Bush’s Stance on Iran
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — John D. Negroponte, nominated as deputy secretary of state, defended the Bush administration’s more confrontational policy with Iran in a Senate confirmation hearing that was peppered with demands from both sides of the aisle that the United States show restraint in dealing with Tehran.

headline: All Over America, Wines Search for Identity
text: MAYBE it was the 2004 Peninsula Cellars riesling that I tried last fall out in San Francisco. It was dry and delicious with a minerally flavor that I don’t find so often in American rieslings. What surprised me most of all, though, was the wine’s provenance: Old Mission Peninsula, north of Traverse City, Mich.

headline: Ex-Enron Executive Reports to Prison
text: Michael J. Kopper, a former Enron Corporation finance executive who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt off its balance sheets, started serving a three-year prison sentence yesterday in Big Spring, Tex.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded: $7,409,805.46

headline: Joining China to Find a Yao Who Can Hit
text: BEIJING, Jan. 30  Two of the world’s most closely watched empires signed a deal here Tuesday. China wants a half-decent national baseball team. The Yankees want a toe in the Chinese sports market, and the chance to find  better yet, develop  Major League Baseball’s Yao Ming.

headline: Spitzer Unveils $120.6 Billion Budget Proposal
text: ALBANY, Jan. 31 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed a $120.6 billion budget today that would increase spending by 6.3 percent over the current fiscal year, a higher spending increase than many expected but one that allows the new governor to pay for his major campaign promises, including billions of dollars of property tax cuts and new education aid.

headline: In Killer’s Courtyard, Drawing Their Own Conclusions
text: On the sidewalk outside the Stapleton Houses on Staten Island, the dreary complex where Ronell Wilson once lived, people talked about the sentence that was handed up yesterday without mentioning the footnote.

headline: New York Lawmakers Obtain $25 Million for Ill 9/11 Workers
text: After impassioned pleas by members of New York’s Congressional delegation, the White House agreed yesterday to spend $25 million for the care and treatment of 9/11 rescue workers who became ill after being exposed to toxic dust at ground zero.

headline: F.D.A. Widens Safety Reviews on New Drugs
text: The Food and Drug Administration announced changes yesterday that were intended to ensure that marketed drugs are as safe as advertised, including the first effort to do a comprehensive assessment of the safety of drugs 18 months after introduction.

headline: German Court Seeks Arrest of 13 C.I.A. Agents
text: FRANKFURT, Jan. 31 — In the most serious legal challenge yet to the Central Intelligence Agency’s secret transfers of terrorism suspects, a German court has issued an arrest warrant for 13 people in connection with the mistaken kidnapping and jailing of a German citizen of Lebanese descent.

headline: Now, for $35, an Insider’s Access to Hot Tables
text: PEOPLE who go out to eat in New York can be divided in plenty of ways, but the division that matters most is this: You are either someone who can get a great table on a Saturday night, or you’re not.

headline: Jury Agrees on Death Sentence for the Killer of Two Detectives
text: A federal jury sentenced a 24-year-old Staten Island man to death yesterday for killing two undercover police detectives in 2003. It was the first successful federal capital punishment prosecution in New York in more than 50 years.

headline: Day 2 of New School Bus Routes Fails to End Confusion
text: For the second day, widespread confusion over changes in school bus routes roiled the New York City school system, leaving parents exasperated and bewildered.

headline: All Areas Open in New Blueprint for New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30  No neighborhoods would be off limits for development in a new $14 billion plan for this city’s recovery introduced Tuesday, the latest foray in a process that has been going on since shortly after Hurricane Katrina flooded New Orleans 17 months ago.

headline: Growing the Winter Tomato
text: Imagine a poem that is perfect in shape but refuses to say anything. And yet it sells well because it is the only kind of poem available for more than half the year, and people insist on reading poetry, even out of season. That is the winter tomato. In redness and roundness it says “tomato,” in every way except the one that matters: flavor.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Sunday about Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy gave the incorrect name in some copies of the city where one of his former assistants now coaches in the National Football League. Rod Marinelli is the head coach in Detroit, not Green Bay.

headline: Florida: $75 Million Donated to Hospital
text: The Boca Raton Community Hospital announced that it had received $75 million from the Schmidt Family Foundation, one of the largest gifts given to a hospital. The money will help underwrite a new academic medical center focusing on hospital safety. The center will expand Florida Atlantic University’s two-year medical training program to four years, qualifying students for a degree from the Miller School of Medicine at the University of Miami.

headline: What’s on Wednesday Night
text: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) WHAT REMAINS: THE LIFE AND WORK OF SALLY MANN “It never occurred to me to leave home to make art,” says the photographer Sally Mann, who built a career chronicling the lives of her children. “The things that are close to you are the things that you can photograph the best.” In this documentary from Steven Cantor, Ms. Mann embarks on a new project: a provocative photo series that explores the subject of death and decay through images of not only her son and two daughters but her husband, Larry, whose body is changing because of a rare form of muscular dystrophy. She also looks at how nature assimilates the body once life has left it, and in doing so confronts American attitudes toward death, through photographs examining the scars left on her property after an armed fugitive, being hunted by police, shot himself; landscapes from the Civil War battlefield of Antietam; a forensics study showing human decomposition; and images of the bones and skin of a pet greyhound long since departed.

headline: When Life Hands You Lemons, Make Pasta and Confit
text: WITH winter having unmistakably arrived, the sunny presence of lemons is more welcome than ever. Each year, demand for lemons peaks with the temperatures, as millions are squeezed for lemonade. But this is the time of year you need their brightness the most.

headline: Architectural Skills: Excellent. Personal Skills: Not So Good.
text: Listening to friends complain about their contractors is a familiar trial of New York living. But how many can claim to have heard a bona fide genius hold forth on this riveting topic?

headline: Italy: Minister Pleads for End to Party Squabbling
