text: Foreign Minister Massimo D’Alema issued an urgent plea to his political allies for an end to the bickering among parties that he worries could bring down the center-left government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi. “I am going to Japan,” he said in an interview in the newspaper La Repubblica. “I humbly ask our allies: Let there still be a government on my return.” Since taking power from Silvio Berluconi last spring, Mr. Prodi has faced deep divisions in his diverse, nine-party coalition. In recent days, a proposed law allowing for same-sex unions has added tension.

headline: Letters
text: Always Time for Her Baby

headline: The Many Roads Not Taken on the Way to Civil War
text: Historians tell stories. That is their profession. And the goal of storytelling is to impose order on a disorderly array of facts, to steer events toward a conclusion that seems satisfyingly final, even inevitable. In “Cry Havoc!” Nelson D. Lankford disrupts the process. He unravels the events that led the North and the South to war in the weeks after Lincoln’s inauguration in March 1861, disturbing the time-honored march of history with a series of provocative what-ifs. At every turn in a now familiar story, he suggests alternatives, missed opportunities and roads not taken.

headline: Mama Hugs Iowa
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa

headline: F.A.A. to Propose Letting Airline Pilots Fly Until Age 65
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 — The Federal Aviation Administration will propose allowing airline pilots to fly until they are 65 years old, dropping a 47-year requirement that they retire at 60, the agency’s administrator said on Tuesday.

headline: A Sitcom That’s All About Me, Sarah
text: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30  Those who know Sarah Silverman only from her much discussed star turn in the 2005 comedy film “The Aristocrats” and from her one-woman concert movie, “Sarah Silverman: Jesus Is Magic,” might bristle at the notion that another overnight wonder has been granted that holy grail of comedy, the self-titled sitcom.

headline: You Want Innovation? Offer a Prize
text: Besides the fact that both are considered great movies, “The Wizard of Oz” and “Silence of the Lambs” don’t have much in common. One is the story of a girl from Kansas who’s transported to a magical land where animals dance and sing, and the other is about a serial killer who eats his victims. You wouldn’t necessarily expect people to have similar reactions to the two movies.

headline: Small Schools to Be Added by September
text: The city Education Department yesterday announced that it would open 20 small secondary schools in September, including five schools for students at serious risk of dropping out. But the department, which has struggled to find sites for new schools, did not announce the locations for 10 of them.

headline: Staten Island: City’s Electrical Capacity to Increase
text: G.E. Energy Financial Services, part of General Electric, plans to announce a deal today that will expand New York City’s electrical capacity by 300 megawatts, the equivalent of a midsize power plant. The city currently uses roughly 12,000 megawatts at peak consumption times. The deal involves transferring power from a General Electric plant in Linden, N.J., by a cable, in use since 1992, that runs through the bedrock under the Arthur Kill and connects to a Consolidated Edison substation on Staten Island. In an auction on Jan. 16, four companies, including Con Edison, bought transmission rights. The deal requires construction of three transformers by the end of 2009.

headline: Nets End 5-Game Trip by Making Their Point
text: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 30  Everything the Nets would like to be was wrapped into their 116-115 victory over the Utah Jazz on Monday night.

headline: Queens: Hit-and-Run Leaves Man Dead
text: A 69-year-old man was killed in a hit-and-run accident yesterday while he was crossing a street in Springfield Gardens, the police said. The man, whose identity was not released last night, was walking across 140th Avenue near 156th Street about 6 p.m. when he was hit by a dark-colored jeep, which drove off. The man was declared dead on arrival at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said.

headline: Mobility Was an Early Game Plan for Bears’ Tillman
text: MIAMI, Jan. 30  Charles Tillman was born in Chicago and plays for the Bears. Those bare facts of his life cover up the reality of his peripatetic existence. Between kindergarten and 12th grade, Tillman, whose father, Donald, was a sergeant in the Army, attended 11 schools.

headline: For Those Who Think They Know Sushi, a Delectable Lesson in Trust
text: A preciously intricate sushi omakase, or chef’s choice — the term literally means “trusting the chef” — is now available to go from Sushi of Gari (402 East 78th Street, 212-517-5340) and the new Sushi of Gari 46 (347 West 46th Street, 212- 957-0046). This collection of items is an indulgence, not your usual sushi takeout.

headline: Food Calendar
text: Beer and Tapas

headline: Rising Costs Put N.Y. Transit Projects at Risk
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority faces surging costs that could force it to eliminate or postpone badly needed projects less than halfway through a five-year, $21 billion program to expand and improve its transit system. By one estimate, the program is now $1.4 billion over budget.

headline: History Teacher Becomes Podcast Celebrity
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the possibility of Rupert Murdoch joining the Chandler family’s bid for the Tribune Company misstated the source of a comment by Alfonse D’Amato, the former Republican senator from New York, about the merits of such a move by Mr. Murdoch. Mr. D’Amato’s comment was from a column in The Long Island Business News, not Newsday.

headline: As the Sun Beats Down, So Can the Stress
text: MIAMI

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Jan. 19 about two shows at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, featuring the works of Henri Cartier-Bresson and Martin Munkacsi, referred imprecisely to some of the countries Munkacsi visited on assignment for the German publisher Ullstein. Algeria and Egypt are part of Africa; he did not visit them in addition to Africa.

headline: Recycle, but Don’t Iron (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: For a Bad Boy Chef, He’s Certainly Polite
text: THE chef Gordon Ramsay has a British television show called “The F Word,” an American television show called “Hell’s Kitchen” and, by all accounts and appearances, the kind of foul mouth and foul temper those titles suggest.

headline: In a Yale Dining Hall, Independent Study at the Microwave
text: AS students streamed into a towering Gothic dining hall at Yale University last week, appraising the plats du jour on a cafeteria buffet, one of their classmates was concocting his own sauce from peanut butter and a dark liquid.

headline: Fire Department Relents on Locker Policy
text: The New York Fire Department bowed to its largest union yesterday by amending a policy that prohibited firefighters from having anything but their names and locker numbers on the outside of their lockers. The policy was intended to keep racist and pornographic material out of the city’s firehouses after a string of complaints. But the Uniformed Firefighters Association said the ban had been carried too far when unit commanders began clearing locker doors of flag stickers, Mass cards commemorating fallen colleagues, and other items. The union threatened to sue if the policy was not changed by today. Late yesterday, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta issued new regulations spelling out prohibited material, including sexually explicit photographs and any discriminatory or obscene material.

headline: Big Investors Breathing New Life Into Gasping Auto Parts Suppliers
text: DETROIT, Jan. 30 — These are dire times for Detroit’s automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of largely invisible companies that make steering wheels, transmissions and other components for the vehicles that roll off the assembly lines.

headline: Ecuador: President’s Supporters Try to Storm Congress
text: Hundreds of protesters tried to storm Congress, forcing violent clashes with the police. The protesters, largely supporters of President Rafael Correa, a leftist economist, had gathered to criticize an effort by lawmakers to raise their own salaries and to show support for a plan by Mr. Correa to convene an assembly to rewrite parts of the Constitution. Tensions have been building between Mr. Correa and Congress.

headline: Talks to Resume on North Korea and Weapons
text: BEIJING, Jan. 30 — China announced Tuesday that talks over North Korea’s nuclear weapons would resume in Beijing next week, the latest in a long series of negotiations that have failed to curb its nuclear program.

headline: British Police Arrest 9 in Alleged Kidnapping Plot
text: LONDON, Jan. 31 — British police conducted a series of raids today, starting before daybreak, to arrest nine people whom the authorities said were terrorists conspiring to kidnap and torture a British Muslim soldier, behead him and broadcast video images of his execution on the Internet.

headline: Maureen Cannon, 84, a Poet of the Everyday, in Light Verse, Dies
text: Maureen Cannon, a heavy hitter in the world of light verse who in the last four decades published more than 1,000 poems, most written in under a minute, died on Thursday at her home in Wyckoff, N.J. She was 84 and had lived in Ridgewood, N.J., for many years.

headline: You Won. Now Legislate! (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Is Not Above the Law
text: Washington

headline: Schoolboy Friedkin, Boxer, Dies at 89
text: Bernie Friedkin, a native of Brownsville, Brooklyn, who was known as Schoolboy and who as a professional boxer in the late 1930s and early ’40s battled many of his opponents to a draw — including three former lightweight champions — died Jan. 18 in Brooklyn. He was 89.

headline: The Boring Old Broiler Turns Out to Be a Superstar
text: IT’S right there, invisible, inside your oven, the most underappreciated, taken-for-granted appliance in your kitchen: the broiler.

headline: Following a Blue-Collar Dude, on the Road and in the Nude
text: “The Naked Trucker & T-Bones Show,” which has been appearing on Comedy Central for the last few weeks, is a kind of road and variety show, a cousin, in spirit, to the Blue Collar Comedians. But it’s a dopier, unwelcome cousin — more wayward and unhinged — with far less investment in the virtue of common sense.

headline: Spitzer to Offer Larger Budget, but With Property Tax Cuts
text: ALBANY, Jan. 30 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer will propose a budget of more than $120 billion Wednesday that would increase overall spending by more than 6.3 percent, a larger increase than his predecessor, George E. Pataki, proposed last year but significantly lower than the budget enacted by the Legislature, people briefed on the plan said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The front-page Your Money column on Saturday, about the possibility that people might be saving too much for retirement, misstated the parameters of a calculator from Fidelity Investments that helps consumers determine their future financial needs. Social Security payments are included  not excluded  in Fidelity’s calculations.

headline: Sosa Agrees to Minor League Deal With Rangers
text: Sammy Sosa returned to baseball yesterday, agreeing to terms on a minor league contract with the Texas Rangers. The deal carries no guarantees except the opportunity to add a chapter to his once-prominent career.

headline: Village May Have Housed Builders of Stonehenge
text: New excavations near Stonehenge have uncovered hearths, timbers and other remains of what archaeologists say was probably the village of workers who erected the monoliths on Salisbury Plain in England.

headline: Manhattan: Hells Angels Member Says He’ll Sue City
text: Richard West, a member of the New York chapter of the Hells Angels, says he will file a lawsuit against the city, claiming that he was illegally taken into custody after a search of the motorcycle club’s East Village headquarters at 77 East Third Street on Monday. Dozens of police officers, backed by sharpshooters, helicopters and heavy equipment, used a search warrant to seek evidence connected to the beating of a woman outside the building on Sunday night. Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer for the Hells Angels, said the police used excessive force. The club had refused to allow several officers to enter the heavily fortified building, so the larger contingent arrived.

headline: One in Eight Adults in the City Has Diabetes, a Study Finds
text: One in eight adults in New York City has diabetes, and nearly twice as many appear to be developing it — a picture even grimmer than that of the nation as a whole, according to the city’s first attempt to definitively measure the rate of the disease.

headline: U.S. Is Urged to Step Up Plan to Attract More Visitors
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  One year after the Bush administration vowed to try to slow the decline of overseas visitors to the United States, travel industry executives and some Democratic lawmakers say that the initiative needs to be stepped up.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the future of relations between Turkey and Armenia following the funeral for Hrant Dink, a Turkish-Armenian newspaper editor killed in Istanbul on Jan. 19, misidentified the issue between the two countries that Turkey has said should be examined by a governmental history commission. It is the 1915 Armenian genocide  not the political status of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that Armenia claims but that Turkey recognizes as part of Azerbaijan.

headline: For Ruland, Reading Is Therapeutic
text: Jeff Ruland gave his winless basketball team the day off yesterday. But things got worse anyway.

headline: An Irish Bar, Defying Time, Manages to Cheat It
text: GARRISON, N.Y.

headline: Sharing Romanian Under a Sphinx
text: MARIGOLD walls, goldenrod tablecloths, egg yolks spilling into moist corn-colored mamaliga: yellow, yellow, yellow at Acasa in Sunnyside, Queens.

headline: State Finds Serious Problems at Gibbs School in Manhattan
text: The New York State Education Department said yesterday that it had found serious problems at a two-year commercial college in New York City, Katharine Gibbs School - New York, and that it would close the college if the deficiencies were not corrected.

headline: Guest Columnist Patrick Schmitt
text: (One of our medalists in the reader column contest was Patrick Schmitt, and as a reward he has this space to write a column. He chose to write about Rex Grossman. But first he answered a few questions from the Fifth Down)

headline: US Airways Withdraws Offer for Delta
text: US Airways said Wednesday that it would withdraw its $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta Air Lines out of bankruptcy after the offer failed to win the support of the official committee of Delta's creditors.

headline: Country Chic in Umbria
text: Tour Douglas Andrews's exquisitely renovated farmhouse in Perugia, Italy.

headline: Istanbul (Not Constantinople!)
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Bush's Visit to New York
text: The president spoke at Federal Hall and visited the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Your Turn to Tell the Story: Cambodia
text: Late last year, we tried a bit of an experiment called "Your Turn to Tell the Story." We're back to try it again based on our recent trip to Cambodia.

headline: Currents
text: Playful objects with an Argentine flavor, shaping Parisian style in fantasy and food and more.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Looking forward to snow days.

headline: Tata Steel Wins Corus With $12 Billion Bid
text: When the bidding was over, Tata Steel stepped away as the winner in a heated battle for its European rival, the Corus Group, topping an offer from Brazil’s Companhia Siderurgica Nacional. Tata agreed to pay at least $12.2 billion for Corus.

headline: Publishing Deal Maker Sells Cambium Learning
text: The former chief executive of Houghton Mifflin, Nader F. Darehshori, who engineered the book publisher’s 2001 sale to Vivendi Universal for $2.2 billion, has sold his five-year old education publishing start-up, Cambium Learning, to a private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson of New York.

headline: Motorola: How Far Will Icahn Go?
text: Carl C. Icahn’s announcement Tuesday that he would be seeking a seat on Motorola‘s board had industry observers wondering what the well-known activist investor was up to this time. Motorola shares jumped 6.9 percent, to $19.58, in a sign that investors hoped Mr. Icahn might force a showdown with Motorola to make significant changes.

headline: Big Investors Bail Out Gasping Auto Parts Suppliers
text: In these are dire times for Detroit’s automakers, and even bleaker ones for thousands of auto-parts suppliers, why are big name investors like Carl C. Icahn, Wilbur L. Ross and Cerberus Capital pouring their cash into what seems like a losing proposition? The answer, suggests The New York Times, is that, while business for auto suppliers has evaporated in Detroit, it is expanding in the rest of the world as vehicle sales increase globally. Of course, the cheap price tags and low interest rates are not hurting either.

headline: Altria Spinoff Highlights Tobacco’s Charms
text: In what at first glance may seem counterintuitive, Wall Street’s enthusiasm for Altria‘s plans to spin off its Kraft Foods unit is not because Kraft, the world’s second-largest food company, will finally shed the taint of tobacco, but rather that the tobacco giant will finally be rid of Kraft. Altria is expected to announce a timetable for the spinoff on Wednesday. After cutting Kraft loose, Altria may step up the pace of its tobacco-related takeovers, analysts told Bloomberg News.

headline: Ex-Enron Executive Reports to Prison
text: Michael J. Kopper, a former finance executive at Enron who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt, started serving a three-year prison sentence Tuesday in Big Spring, Tex. Mr. Kopper, 42, entered the prison about 11 a.m. yesterday, a United States Bureau of Prisons official said. The former executive, a top lieutenant of Enron’s chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, managed daily operations for Fastow-controlled partnerships in the fraud that ultimately destroyed the company.

headline: Sony’s Big Banking I.P.O.
text: Sony‘s financial chief reconfirmed Tuesday that the company was eyeing an initial public offering of its banking and insurance unit, Sony Financial Holdings, in what analysts say could be one of the year’s biggest offerings. Analysts are predicting that the I.P.O. of the consumer-electronics and entertainment giant’s financial arm could be worth $4 billion and take place as early as this summer according to press reports.

headline: ElkCorp Accepts Rival Offer, Pressuring Carlyle
text: ElkCorp, a maker of roofing and building products, said Tuesday that it planned to accept a bid for the company from the Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group. ElkCorp’s board has determined that the binding offer of $43.50 a share by Building Materials is superior to Carlyle’s $42-a-share bid. The move gives the buyout firm five days to raise its latest bid.

headline: Chip Maker Admits Falsification in Options Backdating
text: Admitting for the first time that former officials intentionally priced stock options retroactively and falsified documents, KLA-Tencor restated its past results on Monday to include $370 million in charges related to those backdated options. The company, which makes chip-inspection equipment, handed out misdated options largely between 1997 and 2002, it said in its annual report for fiscal 2006, which it belatedly filed with regulators Monday.

headline: Owner of Hedge Fund Firm Is Sentenced
text: The owner of the hedge fund management firm Durus Capital Management was sentenced Tuesday to three years in prison and three years of supervised release, federal prosecutors said. Scott Sacane, who owned and controlled Durus, waived indictment in December 2005 and pleaded guilty to one count of violating the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.

headline: MySQL Mulls I.P.O.
text: MySQL, one of the leading open source database vendors, is preparing itself for an initial public offering and could be ready to go public before the end of the year, the Swedish company’s chief executive, Marten Mickos, told Computer Business Review. “We are planning to go public,” Mr. Mickos told the publication. However, he added that the company was in no hurry to go public after raising $18.5 million in venture capital at the beginning of last year.

headline: It Takes a Book Party: Hillary Ribs Colleagues
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took a good-natured poke at Senators Barack Obama and Chuck Schumer Tuesday night at a book party she threw for Mr. Schumer at Hunan Dynasty on Capitol Hill, as she reviewed some of the “potential titles” for his new tome about the way forward for the Democratic Party.

headline: Power Plant Protesters Descend on Merrill Headquarters
text: Perhaps emboldened by the emergence of climate change as one of the top issues at this year’s World Economic Forum, global-warming activists stepped up their fight against Merrill Lynch for its role in financing TXU‘s $10 billion plan to build 11 coal-fueled power plants in Texas. TXU’s plans for the plants, which would emit about 78 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air, and Merrill’s involvement have already drawn sharp criticism from environmentalists, as well as a coalition of institutional investors and politicians.

headline: Chicago Merc’s Profit Falls Short of Expectations
text: Shares of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange fell after the company said fourth-quarter profit was below some analysts’ estimates because of higher-than-anticipated costs. Net income rose 35 percent to $102.6 million, or $2.91 a share, from $76.3 million, or $2.18 a share a year earlier. Higher operating expenses and equity losses in unconsolidated subsidiaries cut 11 cents a share from earnings, the exchange said.

headline: Bristol-Myers Hires Bankers for Bidding War, Report Says
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, is beefing up its banking team ahead of possible takeover approaches from rivals, notably Sanofi-Aventis, by retaining the services of three Wall Street banks, The Financial Times reported. Bristol-Myers in the past week appointed Lehman Brothers to work alongside Citigroup and Morgan Stanley to examine its options ahead of an expected takeover approach from Sanofi, the paper said.

headline: London Honors for Kathleen Turner
text: Kathleen Turner was chosen best actress yesterday when the 18th Critics’ Circle Theater Awards were announced in London. Ms. Turner won for her performance in Edward Albee’s “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?”

headline: NYSE in a Deal With Tokyo Exchange
text: The New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Stock Exchange have sealed a pact that could point the world’s two largest financial markets toward an eventual combination. The broad agreement will allow both sides to cooperate on joint developments, such as financial products, mutual listings and technology, according to The Associated Press. Further, it sets into motion the possibility of a true combination once Japan’s biggest stock exchange becomes a public company in 2009.

headline: Ford Expects Aston Martin Bids Today, Report Says
text: Ford Motor is expected to receive revised offers on Wednesday for its Aston Martin brand, which it hopes to sell for more than 450 million pounds ($879 million), according to The Financial Times. Bidders left in the auction include Simon Halabi, the Syrian-born property tycoon; a British private equity firm, Doughty Hanson; Magna, the Canadian car parts group; and a consortium including James Packer, the Australian media billionaire, the report said. The paper said that there may be a third round of bidding if several of the offers come in at the same level.

headline: Private Firm Joins Citi in Big Hollywood Bet
text: Relativity Media, the privately held firm that helped finance “Smokin’ Aces” and “Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby,” has joined with Citigroup in a deal to fund at least 45 studio films in the next five years, and possibly as many as 100, according to reports. Variety said the overall investment could reach $1.1 billion, and The New York Post said the co-financing agreement could be one of the largest pools of outsider money to make its way to Hollywood.

headline: As Tribune Considers Offers, a Former Editor Moves On
text: As Tribune reviews bids for its assets, management at one of its crown jewels, The Los Angeles Times, is trying to keep its employees from running for the door. The announcement that Dean Baquet, the editor of The Los Angeles Times who was fired in November for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau and an assistant managing editor, has the L.A. newspaper worried that the move will spark a mass exodus from its newsroom.

headline: Physical Culture
text: Gear test with Tristan Greszko of Jackson Hole Mountain Resort.

headline: On the Hill: Frozen Pork
text: Although most programs’ budgets would be frozen at their 2006 levels in a large spending bill scheduled to be put to a vote today, education, veterans’ health care, international AIDS help and the Federal Bureau of Investigation would receive more. The bill was made available yesterday and is expected to be voted on today, drawing the ire of Republicans.

headline: The Good, the Bad, the Amusing
text: In Paris, puffed hair, masked faces, even a light sculpture.

headline: A Class Struggle in Paradise
text: A labor union has set its sights on Fisher Island, Fla., one of the most concentrated pockets of wealth in the nation.

headline: US Airways Stands Firm As Deadline Looms for Delta Bid
text: As the clock ran down on US Airways‘ $10 billion bid for bankrupt Delta Air Lines, US Airways’ chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, said in a conference call Tuesday that the offer, a mix of cash and stock, was firm, and that he had no intention of extending the Thursday deadline for the the official committee of Delta’s creditors to respond. Also on Tuesday, US Airways reported a $12 million profit for the fourth quarter of 2006, and Delta said it had secured $2.5 billion in financing to fund its emergence as a standalone airline.

headline: Congressmen Back Up Mitchell’s Steroid Warnings
text: Two weeks after George J. Mitchell warned baseball owners that Congress could become involved in his steroids investigation if he did not receive more cooperation from those within the sport, two congressmen offered their backing for Mitchell's efforts.

headline: The War at Home: So Many Resolutions
text: They wouldn’t be binding, but as Senate Republicans come to perceive a power behind several resolutions harshly critical of President Bush’s new troop increase plan, they’ve been stepping up efforts to squelch them.

headline: Stand By Your Man, Part II?
text: Publicity stunt for Clinton 2008; caution on presidential power; Leaving Dean for McCain, then leaving McCain.

headline: Handicapped Guessing
text: “Little Miss Sunshine” apparently has the edge going into the Oscar homestretch, according to the watchers that Reuters checked with, but it is worth noting that last year, it was all “Brokeback” all the time among the experts, so best to keep that shaker of salt handy.

headline: Study: Western Troops Need to Battle for Arab Hearts and Minds
text: The International Institute for Strategic Studies, the London-based military and political think-tank, has suggested in its annual report that the United States and its allies need to pay more attention to the hearts and minds of local populations in the battle against terrorism.

headline: Punching in at the Factory
text: “I’m just glad it’s finally opening,” Jimmy Fallon told the Baguette last night at the after-party for “Factory Girl.” It was held, natch, at the Chelsea Hotel. The movie’s release had been delayed while George Hickenlooper, the director, made last-minute changes until a week before it’s qualifying run for Oscar consideration, which took place in L.A. at the end of December.

headline: The Price of Fame
text: Ubiquity may have its rewards for movie stars, but FilmExperience is betting that by the end of this year you will be pretty sick of a few soon-to-be famous faces.

headline: A Boost from “Borat”?
text: The Los Angeles Times writer Scott Collins suggested that the Oscars need Sacha Baron Cohen as much as he needs them. With Ellen DeGeneres as host and a group of movies that many young people have not seen, Mr. Baron Cohen’s brand of humor might be just the thing to help Oscar find his edge. Mr. Collins points out that Mr. Baron Cohen’s soliloquy on bodily functions and odors gave the Golden Globes a bump in the ratings and that he could do the same thing for the Academy Awards.

headline: In Vogue and On the Carpet
text: The Bagger has only himself to blame for falling so hard for “Dreamgirls,” but when he is in the mood to spread it around, he always remembers that he was seated just in front of Andre Leon Talley, an editor at large for Vogue, at the premiere. Mr. Leon Talley’s vocal, not to say inescapable, support of the show at its signature moment was contagious. He has since, btw, seen the film seven times.

headline: Taking the Short Leap From “High Falls”
text: After flying home on the red-eye and then face-planting for 18 hours, the Bagger unpacked from his Sundance-and-awards marathon and found some artistic swag at the bottom of his suitcase, including a DVD of “High Falls,” a short directed by Andrew Zuckerman and starring Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard that premiered at Sundance. The Bagger assumes that any filmmaker accessorized by Gyllenhaal and Sarsgaard would know what he is doing, but “High Falls” is a great little movie. It hangs on this question, among others: Is there a moral equivalence between accidentally running over your husband’s dog and said husband getting an anonymous happy ending without the pretense of a massage while on a business trip to Japan?

headline: A Visit to the Off-Season Virtual Paddock
text: A feature of this blog from the racing season has been revived for a moment during this off-season thanks to a question by a loyal reader and, above all, thanks to the Renault team and its head of engine track operations, Denis Chevrier, who accepted to answer the reader’s question.

headline: Obama the Clintonian
text: Obama: More Clintonian than Hillary Clinton. That’s the judgment of Washington Post columnist Ruth Marcus, who writes, “The truly Clintonian figure running for the Democratic nomination is Barack Obama.” She uses the word “Clintonian” not as a slur but as a description of the mixed gifts Bill Clinton brought to the presidency.

headline: 2008 Like It’s Today: More Democratic Word-Slinging
text: John Edwards appears to have abandoned his 2004 trademark of positive campaigning. From The Politico:

headline: Biden Says He’s In…Again
text: We’ve lost track of how many times Senator Joseph R. Biden has announced that he’s running for president in 2008, but we think this might be the last one. The Delaware Democrat, who first sought the presidency in 1988, filed papers with the Federal Election Commission today and will appear on Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” tonight.

headline: How Jobless Rates Forecast the Super Bowl
text: At last the Federal Reserve is using its economic expertise to do something worthwhile: forecast the Super Bowl.

headline: Public Access Wine Tasting
text: Have any of you checked out Wine Library TV? I’m a little late to the game, but it’s a lot of fun in short bursts, basically the video blog equivalent to cable’s low-budget public-access TV.

headline: Purported Pollock Paintings: Still a Pickle
text: As Randy Kennedy reported on Tuesday, an analysis by researchers at the Harvard University Art Museums is casting new doubt on the authenticity of three paintings attributed to Jackson Pollock.

headline: Reclaiming Video Resumes For the ‘Forces of Good’
text: The operators of career Web site Vault.com are encouraging would-be investment bankers to produce video resumes, but they have no intention of inspiring “Impossible Is Nothing II.” Don’t wax philosophical, they advise, and please — no feats of strength.

headline: US Airways Withdraws Delta Offer
text: US Airways said Wednesday that it would withdraw its $10.2 billion offer to acquire Delta Air Lines out of bankruptcy after the offer failed to win the support of the official committee of Delta’s creditors.

headline: Pogue Gets Airbrushed
text: Wow, wait till I tell you about the makeup I wore yesterday.

headline: An Uneven Playing Field
text: In the Times’s Dining section today, my colleague Kim Severson writes about the emergence of — and mild uproar over — a service that sells hard-to-get restaurant reservations for at least $35 a table. It’s called PrimeTime Tables, and that’s what it offers: tables at the kinds of times that are almost impossible to secure, at least at restaurants that book up a month or two in advance, restaurants whose phone lines are constantly busy.

headline: On Lieutenant Governors
text: Lieut. Gov. David Paterson, speaking today at the budget briefing, thanked Gov. Eliot Spitzer for giving him something to do. He added:

headline: Sunset of a Midnight Appointment
text: Remember that midnight appointment Gov. George E. Pataki made, giving his top aide, John Cahill, a part-time job with the Temporary State Commission on Investigation that paid more than $100,000 a year?

headline: The Bike Ride
text: Have you heard of people with photographic memories? Well, my dear husband’s memory can best be described as a negative that never developed.

headline: Senator Clinton: Compromise “Not a Dirty Word”
text: At a conference devoted to “big ideas” for the nation’s future, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said this morning that compromise need to be “a goal – not a dirty word” in politics and government, remarks that reflect her own pragmatic style but that are more moderate than the views of some of her rivals and hard-core elements of the Democratic primary electorate.

headline: Could This Be the Place?
text: In Monday’s post, titled “Readers React,” I included portions of an e-mail to me from someone reminiscing about a restaurant on the central coast of California, a restaurant he didn’t name. I openly wondered whether any of the readers of this blog recalled the restaurant and could in fact fill in the blank.

headline: What Went Wrong at Goldman’s Hedge Fund?
text: In introducing its long article about Global Alpha, Goldman Sachs‘ highly secretive flagship hedge fund, Bloomberg News writer Richard Teitelbaum recounts how one of the fund’s managers, Mark Carhart, recently made fun of Warren Buffett for insisting on investing on solid companies with good management and well-known brands. During an investor conference, Mr. Carhart cited several studies showing that big companies with high price-earning ratios make for “poor bets,” as Mr. Teitelbaum put it.

headline: Seeking an Unlikely Ally
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s Jan. 31 column, “Not-So-Strange Bedfellow”.

headline: A Year Later, Victims of Storm in Guatemala Are Unearthed
text: After a week-long search for survivors, and later, bodies, in the aftermath of Hurricane Stan, which ravaged Guatemala in October 2005, government authorities threw in the towel. They told families that any victims buried in the landslides caused by the storm’s heavy rains would, to put it simply, have to stay buried.

headline: Ashura in Baghdad
text: Baghdad's Shiite Muslims staged their own celebration of an ancient holy day.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis and Sun: Just Friends
text: Sometimes an investment is just an investment.

headline: Isn’t That Special? Copernicus Meets Doomsday
text: With apologies to Dr. Johnson: When a reader knows the world is about to end, it concentrates his mind wonderfully. Or at least inspires him to post a comment. My bet that humanity will avert doomsday provoked plenty of intelligent disagreement. But there were a few optimists, too, and my favorite argument is the one by M. Skinner:

headline: BofA Chief Says Big U.S. Deal Is Unlikely
text: Asked about recent reports that Bank of America was in talks that might lead to an acquisition of Countrywide, Bank of America Chief Executive Kenneth Lewis said Wednesday his company would follow a mortgage strategy of “organic growth.” Speaking at a financial-services conference, he also said the odds were “pretty low” that his company would buy a large United States bank this year, Reuters reported.

text: A video clip from Bud.TV, Anheuser-Busch's new entertainment Web site.

text: A video clip from Bud.TV, Anheuser-Busch's new entertainment Web site.

text: That’s one conclusion to draw from this article about George E. Pataki in New Hampshire’s Union Leader newspaper:

text: A video clip from Bud.TV, Anheuser-Busch's new entertainment Web site.

headline: What Girls Want
text: A video clip from Bud.TV, Anheuser-Busch's new entertainment Web site.

headline: Flushes and Flashes at Ramsay
text: There are stray, non-essential observations about Gordon Ramsay at the London that I didn’t put into today’s review, but I wanted to share them nonetheless. How handy is a blog at a time like this?

headline: Biden Makes Nice to Obama
text: Sen. Joseph Biden, under fire for remarks to the New York Observer describing his Senate colleague and potential presidential rival Barack Obama as “the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright andclean,” was bending over backward on Wednesday to kiss and make up.

headline: Clinton Postpones New Hampshire Trip
text: The New Hampshire bloggers can stand down.

headline: Boycotting the Beijing Olympics?
text: I had a long note from aid workers in Sudan who must, of course, remain anonymous. They’re still steaming over the attack on aid workers in Nyala on Jan. 19, and they’re proposing tough international responses. One of the measures they propose is blockading Sudanese ports, and another is a boycott of the Chinese Olympics or even of Chinese goods. I’m not sure what I think of these steps, and I’d welcome your comments — just hit the “comment” button at the end of the post. Here’s the note they sent (everything below is from them, not from me):

headline: Maliki Tells Iran & U.S. to Chill Out; Plus: Think-Tank Thinks About Iran’s Nukes
text: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq warned Iran and the United States to not make Iraq a proxy battlefield for growing tensions between the two countries.

headline: A Bumpy Rollout for Biden
text: What Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware intended to do on Wednesday was to declare his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination. There was the video posted on his new Web site, with Mr. Biden seated by a fireplace, the conference call with reporters and the denunciation of the war in Iraq and the heralding of his own foreign policy credentials.

headline: Advertising Campaign Causes Terror Scare
text: From the major “Oops” department, Turner Broadcasting has claimed responsibility for a slew of “suspicious packages,” scattered around various American cities, that caused a terrorism scare in Boston, provoked the closure of major roadways and part of the Charles River, and mobilized local and federal law enforcement.

headline: On the Boulevard de Cliché: Men’s Fashion
text: At six o’clock tonight I went down to the street to find my driver, Bernard Alloux, and go and buy a baguette for the trip home. On the way I stopped and bought a pair of stilettos at a place called Ernest, a real dump, but the ladies were nice and I left with the shoes in a gold plastic bag that said:

headline: The Future President Clinton
text: As I survey the political scene, I don’t think it’s too soon to make a firm prediction about the 2008 presidential race. I think Hillary Clinton will be the next president of the United States.
